column5: Bottled. Thanks to Dorqui for this one. Pale yellow in colour. Foamy white head, lacings. The aroma is maize like... barnyardish... The flavour is watery, with hints of maize. It’ has a sweet taste.
Bottled. Hazy yellow colour, small white head. Aroma is maize, hay and hops. Flavour is soap and hay. Sweetish aftertaste, maybe of maize? Papery dry also... yet another funny Italian rated .)

Bottled (BB 12/2007) Pale yellow color, small white head. Aroma of vegetables, cardboard and cat piss. Watery, not much malts or hops to talk about, only some cardboardish notes (liquid cardboard?). This is like those very cheap German supermarket pilseners, but made in Italy making the bad even worse.
Bottled 0,33L. Light foam, a lot escaping. Yellow pale color, limpid and with a light fizz. Lean aroma with light straw and waters cereals notes. Watery, light and indeed trifling taste.

bottle. waiter did not let me ssee botthe, but i guess it was not way overdue. sold as cerveza trigo weissbier, small greek rastaurant, playa del ingles, las palmas, spain. aroma of yeast, citrus and peach. appears cloudy yellow, white thick head. flavor is quite fruity, slight sour note, very faint sweetness, a little bitterness. slightly off-style.

Canned 0,50L. Orange hazy color, medium bubbly. Light and enough vanishing foam. Light scent of cereals, banana, hay and rice. Extinguished and little prickly taste. Sweetish and fruity notes barley, straw and dry grass. Intangible bitter and alcohol content.
[Canned] Cloudy pale yellow coloured. Very thin and watery. It tastes sour and rotten.
An unclear orange beer with a fine off white head. The aroma is hoppy and wheaty with a slight sour tinge. The flavor is very wheaty. An OK hefeweizen.

Here’s the Syuzan Kaido Kölsch 5% One of the things these guys did which was a bit different were they had pull top bottle caps - no bottle openers necessary. Pouring a deep gold with a fast dissipating off-white head of foam. The aroma is buttery diacetyl. The taste is crisp light malts & butterscotch with a sharp hoppy bite. I am not sure how appropriate diacetyl is in a Kölsch but this seems a bit much. Interestingly enough the diacetyl fades and crisp malts + hops start to shine. Somewhat below average. Get rid of that diacetyl and it’d be pretty good. I’ve had it on tap and in bottles in much better form than this.

On tap at CBM Jimbocho. Hazy golden yellow with a small off-white head. Fruity aromas on the nose with malt and a hint of grass. Medium body with nice carbonation. Taste is fruity and sweet. Faintly bitter finish. Not bad at all.

Bottle from Dai Maru Kyoto basement liquor shop. Thin sweetish buttery nose. Sad hazy dirty light yellow color. Mild sweet malt / light hopping comes up on the carbonation / finish has a tiny spot of bitterness and again the butter note. Thin body. Poorly-made stuff.

Not usually a huge fan of this kind of beer, but this one ticked all the boxes. Drunk straight from it bottle it was mildly carbonated but not flat-tasting, with good strong hop flavours on a solid base. Good stuff from the best Ji-beer brewer in Kyoto. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a slightly hazy pale yellow with a medium white head. Aroma is flowery and lightly fruity. Flavor has mild fruit, straw, and faint grass. mouthfeel is light and the finish is dry and abrupt.
Bottled. Hazy golden, brief head. Fruity spicy nose. Dryish with light body and clean mouthfeel. Low bitterness. Uncomplicated and quite refreshing.

Bottle (rated in Apr 2008). Head is mostly diminishing. Body is medium yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers), with notes of passion fruit, ginger, and pineapple. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. A very pleasantly fruity and spicy rendition.

Bottle brought back from Japan and shared by Keir- thanks again, Keir! Pours a cloudy gold color with a small white head. The aroma is really gritty earth, almost dirt-like, with grass, husky grains, and pale malts. The flavor starts earthy, transitions into some musty grains, and finishes really big and malty. Light-bodied, with a malty, dry, gritty mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Very unusual kolsch.

Cloudy golden with a white creamy deminishing head. Smells of citrus and banana, ginger, butter and summer fruit. Medium body with lively carbonation. Sweet fruity taste of banana, wheat and cloves, butter, with a pale hoppy grass light bitter finish. Smooth and lemony - Light and very enjoyable. Refreshing.
Bottle. Old rating found with my Japan trip notes. Poured a slightly cloudy gold. A big nose of juicy malt and tropical fruit. Creamy palate with a fruity flavour. Perhaps a little lollie-ish though.

Bottle from Hausler Getränkemarkt Regensburg. Big and lasting white head over a pale yellow beer with a light sparkle. Clean and crisp pils malt aroma with much nobel hops. Malty with fresh light citrus taste and a firm bitterness. Easy to drink in large quantities and really refreshing.
330ml bottle from supermarket in Kelheim (forget the name). Clear golden colour, surprisingly hoppy aroma, with floral and grassy notes. Good hop bitterness in the flavour, which really lingers.
Draft at La Despensa - pours clear golden, white head. A simple, malty pils, lacking some severe bitterness. Refreshing nonetheless.

Aug. ’15. A 0.33 l bottle that poured a pale yellow body with a small head atop. Mineral water and lemon aroma, only a tad of grainy malt. Flavor was bitter, lightly herbal with a bit less of lemon hops. Touched with bread, too. Quite thin bodied with a short mineral and dry paper finish. Although very light it was a correct and a pleasant pils.

Bottle 33cl. Clear medium golden, small frothy white head, mostly diminishing, light lacing; aroma is malty, grain, grass, floral; taste is medium sweet and bitter, medium duration; medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation, mild dry finish,mineral notes; decent clean Pilsner.

Draft at a bar in Berlin. Pours clear pale golden with a white head. Aroma of grain, light dough and light sweet malt. Flavour is above light sweet and light bitter. Light bodied with moderate carbonation.

(bottle) clear pale golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of floral hops and hay, with some notes of pale malts and heavy elderflower. flavour is mostly the same, floral hops, elderflower and straw, with a light touch of manure and a slightly minerally finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.

Courtesy of and shared with heavy, whose father got them from some of their German guests - thanks! Paaaaaaale shiny gilded yellow body with no head to speak of. Weak, slightly herbal bready aroma. Weak taste, herbal - nicely so, but vague, a bit eggy too again. Must be the brewery’s signature. It really lacks bitterness but is an OK light lager.

Bottled, from Biershop Bayern. Clear pale golden, small head. Distinct grassy nose. Dry with light-medium body and soft, yet crisp mouthfeel, low carbonation. Long bitter finish. Exceptionally moreish and well structured.
*Old rating, best before 01.11. Erstaunlich herb für ein bayerisches Pils. Schöne blumig-grasiges Bier, süffig, frisch, lecker.

column2: Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, Canada
column4: Gulf Islands Brewery (Salt Spring Island Ales)
column5: On tap. Pours mahogany with moderate head. Dry caramel, sweet malts and s bitbof cardboard.

column2: Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, Canada
column4: Gulf Islands Brewery (Salt Spring Island Ales)
column5: Bottle - Caramel and a touch of woody twig. Cloudy copper with a rich beige head. Nice caramel with an simple but easy drinking finish. Solid.

column2: Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, Canada
column4: Gulf Islands Brewery (Salt Spring Island Ales)
column5: Bottle from brewery. Pours a solid amber colour with a nice lasting head. Aromas of sweet caramel,toffee and hops. Flavours of caramel, hop resins and toffee. Sticky mouthfeel with a nice bitterness. Maybe the best beer I tried while at the brewery.

column2: Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, Canada
column4: Gulf Islands Brewery (Salt Spring Island Ales)
column5: Red brown cloudy pour. Lovely foam. Aroma of berries cranberry slight lactic caramel. Tastes tobacco, leather, butter berries grains. Dry palate.

column2: Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, Canada
column4: Gulf Islands Brewery (Salt Spring Island Ales)
column5: Draught at The Beagle Pub, Victoria Amber color. Dry mouthfeel, caramel flavor, strong bitterness, with some hop resins.

column2: Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, Canada
column4: Gulf Islands Brewery (Salt Spring Island Ales)
column5: Bomber. Clear medium copper, creamy off-white foamy head settles and mostly fades. Mild aroma of caramel malt and floral citrus hop. Not too sweet caramel/toffee malt taste, lightly bitter leafy hop, some citrus. Average carbonation, lighter bodied, lightly hopped. Nice enough, but not too exciting. LBW (Lagerboys Be Wary)

column2: Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, Canada
column4: Gulf Islands Brewery (Salt Spring Island Ales)
column5: First rating in a few years, eh? This is now being sold in bombers. Not bad, average bitterness that lasts in the finish, doesn’t have the diacetyl problems of yore, nothing really stands out but it’s a well balanced beer with a stronger malt backing than I’ve come to expect with this brewery.

column2: Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, Canada
column4: Gulf Islands Brewery (Salt Spring Island Ales)
column5: Not a great beer at all, not terrible, I wouldnt buy it again. I was expecting substantially more. It was bizarre, almost enjoyable, but ultimately weird. too salty to be drinkable, but interesting and glad i tried it.

column2: Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, Canada
column4: Gulf Islands Brewery (Salt Spring Island Ales)
column5: 22oz bottle. Lightly hazed golden orange with a frothy white head. Nose was sweet and salty nuts with some faint hops....weird.

column2: Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, Canada
column4: Gulf Islands Brewery (Salt Spring Island Ales)
column5: All butterscotch in nose and flavor. Why would someone make a beer to taste like it had diacetyl? Even if it didn’t?
~This review was made some time ago via another application, and thus the specific details (beyond numerical scores) are no longer available~

Pale watery yellow, tons of empty white foam. settles down quick to 1/4 inch. No bubbling. Smells like sugar and corn. Taste’s like sugar honey corn water. Irritates the nose like ammonia. Slightly carbonated finish, but pretty flat. More like yellow corn syrup water than beer.
Um, not that great...no wonder only two people have rated this. Look like yellow dye was added to water. Tastes like yellow dye was added to water. Glad I didn’t pay for this one.

..finally wasted coops money on this ?ale?..ok...is very yellow...but pretty good head...good amount of bitters, but turns a tad ugly.,.acheaper asian beer, is kinda like day old chinese dumpster quality...is smooth though..

Sampled at Real Beer Expo (Rochester). Golden-brown with a tight, off-white head. TIght-ish nose with a bit of caramel and light hop scent. Malty and hoppy in the mouth. med. body and med. carbonation.

Cask. Golden amber ale with a thin cremay off white head. Sweet caramel aroma with notes of berries. In mouth, a sweet herbal malt, with treacle, lingering hops bitterness. Medium bodied. The Real Beer Expo - Rochester, NY, Oct. 21, 2006.

(cask @ The Real Beer Expo - Rochester, NY) Amber in color with a thick and puffy tan head. Aroma is rather bland but has some hops in it as well. Flavor has a decent amount of hops and an interesting spicy note, possibly from the rye. Some malts at the end make for a very clean and smooth finish. A very different beer to be sure.

Draught at the Buffalo Brewfest. Medium amber color with an off white head, not very long lasting. Decent base beer with noticible hops and a medium body. The rye adds a nice little slant on it with a spicier kick. Not bad.

From a growler purchased at Premier Gourmet: Amber body with a dense white head. Aroma of toasted malts and rye bread. Noticeable hop presence, a hint of citrus and moderate bitterness, but the flavor is mainly toasted malts and rye. Clean and very drinkable like most Flying Bison offerings.

This was a unique beta test, the base being their solid British style pale ale, and rye added instead of what is often added being wheat. Dark yellow with lots of lace. Significant bitterness and toastiness. The best part - unfiltered. Refreshing, decent carbonation though above average.
bottle. solid roasted flavor and aroma, Fuller mouthfeel, fuller flavor, roasted malts, smooth flavor, probably the best FB to date & its 3 yrs old

In short: A highly roasted porter. Ok How: Bottle 12oz. Exact age unknown. Shared by rudolf The look: Dark brown body toped by a medium beige head In long: The strong nose is very roasted bringing burnt wood and ground pepper notes. Taste mostly highly roasted (read “burnt”) malts. Also some burnt caramel, notes of molasses. Finish is dry-ish. That’s all I had on this beer. A very roasted beer is good at covering any problems and feeling a bit dry. And that’s what this beer is was all about. That was my last rate of BCTC. Many more beers ensued but it becomes a bit blurry. I would like use this last BCTC rating to observe a moment of silence for all the innocent brain cells that died during that weekend.

Pre-release sample bottle from goldtwins. Dark as hell with a thin wispy light brown head. Aroma is milk chocolate and dark fruits. Flavor has some sweet dark fruits, chocolate and some molasses. Mouthfeel is full and damn creamy. Thanks Larry, this is a tasty treat.

Many thanks to Steve for dropping this American Strong Ale.. er.. Porter at my house! Poured not much deeper than medium brown with a light dusting of white head.. not lively in the least. The aroma was rich, dark, and malty with molasses, vegemite, and a bouquet of darker fruits present.. alcohol warmth-infused sweetness on the back of the nose that worked very well. This slid slowly onto the palate due to low carbonation, and the warm dark malts covered the taste buds well.. molasses was dominant with lesser aged caramel and again a dose of vegemite.. bitterness was light and herbal-inspired.. sweet finish with the aforementioned dark malts and some alcohol warmth. Medium-plus bodied with virtually no carbonation on the palate.. alcohol was well-masked and served only to amplify the sweetness in here.. warmer malty finish picked up some greener pine notes. Nice one!
Thanks to richlikebeer, Nice aroma of roasted malts, sweet-chocolate with a roasted malt, molasses taste. Very nice beer.

12oz bottle with a ’plain’ and generic looking white label with black text. Poured a deeper brown color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of dark fruits, roast, milk chocolate, and light vanilla. Tastes of dark fruits, roast, chocolate, light nuttiness, and prunes. Alcohol content hidden.

Thanks to hopdog. Pours a deep brown with a medium creamy off white head. Aroma of toffee, sweet malts, caramel, dark fruits and nuts. Flavor of roasted malt, sweet caramel, some nuts, bitter dark chocolate and some earthiness.

Thanks to Rudolf. Black pour, medium beige head that last. Aroma is sweet with lots of chocolate and roastiness and some fruitiness to it. Flavor is chocolate, mollasses, roasted malt and even a touch of espresso in the end. After is sweet and sugary with a touch of anice and the alcohol definitely plays a role. Medium mouthfeel and lots of carbonation with a cloying sweetness that really sticks to your mouth. This is damn good and is definitely an imperial porter bordering stout. Lots of heavy flavor but a sweet chocolate flvor is dominate with a cloying sweet roastiness.

12 oz bottle via Homebrew Mystery Swap (thanks Rudolf!). Bottle has a generic sticker and says ’R&D prototype’... This beer pours a dark brown/black with a huge chunky beige head. Nose is malty with some mild fruity esters and subtle roastiness. Taste starts very sweet and then suddenly turns in an espresso delight with a bit of chocolate and vanilla in the mix. The espresso continues long into the aftertaste, bordering on ashy. There is a bit of smokiness in there as well as some fusel alcohol. Body is light/medium, carbonation is high. This borders on somewhere between a scottish wee heavy and a Robust porter as far as style goes.This is quite tasty and i wish i had another.

Thank you Rudolph. Pours black with a small head and w white halo lacing. Aroma is strong with what has come to be a standard American strong maltiness and alcohol (or what I like to rum cake). So it’s nicely rich but also alcoholic. Taste is also sweet with an oatmeal-like flavor which is offset by an equally strong alcoholic cherry and whiskey. A medium body with a really light aftertaste.12oz bottle with a home printed label, Rodenbach Grand Cru smaller tulip glass.
C hop aroma. Grapefruity initial taste, and then the more acidic rind, then settling into malt. Lace. Quaffable.

Cask, handpump @ the Rook & Gaskill, York, Nth Yorkshire. Slightly oily looking and still, medium, orange gold body with a thick, creamy off-white head that legged and frosted wildly down the glass. Feint aroma of herbal tea, almost like chamomile mixed with St. John’s wort, with a dash of pale honey stirred in. Sour lemon, spruce and well defined herbal and calming St. John’s wort flavours kick it off in the first mouthful. Touch of orange marmalade and toasted malt builds the palate as it goes and it’s soft and creamy texture feels wonderful on the tongue. Becomes quite sweet, honeyish yet its reasonably dry and spicy on the swallow. The citrus and herbal notes are beautifully defined, the body is firm and it crosses the mouth with such rampant ease. This wasn’t bad. I’m a closet junkie for St. John’s wort tea and in this beer it did it huge favours as far as depth and balance. Very tasty, refreshing and quaffable. Nice!!!
Tap. Clear golden color with white head. Aroma is pale malts, sugary, grainy, earthy, a touch vegetal. Taste is the same. Oily mouthfeel with large-bubbled carbonation. Pretty meh.
Pours a clear yellow with a white head. Aroma of grain, straw, dusty. Taste is grain, light cardboard.

0,5 l Flasche aus einem kleinen Laden in Dorfen. Strohgold, klar mit reichlich Kohlensäure und einer dicken cremigen Schaumkrone. In der Nase habe ich Weizen und Heu. Im Geschmack ähnlich mit rundem Abschluss

A really good Helle that is light coloured and fresh. This beer has all the good things a Bavarian Helle need to have. It is highly drinkable, has a good balanced Hops taste and has a decent aftertaste.

0,5 l from Georg, the local hero. Thanks a lot! As expected clear dark golden with a more than one finger thick foamy but only short living white head. Little bit grainy grassy on the nose. Taste ist smooth grainy, some encreasing malt, low bitterness. Typical good bavarian Helles but nothing special in that area.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig, leicht fruchtig. Geschmack malzig würzig, getreidig, leicht fruchtig.
Dumpf herber, geringfügig süßer Antrunk. Mild, etwas bitter, trocken. Mild bleibend, etwas getreidig. Muffig herber Abgang. Naja... 11/7/8/7/11/7
0,5 l bottle. BB 04/13 bread, hay, cereal, citrus, golden, clear, frothy, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, oily feel, slick feel, soft carbonation,

Bottle: Pale greenish-golden, unclear, creamy and lacy white foamy layer, sweetish-grainy nose, traces of peppery hops underneath; quite soft, moderate bitter-swwtish flavour; grainy finish, followed by a slight bitterness. Pleasant, archetypal Helles…

(bottle) Clear, pale golden colour with a big and dense foamy white head. Slightly grainy and doughy malty aroma with present herbal hops. Mildly sweet flavour with a tinge of bitterness, light to medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Grainy malt character with delicately herbal accents, leading into a sweet and slightly hop bitter finish. Decent. 01.XI.11
Künstlicher Geschmack. Das hat definitiv nichts mit Bier zu tun, sondern ist ein Erfrischungsgetränk
Not bad for a Radler type drink as it is an interesting flavour and quite refreshing.
330ml Flasche. Orange und klar. Ohne Schaumkrone. Absolut misslungener Biermix, ohne Aroma. Bier nicht schmeckbar. Schmeckt wie Brausetabletten aufgelöst in Wasser.

* Old rating, 0,33l crown-top bottle, best before 01.2009. Süß-limonadige Orange. Sehr süffig, das Bier ist kaum zu erahnen und kämpft im Hintergrund etwas gegen die limonadige Süße. Netter Durstlöscher.
Orangegelbes Getränk mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr süß nach Orangen. Geschmack sehr süß, Orangen, kein Bier, dennoch guter Durstlöscher.

Bottle. Pours fizzy, clear pale orange with quickly disappearing white head. Clear aroma of C-vitamin pills dissolved in water. Ditto taste. Soft, sweet-sourish, synthetic. Bland. Boring. Bad. Even for a Radler.
light sweet citron aroma,orange, clear, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, sodavand and fresh light bitter finish,
Rated as Becks Twisted Orange. Peach coloured and clear. Has a white head, diminishing. Aroma is fruity, sweet orange. Flavor is mainly sweet, more sweet orange, light bitter finish. Watery texture.
pale, clear, minimal head, white foam, orange, citrus, light body, thin feel, average carbonation, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter,
golden, clear, minimal head, citrus, bubblegum, leaves, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, average carbonation,

Draught. Weak caramel and CO2 aroma. Cloudy, dark red/amber colour. Small stable light brown head. The flavour is nicely roasted, bordering on smoked. Quite malty, hint of horse. Low bitterness, creamy mouthfeel.
I believe this was the beer I tried. It was called Angry Angus, but it was his Scottish Red. Pours reddish brown. Aroma is malt and caramel. It does finish a little sweet. Decent beer.

On tap: Reddish brown bodied with a frothy, off-white head. I’m not a big amber ale fan, but this one satiisfied. The aroma is malty, toffee, caramel, and bit of butterscotch with skinned apples and a hint of berries. Pretty much hop free, but the flavor is still good with that same blending the aroma contains. Sweet finish. Tasty. John S. Rhodell Brewery, Peoria, IL

750 c&c from Bu11zeye. Pours hazy orange amber with a slight head. Aroma is fruity, but with a dark malt suggesting contact with wood. Med body. Very light carbonation. Flavor is arguably a bit oxidized, which may be where the wood suggestion comes from. It’s very lightly spicy, has some fruit esters, but overall its very dark. It’s not quite dry in the finish, a bit fruity, and still seems to have a woody component. It’s actually reminding me of some of the Fuller’s Vintage Old Ales. For which, among other reasons, I’m rather liking it. "rerate": After looking at other ratings, I’m thinking my 750 is rather like that of Zymurgeist2.

Batch 10 Tasted on 6/17/13 from a corked and caged 750mL bottle purchased at Wine and Cheese Place. Pours hazy lightly burnt orange with a very thick and rocky cream colored head that slowly recedes to rocky lace. The nose features a bit more caramel and bread malt than I am used to from a Saison, but there is a nice spicy Saison yeast character as well. The flavor is pretty much the same, with a nice spicy Saison character, but it is a little more malty with caramel then I like in a Saison. The body is medium with lively carbonation and a long caramel malty and spicy Saison yeast finish.

Spicy aroma from the yeast was promising, but it all went down hill from there. This was way to sweet for me, seemed under attenuated. Lots of dark sugar in the flavor. Decent mouthfeel with some carbonation.

Batch #5. Pours a hazy dark amber color with a big fluffy head that fades slowly to lots of lacing. Aroma of fruit, spice, bit of malt sweetness and citrus. Taste of fruit, bit of caramel sweetness and earthy grit. There is some fruity tart and a dry finish. Medium body, crisp and smooth. Nice balance. More fruit flavors emerge as it warms. Very nice drinker, much better than I expected.

Out of a 750 bottle. Pours a nice hazy deep orange with white head and slight lacing. Slight must and esters with wet blanket. Disjointed esters and slight fruitiness. Dry champagne like finish. Tasty.

bottle... dark gold with a bit of orange, nice color, medium cap of a light tan head... dead nose, a bit of sweet flowers, a little yeast but unoffensive boring...taste is more of the same, not much flavor, a lightly sweet saison, sweet yeast, easy to crush at 6.5% but not for me, possibly a good beginner saison beer
Decent for a missouri saison. Tart like a saison should be with a yeasty aroma and sweet finish. 5/23/2010

750 with batch 7 written on the label in magic marker. Pours an orangish gold with a big fluffy head and aromas of blegian yeast, grass and a little bit of lemon or funk. Flavor has quite a bit of cloves with a nice amount of orange fruitiness and a little bit of funk. Just a hint of butterscotch, but not enough to turn me off on it.
It poured a golden color with a white head. The aroma was of light malt and belgian yeast. The taste was slightly tart with coriander and straw.

Bottle. From batch 4. Poured a hazy orange color with a two finger white head. Lots of carbonation and bubbles in the beer. Aroma was citrus and spices. Flavor was spicy, citrus, lemon, and some hop aftertaste. Medium body. A very good beer. Better than I thought it would be.
Clear slightly yellow appearance. Fruity alcohol and rice aroma, light body, some sweetness on finish. Overall very good Sake.

Bottle: Pours a slightly yellow beige color with nice legs. The nose is fruity and light, some alcohol and some umami, which I wasn’t expecting. Rounded flavor and body with a subtle tail and a fairly buttery mouthfeel. Nice drinking Genshu.

Botella. 17,5% alc. Clear lightly yellow water colour. Aroma of dried fruits, rice and alcohol. Pleasant mouthfeel. The flavour is smooth with dried fruits, rice, alcohol and some sweetness. Very pleasant sake.
Clear slightly yellow pour with nice lacing. Rice yeast and overripe fruit aroma. Taste is tangy fruit,rice grainy body. Nice alcohol kick and burn, also. Pretty tasty.

Pours clear w/ a hint of yellow. A rather interesting bouquet of cocoa caramel w/ a hint of foot odor. It lays across the palate with full nectar. Complex flavors of raw sugar cane oil, watercress, bamboo schutes, and herbs. Slightly sweet w/ limes. The finish is herbal w/ a cocoa, sweet lime finish. This is a very interesting flavor profile to say the least.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: Sweet with apple notes and sweetener. Sweet flavor with apple and phenol notes.

From tap at a beer garden in Zurich. Nearly clear light golden with a white head. The aroma is lightly to medium malty with biscuits, cereals and dried fruits. Medium body with a light to medium sweetness and a light bitterness. The flavor is similar to the smell with biscuit, dried fruits and hints of honey. Lightly bitter finish. Aroma: 6 Appearance: 4 Taste: 6 Mouthfeel: 3 Overall: 11

Sampled draft @ Linde-Oberstrass as supposedly Linde-Oberstrass Pils. Orange sparkling creamy white head. Nose is butter to the max in the worst way. Taste is pure awful sweet carbonated butter to the max. Total garbage. The other ratings are less harsh, bad batch, we were served this.
Tap at the brewpub. Golden summer nose, some candy and honey. Decent bitterness over lively carbonation, highly quaffable. Short and surprisingly dry finish. Highly recommended!

cloudy golden color, definitely unfiltered. Massively malty nose of freshly baked toasted malts. Lovely toasty notes in the mouth. Lingering grainy finish. Very malt accented. Refreshing, but needs more hops or increased sweetness. Still a decent Hellas.
Weich süffiger Antrunk, deutlich getreidig, wenig würzig. Die Herbe wird ergänzt durch hintergründige Malznoten. Mild, erfrischend, nett. 11/10/10/9//9

From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is butterish and yeasty. Mild citric, butterish and malty. Mild grassy bitterness coming through. Ends dry with a lasting butterish note.

Draught@brewpub, Zürich Hazy pale yellow color, small creamy white head, lace. Same unclean wheat bun aroma than in the wheat beer plus some fruity notes. Medium-bodied, but mainly tasteless. Some notes of crackers and unfermented sugars. Very characterless brewpub beer.

Draught at the brewpub Hazy orange color. Delicate but quite nice hoppy aroma. The taste has some fresh fruitness, followed by a medium hop impact with some qualities; unfortunately, almost immediately, the body reveals to be very weak, with an extreme poor and short final; at least, the malt is missing, only some hop oils are left.

<!-- i -->draught<!-- /i --> - cloudy copper-orange colour with a little foam; fine herbal aroma; light peppery notes; good malt body and a respectable bitterness; some tartness; long dry herbal and bitter finish - good work

From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy yellow with a small, creamy and off-white head. Aroma is mild fruity, vague citrusy. Flavour has a bit coriander and phenols. Fruity, slight bubblegum. Vague citrusy. Mild spiced into a dry finish.

Draught@brewpub, Zürich Hazy orange color, creamy off-white head. Unclean wheat bun and mango in the aroma. Smooth mouthfeel. Light banana and mango flavors, lime in the aftertaste. wheaty, a bit crisp in the finish and that’s it. Beer has decent body, but not much is going on in palate.

<!-- i -->draught<!-- /i --> - cloudy very dark reddish orange colour with a firm creamy slightly reddish foam; nice lacing; dry and subtle aroma of strawberries; flowery notes; moderately sweet, very creamy; low carbonation and not much malt profile; the finish is quite short and moderately dry with more subtle notes of red fruits - interesting but very unusual wheat beers

Draught@brewpub, Zürich My notes say: "Huusbier Dunkel", I am not sure if this is their "Altbier" or not (website says about altbier that it is "Ein fein-herbes, kräftiges Dunkel-Bier"). Dark nut brown color, decent beige head. Unclean toffee and cold coffee in the nose. Milk coffee flavor with some coffee beans and chocolate. Flavors fade away quickly. Their tastiest beer, but this one is not real gem either.

Draught at the brewpub Hazy dark amber color with a red hue; creamy head, with the foam sticking on the glass. Very light aroma of roasted malt. The body is just one notch above the Huusbier’s, but still not sufficient, with light flavor of sugar and burnt sugar (more bitter than ordinary caramel). In the end the bitterness given by the roasted malt and hop is disturbing, lost in the sea without malt support. I think they have a problem with the malt here… I got information from the waitress that some of the beers are still brewed at Back & Brau (ancient owner of the premises), as they still use their beermats.

<!-- i -->draught<!-- /i --> - cloudy dark brown colour with a big beige head; earthy and biscuity nose; low carbonation and a decent malt body; initially quite sweet with a late but solid bitterness; more biscuity maltiness in the finish - correct

Laffer Antrunk von seichtem Getreide, schwach kommen Assoziationen von Marmelade zustande. Sofort muffiger, gummiartig und unstimmig. Das muffige im Aroma setzt sich fest, stärker wird das Bier nicht mehr. Es bleibt so bei dem laffen Getreide, das durch Gummiaromen weiter heruntergezogen wird. Ein Bier zum Wegschütten! 6/4/4/3/9/3

Bottled (thanks KR!). Pale golden colour with small white head. Aroma is bready malts, some slight fruityness, herbs as well as quite strong grassyness. Flavour is being quite much the same. Not good, not bad either.

Bottled 33cl. It pours a faintly hazy beer with a fast diminishing white head. Fizzy. Some apple juice in the nose. The taste is rather sweet. Some candy showing up. Poor mouthfeel. Watery and metallic with a hint of chestnuts and mushrooms. The alcohol is too present. Musty. Lime and lemon in the finish. A awful lager.

Bottled (BB 11/2007) Golden color, small white head, some lace. Fruity, apple-like sweetness in the nose. Sweetish but light fruity (green apples) malty brew, no hops found. Smooth carbonation. Hammer is quite misleading name for this light and sweetish pale lager - one could expect strong powerful malt likka!
Blond color; frothy head, reminds me soapy washing water. Poor Lager, very low bitterness, and with a light off flavor to lower the score. Stay away.

labeled: "Man’s best choice" - very slightly hazy amber colour with little foam remaining; aroma of corn and caramel dominates; light-bodied, moderately sweet but mainly deeply neutral; no bitterness; short watery finish - a full glass of nothing; my conclusion is that I’m not a man ...

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Donkerbruin bier met veel schuim wat snel wegzakt. Smaak is licht bitterzoet met een zuurtje en iets van bosvruchten en wat karamel.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: 33cl bottle from Cora in Brussels. F: gusher after opening! Medium, tanned, very quick gone. C: dark brown, hazy, opaque. A: sweet dark malty, caramel, dark fruits, candy. T: sweet malty, fruity, caramel, dark fruits, almost dry on the palate, dark bread crust, if there was no gusher could be almost enjoyable but still very simple brew, medium carbonation, partially enjoyed.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Slow gusher. Very dark brown with thin head. A sweet taste with brown sugar. Lightly spicy with clove.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Bottle @ weekly tasting shared with Dutchdrebus. A bit unclear dark red to amber color, no head. Aroma is overripe red fruits. Taste is sourish, red fruits, tart. Average body, low to average carbonation. Quite bad actually.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Bottle @ home shared by benzai. Hazy weird red brownish with no head. Smells infected, sourish, herbs, bad. Tastes sour, infected, herbs, malts. Too much carbo, horrible taste, thin to medium body.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: 29/XII/14 - 33cl bottle from Geers (Oostakker) @ holiday - BB: VIII/2015 (2014-1560) Clear red brown beer, small creamy beige head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: chocolate, bit malty, raisins, dried fruits, sugary, caramel, bit of banana. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: some chocolate, bit soapy, minty touch, bit of mocha, cocoa powder. Aftertaste: quite some chocolate, caramel, nice bitterness.

Black with a brown head - Dark roasted malt aroma with some chcolate aroma as well - Dark malt body with some roasted flavour as weel as some chocolate flavours - The dark roasted malt flavours with bitterness goes into the finish - This was good

Dark brown, almost black. Brown head, three fingers, bad retention. Difficult to see the carbonation through the darkness. Oily texture with little fizz. Aroma is parfum, orange parfum, pine, cedar, liquorice, ash. Taste is herbal, pine, cedar, citrics, roasted malts with ashy coffee hints. Soft sweetness. Some resiny bitterness at the end with cedar and pine notes in aftertaste. Alcohol relatively well integrated.

Bottled. A black beer with a dark brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, hops, citrus fruits, and chocolate. The flavor is sweet with notes of citrus fruits, hops, chocolate, and roasted malt, leading to a bitter finish.
Tap at brewery. Pours deep dark brown. Aroma and flavor are chocolate, roast, coffee, earthy notes, and a hint of booze. Full body

Bomber to myself on 30th March 2019, while on holiday in California. Black bodied, decent tanned topping on all three pours into a lovely 'Kasteel' chalice. Chocolate maltiness throughout the brew, aroma and flavour wise. Traces of vanilla and caramel sweetness in the taste. Liked it.
Bomber. Aroma of chocolate and some vegetable stock. Flavors follow, with chocolate and faint roast predominating. There's also some vanilla here. Rich.

22 oz bottle. Thanks Timo A! Enjoyed on August 17 2018. Black color with a medium size foamy light brown head. Roasted malt, coffee and some vanilla sweetness in the aroma. The flavor is roasted malt, darkness, coffee, chocolate, dryness and bitterness. Balanced.

22 oz. bottle, pours black with a small tan head. Aroma brings out woody piney hops and roasted malt in good harmony. Flavour is robust, with lots of woody piney hops and robust roasted malt. Excellent hop punch interminglign with the roasted malt. Very good.

Got as a gift from RaulMondesi. 22 ounce bottle into snifter, no bottle dating. Pours opaque dark brown/black color with a 1-2 finger dense and rocky khaki head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Thick soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of big milk/dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, caramel, brown sugar, toasted dark/brown bread, and nuttiness; with lighter notes of smoke, charcoal, vanilla, cream, toffee, molasses, dark fruit, citrus, pepper, pine, and roast/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of black/roast/bready malts and light-moderate citrus/pine hop notes; with great strength. Taste of huge milk/dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, caramel, brown sugar, toasted dark/brown bread, and nuttiness; with lighter notes of smoke, charcoal, vanilla, cream, toffee, molasses, dark fruit, citrus, pepper, pine, and roast/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate roast/char and pepper/piney/citrus peel hop bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of milk/dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, caramel, brown sugar, toasted dark/brown bread, nuttiness, smoke, char, citrus, pepper, pine, light molasses/dark fruit, and roast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of black/roast/bready malts and light-moderate citrus/pine hop flavors; with an awesome roast/hop bitter/sweet balance; and zero acrid/astringent flavors after the finish. Lightly increasing dryness from hop/char bitterness. Medium carbonation and medium-full body; with a very smooth, creamy/silky/bready, and lightly sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is fantastic. Zero warming alcohol for 8.5%. Overall this is an incredible imperial stout! All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of black/roast/bready malts and light-moderate citrus/pine hop flavors; very smooth and easy to drink with the mellowly bitter/drying finish. For an American style imperial stout, this does everything perfectly. Very rich and complex malts with supporting American C hops, without overwhelming the malt profile. A highly enjoyable offering, and spot on style example.

65 cl bottle. No freshness info. Pours black color with a large beige head. Aroma is licorice and some roasted malts, caramel, fair amount of hops, some chocolate and hints of coffee. Flavor is bitter malty, chocolaty, mild cocoa notes, licorice, caramel sweetness. Quite nice and pleasant. 4425
On tap at the brewpub. Pours cloudy amber medium white head. Caramel, malty, moderate hoppiness, cirus, light sweetness and some bitterness in finish. Bit watery. Medium- bodied.
Draft at BBQ. Pours amber red with an off white head. Toasted bready and lightly sweet malts, light earthy bitterness, and a quick balanced finish. Quite drinkable.
Classic red ale, caramel and bread with a good dose of citrus and piney hops. Not bad.
On tap at Capitol Beer & Tap Room. Pours Reddish brown with a clinging beige head and a citrus aroma. There is a fairly thin smoked malt flavor with a dry bitter finish.
On tap at Toronado SD. Lacy, hoppy with good malt backing. Dry but still above average brew.

Tap. Pours clear reddish amber with a small beige head and good lacing. Aroma is light with notes of caramel and grass. Flavor is the same, light on flavor overall. Light sweetness, very light bitternes. Light body, overall a boring beer.

Appearance is brownish red with a nice head, bit thin. Aroma is nice earthy hops and caramel, spicy nobles. Taste is initially the nice hop presence followed by a really odd malt combo that ends up like plastic-y toast. Palate is nice and easy drinking. Not the star of the the show.
Draft. Clear red amber pour, off-white head. Caramel malt, grain, and citrusy hops. Fairly light, easy to drink, but boring. I am not a big fan.

Sample at the brewpub. The beer is a deep brownish-amber color with a medium light tan head that diminishes steadily. Rings of lacing. Aroma of malt, molasses and a bit of citrus. Medium body with flavors of sweet caramel malt, citrus and hops. The finish is malty with a lingering sweetness. Decent brew overall.

My Bottom Line: This balanced and cushy Red Ale aligns subtle caramel malts and wooden hops into a cohesive whole which is perfect to attract neophytes into the world of real (craft) beer. Further Personal Perceptions: -A sheet of foam tops the cloudy dark red. -The caramel malt character nears chocolate. -This mouthfeel is yet another wonder from Kern River which feels nourishing yet really easy to drink. -The flavour profile may be tame, but this remains as competently crafted as any other Kern River brew I’ve had. On tap at the brewpub.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Devils Pale Ale 666
column5: Pours a large frothy beige head and has a murky, dark amber appearance. Looks like dirty rusty water, devil's pale ale it seems. Has aromas of earthy hops and nutty malts. Flavours seem to have a bit of toffee and light chocolate hints but mainly some bitter type earthy hops. Also some hints of toasty malts. Medium bodied. Average retention. Fairly smooth sensation and slightly astringent on the palate. Pretty good stuff.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Devils Pale Ale 666
column5: Apparently, I've been living under a rock and only just emerged. This has been around for quite a while now, but I guess I haven't had it offered on tap before—let alone cask. (Nor have I picked it up at the LCBO, if I've seen it there.) I just had it for the first time, and it kind of blew my mind. It's a combination of things I didn't expect. At the start of every sip, I thought, "No, I don't think I like ...," and by the time I was done, I was thinking, "Oh, this is great!" It's a unique, addictive mix of different styles. If I closed my eyes, I would describe it as an aggressively hopped English ESB (which is a contradiction) that leans more to its ale side in hindsight. (By the way, this beer is not at all pale. I've been told that this darker colour is typical of so-called pale ales in England—even if not here.) It starts off as if it's going to be one of those "hop bomb" beers (too common among the widely diverse IPAs and pale ales in North America) that sacrifices flavour purely for dramatic effect. But as it's on your tongue, it quickly morphs and mellows out into an example of an English ale. As such, there is no single point in time during which you can taste this beer as a whole. You simply have to put up with its chameleon character. I'm not too fond of how it starts off, but I very much like how it ends. It was unique in my experience in that I always started off thinking I disliked it, but ended up thinking it was great. Perhaps it's similar to a massage—the pain during treatment is something you have to put up with in order to feel good afterwards.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Devils Pale Ale 666
column5: One of the best brews from this location. Lots and lots of malt flavor and hop bite. Result is a nice westcoast style IPA like beer with more malt. Nice head.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Devils Pale Ale 666
column5: Murky dark amber color with tan head. Aroma starts with biscuits and some spicy bread. Taste starts quite hoppy with earthy notes, some toasted malt on the finish with light bitterness. Medium body, soft carbonation. Overall it’s a quite interesting pale ale but I don’t really get any whiskey.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Devils Pale Ale 666
column5: Canned 473ml. -courtesy of and shared with Domagoj from Pivoteka. Out of BBE date for who knows how long because of unreadable print. Dark amber coloured, medium sized tan head, malt and caramel in the nose. Malt and caramel dominates in taste as well with notes of apples and touch of wood. Rather sweet finish. Not the freshest taste here but it could be even worse.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Devils Pale Ale 666
column5: Sampled from a 473 ml can this beer poured a dark brown color with tan highlights and a huge creamy beige head that lingered forever and left excellent lacing. The aroma was gritty floral and fruity hops. The flavor was bitter, toasty, malty and had a moderate floral hop presence. Medium length hoppy finish. Medium body. Ok.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Devils Pale Ale 666
column5: Well hopped. Hint of caramelized malt. Taste of nuts. Looks like a brown ipa.

column1: Great Lakes Brewery Devils Pale Ale 666
column5: Pours a very deep amber with a medium off-white head. Aromas of caramel malt and light hops. Tastes quite malty with a light bitter finish. Some alcohol in the finish as well. Medium bodied.

column1: Church-Key Riders of the Purple Loosestrife
column5: Bottle, pours a clear yellow, aroma is sweet and the flavour is quite harsh a typical tasting mead and it was okay

column1: Church-Key Riders of the Purple Loosestrife
column5: Cask at Volo, clear amber-gold, completely still. Light aroma of yeast and sweet fruit. Taste is a disaster: alcohol, bitterness and a dull, clingy sweetness. But good grapey-herbal notes like a sweet German white wine, or a muscat. Leafy. Incomplete.

column1: Church-Key Riders of the Purple Loosestrife
column5: bomber from tupalev shared at a KW group tasting. pours thin glowing green. honey and lavender nose but the decaying honey sweetness was the most noticable. the flavour was to deconstructed to really be commented on. way past its prime. i hope to have it again but much fresher.

column1: Church-Key Riders of the Purple Loosestrife
column5: 650mL bomber, last of the night at our KW group tasting. Bottle originally from Jeff, bought by Matt. Thanks guys. Pours a lime green colour with no head or carbonation. Seriously, this is the first time I’ve come across something legitimately green in colour. The aroma is just not good. Beansprouts, booze, minor honey, not at all inviting. Borderline revolting. Flavour is awful, though I can almost detect some honey comb in there. Way too sweet, way too boozy, and kind of reminds me of wax. Bees wax. The earth behind Matt’s house is now stained with a poison which will prohibit the growth of grass for the next few decades.

column1: Church-Key Riders of the Purple Loosestrife
column5: On cask at Volo: Appearance: White wine but slightly cloudy. Aroma: Honey & wine. Flavour: Very sweet, similar to an icewine. Nice though and easy to drink. The 8% is not noticeable.

column1: Church-Key Riders of the Purple Loosestrife
column5: [1805-20081018] Cask. Apple flower blossom wheat aroma and apple skins. Hazy, pale yellow white body with quick white bubbles. Fruity apple skins flavour also hints at sweet apples with some berries. Light-medium body. Tastes better than it smells. (Cask Days 2008 @ Volo; Toronto, ON)

column1: Church-Key Riders of the Purple Loosestrife
column5: cask @ volo tonight. very floral and light. light, light citrus and clear honey flavour, long sweetness is nicely balanced and not cloying. a little cloudy, pale yellow. tastes like a summer day. a very nice mead.

column1: Church-Key Riders of the Purple Loosestrife
column5: Cask@Volo last evening. Nose is a fruity lemon honey mix, very hazy yellow, zero head. Taste is like lemon cough drops, light bodied, a bit sweet. Good. Thank You Ralph.

column1: Church-Key Riders of the Purple Loosestrife
column5: Cask. At Volo Cask Days 2008. this rating has eluded me for a long time - and now I get it on cask! Poured a pale greenish, somewhat oily-looking, no head, a little clouding to it. Aroma of fresh clover and honey - pungently of clover. The taste is very light and delicate, just mild honey sweetness, very grassy and fresh. Incredibly soft and light mouthfeel, still on the tongue, a light quick finish - yummy and dangerously easy to drink.

column1: Church-Key Riders of the Purple Loosestrife
column5: cask at Volo Appearance: Bright with greenish tint mead. Rocky ring on top. Nose: Good mead aroma , slight sourness with honey sweet , flowery , alcoholic side. 7+ Flavor/Palate : Full bodied. Flat front with clean mead-honey feel in center. Flowery feel abound, sweet sugary finish. Slightly flat at end, missing alcoholic punch to balance.

Bottle 200 ml at Volo - Toronto Appearance: thick , mid haze , little to no lace , amber brown. 3- Nose: Medicinal , sour fruity feel with sweets below , touch of plum. 6- Flavor/Palate : spiced vegetable , touch of cabbage , honey and alcohol. Rough vegetable mid with sugary sides.

200 ml bottle from Garthicus. Nose of honeycomb, the sweetness of candi sugar, and some light apple notes. Clear rust with a very few bubbles. Flavor is sweet honey with some golden raisins, and actually only a tiny bit of alcohol. finish slightly sweet honey! Duh! another mead, maybe! Pretty decent if it’s a mead. Pretty poor Barleywine!

200mL bottle from the X-Mas giftpacks that for no apparent reason just showed up at my LCBO, ’seasonably late’ I guess. The word ’bizarre’ doesn’t begin to describe this beer-like substance. They obviously spent a FORTUNE on the packaging of this product, the label on the tiny clear-glass bottle being a peice of cardboard that was obviously cut out by hand. Oh but it doesn’t stop there. In the bottle, it’s a pale gold colour, upon pouring, IT CHANGES COLOUR! I s*** you not, turns a darker amber-gold hybrid colour with surprising carbonation. Wow. Smells, odd. Booze, cardboard, pen ink, Chrystal malts, and a single hop bud getting the crap beat out of it by the booze. Flavour is, UUUUHHHHHGGGGGG. That is the adjective I have chosen. This might be the single sweetest ’beer’ I’ve ever come across. Holy crap. Unbe-f***ing-lievably sweet malt body with some Earthy hops in the finish. There might be more in there but I’m too busy picking up my teeth off the floor that fell rotted out due to the sugar content to notice or care. This product is f***ing insane. Why? And now all that carbonation suddenly disappeared? What? Absolutely undrinkable. It’s like a trip to the dentist. What an insane and probably unneccessary experience. I might have just lost a piece of myself that I’ll never get back (and it’s not just my teeth).

Date: March 27, 2009 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting Words: rated as a mislabeled mead Appearance: clear dark amber, still, viscous Aroma: sweet dark caramelized and honey aroma, light fruityness Body: thick body Flavor: sweet honey flavor, nice fruity character, just a hint of alcohol Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.9/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **4

Pours a mostly still transparent copper amber and some legs. Aroma of sweet dark honey and fruity berry notes with a touch of lavender. Starts with a rich sugary malty sweetness and a touch of raisins and dark berries before a lightly warming finish. A pretty decent mead (mislabeled as a barleywine).

200 ml bottle from an LCBO gift pack. wow these were weird beers. this offering pours a simple still amber. no carbonation at all. the aroma is very sweet. very much a watered down malt extract aroma with an apple note thrown in. the flavour is also quite sweet. there is just nothing to help the sweetness at all. this sample came back lab tested by the LCBO at 14% but there is so much residual sugar that im sure with the proper yeast strain this could have reach ~20% ABV. not that it would have made this beer any better, im just trying to impart on anyone who is reading this just how sweet the "finished" product was. i just dont know what to make of this brewery and im truely surprised to see it remain in business and hold the shelf space it does at the LCBO.

Bottled sample. Amber in colour with moderate carbonation. Aromas of stale pale malts, earthy hops, and chemicals. Some hop flavor, but the thinned out caramel malt and earthy/dirty water notes are strongest. The chemical astringency along with a thin body make for a poor drinking experience. Not good at all.
Clear amber w/ a few gray bubbles. Sweet aroma w/ some fusel notes. syrupy feel. Sweet flavour of caramel & brown sugar w/ an extremely intense, malt liquor-like alcohol presence.

200 ml bottle- Deep brown liquid letting some light in, pours an off white one finger of foam. Nose is very strong spices and port wine with licorice and deep rooted Belgian candy sugar and wine gums. Lots of booze too. Tastes of sweet port wine with clove and peat. Mid way, there is very sweet alcoholic Belgian candy sugar and caramel leading to a very big and boozey sweet malt finish. This is a sipper, but I enjoyed the time I spent sipping on it.

I feel kind of funny drinking a beer called Korruptor with biohazard signs all over the label; is this okay??? Dark brown golden colour with no head and no lacing. Aroma is thick with caramel malts and nothing else that is all to discerning, and over fermented yeast like a roasted hunk of wheat bread. Flavour is thick with alcohol and caramel malts. Palate is thick like syrup. I won’t be wanting this anymore unless someone gives it to me.
Bought in 1.5 liter can. 99 cents can't be beat. Nice amber , mild taste with no after taste. Almost loke drinking purified water or Coors light.
Jasne z³ote i klarowne, drobna, doœæ trwa³a piana. Czysty s³odowy aromat i profil smakowy, wytrawne, œrednie plus nasycenie. Finisz z zaznaczona na œrednim poziomie goryczk¹.
640ml. bottle in Vientiane, Laos. Pours a clear pale gold with a minimal head. Aroma of malt, grain. Taste of corn, citrus, sugary. Watery mouthfeel. An average pilsener.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge The Bards Best Bitter
column5: On cask at the brewpub - Cambridge, MA. Surprisingly dark and the flavor shows too. More like a southern English Brown or a Dark Mild, in my opinion. Varied roasted flavors and not enough snappy hop bite to balance out. Drinkable, otherwise.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge The Bards Best Bitter
column5: Sampled @ John Harvards Brewhouse with the Mad_Indian. Pours amber with an aveage size off-white head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, and hops. The flavor is slightly sweet caramel with traces of bitterness through out. Nothing special.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge The Bards Best Bitter
column5: Sampled with Stegosaurus during our second Boston Tour. Served at John Harvards brewing. Amber pour with a caramel and mild hop aroma. A little bitter at first with hints of a hop taste. Watery and thin for me.

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge The Bards Best Bitter
column5: From tap at the brewpub in Cambridge. Pours nut brown with an off-white head. Slight dusty malt aroma. Malty flavour with a mild bitterness. Mild toffee and caramel note. Malty finish

column1: John Harvard's Cambridge The Bards Best Bitter
column5: Draught pint at JH Cambridge, 8/11/06. Somewhat fluffy, white head is retained at cover, atop a peanut colored amber-bronze. High clarity with a good deal of bubbles in the liquid. Moderate amount of lacing in rings, proceeds down the glass. Rubbery/leathery, very dry yeast-like notes emanate from the liquid. Not a very strong aroma, and somewhat bolstered by some dusty, straw/dry-grass-like hoppiness. A touch of buttercream, earth, dirt and more of the rubberiness, on the end. Not sure what to make of it. It’s not overly sweet or dry, dosent really impress much malt or real English notes on the nose. The flavor contains the rubbery aspect. It’s not autolyzed yeast or anything nearly that bad, just sort of an old, dry hoppiness, or like artificial turf smells. Some definite nuttiness, clean, pale malt sugars and more straw-like notes. Not watery, at all, with a pretty substantial, minimally creamy texture, but there seems to be far more texture than flavor. Certainly nothing lively or even very interesting/complex. No alcohol noted, carbonation is moderate.

No head. Dark brown color. Nose is earthy with hints of whiskey, Halloween candy. Malty mouth with much more caramel, chocolate and whiskey notes. Can’t say its overly complex but not bad (this is 2006 release)

Backlog rating. Can at Chriso’s tasting May 2014. It pours an amber color with a small white head. Aroma is sweet and malty, with notes of toffee, ripe apricots, orange marmalade. Taste is similarly sweet with a lightly tangy finish with small notes of alcohol. Toffee, caramel, molasses, more ripe fruits. Quite light in body with soft carbonation. Overall, not extremely bad but definitely too sweet for me

Bottle shared at Chrisso’s May 2014 tasting 25/05/2014. Thanks to Ian? Japanese Scottish Ale? Dark orange / amber coloured pour with a halo of off whiute head. Aroma is sweet caramel, stale malts. Palate is sticky sweet, . Flavour is corn, caramel bullshit.

25th May 2014 Tasting at the ever gracious ChrisO’s. Hazy gold - amber beer, small very pale cream colourer head. Palate is light and airy. Caramel malts and creamy sweetness. Whisper of tangy dried fruits. Light dry finish. Not too bad.
Chriso May 2014 tasting. Can from kyotolefty. Hazy amber lasting off white head. Bit stale on aroma. Some malt. Not great.

2013 Can @ Chriso May 14 tasting. Pours amber, thin white head, sweet orange aroma, taste presents hoppy caramel, overripe fruits, apricot, malts. An interesting taste but not sure I could stomach a few cans of it.

2013 can @ Chriso. It pours clear amber with a medium yellow-white head. The nose is musty, sweet, sticky, caramel and orange sponge cake. The taste is toasty, orange sponge cake, candied peel, muffin, earthy, toast, hay, sherbet and icing sugar with a dry finish. Light-medium body and fine carbonation. A bit sweet and one-dimensional. Not for me....
(2013 version) Caramel malt aroma. Sweet caramel flavor, plum, raisin, smokey finish. Fairly decent Scottish ale, even though the dry alcool slowly overtakes the caramel sweetness.

can by kytolfty (?) pours clear , light orange almost no foam smls ight , malts. low carbo . taste is a bit metallic, bit hops ( not bitte ) sugar , espcialy in the aftertate. sweet malts, bit harsh aftertaste .

Can from the brewery. 2013 version. Malty nose, caramel and some smoke. Lightly salty. Medium brown with a low head. Malty, smoky flavor, caramel, peat, peaches, orange. Interesting. Doesn’t all mesh so well, but still nice. Somewhat sweet, but still balanced.

Good color from a traditional English brown ale -- not too dark or murky. Sweet chocolate and hazelnut aromas. The bittering punch from English hops slides into a rougher texture, dominated by bitter chocolate notes and faint citrus. Kind of a mixed bag, but quenching on the finish and balanced throughout.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours light amber with an off-white head. The strong raspberry aroma is quite pronounced. You get a raspberry flavor at first, then a mild tartness that whimpers away without much of anything. Great aroma, though.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy dark gold with a poofy slightly off-white head. Good flavoring bitterness immediately, but is a bit too dark in color and has an unusual amount of sweetness for the style. Has a nice bitter drying finish of Saaz (?) hops. In spite of the style discrepancies, this is a very refreshing and tasty beer.

On tap at the brewpub. Poured a dark copper with a dirty white head. Aroma was great: Belgian yeast, spices, banana, and clove. Banana, clove, and belgian yeast make up the solid flavor profile of this one. Good body for the style.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a murky light prown baby poop color with a thick off-white head. The aroma is AWESOME! very strong banana aroma at first, but as it warms, I actually get pronounced mustard aromas. Flavor has a yummy tartness with really good sweetness as well. The esters are rich and can tasted as delicious banana. The honey mustard dressing flavor emerges at warming as well. This is a nice beer. The only drawback is the dark color for a non-dunkel.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy orange-amber with a fleeting white head. The beer is somewhat flat. I detect a mild berry flavor as well as the pronounced wheat taste. This beer lacks the typical Platte Valley Brewing thickness or body. It seems to need more of everything. As close to dishwater as you will ever be served at this otherwise outstanding brewpub. Best part about the beer was the warmer serving temperature. UPDATE 9/13/7: On tap at the brewpub. A way better beer than my previous score of 1.9, I must say. Thin white head, intense orange aroma. Smooth mellow fruity flavor of oranges and coriander. Very toasted malt flavor makes this a good drinker.

75cl bottle (4%) from an organic shop in Vieux-Lille, shared with Soph. Pours an unclear orange, lasting white ring atop. Aroma has sweet, pulpy apple fruit. Taste is moderately sweet, mushy apple fruit, some sweet fleshy notes. Clean, a little smooth, but nicely fruity. Decent.

Bottle shared. Clear golden with lasting small off white head. Sweet apples, light flowery, soft dusty cellar in the background, some honey, grass, earthy touch. Under medium sweet and very light bitter with soft fruity tartness. Under medium bodied with fizzy carbonation.

750ml wired cork bottle. Slightly hazy golden colour, short-lived fizzy white foam head and aroma of sweet apple, cooked apple. Taste is sweet, fruity, apple, juicy with some baked apple, slight tartness and alittle biscuit. Medium bodied, low carbonation, sweet finish. Quite OK

Bottle (375 ml) from my local cheese shop. Clear to shady golden, medium brief head. Fresh mature yellow apple aroma. Medium bodied, low to medium carbonation. Semi sweet, low acidity. Nice and uncomplicated.
Viel zu süß und zu pappig. Leicht in südfrüchten und ebenso im äpfelchen. Trinkbar, dumpf, geht so.
Sample from Erzengel, many thanks. The cidre has got a clear golden colour with a thin body and mild carbonation. Aroma of red apples and sugar. Taste of sugar an dapples. Sugary sweet fnish.
Vielen Dank an Erzengel! Trübe hell orangegelbe Farbe, wenig weißer Schaum. Geruch mild fruchtig nach Äpfeln, leicht trocken. Geschmack nach süßen Äpfeln, leicht mehlig, trocken.

Fruity-neutral nose. The cider starts sweetish with not too much depth. Like the Brut one, only sweeter. Sweetish ripe apples, very easy to drink. Honey, very mild. Ripe apples in the aftertaste. Nice.
75cl bottle from bio store. Clear orange color and thin head. Thin head. Thin body. High sweetness. Aroma is red apples and light herbs.
Nice little cider that says "mild" on the label, but the aste is a little too muuch on the vinegar side to be quite drinkable.
Bottle. Little cloudy golden colour with a little head. Aroma of fresh apples. Very sweet flavour of apple, nearly too sweet, but very easy to drink and tasty.
Bottle. Cloudy yellow coloured with a white head. Sweet aroma of apples and almonds. Flavour of apples with notes of almonds.
Pours brown with a thin tan head. Smells of sweet malt and earthy. Tastes of caramel, some light spice and a mildly bitter finish.
Draft poured a deep brown color. Off white head. Roast and coffee flavor and aroma. Like a light porter. Put down four with a southern BBQ dinner.

Bottle thanks to maniac’s generosity! Pours dark cola/chocolate brown with a medium head that reduces a bit but isn’t in a hurry. Dark fruit/raisin aroma is very strong, with some toffee and chocolate. Taste is very strong chocolate with some graininess and alcohol. Damn, this is good. Funny that this beer goes seven and a half months with no ratings and then suddenly gets three ratings in three consecutive days!

05/21/08 side by side comp with 2007 Tavern Ale. Very dark mahogony. Big raisin plum and coffee aroma over rich sweetness. Plums raisins and molasses flavors with some coffee. Surprizingly light mouthfeeel with some cholate and coffee in the finish. Bit thin for all the roasty stuff and maybe a touch of oxidation? Overall quite delicious. I liked this much better than the subsequent release. Thanks to either Butters or Maniac for getting this.

Pours much darker brown and with almost no head. Wonderful chocolate, coffee, roasty tasting and aroma notes. Definitely fits to be a porter more than a brown. Creamy mouthfeel. Of the two, this one is far superior.
RBSG 07 Minneapolis Grand Tasting: Brown, light head and lacing. Nose of bright hops, nutty malts, creamy. The flavor is balanced, nice and malty. Sweet, creamy. Bien.

Theres a lot wrong with this beer. Near black pour (especially for a brown), with a weird, chewy, marshmallowy vegetal aroma. 3 day old bubblegum comes to mind. A bit of caramel in there. Taste is oddly minty, acetic caramel and more off vegetal flavors. Not digging this.

Sampled at RBSG ’07 Grand Tasting room. Thanks to Immy and maniac for sharing. From bottle pours a cloudy dark orangish-brown brew with an average off-white head that dissolves quickly. Aroma of dark malt with scents of molasses, chocolate, and brown sugar. Taste is lightly carbonated, medium bodied with flavors of apple, dark chocolate and flowery hops. Finish is slightly tart with a dry aftertaste.
Brown colored with a bit of a head on top. Spicy hop aromas with a bit of fruit. Some chocolate malt is apparent in the flavor as well as some toffee.

Bottle... RBSG 07... Pitch black ale (ok, burnt orange when held up to very bright light) with a small, creamy, beige head. Decent retention. Aroma is pure chocolate! Flavor is a touch tangy (probably from oxidation), lightly sweet and chocolaty with a splash of coffee. Medium to full-bodied and velvety with moderate carbonation. Finishes lightly tangy, mildly bitter and very dry. More like a porter than a brown ale. Very good stuff!
Bottle from Alewerks. Lighter amber with nice dense white head. Mild citrus nose. Hint of spice, dry and some earthiness. Nice feeling over the tongue.

Williamsburg, Va - on tap at Alewerks Taproom. Hazy medium golden soft snow white head, light lace. Neutral aroma hint of wort if you try hard. Light bubble gum, some bready notes,some hard candy sweetness. Smooth mouthfeel. Not a whole lot going on here.

APPEARANCE- light orange color, bottle pours a luxiourios head of mighty fine bubbles and lace. There’s quite a bit of sediment hanging and slowly settling to the bottom. NOSE- light resin notes. FLAVOR- some light resiny hopiness. Not a lot of maltiness to provide backbone to the beer. Tastes thin, and un-complex.

From the bottle. Thanks, Nathan! The aroma is orange peel and wet grass, with honeysuckle and cloves. Sweet flavor, with a smooth, balanced bitterness. Light to medium body, crisp, and clean. This is an easy and approachable IPA; very sharp and refreshing.

12oz bottle. Hazy orange golden color with a white head with sediment in the bottom. Hops pine tropical fruit aroma. Resin pine orange hops and malt flavor. Medium body. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Orange, hazy big dense white head. Orange hop aroma. Cloying orange hop flavor that overstays its welcome.
Hazy orange with full head. Lychee aroma. Tropical fruit taste, pineapple, mango. Balanced bitterness.

Williamsburg, Va - on tap at the Alewerks Taproom. Hazy, light golden, soft silky snow white head with a nice film of lacing. Touch of spruce in the aroma with a hint of juniper. Solid citrus bent to the flavor, some sweet caramel notes, a touch of passion fruit fruitiness. Decently thick mouthfeel.
Solid spruce-like hops with a salty backbone with bready hops and a bubblegum finish.
Tap. Pours hazy pale gold with an off-white head. Citrus, light malt, caramel notes.
Golden amber pour. Old school floral and grapefruit hopping and plenty of malt. Not my favorite, but not bad.
I had it on tap. It pours a light amber with a white head. The aroma is pine hops, grapefruit, and grain. The taste is the same. There's a nice, flavorful bitterness to it. It's solid.

A lightly hazed golden ale with a thin lacing white head. In aroma, nice biscuit malt with grassy hops, light mineral notes, light grainy notes, nice. In mouth, a nice biscuit malt with light grassy hops, light mineral notes, OK if a bit plain. On tap at Bar Symon.

Sampled from a 12 oz bottle this beer poured a murky golden tan color with a large fluffy orange-white head that lingered and left decent lacing. The aroma was orange, grapefruit, pepper and yeast. The flavor was bitter and dryish with orange, grapefruit and lemon notes. Medium length finish. Medium body. A fine example of this style.
Nice flavor. A little hoppy. Pleasant aroma. Bbbbbbbbbbbb nbbbbbbbbbb bbbbb ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at Bar Symon. Pours translucent amber gold with a white head. Citrus/floral aroma. Med body. Flavor is sort of citrus with underlying toffee. Ok, but no reason to seek it out.
Draft: Poured a copper orange with white head. Aroma is hops citrus. Taste a little piney and hoppy.

Sampled on draught at Washington Dulles Airport. Hazy orange colour with a thin white head. Aroma of sweet malts and fruity hops. The taste is very pleasant;- biscuit-like malts followed by fruit flavours of orange marmalade, lime and peach. Refreshingly bitter, but not as astringent as some APAs, which is a good thing in my book. Fresh tasting and highly drinkable.

column4: Le Trou du Diable (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Pours near opaque with a thick tan head. Aromas if black licorice, vanilla, prune, raisins. Tastes of raisin, oak, and booze. Full body, assertive carbonation, long boozy finish. Interesting beer but I’m not a huge imperial stout fan in general. ---Rated via Beer Buddy

column4: Le Trou du Diable (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Poured at Shelton Festival, black with medium tan head that lasts. The aroma is roasted malt and wood. Medium body, roast, cocoa, oak, nice sweetness, light dry finish, very good.

column4: Le Trou du Diable (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Clear dark reddish brown with a small short lived off white head. Nose is dark fruit with some molasses, cherry, light vanilla, cocoa, wood. Flavour is lightly sweet molasses with a medium- fruit tartness. Mouth is medium slick with average carbonation. 8/3+/7/3+/15

column4: Le Trou du Diable (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 14/03/2018 - draught glass @Moeder Lambic Fountainas. Black colour with medium pearly tanned head. Nose is toasted, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, boozy, bit leather. Taste is roasted, chocolate, sweet fruits touch, vanilla. Light syruppy, dry bitter ending

column4: Le Trou du Diable (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: @ Brussel 17-11-23 (backlog rating). Ok fyllig öl med tydliga toner av malt och choklad.

column4: Le Trou du Diable (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Tap @ Moeder Lambic. Black with a beige head. Aromas heavy malty, caramel, roasted, dark chocolate, licorice, dark fruits, vanilla, coffee, bourbon barrel. Flavor light sweet, medium bitter, dark chocolate, licorice, vanilla, coffee, dark fruits, bourbon barrel, ending dry and light bitter. Almost full body.
Backlog purge. Bomber to pint glass. Golden with white head. Citrusy aroma, grapefruit and hop resin and light sweet malts. Nice balance of malt and citrus hops, some crystal malt.

I had this in the basement fridge for a very long time. Finally brought it out. It was quite chunky (floaties), which wasn’t ideal, but the aging suited this well, giving it a nice vintage flavor to match what appeared to be a rounded Imperial IPA sensibility. Decent, and a good value at its original price (under $5 for a bomber).

Out of the mouth of a deuce-deuce. The color is a pleasant golden shade, with quite a bit of carbonation and a decent little amount of head. Leaves a nice little bit of lacing on the rim of the glass. The smell is a sweet hoppy aroma. Has a sort of wood scent to it, like a Christmas tree almost. Very interesting and unusual aroma, slightly bitter. The taste is a burst of hops, with that same woodsy flavor. Like walking through the forest. The hops are bitter, but somewhat offset by that unusual tree-like flavor. Very different IPA, really stands out from the others. Distinct. Has a smooth ale feel to it, but the strong hops give it a jagged edge. It’s a really unique beer, and delicious. This 22 might be hard to swallow down, just because of it’s hoppy/woodsy one-two punch, but I’m gonna try. Truly a one-of-a-kind IPA.

Bottle pours light copper and orange with a nice fluffy off white head. Slightly stale hop aroma with some toffee and caramel notes. Crisp hop bitterness which is not unlike the rest of Lagunitas. Citrus bitterness with a sweet backbone. Almost drying on the tongue. No discernible flavors to match the sweetness. Not much backing up the bitterness. Watery mouthfeel. Not a bad beer, but more of an APA. I hope that its age is why the bitterness has dropped out. Wish I would have drank it sooner.

Lagunitas Brewing Company--Freak Out Stereo Ale--2006 Release--22 oz. Bottle--7.30% ABV--40 IBU’s? (4.0 / 5.0) Malt Ale Liquor?--Mild lace head. Slightly hazy bright rich golden color. Mellow floral hop front. Crisp clean mild sweet malt liquor Pils dry sweet mild caramel body. Easy hop spice clean end. Like #10? Sampled 10/30/2006.
Tried at toncatcher’s T3 tasting. Bottle from who else lagunitasfan. Amber yellow color. Lightly hoppy. Easy to drink. Good pizza beer.

Bottle awesome artwork reminds me of posters my uncle had when i was a kid. Pours a golden body with an off white head. Grassy peach with a light dried fruit, caramel notes and a light warming. Pine with a hint of lemon. Nice.

First off, I really enjoyed the Zappa tribute on the label; certainly took me back to the late sixties. This poured a fairly cloudy and dark gold colour underneath a foamy white two-fingered head. The aroma was a nice combination of hops and malt. The taste was much more of hops than malt, with the right amount of bitterness. Mouthfeel was okay, but I did think it was bit on the ’gritty’ side. Finish was a bit on the sweet side; not bad and overall better than I expected, given some of the slagging that Lagunitas beers have taken on another site.

***review from June 18, 2007*** Nice apricot colour with some opaqueness, light carbonation and an average sized offwhite rocky head. So-so retention but suprisingly good bubbly lacing. The aroma is excellent with its aromatic sweet candy grapefruit hops (quite candy-like), canned peaches and lichi nuts and a hint of flowery yumness - one of the better smelling Lagunitas brews. It has a good fresh flavour. Noticable floral hops (?) - very bitter! Yum yum! Some malt and a slight peppermint taste is also detected. I can’t directly taste the alcohol but it’s there. Even though it does taste pretty good it still falls short on interest. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy with an excellent bitter finish.

Beer pours a bright hazy brow when held up the light it appears to be bronze in color a off white fluffy head was produced that had some pretty good retention, this beer looks yummy. Very hoppy aroma as to be expected, grape fruit hops and a caramel malt back bone are making my mouth drool, can’t wait for the first sip. Brew starts off sweet and then finished with a dry bitterness, lots of citusy hops that are almost candy sweet, and a malt flavor that reminds me of leather (in a good way) I would have not say the after taste is tart and I’ve never had that before. This is highly enjoyable it’s pretty much a standard IPA but this is a very high quality one that is well balanced. Review done while watching Canada’s worst handy man."

275ml bottle from Shropshire. Vintage 1989. Slight hiss of carbonation. Pours a clear glowing toffee colour. Cardboard nose from the poor abused hops, but the malt is fine, fragrant, and toffee flavoured. A reasonably firm mouthfeel. The palate is clean and pleasant. Some Indian tea in the finish, and some tobacco in the middle. This is an enjoyable and pleasant experience. Very good.

12oz Bottle. Could this get any lighter? Super-pale yellow-hinted straw color, with no head. Aroma is a distant pear hint, minimal. Flavors are mucky. Rotty-flavored pear flesh, with more stickiness than I expect based on the last hard cider from White Winter. Some glue-like flavors. Little flavor density or texture overall, a bit tart, in a somehow fake-feeling way. Not that good.
Completely clear. Smells like a combo of pear and lemon-lime soda. Flavor is sugared hell in a glass. Acidic, tart, and syrupy rotting fruit. Being awful.

Props to Skyview on bringing the best and the worst to the tasting. Clear "color" with no head. The aroma kind of smells like pear, but with a dash of rubbing alcohol. Oh sweet merciful god... the taste... the horror... It tastes like rubber cement that’s gone bad.

Oh, this *is* really bad. No greater insult to the maker than is otherwise expected with a low rating, but this had notes of fusel alcohol and chemical additives. Very light color. At least the aroma isn’t completely awful.
Pear smell on a horrible product. Chemicals and alcohol. On par with their other ciders. Their mead on the otherhand, fantastic.

White winter makes great products. Except for this. I like cider, but this one is terrible. It has an unpleasant aroma of alcohol and chemicals. a complete failure. I will have to try another bottle; maybe something went wrong.

From a 12-oz bottle shared at JK’s Sprint Gathering, pours a near clear watery cider with some fizz at the top. Aroma is sweet pear syrup and some enriched white bread. Taste... oooph, a bit watery, flat mineral and ground dirt. A bit rough on the palate for my liking. Strongly recommend serving this below 37 degrees if this suits your taste.

12 oz bottle purchased at White Winter (July 2006) and sampled from a White Winter glass, a bit above fridge temperature. Very pale, almost clear yellow-gold with just a touch of fizzy bubbling....quite sweet pear-syrupy nose with a nice hint of earthy, chalky character....medium-dry flavor profile, somewhat mineralic towards the finish, touch watery but quite juicy and tasty....lower carbonation, more "natural" mouthfeel than the apple cider, I think. This is, interesting, made entirely from pears, rather uncommon for a commercial American perry.

pours a creamy orange, fluffy fluffy off white head, very thick lace. nose of malt and floral and citric hops. flavor of creamy caramel, sweet malt, and a bitter note. medium bodied, bitter finish. a good looking and flavorful beer. i brought a growler home from the brewpub.

Old rate. Pours a clear orange/amber, head is thick and persistent. Aroma has caramel, dark fruit, some floral and citrus hops. Thick mouthfeel, boozy. Flavour is very assertively hoppy and lingering...is this an IIPA or a BW? The line here is a bit blurred but I think it lends itself more to the prior and less to the later. Still, decent.
