Amber pour with white head and lace. Aroma of light dried fruit and some resin maybe molasses. Sweet brown sugar, light caramel, and some bread. Medium full bodied beer with light carbonation. Very nice winter warmer.
Pours amber with an off-white head. Bitter with some sweetness. Aromas of caramel and milk chocolate. Almost no aromas hops but lots of bittering hops. Hints of nuts and slightly toasted malts.

Pours deep amber with stark white head, aroma is big citrusy hops complemented by a big blast of caramel and biscuit. Thought this was a IIPA as well, but upon seeing it as a barleywine it fits more true to style. Citrus, candied orange and tangerine up front lead into a big overpowering malt middle with caramel and biscuit, and finishes bitter. Pretty good, but for a "hopwine" I expected more hop character.

Upon ordering this, I was under the impression that it was an IIPA. Now seeing that its a BW, my following notes make a bit more sense: This is a malt bomb, with a prominent soy quality in both the aroma and flavor. I am really anti-soy in beer. The alcohol definitely shines through quite a bit too. A nice appearance and full bodied mouth feel, but not good enough to compensate for the soy in the flavor. The most annoying part about this beer is its misleading name and label. Maybe they put a bunch of hops in here, but its all pretty relative when they put sooo much malt and left so many residual sugars to completely outweigh whatever hops they did include. For me, this is an example of a beer over done.

Draft @ Smallbar Wicker Park, Chicago, IL. Pours an amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty dark fruit aroma with hoppy hints. Fruity malty hoppy flavor with hints of caramel and dark fruit. Has a sweetish malty hoppy finish with some bitterness and some hints of caramel in the aftertaste.
Cloudy amber, No Head but some lacing, plenty of hops and cotten candy odor. tastes quite sweet with molasses. Hops are dominated. Quite a nice effort with wheat though.

Enjoyed via draft in a whiskey snifter. The beer pours a relatively light amber color, with a just-off-white head. The aroma brings strong malt characters, with an especially prevalent nod going to Munich malt. The beer smells almost like a Great Lakes Elliot Ness on steroids. I was surpised, however, by the lack of hop aroma and character throughout the beer. The palate was similar to the nose; strongly malt-centric. Again, a lot of continental character malt makes its presence known. Hops do provide a noticeable bitterness to the beer, but it is ultimatley drowned out by the aforementioned malt sweetness. The finish is fairly clean, and contains a surprisingly subtle note of alcohol. Ultimatley, a well-made, if slightly confusingly advertised, strong ale.
11th October 2008. GABF. Clear gold beer. Aromatic hops nose. A full on barleywine but with an unusual floralness about it. Unusually intense flavour.

column1: The Livery Bourbon Cask Aged Belgian Trippel
column5: (Hand bottle from BBB63) Pours a mahogany body with a spare off-white head. Aroma of bourbon, oak, and caramel. Flavor of bourbon, vanilla, maple syrup, figs, brown sugar, and caramel malt. Bourbon and oak character took away from the Belgian characteristics, but still a solid beer.

column1: The Livery Bourbon Cask Aged Belgian Trippel
column5: Bottle. Nose-Maker’s Mark Bourbon, buttery, woody, caramel popcorn. Body-very dark flat cola. Taste-watered down bourbon, flat Pepsi-Cola, cheap spiced rum, alcohol, really boils down to this: cheap rum, sweet, almost mapely, wheaty, sweet, husky, light Belgian notes.

column1: The Livery Bourbon Cask Aged Belgian Trippel
column5: Date: 04/28/2007 Mode: Growler Source: Tasting, Dark Lord Day, 2007 muddy brown, frothy tan head, sweet chocolate and bourbon aroma, strong bourbon flavor, lots of sweet vanilla brings out the chocolate, fruity esters finally work their way through, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 14/20 Rating: 3.6/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: ***/4

column1: The Livery Bourbon Cask Aged Belgian Trippel
column5: Shared by BBB63 at DLD. From a growler. Pours a murky dark brown with virtually no head. Big bourbon nose. The flavor is a complex blend of the bourbon, (which is pretty well dominanat), spice, caramel, and dark dried fruits. Hides the alcohol very well.

column1: The Livery Bourbon Cask Aged Belgian Trippel
column5: draft at brewpub....i’m pretty sure that this is the correct entry....aroma: heavy on the bourbon and very little of anything else. sugary sweet and little hints of spice.....appearance: this was a dark trippel-style beer and darker than most other trippels i have seen or tried. a very dark,bold brown and very thin head that dissipated quickly.....taste: sweet malt, molasses, dark fruit, and alas a strong essence of bourbon....i don’t believe the version I had was 14.5% though.

column1: The Livery Bourbon Cask Aged Belgian Trippel
column5: Shared by BBB63 at DLD. Thanks! I enjoyed this one. Dark brown color with no head. The aroma was of spices, yeast, and mostly bourbon. The taste starts out with some thick bourbon, but that gives way to a nice mix of wood, nuts, spices, and molasses. Very complex flavor, and really enjoyable.

column1: The Livery Bourbon Cask Aged Belgian Trippel
column5: Growler @ DLD with a thanks to BBB63: Reddish brown pour with almost no head. Some yeasty notes, floral and fruity, caramel, dark fruits, spice. Nice full mouthfeel, very smooth. I thought I picked up a hint of cardboard, but it was faint for a 7 month old growler.

column1: The Livery Bourbon Cask Aged Belgian Trippel
column5: Sample from a growler at DLD by BBB63. Pours a red-brown with no head and an awesome nose. So rich and complex chocolate, cherry, raisins, plums, and carmel. Complex flavors as well cherry, chocolate, raspberry, charred, bourbon, with a little heat. A nice brew.

column1: The Livery Bourbon Cask Aged Belgian Trippel
column5: Growler shared @ DLD ’07 by BBB63-Very interesting brew.Lots of bourbon and some belgian spice stood out in the aroma.Pours dark brown with a thin tan head.Got some spice,caramel malt and bourbon in the flavor.Full mouthfeel with a smooth bourbon finish.

column1: The Livery Bourbon Cask Aged Belgian Trippel
column5: sample from a growler at DLD (from BBB63?), thanks! - pours brown with no head. nose has bourbon, sweet fruits, apples, raisins, vanilla, and caramel. flavor was pretty sweet and hot, toasted and caramel notes with bourbon and vanilla. pretty good stuff.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Barleywine
column5: Tap @ Tap Room Madrid, Madrid, Spain. Hazy brown colour with a thin white head. Aroma is malt, sweet, dried fruits, bourbon. Taste is malt, caramel, raisins, vanilla, bourbon, oak. Full body, soft carbonation.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Barleywine
column5: Tap @ Brody's American Tap House The Hague. Poured murky dark brown with one finger tan head. Aroma: bourbon, oak, vanilla, raisins, sultana, plums, dried figs, dates, chocolate, caramel. Taste: raisins, sultana, dried figs, plums, dates, caramel, fudge, milk chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, oak, licorice, boiled dried fruits. Chewy mouthfeel. Full body with a bittersweet finish full of dried fruits. This is awesome!

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Barleywine
column5: Special treat which calms and brings a feeling a calm fulfillment. Aroma of mélasse and caramel, eben. Pour very dark copper. What strikes is that it is full bodied, ound in mouth, and low carbonated, which brings conforta And calm. Taste of dark cherries jam. Dark caramel and and bourbon cask. Not heavy nor sweet. Well done ! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Barleywine
column5: LCI. Uit de fles geschonken. Heerlijke bourbon BA barleywine, zoet, rokerig, bourbon, mooi in balans, heerlijk!

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Barleywine
column5: Bottle. Red bronze pour. Aroma of caramel fudge, delicious bourbon booze, vanilla, cherry, figs, caramelised malt and some coconut. Flavor of rich ripe red fruit, caramel fudge, raisin, figs, dates, bourbon booze, oaky vanilla and caramelised malt. How a bourbon ba barley wine should be, rich and decadent. Fantastic.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Barleywine
column5: Superbeer people!! Terrific BBA style with much balance, almost equal to Founders or others

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Barleywine
column5: Bottle 12fl.oz. vintage 2018, @home poured into a teku glass. Opaque deep amber, small frothy off-white head, settles quickly to a thin layer; aroma roasted malt, bourbon, vanilla, oak, raisin; taste heavy sweet and slightly bitter, malty, bourbon, oak, vanilla, toffee, dried fruits; sweet and prickly sweet aftertaste, almost no bitterness, alcohol, lingering roastiness; full-bodied, oily to sticky texture, flat carbonation; rich and complex, but handle with care imo too boozy, only drinkable in small sips...

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Barleywine
column5: Zapach intensywny, waniliowy, karmelowy, cukier trzcinowy, w smaku pe³ne, rodzynkowe, goryczka doœæ wyraŸnie zaznaczona, nawet wysoka jak na ten typ piwa, posmak drzewny, orzechowy, wyraŸny finisz bourbonowy.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Barleywine
column5: 35,5 cl bottle at home, bought at Slijterij Groningen, Vismarkt. Appearance: slightly hazy brown with medium sized cream head. Aroma: bourbon, date, dried dark fruits, fig, caramel, some molasse and a metallic hint. Taste: high sweetness and pretty high bitterness. Notes of bourbon, malty sweet, dried fruits, raisins, caramel and also a metallic note, but not unpleasant. Palate: full bodied, sticky texture and soft to medium carbonation. Overall: lovely bourbon aroma, but I think the base beer isn't too complex itself. Good bitterness overall, even though I prefer low sweetness barleywines.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Barleywine
column5: Bottled. 15cl sample. The aroma has caramel, raisin, vanilla, bourbon, sherry. Bit hazy, brown coloured beer with a thin head. The taste is sweet, has bourbon, raisin. Full bodied. Nice.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Cherry Stout
column5: Bottle, 355 ml from debierliefhebber. Shared with Max and Miro B. Black with beige head. Chocolate, some caramel, cherries, sweet, some fruity tartness. Tad thin. Medium bodied.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Cherry Stout
column5: LCI. Uit de fles geschonken. Mooie kersen stout met een bourbon finish. Volop kersen in de mond met een boozy finish en wat hout erdoor. Heerlijk!

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Cherry Stout
column5: Pours black, maybe I imagine the slightest hint of red, with tan head. Scent is bourbon and chocolate with some hint of a sweet, syrupy cherry. Taste is sweet cherry up front with a rich, boozy finish. Balance seems just a bit off. Overall pretty good though.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Cherry Stout
column5: Tap at TheHagueCraft. Sampled from Maurice, thanks. Black with tan head. Big sweet roasted chocolate and dark malts with cherries on top. Sweet and dark bitter. Full body and soft carbonation.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Cherry Stout
column5: Bottle. Pours dark brown with a light beige head. Roasted malt, bourbon oak, tart cherry notes. Bit of dark chocolate.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Cherry Stout
column5: Benzai’s Biertuin Lovely bourbon aroma, some cinnamon, tart cherries, vanilla, roasted, chocolate, coffee, smooth, firm, gentle bourbon flavors, alcoholic,oak

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Cherry Stout
column5: Aroma is cherries and roasted/nutty malts. The flavor is cherries, nutty/roasted malts, fruit and a slightly sweet/warming alcohol finish.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Cherry Stout
column5: 2017 Strong bourbon aroma with just the faintest hints of fruit. Almost completely opaque with a deep, dark red tone. Tan head recedes quickly to a bubbly ring with a center circle cap. Smokey taste. Lots of bourbon there as well. The cherry starts to come through as the beer warms a bit. Boozy alcohol warming the throat in the aftertaste. Smooth tasting with some tartness / bittering in the middle and aftertaste.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Cherry Stout
column5: Near pitch black pour, fast tiny offwhite head. Aroma is chocolate covered cherry truffles, oak, red wine, lighter booze notes. Dark chocolate gives way to sour cherry Liqueur, pinot noir, wood. Medium body with active carbonation. Drinks like a sour/stout hybrid. A sipper that begs for a black forest cake for accompaniment.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Cherry Stout
column5: Pour at the Great Taste of the Midwest, 2016. Not sure how I’ve missed this one previously. Dark brown pour, slightly murky. Malty with some tart cherry in the taste. Hard to find any bourbon or barrel.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Scotch Ale
column5: Pours a dark ruby. Aroma of oak and burbon. Taste is sweet with a bit of sharp bitterness that’s woody

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Scotch Ale
column5: Oh my, this is a bomb of subtlety ! Perfect aroma of scotch, moor . Pour very dark. Taste of scotch, even and moor, with green gofer beens finish. Heavy bodied whixh works fine. Sth very special ! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Scotch Ale
column5: LCI. Uit de fles geschonken. De lekkerste scotch ale die ik gedronken heb: zoet, gedroogd fruit, bourbon en hout. Mooi in harmonie. Zacht van smaak door de barrel aging

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Scotch Ale
column5: Bottle. Dark brown black-ish pour. Aroma of sweet bourbon, caramel fudge, raisin, figs, dates, oak, ripe red fruit and malt. Taste has dates, caramel fudge, rich bourbon vanilla, oak, caramelised malt, raisin and a bourbony finish. Sticky mouthfeel. Just what I hoped it would be, excellent.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Scotch Ale
column5: Poors dark brown, no foam remaining. Aroma is very nice, so is taste. Warm, boozy and sweet, nice barrel aged. (Arnhem 201902) ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Scotch Ale
column5: 355 ml bottle. Pours dark red-brown color with a large beige head. Bourbon is evident on the nose, toasted malts, caramel, some coconut tones. Flavor is caramel and some toffee, hints of licorice, bourbon-y vanilla tones, biscuit, some spice tones. Smooth toasted malty palate, alcohol well hidden, lots of flavor. Very nice. 4426

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Scotch Ale
column5: 35,5 cl bottle vintage 2018 @ home Aroma has very sweet malts and ripe fruits. Also alcohol, liquor and licorice. Flavour has sweet malts, alcohol, liquorice and some mild calvados tones. Finishes with woody notes and liquor. You can taste the alcohol here but it is not disturbing too much. A slow sipper with drinkability not so great.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Scotch Ale
column5: I'm surprised this beer gets such high ratings. The bottle I tasted was pretty rough. Copper colour with weak beige foam. Aroma a little better than flavour, but both super-boozy in a hot, fusel alcohol way. Bourbon barrel aspects were too heavy-handed: overpowering vanillins, oak tannins, mushy oxidation. Perhaps this was once a nice malty, caramelly Scotch ale base, but it's barely palatable now.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Scotch Ale
column5: 33cl flesje. Helder donker robijnrood kleur, fijne romige bruine schuimkraag. De geur van whisky en toffee. Smaak is zoet, whisky, karamel, rozijnen en vanille. Medium lichaam, veel koolzuur.

column1: Central Waters Brewer's Reserve Bourbon Barrel Scotch Ale
column5: 30/XI/18 - on tap @ Billie’s Beer Festival Day 1 (Antwerp), BB: n/a - (2018-1805) Thanks to the RateBeer crew for sharing today’s beers! Clear dark brown beer, small creamy light beige head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: lots and lots of whisky, a bit peated, alcohol, caramel, ripe banana, more peated notes, nice! MF: ok carbon, medium to full body. Taste: alcohol up front, caramel, malty, bit sweet, sugary, more alcohol. Aftertaste: nice, sugary notes, more malts, whisky kicking in, caramel notes, good stuff!
Cask at The Windmill, Stanstead Airport. An amber coloured beer with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, caramel, hops and with a bitter finish.

23/9/2019. Cask at the Windmill, Stansted. Pours clear dark amber with a ruby brown tint and a lasting off-white head. Aroma of fruit, malt, toffee, hint of berries and molasses. Medium plus sweetness and light to moderate bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation. Looks good, too sweet, massively overhyped, but brought by Cornwall count back to 100 for a second time.
Cask at Old brewery, Marlow. Pours amber color, small white head. Aroma of caramel, malt. Taste is medium sweet, caramel, malty, some hops in the end.

Draft at the Crown Rivers, Heathrow Terminal 5. Clear light amber pour, decent off white head. Nose is some Graham cracker. Middle is sweet malt but not cloying, some biscuit, light woody character. Finish is mild malt, touch stone fruit. Drinkable.
Cask: Poured an amber with a thin cream head. Aroma was strong malts. Taste was bold malts, bitterness in the finish.

Cask at the Windmill, Stansted airport, UK. Pours transparent amber with minimum foam. Aroma is malty and a little spicy. Body is average with very subtle carbonation. Taste is moderately sweet with some hints of underlying bitterness. Finish is average.
Licht zoet, karamel tonen maar ook duidelijk gedroogd rood fruit. Best een fris biertje.
Amber color, clear, good lacing. Not intensive aroma of herbs and tea, medium body, low carbonation, smooth.
On tap. Pours a mahogany color with light head. Aromas of bready malts. Flavors add dull fruit and cardboard
Cask at Hare and Hounds, Appleby. Clear copper appearance with lasting thick white head. Aroma is nutty and caramel. Flavour is malty, toffee, bitter, smooth and dark fruits.
On tap at Brewhaus A little light on the nose, but some nice aromas there, spritzy crisp and refreshing, a really good pils

Ahhh, it is but that sweet time of year again where big glass tankards come out and the beer takes a little longer to pour, but goes down in double-time - yes, Oktoberfest!!!. Lunch here at the Brewhaus, a Bavarian dish and this beside all glistening in the midday sun. It shimmers the clearest yellow-gold, nice even and fine streams of bubbles making their way up to burst to life in the form of a condensed pad of snow that laces intricately. It’s aroma a heady mix of gritty, haystack and dusty malts, floral hops and just a touch fresh baked, warm white bread; sultry!!! Big, yet small, rampaging, yet softer than a brush with a feather is the palate. Very clean, broad toasted malts and gritty pale grains dance with tangy, slightly sour malt and hops in back with a good infusion of peppery spices and fresh herbs throughout. The swallow so neat and tight, remains crisp, clean, floral with just a touch of late pilsner malt as it sinks down into darkness. Its front has a subtle sweetness, the very rear a moderate bitterness that flows with the flavour, a lovely linger of palest Summer grains and floral, zesty hops are left well melded to the tongue. Near a litre gone and it holds so well, keeping as if fresh poured with each sip. This is just one fantastic, true to style pilsner, the best I have had since returning from Deutschland and one worthy of more than just a Silver at the Beer awards. Definitely one I’d go out of my way to savour, a truly lovely drop!!! (90cL tankard, from draught)

Sample on tap at the 2007 Western Australian Beer Week Launch Poured a cloudy straw/white, with reasonable head retention, Nose was of rotting wheat, Flavour was slightly acrid with lashings of raw wheat. Not nice at all.
This Witbier had a massive elegant coriander aroma on the nose, which translated into a drinkable belgium white with the mandarins on a secondary after taste. It was great to drink on the sunny day!

Pint on tap at The Garden, Leederville. Golden orange beer, creamy white head. Many tiny bubbles. Nose is citric and a bit grassy. Crisp, clean, bit of bite. Finishes with a herbal dryness and a late dash of bitter lemon. Looks great, smells great, tastes great. What's not to like?
On tap at the Brewhaus, Lovely englis hop aroma, bursting with a malty sweetness.Thick and malty on the palate, with a great floral bitterness. A truly pleasant surprise

Draught @ the lovely, absolutely huge, no expense spared brewhouse, Mindarie Keys Marina, Mindarie. Honestly need to sit back and change my opinion of micro’s in Oz. We brew up some pleasant quaffer’s here and there, but the general Aussie beer drinker doesn’t want lactic sourness, yeasty extremities or high alpha acid ales, he/she just wants something that tastes like beer!?!?. Subconsciously, and hell even on the surface, I didn’t expect much of this ale. ’IPA’ as a term has been used and abused, but there is light at the end of the tunnel. And I think it lies in this gem. Tasted in it’s own standard pint glass, very British. Presented well; tight, though flaccid head of cream that lasted and legged it well down the glass. Body was a bright, sparkling orangey copper that held very fine intermittent streams of carbonation that were sluggish to erupt. The aroma is subdued; fresh, clean malts, orange marmalade, light breadyness and some yeast. Quite Summery and pleasing enough, but it does come alive in the mouth. Zingy, well rounded presence on the palate. Nice blend of juicy ripe oranges, toasted and crystallised malts, biting, spicy and bitter, grassy hops in back and a fresh as fresh, quenching swallow that holds well in the mouth. Body is medium, very firm and solid in feel and lightly prickly in carbonation. You could say this was served perfectly. Aftertaste shows some nutty, toasted malts and spicy, bitter oranges with just and edge of vanilla that my wife picked up on her first mouthful. The fact she found it refreshing was enough to say this was a damn fine Pale ale. This coming Summers perfect session ale. Balanced to perfection, well defined and has it all working in its own favour. Very Nice.

Slightly darker body than the pils, still with no head, this reminds of an English premium bitter, nice harsh citric sort of bitterness, some caramel notes on the taste and then some nutty notes on the finish.

Similar to the Indi White though much hazier and slightly darker body, the coriander and cloves are more in the background, body is more warming, oranges is more noticeable, I probably could not drink too many, almost syrupy, best lacing out of the lot and has a better nose. A 1/2 was served in a pilsener glass.

19/1/2019. Bottle from Real Ale Shop, Wells shared at the second Kesgrave 50/50 bottle share. Pours dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma of milk chocolate, malt and nut. Moderate sweetness and medium bitterness. Moderate body, watery texture, average to soft carbonation. Watery and bland, quite
…

Nice chocolate pour with strong lacing and a good head. A surprisingly good mix of peanut flavor with strong chocolate mixed into it. I absolutely loved it and got some to take home! Paired well with a rib-eye and a lemon cake for dessert.
Bottle. Dark Reddish Brown. Bitter roasted chocolate malty ale with nutty flavour. Porter style? Chocolatey finish. Liked this. (2008)

Pours a very dark brown colour with light brown, thin and lacy head. Aroma is chocolatey, with roasted, coffee notes. The taste is initially sweet, roasted and chocolatey leading to a long, dry and bitter finish.

Bottle from Beautiful Beers, Bury St Edmunds. Pours deep chestnut with a thin beige head. Very pleasant malty chocolate aroma. The taste starts with some moderate spice before the malty flavour comes in on the finish. Biscuit, nut and a little chocolate. Nice enough, but nothing special.

Interesting one this... Having tasted the Roundhead Porter I am a bit confused with this one. Pours lighter than the Porter with a creamy head, lighter than the Porter. On the nose it’s light coffee scent with some hoppy fruitiness and the same yeasty tones as all the other beers from Why Not. Taste is light malty
…
smells sour from a mahogany dark body with white lacing, acidic vinegary flavour then i mild chocolate in the finish.

Bottled. Rubyish brown colour with a small slightly off-white foamy head. Aroma is coffee, toffee, some floral and fruity notes along with some chocolate. Flavour is chocolate, some nutty notes as well as some ripe fruits and toffee to it.

500ml bottle. Poured a deep ruddy brown with a small & fading light tan head. Roasted malt, coffee & dark berry aromas with a delicate milk chocolate note. Good, wholesome bitterness: roasty with a chewy dark chocolate & coffee combination in the finish. Rich, rounded & medium in body with a lingering, dry
…

Bottle from Favourite Beers, Cheltenham. Dark brown with a slight, off-white head. Sweetish, milk chocolate aroma with a touch of rum. Full mouth feel, with plenty more chocolate flavours, roastiness and dry finish. Good.
On tap in west dundee dark brown tan head aromas of smoke and peat not my favorite style taste of smoke and hops would not sample again

On tap on 11-26-08 at West Dundee location. Arrived to the table with a very thick foramy head, brown/red in color and a low/med carbonation. Aroma was very light and was composed of a smokey scent with some other roasted malt. Flavor has a lot of smoke flavor but definitely perfect amount. Other flavors are chocolate, coffee, dark roast, some brown ale flavors and a small amount of raisins. Mouth feel is not very low with low carbonation. Overall, the smokiness is perfect, the beer looks good but still only ranks as a beer I would have once in a while at the bar.

Imperial pint draught, Downers Grove. Deep garnet body under a half-inch white and brown head that slips off the sides of the glass as beer goes down. Smell is indeed smoky; not overdone, though, I need to nose in close to find it. Yes, smoky taste upfront, but more like a Gouda than the bacony whiff of Schenklera (if you ever get to a Tinkoff Rauchbier, it’s in that range. Anyway, equal balance of darker srystal malt and basic north German hop thread lets the rauch take center stage. Very nice.

Draught at Downer’s Grove location 03/12/2007. Was glad to find this on tap on what the tender said was the first day. He was not familiar with the style, and said the brewer had not provided a description yet. He did not seem to interested in my elaborating so I dove in to this mildly smokey treat. Smoke more prevalent in the aroma where the woody smoked aromas meld with a strong malty body. Appears dark reddish brown, a bit effervescent with a nice bubbly head. Semi-sweet dry malty flavor with smoke and cascade hops just barely evident upfront and later in the dry mildly bitter finish. Light to medium in body, very smooth. Solid.

#874 <!-- p --> On tap at the brewery in West Dundee. <!-- p --> First off let me say that I am not a fan at all of the style. But I think that I can appreciate at least some of this. Dark dark with a thin tan head that is quickly discipating. The nose has some smoke to it but is mostly below the grains. The taste up front has some smoke to it but not nearly as offensive as most smoked are. I think that real fans of the style will find this weak and with a lot to desire. But if it is something that is more mild, more drinkable, more interesting and more enjoyable to drink than this is your brew. Give it a shot, you might be pleasantly surprised.

On tap at Great Taste of the Midwest festival. Aroma of sweet smoky notes. Dark auburn color. Tan head that quickly diminishes. Very malty taste, understating smoked flavor. I wasn’t sure what to expect from this one, but it was very easy to drink.

Tap @ S&A Bartender states ABV is 7.5% Pours a very dark brown.black, near opaque, lovely reamy off white head. sweet caramel and dark fruits aromas, alcoholic warming over compex malt back ground. Hope to see more big beers available at this fine establishment.

Dark body, almost black with ruby tinges and a medium size light tan head. Burnt characters on the nose also in the taste, some tar, a little sticky, honey and cinnamon, caramel late in the peace, medium to full body and the alcohol is hardly noticeable, until to late. Served to cold, have 2 or 3 but that is enough.

On tap at the brewery’s "One night stand" event. Very impressive pour, nice amber golden color with extremely cloudy appearance. Extremely thick dense beer. The aroma is straight up ginger, more ginger than any other ginger i’ve had yet. The honey and ginger flavors do well together, think of it as Atlantics Bragget ale and Island Ginger mixed. It’s pretty tastey a bit sweet though, very interesting though.

On tap at the brewery’s "One night stand" event. Oh yeah! This was the crowning Bray’s beer of the 6 I enjoyed that night (I try to do whole pints only none of that taster crap), Pours a dark brown unfiltered with a foamy head that goes away pretty quickly. God if there were more porters like this I think it would be my favorite style of beer! Vanilla and the sweet maltiness go together so well. Damn fine beer. I love this stuff.

Draft at the brewery. Pours very dark reddish brown with a thin white head and lots of lacing. Tastes like nice mild coffee, not too bitter. Slight caramel sweetness. Light body and low carbonation. Smells slightly like coffee, nuts, grains.

Tap at brewery. Pours dark brown with a slight ruby tint and creamy beige head. Aroma is roasted and chocolate malts, earthy hops, figs, raisins, and light cocoa. Flavor is dry, roast malts forward with some chocolate bitterness, ash, and faint dried fruit; dry finish. Light/medium body and low carbonation.
Pours a semi-transparent dark brown with a small beige top. Aroma is light toasted malts and small sweet caramel. Taste again is slightly thin, toasted malts and small caramel. Kind of a let down.

Date: 10/19/1997 Mode: Draft Source: Great Lost Bear, Maine ruby red, headless, chocolate aroma, rich chocolate flavor, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

On cask at the brewery’s "One night stand" event. Poured big bubble foamy from the pump. Brown cloudy color. This beers flavors and aromas are a stark contrast from the vanilla porter i had earlier in the night. Aromas are dark malt, sweet brown sugar, and some dingy cellar smells. Flavors were good although a bit normal, which isn’t a bad thing really, just a little bland. The brewer described it as moderately hopped, but I didn’t get much hop profile out of this one, must be those EK goldings again, i have trouble finding their flavor from time to time.

Draught at the brewery. Dark red toast colored body, really nice looking in a pint glass, but the head is still and not very well formed. Has some hoppy, chewy, course malts and yeast in the nose, with some smoky charred plums and fresh cut cedar (hops) notes. This was supposedly highly hopped, on par with the Edgar IPA I was told, but I disagree - the courseness is distracting and not really necessary, and the bitterness seems artificial and out of place with the grain bill used for this beer. After a few big gulps I’m pretty sick of drinking this beer. The cedar and plum hop aromas are quite nice, but drinking this beer is another experience, and one I’m not into.

Deep amber in color, small off-white head with only slight lacing around the glass, aroma full of caramel malt & a touch of pine, full-bodied, smooth & drinkable, flavors were of caramel, sweet & rich malt, nicely balanced with a good hop character in the body as well, very rich finish with more malt in the aftertaste, a very nice session beer

Bottle 330ml. Clear light medium yellow yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, toasted, citrus, lime. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, cardboard and citrus notes. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20101212]
Bottle 330ml @ fonefan Pours clear pale yellow with a white head. Aroma has notes of lime, floral and grain. Taste is light sweet and sour. Texture is watery with moderate carbonation.
Bottle @ Southern Denmark Gathering , Ulfborg. Pours clear pale piss yellow with an egg white head. Lemon and citrus. Artificial. Dishwasher . . Some syrup/sugar.
Bottle. Clear pale yellow with small white head. Flavour is sweet, citrus and lemon.
Bottle at fonefan tasting. Small head with short duration. Color is pale golden. Aroma and taste are lemon and malt.
Bottled. A light yellow beer with a thin white head. The aroma is a cloying lemon one, while the flavor, though cloyingly lemony still has some malt notes. And no wonder the body is thin.
Bottle, 2.5%. Blah citric aroma. Very pale yellow colour. White head. Sweet flavour, no aspartam detected.
(Bottle 33 cl) Very pale - almost crystal - with a white head. Artificial, sweet citrus in the nose. Thin and watery body with citrusy notes and an artificial sweetness. 130806
Bottle. Pale Golden colour with a big white head. Lemon aroma and taste. Medium body with a sweet finish. One of the better radlers, but still a radler.

On tap at papago. Pours a nice light orange-lemon color with a nice head. Mild malt to caramel aroma. Light to sweet flavor, somewhat full-bodied. Flavor is a little drab, Light notes of fruit and sugar. Ends on the palate a mellow hoppiness, the alcohol finally comes through. A decent brew, but is it an abbey?

warm, red apple pie aroma...yeast, fruit and sugar. flavor is vinous...probably from the alcohol, woody, malty and sweet with vanilla. full bodied and almost creamy. has a strange sourness on the finish that i can’t describe.

At the 2007 Big Beer, Belgians, & Barleywines Festival in Vail. Opaque amber with an off-white head. Strong alcohol nose. This is a great beer with massive fruitiness collapsing onto a sturdy malt backbone. Has an incredibly long finish of caramel, bitterness and aromatic fruits.

Draft at Papago. Clear orange-brown color with an off white head that laced the glass. Smelled of clove, light brown sugar, white wine, and pear. Sweet on the tongue. Flavor is less complex and dominated by malt which imparts a distinct brown sugar flavor. There was a warm splash of alcohol at the end. Not bad, but didn’t completely live up to its billing as an abbey ale.

Poured an orange-brown color with a nice intial head, good retention, good lacing. The aroma was bubblegum and light caramel. The flavor was bubblegum, soap suds, some spiciness, but really lacking other Belgian qualities of dark fruits, candi sugar, yeast, etc... Alcohol was also rather sharp and perhaps this one was a bit on the astringent side of things. Not a great example of the Belgian style.

Tap @ Papago. Had an over ripe apple aroma. Amber body with small head and some lacing. Surpy body texture with a moderate cherry, plumb and slight spice for flavor. Easy on the palate a smooth not over sweet brew.

I can’t believe that the owner Ron can keep coming up with incredible new beers like this. This beer is a light amber color. Starts out on the sweet side with good caramel flavor and ends with a nice bitter, dry finish. Lots of Belgian character. The beer is said to be one of the few brewed in the U.S. with liquid Belgian candy sugar syrup. Most brewers use rock candy. Ron told me that he knows of only two other places who have tried using the syrup, Russian River and Chama River. It really made the beer very drinkable and one that is way to easy to quaff down.

Unter einem "Øezák" versteht man in Tschechien in der Regel eine 1:2-Mischung (eine 1:1-Mischung gibt es lt chemischer Nomenklatur nicht) aus hellem und dunklem Bier. Zu Kaufen habe ich es noch nie gesehen. Im Restaurant gibt es 2 Versionen: Bei einer wird darauf geachtet, dass sich die Schichten nicht mischen. Es entsteht ein attraktiver Effekt (den man von Coucktails kennt), dass das dunkle Bier mit der geringeren Dichte oben ist und unten das helle. Bei vorsichtigen Servieren und Trinken hat man so 2 Biere in einem. Meist bekommt man aber die 2.Art, wo alles gemischt ist und das Bier einen trüben hellbraunen Farbton hat. Dieses ist eine Mischung aus dem Starobrno Tradièní und dem Krušovice Original Böhmisches Schwarzbier (Èerné), das ebenfalls von der Heineken-Familie kommt. Starobrno braut derzeit (Stand Jänner 2018) kein eigenes dunkles Bier. Das Bier vermischt gekonnt die guten malzig-süßen Noten des Dunklen mit den klassischen süffigen Aromen des Hellen. Es mag ein wenig gewöhnungsbedürftig sein, aber mir gefällt es.
Pours a medium ruby brown color. Aromas of malts, something fruity, and some grass. Flavor malty and crisp with some chocolate tones in the finish.
Tap in Graz - A highly addictive beer, somewhere in between a pale and a dark lager. Interesting malty notes, well balanced.
Lane w lokalu w Boskovicach (Czechy). Nie mam zbyt du¿ego doœwiadczenia jeœli chodzi o piwa "r¿niête", ale te robi³o ca³kiem niez³e wra¿enie - trochê chmielu i karmelu, œrednia piana, bardzo pijalne.
Bottle. Amber color with small off-white head. Roasted malt in aroma, caramel, yeast. Taste sweet caramel, roasted malt, yeast. Almost no bitterness.
Pours dark copper with a beige head. Aroma is roasted caramel, nuts and light butter. Flavour is roasted caramel, nuts, light butter and light dark fruit.

Bottle. Reddy Brown with a beige head. Don’t know if it’s fair to call a mixture of Cerne and Pilsner a Vienna but what do I know. Sweet malty flavour verging on over sweet. Nice roasted character and a certain hoppy dryness. Very nice.
0,5l bottle. Clear copper color. Small white head, stays. Sweet aroma, caramel. Malty, sweetish, slight roasted body, buttery. Easy to drink.

Rating #703, bottle from a Tesco in Brno, Czech Republic A brown beer with nice head, and it even has lacings. Aroma is roasted malts but a bit of metal as well. Metal in the aroma is never a good sign, and as expected the taste was ridiculously metallic too, aside from the roasted malts. A person who sat next to me and didn’t have a clue about beer or beer tasting at all, meant that this beer tastes "like old coins", and I have to agree on that one. A bit chokolate as well, though. Beer is thinner than expected. Well, this wasn’t the best expierience, but I guess it’s a quite mediocre beer (or bit below) anyway. I have tasted worse.
Bottle. Clear reddish pour, thin off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts, sugar. Flavor is slightly bitter, slightly sweet. Thick bodied pils. Decent.
A take on a sahti. Light yellow and lots of carbonation bubbles. Aggressively carbonated, malty, with juniper flavour and a drying finish. Some hop bitterness in there. Mostly like a rye beer.
Nice, hoppy IPA, not overly sticky, easy drinking, not a hop bomb,my favorite from Old Baldy.

draught. At 2006 Toronto Festival of Beer. Hazy gold, small white diminishing head. Strong ginger aroma, but not as sweet as some - didn’t make me think "Canada Dry" - lightly spicy and bitter. Flavour wasa nice blend of malt and pungent ginger, sweeter tasting than the aroma indicated, but some good herbal bitterness in the finish - thick, somewhat flat, syrupy - for a ginger, pretty nice ... not as beery as I’d like, but refreshing.

TFOB 2006. Hazy golden orange, not much head. Prominent ginger aroma. Lots of ginger in the flavour, malt is in the background. Reminds me of my Dad’s ginger heavy stir fry.Average palate. Not bad. Could use a bigger beer backing to complement the ginger IMHO, but this was a pretty successful experiment! Nice job Perry.
Not bad for a lager, had some grassy flavor to it, abit heavier for a lager, but that was fine, probably best ice cold.
A great hefeweizen, nice color, lots of Banana, clove, slight tang, expecting less flavor to this one, but very close to German hefes I’ve had.

Sample at the Pittsburgh location. This beer is similar to Three Floyds Pride & Joy, just not as good. Clear golden color with virtually no head or lacing. Weak hops aroma, with a hint of malt. Light-bodied with subtle hoppiness that lives up (or down) to the title, along with a smattering of earthy malt flavor. The finish is pretty bland, and there is no real aftertaste. Didn’t do it for me.

OK, I’m not really sure what a ’Pale Mild’ is. This was lager clear gold, so I’m calling it a golden ale. Very muted aroma. Tangy, lightly sweet, medium woody light bittering. Lagery. Finish is initally lightly sweet, then bitters. Clean drinking. Mild lemony notes. Bland.
on tap at ’Memories’ in Richfield OH. not too bad, very alcoholy tasting. Nothing special about it.

Sampled from a Bottle compliments of a Budweiser Insider. Nice fizzy pour with a one inch white bubbly head that disapeared almost immediatley. Appearance was flouresant gold and amber with tiny bubbles rising like in champagne. Aroma was non existent. Flavor was stale dortmunder with traces of malt detectable. No aftertaste. All in all there was nothing memorable and I found the beer to be beyond boring. I won’t drink it again.
What a nice refreshisg beer. Nice reddish color with an adequate head. This must be a new lager being developed by Bud and they did one hell of a job. Two thumbs up

12/06: Very nice. Looks great, light orange. It’s light,sweet and fruity. Got on tap at Ray’s Place in Kent, OH. 1/07: The bartender at BW3 in Streetsboro told me I was the first person to order this since they got it last summer..still good. Nice looking cloudy bright orange in color. Great unique fruity flavor with slight malt flavor. Smooth and easy to drink, and the aftertaste reminded me of those orange circus peanuts. AB needs to do a little better marketing to get word out on this...first person to drink it in 7 months- that’s crazy.
No aroma. Dark golden color. Tasted like sour apples. Too sour for me. Not very good.

This draft brew from the Oktoberfest Zinzinati poured a head of medium sized white colored bubbles that was fully diminished and left behind a transparent softly carbonated orange colored body. The almost non-existant aroma was malty. The mildly vinous mouth feel was tingly at the start with a mellow finish with a mellow aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of mild astringent malt hops and mild orange. Not one that I would buy again.
Pours golden with a small, rapidly disapating white head. LIght hoppish aroma with some malt. Flavor has some malty character with a touch of hops. Overall a decent beer.

draft at columbus alefest. light colored with a faint hop aroma. thin head the quickly disapated. not much flavor, light floral and citrus hops, but not much. thin mouthfeel and an of aftertaste. AB is getting better, but they still have a long way to go.
Bottle. Clear golden in color with a nice white head. Malty and hoppy aroma. Fruity malty flavor. Sweet tasting. Finish is sweet. Ok.

Draft at Oktoberfest Zinzinnati. Small ivory head that was mostly lasting witih minimal lacing, minimal carbonation, and transparent. Malty nose. Malty and somewhat of a fruit flavor. Finishes somewhat sweet. Tingly mouthfeel. Better than what I was expecting.

If New Glarus would give up trying to please the masses with spotted cow and just get to pleasing me they would brew this every year instead of (who knows, just make it happen) the hint of Bourbon is delightful with the pure taste of a Bock. This truly is the nectar of the gods!!

I was first in line for this at the New Glarus line at GTMW 2006. Poured by Dan Carey himself and it was a very generous pour. Aroma is loaded with major bourbon, buttery caramel, brown sugar. Rich and malty, but perhaps a little too much bourbon? Dark, cloudy mahogany brown with a thick, off-white head that lasted and lasted. Flavor is sweet, loaded with fruity, caramel and bourbon flavors and a touch of vanilla oak in the finish. One of the most intensely bourbon infused brews that I have ever tried but the chewy, dried fruit, malt backbone is there to back it up. Full body, thick and creamy but the alcohol and astringent help dry it out a little. I know I have too many bourbon brews in my top 10, but they taste so damn good.

served for about a minute at great taste of the midwest.. thank god for line cutting. Poured a coppery brown color quite murky w/ nearly no head. Smells of toasted carmels some dark fruits hints of bourbon maybe a touch of tobaccoo (or maybe someone lit up near me.) This stuff smelled good, although I think I liked the regular eisbock aroma better. Palate was full and creamy. Flavor had a very well blended taste some light tartness in the finish after a big carmel, chocolate, bourbon syruppy tastking front there were some hints of a leathery wood as well and a light spice. Very well done.

2006 GTMW. Huge thanks to Dan for putting this together oh so many years ago, and to Nate for sharing this treat. Murky brown body, light tan/off-white head. Amazingly unique peppery A-1 steak and sweet bourbon. Very old-seeming and blended aroma. Flavor has A-1 again, cask, chocolate, sour brown hints, some pepper, aged caramel.
The beer has got a clear golden colour with a steady head and medium body. Aroma of hops and gummybears. Taste of hops, citrus, energy drink and candies.
Clear orange, small head, aroma of mint, fruit juice, mouthwash, flavor of mint, fruit juice, malt, light bodied.

Bottle sample at DSG’s 10K tasting at the Dancing Camel. Thanks avrashi. BBD 1/2007. Clear gold. A little corny and malt aroma, sweet, artificial sweet tomatoes taste. Light body,sweet lemonade finish and a little sweet.

Bottle sample at DSG’s 10K rating celebration tasting at Dancing Camel, Tel Aviv. Thanks avrashi. Clear light golden with no head. The aroma has notes of some weird fruitiness and nail polish. Very sweet flavor with notes of nail polish and sugar. Light-bodied.
At a tasting, thanks Oren for this bizzare experience, clear deep yellow to brown color, aroma of dough with anis spiciness, flavor of dough and apples, piercing sourness. Drinkable but quite bad.

Bottle sample at my (post-)10,000th rating celebration tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks avrashi. Best before 2007. Golden with no head. Aroma of cardboard and artificial fruit juice. Sweet, artificial, fruity energy drink flavor. Light-bodied.
* Old rating, 0,33l crown-top bottle, best before 09.2011. Süßlich-chemischer Energy-Dring, unter dem das milde Bier ein bisschen hervorschaut. Sehr chemisch im Nachgeschmack. Nicht mein Fall.

For whatever reason, the Lufthansa business class lounge at Frankfurt was serving this stuff instead of beer. At least I didn’t have to pay for it. Bright glow-in-the-dark green color, huge yellow head with lots of fizziness. Aroma of grass, hay and lime. Taste is like a light lager with lime juice added, with a metallic finish. If you like soda, try this. if you like beer, don’t.
Hellgelbes Getränk mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr süß nach Limonade und Energydrink. Geschmack sehr süß, klebrig, Limonade, Energydrink, kein Biergeschmack.
Pale yellow color. Artificial citrus aroma. Sticky sugary sweet flavor with lemon and red bull energy drink.

An orange cider with a bubbly white head. The aroma is sweet and plainly of apples. The flavor is quite sweet with strong apples and lighter wood notes, leading to a dry end with notes of apple core in the after taste. Not bad, but nothing special either.
Bottle. Very pale golden colour with a nice white head. Light fruity aroma of apple and some alcohol. Sweet flavour of apple and alcohol.

Golden colour with a small thin white head. Fresh apple fruity aroma with notes of wood and a light acidic touch. Apple fruity sweet flavour with a light acidic note. Sweet finish with a light note of wood.
Bottle. Clear yellow coloured with a white head. Light acidic aroma of apples and wood. Light acidic flavour of apples.
(Bottle 33 cl) Clear, pale golden with a rough, white head. Distinct apple aroma. Medium-bodied, lightly sweet apple aroma with a discreet tartness. Very quaffable. 160806
Bottle. Golden colour with a medium white head. Light sweet apple aroma and a sweet sour, apple, wood taste. Medium body with a sweet dry finish.

Overpowering mandarin aroma mixed with toffee. The head is very thick off-white. Alcoholic taste which is slightly offset with heaps of bitterness. Dry aftertaste caused by the alcohol. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nice malty aroma. Clearish brown colour with ok head. Strong alcoholic malt flavour with smooth bitter finish. Heavy body with low carbonation.

Well balanced brew - heavy toffee malt (a bit too toasty for my palate) and earthy herbal hops - serious ale - dark in the glass and thick on the tongue like an English beer. Enjoyed although I prefer the American style, paler, less malt-driven, fruitier high octane ales.
It pours cloudy brown with almost no head, aroma of toffee, doesn’t really smell like an IPA, taste is mildly bitter and malty.

A decent IPA from a Victorian microbrewery. Had a bottle at Mrs Parmas, decent amount of hops, bitterness and strong malt character. To sound like an absolute beer w##nker for a moment, it tasted a little old school IPA if you know what I mean. In the 2000’s this would have been utterly cutting edge. This being said, a great IPA which i would drink again if on offer.

Pours almost a brown colour with a good white head. Strong aroma of peach, passionfruits and some malts. Taste, however, is s bit disappointing. Way too malty and a tad to bitter for my taste. Some tropical fruits also, but not that present. Quite big body, fizzy aroma and a abit sticky mouthfeel. Overall, an okey IPA, but some flaws in my opinion.

330ml bottle. Pours a deep amber with two fingers of fine off white head. Nose is orange, slight peach and a bit of a boozy note. Taste is really just some citrus and pine, with lots of bitterness on the finish. Body is medium. Not particularly impressed by this. The flavour profile and aroma are very boring. Perhaps it’s an old bottle. This one night need a re-rate.

Bottle (330ml). Hazy copper-brown pour with decent white head and lace. Malty aromas dominate (caramel mainly) with fruity hops (oranges, cherries) and alcoholic presence. Palate is smooth and creamy with a medium body and well balanced malt and hops flavour profile. Finishes moderately bitter with an alcoholic burn.
Pours a dark cloudy brown with a large, frothy beige head. Aroma is malt, caramel, fruit and some hops. Taste is medium sweet leading to a moderate bitter finish. Good one.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours a cloudy copper with a thin tan head. Resin hop aroma with a balanced toffee back. Taste is very dimensional. Tasting a variety of hop flavours like citrus, tropical and also piney/resin, all while retaining the toasty caramel undercurrent. Booze is concealed, just a slight warmth in the bitter aftertaste. Great IPA.

Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass (doh, where’s the pilsener for this one). Sigh, don’t get me started. Anyways, well, here’s the rest of it. The appearance was a fairly decent golden yellow color with a one and a half finger white foamy head that dissipated within less than thirty seconds to leave some fairly decent adequate lightly foamy lacing. The smell seemed to be more of a sweet corn adjunct of sorts with a light cornbreadiness to come out slightly. The taste was mainly sweet and didn’t have much balance. It had a dry finish. On the palate, this one sat fairly light and definitely had a pretty good sessionability about it. The carbonation was dry and not exactly sharp, but it did show its presence. Overall, as my last Tahq Falls beer to put in here, I’d say this was okay, it was nothing over the top nor was it anything bad. Too bad, I couldn’t have had it in a pilsener.
tap at the brewpub - Pours clear yellow-gold with an off-white head. It has a bready malt aroma and a sweet, grainy, bready malt flavor with a light body. Decent.
On tap at the brewpub. While their ales are not very good, I rather enjoyed this lager. Pours gold with a small head. Corn and slight hop flavor.

On tap at the brewpub. Difficult to find much to say about this - as far as I could tell this is a bog standard brewpub lager designed for BMC drinkers. Maybe slightly better than its commercial counterparts but not a whole lot. I say "as far as I could tell" because there were no sampler trays at this brewpub (with only three beers available there wouldn’t be much point anyway) so I was reduced to a miniscule taster in a plastic cup - I sure wasn’t going to have a whole pint. Inoffensive but uninspiring stuff.

On tap at the brewpub. Pour of clear pale gold, with a rim of white. Light distant stale malt, heavy on the dextrose. Edges of pot roast creep in. Flavor is a bold chewy sugar, with heavy and reeking corn fusels. There’s a light nutty sweetness in the sugar but it gets run over buy a truck full of sweet corn. Palate is mostly cloying.
On tap at the brewpub. Pour a hazy orange with a white head. Fairly pronounced raspberry in the aroma and taste.

Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a decent looking hazy orange to amber color with a quarter finger white foamy head that dissipated within less than a half a minute. There was some light lacing trying to stick but mainly slid right on into the beer. The smell had the raspberry that came through slightly tart but let in a decent sweetness to balance. The taste was mainly sweet but had a decent light tartness to balance. On the palate, this one sat about a light on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation seemed appropriately styled and was fairly easy to me. Overall, okay I didn’t get as much wheat I did in the peach and the blueberry one but honestly I’m okay with that.

On tap at the brewpub. Pour of pale evenly hued amber gold. Rim of white. No aroma, save for a light dusting of raspberry and old woman perfume. Fake raspberry syrups drains this beer of any soul. Flavor is dominated by artificial candy. Malt dies. Palate is starchy with a flowery effervescence of raspberry sugars.
Draft. Weqkeat of their offerings spicy and garbage. Surprising since their system looks pretty nice.

Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a decent golden pale yellow color with a quarter finger of white foaminess that didn’t show much lacing once it dissipated. The smell had some light citrus to piney hops that seemed kinda burnt. Hmmm...uh..ok, I guess. The taste was mainly sweet but had a weird burnt/perhaps overly cooked hop bitterness to it. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a sessionability that seemed to be slightly desired. The carbonation seemed okay for the style and okay to me. Overall, hmmm...I’m not sure what happened with the smell but it seemed to have affected the taste. This brewpub has better beers and this isn’t one of them.

On tap at the park brewpub, sampled early August. Ruddy orange body, thin to no head. Light to absent body, with poorly developed bready malts that fail to buffer the palate against strange sour sweaty off-notes that are also present in the aroma. Lifeless stale dreck. I can only pray that the thousands of visitors to the falls who enter this brewpub avoid Porcupine Pale Ale, which may have been secretly developed to help devastate the craft beer movement.

On tap at the brewpub. Pour of hazed orange amber, with a fringe of light fold. Light aroma of pepperoni. Flavor is a meaty sour hop sugar. Very tart West Coast hops, not carried by body or alcohol. Touches of sloppy pork fat edges. Thin bodied with a touch of sweet orange and light grapefruit. Palate has a note of toast, but mostly grass.

Date: 11/07/1997 Source: Brewfest, Real Ale Festival ruby brown, scant head, slight hop aroma, nut brown flavor, nice bitterness, slight sweetness, somewhat complex (phoenix single hop varietal) Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

This was available both on tap and from the cask at the brewpub, and I had the latter version. (I was getting too full at this point to do both that day.) This had a dark chestnut body with a bubbly beige head. The aroma is rich and malty without being sweet, a light floral/earthy hoppiness cutting that back. This has a slightly thin mouthfeel yet delivers plenty of lavor. It tastes of bready malt, dark caramel, smoked wood, pepper, and an earthy/floral bitterness that lasts well into the finish. Nice. Lafayette Brewing Company, Lafayette, IN

From the cask during my Great Lakes region brew tour. Dark red pour with a white head. Bready nose of yeast and narrow acidity. The mouthfeel is thick and warming with low carbonation. There is a wood-flavor throughout and a taste of rye toast. The hops are floral, akin to the taste of hibiscus. Bittersweet baking chocolate finish with notes of cedar. This wasn’t my favorite from this pub, but it is definitely unique and balanced. I’m convinced that Lafayette knows what’s up.

Cask pulled sampler at LBC. My first beer on my first visit to this spot. Beer is very dark brown with a settled head. Thin mouthfeel matches the cask style. Slight coffee notes. A nice alcohol nose shows through toward the end. Deceptively mild tasting, and light on hops, therefore something not to be mistaken for a session beer.
on tap-pours a light brown head and black with red color. Aroma is rich dark malt-chocolate. Taste is rich dark malt-chocolate/molasses, nutty, secondary coppery hops.

Draft sampler glass at LBC. Low level of CO2 helps accentuate this historical style. First impression is that it’s a bit peaty. Then some nice, big coffee notes. A nice hop load gives it a northwestern tilt that really nice. Tastes much stronger than it probably is, abv wise.

Draught during my Great Lakes region brew tour. This porter fills this glass with a ruby body and a small tan head. The aroma flirts with the unorthodox by showcasing a bright grapefruit scent. Of course, more obvious porter notes are present: coffee, caramel. This is an interesting brew indeed. More zesty pine and grapefruit is apparent in the flavor. It certainly isn’t super hoppy, but for a porter. . . . the coffee notes are certainly subdued.

(sampled at the Manitou Craft Lager Festival 8/14/11). Clear amber color. Medium off white head. Moderate bready malt aroma and flavor, with light sweet caramel. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Thin texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

On tap @ 2011 Craft Lager Fest. Medium clear copper, faint head. Aroma of toasted cereal malts, toasted bread, and a freshly made tortilla from Mexico. Tasted of roasted caramel, burnt toast, and some rye. Very smooth and velvety, but almost too much so. Off-tasting finish. Almost pretty good.

Tasted at 2010 Craft Lager Festival in Manitou Springs. Dark amber with a thin off-white head. Caramel and chestnut aroma, flavors matching with a hint of hop resin at the finish. Thin and slightly watery, but this was tasted right after a big doppelbock, so that might explain the discrepancy in body.
tap. copper/amber pour. sweet malty, floral aroma. funky. more floral than the amber but it seems almost like the same beer. not a good bock.

Draught. Body is dark amber. Aroma is lightly malty (cookie, caramel), with a strong note of diacetyl, note of bubble gum. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter, unclean. Medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation. Wow. Quite a study in diacetyl.

Draft at GABF 2013. Lightly musty nose of baked bread, spice / pepper and green vegetable leaf hops, light notes of boiled egg (but not sulfuric, really). Medium body, rich malt, sugary lemon candy hop presence. Low acid and higher than normal sweetness give it some balance problems in the mouth for me, but for the most part it’s clean, just basic and simple.

On tap during 2011 Craft Lager Fest. Transparent straw yellow & a small head. Smells like a clean swimming pool and some fresh grass. Pretty interesting, if a little weird. Tasted of clean munich malt, but with a funny pool-water twang. Dry and slightly metallic. Just a little weird for me.

Tap. Pours clear light yellow with a medium, frothy white head, some retention with good lacing. Aroma is malt (grain, meal), fruity with perfume hops. Flavor is malty with light hop bitterness, perfume notes with corn and fruity esters. Light bodied, medium carbonation.
(draft). Clear, light golden color. Small white head. Light lemon aroma. Very light lemon and malt flavors. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Thin texture. Soft carbonation. Spare lacing.

column1: Brugge Brasserie Diamond Kings of Heaven 2009 - Present
column5: Draft. Dark brown pour, briney, tart, sweet, dark fruit, booze, bit strong fo rme.

column1: Brugge Brasserie Diamond Kings of Heaven 2009 - Present
column5: On tap at Side Door. Pours near clear orange with a gold hue and an off white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma is full of sour berries with some acid and a light oak and funk note. Flavor combined red wine, oak and sour stone fruit and a bit of grain backing.

column1: Brugge Brasserie Diamond Kings of Heaven 2009 - Present
column5: On tap at GTMW 2014, pours an unclear amber brown with a thin off white head, the aroma has a decent amount of tartness and vinegar along with some dark fruit’s, the flavor has a sour and funky front end with plum and cherry coming through with a vinegar like finish, interesting stuff.

column1: Brugge Brasserie Diamond Kings of Heaven 2009 - Present
column5: On tap at GTMW 2014 - Pours hazy amber with a white ring of head. Nose is lemon rind, vinegar--very malty and tart. Taste is lemon, tart vinegar, yogurt, and a bit of cherry. Medium-bodied and well-carbonated.

column1: Brugge Brasserie Diamond Kings of Heaven 2009 - Present
column5: On tap at GTMW 2014 A solid American wild ale from the central Midwest, this diamond in the rough exceeded any preconceived notions about Brugge Brasserie. Rather than a middle of the road forgettable experience it offered a tart bite and strong attitude. If I run across this again while visiting Indianapolis it may merit a full pint. Aroma / Appearance - A cloudy caramel base hazed the glass like a melted stick of chocolate. Tart vinegar bit at the air with the smell of caramel and melted chocolate. Flavor / Palate - A pleasant texture for a 12% ABV beer flows across the tongue. Vinegar soaked Twix bars stick to the corners of the palate with a sweet and sour profile. A full pour might be difficult to drink quickly but this remains an ideal beer for savoring over a long dinner. If other Brugge beers are this excellent I may have to visit next time I pass though the Indianapolis area.

column1: Brugge Brasserie Diamond Kings of Heaven 2009 - Present
column5: Great Taste of the Midwest 2014 Offering (Madison, WI). Pours a dulled decent hazed amber brown hue, a bit of orange glow on the edges and bottom with loose bubbly whitish head. Aromas are sour, a bit acidic with touches of plum, firmer oak and mellow acidity. Touches of wine barrel, tannic elements and firmer sourness, dark fruit shows plum, a bit of prune and dried fruit. Initial is dry, tart and a bit darker. Nice dark fruit. Firm sourness and an off salty element. Some gentle wine barrel, decent oak. More reeled in. Nice acidity, firm sourness but not overwhelming. A bit dry and yogurty into the backend and finish. Some nice tannic plum nectar and skin. Nice stuff. A bit darker, the plums really win me over with subtle citrus, nice acidity without getting harsh. Nice, fuzzy, dry as we finish. A winner.

column1: Brugge Brasserie Diamond Kings of Heaven 2009 - Present
column5: This draft brew from a beer festival poured a small sized head of frothy medium sized tan colored bubbles that were and left behind a hazy dark ruby red brown colored body and a oily lacing. The mild aroma was funky farm house and sour. . The flavor contained notes of sour funk and brown malt. A decent one but not one that I would consider drinking again.

column1: Brugge Brasserie Diamond Kings of Heaven 2009 - Present
column5: Snifter pour served up at three floyds brewpub. Awesome to see this on tap as I’ve been seeking this for awhile... Pours a deeper black almost stouty hued consistency, opaque mostly with deeper red edges. A thin to medium creamy light beige head rests on top which then gently recedes to a wispy film... Aroma of tart cherry and apple cider qualities, sour plum to be sure but wouldn’t have been able to pick it out on their own. Sour and tart and right up my alley. Some similarities to Joe the Plum for the sake of comparison... Earthy sour fruit and somewhat muted sweetness from the base beer. Light sour cherries, a mild degree of soft vinegar, and tart red fruit, plum not so discernable overall. Doesn’t quit deliver on the sour front and is held in check for the majority nor does it really need it. An off sour vapory medicinal note was apparent at first but slowly tapered off thankfully. A touch boozy but not overly so considering the abv and base style that is represented. Just shy of medium bodied, not full or syrupy in any way. A light lingering sweetness left on the palate.

column1: Brugge Brasserie Diamond Kings of Heaven 2009 - Present
column5: sample at GABF on 10/1/11. murky brown pour with no head. light nose with light brett and sweet fruit. medium body with a light funk, light oak and very sweet. tangy finish with light brett. avg.

column1: Brugge Brasserie Diamond Kings of Heaven 2009 - Present
column5: A: The pour is amber in color, maybe approaching copper, with a small layer of white foam that quickly dissipates. S: You definitely get the pickled plums that were added to the barrel. A nice fruity and tart quality overall, and a touch of wine and oak. Maybe a little bit of citrus and a hint of sweetness. T: Unfortunately, the flavor is note quite as enjoyable as the aroma. There are some of the pleasant fruity notes of the plums and wine, but there is also a fair amount of booze, vinegar, and some acetone. M: Medium in body with a low to medium level of carbonation. O: I liked the nose, but there were some serious flaws in the flavor which prevented this from being as enjoyable as the previous incarnation of Diamond King.
Pajiza amarillenta, sin apenas espuma. Aroma cítrico y trigo. En boca se asemeja a witbier belgas. Muy ligera de paso muy fácil, muy suave al paladar, sin apenas gas.
Pale colour, sparkling, small head. Aroma is banana, wheat, no spices. Light bitterness. Not very interesting, but quite ok.
On tap at source, pours hazy weak golden, served with a slice of lemon, ouch. Aroma and taste is clearly influenced by the lemon, crisp and juicy, not bad

On tap @ C.K. Browar, Kraków. Beer was served with a slice of lemon on the rim of the glace. Who does something like that? Milky yellow with a thin white head. Big citrus and faint banana aroma. Taste is very sweet and wheatty. Not on par with most weizens at all

Better than the first two lagers I had. But not even remotely average on the hefeweizen vibe. Pours hazy golden with good head and lacing. Tastes like there is lime already in it even though I didn't squeeze the lime. Orange peel. Sweet, slightly tangy finish. Tap at brewpub.

On tap at C.K. Browar, pours a cloudy dull yellow with a small white head, and served with a lemon wedge. Aroma brings out banana, with lemon and clove. Flavour is dominated by lemon and banana, with light clove and some cocoa wheat. Nothing special here, but it’s drinkable.
Taki sobie Weizen. W zapachu nie czuæ w ogóle pszenicy, piwo strasznie mêtne. Brakuje goryczki. Jedynie smak trochê je ratuje, bo jest doœæ przyjemny i pijalny.

Ca³kiem poprawny weizen, z³ocisty, mêtny, wysoka czapa trwa³ej piany. W zapachu banany i goŸdziki. Piwo wytrawne, w smaku wszystkiego ju¿ mniej, mniej bananów, mniej pszenicy, brakuje treœci, ale piwo jest ca³kiem w porz¹dku.
Aroma yeasty with hint of citrus. Yellow pour with large head. Aroma a bit bland: wheat, veggies, light bitterness. My glass was flat with nearly no carbonation. Faulty but not necessarily bad.
0.15 draft @ CK Browar Hazy, gold with a large, white head. Aroma is quite acceptable actually. Once again too sweet but this was the best of them all.

A clear, nearly colorless sake. Just a shade of yellow/green. Lots of fruity scents, like a fruitcake soaked in vodka. A bit unsophisticated compared to the softer flavors of Niigata or Hyogo ken sake but this is what I miss about not living up north anymore. A simple, yet good Tohoku countryside namsake. Thanks for adding this Jordan!

300mL Bottle: Misty, nice even legs, nose of bright citrus and melon, some like kiwi and alcohol. The flavor is fairly rough with some grain and alcohol notes, a bit more floral and fruity in the tail though with a nice minerally mouthfeel. Quite nice and floral in the finish, balance, mouthfeel and nose. The flavor is a bit brash, but it’s excusable. Overall a very nice nama sake with some excellent flavors vs. the semaibuai. Thanks Dan!

22 oz bomber purchased at brewery in August 2007. First had this after my son and I climbed Grays Peak 14,270 feet. Needless to say I was very thirsty after that romp. Pours bright yellow and very carbonated with a big white head. Nose of horse blanket, spices, funkiness, nice. Tastes comes through bitter and dry with pepper and spices. Good thirst quencher and well done for an American version of a Belgium farmhouse beer.

Bomber poured a clear gold with a lasting white head. Aromas of straw, spice, citrus, pineapple and a hint of banana. Palate was light bodied crisp and slightly dry. Flavors of straw, fruitiness, light spice and a hint of carmel with a crisp slightly dry finish.

Had this beer at the All Colorado Beer Fest on 11/10/2007. Aroma is a sweet scent with banana back tones. Color is a hazy yellow/gold with ok carbonation and a thin head. This is good but not great. Its a very Hefe like Saison with a sweet body and banana back tones.

Draught at All Colorado Beer Festival. Pours hazy yellow with a small, fizzy, white head, lasting with fair lacing. Aroma is average malt (grain, hay, straw), average hops (flowers, citrus), average yeast (dough, barnyard, earth) with notes of banana and pear. Light bodied, sticky texture, lively carbonation, and a bitter finish. Average duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and bitterness.
[GABF, Denver Co - 2006] Golden copper color with a thick creamy head this was a great session beer. I love these types that do not try to kill you will too much alcohol. This was a very good beer.

golden/copper pour with many rising bubbles. thick creamy white head. banana, yeast, psice and vegetable aroma. very spicy and tart. banana, spicy. balance is all off and this is difficult to drink. nice lacing.

Draft: Clear light-orange. Noisy head fizzles into nothing. Uninteresting nose of baked apples, lightly toasted malt, and unripe banana. Very yeasty. Soft and fuzzy carbonation. Sweet and tacky upfront, with honey and toasted malt being the primary flavor. Airy phenols do make an appearance, but any positive influence is minimal. Touch of acidity and honeydew melon increase, but are overrun by the sweetness. Lightly toasted malts dust the palate before finishing overly sweet and uncleanly yeasty with lasting notes of bubblegum. Just another Americanized Saison that’s too sweet, wet, and saturated with yeast.

Head is mostly diminishing. Body is clear dark yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers), with light notes of clove, pepper, and lemon zest. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Aroma started things off somewhat promising, despite being pretty light there were some nice fermentation characters in there. But the clear body and nearly unmatched sweetness keeps this in only the most mediocre tier of American renditions.

Slightly hazy yella. White grape Nelson Sauv hop aroma. Sappy, honey hops, medium bodied, dry Nelson hop second wave. Long hoppy finish. Not all that bitter. I guess the rye lends itself to the full body but Im not tasting it so much. Still a Duet man myself.

[On tap at Fullerton Brewing Co, Fullerton, CA.] A hazy amber pour with a thin white head; clean grape aroma; full bodied with a touch of spice from the rye and a clean crisp bitterness. The rye seems to mask some of the aromatics from the Nelson Sauvin hops, but otherwise this is a nicely balanced IPA.

Can from BevMo in Dana Point. Translucent yellow orange pour with fine dissipating white head. Aroma is grassy, some pine, some light citrus, malt is sort of straw/dusty, but in a good way. Nice. Taste is solid pine bitterness at the start, grassy hops, some citrus, slight spice from rye. Tasty very solid, straightforward IPA. Not super juicy, not super dank, not super Nelson-y, but the crisp white wine flavors are there. Smooth finely carbonated palate. Very good, though maybe not as good as I expected given ratings.
Slightly hazy amber orange with a small white head. Aroma of tropical fruit, mango, pineapple, melon. Medium bodied, moderate to high bitterness, clean, tasty, winning. Definitely reminds me of Duet.

Well, whilst I’m bothering to rate something I might as well have a crack at this one too, because it was a very pleasant surprise. I’ve never had a Spanish-style cider, so I have no idea how close this one is, but this was really distinctive and interesting stuff. The people at Mock Orchards evidently aren’t that impressed - I was only offered the other two for tasting and when I expressed interest in buying a bottle I was greeted with a "You know it’s still - as in uncarbonated - right?" Despite this glowing endorsement I persisted with my purchase, and I’m very glad I did. It’s incredibly pale stuff, and yes - it’s still! Marked matchstick aroma like a Riesling (actually I’m not sure if I can recall a Riesling that smelled like this, so perhaps I should say it smelled like a Riesling with matchsticks mixed in) with a very subtle but incredibly fresh appliness, vaguely like a Granny Smith but far more refined. Incredibly light-bodied and dry, mildly tart with a touch of bitterness and a finish vaguely reminiscent of Cantillon. However the distinctive feature is this amazingly vibrant, fresh, crisp sea air and apple flavour without a hint of sweetness, yet it’s in perfect balance. It’s a lot like a Riesling, only at half the alcohol and dead dry. Incredibly drinkable stuff. I could see myself chugging down a whole lot of this stuff on a summer’s day.

Clear straw gold. Muted aroma. Peppery - in a word - black pepper on tablewater crackers. Dry . Feints at fruitiness. Medium-light body. Longish finish revisits the Saazy bittering. Medium to medium light bittering. Crisp, a bit corny.
Boring and watery. Horridly lacking in just about every department. It wasn’t offensive, but it was underbittered without much coffee, roast or chocolate.

column1: Lewis and Clark India Pale Lager
column5: Draught at 2006 Craft Lager Festival. Pours amber with a medium frothy tan head that diminishes to a patchy film. Aroma is fruity, floral hops, caramel malt (biscuit) and fragrant pine. Moderately acidic and bitter, sweet caramel malt, floral and fruity hops (apple, pear). Medium bodied and fizzy-dry palate.

Draught at 2006 Craft Lager Festival. Pours cloudy copper with a patchy tan head. Aroma is sour yeast (sweat, puke), malt (meal, cereal) and fruit (lemon). Sour and tart, acidic hop flavor, malty with caramel notes, yeast at the end. Medium bodied and fizzy palate.

Filtered light gold. White head. Faint nose: soft rice, pils malt, transparent and bland, nearly odorless. Body is medium to light, decent crispness but flavor is nill. Basically as flavorless and unoffensive as Bud Light.
Draft at the brewpub during Telluride Blue and Brews Weekend 2006: Active with an orange-yellow color and a musty nose. Corny flavors with a bit of a lemony twist at the end.

Draught at 2006 Craft Lager Festival. Pours hazy yellow with a patchy white head. Aroma is chalky yeast (sweat), corn malt (grain, meal), flowers and grass. Medium bitterness and acidity, adjuncts, malt and yeast (sweat). Light bodied and creamy palate that turns dry.

Draught at 2006 Craft Lager Festival. Pours deep gold with a small off-white head. Aroma is huckleberry, malt (meal, cereal) and chalky yeast (sweat). Medium bitterness and acidity, huckleberry and malt flavor, earthy yeast and dirt, straw. Light bodied and dry palate.

column4: Canteen Brewhouse (was Il Vicino Pizzeria and Brewery)
column5: Draught at 2006 Craft Lager Festival. Pours gold with a foamy and fizzy white head. Aroma is corn malt (grain, meal), sour yeast (sweat) and potato. Medium sweet doughy yeast, buttery malt (grain), corn, adjuncts with a bitter hop finish. Light bodied, smooth palate that turns dry.

(bottle) Hazy, slightly murky amber colour with a huge, but not very persistent light-beige foamy head. Medium-sweet and slightly sour-fruity (apples, banana) nose with moderate wheaty and shy toasty and caramelly notes. Medium-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a moderate carbonation for a wheat-beer. Toasty, slightly wheaty malty taste with soft fruity notes and a tinge of caramel; slim and moderately dry, toasty and slightly fruity finish. Decent dark wheat (24.03.08).
Bottle, 5.3%. Roasted banana aroma. Cloudy dark caramel colour. Small white head. Weak flavour with a sour bitterness and no banana. Slightly roasted.
Bottle. Pours a hazy dark golden with a white head. Aroma is wheat, yeasty, some vanilla and banana. Taste is sweet banana
Bottle. Cloudy dark amber colour with a nice head. Soft aroma of yeast, little banana and some wheat. Very yeasty flavour rich of fruitness and wheat.

An unclear dark orange beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet sickening much banana, but also some caramel. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of wheat, combined with notes of caramel and banana.
(Bottle 50 cl) Slightly hazy amber with a creamy, off-white head. Aroma of banana. Medium body with a very soft mouthfeel and sweetish, fruity accents - again lots of banana. 130806
Bottle. Hazy orange coloured with an off white head. Aroma of bananas, spices and malts. Light acidic flavour of bananas and spices.
Bottle. Amber colour with a big tan head. Caramel, wheat, light banana aroma and taste, sweet. Medium body with a sweet finish.
