column5: Can. Just a slightly richer and maltier lager. A very nice colour. Lightly hopped.

column2: Frankfurt an der Oder, Brandenburg, Germany
column5: Pours pale golden with a low head. Aroma is weak malty and metallic. Flavor is malts and metal.

A small can from Simplemart down the road. Not sure if this is the same beer - could be marketed in the Far East as 'Beck's Extreme', the ABV [5%] tallies. Either way, well-named as this is extremely ordinary. A touch on the sweet side, drink as cold as possible.

lager alemana comercial. poca espuma. carbonatacion media. color ambar pálido. poco aroma. gusto menos amargo che la beck's normal y que la beck's gold. menos lupulo. críticos. cuerpo ligero. retrogusto casi inexistente. refrescante con un sabor mas agradable de las otras para mi gusto.

330 ml bottle from a supermarket in Italy. I don’t know if it is a version only for Italy. Colour is pale yellow with a small white head that quickly disappears. Very similar to the normal Beck’s. This is a version less bitter (the only thing that I saved in the normal version…). Aroma is poor. Taste is inconsistent. Terrible.
Draft in Trieste. Pale cold lager. Orange. Sweet, smooth. Odd fruit. Cold and blonde, this drinks clean, but it’s got problems.
i relly enjoyed this beer, poured straw yellow with a one finger white head that faded quickly. good light taste, grainy. very refreshing with a good hop presence.

22 oz. bottle purchased at the brewery. Deep golden pour with a medium white head that leaves some nice lace, and settles slowly to a thin white layer. Fresh aroma of some light grain, hay, and floral hops. Light to medium body, fine, light carbonation, and a pleasant mouthfeel. Sweet grainy flavor dominates, but some light bitter citrus dries it out a bit. Most cream ales are not very assertive, but this has a refreshing aroma and flavor with some substance. I also had it on tap at the brewery, and it was better than the bottled version, but it’s still pretty good in the bottle. Also, at 2:00/bottle at the brewery, it’s quite a bargain.

Draught sample (on nitro) at the brewpub, early August 2006. A bit oily-looking solid gold with a lasting creamy super-smooth head....mild grainy nose offers whiffs of light floral honey and rather bland applesauce....sweet, lightly syrupy body enhanced (?) by bits of apple and lemon, faintly alcoholic growing to noticeably so, somewhat grainy thick maltiness throughout...well, all right.

Sample at the brewpub: Dark golden color with a medium and foamy white head. Thick lacing throughout. The aroma is fruity and hoppy. Light-bodied with bitter hops flavor first and foremost, with a bit of fruit and malt behind it. The bitterness overshadows the other flavors to the overall deteriment of the beer though. The finish retains the bitterness along with a citrus aftertaste. Similar in some ways to Sirius in some respects, but not nearly as good.

22 oz bottle from the brewery 8/17/06: pours deep gold w/ a short lived white head. Light amounts of alcohol, deep green fruitiness up front. A little toasty, but mostly grainy malt. Aroma is a bit malt liquor like. Flavor is malty, a bit sweet, and lightly alcoholic. A bit of floral citrusy hop flavor and bitterness @ the finish & aftertaste. Mostly bitter in the aftertaste that lingers. Fuller medium body, lower carbonation, fairly smooth m/f. Alcohol warmth. More malt liquor like than cream ale like, not a favorite of mine.
Schönes Gold im Glas, in der Nase frisch, leicht zitronig. Im Trunk Zitronenlimonade, im Abgang kommt die Bitternote. Im Sommer ganz erfrischend.
Bottled (thanks fonefan!). Yellowish golden colour, small white head. Aroma is lemon and citrusfruits mainly. Flavour is lemon, some malts as well as some mild salty notes.

Bottled (BB 12/2010) Pale yellow color, small white head. Artifical lemon aroma. Fizzy carbonation. Sweetish, a bit acidic lemon flavor, kind of artifical. Watery finish. Not the most horrible radler, but bland.

Bottle 500ml. Clear light yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is light malty, moderate citrus - lemon. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20100911]
50 cL bottle. Pours pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is mild herbal and citrusy. Citrusy and sweet flavoured. Sweet finish.

Bottled. A light yellow beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of lemon and a bit of straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of lemon and straw, leading to a dry lemony finish. Thanks yespr for sharing.
Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a very pale yellow with a very white head. Sweet lemon aroma. Thin body, very sweet lemon notes - and really nothing else. 110910

Straw color with a nice head. The aroma has notes of pilsner and citrus soda. The flavour has a light sweetness and is rather light and thin - but also quenching with a light taste of pilsner and citrus soda.

Bottled 0,50L. Light and friable head, short duration. Yellow pale color, much limpid and clear with greenish reflexes. Light and fine fizz. Lean scent of lemon, citruses and sugar. Medium pungent taste, washed out and with beer’s absence. Sweetish, sugary, deprives of bitter and with imperceptible alcohol content.

Canned 0,50L. Light and much evanescent foam. Limpid yellow color, washed out, watery and little shining. Light and lean scnet; metallic aluminum, cereals and straw notes. Watery and little prickly taste. Modest bitter and alcohol. Indeed inconsistent.
Light nose, A little citrus. Craft from their brewery. Just ok, was expecting something better. A better summer beer.
Draft@Smiths Restaurant, Winnipeg. Amber beer with a reasonable head. The aroma is lightly hopped, and the flavour is very well hopped. Overall a reasonable IPA. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Rich sweet roasty aroma. Dry roasty taste, with coffee. Drinkable stout.

Lovely tasty stout. Well the most prominent here is the aroma. Solid! Sniffed it for a looooong time. Felt like a barrel aged one. Lots of chocolate,, oak and vanilla. The only thing to put my finger on here is the texture. Felt a bit thin. Maybe my brain was fooled. Thought it was an imperial stout. Pleasant carbonation level. Smooth and easy to drink. Also chocolate, oak, vanilla and coffee in the flavor. Yummi. [Bottle from a trade with jtclockwork] Brewery #1858 Region #122 Canadian province #9 Manchester United - Liverpool 2-1
Draft - Caramel and a touch of wood. Clear copper with a decent white head. Caramel and a nice sweetness with a long finish.
Draft from the brewery. Caramel. Not my favorite beer style or my favorite from HP.
Bottle. Nice crispiness, with solidly malt-backed hops. Some caramel, brown sugar finish. Very drinkable as amber ales go.
Pours an orangey brown color. Malty aroma and taste. Grains also in the aroma. Has some floral notes in the taste as well

Draught at Across the Board, Winnipeg. Pours a slightly hazy medium amber, with a moderate off-white head, which lasts very well and leaves good lacing. Floral and spice hops mix with nutty malt to create the aroma. Moderate floral and sweet citrus hops up front give way to a nice nutty malt backbone, with a little spice in the finish. A nice balanced amber ale.
Bottle poured a clear amber with a small lasting amber head. Aromas of caramel and earthiness. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of caramel and light earthiness with a smooth finish.

I think cascade hops are my favourite. I love what they do to this amber ale. Aromas are really nice fresh green melon and toasted bread. Flavours are sweet and fresh melon followed by a nice light toastiness. I think this is delicious and refreshing. Earlier Rating: 12/25/2011 Total Score: 3.5 A really nice beer! Toasted notes in the aroma. Beautiful auburn in color with flowers and honey on the palate. Great local beer.
Bottle: Slightly hazed, amber with a small white head. Toasty caramel, butter scent. Sweet grain and caramel malt flavour. A little earthy bitter. Pretty good.

ENG: 341ml bottle from Liquor Mart in Winnipeg, poured into the tulip. Beautiful clean, amber color with medium tan head and a bit of lacing. Malty aromas with hints of floral hops. Tastes very caramelly, roasty, malty, a bit hoppy but it’s barely noticeable. There is also an interesting chocolate, woody and soy sauce flavor underneath, perceptible after a little while. Delicate but long bitter aftertaste. Medium carbonation and medium body, a bit creamy. Overall very interesting, tasty and drinkable british-styled Ale. PL: Butelka 341ml zakupiona w Liquor Mart w Winnipeg, przelana do kieliszka. Piêkna, klarowna bursztynowa barwa ze œredni¹ jasn¹ pian¹ i nieco lejsingu. S³odowe aromaty z nutami kwiatowego chmielu. W smaku bardzo karmelowe, palone, s³odowe, nieco ledwo wyczuwalnych chmieli. Jest te¿ ciekawy smak czekolady, drzewa i sosu sojowego, ale gdzieœ daleko, w tle, jakby dope³niaj¹cy resztê smaków. W posmaku delikatna ale d³ugo odczuwalna goryczka. Œrednie nasycenie i œrednie odczucie, lekko kremowe. Podsumowuj¹c bardzo interesuj¹cy, smaczny i pijalny Ale w brytyjskim stylu.
Bottle. Buttery barley malt and light hay aroma. Golden yellow with moderate off-white head. Mildly sweet butter, barley malt and lightly bitter hay flavor. Decent.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Very refreshing and tasteful beer. Just the aroma is a llitle bit missing... But normally it should be forbidden to brew beer with rasperry aromas.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: pours clear pinkish-orange with minimal head, a plethora of fast-moving CO2 streams. Aromatic juicy raspberries on the nose. Starts of very promising with flavours of fresh raspberries, strawberries, jam, but ends abruptly with a water mid-palate and flat light malt finish. Low-medium complexity, low-medium depth, below average transitions, crappy carry, good drinkability. While drinkable and refreshing with an outdoor bbq’d meal, I can’t say it’s a good session beer.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: GCBF 2010. Pale pink-tinted gold, so kind of orangeish in my little sample glass. Light and tart, with a nice balance between wheat and fresh, juicy raspberries. Hits the mark as a simple summer refresher.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Bubbly rose colored pour with a surging white head that falls pretty rapidly. Slightly tart and sweet raspberry soda nose. Grainy wheat flavor, disappointingly low on raspberry flavor, or much of any flavor. Quaffable stuff, but there’s nothing to it.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: 650mL bottle, pours pink with a small pink head. Aroma of raspberries, citrus and tartness. Flavour is really watery, with sour raspberries, too much citrus flavour and a sour / tart finish. Very poor.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Very, very watery. Garish pink colour, puffy head, hint of raspberry. Nothing special.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Intense pink colour, with a punch of fresh picked raspberries on the nose. Tastes completely naturally flavoured. A little watered down to be a true flavoured wheat beer, but the refreshing quality overwhelms the fault. Mild hop to it on the aftertaste. Great summer beer!

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: Pink with small pink head.Light raspberry nose. Light thin watery raspberry taste. Not much here

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5: This thing poured a one-finger frothy head, mostly white but with a pinkish tinge above a well-carbonated hazy body, predominently copper in colour but again with the hints of pink. As for the head, there it was, gone. Aroma was certainly of raspberry and so was the taste. In fact, only raspberry and bugger all to suggest that this might be beer; at least sweetness was not at issue here. Mouthfeel was "average", and the aftertaste was a slight improvement over the initial taste but that isn’t saying much. I just do not like the way this one tastes; too bad as I really like raspberries and beer, too.

column4: Granville Island Brewing (Six Pints - Molson Coors)
column5:
[1713-20080917] 650mL bottle. Raspberry "mild rhubarb" sweet perfume aroma. Slightly hazy, light amber pink body (odd) with a medium-lasting creamy white head. Light raspberry sweetness tang flavour has light wheat throughout. Light-medium body. Nicely made and tastes like beer here (as opposed to a cooler).
(c/o GregClow, w/ him, blankboy, HogTownHarry, jerc)
Draft. Gold pour. Smells and tastes like blueberry kool aid if that exists. Not amazing.

Reviewed from notes and this was on tap at the brewpub. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a nice looking hazy amber to slight purple tinges around the edges of the beer. Since it was a bar pour, the head was fairly thin and there wasn’t much lacing. The smell definitely had the blueberry with a decent breadiness running underneath my nose. The taste was mainly sweet through the blueberry and somewhat biscuit - like to bread goodness all around. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a pretty good sessionability about it. The carbonation seemed pretty good as the wheat part seemed to take over as far as the back bite on the palate goes. Overall, I say this was a pretty good blueberry wheat ale worthy of having again.

bread, citrus, dough, golden, clear,medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, long finish, lively. I cannot say enough about this beer. One would think when they hear it is blueberry flavor it has a strong fruity flavor. the blueberry flavor is so light you can just make it out. Not overpowering in anyway. Combined with the wheat it is a perfect blend of the 2. After having a pint at the brewpub I purchased a growler with a Styrofoam cooler and ice to keep it cold. It was kept cold for the rest of my vacation, in a Coleman cooler with ice in the Mackinaw City area of Michigan, all the way to Grand Rapids, Michigan, where I tried another very good Michigan beer, Founders Cerise. I purchased a growler of the Cerise as well. After Grand Rapids I took the growler’s of beer packed in a cooler full of ice all the way to the Laselle/Peru area of Illinois for a couple of days, then to Des Moines, Iowa for 2 days. Upon returning home to Sioux City, Iowa the unopened growlers were then opened and the beer enjoyed by myself and friends. It was as good as the day I first tried it at the brewpubs. The address of Tahquamenon Falls Brewery and Pub is: M-123 Paradise, Michigan 49768. The phone number is: 906-492-3300. It is not in Newberry, MI.

First blueberry beer for me, EVER. Actually for a fizzy little drink ,this stuff was OK. Or possibly it was the fact I had my kids in tow (at this nice establishment) and I NEEDED multiple drinks to soothe my jangling nerves? Either way I consumed several of them without hurling all over this establishment. So that’s something, I guess....or not. But one supposes, you could have the BEST BLUEBERRY BEER EVER, by cracking a Blatz and shoving some blueberries in your can/bottle/40 ouncer, and lighting out for Blueberry Nirvana.

On tap at the brewery. Poured gold with a slight blue tint. Aroma was full of blueberries and a bit of tartness. Flavor was a bit overwhelming blueberries and it wasn’t aided by the low carbonation in the beer.

On tap...Gold lagerish looking beer with very little head. Blueberry flavor is OK, but the rest of the malt backbone has a fake Splenda-like fakeness. No balancing hops are detectable. While not as flat as their stout, this one was also undercarbed. Dissapointing.

Aroma is a more authentic tart blueberry skin, with edges of vegetal and a core of jam sweetness. Blends well with the malt sugars. Spicy, as if with andouille sausage. Reminds me very much of Fitger’s Blitzen’s Blueberry Porter. It’s all downhill from here. Pour of heavily hazed peach, with gold fringes. Rim of extremely coarse bubbly white head. No carbonation. This beer is 100% flat. That’s horrible. The flavor is a weak soapy malt candy, with artificial blueberries creeping in from the corners. Again, a fake blueberry soap. Absolutely no carbonation. This beer is 100% flat, fresh from the tap. Palate, sans carbonation, is wickingly sweet. Shouldn’t beer be carbonated? At least the blueberry flavor was quasi-authentic.

Slight straw color, nice legs. Licorice, melon, koji in the nose, quite a deep, rich scent. A thick feel, complex . This is the Barley Wine of sakes, layers of flavor, juicy, chewy. The koji and rice flavors are prominent, there is a sweet, fruity taste giving way to more nutty flavors in the middle and a strong but fairly smooth alcohol finish, hot yes, but not rough. Follow is warm and earthy. Somewhat reminds me of a good Belgian Quad. WOW, a small 200 ml bottle , wrapped in a local newspaper with a label affixed to it. What a diamond in the rough! I’m glad you enjoyed these B.D. & thanks for adding all my oddball stuff!

180mL Bottle: Neat newspaper wrap with stickers, just like the picture, with a fairly boring, but discriptive label underneath. Pours a light beige color with some decent little legs. The nose is very fresh and fruity like strawberry and cotton candy, fresh koji and light alcohol. The flavor is a bit neutral at first, then the alcohol slaps your palate with quite a bit of force. After you’re accustomed to the alcohol level, you get a nice snappy minerally mouthfeel. Very masculine! The nose is light and fruity like a little school girl then you take a sip and you’re arm wrestling a drunken sailor. The finish is a bit medicinal and fairly acidic with a long drawn out burn. The nose grabs you, then you’re stuck for the ride. Interesting sake! Thanks Dan-san.

(Tap) Pours an amber color with a small white head. Sweet caramel in the aroma, along with some fruits. Fruity notes and some sugar in the taste as well. Light palate. I think this would make a better ’amber’ than their amber ale.

Reddish amber with a white head. The aroma is malty with some apples and pears. Somewhat thin and flat, but I’ve had more than one of this style that’s the same. Tastes good, the fruity malts continuing into the flavor, complemented by a light, earthy bitterness. Apple finish. Okay. Illinois Brewing Company, Bloomington, IL

Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured an almost black color with a large creamy white head that left excellent lacing. The aroma was toffee, caramel and faint vague berries. The flavor was dark fruits, toffee, caramel and had a bit of a boozy presence. Medium length finish. Moderately full bodied. Enjoyable but I had hoped for better.
Pours cloudy amber with a thick and lacy head. Soft cherry, funk and tea nose. The taste is a bit flabby, and really doesn’t keep the promises that the aroma was making.

750, corked and baled, with a cool label. Murky dark amber. Loose tan film. Mild bready, toffee, cherry nose. Mildly watery, thinnish body. A little bit of cherry on the mid-palate, not much finish. Surprisingly underpowered for the style and abv and all that.

Thanks for sharing, iowaherkeye. Hazy dark copper brown. Very murky with a light thin khaki head. The aroma has some caramel and blackberries. There is also a little bit of funkiness. The taste is sweet blackberries with some toffee and iced tea. There is also a strong candi sugar note in the long lightly toasted nutty finish.

Pours mahogany with no carbonation to speak of. Smells of caramel, buttery, tarte, some spiciness and fruity undertones. Tastes fruity with a lot of sweet malt presence and some alcohol burn on the finish. Not bad, but I found the other quadzillas I’ve had to be more rounded than this one.

Date: 10/05/2007 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting cloudy dark burgandy, frothy beige head turns to cream, streaks of drippy lace, sweet and tart berry aroma, creamy body, rich malt flavor, fruity berry character brings in a bit of tartness to balance the sweetness from the rich malt, the dark caramel sweetness gets a bit sticky after a while, finishes with a nice tart berry bite, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.5/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+/4

Bottle, I’m guessing 2006 vintage: Pours a murky dark copper mahogany with a fairly-full, stringy-lacing off-white head. Aroma of sweet dark caramel, some oxidation and berries. Body starts with a good, dense dark caramel malty complexity with a lot of dark fruity and berry complexity along with a touch of cardboardy oxidation. Finishes smooth and semi-tart. An interesting brew, but could use a touch more sweetness and a little less oxidation.

(750ml bottle, 2006 vintage, blackberry release) Pours a murky brown body with a spare beige head. Aroma of dark fruit (raisins, plum, dates, blackberry), caramel, and mustiness. Flavor of rich malts, cherry, dark fruits, and caramel.

Bottle brought home last July...shared with MRomero. The pour is a very cloudy burnt reddish brown. No real head to speak of. Fruity malt aroma...not that complex, but not bad either. Flavor follows suite....hints of dark fruits, berries...tastes better than it smells. Quite thin mouthfeel, wish it was fuller. A little alcohol kick in the end.

Thin dense head of fine bubbles. Minimal carbonation. Head lingers for a while. Sweet fruity and malty aroma with some caramel. Complex fruit aroma. Lots of dark fruits, blackberries, etc. Quite good actually. Color is a murky mahagony red. Sweet, malty, alcoholic. Dry and fruity palate with lots of vinuous notes. Nice alcohol warming. Finish is dry and fruity with a lingering raspberry tartness. Pretty damn good stuff. Thanks to pmarsh for sharing this one.

Thin dense head of beige bubbles. Light carbonation. Aroma is mosty malt with some dry roasted grains in the aroma. Dark ruby brown in color. Thin and extreamly soft palate. Probably from the wheat. More malts and a dry fruity bitterness. Very strange combination of flavor but still quite good. Noticable alcohol presence. Ready for this. Little bit of string beans in the flavor also. Finishes soft and clean. Different and decent.

Draft at the brewpub, July 2006. A hazy orange-red beer with a rim of brown head. The aroma is of oranges and wheat. The flavor is wheaty combined with notes of caramel and strawberries, leading to a dry wheaty end where a note of berries lingers for a long time.

Deep, red-tinged copper body with a soft, velvety cream-colored head. Very nice clove, chocolate, and fried banana aromas. Phenols are clean and pleasant. Rich and malty flavor with a hint of dark fruit and some nice yeast signatures. Moderate-high sweetness, but plenty of balancing character. Ample, bready texture and body. Very good dunkleweizen, but it’s so flavorful that it’s almost cloying and not exactly quaffable. Great as an 8-ounce sipper though.

very light in color with thin, white head. aroma has some fruit. very light mouthfeel with mild apricot flavour - not overly sweet (or sour for that matter). I presume this is basically the Dooryard recipe with apricot flavouring. could serve a valuable purpose on a really hot day.

Looks like an excellent Pale Ale. Color and head are good. Bring the glass to you mouth and get a nose full of Apricot. Flavour is very strong apricot. There is a sweetness, but balanced well against the fruit tartness and the bittering. An excellent Fruit beer
Draft at TAP NY. Pours amber with an off white head. Citric and flowery hops, with sweet and grainy malts. A bit too prominent of a malt profile, but otherwise pretty good.

In short: A rich creamy caramelized stout with citrusy peppery hops. Fun beer How: Tap at Tap-NY 2012 The look: Clear dark golden body topped by a medium beige head with medium retention In long: Nose is ripe citrusy hops with a spicy twist over caramel. Taste has a big creamy lively body with lots of caramelized malts, some fresh honey too. Rich maltiness that manages to avoid feeling heavy. In fact the malts are stealing the spotlight away from the citrusy hops. I also got a strong spicy-peppery sensation from the hops. A different take on the style (at least this batch was). I liked it. Anyway a few days after drinking this beer I watched Animal Planet, and get this, actual hippopotamus don’t really eat marbles.

On draught at the brewpub. Arrived a hazy amber with a thin-moderate off-white head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left partial lace. Surprisingly light aroma for a DIPA with mild grapefruit and a touch of caramel. The flavor is malt and caramel followed by some grapefruit, both fruit and pith. Moderate bitterness at the finish that lingers very briefly beyond the swallow. Below average for a DIPA.

Name: Hoppotomus IIPA Brewery: John Harvard’s Date: April 05, 2010 Mode: Growler Source: Trade Appearance: clear amber, fine beige head, spider web lace Aroma: big hop aroma, earthy and citrus hops, backing caramel and crystal malts add a touch of sweetness Flavor: rich malt flavor, plenty of balancing hops, touch of growing caramel sweetness, plenty of earthyness, long bitter finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: *** /4

the aroma is cramel sweetness, and citrus - very nice. The appearance is a red/orange, white head. The flavor is caramel, soap, pine needles (where the hell is the soap from?) The finish is long, resiny bittering. Medium/thick in body. Quite good.

Dark, near-brown pour has a nice hoppy aroma of pine and tart spices. This is rather full-bodied and has a nice robust texture. Flavor is IPA standard with a good hop profile that fully masks any alcohol and has a strong malt body. This is a fairly sturdy, enjoyable IPA that is above the usual brewpub-chain fair. One of the better I’ve had from John Harvard’s.
Tap. Aroma of tropical fruits, berries, very hop-forward. Flavor juicy with lots of bitter berries, some alcohol. Very bitter finish and a touch of unpleasant alcohol. Still a nice one though.

On tap at JH. Pours amber with a ring of white head. Aroma of citrus and grassy hops. Flavor of potpurri, sweet grapefruit, nice hop bitterness, with a sweetness in the finish. Nice IIPA but a little light on the flavor.
20070428 Tap at TAPNY. Yet another nice, balanced, hop-forward double ipa from a New York brewer. Sweet and sticky, no noticeable alcohol, cookie notes in background. Nice enough to drink all day.

Tap. Light malt note of light bread, heavy hop aromas of pine and grapefruity/lemon, light yeast of earth and mustiness with wood and sulfur in the background. Head is frothy white, with good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is a hazy red/brown. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium, between watery and oily, and the carbonation is soft. It finishes lightly astringent and dry. A good drinker but not much balance, simple hop character, and not enough complexity throughout. This might have been a little old as this was served on tap, not in it’s usual on cask. Needs a re-rate.
On tap at the brewpub. A almost clear deep amber beer with a huge good lasting beige head. Aroma of strong caramelish malt, red fruits. Taste of caramelish malt, red malt, red fruits, strong malt.
Slušné pivo s pøimìøeným øízem, pøíjemnou vùní a výrazným sladovým plným tìlem.
Tap at the brewpub, easter 2005. Red amber, big off-white creamy head. Grainy ryebread aroma. Bisquit , somewhat dusty, grassy hop notes. Full body, mellow mothfeel.

Sampled at the brewery on our recent return visit to Perth and the Swan Valley. One of two seasonals on offer. Clear brassy golden, average white cap. Grainy aroma with hints of apple fruit. Grainy flavour that is a touch toasty, the same hint of apple fruit, low bitterness.

Another poorly lasting head on a copper honey coloured body. Much better balanced than the former beer as I was expecting this to a bigger tasting beer. Mainly malt showing, touch grainy, burnt toffee on a light to medium body. Nothing outstanding but overall easily drinkable as the alcohol is there but not interfering.

When is hot alcohol a good thing? For some unknown to myself reason it aided this little rocket-fuelled monster. Only 6.4%, but f’firks ’ake it was heady. Poured a bright tawny copper with minimal carbonation and minimal head retention. Light laxed trace of white daubed the glass here and there. Toffeeish, warming, sticky date pudding nose dowsed with clear spirits. Strong kick of hot alcohol in the mouth with a levelled malt, wood, and toffee backbone. Bitter, burnt fruit, pecan pie and a ship load of cough medicine add to its extremities. Finish has again alcohol but it is more controlled, warming and harbouring some pleasant berry, nut and pale malt flavours, and is overall smooth to its credit. Body is treacly, not overly big and very light in carbonation. It hasn’t got the flavour to hold the alcohol, but again for some reason it works as a strong lager. Went well with my Schweinn Haxe, and the fact it was cold and windy outside. Good effort overall.

<!-- i -->brewed with honey and elder for the 150th anniversary of the brewery ... though this one is closed since a long time<!-- /i --> - pours a bright golden-orange colour under a little foam; nice lace; light honeyish (and with some imagination elder-ish) notes in the nose; moderatey sweet, medium-bodied, no bitterness; gentle honeyish finish - no character but acceptable

8/27/18 - Pensacola, Fl - Four Winds International Food Store - 500 ml bottle - labeled as 'Lomska Veronica'. Pours a pale, sparkling golden with a frothy, white head with light lacing. Aroma is skunky, with some sweet cake mix like biscuity notes. The skunkiness mellows as it settles. Flavor has some sweet honey notes with some sweet biscuity back end accents. Mouthfeel is thick enough - sweetness fades just a bit near the end. Overall, much better though, than expected then when I first opened it.

Bottle, 500 ml. Very nice surprise, somehow i tought it's gonna be a below average lager, but actually it's very decent. Good, deep golden, foam can be recalled by swirling the glass. Sour and sweet malt aeomas on the nose, a bit limey, but not unpleasent. Same taste, bit sour, but also sweet, some greenish notes, like white bread in green apple juice. Great carbo and a medium aftertaste. It can be a good choice, especially for 0.85€. R U kiddin' me?

31Jan2018 Sweet grain and cereal malts, sweet fruits, molasses, sweet citrus fruits, tangerine, orange. Slight hazy gold, tiny, creamy, white head. Light bitter. More sweet malts, grain and cereal malts, medium carbonation, medium bodied. Boring. Bottle shared at L42 - thanks to Leighton!

Bottle shared at Leighton's place 31/01/2018. Many thanks! a grainy, dirty orange coloured pour with a fading white head. Aroma is dirty honey, apple, earthy honey. Flavour is composed of sweet pale oxidised grains, honey, earthy, cearal. Palate is semi sweet, moderate carboantion. ok.
Aroma is skunk, malts/pale malts and pale lager yeast. The flavor is malts/pale malts, pale lager yeast, fruit, slightly grainy and a spicy/medium sweetness.

31st January 2018 Bodney Towers sharebottle. Thanks to Elena. Light haze on this gold beer, small pale cream colour head. Palate is airy, semi dry, modest fine carbonation. Pretty grainy malts, fair bit of cereal, some lager character, touch of sweetness. Smooth floralness. Modest citrus. Smooth but very cereal.

Bottle shared in Hackney - picked up in Bulgaria. Pours clear gold with a creamy, white head. The nose has basic grainy malts. Medium sweet flavour, some caramel, paper, cereal grains. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Sugary and bland finish, more lightly toasted grains, cereal. Not very good.

500ml bottle from Billa, drunk at home. Pours clear with a very fast settling frothy head, lacing while the head lasted, persistent bead. Mid straw in colour. At first, a strong malty aroma with bread and wet cardboard. Lively in the mouth, but little flavour is released, some maltiness, medium bitterness, but no hoppy flavours. Slight sweetness and a dry finish. Overall, malty for a lager, not particularly refreshing and very forgettable.
Draught at Grunewoche. Hazy gold with a medium head. Aroma of citrus malt. Flavour is soft hop, hay and malt, light bitter base
0,5l can from Samokov,pure malt flavor,nice white heat,neutral taste,golden color.
Tap @ a summer popup in a park near our hotel in Zurich. Pale lager with clear golden body, white head. Malts and citrus.
Bottle from Drinks of the World Zurich. Good golden body with slight head. Nose is malts, caramel, toast. Flavour is also malts, caramel. Decent.
33cl bottle. Aroma is some malts, taste rather on the sweet side. Nicely crisp, but could be a bit drier. A better than average Swiss lager.

(Flasche) Es hat eine sehr hellgelbe Farbe, fast wässrig, klar filtriert mit einer weißen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist recht getreidig, mit Honig, Tanne und etwas Pappdeckel. Der Geschmack ist spelzig, eher schlank, süßlich und harzig. Der Abgang ist leicht adstringent und eher breit. Bittere gibt es kaum.

Tap at Cafe’ Noir, Zurich, December 2012, affiliated with the brewery and close to its distribution center. Pours clear golden-blond with white head. Faint malt, faint grass and a little honey in the nose. Tastes malty, at first like a generic pale lager but then it gets better. Light body, smooth, delicate carbonation, short finish.
Clear golden, good white foam, decent malt aroma. Refreshing lager without faults. Decent hops.

On tap from Amboss sales outlet & coffee shop 800 metres nortwest of hauptbahnhof Zurich- were under construction for bar. Golden color, good foam. Floral and fruity aromas. Medium body & complexity Good bitterness, well balanced. Very enjoyable
Golden yellow pour, white head. Very mild aroma, like white bread. Pretty well balanced taste, but not very interesting. Medium body. Lively carbonation. Crisp finish.

Bottle 330ml. Clear medium yellow color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, toasted, light to moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20100908]
Clear golden with a medium off white head. Malty aroma with caramel and yeasty notes. Sweet flavor with malt, yeast and caramel hints. Finished sweet.

draught at the brewery - quite cloudy blond beer with a solid and long lasting bright white foam; fresh and fair aromatic hoppiness, slightly fruity with light almondy and herbal tones, medium-bodied and solidly bitter; quite dry and very long bitter herbal hoppy finish - fresh and solid, a beer with character draught at the brewery; 8/2006 - hazy blond colour with a little foam; aromatic hoppy nose with notes of tangerines; clean palate, medium-bdoied and with a decent bitterness; moderately dry finish, some fruity and yeasty notes in the aftertaste (3/6/6/3/12)
draught at the brewery - hazy dark amber colour, little foam and a nice lace; gentle malty and caramelish nose; clean and respectable malt body, low bitterness; the finish leaves notes of marzipan

Slightly hazy gold, moderate white head, temporary lace. Caramel aroma with a lot of creamed corn. Flavor heavily into the sulfurous cooked vegetables, with just a bit of hops bitterness to offset this. Not usually what I’m looking for in a beer, but if I accept it on its own terms, there’s nothing off with it. Medium body and zest.

12oz bottle. Filtered orange-bronze color. Malty straightforward aroma. The taste is simple, toasty malt and light noble hops, with a slight creaminess. Easy drinking light to medium bodied. Mild German Lager yeast tones and a touch of sugary sweetness. A pleasant surprise, nothing world class, but a perfectly respectable example of the style.
12oz twist-off bottle. Deep golden color. Aroma of buttered lobster. Light malt flavor. Balanced hop presence. Flavor is very light on the palate. A very easy drinker. 03 may 08

Semi hazy amber with a thin white head, gone. Aroma of caramel, earthy hops and lake water. Thin body is semi grainy and has some caramel and hops in there to go with a mild peppery finish that’s sweet and a touch dry.
Mild caramel and cereal aroma. Golden with white head. Mild caramel, biscuit, and lite hop notes. Syrupy, with a mild bitter finish.

Pours a golden body with a medium sized white head. Lots of carbonation in this brew. Wheat on the nose, but a little grainy in taste. Medium bodied mouthfeel. I thought it was a pilsner at first, it makes sense thats its a dort.

Name: Fauerbach Export Lager Date: 05/03/2008 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting, Cellar Party Appearance: hazy gold, frothy off white head, drippy lace, Aroma: sweet caramel malt aroma with an earthy bready character, Flavor: rich bready malt flavor, lots of balancing earthyness, touch of caramel sweetness, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

Thanks to Bob for the bottle! Poured healthy medium golden with a well-retained cap of off-white head.. but it was chunkified. The aroma picked up soft bready and caramel notes with dry herbal notes, lemon zest, and sour grains surrounding. The flavor was more centered around the caramel with a bit of cardboard, sour malts, and slight vegetal on the back.. had a tacky, sweeter finish that wasn’t very enjoyable. Lighter-bodied with tackiness, sour notes, and high carbonation throwing off the flow on the palate.. drinkable, but not very good.

Appearance: Pours a clear, yellow-orange body with a wispy, white head. Smell: Mild aroma of spice and damp grain. What a snoozer! Taste: Pale malts with a touch of sourish grain and a handful of biscuit crumbs. Big pop of Noble hops and bitterness. Lightly sour finish. Mouthfeel: Thin-bodied. Medium carbonation. Drinkability: Oh, I wanted to love this one, really I did! But I did not. Pass!
Pours a golden yellow color with a a white head. Aroma is malt, honey, grain, and some peppery hops. Flavor is grainy, honey, a hint of sweet apple, and slight peppery finish.

Aroma is rice and corn adjunct with some tin from can and light sulphur. Taste is bland sweet malts and hops, very generic. Appearance is a clear gold with a thin pearl head that retains quite poorly.

Pours a slightly hazy straw colour with big white foam made up of large bubbles and some lace. Aroma is grainy, corn like and lightly grassy. Flavour is malty sweetness, grainy, unpleasant hop flavour, lively carbonation and maybe a bit of cardboard. Drink this cold and fast and if your on a budget...
Meh... Fairly easy to tell why this stuff is so Cheap. Smells of stale grain, tastes like the bleached white rice that costs $2.00 a pound. You get what you pay for though

light body, thin feel, lively, bread, grass, golden, clear, medium sweetness, Fairly standard and inoffensive beer. Served cold on a hot day it’s agreeable enough but nothing special. It stands up well against the likes of Molson Canadian or any of the other big brewers’ light beers, but it’s not a style I particularly like. One of Big Rock’s budget brews, marketed as Pine Creek.

Bow Valley. Reviewed straight from bright gold can, aesthetically pleasing. Poured some out to note clear, yellowy colour. Medium carbonation. Aroma is corn and grass. Taste is exactly the same, with a bubbly mouthfeel of plain, grainy beer. Certainly one of the better dollar beers, but nothing one should ever drink seriously.

355ml can pours a pale golden color with a finger of white head that leaves no lacing. Aroma is cereal grains and grass. Taste is light malty sweetness with a horrid hop bitterness that lingers on the palate. A terrible brew that just sickens me whenever I taste it. It is one my father purchases on a regular basis.

Single can purchased from Paradise Liqour in Edmonton, AB on 07/22/2011. Colour: Pale yellow, no head. Nose: Smells like malt liqour, abundant gingerale, rotting egg. Taste: Medium sweet, medium-light bitter, light sour. Again gingerale but flat and stale. Quickly fades to bitter cardboard. Absolutely attrocious. Embarrased that Big Rock would make such crap - but now understand why they have the affiliate brewery name "Pike Creek" attached to the can...

Generosity abounds on x-mas day! Though this might not quite deserve it... I’m going to give a few points here. This is really more like beer flavoured water that still has enough % to get the job done but there really isn’t much to go on, it is so damn thin. It’s not actually offensive though, and I’ll never forgive Banks Carribean lager for itself.

This beer is the favorite of pathetic old alchies wiith jobs in my town. Pours piss yellow.Aroma is horrible. stinks like the smell of whiskey coming out of your pours after a morning of hard drinking. The flavour is very light and very cheap. almost like a slightly yeasty tasting glass of water. not offensive, this beer is drinkable but it’s just plain terrible.
Horrible beer. Absolutely no reason why I will ever consume this again. Pour is pale yellow and foamy white head. Tastes like someone peed in my mouth and mixed it with beer. Overall, pretty gross.

Slightly tinted yellow body with gold flakes at the bottom of my square wooden bowl. The aroma was vanilla and light dandelions. Booze are also strong on the nose. The taste was fairly sweet with some vanilla and grain. Light booze in finish.

Clear with just a blush of color, gold flakes swirling around. Mild to medium koji scent. A light buttery feel. Mild flavor, not much depth just a basic musty wood flavor. Momokawa makes much better stuff, I just don’t think they use a top shelf sake to make this gold flake style.

On tap at the brewpub. Beer was just called Dunkelweizen, but this is the only dunkel listed on the site and I suppose I shouldn’t add a new one. Not as dark a pour as I was anticipating, a little light. Sweet and a little lighter than expected for the style.

Perfectly clear medium-dark tan. Nose is caramel, earthy hops, a hint of bananna, orange. Flavor is rich dusty caramel malt, grass. Maybe a hint of bananna & clove in the finish. Nice body. The yeast & clove I would expect from a dunkelweiss just isn’t here.
Golden pour, with some aroma of grainy malt, citrus, honey. Rather watery palate, with flavors of pale malt, slight honey, apricot, and hopcitrus.

On tap at the Golden Avalance Brew Pub. The 4th Pale Lager from this brew pub today. Poured a medium golden color with a small sized white head. Aromas of grain, light citrus and light grass. Tastes of the same with a light honey sweetness. Thinner.
If you’re looking for a delicious blueberry beer, you found it! It smells like blueberry pie and tastes like a light lager with a blueberry finish.
Blueberry present in both aroma and taste. Pale yellow in color. Lager is crisp and clean. Drinkable. Tap at beerfest.
On tap at Kutztown Tavern. Poured hazy pale yellow orange with min head. Strong sweet blueberry corn aroma. Med carb and bod. Taste is sweet floral blueberry.
Light golden pour. Hazy. Aroma of dank blueberries, malt and cereal. It tastes like blueberry cereal...oak, wheat and blueberry.
On tap in the Kutztown local. Pale yellow pour with a pleasant blueberry aroma on the nose. Small white foam head. Blueberry matrix with the Donner weiss texture. Malt smooth and low carbonation.

Say what you want about pale lagers/ales and fruited pale lagers/ales, but this one was something special. The pour was pale gold, so nothing great there, but I loved the aroma, a mix of natural smelling blueberries straight off the bush, plus some hopcitrus and pale malt. I could smell this one all day. As expected, the palate was on the light side in heft, but I truly enjoyed the blueberry flavor, which had the natural blueberry sweet/tart dichotomy, and was balanced with a crisp finish and extremely smooth beer. This one is very good.
On tap at the Golden Avalance Brew Pub. Poured a lighter yellow color with a small sized white head. Aromas of mainly stronger blueberries. Tastes of the same but not as strong as the aromas.
Many thanks to Erzengel for sharing! A hazy pale golden beer with a mid-sized good lasting white head. Aroma of soft grainy malt, straw. Taste of mid sweet grainy malt, bread, straw, diacetyl.

Many thanks to WillemsUrenkel for this bottle! Grainy nose. The beer starts smooth malty with a sourish touch. Lots of grain with a strange sourness behind all - I think this brew is infected. Grainy smooth bitter ending, sourish parts there as well, strange stuff with a hygienic problem.
Danke an WillemsUrenkel für die Pulle. Recht herber, zopfiger Geruch. Start hopfenherb. Mitte herb mit säuerlichem Einschlag. Leicht süßlicher Abgang, bittert moderat. In Ordnung.

0,75 l swing top bottle in company standard design. Now listed on the label with 5.0% alcohol. Pale yellow in the glass, small foamy head. Low citrus und grassy on the nose. Starts malty spicy, a lot of hop herb and bitterness for a Helles. Low citrus, high carbonated. Could be an northern geman Pilsener.
Bottle looks really good. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts mild, malty, modest spicy. Some wheaty notes. Finish a bit drier, but still well balanced. Not bad!
Nice golden beer on tap at the brewpub. Refreshing, quite a fresh nose, almost green, grassy notes. Taste is similar. Dry aftertaste.

Getrunken beim RB Treffen in Düsseldorf am 6.1.07 Das Bier ist mir definitiv zu leicht, eine leicht hopfige Note ist im Mittelteil mit malzigem Unterton vorhanden, das war es eigentlich schon. Höchstens der leicht bittere Ton ist noch erwähnenswert... Test vom 7.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,7,8,7,9,7 - 7,45

Bottle 750ml. w. swing top @ home. Clear medium yellow color with a grey note, a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, light to moderate hoppy, citrus, grass, light sour grass - silage. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, sour grass notes, citrus acidic notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20101223]
Bottle @ LCRBM 08: Poured a yellow with white head. The aroma is skunky and citrus, with a little barnyard. Taste is fresh clean harvest with a hoppy finish.
Litre swing top bottle @ LCRBM 2008. Malty, flowery aroma with a hint of citrus. malty, flowery citric hopbitter flavor. Well balanced helles.
Danke an WillemsUrenkel für diese Flasche. Dunkelmalziger und schokoladiger Geruch mit aromatischer Note. Süßlich-malziger Beginn. Mitte und Schluß schokoladig, malzig, sanft. Ok.

0,75 l top swing bottle with a nice label design. Pours more redbrown than really dark in the glass. Proud light tanned head. Fine CO2 pearls. Malt and hopy on the nose. Light roastmalt with a pleasant sourness at the start. Later a little bit sweeter, buttercookies on a malt grainy basis. Very fresh, could be a little more roasted. Low herb. Easy to drink. (20. Apr. 2013)
Bottle looks really good, nice format. Beer in the glass dark brown, nice head. Starts strong malty, some dry notes, not too roasty. Finish with hints of caramel. Really nice!

Getrunken beim RB Treffen in Düsseldorf am 6.1.07 Sehr mild und CO2 arm kommt dieses Bier daher und wirkt allgemein ungelungen. Auch der röstmalzerne Abgang wirkt alles andere als toll. Unterstützt wird dies durch bittere Intermezzos im Mittelteil. Test vom 7.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,5,6,6,10,6 - 6,25

Bottle 75-100cl. w. swing top @ LCRBM 2008, ’s-Hertogenbosch, Netherlands Clear medium amber orange color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, sour. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20081025]

Bottle. The Dunkel from Vechta smells quite malty, a little bit like bread, light sour and with some hints of chocolate. It has a big white creamy head, which stays normal long. The body is dark red. The taste is malty and light bitter, very well balanced. Normal carbonation, a little bit dry and with a medium body. A nice Dunkles
1 L bottle. Pours almost clear deep orange with a fully gone head. Malty and slight spiced aroma. Smooth and malty flavoured with a mild citrusy to orange note. Caramel malty finish, light bitter.
Bottle @ LCRBM 2008. Gusher. Toffee in the aroma. Toffee flavor with hints of pineapple. Sticky mouthfeel.

column1: Gregg's Pit Brown Snout & Dabinett Cider (Draught)
column5: Swan and Rushes, Leicester. Hazy orange in colour. Aromas are sweet, earthy apple with sharp citrus and wood. Lightly floral. Flavour are light apple juice followed by lots of earthy, woody notes. Hints of liquorice are also present. Traditional and very dry.

On tap at the Auburn Pub. Pours a light amber with a foamy white head. Aroma is lemon zest, malt, and a little hint of goldings hops. Flavor is pretty similar, lemon bite on your tongue followed mid sip by a sweet gentle flavor with a slightly bitter end. Pretty nice drinking hot weather beer. Although it was a bit stinging on the palate and extremely watery feeling on the tongue. Not sure how long this one will be around, but I’ll bet it’s a pretty limited offering.

column1: Fukumitsuya Kazeyo Mizuyo Hitoyo Junmai Ginjo Sake
column5: Another “Fume Blanc” looking sake, has that touch of straw color to it. Light melon and koji scent. A dry sake with vinous, oak and earthy flavors. A light grainy sweetness up front with a cashew flavor in the middle and a dry finish with a scant alcohol follow. My first sake from Ishikawa-ken. An interesting, different style than what I’m used to up here in the north.

column1: Fukumitsuya Kazeyo Mizuyo Hitoyo Junmai Ginjo Sake
column5: 300mL Bottle from IslandHaole: Nice frosted bottle with a cool peel off plastic top covering the screw cap. Pours a relatively beige color with nice legs. The nose is fairly typical of these junmai ginjos with some anise and melon. The flavor is a bit different with some strong koji, minerals and dusty alcohol. A bit strong in acidity and dryness, but the nose is good. Finishes a bit flat and tangy. It doesn’t quite has that nice freshness or umami that I like. A bit strong tasting too, especially for the low alcohol. Thanks Dan!
[Bottled] Clear brownish dark amber. Some soap and saccharine. Too sweet with clean mouthfeel and notes of plums. Chemical bitter finish. Not my drink of choice, but better than their blonde...
Thin, dissipating head with an opaque amber colour. Standard English ale taste, with peppery notes and a ample hop bitterness that makes for a long finish.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Appearance - golden with a light haze. Proportionate head. Nose - lemon and malt notes reminiscent of shandy. Taste - lemon barley water with proper lemon pith finish. Palate - light bodied and creamy. Dry finish. Overall - good.
Nice fresh golden ale light fruits and citrus quite delicate and floral bottle at home.

From Jun 2008 Purchased at Wilbur's Total Beverage. Nice medium gold in colour with a 2 finger head of foam and there's some good lacing. Head retention is very good! The nose has a nice hoppy(grass, touch of grapefruit) aroma with a bit of maltiness in the background, and after it warmed up some, I notice some fruity notes as well. The taste starts off nice with an earthy hop bitterness but then the malty sweetness comes into play and I find myself drinking a very nicely balanced Pale Ale. And...this tastes fresh! Dang. Medium mouthfeel here, the carbonation is light but right, and it finishes on the slightly malty side. Oh, and I find that it's very drinkable. I could easily put away a few of these at 1 sitting. I wish I had picked up more than 1 bottle of this but with UK beers, especially the ones that are light on the alcohol, you just never know what you're going to end up with. In my book, this is a winner.
Bottle. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. No tasting notes kept, just rating.

500ml bottle from Tesco. Pours a slightly hazy golden orange with a thin white head. Nose is orange zest, straw, grass, biscuit and stone fruit, maybe a peach. Refreshing, easy going, light ale with bags of flavour. Very citrusy, zesty, touch resinous, and a nice biscuit, straw, grassy finish. Good session ale if in the pub, at 4.1% abv I could neck a good few of these.

Cask gravity at the Barnstaple Beer Festival, 19/08/2006. A very light hay aroma. The flavour is dominated by roasted malts which leads to a nice bitter finish with dark fruits evident. Pretty good for a low ABV brew, but let down by the aroma.

Bottle with Ken and Vi. Pours a brown amber body with thin off white lacing. Aroma is very spice-forward, some malt, sugar and lots of yeast. Mouthfeel is medium with lots of carbonation, super active abrasive yeast, spice, grain and light fruit. This recipe doesn’t work for me.

Only ok. Not as full as I was hoping. Flavor is ok. A bit too light. More American than I was prepared for. Not a spicy finish as stated and the lemon is there but the other spices are lacking. Color is nice. Tap

Aroma: Yeast, Mild Citrus Appearance: Mildly Hazy Golden Straw/Amber Hue, Passes Lots of Light, White Head Ring, Decent Lacing Taste: Yeast, Mild Lemons, Mild Green Peppercorn Mouthfeel: Average Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Drying

Draft at Eulogy. Light gold chartreuse pour with a white foamy ring. Gently sweet floral notes. Lavender. Thyme. Biscuit. Celery seed. Honeycomb. Pineapple rind. Slight funk. Watery body. Okay but not noteworthy.
Draft at Allentown. Pours clear light gold with almost no head. Smells like grains and bread. Tastes sweet, light, with very mild malt and hops. Light body and low carbonation.

Tap at brewery. Pours clear yellow with fizzy white head. Aroma is cereal malts, lemon zest, grassy and floral notes, and light yeast. Flavor is pale malt base with light fruit esters and faint hops; somewhat watery with a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

Thanks to bu11zeye for sharing this bottle. Yellow pour with a huge white head. The aroma is full of orange and lemons with some wheat, white pepper and Belgian yeast. The flavor is similar with some yeast, wheat, lemons, oranges, peppers and alcohol. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

In short: An amateurish yeasty Belgian blond ale. Bad. How: Bottle 750ml, consumed a few months after purchase. The look: Opens with a loud pop, then pours a cloudy dark blond body topped by a persistent small white head. In long: Nose is very estery, papayas and bananas, phenols, spices. A rather intense aroma that is not all that inviting. Taste is sweeter than expected, bananas covered with white sugar, coriander seeds, hospital gloves, strange vegetal flavors, a whole lot of yeast, lime juice, noes of wet cardboard, more.... An unpleasant after-taste. Fluffy yeasty body with a generous carbonation. Clearly Belgian in nature but I fail to see any Saison character here. This is a mess of disorganized flavors, an overall amateurish impression. For what it’s worth the wife didn’t think it was all that bad so I let her have half the bottle, I didn’t care for that beer one bit. Instead of music, suicide hotlines should have a waiting message suggesting to drink a Monkey Wrench, nobody wants that to be the last beer they drink.

From the March 2013 3R6P tasting. +++ Sampled from a 750 ml corked brown bottle this beer poured a cloudy orange-apricot color with a huge foamy yellow-white head that lingered and left a bit of lacing .The aroma was sweet sugar, candies fruit and a hint of mustiness. The flavor was tart honey, sugar, vague citrus, bread, pepper and a bit of must. Medium length honey, sugar and must finish. Moderately full bodied though overcarbonated. Tasty.
Bottle. Poured a hazy golden with thick white head sea foam lacing. Wheat, banana, a little spice and funk.

750 ml bottle sample at the source. Clear yellow pour. Still. Aroma has orange zest and bright fruit notes. A bit dry, but the fruity aspects sort of even it out. A really nice mead. Would be great to enjoy outside on a warm day.

Pour from a 750 ml bottle at Woodstone Creek during a tasting. The straight-up mead pours a white wine color, slightly darker than the Taliesin, with no head or visible carbonation. It drinks like a white wine, too, sharing the same texture with minimal honey sweetness and good wildflower botanicals. Light-medium bodied, with no carbonation and a dry, smooth mouthfeel. Good mead.

Local swap from TheHoff43, per my preferences. Thanks, dude! Sweet honey nose, baby food accents.Clear amber, still. A bit drier than semi dry. Thin, light, but a bit rough on the palate. Vinous, sauvignon blanc, tangy. Dandelion finish. A wine drinker’s mead, with subtle character. I prefer the sweeter stuff, but this is good.
Bottle. Pours a clear dark orange with a nice sweet, honey aroma.. Flavor is honey, not overpowering. finishes very dry. Quite enjoyable, I need to drink more mead.
750 ml bottle to wine glass at Woodstone Creek. Looks good; a still honey orange. Smells solid; really fine honey. Tastes like it smells, only milder. Solid on the palate. A pleasant mead.

Sampled from 750 mL bottle at the Woodstone Creek Winery and Distillery tasting room... Woodstone Creek Mead is a still mead. It is a yellowish copper color and clear. It is made with Kentucky Goldenrod honey which is evident in the modestly sweet honey aroma. The flavor showcases the honey, but it isn’t overly sweet or just honey-like in flavor as there is a dry white wine like taste as well. It finishes a little dry. Overall this is a semi-sweet mead that has a nice level of dryness and isn’t too heavy on the palate (the body is medium light). A very well done mead.

Sample at tasting room. Poured clear copper color with good legs. Moderate honey aroma. Light to medium body with a dry texture. Medium honey sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Pleasing.
Pours clear deep yellow, still. Fragrant honey aroma with acidic vinous notes. The flavor is largely honey with a dry wine palate. $10.99/bottle at the meadery
750 ml bottle sample at the meadery. The mead is a pale yellow. Still. The aroma has bright citrus and honey notes. Moderate dry and herbal taste. Slick mouthfeel. Solid mead.

Pour from a 750 ml bottle at Woodstone Creek. Pours a clear white wine color with no head. The lemon and ginger add a nice, subtle spice and sharpness to the honey, with very light notes of vanilla and what seems like white grape must. Light-bodied, with no carbonation and a fairly clean, dry mouthfeel. Good first offering.

750 ml bottle to wine glass at Woodstone Creek. Looks good; a still and transparent honey gold. Smells solid; honey, lemon, and ginger. Tastes like it smells, but less robust. Average on the palate with a very dry mouthfeel for a mead. Interesting, but not my favorite.

Sampled from 750 mL bottle at the Woodstone Creek Winery and Distillery tasting room... Woodstone Creek Taliesin is a very interesting and complex mead made in the "Elizabethan-style". I thought that the term "Elizabethan" is usually attributed to Pyment (grapes added), but according to the description of this mead, this is a Metheglin (spice/herbal) and there is no grapes added. Either way, something is definitely added to the honey must (must : mead :: wort : beer) to give it a wonderful cornucopia of flavors! This is a still mead and its color is a clear light yellow. The aroma was a delicate mix of lemon, ginger, and honey. This mixture of ingredients is carried through into the flavor along with some spice and toasted vanilla from the barrel aging. It has a light body. This is definitely an interesting, complex, and memorable mead.

Sample at tasting room. Poured clear pale color with good legs. Heavy lemon grass and citrus aroma. Light to medium body with a slick texture. Medium balanced spicy flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Complex standout mead.
Pours medium yellow, still. Light spice and honey aroma and flavor. Dry palate overall. $14.99/bottle

750 ml bottle sample at the source. The mead is a muddled ruby/brown color. Still. The aroma has fruity berry notes. Strongly sweet. The berry comes through well in a sugary sweet, candy way. Another favorite with the other patrons. I guess the sweet ones just aren’t my speed.

Pour from a 750 ml bottle at Woodstone Creek during a tasting. Pours a red wine color, but one that’s been slightly hazed and browned. The raspberries add a new dimension here, but they don’t really help anything. It’s muddled, with sweet raspberry and honey, white wine grapes, and some earthy and oaky notes. Medium-bodied, with no carbonation and a muddled, fruity, earthy mouthfeel. My least favorite of the lineup.
750 ml bottle to wine glass. Looks solid; a still reddish brown. Smells sol too;honey, fruit wine, and raspberries. Tastes like it smells with a nice mouthfeel. Another good Pyment.

Sample at tasting room. Poured clear golden color with good legs. Moderate honey tart citrus aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Medium honey sweet balanced flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable mead.
Clear light amber in color, still. Fruity honey aroma. Subdued berry notes play nicely with the dry honey flavors in this one. Dry overall. $9.99/bottle.

750 ml bottle sample at the source. The mead is a clear yellow with. Still. The mead is moderately spiced. The ginger does come through, but in more of a subtle way. Slightly on the sweet side, but the ginger cuts that sweetness and helps, at least in my opinion.

Pour from a 750 ml bottle at Woodstone Creek during a tasting. Pours a barely cloudy white wine color with no head or carbonation; just a wee bit prettier than the base Mead or the Taliesin. It’s also got more sweetness than those, as well. Good balance of ginger and honey here, without the subtle citrus notes of the Taliesin. Light-medium bodied, with no carbonation and a smooth, sweet mouthfeel. I’d give the edge to this one between the two, but barely.
750 ml bottle to wine glass at Woodstone Creek. Looks good; a still and transparent honey gold. Smells solid; honey and ginger. Tastes like it smells with a solid mouthfeel. Enjoyable.

Sampled from 750 mL bottle at the Woodstone Creek Winery and Distillery tasting room... At first the ginger in the Woodstone Creek Ginger Honey reminded me of the Woodstone Creek Taliesin. However, after a couple more sips it was quite clear that these were two very different meads. This mead is considerably sweeter. In addition the flavors are ginger and sweeter honey, nbut o lemon, citrus, or toasted oak complexties as found in the Taliesin. This mead had a dry finish. The alcohol content was well hidden as well. In general this is also a still mead and has is pale yellow in color.

Sample at tasting room. Poured clear pale color with good legs. Heavy ginger honey aroma. Light to medium body with a sticky texture. Medium honey ginger sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable mead.
Pours pale clear yellow, still. Light spice aroma, with a moderately sweet flavor with a light body. Light spice throughout. $10.99/bottle

Sampled from 750 mL bottle at the Woodstone Creek Winery and Distillery tasting room... Woodstone Creek Honey Mist is definitely a Pyment. The fruity grapiness of the white wine that is blended in is easily distinguishable. the honey takes a half step or so behind the fruity grape in the bouquet and flavor. Don’t get me wrong, the honey isn’t completely masked; the blend is actually very well done as it is nicely balanced (just enough to slightly showcase or bring out the qualities of the grapes). This is a still mead that has a clear, golden color. After drinking the first couple meads, this one is much sweeter, but probably only moderately sweet on the over all scale. This was another memorable mead and propably the best Pyment I have had to date...

Sample at tasting room. Poured clear golden color with good legs. Moderate honey aroma. Light to medium body with a thin texture. Medium honey sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Soft drinkable mead.

Sampled from 750 mL bottle at the Woodstone Creek Winery and Distillery tasting room... Woodstone Creek Traditional Honeywine is made with Midwestern Wildflower Honey. As a result the aroma and flavor both have a nice floral quality to them. This mead is quite sweet and has a full, honey flavor. Even the actual honeycomb flavor seems to be captured in this still, yellow-colored mead! It has a medium body and is quite smooth on the palate.

Sample at tasting room. Poured clear amber color with good legs. Moderate honey alcohol aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Medium honey sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration with a small alcohol bite. Solid drinkable mead.
Pours clear yellow, still. Sweet honey aroma that is mirrored in the flavor. A sweet dessert sipping mead. The alcohol comes through in the finish. $9.99/bottle.

First off, why is it 96F in the middle of September? Secondly, BIG BIG props to LB for being an oasis in the middle of the hell that is I-70 through Kansas. Onto the beer, just about crystal clear, nice tight white foam, decent lacing. Aroma is fairly light, little bit of cascade hop in there somewhere. Flavor is just pure absolute refreshment, light, but not too light, just about perfect when you’re driving cross country in a convertible and it’s f’n hot.

Pours a very pale straw with a white head. The aroma is virtually nil. The flavor is also virtually nil. There is some graininess to the flavor (which I must imagine is the rye). The malts and hops flavors are very subtle. This simply needs to be bolder and more flavorful...
Very refreshing pumpkin beer! Very nice pumpkin flavor. Well put together. Alcohol level is well blended in the body of the beer. Well done!

Sampled on tap, orange color with a medium foamy head. Notes are pumpkin guts, spices, vegetal, cinnamon, and clove especially as it warms up. Lighter to medium body with similar carbonation. Alright, nose was much better than flavor.
Bottle from Total Wine in Palo Alto, CA. Aroma is sweet potato pie, fall spices. Taste is balanced malty pumpkin pie. Really lives up to the hype. Phyllis Schlafly eat your heart out!
Bomber. Pours a dark orange with a dissipating head and aroma of pumpkin pie spices. Taste is full of fall spices, cinnamon, nutmeg, allspices notes into the sweet finish.

Pours a very dark bronze color with a tiny beige head and poor retention. No lacing. Strong spiced aroma. Similar flavor. Spice-dominated flavor with very little actual pumpkin flavor. A nice change-up from regular beer, but too heavily spiced for regular consumption. Noticeable boozy warmth in the finish.

At home, bomber with the boys. Pours a dark pumpkin color with no head. Pour a dark pumpkin rusted color. Nose is deep spicy sweet pumpkin with autumn spices. Taste is sweet sugary pumpkin with a myriad of ‘ autumn spices’. Finishes on the sweet pumpkin notes... a nice sipper.. Quaff Score 8 / 10

A pumpkin beer. Not a sickeningly sweet pumpkin beer, not a wickedly over-spiced pumpkin beer, but a pumpkin beer just the same, with all the baggage that comes with it. One day I'll learn and just give up on the style, but, dammit, Paste said this bottle was good. I disagree.

A malt-head's delight from a long-time St. Louis crafter whose product, I regret, I drink too little of. Schlafly captures the season well. It looks like a dark red maple leaf right before it is so dry it falls off the tree. It smells of the season's spices and, separating itself from the growing pack of pumpkins, Schlafly's does not have an artificial taste. Just sits rich in the mouth like a balanced dessert.
Draught @ Pilsener Haus. Reddish amber with foamy beige head, light pumpkin aroma, medium carbonation, medium bitter roasted pumpkin taste, smooth body, long pumpkin finish. Very good pumpkin beer.
Truly one of the finest pumpkin ales out there, deceptively big at 8% abv. Perfectly balanced spice that doesn’t dissolve the pumpkin flavors. Look forward to it being tapped here every year!

Reviewed from old notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was slightly hazy/cloudy a golden yellow color with a substantial two and a half fingered white foamy glossed over level sort of head - "nice" is just a decent word to use. Good, hell yeah, definitely good on this one. The smell had a super nice half hefe-esque, grainy to wheaty to a fairly nice sweet gritty, earthiness just running all around under my nose. The taste took those smells to the flavor and just combined fairly nicely. On the palate, this one sat at/about a light to medium on the body with a decent semi-sweet to wanted-to-be spicy glossy on the palate. Overall, I can’t necessarily endorse this beer, but will say it’s okay and leave it at that.

Brewed in Portland, Maine, but tapped at Sunday River Brewing in Bethel, Maine--Golden hazy body with small wispy head. Not a very substantial proffering. Grainy, slightly hefe-esque. Gritty, earthy, watery. Mediocre at best.

6 ounce draught sample at the Vermont Brewer’s Fest (July 2007). Hazy light gold with a huge lasting frothy head and thick lacing; don’t often get a hefe at a festival that looks this good....very sour and wheaty aroma, like wheat bran in buttermilk, banana-clove impressions are muted....creamy body, fairly sharp and dry, has a somewhat Belgian yeast profile though I doubt that’s anything more than coincidental, lightly mineralic, dry and bitter at the finish, estery qualities muted.....somewhat thin on the finish. Overall, OK.

On tap at the Great Lost Bear. Pours a light golden murky yellow with a little fizzy white head. Aroma is mostly biscuity but there’s some hints of citrus and fruits. Flavors are pretty simple, citrus, grass, hops, wheat, and yeast. Overall pretty bland and boring.

Draught pint at the Great Lost Bear, 8/18/06. Thoroughly cloudy, pale-gold/straw body sports a briefly-lived white head, which fizzles to a ring, leaving little/no lacing. Some muted banana in the nose is hinted at, but then blown away by bitter hops? I guess that’s what it is. Dry, with a leafy, herbal pungency and yielding, only minimally, to light cloves, creamed wheat and strong doughiness (white dough, some honey). Some citrus peel notes combine with the bitter hops and the banana is lasting, though never much more than an afterthought in the nose. Strength is rather weak, dulled by the heavy yeast clouding the liquid. Straw, dough, heavy wheat smoothness and nips of hop bittering, almost cascade-like press in to the palate upon first sip. The banana is minimal and fades in to a watery/wheat body that is only bolstered by some carbonation, initially, becoming too wet after warming/breathing. Some honey and lemon-flavored angel food cake-like notes battle with the heavy wheat, while the palate is somewhat bitten by the bitterness, on end. It’s certainly a unique take, and the hops don’t fatigue the palate, there just don’t seem to be enough other malt flavors going on. VERY clean; guess they just used their house yeast? That or they fermented this at a very low temperature for the style. Quenching, no alcohol apparent. Touches of breadiness and hay/straw-like graininess are the extent of the malt contributions after the palate adjusts. Pretty high ratio of water-to-malt, it seems to me. But the hop bitterness helps to clear the palate and does add some livliness. Dosen’t impart much flavor, though (nettles, lemons, grass).
[Bottled] Pale golden. Metallic and bland with traces of maize. Too light bodied with just a touch of late grassiness. Poor, also by low alcohol lager standards as far as I’m concerned.

0,5 l bottle shared. Bottle was obtained thanks to bartlebier. Apperance: A golden body with a eggwhite foamy head on top. Aroma: Grains, a bit of honey, straw and quite some grassy hops. Taste: smooth and sublte sweet ,pale malls, a hint of grains and hay, with quite some grassy hops, with a bit of lemon. Smooth, thin- medium body, a bit high carbonated, but not annoying. Good one for it's style.

Thanks to quack-duck for that one! Bottle looks simple but really good. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts fine malty, fine spicy, some grasy-wheaty notes. Nice dry background. Finish well balanced, malty-spicy. Nice!
0,5 l Flasche. Leicht trübes Bier mit grünem Schimmer, weißer, feiner und beständiger Schaum. Riecht und schmeckt dezent hopfig nach Gras, eher ein erfrischendes Sommerbier.

Big thanks to quack-duck for that one! Bottle looks simple but really good. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts mild, malty, modest spicy. Light dry background. Could maybe be a bit more hoppy. Quite drinkable. Not bad!

500ml bottle [hunted down by bartlebier, now decorating my fireplace, thanks!] Clear, yellow-ish golden colour with small to average, frothy to macropore, rapidly diminishing, minimally lacing, white head. Nice, decently fresh hoppy aroma, slightly grassy and floral, minimally metallic, pale malty background. Taste is slightly floral hoppy, minimally grassy, minimally metallic, sweet-ish, pale malty basis. Typical sweet-ish South-German Pilsener.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein klares goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig, getreidig, grasig. Geschmack hopfig, grasig, lang anhaltende Bitterkeit.
Nettes Pils, das gar nicht herb daherkommt. Leicht grasig mit ausgewogener Perlung und einigen Pfirsichen im Abgang. Etwas klebrig zum Ende hin, aber alles in allem nicht schlecht.

Bottle from trade with beerhunter111 - many thanks! The beer pours out in a cloudy amber colour with low head and medium body. Aroma of grains and caramel. Taste of stew, broth,acid, berries, hops and potatoes. Grainy hints with a dry-bitter finish. Too sour for a Pils but drinkable.
Bottled 50cl. Courtesy of bartlebier. Balanced and without major flaws. Good pale malt back. Decent bitterness. I enjoyed this beer. Thanks a lot bartlebier!

50cl local Getränkemarkt, as this is considered a regional speciality but not regional enough for bigger supermarkets to carry it. - Pours a greenish grainy lager with dull head. Label mentions use of feiner Tettnanger und Hallertauer Naturhopfen, but the doses are minimal; fine and persistent Tettnang spice and pepper remain mere hint. Metallic notes in aroma and defining mouthfeel. Bavarian-style sweet lager graininess. needs more than work to become a decent pils, e.g. different recipe. Rerate: 2nd bottle drunk in full sun with a view, shining a redeeming light on this modest but, granted, refreshing and lager-style SW-DE pils. Not likely to become a house beer, though. 2nd rerate: 2.5-2.8 33cl bottle 07/2013: distinctive lingering spicy/grassy hop presence that balances out the malt astringency at slightly higher temps. Starting to appreciate this more, tastes charmingly artisanal, if still not spectacular. // rerate 50cl bottle, bb08/2015: fresh this becomes muchx crisper, tastier, Tettnang-forward, dry: hop dosage does seem to waver, but this is among the better small-batch BW Pilsners out there +0.5 // Rerates 2015, cases of this stuff: yes this has become my house Pils, and rightly so: fresh and zippy with all that is good, dry, citrusfruity and local. Superb stuff, as only so far colleague pivnizub seems to have noticed.
A golden color when poured with a nice frothy head. Definately can taste the malt and hops. Not too bitter.

Bottle 50cl, from Quack-Duck thanks. A clear golden beer with medium head. Nose is hopy and grainy, aroma is very hopy with sweet malt, very nice pilsner with very interesting hops bouquet on grass and bitterness, but body is a bit less complex and malty that the unfiltered one.

0,33 l can. Yet another Van Pur 4,0 ABV beer. Second in one day. I seem to have suicidal tendencies... Pours clear yellow with quickly dissipating frothy white head and huge air bubbles. Aroma is cardboard, more cardboard and some extra cardboard. Grainy with hints of malt. Taste is light sweet, light to medium bitter and slightly sour. Body is light, texture watery and carbonation above average. Finish is quite long, unpleasant sour bitterness. Really terrible. Note: same "beer" as all other Van Pur 4% ABV beers, same cardboard aromas, so I just copied on of my rates.
Smakuje jakby przep³ukaæ puszkê po piwie wod¹. Pustka, woda, lekka dro¿d¿owoœæ i lekka s³odowa s³odycz. O dziwo bez wiêkszych wad, po prostu woda z %
Gulbrun farge. Vannete. Smaker metalisk ellers veldig lite. Lukter det det er.... kjedelig leskedrikk.

kupio u studenca u Sibeniku ... kupio sam ga onako radi reda ...bilo jeftino pa da probam ... na moje i kolegino cudjenje pivo skroz ok ...cak mozda i bolje od ovih skart lagera iz hrvatske ... iznenadilo me ovo van pur izdanje od 4 posto alkohola ..cak cu ga ponovno uzeti ...skroz ok lager ..

zapach niezbyt intensywny, trochê s³odów, cukier puder, kurz i skórki z jab³ek. kolor z³oty, jasny, klarowny, choæ w toni p³ywaj¹ jakieœ drobne paprochy. pian bi³a, œrednio obfita, ma³o trwa³a. w smaku wodniœcie, odrobina s³odów, troszeczkê trawy, mo¿e kilka nut jab³kowych, kurz. wszystko bardzo lekkie. goryczki brak. nasycenie umiarkowane.
Sama woda, praktycznie. Tu siê dos³ownie nic nie dzieje. Dos³owne nic. I po co to jest?
Fles 33cl thuis. Absoluut een rookgeur & -smaak. Zuurkool met worst. Niet lekker. (2-2013).
For some reason i had both a tick and a rating here, and with the new ratebeer setup for ticks (est. '18) I seem to have lost the rating. Pitty. Warrants a re-rate.
Beer came gushing out the bottle. Taste of smoked ham, with a little roastedness. Body is a bit thin. Decent beer, better than I thought.
Dark opaque stout with a thin creamy moka head. Light sweet chocolate aroma, with light diacetyl. In mouth, good chocolate malt with roasted coffee notes. Medium bodied. On tap at Gibraltar May 2006.
VEry nice beer, the problem is that the grains gave it a very bitter tatse and more like coffee sediments more than the tatse I like about malts. Anyway the foam is creamy and good in general.
Draft at Gibraltar, Buenos Aires Black, medium size tanned head. Aroma is roated, with notes of coffee, wood and smocked salmon. Medium body, dry finish. Flatly carbonated.

Draught at Gibraltar, Buenos Aires. Black, creamy head. Extremely roasty with plenty licorice and aniseed. Medium bodied. Very dry and fairly soft. Roasty flavour with spices, grass and some chocolate. Lasting bitter, near tarry finish.

Draft- August 2006. Draft at Gibraltar´s. Pours a deep black color with a fine nitro-white head. Aroma is slightly roasty and fruity. Taste is very subtle of coffee, a bit of chocolate and bitter sweet. Balanced and pleasant.
Draft at Gibraltar’s. A dark amber beer with a nitro creamy head. Aroma is floral and slightly malty. Taste is malty and floral. A little watery. Nice mouthfeel.
