Nice amber colour with a thin creamy white head. Pleasant buttercotch aroma with light C-hops. Good nutty malt with light floral hops and grapefruits. Medium bodied. Up to par with american ESBs. On tap at Gibraltar, May 2006.
Neither so special, it seems it is the hurry for creating good Brittish beers that meks them do good ones just that.
Draft at Gibraltar Bright copper color, small off-white head. A bit salty rand cereal aroma. Flavor is flowery, hoppy with hints of bread. Very smooth, not much bitterness.

Draught (nitro) at Gibraltar, Buenos Aires. Clear dark amber, creamy head. Resiny hop aroma. Sweet with rounded mouthfeel and rather clean mouthfeel. Notes of honey underneath the resiny hops that lingers on to the finish that holds a persinstant but not very strong bitterness.

Draft - August 2006 at Gibraltar´s. Pours a great copper color with a creamy, white head, that diminishes to a rim after some time in the glass. Aroma is floral, herbaceous. Taste is bitter but balanced with crystal malt, mouthfeel is medium to thin, refreshing with a pleasant bitter bite.
A amber beer with a small white head. Aroma is hoppy, with dried fruits notes. Taste is malty and caramel. Very nice bitterness and mouthfeel. Very good beer.
NOt very iteresting, ha dit in a bar thanks to Fujito. It was just a normal IPA but nothing special but incipit features.
Red colored, small white head that leaves a good lacing. Aroma is soft, flowery but not very hoppy. The same with flavor, nice but too timid for an IPA, with hints of bread. Nice dry finish.

Hand pump at Gibraltar´s. August 2006. Pours a deep red colour with a thin white head. Almost flat and at cellar temperature. The white head becomes a small rim as I empty my pint. The aroma is flowery and fruity. Flavor is bitter sweet with a great caramelly backbone. Bitter and chewy at the same time. Balanced and rich, multidimentional. It really fills my expectations for cask conditioned beer.
on tap at C’est What beer fest. Corny aroma, sweet maltiness in the flavour, not exactly what i was expecting, but i appreciate the effort.

Draught @ The Brewery: Along with pootz I to was filled in on the story of Manchester Bitter, and thusly feel permitted in providing the score it likely deserves. While I would never rate it lower than a Steelback beer, I will rate it lower than any other Neustadt product. Smells of wet, sweet grass. Pours deep yellow, no head. Flavour is slightly sweet, not at all bitter (at least not when cold), and fairly ordinary. Too bad I have a feeling it’s not seeing the light of day again.. haha

Sampled from a 10 liter draft caddy at the brewery. The brewer let me in on the secret of this beer and I ain’t tellin’ except to say that he was going for the Steelback experience....and he certainly acheived it with this lagerale. ;-) I had a laugh seeing this getting lower scores than some Steelback beer and higher than some Neustadt beers......ratings are certainly a funny thing .
Draught. Yellow-gold with a small white head. Grassy, grain, wort, and hay aroma. The flavour is grainy and sweet and lacking any flavourful bitterness.
Corn nose, golden, small white head. Malty taste, sweet, light bodied. Fair, but does not meet the style.

Draught sample at Golden Tap Awards. Light, bright gold with a creamy head. Aroma of candy and popcorn - lots and lots of popcorn. Flavour of a mild malty ale with popcorn floating in it. Where the hell did all this popcorn come from? Based on the name, I guess they’re going for a Boddingtons style bitter - they got the appearance right, but that’s about it.

On Tap. Bright gold with large porus top. Grainy, slightly sour arom , dough , fruity esters.Bitter? Flavour work out slightly better than nose- more harmonious . Gentle bitternes , with light carbonation. Soft biterness till very finish with hnints of spice and dough.

Draught at beerbistro during the 2006 Golden Tap Awards. Pours a clear gold with a small diminishing white head. Aroma: hmmm, I’m not crazy about that. Smells like grain and canned peas with lots of corn and faint hops. Flavour’s no better, it tastes like it smells with a somewhat bitter finish and a slightly unpleasant aftertaste. Medium bodied. I can’t say I’m a fan of this and I’m not sure how it’s a ’Bitter’, in the end I couldn’t finish it. I won’t be getting it again.

Draught. At BeerBistro, 2006 Golden Tap Awards. Clear, brassy gold with a small white head. I was looking forward to another attempt at a bitter, but the aroma? sweet - like corn syrup, if I’m being charitable maybe faint stale herbal hop in there, but as it warmed it reminded me of a swimming pool liner baking in the sun: corn & pvc, yum. The taste, however, was a somewhat pleasant surprise - it really was bitter! - dry (and stale), somewhat herbal hop bitterness, not really sweet at all, but unfortunately a somewhat harsh finish, and way too much corny grain. Average body, very lively mouthfeel, slightly unpleasant aftertaste - I didn’t hate it anywhere near as much as everyone else, but still not a very good beer.

Dark cola body with a foamy off-white to beige head. Aroma is banana, cereals, cloves and coffee. Taste is bitter and slightly sour. Long dry finish with notes of white wine (muscat). Medium body, lively carbonation.

Flasche 0,5l: Kupfer, dunkler Bernstein, kräftige Trübung, stabiler mittelporiger Schaum; frische + kräftig malzige Nase, Malzzucker, Karamell, dunkle Fruchtigkeit, leichte Röstaromen, Kaffee, etwas Schokolade; frischer + fruchtiger Körper, kräftige Hefearomen, Bananen, dunkle Fruchtigkeit, kräftig malzig, Malzzucker, Karamell, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, leichte Röstaromen; angenehmer fruchtig-malziger Nachgang mit deutlichen Hefearomen
50cl bottle shared at the Paas monthly tasting. Thin white head. Clear amber pour. Refreshing

20-08-16 // 500ml bottle from the brewery. Pours an amber-brown colour. Naturally clody, big white frothyhead. Yeast and banana in the nose. Strong malt notes in the beginning in the end banana and yeast. Medium sweet.
First association is bread., but more malty. Aroma is typically Hefeweizen. Very easy to drink despite the heavy aromas. The carbonation is well-balanced. All in all a very likable beer.
Hefig malziger, minimal säuerlicher Antrunk. Trockene, leicht schokoladige Noten im Mittelteil, süffig. Gut trinkbar. 9/8/8/9/8/8
Pours a hazy brown colour with a large white head. Aroma is malty with notes of caramel, wheat, spices and cloves.
Swing top bottle. Dark brown color. Banana and caramel in the aroma and flavor. Hints of roast and citrus. Soft herbal notes. Sweetish. Hopjesvla. Decent.
Hazy brown color, stable white head. Balanced aroma of banana, malts and yeasty notes. Same for the taste, very well balanced, medium body.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes braunes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, röstmalzig, leicht fruchtig würzig. Geschmack hefig, leicht würzig, leicht fruchtig.

Bottle. Unclear amber color with white head. Aroma is caramel, earthy, herbal. Taste is caramel, herbal, earthy, kernig, very moreish. Oily mouthfeel with medium carbonation, quite mineraly. Good stuff!
Swing-Top Bottle from Rehills, Newcastle. Amber with a thick white head. It has a malty, toffee and earthy flavour followed by a gentle nutty and fruity finish. Good.
Dunkles gelb, schaum ok, im Geruch malzig herb im Geschmack recht süß malzig etwas getreidig wässriger Abgang
0,5l Bügelflasche. Bernsteinfarben klar, dünner heller Schaum. Malzduft. Nussig, etwas Kakao. Süsslich-herber Röstmalzgeschmack. Kakao, Haselnuss.

Copper body with a small, vanishing white head. Aroma is grass, hay, honey. Taste is malty sweet: fresh baked bread. Then comes the grass again and a pleasant yeasty note. Medium, bitter/yeasty finish. Soft bodied, medium carbonation.

Bottle from Bottle Baron. Clear amber body with a medium off-white head. Low carbonation. Good lacing. Aroma of earth, raisins and wood. Flavour of steel, salted bread and red apple. Thin body with a watery texture. Soft fizz. Simple and sharp.

500ml bottle from the Offie, Leicester. Reddish brown, very clear, with a large khaki head. Malty aroma with marmalade on toast, toffee, doughy yeast. Sweet caramel malt taste with a balancing bitter hop toward the finish. Heavily carbonated with a nutty aftertaste. Simple but tasty.

“Mariahilfer Bier Vollbier halbdunkel“, Flasche (50 cl) von Hopfen & Malz, Berlin. - Schönes Rotgold, klar. - Milde Nase mit etwas Toastmalz und schwacher, leicht buttriger Hopfenherbe. - Antrunk würzig toastmalzig mit Karamel und gebranntem Zucker, dabei nur dezent süß und grundiert von feiner hopfenwürziger Herbe. Zarte Anisnote. Schlank, beinahe dünn, leicht trocken, mineralisch. Im Abgang sehr milder zitrusfruchtiger Hopfen. - Angenehmes, mildes aber würziges und sehr süffiges Landbier.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown colour with a fluffy white head, light hop aroma, the taste is medium bitterness and with a dry bitter finish.
*Bottle from Craft Beer Kiosk, Wuppertal. Nice caramelly gold-brown in the glass. Fresh caramel, hints of roast. Smooth and sessionable with anice hoppy bitterness. Round and smooth. Nice one.
Bottle at home bought from hopblackburns.co.uk the beer has a sort of haze to it. It's very smooth, crisp, malty,light and touch of lemon lovely lovely beer

Nose is barley grains, toasted cereal, slight lemon citrus, grassy, hay, straw, that fresh wort smell you get in breweries, very slight floral. Taste is lemon citrus, grassy, hay, hoppy, straw, grassy bitter hoppy, some floral.
Getreidiger, hellmalzig herber Beginn. Milde Bitterkeit, geringe Würzigkeit, langer Nachhall. Okay. 10/9/8/10/8/9

Oide Buegelverschlußflasche aus Otto's Brunnen : Pale golden, hazy, big and slowly collapsing loose white bleached head; fresh herbal-grassy hops in the grainy-fruity-yeasty nose; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, light bodied, pretty soft; lingering bitter-sweet herbal - almost with molecular piney traces - hoppy finish with a good dash of balancing pale malt. Good and clean...

(swing top bottle) Hazy, golden colour with a blond and huge foamy head. Slightly doughy and delicately grainy malty aroma with notes of crackers, white bread, backed by herbal and delicately grassy hops. Mildly bitter and slightly sweet flavour, light bodied with a crisp carbonation. Dry and rounded malt and hop profile with crackery Pilsener malt and a good dash of spicy herbal and slightly grassy hops; dry bitter-sweet finish. Pleasant. 31.VII.17

09-08-16 / 500ml swingtop-botle from the brewery. Pours a clear bright yellow colour with a nice white head. Fresh grass in the smell. Light body, light carbonation. light bitter finish. very refreshin Pils.
Bottle. Pours a hazy dark gold colour with a fluffy white head, aroma is light and hoppy, the taste is medium bitterness with some fruit with a dry bitter finish.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein leicht trübes goldgelbes Bier mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig, leicht würzig. Geschmack malzig würzig, getreidig, leichte Bitterkeit.
Swing-top bottle 50cl. Slightly cloudy pale brew with small white head. Fresh impression in the nose, slim bodied but complex enough. Aromatic hops in the background. Balanced and refreshing.

Swing top bottle from the brewery. Golden yellow color, hazy (naturtrüb). Firm white head with big bubbles and good lacing. Aroma’s of grain and grassy and aromatic hops. Flavor is lightly bitter with a light malty sweet backbone. Light body. Finishes medium bitter. Very clean tasting, very solid German pilsner, but enjoy it brewery fresh!
On draught at Delaneys. Pours coppery with a small white head. Smells malty with some underlying hoppiness. Tastes od toasted malt and on the doughy side.

On Tap @ the Brewpub. Pours a slightly darkened orange with little head. Smells a little of fruit, wood, and a small amount of sweetness. Medium bodied with a tart sweetness that gives way to a more natural, dry woody aftertaste. I chose this while my buddy had the ESB (which was also nice) but I’m glad I went with this instead as I have a fondness for Saisons. Pretty damn good.

Draft at Broad Ripple. Nice orange color that carries through a bit in the flavor. Slightly tart and dry start gives way to a chewy, syrupy and woody taste. Not much head to speak of. Finished nice and peppery. After going through all of their samplers, this was the beer I had for a full pint before closing.

A Mes rate. Gravity at the Southampton. Very slightly hazy orange gold colour. Tarty dry apple aroma with some fairly clear barrel and a strange but very enjoyable note of vanilla soaked ice cream wafer cone. You know when all the ice cream is gone and your left with a slightly soggy cone? That’s it. The flavour is the same. Very pithy and fleshy. Lots of wood and a really bright fresh squeezed apple juice finish. Verging towards medium rather than dry. Finishes with some chewy apple skin. Jolly tasty.

Cask (gravity) Worcester BF. Not the driest and rummiest cider but has a certain elan; a smoothness and softness that belies its strength, somewhat coarser than the medium with just a little jammy raisin flavour to see it through.

Cask (handpump) at the Museum Tavern, Bloomsbury. More golden amber than pure blonde. Restrained aroma with hints of citrus. Didn’t get any signature Marstons sulphur, which would have been unwelcome in a golden ale. Moderately hoppy flavour, again with citrus to the fore. Perhaps the cascades do make a faint impression but the citrus is more lemon than grapefruit. Crisp & clean and served in good condition (albeit through a sparkler). Tart bitterenss lingers in the aftertaste. Straightforward but surprisingly decent - no doubt sets out to be refreshing and achieves that.

Golden colour with a fair amount of head. Didn’t have that rather nasty sulpherous smell that some of the other Marstons beers have. Quite a nice, floral aroma and a fresh taste, a little lower on hops than the avarage blonde beer, which was a nice change, a good malt, fruity sweetness balanced it quite well.

State bar. Apparently has just been put on, and tasted noteably fresh. However looked more muddy and mirky than the end of a cask of addelstons. A bit cold so near no aroma. Taste is well balanced honey and fresh grassy hop with hints of lime. Nice beer but soo increadibly mirky.

Cask handpull at County Hotel, JDW, Ashford. Jumping on the US hop blonde beer bandwagon. Gold colour, thick cream head. Slight burton snatch aroma. Citrus hops too. Pretty good condition in the mouth. Then US hop finish, so not surprised it says it has Cascades. It’s fine and perfect for summer.

A Sim rate (Cask at the Gatehouse): It’s ok but my general indifferance towards English hoppy blondes explains the mediocre rate. Aroma and flavour are very hoppy. Flavour is even too much hops. Palate is runny. Not a great beer.

Cask at Bankers Draft (JDW). Bedford. Served at just about the right temperature. Gold with a small white head. Grassy hop aroma with a definite whiff of sulphur. Citrus taste with a grainy background. Some bitterness. Pretty ordinary golden.
Good blonde too. Very yeasty flavour like other MAsrton’s, interesting taste.

<!-- b -->Aug<!-- /b --> Cask conditinoed @ Hymble Plumb, Soton. Sulphurous yeast and light body. The yeast doesnt complement the fresher citrus flavours of a golden ale, but then again the malts a bit heavy handed for my taste as well.

Cask handpump at the Swan in the Rushes, Loughborough. Clear golden with a slim white head. Sulphur aroma, (a bit like Pedigree use to have before they staring mucking about with it some years back, ruining a great beer), Citrus, malty and bitter taste. Not very well put together however, one was enough.

cask at the crows nest, crosby, liverpool. very much one dimentional, lots of citrus on the nose, pretty much overpowered by lemon tang and really the same. bright golden colour and a fluffy white head, good lacing right down the glass too. heaps of bitterness on the finish but nothing really enough to keep interest, fairly dull

column1: Abbey Wright Coeur de la Saison
column5: Aroma: some spices and some metal Appearance: pale yellow, some head, no lacing Flavor: weak, slightly spicy with some metallic-ness, some yeast and some grains, candied fruits, and slightly soapy Palate: watery, bubbly, slightly spiced-metallic aftertaste, soapy feel

column1: Abbey Wright Coeur de la Saison
column5: Draught at the brewery. Soft red and orange color. Flavor is mild fruit, mild cream, some soapy notes as well, with anise and some other spices. Has some fruity yeast scents and flavors, but this is not your traditional saison, in fact it’s pretty weak. Has some bad funk to it all around. Mold in the nose doesn’t help.
On tap at the Pints for Pets brewfest. Dark near black color. Super dark and smoky aroma and flavor, with smoked malts being the focus. Pretty hot in the chest. A tad thin body.
Dark brown with lace. Sour taste out of sweetness, sour rather than much smokiness. Almost as if a sour pickel was thrown in the mash. Light mouthfeel. Like a dunkel beer.

ABC 06. Pours a moslty clear deep amber with a thin off white head. Poured a bit cold, but as it warmed, a nice nutty caramel malt aroma came through- slgihtly estery with some dirty yeast in there. Flavor is more caramel and toasted malts, very light chocolate nuttiness. Not sure on the alcohol, but it seemd a bit weak. Not bad though.

On tap at the brewery. Light fresh hoppy aroma. Mild grassy bitterness with the normal ’beaniness’ in the style. Light golden clear with no head. Medium-light watery body with medium-heavy carbonation. Starts with light sweetness followed by good grainy, grassy notes and flavorful floral hops. Great crisp bitterness throughout with mild gassy burn on the tongue. After is clean with mild bittering.

column4: Liberal Cup Public House and Brewery
column5: Aroma:light citrus aroma... Appearance:Amber,light beige head.. Flavor:citrus and spicy flavor...

column4: Liberal Cup Public House and Brewery
column5: My first cream ale and i’ve got to say right off it was a bit bland. Poured with a dense head, slightly full body. Flavors were pretty simple, I tasted some light malt and a little sweetness, not much else. I’ve got to agree with Clark on the Boddington’s similarities.

column4: Liberal Cup Public House and Brewery
column5: Get it? Scream. Yep.... Nitro pint at the brewpub on 8/18.06. One finger of dense, nitro-induced head is well-retained atop a cloudy, tallow colored body. Not much lace, if any. Soggy, wet pils-like malt, though it’s hard to really tell if it’s pils or American two-row. It’s light, it’s got honey note to it, little, if any graininess. Minty, leafy, peppery hops seem an afterthought, but more likely, is just lost amidst the gassy nitrogen bubbles. Kind of like boddingtons, or something. Soggy, cardboardy, soily hops, hardly any bitterness. The flavor dosent seem overly watery, for a nitro ale, especially a cream ale. So I will give it that. But there’s little here other than some honey and light pale sugar notes. Hops are too bogged down by the nitrogen and creamy-wet texture. Just gets filling, without much actual flavor. Ya....so, that’s about all I can stretch out of that beer. Who the hell puts a cream ale on nitro anyways?
Bottle.Gold with a nice head,aroma of fruit and grass,taste is malty with dark fruit,i hope herman won’t miss his plums.

Cask handpull at Kingston Arms, Cambridge. Gold with lasting white head. Strange to have this after the Bartram Dark Side. Bit of vinegar/citrus/cider, which means it could be getting tired. Not a huge aroma, and then a cidery appley flavour more than plum. Unless of course they are very sour plums you are using. Very sour under-ripe greengages is my guess. Soft in mouth. Finish is pretty drying with more sour plum. Funny, I expected it to be a rich plum beer, but it is far more sour than that.

A golden orange coloured beer with a thickish white head. A light hoppy aroma, with a hint of malty fruit. The taste is dry and hoppy, with a malty undertone, the fruit only comes through in the aftertaste, leaving a smooth, mellow mouthfeel. (Cask - @ The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).

27/4/2019. Bottle from the Real Ale Shop, Wells. Pours very dark brown with a large off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, liquorice, toffee, molasses, fruit cake and a herbal edge. Medium sweetness, moderate bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, above average carbonation. Very nice aroma but went downhill a bit from there.

[500ml bottle from Samphire, Blickling Hall, Norfolk] Pours brown - completely lifeless with no head. Gorgeous chocolate aroma. Salty overcooked cabbage in the flavour - presumably from the samphire. Some tar and cough mixture, but the chocolate just about wins through. Unusual, and could be good, but agree with previous comments about poor condition.

Bottle. Poured a pretty lifeless black, struggled to get even a semblance of a head - cokey and quickly disappearing. Aromas of red wine up front with salty, savoury, smokey notes and some roasted malt. Quite tart on the tongue, sharp berry notes with a light roasted, salty bitter finish. Appearance reflects the palate - lacking any real condition, mostly flat and light to medium in body. Looks like I need to try this from cask.

BC?? Black squash pour slopping mutely into the pot. Fox have really impressed me with their bottled efforts in the past but this is dead and headless like morning after takeout. Nosing reveals damp end of festival vegetal notes, roasted nuttiness, Marmite on toast,coal, coffee, bramble. Not very subtle. Oily, faintly charred and a dab salty. Sourish with black cherry and bramble notes merging into brine, mocha, watery Marmite and cigar smokiness. Some decent stouty notes if you go digging. The interplay of sour, salty, bitter and....rockpool is interesting, but ultimately another English beer wrecked by bottle conditioning, or the lack of it.
Bottle.Black with a small head,aroma of coffee and red wine,taste is of red wine roasted coffee malt with some tartness,long dry black and raspberry finish.

Cask conditioned at The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk. Very dark brown beer, no head. Dark, deep roasted tarry notes abound from the start of the beer, hints of liquorice and, interestingly cloves, maybe this was from the seaweed and a heavy syrupy herbal flavour. Certainly an interesting beer if challenging.

A dark, almost black, brown coloured beer with flashes of ruby red, topped with a thick off white head. A deep,roasted malt nose of coffee, liquorice and burnt sugar. The taste is bitter, with the tannic mouthfeel of an espresso! Coffee flavours are accompanied by roasted malt, caramel and liquorice, but there is an underlying green, vegetable saltiness, that comes from the samphire. (Cask - @ The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).
Golden colour. Good strength. Dry apples taste. Refreshing. Excellent after taste
Pours a clear light golden colour with no head. Aroma is apple peel, fermented apple and a hint of wood. A medium sweet cider, apple flavours, some wood with tannins in a dry finish.
500ml bottle. Clear golden, no head. Nose is medium sweet, apple peel and apples. Flavor is apple peel, soft acidity, dry and acidic finish. Not bad.

Clear deep gold color with no foam. Aromas dry sweet of fermented apples and oak barrel. Palate, medium light body with thin-ish texture leaving rather dry finish. Taste, really dry with a touch of sweet and back of bitter apple peel. Overall, not bad, rather dry cider but has a nice bitter dry apple taste. Not bad
Bottle, One Stop, Wigston. Golden with a light carbonation. Medium sweet apple with earthy apple skin. Light woodiness. Dry, peppery finish. Decent.
75cl bottle from Aldi, Bracknell. A still pale gold pour; some wood on the aroma; medium sweet apple taste; then a much drier finish with a tart apple finish. Very drinkable.
Bought for the 1st time today at Aldi, came in a 2.25 litre box, alc. 6%, well priced and not bad, still cider, dark, dryish, very easy to drink, I will buy this again.

Bottle from Saucy Pears. Appearance - golden with gentle bubbles. Nose - sour apple. Light wood backdrop. Taste - sweeter apple this time. Palate - close to medium bodied with a tangy texture and a dry tangy finish. Overall - a good solid cider.
Bottle at Ash’s. Pours clear gold.with a thin white head. Aromas of oak, apples. Taste is more apples. Dry finish.
Bottle at ash’s. Pours clear golden, nose is tart apple, sugary, taste is dry, tart apple.
Polycask at St Albans festival. Hazy golden color, white head. Aroma of dusty barnyard apple skin. Taste is tart and dry fruit. Very nice.

Polycask @ NWAF 2013, National Winter Ales Festival, The Venue, Sheridan Suite, Manchester, England. [ As Dry Cider ]. ABV: 5.5%. Unclear medium red orange color with a small, fizzy, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy apple, sweet apple, apple - apricot, rubber, vinegar - acetone - petrol, blue cheese, light barnyard. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light acidic with a long duration, tart apples, dry dry. Body is medium, carbonation is flat. [20130124]
From the barrel at GBBF, day 3 on 3 August 2006. Cloudy gold appearance. Slight petrol on the nose. More petrolly in the flavour. Plenty of fruit though and decent light tannins.

Barrel at GBBF 2006. Hazy old gold colour. No head. Lots of petrol/kerosene aroma on this. Wow. Lots of sour apple and interesting flavours. I have written "hot" in my notes for some reason. Maybe the effects of that petrol aroma.

This draft brew from a the brewery poured a head of foamy finely sized bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a transparent softly carbonated copper brown colored body and a good lacing. The aroma was hoppy malty and metallic. The crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of malt and hops. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

Draft. small white head that mostly diminished, fair amount of lacing, no visible carbonation, transparent, and a yellow hue. Malty, hoppy nose and ditto for the flavor. Tingly mouthfeel. Medium body.

Draft at tapping party on 08/05/06. Poured hazy copper with an average frothy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate sour citrus hoppy smooth aroma. Medium body with a slick texture. Medium balanced flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable beer.

Draft at the brewery. Pours clear bright ruby/copper with a thin fizzy head. Tastes like strong tart raspberry, woody malt, yeast, and some tart citrus. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like raspberry, yeast, citrus, and woody malt.
on tap at the brewery; eddish-pink color;nice tart raspberries aroma; great, tart raspberry flavor with hints of oak; dry, tart, oaky finish; a really nice beer;10% abv

Draft from Weyerbacher Tap Room in a 12oz tulip - reddish brown, small amount of head, light carbonation, sour raspberry, cranberry like tartness, balanced with a strong dank oak character. This is one worth trying again, extremely well done.
2016 Bottle: Funky aroma with raspberry in the aroma. There is quuite a sour puch but surely the barrel aging mellows it out. Ripe raspberries abound in the flavor. Overall, this beauty is amazing!

Dark orange pour, bubbly off-white head. Aroma of sour raspberries. Excellent puckering sour notes, sweet tarts and raspberries, hint of vinegar - in a good way, requisite Sweet Tarts candy...lacking anything else substantive to say about an excellent Sour. Thick, tart lively mouthfeel. Very enjoyable. Thanks to my buddy Aurelius for the bottle share at Proof.
Belgian style bomber, average label. Rosy chestnut brown, flocculent sediment. Sour, fruity, yeasty aroma. Very tart, jammy, warming. Lingering sour aftertaste. Solid.
@ Gyllenbock 17-10-28: Trevlig funky med toner av röda bär. Lätt och enkel att dricka

Bottle, thanks Tom. Hazy orange with a small white head. Fresh and nicely drinkable with raspberries, funk, citrus and some grass. The body was medium and the carbonation on the soft side. A nice one.

750 ml corked and caged bottled. Vintage 2016. Hazy garnet red color. Small creamy beige head. Big raspberry sour malt nose. Tangy berry, vinegar flavor upfront. Notes of wood and sour fruit. Mouth puckering. Sip this slowly and enjoy the complex, yeasty, tart, Eastern Pennsylvanian nuances. Sweet!
Bottle shared at DCLawyer’s sour tasting. 2016 vintage. Orange color. Aromas of raspberries. Tastes of tart acidic notes, raspberries and berries. Light body with a dry finish.

Very bright banana/apricot aroma. A little bit of melon and a touch of light lemon as well. Creamy palate. Despite the bright aroma, the flavour seems a little bit muted. A touch of clove but this is also quite dim. Finishes quite watery. Meh.

Sampled at the brewpub. Pours a hazy, straw yellow with a thin, white head. Nose of bubblegum, coriander, Hef yeast, grass. Flavor is sweet, candy, bubblegum, spices, cotton candy, yeast. Finish is sweet and lightly chalky.
Draught, 5% at the brewpub. Weak banana aroma. Cloudy orange colour. Small white head. The flavour is sweet with some clean banana. Hint of spices. OK sweetness. Good bitterness for the style.

Had on tap at the brewery A-pours a cloudy murky deep yellow liquid with a pure white head. S-the nose is very nice, some banance, lots of clove, notes of bubblegum, more spice, pepper and clove. T-sweet up front, notes of bubblegum and banana, touch of ripe lemon, lots of sweet flavor, the spice is behind, good peppery spice to it! M-thick body, full and chewy, grainy feel but soft on the tongue, strong carbonation balancing out the big body. D-huge flavors, great balance, a little dry in the back would have been nice, but a fantastic hefe,
tap @ bullfrog - Hazy yellow pour. arouma is clove and banana and candy gum. Smooth, medium thick mouthfeel. Musty flavors and subdued hops coming at the back end, supported by citrus and funk.
On tap at Bullfrog. Pours a very hazy gold with a small to medium sized white head. Banana, wheat and musk. Crisp yeast and wheat. Light esters. Crisp and light with some spicy yeast. Nice stuff.
Part of a sampler at brewpub. I found all the brews to be slightly better than average though I don’t remember specifics for most of them.

On draft at the brewpub. Pours a hazy grayish gold with a frosty medium sized white head. Aroma of light sweetened spice, banana, bubble gum, cloves and wheat. Taste is much the same as the aroma. Another fine summer brew.

@dmacs UFC100 Gathering courtesy of Rich’s friend Ryan-growler- Thanks. Pours a dull hazy woody orange with a spritzy head that fades to almost nothing. Aroma is high phenolic yeastiness, clove spice , with vanilla, as it wamrs a bit more fruity esters come around- banana- ok thinning wheat and pale toasty malts. Flavor is light lemon zest, phenolic, ester, and a dulling limp wheat malt base, slight crackery and doughy- thins out a bit in the end.

@dmacs UFC100 Gathering courtesy of Rich’s friend Ryan-growler–pours a rich white head and hazy gold color. Aroma is banana, earthy, clove, light/medium malt. Taste is pepper/clove, banana, earthy, light/medium malt.
Sampled at the brewery. Murky yellow gold, this dense white cap. Nice spicy banana aroma. Banana and spices dominate the palate. Not very estery, with a lemony tartness in the finish. Refreshing.

Bright medium gold body with a decent size white head. Banana and cloves in the taste also some orange towards the finish, this was more fuller in body than the federation wheat and more enjoyable. Tried this back in July last year (06) but just noticed it in my notebook.

Re-rate:- On draught at the brewery. Hazy, dusty gold with a tight off-white pad that held and laced with comfort. Banana, pears, ripe lemons, cloves, slight strawberry bubblegum in there - the aroma is now one considerably close to the finest of Southern Bavaria. In the mouth the ester/phenol mix keeps on rocking. The fruits stand out ripe and pronounced with a good-base of sour-dough, wheat malts and fresh, unkilned grain. Clove-like phenols are distant but still lie true in the swallow which is fruity, grainy and quite full with good, clean, ungammy length. The body is light enough to suit most of the patrons here as this is one beer that continues to sell out. Remains good even as it warms, especially with the warmth beginning this years Summer. A rather nice drop now, knew I needed to try it again!!! 8,4,7,3,16 August 22nd - An afternoon in the beer garden of this very friendly local and loyal haunt couldn’t go without atleast one new tasting. Sat on the Iron Bock for hours (due for a re-rate it is in prime-form right now) whilst listening to the live band and thought a change was as good as a holiday. From it’s own-label bottle, unusual amongst the beers here, into a schooner. ’Looks like a typical Aussie lager’ was the first impression. Bright medium gold, highly charged with very fine bubbles that desperately kept the soapy white head alive to leave behind minor lacing. Subtle, zesty, prickly lemon and grapefruit nose with a touch of candyish bubblegum and watermelon. Clean and lively. Doughy, smooth, a little soapy and light in carbonation inside the mouth. Initial bready yeast and overly dominant crystal malts settle in for the length. Lighter touches of lemons and sourish wheat malt, soft grapefruit and cantaloupe play a good part in keeping it tasty, though the crystal has a firm hold over the flavour. Finish is sweet, tangy and fruity despite its malty palate. It’s not a bad drop overall. Has that level of fruit flavours and malt sweetness that make it refreshing yet it could get a little heavy after a few. One to try again on draught for a re-rate. (33cL) 6,3,6,3,12
Cask at Charlies. Clear amber coloured with an off white head. Aroma of malts and fruits. Flavour of malts, fruits and hops. Dry hoppy finish.

DO NOT DELETE THIS BEER. A hazy amber beer with a light brown head. The aroma is sweet malty with primary notes of caramel, but also a bit of hops. The flavor is sweet with caramel dominating in the middle, which in the end gives way for notes of grass and a nice bitter end.

column1: John Harvards Double DLicious Milk Stout
column5: Sample at the Pittsburgh location. This brew is a flat black color with a compact tan head and decent lacing. Chocolate and coffee dominate the aroma. Smooth and creamy body with flavors of cocoa and coffee, as well as a hint of malt. The finish is on the bitter side with coffee and hops, and leaves a pleasant aftertaste. I enjoyed this one.

an above average Wit. Pours a cloudy orange from tap into a pint glass. Thin white head laces delicately. Nose is of wheat, hay, oranges, and a touch of floral hops. A nicely balance easy drinking beer.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy caramel to amber with one finger white head. Aroma is sweet and floral with notes of banana, clove, citrus, honey. Flavor is sweet and floral with notes of honey, clove, banana, yeast, bread. Medium body with a slightly sweet and floral finish. Very nice example of the style.
Alright wit, good example of the style. Nothing especially special, but decent nonetheless.
Pour is lightly hazed golden with a thin white head...smell is nice citrus with notes of coriander...taste is nicely sweet with lemon zest and is nicely spiced...

On tap at Ram - Wheeling. Poured a hazy pale golden with a short cap of white head. Aroma was of faint sweet bananas and orange peel.. non-offensive, but too restrained. Sweet toasted bananas and star fruit in the flavor with mildly tart wheaty notes extending outward.. vegetal notes and orange peel at the back and through the finish.. some peppery spices too. Ugly feel on the palate.. tacky hints from sweetness and sourness don’t mesh together.

(06.18.06) On tap at Ram brewpub, Wheeling, IL. Poured cloudy yellow with small white head. Soft carbonation. Smokey clove aroma. Light-to-medium bodied wheat beer that starts dry with light malt sweetness and spicy clove/smoke/fruity flavors. Finished dry with light hop bitterness. This is a very good drinkable beer that goes well with BBQ ribs.

07/08 Directly from a 0.5 l bottle on a gas station around Katowice. What a name! It had some reddish body. Aroma of some roasted malt some coffee and a bit of alcohol. Flavor is being balanced between bitterish coffee and sweetish caramel. Alcohol is tried to be hidden but it’s felt, well, this is a lager not a Belgian ale so it’s acceptable. Medium body with very low carbonation. Finish was quite long, sweetish and a bit alcoholic, but somehow watery leaving that impression on the whole beer. Not bad at all, but I didn’t like it so much as well.

No 299 Rated: 09.01.2008 Bottle brown, 500 ml Appearance: Body is very clear, carbonation of body is weak, colour of body is rubby, dark like strong tea, with burned caramel. Head is like in fizzy drink and quickly disappearing to nothing after not a whole minute. I would give it 3 but totally no head gives me the posibility of 2 and no more. Aroma: Burned sugar, light alcoholic notes, toasty malt, Munich malt, some notes of cherries and apple being a bit rotten, coffee notes, a bit too sweet. Flavour: Alcohol is much better hidden than in ’Grudziadzkie Dobra Dziewiatka’, heaving also 9% abv. Beer is very soft in terms of carbonation, almost flat, slightly alcoholic, becoming medium alcoholic at the end, some notes of roasted or more toasted malts, some hints of mild coffee and grains, one of simple and poorer dunkler bocks, but not that bad espetially because of greatly builded in alcohol that is felt slightly Palate: Body is medium, texture is wattery, carbonation is very soft on palate, finish feel is moderate alcoholic, a bit metaliic and chalky.

500ml bottle. Shared by Tranquillity - thanks! Dark reddy brown. Sweet, almost rotting fruit aroma, hinting on sour. But not in an unpleasant way at all. Taste at first similar. Sweet and a little sour, but with a huge burnt sticky malty bocky taste. Caramel, and almost vanilla. In fact, I could mistake this for being barrel aged, as it’s mellow, quite woody, and with an oaky and walnutty finish. Slightly biting alcohol on the tongue, otherwise quite soft. Very smooth for 9%. Don’t drink this too cold, it’s much mellower warm (12-14C or so). Well balanced and tasty. Very impressed - a big thank you, Tranquillity!

Bottle, bought in Poland back in ancient times. Dark brown, almost no (white) head. When warm, the aroma is full and cas caramel, raisins, grapes, even cookies. Almost no bubbles, big portwine-flavours, cognac atmosphere and brewed with "a charm from the brewer". Surprising!

A very quaffable beer for such a strong one. Rich flavor with some roasted tones and chocolate in the mix. Not overly complex, but very pleasant. The store down the street carries this beer, I look forward to purchasing it many more times

No 298 Rated: 09.01.2008 Bottle brown, 500 ml Appearance: Pours deep golden, practically amber, clear, well filtered, without sediments, honey like, orangy, intense, very nice as for Polish Strong Lager higher standard. head is small to medium initially, regular in structure and rather frothy, rather white in colour, quite quickly decreasing to very small, there are very weak traces of lacing but almost none at all. Aroma: Nice, denoting rich malt content, malted barley, some notes of chalkyness and light alcoholic nose, but as for 9% alcohol is very well hidden, some gentle notes of Polish aromatic hops. Typical aroma of Polish Strong Lager, high standard balanced, good and inviting. Flavour: Coming back to the content of alcohol - 9% it is of course felt, but in fact, very well balanced in. There is a high extract of barley maltsmaking the body heavy, medium to full bodied, sweet and balanced with apropriate level of carbonation and apropriate ammount of hoppy bitterness. Hops are herenot very aromatic but bitter. All in all very good as for 9% but a bit too sweet (not all the malt was fermented because of its high ammount what is said on the internet side of a brewery). One drinkable but enough, something artificial is here present. Palate: On palate you can feel some saltyness, bitterness and some additional harshness, barley grains are felt weaker, alcohol is medium to strong and there is strong sweetness for balancing purposes making this beer less drinkable.
Draught @ Antikwariat, Warsaw. Fresh spicy aroma, untypical for Polish lagers. Not too strong though. A bit darker than expected, small head. Teaste meady, medium finish. Pear, hops in the taste.

0,5 L plastic bottle, from the Euro Deli and Market. Pours a dark brown color, with a fizzy, fleeting, beige head. The nose is anise, cloves, cough syrup, and lots of phenols. Sticky and cloyingly sweet. Flat, sticky, and a little acrid. Pretty gross.

2000ml bottle. Clear, dark chestnut colour with ruby glimmer and small, more loosely bubbly than frothy, fading, off-white head. Toasty, bready and slightly fruity aroma, hints of pumpernickel and blueberries, a touch of dark honey. Taste is sweet, sugary, hints of burnt caramel, pumpernickel, dark honey, some treacle, maple sirup, a fruity touch of blueberry and citric acid. Slightly sugary and artificial of course, ot unattractive, though.
70 oz. bottle. Poured fizzy, dark ruby. Aroma was lightly burnt bread, molasses, caramel, burnt sugar. Taste was sweet, molasses, maple syrup, brown sugar, dark berries.
Brown color. Thin , beige head. Highly carbonated and sweet. Burnt caramel and dried fruits in the aroma. Taste is almost artificial.

2 L bottle. Pours brown with some head and lively carbonation. Aroma is of sweet malt, dark fruit and molasses. Body is medium and crisp. Taste is of bread, brown sugar, molasses and a lot of plums. Finish is long and sweet. This tastes more like sweet soda than kvass.
2l bottle from a Russian shop nearby. Taste is bread, malty sweet, probably honey, and the savory element of fermentation. Like.
No esta mal, pero no es una cerveza, ni de cerca. Apaga sed,tiene su bueno sabor,pero es solo una bebida maltosa.

Big liter bottle thanks to a student. Pours a dark brown color with a small carbonated head, looks like cola. A big malty nose .Sweet berries, unfermented malts, wort. Very sweet and grainy. Actually nice. Not beer, but a nice cola like drink.
Brown, small head, aroma of grape juice, caramel, flavor of grape juice, caramel, sourish, mild, light bodied.

Huge PET bottle. Clear brown, no head, soft drink-like bubbles. Aroma is pretty inviting - bread, sour cherries, cheap red wine, malt vinegar. And then it is a bit too sweet really. But there’s some berries and enough of a hint of acid to make it refreshing. Really a soft drink, but pleasant and has some complexity.

column1: John Harvards Highland Heather Scotch Ale
column5: From old notes. +++ Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a reddish brown color with a medium sized foamy tan head that left a bit of lacing. The aroma was malty with a bit of vague herbs and perfume. The flavor was nutty, malty and a bit woody with notes of herb and perfume. Medium length finish. Medium body. Solid.

column1: John Harvards Highland Heather Scotch Ale
column5: Sample at the Pittsburgh location. Pours a dark amber color with a medium thin beige head and spotty lacing. Amazingly floral heather aroma, which was easy to verify as they had a glass of heather at the bar. Some malt in the nose as well. Medium-bodied with a rich malty character, and again the floral heather is predominant in the flavor. The finish is smooth and sweet with a nice aftertaste of floral hops. Hands down one of the most unique beers I have tried in quite some time. The closest comparison I can make outside of beer is to Breitenbach’s Dandelion Wine. I hope to try this again someday.
330 ml can in a Brugges hotel room. golden with white head. grainy pilsner malt, faint grassy hay-ey hops with no aftertaste. meh.
Can 0,5ltr: Clear golden colored brew which looks an malt infused drinkwater, and nothing more.
light sweet malty aroma,pale, clear, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, astringent,
Light golden coloured and clear. Has a white head, medium duration. Light aroma, sweet and a bit sharp bitterness.

33cl can from a Carrefour in Bruges. Pours clear golden and fizzing, with a slowly collapsing, foamy, white head. The weak aroma contains corn, grass, malt and wet cardboard. It tastes light sweet and light bitter with a light grassy and metallic finish. Slick texture, thin body, fizzy carbonation. Extremely cheap, and the content reflects the price tag...
03-11-16 // 500ml can in Brussels. Bad mass pilsener. Just malty and grains. Not good.
Une pilsener assez banale mais fraîche et agréable avant un match de l’euro...

White long lasting head, clear gold colour, malty and grassy hoppy aroma, some skunky, taste malt and grassy hops but not well balanced, commercial cheap beer, 0,33l can for 0,34c in Carrefour in Brussels.

33cl can at home early morning of 7th Dec 2015 after a 5 hour shift behind a bar. Light golden body, bright and clean, white head. Soapy nose and taste, some grains in there too: not nice actually. Glad it was only a small can!
Helles gelb schwacher Schaum, Geruch leicht metallisch dumpf, Geschmack leicht getreidig metallisch wenig herb wässrig

From old notes. 330ml bottle. Clear dark amber color with off white head. Malty aroma, grainy, bready, light caramel, light smoked, some grassy notes. Sweet and light biter taste. Light to medium thin to oily body with soft carbonation.

Review for the past. From a store on Corfu. Poured a clear amber color, topped with a white head. Smoked malt in the aroma. Taste had some smokey feel and mild bitterness. It wasn’t that bad, as it seems from the notes.
From the archives: 2012 October. This was a surprise: smoked pale lager - you do not see that everyday. I hoped for more body, and more hopps. Still it was good an refreshing. Worth a try.
Enjoyable beer from Greece, very light watery body, slightly smokey slight bitterness and easy to drink. Ok beer.

[Thanks to fugitive]. Bottled. amber colour with a frothy white head with excellent lasting and nice lacework. Aroma is smoked meat and malty. Flavor is smoky, smoked ham, wooden notes. The final is malty with notes of bitterness.

500ml bottle served comfortably chilled in a tall Craft glass at Fat Snail Café in Rethymno. Clear amber coloured body with a slowly fading, off-white head. Dotted spots on the glassware. Plain and mild smoked malts to the nose. Smooth taste of caramel malts on a subdued backbone of bacon. Semi-sweet to the ending. Pretty straightforward, but quite nice (Rethymno, Crete 12.08.2012).
0.5 l bottle. Pours black with creamy brown head. A: capucino, T: mild carbonated, medium body, coffee, slightly bitter

Bottle at home, 09/09/18. Light black with a well presented lasting tan covering. Nose is light charr, toffee, hint of coffee, brown sugar, cocoa sprinkle. Taste comprises bitter chocolate, roast malts, toffee, light spice, liquorice, brown bread, dried fruits. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, drying close. Decent porter.

Bottle from the brewer's own stall at the Dartmouth Food Festival. Dark brown with a small beige head. Liquorice, chocolate, a little blackcurrant and some toasty malts. Dryish. An ok porter, but a little forgettable perhaps.

27th August 2011 Gravicask at the Angel mini beer festival, Kelvedon. Clear amber beer, residual white head. Light crisp palate. Nice combination of mild toffeeish malt with fruit salad and a splash of coca cola. Finishes semi dry, malty aftertaste.

Cask, handpump at The Turf Tavern, Oxford 02.09.10 Pours reddy brown with a light foamy head. This is malty in the mouth and with a nice fruity aroma, I get plum skin’s, tangy and tasty but no world beater. A6 A4 T7 P4 Ov13 3.4

Cask (gravity dispense) at Woodies Beer Festival, New Malden on 21 August 2010. Copper colour. Off-white head. Excellent condition. Fruity malt aroma. Subtle roast and caramel notes. Some tangy hops. Sweetish on the palate with some spicy notes. Herbal character. A little reminiscent of mauby, a Caribbean drink made with bark and spices. Bitter aftertaste. Unusual but not unpleasant.

Cask-conditioned at the Coronation, Bristol 24/08/10. Deep, clear chestnut in colour with a billowy white head. Nutty aroma with some bready malts and hint of sweetness. Flavour was malty with plenty of hedgerow plum fruit, sweetish cereals, a touch of marmalade and a decent, bitter finish. Unusual and enjoyable.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Amber with a small off white head. Rough, slightly metallic malt aroma, sweetness coming through with a hint of lemon. Taste is sweet, nutty and earthy with some burnt cardboard. Mid bitter finish. Excellent. Cricket themed beers have been thin on the ground this year.

Cask. Somewhere in Helsinki. No sign of where, but had it late 2006. Amber meets nutbrown colour with small head that vanishes quite quick. Aroma is wood, some toffee and mild dark berryish notes. Flavour is hops, wood and some slight citrusfruits.

Cask @ The Rake. Copper coloured with a thin white head. Has a hoppy floral aroma and as mentioned below there is a lemon washing up liquid hint. Floral hops and a touch of malt in the taste with a sort of citrus zing to it. I found it quite refreshing.

(Cask at Priory Arms, Stockwell, London, 7 Aug 2007) Chestnut brown colour with brief head. Malty nose with dark fruit, raisins and prunes. Malty taste with notes of dark fruit, toffee and earthy hops in the finish. Was there a hint of butterscotch as well? A bit too much malt sweetness for me. As some have stated before me, a bit odd, but drinkable.

Cask gravity at Ashford Rugby Club BF 2007. Chestnut colour with lasting beige head. Odd washing up liquid lemon up front. Some good cakey fruity malt. Lemon is there, but settle down to lemon curd. Odd but strangely enjoyable.
Brown colour,with a sour hop nose,malty slightly odd with a hint of bitter showing through .

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Absolutely horrible. Tasts like someone squirted lemon juice into my coffee and then let it get cold. I love coffee & I love beer, but this is a bad science experiment!

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: One of the better brown ales I have tried. The coffee flavor come through, but is not overwhelming. The finish is very smooth.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: They were not lying about the caffine in this beer........it could just be me, but this made me kind of twitchy. All in all a great brown ale

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: (On draft at Aladdin’s in Pittsford, NY) Canal Town Brown is a sparkling mahogany with a fizzy off-white head. It is rather transparent looking and leaves good lacing. The aroma is of sweet malt, medium roast coffee and buttery toffee. It is medium bodied, slightly chalky, not watery, and softly carbonated. The coffee flavor is very subtle. Malt with saltines and butter-- the flavor is a bit disjointed and there’s not really any bitterness to speak of. Maybe some day I’ll "get" brown ales-- as for now, all they ever do is make me want a porter! That said, this wasn’t that bad.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Sampled at the brewery. This is an outstanding brown ale. CB has added just the right amount of hops to let the coffee flavor through. If you like coffee, try this ale. As the outside temps plummet, I will actively seek out a growler of this. Nice job! 12/04/06: Re-Rate--Cask at Monty’s Krown. Unfiltered, unpasteurized and hand-pulled. A further polishing of the coffee aroma and balancing of the chocolate malt. Tan head. Flavor enhances as the ale warms. The lacing is heavy and shows each and every swallow. The best brown ale I have had...period. A must try.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: (draft @ Monty’s Korner - Rochester, NY) Dark brown in color with a very thin brown head. Aroma is very sweet and malty with some hints of coffee and caramel malts. Taste begins rather sweet with a nice smooth coffee middle and a very smooth and sweet finish with a touch of coffee. A bit watery but really nice.

[tap @ Bukowski’s] Pours a dark, hazy brown color with a tan, frothy head. Aroma is sweet, toasty caramel malts. Flavors are dense, sweet malts, sort of chewy and very nutty. Finishes with a spicy bitterness that balances the initially dense, malt-bomb of flavors. Delicious!

Clear, red-copper body with a filmy off-white head. Very toasty nose with Munich malt notes of dark bread crusts and sweet roasted nuts. More toasty Munich malt in the flavor, plus light plum characters and moderate Noble hop qualities. Medium bitter finish. A nice, stylish American alt.
Draft. Brownish pour. No head but lingering lace from top of glass. Hoppy with notes of chocolate initially and at the finish.

Strusselspalt dry-hopped cask, tapped 2 hours before serving, from a tulip, at the brewpub on 8/22/06. Dense, creamy off-white head never falls below cover, and is initially quite large. Strong lacing is left. The body is not quite bright, but almost there, showing just a touch of haze. Very layered color scheme; some nut brown tones, bits of brass, straw and burnt mahogany, with an extremely faint chestnut highlight. Very hoppy nose, but highly aromatic and not bitter/sharp at all, with that robust, tangy German-hop twang, producing various notes of dry grass, hickory nuts, lightly tart cherries and strong leafiness. It’s got a very high strength, which even carries it through the multitude of high-speed ceiling fans that sit above the bar, wisking away aromas. Creamy, smooth malt behind the hops seems to be very balanced in dryness, with just a hint of chocolate dabbed atop light sourdough, with reserved fruitiness adding further complexity. Yeast is rather clean, not distinctly German, if it is indeed so (not sure). Frothy, engaging carbonation brings on a comforting malt body, with perfect attenuation and fruity/grassy, highly flavorful hops. Great integration of flavors. The hops match the malt well, the malt being neither too dry/pale and grainy, nor too dark/sweet and creamy and the hops providing a good mix of lighter, more piquant fruity notes and softer, earthy/leafy notes. Goes down ridiculously quickly, with a light, lingering nuttiness. Let’s see more of this, Will!
Draft: Poured a hazy yellow with white head. Huge banana aroma. Taste was very banana with light

Cloudy golden pour with moderate white foam with medium duration. Strong grassy wheat aroma. Light body and texture with slight fizz. The taste was also grassy with a little malt. Sour wheat finish. Surprising taste for a wheat beer.
From tap. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is mild butterish and grainy. Butterish, estery and toasted malty. Toasted finish.
Draft. Pours yellow white head. Nose/taste of banana, light clove, light lactose, Land O’ Lakes butter spread. Light bodied.
Draft - Very buttery. Clear gold with a decent white head. Buttery sweet mess. A train wreck of not good, but I do like butter so not un drinkable.

Tap at the brewery. Pours brilliantly clear yellow with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is buttery wheat malt and earthy hops. Flavor is buttered wheat malt, light hops and bitterness with a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.
Tap at the brewery. Hazy yellow pour with a carbonated head. Very thin body. Mild orange on the nose and taste. Not great.

Draft at the brewery. Pours a cloudy pale straw color with a tiny white head. Scent of wheat and light citrus. Tart citrus and wheat taste. After a few beers here Jason and I began to agree with beerlando’s assessment. Every beer so far has had a thin water feel.
Draft @ the brewery. Pours cloudy pale straw color with white head. Aromas of wheat and light citrus. Tart citrus and wheat flavors. Thin and watery.

hazy straw, thick dense white head, med-body, high co2. aroma: funky chicken coop, fruity. taste: T1= bright, yeasty, wheat, coop, co2. T2= very chicken coop, touch of herbal hops, heather? T3= dry, wheat tartness, coop funk residue. backgroud wheat flavor is good, but the coop flavor does the funky chicken dance all over the aroma and flavor.
Ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnieñ z degustacji w ramach uzupe³nienia profilu.
Aromat s?odowy, neutralny. W smaku zaskakuj?ce, do?? rze?kie, s?odowe. Zaznaczona goryczka. Niespodzianka, pijalne!

500 ml can bought at CR Vanguard on Nathan Road, Yau Ma Tei Clear golden bronze colour; One quarter finger head with residual soapy white foam which fades in 30 seconds; Good sticky lacing with fizzy carbonation; Sweet aroma of malt, with canned pineapple, caramel, floral, dull metallic, sugar, bread, lemon and light grass; Mid to light sweet taste of malt, with floral, very light caramel, light fruity ester, sugar, light biscuits, light yeast, lemon, medium bitter hops and strawy grass; Mid to light body. Slightly slick palate; Mouth feel is fair maltyness in pretty thin body. Some surprising light caramel with light tropical fruit ester, fair flower, omnipresent light sweetness. Biscuity and fairly yeasty. Lemon to round. Pretty good!... Hoppiness is floral, lemon and light grass in nose and taste. Bitterness is very notable for a lasting, mid-astringent sweet-bitter finish; Fairly dry after taste. Sweet and fairly bitter to mouth. Comments: The pineapple ester make this one an attraction as well as distraction. It’s nice to sniff and to sip, which hides some of its dullness and works well with the caramel, biscuit dryness and rather notable lemony hops. As a Euro Strong Pale, this is very drinkable and a surprisingly nice cheapo!
500ml can. Clear dark amber color. No head, flat. Cherry, berries, sweet notes in aroma. Sweet, berries, metallic taste. Caramel in aftertaste. Alcohol is not in a front row, but detectable in room.

500ml bottle (Biedronka, Poland) Sweet berry aroma, but as I try to work out what berry, I detect coconut. Bold gold, very brief head. Heady alcoholic palate, but lots of sweet malts, and a harsh metallic hoppiness, copper coins. Remarkably light in feel, not oppressive. Temptation to throw this away down the sink ... very low. Scary, I wonder what Ares would say about us drinking all of this...
Eltaisen maltaisen liejuinen tuoksu. Ei juuri hapotusta tai vaahtoa. Kohtalaisen mauton, maltainen suutuntuma. Liejuinen jälkimaku? Jännän makuinen mutta ei hyvällä tavalla.
Feel a bit of stiffness, but otherwise a very good beer, hops and caramel are nicely balanced
Herbal hop nose. Herbal character and a bit toasty. Slightly soft body. Test of 17.08.2010.
can, thanks to Michau! Clear, golden colour, large white head. Malty nose. Full-bodied, bitter-sweet. Sticky malt flavours, bitter hops in the finish, quite sharp.

Can 500ml. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, sweet malt, fruity. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average to long duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20101211]

Radler sind schon eine spezielle Sache. Sie fallen nunmal mit ihrer Limonade und diese hier ist nicht gerade herausragend. Das Bier dahinter auch kaum zu vernehmen. Wieder mal eine dünne und künstliche Sache.
Bottle from Getränke Kistner in Forchheim. The beer pours out in a light yellow-golden colour with low head and thin body. Aroma of lemonade. Taste of lemonade, mild beer and sugar. Sweet finish..
Pale yellow, not so well balance between lemon and beer, too little alcohol content, sweet finish

It’s light-golden with a small, white head. The aroma has notes of lemon, malt and a little butter. The flavour is moderately sweet with notes of slightly harsh citrus, malt and a little butter, and the finish is a bit sourish.
Bottled at PBF. Clear very pale yellow no head. Sprite aroma. Artificially sweet. Sticky and primitive. I’m not sure I could discern this stuff from German sprite while blindfolded...
Bottled. Pale yellow colour, small white head. Aroma is lemon and cardboard. Flavour is very much the same. Rather dull.
Bottled (PBF, BB 10/2009). Very pale yellow color, not much head. Lemon-Sprite sweet nose. Lemon soda pop flavor, some citrusy notes (not very strong). Another totally useless "beer".

Bottled. A light golden beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is dominated by lemon, while the flavor has strong notes of lemon and only light notes of malt, leading to a dry cardboardy and bitter finish.
Clear golden with tiny white head. Sweet aroma dominated by lemon. Sweet flavor with loads of lemon and caramel notes. Ends sweet.

Bottle 50cl Clear light yellow color with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, citrus softdrink. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. (130608)
bottle @ supermarket (ingolstadt) yellow colour, normal body, average carbonated, white head, yeast, banana, bubblegum, easy to drink

Das Altmühltaler Weißbier sprudelt schön im Glas und hat eine hellgelb-trübe Farbe. Der Antrunk ist spritzig, fruchtig und auch würzig. Im Abgang findet ein Wechsel vom leicht süsslichem Mittelteil in eine dezente Säuerlichkeit statt. Das Bier ist im Ganzen angenehm mild, recht erfrischend und süffig.
Beer with gold color, light bitterness, fuzzy aspect, average carbonized, good volume of foam on top, (bought a 50cl bottle beer at "Kaufland", Ingolstadt, DE #812)(#105 DE)(#41 Bavaria).

0.5l bottle. Hazy pale golden body with a thick white head. Aroma of sourdough, cloves, earthy hops, sulfur and some banana. Taste of bread, dough, spicy hops, cloves and some banana. It’s more spicy than fruity. I prefer weizens with way more banana character than this.

Hazy amber/yellow with medium white head. Aroma is ripe banana and apples and other fruity stuff. Also yeasts. Taste is much of yeasty sourness with a little hoppy bitterness and a little malty sweetness. But the sourness kills it all. Finish is more of the sourness leaving a malty banana touch on the tongue. Medium body. Ok. Could have way less sourness for me.
* Old rating, many thanks to kevnic2008 for this beer. Best before 03.11.10. Mild-weiches, leicht bananiges Weizen. Nett.
Trübes goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig. Geschmack hefig, fruchtig nach Banane, leicht würzig.
Postupnì sem budu doplòopvat piva, co jsem vypil a zapsal si, chvilku to asi bude trvat a proto k tìm døíve vypitým pivùm nebudou žádné "dojmy" .
Pours cloudy colour with small white head. Good banana and clove notes on the tongue.
Bottle @ Southern Germany. Pours cloudy golden with a small egg white head. Sweet orange and wheat with a bit of yeast. Medium and smooth. Soft..

Cask, Jersey Fest 06. Golden with a big white foam. Aromas are light malts with lemon, pepper and plently of hops. Flavours are grassy, fresh hops with light caramel malts. Citrus notes with butter. Peppery and dry on the finish. A typical golden ale.

Cask, Eden Arms, Doncaster. Straw colour, thin white head. Grassy notes, lots of hops. Taste is much of the same really, lots of hops, maybe some citrus, bitter finish, quite dry on the palate. Not bad.
On tap at the brewpub. Active carbonation, appealing to the matcha tea trend. White head on yellow. Medium mouthfeel.

(Draught) Sampled at the brewpub on September 19, 2006. Dissipated, white foam head with lightly carbonated miniture bubbles. Golden body. Nose of creamed corn and club soda. Flavour is very smooth, creamy and even with a corn base. Lingering milky finish. I somehow prefer the batch at GCBF a couple of weekends ago.

Hazy blonde colour. Woody, almost creamy-marshmallowy malts, with a distinctive green tea note. It’s quite malty, sweet, with a grassy tea note in the finish. An odd duck, that’s for sure. I don’t think the concept works all that well here, as I can’t see what changes I’d make to improve the character of the beer but yet I can’t say I like it a whole lot either.

I found this to be the most fascinating of the beers at hugos and probably on my trip to victoria. you wouldnt think these flavors would blend but i feel they do rather well. cool slight green yellow (isnt that suppose to make a blue?) clear beer. small nose of herbal freshness. mostly effectied was the taste. the pilsner pops at the end with a nice green tea bitterness, kinda in the way hops so...somewhat czechish. good. again i had a good buzz.

A light amber orange coloured beer with a weak white head. The nose is hoppy, with a light fruity element, and a malty background. The taste is dry, hoppy, again, some fruit accompanied by a smooth biscuity malt in the finish. (Cask - The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk.
Cask at Peterborough BF ’06. Amber with a small white head. Floral hoppy aroma. Slight sourness and a good bitter finish.
Cask at Peterborough BF ’06. This is described as a festival special. Amber with a small white head. Faint sweet citrus aroma. Sweet strawberry fruit taste. Low bitterness. Fair.
Cask at Peterborough BF ’06. Golden amber with a few bubbles. Sweet floral, buttery aroma. Gentle citric hop taste with sweet malts. Low bitterness. Good.

Notes from ABC fest 06. Pours a murky turbid brown with some slight amber highlights and fizzy white head which leaves a bit of lace. Fresh picked raspberries, raspberry jam- fruity esters, and light chocolate nutty hints in the aroma with more chocolate in the flavor to balance the slight tartness of the berries in the end. Overall- this one is loaded up with berry flavor- thcik sweet and toasted malts and a dry chocolate nutty finish with light bitterness.

Sample at the brewpub. This beer pours a deep mahogany color with a medium off-white head with good lasting power. Thin stringy lacing. Aroma of raspberries and malt. Medium bodied and fully tart with raspberry being the dominant flavor. Some roasted malt and sweet spices make it interesting. The finish is fruity and lasting. This turned out very good.

Wow! One of the best offerings from this brewer in a long time. Sampled on draft at the brewery this beer poured a dark brown color with a hint of a reddish hue and a small white head that fades quickly. The aroma is sweet berry and is tangy and spritzy. Very pleasant. The flavor is strong sweet raspberry that fades into a sweet Belgian-esque middle with a hint of roasty malts and a very long tart and tangy finish. Marvelous!

Draught at Pizza Port, Carlsbad California. Clear deep amber/brown beer with a nice beige head. Roasted chocolate aroma, caramel, biscuits, nuts, some dark bread. Roasted chocolate and cocoa flavor, dark bread, fruity notes, some grass and peach. Quite ok.

January 6th, 2012 - The great American Brown is a great brown, offering up a smell straight up front combing coffee and grass notes with gentle wafts of pipe tobacco fresh from the tin. The aroma matches the wardrobe, which glimmers in the daylight, a dark chocolate lab brown, glossy and also murky. The most notable aspect of the flavor is a long, rolling aftertaste of roasted coffee, served on a mild and soft palate. The rest of the flavor is mostly built of roasted cashew, roasted chicken and a mild and mellow chocolate note.

28/12/2012 Brasserie 4:20 (tap). Bevuta al Pizza Port Tap Takeover. Bruna, riflessi mogano-rubino, limpida, schiuma bianca abbondante e abbastanza persistente. Al naso caramello e luppolo si sposano alla perfezione. In bocca mostra un equilibrio mostruoso, note di tostato, pane, caramello e luppolo, un mix praticamente perfetto. Corpo medio, carbonazione corretta, grande beva. Brown ale magistrale, freschissima, elegantissima e super bilanciata, chapeau!
dark brown very malty with excellent chocolate malt character and caramel, but not sweet. Full bodied. Very nice

Draft @ Pizza Port Carlsbad, Carlsbad, CA. Pours a dark amber brown color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty caramel aroma with hints of chocolate and hints of hops. Roasted malty caramel hoppy flavor with hints of chocolate. Has a roasted malty chocolate and caramel finish.

On tap at Pizza Port Carlsbad. Deep, and dark brown pour. Huge creamy beige head and thick lacing pattern. Aromas of chocolate, crystal malt, smoked dark wood. Taste is chocolate with cooked cherries on top. Other small notes of raisin, dark fruit, earthy hoppiness in the back end accompanied by slight vanilla. Tad bit bitter on the mouth.

Tap at Pizza Port Carlsbad. Webby beige lace on a deep amber to marron. Floral, fresh nose with herbal hops. Taste is ligher, herbal, juicy, quenching, mild roast, moderate bitterness. Lemon tartness in the back end. Enjoyed this a bit more than the Good Grief Brown. Clean body. But when you’re at Pizza Port, just stick to the IPAs and heavy stouts.
Very dark pour. Standard nut brown aroma, but not sure if it is actually a nut brown. Very smooth to drink. Despite its heavy color this isn’t a heavy beer. All around great

On tap at Toronado San Diego: Served with a thin layer of film for a head while the liquid was a dark almost black color of brown. As for the nose, a nutty and roasted aroma that intrigues the senses as well as my appetite. The flavor is also nutty with semi roasted malts that has a nutty/meaty flavor of cashew or perhaps pistachio. This one of the best and richest brown ales I have tasted.

On draft (guest) Making a return visit to Lizardville for the tapping of two Pizza Port kegs I opted first for this brown ale. I’m not sure how they made it to Ohio but both were excellent, fresh, and a nice easter egg for those who were looking for a change of pace. I would not complain too much if Port Brewing / Lost Abbey were to break into the Ohio market. Aroma and appearance - The opaque ruby brown body matched the mood of the dimly lit bar. Dense short lived plumes of foam rested on top like packing peanuts in a shipping container. Heavy roasted malts, oak, and a mellow mood felt like a hipster coffee drink from the local grocery store. Flavor and palate - Carbonated and lively this had quite a punch. Warm and woody the feel was soft on the tongue. An ashy finish bit back though - this was not timid and mild. Like licking a dusty floor it eventually leaves a mark on the palate. The hops betray that Pizza Port (ie West Coast) touch. This is a sessionable beer with a regional twist that makes it worth getting your hands on when you don’t want a heady high ABV monster.

Draught @ Hof-Apotheke, Marktplatz 5, 31675 Bückeburg, Röcke, Niedersachsen, Germany. Clear medium to dark yellow color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, light hay, sour notes, light hoppy, citrus, dishwasher water. Flavor is moderate sweet light citrus acidic and citrus bitter with a average to long duration. Body is light medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090904]

Draught at the brewpub. It is clear, golden, pearly with a huge, creamy head. The aroma has notes of malt, light flower, grain and hints of cabbage. The flavour has a light sweetness and while very cold it has a touch of rusty iron, but that disappears as it gets a bit warmer. The other notes are malt, straw and light flower.

Draught at the brewpub. Good bready and grainy aroma. Clear golden colour, shiny. Nice stable white head. The flavour has some of the same breadiness, almost like rye. Also good dusty notes. Low bitterness, but still refreshing.
Pours a clear pale golden with a big white head. Aroma is malty, hoppy and a bit grainy. Taste is sweet malty and some hoppy bitterness

A hazy amber beer with a thin orange head. The aroma is sweet with notes of butter. The flavor is sweet malty with light notes of butter and caramel, leading to a slightly metallic end. It seem a bit over its prime - inspite of being served at the brewpub.

(On tap) Slightly hazy amber golden with a small, off-white head. Discreet aroma of fruit and perhaps a touch of butter. Light and somewhat watery, a bit of caramel and an edge of roasted malt with fruity touches and again some butter. Basically no bitterness. 051106
Draught. Pours a hazy dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma is sweet malty, slightly roasted. Taste is sweet and slightly roasted. Soft creamy mouthfeel
Draught at the brewpub. Very cloudy yellow colour. Big stable off-white head. The flavour is mildly citric, slightly orangy. Good mouthfeel. Not bad, but does get boring after a while.

A hazy yellow beer with a thick light orange head. The aroma is sweet with light notes of yeast, straw, and malt. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of citrus, as well as straw, and lighter notes of yeast, leading to a dry slightly bitter end, where a slight acidity lingers for a while.

(On tap) Hazy, pilsener golden with a dense, white head. Very fresh and fruity - citrus in particular. Light-bodied but not exactly watery. Fresh but also rather acidic fruitiness. Very subdued bitterness. Typical German brew pub beer - in the good end of the scale. 051106
Pours a hazy golden with a big white head. Aroma is grainy, sweet malty and somewhat hoppy. Taste is malty, grainy, slightly yougurth sour and some hoppy bitterness.
Draught. Served hot. Pours a clear dark red, with a violet head. Aroma is of sweet cherries and almods. Taste is cherries and very sweet.

Draught @ Hof-Apotheke, Marktplatz 5, 31675 Bückeburg, Röcke, Niedersachsen, Germany. Light unclear light medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting - diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate yeasty, fruity, banana, rubber notes. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery - creamy, carbonation is soft. [20090904]

Draught at the brewpub. It is unclear golden with a huge, creamy head. The aroma has notes of clove, yeast, banana and wheat. The flavour has sweetness and notes of banana, clove, wheat and the finish is slightly spicy. It is a really nice weizen with a good balance and harmony.

Draught at the brewpub. Weak spicy aroma, perhaps a little plastic. Cloudy orange colour. Not as cloudy as their Helles. Big stable white head. The flavour is spicy, slightly phenolic, but still OK. Good mouthfeel.

An unclear light orange beer with a huge off-white head. The aroma is sweet malty with strong notes of wheat as well as light notes of bananas. The flavor is very wheaty and sweet again with light notes of banana, leading to a dry citrusy and wheaty end. A very refreshing Hefeweizen.

(On tap) Hazy pale golden with a rather tall and handsome, white head. Distinct yeast and citrus in the aroma. Medium body, lightly sweet with very fresh notes of banana and clove. Lightly phenollic, no bitterness. But very fresh overall. 051106
Draught. Pours a cloudy golden with a white head. Aroma is buttery wheat. Taste is wheat, banana and a yougurth like sourness

column1: Davidson Brothers Summer Wheat and Rye Ale
column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear gold with a thin white head. Toast, very small rye notes, citrus and spice. Medium bodied, light grain. Toast, crisp grain. Crisp light sweetness, cereal grains. Bitter finish. Nice and easy drinking.

column1: Davidson Brothers Summer Wheat and Rye Ale
column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draft. I think this is thr ryely summer. Light tan color. No head or lacing. Taste is carmel, crisp and slightly boozy. Not really sure what the abv is on this but easy drinking

column1: Davidson Brothers Summer Wheat and Rye Ale
column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: on tap-pours a light tan head with amber color. Aroma is malt, sweet. Taste is malt, sweet, rye bread&rye whiskey. Mild carbonation.
Pours a pale straw yellow with a thin white head. Aroma is bland wheat, and the flavor is similar, but a little less bland. Softly carbonated with a light body. Not very memorable.

On tap at the Vierling, Marquette. Light, hazy yellow body, thin, tight off-white head. Nose of hay, citrus, and coriander. Sweet. Clean body with citrus and coriander notes finishing with a long, grassy, bitter hops flourish. Another competent beer, but Vierling’s palette could better please the palate with more challenging or non-standard brews.

Thin yellow, lightly clouded pour, with a rim of white. Flavor a thoroughly savory spiced sugary water, with a tinge of orange. Noticeable coranider, leaning towards Grains of Paradise. Drinkable, but edging on watery. Floral herb notes dominate the finish.

5 oz draft sample at the brewpub, late July 2006. Watery yellow-gold with a small ring of head....very faint spicy nose offers bare wafts of orange, ginger and other cooking spices but you have to work to get it.....much better in the body, well-balanced sweet citric fruity/acidic qualities and sour wheat malt, with enough aromatic coriander and ginger to give it bite....at the end its a bit of an alcoholic 7UP with the strong citric character and heavy carbonation, and it could be fuller, but it was a decent summer refresher if nothing else.

On tap at the Horsebrass. Pours light golden with a small white head. Very floral hop aroma, citrus and spice. Light honey sweetness upfront with a fruity hop finish, light spicy hop crisp ending. Smooth throughout and clean finish.

Amber with lively carbonation, great lacing and a foamy head. Fruit and bitter hops in the nose. Some notes of citrus and grassiness. Wet grass, really. Toasted malts. Flavor really shows the Saaz hops. A little buttery, not much though. Sweet and toasted malts. Lots of bitter berry notes with a great deal of citrus. Very slick palate, almost oily. Sweet and a sticky or coating. Bitter and citrusy finish with a nice balance of malts.

Hazy golden colour. Saaz, heavy bread pale malts, light alcohol, big grassiness in the aroma. Moderate bitterness. Light bready pale malts and heavy Saaz hops in the palate. Again light alcohol in their to dry things out. The attenuation is quite good on this beer, and that I think is necessary in the style to keep it from being an unbalanced cloying mess. So nicely done there, this is really well-balanced. Not the sort of beer I normally like but this is good stuff.

Tap at the Uber Tavern in Seattle. Pours a neartly clear, slightly oily yellow with a moderate head and great lacing. We’ve got a strong and enjoyable Saaz aroma, but the beer really shines in the flavor; this is just a brilliant bitter hoppiness very different from all of the citrus and resin one gets with the west coast c-hops. Cracker malts provide a bit of a backbone, but this is really all of lovely, pure, grapefruit-pithy hops. Delicious. I’d love to try this one again.

Had on tap at Uber. They had this labled as an "Imperial Pils, only keg in WA!". But, this has to be an Imperial IPA....nothing pilsner like about this beer. The bartender mentioned that this beer was the result of a "class" that was taught....not sure on the details. This beer had an incredible skunky hop aroma and taste. This is one for the potheads, I mean hopheads. Amazing aroma and taste...a pure hop heaven brew. A nice bite, but not alcoholic at all. I love it. Pretty thin...
