Cask gravity at the Barnstaple Beer Festival, 19/08/2006. A dark brown colour with a small lasting head. Aromas of honey, chocolate, malt and a little citrus. Taste of bitter dark chocolate, honey, roasted malts and nuts. A little sweetness. A smooth, moderately bitter finish with cocoa and a little citrus. This is uncomplicated but absolutely delicious and easy to drink - my idea of the perfect bitter.
* Old rating, bought at the brewery. Best before 05.10. Schön süffiges, feinherbes Pils. Süßlich-malzig, angenehm mild, sehr lecker!

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and it’s not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog! Ins Glas ergießt sich ein stark goldgelbes Pils mit mittelfeinem, kurzlebigem Schaum. Der Geruch ist stark bitterhopfig. Der Antrunk erfolgt sehr herb und sehr rezent. Trinkt sich anfangs fast wie ein Jever oder Flensburger. Die Mitte wird dann etwas milder, die herbe Note nimmt etwas ab, und der Bitterhopfen schraubt sich etwas zurück, was dem Bier auch verdammt gut tut. Zum Finish hin kommt dann doch noch ein ordentliches Pils raus, das mit einer guten Würzigkeit glänzen kann, von der am Anfang allerdings nix zu merken war, da der Hopfen alles weggebollert hat, hehe.

Prickelnder, leicht säuerlicher Antrunk mit deutlichen Gerstennoten. In diesem Part erinnert das Bier kuam an ein Pils, auch später fehlen sämtliche herbe oder bittere Noten, die darauf hinweisen könnten. Süffig-säuerlich, vielleicht dann doch minimal herb im Abagng. Ein netes Bier – aber ein Pils? 8/9/10/9/7/9

The bottle looks simple, but good, as well as the beer in the glass. Quite zippy, nice head. Starts mild, soft, nicely hoppy, not too dry. Flowery-fresh. Finish more and more spicy, a but grasy. Well balanced and quite drinkable. Good pils!

bottle, traded with Erzengel - Danke! Slightly hazy pale golden yellow with a decent white head. Hoppy-fruity nose. Malty background, aromatic and dry bitter hops combined with a fruity touch. Interesting an fascinating. Very nice, a pity the brewery is about to close down.

Pale golden coloured, slightly hazy, big fluffy white head, quickly collapsing to an astonishingly stable thin foamy layer; pale-malty, grassy-hoppy nose with a touch of yeast; moderate to stong dry bitter flavour, soft MF, light body; sweet-malty, yeasty finish with a strong lingering dry bitter aftertaste. Unusual Pilsener, the opposite of a bland german mass-market Pilsener........

(bottle) Clear, pale yellow colour with a blonde not very persistent foamy head. Herbal and grassy hoppy aroma with touch of lemon. Bitter flavour with a light malty sweetness in the background. Raw herbal hoppy taste, getting slightly grassy towards the finish, which is quite dry and bitter with a tinge of metal. Rather slim and rough Pilsener, thus not very charming but still pretty drinkable.

Schöne gold-gelbe Farbe im Glas. Der Antrunk ist angenehm malzig-süffig, leicht süßlich, aber nicht zu aufdringlich. Der Hauppteil ist mild-malzig, irgendwie mit einem rauchigen Touch. Sehr interessant. Im Nachgeschmack ist das Bier vollmundig, ganz leicht herb und angenehm mild-malzig-würzig mit einer ganz leichten erfrischend-säuerlichen Note. --> Sehr leckeres Export! Test vom 17.11.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,12,12,11,12,12 - 11,85
Pretty nice malt profile. Bready, kinda sweet, with a hint of hops. Test of 08.05.2010.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and it’s not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog! Ins Glas ergießt sich ein minimal blassgelbes Bier mit seifiger mittelporiger Krone. Geruchlich dominiert ein würziges Hopfenaroma. Der Antrunk erfolgt süßmalzig, mit dezentem Aromahopfen im Hintergrund. Nach mehreren Schlücken wird’s auffallend bitterer, was aber nicht schadet. Im Gegenteil, es rundet das Ganze gelungen ab.

Süßlich herber Antrunk. Dazu angenehm getreidig, wobei die Süße bestehen bleibt, das Bier insgesamt aber milder wird. Dazu stößt ein geringer Malzton, zum Schluss auch bittere Nuancen. So wie sich das Bier im Mittelteil präsentiert ist es auch im Abgang: Süffig, herb, etwas süßlich. Nett! 10/9/10/11/9/10
The bottle looks simple, but good, the beer in the glass is okay. Starts strong, spicy, quite sourish, a bit metallically. Finish also a bit grasy, modest fruity. Interesting export, quite drinkable!
bottle. Clear golden colour, mid-sized head. Malty, slightly fruity with a herbal hoppy touch.

Bottle: Golden coloured, big fluffy head, lively carbonation; sweetish-grainy nose, a bit bready; sweet-bitter flavour, soft MF; sweetish-malty, slightly bitter finish. A pleasant, unspectacular Helles.........

(bottle) Clear, golden colour with a fluffy foamy white head. Moderately sweet malty, slightly citrusy aroma with shy traces of hops. Initially sweet malty taste with a subtle fruitiness and a dense herbal background; medium to light body, lively carbonation. Dry and moderately bitter and fizzy finish with light notes of herbal hops. Drinkable but not convincing.

500ml flip-top bottle bought at Great Food Hall in Pacific Place, Admiralty. Golden honey colour; One-quarter finger head and soapy white foam which fades in 40 seconds; Fair sticky lacing with notable sparing carbonation; Aroma of bready malt, with strong floral, strong honey, light mustiness, bread, yeast, light lemon and thin grass; Close to medium sweet taste of malt, with barley grains, floral, honey, light cookies, strong bread, light spices fair lemon, fairly light bitter hops and grass; Light body. Thin palate; Mouth feel is moderate maltyness in a light thin background. Strong barley grain with good honey, floral and cookie characters. Good breadyness, pleasant sweetness rounded with light lemon. Alright…Hoppiness is strong floral, light lemon and thin grass in nose. And more or less the same in taste plus spices. Bitterness is light for an abrupt, very low-astringent sweet malty finish; Slightly dry after taste. Bready and fairly easy to mouth. Comments: This is one of those Helles that hits just the right notes in honey and cookie maltyness, but stop short of being solid in body. Easy to drink, close to decent but can do much better. Okay.
Leichter, süßlich herber Antrunk. Die Herbe steigt und bildet einen passenden Ausgleich zur Süße. Hell würzig, rund. 9/9/9/9/8/9

50cl fliptop bb04/2015, Maruhn. Smells of damp earth, downtrodden grains and fresh eggy proteins. Quite fresh, gently floral hop and fruity malt touch underneath a base layer of upfront biscuit-bready cereals. No sulphuric or coarse notes as often appear in this style, makes for another underwhelming well-made, smaller-batch export.
*Old rating, best before 24.04.07. Nettes süffig-süßes Export. Mild-weich, leichte Herbe, nett.

Part of sampler tray at Faust Braustuble, Miltenberg am Main, Bavaria. Pale greenish gold with white head. This is a slightly sweeter beer but also with quite a herby, grassy character. There is a distinct lemon note, some hop. It’s ok.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit durchschnittlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig, leicht herb. Geschmack malzig würzig, getreidig, minimale Bitterkeit.
0,5 l swing top bottle BB 30.06.14 golden, minimal head, white foam, bread, cereal, herbs, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, oily feel, slick feel, lively,
Bottled, from biershop-bayern.de . Hazy pale golden, mid sized head. Mild fruity lactic nose. Light-medium bodied with soft mouthfeel. Grassy and fruity. Laidback and drinkable. Mid bitter finish.

Purchased this at a Classic Deli, Cowley Road, Oxford consumed at home Sunday 19th August 2012 Pours gold with large white head, little sweet in mouth, slight minerally edge. Fine and happy to drink this beer but in truth it doesn’t do an awful lot for me. A6 A4 T6 P3 Ov12 3.1
Pours golden with a thick, off-white head. Aroma of pale malts with a little bit of nuts, plus light hops. Flavor the same.

Draft to taster at Shoreline. Looks solid; a completely transparent gold with white head. Smells like most blueberry beers; not much besides the fruit. Tastes like it smells with an average mouthfeel. Eh.
This is my favorite ’girly’ beer. Perfect balance of fruit and hop flavors.

Draft at brewery. The pour is very light yellow. The aroma has a faint hint of blueberry. The taste is light with the lightest hint of blueberry. Not a fruit beer by many standards. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sampled at the brewery. Clear golden with minimal off white ring. A little blueberry in the aroma with grain. Blueberry is prominent in the flavor but is not at all over powering. Soft hops that are not ideal with the blueberry. Something like orange zest bitterness.

This draft brew from a beer festival poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a . The mild aroma was blueberry. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of blueberry and hops. An OK brew just nothing special.
On tap at brewery - pale yellow with white head. Aromas of blueberries, as expected. Not a bad beer, but it was a little too something I can’t put my finger on.
A very good blueberry ale. Sightly tart, good blueberry notes, the base beer is alright.
Best blueberry beer that I’ve ever had - even better than Goose Island’s Cubbie Blue which is fantastic as well - not too fruity like Berryweise

On tap at brewpub. Blueberry aroma. Yellow w/ small white head. All I could taste was black pepper... didn’t get blueberry out of it at all. Light bodied. Not impressed, but I don’t like pepper in beer. (initial rating was 2.6) Re-rated on 9-7-13. Completely different experience than the first time. Wheaty malt and light blueberry aroma. Flavor was a really nice creamy what malt and fresh blueberry flavor.
Tap at brewpub. Blueberry malt aroma. Golden yellow color with small head. Slightly sweet blueberry malt flavor with a hint of hops. Light black pepper finish. A very nice fruit beer.

Pours a clear straw yellow on tap with fluffy white head that dissipates quickly to leave moderate lace. Aroma of light hay like grains and a touch of earthy grass hops underneath. Taste follows, light and crisp, super crushable. I'm confused by the description here as it says ale, but it definitely had the lager body.
Could definitely see the Czech hops, feels like a pilsener. Nice easy flavor. Smooth and tasty.

95 degrees outside? Check. Guacamole and chips in hand? Check. Sitting on the patio at Antlers on the Creek overlooking Lightner Creek? Check. Is this a great beer to accompany all the above? Check. Grainy, tinge of honey; golden color; pale, biscuit maltiness, nice grassy hops in the finish; ligth, but not watery; drinks like a light Pils.
Very typical pale lager. A slight grassy hop flavor from the Saaz hops, but nothing else going on. Really weak stuff. Lightly sweet watery finish.
On tap at the Carver Brew Pub in Durango. Poured a lighter and clear yellow color. Typical pale lager...aromas and tastes of grains and generic sweetness. Thin body.
tap. straw color with clarity. carbonated to thin head. almost no aroma. grain, wheat, sour lemon. off.
on tap-pours a white head with gold color with effervescence. Aroma is faint sweet grain. Taste sweet grain, faint hops. OK carbonation.

On tap plus growler purchase. Yellow color with a creamy white head. Smell is pretty standard with cloves, citrus, and banana. Taste is very smooth and easy to drink. More malty than most hefes are. This was a pretty good beer.
weiss on tap 7/14/11 dillsboro bbq... Clear yellowy gold. Thin white ring. A is lemon, grass, wood, yeast and grain.. F=A..very mediocre. Lite tartness on finish is out of place . 5/3/5/3/2.9

Appearance: A yellow-hued body, good clarity, underneath a bubbly, white head. Smell: Aroma of wheat malt, fresh grains, and bitty notes of citrus and spice. Taste: A taste of malted wheat with a backing of raw grain. Modestly sweet. A light touch of lemon, some slight herbal tones, and a low spiciness. Lightly bitter. Also a hint of grain astringency. Drying finish. Mouthfeel: Light-bodied. Medium-plus carbonation. Overall: A decent, mediocre hefe.

Draft @ the brewery. Pours a slightly hazy yellow color with a white head. Has a fruity wheaty citrus aroma with yeasty hints. Fruity wheat malty slightly tart citrus flavor. Has a sweetish fruity wheat malty citrus finish.

Tap. Golden amber color, thin white head. Bready flavor. Sharp with a hearty earthy bitterness. A touch of nutty flavors and a hint of metal. Aroma is of fresh baked bread and the slightest aroma of those freshly toasted nuts at the fair/flea market. Very familiar. Paired very well with the spicy BBQ sauce at the Dillsboro Smokehouse.
Golden yellow whitish cover. Aroma is wheaty, lemon, light spice. Taste is tart, soured wheat, lemony.
Samped on draft at the brewery. Pours a hazy pale yellow with a medium head. Decent retention and lacing. Aroma of yeast, bread and citrus. Taste is very similar. Tart and dry. Medium bodied.
Not one of my favorites of Dieters. Looks pretty good, but me not being a big fan of wheat beer I didnt really like it to much. Still not bad though.
Growler, poured from the brewer himself. Pours a clear golden light amber. Light thin head. Aroma of wheat. Decent wheat beer. I like this it is very well balance, crisp and drinkable. Thaks Dieter.

Sampled at Brewgrass in Asheville. It was so hot at the festival I drank this like gatorade. Poured a light copper color with a large foamy head. Hints of sweet wheat, candied sugar, spice. Finished thin and sweet on the palate. Carbonation was perfect for the heat.

Draft at Logan Airport The bock poured a dark deep amber to red. The white frothy head had nice lacing. This is great looking beer. There is a malty taste and aroma. The beer had a medium body with average carbonation. The finish was dry and not bitter. Great for short layovers between flights.

From tap at Fenway. Pours hazy dark brown with a fully gone head. Aroma is caramelish and roasted malt. Slight breadish and medium sweet. Lingering dry roasted malty. Smooth caramelish and light bitterness into the finish.
Had this after a Jon Lester no-hitter. Refreshing bock, not extremely dark. Could have been a bit smoother, not much of a head. One of the best beers i’ve had at Beer Works.

Bottle, review from old notes. Pours clear, some head, lacing and bead. Copper in colour, not very red. Roast malts on the nose and in the mouth. Mild bitterness. Overall, not the worst Irish ale, but pretty boring.
Notizen: -wässrig -mild -leicht herber Mittelteil -Abgang hopfig -leiht bitter Test vom 27.4.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,9,8,8,5,8 - 8,00
Aroma was weak some sweet wet malt. Gold body with dirty dish soap head. Wet malt mash with some wet wheat grain flavor. New country rating for me nothin special from this bottle.
Bottle. Golden color with light copper tones. Sweet aroma. Sweet malty flavor. Not so interesting.
Bottle. Clear, golden colour with a weak head. Aroma of malt and wet paper. Flavour of malt and grain, and hints of vegetables.
Bottled. A light yellow beer with a lazing thin white head. The aroma is sweet with notes of metal and straw, and so is the flavor.

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of KnutAlbert. 4.6 ABV. Clear golden with a creamy, white head. Discreet, lightly sweet malt aroma. Medium body. lightly sweet malt and a dry, lightly hoppy finish. But Irish Ale? I wondered if I translated the Cyrillic letters wrong and this actually was the Spetsialno? 110108

500 ml bottle with pull-off cap, thanks to KnutAlbert. ABV is 5.1%. Deep copper coloured beer, decent off-white head. Moderate aroma of malts, some fruit and caramel. The flavour also has some malts and fruit, but is fairly bland and lacks hops. The mouthfeel is more watery than you expect from a beer this dark. Nothing offensive about it, just boring.
Bottle. Clear yellow coloured with a white head. Aroma of malts, fruits and hops. Flavour of malts, grain, cardboard, fruits and hops.

Bottle. [Great two day tasting session @ Papsoe] Small thick white head that lasted. Clear flat looking body with a yellow color. Aroma of grain, caramel, vegetable and light metallic notes. Over the palate light grass. Medium bodied with a soft carbonation and light dry texture. Light bitter and sweet flavor. Light dry and bitter finish.

Keg at the brewpub. Clear copper, large creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of grapefruit and caramel. Taste is grapefruit, pine, citrus, pale malt. Medium bodied. Decent but a bit off balance. Clearly not named after JK. ;)

<!-- i -->65% Weizenbier and 35% soda<!-- /i --> - strange clear green-amber colour, almost no head; lemonish nose with some spicy touches; very sweet, moderate malt body, very dry but sweetish finish with more citrusy notes - no beer character

Draught at the brewpub Hazy blond color. Simple aroma, the flavor is more crispy; the bitterness is high, but without specific hop character; the final (long) is very dry. Very simple. This is another brewery that should not exist; they bought a brewery that can brew 1000 litres at a time, 4x1000L fermenters, 6x2000L maturation tanks… just to find out that the people in the region are not ready for anything else than a blond lager. The young brewer is a nice guy, he comes from Dresden, but he said that his previous experience was "brewing with a computer" :o

<!-- i -->draught<!-- /i --> - hazy golden-blond colour with a modest foam; aroma is mainly malty with notes of peanuts; a good body and a decent bitterness; the finish is quite long and malty with more notes of peanuts and almonds - relatively easy but very good and efficient

bread, hay, cereal, grass, spruce, dough, barnyard, cheese, woody, golden, cloudy, sparkling, frothy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, umami, medium body, slick feel, creamy, lively, bitter, abrupt finish,

0.33l bottle from coop in swiss sommer beer taster 6pack. pours a hazy pale golden with a medium white head and little lacing. mild aroma of hay, coriander, spices, kinda witbierish. aroma of grass, bread and coriander. mild, dry, refreshing, slightly astringent. i say this is a witbier.
Draught. Pours pale yellow and hazy with a white head. Easy drinking, wheat like and rather bitter.
Langweilig milder Antrunk, etwas zitrusartig und grasig, stark karboniert. Im Mittelteil muffiger werdend, es ist aber noch genügend Frische vorhanden. Kaum hopfig, wässrig ausklingend. 6/5/6/4/6/4

From tap at Steinfels. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is coriander spiced, dry yeasty and light spiced. Fruity, estery banana and oranges. Bitter and mild citric into a refreshing finish.

Zurich, 07. I liked this one much better than Paul 01. Beer is cloudy yellow in colour with a decent foamy head. The aroma and taste have nice fruity notes and has some light crisp hops in the finish.

pours a hazy pale orange colour under a solid creamy white head; a gentle aromatic and fruity hoppiness along with some corny notes; a medium malt body; the palate is quite neutral wuth a moderate bitterness which increases in the finish; dry and fruity aftertaste - a pleasant thirst quencher

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: Location: Draft at the Brewpub, 3/22/14 Aroma: It has a toffee/caramel nose with some buttery hop notes Appearance: It pours a dark orange color with a small beige head on it Flavor: The taste is caramel sweetness, light and thin flavor-wise, with a very mild hop note Palate: The body is light and the mouthfeel is thin, and it has an average carbonation Overall Impression: This was a less than okay, fairly thin/watery example of the style. It isn’t terrible. Pretty much on par for Gaslight.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft from backlog. Pours copper with off white head. Nose and taste of caramel, light grassy hop and touch of pine. Lighter medium body.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours an off white head and dark copper color, almost mahogany. Aroma is faint medium malt-caramel. Taste is medium malt-caramel, smooth, hint of hops bitterness. Mild carbonation.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft at the Brewpub. Poured a clear rusty copper with an average sized creamy mostly white head. Aroma of grains, medium toast, dry citrus rinds. Medium bodied with a dry finish, average carbonation and a medium duration on the aftertaste. Flavor of grains and wet toast. Meh nothing special but drinkable.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden deep amber with a small white head. Aroma is fruity and towards citrusy. Roasted malty, breadish and fruity hoppy. Bitter and dry roasted malty finish.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft. Pours an amber body with a thin off white head. Dry with a bitter hop tone, light toasted malt, hints of caramel and a mild pine in the finish. A decent German style ale.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: On tap at Gaslight. Pours a clear orange tinged amber, thin beige head. Sweet caramel, candy, malt. A touch of vanilla and toast. Nice hop presence, but somewhat unexpected. Citrus, malt, earthy. Malty, a touch of metal. Decent.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: Deep copper with tight white head and lace. Cherries, honey, and an earthy aroma. Soap, cherries, and dry maltiness with a medium bitter. Medium bodied with a bit over aggressive carbonation. Not very special at all.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft sample at Gaslight. Poured clear copper color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with fair lacing. Moderate toasted caramel and tart citrus aroma. Light to medium body with soft carbonation. Medium balanced flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration.

column2: South Orange, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours no head and copper color. Aroma is medium fruit, medium malt, clove. Taste is medium fruit, medium malt, clove, secondary flat hops. Mild carbonation.

Bottle at Far Bar in LA. Pours a chestnut colour with a small tan head. The smell is toasted malt, fruit, caramel. The taste is toasted malt , caramel, fruit and dry ending. Light+ with active carbonation.
Bottle sample at a tasting at Na’ama’s place. Thanks Na’ama. Clear amber. Aroma of malt, caramel, light alcoholic hint. Sweetish flavor with malt, a bit of caramel, and a bitter finish.
Draught at Vector. Mild sweet malt, light notes of plum and nuts. Basically just another bland and boring local Alt, this is getting pretty sad.

Bottle. Aroma is fruit, toffee, maltiness. Taste is quiet sweet, lots of malt, maybe a bit milky(!), toffee, soft and easy drinking. Possibly some hoppiness lurking, but only just a hint of it. Pretty easy going beer.

Bottle (bought in Gifu, sampled in Tokyo) Dark ruby color, creamy beige head, some lace. Sweet caramalt aroma. Medium-bodied. Sweetish, caramel, a bit grainy maltyness. This "amber ale" (altbier??) has certain industrial vibe in it.

Bottle. Yeasty and malty nose, with some fat raisins. Deep copper color. Caramel dominates the flavor, some plummy or light prune is present. Decent bittering. Thin-medium body (maybe just a touch heavy). Okay. Unexciting (like the style).
Botella de 33 cl, adquirida en Yamaya en Nagoya, Japon. Color ambar. Sabor a malta, ligeramente a caramelo y acido.

330 ml bottle from Takashimaya @ Nagoya Station. Pours deep amber with a nice head - that goes away fast, leaving some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is very malty, but also filling your nostrils with a thick, almost soapy sensation. Some fruity undertones also there. Taste is quite smooth, bitterness mellow. Soapiness still there but also malt biscuits and light bitterness in the aftertaste. Medium-bodied, easygoing beer - won’t remember much about this one but it feels fine at the moment.
Bottle (33 cl), courtesy of Ingo. Clear copper, medium beige head. gRainy, sugary and nutty malt aroma with some herbal hops. Light to medium bodied, medium carbonation. semi dry, firm bitterness.

33 cl bottle thanks to Ingo! Sampled on April 8, 2013. Clear copper color, orange head. Sweet, fruity, sugary scent. Grainy, dry taste, some toffee. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness that is a bit harsh and dry.

Taster showing straw with a finger of clean white foam. The nose shows intense notes of malt. The palate is well carbonated and light bodied. Mildly sweet with a mid palate of corn malts and a moderately intense bitterness on the finish.
Bottle 33cl / Botella 33cl. @ MaxValu Taiko, Nagoya, Japon. A: Golden / Dorado. T/S: Malt, bitter, slightly hoppy / Malta, amargo, ligeramente lupulado.
Bottle from Nagoya station. Aroma is a bit creamy, grassy hops, herbal. Taste is alright, crisp, little bit of sweetness, something a little strange. Got a macro feel to it, but it’s alright.

Bottle (bought from Gifu) Golden color, decent white head. "Green", hemp-like hoppyness in the nose. Light to medium-bodied. Harsh hoppyness in the flavor. Hoppyness is quite "green", raw pellet like. Unbalanced German-type pils.

Bottle. Nose of corn starch, grain, and some minimal wet cardboard. Clear bright gold straw color. Sweetish malty initial, grass, and heavy bittering. Thin-medium body (a bit thick). Very hard bittering for a pils. Okay. Label touts its gold prize in the Japanese "International Beer Competition."

330 ml bottle from Takashimaya @ Nagoya station. Pours light yellow, looks a bit watery but has nice foam. Has some carbonation. Aroma has a bit of malts, feels fresh although there is a bit of cardboard too. Taste is crisp, bitter and spritzy. Not bad as a pilsener although it could use a more solid body.
Bottle. Poured bright gold, rough tall head. Musky aromas of hay, corn and wet hops. Medium body, fine carbonation. Quite tart and bitter, but not unpleasant.

400 yen from the Kintetsu department in Kusatsu. A nice clear straw gold pour with a thick fluffy head of foam that lingered & leaves lots of lacing behind. The aroma is grassy with a sharp noble hop bite. Light body, a bit rough mid-mouth but a very bitter finish. It is ok but the bitter finish is really ascerbic, not for me. It is ok but too bitter & not smooth enough for a pilsner. I prefer their miso beer.
Bottle @ yespr. Pours a slightly hazy yellow color with a white head. Has a fruity malty grainy weak grassy aroma. Fruity malty grainy flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy grassy bitter finish.
Sharp and tangy. Orange with a flat head. A dirty underlying flavor that is rather tart.

column4: Sabeco - Saigon Beer Alcohol Beverage Corp. (ThaiBev)
column5: Oct 2019. Can while sitting at a table on the pavement outside the Crazy Buffalo bar opposite Pham Ngu Lao. This was my iconic Saigon moment. Loved it. Oh, the beer? Typical global pale lager. But that's not the point. I was drinking 333 in Saigon at a pavement table outside the Crazy Buffalo bar opposite Pham Ngu Lao. That's the point. Iconic. If you're going to drink a beer in Vietnam it has to be 333. Extra points for that. It's not the same if you drink it anyway else.

column4: Sabeco - Saigon Beer Alcohol Beverage Corp. (ThaiBev)
column5: Clear golden color with white head. Light beer, light cardboard aroma and taste, mildly sweet. Notes: can on a bus from Hanoi to Ha Long, Sep ‘19

column4: Sabeco - Saigon Beer Alcohol Beverage Corp. (ThaiBev)
column5: A surprise find at A-Mart in Jingmei, bought this one purely for sentimental reasons. Takes me back to my Saigon days, and yes, still got that chemically afterburn. What the hell, drink it cold!

column4: Sabeco - Saigon Beer Alcohol Beverage Corp. (ThaiBev)
column5: yellow with a small white head. aroma is light malt and cardboard. quite bitter, very mild malt body with astringency, rice syrup is there. body is fine. another pretty fine thirst quencher that fits saigon well.

column4: Sabeco - Saigon Beer Alcohol Beverage Corp. (ThaiBev)
column5: Golden, clear with small and quickly disappearing white head, no lacing. No aromas. Light malty, a bit sweet taste, very, very light bitterness in the finish. Going to buy water next time...

column4: Sabeco - Saigon Beer Alcohol Beverage Corp. (ThaiBev)
column5: Bit of a 'go-to' beer whilst in Vietnam, more available towards the south (Siagon) but still everywhere. This rating coming from the Lauguna Angsana. Large but brief frothy head (for the only one I poured). Golden translucent colour. Corn syrup aroma. Crisp, short palate, inoffensive when drunk suitably cold. #Spiesy-Is-Back - after a long spell off (+10yrs), whilst ratings of good beers increase the enjoyment, paying attention to this "go-to" Vietnam staple, has hurt, whilst keeping honest the experience.

column1: Snake River New Delhi Freight Train IPA
column5: In nitro at the brewery it is a clear deep Amber color with a creamy off white head. The Aroma is of citrus and the taste is strong caramel with a Smooth finish

column1: Snake River New Delhi Freight Train IPA
column5: In nitro at the brewery. Pours a clear deep copper with a creamy off white head. Aroma of pine and citrus. Flavors of grass and caramel. Smooth finish.

column1: Snake River New Delhi Freight Train IPA
column5: On tap at brewpub: Darker than expected color for an IPA, sort of a deep amber with reddish tones. Nice malty taste, but not as much hops as I predicted. Citrus and floral tones are present, but the intensity is medium and in check with the hops. Easy drinking, however!
Ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnieñ z degustacji w ramach uzupe³nienia profilu.
Piwo wypite jakiœ czas temu. Ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnieñ z degustacji, w ramach uzupe³nienia profilu.
Greetings from Bydgoszcz, Poland to all Beer Geeks and Hopheads around the world!
Wypite przed kilkoma laty, nie jest ju¿ produkowane… Ocena przepisana z notatek.
From bottle pours golden with little head. Very smooth light flavor, no real finish.
Canned. Clear golden fizzy body, huge foam. Bready aroma. taste was little bit malty, more bready, some hoppy tones. Drinkable.

On the plus side of drinking again, skunky but still moderately fresh and clean. Good effervescence and color help this beer’s rating. The aroma has some nice natural hay elements and skunky, corny bits too. The flavor is moderately bitter and moderately sweet. As usual, a lot of bread flavors, but also some off flavors such as plastic and DMS.
Bottle. Clear yellow colour with fine head. Sweet malty flavour with bready grassy notes.
Bottle. Frothy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate hoppy and light malty aroma. Week grassy notes. Light bitter flavor. Short light bitter finish. Watery palate. OK PL.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, grass and hops. Semi oily palate.

Clear yellow Color, Good Head, Decent Lacing, Grainy Aroma. Sweet, Malt, Grain, Corn, Light Bitter Finish. Nothing too bad, Nothing too memorable. Just like many others from the region, seemed to be just OK. Decent.
A mysterious EPL; light in color, watery, and weak, but not absolute garbage.

Pint can. Pours clear light gold with a 2 finger long lasting white head. The nose is grain, sweet malt, a touch of iced tea and grassy hops. The taste is biscuits, grain, grass, light honey and citrus zest. Medium semi-creamy mouthfeel. An OK beer.

Can from Tops in Tempe as Zagloba Premium Beer. Brassy gold color with a large frothy white head. Grainy, spicy aromas. Medium body with creamy carbonation. Flavor is sweetish caramel with very little hop to balance. Ok, but that’s it.

Lightly hazy straw-gold brew, thin, beady head. Funny label. Sweet straw, coldwater malt aroma. Graham sweetness, black pepper, some funny over-sparged flavors, moderate astringency. Finishes with a spittable grain bitterness and a clinging unpleasant sweetness. I search in vain for a lager gem surpise from the Soviet Bloc. Picked this up for $2.29/500 ml at Rosemont Liquors, Rosemont, IL near O’hare.

Strong aroma yet grainy flavor with dominating hoppiness. A pleasant yet rich and balanced taste where 6% alcohol overshadowed by vriety of flavors and is not as upfront as in some other pilsners. Slightly weak finish and plain aftertaste. Deffinately a great Polish beer.

Mid-golden bodied with extremely light carbonation. A short, white head fades fast but clings to my Pils glass in a watery lace. A light hint of pine to a grassy, grainy, herbal aroma. Buttery palate carries honey-sweetness with light, bitter hopping. Not a bad beer, and it’s literary reference has sparked in me an interest in the work of Henryk Sienkiewicz. While it doesn’t seem like an easy read, I have added the 1999 film "With Fire and Sword" to my Netflix queue Single bottle from Cornfield’s cellar.

I’m puzzled somewhat by the two Zagloba listings. My bottle, purchased in a Polish neighborhood yesterday, is definitely fresh. But the label lists the abv as 6%, more akin to the older version of the beer. Definitely a good Bohemian Pilsener. Golden with a creamy white head and steady beading, it exhudes an aroma of bready malts and light grassy & floral hops. Creamy mouthfeel. The flavor is a smooth balance between the malts and the hops, finishing on a lightly sweet note.
Typical euro Pilsner more like a lager. Fresh on draft. Nothing bad. Very refreshing. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(draught) Nice clear golden colour. Good carbonation and head which persisted. Sweet malty and noble hop aromas. Easy to drink yet rich and satisfying lager, reminds me of some Czech beers. Absolute bargain in Swiebodzin, Poland and as good as any lpremium ager anywhere. Nostrivia!

To w³aœciwie wariant tego, co mieliœmy na polskim rynku, tylko czystszy, bardziej wyja³owiony. W tamtym czasie smakowa³, jak piwo z zagranicy. Mniej s³odowy, l¿ejszy, mocniej wysycony. W myœl obecnych standardów by³by tym, czym wtedy by³a nieeksportowa wersja w w stosunku do niego samego.
From bottle in shaker. Pours golden and clear with thin head and modest yeast aroma. Typical euro-lager: quite drinkable.
Gutes Bier mit leicht süßlichen Aroma. Beliebtes Bier in Polen. Lässt sich gut trinken.

hazy, orange brown with thin, but foamy, white head and great lacing. Citrusy, pine arouma, nice caramel malts. Finishes dry and astringent. A little flat and grassy and some skunk, but not that bitter. I didn’t get much wheat notes from this one. update 7/17 - I think they may have improved the recipe since I last had this: Aroma is awesome floral. Soft body, malty sweet. Fruity citrus. Light nut, some astringency. Smack of bitter @ finish.

On tap @ the brewpub pouring up deep clear copper and off white head. The light aroma is sending out modest notes of citrus and sugary malt sweetness and little else. The taste is crisp and refreshing with a long pulse of malt sweetness that bleeds into orange and tangelo like citrus hop flavor. The citrus comes through and mingles with the light malt backbone creating a very nice flavor. Toward the finish mid to modest hop bitterness helps take this to closure.

Pint on tap, Long Island. Pours a hazy golden color typical of a wheat ale. Aroma was very subtle but hints of sweet floral and citrus aromas were present. Flavor was sweet, not very bitter, very reflective of the large amounts of amarillo hops. Palate was smooth, good full taste.

On tap at the Lake Grove location. Pours a lightly hazy deep amber with a thin linen white head that faded to a ring after the first sip and left a layer of spotty lace with each sip. Pleasant aroma of grainy malt and fresh pine hops. The flavor is mild wheat up front followed by citrus and pine. Definite hops bitterness at the finish, but not excessive, that lingers for several seconds beyond the swallow. One of the better beers that I have had from this brewer.

Update 12/26/2012: It’s been awhile but had this on tap again. Lots of lemony, citrusy notes with bitter hops and pale bready malt in the finish. Tasty, fruity, hoppy pale ale. I still enjoy it! 9/10/2008. On tap at JH. Pours a clear orange with a small white head. Aroma of sweet caramel malt. Flavor of nice malt, honey wheat, light citrusy hops, and orange peel with a wheat finish. Tasty, decent, but not very exciting. Plenty drinkable. 7/4/7/4/13 (3.5/5) Update 4/9/09: Had this on tap again. Definitely more citrus hops come to play in this one with a sturdy malt backbone. I don’t know why I rated this a 3.5 before, it’s quite good! 7/4/8/4/14 (3.7/5)

Tap. Aroma highlights the hops with fresh cut grass and woody pine. Flavor continues with both resinous piney hops and some straight bitter hops. Vague sweet fruitiness kept to a minimum. A mix of good hop action and fairly harsh hop action. Didn’t get me going.

20070428 Tap at TAPNY. Fair beer, a nicely done American wheat with enough kitsch to be interesting. Tropical fruit salad underlying the aromas and flavor. More yeasty notes than most of the style as well as a fuller body and a nice touch of sweetness.

On tap at the brewpub on 9/14/07: Transparent bronze with a thin, wispy-lacing white head. Lightly sweet grainy wheaty aroma has some citrusy hop character. Body starts faintly sweet with some husky grains and fresh grapefruity hop balance toward a crisp finish. Decent American wheat.

Tap @ Lake Grove: Poured a hazy copper color with a medium sized creamy off-white head. The aroma had fruity hops with notes of oranges and caramel malt underneath. The flavor was full of orange flesh and orange rind. Some semi-sweet malty notes show up. The finish was dry and moderately bitter. Light to medium bodied.

Tap at the Lake Grove location. Burnished deep gold colour. Hazy appearance. Beautiful bright orange citrus aroma with light mango and other tropical fruit notes. Flavour shows a lowely wheaty spiciness playing off of the sweet hoppy fruitiness. A touch of caramel sweetness helps brings both together. Soft bitter finish. Warming brings out a touch of resinousness. Very nice brew.

column1: Stone Arch Between The Locks Light
column5: Pours a clear golden colour with a small white head. Palate is grainy. Comparable to your average light beer except with a little more crisp of a finish. Semi- floral aroma in a way, decent for a light beer.

column1: Stone Arch Between The Locks Light
column5: Decent light beer. Still sucks because it’s a light beer however this was made very well and didn’t have any skunky character. Wouldn’t buy again but would suggest to a wimpy bland tasted beer drinker.

column1: Stone Arch Between The Locks Light
column5: On tap at the brewpub. The body is hazy light yellow with a bright white head. The aroma is bell pepper with not much else. The taste is bread crust with some bell peppers. This is pretty good for the style.

column1: Stone Arch Between The Locks Light
column5: Pale straw color with a diminished off-white head. Light malt and faint grass aromas with the flavors to match, actually less flavors to match.

column1: Stone Arch Between The Locks Light
column5: Name: Between the Locks Light Date: 06/24/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub pale yellow, fine white head, light sweet corn aroma with light floral hops, light malt flavor, lots of balancing bitterness leaves it dry and overall bitter Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.7/5.0 Drinkability: 5/10 Score: */4

column1: Stone Arch Between The Locks Light
column5: On tap at the sone Cellar Brewpub. Poured a light and clear yellow color with a small sized white head. Aromas of tastes of grains and a little grassiness. Thin and watery.

column1: Stone Arch Between The Locks Light
column5: Picked up single 12-oz bottle from brewpub. Pours a clear golden amber brew with a nice off-white head that slowly dissolves to a fine film and good lacing. Aroma of light multi-grain, some flowery hops, some popcorn, and light dark berries. Taste is average carbonated, multi-grain, smooth, sweet flowery hops and a good balance of bitterness and malt. A very flavorable beer for a light lager.

column1: Stone Arch Between The Locks Light
column5: Cider/Yellow With No Head. Very Little Aroma. Light Malty Grains...Lightly Dry Aftertaste...Thin Body...A Really Respectable Alternative to American Domestics For Those Who Enjoy the Lighter Side of Life.

column1: Stone Arch Between The Locks Light
column5: Draught sample at the brewpub, early October 2006. Clear light yellow-gold with just a touch of head, thin-looking...faint but quite fresh grassy-sweet aroma, perhaps a touch of honeysuckle....body is also sweet and grassy-earthy, touches of honey and hints of corn sugar, smooth supple and rather appealing despite the lightness of texture and slight blandness....pretty solid light beer.

column2: Sackets Harbor, New York, United States
column5: Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a fairly dark brown color with a finger’s worth of eggshell white foamy head that fell off at a decent pace but didn’t leave any lace. The aroma gave off a nice blend of roasted nuts, smooth sweet caramel/toffee malts, crisp dried leaves, some toast and a little bit of earthiness at the end. The flavor leaned into the dried sweetness at first and then developed the roast slightly. Nicely blended aftertaste and finish. The feel was roughly medium bodied, perhaps just a touch under with a fair sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine, somewhat low, but that didn’t bother me. ABV felt appropriate. Overall, pretty good brown ale worthy to come back to if I could get it again.

column2: Sackets Harbor, New York, United States
column5: Cask Stillage from the Jug at the Colorado Convention Center, Denver 30/09/2005 Golden coloured and slightly hazy in appearance with a spicy flavour and a hint of dryness in the finish.

column2: Sackets Harbor, New York, United States
column5: Sampled at the brewpub. AU16/08. App.: Cloudy straw with a small white head. Aroma: Slightly sour/funky wheat, some dirty citrus and coriander. Palate: Medium-ish body, medium-soft effervescence. Flav.: Over-the-top coriander dominates, maybe some light cereal/malt; dry with no bitterness and lingering coriander then a little ester. Messy.

column2: Sackets Harbor, New York, United States
column5: Had 7/29/06 at Four City Brewfest. Lots of wheat and coriander in the aroma. Light citrus in the flavor. I thought it was good.

column2: Sackets Harbor, New York, United States
column5: Hazy blonde with a thin creamy white head. Light citrus/mandarin wheat with bananas and coriander, and sulfur notes. In mouth, straight coriander, very light, unbalanced. A very boring wit. August 26,2006 at the pub.

Aroma of malt, grains, light fruit, light hop. Flavour is malty and grainy, moderate sweetness, with a light bitter finish. Crisp and smooth. Not being a fan of Kolsch, I found this one of the better examples I?ve tried.

Huge thanks to Erzengel for that 1l-bottle. Looks really good. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts mild but not washy, malty, modest spicy, mild sweet notes. Hints of cookies. Well balanced finish, still mild, grasy-malty. Quite drinkable. Nice!
Many thanks for this bottle to Erzengel. Pours a cloudy gold with thin head and some mild lace. Nose of grass, grain. Medium body and carbonation.

1l-bottle. Dark golden and slightly hazy in the glass. The beer starts smooth, but a bit watery. Hints of grain in the mainpart, no deep body, even for a Kölsch. The aftertaste is not too sweet, but a bit sweetish, hints of grain together with a smooth slightly malty aroma. Slightly bitter. Nice, but nothing that special. But I like the smoothness. --> 10/12/9/10
Notizen: -sehr mild, teilweise wässrig -hopfig im Mittelteil und im Nachgeschmack (dort sehr) -säuerlicher Nachgeschmack Test vom 28.10.2006, Gebinde: Fass Noten: 8,7,7,8,-,7 - 7,26

Draught @ Brauhaus Gummersbach, Hindenburgstrasse 15, Gummersbach, North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany 51643. Unclear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, grain, hay, toasted, caramel notes, light hoppy, citrus - orange. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration, citrus, caramel malt. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110306]
Gravity, Peterborough Beer Festival 2006. Black with a bit head at first. Aroma is very sulphuric, with some berries and chocolate. Watery in the mouth. Not good.
Cask @ Peterborough BF 06. Sulphur, malt, sweetness. Roasted chocolate. Beer farts. Flavour is watery malt, some sulphur, some coffee, slightly watery. Bitter finish. Nothing special

1 l Flasche. Trübes, bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit weißer, recht flacher Schaumkrone. Riecht deutlich nach Sauerkraut. Schmeckt braufrisch und süffig, sowohl im positiven als auch negativen Sinne: Sehr gut trinkbar, lecker, aber einen Tick zu flach, wenn auch nicht so glatt wie ein Fernsehpils.
On tap at the brewpub. Trübes dunkel goldgelbes Bier mit einer mittelgroßen leicht beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht hopfig, helles malz. Geschmack sehr hopfig, Karamell, würzig hopfiger Abgang.

Aroma of grains, hay, citrus, light hops. Flavour is light malty and light fruity, with a moderate bitter finish. Wow, surprisingly smooth and quaffable Pilsner from this very small and local brewery, much better than the average (German) Pilsner.
Hazy golden yellow with white foam. Sweet peach taste, unfiltered. Girft from friend, not a typical German beer. (Velp, 201204)

Notizen: -Antrunk leicht herb -süßer Mittelteil -recht bitter werdender Nachgeschmack, außerdem leicht rauchig -im Mittelteil malzig im Unterton Test vom 29.10.2006, Gebinde: Fass Noten: 12,10,10,9,-,10 - 10,05

Draught @ Brauhaus Gummersbach, Hindenburgstrasse 15, Gummersbach, North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany 51643. Unclear light to medium yellow yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, light to moderate hoppy, citrus, light citrus - soured milk. Flavor is moderate sweet, light acidic notes and light bitter with a average duration, grainy, malty, straw. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20110306]
Gravity, Peterborough Beer Festival 2006. Amber with no head. Malty with some hop in the aroma. Slightly fizzy. In the mouth, oranges and caramel malts. Sweet.
Cask, Peterborough BF 06. Hop/malt mix, some sourness. Looks hazy dark chestnut, thin head. Some carbonation, some alcohol in the flavour, bitter hops.

On tap at the brewpub. Amber in the glass, white head. The beer starts smooth, malty and dry, even a bit roasted-dusty. The mainpart is malty dry. Hints of caramel, smooth malt. Nice. The aftertaste is long, intense smooth malty, caramel em with hints if roasted dry malt. --> 11/12/11/11
Gravity, Peterborough Beer Festival 2006. Copper with no head. Aroma of roasted hops and some slight coffee. Slightly fizzy. Very drinkable.

Cask, Peterborough BF 06. Dark chestnut, thin white head. slightly cloudy. Aroma of toasted malts, some hops, some coffee. Watery malt and coffee, some coffee bitterness. Loars of toasted malt and bitter hops. Burnt.

Milder und getreidiger sowie leicht hopfiger Antrunk. Nur sehr leicht würzig und spät malzig, dabei ist ein getreidiger Unterton durchgängig erkennbar. Zuletzt herb und leicht hopfig. Zu mild. Test vom 9.5.2007, Gebinde: Fass Noten: 11,8,8,8,-,8 - 8,31

Bottle from Bottle Mix, Kettering. Hazy very dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, oxidized and dark fruit. Flavor is quite sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 110219

Aroma of fruity hops and dark malts. pours dark reddish brown with thin tan top. Taaste is medium bitter with a background of dark fruit - dates and even fig. Palate is medium bodied sticky texture average carbonation and a bitter finish. Overall I really wanted to like this because the style is so rarely found these days but it made me suspect the cellar man

On cask at Towcester Mill Brewery, Towcester. Pours dark ruby brown with a tight off white head. Aroma: roasted malts, dark fruits, caramel. Taste: rich, light to moderate sweet, light bitter, dark malts, plums, dark fruits, caramel, light smoke. Medium bodied, average car, sweetish malty finish. A decent old ale

Gravity cask at the 2018 Leicester Beer Festival. Very dark brown, small off-white head. Malt, smoke and plums in the aroma. Sweet taste with a touch of harsh astringency. Some bittering hop in the finish. Long bitter aftertaste with charcoal and salt plum. Not bad but a bit underwhelming.

Cask at the St. Ives 'Booze on the Ouse' beer festival, 2017. Pours dark ruby brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of nut, caramel, malt, hop, whiskey and dark fruits. Medium plus sweetness with moderate bitterness. Light to medium body, slight oily and watery texture, soft carbonation.
Cask @ St Ives Boozeon the Ouse festival. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are caramel, fruits, rich malt, toffee and has a sweet malty and light warming finish.

[Robin Hood Beer Festival, Nottingham Castle, 2015] - Nobby’s Brewery, Nottinghamshire, T’owd Navigation, 6.1%. Jet black, with a big (!), frothy light beige head. Rather mild aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malts. Medium body, hardly watery, mild carbonation. Chocolate, sweet licorice and bitter roasted malts vye for attention at the outset. Middle is drier, but licorice remains, dark chocolate with a hint of vanilla. Finish has the skins of dark berries, chocolate, nuts. Bitter espresso after taste. Intriguing, multi-leveled stout.
All in all not a bad beer from a small brewer who’s beer takes slightly longer than others to drop bright as the landlord explained!
Dark ruby color, decent steady beige head, lace. Light toasted aroma, some coffee. Medium-bodied. Some caramel, then toasted malty, coffeish flavor. Some bitterness in the finish. Rounded, a ok.

50cl bottle from AlesByMail. Batch No. G491100812. BBE 10/08/2013. Dark brown, creamy, lasting, cappuccino head. Aroma is tempting with roasted malt, sweet caramel and some coffee in between. Flavor is roasty and hoppy with caramel and light spicy notes. Finish is dry and long. Medium to full bodied. Great brew.
Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Dark gold with a yeasty, cardboard aroma. Taste had fruit but was quite watery. Medium bitter finish.

On tap at brewpub. Poured a clear golden color with a small head that fell quickly to a ring. Aroma of light malt and yeast along with a slight funkiness. Taste was very mild and muddled with a light sweetness, yeast and a hint of spiciness. Not well balanced and kind of bland. Light bodied and on the watery side with moderate carbonation. Not one of there better beers.

Tulip glass at stewarts.... I was really looking forward to this beer. Decent orange color, ok head. Nose is sweet? Lots of flowers and some hay. Taste is sweet.....light hay. Some yeast notes. Not dry and spicey like most saisons.... Disappointed in this one.. Medium body and average carbonation... Overall: Let down... maybe i am spoiled with such great sasions availble all the time at SL... aka saison dupont

Aug. 2006 - Poured straw color...looks watery...nice head and lacing. Aroma had slight barnyard funk presence. The flavor of this one was kind of overboard on spices and hops. Very bitter, not very sweet and not a lot of funk. Mouthfeel was very carbonated, almost too much so, and full bodied. Not my favorite Stewarts offering.

Name: Saison D’oars Date: 07/26/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear gold, fine white head, sweet fruity candied malt aroma with light spices, big body, lots of sweet fruity estery flavor, plenty of spicyness balances the sweetness and creates a bitter finish, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: **/4

Draft at SBP. Very clear medium gold colored with off-white head. The aroma is pale malt, slight funky yeast notes, corn, hops. The palate is on the watery side, with flavor notes of pale malt, subdued hops, fruit, and not a lot of funk. This is a beer that would have benefitted from not being filtered.

Draft at BCTC. Clear gold colored body with a very small head. Nose of grainy extracts and oily corn scents. More grains tasted, with corn and some slight sourness present, and then it’s nearly boozy like a tripel. Starts out not so well, ends better, with a slight dryness, but it’s too sweet, underattenuated, sticky and I can’t shake the corn adjunct flavor.
Hazy yellow pour. Yeasty, sweet with a hint of zest. Very pleasant, creamy mouthfeel

Sampled from tap at the brewpub. Hazy, golden yellow with a slowly diminishing, white head. Sweetish, slightly yeasty-spicy and a little fruity aroma of orange peel, coriander, vanilla, banana and clove. Sweetish, yeasty-spicy and slightly fruity taste of orange peel, coriander, vanilla, banana and clove, followed by a short, slightly bitter, moderately yeasty-spicy finish. Medium body, smooth and slightly effervescent mouthfeel, average carbonation. Nice and simple, lovely in the sun.

Tap sample at the brewpub. ABV is 5.2%. Hazy yellow colour, white head. Aroma of lemon, coreander, wheat. Flavour is light sweet, wheat, some citrus, light spicy, hoppy bitter finish. Light bodied. Could happily drink a few of these I guess.

Draught @ Hanze Stadsbrouwerij, Houtmarkt 56B, Zutphen, Netherlands 7201KM. ABV: 5.2%. Unclear hazy medium orange yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is light malty, wheat, moderate yeasty, sweet fruit, herbs - spicy, light coriander. Flavour is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration, spicy yeast, sweet fruit - tropical fruit, yeast, late in the finsh some white pepper notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20130926]
Draught, 5.3% at the brewpub. Phenolic aroma. The flavour is better though, spicy and citrus. There is a hint of plastic in the finish, but not too bad. Hazy yellow colour. Small white head.

From tap at the brewpub as Witte Wold, 5.3%. Pours hazy yellow with a diminished white head. Dry stery aroma with a light yeasty phenolic note too. Medium dry and fruity flavoured from the back of the nose. Light acidic touch and medium dry into the finish.

Brewery tap: tasting glass. Grapefruit, lemon and grape sugar in the aroma. Thin. A faint sourness in the flavor. Grape sugar. The first signs of infection? Re-rate 28.04.10. Cellar run @ the brewery. Pale blonde, cloudy. Coreander and citrus in the aroma. Citrus and lots of coreander in the flavor. Almost herbal and just a bit out of balance.

Sampled from tap at the brewpub at 6.5% abv. Clear, golden yellow with an off-white head. Sweetish, slightly spicy and a little grassy aroma of straw, caramel, banana, cloves and vanilla. Sweetish, slightly spicy and a little grassy taste of caramel, banana, vanilla, some clove and straw, followed by a short, slightly grassy-bitter finish. Medium body, slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Nice, only a bit bland.

Aroma of fruits, some citrus, yeast, spicy notes. Flavour is moderate to medium sweet with a light bitter finish. Also a bit acidic. Also seemed to detect some diacetyl. Not very good I’m afraid, unbalanced.

Tap sample at the brewpub. ABV 6.8%. Hazy light amber colour, white head. Aroma is fruity, light-spicy yeast, some sugar. Flavour is quite sweet, light malty, spicy yeast, white fruits, light-bitter finish. Light-bodied. Nice.

Draught @ Hanze Stadsbrouwerij, Houtmarkt 56B, Zutphen, Netherlands 7201KM. [ As Hanze Liesje Blonde ]. ABV: 6.5%. Light unclear medium amber orange color with a average, creamy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, fruity, light moderate hoppy, moderate yeasty. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, caramel, fruity, yeasty. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20130926]
Draft sample at Brewpub Slightly hazy dark blond with a good white head. Rather sweet (caramel) but also with a nice bitterness and some orange fruits. Ok body and carbo.
Mustard aroma. Interesting. Slight acidity, sourness. Pretty good. Tap at the apeldoorn festival.
At festival in Apeldoorn. Looks a lot like Orange drink. Slight Orange peel finish. Bittersweet. Mineral aroma. Pleasant. Mustard aroma.
Tap at Hanze, Zutphen: Hazy golden sweet brew with some bitter finish at the end.,
Draught, 6.5% at the brewpub. Spicy aroma, black pepper and clove. Hazy yellow colour, small creamy white head. The flavour is also spicy, has a little acidic bitterness.

From tap at the brewpub as Lisje Blond, 6.5%. Pours almost clear to slight cloudy golden yellow with a lacing white head. Mild spiced and dry wheaty aroma. Light soapy flavoured with a mild wheaty note and a subdued spice and bitterness coming through. Dry and light spiced finish.
Tap at Hanze, Zutphen: Quite good looking amber with slightly sweet taste with an slightly sour aftertaste.

Draught, 5.6% at the brewpub. Buttery, dusty aroma. Hazy brown amber colour. Small creamy head. Quite a lot of butter in the flavour, citric finish. Does not taste infected as such, but not very pleasant.

From tap at the brewpub as Fikkie Amber, 5.6%. Pours clear and golden amber with a diminished white head. Aroma is roasted malty and somewhat butterish. Roasted malty flavoured with distinct notes of diacetyl ad some off citric note into a mild sweet finish.
Clear amber color, medium head. Aroma is light malty, caramel. Bit sweet taste, sticky, bit dry.
On draft at Hanze Stadsbrouwerij, Zutphen. Orange/amber coloured. Caramel malts dominate in aroma. Sweet flavour, which becomes more bitter in finish. Unimpressive, but by no means bad.

Tap@HanzeBrewpub, Sep 07, 3.1: Sweet caramel and light herbal aroma. Amber color, off-white head, good lace. Sweet, hints of caramel, caramel malts, light bitter, light herbal, sticky mouthfeel. Well balanced but uninteresting. Tap@HanzeBrewpub, Dec 06, 3.4: Iron and hints of caramel. Amber color, beige creamy head, good lace. Caramel malts well present, light sweet, herbal, nice bitterness. Refreshing beer.

A faint hoppiness in the flavor. Some raspberry esters. Light butterscotch character. Thinnish but tasty. Re-rate 28.04.10: cellar run @ the brewery. Amber color, hazy. Nutmeg, cardemom, caramel and cigar tobacco. No specific aroma. Fairly long aftertaste with caramel and tobacco.
tap at Hanze, Zutphen: Hazy pink coloured brew with an Ben and Jerry sweetness.
Pink and cloudy. Artificial raspberry aroma. Sugary sweet flavor, artificial raspberry. Just a touch of chichory-like bitterness. Didn’t like this one.
Aroma of caramel, malt, bread and a hint of dried fruits. Deep Amber with a creamy off-white head. Medium + sweet and medium bitter. Dry and slightly bitter finish. Overall a very nice Bitter.

Rubinowe klarowne z fajna gêsta i bardzo drobn¹ pian¹. Aromat ciekawy, zio³owy, chmielowy. W smaku super, kwaskowe, s³odowe i goryczkowe. Wszystko bardzo fajnie zbalansowane, dobrze wysycone i pijalne. Porz¹dne piwo

Draft in Edinburgh, clear deep amber colour, with white foam put on top. Weak aroma, bit caramel. Taste reasonably bitter, mild sweet. No carbo at all! Only the taste presents some character, bit the big problem is the lack of carbonation; it's incredibly flat and doesn't carry the aroma. Pity, but I can hardly finish the pint.

Deep amber, quickly diminished head and lacing. Roasty toasty, malty, better than I remembered it from years ago. Label says 5.0 abv (not 4.5 as this page states) A bit metallic and watered down for my taste. 12oz bottle gifted from our friend Barn

Cask beer served at the Last Post JDW Southend. I've had this in tins with Mr Thatcher at the fabulous Leigh Folk Festival. It's a top session beer, Steve Cropper and Carole Kaye getting in the groove, could do with some Robert Fripp to make it a bit more interesting. We can be Heroes, just for Sunday.
Clear deep amber colour. Flavour of caramel/toffee, tasted slightly watery to me with low carbonation.
Cask at John Scotts Avenyn, Göteborg. Clear amber with white head. Caramelly, malty with hay, herbs and citrus. Dry with low to medium bitterness and soft carbonation.
From sampler tray at Ugly Fish. Looks like water. Smells like sake. Taste is semi-dry, rice, alcohol, umami. Ok.
Bottle. Pours clear and still. Melony and slightly boozy. Relatively clean with some slight sweetness in the finish. Decent.
Nice experience. In the aroma I get white wine and slight citrus. Taste has very long length. Palate is full bodied.

Pours a clear water .. smell is of slight vanilla, rice, and slight alcohol with a melon rind 10 feet away .. . clean stuff for the most part .. . probably just above the average mark for junmai’s . .. . .governor elect, get it right moron!

Crystal clear and headless like vodka, aroma is very sweety lychee tropical smell, flavor is very crisp and refreshing, like a fruity water with a slight alcoholic tingle. No rice taste, dry palate afterwards.

Bottle: Pours clear with no legs. The nose is light and ricey with some dry koji notes and some faint melon. The flavor has a mild impact with light acidity and moderate alcohol. Fairly dry and one-dimensional. Light finish. Boring.
very clear, slightly yellow, a popcorn/butter flavor, grains, some diaper, very easy drinking, little to no alcohol despite being 14%
Pours a pale yellowish green color that is very clear. Nose is grainy and fruity and dry. Taste is ultra smooth and has a nice medium boozy finish. Not bad, very pure.
Bottle enjoyed in West Village, Manhattan. Nicer than expected - a bit buttery. About as good as can be expected for a mere junmai sake.

Bottle from Mitsuwa. This is a crystal clear sake. Strong grainy aroma with a bit of alcohol. Some dark fruit qualities. Very smooth. No harshness at all. Slight sweetness in the finish. Very mild and easy to drink.

Tasted a week or so after the release. No date on my notes, but I remember we were on our way down to the Malthouse, where Luke Nicholas was giving away free Monk’s Habit and Epic (Neil Miller was having no trouble accepting them). Two "pint" glasses. One freezing cold, while the other sits above the fireplace to warm up. Chocolatey, with a "whoompf!" of over-extracted espresso. Other than that it’s smelling and tasting like Sultry Dark. Once it gets warmer, the base beer seems to thin out a bit and show of the mildly unpleasant astringency of the coffee. Overly toasted toast and filter coffee is scrawled in my note book. I liked the idea but think they missed the mark somewhat. Ended up tasting a bit like beer + filtered coffee + burnt toast (true, that’s better than it would be without beer - but only just).
Awful awful beer....if that’s what it really is? tastes like Kahlua and Coke

Tasted 3 times. All from keg . 1st tasting at Shed 22 day after Mojo was released. Little to no coffee characteristics evident, sulphur aromas unpleasent became chocolaty as warmed but still no coffee, disapointing. 2nd tasting at NZ beer awards , much different, extracted coffee aroma like that of the tamping bin, rich slightly cloying but pleasent coffee flavour , alittle light in bodey. 3rd tasting at Backbencher,. muted coffee aroma , still alittle like extracted grinds, rich coffe on palate , diminished bitterness.

Wow, this really is a knock-out Stout. I’m surprised no one has reviewed it on this site yet as it’s been at the brewery for several weeks and has been written up in the papers too. It looks great, smells of coffee and tastes wonderful. The best beer from Macs so far in my opinion. It has roasty-toasty notes and a lingering bitter aftertaste. The brewery serve it too cold. Buy several pints at once and enjoy them over an hour or two - the flavour improves as the beer comes up from the lager temperature it is served at.

column4: Microbrasserie Saint Arnould (Coop Brassicole des Laurentides)
column5: Originally rated November 2006. Pours a hazy deep caramel-red colour with a tanned creamy head that has decent retention. Lacing is minimal and carbonation is average. The nose is beautiful with yeast and spices that reminds me of Unibroue. Mild bananas are present too. The mouthfeel is pretty thin, but it does stick a bit. Light roasted malt is part of the flavours, with some little bitterness and not much aftertaste. Too bad for the lack in the taste and mouthfeel, this brew could of been something special.

column4: Microbrasserie Saint Arnould (Coop Brassicole des Laurentides)
column5: bottle, pretty sure this quite old. still not too bad. milky brown pour. malted milk balls, light chocolate malts, wheat notes. kind of muddled together. found this in the back of the fridge. not worth the wait

column4: Microbrasserie Saint Arnould (Coop Brassicole des Laurentides)
column5: Rich ruby in colour, thin white coloured head, light lacing. The aroma is sugary, some caramel malts, some plums, wheat. The flavour is a little on the light side plus a bit watery, some caramel and fruit. Sweet mouthfeel, medium/light body, medium carbonation. Finishes sweet, watery, coats the mouth. Seems to die off too quickly, after a promising start this went nowhere. 341ml bottle from La Trappe a Fromage in Gatineau, Quebec. Opened on December 27, 2007. No date.

column4: Microbrasserie Saint Arnould (Coop Brassicole des Laurentides)
column5: [737-20071002] Bottle. Belgian candied wheat aroma. Slightly hazy, red brown body with quick light tan bubbles. More Belgian wheat in the flavour. Medium-full body. Nice, weathered well but could be a tad past prime.

column1: Boulder Beer The GABF 25th Year Beer
column5: Bottle courtesy of mdbf79. Served in a Bruery tulip. Pours a fairly-clear golden-copper color with a small white head. Touch of lacing and a bit of a collar. The nose has a bit of bready malt and light caramel with some earthy hops. Hops to the flavor with a good bitterness and light bread. Medium body and good carbonation. Dry finish. Good.

column1: Boulder Beer The GABF 25th Year Beer
column5: On tap in GABF 2011, 30th Anniversary, in the retro-1981 tent. Clear light golden with a thin white head. Very balanced aroma between biscuity malts and grassy citrus hops. Nice flavor of grassy pine hops balanced by simple dry biscuit malts, creating a simple, off dry, drinkable session brew that takes you back 3 decades.

column1: Boulder Beer The GABF 25th Year Beer
column5: Chunks of sediment floating about then settling on the bottom of my glass, golden color, honey and faint resin in the nose, has a somewhat citrus finish.

column1: Boulder Beer The GABF 25th Year Beer
column5: Yeasty sediment pour. Reddish color blocked by massive deposits of sediment. Not sure if I got a bad batch or if they brewed this one 25 years ago. Taste is slight licorice. Nothing fancy.

column1: Boulder Beer The GABF 25th Year Beer
column5: 26th August 2008. Cloudy amber beer. Soft palate. Mild creamy hops and malt. Slightly dry finish. Well balanced and easy drinking.

column1: Boulder Beer The GABF 25th Year Beer
column5: Bottle. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head. Has a malty caramel aroma with some hoppy hints. Sweetish malty hoppy flavor with some caramel hints. Has a sweetish malty hoppy finish.

column1: Boulder Beer The GABF 25th Year Beer
column5: Bottle. Picked this up in South Bend after Dark Lord Day 2008. Poured a copper/dark gold color with a fluffy white head. Lacing and carbonation streams. aroma of caramel, citrus/pine/grass and biscuit malt. Flavor reminded me alot of an English Pale Ale. Dry biscuit with caramel and an earthy, English hop finish. Very easy drinking.

column1: Boulder Beer The GABF 25th Year Beer
column5: Mid-hazed amber/vermillion under a mostly-holding film of ecru. Yeast, malt & hops find pleasant contrast in the aroma. Organized chaos. Peppers. Fruit. Palate is dirty, dry & alcohol laden. Flavor is tart & yeasty with a fruitiness and deeper bready qualities. A bit astringent yet rather good. Bomber from Grapes of Mirth, Columbus, OH 43215

column1: Boulder Beer The GABF 25th Year Beer
column5: Bottle. Pours an amber body with a 1 finger white head. Lots of malt, pale and simple, a few spices, and a floral hoppy finish. Pretty lame beer to commemorate one of the best beer festivals espically for its silver anniversary.

column1: Boulder Beer The GABF 25th Year Beer
column5: Dark amber color with white head. Nose is dough and citrus. Flavor has a nice hop front that is followed by a nice malt backig with a nice little pepper bite. Had some oxidation due to the age, but was not too bad.
Clear golden body, white head. Fruity hoppy flavour, sour fruit aroma. I’m not much of a saison fan.
Hazy straw body with white head. Aroma is medium sweet, orange, some clove. Taste is medium sweet, orange, lemon sour, some banana. Light body, some effervescence.
Cloudy golden body with a thin white head. Belgian yeast aroma, banana as well. Light sourness, citrus and spices, very nice. Good ending.
Draft at the brewpub, 8/26/06: No light gets through this orange-straw beer. Sweet lemon-lime tartness. Wow ... tangy! Almost puckerish.
Hazy golden body with a small white head. Sweet fruity aroma. Sweet fruit flavor, some sour hints and a bit of spice, with some subtle apple hints.

22oz bottle-pours a dissipating tan head and black color with red highlights. Aroma is dark malt-ash/charcoal, some chocolate, hint of vanilla and fruit. Taste is dark malt-ash/charcoal/coffee, some chocolate, hint of vanilla and fruit, slight bitterness from the hops. Medium body. Dry finish.

Brown head with black/cola body. Aroma is medium sweet, coffee, light vanilla, chocolate. Taste is medium sweet, vanilla, cardboard, some coffee. Watery light-medium body. I got perhaps the first beer from a brand new keg, but I can’t see how that explains the incredible difference in my perceptions compared with the others.
Pure black body with a creamy ivory head. Aroma of vanilla and roasted malts. Taste of vanilla, hops, barley and coffee. Sweet roasted ending.
Opaque espresso color, not very heady, good enough. Sweet toffee malt aroma. Delicious. A little bit of vanilla but it’s pretty well hidden. Thick mouthfeel. Roast vanilla, coffee. Fabulous.
Dark black body with a medium light brown head. Sweet caramel and roasted malt aroma. Sweet light coffee bitter with a very smooth vanilla overtone, some light chocolate and roasted malt in the end.

Cask sample at WBG Cask Fest 2006. Dark amberish red tones and a nice big head. DIPA resiny pine all over the nose. Huge grapefruityish body with faint malt hints and nothing but hops into the end from there. Even though it seems a bit flatter than it would be on a regular tap, it was still what I would call potent. Yum.

On tap at Brouwers. In terms of hoppy aroma, this might have been the best smelling beer I have ever encountered. Woody, piney, earthy, perfumey, floral, citrus. Pretty much every aroma a hop can give out was there. It was intense as well. Poured a yellowish orange that was pretty hazy. Flavor is super bitter with discernible woody and earthy notes. Hardly any malt, probably some for body. For how bitter is was, it was very smooth. I thought this was amazing!

Tap at Brouwers Hopfest Sept ’07 Pours relatively pale gold with a fine white head. Lemon and grapefruit aroma, marvelous leafy hops. Flavor is very dry with eucalyptus herbal flavors. This one is all about hte hops, a long, uber-dry finish, deeply resinous. There’s no malt here to distract anyone, but it’s really nice! Relatively light mouthfeel. I could drink this one in reasonable volume.

Tasted on tap at the 10th Annual Bistro IPA Festival. This IPA pours a cloudy yellow gold color. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is citrusy and floral, a touch sweet. A medium bodied IPA. The malts are fruity and sweet. The hops are citrusy and grapefruity. Nice balance. Crisp and clean. Medium to high on the bitterness scale. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is bitter.
WA Cask Beer Fest ’06. Pours deep orange with a tiny off white head. Aroma is faint hops. Big punch in this beer with a big alcohol nose and taste. Piney hops. Lingering pine and alcohol aftertaste.
Brouwers. Amber hued. Nice citrusy aroma. Big hoppy finish. Nice slightly sticky mouthfeel. Good overall.

Had at Brouwers Cafe. Small, creamy, off-white head. Not much in the way of an aroma, especially for a DIPA. As the name implies and has described by the waiter, there is a big, long, lingering aftertaste. There is decent amount of carbonation. Not really sure about the aftertaste thing, though.

Amber with no head or lace. Bitter hops in the nose with some pine. Citrus as well. Toasty and caramel malts. Bitter citrus flavors with some pine and floral qualities. Some heat. Fluffy and a bitter tail with a cloying, floral end.

Draft at Brouwer’s Cafe Hopfest ’06. Hazy reddish amber with a scant white head. Completely over the top. Just guessing, but the recipe probably calls for starting with too many hops, and then adding more at ten minute intervals. This was my last beer of the nite, and what a way to end up: every dimension of hoppiness in the aroma and taste, and pretty much all at once. Full body and a resinous bitter finish.

Draft at Brouwer’s Cafe Hopfest ’06. Dark amber, minimal head and lace. Big piney and resiny nose. Rumors of malt in the palate, but it’s all about huge caustic resinous hop. Just in case you forget that, there’s an almost charred element to the hops. Not from any roast malt--from hops. Not sure how I know this. Enormous lingering bitter finish. Maybe the best resin-driven IIPA I’ve had. The GF says it "tastes like someone’s shoe in a toaster oven." I’m guessing this means that other palates may detect a leather note that I’ve missed.

650 ml bottle. Pours an amber gold with a white head. Big malt smells with some grassyness. A sweet carmel taste malty upfront with an alcohol taste following and a bit of paint thinner flavor overall. Low carbonation and a very short cloying finish. Not very pleasant.

650 ml bottle at a local Indian restaurant. Pour was golden with a small white head. Big and little bubbles appeared. Not very much aroma. The first few sips I was not sure what to expect. After it sat for a bit, the taste was a bit like a Belgian Triple. Slightly sweet with a clean finish. I liked it and would order it again.

650 ml bottle with myself on 6th March 2019 while in California, bought from some random English/Indian shop in Forest Lake, Orange County. Pours a misty old gold/orange colour, fast fading wispy white head. Fruity aroma and taste. It's a 'style hopper' being half lager, half Belgian Tripel and half Belgian Strong (OK, thirds of each). Actually it's different and interesting, I liked it.

600 ml bottle. Pours golden with fluffy, white head and soda like carbonation. Aroma is of some grassy hops and lemonade. Body is medium and crisp. Taste is of chalk, mineral water, some chemical and robitusin. What a waste of money.

22oz bottle 2/1/17 (Binny’s Montgomery)-40° in Lager Glass. Pours golden with a small head. Aroma of sweetness, grains, and malt. Taste of the same with a bit of alcohol. This light to medium bodied brew was nothing to write home about,

Bottle. How can you go wrong with a monk on a beer label and a special beer make for beer lovers? Well, I guess this answers my question. I guess this monk was drunk when he agreed to have his picture on a Malt Liquor from India (not that there is anything wrong with India) ...

Bottle from notes. Didn’t record where just that I should never do this again. Pours a clear dark golden color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have old cream corn, apples, metallic notes, off vegetal notes, skunk, just a mess of a beer. Why?
Taste is Crisp, malty alcohol boozy, spiced. Gold and clear in color. Oak like malt nose. Medium to full body. smaller head with some lace. This one is a sipper.

Every once in a while i remind myself of what good beer is like by punishing my palate with a crappy european lager or third world country malt liquor. Today is one of those days! Thins white head of varying sized bubbles that dissapates rather quickly. Interesting arome with cream soda, corn, skunk and some biscuity malts with a lingering synthetic vanilla aroma. Color is like urine after a night of heavy drinking. Taste is about the same! Actually, it is not as bad as i expected. More corn and cream soda and is quite sweet. Lively in the mouth with a noticeable alcohol presence and warming. Dry and a but tart at the finish. Not as bad as i had hoped but certainly not that good either!

Pours a straw from a bottle, quickly dissipating head with little lacing. Very surprised by this one. Not much aroma, a little sweet rice flavor, round mouthfeel, one of the better pale lagers I've had. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A Mild under any other name, but moreish, well balanced and full bodied and rewaeding for its strength. Cask GBBF 2009
Cask. Very dark red/brown with a good sized head. Some cereal malts in the scent. Bitterness kicks in late. Cereals with a roasted hop back. Rich but watery.
Keg at The White Horse, St Helier, Jersey. Brown nitro keg with foam head. Nasty thin, malt dry bitter. Heavy paper card flavour with little character. Awful.

Bottle. Orange/gold and still. Aromas are earthy and woody with sweet and sour apple. Hints of vinegar. Flavours are dry and woody with apple. Fairly sweet and soft. Dry on the finish. Alcohol remains hidden. Not too traditional, but decent.
A nice pale ale with a fresh touch. Moderately hopped, not very interesting.
0,25l draft pour. Pours yellow with white head. Fruity and grassy hops, medium bitterness.
Restrained aroma in a rich golden pour. Hop forward balance with a boozy body and clean bitter finish. A brew that grows on you (quite quickly too).

This is a backlog rating from 2011 from a bottle, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are pale malts, grass, fruit, decent.

Clear yellowish golden. White head, two fingers, decent retention. Soft carbonation visually. Watery texture. Aroma is cat piss, tart tropical fruits and citrics. Taste is gooseberry, tart tropical fruits, citrics, wet grass, pine hints. Soft bitterness at the end. Clean and fresh.

330ml bottle at home. Pours lightly hazed pale golden with a loose white head. Aroma: malty, grainy, lemon citrus, grapefruit, grassy. Taste: light sweet & moderate bitter, dry, floral, lemongrass, gooseberries, white grapes, citrus jelly, grassy hop, pine needles. Dry finish. Light to medium body with soft carbonation. Lovely.

Cask at Heaton Hops. Malty and grainy aroma with some fruit. Hazy golden color with medium sized creamy white head. Floral and fruity taste, grapes, bit grassy. Thin to medium body, soft carbonation, creamy.

Appearance- Clear golden colour with super weak white foam that fizzes out like soda. Aromas- Sweet and sharp of grapefruits, pine and resin with notes of bitter orange and light egginess. Palate- Medium body with smooth texture but rather high carbonation leaving bubbly finish on the tongue.
