Taste- Sweet of peppers, bitter herbal hops that carry earthy, pine and citrusy characteristics. Overall- Drinkable but not for me, over carbonated, no foam, and tastes fairly unexciting and dull.

18.04.2015, tap @ UNA: Small shortlasting head, very light color. Aroma is fresh foresty, leafs, hay, fresh hops, citrus peel, grass, bark, pine needles. Taste is slightly dry grassy, weeds, leafs, dried grain, hay, bark, hops, paper, pine needles, lawn. Longlasting bitterness, slightly dry papery mouthfeel. Nice.
Nice amber colour. Aroma of bread, hops and some caramel. Taste is a bit vinious with nice hoppy finish.

Unclear/murky brown body, off-white/beige head, very fast away; Big nose where alcohol really shines trough (in a nice way), on a back ground of grapefruit; Balanced body, big carbonation, soft texture; Soft pleasant long finish, some bitterness, warmer aromas of malt, sugar, caramel as well as being a very little sour/acidy. All in all a nice beer, that I could easily drink again.

Clear, amber ale, with medium-low carbonation and creamy head. Light-bodied, and a little watery, but not unpleasantly so. Aroma of malts: caramel and bread. Flavour reveals a spicy hop, with grapefruit notes and pepper. Very drinkable!
Cask at GBBF 2010. An amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has light notes of citrus fruits and malt. The flavor is sweet malty. Boring.

Cask @ GBBF 2010. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel flavor with some hints of toffee. Sweetish malty weak roasted caramel flavor. Has a sweetish fruity malty caramel finish.

18th May 2007 Warning! Early amateur rating! Pint in a St Hellier boozer, Jersey. Served as ’Jersey Cream Ale’. Wasn’t until a couple of years later and meeting the brewers they confirmed this was Mary Ann. Sweet and creamy ale, good carbonation. Served cold. Best pint in Jersey!

From cask. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is caramelish malty and slight fruity. Sweet caramelish, breadish and gradually dry bitter into a mild fruity and bitter finish.

Cask @ GBBF 09, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear medium amber color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, light roasted, toffee notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20090804]

1. Cask Handpump at the GBBF, Earl’s Court 07/08/2009 Some fruit aroma. Golden coloured and malty with a crisp and slightly bitter caramel finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the GBBF, Earl’s Court 05/08/2010 Hoppy aroma. Golden coloured hoppy and floral with a hint of dryness in a full malt finish.

A Mes rate: Cask at GBBF. Golden brown with no head. Malt and hop balance pretty well in the aroma but it’s let down by some diacetyl. Nice malty flavour. I actually feel a little harsh with my numbers as the malt is pretty good but it just doesn’t do much else. Just about some hop presence in the finish but they’re pretty uneventful too.
Cask at GBBF 2009. Gold, lasting beige head. Sweetish malt. OK yeast, malt balance. Drinkable enough bitter. Some hop tingle on finish.
Golden with a small white head. Grassy aroma with some apple peel. Thin and sweet flavour mostly caramel
Chestnut colour with a small off-white head. Toffee and malt aroma with a fruity touch. Sweet toffee and molasses dominated flavour

Bottle 500ml.@ ChrisOs. [ Vintage BBF 0609 ]. Clear light dark brown colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, chocolate, oxidide, light roasted. Flavour is moderate to light light heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, caramel, raisin, dusty, oxidide, licorice notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20110807]

500ml bottle (ChrisO’s, post-RBESG2011 Sunday) BB2009 drunk 201108 Hmm, my notes say "oak farm midlife crisis". Dark, nice tight dark head. Slightly woody aroma. Dry, a bit nutty and marmite/yeasty. Refreshing palate. Nice dry finish. Honey. Past its BB and shows it. Sorry brewer - blame Chris!
Bottled. A deep red beer with a tan head. The aroma has notes of malt, oxidation, and metal. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, metal, and oxidation, leading to a dry oxidized finish.
Bottle @ Chris O’s. Thanks guys. Pours dark amber with a small bubbly head. Tart fruit, chocolate and ashes. Dusty. Ok.

1. Cask Handpump at the New Oxford, Salford 24/08/2007 Fruit and malt aromas. Small white head. Dark and smooth on the palate with some alcohol present. Crisp and slightly bitter roast malt finish. 2. Cask Stillage from the cellar at the Milds, Stouts, Porters & Strong Ales weekend Prince Of Wales, Foxfield 06/10/2007 Roast aroma. Mid brown coloured and slightly fruity with a bitter lasting roast finish.

Bottle. Near black with a beige head. Aromas are herbal and earthy with dark chocolate. Lightly roast malts woody notes. Flavours are molasses and dark chocolate bitterness. Liquorice with some woodiness. Smoky with some tart berry. Pretty decent.
Bottle.Almost black with a large head,aroma of licorice and hops,taste is of malt and coffee.

A dark cola brown coloured beer with a weak, off-white head. Light toasted malt nose, vinous with a hint of liquorice. A bitter dark malt taste, strong coffee and bitter chocolate, and a vinous, fruity flavour. A long bitter finish. (Cask - The Ouse Amateur Sailing Club, King’s Lynn, Norfolk).

Cask@St Albans BF 06. Quite sweet and caramelly, subtle notes of mollasses. Some green apple and some light sulfuric eggyness, which suggests it wasn’t quite as fresh/ready as it could have been. Some cereally and nutty malt notes also noticed. Tasted quite OK in the end though.

500ml bottle @ monthly tasting, Chez Sophie, May 18, courtesy of myself, thanks to kerlshdrinker. Surprise end-of-the-night German pils. Pours clear gold, white head, distant bubblegummy sweetness. Taste is smooth, clean, a touch oily with a pleasant light sweetness. Ok

Half litre flip-top bottle; BB 5th Jul 18. Shared in Chez Sophie (cheers Mat) on 29th May 18. A large snow white head sat on top of the clear golden body, clean and bright looking. Grainy/malty nose, more hop presence in the taste. Some herbal and grass like flavours give the beer a decent bitterness over the malty base. An easy drinking Pilsner (like so many).

grass, spruce, citrus, herbs, pale, golden, amber, orange, clear, hazy, cloudy, rocky head, frothy, minimal head, white foam, light sweetness, medium sweetness, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, medium bitterness, very bitter, lightly sour, medium sourness, heavily sour,
Milder, getreidig herber Beginn mit leicht erhöhter Karbonisierung. Monoton, konstant. Kurzer Nachhall. Sehr langweilig. 9/5/8/5/6/6

Bottle shared at the brewery during the Bamberg Jolly of January 2014. Pours clear gold with a frothy, white head. Great beer, with rich dried cereal character, light grassy and herbal hops. Light in body with average carbonation. Crispy cereal on the finish with nips of dry hay, moderate bitterness. Great balance. Lovely stuff.
Pours a clear yellow beer with medium head. Nose is malty . A grainy and malty pilsner with hops notes, finish is grassy.
Bottle. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy weak metallic aroma. Fruity malty grainy grassy flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy grassy finish.
Helder geel bier met schuim. Smaak is biter hoppig en fris, gras en hooi. Goed bier.
Klares goldgelbes Bier mit einer fingerbreiten weißen Schaumkrone. Geruch getreidig, malzig, leicht hopfig, grasig. Geschmack sehr malzig, unangenehm hopfig, würzig, naja!
Vernünftiges Pils mit ausgewogener Getreidenote, milde Hopfigkeit und recht mildem Ende. Trinkbar, unspektakulär, vollkommen in Ordnung.
From a Growler. Nice deep amber color, malty aroma. Malty flavor but not sweet, hops in the back ground, slightly dry finish. Great beer, could drink it all day long

I came across my notes for this beer while cleaning my basement. I’ve had the empty 12 oz. bottle sitting on my desk since the summer of 2006. I picked this up at the liquor store located under the Mangy Moose Saloon in Teton Village. Pours a slightly hazy golden amber with a moderate white head that lasted through about half the glass. Light citrus aroma. Flavor was a bit more hoppy than the aroma would suggest with medium bitterness at the finish.

Bottle than I scored at the Mangy Moose in Teton Village near Jackson. Medium amber color with an average off white head. Medium hops presence as well as citrus and floral tones. Nice balance of maltiness blended well to create a very smooth and drinkable brew.

Cask, Full black liquid with a tight creamy tan head. LIght rings of lace mark each quaff, big and small. Full roasted malt aromas, with backdrops of hearty roasted coffee, rich dark chocolate, and aged tobacco. Thin, yet a slightly slippery quality in the feel. Bittersweet chocolate, wrapped with a hint of lightly acidic coffee. A mild sourdough quality toward the finish with a nice dry roasty linger. A nice relaxing stout.

On cask. Beautiful once settled, filling in as opaque, completely and solidly black, with the creamiest, solid tan foam head stretching one inch tall in the English pint glass. There’s some lightening at the edges of the glass as the head recesses, but we’re talking about less than an inch of beer remaining by that time, and after we’re able to peer through the sandblasted dark tan lace. Aroma revels in crunches espresso grinds, dark chocolate undercurrents, blackened cigar wrappers, and a touch of lactic mocha sweetening to preempt a semi-sweet morsel beat. Flavor affirms its stout status with smooth, melting milk chocolate Hershey squares. Casual cask consistency with a slippery, uniform jello scattering when it hits the tongue. Incredibly smooth. Mild Colombian bean roastiness protrudes in the aftertaste, and when the tongue presses upward, a lactic and mocha bean flavor is additionally excreted. Creaminess encompasses more space the longer it sits in the mouth, and when it’s eventually sipped down, a tannic tract lines the middle of the tongue. Roasty grinds linger with a melting milk chocolate melody. Tiny Fuggle-esque bitterness presents itself near the end of the glass. All in all, a decent rendition.

Black pour big thick chocolate creme of wheat looking head w/ thick lacing Aroma is light coffees & chocolates hint of alcohol nice roastiness Pal is nice lightly creamy but to thin Flavor is light chocolates light burnt malts light coffees & tobacco a smooth sweetness w a lightly bitter coccoa finish A bit thin & small for the style or maybe I’m just used to RS being IRS but its good stuff. Probably the best beer i’ve ever had at the ale house.

Pours to a pitch black reverse cascading body that took quite a while to settle out. The head is thick, creamy, lasting, and tan. The flavor is sweet, creamy, black patent dryness, coffee. Something comes off as out of place. Perhaps an ultra-light banana? The palate is medium-full bodied and slick. Dry roasty aroma that is not very apparent. At first a ho-hum stout. As I drank more of it, it becomes a pretty average (decent) beer.

Clear deep copper coloured body with a nice rich three centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of alcohol, pine, grapefruit, a ton of rich resinous hops and a bit more of the alcohol, with some malt and biscuits around as well. Medium to Full-bodied; Super assertive pine and rich resinous flavours with a big sweetness
…

Bottle at the IP2 bottle share, and courtesy of trade with Asbjorn. Region #106. Pours hazy dark amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of toffee, molasses and malt. Medium plus sweetness, light bitterness. Medium to full bodied, slick texture, and soft carbonation. Good brew.
Pours clear ruby, small amount of head. Oak, earth, caramel sweet malts and pine hop. Classic formula done well. Harsh and biting. These guys haven’t blown me away yet but I’m waiting for it.
Bottle. Deep orange pour, off-white head. Aroma of floral hops, resin, pine and caramel. Flavor is slightly bitter, fruity and with a huge body. Amazing brew.

Bottle. It poured a golden color with a white head. The aroma was of floral hops with some citrus and vanilla. The taste was similar to the aroma with more hops and some caramel malts, with more vanilla, grapefruit and spices. Tasty.

Dark orange with a thin off white head. Very sweet malty nose full bodied with a lot of hop flavor and little bitter
…
Big thick pine resin aroma and flavor, very bitter. Big bodied and chewy. There are better hop combos than this, but it’s good.
Pine. Strong. Decent. Drink in big swigs. ---Rated via BeerBuddy for iPhone. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Good pour with 1 inch eggshell head that sticks to the side of the glass ... with a big piney nose as soon as the beer hits the glass .... I am gonna like this one. Deep amber/reddish orange... maybe not the right color for a DIPA, but no complaints here... still a very nice color.
…

cloudy amber color; lots of hops in the aroma; fruity, citrusy hop aroma with herbal notes; a bitter. Hoppy beer; piney, citrusy hops with herbal notes and tropical fruit notes; medium bodied, slightly sweet malt base; bitter finish with alocohol notes

Bottle: Deep golden, clear, stable and creamy white lacy head; sweet grainy nose, traces of honeyish pale malt detectable; mild sweetish flavour, "interupted" by a pretty low bitterness, almost medium bodied and really soft; short malty finish with a little bitterness in the aftertaste. Very unspectacular, but clean and soft…
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit durchschnittlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig, leicht herb. Geschmack malzig würzig, getreidig, minimale Bitterkeit.
Bottle @ Home. Pours yellow with a white head. Aroma of malt, grain, light sourness, hay. Flavor is malt, grain, hay. Medium body, average carbonation. 271013
Bottle 50cl, a clear yellow beer with medium head. Nose is on sweet grain, aroma is sweet, grainy, light metallic touch, hay hops, very classic.

#667 Der grobporige Schaum ist schnell verschwunden. Im Duft leicht blumig. Im Antrunk ein typisches Helles: Erfrischend leicht, etwas getreidig und im Abgang nur leicht gehopft. Das geht zwar alles auch nur Spur vollmundiger und würziger, nichtsdestotrotz ist dieses Hell recht ordentlich, auch wenn die Flasche sowie der unbedruckte Kronkorken schon etwas nach Billigheimer anmutet. Test vom 20.4.2011, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,9,10,9,8,9 - 9,10
Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and grainy. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter.

Bottle, bought @ SKY, Süderlügum. Pours light hazy golden with a small, frothy, white head. Ends up as a thin film. Aroma has sweet malts, doughy, some hay. Fairly sweet. Medium carbonation, small bubbles. Fairly light mouthfeel. Flavour is mildly sweet, doughy malts, light Corn Flakes, citric, soft hay-like bitterness. Not terribly good.
Bottle at DSG 2011. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is fruit, malt, hay, hop. Flavour is fruit, malt, hay, hop. Ordinary beer.
Golden with a small white head. Aroma of grain and hay. Dry grainy flavour with a touch of DMS
Flöska. Clear golden like. Grain aroma. Thin mouhfeel Grain flavour, and ya bad. simple,

Bottled (6%). Murky deep golden Fruity and phenolic up front. Medium bodied with winegums, orange and crystam lat. Finishes with low bitterness and some strawberries. More concentrated and flavourful than refreshing.

Tap@Brewpub. Aroma is very citric with an apricot background. Hazy, yellow color, small white irregular head, few lace. Fruity sourness, quite complex flavors, fruity (banana, apricot, apple), light bitter, light spicy. Flat and a bit watery.

50cl bottle. A clear pale golden beer with a mid-sized most good lasting white head. Aroma of soft grassy hops, floral hops, hay, pale malt. Taste of soft floral and grassy hops, hay, pale malt, mild bitterness, okay!

W aromacie s³odowe, chleb, skórka od chleba, nieco dms. W wygl¹dzie klarowne, s³omkowe, piana szybko opada do obr¹czki. W smaku chlebowe, pe³ne, nieco zio³owe, jest te¿ œrednio przyjemna ³odygowoœæ trochê psuj¹ca odczucie w ustach. Pijalnoœæ wysoka, lekkie. Ogólnie zbyt delikatny zapach, za ma³o te¿ pieczonego charakteru w smaku. Œrednie helles.
Flasche - Bar in Neukölln - Nettes, frisches Helles mit teigigen Aromen. Dazu Heu, leicht süßlich. Körper mittel, Textur cremig. Gut.

Flasche von Getränke Hörl, Dollnstein. - Goldgelb, fast klar. - Nase angenehm getreidig-brotig hellmalzig mit zarter Malzsüße und feiner herber Grundierung. - Antrunk mild brotig malzig mit sehr dezenter Süße. Feines Zitronenöl und ein klein wenig Gras runden das saubere helle Malz perfekt ab. Durchschnittlich rezent, schlank und angenehm trocken. Im Abgang ein klein wenig Zitrone und milde aber nicht zu schwache Hopfenherbe. - Ein sehr schönes Helles: mild aber aromatisch gehopft, angenehm ins Trockene spielend und nirgends fad.
Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is grassy and straw. Cornish, grassy and light straw.

Draft at Fränkisches Bierfest in Nürnberg. Mostly clean pale malt aroma with light apple / pear esters. Grassy, lightly hoppy with mild lemon and pepper. Clean flavor, quenching acid, light body, lightly bitter and semi-sweet with excellent malt firmness.
Süßlicher Antrunk, hell malzig. Süß herber Mittelteil, geringe Intensität. Fast wässriger Ausklang. Süffiges, eher langweiliges Bier. 10/9/10/7/9/8

Tasted 20080620, 0,5 l bottle, at the pub of the brewery. Poured cler pale yellow with a small white head. Not a clear nose with some sulphuric and sourish yeast. Acidic and metallic medium body, some malt, some sourish and sulphuric yeast flavor, grassy hop. The beer was on the dead yeast too much...

Bottled(500ml). –from Tesco Budapest. Pours a pale yellow colour with medium sized airy head and dusty bready nose. Typical weak and cheap hungarian beer without any trace of hops, wheat or anything else. Costs about 0.35 €.

Courtesy of and shared with ozujsko (thanks!) Poured a yellow body with a big white rapidly collapsing head. Extremely lively carbonation. Unpleasant acidic eggy and dusty nose. The taste isn’t much better either... metallic hops, bad corny fruitiness , eggs. Reinheitsgebot my ***. Heck, it’s even worse if they managed to produce these "flavours" while adhering to it. Typical hungarian crappy lager. By the only bigger brewery there that seems to be able to do them right from time to time.
Bottle from Tesco, Irlam. Bright amber with a creamy head. Has some pale malts with fruit in its nose. Smooth enough in the palate.
good citrussy aroma and flavour, some nuts and dryness. Perhaps lacking in the majesty and profundity of a great beer, but refreshing.

Belgian blonde brewed for Tesco, with thinnish, off-white head and bright, deeply orange blonde colour. Aroma of peaches, nuts, young ’jenever’, jute, bread, cognac and wet dog. Taste a dry fruitiness with light citrus acidity, caramelly malts with some spicy yeastiness, finishing moderately hoppy with some gin-like and therefore badly hidden alcohol. Straightforward and not too well-balanced but I guess an okay introduction to Belgian ales for British consumers not yet familiar with them.

AROMA: citrus, APPEARANCE: golden, clear, frothy then minimal head, white foam, TASTE: medium bitterness, PALATE: light body, thin feel, average carbonation, OVERALL: no character, sort of reminiscent of a Triple, very thin. Cheap though.

Dusted honey-amber with a billow of Belgian head. Nose high on ground coriander seed, lemon and lime jelly, fruit pastilles, exotic peppery spice, maybe grains of paradise. Orange wine gum and coriander seed flavour squarely in the perfumed Belgian camp. Soap and fruit pastilles. Full mousse-like body. Very decent. Earlier Rating: 5/12/2009 Total Score: 2.8 After 6 months of hopefully scanning the shelves in my local Tesco for new beers, eventually I cracked and bought the only rate they’ve got. Pours too brilliant fizzing amber with a dying white head. Pleasant ridiculous mulled orange and woodsy spice aroma. Thin papery palate with aspirin, cardboard and coriander fizz like Leffe Blonde, but worse. Nectar on top of two bottles of Toon.

Bottle from Tesco in Wokingham. Poured a hazy amber colour with strong carbonation and a dense, fluffy white head. Aroma of grain, Belgian yeast and candy sugar. Cereal flavours with caramel and some floral and pine hop notes. Lingering tart fruit palate, slightly soapy and a bit of a hint of copper.

Cork and caged 750ml bottle: poured into three ’La Chouffe’ stemmed tulips on 27 Aug 2013 at my son-in-laws. Looked fine in the glasses, the third one having a darker golden hue than the clear first two glasses: the sediment making the final glass meatier and richer in everything. Good white heads on all three glasses, none however stayed around for any great length of time. Yeasty, spicy, with orangey notes in the nose and taste: this promised so much but fell away as a metallic feel took over the taste. I usually enjoy my Tripe’ls, but this was a poor example and I struggled to finish my two glasses (my son-in-law not wanting more than one glass). The glass with the sediment was better, having more flavour and character, but it still had that annoying metallic note within it’s taste. Overall a bit of a let down for a Tripel.

750 mL bottle in increments into a Gouden Carolus glass. Golden brown, fizzy, lively head, but degrades to bubble bath texture. Nice malty tripel aroma. Smooth, crisp malty taste. A ’solid’ tripel, rather than one with flair.
750ml bottle from Tescos. Amber/gold pour with a white head. Fruity, sugary nose, some citrus. Sweet fruit flavours, bit of apricot in there. Does the job.
750ml bottle. Pours dark gold with a small head. Aroma is candy sugars, a little banana and bubblegum. Taste is mostly carbonated water. Some yeasty esters. Some candy sugars. Boring.

After waiting for over a year, I have been curious when the brewpub would have this one available again. On draught at the brewery/brewpub pours a clear pale golden amber brew with a thin off-white head that quickly dissipates to a bubbly white ring. Aroma of bready white malt, a touch of corn syrup, fruity pears and a touch of grassy hops. Taste is a little thin with some white bread and multi-grain malt, a touch of fruit such as bananas, pears and even some peach. Finish has a mild grassy hop and wheat aftertaste that quickly disappears but remains some light pear flavor. An interesting multi-personality wheat ale.

Golden color with a fairly think white head. Malt-o-meal aromas and a touch of what seems to be acetaldehyde. Light sweet wheat and a touch of mild citrus. Touch less funk in this one than I seem to find in the others here. Likely one of my favorites here.

Un-Muzzling Olde Muzzlehatch Ratings, #98. 500ml bottle purchased at the meadery in August, 2006, consumed in August, 2008 at my apartment at the time in Burlington, VT, from a White Winter Winery glass, beginning the tasting right out of the fridge. Lightly viscous, translucent plum color, no head (still), thick oily legs in the glass...currants, smoky caramel, honey, a light muskiness and only the faintest whiff of booze...very, very sweet, rich and port-like, currant flavor quite strong throughout...alcohol apparent but doesn’t feel anywhere near it’s true strength...slightly drier at the finish, thick and syrupy throughout but not really cloying. I did this over two days and saw no real deterioration over that time. Pretty nice stuff; about time I try some more things from this company.

Sampled from the bottle at Winter Dabbler. Pours a clear deep amber red with a bubbly head that dissipates completely. Aroma has lots of dark fruits, touch of dry honey and a decent amount of booze. Flavor is intense with syrupy dark fruits, honey and a decent amount of booze.
Smells like cough medicine and port and honey and medicine. Amber pour looks like whatever Tons of honey tangy mead fruit cake medicine oxidized notes booze. Wow hot. Shit. Tastes good I guess.

Pours the color of a nice red wine. In the bottle it smells of tar and asphalt. In the glass it’s boozy yet fruity. The flavor is high on dark berries and currants. Has a wine like sharpness and a boozy burn in the finish. Thanks Kevin it’s one I have been wanting to try.

Thanks to Kevin for the share at CCB. Nose is ethanol and berries. That’s it. With the big ABV it’s hard to find much else but I’m surprised at how well the currants stood out. Color is a dark red/purple hue that is nice as hell. Each swig was generous portions of spicy alcohol and dark red fruit with a honey finish. On the drier side but still sweet. Not bad at all.
Bottle at White Winter Winery on Nov. 18, 2011. Rich orange pour with nose and taste of honey and black currant.
Pours a purple color with honey and red wine aroma. Flavor is somewhat light, but not offensive. Good.

Bottle. Pour was deep dark with a consistency of syrup. The black currants were very prevalent in this one. Very sweet flavors of honey, currants, spice, and a good amount of oak. It was a treat to have this. Very fine.

Thanks to who shared this from the STL group. Pours reddish purple with a minimal head. The aroma has lots of alcohol, light fruit and the fruit that is there seems to be on the artificial side. Thick slick body that is quite smooth. The flavor starts with fuesel alcohol, black currents, black cherry and some tartness. The finish is a whirlwind of alcohol heat. Okay, but not my thing.

Holy shit this is fuesel! Aroma is alcohol, dull red fruit, and vodka. Smells like a bum eating cranberries. Taste is vodka-infused, herbal cranberries. Finish is cloying, slightly burning, and sweet. Tastes pretty nice in some aspects, but this needs to burn off some alcohol. It’s like Apis Jadwiga and Night Train Express had sex. Speaking of which, I need to kill the rest of this bottle and go home to beat my wife.

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Bottle, thanks to pivnizub. Bottle Golden color with small white head. Grainy aroma. Fruity taste with grainy hints. Bittersweet finish. Drinkable.

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Ein Pils aus einer Weißglasflasche. Hm. Der Geruch ist sehr hopfig ausgefallen. Geradezu voluminös für ein Pils. Geschmacklich ein kerniges Pils. Leider kommt dann alsbald eine unangenehme Bitternote zum Vorschein, welche die erreichten Eindrücke wieder zunichte macht. Schade drum.Test vom 7.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Getreidig ist das Bier fast durchgängig, dazu kommt ein fast beißender bitterer Ton, der allerdings nach wenigen Schlücken volkommen verschwunden ist. Weiterhin präsentiert sich das Bier recht kernig. Als etwas einseitig empfinde ich, dass sich das Bier vom Antrunk bis Abgang kaum verändert, erst im Nachgeschmack wird das Bier etwas malziger. Test vom 15.11.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,10,10,11,8,10 - 9,85

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Bottle. Pours a clear, pale yellow with a white head. Malty, dry hoppy aroma. Sweet and with cereal notes. Flavour is quite sweet. Malt, bread, hops, bitter. Finish is dry with a lingering medium bitterness. A so-so beer. Liked the bitterness, but it was much too sweet for my liking. 24-04-09.

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Clear plastic bottle 33cl. @ home. [ Trade by MiP ]. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, bread, grain, straw, keller, light hoppy, grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20081027]

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Clear yellow colour with a white head. Malty, sweet aroma with notes of cereals and straw. Malty, grainy sweet flavor with a light fruit note.

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Bottle, thx to MiP. Clear, golden beer with a white head. Grainy nose with floral hops and pale malt. Slightly sour, grainy flavor with some grassy and floral hops giving a little bitterness. Medium body. Medium lenght grassy, piney and bitter finish. A decent, easy drinkable and quenching pilsner. Rather boring though. (080731)

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is fruit, malt, hop. Flavour is malt, hop, citrus. Strange bitterness.

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: 33 cl bottle (yngwie). Tasted at cottage in Korshavn, shared with gunnfryd and yngwie. Clear golden color, ok white head. Aroma is hops and malty sweetness. Flavor is a strage maltyness, some bitterness and hints of citrus.

column2: Ostheim v. d. Rhön, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Clear glass bottle. Light skunked bitterhop and hayish aroma. Deep golden, low visoble bibbles, lacing aggshell foam. Light hayish malt, peppery grassy hops - unfortunately somewhat skunked - the clear glass bottle is a stupid idea. Chewy body for a pils, slick mouthfeel. Bready finish laced with grassy hops.

column1: Medovina Classic Mead - Off Dry Oak Aged
column5: 375ml bottle 2006. Clear at first with lots of sediment towards the end. Aroma is honey, floral, medicinal, oak and apple. Flavor is alcohol with minimal honey some acidity, oak and hot alcohol. Light body, still and dry. This one is very dry, it losses all it’s honey flavor.

column1: Medovina Classic Mead - Off Dry Oak Aged
column5: Date: 03/24/2007 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting Appearance: clear pale yellow, nice legs, Aroma: dry woody and alcoholic aroma, Flavor: very dry flavor, big wood character, warming, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

column1: Medovina Classic Mead - Off Dry Oak Aged
column5: Poured a clear light yellow color with nice legs. Sweet honey and fruity aroma with some candy notes and fusel alcohol. The flavor was light. Light honey, light sweetness, and light alcohol. Big warmth.

column1: Medovina Classic Mead - Off Dry Oak Aged
column5: Pours a light yellow color. Aroma is of honey with woody vanilla notes. Flavor is of sweet honey with bitter woody notes, and a hint of vanilla.

column1: Medovina Classic Mead - Off Dry Oak Aged
column5: Pours a pale yellow. The flavor is a little on the hot side. There’s a slight tartness in the back and this is a bit more harsh than the rest of the Medovinas that I’ve had. A touch of vanilla from the oak turns up toward the end of the glass.

column1: Medovina Classic Mead - Off Dry Oak Aged
column5: No head (still). Body is light yellow. Aroma is notes of honey, minerals, lemon/lime, flowers, alcohol (some isopropyl character), hint of wood. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic. Light to medium body, watery texture, flat carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Not a lot of oak character that I could detect, and some higher alcohol is evident as well, but otherwise it’s got the usual bulletproof Medovina characters. As always, I prefer the semi-sweet and dessert meads from Medovina, but this is a class act apart from the alcohol.
On tap at Redoak beer cafe. A very good IPA, could do with a bit more bitterness but lovely nonetheless.
A rather good example of an IPA. Could benefit from a slightly longer finish, although it is quite smooth. Very enjoyable

Had on tap at Redoak Clear brown color, off white head, good sticky lacing on the sides of the glass. A bit of ABV legs on the sides. Nose is caramel malt, grapefruit, wood and earth. Not as floral as I expected but a pretty big nose for the style. Taste is quite earthy with a lot of grapefruit. Nice but overall a bit big I felt. Lots of floral and earthy woody notes to this. Oily and heavy feel. Felt bigger than the 6.5% implies. A bit too earthy and woody for my taste but did like.

Draught, sample, at Redoak Boutique Beer Cafe, Sydney, on July 10, 2013. Clear brown color, teal head. Sweet, caramel, hoppy, berry, cream scent. Sweet, caramel, floral, hoppy taste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Sweet, berry aftertaste.

Draught at Redoak Beer Boutique. Pours a clear medium amber with an off white head. Smells nicely of floral and citrus hops. Tastes of a passion fruit and grapefruit sweetness, with a large bitterness to follow. Medium bodied, light carbonation, oily/syrupy texture. Finishes bitter with a long duration.
Pours a cloudy amber colour with a white head. Aroma is fruity with notes of pine and grapefruit. Taste is also fruity with grapfruit leading to a decent bitter finish. Pretty good.
Tap. Clear gold body with a large white head. Aroma-taste: resinous, floral herbal hop notes, hay, caramel. Medium to full bodied. Nice.

Draught. Pours Clr copper orange with well laced off white head. 4 Rusty grassy hops with a decent bouquet grains and 7 Decent bitterness over a complex malt body, biscuits, pitted fruit, toast 7 O 16 P 3 A touch rusty, hops lingering

Tap, a bit too cold at RedOak. Orangeish amber, small light beige head. Very hoppy nose - floral, with pine and spice, darkish toffee - smells fabulous. Taste has very moderate sweetness - it’s pretty dry, despite deep toffee. Nectarines, kumquats, mild hard spices. Just a _little_ window cleanerish. Nice balance, but genuinely highly hopped in both aroma and bitterness. Traditional but bold.

On tap at Redoak. Review from notes. Pours a deep amber with good creamy slightly offwhite head. Nice looking beer. Good hop aromas with the usual suspects. Plenty of grapefruit and pine needles. Soft light caramel to hold it all together. Flavours are pretty much identical. Soft light caramel sweetness with plenty of resiny hops. OK Bitter finish. Probably my pick out of their beers.
Draft - Sweet banana and wheat. Cloudy yellow with a decent white head. Light sweet candied banana.
Definitely a Brewsters original and one of the best they make. Great balance of banana, bubblegum and cloves in both the Aroma and flavor... Love when they come out with this beer every spring!

Pours a very cloudy yellow as expected from a hefe, small white ring of foam with very little lace on the glass. Aroma is cloves, yeasty/wheaty, banana, and light bubblegum. Taste is banana, clove, yeast and a bit astringent on the finish. Not bad but not great.

On tap at the brewpub. A story of banana, in the aroma and in the taste. Banana bits in the mouthfeel, though otherwise smooth, with a bit of astringency in the finish. Lacy, thick appearance. Nicely drinkable.

Pint on tap at Oliver Square location in Edmonton. Poured a hazy copper color with a small white head and little lacing. Aromas of banana and cloves and some yeast as well. Taste is yeast and cloves with a light sourness in the finish. Nicely carbonated providing a decent mouthfeel. Overall, this is a good beer, but not one of my favorites from Brewsters.

Pint @ Brewster’s. 5.2%. Cloudy, orange/honey coloured pour with a frothy white foam, medium retention. Aroma is yeast and bananas. Taste is more bananas , yeast, orange, coriander, and almost a sweet gingery taste lingering in the finish. Creamy, cool and very well balanced.
5 ounce sample at the 11th Ave brewpub at 5-beer sampler for $8.50CAD. Very good, even not being my favorite style
Very cloudy creamy yellow colour with medium head. Aroma of banana, wheat and cloves. Taste was watery, with a citrus lemon coming through. Refreshing but not a great hefe.

For this pour I used my German weissbier glass which compliments the naturally substantial head of wheat beers. Gunther’s is unfiltered and cloudy and a nice golden bronze in color. Excellent lacing left on the glass. The nose is of banana, clove, and coriander. There are notes of yeast in the aroma. It is a sweet smell and quite appetizing. There are hints of slightly sweet banana in the taste but it is not overpowering. I can now distinctly taste the large proportion of wheat used to brew Gunther’s and I am a fan. There are some light hops providing a bit of bitterness in the finish. Gunther’s is medium bodied and quite highly carbonated. I almost find the carbonation leads to a bit of bloat in the gut and can slow your enjoyment of this down. At times in the middle of the sip there is almost a little something missing that briefly makes the beer seem watery. Overall - when in the right conditions I love this beer. Namely in the summer heat on a patio or deck.

Fairly low creamy head and silty tangerine colour. Nose: wheat, lemon peel, young barley, teriyaki sauce. Taste: early cream soda then sour mash, poppyseed, and then more sour mash to end things. This one was off track and its personality did not match its label. Sour dominant and not overly bearable.

column1: Rock Bottom South Denver Flat Foot Copper Lager
column5: yep it’s a light coppery yellow beer. smells like wet asphalt & wild fields-that’s a good thing for me. taste is an assload of butter, sweet toffee and grain huskiness. finish is not pleasant. plastic, melted metallic.

Cask Handpump at the Penny Black JDW, Northwich 11/10/2010 Citrus hop aroma. White head. Golden coloured hoppy and citrus flavoured with a hint of dryness and bitterness in a slightly grainy malt finish.

Cask, The Screes Inn, Nether Wasdale. Golden with a cream head. Aromas are creamy with caramel malts. Lightly fruity. Flavours are smooth and creamy with light hops and some fruitiness. Some hints of caramel malts. Pretty decent.
33cl bottle. A clear golden beer with a mid-sized most good lasting white head. Aroma of spicy hops, pale malt, some grains. Taste of intense bitter hops, spices, grains, long biterness

0,33 l Flasche als Wettelsheimer Wet Premium Pils aus dem Raiffeisenmarkt in Hilpoltstein. Orangegold, klar, mit schnell abfallender Schaumkrone und kaum lacing. In der Nase leicht grasig, im Geschmack leichte Zitrusnote. Malzig-herber Abgang
Pils o mocno ³odygowym charakterze, mineralny, s³odowy, pijalny, klarowny z konkretn¹ bia³¹ pian¹. Przyzwoity, wra¿enie nieco psuje nadmierna ³odygowoœæ
Als Wettelsheimer Wet - Flasche - schönes, rundes Pils. Hopfig, würzig, moderat bitterer Abgang.

Sampled @ omhper, thanks. Lasting white head. Clear yellow color. Fine nobel hop aroma. The nobel hops is also clearly present int he taste that is in perfect balance with booth the malt and the bitterness. Fine body and very enjoyable.

Premium pils bottle in Gunzenhausen. Pour was golden and bubbly, nice white head. Aroma of grains and hay and grass. Flavors followed, some citrus notes under it all and herbs. Mouthfeel refreshing and medium bodied, clean. A nice pils. Good hop assertiveness.
Bottled, thanks Teja! Clear pale golden, brief head. Grassy nose. Dry with light-medium body and firm, crisp mouthfeel. Grassy with some crisp bread. Long bitter finish. Refreshing.
Clear golden color, small white head that leaves a fair lacing. Smell malts, a bit sweetish, grains.

Flasche (33 cl, als Wettelsheimer Wet Premium Pils) bei Erika & Hilde, Berlin-Kreuzberg (wo es so finster war, daß ich die handgeschriebene, stark abgegriffene Speisekarte kaum entziffern konnte). - Herber Antrunk, aber wenig Hopfenaroma. Würzig aber auf Dauer etwas fad. - Durchschnittliches Pils.
Herber Antrunk mit geringem Hopfen. Wenig würzig, etwas trocken, zum Ende bitter-süß. Naja... 9/7/7/7/10/7
Draught at the Bierkeller. Clear amber, medium tan head. Bready, slightly cookiesh and nutty. Semi dry, low biterness. Nice.

500ml bottle from trade with Kolshtrinker. Many thanks chap! Drunk whilst cooking a beetroot and mushroom wellington. Pours clear copper, with the thinnest ring of bubbles atop. Caramel on the nose, good caramel to taste with a confident sweetness, a touch slick on the palate, thin body. A little drying on the close, distant cardboard hints, but generally enjoyable. Appeals to my sweet tooth.

50cl bottle. A clear dark golden beer with a mid-sized most good lasting off-white head. Aroma of toasted malt, mild sweet malt and straw. Taste of medium sweet toasted malt, caramel, mild spicy hops. Good!

Draft at Fränkisches Bierfest in Nürnberg, 2013. Clear auburn. Fine white collar of foam. Nondescript aroma of toasted bread, brown sugar, licorice (Hallertau), plum and a hint of rotting fruit, candy apples and DMS. Firm and pointy carbonation. Initial sip reveals a simplistic maltiness reminiscent of toffee and toasted bread, as a leafy-hop tickle lags behind. Fairly thin, with prominent alcohol thinning out the body. Malt textures never fully bloom, and it’s increasingly flabby akin to wet paper and gummy candy. Merely a suggestion of bread crust. Caramelized sugars are uprooted by an unripe plum twang and a late note of hard peach candy also cripples the malt development. Finishes timidly peppery with licorice-like Hallertau trailed by apple butter, stale apricot, paper, concrete and toast. Pretty defective beer. Not exactly a great first impression from this brewery.

W aromacie s³odowo, kwiaty, zio³a, pieczywo, zbo¿e. W wygl¹dzie klarowne, bursztynowe, piana nik³a. W smaku s³odkie, chlebowe, zio³owe, z lekko przyprawow¹ nut¹, ca³kiem smaczne, pe³ne. Goryczka œrednia, zio³owa. Cia³o œrednie. Bardzo przyzwoite, smaczne marcowe
Clear amber with little white head. Aroma is butter peach fruity stuff. Taste is gummy bear sweetness with some malty accents. Smooth and full bodied. Nice.
Bottle. Nose is bread, honey, wheat. Palate is sweet, grainy, wheat, Malt backbone. Good.
Bottle. Clear golden color with white head. Aroma is nutty, bready, caramel malts. Taste is caramely, nutty, bready, a touch of tartness. Medium carbonation, high drinkability. Quite nice!
OK light brown head. Clear amber color. Apricot aroma with a light roasted maltiness. Complex malt taste with a bit of residual sweetness.
Bottle at Erika & Hilde, Neukölln - rotbraune Farbe, geringe Schaumkrone, recht prickelnd. Würzig, Karamell, leicht blumig. Körper ist recht voll. Gut.

Draught at the brewpub. Clear dark golden color with thin bubbly white head that dissipated quickly and left no lace. Distinct grainy malt extracty aroma with a touch of sprucy hops. Flavor was similar with a sour fruity note and a grainy bitterness. There was also a subdued cleaning-product flavor, a bit like bleach. Wish these guys would consider switching to all grain beers.
On tap at Buffalo Gordon Biersch. Clean, fruity, a bit of spice. Very subtle. Should not have had this AFTER the double IPA. I'd try it again.

Pours a dark, barely translucent honey-golden-brown with a fairly thick and frothy white head. Aroma is strong, yeasty and malty with an undertone of what must be rye. Flavor is malty and yeasty with some of that rye flavor - not complex but still pleasing and enjoyable. Thick, tingly texture leaves behind a good fizzy feeling.

On tap at Restaraunt. Hazy gold with small white head. Aroma of yeast, malt, rye. Flavor of malt, spices, a touch of banana and clove and some breadyness that is very faint. Odd brew, not much flavor to it like most of GB’s other brews.
On tap @ GB (San Diego) - Pours a hazy golden color with thin white film head. Aroma is yeast, sweet malt, and esters. Flavor is malt and spice. Light to medium body. A decent beer.

On Tap at Columbus Microbrew Fest - Poured cloudy copper with a big offwhite foamy head that stayed well. Aromas of bannana, clove, and caramel. Flavor is bannana, clove, toasted malts, and caramel. Medium bodied with soft carbonationa and pretty unique. Enjoyable.

Draft at Columbus, Oh. Poured hazy dark copper with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with very good lacing. Moderate toasted malt, banana and clove aroma. Medium body with a smooth sticky texture with soft carbonation. Medium balanced malty wheat flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. This beer went well with my blue cheese wedge salad.

Sampled at the 2006 Southern Brewers Festival. Did not know this wasn’t in the data base or I would have taken more detailed notes about the beer. In any event, I only noted what I thought about it, not alcohol content or commercial description. Pours hazy orange. Smells like a rye based wheat beer with a semi-sharp nose. Odd but drinkable. Sharp rye mellowed by earthy tones. Dryish full body. Not bad.

Bottle, thanks to WeeHeavySD for sharing! Pours a very light clear yellow. Sweet and dry aroma, of honey, nuts, and fruit. Very dry, crisp taste, of honey, grapes, and alcohol. Lingering dry honey that ends a bit watery. Different and pretty tasty.

750ml from Porterhouse, thanks Kevin! I was just talking about the many Kevin’s I know and now I can add this one. Pours golden pale yellow. Nose is dry and nutty. Taste is sweet, vinous and all in all pretty tasty.
Very pale. Aroma is light honey, and dried fruits. Taste is very watery, with faint honey notes accompanied by the alcohol. The alcohol does not show it’s face much, but the lack of depth killed it.

Bottle from porterhouse; Thanks Kevin!!! Nose sm4ells like a muscato desert wine, not sweet but yeasty and fruity! Translucent pale yellow with a coating of ultra fine bubbles on the sides of the glass; flavor is dry and semi-sweetwith honey and white grape notes; finish has a tiny bit of alcohol warmth. Could have almost passed as a cross between a chardonnay wine and a junmai sake. Wish this bottle had been the 375ml and the Bartlett Sweet was the 750ml!

This draft brew from the brewery poured a medium sized head of frothy light brown colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a no visible carbonation dark ruby red brown colored body. The aroma was malty sweet dark chocolate and dark malt. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The thin yet flavorful flavor contained notes of sweet malt and dark malt. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

On tap at Brockway. Poured a clear mahogany with a short-lived cap of off-white head. Interesting array of coffee, molasses, dark chocolate, and other sugars.. deeper roast to it.. intriguing. Flavor had tasty coffee at the core.. dark chocoate and other deeply-roasted sugars afterward... herbal and soapy notes weren’t as lucrative.. nice coffee again at the finish.. almost a "7". Lighter-bodied with mild bitterness... a tad grainy.. OK feel to it.

Pours mahogany/black with a thin, tan skin. Aroma finds a touch of vinegar to coffee bitters and milk chocolate. Alot of raisin in the flavor before smooth roastiness and a hint of alcohol to finish. I couldn’t find the caramel notes as advertised, but I didn’t mind as this was a fairly solid porter. On tap at Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL 60067

Handsome pour, a deep brown body with ruby highlights an a creamy, dark tan head. Heavy lacing coated the glass to the finish. It smells of lightly roasted barley, caramel, milk chocolate, and coffee grounds. I found it a bit thin, but it still delivered a mouthful of roasted, dark caramelly flavors. Not too shabby. Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL

This draft brew from the brew pub poured a medium sized head of frothy fine to medium sized white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a transparent softly carbonated light orange colored body and a good lacing. The weak aroma was malty. The semi-flat mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The thin flavor contained notes of malt hops and dough. A decent one but not one that I would consider buying again.

On tap at Brockway. Poured a clear lighter golden with a sticky white cap and lacing. Aroma was soft and rather pleasant.. sweet caramel with some floral notes... perhaps a pinch of honey. Soft caramel and honey flavor base with moderate floral and spicy bitterness.. oh-so-slightly toasted.. medium-high pine and floral bitterness through the finish. Just about medium-bodied.. nice consistent bitterness throughout.. felt good.

Served a bright, deep golden under white. MIld aroma: pale malt and mild lagering yeasts next to nothingness. Hallertau presence is surprisingly fat, contributing a smooth, constant bitterness to the flavor. The beer has an identity crisis as mentioned, but I could certainly make this a go-to Pils. On tap at Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL 60067

To me this came across more like a Bohemian Pilsener than it did a Märzen, which is the style it’s called at the brewpub. I probably would’ve scored it higher had it been called something else. The body is a bright gold with a fluffy white head. The aroma is a sweet grainy malt with a light floral/herbal hopping. Medium bodied, the flavor echoes the aroma, finishing on a crisp, bitter note. Okay, but I question the style. Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL

This draft brew from the brew pub poured a medium sized head of frothy white colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a transparent softly carbonated light straw yellow colored body. The mild aroma was malt hop. The semi-flat smooth mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The mild flavor contained notes of corn malt and hops. Not one that I would likely buy again.

On tap at Brockway. Poured a clear, bright pale golden with a pool and a ring of white head. Mild aroma with sweet pale malts, some honey, and a hint of citrus. Flavor found soft pale malts and honey again at the base with a mild floral and lemony bitterness... crisp and quite tasty. Light-bodied but never watery.. ideal medium carbonation... refreshing!

Pours ultra-pale with a short whitey that fades quick to film. No aroma ("subtle" is right!). Flavor finds a thin, light nuttiness to a lagered sourness. Well made... it is what it is. On tap at Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL 60067

This was getting pulled offline at the brewpub because there was yeast in the tank, but that was fine with me. It poured a very pale yellow body, only slightly hazy, with a big creamy head that did some nice lacing. It’s a very light lager, so the malty sweetness was pretty modest, but it was notably adjunct free. It finished a a mild but surprising grassy bitter note. Acceptable warm weather fare. Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL

Mid-golden and clear (yes, clear) with a thin white head above. Alcohol does not hide well beneath mild banana and toasty malts. Fairly sticky palate, overtly sweet with banana and citrus notes. Biscuits linger beneath but the finish is both sweet and sour. There were too many factors that threw me off this beer. On tap at Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL 60067

This had the look of a Kristallweizen, a clear yellow body with a frothy white head. Very creamy mouthfeel. Like the nose, the taste is full of fresh banana, some soft wheat flavors, a dash of clove, and a light lemon twist at the finish. This is good stuff for Summer weather. Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL

This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a transparent typically carbonated light orange colored body and a fair lacing. The mild aroma was hoppy. The crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The mild flavor contained notes of mild hops and mild astringency. Notable abscence of caramel malts. Not one that I would likely buy again.

On tap at Brockway. Poured a clear medium golden with a short white head and sticky lacing. Aroma was sweet, but I couldn’t peg the driver... some pine and citrus bitterness too.. not complex, but I had trouble pegging some elements. Tacky, sweet caramel and bready malts in the flavor with floral hoppage.. medium-high bitterness.. decent balance. Just less than medium-bodied.. OK flow to it.. some spices on the finish.

Soft hop aroma, fruity. Gold body that is mostly clear, slightly hazy. Frothy, off-white head. Excellent lace. Some bubbles. Not very good retention. A pale ale should have more cloudiness like a true ale. Small head also contributed to a relatively low rating for appearance. Not very hoppy at all. A little thin on the palate. Hard to drink. Has a harsh aftertaste. Needs more hops and sweetness. Not a good beer.

Served as a pale, bright amber with constant effervescence and a white halo by the time I got around to it. Dishwater & citrus nose is not the most appealing with more orange than grapefruit. MIld honey under a woodsy bitterness and an ABV hit to follow. Tingly mouthfeel with a dry finish. On tap at Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL 60067

Interesting spin on an ESB in that it relies mainly on the hops for flavor... something that appeals to me. It pours a clear bronze body with a pillowy white head. The aroma is strong with floral hops, the sweet malt barely squeezing through. The flavor begins with some light malts, mayhaps a touch of apple, but then the flowery bitterness rushes forward and takes control. The finish is a prolonged bitterness. Not bad. Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL

50cl bottle from the Mad Squirrel Shop, Chesham. A clear pale amber pour with a fast fading white head; malty aroma with a slight sourness; thin in the mouth with a rather sugary, fruity malt taste; light herbal bitterness and a biscuity finish. A tasty bitter.

(Cask at Southampton Arms, Gospel Oak, London, 20 April 2017) Pale amber colour with foamy, off-white head. Fruity, malty nose with apricots, orange peel and a touch of caramel. Malty, fruity taste with notes of apricots, orange peel, toast and a balanced citric, slightly earthy, bitterness. Light body, with a touch of sweetness. Tasty and well balanced. Quite nice.

Cask, Barking Smack Great Yarmouth. Golden amber appearance with creamy white lasting head. Light aroma of malt and subtle fruits. Smooth taste, nothing too strong, malts and some hoppy flavours with a dry but refreshing aftertaste. Easy drinking session beer.
Cask @ Spread Eagle, Ipswich. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are fruits, wood, flowers, hops and malt. Nice bitter finish.
Cask @ Spread Eagle, Ipswich. Pours golden with an offwhite head. Aroma of malt, grain, grass, wood. Flavor is light sweet, malt, grainy, grass, wood. Medium body, average carbonation. 150217
Cask @ Spread Eagle, Ipswich. Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and caramel. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 150217

Cask at the Spread Eagle, Ipswich. Pours pale amber with a lasting bubbly off white head. Aroma is light floral, hoppy, caramel and fruity notes Medium sweetness, moderate but sharp bitterness. Quite light bodied, slight sticky texture. This is a nice light very drinkable floral fruity bitter

Bottles from Coppers, Newcastle and Bakers & Larners, Holt, Norfolk. Golden coloured with a sweet toffee, malty and citrus flavour followed by an earthy and gentle woody finish. Excellent considering the low ABV.

Cask at The Ship Inn, Dunwich, Suffolk, Saturday, ’Boxing Day’ 25th December 2015 Warm gold with a tiny white head, good clarity. Safe and traditional bitter, middling bitterness, nothing to get excited about it’s fine. A6 A4 T6 P3 Ov11 3.0

Backlog rating. Cask at Kings Arms, London. It pours a clean golden color with small off-white head. Aroma is biscuit, bread dough, caramel. Taste has more dough, bread, biscuit and some light bitter grassy notes. Light bodied with ok carbonation. Overall, decent

Cask conditoned - gravity dispense - Peterborough BF. A copper coloured beer with some lemon and some phenolic notes in the aroma. The taste has a touch of citric hoppiness. It is a light beer with maybe some orange notes also. Easy going and acceptable.

Cask conditoned - gravity dispense - Peterborough BF. A copper to orange coloured beer. The aroma is straw like with some nasty grassy notes. The taste replicates the aroma. Tastes a bit like hay dipped in brandy. Very disappointing.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Peterborough BF. A hazy orange coloured beer. The aroma is citric with orange notes and some spices. The taste is yeasty and dry. Some phenolic notes. Tastes like a Hefe but smells like a Wit. A bit of a mish-mash, but tasty nonetheless.
Bottle 0,3ltr: Clear orange coloured brew with an sweet fruity and floral taste. Decent beer indeed.
C: Hazy yellow to orange. S: Wort and hay. T: Wort and hay. P: Quite a sticky mouthfeel.
Hazy yellow orange color, smalle white head. Smell wort, barnyard, citrus and light alcohol. Pretty standard tripel taste. Little sticky. Carbo and body decent.
Just bitterness and burned flavor. Hard to discern any flavor. Will still finish it but won’t have it again.
30cl, exclusive Dutch brewfirm, from Slijterij van Bergen Eindhoven, complex brew, balanced, hazy, small head, nice brew
Bottle from Mitra van Bergen. Murky light orange body with lasting head. Sweet, floral and slightly sweet nose. Nice taste of oranges, citrus and fruits. Smooth texture. Pretty good.
Clear orange pour, small head. Aroma is malty, too malty, with faint yeast and fruit. Flavour is too sweet of malts with fruit. Disappointment.

A clear golden colored beer, with a thick foamy white head. The aroma of malts with fruits like citrus and yeast. The taste is dry with bitter and fruity sweet. There are some grains. The Aftertaste is sweet with bitter.

Darker blond coloured beer with lots of carbonation and an average white head. Malty aroma with some light yeasty and alcoholic touches. Full yeasty bitter palate. Finish is again bitter, fruity yeasty touched with and underlying hoppy hint. Long full ending, nicely balanced.
Dark blonde color, cloudy. Anis, cake dough and malt in the aroma. Sweet, rather alcoholic flavor with anis and vanilla. I prefer the aroma to the flavor.
Softly malty with a bit of toasty character. Some light sweetness and a bit of light breadiness with a bit of light pepper. Has a decent sweetness and a bit of grassiness. Pretty nice.
Tap. Pours clear reddish amber, small off white head, some lacing. Aroma of caramel, light pine. Flavor is the same, light sweet, light bitter, light metal finish. Light body, creamy mouthfeel
Draft at Anacapa. Nose is caramel, with hints of bubblegum and roast. Clear amber with a small beige head. Flavor is lightly bitter with some light caramel. Nice lightly bitter amber.

A clear red/amber color with an off-white head. Malt forward amber ale with caramel, toffee, and toasted bread up front on the nose. Some mild hop aromas, mostly floral and citrus peel, maybe a hint of pine. The taste is also on the sweet side with toffee and bread providing most of the flavor. A hint of pine, some light citrus fruit and peel notes, and a mild bitterness on the finish.
Clear golden with a fizzy white head. Rich butterscotch and malt aroma and taste with a dry butter and bread finish.

Light brown with reddish tinge, fine long-lasting head. Very malty, toasty aroma with light hops - nice. Full, slightly sweet malty flavor. Fairly bitter, lightly tannic finish, maybe a touch harsh in some way. Very toasty overall, about what I’d go for when brewing a red ale.

Aroma of floral hops over red berries. Appears a red amber color with a small white head and no noticeable effervescence. Flavor of biscuit malt with a nice hop bite - could use a bit more malt sweetness. Palate is light to medium-light and quite pleasant. Overall, a decent red ale.

So successfully received last year, this was brought back as the summer seasonal once again. Murky straw yellow with a thick dense merangue of a head that demonstrates excellent retention. Fresh zesty lemon and wheat aroma with a vaquelly vanilla quality as well. Mildly sweet and spicy, wheaty, with a refreshing citrus note and a soft mouthfeel. Very well done!

I really like the pints of this I had during the World Cup. The beer was refreshing and had a nice fresh spice flavour. I even bought 20 liters for home. At home there was a strong lemon butter flavour that I hadn’t noticed in the pints at the pub. 6 weeks later I found the same notes in a pint at the brewpub and switched to the Pale. Rating is a bit of a split between fresh and lightly aged.
Draught at the brewpub Hazy blond color; creamy head. It has a sourish aroma and a quite dry mouthfeel, a bit acid as well, and very little wheat character. Refreshing.

(Draught) Sampled at the Great Canadian Beer Festival 2007 in Victoria on September 8th, 2007. ART-Y-FIC-IAL... Nose of yeasty wheaty base. Minor apple flavour with a cider basis. Bad. 4/3/4/1/6. Re-rate: (Draught) Sampled at the Great Canadian Beer Festival in Victoria, BC, September 8th 2008. Thin, white foamy head atop a cloudy golden body. Nose of tart, wet wheat and cardboard. Clean, mild and spicy flavour. Not the best example of this style but passable. 3/4/7/3/13
Hazy yellow. Light banana, marshmallow and melon on the nose. Thinnish, grainy, slightly acidic character. OK, but that’s it.

After the seasonal offerings of kolsch and witbier ran dry, they have treated us to this little gem. A hazy honey yellow with a creamy white head. Banana and a touch of vanilla aroma. Mostly banana in the palate, very subtle spiciness, and a citrusy tartness to the finish. Nice.

Yellow and with more aggressive spice than Brian’s Wit. Just a touch of the butter notes that were in the Wit at the end of the batch. I hope that this one ages a little better. A nice refreshing beverage a week before it hits the tap. Surprising in that it is the same yeast as Brewsters new Hefe.

On tap at Stonefly brewpub. Murky amber with a thin off-white head and some lacing. Aroma of grapefruit, pine, caramel and heavy floral hops. Hopped up and hoppy. Taste is a grapefruit burst mixed with some orange, mild pine and caramel. Moderately bitter on the finish along with mild acidity. As an IPA, this one set out what it was suppose to do and did not disappoint.

Sampled on draught at the GTMW ’08. Pours a semi-clear golden orange brew with a thin white head that quickly dissipates to a thin white ring and some spotty lacing. Aroma of a good balance of caramel malt, grapefruit and citrus zest with a touch of pine. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonated with a more grapefruit flavor that hides some of the caramel malt flavors. Finish is mildly IPA bitter with a light aftertaste of grapefruit and citrus zest. Pretty much an average IPA overall.

On tap at Stonefly. Poured translucent orangey-golden with a short cap of white head. The aroma picked up nice doses of grapefruit and caramel with a touch of pine.. juicy!.. weak off-notes of vomit threw me off, but this was otherwise solid. Juicy orange and grapefruit bitterness steal the show in the flavor (which is a good thing).. pine provides more bitterness on the back-end.. grapefruit meat and caramel support all this hoppage well.. bitter and tasty overall. Well-balanced on the palate, and the lingering bitterness stuck around for a while.. warm, yet refreshing.

On tap at Thirsty Troll Brewfest As things wound down I decided to give this a shot. The pickings were slim by now for finding new beers and I wasn’t quite ready to fall back to the Ale Asylum standbys. This was a complete contrast to the Two Hearted. Whereas it embodied all the possibilities of an IPA this one barely passed muster. It’s not bad for a brewpub release but it doesn’t set itself apart. Aroma / Appearance - The body was a golden wheat color that was just a little different. Active carbonation percolated to the top regularly. Grain, caramel and hops formed a creamy nose that was inviting but not unique. It lacks the punch one normally associates with an IPA. Flavor / Palate - Unlike the nose the body is all business. I was immediately able to pick up the bitterness which hangs around a long time. Cookie dough, citrus and string pine notes kept me busy before the fading finish. It wasn’t a bad IPA but it just felt a little unbalanced.

Cloudy orange body, foamy white head. The bitter side of resinous grapefruit hops and lightly sweet crystal malt make up the aroma. A tasty pale malt base undergirds the same strong grapefruit rind and plant stem hohps. The bitterness is approaching harsh because it’s a dry beer and there isn’t a lot of citrus flesh hop flavor. Still, it’s very drinkable and well balanced.

Listed as 7%. Pours to a very hazy caramel amber body with a thin white head. The aroma is hard to distinguish over the nasty stale cigarette smoke air. I about gag from the sheer amount of nasty smell in this brewpub, and there’s only about a dozen people here and nobody’s smoking. WTF! The flavor is bitter grassy pine hops. Bitter oily resins linger in the sharp palate. Quite decent for $2.50 a pint at a bar. The palate is "harsh" with tons of oils. This one’s a drinkable local brew when you want to go out, get hammered, and only spend $15 all night. Aroma definitely affected by smoky atmosphere. This brew is up there in IBU... 80+.

This poured the appropriate color for an IPA...it is an amber color but lacked a sparkling brilliance that is usually present in professionally produced beers of this style. The head was rather weak and didn’t linger. The beer smelled faintly of hops, and had an expected hop bitterness. However, this taste was accompanied a sourness that was off. Mouthfeel was a bit flat and watery. I didn’t find this beer very drinkable.
Hazy Dark amber color with a moderate off-white head. Orange and yeast aromas. Dusty yeast flavors that I found in the IS as well. Woody and dry malt flavors Quite traditional.
On tap. Very light golden in colour with almost no head. Malty and slightly sweet. A bit grassy and maybe a weak hint of caramel. Kinda refreshing.

Tap @ Mesa, Az. Location. Malty and sweet aroma. Dark golden body with thin head. Flavor was maybe overly sweet as some bock’s can be for me anyway. Some toffee flavor as well. Medium bodied beer that left a candy toffee aftertaste on palate.

Straw color with a flimsy white dissipating head. Scents of dough and light wild flowers. A touch of soap in the background. Not sure if it’s the glass or the beer, but either way the lack of substance shows. Light malt and grain flavors. A hint os green hops come in the middle and departs quickly. Hit and run brew.

On tap at brew pub. Again, This place is great food but they have to step up on the beer! Light yellow/golden color. Smell of light hops, bread, citrus and a little toasted malt. Tastes the same but very light and watery. Almost tasted like a lite beer from Miller. Refeshing, YES, but won’t drink it again.

Available on tap only at the brewpub near Waukesha, WI. Pours a clear, light golden pale brew with some lacing and no head. Aroma of very light citrus hops, some wonder bread dough, and saw dust. Taste is watered down, highly carbonated, and a too clean finish. Hardly any aftertaste to this. I have no doubt it’ll keep the diet beer drinkers happy.
On tap at brew pub. Pours a dark yellow/aber color. Has a slight bready/hop aroma to it. Taste of what a homebrewed pilsner would taste like. Slightly watery,but very drinkable on a hot day.
On tap at the Longneck Brew Pub. Poured a medium amber color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of grains, somewhat earthy, and toasted caramel. Tastes of graininess, toasted and caramel.

On tap at Longnecks Brew Pub. Amber with a thin white head. Light aromas of sweet malts and mild hops. Taste of caramel, sweet malts and mild hops. Semi-thin body finishes somewhat dry with a mostly tasteless hop finish.

Dark copper to light brown color with a diminishing off-white head. Mild caramel aromas with a backdrop of some earth and weedy hops. Flavors seem to match the aromas with a touch of toasted grain, light caramel, with earthy hops coming in the middle. Quite thin in both flavor and feel.

This beer’s name is actually called "Longneck’s Amber Grains of Wayne" named after Wayne S., part owner and brewmaster. Pours a hazy light brown brew with a fast dissolving off white head. Aroma is minmal with some caramel, light grassy hops, and earthy malt. Taste has some character of cardboard, earthy bitterness, and some-what watered down carbonation. Light body is any. Finish is more like a pilsner than a amber ale. Probably one of the brewpub’s best brews.

On tap at brew pub. light brown color with small whitish head.Hard to pick up any aromas maybe a little malt. Has a nice malt flavor with a hint of hop bite. A little watery though. I would say this is there best brew.
Another watered down brew from Long Necks. Some caramel maltiness of the tongue and a small amount of East Kents are apparent as well. Not a good representation of the style.

column1: LongNecks Endless Summer Light Wheat Ale
column5: On tap at the Longneck Brew Pub. Served with a slice of lemon. Poured a lighter and cloudy golden color with a small sized head. Aromas of sweaty wheat and some citrus (from the lemon?). Tastes of wheat, citrus, and grainy. Fizzy, light and thin body.

column1: LongNecks Endless Summer Light Wheat Ale
column5: On tap at Longnecks Brew Pub. Pale yellow with a thin white head. Aroma of corn and perfumed malts. Flavor of corn, lemon, wheat all wrapped up in a thin body that’s too bland and astringent.

column1: LongNecks Endless Summer Light Wheat Ale
column5: Pours hazey light golden body, hardly any distinct nuances in the aroma. Very plan, and watery. Over malted- trying not to be too critical, but it was a sad representation of this style.

column1: LongNecks Endless Summer Light Wheat Ale
column5: Lightly hazed, light straw color with a somewhat fizzy white head. Seem to catch more glass cleaner soap than beer aromas. Some hint of citrus and maybe a touch of wheat. Watery wheat and and light citrus flavors. Finish is dry and again watery. A mix of an american wheat and a weak pale lager.

column1: LongNecks Endless Summer Light Wheat Ale
column5: Available only at the brewpub on tap. Remember to ask bartender to place lemon off to the side. Pours a light clear pale golden brew with a fast dissolving white head. No lacing. Aroma has hardly any scent. Just barely any citrus and hay to the nose. Taste is very light body, highly carbonated, and watered down beer. Hardly any wheat taste. Finish is clean and no after taste. At least the lemon will give it some flavor.

column1: LongNecks Endless Summer Light Wheat Ale
column5: this stuff is crap.. boring water... not worth the rating... thank god I was coming down from a skydiving rush or I’d have been really po’d

column1: LongNecks Endless Summer Light Wheat Ale
column5: Has a nice color to it with a small white head.Not much more to say about it.Has a faint citrus aroma to it.Not much of the typical wheat beer flavor to it.Seemed to be watery.

column1: LongNecks Endless Summer Light Wheat Ale
column5: Very watered down wheat beer, faint aroma of grass. Clear blond color. Really nothing here, a wheat beer for the masses.
Bottle courtesy Alex. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Amber colour. Light malty and hoppy and vinius aroma. Sour. Grapes present. Heavy sour flavor. Long delicate nice finish. Oily palate.
Bottle at Alex’s. Thanks. Pours a hazy brown. Tart. Aromas of earth and resin. Slightly moldy. Some berry aromas. Oxidized? Cork? Tart and bitter finish.
Pours hazy brown with with a small tan head. Dry mouldy and earthy. Wineous, fruity and light yeasty. Wineous and fruity. Dry wooden and earthy. Ends dry and slight wineous citric.

Bottle at Alex. Hazy red coloured with a small off-white head. Fruity and light acidic aroma of red wine, earth, oak and mould. Fruity and light acidic flavour of red wine with notes of oak and earth. fruity finish.
Copper with a small off-white head. Aroma dominated by dusty cellar notes with berries and a hint of wood. Dry, slightly tart, dusty malt and fruit flavour

Bottle 750ml. @ RBESG10 in Brasserie 4:20, Via Portuense 82, Roma, Italy. Clear medium to dark amber color with a small, fizzy, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, damp stained, keller, earth, wood, grape. Flavor is light heavy sweet and moderate acidic with a long duration, berry - grape tart. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100606]
6th June 2010. Bottle at Brasserie 4:20. Clear brown beer. No head. Sherryish sour nose. Light dry palate. Dusty malt and sour with a dash of cider. Really not good.
Bottle at RBESG 2010, Rome. Clear deep red/brown - offwhite head. Mouldy. Fruity. Rubber. Light acid. Fruity. High malty. Grapes. Nutty. Light rotten. Sweetness. A bit wierd.
0,5 l Flasche aus einem lokalen Getränkemarkt. Goldgelb, klar mit feiner Schaumkrone. In der Nase grasig, im Geschmack grasig, hopfig, intensiv bitterer Abgang

It’s golden with a creamy, white head. The aroma has notes of straw, malt and a hint of celluloses. The flavour has a light to moderate sweetness woth notes of straw, malt, grass, and the finish is dry – it’s refreshing.

Bottle: Clear, golden coloured, stable foam like beaten egg-white; distinctive sweet-malt in the nose, supported by some "oaky" hops...; moderate sweet-bitter flavour, soft MF; short sweet-aromatic-bitter finish. Who needs a Warsteiner.............?

(bottle) Clear, greenish golden colour with a thick and persistent fomy white head, slowly lacing. Moderately sweet grainy aroma with honey, hay and spicy hops. Swet-bitter flavour, light to medium body, soft carbonation. Rather malt-accented taste with a touch of honey and a balanced herbal hoppy note; moderately dry and bitter finish. Pleasant Pilsener.
Bottle, bought at the brewery. Golden color, hay aroma. Malty hay-like flavor with some hops. Grassy bitter aftertaste. Rural beer, but with a fairly clean mouthfeel.
Bottle. Pale golden, low white head. Juicy grainy aroma, grassy hops. Medium body, chewy grainy, hayish retronasal, grassy light herbal hops, a bit Landbierisch.
Bottle from a local supermarket - clear golden color, white head. simple and average Helles. okay.
50cl bottle. Pours clear golden colour with a mid-sized most good lasting white head. Aroma of grains, pale malt, mild hops. Taste of mild bitter hops, spices, grains.

0,5 Euro-Flasche aus einem lokalen Getränkemarkt. Helles, klares Bier mit mittelmäßig Kohlensäure und einer kleinen Schaumkrone. Riecht sehr nach Weizen, leicht würzig. Im Geschmack leicht süßlich, Weizen und ganz leichte hopfenbittere. Nichts besonderes
0,5l Flasche. Hellgelbes Bier mit kleiner Schaumkrone. Riecht süßlich malzig. Schmeckt auch so zum Schluß etwas wässrig.

Poores into the glass in appealing golden brown color. Foam is not vary stable. Sweet aroma of malt, little hop aroma. Tastes malty, not much hop aroma or bitterness. Quite sweet. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It’s golden with a creamy, white head. The aroma has notes of malt, flower, light straw and hints of raw meat. The flavour is moderately sweet with the same notes as the aroma. The finish is bone dry, light bitter and also slightly sweet.

Bottle: Almost creamy, stable white head, a bit lacing, golden coloured; traces of herbal hops in the sweet grainy and malty nose (background in the barnyard detectable...); light to medium bodied, first comes a bitter flavour, rounded by some sweet-malty traces; hoppy sweet finish with an rural aftertaste. A well crafted and spicy franconian Helles.........

(bottle) Clear, pale golden colour with a foamy white medium head. Soft malty aroma with hay and distinctive herbal hoppy notes. Moderately bitter flavour with a sweetish edge, light to medium bodied, moderately carbonated mf. Restrained malt-character with herbal hops and a rural touch from the beginning. Aromatic, dry and moderately bitter and hoppy finish. Pleasant, hop-accented, thus a bit uncommon Helles.
Bottle, bought at the brewery. Grassy aroma. Thin, hoppy and grassy flavor with a hint of apple. Light bitter aftertaste. In Ordnung!

.33l bottle @ Hanniku’s Cave. Pours clear copper with low head. Aroma is malts, caramel, bread, strawberry, alcohol. Malts is caramel, dark malts, honey, strawberry, taffy notes. Medium body. Easy to drink. Nice beer!
50cl bottle. A clear golden beer with a small white head. Aroma of mid sweet grainy pale malt, hints of honey. Taste of sweet pale malt, straw, honey, slightly boozy. Okay!
Bottle Thanks to Beerhunter111. Golden body with white head Aroma is malts with hints of alcohol and fruits. Taste is malts alcohol some artifical sweetness. Aftertaste is sweet.
Pours a deep yellow color with a small head. Aroma of some caramel, malts and caramel.

on tap at fraenkisches bierfest 2013 in nuremberg, listed as wettelsheimer maibock. clear pale copper with a persistent bubbly head; aroma of wet tin and soggy grain; lightly grassy, plenty of alcohol showing, tinny finish

Hellmalziger und deutlich süßer Antrunk, in dem die Herbe fast etwas verloren dasteht. Honigartig süß im Mittelteil, dazu leicht bananig. Zum Ende hin auch etwas alkoholisch, was das Malz unterstützt. Insgesamt ausgewogen. Harzig, hellmalzig aromatisch, hintergründig hopfig, was schwer vom hellen Malz zu trennen ist. Ein nicht unbedingt komplexer, insgesamt aber gut gelungener Bock mit ansprechender Intensität, zumeist vollmundig.

column1: Three Cats Yarlington Mill SV Cider (Draught)
column5: Polypin at Merton Summer Beer Festival 05-07-07 Tried this before the beer festival started. Poured a warm golden colour and was very interesting to contrast the appearance of this single varietal cider with the Olivers version of the Yarlington Mill the latter was much lighter. Plenty of nice scrumptious apples in the nose taste was crisp and dryish but nice apple flavours swishing around, this was very good from the East Midlands only cider producer (so I’m told)

column1: Three Cats Yarlington Mill SV Cider (Draught)
column5: From the barrel - Peterborough BF. A bright orange coloured cider. The aroma is apply with good alcohol notes. The taste is on the dry side with some tannin notes. A good effort from the tiniest of producers of which little is known!!

A hazy, pale yellow coloured, still perry. A light, sour, fruity nose, only a tiny hint of pears though. The taste is sour and sharp, fruity again, but still no apprent pear element, apples and citrus fruit more than anything! The festival programme, and the cask announced this to be only 7%(Cask - 2007 Cambridge Beer Festival).

From the barrel - Peterborough BF. A gereeny white coloured cider. The aroma is slightly medicinal. There are no obvious pear notes and it’s not to welcoming. The taste is very lemony and astringent. Again no signs of pears. A bit odd and not too likable.

Box, William Wygston, Wigston. Hazy golden with no carbonation. Pulpy but not overly sweet apple with a woody dryness. Earthy and bittersweet with some green apple tanginess. Lightly funky barnyard character with yeast. Dry finish. Good cider with lots of character.

Cask handpull at The Crosse Keys London as Perry’s Redstreak, 6.1%. Three stars at the Great Taste awards! Yet a poor RB score. Who to believe? Pours a pale golden yellow, still and clear with a small bubbly off white head. Aroma is intense stewed spiced apple, apple sourz, sugary. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is smooth sugary apple flesh, lightly tart, some crisp pear juice. Very popular with the flies in this establishment. I like it too. Very drinkable. (6-3-7-4-15=3.5)
