Tap at the brewery. Pours hazy yellow with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is creamed corn, Pils malt, and earthy hops with a light fruitiness. Flavor is light floral hops and bitterness, Pils malt and a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

Draft at brewpub on 08/26/06. Pale color with an average fizzy white head that diminished slowly with fair lacing. Moderate complex sweet spicy aroma. Light to medium body with a sticky texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration.

Pours light yellow and hazy with a thin white, maintained head. Aroma of flowers, lavender, bubble gum, and honey. Tastes of honey, light toasted malt, saffron, and lavender. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and slightly sticky with lush carbonation.

column1: Bluegrass Chris Cold Cocked Malt Liquor
column5: Draft at brewpub on 08/26/06. Dark pale color with an averaqge fizzy white head that mostly diminished with fair lacing. Moderate grainy aroma. Light to medium body with an oily texture with soft carbonation. Medium sweetbitter flavor with a medium bitter finish of moderate duration. Drinkable bber.

column1: Bluegrass Chris Cold Cocked Malt Liquor
column5: Pours light golden and clear with a thin white head. Aroma is grainy and husky with notes of corn. Taste is sweet, malty and slightly sticky. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with lively carbonation. A pretty good malt liquor, not unclean tasting, but full bodied and sticky.
Wässriger Beginn, spät etwas bitter. Metallern, plörrig, billig. Die Aromen steigern sich leider in Mittelteil und Nachgeschmack. Schlecht. 8/6/5/5/5/5
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig malzig, grasig. Geschmack hopfig bitter, malzig, leicht würzig.
It’s golden with a creamy, white head. The aroma has notes of grain, straw and flower. The flavor has a light sweetness and notes like the aroma, and the finish is rather dry.
Yellow with a small white head. Weak fruity and grainy aroma. Sweet grainy flavour with notes of hay and fruit.

Clear, yellow colour with a mid-sized foamy white head. Medium to light bitter flavor, light body, slim and slightly fizzy mouthfeel. Nothing special here, a less then average outing for a German pilsener. I haven’t too many bad beers here, but this one is below average.

50 cl bottle. Rated on 20.10.2010 A bit dark-yellow color, thick and disappearing head. Basic aroma to pils with butter. Rather harsh hops in the flavour, also some butter. Too much CO2 on palate, the harsh hops linger in the aftertaste. Not my kind of pils.

0.5 l bottle. Golden color. Malty aroma with herbal-peppery hops in the background. Dry malty flavor with herbal-peppery hops and hint of metal. Dry crisp bitterness in finish. Not very fresh bottle (BB Dec 2010) but still fairly enjoyable dry pilsner.

.5L bottle - Shared this one w/ SkyCop32. Pours a nice golden yellow color with a minimal fizzy white head. Aromas of grains, straw, hops, and a hint of fruit. Flavor is a nice crisp pilsner taste. Starts grainy with touches of pepper and fruit and finishes with a mellow hop.

Bottle 50cl. Clear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, toasted, moderate hoppy, grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is light medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light metalic. [20091004]

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Clear golden with a small lacing white head. Malty aroma. Medium body, malty but not the best quality malts, a little soapy with a distinct metallic touch. Subdued bitterness. 041009
Quality beer with a light finish for a darker porter— some aftertaste though ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle. Opaque dark brown pour.msmall creamy tan cap. Rich roasted malt aroma is reminiscent of prune and Worcestershire sauce. First sip has notes of soy sauce and roasted portobello mushrooms. Subtle notes of licorice, balsamic vinegar and plums. Medium bodied as you would expect for a Baltic Porter. Complexity grows as brew warms. Outstanding!

Bot. 2014 vintage Aroma: not super complex but with neat depth, coffee, soy sauce, alcohol, and coffee. Look: poured dark brown, smallish tanned ring on glass of foam. Palate: full bodied, smooth, creamy, slight side astringency. Taste: soy with mix of dark chocolate and coffee. Perhaps a bit past its prime. Old school feel.

Black hue with a thin light beige cap. Nose has a light touch of soy sauce, soft German pretzel, dark roasty malts, a kiss of licorice and a semisweet touch of earthy cocoa. Smooth flavor that’s got some cocoa and licorice and anise and dark malty roasty slickness. Kinda weird and all over but full, slick, and a little boozy.
Aroma is caramel, chocolate, dried berries and ash. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter. Medium body, sticky feel with average carbonation.

2/17/19 - Tallahassee, Fl - Market Square Liquors - 12 oz bottle. Purple-black pour, thin bubbly bone colored head. Dates and rum raisin aroma. Rib-sticking flavor brown sugar, plum fruitinees, dates, canned baked brown bread. Chewy, thick rich mouthfeel.

No surprise Duck-Rabbit nails the Baltic porter so well; these guys know dark beer, and their spot-on version of a difficult style only furthers this assertion. Deep veins of chocolate and dark fruit are layered on top mild notes of anise and bitter coffee. Never grows roasty, though, staying firmly entrenched in the classic porter unsweetened cocoa profile. Not a trace of the 9% ABV, and the fade leaves lingering traces of pumpernickel bread and pitch-black chocolate. Very nice.

Bottle. Deep brown-black. Mostly opaque. Aroma is of alcohol, sweet malt and some darker malt. Pretty good - strong, malty with darker malt flavor. Only downside is it's a bit too sweet. Almost like an ale version of a darker doppelbock.

12 ounce bottle into snifter; not sure on bottle dating, but has the 12 notched out on the label. Pours opaque dark brown/black color with a small dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin lace cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of big milk/dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, caramel, brown sugar, molasses, toffee, nuttiness, and toasted dark/brown bread; with lighter notes of licorice, raisin, plum, prune, fig, date, cherry, sherry, smoke, charcoal, leather, tobacco, herbal, grass, and yeast/roast/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/roast/bready malt and light fruity yeast/earthy hop notes; with great strength. Taste of big milk/dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, caramel, brown sugar, molasses, toffee, nuttiness, and toasted dark/brown bread; with lighter notes of licorice, raisin, plum, prune, fig, date, cherry, sherry, smoke, charcoal, leather, tobacco, herbal, grass, and yeast/roast/toasted earthiness. Very minimal herbal/roast bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of milk/dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, caramel, brown sugar, molasses, toffee, nuttiness, toasted dark/brown bread, licorice, dark fruit, smoke, leather, tobacco, herbal, grass, and yeast/roast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt and light fruity yeast/earthy hop flavors; with a nice roast/hop bitter/sweet balance; and zero cloying/acrid/astringent flavors after the finish. Minimal dryness. Light carbonation and medium-full body; with a very smooth, creamy/silky/bready/grainy, and slightly sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is great. Minimal warming alcohol for 9%. Overall this is an awesome Baltic porter! All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt and light fruity yeast/earthy hop flavors; very smooth and easy to sip on for the ABV, with minimally bitter/drying finish. Very rich malt complexity, and complementing restrained dark fruity yeast notes. A very enjoyable and spot on style example. Not sure of the age, but likely has a couple years on it. Very impressive.

The aroma is licorice and figs/dates, smells delicious! Pours a dark brown almost black with amber hues, light tan head fully diminishing. The taste is medium sweet/sour. The body is medium/full, the texture creamy, the carbonation lively and the finish long. Sorry but I don't like the flavor/taste of this. For me it is nauseous, a little sickly sweet and not to my liking at all.

column1: St. John Brewers Virgin Islands Tropical Mango Pale Ale
column2: Cruz Bay, St. John, United States Virgin Islands
column4: St. John Brewers - The Tap Room
column5: Wypite na BVI . Kolor pomarañczowy, mêtne, znikoma piana. Zarówno w aromacie jak i w smaku dominuje mango i owoce tropikalne. Orze¿wiaj¹ce, mocno owocowe, piwo na upa³y w tropikach.

column1: St. John Brewers Virgin Islands Tropical Mango Pale Ale
column2: Cruz Bay, St. John, United States Virgin Islands
column4: St. John Brewers - The Tap Room
column5: Pours orange amber with thin head. Aroma is (surprise!) mango and slight caramel. Taste is sweet mango with an ever so slight hop backbone building. Finish is slight hoppiness. Would be a decent beer on a hot, summer day.

column1: St. John Brewers Virgin Islands Tropical Mango Pale Ale
column2: Cruz Bay, St. John, United States Virgin Islands
column4: St. John Brewers - The Tap Room
column5: Nicely done. Good mango influence with a hoppy finish. Crisp and clean. Other tropical notes.

column1: St. John Brewers Virgin Islands Tropical Mango Pale Ale
column2: Cruz Bay, St. John, United States Virgin Islands
column4: St. John Brewers - The Tap Room
column5: Mild and fruity. Pours golden with a dense aroma. Mango and tropical fruit, a little grassy hops and overall has a decent balance.

column1: Ballast Point Black Marlin Porter - Bourbon Barrel
column5: Sample at beer junction. My first impression is why is there mint in this. As it’s starts to warm there is more cola flavor that makes and appearance. Not bad, could use a little work.

column1: Ballast Point Black Marlin Porter - Bourbon Barrel
column5: Black pour with a thin beige head .... Aroma of dark fruity yeast, caramel malts, dry oak and light bourbon .... taste is of caramel malts, vanilla, coconut, bourbon, dry oak, molasses and roasted malts ..... Finish is dry sweet and oaky with candi sugar, molasses .... Solid and tasty

column1: Ballast Point Black Marlin Porter - Bourbon Barrel
column5: Growler from SJ. Nice notes of Wood, bourbon, roasted malts, chocolate and hop. Nice roasted finish, good booze flavor, not bad.

column1: Ballast Point Black Marlin Porter - Bourbon Barrel
column5: Draft. Exceedingly dark brown, small bright tan head. Jack Daniels completely overwhelms both the aroma and the taste.

column1: Ballast Point Black Marlin Porter - Bourbon Barrel
column5: Snifter on tap at the Brass Tap. Near-black color, with a good thin khaki head. Leaves nice, thicker lace. Medium to bigger body. Velvety smooth, lighter carbonation. Lightly slick texture. Very nice, noticeable amount of bourbon barrel, big vanilla, and lightly woody, spicy whiskey flavors work great with the chocolate, light coffee flavors of the porter. Moderate bitter, moderate sweet taste, and just a mild hint of bourbon-type alcohol warmth that is actually pretty pleasant in this application. Fantastic barrel-aged porter, very satisfying. Supremely enjoyable, well-done stuff. Strikes a near-perfect balance. I’m ok with paying $6.50 for the 10oz glass.

column1: Ballast Point Black Marlin Porter - Bourbon Barrel
column5: On tap at The Local in San Diego. Dark brown pour with ruby on the edges and a small khaki head. Aroma is some light roast, heavy sherry and rum booze (does not smell like bourbon here). Flavor is a rather disgusting combination of roast and straight up cheap whiskey (oh, hey Black Velvet) and is barely drinkable. Way light bodied, way to thin for the bourbon barrel aging. I could not finish a 3 ounce taster of this one. It was really bad.

column1: Ballast Point Black Marlin Porter - Bourbon Barrel
column5: On nitro at Old Grove. Pours a pitch black with a thick tan Head with exellcent lacing. Aroma is of bourbon, roasted malts, coco, and a little booze. Taste is similar to the aroma but also has some coffee and grassy hop notes. Has a medium body with a slighty watery mouthfeel and a slighty bitter, medium finish. Overall, a pretty nice BA porter.

column1: Ballast Point Black Marlin Porter - Bourbon Barrel
column5: Tap at Churchill’s for SDBW. Pours a deeper brown, cola highlights. Low foam. Mild bourbon nose, small sugar, no tomato past, small vanilla. Taste is thinner than expected, watery, low abv can’t handle the barrel aging. Didn’t come out as intended.

column1: Ballast Point Black Marlin Porter - Bourbon Barrel
column5: Cola, oak, and chocolate aromas. Bourbon kicks in on the first sip. Good body. Slightly sweet with dark fruits and licorice in the finish.

column1: Ballast Point Black Marlin Porter - Bourbon Barrel
column5: On draught at Aces & Ales in Las Vegas. Pours dark brown with a medium foamy tan head that diminishes gradually. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla and malt. Medium-bodied with flavors of roasted malt, oaky bourbon and vanilla. The finish is mildly boozy with a roasty malt aftertaste. Pretty good all around.

I don’t know if the information I entered is correct, but it’s my best guess. Poured a hazy copper-brown (although the light was low, and it was hard to tell), and tasted of wheat and malt with some light spice, not as much as other dunkels (if that’s even what this is). Enjoyable, but the flavor in the finish wasn’t as great as others I’ve tried (still not bad).

Draught at 2nd Annual Festival of Iowa Beers. Use your imagination as far as what "WTF" stands for. The brewer described it as an unfiltered American wheat dry hopped with amarillo gold hops. The beer was a hazy yellow-brown color without any head. Smelled of flowery hops and pear. Interesting flavor with cereal grian, white bread, caramel, and fruity hop notes. Finished with some hop bitterness. Not bad.
From the Festival of Iowa Beers, rich buttery brew with bright copper color, flavor was butterscotch (but in a good way), sweet and malty, very rich.

Draught at 2nd Annual Festival of Iowa Beers. Special brew described by one of the brewers as an ugly uncle of the 20th anniversary Dopplebock. It had a clear copper color with a thin white head that left some lace. Smelled of buttery caramel. Sweet on the tongue with a complex mixture of alcohol, caramel, molasses, and candy apple flavors. One of the better beers I tried at the festival.

Too little like either a beer or a lemonade to have the thrist-quenching properties of either. The lemon component was weakly sweet and the beer component was pale malt without the slightest bit of hoppiness. I think they were going for a radler-type drink, but it’s just not very good. Sticky, sweet, and weak flavors.

Draught at 2nd Annual Festival of Iowa Beers. Hazy whitish-yellow color with bubbly white head. Light citrusy aroma. Flavor was distinctly lemon, and was a bit cloying in my mind. The cereal grain malt flavor was really repressed by the fruit flavor. Tasted more like a carbonated hard lemonade more than a beer. A thirst quencher for sure, but not exactly my bag.
on tap-pours copper with a light tan head that laces. Aroma is medium malt-bready. Taste is medium malt-bready, some earthy hop. 3.8

On tap at the brewpub. Cloudy deep brown body with a thin light khaki head. Caramel and toasted almonds start the nose along with some cereal grains. The taste is orange peels a nd bitter toffee candy. The finish has lots of the citrus along with some bread crust. Decent, sweet and fruity.
(Draught) Pours a clear amber body with a small beige head. Aroma of earth, grass, dust, light roastiness, and coffee. Flavor of earth, roasted malt, and grass with a bitter finish.

Pours a pretty ruby color with a small head. The aroma is roasty with some coffee, some plum, and some mild hops. The flavor is odd, I can’t quite put my finger on why but it has a roasty flavor with some pear and some nuttiness with a little bit of mild woody hops.
TAP: rich copper pour, no nose. Sweet, malty, mild coffee/chocolate, some bread on taste. Easy drinker, pretty good.
From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 13/10/2007 Some roast aroma. Mid brown coloured smooth on the palate and roasted with a crisp and slightly dry malt finish.
Reddish copper creamy off white head. Toasted malts and a light hoppiness. A nice balanced brew. Slightly dry in the finish with a touch of puckering bitterness. Solid.

Re-rated at GABF 2009. Pours clear tawny with an average, creamy light brown head, mostly lasting with good lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, straw, cereal), light hop (herbs), average yeast (earth) with notes of dates and cinnamon. Light bodied, thin texture, average carbonation, and a chalky finish. Average duration, light sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.
Draught at 2nd Annual Festival of Iowa Beers. Clear light brown color with thin off white head. Light nutty, roasty aroma overpowered by sprucy hops. Hops dominated the flavor as well.

column2: West Des Moines, Iowa, United States
column5: Draught at 2nd Annual Festival of Iowa Beers. Clear orange color with thin white head. Smells of light malty caramel. Spicy on the tongue with biscuit and caramel malt flavors and a bitter finish.

column2: High Point, North Carolina, United States
column5: hints of oak aromatics and even a hint of almond. Color is off, much too clear for the style. Has little flavor to it. The aftertaste is none-existant. This beer needs to be beefed up with more grain complexity. Lacks a significant mouthful; The increase in grain complexity should also correct this as well. Taste does not live up to what the aroma promises. There is very little flavor to this beer but can be corrected by utilizing a more complex grain profile. The beer seems to not need alterations in any other aspects.

column2: High Point, North Carolina, United States
column5: Nice Vienna. Clear, pours amber, tan head, a little light on mouthfeel but well hopped. Sampled at Taste of Triad 2006 and again on tap at restaurant.

On tap at the Springfield, PA location. Poured a deep and cloudy orange (almost a copper) color with a small sized off white head. Aromas or oranges and all around citric. Tastes of oranges, light caramel and a very light grapefruit finish. I too would not believe the 80+ IBUs - I found this one to have a very light bitterness with a medium sweetness to it. Light lacing left on the glass.

On tap at the John Harvards in Springfield PA. Pours a ruby red amber with a medium off whie creamy head that left light lacing. Aroma of orange and various other citrus. A little light for what I was expecting from this beers aroma...expecting more from the Simcoe. Flavor of pine, orange, grapefruit and some malt balance. Very light bitterness for the 80+ IBU’s they said this one had.

silphium hit this one on the dot...the sample was hard enough to choke down...brown body with large beige head.....aroma of light roasted malt and nuts...flavor is a watered down version of the aroma, and is barely cognizable...thin palate...simply awful

On tap at GRBC. Dick Cheney himself would blush at this beer’s lack of character and integrity. Translucent orange-brown body, thin buff head. Light nutty, toasty aroma. Bland, lifeless body with toast and light biscuit, and maybe a smidgen of chocolate. Strange watery, grainy finish. No palate development whatsoever. Served in a tulip glass, perhaps to give the impression this beer merits introspection. It’s quaffable, I must admit. It’s water.

Cask hand pull at Clark’s, Amber with white head. Nose is indistinct, some malt and grassy hops. Taste was abit on the weak side, almost like water, but had citrus and malt taste. this was not a terrible brew but, for its type iv had better

In short: As good as a cask English Bitter can be. How: Tap at Clark’s Ale House, Syracuse NY The look: Clear golden body with a medium off-white head In long: Although classified as an IPA here this is to me an English Bitter. Smooth as smooth can be. Little airy bubbles in a soft caramelized body. Light orange flavour. Hopping has a dry tree leaves character. Rivals with the best English Bitters on cask I had on cask in England. I couldn’t believe how quickly I drank my pint. Noting fancy, nothing innovative but man that pint was good. The best way I found to get a taste of England without having to deal with the England food.

Cask hand pull at Clark’s, Syracuse. Amber with one-finger white head that lasts, big bubbles. Nice appearance. Nose is indistinct, some caramel and toffee, dusty and grassy hops. Taste a bit insipid: toffee, biscuit, a slight touch of citrus. Aftertaste mildly malty. Creamy, low carbonation on the palate.

Brewed specifically for Clark’s Ale House in Syracuse, and had on cask there at the real ale festival. Good hop scent. Light gold colour with a bit of bubbles on top. Batch went very quickly. Mild and light mouthfeel. A bit better than average as far as the cask ales I have tried.
Can of beer costing 79p from Home Bargains. Very tasty can of knockout juice that goes down an absolute treat. Smile at least, you can't say no to the beauty and the beast.
12 oz. bottle. Pours a clear golden color with a medium sized white head. The aroma and flavor have pale and grainy malts, bready, light citrus and floral notes, soft summer beer.

It pours golden clear with a white head. Head retention is very good. It is grainy sweet with some citrus and low lemon. It is grainy sweet in the flavor with some lemon and citrus in the background with a slight herbal quality. It is medium light bodied. Overall, an easy drinking beer with summer flavors.
355ml can. Clear golden, small white head. Aroma is floral, light fruits. Taste of light citrus, floral, grassy, minerally, malts. Light body.
Pint cuckfield. 5% on the label. Refreshing certainly but a bit iron-y, especially aroma wise. As expected, not great.

Draught at the brewery. Head is mostly lasting. Body is medium yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (cookie), with notes of insecticide, cleaning products, diacetyl. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter, unclean. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation. Truly horrific. This was the only thing that reeked of all the beers I tried here, and a second sample of the same beer had the same bug spray smell, so it was obviously not the glass either. Undrinkable.

column1: Bull & Bush Rye of the Tiger
column5: Draught at the brewery. Head is mostly diminishing. Body is dark amber. Aroma is moderately malty (cookie, caramel), lightly hoppy (flowers), with notes of diacetyl and bubble gum. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation. Malty nose ruined slightly by some butter and Bubble Yum, and just too sweet to drink much of.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Decent pale ale with a hoppy hint on the initial taste. Overall an average pale ale

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: An experiment by Magic Hat, served up at Clark’s Ale House real ale fest. Good hoppy aroma and light citrus taste, even sour in aftertaste, though suggesting something off that day. Dark yellow tinge with some head and bubbles. Lighter in body though certainly bitterness is there.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: Pours an apricot color with no head. Smell is full of honey and dried apricots with some floral notes. Taste has a very slight bitterness from the fruit, but is smooth and full of honey. Not an elite mead, by any means, but solid and drinkable.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: Tasting at mcbackus 10/19. Pale gold/yellow color. Apricots and sweet wildflowers come through on the nose. Flavor has a great balance of apricots and honey. A good combo of apricot and honey. This one is really delicious.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: 750 ml bottle. Pours a clear pale gold with no head. Strong aroma of apricots. The honey mead is also present in the nose, but to a lesser extent. The apricot flavor is much more subtle in the flavor than the aroma. I am not an apricot lover, but I was surprised how much I liked this mead and how well apricots and mead paired.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: 750 ml bottle. Pours a clear, pale gold tinted pink with no head. Strong aroma of strawberries and honey. Flavor is also starwberries and honey, but not as strong as the aroma would suggest. Sweet finish, maybe a bit cloying. A good pairing with a sharp cheddar cheese.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: Flowery and pleasant. It was like Easter in my mouth. The smell and taste are both winners in my book.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: 750 ml bottle. This is my least favorite mead that I have tasted thus far from Earle Estates. Pours a clear pink with no head. The aroma of pear, raspberry and honey seem to be fighting each other for dominance instead of combining harmoniously. Same is true for the flavor. The sweetness of the pears and honey seem to fighting against the tartness of the raspberries. This is a case where the sum of the parts does not equal 100%.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: 750 ml bottle. Pours a very pale gold with no head. Pleasant aroma of apples and honey. Flavor is also apples and honey. Apples and honey are a natural pairing and while I liked this interpretation, I was still expecting a little more, along the lines of their pear mead which I think is outstanding.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: 750ml - Pours a magnificent deep red, with plently of berry aroma. Incredibly pleasant first sip, like a slice of berry pie without the sweetness. The honey comes on at the end. Lovely, Earle Estates’ best.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: Very soft and very delightful. Great on the palate, it got better with every taste and breath. The best of their meads.

column2: Penn Yan, New York, United States
column5: 750 ml bottle. Pours a deep purply red with no head. Aroma is of raspberries and honey, as is the flavor. I find this mead a bit more cloying, which I think is a result of the 8% residual sugar content.

Cask, Hoylake Lights. Served ridiculously cold, in a ’chill out’ glass....Why oh why ? If I want to ’chill out’ I’ll seek my pleasures elsewhere. Why the brewers revenge ?! Intriguing, perhaps some unspeakably vile ingredient has been injected. Perhaps some bodily fluid ? It certainly tasted like it, from what I could glean. Hazy amber with a lingering white head. Some fruit in the aroma. Initially not bad, with some balanced enough malt and hops, but a really nasty aftertaste, damp wood ?verging on stale, maybe I just had a bad one, but I couldn’t finish. Revenge taken.

(Cask at Welkin JDW, Liverpool, 25 July) Amber colour with frothy, brief, off-white head. Malty, fruity nose with notes of apricots and mandarin. Rather closed and thin. Malty, fruity taste with mandarin and apricots, slightly acidic (?). Rather boring stuff, actually.

1. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 05/07/2006 Slight chemical aroma. Amber mid brown coloured and fruity with some acidic taste. Bitter slightly dry malt finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Smithfield Hotel, Manchester 04/05/2007 Small white head. Hoppy aroma. Golden coloured hoppy and fruity orange with some dryness in a crisp bitter finish.

column1: Rock Bottom Denver Deep Drought Dry Stout
column5: Deep roasty chocolate nose. Deep brown with orange hues, medium head. Dark chocolate malt bittersweetness, slight bitterness, not much hop flavor. Nice carbonation, medium body, slightly creamy mouthfeel, finish has some slight gasoline notes. Not tons of depth, decent, just not terribly remarkable.

column1: Rock Bottom Denver Deep Drought Dry Stout
column5: Bottle shared by Dogbrick as a precursor to his Portland beer tasting. Pours a dark brown with a medium tan head. Malty aroma with oxidation and vegetables. Roasty aroma that is loaded with plastic and veggies. Bad bottle? I hope so.

column1: Rock Bottom Denver Deep Drought Dry Stout
column5: Sample at the "Portland? Psh More Like Beerland" tasting on 03/10/10. Dark brown pour with a thin light beige head that dissipates steadily. Aroma of roasted malt and vegetables. Medium, dry body with flavors of toasted malt, mild coffee and caramel. The finish is soft and sweet with a light roasted coffee aftertaste and some more vegetables. Below average overall.

column1: Rock Bottom Denver Deep Drought Dry Stout
column5: Bomber poured a clear dark reddish brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of cocoa, cola, light coffee and light roastiness. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of cocoa, cola, light roastiness and light coffee with a crisp lightly sweet finish.

column1: Rock Bottom Denver Deep Drought Dry Stout
column5: Draught at the downtown Denver brewpub. Head is mostly lasting. Body is dark brown. Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, toasted bread, caramel, coffee). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation. A real shame they didn’t get the bitterness right; this is too sweet for a dry stout but otherwise this was a seriously nice beer. And yes, it’s called "Drought", as in a long period with no rain...an apropos name for a dry stout indeed, but surprisingly the only beer with this name in RateBeer’s entire database (as of Sep 4, 2006).

Cask (handpump) @ NWAF 2012, National Winter Ales Festival, The Venue, Sheridan Suite, Manchester, England. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, moderate hoppy, citrus, peach, pineapple. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, fresh. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120118]

Cask@GBBF2012. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is fruity, mild coriander, some wheat as well as some toffee. Flavour is fruity, wheaty, citrusy and some mild toffeeish notes. Very pleasant golden ale.
Cask at Great British Beer Festival 2012, Olympia, London. A hazy golden coloured pour with a small white head on top. Yeasty, fruity aroma. Tastes yeasty, lemon, fruity. Refreshing and tasty.
Cask at GBBF 2012. Pours a hazy yellow colour with a small white head, floral aroma with some wheat, taste is some citrus and some spices with a long dry finish.
On cask at the congress, longton. Pours clear pale gold with a lasting white head. Pleasant, sweet but not like a traditional wheat beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Has a lingering weiss aftertaste, fairly light-bodied but still full of flavour.

On cask at the 2012 NWAF, Manchester. Pours a blonde colour with a thick white head. Huge apricot aroma with caramel, yeast and alcohol. Similar upfront apricot flavour with caramel, yeast and barley also. Quite dry to finish with moderate carbonation and an oily mouth-feel.
Cask, Lathkil Hotel. What a fantastic introduction to wheat beers, I thought this was bursting with interesting clove and banana flavours and aromas, i’d like to try more of this style of beer.

Cask - The Flower Pot, Derby. Poured with a lasting, small white head atop a golden yellow body. Has the general spicey, ginger, lime character of a wit with notes orange peel on the nose and lemon on the tongue but with no real traces of wheat to be found. Light, crisp & refreshing body after a day of exploring the city with light to medium carbonation and a shortish finish. I liked it but just not very wheaty at all, more like a spicy golden.

Cask at the King Billy, Nottingham. This has a pleasing aroma redolent of pineapple. The flavour, however, isn’t as enjoyable; it seems to combine the sweetness of bubblegum with pine needles. The effect is rather cloying. I had a half; a full pint would have been difficult to finish. I’m giving it extra marks for effort.
50cl bottle from Pastures Discount Foods. Thin white head. Hazy golden pour. Ok

Bottle. Pours a clear golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma of lemon, slight honey and subtle varnish. Taste of lemon, straw, slight honey and subtle grassy, herbal hops. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A dry, honeyed herbal hop bitterness in the finish. A really lightly hopped golden ale with a soft honeyed character to it. Very average.

Cask conditioned at The Imperial Tavern, Worcester. Gold with white head. There is quite a flowery note to this beer, perfumed and slightly fruity, tart to the palate. Sourish apricot note with a light cereal background. Just okay for me.
Cask@acorn Inn, Lichfield. Pale golden beer with small head and patchy lacing. Aroma of pale malts and a hint of herb. Taste is lemon, herb and light malts. A little bland.

Cssk, Woolpack Beer Festival, Chelmsford, 4th April 2015. Proper bright with no lacing. Aroma is fresh grass, spruce, light herbs, lemon. Taste is lemons, honey, marmalade, relatively clean, finishing of strawberries and lemons. Standard
cask@Birmingham beer fest 30/10/13 No head, mid blonde, noble hops and caramel malt sweetness on nose. Sweet, low hop rate, sticky caramel, low carbonation, yeast esters and some diacetyl. not a fan
Cask at Brum Beer Fest; gloden blonde pour with soapy white head, malts aroma, grassy taste some malt tasted very lagerish.

Bottle from myBrewerytap. Pours clear golden with a tiny white head. Aroma of caramel and weak citrus. Taste is moderate sweet caramel, short very weak bitter finish, a bit on the sweet side overall, watery palate.
500ml bottle. Pours gold with a small head. Aroma is butter and grass. Taste has some fruity malt to start with a buttery finish. Oily.

Cask@Junction Tavern, London. Yellowish golden colour with a mediumsized foamy white head that leaves some lace. Aroma is sweet malts along with some floral and biscuity notes. Flavour is quite similar with some quite zesty and resiny notes.
Cask Handpump at the Assembly Rooms, Derby 07/07/2006 Slight grassy aroma. Golden bronze coloured and fruity. A little thin on the palate. Some bitterness in a dry wheaty finish.
Cask Handpump at the Assembly Rooms, Derby 07/07/2006 Spicy aroma. Cloudy yellow coloured slightly fruity and spicy with a dry lasting finish.
Cask Handpump at the Flower Pot, Derby 07/07/2006 Hop aroma. Clear golden coloured hoppy and fruity with some bitterness in a dry malt finish.
Cask Handpump at the Assembly Rooms, Derby 07/07/2006 Fruity and floral aromas. Golden coloured hoppy and fruity citrus with a slightly dry crisp and bitter malt finish.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: black with tan head . pine and coffee aroma , taste is espresso with hop bitterness. big carbonation that works well . lingering aftertaste

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: (5.8% ABV when I visited) Brown-black body with tan head. Arome is moderately sweet, coffee, some chocolate, light icing. Taste is medium sweet, sugared coffee, light chocolate. Low carbonation, medium body.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: On tap from the brewpub. Black, with a tan head. The aroma is chocolate, coffee and sweet smelling. The body is medium and carries the aromas over. Good balance to the sweet,

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Sampler. Pours a dark brown almost boardering on black with ruby highlights when held to the light. Small bubbly light tan head that left lacing. Aroma of sweet malts, chocolate, some coffee and lactose. Flavor of roasted malts, cocoa, coffee and some general sweetness.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours a diminishing tan head with black color. Aroma is coffee, malt, sweet, milk. Taste follows, creamy, slight bitterness. Mild Carbonation.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Lightly hazed amber body with white head -- darker than usual for a hefe. Aroma is medium sweet, bubblegum, some banana. Taste is medium sweet, caramel, some banana, bubblegum. Light body, light creaminess, acidity. Despite the name, is this a dunkelweizen?

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: On tap at the brew pub. Hazy brown with a medium head. Smells like some artificial berry cereal. The bartender said it was orange. Wheat and fruit, kind of a formula.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours a creamy offwhite head with hazy copper color. Aroma is rich malt, heavier hops, spice. Taste is rich malt, wheat, heavier hops with slight bite, spice, dark fruit. Effervescence that jumps onto the tongue. Medium bodied.

Draught at the brewpub. Cloudy golden, small head. Orangey nose. Fairly sweet with rounded mouthfel and light body. Low bitterness. Rather neutral, except for the orange flavour which probably derives from the orange wedge it’s served with.
Sample at the brewery. Pours murky orange, thin white head. Aroma is very light with wheat and fruit. Taste is also lacking slightly, very mild but smooth breadiness.
on tap-pours a white head and cloudy gold color. Aroma is mild light malt. Taste is sweet light malt/wheat, fruit, secondary spice/pepper hops.
Tap @ Brewpub: Gold, white head and nice lacing. Nose of light husk, very thin and vague. No esters or clove. American? Clean though.

Sample tray. Great white head. Lots of carbonation. Dark yellow. Almost no aroma. Dirty lemon flavour and creamy body. A bit biting on the tip of the tongue. Refreshing. Lemon is strong but not much else.

Bottle: Dirty straw in color, very thick and hazy, moderate white froamy head, decent lacing. &nbsp Sure is one cloudy mo-fo, especially that last pour. &nbsp Straw, hay, and slight wheat malt on the nose. &nbsp Not as wheaty as I would have thought, but its there... albeit minor. &nbsp Has a slight barnish funk, slight sulfer but much less than other examples. &nbsp Fairly wheaty on the tongue, a bit husky tho. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel, albeit not as wheaty on the finish than I would like. &nbsp Overall okay, a little dull, but fairly decent.

On draught at the brewpub in Sandpoint, Idaho. Pours a hazy golden yellow brew with a creamy white head that dissipates slowly and leaves behind an excellent lacing. Aroma of wheat malt, light enriched flour and some earthy herbal hops. Taste is smooth and light with very little carbonation. Not your typical wheat beer as it does not have the yeast or banana esters as most other wheat beers I’ve tried. Finish is almost clean with a sweet bread aftertaste. Very refreshing for an American Wheat beer.

Tried this beer at Mick Duff’s in Sandpoint, ID. It had the typical cloudy appearance of a wheat beer and a smooth pour down the throat. I thought this was a good summery wheat beer and would recommend it. They have 22 oz bottles for takeout or you can purchase a growler (1/2 gallon). The beer is not pasteurized, so you have to keep it cold if transporting.

Draft at Fall fest Schweitzer Mtn. Pour.s a light hazy golden color. I Iforwent the slice of orange that was offered in order to better tast the brew. nice clean somewhat estery aroma that leads into a smooth clean crisp flavor. no off flavors or overbitternes justs a clean finish. this is the best beer that Mickduffs has produced that I have tasted ,very nicely done well worth a second glass

column2: Red Bank, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours a thin creamy white head that laces with yellow color. Aroma is ginger, honey. Taste is ginger, honey, pine, wheat, mild hop, mellow. Mild carbonation.

It’s a hazy, coppercolored beer with a rather big-bubbly head. The aroma has a nice note of aroma hops. The favour has a light caramel sweetness and notes of fruit/aroma hops and a spicy bitter and long finish. It’s initially OK, but as time went by it became boring. I guess I expected something more like the big American IPA’s, something in better balance and with more power on the hops... 1738

Cask conditioned handpump The Pub Leicester. A golden beer with a loose white head. Really nice hops in the nose. Gooseberry to the fore. Also great hoppy flavours in the mouth, although there’s a weird wet wood note. Super bitterness and great hops. Good.

Cask. Criterion, Leicester. Apple cores and spruce. Hoppy. Caramel malt base. Clear golden amber colour with a medium white head with good lacing. Taste is medium bitterness. Palate is clean and very refreshing with some oiliness. Dryness on the finish.
Hand pulled at the Pub, Leicester. Golden beer, with no head. Very thin body. Lemony, fast fading hops. Very clean and refreshing. A good, but not massive Golden.

On draught in the Devonshire Cat, Sheffield. Golden coloured and summery beer. Some lemon flavours but overall not a strong tasting beer. A little insipid when compared against Abbeydale Absolution. Not bad but not good.
Cask, Swan and Rushes, Leicester. Dark gold with an off-white head. Aromas are spicy pine and caramel with floral notes and nice hops. Flavours are sweet and earthy with spicy pine hops. Pretty good.

Bottle. Amber/gold with a bubbly head. Aromas tea and lemon with light sweet pine, toffee malts with some fruit. Quite dry. Flavours are toffee malts with apple fruitiness. Pine hops towards the finish. Soft and tasty with a good level of hopping.

column4: Sociedade Central de Cervejas e Bebidas (Heineken Group)
column5: Bottle from supermarket in Portugal. Amber color, white head. Malts, caramel, some wood

column4: Sociedade Central de Cervejas e Bebidas (Heineken Group)
column5: Aroma; malty grainy scents. Look; off white bighead, dark amber clear body. Taste; smooth malts, caramel, syrup, roasted malty notes - malted finish. Feel; smooth. Overall; quite okay. [33cl.btl@SintraRegionPortugal]

column4: Sociedade Central de Cervejas e Bebidas (Heineken Group)
column5: Brownish/red color with a fine tan head. A bit sweet caramel malty aroma. Medium body and an average carbonation. Tad sweet and a moderate bitterness. Toffee and malty flavor. Ok decent dunkel. A bit more bitterness would have helped a lot. [Bottle from a local grocery store in Lisbon, Portugal]

column4: Sociedade Central de Cervejas e Bebidas (Heineken Group)
column5: 0,33 l.Copper colour with small head.Malt and caramel taste. Not bad for a portuguese beer.

column4: Sociedade Central de Cervejas e Bebidas (Heineken Group)
column5: Ruby color. nice head. Aroma is malt, taste is little bitter and sweet. Before the beer market in Portugal started to increase this was my favorite portuguese beer...

column4: Sociedade Central de Cervejas e Bebidas (Heineken Group)
column5: Rich ruby body, sandy white head. Big malty nose, sugary and curranty. Initial dry, toasted bitter taste. Middle of more malt without anywhere near the level of sweetness I was hoping. Cereal dust sweetness to the finish. Surprisingly leggy without being that sweet. Was made to look like a prick for ordering this when everyone was supping litres of Sagres for the same price. Not really worth it. Bottle, random bar on Riberia Square, Porto

column4: Sociedade Central de Cervejas e Bebidas (Heineken Group)
column5: One of my favorite mass production beer in Portugal. Good colour, nice taste and almost no head. A simple but rather everyday beer, specially for those rainy days.

column4: Sociedade Central de Cervejas e Bebidas (Heineken Group)
column5: Bottle in Porto. Pours clear dark red/brown with no head. Aroma is caramel. Taste is light sweet. Body is watery and flat. Finish is short and sweet.

column4: Sociedade Central de Cervejas e Bebidas (Heineken Group)
column5: Backlog june 2010 Algarve, bought at large supermarket . Amber & ok foam. Medium body & complexity Pretty ok

column4: Sociedade Central de Cervejas e Bebidas (Heineken Group)
column5: 33cl bottle. Dark brown colour with a good formation but quickly diminishes tan head, any way, nice lacework on the glass. Aroma is fruity and slightly toasty. Flavour is moderate toasted malts, citrus hints are also present, slightly bready on palate, with a final caramelized and sweet. Carbonation is medium. Body is medium. Texture is slightly creamy.
Creamy tan head with cola-brown body. Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, some chocolate, light vanilla. Taste is medium sweet, chocolate, caramel, some roasty, light nutty. Light-medium body.
Refrigerated 0.5 L brown bottle at the source. Cloudy light orange with big white head. Aroma is clove, medium body, medium carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is clove and banana. Nice Hefeweizen.
Dirty yellow/brown color ; medium-sized , white head. Clove , fruits and wheat in aroma. Sweet malty taste with notes of fruits and spices . Drinkable .
Slightly skunked aroma. Hazy amber pour. Good mix of fruity sweetness and tart.

Das Flaschendesign wurde (leider) vor ein paar Jahren geändert - jetzt gibts alle Kalt-Loch-Biere in der Longneckflasche mit gleichem, nur in der Farbe verschiedenem, Etikett. Der "alte" Fachwerkmarktplatz und die bayerischen Flaschen gefielen mir besser! Aber nun zum Bier: Sehr schöne hellgelbe Farbe, mild-hefiger Geruch. Der Antrunk ist bananig-säuerlich und sehr erfrischend. Zum Hauptteil kommt eine angenehm vollmundig-säuerliche Hefenote hinzu, die sich auch lange bis in den Nachgeschmack hält. Dabei nur minimal herb. Auf der Zunge bleibt eine mild-säuerliche Hefenote mit ganz leichter Herbe und nur minimaler Süße! --> Interessant säuerliches, aber sehr lecker-süffiges Weizen! Test vom 1.8.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,12,12,11,12,12 - 11,85
Aroma is lemons, bananas and slightly chemical. The flavor is lemons, wheat, relatively thin in body and mild sweetness/bubblegum in the finish.
Light banana, slightly clovelly well made hefe. Light and refreshing. A bit sour than usual.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and it’s not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog! Im Glas steht ein orange-hellbraunes Weizen mit mittlerer Trübung und guter Weizenkrone. Der Geruch ist hefig säuerlich, spritzig frisch. Der Antrunk ist sehr sauer, dezent hefig und minimal fruchtig-säuerlich. Der Abgang erfolgt fruchtig sauer, mit einer minimalen Süße im zweiten Abgang. Kein besonders gelungenes Weizen, aber man kanns trinken.

Spritzig hefiger Antrunk, in dem bereits säuerliche Noten vorhanden sind. Diese spitze Säure wird noch intensiver und vermittelt im Mittelteil Assoziationen mit Gose. Weiterhin deutlich hefig und söuerlich, was den erfrischenden Aspekt weiter hervorhebt. Gleichzeitig hat das Bier eine angenehme Würze, die aber eher auf Kräuternoten als auf dem Malz basiert. Das Bier ist so durchaus interessant und setzt sich von anderen Weizen deutlich ab.Im Abgang zusätzlich etwas herb. Sommerweizen!
bottle. Cloudy pale yellow colour, large white head. Fruity (mango, banana) with some spicy accents.

The bottle looks simple, but good, the beer in the glass light orange, nice creamy head. Starts fresh and zippy, very fruity, quite sourish. Notes of apple and lemon. Modest yeasty. Finish a bit milder, but still intense fruity. Unusual but good hefeweizen!
Mukava olut, joka maistuu hyvältä. Drinkki veljeni terassilla. Suosittelisi sitä!
Bottle at the brewery - hazy mahagoni color, beige head. okay Dunkles Weizen, standard. not too sweet, which is nice.

500ml bottle at home. Pours clear very dark brown with an off white head. Aroma: Yeasty, nutty, bubblegum, some chocolate. Taste: light to moderate sweet, subtle banana esters, milk chocolate. Medium body, soft carb, smooth mouthfeel. Not bad

From bottle at Gerber Hotel. Hazy/murky brown. Oxidized. Honey, ripe banana (its rotten part), date honey aroma. Sweet taste: date honey and Elvis Presley pb and banana sandwich. Smooth texture, slightly green aftertaste but mostly sweet, medium body. BBD 5.11.17.
Boca 0.5L - iz obeæane zemlje, meni èisti prosjek, možda i ispod toga...èudna aroma, okus se kratko zadržava u ustima

Refrigerated 0.5 L flip-top bottle listed as Miltenburg Dunkle poured into aweihenstephan glass. Dark brown with big light brown highlights and small off-white head. Aroma is milk chocolate, medium/light body, medium carbonation, and pretty good small-bubble lacing. Taste is milk chocolate and banana.

0,5 l swing top bottle BB 24.08.16 banana, cereal, dough, brown color, cloudy, frothy, tan foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, slick feel, lively, long finish Indeed a very good Dunkelweizen.
Taste is crispy bready with roasted malt. Amber brown and unfiltered, Nose is nutty with yeast. Medium body, some lace to head. Would pair well with many meals

Bottle from Sprout’s: Poured a dark muddy pond water color but was topped delicately with a large frothy foam cap head. Big bold aroma of Traditional German yeast scents that suggest bubblegum balls, clove, and light banana esters. Some olfaction of wheat but minor. The flavor is little off and comes across as bland and tasting like a sweetened carbonated beverage that has gone flat yet there is carbonation still left in the beer. Lips get a salty finish followed by a slight after note of cheap gumball machine gum. Nothing special but will be keeping the bottle and storing some of my cooking oils inside of.
Malzig herber, wenig hefiger Antrunk. Herber werdend, Noten von Banane. Schwächer zum Ende, noch leicht malzig. Ok. 11/8/9/8/8/8

[022-20060829] Tap @ Orange Lane (Moncton, NB). Smells like banana bread. Cloudy, amber body with a frothy, creamy head. Tastes like drunk bananas, very boozy and gravelly and grainy. Fully, prickily body. Reminds me of a souped up Rickard’s Red, sadly.

Draft at the brewpub. Dark amber body, decent beige head and some lacing (3+). Floral herbal aroma, light yeast notes. Sharp wheaty bite in the flavour strong note of something – clove? Dry bitter finish. Sulphur? Average palate. Interesting but incoherent and the sharpness is off putting. Hard to finish. Disappointing. Does not seem like any other wheat I have tasted. 5/3+/5/3/11

column2: Toms River, New Jersey, United States
column5: American Style IPA, its amber in color & Menuim bodied massive hop aroma & flavors abound in this beer. Well balenced with a gentle caramelly biscuty malt flavor. Best IPA around. Only found at Basil T’s Toms River.

column2: Toms River, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours a thin white head with gold color and effervescence. Aroma is crisp citrus hops. Taste is lots of crisp citrus hops, some malt. Good carbonation.

column2: Toms River, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft from backlog. Pours cloudy golden yellow with white head. Nose and taste of banana, clove, wheat malt and light spice. Medium bodied.

column2: Toms River, New Jersey, United States
column5: Tap on my recent visit. Pours a cloudy yellowish slightly golden color with a small white head. Aroma of lemon zest, wheat malts and some banana and slight clove. Taste is refreshing, slightly watery but rather solid for this style, lemon zest, banana clove and some other spice notes in there too, I actually liked this one, and for me saying that of this style, that is saying something.

column2: Toms River, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft. Poured a hazy golden/yellow with a small white head. Aroma of grass and light lemon. Earthy taste of grass,wheat and lemon. A little watery but an okay beer.

column2: Toms River, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours a thin white head with cloudy gold/yellow color and effervescence. Aroma is banana. Taste is banana, musty wheat, minor clove. OK carbonation.

column1: New Albanian Mt. Lee California Common
column5: Growler: Deep gold with a tall, yellow-white head....bubbly. Cheesy/yeasty grain malt aromas. Malty...creamy...rye malt? Grassy/earthy hop bittering. Very APA-like. Pretty good.

column1: New Albanian Mt. Lee California Common
column5: Draft @ brewery. Bready caramel malt aroma. Amber with a moderate off-white head. Caramel malt and herbal hops flavor. Body on the light side of medium, average carbonation.

column1: New Albanian Mt. Lee California Common
column5: On cask at GTMW 2013 - Pours hazy amber with a thick tan head. nose is nutty and malty, bready and slick. Taste is bready and malty, with gentle, smooth carbonation. Nutty and grainy, with no hop presence to speak of. Not really that great.

column1: New Albanian Mt. Lee California Common
column5: 2/19/2011: NABC Mt. Lee California Common... Aroma: Grainy malt with some caramel/toffee notses; spicy pine hops. Appearance: Mostly clear golden amber color; frothy off-white head; lots of nice lacing. Flavor: Decent maltienss with a hint of banana; spicy yeast in the middle; fruity and a generous bitterness for the style. Palate: Medium body; mostly smooth. Overall: Interesting interpretation, but good. Draught sample (6.1% ABV; 68.6 IBU) at New Albanian Brewing Company in New Albany, IN. Rating #30 for this beer.

column1: New Albanian Mt. Lee California Common
column5: Draft. Summer 2012. Aroma is minty, woody, crystal malt sweetness. Color is a slightly hazy orange, wispy off-head head. Flavor is toasty, malty, caramel, firmly bitter, some fruitiness, woody hop flavor, some citrus and mint. Body is medium, soft carbonation. Overall, firmly bitter and malty, woody and minty hop flavor.

column1: New Albanian Mt. Lee California Common
column5: taken from notes: I enjoyed this on tap at the brewpub in New Albany, IN. Served cold in a tulip pint. A - A deep copper burnished caramal w/ an inch of light cream that drops quickly. Has a fine bead. There is moderate stickage. The contrast between the red/amber and light tan head is striking as the rings of lace cling tenaciously. S - Nice mellow simcoe and cascade citrus w/ subtle floral notes and tangerine/clementine-like juicy sweet aromas. M - Very mild bitterness seamless malt and hop unity, the sweetness seems to be submerged at first but actually works in tandem w/ the slightly bitter and tart notes of the fresh hop notes riding the fruity and effervescent feel. T - Very much like a pale ale w/ the accent ofn the flavor of the simcoe and the cascade along for the ride. I am very impressed w/ the 1st beer I have had at a brewpub in Indiana. Nice malt anchoring(no pun intended) the sweetness is restrained, but has a nice dry and lightly grainy mild roasteed flavor w/ subtle rye notes -kind of bready as it warms w/ a subtle astringency and the hop flavors remain all the way true to the end. D - Described as a "session beer" on the menu, I can’t exactly agree, but 5.6% is close enough. Very Drinkable, I could return to this without hesitation. For me this has a swiss army type of universal flavor. The malt smoothness and plenty of hop sweetness and citrus flavor. This ale is well crafted and hard to find fault with the quality.

column1: New Albanian Mt. Lee California Common
column5: Served on tap at the brewpub. The appearance is a lighter amber with a white head. The nose is light caramel, and kisses of hops. The flavors are similar with the hops underwhelming a bit.. The mouth is medium carbed and bodied. Would like a touch more hops but a nice session-able beer.

column1: New Albanian Mt. Lee California Common
column5: On tap at the brepub. Meh, this one was a bit off balance. I am not too familiar with this style, but I would choose plenty of other offered beers over this one, as this NABC location has one of the best bottle lists in the world!

column1: New Albanian Mt. Lee California Common
column5: Draft. Hazy amber body. Off-white, frothy head, diminishing. Aroma of grain, pine, biscuit, citrus. The flavor is lightly to moderately bitter and lightly sweet. It finishes lightly sweet and moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Very much hop forward with bitterness throughout the sip. Earthy, yeasty notes in the finish.

column1: New Albanian Mt. Lee California Common
column5: On tap. Pours a cloudy orange with an off-white head that laces nicely. Aroma has a strong pine hop profile with a slight undertone of biscuits. Flavor begins with a strong hop presence, but the biscuit note grows to a well balanced finish.

column1: New Albanian Strathpeffer Heather and Honey Ale
column5: Growler. Honey and heather aroma. Clear amber with big head. Strong peppery heather flavor with bitter finish. Basically gives you what it says - a well made and very unique beer for the US. How much one likes or dislikes this beer hinges on his/her tolerance of heather.

column4: Sabeco - Saigon Beer Alcohol Beverage Corp. (ThaiBev)
column5: Bottle 330ml. @ [ Assentoft Tasting by Hansen & Zita ]. [ As Saigon Special ]. ABV: 4.9%. Clear medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, grass, silage. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, sweet malt, cardboard, silage, grass. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20190914] 4-3-4-3-7

Barwa ciemnobrunatna, klarowne, piana jasnobe¿owa, doœæ obfita, ale niezbyt trwa³a. W aromacie ciemne s³ody, spalony tost, ciemne owoce, ciemne pieczywo. W smaku pó³s³odkie, wyraŸne nuty ciemnego, przypalonego pieczywa z dodatkiem owoców - wiœni, czereœni, œliwek. Niezbyt wiele czekolady, trochê karmelu. Alkohol œrednio ukryty, nieco dra¿ni, goryczka niska do œredniej, nieco brakuje, wysycenie nieco za wysokie. Nie jest to z³y porter, ale ma pewne wady, przez co jest typowym przeciêtniakiem.
Troch? ciemnego chleba, s?odkie ale rzadkie. Aromat s?aby. Piana szybko opada i znika. Puste, mega ?elazo, najs?abszy porter jaki pi?em.
looks more like a brown than Baltic porter. Light with generic sweet malt notes. Nothing noteworthy. Disappointed in the first of 3.
Svart i färgen, beige skum. Smakar och doftar mörk malt söt choklad, praliner, lakrits och lite kaffe. Lite för tunn i kroppen.
Bomber @ Savoy bistro Portland OR. Overly sweet and clearly laced with additives. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Black colour with a beige head. Sweet malt, roasted malt and chocolate aroma. Rich sweet flavour with roasted malt, coffe and chocolate
Bottle, sample (8%) at GBF 2011 cons 2011-09-02 AP: black wee beige head AR: honey, fudge, syrup F: chocolate, coffey, caramel, syrup

(bottle, 4/30/10). Dark brown color, with ruby hue. Medium tan head, which is mostly diminishing. Sweet malt and chocolate aroma. Sweet chocolate flavor with light coffee. Avg duration. Very light bitter finish with lasting sweetness. Thin/slick texture. Soft carbonation. Fair lacing.

Serving date: 2009-01-28. Served in snifter. 500 ml bottle with freshness date on label (Best before 2009-09-26). Recommended cellaring temperature on label. The pour seems black at first, but soon reveals a very dark-brown color with deep ruby hues. The liquid is very clear. 1 cm cappuccino colored head that dissipates rather quickly. Very very small lacings are left behind. In the nose, there’s cream and coffee with a slightly burnt character. However, most noticeable - and a bit surprising - is a prominent smell of toffee. The taste is also of coffee and a general roasted flavor, burnt caramel, and notes of bitter chocolate in the middle. In the slightly bitter finish there are more coffee flavors and nuances of toast. The hop character is minimal, and I think I would have liked it to be a bit bigger. The mouthfeel is rather smooth and "calm", with a medium body and mild carbonation. Basically no taste of alcohol. This is a very good porter, but I must say that I was expecting a little more from it. It could have been a little bolder and have slightly richer flavors. With the well hidden alcohol it almost appears as a very good session porter. But the high ABV would make such a session rather short. Recommended for porter enthusiasts, and I must say that I could definitely see myself buy this one again. I would really have liked to try it at 9,4%, since I think higher ABV would have served it well. Serving type: bottle (Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate aroma with some hints of coffee. Sweetish roasted malty chocolate and caramel flavor. Has a sweetish roasted malty chocolate finish.

Canned (from old collection I bought). Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is bready, cardboardy, some earthiness as well as hayish notes. Flavour is quite similar with some grainy notes in it as well. Slightly better than the 2.8 % one.

(Canned) Golden colour with airy, white, brief head. Malty nose with hints of grass, malt sugar and boiled vegetables. Malty, sugary, slightly chemical taste with grain and vegetables, modest traces of grassy hops. Thin body. Rather unpleasant.
Golden.White head. A slight feel from grass and metal in aroma. The flavor and palate is little grassy and bubly.
(50 cl can) Thin sweet malty scent, also grainy. Clear golden color, white fading head. Weak malty and bitter taste, some toffee aftertaste. Low bitterness, rather thin body.
Canned Pale golden. Short white head. Metallic and with artificial sweetness. Loads of vegetables in the flavour and also some odd perfume...
Pale yellow, white head. Vegetable aroma with spicy notes. Not much flavor at all, maybe some bitterness after a while.
Przyjemny zapach piernikowy. kolor czarny, ogólnie przyjemny smak nie kwaœne z nutami piernika, dosyæ s³odkie ale orzeŸwiaj¹ce i pijalne, aczkolwiek trochê za bardzo karmelowe. Du¿e nagazowanie.
Dark brown, fizzy head, sweet aroma. Sweet base, grainy, burnt caramel, molasses.

kwas chlebowy to dla mnie nie piwo i to nie tylko w tym przypadku, ale wogole. No ale jako tradycyjne Ale klasyfikowane no moze i od dawien dawna produkowano napoj na zakwasie chlebowym. Zyto jest tu podstawa i chleb do tego drozdze niepiwowarskie. Nie tworzy sie piana. W smaku jak kwaskowaty sok jablkowy. Chlebowe aromaty. Lekko pikantne na podniebieniu wrazenia. Ale ten napoj bezalkoholowy w upalne dni nawet da sie wypic
Bottle.Amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is malt, nuts, spices. Flavour is sugar, malt, nuts, spices. Unpleasent beer.

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium to dark brown colour with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, brown sugar, bonbons, powdered brown sugar. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet with a long duration, candy, browm sugar, brunsvier sukker. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20130217]
sweet sugar aroma,brown, off white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, soft carbonation, very sweet finish.
Dark brown coloured with an off-white head, mostly lasting. Sweet aroma, notes of soy sauce. Flavor is heavy sweet, syrupy texture.

Bottle. Pours deep brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, coffee and burnt grains. Flavor is sugary sweet with some malt, roasted grains, chocolate and caramel. Medium body, average carbonation. Quite pleasant, but a way to sweet.

Bottle 500ml @ fonefan Pours clear dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt and burned caramel. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

Bottle. A clear, brown beer topped by a small, beige head. The aroma is roasted and spiced, with some toffee and dried fruits. Toffee, spice hints, roasted malts and some dried fruits in the flavor. Some chocolate too. Dry on the palate, carbonated like a soda drink, and rather thin. Toffee and dried fruits in the end. Quite drinkable and quenching, but not my kind of drink. 130217

Cask takeout from Middle Farm, Sussex, Nov 09. Transporting this to London seemed to have had a bad effect on it. Glowing yellowy gold, almost like a bitty orange juice. Very, very sharp and acidic with a beast of an aftertaste. Slightly cheesy. Too much to even finish. Described by one of my drinking companions as "Made from apples. And PAIN."
Cask Stillage at the RUFC, Bromsgrove 15/07/2006 Strong fruit aroma. Golden coloured cloudy fruity and tangy with a crisp and dry finish.
Cask Stillage at the RUFC, Bromsgrove 15/07/2006 Some fruit aroma. Clear golden fruity slightly rich on the palate and sweet with a crisp finish.

Polycask @ NWAF 2013, National Winter Ales Festival, The Venue, Sheridan Suite, Manchester, England. Clear light to medium yellow color with virtually no head. Aroma is moderate to heavy apple, vanialla, Apple Pie, apple porridge. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and light light acidic with a average duration, tart apples, apples, dry. Body is medium, carbonation is flat. [20130124]
Cask Stillage at the RUFC, Bromsgrove 15/07/2006 Fruity aroma. Golden coloured and fruity with a crisp and slightly dry sharp finish.
Cask Stillage at the RUFC, Bromsgrove 15/07/2006 Hop aroma. Golden coloured and hoppy with a crisp and slightly dry bitter malt finish.

Date: 04/12/2008 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Hickory Hops Appearance: clear dark red, wispy beige head, Aroma: sweet dark caramel aroma with lots of earthy character, Flavor: sweet dark caramel flavor, touch of candy sweetness is reeled in by a big earthy character, touch of tartness, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: **/4

Dark pruple-ish red, no head. Nice red wine and tobacco aroma, and the flavor definately continues the red wine character. Some leathery notes, some roacky, stoney noates, as well. . As it warms, a suble citrus flavor emerges. Not bad at all. On tap, Flying Saucer, Raleigh.

Draught at Flying Saucer in downtown Raleigh. Mahogany color, clear, medium beige head. Aroma is a little thin, but with some caramel. Flavor is sweet, stronger on caramel, but thin on finish. Still, very smooth. Little bit of alcohol in aftertaste.
On tap at the Durham WBF. Clear amber with a small off white head. Candylike sweet malty nose and flavor, rather one dimensional. OK.

I had this beer at the World Beer Fest in Durham, NC on 10/7/06 and it was incredible. The sweetness of it was very different from other Doppelbock that I have had. There was a richness to it, nutty and chocolately with a hint of fruit.

Pint @ Harrison Grille. Was told this is 8.5%. Ok nose, sweet. Malty, cardboard, nutty, chocolate, caramel. Clean orangy brown color, no head or lace. Sweet flavor. Roasted malts, Maple, caramel, lite chocolate, molasses. You get the idea. Medium body, smooth creamy oily mouthfeel, sweet sticky finish. Tasty enough, but a little unlively on the mouthfeel. I’m not the biggest dopplebock person. Abv wasn’t that apparent. I liked the maple aspect of it.

Sampled at the 10th annual Brewgrass festival in Ashville. Chestnut – walnut colored. Very clear with a light thin head. Very sweet and malty aroma. Sticky, nutty, sweet. The flavor was not what I was expecting as the guy serving this at the booth did not know what type of lager it was (in fact, no one at that festival was ever able to explain what type of lager anything was…at any booth..irritating). As such I was surprised by the sweetness. In fact, I found the sweetness overpowering and cloying. There is some toasted malt that tries to balance it, but with no success. If there are hops in here they are negligible and add little if anything to the flavor. Mostly a candy sweetness that is overpowering. A sticky, creamy body.

Draft... NTB Ernesto Festo ’06... Very dark, clear crimson ale with a small, frothy, off-white head. Malty, fruity aroma with notes of chocolate and dark fruit. Very chocolatey, cloying flavor features lots of light molasses and dark raisins. Medium-bodied with mild carbonation. Lengthy, very sweet finish.
Bottle. Copper-bronze in colour with a small head. It is sweet in character, both nose and taste are sugary.

Tasted this at the Esquire House, Glasgow (JDW) in April 2010. Cask, handpump dispense. Crystal clear straw in colour with a thin white head. Thin malt in the short aroma with a touch of green apple. Thin insipid resiny mouthfeel and poor lacing. Pale malts give a maltloaf base with faint citric grapefruit notes. Bitter metallic hop resins kick in with strong astringency. Finish is very dry with woody briar notes. A poor session bitter, better Bitters in the extensive Holdens portfolio.
Bottle @ 3.7% ABV. Sulphur, grassy hops, biscuity malt (Marris Otter), fruity, caramel. Bitter. Dry finish. Well carbonated. Thin white head, dark gold body.

500ml bottle at 3.7%. Pours pale orange with a large head. Aroma is grainy, a little dusty and metallic. Taste starts with some watery orange and has a grainy, medium bitter finish. A bit thin but it’s low abv.

Live rate. Bottle from Booth’s, Ilkley. Pours pale and lagery with no visible carbonation and a slim white skim. Metallic, faintly grassy aroma with pleasing hints of apple turnover as it warns. Pleasantly buttery Black Countryness with licks of pine, straw, sugared puff pastry and corn. A bit throwaway and metallic, but it’s alright.
Cask @ Volunteer Arms, GBBF 2010. Pours a golden color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty nutty caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

Cask (handpump) @ JDW - The Manchester & County, 49 Piccadilly, Manchester, Greater Manchester, England M1 2AP. Clear medium orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, toasted, light to moderate hoppy, citrus, grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat to soft. [20100425]

(Cask at Edgar Wallace, Strand, London, 3 Aug 2010) Pale amber colour with foamy, off-white head. Fruity nose with orange, mandarin and floral hops. Fruity taste with notes of orange, mandarin, dried apricots and fresh, floral hops in the finish. Light body, balanced sweetness, generous floral bitterness. Refreshing, nice and highly drinkable.
Cask at The Market Porter.Golden, small froth. Green apples aroma. Flavours of earth and apples. Body is light. Good enough bitter.

12th April 2010. Clear gold beer. Very light carbonation. Semi dry palate. Not too much malt, just enough to provide a base for some nice hops that cut through. Orange and grapefruit and a dash of spcice. Not a hop bomb but the hops cut through well here.

First tasted this in The Esquire House, Glasgow (JDW) in October 2007. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear pale gold amber in colour with a thin white head. Strong dusty hop aroma, floral notes long in the nose. Thin resiny mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a thin fruity note of clemantines, this initial sweetness fades fast though. Strong infusion of dry hop pellets gives a very dry bitter aftertaste which sucks the moisture from the palate. Finish is very astringent with strong hop resins still giving tart citric notes in the mouth. Dry and cloying at the end. A very dry bitter and maybe too astringent for some.

Cask conditioned - handpump Wootton WMC A copper coloured beer with a whitish head. The aroma has a touch of caramel amongst the predominant malt. Same again in the mouth with a bit of coffee and diacetyl. Odd in places but drinkable.
Cask, Wetherspoon’s, Hammersmith. A fairly standard, and fairly boring, bitter. A bit sweet, a little bitterness in the finish, but it does not convince.

Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Amber to copper with white head. This is quite an odd bitter, I found it very flowery and perfumed, almost like drinking marigolds (not the rubber gloves by the way). Sharp hops with a heavier fragrant malt. Quite unusual.
Counting house. Aroma was quite minimal, nutty and grassy hints though. Taste is similar, a nutty lightly biscuioty malt with grassy and raw bittering hops.

A Mes rate: Cask at the awful Holborn JDW. Nice clean amber brown with a slim white head. Decent malt hop balance in the aroma with slight tobacco. Nice malty flavour with some slight sweet fruit and a decent citric finish which eventually turns bitter.
Cask @ JDW. Golden with a white head. Nose of hops, grapefruit and a bit of malt, taste is much the same. Decent palate but nothing exciting overall.

[i] Cask at JDW. Penny Black, Bicester 22-09-07 [/i] Copper in colour with small white head. fruity hop aroma, taste is also fruity, hoppy, and suprisingly quite robust with reasonable bitterness not too much sweet malts but they were there, a nice bitter.

Cask (handpump) @ Robin Hood, DY8, Amblecote. Clear medium amber color with a small fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, moderate hoppy, citrus, toffee. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to creamy, carbonation is flat.

Cask conditioned @ South Western Arms, Soton. Dark copper. Malty fruity nose. Growing spicy hop flavours in the mouth with a tasty bitterness. Malt becomes a bit stodgy towards the end although the nice hop flavours help to compensate for this.

Cask conditioned at the Bag O’Nails, Bristol 27/6/07. Deep golden coloured with a lacy white head. Aroma of grapefruit and elderflowers. Flavour of biscuit malts with some summer fruits. A good session beer.

Milky white resolving into pale gold with a persistent creamy head. Orange and barrelwood in the nose. Biscuity smooth malt with a gently citrussy note of lemon. A touch of hop bitterness in the finish. Long, distinctly wheaty afters.
Cask Handpump at the Crown Inn, Stockport 15/07/2006 Citrus aroma. Clear golden coloured with citrus and passion fruit flavours. Crisp and slightly dry malt finish.
Cask @ Duck & Drake, Leeds. Golden-yellow with a creamy head. Has a very bushy floral aroma similarly woody taste with a fair bitterness.

18th February 2013 Cask at the Market Porter. Clear gold beer, good white head. Palate is softish with mild carbonation, nice mouthfeel. A little creamy malt and decent citric hop - medium bitter. Orange marmalade and a little pink grapefruit. Finishes smooth with medium bitterness. Like this! Fresh, reasonably well hopped and a good mouthfeel.
Gravity cask at the Merton BF 2012. Clear gold with a white head. Pleasant crisp beer with clean malt and subtle hop balance, somehow under powered for the hop variety used.

Cask, gravity at Merton Winter Beer Festival, 17th & 18th February 2012 This looked superb in the glass, great clarity and with a lovely bubbly white head. Hoppiness evident on nose but for all of its promise whilst a very pleasant beer it came across as just a little too sweet, little too much malt and not enough hoppy punch. A6 A5 T7 P3 Ov13 3.4
Cask conditioned at Merton Beer Fest ’12. Greenish gold with white head. Dry, light malt body with a light lemony hop note. Clean and fresh, drying in the close, really quite decent.

Gravity, Solihull 09. Bit empty after the Pictish, with big hops but not as much in its locker to back them up. Misting gold with good lace. Herbal hop, orange, bay leaf, bite of apple aroma. Dry and almondy; alcohol detectable, good rasp of grapefruit, green apple, faint biscuit. Not bad.

Cask Conditioned, at the Market Porter, Borough, London. Golden yellow, with a full bright white head. Lovely citrus hop aroma lifting generously from the glass. Good structure and bitterness on the palate, with clean streamline flavours running front to back. Generous and complex to warrant a 2nd and 3rd pint. Lovely drop of beer, certainly didn’t seem retired to me last night.

1. Cask Handpump at the Crown Inn, Stockport 15/07/2006 Hoppy aroma. Clear golden coloured and hoppy with some alcohol present. Crisp and bitter finish. 2. Cask Stillage at the E & S Brewery, Elland 12/08/2006 Fruit and spice aromas. Golden coloured hoppy and fruity with coriander spice flavour. Crisp dry finish.
V 100piv. Vona vyrazna kavova silna. Chut kavova horka dlhsie ostava. Cosi mi tam ale chyba.

330 ml bottle. Murky black, stable fluffy head. Dry lemon notes, coffee, coconut, toffee, burnt malt. Dry bitterness. Medium bodied, oily creamy texture, soft carbonated, dry bitter finish. Very decent.

DWFIA; Bottle 0,5L. Named Pilger-Bier. ABV 5. Pours moderate, clear gold and frothy with a moderate lasting and lacing white head. Nose is shy, pale malt, toffee, butter, sitrus and spice. Taste is moderate sweet and bitter with a somewhat lasting citric finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to average.

Bottle @ home. Clear golden color, medium to full sized white head that lasts for a decent while. Aoma and flavor are malts, sweetish grainy a bit, a slight hint of sugar, lightly some dusty maltiness. Average body and low to average carbonation. Quite alright. 6-4-5-3-10.

Bottle. Clear golden color, thin white head. Slight floral, malty aroma. Dry taste, medium to high bitterness. Rather unimpressing aftertaste, maybe a bit malt and hops. Average carbonation, average body.

From the bottle. Pale gold with a fleeting, foamy white head. Aroma is yeasty white bread, apple, plastic. Taste is mildly bitter with a bit of a green apple undertone. Body is fairly light with a bit of water in the texture. Drinkable but not worth repeating.
Courtesy of Jaghana. Doree, tres legeer mousse. Nez malté houblonné typique. Gout malté noisette un peu doux et houblonné puis metal , amertume noisette fin de bouche.
Fles 50cl thuis. Fris, licht zoetig. Licht bitter en kruidige nadronk, maltig. (11-2013).

Bottle. Clear golden color, fine white head. At the start a very floral, grassy aroma, which changes into a more sweet, honey caramel aroma. Sweet taste, medium bitter. Honey, floral, herbal aftertaste. Low carbonation, silky mouthfeel.

0,5 l Bügelflasche. Aroma: Malzig süß, Sahnekaramellbonbon. Erscheinung: Goldgelbes Bier, flacher, weißer Schaum, gute Gardine. Geschmack: Süßlich, Karamell, minimal bitter. Nachgeschmack: Ganz leicht Säure auf der Zunge, im Abgang dann wieder eine leicht Süße. Gesamt: Süffig (im positiven Sinne).

0.5l flip-top bottle as a part of a bavarian beer set from marktkauf/edeka. pours a hazy pale golden with a medium white head and a nice lacing. aroma of floral hops, citrus, grains. flavour of grass, green apples, bread. little bitterness, dry finish. this is a zwickl not a helles, but what the hell, it is still good.

The smell of yeast, light sour, some bread. The white small head is foamy with a rather short duration. The body is pale yellow. A soft taste of citrus, some bread, light touch of cardboard. The body is light, dry and creamy with a normal carbonation.

Refrigerated 0.5 bottle poured into a weizen glass. Light brown with big beige head. Aroma is clove, medium body, medium carbonation, and good small-bubble lacing. Taste is clove, some chocolate, and banana. Not very dark for a dunkelweizen.
