Pours an average frothy off-white head that mostly diminishes. Body is hazy, amber colored and with sparkles visible. Aroma contains moderate malts (light bread, cookie, straw, molasses), light hops (orange, lemon), light yeasts (horse blanket, leather) and mainly sweet dried fruits like raisin, grape, cherry, apple and cassis. Flavor is light acidic, then quite sweet and finishing harsh bitter and a bit boozy. Body is medium to full with syrupy texture and soft carbonation. Unbalanced, it's ok up to the finish which is too harsh.
Bottled - LCRBM2 - A muddy brown coloured beer. The aroma is yeasty with brown fruits. The taste is a little too harsh. Candy sugar and yeast notes in disharmony.
Low Countries Ratebeer Meeting 2. Cloudy brown colour with no head. Sour woody aroma, some fruit, but not wonderful and too woody for me.
[2nd Low Countries RateBeer Meeting] Malty, butter aroma. Hazy, orange-brown coloured with a lasting, medium head. Taste is sweet, malty and fruity. Unimpressive.
LCRBM2: aromatic beer. Malty, thin to medium bodied. Very fruity, cherry esters.

Huge white creamy head. Hazy yellow color. Grainy, yeasty nose with intensive notes of blancmange powder. Flavor is quite grainy, light bodied and light yeasty with some hop bitterness in the end. Light dry finish. Unharmonic, very grainy beer.
Draught: Yellow color, white head. Quite sourly aroma of citrus and lemon. Flavor is fresh, light sourly with fruity notes. Light dry end. Refreshin but one-dimensional brew.
11th September 2009 Cask at Chapel Beer Festival. Clear brown beer. Low carbonation. Semi soft and dry palate. Soft toffee malt. Some hop balance. Finishes dry and malty.

Cask handpull at Market Porter, London. Chestnut, thin beige head. Earthy and fruity best bitter, drying hop on end is there but not over the top. Decent red berry jammy fruit. Fine. Little bit of yeast. Jammy strawberry.
Cask in the counting house. Aroma is fruity, caramel peppery hops, grassyness. Taste is similar quite thin but very drinkable.

Cask at the Old Manor (JDW), Bracknell. Brown with an off-white head, slightly cloudy; faint malt aroma; very thin and watery, some fruity malt and caramel flavours; slight bitterness to the finish; underwhelming.

Cask at ’Spoons, Milton Keynes. Amber brown with a white head. Faint aroma, definitely some hops. Pleasant light fruit and malt taste and slight bitterness. One of those rather ordinary beers that somehow ticks the boxes.

A Mes rate: Cask at the Wenlock. Solid mid brown with a bubbly off white head. Nice creamy malt aroma with brown sugar, vanilla and very light hops. Lovely nutty flavour with slight coffee and dusty hoppy tobacco. Nice bitter finish with a delicate sweetness and some more nutty notes. Good balance. Decent stuff.

The Fountain Inn, Gloucester, 02-09-06. This beer poured a light brown colour, with a small head. Really good easy quaffing ale which would make a good session beer, malty flavoursome and hoppy a very good standard bitter which unfortunatly I never quite gave the the respect it deserved as I had to neck it down a bit sharpish owing to a Rugby fixture kicking off 35 mins from the time I left this pub.

The body was dark copper with a light and slight khaki colored head. The aroma was smoky tobacco wtih some caramel. The taste was sweet caramel with a touch of smoke. There was also some musty old water, but it was not distracting. The finish was iced tea on this relatively thick beer.

Brought from my motherland Taiwan by a friend. "Takau" (meaning "hitting a dog") actually is a local Taiwanese slang word for "Kaohsiung", a city in Southern Taiwan where this newly founded micro-brewery is based. Coming in a 350ml can, “can-conditioned”. Canned date 31/08/2006, “best enjoyed within 60 days”. Served cool in a jug. Look: very dark mahogany hue, nearly black; the foamy tan beer head comes thick yet fluffy in texture, gradually settling to a thin cap with a huge hissing sound, while the carbonation remains lively throughout the drink. Nose: smoothly sweet dark chocolate-milk mixed very well American flowery hops, a peachy note and bits of roasted walnuts. Medium-bodied, harmonious, not too complex. Alas, the aroma doesn’t hold too long. Taste: thin-textured bitter black malts and slightly sour roasted malts upfront, with a tinge of treacles, chocolate fudge and roast nuts closely behind; the pale malts lend a lighter edge to the roastiness, as do ripe black plums impart a subtly sour fruitiness to balance the moderate malts... dryish+bitter licorice and hops quietly develop towards the medium-length finish. Palate: it feels slightly thin on the palate and the fluffy fizziness is not optimum. Overall this porter is slightly off-balance, with a sour fruity tinge as a balancer like a porter should have, but lacks a sound weight of maltiness to make a delicious porter. But for the first porter brewed in Taiwan, this is not a bad start!
Bottle. Aroma ismore floral, some herbal tones. Light golden color, white foam. At the beginning light malty sweet, after some hops also. Not bad.

(Bottled). Ty oh6gdx. Pale yellow color, small white head, lace. Aroma of grains, diacetyl and harsh alcoholic hay. Buttery, diacetylic, sweet malty with grassy late hop bitterness. Fizzy carbonation. Aftertaste has mostly light butter and is quite watery. Unremarkable Russian bulk lager.

Bottled at Petalax Beer Festival. Clear pale golden, rich head. Evident buttery diacetyl aroma. Sweet and medium bodied with some grass and stale butter. The diacetyl aside it’s fairly clean with a sharpish salty finish. Quite unremarkable, except for the diacetyl.
Bottled. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is malts, diacetyl and quite eggy. Flavour is malts, some diacetyl and a bit papery dryness.
500ml bottle. Nondescript aroma. Fizzy. Mostly bland. Slight sickly unpleasant chemical hops.

Bottled. Aroma of light skunky and herbal hops. Pale yellow color, white irregular head, few lace. Light sweet, malty, bitter and herbal hops in the flavor. Medium body and refreshing. Did go weel with baked potatoes and meatballs.

Draft... Clear orange ale with a mid-sized, creamy, white head. Malty, earthy aroma with notes of juniper and toffee. Solid malt backbone surrounded by medium bitterness and warm alcohol. Medium to full-bodied with a tannin mouthfeel and mild carbonation. Bitter, dry finish.

Draft - Could be a D-IPA just as well. Clear sparkling orange, thick white creamy head. Hopped up nose of earth, pine, and evergreen, with a soft toffeeish undertone. Well bittered flavor up front that becomes a touch boozey half way though. It receives a light sweet nutty maltiness that rounds it out nicely. Medium to full bodied, soft carbonation, dry bitter finish. One of my favorites from brewer Joe K. Locals should get out to try it soon. It goes very quickly...
Cask handpump at The Phoenix, Canterbury. Golden with bubbly white head. Faint grassy hop. Bit watery in mouth, no noticeable malt with nice dry grassy, citric hop on end. Inoffensive
Hazy yellow colour with medium head.Aroma of soap and ginger.I guess this must be a type of wheat beer,without to be well finising really bad.

Bottled. A hazy orange beer with a white head. The aroma is very perfumy. While the flavor is sweet with light notes of oranges besides a weird perfumy note, leading to a dry bitter end with notes of straw. The alcohol prickles the tongue towards the end.
rbesg06gt, bottled. yellow, light texture, hint of creamed corn in the aroma, flat and listless
[Sampled at RBESG 2006] Hazy golden. Spicy and herby aroma and flavour. A bit thin, but ok.
(Bottle at RBESG 2006) Shady yellow color, white head. Grainy and puke like scent. Thin grainy mouth feel, low bitterness. Grainy taste.
Hazy yellow, decent white head. Clove, ginger & pepper in aroma. Spicy flavour as well with some notes of orange. Thin bodied.
Somewhat hazy yellow, small head. Spicy aroma, some ginger and pepper. Thin, malty flavor.
(Bottle 50 cl) Hazy, pale pilsener golden with a nice, white head. Unusual aroma of ginger. Medium-bodied, lightly sweet with notes of ginger. Unusual but not unpleasant as such. 260806

column1: Arkells Her Majesty The Queens 80th Birthday Ale
column5: Bottle. Golden beer with a light head. The aroma is fruity, spiced and hopped, and the flavour is dry, toffee and roasted. Overall a disappointing beer.

column1: Arkells Her Majesty The Queens 80th Birthday Ale
column5: Bottle. Golden with a small white head. Aromas are caramel malts with toast and apricots. Flavours are soft buttery, toasty malts with initially sweet, then bitter lemon. Dry and hoppy on the finish. I can imagine the Queen getting rat-arsed on this.

column1: Arkells Her Majesty The Queens 80th Birthday Ale
column5: Bottle, at Kookfest, September 2006. Gold colour. Not fizzy to look at but intensely prickly on the tongue. Otherwise, pretty respectable. Hints of bread and toasty malt in the aroma, with noticeable creamy toffee too. More toffee on the palate but the hops are also pretty pronounced, producing a well balanced, smooth and easy drinking beer. Unfortunately, I’m a staunch republican so I have to score this beer 0.5. Only kidding.

column1: Arkells Her Majesty The Queens 80th Birthday Ale
column5: Bottle @ Kookfest. Pale colour. Unusual nose - slight banana with tangy hop. Grainy malts and sweet caramel. Not too bad but a bit on the sweet side.

column1: Arkells Her Majesty The Queens 80th Birthday Ale
column5: Kook’s Farewell Gathering. Malty, cardboardy, dull bitterness. Light coloured. Nothing interesting. Average and drinkable. Not a lot to say.

column1: Arkells Her Majesty The Queens 80th Birthday Ale
column5: Bottle (Chris_o Gathering06): Malty, quite bready and morish. Golden in colour. Tasty.

column1: Arkells Her Majesty The Queens 80th Birthday Ale
column5: Bottle at Kook’s Leaving Do at Chris_o’s. Deep copper colour, no head. Caramel aroma. Bit of toffee, very malty toffee. Some hop on the end. Goodish carbonation with prickly sensation on end. Goodish balance, but not sure about that toffee. Bit bready on the aroma.
GABF 2006: Hazy pale yellow color with a white head. Light tart citrus nise. Hints of rose hips. The flavor was sweet and malty with light fruit and tartness toward the finish.

This draft brew from the brewery in Indianapolis, IN poured a small sized head of finely sized white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a hazy typically carbonated dark orange colored body and a good lacing. The fruity aroma was malty with orange notes. The crisp semi-thick mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The complex flavor contained notes of malt and fruit. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

Draft at Brugge Brasserie. Small off-white head that became mostly diminishing, good lacing, hazy, and a straw yellow hue. Nose was malty, sweet and some spicyness. Ditto for the flavor. Nice mouthfeel and medium body.

Gold color; sweet malt aroma. Some tropical, meaty citrus fruit notes gave some tartness, but sweet malts were also present. Fairly smooth. Recipe from head brewer Rich Chapin. 19 IBU...don’t know ABV but not like a strong Belgian ale.

On tap at the brewpub bar as a full sampler, showing a black/brown hue with a hint of ruby highlighting at the base, an abundant layer of thick, cakey, brownish tan head foam with some decent persistence, and clingy spots & streaks of lacing. The nose was roasted, with a slightly burnt, smoke & wood scent, cocoa, and coffee on the back end. A little better than medium bodied, assisted by the subtle creaminess to the mouthfeel more than the moderate carbonation, the taste was similar notes, with the addition of some roasted, earthy, and slightly tannic bitterness, and a touch of mellowing, toffee sweetness. A tasty Stout, with all the necessary components. Recent batch brewed by Iain during Jim’s sabbatical. A roasted, iced coffee nose, a touch burnt, with just a hint of molasses. Medium bodied, with a lingering roasted & earthy astringency that was quite dry and favorably parched. Not much sweetness to speak of, and I liked it that way.

Not much aroma. Cascades when pulled from the tap. Fully opaque body. Light brown, Guinness-style head. Nice, yet unnatural, looking lace. Somewhatdry, but definitely more flavor than Guinness. Doughy. Nice. Faint bitterness. Quite good actually.

I start out a bit biased because I’ve never been thrilled with nitro’ed beers, but this wasn’t too bad. Looks nice, of course, an extremely dark brown body, clear at the edges, with a creamy tan head. The muted aroma has roasted malt, barley, and coffee with a touch of cocoa. A bit too smooth of a mouthfeel for me. The flavor accurately reflects the nose having just a hint of bitterness in the finish. Okay, but not a thriller for me. Rock Bottom Yorktown, Lombard, IL

Mug Club Draft. Muddy dark brown in color. A nice nitro swirl of tiny bubbles, under a half-inch ecru head. Smell is very light cocoa with hints of mild coffee. Taste has all the texture of a nitro oatmeal stout, not quite velvety, more a velour. Light vanilla and a slight Guinness sourness in the finish. No alcohol burn makes this an easy beer for lunch; I had mine with chili.

Never heard of "Ottweiler" before this, so perhaps this beer is already on here and I did not know where to look. However, this "altbier" is rather tame in every respect. Decent mounthfeel makes this Birra Rossa a bit different from many other "Birre Rosse" that make their ways into Italy. Nothing more than a nicely balanced, copper-colored alt. .33L bottle.
Bottle. Deep amber to chestnut body. Thin cream coloured head. Malt, hops, candied fruit, oak and rye bread. Bittersweet with a dry finish.

13th January 2018 Thanks to my sister-in-law, Sarah, for the xmas prezzie. Clear deep amber beer, small pale tan head. Palate is light, dry and has a decent fine crispness. Smooth dry malts, very mild sweetness and some earthy character. Mellow floral bitterness. Decent tangy fruits, a trace of BlackBerry. Smooth dry finish leaves a mild fruity bitter linger. Quite juicy if dry and fairly drinkable.
Bottle. Sweet toffee and nutty aroma. Pours with a dark copper colour and frothy off white head. Sweet malty flavour with toffee and nut notes. Medium body. Sweet finish.
Bottle at home. Pours clear deep amber, nose is toffee, caramel, floral, taste is similar. Standard bitter.
Bottle at home.. Copper... Thick bubbly tan head.. Floral toffee fruit nose.. Soft sweet toffee fruit nose soft caramel woody toffee fruit

Clear amber/copper color with small off white foam. Aromas of sweet figs and dried fruit with notes of caramel and a mild touch of chocolate malt. Palate, medium body with smooth creamy texture leaving long finish. Taste, sweet of oak, dried fruits following more bitter hoppy taste and nutty back bone. Overall, nice decent beer, not watery bitter, something more reasonable and actually enjoyable.

Bright bottled from cask at Kookfest, September 2006. Copper colour with a very slight haze. Earthy, vegetal aroma. Very flat mouthfeel. Fair amount of robust, rustic hop. OK but not particularly noteworthy.
Bottled from cask. Rough earthy malt characters, aswell as a slight green hop character. Quite sweet, with an empty finish. A little dull.

Pale dirty brown body with very little head. What do they use to brew this? This Thames Tunnel sure looks similar to the Thames River! I’m surprised by the low ratings. Of the countless light same-old cask Bitters I had in London this one was one of my favourite. Delicious toffee/malt flavours well balanced by those mild English hops. Nothing extraordinary, just well put together and something I could drink on a regular basis in large quantity.

Cask takeaway @ Kookfest. Mushroom, toasty cereal, earthy malts cellars and toffee. Light mouthfeel, soft and flat. Sweetish without backup of hops. Fairly similar to some other cottage beers but not quite as good.
A Mes rate: Cask at The Phoenix in Canterbury. Malt and toffee all round really. Bags of toffee in the nose and a surprisingly sweet flavour. Flat. Slight tartyness in the dryish finish.

Bottle at Kook’s Leaving Do at Chris_o’s Thanks to Mungo for bringing this one. Pale chestnut colour with no head. Earthy, toffee aroma, but tastes fairly flat in mouth even though it was quite bubbly in the bottle. Rich, like a number of cottage. Bit flat. Finish has some dryness.
Bottled from Cask (Chris_o Gathering06): Copper with a nice glassy hue. Nice clean bitter. A bit simple but nice fruits and malt.

22 oz bottle from backlog notes 07. Pours dark brown with reddish highlightsand a small beige head. The aroma and flavor have some roast, grass, funk, Brett, light chocolate, barnyard, wood,, fairly interesting beer from these guys, no sign of the abv.

750ml bottle poured into a shaker. Pours a clear nut brown with a bringt ruby hue. Aroma is tart and funky. Taste is light sweet and light tart. Super funky. Ok, this may be one of the better two brothers brews that ive had. Very enjoyable.

There is an aroma and a taste... Just not sure it's super pleasing to me...wish it was more saison ish and less horse blanketie...it's weird...like a sour a saison a blonde and your grandmas perfume store all in one... ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured a beautiful dark color that lit up terrifically under light to a deep ruby red. Notes were of yeast and malt. The taste combined the yeast with slight hops and grass.

A black saison that brown interesting. Pours a medium to dark cloudy brown, but far from the hue of a black IPA or imperial stout. An incredibly pungent funky brett aroma with notes of horse blanket, oak and chocolate. Moderate to faint sourness on the palate with dense carbonation
Retro release 9 o 15, thanks to secret Santa. Murky walnut color with fine creamy white foam, yeasty herbal aroma , flavor is yeast, roasted nuts, hoppy with nice finish
On tap at Busters on 28th, a black saison huh? more like a watery boring not even really black, no roast characteristic saison.. just bland and boring.

Bomber. Deep brown body with ruby highlights. Fizzy, off-white head. Aroma of char, barnyard, brett, roasted grain. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Light acidity. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Lightly tart finish. Taste of roasted grain and lacquer. Odd flavor — the roast and bitter hops are at odds with the funk.

I rather enjoyed this. Very mild oak and mild sour(brett) flavor. I think the sweetness countered the sour a little and made it less tart. A fuller bodied fuller mouth feel sweeter version of a mildly sour flemish brown. Serving: Bottle

22 oz. bottle. Pours brown black copper color with a nice tight soapy white head that dissipates to a wispy film and collar. Aroma has a nice farmhouse scent with some light citrus and malt notes which consist of lemon and fresh baked bread. Taste has subtle funky farmhouse along with a gentle tart brett flavor and bitterness and some plum dark fruit notes along with some roasted malt. Palate has a full and drying finish. Quite nice and unique!

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Hazy yellow color with a thin white head. Pungant sour nose. Very tangy beer with lots of lemon rind and what seemed like lactic acid. Finish has some clove spice. More tangy than I like in a hefeweizen.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Deep golden color with a sticky white head. Fresh hop nose. Lots of orange juice flavors with the finish tending more towards a grapefruit rind bitterness. Okay pale ale, and good with the fish and chips.
350 ml. can. Pours clear yellow, short fizzy head. Aroma is cabbage. Flavor is stale vegetables, paper and plastic. At least it was cheap!

(Bottle, Xi’an, China, Muslim Quarters) Pours a pale yellow body with a small white head. Aroma of grain and grass. Flavor of malt, mild hops, and lemon. Cold tastes similar to Budweiser than more lemon evident as it warms.

Bottle (in Xi’an) Clear pale straw, no head. Initially hoppy vegetable aroma, pilsner-like, but vanishes quickly. Medium body and carbonation. Sugary sweet with some short-lived bitterness in finish. A very strange beer - I would not be surprised to find that it is not brewed, but manufactured - it seems so artificial.

628 ml bottle, probably only available in the Shaanxi province, hence it is named after the city of Baoji. Pours golden, but a bit darker tinged than usual, quickly dissipating white head. Aroma is surprisingly malty. Flavor has quite a bit of malt, for a Chinese beer. These Still some off- adunct flavors and a little cabbage. A little bitterness lingers on the tongue. For a Chinese lager this beer is alright. Note: Chinese beers actually list the amount of pure malt on the label and this one says 10 (degrees) which is most I have seen on any Chinese beer - the same as Qingdao.
(Bottle) Pours a clear pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma of light citrus and skunky metallic. Falvor of metallic and grain with a watery mouthfeel.

On draft at Lakers near Peking University, served in a ’tube’ that holds 3 liters. Yep, go tube or go home. White, soapy head. Clear light yellow in color. Aroma has a hint of rice and B vitamins. Watery taste.
Hellgelbes minimal trübes Getränk mit sehr kleiner Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr schwach nach Malz. Geschmack wässrig, minimal malzig, säuerlich.
Slightly more bitterness than a typical Chinese macro lager. Not too interesting.
Draught @ BeerMania, Beijing. Light straw colour. Light body. Touch of graininess. Refreshing-ish. Clean, nothing wrong with it.
(can in Beijing) pale lager yellow with white head. Faint smell of corn in the aroma. Thin malt flavor with thin body.

Bottle @ weekly tasting shared with Dutchdrebus. Clear amber color, average sized white head. Aroma is a bit sweetish and indeed cherries. Taste lightly malts, cherries, hints of sweet and sour. Average body, medium carbonation. Quite decent.
Bottle @ benzai. Clear amber to ruby colour with a small slightly pinkish head. Smells cherry mostly. Tastes cherry, cherrypeel, watery. Thin body, soft carbo.

Bottle, 6.5%. Oxidized aroma, some cherry and slightly metallic. Cloudy, very dark red colour. Big, stable tan head. The flavour is mildly cherryish, unfortunately also with a distinctly metallic aftertaste, almost bloody. Hint of berry bitterness and sourness to balance the fruit. Not too sweet, just right for me. Not sour either. Good mouthfeel, almost creamy carbonation. Would have been an OK beer without the metal notes. Must be drunk quickly, then the aftertaste is not too bad.

Bottle. Orange red color, big creamy head. Cherry juice and chewing gum in the aroma. The flavor is like cherry wine, the beer is relatively dry. I expected much sweeter, but there is only a light fruity sweetness. Short aftertaste. Certainly not bad, but there is room for improvement.
Bottled. Aroma of fermented cherry juice. Red color, light hazy, off-white head, fair lace. Light sweet, light bitter, some cherry but not much. Not complex but very drinkable.
A Mes rate. Bottle at LCRBM #5. Slightly cloudy, yellow gold body with a good white head. Fruity, faint tarty sugar notes, some burnth plastic. A little rough at the edges and uneventful.

At LCRBM 2009, Kulminator, Antwerp (Belgium) Hazy blond, orange body. White, fizzy/creamy head. Aroma of hops, flowers, ... quite subtle but ok. Moderately bitter, lightly sweet flavour (yeasty and flowery). Well balanced. Not very complex, but ok.
Bottle at LCRBM5. Cloudy pale gold, lasting white head. Looks like a wit, some lemon on aroma. A bit funky in the mouth. Bit dirty. Some citrus on end, quite agricultural. Not great.

Bottle 50cl. @ LCRBM09 - Low Countries RateBeer Meeting V, Kulminator, Antwerpen, Belgium. Unclear light to medium yellow color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, rosehips, citrus - lemon, moderate yeasty, anis seed, star anis. Flavor is moderate sweet and light light acidic with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090905]

Bottle shared at LCRBM09. Sweet, flowery nose, fragrant and pleasant. An odd plastic note that can be ignored (at first). Taste is less pleasant: lightly sweet, rolling into a one-dimensional, sticky, disproportionate bitterness. Lightly bitter aftertaste with more of that floral perfume. Odd. Not quite all there.

[9/5/09] Bottle sample during LCRBM at Kulminator in Antwerp. Cloudy yellow. Aroma of fresh fruits, some wheat, citrus and some spiciness. Sweetish flavor with some acidity and some slightly unpleasant spicy bitterness with fruits and candies. Light-bodied.

Bottle &#40LCRBM 09&#41: Heavily perfumed lemony-orangey nose, some wheat in the background; moderate sweet-bitter flavour, very light bodied for a beer of 5.5%; short fruity-wheaty finish with a little touch of alcohol. Refreshing, but not too complex.......
LCRBM 2009. Looks good, modest turbid, nice white head. Grasy aroma. Tastes a bit moldy, modest fruity. Finish modest sourish, still grasy. A bit boring but not really bad!
pale, hazy, white foam, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, light sweetness, medium bitterness, floral, citrus, hay,
Hazy light blond beer; white head. Fruity aroma especially oranges. Tastes similar. Very refreshing one with a nice bitterness in the aftertaste.
On tap: as BNB and Silphium noted, fairly typical of Founders. However, that is not to say that this is a bad brew. I found it to be very hoppy (PNW varieties), and in a good way.

Draft at brewpub. Poured clear dark amber with a fizzy white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate sweet malty and sour citrus aroma. Medium body with a slick texture. Medium bitter flavor with a medium smooth bitter finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable beer.

dark amber/brown body with small off-white head...aroma is typical of a Founders hop-infused beverage...as Silphium notes, it begins very piney and finishes with a sugary malt complex...flavor is of Amarillo hops...very similar to all of their IPA variations. Very tasty, and well done.

On tap at Founders. Murky orange-brown body, thin/medium buff head. Piney hops aroma with caramel and sweet breads. In the vein of their Double IPA and Devil Dancer, this is a dense, rather complex IPA with a strong emphasis on Amarillo hops at the beginning of the palate, leading to a firm, less distinct bitterness backed by ample bready, toasty, caramely malts. Incredibly smooth for an IPA of this ABV and bitterness. Probably a one-off of the Devil Dancer.

Draught@Punavuoren Ahven. Amber color, small firm off-white creamy head. Clove hoppy aroma with notes of sweet maltyness. A bit watery, but creamy mouthfeel - like in Kilkenny. Light toasty and hoppy finish and aftertaste. Very Irish ale like and tastier than the most of its Irish exemplars.

Dark coppery color, little yellow head. Mildly caramelly, slightly hopped and dry aroma, fruits come up also. Thin to medium bodied. Traditional Stadin flavor: hopped, floral, slightly flowery and caramelly, aftertaste lats with dry lemon.

On tap at CBC, Clerkenwell on 18th October 2019. Russet copper with pale tan scantly lacing foam, shallow in depth. Spicy cherries and plums in an invitingly smooth fruity aroma. Rich and intense cherry, ginger, spice and soft fruits in-mouth, with a hot peppery note. Spicy, fruity finish. Velvet smooth on a full body. Absolutely superb.

pours clear extra pale yellow and showing its legs. slightly floral and dry fruits, white grapes, bone dry white wine, minerals, faint apples and pears, hint of spices, woodsy and nutty notes. flat carbonation, medium body - oily, dry lightly floral and mineral finish. interesting offering but using old varietals of apples doesn’t add complexity and depth necessarily.

2018-12-27. Crisp yellow body, headless. Aroma of apple, lightly dry. Flavour is similarly apple forward, with touches of stems and skins tannins around the edges. Average bodied palate, uncarbonated. 7/3/7/3/14 Small sample at the cidery, Quebec City.

pours unclear extra pale yellow with a small bubbly and dirty head. floral and vinous notes - white wine grapes, dry white wine, faint apples, pears and small orchard fruits. lively yet a bit strong carbonation, light body - tad watery, dry lightly floral and mineral finish. ok.

Originally rated December 2006. Purchased on the island where it is made. Pours a bright golden clean colour with no usual bubbly small head. No carbonation is found either. Weird, says carbonated sparkling light cider on the bottle. The nose is nice though, with the apples sticking out. Quite a dry mouthfeel. The taste is not really punchy, so lacking in taste. Mild apples and the dryness stops quickly after the finish, so the aftertaste comes back to a watery feel. So, great smell, but overall missing the boat.
Aroma:light aroma,.peach and apple jice.. Appearance:Clear yellow,no co2... Flavorwater,with a light cider flavor...

2018-12-27. We tried two versions, one aged a year in the bottle. (They don't seem to distinguish the two in the labelling, unless I wasn't paying attention.) The younger version is crisp and yellow, sweet fruity apple. Fairly simple. The older version has more caramel notes and a touch more complexity. Both are smooth and sweet throughout. The paler version has more bits of stems and skins tannins around the edges. 7/3/7/3/15 Small sample at the cidery store, Quebec City.

pours clear pale yellow, no bubbles. faint but fresh red apples, flowers and white grapes, dry white wine, hint of woodsy notes. flat carbonation, light body, dry lightly floral finish. interestingly more complex than their (higher abv) hard ciders, although a tad muted. ok.

Brought from my motherland Taiwan by a friend. "Takau" actually is a local Taiwanese slang word for "Kaohsiung", the 2nd largest city in Southern Taiwan, where this newly founded micro-brewery is based. Coming in a 350ml can, “can-conditioned”. Canned date 31/08/2006, “best enjoyed within 60 days”. Served chilled in a small weizen glass. Look: murky dark yellow-orange honey hue; the white creamy beer head builds up slowly but surely, to 1cm thick then slowly dissipates with patience… gentle streams of fizziness decorated with large bubbles ejecting from the bottom of the glass. Pretty solid. Nose: typically weizen-yeastiness: sweet lemons, green bananas with a touch of green apple peel, combined with a touch of vanilla, clove, while a swirl brings out some apple-ish fruity perfume. The wheatish maltiness is just about enough to render a rough balance, while the dense sugary edge of wheat-malts bears a little resemblance of oxidised honey as well as caramel. Flavour: a light palate is full of doughy wheat-ish and lesser caramely malts, on top of the sour-sweet fruitiness of lemonade, green banana and bubble-gum, while the spicy yeastiness gradually gathers pace and demonstrates a rich flow of ground clove in parallel with a prevalent flow of savoury-sweet, exotic shellfish-ness(like steamed clams!!), and a slightly tangy, dryish-bitter aftertaste like dried lime-peel, light but lingering finish. Palate: fine fizziness on the mouthfeel, medium-bodied, with an initial good balance falling off and not holding well as the carbonation evaporates. Considering it’s a canned weizen, I’m quite surprised by the quality and texture it has shown. Well down, Takau! This is not some easy beer to start one’s business with, mind you. The only downside is the yeastiness does bring me some headache which hasn’t happened to me before with any HEFE-weizen…

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Lumpy Dog Brown
column5: Sample por at the brewpub. Pours a dark brown with a thin off white head and good lacing. Aroma is molasses and nut and wood. Taste is sweet sugars, molasses and a woody nut. Pretty solid brown ale.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Lumpy Dog Brown
column5: On tap at the brewpub (Lombard, IL) One of my favorites of the standard fare. Pours a deep dark brown with a small head that doesn’t do to much in the way of sticking around. Aromas are lighter, touches of nutty sweetness, chocolate, and a bit of smokiness. Maybe some coffee. Taste is similar, lighter fare on the side of light-med bodied, surprising, easily drinkable, a little watery. A decent darker brew and for 2 dollars a piece on Tuesdays, I can be a believer. Cheers!

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Lumpy Dog Brown
column5: On tap at the brewpub/restaurant bar. Footed ale glass served. Labeled a brown ale, but on the board as a Scottish, description connotes Scottish style elements, tasted like a Scottish, and is rated as a Scottish. Poured a dark brown with some ruby tint. The head was foamy, diminishing, and offwhite/light tan, with some good lacing. The aroma was lightly sweet with roasted malt. The flavor retained the roasted notes and added some dark fruit with a hint of tangy nature. Not much,if any, hop bitterness. The body was medium to full and very drinkable.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Lumpy Dog Brown
column5: Brown color with a medium head. Aroma is typically malty. Standard caramel malt with light fruit. Boring - isn’t this the same as the Corporate version?

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Lumpy Dog Brown
column5: On tap at Rock Bottom Yorktown. Rock Bottom Yorktown Lumpy Dog Brown is a deep mahogany color with a nicely formad off-white head. The aroma is very fresh and the taste is smooth with nice malty flavor and some sweet notes of prunes and caramel.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Lumpy Dog Brown
column5: on tap at RB Yorktown, pours dark red with off white head. nose is smokey, caramel, toasted biscuity. flavor has some smoke, toasted biscuit, and balanced well. a decent hop presence too. nice.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Lumpy Dog Brown
column5: Draught. In an effort to give the local Rock Bottoms regular line up a shot I tried their Lumpy Dog on draught 02/17/08. It was a solid brown, appearing reddish brown with a creamy light tan head. Aroma was typical malty, a bit cereal grain. A touch nutty, some sweetness from teh malts, not bad, a bit over carbonated in the mouth which was a turnoff.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Lumpy Dog Brown
column5: On tap at brewery. a very fresh sample. pours reddish mahogony with light tn head that is nicely frothy. Aroma is sweet and dark. Starts with a blast of dark caramel and syrupy flavor. saublte roasty chocolate and mouthfeel is full. has a hint of cherry and cigar leaf under the malt.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Lumpy Dog Brown
column5: On tap at R.B. - Yorktown. Poured a clear, deep reddish-brown with a nice initial cap of off-white head. Toasty caramel and vegetal notes form an odd aroma.. light earthy tones.. not appetizing. Odd blend of dark caramelly sugars in the flavor.. some toasty chocolate notes.. too sweet and it had an ugly finish. A little bit tacky on the palate. Didn’t enjoy this one.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Lumpy Dog Brown
column5: There are rocky tendencies to a slim, ecru head that leaves moderate lacing above a ruby body. Smoked malt aroma with chocolaty, cocoa notes beneath... all of which carry through to the flavor. A harsh sweetness doesn’t bother me before hefty, roasted malts. A thick body carries full flavors. Screw any allusions to hoppy English ales, we’re approaching robust Porter territory here. On draught at Rock Bottom Yorktown, Lombard, IL 60148

Bottle at home. Clear golden with white head. Sweet pils malts, light herbs, a touch of cardboard, honey, soft peach. Under medium sweet and bitter. Almost medium bodied with slick feel. Not bad but really just like a macro lager.

Bottle 33 cl, 6 months before BB date. Pours a clear golden with a small to medium and fading white head and an aroma of soft sweet malts, floral hops, cardboard, grain and caramel. The taste is medium sweet with a medium body and a soft carbonation. Old, but still a bit enjoyable.
Oerol, terugweg in de trein. Bier gekocht bij slijterij op West. Lekker zuipwater. Weinig smaak maar het gaat als een tierelier naar binnen. Backlog from 2015/06/19.
Bottle @ home. Clear golden color, small white to off-white head. Smell and taste malts, cardboard, dust, old fruit, musty. Crap.

Bottle 25cl. Appearance: Clear yellow color with a small to average, fizzy offwhite head, leaving a fair amount ogf lacing. Aroma: Malts, cereals, butter. Taste: Quite sweet malts, slight more bitter grainy finish. Body is light, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. Not much wrong, but also not much going on and as Urtype Pilsener your expecting a bit nmore.

25 cl. bottle @ home, bought @ Coop, Culemborg. Bottle was a gusher, which is a bit surprising in a lager. Didn’t look, smelled or tasted infected though. Slightly hazy yellow with a firm white head. Grainy aroma with some hops. Taste is bitter and finish also. Quite a nice pilsener.

Clear golden colour, white head. Aroma of malts, butter, biscuit. Malty sweet flavour. Malty sweet biscuity finish. Not bad, but was hoping for at least some pronounced hoppiness in an Urtype Pilsner. (From 25cL bottle @ home)
I think this is actually better than most people here write. Has a slight fruity arome and is very easy to drink. Comes in a 25cl bottle

Bottle 25cl. @ home. Clear medium yellow color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, buttery, sweet malt, sour malt. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20081117]
Bottle in Schiermonikkeoog. Yellow body, some head. Dry with fruity nose. Sweet tasting. Okay. This whole Zeevaarder series is rank.
Fles 33cl thuis. Licht kruidig, rood fruittonen, malten, licht zepig. (12-2017).
Bottle at home. Hazy amber with a thin beige head. Notes of orange zest, metallic oxidation, yeast, bubblegum, passion fruit. Medium body, low carbonation and a bitter-sweet aftertaste
Oerol, terugweg in de trein. Bier gekocht bij slijterij op West. Meer blond dan amber. Backlog from 2015/06/19.

25cl Bottle Appearance: Clear dark amber color, with a small beige head. Aroma; some malts, some raisin ? . Taste: malts, light raisns, a hint of caramel, slightly bitter. Average to medium body and carbonation.

Backlog rating. 33cl bottle at the Chriso’s May tasting, London. It pours a hazy amber color with a small tan head. Aroma is sweet and crispy, with notes of sugary malts, dried fruit, stale hops. Taste is again quite sweet and simple, with caramel, dust, dried fruits. Light to medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, meh

Bottle shared at Chrisso’s May 2014 tasting 25/05/2014. Thanks to Leighton. Golden dark orange coloured pour with a loose white head. Aromais nutty malts, slight stale, and some warming spices like nuutmeg, Flavour is rather dull, some orange, soem caramel and some oxidation. Palate is flat and flabby. Boring beer.

Bottle shared by my uncle. Clear dark amber color, small off-white to beige head. Weird aroma, some malts, some grape peel. Taste malts, dark grape peel, a hint of caramel, slightly bitter. Average to medium body and carbonation.

25th May 2014 Tasting at the ever gracious ChrisO’s. Lightly hazy gold beer, small white head. Palate is light and airy and a little soft. Very modest carbonation. Tired sweet malts, touch of paper and honey. Liggt dried fruits. Light papery finish. Not quite up to scratch.
Chriso May 2014 tasting. Amber lasting white head. Not fresh on aroma. Some malt. Some citrus some orange. Bit stale.

30 cl. bottle @ home, bought @ Coop, Culemborg. Dark clear amber with a thin white head. Aroma of boiled cabbage, similar to low alcohol beers, with some malts. Taste is luckily slightly better; roasted malts with some light molasses and some hops. Semi bitter with a good aftertaste.

250ml bottle Appearance Clear medium yellow colour with a average frothy head., leaving some good lacing, Aroma : moderate yeasty, coriander,citrus. light parfumated Taste: moderate sweet, quite some citrus and parfumated floral and , citrus finish.Aftertaste is similair and has a long duration. Body is thin, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. Far better then expected, but it needs the rigfht temperature not to cold not too hot.

ok eerlijk toegegeven, voordat ik hem nog moest openen had ik mijn bedenkingen, ’t zal wel een waardeloos bier worden d8 ik. maar het viel mij eigenlijk best wel mee. ’t is geen topper maar echt slecht was het ook niet. aan de andere kant moet je hem niet laten opwarmen in de zon, want dan is ie daadwerkelijk niet te zuipen... maar verder typisch witbiertje, licht en vrij dun. citrusje aanwezig.
Tap, didn’t take proper tasting notes. Spicy, lemon, low carbonation. Not bad.

Backlog rating. Bottle at Craig tasting at Chriso’s, London. It pours a light straw color with a medium white head. Aroma is crispy, bready, lightly spicy, with notes of tangerine and grass. Taste is crispy and grainy, with notes of hay, cereals, bread, caramel, grass and citrus. Light bodied with good carbonation. Overall, somewhat too grainy

Bottle shared at Chriso’s mid-week lasting 03/07/14. Hazed yello hay coloured pour with a halo of white head. Aroma is orange and lemon citrus, peel, dry, nice wit yeast presentation. Flavour is composed of sweet orange peel, hay, wit yeast phenols, doughy wheat grains. Palate is soft and a biut flabby and grainy on the tongue. Not a bad wit.

Bottle at Chriso going Dutch tasting, 03/07/14. Clear pale yellow/blonde with a moderate off white covering. Nose is citric rinse, bready pangs, musty, light caramel. Taste comprises melon, lemon rind, light mineral notes. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Sub par wit.

3rd July 2014 Craig on Heat Tasting at ChrisO’s. Light haze, very pale gold beer, small white head. Soft dry light palate. Sweet papery malts. Mild sweet generic fruits. Light airy finish. Papery and messy.
Bottle at Craig on heat tasting. Pale gold thin white head. Ok some wit some soap ok hop.

Bottle shared at chriso’s. Pours clear yellow with a foamy white head. Gummy white grapes in the nose, some pale bread. Medium sweet with sugary cereal, white bread, hay, gummy fruits. Light bodied with average carbonation. Sweet finish with light paper, flowers, white bread, grape. Meh.
Bottle at chrisOs... Light yellow... Small white head... Soft fruits.. Light grassy lemon nose... Soft fruits.. Light yeast lemon

Bottle at the December THT. Poured a hazy reddish brown with a frothy off white head. The aroma is sweet fake sugar, raspberry. The flavour is moderate sweet with a bubbly fruity sugar bomb palate. Medium bodied with lively carbonation.
THT December at deanso’s, still. Murky brown red with light pink head. Big sweet with a pinch of salt. Cherries, berries, lemonade. Soft carbonation, medium body. Feels like a smoothie.
small bottle shared at december THT. Black cherry aroma. Clear pink/amber pour. Too sweet.
Bottle at THT. Clear bright red with pink head. Massive cherry candy, that’s basically it. Very sweet. Medium bodied. Like Belle Vue or something, liquid candy.

Bottle shared courtesy of and with a slightly enraged (but willing to share) Malaysian stink badger at the December THT. Clear red with a ring pink head. Aroma of massive artificial candies cherries. Flavour is heavy sweet. Light bodied with soft carbonation.

Helder rood met roze kraag. Aroma van zoete en zure kersen en de smask evenzo waarbij de zure kersen er toch bovenuit springen tov de redelijk zoete kersen, mondgevoel is zacht en glad. Op een warme zomerse dag kan het .

25cl bottle Appearance: Clear deep dark red ,with a average to large, frothy, Pinkish head. Suprisingly good lacing for it’s style. Aroma: Is a bit too Artificial cherry syrup , Taste: Heavy sweet cherry syrup. Howver it’s saved by a citric and wheat sour finish and aftertaste with a long duration, Which balance things out. , Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft.

25 cl. bottle @ home, gift from Hilde but bought @ the Local Coop Supermarket. Dark red with a pink head. Smells and tastes like cassis (blackberry lemonade). Not overly offensively sweet but still more lemonade than beer.
Beetje frisdrankachtig. Bijna geen schuimkraag, beetje roodbruinig van kleur. Smaak is goed met een ’zuurtje’ erin.

Bottle 250ml. Clear deep dark red colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, pink red head. Aroma is moderate to heavy cherry, almonds. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light light citrus acidic with a long duration, cherry sauce, cherry, almonds. thin. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20120318]

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Powerhouse Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a near clear gold with an orange hue and a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a decent amount of citrus that is slightly bitter with a grain backbone. Flavor is similar with citrus upfront with some tropical fruit and a bit of grain underlying.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Powerhouse Pale Ale
column5: My main beer at the Bottom, if there isn’t somethign special on tap. Nice color, hoppy aroma, and easy to drink with just enough hop bite. Not as good as the seasonal American Dream but - a trusty standby for me.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Powerhouse Pale Ale
column5: copper pour with a small white head. light hops aroma and taste. great blend of hops.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Powerhouse Pale Ale
column5: Poured draft at the brewpub (Lombard, IL). Poured a dark golden color with a bit of a darkness to it. Nice substantial head that sticks around. Nose of sweetness and hoppy floral and fruit notes as well. Taste is a well balanced APA that was sufficient. Light caramel malts balanced with some decent hops was predictable, but a good predictability for myself. A decent APA that did a good job of keeping me interested in coming back.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Powerhouse Pale Ale
column5: Mug Club served at Yorktown. Cloudy, amber/orange color, with an off white, foamy head, and nice, clinging lace that spiraled down the inside of the mug. The aroma was floral, a little resin, sweet fruit, and mid-strength citrus. These notes in addition to a mellow hop bitterness, balance this medium bodied APA nicely. Cask pour 7/25/09: Although the nose was even more fragrant due to dry hopping, the head and lace were impressively thick and long lasting, and the flavor carried the consistent hop bitterness to finish; the body fell off quite a bit to more of a watery state. Consider the rating a push...not a pull. Jim’s latest version is a bit more assertive, with caramel sweetness, grapefruit, and a touch of pineapple tang, livelier carbonation, a more pronounced & lingering, citrus & rind hop bitterness, and a rather crisp finish. +.1

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Powerhouse Pale Ale
column5: Cask: Pour is hazed orangey amber with a dense sticky off white head...smell faintly citric and earthy...taste is nice and toasty with a faint lingering citric bitterness....nice....

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Powerhouse Pale Ale
column5: On tap at Rock Bottom Yorktown. Rock Bottom Yorktown Powerhouse Pale Ale is a cloudy, yellow/orange, amber color with a thin, creamy off-white head. The flavor is wattery with some nice citrus flavors attributable to the hoppy undertones.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Powerhouse Pale Ale
column5: hazy apricot, slight head dissolving into bubble ring. big grapefruit, evergreen hints in the nose. taste is smooth toffee, and light grapefruit. slightly bitter after-taste. light & refreshing. tasted at Rock Bottom Chicago First Annual ROCK FEST

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Powerhouse Pale Ale
column5: Slighly hazy light amber thin nice lacing white foamy head. Slight hops aroma mild flavor is mild floral bitter. Some lingering bitterness.

column1: Rock Bottom Yorktown Powerhouse Pale Ale
column5: on tap at RB Yorktown, pours cloudy gold with white head. nose of piney, grassy, grapefruity hop notes. flavor is much of the same, actually pretty hopped up for an APA. very sessionable and surprising how hoppy this is for a regular line up RB beer. I also had this on cask and it was served at room temp and tasted infected. the cask score is 5/3/3/2/8=2.1.

Bottled: Light fruity peach aroma, not intensive. Light yellow color, nearly no head. Flavor is more lemonade than beer. Peach flavor, artificial sugar notes, nearly no beer character. Light bodied, unpleasant sugary, empthy finish. Ugly.
Draught at the pub: Aroma of elder flowers and lemonade, sweet. Yellow to golden color, frothy head. Nice elder flower flavor, light sweetness, dry bitter end.

Draught: Light flowerly, sweet malty aroma. Light amber, cloudy color. Small foamy head. Light to medium bodied. Light sourly, light citrus hoppiness. Light sherry notes and malty roastiness. Dry bitter finish. Very good, aromatic beer. Maybe a bit light in the end.

Draught: Black tea color, off-white head, quickly diminishing. shadowy, low carbonation. Fruity, light herbal hop notes. Hints of honey and lychees. Flavor is sourly ,alty with fruit and caramel notes. Dry, aromatic bitter hop finish. Very hoppy and aromatic "lager"?
don’t bother with this one... super ugly, clear mostly a bit of pee looks like water and that’s what it tastes like, nothing bad about the nose or taste just not worth paying money for water

On tap at the Mickey Finn Brew Pub. Poured a light and clear yellow color with a small sized white head. Aromas and tastes of watered down something (there was barely and aroma or taste to this one). I like the way the serving suggestion says serve this with a salted rim and a lime (at least it would have some flavor and smells then!). One brewed for the masses.
I had this on tap, took a growler home for further study and it fell out of the car and lost most of its head. Still, it was a favorful and plaesing beer, albeit sans carbonation.

With apologies, more or less, to Gary Taylor, who has this at the brewpub as one of the three (out of eight or so) beers that’s actually brewed on sight - - I should’ve rated this as a drainpour, totally, but I’m in a good mood (regardless of my needing a new ejector pump for the addition’s washroom) because of good vibes from non-beer related sources. It pours a clear, iced tea brown with a minimalist’s head. No lacing. The smell is of blueberries and a handful of mud. There’s a rusty malt somewhere beneath the heavy blueberry taste. Hard to recognize as a beer. Or as a fruit drink. Nice brewing facilities at the brewpub. I wish Gary would use them more wisely. Even the IPA, which I’d enjoyed in the past, has been dumbed down to the point that the hop bitterness wouldn’t wash the blueberry flavor away. Taylor Brewing Company, Lombard, IL

On tap the Springfield PA location billed as the "Fancy Lawnmower Light". Pours a translucent clear yellow with a small bubbly white head. Aroma was lightly sweet and malty, really no hop presence. Flavor was light, grainy, grassy and malty. Just really light in flavor and aroma overall. Watery.

On tap at the Springfield, PA location. Poured a lighter golden color with a very small, if any head. Aromas and tastes of grain, very lightly fruity with a light grassy finish. Lively yet thin and watery body. Oh yeah, the person seating me told me this was a new one and was a Pale Ale even though the menu he gave me listed it as a lighter beer brewed in the Kolsh style.

On tap at Springfield location. Pours a translucent golden amber with really no head. Aroma of caramel, grains and light hops. Flavor was malty with a light hop presence. Really kind of non-descript overall.

On tap at the Springfield, PA location. Poured a medium and see through orange color with a small sized off white head. Aromas and tastes on the weak side and contained some citrus, caramel, and grains. Body was thin and watery.
Quality beer? Hmmm well ok. It was nothing wrong here. But a pale lager at 3,5%.....you know what you get Spendrups pale lager with more water Evil never sleeps [Can from Konsum in Strômstad, Sweden]
Pours clear pale yellow with minimal head. Aromas of sweet maltyness, canned corn, malty syrup. Taste has malty and sweet notes of grains, bread, syrup, hints of herbs
Can. Golden coloured with a small white head. Aroma is bulk-bready and malty, hints of some hops. Flavour is vegetably malts and earthy hoppyness.
Beer share at Lennarts, Malmö - Golden pour with white head. Grassy hoppy and grainy, seeet malt, some corn sweetness, cardboard, very watery, rough grainy finish
Can at Lennart. Clear golden colored with a small white head. Malty aroma of grain and hops. Malty flavor of hay and hops. Hoppy finish.

Can. Pours clear golden liquid with moderate white head of low retention. Grainy nose. Sweet corn. Some cardboard. Light body. Lively carbonation. Clean malty taste. Bready. Minimal ending bitterness. Rather basic and inoffensive.
*Can from Hemköp in Stockholm. A bit unround. Sweetish grainy with malty hints on a watery body. No bitterness, "golden" sweetish aroma.
Can from Lucullus in Örebro. Very light smell, I get a hint of bread. Light taste and it is dominated by a clear metallic aroma. the metall is very disturbing and makes this very hard to drink.

Off-white head, clear pale golden body. Tiny dots as lacings, one mat at bottom. Aroma of pale malts, bread, wet straw. Tastes pale malts, bread, wort, bread’ish hops. Finishes in a bread with a few thin hops. [33cl can 3.5%abv BB08DEC14]

33cl can from ICA Kvantum, Strömstad. Pours clear golden with a minimal white head. Grainy aroma with some slightly fruity notes and hints of cooked vegetables and grass. Slightly sweet, fairly watery and not much flavour. but fairly decent bitterness. Not really bad, drinkable, but nothing more.
On Tap @ the Brewpub. The head is medium, the body orange and cloudy. It smells yeasty-sour. The taste is yeasty, fruity, a bit citrus. Nice Weizen! 9/11/11/11/-/11

Draft @ brewpub in St Petersburg. Pale, milky bone yellow. Mild lemon-lime and pith aromas. Lively carbonation. Subtle yeast character. Better than the standard weizen. Refreshing with nice acidity level.
Draught @ brewpub, St. Petersburg. Cloudy yellow. Fluffy head. Slightly peppery, wheaty character. The body is a little bit hard. Finishes dry, overall a decent wheat. Quite drinkable.

Medium creamy white head over hazy yellow body. Acidic, milky aroma with notes of coriander and citrus. Taste is light acidic, flour, and again coriander. Vaguely citric background. Decent wit. Drinkable. (0.33l on tap.)
Lovely. Bought this at the Continental Market in Kirkcaldy after tasting it at a market stall.

Bottle 75cl. Cloudy orange with a slim white head. Looks like a wheat beer. Intense sweet and sour apple aroma. Taste of nicely sweet apples and barnyard. Quite highly carbonated (maintaining its head). Very well balanced, with a lovely dry finish. Excellent.

Pours black with a big brown head; aroma is very sweet, some fruitiness and sourness, can?t get much roast nor chocolate, weird smell for a stout; taste is very very sweet, let?s some dark malts shine through, sweet drinking-cacao, got a quite strong sour note, sweet cacao finish; mouthfeel is thick creamy with high carbonation and a heavy body; a weird brew

column1: Shady Grove Sparkling Locust Honey/Apricot Dry Mead
column5: Draught. Pours a greenish tint of yellow with lines of bubbles and a slight white head and falling legs. The aroma is vinous with light honey and faint fruity sweetness, occasional waft of sulfites. The flavor has a dry champagne-y quality to it, but the honey comes out in the finish. The apricot is very mellow; I probably wouldn’t have been able to isolate it had I not known it was there. Good to accompany the sushi with which it was consumed, but not a great mead on its own.

column1: Shady Grove Sparkling Locust Honey/Apricot Dry Mead
column5: On Draught. Pours a very light, clear yellow with a quickly fading spritzy head. There is just a medium level of honey in the aroma and a light dry, fruitiness. The mouthfeel is very dry and quite light. The honey is subdued for a mead. The apricot flavor is an afterthought more than anything. Mild alcohol burn is noticed.
Golden color. malty flavor. No specific aroma. Hint of onions. Distant hops, revealing itself slowly in the aftertaste.
Aroma is caramel with a bit of toffee, some grassy hops too. Taste is similar with more roasted notes coming in.
Skt. Clemens, Aarhus, DK. Tap, 090710. Amber with white head. Aroma of malt and fruit. Flavor is honey, spices (heather) and caramel.

Draugt at Sct. Clemens. Creamy white fair mostly deminishing head. Dark yellow cloudy colour. Moderate hoppy slightly acetic aroma. Week but delicate sweet/bitter flavor, Average finish. lively carbonated, ok palate. Refreshing mild taste, not as soapy as other Clemens.
Draught at the brewpub "Sct. Clemens". Unclear yellow - white head. Typical Apollo/Sct. Clemens taste/aroma. Malty, straw, light citrus, light honey, sweetness.

Draught at sct. clemens, Aarhus. Hazy yellow with little creamy head. Aroma is mildly malty with sweet honey. Great mouthfeel and the honey makes the beer stick a little to your teeth. Sweet and fresh.
Draught at the brewpub. Light hazy yellow colour with a small white head. That apollo yeast I just don´t like, fruity aroma and a sweet light honey, spicy taste. Medium body with a light dry finish.
Very pale yellow with no head. Honey, slightly spiced. Thin and watery.No body at all!
Cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma is dominated by grass with some malt and flowers (honey?). Cloying sweet flavour, candy and honey.
Draught @ the brewpub, Odense. Hazy golden color with a white head. Light aroma of fruits, honey and spices. Light flavour of fruits, spices and hops. Light hoppy finish.

(On tap) Slightly hazy pilsener golden with a neat, creamy head. Lightly tart fruity aroma. Fairly light body with light, fruity notes. The honey is hardly detectable. Decent balance between sweet and sour and manages to end rather dry. 110906

An unclear orange beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma is sweet and quite perfumated flowery, like a grass meadow in summer time, these notes are combined with some heavy somewhat cloying notes from the yeast. The flavor is very sweet, and the honey combined with the flowery and citrus notes leaves a layer on the tongue. But it also has a note of sour milk, is this a brewing flaw? the flavor really reminds me of youghurt naturel with eucalyptus honey, which I loved to eat when I was a child, but I’m not that fond of it as an adult and in my beer. I happy, that I only ordered 25 cl, since it get very cloying in the end.

@ Sct. Clemens. Pitch black with a dark brown head. Absolutely beautiful. Aroma is roasted malt and a bit of smoke. Flavor is rather sweet and light bitter. The finish is sweet and has a lasting roasted bitterness. Could use a bit more body, but certainly the best I’ve ever had from Sct. Clemens. 050211
Growler shared by Anker, thanks. Black body with a medium brown head. Aroma is sweet, malt, chocolate, yoghurt. Flavor bitter chocolate, sweet liquorice.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Tap at Spuyten Duyvil. Deep orange colour with a massive tight-laced tan head. Nice looking beer. Aroma is very fruity showing red grape, blackberry and raspberry that I just didn’t know this hop had. Rich and sweet smelling with a contribution from both caramelly/toasted malts and the inherent sweetness that this hop seems to have. So fruity that it’s hard to believe there isn’t added blackberry. Caramel and heavy toast overlayed on the rich heady fruitiness and a fairly assertive earthy resinousness. Flavour is chewy and sweet up front but is balanced by the high hop rates. Moderate to strong bitterness on the back. I was expecting nothing and this certainly gave me a lot more than that. A very unique and tasty brew.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at the Sly Fox IPA Project 2006. Solid IPA. Had a good sweet bitter bite to it. Not as dry as some of the other IPA’s from here.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft from SFR. Pours deep coppery with 1-finger off-white head. Aroma is caramel malty and hoppy. This one tasted and finished on the less fruity but more bittery hoppy end of the spectrum. As with all the SF varietals, this one has a solid, firm, hefty caramel malt base that shields and tempers a well hidden alcohol wallop that will knock you on your ass if you aren’t careful. I’ve tried to session the varietal IPAs, and it doesn’t work too well.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: on tap at SFPN at Andy’s. Aroma is floral hops, some spicyness, and citrus. Taste is the same, with some citrus and malt....lightly bitter throughout....nice beer.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draught at Brewery: Aroma of spicy hops. No malt aroma. Poured FLYERS (Burnt) Orange. Great color! Medium, white, creamy head lasted. Great lacing. Clear. Flavor of grapefruit and citrus. Bitter! No other flavor really discernible. Medium body. Nice texture. Lively carbonation. Bitter finish. Overall, a good IPA.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On tap at Phoenixville. Pours a lightly hazy golden amber with a medium creamy off white head that left some lacing. Aroma was floral, mixed citrus and some pine. Also getting some caramel and grapefruit as it warmed. A little on the light side as far as aroma goes for an IPA. Flavor of spicy hop, caramel, very nicely balanced. Great hop bitterness, citrus, grapefruit.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Average offering from this year’s IPA Project, deep amber in color, big off-white with excellent lacing around the glass, nose full of hops with hints of citrus, pine & earth, fairly full in body but very drinkable, abrasive body of flavors, not a whole lot of malty characteristics for balance, this beer is basically all hops, bitter & dry finish with more tones of pine & citrus

Pours brilliant golden amber with no head. Aroma with hints of an alcohol and pears. Similar is flavor, with evident alcohol note, sweet note of pear, which you can detect it only, if temperature of cider is over 10°C. Drinkavble, but not so enjoyable. One bottle is over my head.

[On tap at Back of Beyond (JDW), Reading] Sharp & sour apple up front, Lots of vanilla and a light oakiness come through after. A creamy, slightly powdery mouthfeel. Lasting sour apple & vanilla aftertaste. Always struggle for something objective to say about ciders, but this was quite a pleasant one.

With a sour and sweet aroma this dry cider is easy on the nose and easy to pack down. It has a clear yellow appearance with a light carbonation coming from the bottom. It has a sharp taste on the tonge with with a short linger to the back of the throat with a nice apple fizz flavor. Not many additional eliments, a pretty rudementary cider.
Box - The Anderson - Fortrose. Nothing special, couldn’t really find anything nice to say about this one.
Tap. Clear golden with tiny fully diminishing white head, Flavour is apples, little tart, little acid, little funk and a little citrus.
On tap@The Warf.Pours golden.Aroma of apples, funk and leather with some notes of cheese.Flavor is sweet leathery apples with some funk.Medium body.Nice still cider.
On tap at the Wharf. Golden colour with no head. Aroma is ripe, apple, yeast. Flavour is dry, apple, alcohol, yeast, acid, citrus. OK Cider

On tap The Wharf. A clear, still cider that smells big time of leather. Like walking into a horse equipment store, or maybe like walking past a chicken farm. Apples too of course. It’s a bit thin on the palate, very dry and quite puckering. Lots of apples and leather in the flavor. Some citrusy acidity. Apples, acid and leather in the finish. Nice. 101204
Cask @ The Angel, JDW, Angel N1. Pours a hazy pale golden color with no head. Has a fruity sweetish fresh apple aroma. Sweetish fruity apple flavor. Has a sweetish fresh apple finish.
On tap at Pig’s B’ear Festival ’10 at The Pig ’n’ Falcon, St Neots, Cambridgeshire. Gold. Sweet fruit aroma and taste. A little cream and astringency. Acceptable if not particularly memorable.
Keg at Bavaria Brauhaus. Reddish brown with a medium of white head. Burnt toffee aroma, flavour is caramel, yeast, a little clove, banana
Dark brown with thin head. Aroma and flavour have plenty of sweet malts and caramel. Quite bready.
Draft at the Barrel & Horn, Bromley. Copper coloured pour with a white head. Nose of sweet malt, toffee, orchard fruit, caramel. Flavours of banana toffee, sweet malt, more orchard fruit. Good.

On tap, poured into an Imperial style half pint glass. The aroma is mellow, with a citrus and caramel character as well as a very light pine note. It pours a clear golden brown with a very light micro bubble white head. The head reduces to a thin ring with a light, wispy surface coverage that leaves very light lacing. The taste is a medium bitterness with a light sweet backing. It has a somewhat gritty texture, but it does go down smooth. It’s a medium bodied IPA with a light, prickly carbonation. Characters of caramel, dry grassy / chalky, and a juicy citrus finish this beer. It finishes crisp, and leaves a light, short lived aftertaste with flavors of pine and citrus
April 29, 2014 - on tap at Lily’s. Clear yellow pour with some head. Aroma and taste of citrus and piney hops with some malt.
tap at 2012 michigan winter beer festival. caramel malt and some hops. it’s just ok.
Smells of hops and malt. A bit mild, and one dimensional on the flavor. Not particularly good, but not terrible. Really lacks the ipa hop bite and malt balance. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap: The aroma consists caramel, roast notes, pine, and some perfumey/floral notes. It’s a transparent amber with a one finger white head that leaves a nice sheet of lacing on the sides of the glass. The flavor starts with moderate toasty caramel flavors. The finish has piney and floral hops. Light-medium bodied mild carbonation. Overall, it’s decent, but I’m not a fan of caramel flavors in IPAs.
on tap at brewery. pours cloudy off orange with medium thick head. floral aroma . taste is very hoppy and mango with lasting flavor solid ipa

MBGSF 2011. Poured clear copper color with an average frothy off-white head that lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate balanced aroma. Medium body with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Moderate smooth bittersweet flavor with a moderate bittersweet finish of medium duration. This is an interesting brew.

On-tap at the pub, one of their winter seasonals...Pours out a super clear medium straw, nice. There is great retention from a bright white head, but even better lacing. It totally coats the glass...The aroma is ultra boring, only a whiff of hops, then just dead...The taste is ok, mostly light hops, a hint of pine, just not a lot going on...The finish and feel are great, lasting and very carbonated. Too boring to drink, not worth my time. Pass.

This draft brew from a festival poured a small sized head of foamy fine to medium sized white colored bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a transparent orange colored body. The aroma was hoppy and caramel malt. The mouth feel was smooth at the start and mediumly tingly at the finish. The flavor contained notes of hops and caramel.

Draft. Off-white small head that quickly dissipated, lackluster lacing, transparent, no visible carbonation, and a golden hue. Caramel, some malt, and piney(?) hops for the nose. Flavor was caramel, lightly malty, hoppy, and dry. Mouthfeel was fairly smooth and dry. Light body.
(Draught). Nice smell, acidic and spicy. The taste is very fresh and fruity and it has a good bitterness with spicy elements in the aftertaste.
Clear golden liquid with a small white foam. Smell of coriander and citrus. High carbonation. Taste of coriander and citrus. Very fresh.
50 cL bottle. Pours clear yellow with a huge white head. Aroma is mild citrusy. Dry and hoppy flavoured. Light citrusy flavoured. Dry bitter and crisp finish. Nice and easy.
Hazy, bright, yellow color. Not so much foam. Aroma of citrus and herbs. Taste of citrus, some spices and a bitterness in the end.

Bottle, 50cl - Hazy pale yellow color with a small creamy head. First thing that hits u with the aroma is citrusfragranced cleansing detergents. Flavor is flowery sweet with strong notes of citrus and detergents. I’m thinking there must be something wrong with this bottle since I don’t remember it tasting like this the first time I had it...

Bottle from Jesper: Clear golden / Yellow color, with a nice creamy head. Aroma of lots of citrus, flowers, and citric nose in the end. Flavor is smouth creamy mouth feeling. Thin body, and a short sweet malty finish.

Draft @ Bishops Arms, Malmö. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity spicy coriander aroma. Sweetish spicy citrus and coriander flavor. Has a sweetish wheat malty spicy finish.
(On tap) Slightly hazy pale golden with a creamy, white head leaving laces. Very perfumed coriander nose. Light body with fruity accents and a strange and astringent bitter finish. 180908
Cloudy golden with medium white head. Sweet aroma with loads of citric notes. Sweet flavour with lemon, malty and coriander notes. Ends sweet.

Draught, 4.7%. Hazy greyish golden colour, small white head. Very spicy aroma, loads of coriander. There is also plenty of coriander in the flavour. A bit thin flavour and mouthfeel, but also some lemon to give it flavour. An exaggerated wit, but OK.
Smak och doft av karamell, humle, malt, citron, citrus, örter. Avrundas av en tydlig beska.

Bottled at Stockholm Beer Festival 2007. Copper color with creamy head. Perfumed aroma with clove, pepper honey, grassy hops and plenty of fruity esters. Sweet, honeyish, peppery, clovey and fruity flavor with grassy dry hops. Dry hoppy finish.

Bottled at SBWF. Clear dark golden with a massive white foam. Hoppy grassy aroma with notes of raw yeast, pepper and lemon. Bitter flavour of grass, lemon, yeast and pepper. Bitter citrousy and grassy finish. Nice!

Bottled@SBWF2007 Dark honey color, small beige head. Grapefruit and pine needles in the nose. More IPA-like than Belgian ale (or maybe XX Bitter). Good pine needle hoppyness - I guessed Amarillo but German hops are used here! Nice fruityness and so far the best one Sigtuna I’ve had.
Bottled@SBWF2007. Golden colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is hoppy, grassy and slightly yeasty. Flavour has pretty much the same, with some nice alcoholic sting also. Belgian Ale meets IPA.
(Stockholm Beer Festival 2007) Draught. Golden/amber color. Hoppy, grassy aroma with some fruity notes. Hoppy flavor, grapefruit, some other fruits, grassy and a bit metallic. Some citrus.

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 7 Oct) Golden amber colour, slightly hazy, with frothy white head. Fruity nose with apricots, oranges and hints of yeast. Fruity taste, slightly sweetish but mainly dry, notes of yeast, apricots, oranges and mandarin. Hoppy and spicy finish. Smooth, but firm, mouthfeel. Very nice beer.

[Bottled at the brewpub] Hazy amber, rich but brief head. Aroma of grass and marzipan. Dryish with firm, rounded mouthfeel. Evident but not overpowering Belgian style almondy yeast character. Powerful spicy hop finish with biting bitterness. Think De Ranke XX Bitter, think excellent and you can picture this beer.
Small bottle at a very nice noodle and sushi place in Japan town, San Francisco. Tasted like a warm ocean breeze (even though it was served cold) on a beautiful spring day. Very refreshing and light.

Bottle at home. Pours fairly clear with tinge of yellow. Nose is mostly alcohol but with some coconut. Tastes of banana, vanilla, rice, coconut milk and alcohol. warming finish pretty strong stuff without much nuance.
Alright, I’m just being a ratings whore with this one. I dont know how to appreciate sake like I do with beer. Definitely sweet, but not overly fruity. Clear pour.
Bottle from Mitsuwa. Pours as clear as water. Aroma is dry and a little fruity. A little bit of a banana like flavor with some alcohol. Not really all that subtle.
on tap-pours an off white head and copper color. Aroma is (too)perfumy raspberry. Taste is perfumy raspberry, wheat. OK carbonation.
The razzberry flavor in this wheat ale was harsh and overly tart. ( I don’t know if it was from fresh or from extract.) Wheat malt character was largely undetectable. I was very disappointed.

Cask handpull at the Grainstore tap, Oakham, 26/06/14. Narrow haloed gold. Aniseed, cedar and chlorine aroma. Paper aniseed flavour stale with plastic and cardboard. Some redeeming almond and cherry blossom. Unlikeable.

Cask, Swan and Rushes, Leicester. Brewed in "celebration" of Wayne Rooney’s injury. A bright amber beer with a small head. Aromas are fruity with fresh hops. Some light caramel and toffee malts. Flavours are caramel and toffee malts with pear and apricot fruitiness. Lightly hoppy. A bit thin, but decent.

column1: Richbrau Attack of the Bloob Blueberry Wheat Ale
column5: Thanks to maniac for the bottle! Pours a hazy reddish color with a pink head, almost disconcerting. Aroma is of blueberry pancakes. Flavor is tart blueberries, followed by a touch of sugary grain, and a finish of fruity bubblegum. Not horrible, but not quite my thing either. The sour note really helped this one.

column1: Richbrau Attack of the Bloob Blueberry Wheat Ale
column5: This beer is sort of a brick-ish reddish color. It has a fruity, sweet blueberry muffin aroma. It tastes buttery with a slightly blueberry flavor that’s just a touch sour.

column1: Richbrau Attack of the Bloob Blueberry Wheat Ale
column5: An interesting beer, body is of a blueberry juice color with a small colored head. Aroma is slighlty buttery and fruity. Taste is rather nice, and lacking in the diacetyl. Blueberry, wheat, hops, very nice overall. Semi-sweet and dry ending.

column1: Richbrau Attack of the Bloob Blueberry Wheat Ale
column5: Cloudy brown body with a small creamy white head. Sweet blueberry aroma with a noticable wheat background. Flavor of light blueberries with some wheat in the end.

I got to try a barrel tasting of this when I visited the brewery before it came out. As I understand, they won a bronze that year for the beer. The brewmaster told me that he used about 15 pounds of pure honey per 60 gallon batch.
(draft). Clear gold color. Small off white head. Light sweet honey aroma. Honey and alcohol flavors. Avg duration. Light alcohol finish. Thin/slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

GABF 2008 poured a clear gold with a lingering ring of ivory foam. Aromas of honey, fruittiness, light straw and light spice. Palate was medium bodied smooth and slightly syrupy. Flavors of honey, carmel and fruittiness with a smooth lingering sweet finish.

Draught at the brewpub Cloudy golden color. Strange aroma, fruity, like grapes, or wine wort. Strong body, but the alcohol kick is strong too; sweet malt flavor with fruity notes. It reminds me some German blond Doppelbock. More a curiosity than a great beer, but drinkable.

12 oz bottle. higher alcohols very evident, yet does not belie its 12% abv. Tastes more on the 7-8% level. Still very drinkable. Honey evident in the aroma and in the flavor, the malt tries to keep up but just can’t. A bit out of balance, but still a pleasant surprise.

Sample at the brewpub. This beer pours a clear honey color with a thin off-white head that diminishes steadily. Spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma of honey and brady malt, along with some spice. Medium-bodied with a mouthfeel like a lighter Barley Wine, this is definitely a sipper. Flavors of wheat, dark malt, tart fruit and honey are all present. The finish is round and sweet with a lingering honey and spice aftertaste. Although this is a unique beer, it is hard to imagine drinking an entire snifter of it.

12-1-07 tap at brewery Smells of honey and sourdough bread, with a background of alcohol. Hard to swallow because the taste of alcohol is not well masked at all. Can actually taste the honey too. Has a honey texture and aftertaste - the name is not lying - this is a HONEY beer! Not big on the honey texture - it seems to sap all the moisture out of the mouth and stays on the tongue for longer than I’d like and the alcohol presence in the taste isn’t great either.

2007 PP Strong Ale Fest: Poured a clear golden color. Sweet aroma with honey and malt dominating. Moderate level of alcohol on the nose. Sweet malty flavor to start. Honey and alcohol on the finish. Medium-full body.

Name: Hawaiian Honey Aloha Ale Date: November 30, 2007 Mode: Draft Source: Tasting, Strong Ale Fest Appearance: hazy dark gold, fine off white head Aroma: sweet honey and malt aroma with a peppery spicy edge Body: big body with a bit of stickyness Flavor: rich sweet honey flavor, touch of alcohol, light spicyness adds the needed complexity and balance, lasting sweet honey finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4 Date: December 01, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Words: fermented with champagne yeast Appearance: clear dark gold Aroma: dry honey aroma with just a touch of sweetness, light earthyness Flavor: rich honey flavor, light sweetness considering the amount of honey but I guess that’s why it’s 13%, light spicy pepperyness from the alcohol Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: ** /4

Pours light yellowish with a smell of almost exclusively honey. Alcohol also present in nose. Taste is much the same with sweet honey, and alcohol warmth in the finish. Never had a mead, but this is what I imagine it being like. All 13% is noticeable. Interesting, but not something you’ll want much of, I’m guessing.

7/27/2010: Piece Fornicator... Aroma: Biscuit; yeast and spice; some alcohol. Appearance: Cloudy, tarnished gold color, dull; whispy white crown; hanging lacing. Flavor: Wheat, generic fruitiness, grain and biscuit maltiness; tinge of white grape; flash of alcohol in the finish; strong and gets stronger as it warms; moderate, earthy bitterness in the finish. Palate: Good mouthfeel. Overall: Good, but what style of beer is this? Seems like a wheat bock... Draught (8% ABV) at Piece in Chicago. Rating #19 for this beer.

Bottle 22fl.oz. Clear medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, grain, malt, fruity, sweet malt. Flavour is moderate to light light heavy sweet, light light acidic and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration, fruity, peppery, malty, sweet malt, pineapple notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20111216]
clear yellow, small white head. crisp hoppy aroma, faint sour tinge, faint note of medizine. flavor is mals, fruts, hps, faint citrussy note.
Bottle at Pinball’s - Thanks. Clear golden - white head. Sweetness, honey notes, light hay, light grainy notes, light gunpowder, rather high sweetnes - too sweet.
