Sample from 65 cl. bottle. Clear, golden colour with a white head. Aroma is sour apples, malts and caramel. Sweet taste with notes of caramel, bread, sour fruits and light hops. Bitter, dry finish.
Bottle at pinball. Clear golden coloured with a medium sized white head. Fruity aroma of malts and caramel with notes of bread. Malty flavour of caramel, bread, fruits and hops. Hoppy finish.
Bottled. Light golden colorued. Unclear. dense off white head. aroma of sweetness, herbs and some fruits. flavour of herbs, sweetness, light caramel. Medium bodied. fruity end.
Bottled. A hazy dark yellow beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of malt and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, lemons, and straw, leading to a dry and alcoholic finish.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is fruity, peachy and slight citrusy. Mild yeasty. Light metallic, fruity and light yeasty, Light peachy and smooth fruity into the finish,

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of Pinball. Pours a clear yellow with a creamy white head. Sweet malty nose with some hops. Medium body, again a solid base of sweet malts with a slight tartness. A dry hoppy finish. I believe this to be slightly infected. 161211
Amber colour with a soapy head. Piney, citric hop aroma. Grapefruit hop flavor, lingering bitter finish. Quite good. GCBF.

Bright amber colour. Big woody hop aroma. Sweet flavour - lots of caramel and toffee. Light bitterness. Very chewy IPA, too much so. The low attenuation of the house yeast serves many of their beers really well, but not at this gravity level.
[2006 Great Canadian Beer Festival] A golden IPA with a mild head. Smells very strongly of hops, but the taste isn’t as strong and overall has a nice mouth feel. A really nice IPA, very drinkable.

Hard to rate this @ the Farmer’s Market with that hipster fish monger downwind. Lowball glass at home, sweaty bottle. Clear, active, yellow & amber body. Smell is mushy/caramelized red fruit, grass, alcohol, & yeast. Lacking. Taste is better. Damp, macerated apples. Saline. Very mellow alcohol. Not much tartness. Could be juicer. Moderate acidity. Earthy bitterness. Pinch of sourness on the finish. The carbonation is really nice. Strong, but not irritating. Husky dryness. After a few slurps, my tongue feels like I was just eating a bowl of almonds. Tasty cider, but it could use a bolder nose. I’m more concerned though about what kind of sucker pays almost $24lb for swordfish?!
Pouring at the Applepalooza event at the Astor Center. Pours a clear straw gold. Apples and pears on the nose, sweet candy. Light musky yeast. Apples dry out a bit, crisp on the finish.

750mL Bottle, poured at CiderDays 2011. Complex, but a bit calus. The bitterness is very forward in this cider and I think that’s something that’s a matter of taste. As a hoppy beer drinker, I notice the bitterness in cider, but rarely comment on it’s intensity. Great structure and complex. A cider for slowing down. Enjoyable.

A: Pours light yellow with a small white head. S: Aromas of apple skin, light booze, and a hint of tartness. F: Tart apples, light spice, no booze despite the ABV. M: Medium in body, light carbonation, tart finish.

bottle Tampa xmas gathering pours a light hazy golden, thin fizzy white head. aroma and flavor, what really stuck to mind is how acerbic the mouthfeel was, nice dry finish with bitter apples, but I would have loved to a tad more sweetness in there.
Never would have guessed that this was 10%, alcohol nicely hidden. Pale yellow color. Flavor is slightly acidic in carbonation, apple skin, light tartness. Nice cider.

I want to preface by saying that goldtwins and JoeMcPhee know nothing about good cider (for goodness sake they think everything tastes like dill). Special bottle provided by apoptosis and notalush (yeah I put the woman first, someone thank me for it) [Completely unrelated, I am having deja vu right now]. The cider does pour an ugly color (which is usual for a lot of cider), almost clear water but has a hue of yellow. Aroma is some booze, isopropanol, light apple sweetness, which is spiky. The alcohol however adds to the heft of the beer, which is uncommon in a lot of ciders. Taste is granny smith apples skins’, slight sour apple, grapes, and again heft from alcohol. Again the alcohol ends a heft (and in a way a legitimacy) to the cider which is rare among ciders. P.S. screw Larry and Joe.

Poured a clear pale yellow with a bubbly white head. The aroma was crisp and sweet with notes of red and yellow apples. The aroma had a clean finish. does that make sense. The flavor had a short sweetness with notes of apples and tannic apple skin. Clean finish and a lively mouth.

Bottle shared by notalush and apoptosis. pale straw colour. Aroma is quite light and boozy. Crisp appley nose, lightly acidic with a touch of tannic appley flavour. Cidery flavour (duh), with a light lingering peppery flavour. Decent Normandy-style dry cider. Quite dry and champagne like. Fine carbonation.

I’m not that experience with cider’s in general, so this is mostly an opnion of how I enjoyed drinking it...it has a pale yellow body with a big bubbled, quickly fading head. Highly carbonated. the finish is slightly sweet and wine-like. Strong, natural apple flavor with lots of yeastiness. A good amount of tart sourness. Crispy apples in the aroma, with honey as well. I look forward to trying more of their products in the near future.
Clear, golden colored, small white head. Malty, grain, medium sweetness, light toffee and biscuit, medium-light bitterness, grassy and floral. Medium-light bodied, soft carbonation, tad watery.
Cask at the David Macbeth Moor. Pours clear gold with no real head. Aromas of lemon barley water. Taste is thin, flat stale malt. Sweet finish.
Cask at the standing order. Pours clear golden, nose is floral, sweet toffee, taste is similar, ok.
Cask at a pub in Oxford. Fruity and malty smell with a light hoppy aroma. Similar taste. Easy to drink.

On cask at the Alexander Graham Bell. Appearance - golden and murky. Nice head. Nose - delicate and slightly malty. Taste - a mixture of green vegetables and malt. Some fresh citrus on the finish. Palate - close to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a fairly fresh finish. Overall - needs more early hopping. It could be a tad more bitter.

Cask by hand-pump at Hengler’s Circus, Glasgow (6.0% abv) on 3 Mar 2014: hazy golden amber, small lively off-white head, melon and tropical fruit aroma, thick film of lacing, sweet, fruity, syrupy, prolonged fruity aftertaste. Half pint (4.2%) by hand-pump at Crystal Palace (JDW) Glasgow on 15 Jul 2019: faintest malt aroma, pale golden amber, very short-lived off-white head, negligible lacing, bready, biscuit malt, some caramel, oily, sweet malty finish. (5 3 7 3 14)
Cask @ The Edward Wyllie JDW. Hazy yellow amber, good head. Biscuit, grain tropical fruit aroma. Very dry biscuit resin flavour. Bitter aftertaste. Unusual but drinkable.

Cask at the Marine Hotel, Stonehaven. it pours clear golden with a small white head. The nose is wood, earth, nutmeg, cinnamon and honey. The taste is straw, grain, light bitterness, touch of honey, spice, Chelsea Bun and some astringency with a dry finish. Light-medium body and soft carbonation. A touch watery really... Ok at best.

Uneventful neutral nose with a clear cut brown filtered body, slim head. Steely ramping grass sheen on the palate with a dour backend. Overall finishing on a sultry bowling authentic malt sweetness turns the screw really well.

Cask at GBBF, August 2006 (I think - notes not entirely clear). Gold in colour surprisingly enough. Some grassy hop character although not exactly bursting with them. Light biscuity malt. Clean, dry mouthfeel. Not particularly memorable but decent enough.

Bottled 330ml. -from Eataly Genova. Slightly unclear paaaleeee yellow coloured, medium sized airy white head, dusty and mild spicy nose. Light yeasty, mild spicy, fruity and wheaty with dryish spicy finish. Heavy carbonation.
Spices, wheat, hay, cloudy yellow with a good white head, light body, medium carbonation, spices, hay, lemony, a bit of soap...not my favorite wit.

Ottima Weiss molto equilibrata, aspetto limpida bionda schiuma. A grana fine bianca, al naso lievito, leggera banana. Bevuta scorrevole, birra semplice ma ben fatta, dolcezza contenuta con sentori di frutta e banana. Carbonazione media.
Wheat, lemony, tart, some yeast notes, cloudy yellow with a thin white head, light body, quite fizzy, taste is similar...not bad.

My Bottom Line: Pear juice, white grapes and citrusy angles whirl into an acidic finish in this otherwise phenolic, vinous Weizen. Further Personal Perceptions: -A creamy head of foam covers the misty white. -The mouthfeel is slender and fluffy. -Once you get used to the higher-than average acidity, this is really quenching. -The nose doesn’t let on to the prevalent pear juices and acidity. Clovey phenols are kings in the aroma. On tap at Bir&Fud.
Tap. Color dark yellow with small white head. Aroma yeast, wheat. Taste wheat, sour, yeast.

Bottiglia 33cl, comprata in birrificio e bevuta a casa. Chiara torbida con schiuma fine e persistente. Ottima waizen. Esteri alla banana come da stile, bella acidula e beverina. Montegioco sugli scudi ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhold

33cl bottle. Pours reddish brown with heavy sediment, smallish head. Aroma i start berries, smells vinous and winelike, oxidized. Flavor is sweet and malty, hint smoky, hint of "incense" flavor, also VERY boozy, this tastes like berry malt schnapps. Oddest flavor almost like frankincense, its strange and boozy as fuck.

Van 't vat. Wazig roodbruin bier met een weinig wit schuim. Geur: fruitig, rood fruit, licht zoet, mout. Smaak: licht zoet, karamel, alcoholisch, fruitig, wat maraschinokers, wat amandel. Volmondig. Medium koolzuurprikkel. Afdronk: zoet, fruitig, wat cassis, wat alcohol verwarmend. Al bij al een aanvaardbaar zoet en complex bier.

Bottle. Pours hazy brown with a medium, bubbly off-white head, medium retention. Moderate caramel and bready malt, dark fruits, lightly oxidized, light spicy alcohol and a sweet finish. Full body and medium carbonation.
Keg at open baladin. Pours deep amber, nose is caramel, toffee, light fruit, taste is sweet, toffee, berries.
@Saint Bon-Chien & Friends - hazy amber beer; aroma of dark fruits and molasses, blueberries; full-bodied way too sweet; sticky palate; some tartness; aftertaste of caramel and blueberries

Ok it’s an atypcal barley wine but...aroma of plum, dark druits with a tart sensation from the blueberry, full body, quite fizzy so extremely easy to drink, alcohol is more than well hidden, again a bit tart with more blueberry and other dark fruits, maybe some year in a cellar can improved this beer...goo job.

11.2 ounce bottle from Winking Lizard. Smell the blueberries for sure. This is hazy reddish in color and not much carbonation. Think I was expecting more from the description. I don’t taste the blueberries and do taste the 11percent alcohol. Taste a little more like plums and has a dry finish. Overall this is a very interesting beer that I’m sipping on.
Im Birra Berlin gekostet. Ungewöhnlicher Barley Wine in Farbe und Geschmack. Das macht der Heidelbeerensaft.

On tap at Ranzani 13, Bologna on 2-Sep-2016. Hazy amber colour with a thin white head. Aroma of alcohol, malt, dark berries and pine. Full bodies and soft carbonation. Alcohol up front, with the added blackberries adding a subtle tartiness to the ale. Sweet, medium hopped, with lots of caramel, malt and alcohol.

Bottle shared with Simonsen at Hvaler Dark copper, thin beige head. Smell of vinous malts, caramel, herbs and spices. Medium sweet, nice malty flavors, quite herbal. Medium bitter, resin tail. There are some good tendensies in this one, but, it’s too heavy for me. Bottle share is recommended

Draught, Ambasciata di Recco, Genoa. Misty orange-golden body. Odd agrumey nose, something strange about it. Acidic odd agrumey taste, completely off, a bit funky too. Not completely offensive and drinkable in that state but far, faaaaaar from what a hefe should be.

10/10 Draught at the L’Ambasciata di Recco, Genova. Murky pale yellow bodied with medium sized and compact head. Fine aroma, yeasty and estery bubblegum, typical for the style. Flavor however, was sour, don’t really get how, we thought it might be a bit old barrel, but supposedly isn’t made well. Some esters may be felt beyond that. Sour finish. Ruined beer which you can’t enjoy.

Bevuta all’Ambasciata di Recco a Genova &#40dove ora penso abbiano trasferito anche la produzione della birra Lion) pessima weizen con odore di solvente, acida, probabilmente infetta, quintali di sedimento e ci hanno pure informato che era il principio del fusto &#40facendoci aspettare mezz’ora per servirla&#41.

No head, hazy yellow-orange. Old dog poop (the poop being old, not the dog); wheat and/or other grains. Meaty esters in the taste, not fermented out, soupy; seems to bubble out of a fermenting tank in problems. Light body, despite the former: it’s as suspended undiluted grist. Disappointing, unfinished beer.
oro schiuma media media persitenza naso speziato leggere note di malto e cereale non molto corpo buona dose di spezie piuttosto effervescete
On tap at Drunken Duck, Quinto Vicentino. Pours cloudy golden with medium white head. Malty, some vague citrus notes, light hoppiness, bit yeasty, sweetish. Light bodied.
Bought as Lanik Pils. Very floral spicy hops. Prefer a bit more dryness or fruitiness. Not sure about the floral spice. A little overpowering the malts.
In se’ nonostante il corpo esile racchiude un perfetto equilibrio tra il malto e l’amaro della luppolatura e della "fermentazione". beverinissima.

Dark brown coloured body with a three centimetre tall light brown head that fades fast to just a small coating on top. Aroma of roasted malt, smoked peat, lactose, cream, oak and a good deal of vanilla pods. Medium-bodied; Very dry, roasty flavour with the earth, nuts and malt all coming through, with a touch of a vanilla and oak flavour along with a lot of lactose and cream flavours. Aftertaste very dry, with smoked peat notes, grain, oatmeal, a hint of sugars and just an overall malty feel throughout. Overall, a decent dry stout that shows well and has the characteristics of those from the Carribean and certain parts of Africa, which is nice and good to try for those who haven’t had beers from those locales or can’t get dry stouts too often. I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased from Merchant’s in Dearborn, Michigan on 24-July-2015 for US$3,79 sampled at home in Washington on the first slightly chilly day here for the season, on 11-November-2016.

Bottle. Pours black with a earthy brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of dry roasted malts with a sweet dark grain backbone. Flavor has a combination of musty roasted malts and dark grains with a dry finish.

Bottled. More or less pitch black colour with a small beigeish brown head. Aroma is coffee, mild roasted notes along with chocolate and some hops. Flavour is toasted, mild toffee, coffee and some chocolaty notes. A bit watery and thin, but otherwise pleasant.
Bottle at Craig’s. Pours black, nose is chocolate, light smoke, taste is chocolate, fruity, fizzy.

330 ml bottle into pint glass, best before 7/2016. Pours fairly pitch black color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense brown head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty foamy lacing clings on the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toast, dark bread, light smoke/char, raisin, plum, herbal, and roast/yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with solid balance of dark/roasted malt, earthy hop, and yeast ester notes; with decent strength. A bit too fruity on the nose, but not bad. Taste of dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toast, dark bread, light smoke/char, herbal, light fruitiness, and roast/yeast earthiness. Moderate amount of roasted/earthy hop bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toast, dark bread, light smoke/char, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Good balance and robustness of dark/roasted malt and earthy hop flavor; with a good roasted bitterness/sweetness balance and zero astringent flavors after the finish. Very restrained amount of yeast character in the flavors. Medium carbonation and body; with a smooth, crisp, and fairly creamy/chalky mouthfeel that is good. Light-moderate dryness on the finish. Alcohol is well hidden with zero warming present after the finish as expected of 5%. Overall this is a very solid dry stout style. Good balance and robustness of dark/roasted malt and earthy hop flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A nicely enjoyable offering.
Black of color with an off white head. An aroma of roasted malt, burnt wood and coffee. A flavor of coffee, roasted malt and burnt.

Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate chocolate, light vanilla, espresso, and light roasted grain. It pours a dark brown with a faint orange glow around the edges of the glass. It has a small beige head that quickly settles to a minimal film outlined by a thicker ring. There is minimal lacing left on the sides of the glass. The flavor starts with light dark chocolate with just a touch of fruit. The finish has some light roasted grains, coffee, a touch of burnt flavors, and tart fruit. It’s light-medium bodied with light-moderate carbonation and a somewhat thin mouthfeel for a Stout.
Black beer with brown frothy head. Roasted coffee / nutty flavor with chocolaty undertones. Nice stout. I’ll have another.

Bottle from Mi-Orge Mi-Houblon, Arlon, Belgium! Pours deep black with a really huge frothy brownish head. Smell has lots of coffee and some sweet chocolate. Starts with sourish roasty malts, chocolate and some yeast. Finish is yeasty-sourish, slight roasty with a hint of chocolate.

column2: Marsango di Campo San Martino, Italy
column5: Tap at Birrimini, in Rimini, Italy. Pours pale gold, fairly hazy, with limited white foam. Aroma is a little cereal but most of all rather lemony. Not what you'd want from a pils. Body is thin with moderate carbonation. Taste is lemony and sweet. Finish is regular.

column2: Marsango di Campo San Martino, Italy
column5: On tap. Hazy yellow to orange color, medium white head. Aroma banana. Taste banana, spices, wheat, higher carbonation then usual hefeweizen. OK, but nothing special.

column2: Marsango di Campo San Martino, Italy
column5: Ebc 9, profumi molto lievi di pane e lieviti. Al gusto modesta, poco intensa finale leggermente luppolato

column2: Marsango di Campo San Martino, Italy
column5: On tap from their stand in Verona. Bright orange color, creamy white head, persistent. Aroma is mild fruity (yellow fruit), some spices, some herbal hoppy notes and a woody tone, noticeable alcohol. Taste is well balanced, body is medium, maybe a bit ’sparse’, average carbonation creamy texture, short dryish finish.

Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of bacon and beech wood smoke. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, bacon, smoke, and rope, leading to a dry finish. Nice.
(Bottle 33 cl) Courtesy of fiulijn. Slightly hazy with an off-white head. Distinct smoky aroma. Medium body with fruit and caramel and fat, fat Bamberg smoke. Sweetish finish. 200608
Hazy amber with tiny off white head. Smoky aroma with caramel and fruity notes. Smoky flavor with caramel notes.

Hazy orange color; creamy head. It has a mild smokey aroma. Medium body, it has some good malt flavor, on the sweet side, and a pleasant smokey touch. Low bitterness. Quite well brewed, even if not daring.

Bottle. [After party @ Papsoe, thanks buddy] Rocky white head with spare lacework. Cloudy golden color. Aroma of fruit, smoke, caramel, grain and mild spice. Over the palate came sweet bacon and roasted malty notes. Light bodied with an average carbonation. Light sweet flavor with a hint of bitterness. Light sweet bacon finish. 7 / 3 / 7 / 3 / 14

33 cL bottle. Pours hazy orange with a fully diminished white head. Salami smoked meady aroma. Flavour is a distinct salami smoked flavour with a light citric note. Ends light orange fruity and meady. Strange yet good.

Slightly hazy orange beer with a small head. Very rich smoked nose, but without exaggeration, smoked ham, but also roasted chestnuts. Smoked taste, beechwood smoked bacon. Very good, but maybe just a tad too restrained. Medium body, ends a bit sharp/astringent. Very, very good smoked beer, to vie with the better Franconian ones!
Vom Fass in Venedig. Gelb und sanft trüb. Weisser Schaum. Frisch grasiger Getreideduft. Im Antrunk Äpfel, Gras und herbe Noten. Gut nach nem heissen Tag.

50cl bottle from Da Aldo pours a murky brown with some clumpy, white head. Nose is odd... brown ale? Dubbel? Plum, brown sugar, mild anise, yeast, pear. Flavor says dubbel, clove, anise, candy, brown sugar, plum. Full, sweet finish. Definitely not a stout.

column1: San Gabriel Ambra Rossa di Treviso
column5: Bevuta in bottiglia. Birra tipica rossa. Buona ma niente di particolare da segnalare.

column1: San Gabriel Ambra Rossa di Treviso
column5: On tap @ Very Good, Venezia. Rot-braunes Bier mit feinem festem Schaum. Holzig-pilziger Duft. Antrunk rotes Malz. Süffig, aber auch etwas dünn.

column1: San Gabriel Ambra Rossa di Treviso
column5: Aroma: chestnut & herbal Appearance: tea amber, hazy, small white head Flavour: malt & tangy Palate: finishes quickly

column1: San Gabriel Ambra Rossa di Treviso
column5: Bottiglia 50 cl, schiuma fine beige chiaro evanescente, colore ambrato velato, al naso e in bocca malto zucchero di canna caramello leggero tostato, corpo medio, carbonazione moderata, dolce con amaro moderato. Classica rossa. Niente di speciale. Se non avessi letto gli ingredienti non avrei mai detto che ce il radicchio, forse il retrogusto amaro? 20.06.18 Sottomarina

column1: San Gabriel Ambra Rossa di Treviso
column5: The beer has got a hazy amber colour with a small head and medium body. Aroma of malt and bread. Taste of malt, straw, hops, fruits and bread. Malty finish.

column1: San Gabriel Ambra Rossa di Treviso
column5: Bottle at some bar at Quartino Chicago Magnificent Mile. Who puts chicory in beer? This is just weird tasting and mostly unpleasant. Odd smell also.

column1: San Gabriel Ambra Rossa di Treviso
column5: From 50cc bottle. Evaluated with a strong cold. Pours hazy amber, with foam that disappears soon. Aroma is only malty, for what I can perceive. Body is medium. Taste is moderately bitter. Finish has some feeling related to the radicchio used in the recipe.

column1: San Gabriel Ambra Rossa di Treviso
column5: Birra abbastanza deludente. Sia al naso che in bocca fastidiosi sentori da lager industriale. Ci sono alcuni sentori interessanti (tra i quali del maltato e dell’erbaceo), ma sono slegati tra di loro.

column1: San Gabriel Ambra Rossa di Treviso
column5: Bottle 0.33L. Clear amber body with an average, frothy, off-white head, mostly diminishing with some lacing. Moderate malty (grains, bread, some caramel), light hoppy and yeasty aroma. Light-to-moderate sweet and light bitter flavour; moderate-to-heavy "bready" finish. Medium body with watery-to-oily texture; average carbonation.

column1: San Gabriel Ambra Rossa di Treviso
column5: Draught @ Heritage Birreria Artigianale, Tamka 9, Warszawa, Poland 00-385. [ As San Gabriel Ambra Rossa di Treviso ]. Clear medium orange amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, nutty, caramel, sweet malt, dusty. Flavor is moderate sweet with a long duration, sweet malt, dusty, nutty - earthy. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20160205]

From 50cl bottle. Pours hazy light amber gold with white foam, scarcely persistent, actually. Aroma is banana and generally fruity. Body is average, with intense carbonation, too much. Taste is sweet, but also reminding of orange. Finish is average.

Draught @ Heritage Birreria Artigianale, Tamka 9, Warszawa, Poland 00-385. [ As San Gabriel Hefe Weizen ]. Unclear matt medium orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, wheat, light caramel, moderate yeasty, weizen yeast, banana, fruity. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average to long duration, banana, fruity, yeast, wheat. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20160205]
Bottle shared by Fajry in a train. Many thanks! Quite classic weizen with light sourness, classic clove, light banana. High carbonation, refreshing.
Bottle shared by Fajry in train, many thanks. Pours hazy golden color, white head. Aroma of clove, banana. Taste is medium sweet, clove, banana.
Bottle kindly shared by fajry, many thanks. Golden color with huge white head. Banana, clove, wheat in aroma. Taste, wheat, banana, clove. Good.

Keg at Birreria Heritage Artigianale, Warsaw, Poland. Cloudy golden, small head. Honey and banana up front. Mid sweet with medium body and well rounded mouthfeel. Gentle and soothing, honey covered grains. Low bitterness. Mellow and pleasant.
Cloudy brown color, big off white head that went away fast. Aroma of banana, apples, wheat, some spices. Medium body, average to high carbonation. Taste is medium sweet. Weird hefe, but good.

Bottle 0,5l, bought at Famila supermarket in Muggia (Italy). Hazy liquid, color of unpolished amber with unsteady creamy foam. Medium body, medium to heavy carbonation. Sour, a bit honey and veggies in aroma. Strange but not bad.

Bottle, 0.50l. Hazy amber brown color with large rocky off-white head and sparkling appearance. Aroma of wheat, banana, yeast, rubber and medicine. Taste starts with light sweet grainy and caramel malt, follows by strong sour apple and vegetable acidity, a bit spicy mouthfeel, but without any bitterness. Medium body, slick texture and soft carbonation in palate. A bit too thin and boring...
Bottle Aroma-banana Appearance-pale, cloudy, white foam, Taste-light sweetness, lightly bitter, Palate-light body, thin feel, lively, astringent finish Overall-good
True to type Helles, malty, full body, light hop imprint. Unfilteres, fresh. On tap at the brewpub. Very refreshing after a long mountain walk.
On tap at the Brewpub in Alleghe, in the heart of the Dolomites. Unfiltered red/amber. Fresh, hoppy, full bodied. Malty, but With fine hop bitterness. Well worth a detour.

08May2019 Sweet grain malts, caramel, bread, Belgian yeast, light spices. Hazy gold, small, creamy, white head. Light bitter. More sweet grain and cereal malts, yeast, bread, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Alright. Bottle at Ristorante Santo, Zürich.
Hazy yellow/green liquid, average head. Aroma of citrus. Light body, average carbonation. Taste is bitter, lager.
Bottle. Pours hazy pale yellow. Aroma and flavor citrus and floral notes, cereal and toasted malts, light spice, and faint pine. Light/medium body.

Bottle at home. Pours hazy yellow with a large, frothy white head, long retention with good lacing. Aroma is heavy citrus and pine hops, cracker malt and light pear esters. Flavor is heavy citrus and pine hops and medium bitterness, cracker malt and a dry finish. Light body and moderate carbonation.
Disig gyllengul öl med ett gräddigt vitt skum. Doft och smak av citrus, maltighet och viss blommighet. Trevlig efterbeska och en torr munkänsla.

Bottle at Erzbierschof Monday Club. Pours hazy pale yellow with a little head. Aroma is slightly grassy hoppy, but really not that much. Body is light, crisp carbonation, again watery and short. Super dry, rather refreshing. Okay, but atypical for a Session IPA.
Hazy, nice head, yeasty aroma, fruity, alcohol, yeasty flavor, fruity, bitter, nice, weird, medium bodied.
Sampled at Mechazilla’s epic insanity tasting session. Gentle tropical fruitiness, mildly bready, a bit thin on the body, light bitter finish. Not bad but maybe a bit too sessionable.
Bottle; pours a cloudy straw color with a white head; malty aroma with some lemon and floral notes; taste is lightly bitter with citrus, malt, and caramel; finish is dry and lightly bitter; okay beer

Mechzilla tasting. Thanks for sharing the bottle Juan. Soft grape and pineapple notes on the nose. A bit of grass in there as well. Good carbonation with a light body. Easy drinking but a bit simple. Not bad.
Bottle at Erzbierschof Monday Club. Pours hazy pale yellow. Aroma of vomit and a mishmash of food leftovers. Body is light and acidic. Meh.
Hazy yellow, white head. Citrus, metallic, spicy Belgian yeast. Nearly no bitterness, medium sweet, slightly weak carbonation. Somehow not very interesting.

Meine Version heißt Heller Bock und hat 7,0% ABV Eine große Krone aus dichtem Schaum bedeckt die schöne, trübe Bernsteinfarbe. Das Bier hat viele Kohlensäure Perlen und wenig süßen Geruch. Der Antrunk beginnt sehr vollmundig und sehr wenig rezent. Es folgt ein voluminöser, karamellig süßer Körper. Hervorragend! Leicht fruchtig aber sehr zart. Der Bock hat eine etwas flache Struktur ist aber super süffig. Der geht gut runter.
Van het vat in de brewpub. Donkerbruin bier met schuim. Smaak is licht bitterzoet met iets van chocolade en koffie. Is iets te waterig in de mond.
Dunkler, mild röstiger Beginn. Erfrischend, wenig herb, die Röstnoten werden schwächer. Dunkel getreidiger Abgang - ziemlich Standard. 10/8/10/9//9

Draft at Hopfen & Co., Bolzano, Italy. Pours a nice deep brown, with moderate brownish foam, medium grain. Aroma is a combination of malty and something unpleasant like cleaning product. Body is average with good carbonation. Taste is medium sweet, moderate bitter. Finish is fairly long.

On tap at the source in Bolzano/Bozen - Italy. Dark brown pour, gassy ivory foam. Nose: bit anonymous really, toffee a bit, roast. Mouth: light roast, pinch of sweet with a decent grassy finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Glass jug 2.5 liters at brew pub in Bolzano 150514. Dark chestnut body with a rather weak head. Rather sweet taste but with nice maltiness and caramell. Nice dunkles. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dunkelbraun und trüb mit einer feinen Blume, die aber sehr schnell zusammenfällt. Ohne Geruch beginnt das Dunkle stark rezent mit relativ süßem Körper. Das schmeckt zwar trotzdem frisch, ist aber nicht so spannend. Im Nachtrunk etwas Cola bevor das Bier ganz zum Abschluss doch noch leicht herbe Aromen entwickelt. Da war das Dunkle vom Gassl Bräu um Längen besser.
Birra particolare. Molto buona. Retrogusto dolce al palato con secondari di legno, cioccolato e frutta. Ottima molto fredda per accompagnare grigliate ma anche da bere sola.
bottle velata diacetile non molta schiuma lieve citrico erbaceo non molto secca

Tap into bottle in birreria Pedavena, Trento, IT; drinking at home with Rotin. Aroma strange for lager - intensive spicy, light fruity, with tones of banana, coriander and cardamom. In taste again banana, but it is sour and dry, only light bitter with notes of hop, malt. Noble and good balanced beer. But if I should guess without knew it’s lager, my tipe will be some belgian ale :-) Interesting piece from italian brewpub. I’m sad that Trento is so far to enjoy it more often...

,,Bottled" right in the pub Pedavena. Color amber,very hazy. Intense spicy (vanilla),fruity (banana) and sweet malty,caramel-like aroma. Flavor pleasantly sour,sweet spicy and malty. Light salty astringency,very low bitterness. Complex and well balanced. Great and interesting beer.
Very good italian old brewed beer. Today is very difficult to find this beer in Italy,there are only few pubs where you can taste this equilibrate beer.

Hefig-herber Antrunk, dezent bananig, zum Mittelteil ansteigend. Dann herber, die Hefigkeit fährt zurück. Erfrischend, wenig getreidig, zum Ende wird das Bier zunehmend trocken. Dabei ausgeglichen, süßlich. 12/10/9/9//9

On tap at Dry Dock poured an opaque black with a small lasting brown head. Aromas of coffee, dark chocolate and light vanilla. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of coffee, dark chocolate and a hint of vanilla with a smooth lingering coffee finish.

At first look, this is a typical oatmeal stout. Dark and rich brown hue with a fantastic fluffy light brown head. A closer look yields a thick body, cask conditioned and the aroma…. This oatmeal stout is infused with coffee, light to heavy malt with hints of molasses, milk chocolate and an enticing mild coffee shows through. The yeast gives it a slightly sweet smell too and even a bit of tar and smoke due to the cask conditioning. Tasting brings the enjoyment of beer to a whole new level. Initially a light sweet yet bitter flavor with the expected coffee, but it grows in the mouth with a pleasantly developing taste. Complex flavors of smoke and roasted coffee succumb to an agreeable acidity in a stout. Smooth body with a slightly oily yet creamy texture allows this to be a very drinkable oatmeal stout. Finishes average for this type of beer and with a delightfully soft carbonation and slight acidity to the feel in the back of my throat, I drink another. This is a really great oatmeal stout. With the infused coffee, it makes it that much more interesting and drinkable but the cask conditioning makes this ale amazing and I can’t wait to drink another.

The best coffee-infused beer I’ve ever had (on cask at the brewery). The coffee and oatmeal had me looking for the eggs and bacon! Man, this was good. PLEASE make it again! Solid black body, nice head, coffee notes, slight metallic and roasty flavor - yum!

cask at the brewery. solid black body with a nice puffed brown head that lasts. coffee aroma comes through well. straight up in your face coffee flavor with no astringency. dry roast flavor throughout this. coffee lingers and lingers. sweetness lies underneath in a fruity way. wonderful rich mouthfeel. a winner.

Cask conditioned – gravity dispensed: Penetrable black. Dense and sticky beige foam. Striking aromas of smoky coffee, potting soil, tar, and chocolate fudge. Fairly ashy and hints at dried plums. Soft carbonation supports a silky and oily body. Dazzling interplay between rich yet acidic java and pungent smoke-accented roast. Delightfully beefy at the center, but a chalky dryness ensues and accentuates the lush chocolate which hugs the palate and bolsters the body. Malts are fairly shallow and unpronounced, but the coffee is seductively silky and gritty with notions of char and compensates with heaps of multilayered decadence. Also fairly estery with notes of ink and juicy plums, but still quite quaffable due to the moderate level of dryness. Lightly metallic zing complements the understated malt sweetness, but doesn’t overwhelm or detract. Finishes immensely tarry and chocolate fudge-laden, yet deceptively light with dry char and subtle but effective notes of billowy smoke. Cheers to Kevin and the gang for not only serving Real Ale that’s finely conditioned, but also without the use of a sparkler. A fun couple of pints this was.
A hazy orange beer with a white head. The aroma is sweet with notes of straw and caramel, while the flavor is quite dry with notes of straw, malt, and caramel.

(Draught sampled at the brewery) Rating from the mind here. Had a few samples of this beer at the brewery. Golden color with a white head. Hoppy citrus like scent. Smooth bitter hoppy taste. Smooth mouthfeel with medium bitterness.

(Draught at Glenfiddich Warehouse 68, Stockholm, 20 Oct) Amber colour with huge white head. Fruity nose with lots of berries (blueberries, crowberries, raspberries). Fruity, slightly roasted, taste with notes of berries, caramel and earthy hops in the finish. Very good balance with a nice hoppy character, without straying too far from the main road.

Draught at Glenfiddich Warehouse 68, Stockholm. Clear copper colour, fairly brief head. Resiny hop aroma. Fairly light bodied with clean, crisp mouthfeel. Notes of grapefruit and apples. Salty somewhat resiny finish with good bitterness. A bit too streamlined for my liking.

Draught at Glenfiddich Warehouse No. 68, Stockholm. Clear bronze colour topped with a firm white head. Mild aroma of lemon, pepper and earth with a slightly sourish/woody undertone. Bitter but not aromatic flavour of orange-peels, pepper and wood. Smooth mouthfeel. Simplistic bitter aftertaste of wood with touches of lemon. Decent but Dugges can do better than this.

Draught at Kungälvs Beerfestival: Deep hazy red colour, nice creamy head. Aroma of hops,citric,malts. Flavor is a nice balnced of malt hops and a creamy/smooth bitter finish. Medium body, medium finish. Nice!

[Draught at The Rover, Göteborg, Sweden] Hazy amber colour, fluffy head. Yeasty, sulphur-like nose with egg tones. Citric, light malty flavour with a smooth mouthfeel. Weird yet drinkable beer, low on Co2.
[Draught at The Rover, Gothenburg, Sweden] Light amber. Bubbly head. Citric nose. Citrus and some flowery notes in the flavour. Some dough aswell. This one feels like a real ale.

(Draught) Pours copper amber. Small white head. Aroma of floral, citrusy hops. Toffee malt. Iron. Some perfume. Fruity. Flavor is flowery bitterness. Smooth maltyness. A bit peppery. Small, smooth afterbitterness. Small to medium body.

Zythos Bierfestival 2012, Leuven, Belgium. It pours clear gold with off white head of foam. The aroma offers up citrus and mango as well as a bit of garlic and asparagus like nuances. Hmm. The taste has garlic and onion bleeding into some citrus and it works pretty well. I also get some spicy hops and a touch of black pepper. All in all a tasty offering.
Tap at ZBF’12, Leuven, Belgium: Hazy blond coloured brew with an taste of grapfruit and some aftertaste like an kind of American hoppiness.
I tried it but I’m not a fan of bland beer. They had this in my hotel rooms mini fridge and I needed a beer after a long day of traveling

Blik @ Idre Fjäll, VIII 2018. Naar alle lagers 3,5 procent lager nu ook de Heineken. Eerlijk is eerlijk deze mag dan maar 3,5 procent zijn maar doet slechts weinig onder voor zijn volle broer van 5,2 procent. Moutig, goeie bitter en door drinkbaar. Alleen door de alcohol qua smaak net ff minder sterk. Maar alles wel met typische heldere gele lager kleur en dito witte schuimkraag.

Can from Sara, Gothenburg. Pours a bright slightly golden yellow with a thin white bubbly head that disappears quickly. Aroma is sweet, caramel and sugar with little hop. Taste is thin, watery and sugary. Fizzy thin mouthfeel with a sweet finish. Poor.
Quite pale and smells of grain. A good taste, just a bit too little of it. Not much to cheer about, but an alright beer.
The best that probe the international 3.4 bottle lager with a character of hops very accented. Quite good, the Dutch

330ml bottle from ICA. Clear pale golden, small white head, weak lacing. Grainy and sweet nose, white bread and metallic notes. Light-bodied, medium carbonated, watery mouthfeel. Mid-sweet taste, grains, white bread and boiled vegetables. Mild grassy bitter finish.

column1: Bruveris Ingver Alus 10 Gadu Jubilejas Alus
column5: 500 ml bottle. Amber. No head. Slightly hazy. Rounded oily maltiness. Very delicate. Some caramel. Low carbonation. Soft texture. Little flavours except powdery wheaty flavours. Rather watery finish. Some bready notes.

column1: Bruveris Ingver Alus 10 Gadu Jubilejas Alus
column5: Bottle. Not so clear. Aroma is spicy and flavor is light ginger with some vegetable tones. Not so bitter.

column1: Bruveris Ingver Alus 10 Gadu Jubilejas Alus
column5: Big white foam. Nice flowe spicearoma. Taste of the ginger is there bt not to much. Wery small bitterness. A blend beer.

column1: Bruveris Ingver Alus 10 Gadu Jubilejas Alus
column5: 500 ml bottle. From Latvia. Hazy golden colour with fluffy, fast vanishing head. Aroma: spices, vegetables, toffee, grains. Spice, honey sweetness and cardboard in flavour. Quite strange but not bad.

column1: Bruveris Ingver Alus 10 Gadu Jubilejas Alus
column5: 500ml Bottle - Golden in colour with a slight haze. Slightly funky aroma with ginger and a bit of honey. Sweetish taste with malt and the ginger being noticeable although not overwhelmingly so. Sometimes it seems like this brewery have got a deal with some local grocer when it comes to ginger and they just have to use it. I am all for creativity but there is no need to use it in virtually every beer that you produce. It gets a bit tedious! The beer is drinkable though, I just feel that these brewers have more potential than they are currently showing.

column1: Bruveris Ingver Alus 10 Gadu Jubilejas Alus
column5: Bottle, 4.5%. Buttery and oxidized aroma. The flavour is oxidized and slightly plasticky. Must be the weird ginger as it is not past BB date.

column1: Bruveris Ingver Alus 10 Gadu Jubilejas Alus
column5: Small white head. Yellow body, slightly hazy due to particles. Rich malty aroma with fruity honey notes and a touch of toffee. Dryish and sweetish taste of tobacco and light malts with fruity milky notes. No real aftertaste; just fades out quite quickly leaving a watery lightly metallic aftertaste. Nice, in a kind of mellow way, and probably a little bit old. (0.5l bottle from KnutAlbert.)

column1: Bruveris Ingver Alus 10 Gadu Jubilejas Alus
column5: Hazy golden beer. Malty body, full flavour. Grain, spice, honey. Rather sweet, but som warm spices balance out the sweetness.

column1: Bruveris Ingver Alus 10 Gadu Jubilejas Alus
column5: 500ml bottle - thanks to Knut Albert for sharing. Firm white head over an unclear, beige head. Unusual aroma and taste. The aroma can best be described as a mix of dried vegetables and wet paper notes. The spicy flavour has also got hints of dark honey, wood and ashy malts. Flat and dry mouthfeel. Strange, but drinkable (Oslo, 04.04.2008).

column1: Bruveris Ingver Alus 10 Gadu Jubilejas Alus
column5: (BBE 1/08) Golden colored, slightly hazy appearance. Little white head. Sweet honeyish aroma with lots of paper and cardboard, some weird perfumy-grainy note also comes up. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is more like same than aroma: honey and grainy sweetness with cardboard. Aftertaste is somehow biting and tangy with this cardboard still.

[cask at the Wellington, Birmingham] Light, golden colour, quite flat with a thin head and no carbonation. Little initial flavour besides a soft hoppiness, but an attractive dry biscuity malt aftertaste is very welcome. Low abv, so quite light. One of the pack of decent golden ales [17062009]

Cask at Spoons, Milton Keynes. Bright gold with a white head. Grassy aroma with a little eggy sulphur. Pleasant sweet malt taste with a little bitterness. Served too cold. Spoons appear to have cranked up the chill during August. But not bad.

Cask conditioned handpump Moon On The Square Northampton. A golden coloured beer with a whitish head and lacing. Grassy hops in the nose, and not a lot in the mouth. Pretty boring and thin, and a pale shadow of the GK beer I had just drank. Score 2.7 Subsequent rating scored 2.9. Average becomes 2.8
Cask at the Standing Order (JDW), Stevenage. Straw with a loose white head; sulphurous aroma; pleasant hoppy flavour with a dry hoppy finish. A refreshing pint.

Cask gravity, The Cock, Hemingsford Grey, Cambs. Yellow amber under a fleeting white slick. Lemony orange aroma with some musky hop rubs as the head subsides. Herbal grassy and lemon balance, bread, clean fresh biscuity linger. Really sticks around. Tasty solid stuff.

Cask (handpump), The Maltings, York, October 2006. This was actually listed as Harrowby Dark, so I was a little surprised when it poured golden and tasted like a pale, fairly hoppy session bitter. There was no proper pump clip, just a hand-written label. Shortly afterwards, however, Yorkshire Dales Darrowby Dark came on so its seems they got their Harrowbys and Darrowbys mixed up. I’m assuming it was actually the Harrowby Pale that I got. The beer? A pleasant, easy drinking, dry session beer. Despite the colour more a bitter than a golden ale.
Cask Handpump at the Alexandra Hotel, Derby 29/09/2006 Fruit and hop aromas. Clear golden coloured hoppy fruity and slightly pale. Some dryness in a crisp and lasting malt finish.
Cask@Swan and Rushes, Leicester. Nice looking pale beer with a light head. The aroma is lightly dry and hopped and the flavour is nice and dry. Overall a good beer.

Cask, Swan and Rushes, Leicester. Hazy gold and orange with a small head. Aromas are earthy, spicy hops with mellow lemon. lemon drop sourness with bitter pine. Flavours are dry lemon with caramel malts. Sweet hops with pear and pineapple fruitiness. Spices and light bitterness on the finish. Fairly tasty for its strength.

Tap at Klub Optimist. Proper stout-like pour with huge brownish pillow head. Big bubbles. Bright, strong coffee and malt up front that ease to a porter-like slightly sweet/sour finish. Reminds of some lighter style stouts in north america. Awesome for the region, but the sweetness undercuts it for me.
On tap at Klub Optimist. Very good black beer. Very similar to a flavorful porter. Rich white head with creamy aromas. Flavor is full of chocolate and cream and coffee. So good I went twice.
Way better then "Wfb Svetlo" but again too thin and watery.Has some fine coffee and dark chocolate aromas but not enough to make it a good Schwarzbier.It’s OK to drink it from time to time...
Canned(500ml). –Pale golden almost yellow coloured, white head, fizzy. Slight hoppy, bready and some corn notes in aroma. Bitter finish and a bit too watery, drinkable but boring.

Draft 0.5l at the Fat Cat Pub Zemun Belgrade Serbia.Pour it golden colour with small white head.Aroma of citrus and malt.Taste is sweet with some funky flavour.Honestly not bad.Quite drinkable and interesting to try.

Draft at Belgrade Beer Fest ’09. Best surprise at the fest for me. Didn’t know anything about this brewery (from sabac?!) and this actually blew away the tamno (dark) beer of theirs. Golden-red pour. Light bubbly head. Sweet, sparkling, crisp red beer. Tart with citrus undertones. Slight metallic finish but really good. Best local beer I’ve had in a long while, really reminded me of a good red.

Draught at the Belgrade Beer Festival. Lovely appearance - dark golden, almost copper in color, solid lasting head. But the taste...very artificial flavors, bland hops flavors, soapy and chemical aromas, traces of yeast, no signs of malt, unpleasant sour aftertaste. In other words - dreadful!

Piwo z doskonalym chmielowym aromatem, mocna i dobrze wyczuwalna goryczka. Intensywny bursztynowy kolor, klarowne, nagazowanie idealne. Obfita, zwarta, smietankowa piana utrzymujaca sie dlugi czas. Podawane w firmowym szkle. Pite na miejscu w Sabacu

Draught at the Belgrade Beer Fest 2006. -I think that it became tradition of BBF to have every year one lousy draught beer. Two years ago it was Kej Svetlo and this years laureate is Èeško Pivo from Šabac. Pale golden, huge lasting white head, skunky nose. Slight hoppy and yeasty aroma tipical for slovenian home brewed beers.

It started out with both some yes and some no, and that’s just the way it finished. Head - what head? However, the body was an excellent, rich amber in colour, a little on the hazy end of things. Might’ve been some aroma there, but precious little; perhaps a hint of malt but bugger all else. Taste was "odd", not unpleasant but certainly off-putting. Mouhtfeel was may be a little "sharp", and the aftertaste was strictly forgettable.
Banana notes keep the nose interested. Pleasing color. Light in body. Surprisingly good.
Clear amber colour with thin light beige head. Mild spicy nose. Mild yaest and spice taste to start with mild malt midway through and light malt finish.

Pours a clear copper color with a thin white head. Good aroma of spicy, biscuity malt. Good flavor of spicy, biscuity malt with a sweet finish. The body is light to medium with a creamy texture and moderate carbonation. Well-done.

Bready malt forward aroma with notes of anis and doughy malts. Clear, deep copper coloured body is topped by a low, off white head that recedes to ring. Thick bready malty flavour. Chewy mouthfeel, soft bubbles, medium body with lightly effervescent carbonation. Simple, straight forward but well-made. Sampled with beerbuzzmontreal, cathschlag, Glouglouburp, MartinT, Siroy and Yowie. It’s strange to see the differences in reviews here since I had it with two different groups in Montreal and we all quite enjoyed it and I have had it once more back in BC and enjoyed it then also. One bottle left in the cellar... we’ll have to see how that one turned out?

Clear bronze body with no head to speak of. Very malty body with a simple but very pleasant toasted bread and cake flavour. I like very malted beers with a crunchy/chewy body while not being sweet. That’s the case here. The carbonation is low and the drinkability is high. Simple but very effective. Not many ratings so far but I was surprised to see mostly bad reviews except from one which happens to be someone I drank the bottle with. Mmmm…. Weird. Although it wouldn’t be the first time that french speaking quebecois disagree with the rest of the country.

Poured a very clear, light brown with a minimal head and some lace. Aromas of caramel, with very light malting. Tastes similar - heavy caramel, very sugary sweet with very light malting and pleasant hops. Unpleasant acrid aftertaste. Carbonation rather nice - weak at first but rolls off the tongue nicely at the end. A drinkable beer, but not in any large quantity. Thankfully I shared a bottle.

A dark amber lager with a thin off white head. A rather buttery malt, lots of butterscotch, cloying. In mouth, a lightly sweet caramel malt with some nice peaty notes, woody, but also some boiled corn. Medium bodied. If it wasn’t for the diacetyl and corn, this would be comparable to the Trois Mousquetaires Okto. Thanks Capflu.

Bottle: Pours a medium clear copper with an off white head. Great toasty sweet aroma with caramel and marshmallow, candy sugar tones. Flavour was firm malt in the front with a thin ’hollow’ not bitter enough finish that was a let down. Tasted side by side with Granville’s Oktoberfest, and I found the GI to be more rounded. Phillip’s finish let me down.
Amber body with decent head. Aroma is lots of caramel and metal. Flavour is sweet, thin and with strong diacetyl. Finishes sweet and unpleasant. Just seems to be off.

2019-08-20. Crisp yellow body nice creamy white head. 3+ Aroma has mild lightly floral hops, muted pale malt. Flavour has mild bitterness throughout, light grassy hops, muted pale malt below. 6+ Average bodied palate, soft carbonation. Decent simple lager. 6/3-4/6/3/13-14 On tap at Craig Street, Duncan, BC.

Yellowy gold body and okay foam, sweet cabbagey grain on the nose. Flavour is citrusy grain and nothing else. Medium mouthfeel. Okay, not offensive, which is I suppose the goal for a middle class brewpub lager.

This is my favourite lager so far. There is a nice flavour while swallowing which I suspect is the nuttiness the description suggests. I usually go for Fat Tug IPA or something similar and thought I'd try this for a change. Very happy with it! It is also served at the Pioneer House on the highway in Duncan.

On tap at Craig Street, pours a clear pale golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is pretty bland even for a lager, with light biscuity malt and straw. Flavour is a bit stale tasting, with straw, biscuity malt and a sort of cardboardy quality. Not too off-putting but it’s a below average pale lager.

Bomber. Clear bright golden yellow, frothy white foam settles and lasts. Grainy buttery lager malt aroma. Mostly clean grainy sweeter lager malt taste, some buttery notes, a hint of citrus. Average carbonation, light bodied, lightly hopped. LF (Lagerboy Friendly)
Draft - As with many of their beers the grains are really evident, making this a pretty flavorful lager.
Light hoppy, grassy aroma - plain. Fairly full bodied for a lager. Clean and smooth with a hint of citrus on the finish. I’m not a big lager drinker, but for the style this was pretty good.
Draught at the brewpub Hazy light blond color; served too cold. Simple Lager, with smooth mouthfeel, a hint of crispy malts in aroma and flavor, some corn.
on tap at brew pub. Crisp and tasty, very mild hop taste and well balanced. I am not a fan of Lagers, but this is a very tasty example and some of the best I have had.
No nose Pale yellow low head Light flowery hops, a hint grain. Fresh

2019-08-20. Crisp amber copper body, modest head. Aroma of mild malt, light caramel and toasty malt. Light mineral undertones. Flavour is mild, lightly toasty malt. Light bitterness. Average bodied palate, moderate carbonation. Okay, not a style I’m personally fond of. 6/3/5/3/11-12 On tap at Craig Street, Duncan, BC.
Coppery brown body and modest foam on top. Soft caramel and brown sugar aroma. Flavour is sweet dark bread with no depth. Mouthfeel is weak. Inoffensive to far past the point of being boring.
On tap @ the brewpub. Ruddy colour. Toasty caramel, nutty. Sticky, light, mild bitterness.

On tap at Jakes At The Lake. Clear medium copper, fading off-white foam. Grainy caramel malty aroma. Moderate caramel chocolate malt taste, not too sweet, a bit sticky, bland earth, no bitterness. Average carbonation, medium bodied, lightly hopped. Not as desireable as Eve the bartender. LBW (Lagerboys Be Wary) ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft. - Caramel, toasted malts and some grain. Clear amber with a thin brown head. Tastes just as it smells with a heavy malt profile.
Pours a deep copper. Aromas of hazelnut, toffee, caramel. Flavours replicate the nose. Low carbonation. The finishing is lingering toffee and nut with a very light bitterness. Decent.
Draught at the brewpub Hazy amber color, with creamy head; served too cold. Mild caramel aroma. Some caramel and roasted malt flavor, a bit dusty; correct bitterness. Boring.
on tap at brew pub. Deep brown with a thin head. Nose of caramel and malt. Tasty, but nothing to write home about. Just an ok Irish Ale.
On tap at the Alibi Room - pours a deep amber. Flavour is sweet, nutty, and malt-caramel. Quite good, but the different elements don’t work exceptionally well together.
Tap at the brewpub. Light berry aroma. Hazy dark golden, nice lacing head. Good malty start- fruit pears apples light spice. Relative light body solid mf.
1L PET bottle. Dark brown fizzy looking drink. Very sweet, some caramel and faint raisins in aroma. Very sweet, caramel and some rye in taste. Very sharp and fizzy carbonation.
2l bottle, Tallinn. Very sweet fizzy kvass. Tasty breadiness, and caramel, but not special, just a chemical soft drink, and definitely not a beer.
Canned. Hazy dark brown colour, small beige head. Strong ryebready malts in aroma. Flavour is strong ryebread, malts and coca-cola. Aftertaste is caramellish rye and malts.

Can (BB 06/2007). Very dark ruby brown, small tan head. Strong rye bread aroma. Very cloying sweet, sugary. Carbonated. Rye bread flavors. Some "real kvass" qualities, but way too sugary to enjoy really.

I’ll preface by saying I really enjoy the standard Fog Fighter. However, this spin-off was pretty poor. Sickly sweet and with a cherry cough syrup flavour that stuck on my palate until I could wash it away. A rare miss from a usually solid brewer.

Cloudy pinkish-brown. Cinnamon, sugar and alcohol aroma. Hmmmm...cherry pie concentrated, but it clashes with the spicy, alcoholic tripel that lies underneath. It just ends up being too sweet, since the Fog Fighter is quite sweet to begin with, and the alcohol is never something I welcome in a fruit beer. They also have a cranberry version, which I missed, and that sounds like a better combo on paper.

Not much of a head on this one, and what there was ran away quite quickly. The aroma was indeed that of honey, and the colour was a cloudy amber. Taste was not at all sweet, leaning more toward the malt side of things, with some hopped bitterness in the aftertaste. Mouthfeel is decent. A drinkable beer, but by no means a remarkable or even a particularly good beer.

650ml bomber from a BIF : Poured a dark gold with a smallish cap that didn’t last well. Aromas are a tad flat, mostly grains sweetness and some must. Flavor is malty-sweet, some floral a bit of grass and a wet malty sweet finish. Not really my type of honey beer but I suspect this sample was on the shelf a while.
Sweet raspberry honey aroma. Somewhat hazy yellow. Consistent honey character, light malts.

Bottle, courtesy matta. Pours deep gold with copper core and off white head. The aroma is honey and malt sweetness followed by infected bottle acidity and tartness. The taste is both honey sweet and malty sweet followed by tart acidity as noted in the nose. But the tartness is milder than the nose hinted at. Toward the finish I also get a metal note. Not so good.

courtesy of matta with an A. Pours hazy golden, with white lacing. Aroma is hoppy with a syrupy / honey nose. Taste has some faint notes of honey with high carbonation and a thick mouthfeel. Sweet with plenty of honey. Good but nothing spectacular.

Bottle, courtesy MattA. Pours a golden hue, with wet lacing and a creamy head. Honey nose, dry hops, some brown sugar. Flavor is a bit infected, with honey and biscuit. Kind of plain and just not that good. Crisp, hard to stomach overall.
Pear, orange rind in nose, some honey in background. Pop-like, lots of apple juice notes, thick but flat body. Plain, not much aftertaste to speak of. Not bad.
bready nose kinda sweet yellow color flavor is all malt sorta earthy ok no a fav but quaffable
Thanks to Mike and Jason for bringing. Honey colour with big head. Above average carbonation and mediuym mouthfeel. Pleasant honey aroma, like a mead.
very enjoyable the first tasted was just a very refreshing honey flavor mellows out by the end.

Draft at Cask Night at the Park Pub--this was one of the cask offerings. Nice stuff. Lunar somehow seems like the forgotten ale lineup for Baron, but some of that talent and attention to detail shows through on the top-fermented side now and then. Maybe if I’m not thinking of Lunar often enough, it’s my fault, not theirs. This one poured a deep mahogany with brilliant garnet highlights. Nice creamy/sudsy tan head. Not very like an ESB, and not very like a casked ESB, at that. Mild brown sugar and even licorice notes on the nose, swirling around a tea and biscuit mix that’s actually quite palatable and understated. More of the same weird dry/sweet dichotomy happening on the mid-palate, with a nice light, clean, drinkable body. Neutral finish. Startlingly good, without a doubt.
Hazy dark amber. Very caramelly nose. Chewy Munich/Vienna malt character. Light earthy hops. Fairly sweet finish.
Cloudy yellow. Light aroma of peach and pale malt. Crazy tart peach-lychee juice. Light fruity bitterness. Not entirely cohesive as a beer but good as a fruit juice.

pours topaz with a thick foamy head, foamy retention, sticky lacing, very active fast moving CO2 streams. Muted nose. Drinks 6/10-sweetness level, watery texture, aggressive burpy carbonation, tastes of bittersweet honey, hints of grapefruit, ends with a lingering sharp bitter hoppy finish. Medium complexity, medium depth, okay carry, good transitions, good drinkablility. A variety of elements - sweet, bitter, hoppy, crisp, honey. Too watery and thin for my tastes however.
5 ounce sample seasonal draft at the Swans bar at $10.00CAD for 6-samples. Very good.
pours a yellow with a nice sweet honey aroma and honey taste but also very pale flavours and light on the palate
Hazy gold,fast fading beige head. Neutral nose, Light sweet profile, bland and boring

Had this at a cask festival at Central City; the version was slightly different from the norm (no details provided). Aroma has strong honey notes. A light body with a sweet attack yields a very clean, crisp finish. A good summer/patio ale, but really not that remarkable.

Pours a clear pale yellow with a finger-thick egg-white head & some lacing with an unremarkable aroma - no honey yet. Taste is very refreshing, solid pale malt with a leafy green hop taste and definite honey in the finish. Body is crisp and tightly carbonated (served on draught). Well executed, nice honey taste, otherwise unremarkable.

7/14/07 On draught at the brewery. Aroma is sweet caramel malt with no discernable hop character. Appearance is a clear light gold with a low white head. Flavor is grainy sweet malt forward with a caramel note, followed by a fermenting honey note, sourness and moderate bittering, but no hop flavor. Mouthfeel is low bodied with a medium/high carb feel. Overall, this is clean and simple like a lager, and just not round like a pale ale should be.

Tap at Swans. Nice hop notes, lightish body, light honey spice, quick green finish, light resin stickyness. Wastly improved from last time I had it. Old rating: 3 2 4 1 8 Pale golden, no head or carbonation. Neutral aroma. light papery flavor. Watery, light honeyish aftertaste. Boring.

(Druaght) Pint @ $3.50. Pours a white, frothy head with a amber body. Nose of dough and honey. Somewhat crisp in flavour with a mild maltedness and slight bitter finish. Your average beer on the Island.
Golden-amber colour. Honeyish, light bready malt aroma. Light leafy hops. Light flavours, mainly pale malts. Light bitterness. Smooth sailing, yeah that about sums it up.

On tap at all three Elysian locations over the past few years. Pours an almost perfect amber hue for this kind of brew. Small retentive white head. Aroma is lots and lots of sweet tender malts with a bit of fruits tossed between. Flavor is fairly sweet in the malt factory, while also being quite caramely at the same time. A tiny bit of roast is found towards the finish which ends strongly hoppy, and lingers. Pretty good for an amber.
Tasted at Elysian Fields on 1/3/08 - Great nutty aroma, nice white/tan head with lots of lace. Slight hazy amber color. Nutty and caramel notes. very enjoyable.
On tap at Elysian, Seattle. Pours hazy amber with a thin, off-white head. Medium body and light carbonation. Lightly sweet aroma and taste; mostly nutty, with caramel a touch of fruit and citrus.

on tap-pours a light tan head and copper color. Aroma is hoppy-citrus-grapefruit, medium malt-caramel. Taste is hops-slight metallic citrus, equal medium malt-caramel. Light side of medium body. Mild carbonation.

Draft at Elysian Fields. Pours medium clear ruby amber with a moussy white head and plenty of lace. Pretty vacant nose and a modest attack, but a surprisingly nice rich earthy leafy resiny mid-palate and finish. Solid effort for an amber.
cloudy, brownish amber with excellent head retention. mild, smooth mouth feel. excellent balance. a mighty yet mild beer.

On tap at Elysian, Seattle. Amber/red colour with lasting beige head. Red berry malt and hop aroma. Smooth in mouth, almost creamy with nicely balanced red berry malt and tingly hop to finish. Never a fan of amber ales, but this is good.
On Tap At Elysian Fields Seattle. pours out a nice dark amber topped with a nice head. a nice smooth body. a great blend of hops on this one.
On tap at the new Elysian Fields. Dark amber with decent head. Very drinkable amber....just enough taste without being overwhelming. Good hops are balanced well.
Hazy amber colour. Chewy caramelly, earthy, leafy aroma. Full body. Clean, with an even balance that lands on the rich, earthy, hoppy side of the style. Nicely done.
These beers are hard to rate but i give it a thumbs up. The heat (spiciness) is well done, and shows up a lingering hot finish. You couldn’t drink a six pack, but one is ok.
GCBF sample. Cap and Oakes are joking right? Light peppery nose. Clear gold. Starts OK but builds to heartburn. Not what I want in my glass, or my mouth.

(Draught) Sampled at the Great Canadian Beer Festival 2007 in Victoria on September 8th, 2007. Pretty bland until mid-palate than - WHAM - a strong spiced finish. Okay, I like the finish but nothing interesting.

GCBF. Hazy, vibrant amber coloured brew with a big chipotle nose. The malts and body were a bit thin, but the flavour was fresh and big chipotle. The finish had a mild, insistent heat. I can’t call it a masterpiece of beer, but I’m a huge chipotle lover and so I liked it anyway.
Cask @ Chelmsford Winter Beer Festival. Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, maltyand caramel. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 160217

Cask @ Chelmsford Winter Beer festival. Pours dark golden with an offwhite head. Aroma of malt, caramel, wheat, fruit. Flavor is light sweet, malt, fruity hops. Medium body, soft carbonation, sweet finish. 160217

Cask (handpump) @ Baxters Court (JDW), 282-284 Mare Street, Hackney, Greater London, England E8 1HE. [ As Nethergate Augustinian ]. Clear medium amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, cookie - biscuit, caramel, coffee notes. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, caramel, fruity, biscuit malt. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20141205]

Cask handpull at The Crosse Keys Bishopsgate as Netgergate Augustinian. Clear pale orange gold, still, bubbly beige head. Aroma is sugary, some damp clothes, honey. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is quite sweet, bready, lemon boiled sweets, thin sugary malt with a musty bitter finish. Quite decent if a bit simple.
Cask at Crosse Keys (JDW), Gracechurch St. Pours chestnut with off white head. Some dry berry fruit, caramel, bitter finish. Solid bitter.
Lovely reddish aroma. Mildly honey taste. Quite sweet and also bitter. Really quite delicious ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask at Ruislip Manor (Spoons). An amber coloured pour with a medium white head on top. Fruity, malty, caramel aroma. Tastes similar, fruity, malty, caramel, bitter finish.

Draught (Tivoli (JDW), Cambridge) Soft malty aroma, a little nutty, some sweet esters. Beautifully rich malty body, nutty, fruity esters. A touch of soft bitterness, a little earthy and herbal, a bit nutty and twiggy - lovely right to the bottom.
Cask at the Crosse Keys (JDW), London. Dark amber with a loose cream head; nutty aroma; soft nutty malt taste; and a dry, satisfying finish.

Cask @ Beer Shack, Burnley. Copper-gold with a creamy-smooth head. Has a lightly sweetened aroma and taste that’s mostly sugary but there’s just a hint of fruit. It’s smoothish texture feels nice in the palate.
Tap in Frankfurt at a Restaurant. Nose is watery apple, some wood, dried apple. Palate is sweet and sour apple, watery pear, some vanilla. Ok Apfelwein.

From fass in a cafe in the Frankfurt Altstadt romer square. My first Apfelwein. Cloudy orange color, flat. Simple nsoe or apple, tartness, light tannins. Semi tart flavor, semi sweet as well, dry but not very taniic and quite fruity and nice.
Hazy orange color with no head. Aroma is tart apples, some yeast. Taste is sour, some milky yeasts. No carbonation. Not too complex, but fun.
Säuerlich apfeliger Antrunk. Rund fruchtig, etwas steigende Fruchtnoten, milde Herbe. Trockenes rundes Ende. 9/9/9/9/11/9

Thanks to erzengel for sharing!! Pours a hazy apple juice color with some bubbles sticking around. The smell is deep apple aroma, some tartness lingering. The taste is earthy apples, some tartness ending dry. Light in body but with some graininess and light carbonation.

Ich mein, ich mag ja saure Sachen. Selbst Essig probiere ich gerne auf einem Teelöffel pur als kleinen Geschmackstest nach dessen Kauf. Aber irgendwo hört der Spaß mit der Säure auf. Selbst als gelegenlicher Granny Smith Genießer bin ich von dieser Mischung übelst geschockt. Sicher, Äpfelchen und Zitrönchen sind hier sicher im Aroma. Doch der Geschmack ähnelt eher dem Zitrönchen - und das passt mir herzlich wenig

Sample from Erzengel, thank you! The Apfelwein has got a hazy golden-orange body with a flat body. Low carbonation. Aroma of ripe, green apples, acid and fields. Taste of crisp apples, green apples, leaves. Harsh one, yet surely a good example of a standard Apfelwein. Little bit too sour for me though.

Hazy in the glass, fresh and a bit neutral beginning. The cider starts fruity and a bit watery. Fresh, smooth, fruity and quite dry. Nice ripe apples, fresh, smooth, not too deep. The aftertaste is round and smooth, dry, no tannins, smooth, fruity and easy to drink.

Bottle, probably from a Tegut in Marburg. So, this one is unfiltered, let’s see what difference it makes. Misty chalky yellow body with a tiny head. Sweet apple nose, kinda nice, slightly vinuous. Hm, not bad so far. The taste is... damn, dusty, mild appley taste, getting tangy in the end, vague glue, somewhat dusty. Ok at first, this somehow became more and more sour later on as it was open, ending up being less inspiring that it first was. Somehow. Meh. For the price, I shouldn’t complain.

Bottle from Marktkauf, Speyer The color is blond, very cloudy; while pouring it seems that the carbonation is low. There is a light aroma, a bit fruity and lemony, sour, and, as often for German ciders, also a scent of warm plastic (it reminds me the lights on the Christmas tree). The lack of carbonation improves the mouthfeel; the flavor is anyway quite simple, without clear fruits, and instead a white wine impression, and light acidity. At least, compared to may German ciders, this one doesn’t have all the flaws that the others have.
Not a big fan of this. The peach aroma was there but the flavor was missing and the overall experience was just lacking.
You know that book "The Unbearable Lightness of Being" by Milan Kundaris? And the joke is that "unbearable" connotes heavy, so it’s a heavy lightness? This beer has been reading that book.
At brewpub in Sept. Pour was a hazy yellow/brown color witha small white head. Aroma really is mostly Peaches and ginger. The flavors are the same with some iced tea hints. Not bad.
GABF 06. Aroma is of peaches, and ginger, go figure. Taste is sweet peaches, ginger, with a lightly tart finish. pretty good.
This is actually a pretty delicious brew. Cloudy and much darker than a wheat. Sweet peach flavor initially, with the ginger adding a nice compliment.

[Cask at Milton Keynes Beer Festival 2011] This was only 6.5%ABV, so don’t know if it’s a different version or just a batch that turned out differently? Pale gold. Taste more reminiscent a cider than a perry, albeit cider tinged with a hint of pear drops. Alcohol shows through quite strongly, giving a slight (but not overwhelming and unpleasant) hint of nail varnish remover. Sweet (but not sickly), with just a dry hint in the finish - it did remind me of sherry as others have said, but a pale, medium-dry sherry. Decent effort this.

Polycask at Merton Summer Beer Festival July 19th Strange one this the aroma is the first thing that i ntrigued me at first I thought rum but then when chatting to friend Bob we felt that it could have been aged in a sherry cask. It pours very light in colour light straw colour and the taste is in my opinion a little too strong and unbalanced what pear there is seems to be fighting a losing battle with the spoirit to assert itself. A lot of people liked this, I thought it was just about ok.
Bottle. Tastes quite spirity and sweet, has some slight dessert wine characters. Some pruny fruit, with spirity pear flavours, with some warming alcohol. This was pretty good.
LCRBM2. Musty, spongy aroma. Looks like white wine. Fermented pear flavor obviously, sherrylike notes, wooden finish. Oily mouthfeel.

Bottled - LCRBM2 - A clear lime green coloured perry. The aroma is very alcoholic, seems like a pear licqueur or a spirit. The taste is also very heavy and strong. Very sweet, pear fruits. Too much alcohol for me, but then this bottle was over 12 months old, so it may actually have picked up strength from its original 9.5% over the time.
Bottle at LCRBM 2, Kulminator, Antwerp, Belgium Clear, pale, yellow body. Looks like a watery wine. Aroma of liquor and pears. Watery, alcoholic, peary flavour. Moderately sweet.
LCRBM2. Thanks to maeib for this one. Clear pale gold, no head. Varnish aroma. Crude. Very alcoholic and I can’t get past that varnish flavour and aroma.
Bottled, LCRBM. Aroma of apple, apple, more apple and some alcohol. Yellow color, clear body, no head or lace of course. Sweet, apple, hint of varnish, sticky and very warming.
LCRBM2: Pear, a bit sugary and very alcoholic. Some oak in the aftertaste. Vinous. Not something I’d look for.

[2nd Low Countries RateBeer meeting] The aroma is winey/sherry-like with pear and alcohol. Indeed more a wine appearance and colour, no head. Woody sweet sherry taste with some pear fruitiness. Quite alcoholic. Not my thing.
This IPA was OK, it was not make the brewer on staff now. The new IPA is much better, it’s won medals. The old brewer is in Durango the owner said, so avoid those brews!!

This beer is called Ice Pick Ale now... And they are going to stop making it... Good thing. Hoppy and citru nose(smells better than it taste) Pour light orange but a very watery body and mouthfeel. Flavor had no balence way to bitter

Originally designed as an IPA, this pale ale has a mellow, yet full hop aroma. The color is almost amber, but not too dark. It develops a nice head, which could be slightly heavier. This ale is extremely drinkable, but pleases at each sip; characteristic of a good english pub ale. The IPA origin of this beer is evident in its hop profile. This beer also finishes clean, and is best after warming a little.

Tasted on tap at Brewpub in Ashland. This amber pours a dark copper color. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is cereal malts and citrusy hops. A medium bodied amber. Malts are caramel, fruity and sweet. Hops are aggressive for an amber and citrusy. The beer is wet hopped with 200 pounds of less than 24 hour old centennial hops. . Nice balance. The wet hops add a hop kick that is unexpected for an amber. Nice touch. A very drinkable amber. Well balanced. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Argyle Scottish Ale
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Growler from the brewpub in Milwaukee: Not bad for style if not a bit light in body, well balanced beer with a hoppy aftertaste

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Argyle Scottish Ale
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Pours dark copper, very clear, with a smooth white head. The waitress said this was on cask, but I think it was really on nitro due to the smoothness of the head and body. Very nice malt flavor up front, slightly earthy tone to it, caramel, and a light chocolate hint. Finish was fruity with a light hopping. This finished very clean and smooth leaving your palate wanting more.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Argyle Scottish Ale
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Clear brown, white creamy head. Very light sweet nose of brown sugar and cherry brandy. Flavor was light as well with notes of earth, chocolate and another hint of cherry. Light bodied, medium carbonation, soft malty finish. Maybe my batch was off. Just seemed disjointed. Pretty disappointed with this one since all the others were decent....

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Argyle Scottish Ale
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: A very nice Scottish ale, deep brown in color, soft & fluffly tan head, lots of malt in the nose with hints of chocolate & roasted nuts, full bodied, sweet body of flavors with notes of alcohol, caramel & dark chocolate with a nicely balanced profile of hops, very well-rounded beer, very smooth finish with a little more touch of alcohol & malt

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Argyle Scottish Ale
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On tap at the KoP location [10oz]. Poured a dark brown color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of chocolate, caramel, nutty and lightly earthy. Tastes of chocolate, caramel, and nutty. Didn’t get the typical peat / smokiness - this one was had a stronger chocolate quality in both the aromas and tastes. Light lacing left on the glass. Lively body.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Argyle Scottish Ale
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Pours a deep brown with some red coming through. Average bubbly/foamy head that left some lace. Aroma of sweet grainy maltiness wiht lots of caramel and some various fruits. Flavor was also malty as expected, grains, some dark fruits, caramel and even a bit spicy.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Nevermore Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: 290814. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is butter, roasted malt, caramel. Flavour is butter, roasted malt, caramel, hop. Boring beer.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Nevermore Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: [ As Rock Bottom King of Prussia Nevermore Lager ]. Clear dark brown color with a small to average, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, chocolate, dark malt, sweet malt, coffee, butterscotch. Flavour is moderate sweet with a average to long duration, dark malt, blackberries, sour coffee funnel notes . Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20140829]

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Nevermore Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Light but chocolaty. Easy to drink. Very tasty for the local pub. They only have on tap, never in bottles.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Nevermore Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Pours hazy dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted malty and breadish. Flat malty, roasted and breadish. Bitter, dark malty and hardroasted. Dry and herbal into the finish.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Nevermore Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: The beer pours dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma is toasted malt, tobacco, rye bread and light dark fruit. The flavor is light sourish malty with light tobacco notes. Sourish toasted finish.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Nevermore Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Pours clear dark reddish brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, toffee, butterscotch. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long butterscotch finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Nevermore Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Very dark brown with small tan head. Aroma is light roasted malts, butter, little bread and caramel. Flavour is malt, caramel, little bread, little coffee, notes of butter, medium sweet, notes of berries and a little bitter.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Nevermore Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: A clear, dark chestnut to brown beer with a finger-thick dark beige head. The aroma has quite a lot of butterscotch, with some toffee and prunes. Grassy hints. It’s medium bodied and soft on the palate, semi-sweet, with flavors of toffee, prunes and butterscotch. Some bitterness. Rather boring this one, and not too good either. 140829

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Nevermore Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
