33cl bottle at home. Pours a clear amber red colour with a moderate soapy head. Aroma of citrus, raisins, malts, caramel, candy sugar. Taste is medium sweet, moderate bitter with a low dry finish. Notes of caramel, slight hop, malt, metal, wood. Texture is oily to watery, light bodied with medium carbonation
Botella 33cl Kaisen Sushi (Oviedo) Cerveza con olor afrutado, suave y facil de beber
Very subtle nutty aroma. Looks deceptively fizzy but actually quite flat. Well rounded flavour. Bitter with a sharp taste of hops. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask @ GBBF 2013. Pours a dark ruby brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor with weak hints of dark fruit. Has a weak roasted malty caramel finish.

Cask. Dark brown or near black shade with ruby hints. Creamy head that disappears after a while. Tastes light roasted and malty. Coffee hints, quite a nutty finish. Slightly watery on the palate. Nothing new or different about this mild.
From cask. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is toasted malty. Bitter, toffee malty and dry breadish. Mild herbal hoppy note. Bitter and dry finish.

Gravity Dispense at Pig’s Ear BF, London - 05/12/12. Hazed chestnut brown with a thin off white head that clears to the edge of the glass. Nose is malts, nuts, barley, light coffee. Taste follows nose, coffee a little more prominent, roast malts/ Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Ok mild.

Cask at Pigs Ear BF 2012, London. Pours clear brown with a creamy, tan head. Dark toast nose - that’s it. Light sweet flavor, some burnt plastic, dark bread, light earth. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Bland finish, light sweetness, a bit more earthy bitterness and burnt bread. Meh. The beer is in fairly good nick so can’t blame conditioning for this beer’s mediocrity.
Cask conditioned at Far From the Madding Crowd, Oxford. Very dark brown with beige head. Fruity, liquorice, coffee flavours, rich, full and a touch sweetish, lasting on the palate. Decent beer.
Cask at the 2010 Battersea Beer Festival. Hints of coffee on the nose, then a creamy plummy body with hints of redcurrant and dark malt. Dry finish, a nice mild but a bit thin.
Cask at Battersea Beer Festival, 11th Feb 2009. Dark brown, nearly black, some cream head. Initially good flavour of roasted malt but then the palate thins out and its a bit sharp. Hoppy finish.

Cask gravity @ Reading Beer Festival 2008. Clear dark red brown color with a average, fizzy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, roasted, cold coffee, barnyard, earth, notes of chocolate and vanilla and licorice. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is flat. (030508)

column1: Swashbuckler Captain Rudes Black Water Stout
column5: Pours a dark brown with an off white head. Light roasted aroma. Thin for a stout but still has some nice roasted malts flavors. Fairly enjoyable

column1: Swashbuckler Captain Rudes Black Water Stout
column5: Pours brown-black with a 1-finger tan head. Smells of chocolate, coffee, hay, floral. Taste is bitter and mildly sweet with a little tang to it - subtle coffee, mild chocolate - something a little off to it though. A passable stout, but not noteworthy. Smells much better than it tastes.

column1: Swashbuckler Captain Rudes Black Water Stout
column5: Black pour very creamy tan head decent sticky lacing .... aroma is roasted coffee and chocolate ..... taste is a little sweet caramel malt with a decent roasted coffee and chocolate flavor ..... finish is dry and roasted with a nice oily mouthfeel .... actually isn’t a bad stout at all

column1: Swashbuckler Captain Rudes Black Water Stout
column5: Dark brown, basically black, tan head. Aroma is dry, roasty, some chocolate and caramel. Full bodied palate, dry roastiness, bitter baking chocolate, unroasted coffee. Also had a mocha version: Dirty light brown, tan head. Aroma is sweet chocolate, coffee. Taste is mocha, sweet milk chocolate, light roast finish. I preferred the dryer roastier original, but I can see the market for this at the faire. Mocha score 8:2:7:4:16

column1: Swashbuckler Captain Rudes Black Water Stout
column5: Draft at the Penn Spring Brewfest. Black-red color, small steady head. Smooth and malty, nice choco-roastiness. Good, but just doesn’t blow me away like some of their other offerings. Still above par for sure. Nice body/mouthfeel.

column1: Swashbuckler Captain Rudes Black Water Stout
column5: Draught at the PA. Renaissance Fair. Small tan head, good retention and some thin strips of lace hangin around. Black bodied brew with some brown edging. Nose is Chocolatey, lightly roasty, fruity with some faint berry notes. Body is Med/full, lightly oily on the palate, a little chalky. Chocolatey, weak coffee flavors, licorice with a hint of caramel malts and some light sour notes as well. Almost dry, chocolatey finish.

column1: Swashbuckler Captain Rudes Black Water Stout
column5: On tap at the PA Renaissance Faire. Poured a dark black color with an averaged sized tan head. Aromas of was roasty, smokey, with some cocoa. Tastes of roast, dark chocolate, with a bitter coffee finish. Nice bitter finish. Some lacing left on the glass.

column1: Swashbuckler Captain Rudes Black Water Stout
column5: Draught @ PA Renaissance Faire. Pours a dark, dark bown with a medium light tan bubbly/creamy head. Aroma of chocolate, dark fruits, hints of vanilla, oatmeal and lactose. Flavors of the some with hints of coffee.

column1: Swashbuckler Captain Rudes Black Water Stout
column5: On tap at the PA Renaissance Faire... Appears black with a foamy, tan head that slowly fades into a small cap. Lovely chunks of foam lace sticks all around the glass. Smell is of toasted oats, grains, cream, cocoa, light caramel, and an open bag of cereal. Taste is of the aromas with a decent mixture, making for a toasty, sweet, full brew. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, sweet, grainy, semi-dry, with CO2 bubbles bouncing off the middle of the tongue.

column1: Swashbuckler Captain Rudes Black Water Stout
column5: Dark brown with a mountainous rocky tan head. Redolent with dark chocolate, thids dry style stout was sweeter than others that share the style. A syrupy molasses sweetness envelops the tongue at the finish. This lacks the roasty bitter character of its cousing, Peg Leg. Not at all bad, but overshadowed by its older cousin.
Golden appearance. Clear. Bread butter malt aroma. Similar taste. Smooth light to medium body. Minimal bitterness.
Pathfinder Tours Diamond Twenties. Pleasant pale ale with a touch of bitterness.
Cask at the Volunteers Arms, GBBF. Pours clear yellow with a white head. Aroma of malt with butter. Sweet taste and finish.
Pours a finger of head on a slightly hazy light straw body. Aroma is dry grain with honey. Really nice. Taste is mild lemon, grainy with a mild metallic bitter finish. Texture is fizzy. Nice.

500 ml bottle. Unclear golden body with a big off-white head. Aroma has mild malt and some butterscotch. Flavor is sweet, mild malt, toffee, butterscotch, some cellar notes and medium bitterness. Medium body and aftertaste. A pretty average beer slightly tainted by butterscotch.
A body of hops, with herbal and floral taste thrown in. Just the briefest bit of bitterness and a lingering taste of hay. Okay to drink, really, a pale ale with some character!

Good lacing on the glass, minimal head retention. Golden colour with just the tiniest cloud. malty on the nose, with sweet caramel, almost a herbal, or woodiness. sweet, with the bitterness biting later, smooth and malty, with a light fizz. pale ale.

500 ml bottle. (K-Citymarket) Jyväskylä, Finland. Cloudy golden colour with a small white head. Grassy and floral hops, mild bitterness, malt and some sweetness in the aroma. The flavour is biscuity malty sweetness, some hops and mild dryness. Very English all the way.
0.5 l bottle from local supermarket. Golden colour, head dies fast. Taste has malts and hops in an English Pale Ale way. Quite OK, but nothing special.

50cl bottle from Citymarket Jumbo, Vantaa. BBE Jul 2016. Pours unclear pale golden with a thick white head. Creamy mouthfeel, smooth. Biscuity, caramel malty, citrusy aroma, jummy! </br> Flavor has caramel, biscuity like maltyness, citrus. Juicy and refreshing. Medium bodied. A very well made English pale ale, I like these alot.

Bottle from Rheged. Pours a hazy copper colour, no head. Doesn't look too appealing, it's not bottle conditioned, and it wasn't chilled so it shouldn't look like this.... I'm not too sure about the nose and palate either....drain pour! I'll buy another bottle next time I'm down that way and try again!
Cask. Aroma of citrus, bready malt and hops. Taste has smooth citrus, bready malt and creamy bread. Allright.
Pours amber, medium hite head. Aroma burnt toast.Taste lacking, very malty, watery and metallic. Ok
Bottle. Pours a dark gold colour with a thin white head, the aroma is light with some fruit, the taste is medium bitterness and fruity with a dry bitter finish.

Bottle from Rheged. Appearance - golden with a thin but decent head. Nose - cornflakes with an orangey note. Taste - more oranges, some mineral, orange barley sweets on the finish. Palate - light bodied, tangy texture, dry tangy finish. Overall - it grew on me!

Bottle BBE: Apr 2016. Chilled. Pours a clear chestnut brown body with medium, tight, off-white head; good lacing. Rich treacle toffee nose, a little floral. Dominant, medium-heavy sweetness to taste; a little butterscotch. Full-bodied with a creamy texture, medium-low carbonation (spot on for style) and a tooth-coating, honey-sweet finish. Overall an enjoyable, but overly sweet ale.

Bottle from Keswick bottle shop. Pours slightly hazy deep golden. Small frothy white head. Biscuit and malt on the nose. Faintly floral. Lightish body. Low carbonation but pleasant. A little watery with very light hops. Pleasant enough and drinkable.

Dog and Gun, Keswick. A pale ale, golden but a little hazy, not perfectly clear. Head goes quickly. Little aroma, hint of hops. Good body, biscuity malt and slightly floral hops. No great bitterness for a pale ale. Drinkable stuff though.

Cask (gravity dispense) at St Albans Beer Festival, September 2006. A copper coloured best bitter. Plenty of chewy, dry malt character backed up by tangy, spicy, hop bitterness. Decent balance. Hardly spectacular but a pleasant, easy-drinking brew.
Cask Stillage at the Bhurtpore Inn, Aston 11/07/2006 Straw aroma. Mid brown coloured with some alcohol present. Crisp on the palate with a roast malt finish.

(Cask at Marble Arch, Manchester, 27 July) Amber/orange colour with firm off-white head. Malty, nutty and fruity nose with orange, apricots, mandarin and dusty hops. Taste starts malty and nutty, evolves into a bitter finsih with loads of dusty, earthy hops and a hint of dried fruit (apricots, prunes). Complex and very nice.
Cask Stillage at the Bhurtpore Inn, Aston 11/07/2006 Fruit aroma. Golden amber coloured fruity and hoppy with a bitter and crisp malt finish.
Cask Stillage at the Bhurtpore Inn, Aston 11/07/2006 Very fruity aroma. Golden coloured with a very fruity raspberry flavour. Crisp on the palate with a bitter lasting finish.

column1: Purple Moose Snowdonia Ale / Cwrw Eryri
column4: Purple Moose Brewery (Y Bragdy Mws Piws)
column5: Bottle. Pours straw with white head. Light citrus hops, bread malts, nice lingering bitter finish. Fine. Cask at The Anglesey in Caernarfon. Similar vibe to the bottle, less citrus slightly sweeter, smoother obvs. possibly not in the greatest condition. Nice though. 3.1

column1: Purple Moose Snowdonia Ale / Cwrw Eryri
column4: Purple Moose Brewery (Y Bragdy Mws Piws)
column5: Cask at Y Garth, Pennal. Pours gold with a small head. Aroma is sweet straw with a lttle lemon. Taste has straw throughout with grain on the finish.

column1: Purple Moose Snowdonia Ale / Cwrw Eryri
column4: Purple Moose Brewery (Y Bragdy Mws Piws)
column5: Decent bitter. Lovely and smooth. Very refreshing. Good balance of bitterness and a little sweet.

column1: Purple Moose Snowdonia Ale / Cwrw Eryri
column4: Purple Moose Brewery (Y Bragdy Mws Piws)
column5: Half-pint, cask ale at Borough Arms. Clear golden coloured body. Low white head blanketing the upper part of the glass. Moderate taste of leafy hops, semi-sweet. Taste of biscuit followed by a bone dry ending. Satisfying. (Neath 02.10.2018).
650ml bottle Gold pour with ok head. Grainy aroma. Sweet clean taste. Uninspiring.

Can in Seattle, brought from my brother who got it in Qingdao. No head, very pale watery yellow. Super light. Skunky green grain on nose. Modestly crisp, sort of. Lots of honey. Not disgusting, or offensive. Very light.
600 ml bottle. Pours a clear golden with a white head. Light malty aroma. Lightly sweet and bitter with some berries in the beginning then dried fruits. A little boring.
Klares gelb mit wenig Schaum. Etwas Malz, Reis, minimal fruchtig, Nuancen von Gras und Zitrus, sehr wässrig.

Half pint. Cask @The Crescent, 5.Jul.2012 Dark amber hazy body, spare creamy head, bubbles stick to the glass. Cake, spruce, herbs, sweet corn and aloe vera. Some bitterness in the taste, hint of honey, lime and orange.

Half pint, hand-pulled cask at the Crescent, Salford. Unclear, dark amber. Filmy layer blanketing the glass as it goes down. Caramel malts to the nose followed by a malt-fruity taste and ending up with malt bitterness. Alright, feels a bit thin, though. Retired? (Greater Manchester, 05.07.2012).

Cask conditioned at the Woolpack, Banbury, Oxon, 12-01-09. Pours mid amber in colour with a white head. Reasonable fruitiness and bitterness come through in this bitter, bit earthy at times, maltiness showing throughout, its good but not as good as the Silverstone Pitstop which I’d had beforehand. A6 A3 F6 P3 OV13

Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Brown amber with white head. The beer of choice last night, sweetish fruity malt with a touch of malt loaf in the body, reasonably bitter on the finish, some light hop. Easy drinking dark bitter.

Cask at the Market Porter in Southwark. Something of a dark sugary fruit aroma. Dark amber color with an enduring beige head. Starts slightly sweet malt, with floral hop. The finish is lightly bitter, then some malt creeps back along with floral aspects. Dry on balance.
Cask Handpump at the Ship & Mitre, Liverpool 28/08/2006 Fruit aroma. Mid brown coloured and fruit flavoured with a crisp and dry lasting malt finish.
Cask: Light golden yellow. Malt and hops in the aroma. Quiyte a creamy, hoppy flavour, also a little sweet. Really nice refreshing ale.

On cask at Bruxellensis. This brew was a lot more floral then the No. 3. The hops actuall displayed some of their floral character and not just their bitterness. Malts were light up front with a bit more fruitiness showing as it finished. Very light on the palate without a strong flavor, kinda tough being a subtle flavor brew in a mostly belgian beer festival.

Pleasant Pale Ale. Had a fair bit of this recently. Both in Brussels (?!) and Locally at home. Golden, light head, easy retention. Def, Goldings on the bitter edge, and bit light on the nose, although typical Gadds. Bitter, rather than Floral. Definitely fruity hop notes in the finish.

Cask handpull - Bruxellensis Festival. Eddie Gadd was actually at the festival and we had a bit of a conversation whilst I got this beer. He had actually read my posting on his Dogbolter and quoted it back to me. Amazing. And a really nice bloke too. Bizarre to see this beer at this festival. Golden/copper colour, thin white head. Bit of malt and grassy hop aroma. Bit of tangerine fruit flavour. Nice pale ale. Dryish finish.

Cask Hazy orange-amber, with transparant cask head. Fresh hops, but very dry and discreet, bit of lemon & grapes. Wry, slight bitterish with a bit of Brussels’ endives. Citrus in the finish again. Very light, apt for the ABV. Ends in a wry after’feel’ rather than -taste. Good hoppy, light bitter.

column4: Pivovaren Zavod Varnensko Pivo (Ledenika i MM AD - Bulbrew)
column5: 500ml can from CBA, drunk at home. Pours crystal clear with a short-lived frothy head, plenty of lacing while the head lasted, a coarse persistent bead. Golden straw in colour. On the nose, strong biscuity malts at first, but quickly fading. In the mouth, average carbonation, medium body, releasing some biscuit and bready malt flavours with hints of honey, but no real hop presence, minimal sweetness and a mid bitter finish. Overall, quite malty and not badly balanced, but ultimately just another forgettable Eastern European lager.

column4: Pivovaren Zavod Varnensko Pivo (Ledenika i MM AD - Bulbrew)
column5: Bottle. Golden color. Malty aroma. Flavor is more grainy and malty. Common lager.

column4: Pivovaren Zavod Varnensko Pivo (Ledenika i MM AD - Bulbrew)
column5: Golden colour with medium head.Sweet aroma of malt and honey.Flavor is hoppy and light grainy feels soft with short finish.Hard to find even in Varna.

column4: Pivovaren Zavod Varnensko Pivo (Ledenika i MM AD - Bulbrew)
column5: Bottled. An orange beer with a thin white head. The aroma is metalic malty, and the flavor is sweet with notes of metal and a hint of carraway seed(?), before a dry end sets in.

column4: Pivovaren Zavod Varnensko Pivo (Ledenika i MM AD - Bulbrew)
column5: bad, very bad! something between beer and vinegar. I’m not sure that it could be find in the shops and pubs. nasty, like the most beers during the communism

column4: Pivovaren Zavod Varnensko Pivo (Ledenika i MM AD - Bulbrew)
column5: rbesg06gt, bottled. i always wondered what bulgarian beer must taste like. now i know that it’s pale, cardboardy, fizzy and has no bitterness

column4: Pivovaren Zavod Varnensko Pivo (Ledenika i MM AD - Bulbrew)
column5: Bottle at RBESG 2006. Inoffensive brew, if a little boring. Seemed to have a bit more body to it than the crappier pale lagers.

column4: Pivovaren Zavod Varnensko Pivo (Ledenika i MM AD - Bulbrew)
column5: Bottle. Very thin and boring pale lager. Some sweetish pale malt characters and lets face it, not a lot else. At least i got a new country off the list i suppose.

column4: Pivovaren Zavod Varnensko Pivo (Ledenika i MM AD - Bulbrew)
column5: [Sampled at RGESG 2006] Pale golden. Frothy head. Thin and dryish international lager. Boooring...

column4: Pivovaren Zavod Varnensko Pivo (Ledenika i MM AD - Bulbrew)
column5: (500 ml bottle on RBESG 2006) Label sais "10%" but is most likely the degree plato before fermentation. Clear pale golden color, white head. Sour malty scent, malty taste. Thin mouth feel, low bitterness.
Bottle from SinH4. Amber with creamy head. Grassy with some chewing gum, hay, a bit of bitterness, bread. Very nice and rustic.

Bottle from Hopfen & Malz, Berlin. Rich, bready malt nose with spicy, slightly lemony hops. Almost clear gold with a low, thick head. Flavor of spicy hops, minerals, and crisp, crackery malt. Decent, but almost certainly needs to be tried on tap and fresher.
oro leggera velatura cereale discreto erbaceo lieve zolfo pane amaro discreto

Tap, Steinkrug. Creamy dense head. Aroma is grassy hops, earthy malts, bready, hay, rustic. Taste is rustic barn, hay, bready, earthy, cereal, very bitter herbal finish. Mineraly mouthfeel with natural carbonation. A very rustic experience, great stuff!
02-02-19 // on tap at BrewDog Berlin Mitte. Super süffiges Kellerbier. Stark. Getreidig süß.

Disappointing. Clear golden body with a small, vanishing white head. Aroma is cereals, mild grassy. Taste is malty again, cereals and some honey. Long grassy finish. Low body, soft carbonation, watery texture. To clear to be a keller, no yeasty notes at all. Where is the fresh baked bread of a Fränkisches Kellerbier. I think the doggos here did not handle the keg with care. Deserves a new chance, in a better place.

From barrel at Moor. It pours clear amber with a small bubbly white head. The aroma is sweet, oily, sticky, sponge cake, muffin, grassy, herbal, sweet, cakey and almond. The taste is slick, soft, sweet, cakey malts, brioche, orange muffin, toasted almond, touch of warmth, orange blossom, biscotti, bead, brioche and candy with a drying finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Sounds sweeter than it is. Fun stuff. Flavourful.

50cl swing top bottle. A clear dark amber beer with a mid-sized most good lasting off-white head. Aroma of mild reddish grainy malt, hints of caramel. Taste of mild sweet caramalish malt, grainy malt as well, traces of nuts.
03-10-17 // Bier Tasting im Bayern-Zelt @ Tag der deutschen Einheit 2017 in Mainz. Red golden unfiltered. Full-flavoured graininess, mild hop aroma.

Nice, heavy swingtop bottle, suitable for homebrew. Decent label of a napping monk. Foggy, dark tea colored brew with a respectable oatmeal head which sticks to the side of the glass. Very pleasant, nutty, slightly grassy malt aroma with distinct honey tones. Very smooth, very very nice. Sweet, malt forward, toasted straw and leathery notes, somewhat tannic. Very much en pointe and to style. Only complaint is that the brew went a little flat. Beer Stop, Tallahassee.

Bottle from Arden Wines, March 2016. 2:30am. My least favourite of the Weissnoher quartet (sounds like a 40s bebop combo) but still a decent beer. Fliptop pouring slightly veiled bronze with a fine narrow cream collar. House nutty, praline, cherry blossom, shrubby hop, toffee-hinting, Hovis biscuit nose. Sweet again but balanced and nuanced enough to keep you pivoting your elbow and searching for metaphors; milk chocolate, cherry, marzipan, toffee popcorn, thistle and digestives this time. I’m talking bollocks- this is just as good as the others; 737314.
Butelka. Aromat typowy, charakter lagerowy, karmel. W smaku goryczka niska, lekko s³odowe. Nawet pijalne.
16.9 oz bottle pours Amber with a off white head. Aroma of caramel, fruit and grass. Taste is sweet and malty.
Ein sehr süßes und karamelliges Märzen. Interessantes Aroma, wenn auch nicht ganz mein Favorit.

Swing top bottle. 5.4%. Archer Road Beer Stop, Sheffield. Hazy, copper colour. Thin, dense, lasting, white head. Aroma is sweet and nutty. Some caramel. Notes of leafy vegetable. Bit of chocolate. Taste is nutty and sweet. Medium body. Soft carbonation. More sweetness on the finish. Tasty beer, but too sweet for me.

0,5 l Bügelflasche. Aroma: Karamellig, süß malzig, leicht würzig. Erscheinung: Kastanienrotes Bier, cremeweißer, feinporiger Schaum. Geschmack: Malzbetont, süßlich, ausreichend würzig, minimal bitter. Nachgeschmack: Würzigkeit hält sich, minimale Bitterkeit auch. Gesamt: Sehr gelungenes Bier.

Tallahassee, Fl. - Beer Stop - pop-top 500 ml bottle - labeled as Monk’s Fest. Slightly hazy, medium copper pour, slight off-white head that clings to the edge of the glass. Aroma has some molasses accents, some dates, a hint of brown sugar. Sweet leaning flavor, brown sugar, light maple syrup, some prune-like fruity accents, Decently thick mouthfeel.

Draught @ Brauerei Bräutigam, Dorfstraße 12, Eltmann-Weisbrunn, Bavaria, Germany 97483. [ As Bräutigam Dunkles ]. Clear medium amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, hay, caramel, nutty notes, light to moderate hoppy, grass. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter with a long duration, grass, caramel, dry, nutty notes. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20140510]
In bottle as dunkles...is it really the rauch? Amber, thick head. Aroma is fresh, malty. Flavors are delicious liquid bread. Quaffable and very good with toasty finish. Smiley.
As Dunkles. Dull light brown. Toasty, maybe some light smoke. On the palate, the smoke is subtle with caramel influences, leading to a toasty finish. Great foam.

Bottled@brewpub, had it with breakfast (which was cheese & bacon...). Deep amber colour, mediumsized beige creamy head. Aroma is caramel malts, some hops and a bit toasted notes. Flavour is very dry roasted malts along with some slight peppery notes.
Cloudy brown. Metallic roast aroma. Very complex flavor - but my notes are lacking: Nutty, berrylike, honeyish notes. Medium body, mellow mouthfeel. One to seek out again!

Bottle. Smoked ham glazed with honey was the first thing that came to mind on the first sip. Nice salami aroma. Has an ever so slight ;actic sourness (very, very slight), which marked it down a little bit, pleasant otherwise.

(bottle, without label, shared by DerDoppelbock - many thanks !) Hazy amber colour with a short off-white creamy layer. Chalky, sweet malty and slightly fruity aroma with a delicate smoked note. Bitter flavour, aromatic smoked malty taste, medium bodied with a smooth carbonation; moderately dry and bitter finish with a lasting smoke-malty aftertaste. Quaffable and moreish (06.10.06).

Bottle at Bruxellensis Festival 2006, Brussels, Belgium Off-white head. Hazy, brown body. Aroma of smoked bacon and caramel. Very nice aroma! Lightly sweet, moderately bitter flavour with some extra bitterness popping through to the end. Very smooth with a nice (but not very much) complexity. Very well balanced. Great.

Bottled - Bruxellensis Festival - An amber coloured beer with a hint of red in its body. The aroma is smoky with toffee. malts and fruits. The taste is smoky also. Good alcohol notes. A little bit of paint stripper. Malty yet slightly flowery. Tasty and interesting.

Chestnut colour, no head. Nutty, chocolate and easy, soft smoke. Touch of smoked ham and (beech)wood. Smoked taste, in the softest way, near sweet honey-cured Virginian ham. Light to medium bodied. Another superb starter to Rauchbier; subtle. For this one, thumbs up for Dan Shelton, who offered me this exceptional beer.

Pint in Lewes, East Sussex. Ive searched this beer on the net and it says it is dis continued, but believe me it was on tap in this pub. I forget the name of the pub but the owner is from Swindon. Dark amber in appearance with a good creamy looking head. Strong taste, but not to pleasant. However I was in need of a beer with some flavour so enjoyed it.

Not sure what to call this. Interestingly enough, the waitress claimed this had been made with the Hefe yeast. Who knows. Pale yellow, little head. Aroma faintly spicy. Flavor was almost all yeast, the light malts of the lager utterly obliterated. Flavors were spicy, a bit of clove, and some coconut, a flavor component I don’t think I’ve ever picked up in a beer before. Not awful, but definitely experimental. Really highlighted the yeast in a big way.

Pours a mustard yellow color with a white head. It has a faint aroma of bananas. This lager is spicy with notes of cinamon, cardamom, and mase with a creamy banana flavor. It’s banana bread in lager form (well, not exactly your typical lager form). Only available at Legend Brewing Co. on tap.

On tap at the brewpub. Clear golden body with a medium frothy white head. Sweet light banana aroma. Very light banana flavor, with some light hops. Originally they were trying to crisp up the lager, but they went a tad overboard on the belgian yeast giving this a definite hefe feel. I’d call it a Kristallweizen but it doesnt have the requisite wheat.

Tap at Legend Brewing -- An experimental batch of the regular Legend Lager that was meant to give it more spice. Pale gold body with a frothy white head. A belgian yeast style aroma, banana and wheat. Taste is similar, bready, banana and some light malts, hops are rather limited. Almost a hefeweizen, but definitly a lager.

Tap, 9-07-06. Black with beige head, fades to film. Aroma has light fruit up front, coffee tends to dominate through the middle. Flavor, coffee front to back, bif choclate character as it warms. Nice brew, coffee tad too much for me though.

Cask: Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, coffee, and a hint of grape. Dark brown with moderate brown head that lasts a minute or so. Lots of vanilla, moderate chocolate, and just the slightest touch of grape. Finishes with a big roasted coffee flavor. Very nice and stout-like.

Tap at WC as Hoppopotamus. Ruby red pour and some very hoppy malted aroma. Caramel, sugar, pine or some sorts of tree and further hops. Heat. Good balance between the alch and hops. Drinkable. Wish it was more lasting.

Cask at the brewpub. Pours clear clear amber with a small off white head. The aroma has a bit of florals, some spicy rye notes, a bit of a citrus note in the distance. The taste has a sweet orange juice and a small bitter note.

Pours a clear amber/ruby color with a thick tan head...nice lacing and retention. Aroma has nice floral hoppy notes...earthy/spicy with lt fruitiness...sticky caramel maltiness. Flavor has significant caramel and very nice floral hoppiness...earthy and bitter with mild fruity notes...slightly sweet. Mouthfeel is full and sticky with a bitter fruity/earthy finish.

Draft @ brewpub. Pours deep amber color with thin white head. Aroma is floral hops and light toasted malt. Taste is sweet with floral hop and caramel flavors. Medium body and light carbonation with a dry, malty finish,

Tap - Wilmington. Pours clear tawny with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is fruity esters, caramel and bread malt, floral hops, Belgian yeast and sugar. Flavor is malty with medium hops and bitterness, fruity esters, spices, and a dry finish. Medium body, warmth, and carbonation.

Tap at Iron Hill Phoenixville as the Hopopotomus. Pours out a cloudy darker copper color with a small white head. Aroma is of light citrus hops and some caramel. Taste is some sweet malts, caramel, light fruity notes, and grapefruit hops. Dry finish. Would have liked this one much hoppier for the name of it. None the less, rather solid.

On draft at Iron Hill, Phoenixville. Served as ’Hoppopotomous.’ Poured deep ruby red with off-white head. Solid sheets of lacing. Sweet caramel and malts dominated this one. Some surprisingly subtle piney, grapefruit bitterness. Medium bodied. Wondering where the hops were with this one. Not the hop bomb I was expecting.

On tap @ Iron Hill Wilmington. Deep clear amber with an off white head that leaves a good amount of lacing. Citrus, pine and resin hop aroma with lots of sweet caramel. This one starts sweet and finishes long and bitter. Medium body with a sticky syrupy mouth feel. Pretty good just a bit sweet for my tastes.

Cask at IH Wilmington. "Hopkowski"... Poured into a pint glass, nice big cascading head. Redish orange color. Nice aroma of fresh hops. Piney. Taste is a hop and malt bomb... Super smooth texture, slight alchohol in the taste... Taste is on the hoppier side. Overall a nice enjoyable beer.

This beer was listed on their Features menu as ’Red Cindy’, but seemed to match the description of this beer. So instead of added a new beer, I’ll just go ahead and submit my rating under this name. It seems to have many aliases anyway. But by whatever name you call it, this was one fantastic beer! It pours a beautiful amber color with a copper hue. The head was little off-white and left a ton of lacing around the glass. The nose was full of pine, grapefruit, grass, lemon and a hint of caramel. The flavors were inticing and delicious, with dry and bitter notes of piney and flowery hops, a touch of caramel, grass, earth and wood. The balance was superb and the drinkability was outstanding. This is one of those IPA’s that you can drink one right after the other all day long. The finish was remarkably hoppy and dry. Unfortantely I forgot my growler on this trip, but I will certainly make a special trip back just to get more of this!
Poured into wine glass a bright gold. Honey and yeast in nose and mouth. Alcohol well hidden. This is the sweeter style common with wineries.
Honey and yeast nose, some fusel alcohol. Very pale champagne. Honey and acetone, lemon and apple tang and nice pistachio accents. Light body, smooth.
Decent mead. Sweet and honey like in the nose and mouth, but a slighly odd spicyness as well. Almost gave it a beer like quality. Alcohol is well hidden. Decent.

I drank a bottle of this last night. Easily the best mead I have ever had. It has a very sweet honey aroma and taste. Be cautious when drinking this though, the alcohol is hidden so I didn’t realize how much I was consuming until it hit all at once. So be weary, cause this mead can be a dangerous friend. With that being this is easily now my favorite mead.

750 ML Bollte-Clear golden pour, not much else you can say about it. Very standard mead/honey taste, really no other flavors added. Sweet, but not overly so. Very basic mead, but very good. Well done example where less is more

From tap & mallet, poured from a bottle into a gay little glass. Clear light clear/yellow. Minerals and touches of urine in the nose, sour grape too. Flavors are soft, delicate...not overly sweet at all...very tasty...lots of apple and grape flavors actually...its not exactly complex or funky, but by god, it’s pretty damn good and refreshing and I really like those bright apple/grape notes...could easily use this to get my 6 year old to go to bed on command and to create a toddler alcoholic.

Pours a clear light white wine color. Aromas of apple, some rubber, candy. Taste is pretty exquisite, if simple and straight forward. Slightly medicinal, sweet, yet not cloying, savory and full bodied. Alcohol is hidden. This is a nice mead. Like.
Clear pale yellow color. Sweet and estery nose. Honey and pineapple and some apple and grain flavors. Alcohol much like a wine. Overall good, but nothing to distinguish it.

750 ml bottle. Pours a clear, somewhat pale gold with no head. This is a still mead. The aroma is honey with some fairly strong alcohol vapors, which surprises me given the abv on the bottle is listed at 8%. The flavor is straightforward honey, clean and not earthy. Sweet but not cloying. This mead is actually lighter in body than I would have imagined given its sweetness. Better than I was expecting.

Bottle. Pours clear light gold, no real legs. Aroma of honey and citrus notes. Flavor is pure honey up front, a bit of citrus tang, sweet. Mouthfeel is medium-heavy, light watery. Overall, I thought it was very tasty, just a simple mead with alot of flavor.

Bottle from The Bier Stein in Eugene, OR. Poured a golden yellow with a small white head. I was slightly disappointed with this one. It was dry like a champagne, but had an odd sour flavor. Not bad, but could have been better.

Bottle from the Bottle Shop in Eugene, OR. This looked excellent in the shop, and I was looking forward to drinking this limited edition brew. However, it failed expectations. Refreshing brew and kinda sour. While I tend to like that, it didn’t have any backbone. Well brewed, but a let down.

(750ml bottle, thanks dickinsonbeer) Cloudy lemon yellow body with small white head. Aroma is medium sweet, lemon, lactose. Taste is medium sweet, lemon, lactose, lavender, flower, bread. Creamy medium body with low carbonation.

1st annual Shenandoah campout. Pours a fairly light strawish gold with a hazy look and a decent lasting pure white head. Aroma is earthy, phenolic (in a bad way)_, doughy almost baby fod like, dirty diaper hints, sweaty, herbal and DMS laden. Doughy, cream of wheat malty flavor, herbal and grassy- astrinngent, more DMS, creamed corn and some cabbage. Finish isnt as dry as I had hoped either. Meh- this was a pretty big let down.

750mL bottle, #134, sampled at the 1st Annual Shenandoah Beer Throwdown, courtesy of Dickinsonbeer. Thanks, Paul! Pours a hazy, golden color; good off-white head formation with solid retention and glistening, fine-bubbled lacing. Lots of funky yeast character, yellow fruits, bananas, and overripe fruits in the aroma; quite pleasant, dense, and funky. Average carbonation. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: chewy overripe yellow fruits, intricate yeastiness, bread, and Belgian sugars; definitely overripe, but quite generous and funky overall. Medium finish: breadiness, toasty malts, Belgian sugar, and bananas.

Sample provided by Styles. Clear pale body with a medium sized white head, fading. The nose is apple juice, bread, honey and pear. The flavor is apple pear and doughy bread. Medium/light body is thin and watery with soft carbonation.

Sampled at CapFlu’s with about 20 other beers that I barely remember. Sour, lemony wheat aroma. Pours pale yellow with a nice white head. Raisins, grassiness. Sweetish finish. I rated it high but who really knows how good it was.
Dusty gold, Smells grassy and a bit fruity, but it’s in general rotted, mustiness kind of smells like garbage. Some fruit in the flavor and some nice hops, but not generally that pleasurable.

(12oz bottle) Sampled at the Post-Great Canadian Beer Festival 2007 in Victoria on September 8th, 2007. Large white frothy head with a cloudy yellow and unfiltered body. Nose of citrus and vanilla. Smooth creamy malt with active yeast base and spiced mint.

Bottle, brewed at Jantzen Beach, sold at BelmontOpaque yellow, whispy head. Aroma of yeast, pear, fresh malt, marshmallow. Sweet and spicy palate with pear, mango, light pepper and coriander seed. Sweet, milky character. A very cool interpretation - distinct and definitive, and not just another ginger/coriander Belgian masquerading as saison.
ambrato carico schiuma media discreta peristenza maltata caramello cereale amaro non pronunciato trendente al dolce
chiara schiuma media non molto persitente naso fresco leggermemnte acidulo poco fruttato speziatura delicata anche in bocca
Blond ok senza aspetti che spiccano, bionda frizzantina, al naso discreto lievito, miele, cereale, al palato scorrevole con punta di lievito, malto dolce.

Bottle@Bagia Cafe, Alberello. Vibrant cloudy golden beer with a strong white head. The aroma is sour and the flavour is refreshing yet sour with some fruitiness, yeasty and bitterness. Overall a better beer than the ratings say. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
15th January 2011 Hazy amber gold beer. Little white head. Dry palate. Light minerals. Bitterish tangerine and orange.Floral tones. A little cream malt underneath. Dry finish. Tasty but over dry.

Slightly aged sample Thick, off-white dense head over clear copper beer. Slightly sourish nose, touch of wine, partly acetic, partly lactic. Vinous flavour, again acetic and lactic, nowhere exaggerated, some dark-red fruit. Very light MF, for such a beer; if quite slick, film-like, there’s more to this than acidthinning. MF is cruelly missing; if not, the beer might be called pretty succesfull in a Belgian way, IMO.

Honey and yeast taste becomes sour palate with some fuity nutes. Medium long, bitter finish. White and thick head, which is disappearing quickly - stays on top for circa 1 minute. Hazy, honey-like colour.

Bianca anomala, colore ambrato chiaro; naso agrumato con sentori di ananas, tropicale; palato lievemente astringente con malto, poca se non assente la banana e il pane; rinfrescante e gustosa, stile e nome da cambiare
oro tobida media schiuma buona persistenza cereali lieve citrico poco speziata un po astringente
Pale ale ambrata. Poca schiuma. Odore di olive e lievito. Acquosa. Corpo leggerissimo. Pessima ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Amber colour with white head. Olive aroma, olive taste, some sweet malt, caramel, slightly bitter. Light body.
Bottle at DOC. Intriguing aromas of olives, nut, and spice. Taste is sweet, with light sourness and bitterness; long length. Palate is velvety, and medium bodied. Amber, with a frothy head.
De color caldo de pollo, extremadamente turbia, la espuma no duró apenas un segundo. El aroma era regular, el gusto pésimo. Nos la vendieron como muy buena y acabó en el fregadero. Una lástima.
en botella.Tostada turbia .aromas dulces,caramelo,levadura.......un poco metalica ,no me gusta. Encima la venden carissima.Desastre.

Bottle at Desiderio, pizzeria in Ancona Amber color. Some aroma of malt, yeast, alcohol. Light caramel flavor, metallic, dry, with light astringency, and yeast; ordinary bitterness. Nasty beer; just an overpriced home brew; not even a can of Sprite could make it drinkable.
ambrata buona schiuma un po grossolana media persistenza naso piatto lieve cereale un toco di caramello non amara disarmonica
Served at Tutto Italia in Epcot. Pours gold with a white head. Medium body. Flavor is quite floral, some what bready, Maybe a little grassy. I’m liking it.
On tap as Sheriff Lager Chiara at Old Wild West restaurant Pomezia Italy. Bland and watery lagery with almost no taste. OK for a hot day in the sun.
Pours gold with a smallish white head. Aroma is light bready malts. Flavor is light bready, slightly sweet malt, with a slight crispness at the end. Ok.
Bottle. Pours a golden body with a white head. Sweet grain y notes a lighter bread y character with some sweet earth tones. Decent but i wouldn’t buy again.

Not sure if it is suposed to stand here. The can said: Gambrinus V Plzni Roku Original 10° Can, 33cl @ Plane to Prague. Aromas of bread and grains. Yellowish golden colour, off-white head. Lacing and a bid sparkling. Even in a plastic cup. Flavours of breas, sweet, grain. Waterish, but the grains stay in the aftertaste. Good pils for on a plane.
Pint @ Prague. Easy, but tasty beer. Some say it’s not full bodied but works very well with me, as long its served cold enough.
Honest and cooling. She is one of more the taking in the Czech Rep.................................Honesta e refrescante. É uma das mais tomadas na Rep. Tcheca. Pilsen melhor que a Brahma...

swing top bottle (500ml). -Cloudy pale yellow coloured, huge airy white head, offensive and strong sourish grassy cereals nose. Acidic hoppy barnyard, boiled vegetables and pickles taste with some acidic apple finish. Simply undrinkable. The nose is awful, the taste even worse. If it weren’t from Italy, I would have thought it was spoilt.
Fine, dry pilsener with crisp hoppiness. Similar to the best pilseners in Northern Germany. Fancy finding this at 2000 metres above sea level at Mount Etna! Long lingering piney finish.
Cloudy yellow color, foamy white head. Aroma of light citrus. Taste is watery bubblegum. Not exciting.

Bottle 50cl. @ home. Unclear hazy medium orange color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate yeasty, banana. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is creamy, carbonation is soft. [20090525]
Always suprised with the Germania brews, might be another name for park hefe? But anyways, for the price, its nice. Some banana, light citrus, not spectactular, but worthy of drinking.
( Bottle 500 ml, thanks Dolty ! ) Hazy yellow color with a thick white foam. Notes of citrus and yeast. Light body with soft malty finish. A thirst quencher !
Pours a dark copper colour thin white head, Aroma is spicy malty Taste is sweet malty with hardly any bitterness Overall sweet and malty needs a lot more hops bit dissapointing
Cask @ Kings Arms, Salford. Clear amber-gold with a creamy head. Malt nose and fairly crisp with very light tropical fruit flavours in its taste.
Bottle from Coppers, Newcastle. This is a hazy amber-brown coloured beer with a sweet red fruit and malty flavour, slight chocolate and roasted notes with bitter coffee on the finish.
Cask conditioned at Harbury Beer Fest ’08. Bronze to amber with white head. Quite thin and watery on the whole and with a cheapish tea like hop note, a little like G.K. Malty finish. Not great.
Cask Stillage from the cellar at the Crescent, Salford 01/09/2006 Some hop aroma. Bronze golden coloured and hoppy with a slightly bitter lasting malt finish.
Cask Stillage from the cellar at the Crescent, Salford 01/09/2006 Some fruit aroma. Clear golden coloured and hoppy with a crisp and slightly creamy malt finish.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Rushden Historical Transport Society. A golden coloured beer with a white head. A little off-putting fruit skin in the nose, but better in the mouth with some nice fruity malts and warming alcohol. There is a strange worrying pineapple note though.
Cask Stillage from the cellar at the Crescent, Salford 01/09/2006 Fruity aroma. Bronze golden coloured with some alcohol present. Crisp on the palate with a slightly wheaty malt finish.
Cask Stillage from the cellar at the Crescent, Salford 01/09/2006 Some fruit aroma. Golden coloured fruity and slightly hoppy with a little dryness in a crisp malt finish.
Cask Handpump at the Crescent, Salford 01/09/2006 Black slightly rich on the palate and fruity. Smooth on the palate with some dryness in a full roast finish.

Ich sage "Vielen Dank an Kappeldav für dieses Bier"! Der Geruch ist ganz leicht rauchmalzig. Der Antrunk ist ziemlich flach mit leichter, rauchiger Note. Im Hauptteil wird das Bier etwas vollmundiger und einen ganz kleinen Tick süßlicher. Dazu mischt sich eine sehr sehr dezente Rauchmalznote zusammen mit einer angenehmen Röstmalzigkeit. Der Nachgeschmack ist eine angenehme Komposition aus angenehmer Herbe und leichten Rauchtönen, die mir aber zu sehr im Untergrund bleiben. Auf der Zunge bleibt eine angenehme, aber mir etwas zu flache Note aus Rauch, Malz und angenehmer Herbe. --> Mir ist es insgesamt zu "flach auf der Brust". Die Aromen könnten allesamt etwas stärker ausgeprägt sein. Aber für ein sächsisches Rauchbier doch schon ganz lecker! Test vom 11.9.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,10,11,10,12,10 - 10,45
Bottle. Deep Amber with a thin head. Aroma is smoked caramel. Flavour is light smoked bacon with some caramel on the palate. Finish is lingering smoke

Malzig-wässriger Antrunk in dem die Rauchigkeit nur einen kleinen Anteil hat. Auch im Mittelteil wird das Raucharoma kaum stärker, hintergründig ist das Bier süß, insgesamt eher wässrig. Im Abgang etwas malziger, andeutungsweise herb. Ein wirklich sehr schwaches Rauchbier! Vielen Dank an kappldav123 für das Bier! Test vom 29.4.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,8,9,7,11,7

Bottled 330ml. -trade with kappldav123 (thanks David!) Darker amber coloured, small white head that went away fast, dusty smokey and caramel nose. Slight roasted malt, caramel and some smoke with flowery and mild spicy notes. A bit thin but never mind, it’s average German smoked beer.

Bottle that ogivlado got in a trade, with kappldav I guess and shared with me (thanks and thanks!). Poured a cola-like brown/black/red body with an off white head. Light smokey nose, some light soy sauce, roast, rosehip and caramel. Dryish. Light background smoke in the taste, rosehip vs. caramel mix, interesting. Nice maltiness, freshm not too hoppy. Some bacon. A very good light smoked.

Bottled 33cl. Courtesy of kappldav123. It pours a clear nut brown beer with a small, bubbly, quick diminishing light beige head. Wort, gone-off peanuts, petrol, wormwood and a huge amount of patato and stuffy sitting room in the nose where some lovely chocolate, luscious malt, smoke and salty crackers manage to sneak in. Smells a bit like a garage. A lot of patato, marzipan and wormwood in the taste. Strange. Spicy, medium bodied and malt accented. Subtle carboantion. Low bitterness. Not much lacework. Remarkably spicy on the swallow. (Reminiscence of wormwood). Patato present again in the finish which is spicy, chocolatey and rather interesting with plenty of character. Residual sugars detectable. Good balance throughout. Different. Thanks a lot kappldav123!

Bottled. Clear mahoganycolour, brief head. Mild beechwood smoke mixes with ripe strawberries. Mid-dry with light body and clean mouthfeel. A mild pleasant smokiness prevails, not rivalled by much hops nor bitterness. Not much depth, but the smoke flavour is really pleasant.
Bottle from Kappldav123, thanks! Brown color. Smoked cheese, sausage and beechwood in the aroma. Malty smoked sausage flavor with hints of mango and pear. Lovely!

Bottle 33cl. Clear light to medium brown color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, sugar, smoke - bacon smoke. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20090621]

Bottled@Fonefan. Amber colour, small beige head. Aroma is smoked wood, some quite baconlike notes as well. Flavour is tar and smoke along with some caramel as well. A bit to the sweeter side of the smoked Germans.

Tap at Becher-Eck in Kreuzberg. Dark brown-black body with a rocky tan-brown head. Taste has the faintest hint of ash, but this is dominated by the utterly tyrannical hammy tones of overripe fruit -- marmalade mixed with the kind of notes you only get from hot fermentation. So yes, very fruity, and very unusual for a Schwarzbier. Candyish. Watery body.
Berlin beer fest. Solid mahogany with a thin head. Aroma is a little bland. Flavour is sweet, very sweet. Texture is flat and sugary.

Draft at Ambrosius. Lovely very dark beer. But it is way too sweet. Loads of amlt and chocolate, leaving a sugary finish. Need to work more on this, seems their focus is very much on keeping the prices down.
Draft @ brewpub. Nice black with stable head. Sweet licorice candy aroma. Thin and sweet and a bit soft. Way too sweet for me but clean. Soooo sweet!

Draught @ Ambrosius Bier Club, Warschauer Straße 26, 10243 Berlin, Germany. Clear dark red brown color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white to light beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, dusty, brown sugar, notes of sour berry. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090918]

Draught. High creamz and lasting off-white head. Very dark red brown almost black bodz. Mild coffee aroma and roasted malt with a touch of caramel. Very sweet brown sugar caramel coffee flavor with low carbonation and a long sweet aftertaste.
Draught at Ambrosius Beer Club. Clear dark brown - offwhite head. Licorice, roasted, brown sugar, sweetness, malt candy, nutty, chocolate, syrup. A bit too sweet.

Draft. A deep red beer with a tan head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet malty - the sweetness seems a bit artificial, making the body thin. The finish is dry with a light bitterness.

On tap. Also called both "Schwarzbier" and "Dunkel". Clear brown with an orange glow and an off-white head. Sweetish aroma of roasted malt. Medium body, fairly sweet roasted malt and a whiff of pumpernickel. Subdued bitterness. 070109

On tap. Small white head and clear yellow like a lager. Some malts and fruity hops in the aroma - reminds me of pineapple yogurt. Quite full taste and palate, malts, hops, distant fruity hops, nice mild finish. Decent beer.
Draft. A golden beer with a lazing white head. The aroma is sweet malty with light notes of straw. The flavor is very sweet, leading to a dry, but crisp finish, with a very low bitterness.
On tap. A clear, yellow beer with a small, white head. Clean, malty nose. Medium body, clean malts and slightly perfumy hops with a surprisingly distinct bitterness for an Export. 070109

From tap at the Ambrosius Bier Club. Pours hazy orange with a creamy white head. Mild caramel malty aroma with a light bitterhops flavour. Flavour is mild vegetable acidic and with a light bitterness showing through. Slight infected acidic finish yet still bitter and mild fruity. Not good.
Draught. Golden colour, big stable white head. The flavour is a bit sweet for an export, but nicely flavourful. Fruity and bready.

Tap at Becher-Eck in Kreuzberg. Pale clear yellow pour with a bright white head. Nose of gentle, citric hops, there in the mouth with some bread, oh man just super soft mouthfeel, light body and soft water accentuate the hops and the clean malt. And is it ever dry. On this evening, a juicy, near-perfect pils.
On tap at Ambrosius. Pale lager, malt, and grain, quite sweet. Subtle bitterness, but not enough to balance. Ends up too sweet and not at all elegant. Cheap, though.
Light golden with a thick head. Soft malt, doughy bread. Soft, malty, doughy...and boring.
Draft @ Ambrosius. Glassy gold with scant lace. Aroma is sweet and somewhat funky. Sticky palate is thin. Sweet and doughy.
Draught at Berlin beer fest. Golden colour with a small white head. Sweet aroma. Soapy taste, low carbonation. Gentle bitter aftertaste

Draught @ Ambrosius Bier Club, Warschauer Straße 26, 10243 Berlin, Germany. Clear medium to dark yellow color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, straw, toasted, moderate hoppy, grass, citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090918]
Draught. Low but lasting creamz white head. Clear golden bodz. Mild barley malt aroma, fruity and sweet. Fruity and malty nicely hopped flavor. High carbonation. Long aftertaste.

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Not bad but not great, i found the flavours slightly muddled and was heartily dissapointed with it considering what i’d heard

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Tasted 09/06 Inch bar Dunedin. Good rich amber in the pint. Full & weighty. Big up front hit of citrus and vanilla biscuit malts softens in the mid a bit but gives a good strong finish. Delightful

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Yum yum yum. Without knowing what this was when I tasted it, I thought it was a strong or double IPA. Almost American in hoppy goodness. But this is English to the max, made robust by generous hop use and oak maturation (?) - just superb. Looks dark for a pale (rich amber). Tasted amazing with a lush apricot summerfruit gust as you swallow with hints of gingerbeer and late honey. Dry firm and well-balanced bitterness which is pretty smooth overall. Find it now! LOCATIONS: Tonic (on Princess St) and The Inch Bar (near the gardens). Do not delay - this’ll last a week!

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Tasted 07/09/2006. Flagon in the scorers room at the end of an enjoyable BrewNZ. Notes written from memory, a few hours later. Deep amber. Big bossy caramel and toffee malt notes jostle on the nose, with a flourish of vanilla and orangey hops. Sweet chewy malts are well-balanced by an aggresive yet smooth hop flavour and a long bitterness, which leads into a very pleasant, and drawn out, woody finish. Superb. I want to try more of this. I’d even be happy to see the end of the regular 1812, if this one replaced it.

column4: Emerson's Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Tasted twice, once via beer engine with a sparkler from a keg , then the next day from a keg co2 serve. Big vanilla notes jostle for space with citrissy hop aromas. Assertive fruity hops start the palate with a hint of dry malt , fading to a huge oaky vanilla finish. Oaky Vanila seemed diminished when served by beer engine, but hop aromas seemed extentuated. outstanding beer.
nice, enjoyed this beer. very good for the style blah blab blah heres your character count

From notes. Clear ruby. Off white carbonation. Great malt elements- toast, burnt caramel/toffee, cookie. Flavor adds some hop notes towards the finish- earthy, lightly bitter, lightly floral. Nice combo of sweet and toasty with enough bitterness and dryness to balance. Medium body is just a bit smoother than balanced. Excellent marzen.

Draught at Beers in the Plaza as "Oh! Fest!". Amber with a big head. The aroma is pure toasty malt with a pleasing sweet-nutty quality. The flavor is rich toasty malt with a light hint of grainy sweetness before a dry finish with just a touch of hops. Not a style that I go crazy for, but this is a very nice example.

Beautiful dark amber pour with a hint of deeper red tones with a cream colored head. The nose was sweet from caramel malt and some apparent dark fruit, as was the flavor, with a touch of biscuit, earthiness and a medium full mouthfeel.
Out of the tank in the back? Thanks Craig. Reddish amber, roasted malts, hoppy, bready, little caramel, dry finish.

Bottle from Aspidites. Drank out of a snifter. I don’t know, maybe that was a bad move, but this stuff is not enjoyable to me at all. I’m surprised the ratings are all so high. Aroma is very vegetal, almost watermelony, and the flavor is a dank, dangerous muddy, fishy flavor that I dread going near every sip. I love a good Oktoberfest, but this just isn’t doing it for me.

This Marzen poured a deep yellow gold color from a fresh growler. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is caramel and malty, Medium bodied Marzen. The malts are caramel and fruity, semisweet. The hops are earth and floral, there is also a nice rye bread like spiciness here that is quite nice. Nice carbonation. Good balance. A very drinkable Marzen. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

On tap at the Schooner’s Brewery/Restaurant in Antioch. The beer poured clear copper – caramel color with light tan foam ring. There’s a mild aroma of spice, faint dark fruitiness and caramel malts. The fruitiness noted in the nose jumps out in the flavor with dates and prunes that meet up with a mild spice and beat sugar flavor mixture. There is also a diluted caramel sweetness running through along the background.

Courtesy boboski. Pours a nice glowing red-copper color with a broken off-white head. Aroma is a meld of sweet malt, spice, cut apples, and light hints of brown sugar. Easy palate - medium-bodied, lightly carbonated. Taste is mildly dry throughout and contrasted by varying tones of spice and hops and a hint of sweetness that provides nuance and balance. An interesting, well done brew.

The pour creates a thin, light beige head that sips atop a crystal clear body of a most stunning color array: exquisite deep mahogany, ruby and deep fiery orange/brown. Beautiful, sedated. the aroma is loaded with bready German malts, just piling out of the glass. Dark malts extrapolate deep-seeded dark fruit notes from one of the most complex expressions of the style I’ve encountered. Mild hops disperse across the waves of grain. The nose is neither too sweet nor too raspy, just enticing and fresh, full of life and ambition. Alcohol is nonexistent, so are any flaws. The flavor is pleasant, mildly to moderately bitter, a perfectly integrated spice topping to dress a malt base of intricate detail. Malt is laden with toast, caramel and Viennese tradition. Sweetness is medium and delectable. The finish is malt-centric, hops fluttering about in a sweet descension to nothing but raw caramel long after the finale. The mouthfeel is very lowly and softly carbonated, a variety of which would lend to excessive and joyful Autumnal quaffing. The palate is soft even though its weightiness is substantial. Just incredible, a feat that will be hard to topple in this category. Certainly, this doesn’t adhere to any traditional stylistic guidelines, and that’s okay. This beer accellerates at pushing the envelope. When it’s all said and done, it’s still closer to a Märzen than any other style. Awesome. I would absolutely love to have access to this on a regular basis, in Autumn or otherwise.

Aroma is bread, spices and an undercurrent of hops, while the appearance gold-orange and cloudier than most IPAs. The flavor is citrus, tea, bread and a dryish finish. I’ll give them credit for trying something different, it just didn’t work though.

aroma is decent breadiness hidden beneath a pile of crushed asprin. appearance is murky gold with zilch head and moderate lacing. flavor is strong ginger like flavor with more fresh bread and a dose of something more rotten, hops are unable to shine through this mess. what a strange beer.

very hazy orange pour with a thick white head. Aroma is light sweet biscuity malt with an herbal hop and green tea presence. Tea flavours feature prominently and covers up a lot of the malt sweetness at first, though some breadlike sweetness is in there somewhere. Also a light herbal hoppiness and a kind of chalky mouthfeel to the finish.

Murky orange pour with white ring of head around the glass. Herbal, sweet aroma. Flavor isn’t as sweet: has a malty biscuity taste with light medicinal bitterness and odd herbal note. Odd yeast characteristics. KInd of flat. No real hops. This beer was like drinking some random concoction some strange relative made you to make you feel better when you’re sick.
12oz bottle. Pours a murky peach color with no head, ugly. Aroma is oddly sweet, some biscuits and crackers. Flavor is salty... blech... spat it out.

Bottle thanks to 17thfloor. Orange and cloudy with creamy off white head. Aroma is sweeter grain and biscuit malt with that same sand creek house smell. Flavor is light hops and medicinal with some chalk. Light and chalky body. Bleh.

Hazy, orange, yellow-tan color with moderate off-white head. Aroma is earthy; grass, hopps, and some sweetness. Taste is flat and somewhat bitter; hopps, malt and some citurs, possibly some ’green tea’ flavor.

12oz bottle. Opaque orange-tan color, foamy off white head. The aroma is strong and certainly unique, some earthy floral hops doused in a herbal green tea. Medium body, with some earthy, flowery hop character and an odd lemon-lime tea taste on top of the toasty malt. Some English IPA qualities, but pretty much a unique concoction. Doesn’t exactly work out so well, but the bottle hardly wreaks of freshness either. OK at best.
Dead aromas, faint leafy herbal nose. Tannic bitterness that doesn’t have much malt to balance it. Bleh.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Bockyhorsey - Pours a cloudy dirty blonde color with no head. Faint lacing. Aroma is toasted malt and esters. Flavor is quite odd. It does kinda taste like tea. Weird. It’s not very bitter. Not getting much of the three C’s hops. A different beer for sure. Thanks Bill.

column4: Löwenbrauerei Hall Fr. Erhard Schwäbisch Hall
column5: Piwo z³ociste, lekko zamglone, skromna bia³a piana. W aromacie g³ównie goŸdziki i lekkie jab³ko- no i to by by³o na tyle. W smaku goŸdzikowe, jab³kowe, lekka brzoskwinka, banan gdzieœ w tle, lekki gwóŸdŸ. Trochê lichy weizenik. Nic ciekawego.

column4: Löwenbrauerei Hall Fr. Erhard Schwäbisch Hall
column5: Angenehm hefig mit schönen Fruchtnoten. Etwas im Zitrus, prickelnd, süffig. Gute Balance, würziger Abgang. Nicht schlecht.

column4: Löwenbrauerei Hall Fr. Erhard Schwäbisch Hall
column5: bottle from local Norma. Cloudy golden yellow with a creamy tall white head. Yeasty fruity nose. Smooth and velvety from the start, yeasty and wheaty flavours with a pleasant but not overpowering fruity character, shy banana and bubblegum. Very well balanced, smooth and velvety, highly drinkable. An extremely pleasant example of the style.

column4: Löwenbrauerei Hall Fr. Erhard Schwäbisch Hall
column5: 50cl bottle. A hazy golden beer with a small off-white head. Aroma of phenols, mid sweet banana, yeast. Taste of mid sweet bananan, yeast, phenols, some clove. Easy to drink!

column4: Löwenbrauerei Hall Fr. Erhard Schwäbisch Hall
column5: 19-07-2017 // draft at Biergarten Unterwöhrd, Schwäbisch Hall. CLoudy orange Hefeweizen, yeasty nose. Taste is mild banana, yeasty, some light citrus notes. Medium carbonation.

column4: Löwenbrauerei Hall Fr. Erhard Schwäbisch Hall
column5: Trübes helles gelb, Geruch fruchtig citrus etwas hoffe, im Geschmack schön frisch, Hefe, citrus etwas Getreide leicht säuerlicher Abgang, lecker

column4: Löwenbrauerei Hall Fr. Erhard Schwäbisch Hall
column5: From the draft.. Apperance: A Unclear hazy medium yellow colour with a average, white frothy head, which leaves some good lacing.Aroma is light malty, wheat, moderate yeasty, orange - citrus, peach, clove. TAste: is slightly below moderate sweet , light sour wheat tones, a bit of citrus, light malts, wheat, yeast , clove. Mediium body, soft carbonation, texture is watery, A not super thick heavy weizen, with some good sour wheat. easy drinker.

column4: Löwenbrauerei Hall Fr. Erhard Schwäbisch Hall
column5: Vom Fass. Hellgelbes trübes Weizenbier mit schönem festem Schaum. Fruchtiger Hefeduft. Etwas Apfel und Banane. Fruchtig auch im Antrunk. Dann Getreide. Sehr rund.

column4: Löwenbrauerei Hall Fr. Erhard Schwäbisch Hall
column5: Hefetrübes goldgelb mit reichlich weißem Schaum. Hefig-fruchtig. etwas Banane, eine dezente Säure im Abgang, sehr spritzig.

column4: Löwenbrauerei Hall Fr. Erhard Schwäbisch Hall
column5: 0.5l righf from Bavaria. Not a pro to this type of beer. Feels great on tongue, creamy.
19/10/06 @ Rosies - Hastings. Darkish, black/red. Toasty, toffee almost coffee. Nice drop.

Tasted 14/09/2006. Rigger from BrewNZ. Deep garnet, bright, with a disappearing off-white airy head. All crystal and roasted malts on the nose. Nutty malts up front, and through the middle, followed by a pushy roasted finish and a very gentle hop smack. Mild fruitiness and toast on the palate. Maybe a little soapy through the middle-end and slightly hot in the finish but otherwise very drinakable. Lingering roastiness. Good pub beer, quite sessional.

Bottle. Ended up being quite interesting, i was expecting something really boring, but tis had some nice refreshing sourness to it. Nice citrus, earthy bitterness to finish. Pleasant if not mindblowing.
LCRBM2. Hazy gold with thin beige head. Nice hop aroma, some odd lemon. Light flavours. Nice hoppy finish. Very much in the style of this kind of blond beer.
[2nd Low Countries RateBeer Meeting] Aroma is citric, hoppy with some diacetyl. Hazy, yellow coloured with a white head.Taste is sweet, just a bit sour, citric and hoppy. Quite fresh.
LCRBM2: Dusty, citric, slightly hoppy aroma. Hoppy flavor with a lot of citrus. Very good!

Light amber to yellow coloured beer with a small white head and very little carbonation. Sweet fruity aroma, some roasted malts. Finish has a very slight alcoholic roasted touch, a little sour. Rather good one.

500ml bottle from Dan Murphy's 7.4%abv BB 08.2020 Been many a year since I've tried a (commercial) Perry! Clear pale gold body. Good aroma - quite vinous, really ripe yellow pear, stewed fruit, touch of butter and kerosene funk. Low carbonation, full body, semi sweet, touch of acidity, has that lovely oily texture that a good Perry should. Packed full of sticky juicy ripe pear flesh and yellow skin, buttery, vinous like a Pinot Gris, reasonably sweet, slightly herbal. Really nice, so much more character than a boring old Apple cider.

0,5L bottle, vintage 2011. Pours golden with white head. The head stays for a brief moment. Aroma is sour, oak, pears, apples. Flavor is very sweet and sour, apples, pears, wood. Overall: too sweet, but not awful (this may be an alias of 74019, tastes similar).
50cl bottle. 2011 vintage opened on 27.11.14. Aroma of a decent perry. Slightly acidic. Somewhat resembles barrel aged ciders. Sweet, and fruity. Medium bodied. Easy going. The warmer the better.

500ml bottle from Tesco, Shrewsbury. Pours very pale yellow, with a custardy vanilla aroma. Taste is sweet perry pears, icing and a deliciously fruity tang. Nice but perhaps verging too far on the sweet side for me.

Bottle shared with McTapps. Fine Cider with a gently strong abv background which you will not really recogniye. Ripe perries but even more riper apples with a sweetish aftertaste. Enjoyed that one really.

Bottle bought at Morrisons in Newport / IOW. Pours out in a clear vanilla-golden colour with smooth body. Aroma of ripe pears and juice. Taste of ripe pears, ripe apples, leaves, caramel and honey.. Easy and smooth to drink, enjoyed it.
Bottle from morrisons. 2013 vintage. Very pale yellow with carbonation. Aroma of pears. Taste is pears, apple peel and some sweet sugar. Decent.

Bottle. Pours a rather clear yellow with not much of a head. Aroma is apple, a bit of pear, some vinegar. Taste is rather sweet, but also somewhat sour. Apple is strong as is pear and vinegar. Good sipper.

Bottled (2011 vintage, from Alko Prisma, Vaasa). Pale yellowish golden colour with not too much head. Aroma is pear, a bit white wine like, some slight vinegar, mild fruit sugars as well as some vanilla. Flavour is sweet fruit sugar, some pear, and mild vanilla. Actually quite nice, and hides the 7.4 % the bottle states very well. Good refreshing cider, which lies somewhere between "mainstream" and handcrafted stuff.
20713. Bottle at home. Pours clear light golden with a nice head. Aroma perry. Sweet body. As always too sweet for my taste.

cask@Pratts and Payne, Streatham, London - Golden pour with a puffy large white head. Citrus hoppy taste and aroma, orange,lemon, with floral notes, pine and grassyness to it. Good bitter finish. Very refreshing summer golden ale. Lovely.

Cask at the George on the Strand, 06/08/13. Clear light golden wth a thin white head. Nose is light hops, bitter orange, soft bread dough, light toasted malts. Taste comprises orange pith, tangy citrus, subtle hop presence, straw. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, dry finish with light hop bitterness. Ok GB affair.

Cask conditioned handpump Harp London 12/08/12. A golden beer with an off-white head. A fusty aroma with light but tired hops. Hops are better in the mouth with some grassy bitterness. Quite ordinary. Not sure what happened to the citra or amarillo.
Good floral aroma. Strong, hoppy ale with with a dry bitter finish. Enjoyable summer beer.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 10, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear medium orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, light to moderate hoppy, citrus, lime, orange - citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, fresh, peel bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100803]

(Cask at Harp, Covent Garden, London, 7 Aug 2010) Golden colour with frothy, off-white head. Fruity, hoppy nose with citrus, grass and floral hops. Fruity, hoppy taste with notes of citrus, apricots and grassy, floral hops in a refreshing finish with a generous bitterness. Rather light body, with a touch of sweetness. Tasty and refreshing. Quite nice.
Cask Handpump at the GBBF, Earl’s Court 03/08/2010 Hoppy aroma. Golden coloured hoppy and fruity with a lime flavour. A hint of dryness in a bitter and slightly peppery malt finish.
Cask@GBBF2010. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is fruits, nectar, wood and some mild spices. Flavour is citrusfruits, some nectar, tropical fruits and mild grassy and wooden notes as well.

Cask (gravity dispense) at Ealing Beer Festival, July 2009. A decent, grassy golden ale. Plenty of herbaceous hop character. Clean and fresh with a fairly firm mouthfeel. More hop presence in the aroma than on the palate. Straightforward but pleasant.
Cask at Ealing beer fest 2009. Golden pour with small head. Slight hoppy aroma. Citrus, hoppy taste. An OK beer but Twickenham ales don’t really do it for me.
an an all round exellent session beer enjoyed at the home of the brewary the white hart ufford (a must visit)

Cask at The Tobie Norris, Stamford, Lincolnshire. Gold with a small white head. Floral hop aroma with a summery meadow taste with grassiness and nettles. A hint of coriander. Mid bitter finish. Very good.

Cask, handpump at The Table Norris, Stamford with Nigel (Hopshackle) Loz and the Rev 28-01-10 Pours clear gold white head, good clarity. Some light floral touches on the nose, pleasant crisp golden beer touch dry at end, but nice easy going sweetness throughout, enjoyable. A6 A4 F7 P3 Ov13 3.3

A Mes rate. Rated at my desk during office hours, but it was the morning before our Christmas trip. Big thanks to David for bringing this is in as a take out from his local. Clean gold with a thin white head and plenty of condition for a take out. Plenty of hops giving up some good citric fruity character with some excellent dry earthy malt underneath. Pleasing hints of straw and hay too. Faint lick of peat and spice in the finish. Easy drinking and very enjoyable.

Gravity cask at the Pembury Tavern, Hackney, London during their festival on 18th November 2009. Pale gold with quickly disappearing white head of foam. Deliciously fruity/floral hop aroma and a grassy hop kick with some smoke notes and a very slight savoury touch. Dry hoppy finish on a slightly zingy mouthfeel. Very flavoursome, enjoyabe pint.
Cask at the peterborough beer fest 2009. Alround rating: Pale honey light caramel malt, floral and grassy hop. The generic 3.

Cask-conditioned at the Great Western Hotel, Exeter 25/07/09. Pale gold with a fluffy, white head. Aroma of lemon, pineapple, a touch of green herbs and sulphur. Easy drinking, with grapefruit hops, a hint of pine and a decent dry finish. Excellent.

Cask, The Tobie Norris, Spamford. Lacy straw pint collared with froth. Burton kolsh, farmyard manure sweetness, lemon and lime jelly soft tangy nose. Immaculate snatchy sessions mingling hum, citrus and sweetness with balance. Zing but no harshness; sweet oaty malt creaminess, maybe US hops, maybe not. I like that ambiguity sometimes. Soft, lemony, sulphurous and delicate. GOATY. This one well and truly hit the spot.

Cask (handpump) @ Great British Beer Festival, GBBF 2008, Earls Court, London, England SW5. Clear light to medium yellow orange golden color with a average, frothy - fizzy, good - fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, light to moderate hoppy, citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. (080808)
Cask at GBBF08. Good fruity aroma. Hazy yellow colour. Stable frothy white head. Watery flavour hint of fruit. Weak grassy hops, medium bitterness.
Helles goldgelb schwacher schaum, malzig getreidig im Geruch, laff getreidig im Geschmack, nichts besonderes...
0,5l Flasche. Hellgelbes Bier, weisser Schaum. Grasiger Duft. Sanft Honig. Antrunk Getreide. Wenig herb. Langweilig.
0,5 l Flasche. Erfrischender, maischiger Geschmack, fast wie ein alkoholfreies Bier.
This was the only beer I drank while stationed in Germany and drinking on the economy. The flavor was great and it was a very smooth beer.
17-12-16 // from the bottle. Golden beer. Well carbonated. Solid pils, with some herbal bittter notes.
500ml Flasche. Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Pils mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig, grasig. Geschmack herb, grasig, minimal würzig.

Geruch ist eigentlich nicht viel vorhanden. Im Glas ist es schön hell-bernsteinfarben und sieht sehr ansprechend aus! Der Antrunk ist süffig und sogar ein Bißchen süßlich. Im Hauptteil kommt das Hopfenaroma mit deutlicher, aber angenehmer Herbe voll zur Geltung. Der Nachgeschmack wird etwas herber und hat auch etwas von "Kaffe oder Cappuccino". Es wird leicht süßlich und die Herbe kristallisiert sich deutlicher heraus. Auf der Zunge verbleibt ein langer, eher sehr langer Herber Nachgeschmack, der mir aber sehr angenehm erscheint und nicht negativ auffällt. --> Insgesamt ein gutes Pils, sehr charakterstark und eigen! (Test vom 24.4.2008) --> 12,10,11,10,12,11 - 10,85
Clear golden colour with medium head. Aroma is malt, grassy hops. Flavous malt with hoppy finish.

330ml bottle. Clear golden colour with average frothy white head. Slightly dull muggy grainy aroma with a fading dry grassy hop note. Bitter hop in the foreground, then grain, grassy background. Interesting taste dimensions, somewhat turned about 90°. Fresh citrus kick right before the finish, dry hoppy fadeout.
Bottled 50cl. Clear pale golden, decent lacing white head. Some boiled vegetables in the nose. Good bitterness. Grainy. Dry finish. Reminiscent of a northern german example of the style.
15-09-18 // straight from the bottle. Classic pilsner with a light sweet grainy body and a herbal hop bitterness.
Helles goldgelb, schaum ok, im Geruch würzig malzig leicht muffig etwas Hopfen, mild würzig leichte süße etwas getreidig etwas Hopfen mild herb

The Porter from The Tap is a fairly impressive offering, as it provides a very drinkable beer in a typically heavier category. It pours a dark, murky, dark chocolate color with a medium brown, fizzy head. Excellent lacing. Aroma is of sweet malts with a distinct presence of milk chocolate. Very aromatic. This, however, is where the switcharoo occurs. Initial taste is moderately bitter, with a dark chocolate, bitter taste, ramping up to a heavy bitter finish with sour notes and a long duration. Lightly carbonated, it is medium bodied, but light for the style. It is creamy, but creamy in the way that skim milk is creamy. Moreso than water, but clearly not whole milk, which make this a very drinkable porter. Reviewed on January 9th, 2007
on tap-pours a thick creamy brown head and black color. Aroma is coffee-dark malt. Taste is coffee-dark malt, then hops bitterness, acidic.

Typical porter brown black with a slight head. Aroma of coffee, and uh-oh, broccoli hops. Yeast and green hop flavor. Yuck! The hops probably really aren’t all that pronounced here, but unfortunately this happens to be a varietal that I apparently despise. Run across this flavor before, not my bag at all. Thanks to Maniac for the opportunity to sample at the 4th Richmond Gathering, growler. This beer isn’t nearly as bad as my rating indicates, it unfortunately hit a flavor profile I can’t stand.

Thanks to Maniac for his unfailing searching for more ratings for me! This aroma definitely had a bit of an odeur of sour milk, also lots of chocolate malt and coffee. Opaque brown body, you know how we do, playa. The flavour is mostly coffee.
Growler, from The Tap. Dark black body with a small creamy brown head. Sweet roasted malt and chocolate aroma. Dark chocolate flavor with some strong bitter, and some sweet coffee flavor.

Draught pint at Redbones on 9/8/06. Very dark, nearly-opaque black/brown body has a light-tan head perched atop it. Very well-retained and lacing quite profusely. Buckets of chocolate malt are manifested in the nose, which has a good deal of roasted bitterness. Some nuts, soy, a hint of vanilla bean and molasses, it all makes for quite a complex aroma. The base malt sweetness, however, is full and thick, allowing for the roasty/ashy/acrid notes to take their aggression out on the sweet malts and not on your nose. Hop apparency is very low, maybe a touch of leafiness thrown in for good measure, but it’s difficult to discern amidst the malts, which this beer certainly focuses on. No alcohol in the nose. Medium-high to high strength of aroma. Where the nose has the benefit of clearing itself in the smoke-free air of Redbones, the palate is not so fortunate. Though it begins strongly enough, by the end of the glass, the palate is near beat-to-death by the huge tar-like roastiness that hangs on the finish. The chewy, thick, fudge-like-consistency of the malts certainly helps balance this sensation, and the carbonation is appropriate, delivering a lightly brisk wave of respite, but in the end, the bitterness just builds too heavily (for me anyways). Still, it’s wonderfully brewed and probably wouldnt bother most dark-beer lovers. The lack of hop flavor certainly goes a long way as well towards helping keep balance. Some notes of hazelnut, vanilla, chocolate graham crackers and creamy vanilla all help add complexity. Tone down the malt bitterness (near astringency) about 33% and this would be world-class stuff. Lovely texture, unfiltered and all. No alcohol apparent in flavor.
Very interesting use of a single hop. Obviously not too complex, the ale becomes a very malty body. Almost sweet.
