Hazy amber, with a thin soapy head. Aroma is lightly piney soapy hoppiness, honey, and light caramel. Taste is piney, floral with a light hoppiness and some honey.
Orange yellow,small lasting beige head.Light citrus hop nose.Nice malt start with medium strength hop bitterness in the finish. Decent body,softly carbonated. A nice brew!!

This was actually a really well built porter. Dark bitter chocolate start, slightly burnt taste to it, soft licorice note, and a bit of coffee in the finish. Lighter palate, a touch watery, but a good sessionable porter. A touch more carbonation would have brought out more coffee in the finish and might have made the palate less watery, but I’d order this again anytime.
Very solid Porter here. Lots of chocolate flavor just as advertised. Lots of burnt malt flavors but not to much acidity. Full , smooth mouthfeel.
Pretty hearty pale ale here. Lots of earthy flavors in this one. Some are from the rye and some are from the hops. A little bit different flavor for a pale ale, but I still like it.
Basically a wheat beer with a little extra grainy flavor. Still has that trademark Iron Horse velvety smooth sweetness to it. Nice.
Okay beer, but lacking many of the qualities need for a good full flavours complex Bock. Beerhouse Kiev
The head is ok, the body brown. It smells darkmalty, roasty. The taste is creamy, raisin, a bit plum, roasty, aromatic, a bit sweet. Overall ok. 11/12/11/11/-/11
Draft at the source. Hazy amber color, medium tan head. Aroma of rising brown bread dough. Taste is watery dough and caramel.

Draught at the brewpub. Nice amber/brown coloured, medium sized off-white head, caramel in the nose. Sweet malty, caramel and some lactic notes with hint of alcohol and plums in the finish. Also some strange acidity near the end (later it turned out that all of their beers have that strange acidity). Why, I really don’t know.
Reddish-brown, light toast aroma with alcohol. Sweet and with a hint of toast but the malts are entirely underdeveloped. Bland as a result of tasting underattenuated.
Draft at brewpub. Reddish brown. Sweet yeasty aroma. With dough. Manages to have some dark malt character. Although best of 4 is still lame kit beer yeasty underfermented and annoying overpriced.

Draught at Arena Beer House, Kiev, Ukraine. Pours a dark clear brown with an offwhite head. Smells slightly of honey, malt. Tastes of a heavy sweetness, and a small bitterness. Medium bodied, light carbonation, oily texture. Finishes dry with some honey.
The beer has an amber color, the head is a couple of centimeters high. Quite sweet taste with raisins and sweet candy. Not bad, but not the best bock I have tasted.

Small beige head; clear dark brown body with ongoing carbonation. Sweet bready aroma with notes of watery licorice. Taste is sweet roasty malts with notes of raisins. Watery burnt aftertaste. Licorice and burnt almonds. Faint bitterness. A decent dunkel; way too watery for a proper bock. (0.1l on tap.)

On tap at Shato Robert Doms, pours a cloudy yellow with a small white head. Aroma brings out straw and wheat. Flavour is along the same lines, with straw, nice yeastiness, and cereal graininess. Clean and drinkable. Solid.
Tap at brewpub. Hazy golden. Malty and fruity aroma, apples, green apples. Sweet, young and spicy brewpubish taste. Spicy finish. Brewpubish ok.
Draft. Pale straw color. Aroma: yeast, spicy hops, malt, slightly sweet syrup. Taste: mild sweetness, malty, grain, soft, need more hops.
Draught. Yet another wit like brew that tasted pretty bland on the verge of terrible.
The head is ok, the body like a Wit. It smells yeasty, malty. Taste is yeasty, a bit fruity, mild, sweet-citrus. Ok mild but drinkable. 10/10/9/9/-/9
Draught at the brewpub. Cloudy yellow coloured, small creamy white head, yeasty nose. Malty, quite yeasty and grainy with notes of barnyard. Slight lemony finish. Not bad.
Cloudy and quite pale. The aroma is a little bit phenolic. The taste is boring and fairly yeasty. Pretty dull.
Draft at brewpub. Milky canary yellow with lasting head. Bland pale malt aroma. The palate is yeasty but not too sweet. Just a boring beer with a nutty cereal grain character.

Draught at Shato, Kiev. pours a cloudy yellow with a white head. Smells a bit of citrus, some grass. Tastes of a medium sweetness, mild bitter, and some grassy citrus. Light bodied, medium-heavy soft carbonation, oily texture. Not bad, but finishes somewhat wanting.

Draft @ Shato brew put. Hazy yellow coloured beer wiht some medium white head and a huge amount of carbonation. Rather fruity light hinted aroma. medium to full palate. Finish is again sweet fruity with some short hoppy hintes and maybe a touch of almonds. Overall maby to sweet but actually rather refresshing and easy drinkable.

On tap at Shato Robert Doms, pours a cloudy golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma brings out cereal grains and straw. Flavour is along the same lines, with cereal grains, straw and a pleasant yeastiness. Clean and easy drinking. Solid.
Tap at the brewpub. Cloudy golden. Sweetish aroma, done nail Polish. Young and spicy brewpubish taste. Spicy abrasive finish. Brewpubish ok.
Dratf. Hazy golden. Aroma: malt, yeast, sweet syrup. Taste: fruit and malt, bubbly, slightly sweet like soda.

Draught at the brewpub, Kiev. Cloudy pale yellow with large foamy off-white head, high carbonation, bread like aroma, slightly salty orange peel taste, medium bitter finish. A bit strange, with the salty taste.
Aroma is a little like raisins-wine. From the start has a soft and light taste. Looks slightly brown and is in the aftertaste sweet, almost a hint of banana at the end. Watery average!-
Draught. This beer tasted just like the other two unfiltered brews. nothing special here. Kind of bland and malty.
The head is ok, the body blond and cloudy. It smells mild, yeasty, boring. The taste is yeasty, malty, a bit creamy, banana. Boring. 11/8/8/7/-/8
Draft at the source. Hazy amber color, scant white edge head. Aroma of raw bread dough and straw. Taste is slightly funky straw.

Draught at the brewpub. Cloudy golden coloured, medium sized airy white head that went away slowly, rather dusty sweet nose. Sweet malty, light fruity and spicy with notes of yeast and caramel. Not so watery but a bit too strong fruity sweetness here.
Very pale and hazy, just like the silver. The aroma is doughy and yeasty. The taste is doughy and there is a touch of tartness in there as well. Not horrible, but not exactly a world-beater.
Draft. Straw-yellow, slightly blurred. Aroma: malt, a little yeast, freshness, apple and spicy hops. Taste: apple juice or cider, a good malt body, fruity.
Draught at the brewpub, Kiev. Inky dark brown with small frothy tan head, faint caramel aroma, high carbonation, bitter roasted malt taste, thin body, long burnt finish. Nice local brew.
DWF; On site, draft. Grassy, known drill. Revelution beer. Go, go Ukraina!! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draught. This was very similar to the Zolte. I liked it a little more but not much. Seems odd ot offer two nearly identical beers.

Small white head over hazy yellow body with ongoing carbonation. Faintly grassy rubbery aroma. Taste is grassy hops, primarily, followed by a mealy, papery, rubbery aftertaste. Some spice as well. Some bitterness, though not that much. More hops than the zolote, which again helps. (0.3l on tap.)

Imperial pint poured on tap at the brewpub (Lombard, Il). Pours a yellow straw murky pour, typical glowing wheat, light head that clings a little. Aromas are very light, typical wheat cereal qualities and very light orange rind in the nose. Subtle flavord in the initial, cereal wheat without the wheaty bitterness, light orange peel and ester, not much coriander. Nice and sessionable, but a little underdone. Decent.

Hefty clouds within and slight whites above hang in lacing sheets over a lemon-yellow body. Lagered lemon nose with banana annotation. Thick and wheaty with a strong alcohol detraction. Banana flavor dominant with a strong grapefruit finish that is too brash to compare to the Hoegaarden Wit that the bartender compared this to. On tap at Rock Bottom Yorktown, Lombard, IL 60148

Mug Club draft. More of a nice, cloudy orange than the nearly white I’ve found with other draft wits. A nice clean wheat beer smell with threads of orange zest. Problem is they served me a glass that they had in an ice cooler, so it was served too cold. I lost any complexity the beer might have had, but did enjoy it as a nice, light wheaty beer with that orange again, and perhaps some grains of paradise. As the beer warmed up toward the end, I also got a bit of lemon to it, too.

column1: Rock Bottom Cincinnati The Dominator IPA
column5: Draft from cask. Poured hazy copper color with an average rocky off-white head that was mostly lasting with fair lacing. Moderate floral and sour citrus hoppy aroma. Medium body with a slick texture. Heavy bitter flavor with a medium smooth bitter finish of long duration. I would recommend this to a freind.

750, capped and corked. Pours a slightly hazy bright orange with a scant white head. Big orange nose, hay, pencil. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Oranges, light caramel, pencil, and hay on the mid palats. Long grassy finish.

Another entry from notes. Bottle traded for and shared at Fantomefest 2014. Cloudy sunglow yellow in color with some soapy head around the edges of the glass. Nose and flavor are closely interwined. There is a lot of soft peach/stone fruit tartness that finishes with a fair amount of earthy, dank funk. Medium mouthfeel despite it’s rather delicate flavor with good carbonation and a pleasant, enduring finish. One of the shining stars of the tasting, a real treat to drink.

750ml bottle from Kamiel. Clear dark orange with an off white head. Quite tart, slightly alcoholic, lemon, grain, apricot, bit bretty and orange, tang. Mild carbonation, moderate body, tang and interesting, dry, apricot and orange. Good.
Don’t know how to describe this, it’s kind of a saison, with a sour body. Reminds me of a tardy wine as well. Weird, but very good.

Bomber. Thanks to Takahara for this. Sharp and immediate stink: sewer and sauerkraut, sour grass, with a tiny sweetness in the background. Cloudy light copper color. Big puckering initial: sour pears and fermented cabbage / sour fruit continues, and apple and apricot notes emerge, some leather, too. / finish has trickling sourness, which fades out like fog in the morning sunshine. Lovely.
8% cloudy honey gold pour, sour, barrel-aged woodsy & sour aroma. Very sour & sweet, tasty stuff.

Starts as a clear orange amber; after pouring the yeast fond it becomes darker, unclear and rather beige, inbetween amber and brown. Quite a bit of visible carbonation. The nose is mildly sour with some fruity touches, a bit vinous. The taste starts out mostly sour but in a pleasant way, almost hinting of geuze-like sourness but with more punch to it and fewer earthy notes (and with carbonation on the tongue) and a balanced dose of spices, decent bit of hop bitterness as well. It feels more alcoholic than most other Fantômes, though this might be because of the yeast having transformed any residual sugars. Once you get to the yeasty bottom, there’s less sourness and it shifts from a saison to a typical amber, still well-balanced but more present spices, now a solid dose of alcohol. An excellent apéritif, less easily drinkable and somewhat stranger in balance than your typical Fantôme saison but in return it packs more power.

Bottle shared at CBC Clerkenwell, London during the Birthday Celebration of Jack & Leighton - many thanks to Paul for supplying the Fantome; it’s just not a real party until the Fantome starts a pourin’. Pours cloudy, orange-gold with a fine, fading white head. Tangy orange citrus aroma with sugary, pale bread. Big sweet falvor with further notes of lightly tangy citrus, and mild orange peel bitterness. Full bodied with fine, spritzy carbonation. Lightly warming to finish with moderate dry citrus fruits, some dough, sugar, faint yeast. Decent. Very drinkable for the ABV.

Bottle - big thanks to Paul at Jack and Leightons birthday pleasantries, 13/04/13. Heavily hazed golden orange with wee floaters to keep me company. Nose is tarte fruits, sour tones, lemon rind, light sugar, bitter orange, sour peaches, farmyard. Taste comprises a good level of funk, soured fleshy fruits, burnt notes, lemon rind, spice. Medium bodied with bite, fine carbonation, dry in the finish. Nice stuff!

Bottle. Cheers to monsieur Scopey for supplying this. This apparently had been aged a few years. The pour’s hazy amber with a small head. The aroma’s tart underripe melon, some lemon and peaches. Light farmhouse funk. The taste is tart apple cider. A bit of lactic acid. Mild warhead candy acidity. Wheaty funk. Light body. Fine carbonation. Overall, this seems to have developed some interesting flavors. Nice.

A mid golden orange coloured beer with a thick white head. The nose is slightly sweet, with a biscuity malt aroma followed by a hop smell. the taste is very dry, plenty of hops, that make it quick bitter, then a mellowing biscuity malt flavour comes through to balance. The finish is long an dry. (Cask - The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).
(cask) deep amber with nice head and nice lace. Light hops/malt aroma. Flavor is biscuit malt with some floral hops. Great cask mouthfeel.
Draft. Amber with a thin head. Light hoppy aroma with a hint of malt. Very well balanced flavor, with floral hops and bready/biscuity malt. Light sweetness and a hint of earthiness. Pretty good.

Draft, at Nodding Head on 7/24/09. Pours brownish-amber, topped with a small off-white head. Aroma is nice and a bit hop-forward, with notes of citrus nicely balanced by toffee, caramel, and fruit. Flavor exhibits nice balance as well; with good interplay between toffee, caramel, lemon and grapefruit. Citrus lingers on the palate. Very tasty, and quite easy to drink.

(10/19/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in Philadelphia. Clear amber color. Aroma of hops with some grapefruit and lemon hints. flavor has nice hoppy tones with some peach and citrus, and a malty, a bit biscuity, background, with some caramel. A bitter finish with some earthy hop notes. Medium-bodied. Pleasant.

Draft - part of sampler at brewery. Pours a orange/red/amber color with a 1+ finger white head. Aroma is floral, citrus, dough and a little caramel. Flavor is mild malts with a nice dose of floral & citrus hops. Probably my favorite of the sampler. Very drinkable. Could session this quite nicely.

Draft pint at the brewpub. Reddish amber with a slightly sticky top. Caramel aroma. Tangy and tart, this is a well balanced, predominately caramel but with a nice tart hop bite. Very nice ESB. (#3190, 11/9/2007)
Floral flowery flavor and aroma. Amber color with thinner body. Light hop finish.

Firkin at Capone’s. Served at room tempature. Cloudy orange body with thin head. Aroma has a citrusy, malty, caramel aroma. Flavor has a slight hop bitterness, a little soapy. Smooth bitterness and a full mouthfeel. Gave me light burpy hops.

Draft at Capone’s. The pour is medium copper with 1-finger off-white head. Aroma of citrus, buttery diacetyl, caramel malt, lemongrassy notes, hops. Tastes earthy caramel malty, with buttery notes, slight fruit, and slight hops. Light palate with little carbonation.

Draft at Capone’s. Poured a clear copper color with an average white head. Aroma is balanced with some caramel malt and cirusy hops. Flavor is well balanced and this ESB goes down nice and smooth. Excellent session beer.

July 9th, 2015. Cask @ The Railway Tavern, Chelmsford. Deep gold pour with a small head. Gentle white bread. Springy fruit aromas. Some white grape and honeyed melon. Pale malt body with more spring fruits. Light grass. Soft and easy-going blonde.

Cask, The Whiffler, Norwich, 01/09/15. A-haaaaa! Gold with a loose clasping foam. Vague jelly of tangerine citrus snout building with rubs of leaf, mint, ganja. Decent. Mellow wash of diluted mandarin, lychee overtaken by cashew soft malt. Pleasant but peters into vapidity.

Cask at the Pickerel, Cambridge. Mid-gold with a tiny whitish head. Light grapefruit, peach and toast notes. Taste is more bitter than sweet, bringing out the citrus elements. Too bitter in the finish but otherwise quite pleasant. Slightly better than your average golden beer.
Cask, Railway Tavern, 9th July 2015. Golden appearance with white lacing. Aroma is peaches. Light summer fruits. Nectar. Taste is lemons, honey, nectar and straw
500ml bottle from our kid. Pours clear golden orange, nae head. Aromas of barley orange sweets. Taste is pish, frankly. More sweeties than beer. Not my thing at all.
July, 2014 Jubilee, Norwich. Some caramel, some hop smudge, a kiss in the direction of citric. A muddy summer drink. OK.

Cask gravity at The Hub at Whittlesey, Saturday 10th January 2015 on Whittlesey Straw Bear weekend (we stopped at Peterborough Central Travelodge) Fairly run of the mill golden. This lacks bitterness and not so hoppy. I guess that I should have known with Woodfordes not to have high hopes. Pretty boring. A5 A4 T6 P2 Ov11 2.8
spruce, dough aromas from a pale gold body and a thin white head, quite smooth and bitter hops in the mouth refreshing aftertaste (ive just had a kebab so it was mightily needed) not bad but bland.

Couple of pints or so from a Polly Pin at a party on 7th June 2014, some 6 miles from the brewery. Light golden with a wisp and collar. Pleasant enough blend, with the malts just about winning in both the aroma and taste stakes. Mildly bitter finish, ideal session garden ale on a warm Norfolk day.

Cask handpull at the Woolpack, Debenham (before seeing excellent The Floe in concernt). Light amber colour, with a very small, soon dissipating, white head. Citrus honey aroma. Medium body, with soft carbonation.
Cask at The Harp London WC2 30 Apr 06. Golden brown coloured. A cautious beer with a subte fruity aroma and flavour. Well balanced. A bit dull.
Cask Handpump at the Wardwick, Derby 29/09/2006 Very fruity aroma. Amber coloured and very fruity with a slightly sour taste. Crisp full malt finish.

Cask conditioned at a Wetherspoons. Golden beer with white head. The pumpclip was definitely Holts, but then rambled on about Black Country Beer. It appears that Highgate are brewing the Holts, Plant & Deakin Entire to me however this was a dull copy with a mish mash of flavour. There is a grainy malt, thin with a yeasy, bready note, some boiled hop, largely boring.

On tap@ Internationales Berliner Bierfestival. Dark copper body with a minimal vanishing beige head. Aroma is cherries, toffee, mineral. Taste is malty sweet,mineral. Fruity and malty finish. Low body soft carbonation oily texture.
A reasonable Schwarzbier, probably even bordering a Porter given its predominantly sweet and malty flavors.

Leicht süßer, erstaunlich geringer Malzantrunk. Ebenfalls geringfügig herb, süffig, zunehmend getreidig, wenn auch eher im Hintergrund. Süffig, eher langweilig da glatt und ohne Aromenspitzen. 7/8/7/7/8/7

Aroma: faint; a bit of malts and a whiff of herbs. Appearance: black; opaque; head medium, fairly stable. Taste: sweet, a little sour. Palate: body below medium; carbonation very soft; finish sweet and slightly sour. Overall: meh.

* Old Rating. 0,5l crown-top-bottle, best before 09.05 . Malzig-röstmalziger Antrunk. Etwas zu süßlich, aber dadurch sehr süffig. Anklänge an Karamell und Kaffee, dabei recht süßlich. Der Nachgeschmack ist würzig-süßlich, malzig-röstmalzig und nicht zu schlecht.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein schwarzes Bier mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, erdig, leicht würzig. Geschmack röstmalzig, leichte Kaffe Aromen, erdig, trocken malzig, leicht süß.

500ml bottle. Clear, reddish dark brown colour with average, frothy, half-way lasting, ochre head. Minimally roasty dark malty aroma, hints of roasted grain, a touch of treacle, minimally grassy hoppy overtones. Taste is dry dark malty, slightly roasty, subtle sweetness, cautious hints of treacle, bitter hoppy overtones. More than just OK.

Im Grunde nichts anderes als ein schwarzes Export. Etwas dünn mit ein paar zuckrigen Noten und ein klein wenig Getreide im Hintergrund. Trinkbar, in Geselligkeit wahrscheinlich süffig und durchaus ok.

Pours out of the bottle in a deep black colour with low head and medium to thin body. Arpma of malt and grains. Taste of mild roasted malt, dark bread, leaves, light nuts and torf. Hints of caramel. Watery and thin finish. Easy to drink but tastewise just average and boring.

Bottle: Clear, ruby-amber coloured, bigger and very slowly collapsing loose white head, mild to moderate dry toasty-caramelly nose, some fruitiness detectable; light bodied and soft; a malty bitterness is added in the slightly lingering and moderately dry toasty-caramelly finish. Nice Schwartzbeer…
At Internationales Berliner Bierfestival 2016. Yellowish with a white head. Soft and easy to drink with hay, malt and some grain. Also hints of fruit.
Draught at the 16th BBF. Pale yellow even lighter than lemonade, short white head. Lemony wheaty nose repeated n the mouth with a bit of sour grain. Dense medium body. OK.

Had this at the Bergrestaurant Schwedenstein in Steina. In the winter that’s the only place where this beer is available. Looks good in the glass, modest turbid, creamy head. Starts mild, a bit fruity like lemon and apricot. Becomes more and more yeasty without being too dry. Well balanced finish, quite drinkable. Not bad!
on tap at berlinerbierfest06. hazy golden. full aroma of pancake mix and passionfruit. grassy and floral and fresh with a prickly finish, a good example of the style
Draught. Fruity aroma. Malty flavour with medium bitterness. Nicely hop aromatic and with a good, naturtrübiness in both flavour and mouthfeel.

column1: Will-Bräu Original Bayerisch Hefe Weizen Alkoholfrei
column5: Thanks Caesar for sharing this with me. I deeply respect you for drinking half of your glass cause this is truly undrinkable: sweet, very sweet, wort, made me shiver. Undrinkable. Yuk. 4-2-4-2-4

column1: Will-Bräu Original Bayerisch Hefe Weizen Alkoholfrei
column5: Weiss alemana sin alcohol. Ambar claro sin filtrar. Bastante espuma voluminosa. Sabor tipico de weiss, levadura. Cuerpo denso. No esta mal para ser sin alcohol aunque algo se nota.

column1: Will-Bräu Original Bayerisch Hefe Weizen Alkoholfrei
column5: Pours opaque yellow-brown with a massive white head. Taste is on the sweet end, lots of honey. Not bad at all, but quite far away from the flavours you would expect from a beer. Low carbonation.

column1: Will-Bräu Original Bayerisch Hefe Weizen Alkoholfrei
column5: Getreidige Noten, gezuckerte Cornflakes. muffig bananig, wenig herb, pappig. Ne. 12/7/6/6/5/6

column1: Will-Bräu Original Bayerisch Hefe Weizen Alkoholfrei
column5: 500ml Flasche. Trüb und golden mit grosser Schaumkrone. Leicht brotiges Aroma. Dezent süss. Ansonsten wässrig.

column1: Will-Bräu Original Bayerisch Hefe Weizen Alkoholfrei
column5: Sehr trübes dunkel goldgelbes Bier mit einer mittelgroßen stabilen weißen Schaumkrone. Geruch süß bananig, brotig. Geschmack süß brotig, bananig, leicht hefig, schwacher wässriger Körper.

column1: Will-Bräu Original Bayerisch Hefe Weizen Alkoholfrei
column5: Pours cloudy pale yellow with a white head. Aroma is wheat and straw. Flavour is wheat, straw, hay, sweet.

column1: Will-Bräu Original Bayerisch Hefe Weizen Alkoholfrei
column5: Pours cloudy golden with a white head. Aroma is wheat, bread, light banana and grain. Flavour is wheat, bread, sweet, light sulphur and phenolic notes.

column1: Will-Bräu Original Bayerisch Hefe Weizen Alkoholfrei
column5: Pours an unclear and golden beer with a white head. The aroma is malt, fruit, yeast and straw. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall a boring beer.

column1: Will-Bräu Original Bayerisch Hefe Weizen Alkoholfrei
column5: Markhaven Summer Fun 2012. Cloudy golden with a lasting white head. Weak and relatively clean aroma of grass and breadcrust. Thin and watery flavour with grainy character and a bit of sugar flavour
Bottled. An unclear orange beer with a white head. Both the aroma and flavor are sweet malty and it ends on a light dry note.
Bottle. Golden colour with a medium white head. Lemon, fruity aroma and taste, sweet. Medium body with a light dry finish.
Bottle, 4.5%. Standard pilsner, slightly bready and fruity. 6 months past BB date, probably better fresh.
Bottle. Clear yellow coloured with a white head. Aroma of fruits, malts and grain. Flavour of fruits, malts and hops.
(Bottle 33 cl) Pale, pilsener golden with a tiny, white head. Aroma of malt. Medium body with a rather dry malt character and a very discreet hoppiness. 130806
Bottle. Pale golden colour with a small white head. Artificial lemon aroma and taste. Medium body with a sweet finish.
Bottle, 2.6%. Clear pale yellow colour. Small white head. Lemonade aroma. Weak flavour. Aspartam.
(Bottle 50 cl) Pours almost crystal clear with a tiny, white head. Some citrus aroma. Thin and watery with artificial citrusy nose. Artificial sweetness as well. Stay away from this. 130806
Nettes Helles aus dem Chiemgau. Hat im Brewpub besser geschmeckt als in der Flasche. Trotzdem solide.

Bottle 500ml. @ home. [ As Schnitzlbaumer Export-Hell ]. Clear medium yellow color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, light fruity malt, moderate hoppy, grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, fruity malt, pale malt, grass. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20160127]
Weich herber, milder Hopfen. Etwas laffer Mittelteil, erst später steigt die angenehme Herbe, das Bier wird dann insgesamt würziger. Ok. 10/10/10/10/8/10

Bottled, from Biershop Bayern. Almost clear golden, mid sized head. Fruity nose with some bread and grass. Fairly sweet with medium body and rounded mouthfeel. Predominantly fruity and bready. Mild grassy hps lead to a lightly bitter finish. Standard helles, for good and bad.
50 cl bottle. Pours clear golden color with a large white head. Hay and some pale malts on the nose, faint hops. Slick palate, hay and mild pale malty flavor. Very simple, drinkable. 2313
50 cl bottle @ olio, BBE 21.07.2015 Aroma has butter and grain. Flavour has cardboard, harsh malt, butter and some grassy hops. Leathery feeling on palate. Feels old, otherwise quite basic helles.

500ml bottle, thanks Timo A. Pours clear yellowish golden with a small head. Aroma of hay, butter, bready malts, hints of grass and earthy notes. Taste is grainy, earthy and buttery with some hints of hay and grass. Finish is crisp, bready and buttery. Decent, but feels a bit off.
Pours a clear golden body with a medium white head. Aroma of grain, grass. Flavor of grain, grass, and earthiness with a crisp clean finish.
Bottle @ Getränke Winkler, Traunstein. Pours hazy pale piss yellow with a white head. Straw, hay and grass. Smooth and dry with some good hops. Succes!
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit durchschnittlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig, leicht herb. Geschmack malzig würzig, getreidig, minimale Bitterkeit.

50cl bottle from trade with kevnic2008! Pours clear dark golden colour with a mid-sized most good lasting off-white head. Aroma of strong mild sweet malt. Taste of sweet strong malt, honey, mild hops.

Flasche 0,5l: Dunkles Braun mit einer leichten Trübung; in der Nase sehr malzig, dunkles Karamell, Röstaromen, dunkle Schokolade, Tannine; im Körper dunkle, würzige Süße, Tannine, schwarzer Kaffee, ungeröstete Kaffeebohnen; Schwarzbrot/Pumpernickel im Abgang
*Old rating, best before 06.12. Süßlich-karamellig, etwas fruchtig. Malzig-getreidiger Körper mit nicht viel Herbe. Süffig-würzig im Abgang.

Thanks to kevnic2008 for that bottle. Looks very simple but okay. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts strong-malty, fine spicy, nice dry background. Light metallically notes. Spicy aftertaste. Not bad!
bottle from kevnic2008 - danke! Clear golden colour, mid-sized white head. Malty base, some shy hops, hints of fruit.
Clear golden colour. Medium body with sweetish caramel and roasted malt with a fruity touch. O.K.

Süßlicher Malzantrunk, frisch und getreidig. Dabei ist das Malzaroma beriets im Antrunk etwas röstig, steigert sich aber im Mittelteil noch leicht. Auch hier ist das Bier noch süß, eine aufkommende Bitternote verdrängt dies. Mild getreidig, etwas würzig und hopfig werdend. Im Abgang erneut würziger und leicht hopfig. Danke an den Doppelbock für das Bier! Test vom 31.3.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,9,9,10,8,9 - 9,10

Bottle: Deep golden coloured, floaties visible, quite stable fluffy and lacy head; moderate to strong sweet-malty nose with a solid touch of presumably Tettnang hops; moderate to solid sweet-bitter flavour, medium bodied; robust malty and distinctive aromatic hoppy finish. A pleasant, well rounded Festbier..........

(bottle) Unclear, murky golden colour with loads of ugly floaties and a short foamy white head. Slightly sweet grainy aroma with notes of cara-malt, subtle fruity accents and a tinge of herbal hops. Sweet and slightly bitter flavour, medium to light bodied with a quite soft carbonation. Solid malty base with biscuits and traces of cara-malt; moderately dry, sweet and slightly bitter finish with a delicate hoppy touch. Hearty Festbier, nice (28.05.08).
¨Bottle. Clear golden coloured with a white head. Aroma of malts and fruits. Flavour of malts, fruits and hops. Hoppy finish.

Oct 2019 - bottle at Arno's in Sathorn, Bangkok. This is an American beef burger joint, but they serve some hard to find beers, and do salads so I can eat here. Lager is very watery with little flavour - I suspect the colour is due to caramel rather than roasted barley. Whatever it's an ok drink.

Pour a dark amber with an abundan beigt head. The aroma is toasted malt, brown sugar. The mouthfeel is medium. The taste is nice balance of bitter and sweet, with some toasty malt and floral hops. Slow lingering bitterness with a hint of caramel.
Deep reddish, brown colour with a large beige head. Sweet malty aroma with a light roasted note and hints of fruit and bread. Malty, bready flavor with a light fruit note.
Dark brown brew draught at Apollo. Sweet butter but also with notes of strabarew I thought. Some ryebread, rosted aroma. Sweet flavour. Medium body and slightly malted and dry finish.
Draught at the brewpub. Dark brown colour with a big beige head. Light butter, light roasted, rye bread aroma and a sweet butter, apollo yeast, light roasted taste. Medium body with a dry finish.
On tap. Dark brown in colour with a small head. Malty and hints of dark fruit and rye. Notes of butter and carame. Very clean.

(On tap) Clear mahogany with an orange hue and a handsome, dense, beige head with good retention and leaving a pretty lacework. Aroma of roasted malt. Light and somewhat watery body, with notes of roasted malt and some butter. Dry but not overly bitter finish. Very distinct Apollo character - whatever that is. Nowhere near a Czech Dunkel. 041006

Draught at Apollo. Dark/dark brown - offwhite head. Rurned, malty, sweet, ryebread, dark fruits, sour (the apollo taste), high malty. Hints of a taste of danish chirtstmasbeer - the kind for chikdren with no alchohol or very little.

Draught @ the brewpub. Dark brown coloured. Dense brownihs head. Sweet, buttery aroma with light notes of caramel. Light roasted, herbal and sweet flavour. A bit bland and buttery. Medium bodied. Has a light roasty end. Easy to drink, and has the unmistakably sign of Apollo yeast.
Draught at the brewpub. Clear brown coloured with a beige head. Aroma of malts, caramel and straw with notes of yeast. Flavour of malts, caramel, straw and hops.

A brown beer with a red shine under a brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of licorice, malt, and caramel - nicely inviting. The flavor starts out sweet with strong notes of licorice and caramel, but with a note of butter lying in the back ground - brewing flaw? After detecting the butter in the flavor it is also evident in the aroma. The end is slightly roasted. The mouthfeel is too carbonated. Some good and some bad notes.

Draught at the brewpub. Very dark brown coloured with a pale brown head. Malty aroma with notes of chocolate, hops and some caramel. Malty flavour with some hoppiness underneath. Thankfully, Not as sweet as most Czech dark lagers.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: Found in can from Franklin, NC Ingles. Just a well put together beer with a great flavor throughout. Really a go to fall IPA for me.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: Deep golden color with a taller, stable ecru head. Scents of earthy malt, and mild citrus. Flavors concur with the scents as the earthiness is present throughout, both in the malts and hops. Earthy and mediocre 3/10

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: (From notes). Consumed at the May 2011 LEAF Festival, about 1 mile from the brewery. A - Amber. Clear. Nice bone head is creamy and has very good retention. S - modestly hoppy aroma for style, with toasted malt T - fairly rich and earthy, with plenty of toasted malt and hop bitterness. As expected, this IPA has a bitter finish and lingering bitter grapefruit rind aftertaste, but I thought this one had too little actual hop flavor given this level of bitterness. M - medium body is a bit full for style. Adequate if light carbonation. O- Good beer, and certified organic, but disappointing given the outstanding track record of this brewery.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: Old rating. Decent IPA. More biscuity than hoppy. Mild floral hops. Easy drinking, but fairly basic stuff.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: 11/27/13. On tap at the Mellow Mushroom in downtown Asheville. Amber orange pour with a small frothy khaki head. Mild aroma, grainy, husky malts with some caramel and biscuit aspects, very mild hops - touches of floral and citrus. Mild flavor as well, again malty with barely a touch of floral and citrus hops. Meh.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: Growler from an Asheville grocer. Amber color. Most beautiful lace. Tastes of earthy leaves, sharp bitter hops, loads of citrus. Aroma of grapefruit and caramel malt. Finishes with sharp bitterness.(3525)

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at Mellow Mushroom in Asheville. Cloudy light straw color. Nose is a bit tame. Flavor is fairly heavy on grain tannin. Moderate bitterness. Light-medium body.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draft in a flight at the brewery. Poured a golden color with a fairly small head. Nice level of hoppiness all around that makes for a pleasant drink.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draft at the source. Hazy amber color, thick white head, solid lacing. Aroma of grapefruit taste is tropical fruit, moderate bitterness. Nice.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draft to pint at Pisgah. Looks good; deep orange with ample head. Smells solid; hoppy and malty. Tastes like it smells with an average mouthful. Pretty good.

My Bottom Line: Timid sweet fruitiness and base malts level out the intrinsic fruit tartness in this softspoken, but rather generic Fruit Beer. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam tops the clear rosy red. -The chosen malts don’t really fit with the blueberry fruitiness. -The malts’s sweetness is cleanly extracted, but I just don’t think this is a great recipe. -Some wooden hop bitterness dries out the back end. -The fruitiness could be more expressive/juicier. On tap at the brewpub.
OCntains a good appearance like reddish. NOt too much flavour. The aroma is like soft malts and good foam.
Bottle. BB nov07. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Dark red amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter powerfull chocolate notes. Long nice finish. Creamy palate. Excellent.

Bottle @ chriso’s Pre-GBBF Shindig 2008. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty bready caramel aroma. Sweetish malty bready caramel flavor. Has a sweetish malty bready finish.

Bottle 50cl. @ home.
Light light unclear medium red brown color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, roasted, caramel, brown sugar, vanilla notes, licorice notes. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20081023]

Bottle, 2008 Pre-GBBF Chris_o Shindig. Ruby highlighted brown, light tan head with some decent lace. Sticky thick aroma, cough meds, licorice, artifical blackberry sweet. Soft vegital malt flavor, butter and roast around the edges. Tastes better than it smells, but too rough, too estery.
A Sim rate (bottle at Chris O’s): Malty aroma with caramel sweetness. A bit off-putting with its bizarre sweetness. Bitter, fake caramel flavour. Something unpleasant about it. Malty and not great.
Bottle at Chris_o Pre GBBF Shindig 08. Very dark ruby, thick beige head. It’s alright. A bit sweet, some candy sgar. Bit sweet. Some choc/coffee.
Dark brown with medium beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt and breadish notes. sweet flavor with bread, caramel and mild chocolate notes. Ends sweet.

Bottle. Medium high off-white head leaving nice curtains. Clear very dark red brown body, almost black. Roasted barley malt aroma. Mild and relatively sweet roasted malt flavor with notes of caramel and coffee. Low carbonation, short aftertaste.

Bottle 0.5 l. Bought Humletorvet Slagelse. Color very dark brown with small white/beige head. Aroma dark chocolate and perhaps a little bit of coffee. Slightly bitter, flavors quite discrete - a bit disappointing with the promising aroma. Malty. Dark brown Danish bread. soft carbonated mouthfeel. Neithera bock nor a stout -perhaps e new beer type a - bout.

Deep dark amber colored, medium sized thick beige head. Strongly sweet and rich aroma with dominating chocolate and toffee, maybe still too obvious one aroma. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is also very sweet and dominated by this toffee-chocolate, still I was very surprised that this has 8% ABV. Aftertaste dries slightly with some caramel still. Too sweet for me.
Bottle shared with Odeed; must have been an infected one; Nose was yeast, coffee, and skunky sourness; Brown with a small beige head; flavor of sour coffee and not much else, body very thin.
(bottle from bbb63)dark brown witha light brown head.some raosted malt and oatmeal in the nose.light watery body.flavor was mostly sour.maybe a bad bottle?

#989. Bottle. Thanks to whoever brought this to the White Elephant exchange at the Chicago Area gathering at Flossmoor station. Dark ruby with a medium head that is quickly discipating. Nose is malty, grainy. Taste is roasted malts, sharp sugars nuts and dark fruit skins. Tangy.
This was another super funky brew from them.My second and hopefully my last. It looked very nice but after their Barley Wine I was cautious. Shoulda’ known. Muddled and misguided. Needs alot of work.

Bottle from tjthresh. Poured almost black with a thick off white head. Very roasted aroma, coffee, chocolate. Rich velvety mouthfeel that coats the flavors of again, coffee, chocolate molasses and a bready yeastiness. Nice finish. A nice oatmeal stout.
Black with a roasty malt aroma. Flavor was a bit thin. Roasty malts, coffee, chocolate with a rich roasty finish.

Bottle from Secret Santa. Good roasted malty aroma with a mild sweet chocolate. Black body with tan head. Was little hard to get a good description of the flavor on this one. I had a couple of coffee beers before this one. Had a good medium sweet roasted malt presence noticable. Smooth enjoyable brew on the palate.

12 ounce bottle. Black coffee with a light brown head. Aromas of coffee with creamer, rolled oats, come light chocolate syrup notes. A bit hop hops in the nose and plenty of a bitter end. Lush on the palate. Very full and rich. Nice. Some good chocolate character. Not bad at all Chuck.

Bottle. Thanks Noah (htsprint1) and Jen. Dark chocolate brown with a small but frothy tan head. Nose is chocolate, oatmeal, roasted coffee, prunes/raisins, toasted walnuts. Medium body with a smooth, creamy feel. Flavor captures the aroma. Some sweetness and a bit of bitter coffolate. A nice drink.

Draft sample at Back Road Fest. Poured dark brown with an average creamy brown head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate toasted sweet malty aroma. Medium to full body with a creamy texture. Medium sweet roasted flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration.

Putting my rating here since this is the only alt listed for natty greene’s and well, I didn’t have the entire ratebeer database on hand when I ordered my growler so here it goes. Growler from the brewpub. Pours a murky light brown with a ruby red tint. Slight head that lasts and lacing that doesn’t quit. Toasty grain aroma with a touch of red fruit. Nutty flavor with a dirty bitter hop finish. Very reminiscient of a fresh hop experience here and pretty nice. These guys make good beer and are desperately underappreciated in the NC beer scene. Solid, varied, true to style, and always consistent.
Pours cloudy yellow with white head. The aroma is citrus, pine grapefruit, lemon. The flavor is very light caramel, toasty with citrus grapefruit pine. Nice bitter finish

It pours dark golden with orange tinges. The head is white and leaves plenty of lacing. It has a faint hoppy citrus aroma with more dried fruits like apricot present. It has a citrus taste with dried fruit more present than traditional strong citrus. There is a moderately bitter effect on the palate.
Bottle shared with McTapps. Hitting the scores in a nice dry way with some crispy hops, some citrus fruits and a decent bitterness towards the end. Refreshing one without hitting it high.

US State 20/51 - bottle from a trade with gopherfan99, thank you so much, Steve. The beer has got a deep golden-amber colour with an steady head and medium body. Aroma of hops and pine with citrus hints. Taste of hops, pine, mild herbs, light spices, thyme, citrus fruits and mandarinas. Mild and smooth finish. Quaffable and enjoyable beer.

Bottle (trade with non Rate Beer Member); pours a cloudy yellow orange with a white head; aroma is bittersweet with caramel, malt, and citrus; taste starts sweet from the caramel and then becomes bitter with the citrus; light bitter finish; pretty smooth

Pours a nice gold amber with a white head. Aroma is citrus fruit, some hints of malt. Taste is fruity with some malt flavor and enough hops to be noticeable. True to the English style. On the sweet side for a IPA but a tasty drinkable beer.

Great looking in a Tulip Glass. Very little head. Well balanced and smoothe IPA. Not many fruit tones from the hops, but an all around hoppy taste. The taste of malt lingers afterwards. I could drink a 6 pack and not be displeased. Not all in one sitting though.
Pours a nice gold color with hints of red. Aroma of citrus, malt. Well-balanced taste with malt and hop. Pretty good everyday IPA.

An excellent every day drinking IPA that showcases EKG hops in both aroma and flavor, preserves a healthy malt/hop balance, and mixes with pretty much any pub grub, or enjoyable on its own. Well done. Wish it was year round.
From tap at brewery. Pours a nice golden yellow with decent white head. aroma is all citrus fruity hops. Taste was fruity with a light malt bill and very little bitter. A mild IPA but good!

On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazed gold with a thin white head. Soft wheat on the nose, a touch of yeast. Medium bodied, wheat and a bit of graininess, light musky yeast. Soft sweetness into the finish with a touch of grain and wheat. Tasty enough.
I couldn’t finish the pint. Too much banana - almost fruity flavor. Does not meet my criteria for a hefeweizen.
Draft: Cloudy, yellow, with a small white head. Orange and wheat malt aroma. Sweet....orange-lemon-banana and wheat flavours. Pretty solid.
This poured a hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma was of wheat, orange and banana. Flavor similar, clean and refreshing

Sampled on tap at Natty Greene’s in Raleigh. Pours a hazy yellow color with white head. Served with a lemon - big party foul for a hefeweizen! Yeast, wheat, lemon, corn husk aromas. Yeast, wheat, light bubblegum flavors. Light bodied. Kinda tangy. Just not a very good hefeweizen.

Poured as a 4 oz taster at the Greensboro pub. Comes served with a slice of lemon, even on a taster. I know that in Germany it’s common to squeeze a fruit juice in hefeweizen, but it probably isn’t needed here. Correct to style - obvious banana and clove notes on the nose and the palate. Finishes clean. One of the better American hefeweizens I’ve had.

Tap at Natty Greene’s downtown - pours cloudy orange with a white head. Aroma is the typical banana and clove. Good example of the style, though I wish they wouldn’t put the stupid orange wedge on the glass.

Draft at brewpub. Pours cloudy yellow with a thin white head. For some reason at the brewpub they stick an orange slice on the glass. Nice estery notes on the nose. Has a nice banana and clove thing on the tongue. Finishes clean. perfect for the summer. I wish everything they did was this nice.
Draft at the source. Cloudy variegated yellow orange. Comes with a lemon slice. Aroma of orange. Taste is slightly bitter, watery orange and lemon.
Tap. Hazy golden with small head. Tart wheat. Very minimal clove and banana. Refreshing, but not overly flavorful.

Draft at the brewpub. Opaque with a quarter-inch of cream above that leaves frosty lace behind. Mild dry cocoa aroma. Tastes of dry cocoa and coffee with a touch of cream. Medium body is lightly carbonated, a bit too watery, and has a slightly dry finish.

Location: Draft at the brewpub, 10/22/14 Aroma: This one has a smoke aroma, with some meat notes, and some underlying roasted malt Appearance: Pours a dark brown color, with an orange hue, a beige head, and light lace Flavor: It has a smoke forward flavor as well, with light roast, as well as a light bitterness Palate: It has a medium body, average carbonation, and a smokey and semi-dry finish Overall Impression: This is a pretty tasty and true to style Smoked Porter. It hit on the marks I was looking for. Well done. One of the best offerings from Black Forest that I have tried.

Growler filled at the brewpub and consumed two days later. Pours black with a thin off-white head that lasted through the first two sips and left patchy, spotty lace to the end. Very pleasant aroma of wood smoke, roasted malt, and a bit of chocolate. The flavor is similar with wood smoke, roasted malt, mild chocolate and just a bit of chalk. Mild bitterness at the finish. Easy to drink and very enjoyable!

Pours a medium to dark brown with a faint off white head. Heavy notes of smoke, wood, caramel and chocolate. The Flavor is slightly metallic and the palate is a little watery. Heavily smoked but lacking in body.

It really pains me to give this such a low rating as Black Forest is usually very on point with its offering. A careful look at my scores, however will reveal that this beer only really fails on a specific point. The aroma is nice a smoky with a bit of malt. The flavor follows in kind except for a strange chemical taste right before the smoke. I can best describe it as camomeal tea (which I also dislike intensely).
one of my favorites out of BF. this beer has an incredible smoked flavor and wish they had it back on the menu.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours black with a thick tan head. Aroma of smoked and roasted malt (not very meaty though). Flavor of smoke, sweet malt, charred malt. Pretty good smoked beer, easy drinking. It grew on me as I continued to drink and I was really enjoying it by the end of the glass. 7/4/7/4/14 [3.6/5]

Aroma is smoky, earthy, malty. The appearance is deep brown, opaque, minimal tan head. The flavor is smoky, peat, earth, light chocolate. The finish is smoke, pine hops. The mouthfeel is oliy, medium to medium/thick body. Good. This is a growler from the brewpub, I suspect it’s a little flat from an improper sealing.

Tap at the brewpub: Deep dark brown with a ruby highlight to it, topped by a creamy tan head. Roasted aroma- fairly simple with some earthy peat/soil like notes and roated malt. There’s a hint of woody smokiness in there. Decent body, relatively light. The Flavor incorporates smoke and earthy bitterness. A bit gritty and earthy. Quite a roasted bitterness, near ashy-ness is present throughout, with bitter tobacco and peat. The smoke is there but leans toward ashy bitterness. The finish is long earthy and bitter. It is a bit smoky, but in the form of ash. Not much depth.

on tap at the brewpub. Just about black in color with a tan head. Aroma of smoke, roast, mild chocolate, molasses and chalk. Taste is nice and smoky, with some roast, chocolate- medium mildly sweet body with molasses. Finishes with lingering smoke and a touch of bitterness. Very nice!

Damn brandon, I thoroughly enjoyed this puppy, but i love smoked beer. Big wide mug at the brewpub on their Octoberfest. Color is black with some brown tinges. Small tan head turns into lacing. Aroma is mild though, faint smoke and not much else. Dont try it for the aroma. Taste is what makes it. Actually smokey, something different for smoked porters. Just a tad of bitterness. Leaves a nice present smokey aftertaste. Just a bit of bitterness and a sllight sweetness thoughout.
0,33 l Flasche. Leicht säuerlich, malzig, dezent bitter, weich im Abgang. Gar nicht schlecht.
Pale light yellow color. Some bubbles and a big white lasting head. Medium to thin body. Smooth. Mild, not that bitter taste.
Malt and hop in aroma Rather strong in hop in balance Medium to light body Bitter, clear finish A german pils, a bit smooth side.
50cl bottle. Pours clear golden with a huge good lasting white head. Aroma is slight malty, pale malt, some grain. Taste of medium hops, medium bitter, some grain and pale malt.
Clear pale yellow, white lasting, lacing foam head. Not a nice aroma, but OK in taste. A normal German mass produced beer. (Velp 201508)
*Old rating, best before 27.04.10. Malty-grainy brew, fresh, slightly malty-sweetish, dry and slightly bitter end.

Flasche (50 cl) von einem Getränkemarkt in Kassel. - Helles Goldgelb, blank. - Nase angenehm fruchtig-hopfig, leicht süß. - Antrunk mild und rund mit schön zitronigem Hopfen. Leicht süßliches helles Malz. Mild rezent, weiches Mundgefühl. Auch im Abgang vorwiegend zitronige Frische, nur milde Bittere. - Eher mildes aber schönes, süffiges Pils, charakterisiert durch mild-zitronige Hopfenaromen und weiches Wasser.

0,5 l bottle. Typical Pilsener appearance, light golden, white head, medium CO2. Starts surprisingly herb hopy, followed by a grainy bitterness. Later comes a little bit citrus. More than an average Pilsener.
bottle @ pizza-bar in Kassel, yellow colour with foamy white head. Smell: hoppy. Taste: nice malty, some hoppyness and some fruity notes with some sharpness. Simple, typical German one.

Bottle, shared by MiP. A clear, pale golden beer with a decent, white head. Neutral nose with pale malts and a fruity touch. Medium body with flavors of pale malts and some fruity hops. Low on bitterness. The finish lasts for a short while and is rather tasteless. Not bad at all, but really boring. Dry and quenching though. 100813
50cl bottle. Pours clear golden with a huge good lasting white head. Aroma of mild hops, some barley and pale malt. Taste is grainy, medium bitter, pale malt, average Pilsener.
Butelka Najlepsza jest piana - bia³a obfita, trwa³a. Barwa z³ota - piwo klarowne. Aromat s³odowy, nieco stêch³y. W smaku s³ód, nieco chmielu. Lekko s³odkie. Do wypicia, ale przeciêtne.

Bottle. A clear, slightly pale golden beer with an off-white head. Pale malts, slightly spiced hops and some fruityness in the aroma. It’s dry in the mouth, fruity and malty, medium body. Quite dry in the finish too, with a fine bitterness. A tasteful, quenching and easy drinkable beer with good hoppyness. 100813
Yellow with a small white head. Weak fruity and grainy aroma. Sweet grainy flavour with notes of hay and fruit
Bottle @ Danish Summer Gathering, 2010. Pours clear pale yellow with a small white head and lacings. Nose is perfume and grain. Dry and grainy flavor. Medium bodied, Short dry end. Ok

Bottle 500ml. Clear light to medium yellow color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, moderate hoppy, citrus, green grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, green grass. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100813]
clear light yellow, smooth small white head. faint aroma flavor is hoppy, malty balance.
Bottle. Clear pale yellow with a small white head. The aroma is fruity and light hoppy with some caramel. Clean malty flavour with some hops and fruit.

Bottle, 5.1%. Subtle flowery hop aroma. Clear yellow colour. Small white head. The flavour has a distinct bitterness. It is not just pleasant, but it is clean enough. There is a good flowery aroma hop note to make it flavourful and refreshing.

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of MiP/KimJohansen. Pours a clear yellow with a white head. Clean malts in the nose. Medium body, again a clean maltiness with flowery hops that leave quite some bitterness. 130810

This beer raises a very tall white head which slowly settles as I drink. A nice cap of foam hangs till the last sip and makes for some slick lacy finger patterns on the glass. Its body has a somewhat tan, sandy amber color which is quite murky. The aroma is yeasty and estery with tons of wheat and some hints of its 8% abv. I also pick also pick up on some hops in the background that add a light earthy/spicy/floral character. Its medium to full body has a big yeasty and malty character with notes of banana baby food, unripe peach, pear, mellow phenolic clove and sweet wheat. Towards the finish there is more grainy wheat and light hints of hops and mildly spicy alcohol. The palate feels heavy, smooth and slick with mild carbonation.
Old tick. This one was very banana like and sweet, not sure when or why it was discontinued.

Bottle at O’Connors, Uppsala. Hazy orange color, very little white head - was completely clear before the yeast was poured from the bottle. Cloyingly sweet aroma with overripe fruit, syrup and berries. Taste is sweet and spicy with berries and toffee combining in a way that is similar with some barley wines. Very full body, sticky texture and a flat carbonation. This was a really interesting, complex beer - didn’t detect much wheat in the taste or aroma, though.
65 cl bottle. Originally rated on 20100417. Pours hazy golden color with a small head. Aroma of wheat, hops, ripe fruits and some grass. Flavor of hay, toffee, hops, ripe fruits and wheat.

65 cl bottle @ O’Hara’s Freehouse. Rated on 17.04.2010 Rather unusual appearance; after the pour I can see the yeast falling towards the bottom of my glass. Aroma is somewhat sweet banana esthers, yeasty notes, fruits and hints of alcohol. Flavour is sweetish with wheaty notes, fruits, banana esthers and yeast. Finishes with somewhat stinging alcohol. Good still.

22 ounce bottle into weizen glass, no bottle dating but this has been retired for a couple years at least. Pours very hazy golden amber color with a fairly dense 1-2 finger white head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Spotty foamy lacing on the glass. Aromas of big banana, lemon, pear, wheat, caramel, honey, clove, bread, orange, pepper, bubblegum, earth, and yeast spices. Pretty nice aromas with good strength and decent balance; the age is definitely apparent. Taste of banana, orange, clove, pear, wheat, biscuit, caramel, lemon, pepper, honey, earth, toffee, and yeast spices. Lingering notes of banana, light fruits, wheat, biscuit, clove, caramel, pepper, and yeast spices on the finish for a good bit. Nice balance and complexity of flavors; good fruity/spicy flavor balance; zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a slick and creamy mouthfeel that is good. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish. Overall this is a very nice imperial hefeweizen. Nice balance and complexity of flavors; and very smooth to drink for an 8% beer. Very enjoyable offering, despite the noticeable age.

Bottle. 22 oz. Pours a deep, brilliant yellow with a pristine, tightly bubbled white head. Beautiful lacing throughout. Aroma of lemon zest, fresh cut hay, slight grassiness, and hints of orange peel, clove, and banana. Medium bodied with a loose, silky, creamy palate. Slight tanginess from the citrus flavors. Extremely smooth finish. Excellent weizen.
Bomber. Pours a light orange, cloudy and unfiltered. Arom is a light floral, sweet. Taste is ripened fruit, apples maybe. A nice wheat beer offering!

Bottle at Dan’s, pour courtesy of Aaron. Thanks! This bottle is probably 2-3 years old, so my rating would probably change if this was fresh. Anyways, poured a hazy orange with little-to-no head. Aroma is very musty, dead malt, fungused bread, and some metal, IDK, haha. Taste is old, liquid bread, stale wheat, and just not very appetizing. Thin body and overall the taste is just expired. Bleh.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, slightly orange with white head, aroma has notes of wet grain, some slight vanilla, touch of biscuit, bread and mineral water, lots of cardboard as well. Taste is cardboard, vanilla, some dusty mineral, some slight off taste hints of bread, finishing fairly sweet. Definitely past its prime.

column1: Big Horse Moped Rider English IPA
column5: Growler, first pour. Deposits in glass a clear, medium amber color. Nice whitish head forms and retains for a good bit, leaving decent lacing as the beer is consumed. Medium bodied with fairly soft carbonation. Herbal and grassy nose, slight bits of toast in aroma. Flavors seem to be malt dominant towards the front with biscuit and then a pleasant, slow bitterness towards the finish that balances out nicely and lingers. Quite solid, easy to drink English IPA

Sampled on draft at the Monroeville PA location this beer poured a black color with a small tan head. The aroma is Sweet and roasty malts with a hint of coffee and chocolate. The flavor is rather bitter followed by roasty malts, a hint of coffee and a light finish of dry bakers chocolate. The mouthfeel is moderately thick. Much more bitter than sweet and the chocolate is rather subtle.
On tap at the brewery as "Rye Not." This is a pretty straightforward rye beer, with a good amount of grainy flavor and a decent hop bite. Good with lunch, too.

Northeast Bucket List Trip Beer #53. Keg at the brewpub as "Rye Not." Pours a hazy orange with a thin creamy off-white head. Good head retention. Aroma of rye and pale malt. The taste is the same. Medium bodied, strong lingering bitterness.

Bottle. Pours a murky pale yellow with a thin white head that lingers. Lemon aroma. Fruity beginning with a hop bite at the end. The style of wheat beer is not my favorite and I’m not fond of the rye beers but its okay. I’d take one if offered but I probably wouldn’t look to buy it.

From a bottle from the brewery. Pours murky orange brown with a bubbly off white head. Tastes like malt, pine hops, dry grapefruit, nutty caramel resin. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like nutty grains and light hops.

Bottle from brewery. Pours hazy brownish-gold with creamy off-white head. Aroma is cereal and bready malts, light orange peel, light honey, light rye, faint spice and some floral notes. Flavor is dry malts, rye, light floral hops, faint citrus, and faint honey; dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
On tap at brewery. Hazy golden with a large bubbly white head. Aroma and flavor are both of sweeter malts, cereal, rye bread, tropical fruit, and booze. Slight honey in the finish.
on draft at the brewery, clean and great, Tons of rye flavors which I enjoy, dry and hoppy a great beer that you can drink pint after pint

column1: Ringneck Bourbon Barrel Aged Poor Richards Ale
column5: Wax-sealed bottle: The beer is a murky brown-amber color with a medium thick and rocky light beige head. Sticky patches of lacing mostly near the top of the glass. Strong aroma of molasses, malt and coconut. Rich and very smooth-bodied. The barrel-aging definitely imbues the original version with a pronounced bourbon flavor. Woody, malty flavors along with hops and peppery alcohol. The finish is round and sweet, with a lingering bourbon aftertaste. Very good overall.

column1: Ringneck Bourbon Barrel Aged Poor Richards Ale
column5: GABF 2006: Clear light amber color with an off-white head. Some vanilla but light on the barrel. The flavor was woody and malty. Bitter finish with a light to medium body.

column1: Ringneck Bourbon Barrel Aged Poor Richards Ale
column5: Draft... GABF ’06... Mostly clear golden ale with a small, tight, white head. Decent retention. Toffee, brown sugar, subtle wood and bourbon in the nose. Pretty hot, flavor-wise. Big, chewy caramel, heavy bitterness and alcohol. Good balance; minimal sweetness. Medium-bodied and lightly creamy with fizzy carbonation. Finishes caramely sweet, then astringent and dry.

column1: Ringneck Bourbon Barrel Aged Poor Richards Ale
column5: I really enjoyed this brew. Pours out a dark brown color with a small tan head.Aroma is very malty with nice hints of bourbon. Flavor was superb. Very malty with huge hints of vanilla and bourbon. This is the first bourbon aged scotch ale i have had and its great.

column1: Ringneck Bourbon Barrel Aged Poor Richards Ale
column5: Bottle from Matt (drbayern) Thanks! This is one hell of a good scotch ale. Pour is black in color with some nice head retention. Smell is oak, vanilla, some hops, sweet caramel, and a touch of bourbon. Taste is smooth and rich, with some roasted malts coming through to kind of balance the barrel aging process. I am typically not a fan of the barrel aged beers, but this one certainly does it justice. Very nice!

column1: Ringneck Bourbon Barrel Aged Poor Richards Ale
column5: Draught sample at the brewpub, early August 2006. An opaque dirty, very much unfiltered yeasty brown body with a lasting creamy head and a lot of lace....sweet, rustic and smoky aroma, touches of molasses along with the bourbony vanilla tones, faint spices flitting in and out and hard to grasp....molasses strongly evident in the body, corn grits seem to be a major component in the malts and are well-complimented by the booze, with faint peaty caramelized barley sitting lightly underneath...thick and near-cloying but fascinating. Scotch ale? I dunno, but it’s a neat experiment anyway.

column1: Ringneck Bourbon Barrel Aged Poor Richards Ale
column5: Stunning ale, the best barrel aged beer I’ve ever had. Had it at the restaurant on tap the last week of August. Smells full of bourbon, brown sugar. Looks thick, dark brown, doesn’t appear to be filtered. Taste is amazing -- sweet malt balanced by dry bourbon, medium thick body that tricks you into thinking you’re actually sipping a bourbon, so you drink it slow. The finish is dry, which is a great change, since all barrel aged beers I’ve had are sweet imperial stouts. Note from Chris, the brewmaster: They were one of 100 breweries making an old American recipie from Ben Franklin or something like that. All they had was a list of ingredients, no proportions. He says the base beer is a Scotch ale. He used 25% corn in this beer, as corn was one of the ingredients on the list. He plans on taking it to GABF, but made only 55 gallons of it, so when you find it, snatch it up.
Pours pale copper. Smells of sweet apples, some honey hints in the backdrop. Tastes sweet and syrupy with some spicy hints on the finish.

Bottle. Pours a clear yellow, no head. Big sweet apples, candy apple aromas. Quite sweet, a touch vegetal and funky. Weird, overly sweet and plasticy. Bleh. Lingering sugar on the finish. Nothing great.
Pours black with low tan head. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malt. Taste is roasty with a chocolate sweet finish. Light and smooth body with soft carbonation.

Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours black with a brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has strong butterscotch note with dark grains and roasted malts supporting. Flavor is full of sweet dark grains and butterscotch.
Keg at the brewpub. Dark brown, thin creamy tan head, fair retention. Aroma of pure diacetyl and a hint of roast. Taste is diacetyl, dms, roast, caramel. Thin. A mess.

Reviewed from notes. The appearance was an almost black color with a finger’s worth of eggshell white foamy head that dissipated at a slow pace. Mild lace. The aroma had some roasted coffee notes, light oatmeal, light dark chocolate nibs and ends with some cereal/grainy sweetness. The flavor leans to the sweet side and rolls into a smooth sort of oat/grainy aftertaste and on into the finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionable to sipping sort of quality about it. Roastiness was smoothed out fairly nice by the oatmeal. Overall, nicely done oatmeal stout well worthy of having again.

4 oz. pour, on tap at the brewpub in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. Consumed on 4-23-16. Dark brown. Beige head. Pretty good lacing. Coffee and burnt caramel scents. Coffee flavor. Dry, verging on caramel. Basic stout flavor. Not bad but nothing special in taste. Light body. Unremarkable palate.

Sample at the brewpub. Almost black with a steady tan foam. Light roasted aroma. Oatmeal is noted and makes for a smooth beer. Light chocolate flavors. Just a bit of bitterness. This is nice if subdued.

On tap at the Escanaba Brewpub as the "Blackbird Oatmeal Stout." Pours a deep mahogany, fringe in brown. Head is an off-white. Light nutty aroma. Wow. This is terrible. A totally watered down, flavorless, lightly roasted garbage stout. A bit of salt, tannin and not much else. Minerals and water. Very little body. This is just plain a terrible stout. I can’t tease anything worth anything out of this. Faintly roasty with a bit of chocolate powder. But this is an embarrassment of a stout.

A very sub par sweet stout. Aroma was near nothing. Pour was a flat deep brown with no head. Taste was very weak and boring. A slight coffee flavor with water overpowering. Just a little bit of bitterness in the aftertaste that reminds you that you are drinking beer. Very flat and thin mouthfeel. Blah.

Typical H&H background beer aroma, you know, just plain good ol beery. Just a hint of stout smell. Black with a red tinge. Nice tasting stout, it has more carbonation than I expected and I welcome that. Good roasty flavors; fun, fresh and friendly. Much better than I expected, pleasantly surprised! May be my best H&H to date!

On draught at the brewpub/restaurant in Wausau, Wisconsin. Pours a clear dark cola brown brew with a thick and lumpy light tan head that has some excellent retention and sticky lacing. Aroma of toasted dark malt, a near schwarzbier character, some flowery hops and a touch of chocolate. Taste is smooth, creamy, quite malty with a toasted malt and chocolate flavor with a touch of molasses in the near finish. Finish is sweet at first and then a lingering semi-dry aftertaste with flavor of toasted dark malt. Quite enjoyable.
On tap in the city. Drinkable IPA that doesn’t go beyond the basics. Nothing special. But there aren’t other brewpubs in the area.

Tap at the Empire State location. Pale golden/crystal clear with a sticky white head. Aroma of fruity orange and mango with a touch of pine as well. Lean, clean pale malt with a light bready accent. Flavour is nicely hoppy, more IPA than double but it shows orange citrus, pine and a light resinousness. As it warms a bright spicy flavour comes through on the finish. Not a big massively hopped IIPA, but it’s still a nice pint.

7.7% on this one. Deeply hazed rust, light tan creamy head. Nose held notes of pine and citrus, hints of florals, and just a touch of sweet caramel malt. Soft bitter flavors throughout with lighter shades of nutty earth. Light to medium bodied, soft carbonation, soft bitter finish. More like a Light Imperial IPA in my book...

Pours copper with a thick off white head. Aroma was malty with hints of orange, citrus, graitfruit, pine and caramel. The graitfruit was over hinted in the aroma and taste. Pretty average for a Double IPA. Of course I am being picky because I love this style.

Pint glass at 51st and 6th ave. Couldnt really piick up any aroma (probably my allergies). Nice, copper color with fine head. I was expecting monster hops, and while this has a dominant hop presence, it wasn’t overwhelming. Very creamy feel to it - the malt backs it up nicely. Noticed hints of nut and vanilla. Lacing follows the beer down. Hop flavor intensifies as you drink. Alcohol also more noticeable too toward the end. A good beer, not sure how it holds up to other Imperial IPAs.

A pretty big beer. Very malty, somewhat boozy. Good esters, orange peel, caramel, moderately sweet, medium-heavy bittering. Mouthy. I was talking business with a collegue and didn’t get real good notes, but my genera limpression was that this was a fairly substantial brew with a kick, but on the beaten path.
Unbalance overflow on the head. All over the floor. Dark and murky and chocolaty. Quite nice but somehow a little on the amateur side but very drinkable and a good effort.

Bottle. Just had an ’old engine oil’ which was fantastic; might influence ratings here. No real head, dense black, quite sour smelling. International roast coffee, a little thin, i’m not getting that ’creamy mouthfeel’. Smokey like smoke essence in canned tuna. Northern rivers beers seem to taste like adequately made concentrate kit home brew - inoffensive, unimaginative.

Good tan head gone in sixty seconds carbonation rapid cover to edge of glass aroma coffee aniseed liccorice flavour strong coffee liccorice cocoa taste all bitter finish bitter dry flavours medicinal taste
330ml bottle. Very tasty and leaves you wanting more. Pours a dark brown colour with medium head that disappeared reasonably quickly. All in all not a bad drop.
Pours a dark brown and tanned head. Roasted malt with chocolate and coffee notes. Flavour is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and licorice. Medium bodied, creamy and slight bitter finish.

This is not a bad beer by any means, but it really didn’t live up to what I was hoping it to be. The head didn’t last as well as I expect and it tended towards being a bit too roasty (almost felt like charcoal). Overall though I wouldn’t knock it back if you bought the next round.

Poured a black body with a short lasting, light tan head. Dark chocolate on the aroma also a bit of smokiness. Coffee notes more so than the chocolate and the smoke in the taste, drinkable but not outstanding for me.

RE-RATE: Bottle (330ml). Poured black with a large, dense, rocky, light-brown head which lasted superbly. Aroma was of dark toasted malts with dark chocolate, espresso coffee, licorice and some salt. Flavor was similar to aroma but well balanced; toasted malts, dark chocolate, a moderate bitterness, milky espresso coffee and some licorice in the finish. Medium bodied with lively carbonation a dry/creamy mouthfeel and a good finish.

hey, a decent english sort of stout. quite solid black looking, with a loose head and too much carb. coffee pralines in nose. salty, licorice and coffee flavour - guinness yeast? good spicy hops on finish, not that bitter but a bit of goldingsy pepper to finish off. fairly strong roast barley character but in a nice fresh toasty/bitter way rather than a pinched tinny way. reminds me of a few of my more unambitious HB stouts - drinkable, simple, good balance of roast, acidity and sweetness.
Bitter malt chocolate aroma. Dark borwn coca cola colour with fair head and alcing. Malt chocolate sweet flavour. Fizzy palate.

Medium creamy lasting head over clear yellow body with carbonation. Sweet faintly grainy malt aroma with notes of caramel and straw. Taste is sweet straw with grassy hop notes, and the signature Tinkoff papery rubber aftertaste. Not bad, but I’d prefer to do without the aftertaste. (0.3l on tap in the Moscow brewpub.)

On the hand pump at Ortinos Northside. Pours a translucent brownish amber with a creamy light tan head that laced and sustained. Aroma was toasty/nutty with hints of hops and grains. Flavor was nice and smooth toasty/nutty, cereal, light hop bitterness, hints of caramel and chocolate.
Cask at Capital Ale House. Deep reddish brown. Aroma was a bit of caramel and some cocoa. Flavor matched, with a sublte hop bitterness at the end. Not bad. Sort of like a pumped up Newcastle.

Poured a hazy brown color with a medium sized, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of nuts, caramel malts, and cocoa. Taste of roasted malts, chocolate, caramel, with light citrus, and mildly bitter, hop finish. Fully attentuated.
Cask at Capital Ale House in Richmond. Slightly hazy reddish brown body with a medium frothy tan head. Sweet molassas and malt aroma. Sweet malty and caramel flavor.
Cask at Capital Alehouse. Red body, medium frothy tan head. Molasses, malt aroma. Tastes like tobacco, disgusting. Palate extremely watery. Bad cask?
Cask @Victory. Dark brown pour with decent head. Smooth, sweet taste with nice hop balance. A very sweet, almost chocolately-malt finish is present. Overall a very pleasant and refreshing brown ale.

On hand pump at victory. Nice dark brown color with large tan head. Some nutty aroma as well as hops. The body was ok it could have been a little thicker. The taste was slighty nutty with sharp hop finish. Nice lacing around glass at the end.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Fat @ Liquid Gold. Mörkbrun öl med ett lätt smutsvitt skum. Doft och smak av malt, karamell, torkad frukt, fikon och alkoholsötma

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Lekko zawód, spodziewa³em siê wiêcej. Ale z³e nie by³o. W aromacie trochê kawy, czuæ rodzynki, trochê alkoholowe, dro¿d¿owe. Piwo bardzo ciemne, doœæ gêste, oblepia szk³o trochê, drobne do œrednich pêcherzyków. W smaku doœæ s³odkie, rodzynkowe, troszeczkê czuæ dro¿d¿e, nieco alkoholowe, wiêc podobnie jak w aromacie. Przyjemny posmak, trochê musuje na podniebieniu, œrednio wysycone. Ogó³em ca³kiem przyzwoite piwo, ale mo¿na by³o liczyæ na wiêcej.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: W aromacie dro¿d¿e, s³odycz, rodzynki, czuæ te¿ niestety alkohol. W smaku s³odkie, czuæ rodzynki, alkohol ca³kiem nieŸle u³o¿ony.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: W aromacie dro¿d¿e, kawa, suszone owoce. W smaku wyraŸne rodzynki, dro¿d¿e, mocno belgijsko, alko trochê czuæ. Rozczarowanie

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Dark brown color. Big, white head . Raisins, toasted caramel, yeasts and dark fruits in the aroma. Moderately sweet with warming ending.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: 28-09-19 // bottle shared at Mon Petit Cafe Suttgart on Zwanze Day 2019. Murky brown. Sweet raisin nose. Yes belgian quad but not too belgian. Has the american touch. Raisins all the way. Touches of vanilla. Good.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Copenhagen 27/9 2019. 75 cl bottle from Fish & Beer, Amagerbrogade, Kbh S. Corked bottle. Lost Valley usual design which looks like a Church window. The Four Horsemen in full Charge on the label. Pours slightly unclear dark Maroon with a red hue. Big off-white head. Settles as thin but unbroken layer of foam covering the surface of the beer. Crawling up the sides of the glass. Substantial Lacing. Aroma is intense and of sweet, fermented, dark fruits with a sharp sour odor. Plums, figs and raisins soaked in alcohol. Sugar, toffee. Sweet, prominent presence of booze. Light carbonation. Medium thick, oily, slightly sticky almost flat texture. Flavor has a strong sweetness on the verge of being sugary. Followed by a moderately strong sourish bitterness. Lingering. Splendid, Damn Sweet - but not too Sweet - Ride Down the Highway to Sweet Hell.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Pours clear, dark mahogany with a full, beige head. Aroma is strong dried fruit, caramel and light roast. Taste is raisin and sugar candy, moving to banana esters, roast and Belgian yeast. Finish is raisin and roast. A good Quad.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: On tap at the Lost Abbey Brewing Co. Wine flavor, slightly on the malty side, reminds me of barley wine flavor. Dominantly malty and caramel scent, with slight note of dry fruit such as raisin. This beer possesses a sour kick and cane sugar flavor.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Pite z butelki na panelu w Morzu Piwa. Wiec ocena z wspomnieñ. Piwo doœæ ciekawe ale spodziewa³em siê leprzego

Medium white head, pale yellow body. Sweet caramelly faintly fruity aroma. Taste is bitter and slightly citric with notes of flour. Bitter, softly metallic aftertaste. Not bad, but lacking in taste. (0.5l bottle.)
0.5 l bottle. Yellow color beer with small head. Aroma of corn, hop, malt. Taste slightly sweet, corn sugar and fruits. Sweet aftertaste.
Nice taste and good price relating to its quality, we really enjoyed the 0,5L.
Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Light bitter flavor. Short light bitter finish. Oily palate.

resin, floral, grass, spruce, citrus, caramel, bread, hay, pale, golden, amber, clear, hazy, cloudy, rocky head, frothy, minimal head, white foam, light sweetness, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium bitterness,
From bottle. Transfer of an earlier rating without text recorded, rating only.
Dunkles Goldgelb mit kurzlebiger Krone. Der Antrunk ist sehr malzbetont, würziger Körper mit Alkoholnoten. Feingehopft im Abgang. Stark Katerverdächtiger Geschmack!
26.11.2016 - A torture to drink this. Needed about an hour for 0,5l bottle. Bad taste and no aroma.
Bottled. 25cl sample. The aroma has grains and grassy herbal tones. Clear, golden coloured beer with a thin, white head. The taste is light bitter, light grainy sweet, has some herbs and grass. Okay.
50 cl bottle. Medium white head. Golden colour. Aroma is alcohol, malts and biscuits. Medium sweet. Grass flavour. Oily texture. Sour finish.
Mild würziger, eher monotoner Beginn. Steigend mit bitteren Beinoten, ein wenig süß. Würzig malzig-karamelliges Ende, hier angenehm. 8/7/8/8/7/8
Bottle 50cl kindly given by Quack-Duck. A clear yellow beer with low head, nose is grassy. Aroma is on hay, body with low complexity, watery, nut notes, vegetable touch, not out standing.

Golden Color with a nice white head, keeps a thin lacing for a while. Aroma is malty and sweet, hints of grass. Flavour is like aroma with more sweet notes. Low to medium carbonation in a light to medium body with a slightly bitter finish.

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Retour aux Racines
