column5: On tap at DDC 15th anniversary. Muddy amber brown pour. Aroma is slightly earthy, ginger, rootbeer, with lots of toffee. Tastes more like rootbeer soda than it smells like. Malty, nice rootbeer flavor. Palate is a tad thin and undercarbed. Interesting little beer.

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Retour aux Racines
column5: Not bad for what it is. Pours cloudy brown with good head and lacing. Some sweet root taste, while still balancing out with the beer side of the affair. Finishes with light sweetness and malty residue on palate. Tap at brewpub.

No head whatsoever. Dark brown, almost black, opaque body. Sweetish, gingery aroma with roasty notes of dark rye bread, with maybe a touch of cinnamon and caramel. Taste is watery ginger and mild roasty bread. No aftertaste. Soft and silky mouthfeel. Harmonic. Reminiscent of traditional Norwegian homebrew like my grandfather made, but of higher quality. Very nice, if not earthshattering. (0.3l, but whether from draft or bottle is not clear.)

Tap at the brewery restaurant. Aroma red fruits, caramel, malty. Hazy deep red colour. Short lasting creamy head. Taste is nicely balanced. Initially caramel, berries, hints of coffee. Then hops kick in floral. Long bitter finish. Carbonation just right. Very good.

Hand bottled to PET from brewery kindly donated by Gurthnar. Red brown color with medium off-white head. Fruity, malty aroma with caramel. Taste malt, hoppy bitterness, some fruitiness. Light hoppy bitterness in fruity finish.
Bottle. Pours hazy brown, white head. Aroma is caramel, malty. Taste is caramel, alcohol, medium bitter.

Ruby red with slightly colored foam , poored so foam goes quickly. Unfiltered , cherries and earth (chocolate ??), slightly sparkling not too sweet. Best of all 3 beers. (Moscow 201204) ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Small offwhite head quickly shrinks into thin film. Deep, dark, reddish brown hazy body. No aroma that I can make out in this smoky brewpub. Taste is sweetish, watery licorice, with a dryish aftertaste. Faint peppery notes. Hoppy background. (0.35l on tap.)

Cask @ GBBF 09, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear dark brown color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to light light heavy malty, dark roasted, burnt, stove. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20090805]

Bottle conditioned from Asda, I think. Cloudy red black, big fluffy beige head, insistent condition. Fruity tart aromas with hints of earthy chocolate, dry bitter yeast and chocolate in the mouth with a much subdued fruitiness lurking at the back, gentle lingering dry bitterness in the finish.
Cask at The London Drinker Festival 2009. Very dark brown with a small froth. Tart berries aroma. Berries flavours blend with slightly dry roast. Light-bodied as appropriate. Old-fashioned mild.

Bottle@BlindTastingSession. Nice complex complex aroma with laurel, licorice, black berries and chocolate. Hazy, dark brown colour, fine light brown head, good lace. Sweetish, sourish and bitter. Unbalanced complexity of fruits, chocolate, laurel and old tea. Quite watery.

Angry fist of Santa tasting at Chris_o’s. Very deep chestnut/ruby with thin beige head. Hey it’s a mild gueze. Some mild choc flavours. It they intended it, it would be brilliant, sweetness from the malts. Very drinkable. Yes it’s infected, but lovely. Interesting.

A Mes rate: bottle at Chris_O’s "Who’s Afraid of the Big Bad Wolf / Hog Fest" tasting. Mid amber with a thin off white head. Earty aroma with a slight sourness. Lemon acidity with a clear lambic like feel thanks to an obvious infection. It’s odd, clearly wrong and I can’t help liking it. Think of a Flemish mild and you are pretty much there. Slight sweetness from the malt puts it quite close to a Duchesse. I’m in two minds here. This is clearly not drinking as the brewer intended it and I know it’s wrong. But I quite like it. So I’m rating it as such. Who cares?
Bottle at chris_o’s cowboy with beasts of a wolfish nature rather than the normal wilderbeast banter. Alround rating: Tart soft brown malts, sour infected beer, but still of relitive drinkability.

Bottle @ Chris_o’s Pre-Beer Exposed Tasting, September 2008. Pours deep nutty brown with a good, creamy, off-white head. Aroma is light raisins, malty and sour grapes. Okay mouthfeel. Flavour is sour and infected. Somehow drinkable anyways (?).

Bottle Conditioned. Pours a dark brown colour with a light brown head.A real biscuit aroma,Plenty of dark malts in the tsaste with a hint of toffee, with a dry malty chocolate finish. A good well balanced beer.
Cask Handpump at the Community Centre, Tarporley 26/01/2007 Some roast aroma. Thick white head. Dark and smooth on the palate with a bitter chocolaty malt finish.
Tried at the Gas Lamp Loungr, Louth. Amber colour with a white head. Soft fruity aroma with malty caramel. Taste light bittersweet to light sweet. Very refreshing.

Gravity poured half-pint at a mini-beer festival in ’The Malcolm Arms’, in the Lincolnshire village of Anton’s Gowt (I kid you not). Deep amber body with a full but swiftly departing white head of bubbles. Malty yet with a very dry finish: the smell was fruity, dark berry type fruits. The taste also dark fruits with some semi-sweetness before the dry finish kicked in. No hop presence detectable until the finish: I found it a strange but not unpleasant brew.
[Cask at the Bacchus Hotel, Sutton-on-Sea] Amber with a thick white head. Rich & fruity at first, but by the end it becomes herby and a little sour, with a moderate dirty bitterness. Not great.

Cask at Green Man, Stamford, Lincolnshire. Amber with a small white head. Grainy Ovaltine and breakfast cereal aroma. That’s not bad, but it’s the taste I don’t like. It’s rounded, leathery malt with a rather oppressive milky Horlicks taste. Some bitterness. The theme here is obviously proprietory bedtime drinks, and it clearly doesn’t work for me.

Cask conditioned at Harbury Beer Fest ’09. Brown amber with no head. In a festival of great beer this was the stinker, there was a fusty, mouldy taste to it, tart and I poured it after a short while. yeeuk.

Bottle conditoned. Poured a mild brown colour with a medium white head. The beer has a real fruit aroma with a real taste that was very fruity with a hint of pears. The beer has a bitter hoppy aftertaste.

Draught Orange-amber-gold with a very persistent, just off-white head. Served way too cold. Malty, with a touch of seaweed (iodium?), mild-sweet. Oppressive malts taste, grainy, very toasted & almondy. Some garden herb flavours, like aniseed. Medium bodied, mild alcoholburn. Another Lefebvre labelbeer; probably Bonne Esperance.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: Tallboy can. Clear golden color with bubbles. Dusty pear aroma. Taste is sweet sweet pear. Perfect for Americans who want pear juice and bubbles.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: Draft. A nice very decent cider unfortunately on the tale end of a cider night. Want to try again on a fresh palate. What I noticed of it has me coming back for more. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: Well, that one was picked by my wife. Although the idea was good to try pear juice, you don't taste the pear.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: Disgusting! Absolutely disgusting drink. Very little pear flavor, sugar is used to cover up the alcoholic flavor due to the poor quality of the fruit used if any. Aromatics are added that do not fit the drink flavor to cover up more of the poor quality. Extremely over priced as well. This should be $1 dollar a can and that is still too much. This is the worst cidar I have ever drank.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: Pours straw gold with no head. Aroma is apple and pear. Taste is sweet and tart with notes of pear, apricot and mango. Light and fizzy. I’m not big on ciders but this is a better than average one.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: Pint can at Lulu’s Pizza. Initial pour has bubbly head, which fades fast, clear golden body with lazy carbonation. Aroma seems more apples than pears, as does taste. A bit more pear flavor comes in late, finishes clean. Summer quencher.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: Still having trouble rating ciders. Figuring out though that I prefer variations like pear, apricot, mango, etc. over the standard apple. This is one of the popular and trendy ones. Seen it at restaurant or bars to pair with dinner or mixtails and such. Has a dry flavor and feel. Not overly sweet. There is a little tartness at the end. Appearance is a super light green-yellow. Seems a little mass-produced...but not bad.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: 500 ml can. Pours a clear, pale yellow with a thin, fizzy, white head. Aroma of tart pears and sugar. Sweet and tart flavour of pears with a dry finish. Light body with a sticky texture and fizzy carbonation. Tastes like a soda.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: 500ml can. A very pale yellow clear body, small white head with residual foam. Aroma of fermented pears and apples, white wine, candies. Refreshing taste of green grapes and pears, hints of apples and caramel. Much more sour than I expected.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: Nice colour, great deal of carbonation. Nice on the nose, very light tasting, very distinctive wne flavours. Wouldnt buy again.

Bottled 33cl. It pours a golden beer with a small whitish head. Lots of bubbles rising from the bottom of the glass. The nose has all the typical Feldschlösschen elements. Soy sauce, lemon, bad cheese and garlic?! Decently hoppy. Some sulphur. The taste is mainly of rotten cheese and vegetables. The mouthfeel is horrible. Rather metallic. Some earthy hops show up. A hint of lemon. The finish is of vegetables, soy sauce and lemon.

Bottled, thanks Bov! Deep golden. Pea soup aroma. Medium bodied with sweetish macro-lager like boiled vegetable flavour. The mouthfeel is raw and mellow. No bitterness. Oh, so Carlsberg owns Feldschlösschen? That explains it...

clear golden colour with a persistant little foam and a nice lacing; decent herbal hoppiness; clean palate and a medium malt body, creamy mouthfeel and a late moderate bitterness; more malts and herbs in the finish - I cannot believe it but I think Feldschlösschen has just brewed a second decent beer !
Draft. Aroma of caramel. Flavors follow nose as this is a sweet version of the style. Bit of chewy oak on the finish.

[Tap] Tried this at the brewpub in mid-September. Pours a bright orange color with a wispy white head on top. Light caramel, straw and astringent grain nose. The taste was pretty disappointing. Pale lager-like cracker and light caramel malt backbone. No major off flavors. Very light for the style. Looked pretty good, but otherwise I did not enjoy this one very much.

Draft at the brewpub. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head that leaves some lace. Faint aroma, with notes of caramel malt, dry grains, crackers, and mild spice. Flavor of toasty and caramel malts, graham crackers, sugar, grassy hops, and citrus. Light-medium bodied, with medium carbonation. Bitter for the style, with a dry finish. Mediocre Oktoberfest.

Sampled at the brewpub. Pours orange / amber with a solid tight head. The aroma has sweet caramel malt and bits of spice, fairly clean. Medium body that is lighter than normal for a marzen. There is some gentle carbonation. Flavor starts with caramel mal that is a bit grainy. Not very sweet. There is some nuttiness and hints of stone fruits. The finish gets slightly medicinal and astringent but pulls back to what it should be. There is a lingering taste of bitter lemon for some reason. Okay Oktoberfest.

Sample #3 from the brew pub. Caramel amber hue. Filtered with a clinging spotty off-white head. Slight caramel, cocoa and bread in the nose. Lively and rich. Medium bodied. Bready malts and a nice hop dryness in the finish. Good balance.

tap at brewpub-carme lamber with no head but my date had a glass of this and it had a good head-go figure! toasted wet grains on the nose with some light spicy notes from german hops. pretty true to style on the nose. amber grains dominate the flavors with a little hops on the finish. pretty standard for the course, but not bad. body suffers somewhat and their yeast tone from this brewery I could never get into it. I think they repitch too many times.

On Tap at the brewery Copper with an almost red kind of tint to it. Thin white head that is quickly discipating. The nose is your typical marzen with malt and some cream. The taste reminds me a lot of the spaten oktoberfest with its malt and cream. Overall a very solid oktoberfest.
Pours a bright gold with a big white head. Not much aroma. Has a sweet toasted maltiness with notes of maple syrup, toffee and spice. A very good effort.

Beautiful crystal clear dark golden amber color with a small white head. Clean biscuit malt aroma but not much else. That continues into the taste with a light dry woodiness. Light medium caramel sweetness balanced by a nice earthy bitterness. Doesn't really have the German fest bier flavor. Good amber beer but not really a Marzen/Oktoberfest.
Aroma is caramel and mildly sweet bread/malts. The flavor is fruit, malts, caramel and a medium sweet/grainy finish. Smooth, easy to drink, pretty decent.

This is yet another supermarket beer that I consider to be underrated for what it is. C'mon folks, it's a contract beer from Trader Joe's not an import from Germany. And for that matter, you can get 12 ounces for less than a buck 1.50, so sometimes you have to either adjust your price point or adjust your expectations. This Lager pours copper-colored. The head is nice while it lasts, but it doesn't have the greatest retention. Grainy sweet malt smells and flavors. A bit of leafy hop bitterness near the end. Body is light-medium. Carbonation is just shy of sharp - just a bit too lively but not by much. Quite decent overall.

$1.08 bottle, Trader Joe's. Golden Orange with a small white head. Aroma is brown leaf, light caramel, hint of smoke. Flavor is very similar: brown leaf and grass, black tea, black pepper, light smoke. Really not bad - a bit thin, but a buck well spent.

12 oz bottle from Trader Joe's, poured into a tulip glass. Clear copper with a white head with long lasting lacing. Toasty, peppery aroma, light caramel, cloves and sweet malts, toffee. Nice drinking beer!
Clear copper with a white head. A little bready up front with zest earthy hops. Toasted malt, too. Medium bodied. Surprisingly nice.

12 ounce bottle Trader Joes is not known for stellar beer. However for less than $1.25 a bottle the cost of entry is pretty low. As a result it got thrown in with the other beers. One is enough; I am not likely to find myself going back again unless the beer budget gets very tight. If Gordon Biersch is your thing though give it a try. Aroma / Appearance - The cloudy coppery body manages to maintain an average clam presence that is the highlight of this beer. The snowy head and idle carbonation trap a mixture of Wurthers, malt, and semisweet chocolate chips. Crispness and freshness can do little to mask a "meh" bill. Flavor / Palate - Dry, light, and crisp malts get the job done with little fanfare. There’s not much depth or many style points. Fortunately it also lacks any glaring flaws. This just simply is. One is enough to confirm why I rarely pick up the Josephbrau brand.

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Clear light brown brew with tan head. Nice aroma of caramel malt, some complexity in the malt notes, and simple light grassy hops. Taste is standard issue Oktoberfest - slightly sweet up front with a decent degree of hops in the finish. Its not a standout but holds its own and compares favorably to more prominent brands. Pretty good.
From the bottle. Malty aroma, light head, medium carbonation. Golden copper color. Sweet malt up front, light bitter hop finish that fades quickly. Easy drinking beer.
Copper gold tint, clear beer with a light foamy white lace ring head. Aroma is vienna malt. Flavor is light and bitter with a medium malt backbone. It was almost gone before I could rate it.

Cask. Clear hazelnut brown with a small white head. Not much to it; light dark berries, dark bread, wood, light brown sugar. Light body, watery texture, light sweet and acidic. Short light sticky finish. Nah.
Cask at The Bell in Waltham st Lawrence. Dark golden beer. English bitter with dry lemon. Must be the tea coming through.
Cask @ White Swan, Hebden Bridge. Golden with a small head. Has a mild sweet berry aroma and taste with the nose being more dominant. Easily a session ale.

Cask at the Bear (JDW), Maidenhead. Amber with a loose cream head; perfumed aroma that immediately made me think of tea - at first I wondered if this was just the power of suggestion from the name, so I was glad to see that there was tea in the recipe; in the mouth it’s very soft with a malty body and an immediate fresh herbal tea-based bitterness; that gives a long dry finish. Certainly full of flavour, and an interesting one at that.

8th April 2013 Sir John Oldcastle Spoons. Clear gold beer, little white head. Fresh light palate with fine carbonation. Mild fresh pale malt. Mild minerals. Pleasant light hops - light lemon with a touch of noble hop like greeness. Whisper of herb. Light crispy finish. In very nice condition and pretty drinkable. Didn’t notice any tea!
Cask at Ascot Festival 2011. Pours a dark amber with a firm white head. The aroma is all floral hops, the taste is malty with carmel with a dry bitter finish.
Cask (Southampton Beer Festival 2010) - Copper coloured. Tea, malt and dried fruit feature in the aroma. Malty and fruity taste with hints of dried fruit, tea, nuts and caramel.
Cask @ Wenlock Arms, Clear amber with no head. Aroma has dusty hops and mild fruity notes. Moderate sweet flavor with caramel, floral hops and malty notes.
Cask handpull at Wenlock Arms. Some flowery hop, some malt. Bit bleachy acidic aroma. Bit harsh and thin.

Tasted by half-pint at the Magpie&Crown, Brentford, W. London. Served by a handpump. Appearance: translucent, dark amber hue, coming with a nice foamy head and low carbonation. Smell: like another Itchen Valley’s beer tasted immediately before this one ("Wykehams Glory"), the nose is full of aromatic floral hops, which falls behind a sweet peary fruitiness. Simple in composition, but very harmonious and pleasant. Taste: biscuity malts with a mildly caramely edge leads the palate, quickly ensued by a mildly citric, tangy taste of hops and more Fuggles-like bitterness in the end. Good structure. Palate: softly fizzy on the mouthfeel, light-bodied, refreshing... This bitter comes with a good flavour profile and enough hop presence to make it taste more interesting (besides being fresher and nicer in condition) than the Wykeham’s Glory tasted immediately beforehand, hence slightly higher in total score. Not bad~~

At first it seemed as a regular Polish fruit beer. It had, however, some actual lager flavour in the end that made it up for the raspberry flavour. Not that terrible, as far as the fruit beers go in this country.

Bottle, poured a dark amber, lots of carbonation, and a large pillowy white head. A strong malty aroma with a belgian-like yeastiness. Yeasty, a good hoppiness, some sweetness and a hint of chocolate on a smooth palate. Just a little raw, like homebrew.
Bottle - September 2006 A Lot of sediment. A deep brown color, turbid, white head. Aroma is of skunk and yeast. Infected, phenolic awfull taste. Avoid.
Tap, Brewpub, Ann Arbor, MI, USA. Medium gold. Bready aroma. Sweet honey flavour. Some spice but overpowered by sweetness.
tap at the brewpub - Pours yellow-gold and has a light cereal grain and citrus fruit aroma. The flavor is sweet with some light bitterness in the finish and a light body. It’s okay.
Starts of just a typical pale later, hut it ends up having a decent amount of hops. Not bad.
The aroma was decent, color and head were ok. The taste is better than one would expect. I suggest this beer for summer sipping.

On tap at the brewpub. The body was dark gold with a white head. The aroma was malty with some potatoes. The flavors were bread and potatoes with some pecans. There was also some strangeness in the nasty finish.

Draught sample at the brewpub, early August 2006. I am SOOO excited that brewpubs are now getting in the act of producing clones of past masterpieces like Schlitz and Natty Boh, let me tell you. Anyway....pale gold with a smallish ring of head, no lacing....faintly grassy, corn-sugarish aroma, reasonably fresh but dull....odd cidery character on the tongue with a trace of ashes, a bit of DMS shows up in the nose as it warms to almost room temp....seems a bit off, overall.
On-tap in Gardner. Very decent maltiness and drinkability. Nice copper color - good mouthfeel - medium bodied, and somewhat refreshing.

From old tasting notes. Pale yellow gold color. Light grainy malt nose. Faint tart Apple taste. Sour grainy finish. Watery and cheap. Back in the 1970’s, you could buy a case of 16 ounce returnables for under $5.00.

Someone I know from the Scranton, PA area bragged to me about how great this beer was so he brought me one. First off the label looked like I made it on my HP Deskjet 400. I have seen better homebrew labels. It was in a 16 oz returnable which was cool. As for the beer? it was thin, fizzy, and pale yellow. It had NO aroma. It was watery and had almost zero flavor, and what little flavor was there reminded me on a watered down Olde English. All I can say is this beer is a conversation piece.
Mild hop nose, with a hint of malt, golden,and a tiny white head. A dusty hops taste, slight malt also. Light bodied, sweet. Average.

Draught. Clear yellow-golden with a small white head. The aroma has rather sweet malts and faint influential fruitiness and cereal. Clean palate with some fruit flavour, sweet cereal, and creamy bitterness in the finish. Mediocre.

On tap at the brewpub. Clear gold ale with fine smallish top. Grainy, slightly medicinal aroma, sweet grassy top. Sweet, light bodied, gentle with medium/strong carbonation. Character dominated by pale mats. Short finish (watery).

tap on the premises. clear light brown reddish with a small off-white head, some retention and lacing. fruity maltiness, toasted cereals - still far from a certain level of roastiness, low but present umami and slightly bitter coffee components - this is the closest it gets as to its smoky AND porter profile, bit of lactose-like sweetness, grassy and peppery notes. moderate carbonation, light body, short grassy-spicy finish. blah.
Bottle at my parents. Mildly floral, fruity. Light smooth bitter taste. Hint of citrus. It’s alright.

Bottle from Hasegawa. Light citrus and grass notes on the nose. Above average carbonation with a light body. Some light pine and more citrus on the palate. Slightly harsh bitter finish. Unbalanced but not terrible. Pretty standard.
A dark golden beer with a yellowish head. The aroma has notes of citrusy fruits, malt, and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, citrusy fruits, hops, and straw, leading to a bitter finish.
33 cl bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma is mild fruity, yeasty. Bitter, citrusy. Bretty like. Crisp grassy and bitter fruity finish.
Bottle at Ungstrup. Clear amber colored with a medium sized white head. Fruity aroma of hops with notes of brett. Fruity flavor of hops and pine needles with notes of brett. Hoppy finish.
Hazy golden pour, white head. Faint aroma, fruity, orange perhaps. Mild taste, some bitterness towards the end. Soft mouthfeel, not too heavy on the carbonation. Decent ale but nothing special.
From a bottle poured a copper color with a good amount of head. Light hoppy flavor with a quick finish.
On tap at rakubeer hiroshima. Easy drinking APA. Some citrus notes and a slight bitterness. Light carbonation. Enjoyable but not memorable ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pleasant hoppy citrus nose. Grapefruit flavor, bread, floral bitter finish. Quite bitter for a fruity ale, almost with an IPA mouthfeel.
Tap at Yellow Ape. Light amber golden colour, white frothy head. Aroma is hoppy, citrus, biscuits. Taste is pleasantly bitter, citrus, biscuit malt, decent. Nice carb.

Sampler glass. Different brewer, different recipe than last summer’s German Hefeweizen. In the sampler glass, it’s cloudy yellow, almost wit colored, with a short, bubbly head. Smells pretty clean, with low esters. Taste starts with a load of banana and a bit of vanilla, but doesn’t sacrifice a good, basic wheat and barley malt background. Clean wheat balance, no lingering taste when done. Earlier Rating: 10/9/2006 Total Score: 3.4 Draft. This would be fine served in their chilled mug, but I think it killed the smell until I could warm it up a little. Cloudy yellow with streaks of orange. When I do get some aroma, it’s just a nice enervating wheat malt. Taste is bit closer to orange than the lemon of other German weizens. I get more of the gently wheat. Only a slight hint of the style’s usual banana and clove, but I didn’t really missit, until some ’nanner came up later when I burped… pard’ me!

Well hazed golden, near opaque with a holding white head. Banana, banana and more banana in the nose. Thick creamy mouth with a hearty, fruity, yeasty flavor. I like the smell and taste of bananas, so I’m cool with this brew but I would normally hope for a little more complexity. On tap at Rock Bottom Yorktown, Lombard, IL 60148

An original from Chris Boggess’ recipe book: Kind of scary looking, actually, the cloudiest hefeweizen that I’ve ever seen. The creamy head that does excellent lacing makes up for the frightening look of the body. The aroma is strong with fresh bananas and a touch of clove. Nice & creamy mouthfeel. Plenty of the bananas, some wheat, clove, and other spices make up the taste. Slated as a Summer special, this is a refreshing drink however late in the season. And despite its disturbing appearance. Rock Bottom Yorktown, Lombard, IL

column1: Baird American Dream Strong Pale Ale
column5: Med-dark amber color. Smells like the fruit cups I used to bring to school in junior high, grapes, bananas, apples, kiwi. Well balanced mouth with some grapenuts. Slight hop bitterness, but not too hoppy. Bitter dry grapefruit finish. Lighter body than I expected, but nice.

column1: Baird American Dream Strong Pale Ale
column5: golden brown in color with an off white head. butterscotch nose with citrus floral overtones. bitter hop character up front. not a strong pale feel more of a standard pale. tangy extract malt tips that stick to your palate. a low abv for a strong ale but i guess still in its class. would work out to be better in just plane "pale" genre.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Nice dark amber in color, very clear, with a off white head. The smoking on this brew was excellent, not over the top, but not weak by any means. The bartender said this was a smoked porter, but didn’t seem like a porter to me. Great caramel sweetness up front that really just mixed very smoothly with the smokiness. This brew never felt out of synch, all the flavors just worked perfectly together, and I never got tired of this beer (as I do with some smoked beers) just a delight to drink the whole way through. The best collaborator brew so far in my opinion.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On Tap At Widmer Brothers brewery/pub in Portland OR. pours out a almost black topped with a small off white head. A good smoke on this one. Almost like smoked salmon

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On tap at Oaks Bottom. Aroma of chocolate, swet wood smoke, caramel with just a little burnt edge. birch beer-ish color, slightly darkened & thin head. kind of anonymous in the mouth. falvor on the sweet side, maple, something dark & dry. more like a smoked baltic porter than anglo-american, unique but not fully realized.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Collaborator Project in the form of a smoked porter on tap at Oaks Bottom. Definite smoked malt aroma. Super-clear beer, darkest of browns with a ruby hue when backlit. Fair off-white head with no lacing left behind. Nice smoked flavor plays well with the chocolate dominant malt flavors. A bit thin in body. Nicely done, just a bit lacking in body flavor.

Bottle- Pours a deep amber body with brownish hues. The head is short lived and pink. Nose is fruit(strawberry) and sugar and weird malts and a slight funk. Tart and sweet strawberry, with very sweet malts and some burnt sugars with very little in the way of balancing(hops). Caramel malt and fruit finish. Cloying, messy, nope, not again. Thanks Dave!

tried at the c’est what? spring beer night. Very similar to the debeau cherry, this must be another failed experiment. Another fruit beer that doesnt taste of fruit at all, i’m getting more caramel from the maltiness than anything else. there is a slight fruity tinge in the aroma, and i’m not een sure its strawbeery. dismal at best.

[164-20061228] 200mL. Smells like really rotten fermented strawberries and strong chocolate. Clear, dark brown body with no head but white bubbles. Flavour is reminiscent of chocolate-covered strawberries. Medium body with an interesting roundness. Terrible first impression but eventually evened out.

Bottle from the brewery. Brown with ruby tints and a tiny head. Sweet aroma of caramel malt, with mild hints of strawberry and pink bubblegum. Same light body as the cherry. Flavour follows the aroma - sweet malt, very faint strawberry. Like the cherry beer, it’s not bad, just boring, and doesn’t have much fruit character.

Bottle courtesy of GregClow. Pours a hazy dark ruby-brown with a spare diminishing off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, some strawberries but not much and a hint of spices -- pretty blah. Flavour of caramel malt and a light taste of strawberries and chocolate. Light bodied. Pretty mediocre stuff.

Dark brown in colour with low carbonation. Aromas of strawberry, chocolate, and caramel. There’s also a bit of a boozy note, which seems out of place for a 5.5% beer. More chocolate-caramel flavors in the mouth, with a bit of stale coffee and sweet strawberry extract. Hollow palate in spite of the sweetness. It might pass as a dessert beer. Needs some acidity and some more pale malt to balance things out. Thanks to gregclow for the sample.

A dark reddih ruby brown ale with a thin off white head. Aroma is of light porto, berries and maderized cardboad. In mouth, a dead stalre beer, with a light residual sugar, light strawberry extract, no body, a bit of a stale watery brew. Bottle courtsey of KProbst, Oct. 2006.

Bottle (200ml - clear). Courtesy of GregClow. Deep clear ruby with a large frothy slightly pink lasting head. Aroma is very much like their Debau-Cherry - pretty lush strawberry & cream up front, soon devolving to mildly papery caramel malt with some herbal notes - this one’s a little more appealing than the ’Cherry - and a sweeter, too. The taste is again a big let-down - slightly tart strawberry gives way to stale cardboard malt and a stale bitterness in the finish. Watery, thin, flat body, slightly ugly aftertaste - interesting, but not a success.

Bottle. Brown body with a small off white head with a light pink tint fades. Sweet aroma with notes of vanilla extract, and rooty notes over a rather muted strawberry, and slight notes of chocolate. Flavour is muted and muddled. Sweet malt, hints of cocoa and very muted strawberry. average palate is a touch flat but slightly more full bodied than average. A bit muted and simplistic at times but hints at potential - needs more of everything, more oomph. I was a bit worried opening this one since the bottle of their wheat I opened earlier in the day was very badly infected, but this one showed no such signs and was pleasant.

200ml Bottle, thanks to GregClow for obtaining it from the brewery: This one starts off great with a deep ruby brown pour with a creamy head accompanied by excellent lacing. The aroma is ripe, real strawberries with noticeable alcohol notes and demara sugar. Sadly, things take a bend right around tasting time. The strawberries are muted, as I’d hoped, but sadly so is everything else. The sugar and alcohol are mildly present - too much alcohol for 5.5% - but the entire thing tastes watered down. No mouthfeel, no substance, no body at all. If they can figure the process out I think the potential is big; reality, not so much.

column1: Newport Beach Snug Harbor Honey Ale
column5: Sampled on 4/18/2010 at the brewery/brewpub. This fruit beer pours a medium orange gold color from the tap. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity and sweet with some honey. Medium bodied fruit beer. The malts are fruity and sweet. The hops are slightly floral. Nice balance. Decent carbonation. This beer really tastes like a blonde ale with honey added. It tastes better than that but it certainly has that feel to it. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

On tap @ Newport Beach Brewing. Amber pour with a white head. Aroma is sweet caramel, toast, and bread. Somewhat grassy, some earthy and spicy hops, and yeast. Nice sweetness to the flavor. Big caramel and toast. A touch of wax, some grass, and spicy hops. Mild bitterness and a touch yeasty.
Clear amber with no head. Spicy caramel aroma. Medium body . Flavor is rich with caramel malt and Oktoberfest spice with a mildy bitter finish. Pretty nice.

# 3505 ersma: erstaunlich. verschiedene hefe-farben sind mir so noch gar nicht aufgefallen, aber anscheinend gibt es hefe-dunkel und hefe-hell als farbbezeichnung... dunkelbrau, trübe mit mittlerer verschäumung. der geruch ist hefig mit leicht getreidigen noten. der antrunk  hefebetont, dahinter malzige süße mit leicht röstigen noten. schnell kommen herbe aromen hinzu, die ab der mitte einen stumpfen gaumen machen. der abgang ist leicht röstmalzig, getreidig, herb und hat nur noch wenig hefe-aromen. flasche: die etiketten sind ok, kämen aber auch mit weniger schriftarten aus. fazit: recht hefelastig. aber noch gut trinkbar. 11,9,9,10,10,9 - 9,40
0.5 l bottle at Bootsverleih, Marburg... Nice dark clody color, good head... Nice smokey malt and banana aroma... Mild Weizen taste... Nice smokey ending...

Herb-strohiger Antrunk mit unpassendem Malzaroma. Da dies eh nur sehr midl ist und von einer säuerlichen Wässrigkeit überdeckt wird, spielt es aber sowieso keine große Rolle. Oberflächlich deutlich herber werdend, auch die Säuerlichkeit nimmt zu. Eine Fruchtnote fehlt völlig. Das Malz kommt kaum noch zur Geltung, das Bier wird im Abgang muffig. 10/6//6/5/9/6

Bottle: Hazy, mahagony coloured, bigger fluffy tanned head, that slowly collapses; caramelly-sourish aroma with a touch of bananas; moderate sweetish (malty)-sourish flavour, light bodied; toasted malt and bananas in the finish, meeting there a light acidity. Not bad, but not my favourite style......

(bottle, from pivnizub) Hazy, murky brown colour with a huge and stable beige foamy head. Sweet and toasty wheat aroma with notes of banana, caramel and cloves. Medium-sweet flavour, light to medium body, quite smooth carbonation for a Weizen. Slightly toasty, wheat-malty taste with a touch of caramel and a shy fruitiness; short, medium-dry, wheaty and clovy finish. Probably brewed in Herborn (or elsewhere).

Draft. An unclear amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel as well as lighter notes of spices. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel as well as lighter notes of spices and nuts.

On tap at the brewery in August 2009. A: Pours a dark gold and is fairly cloudy. White head that is fairly long-lasting. S: A little bit of roasted malt, some hops, and a little bit of citrus. T: Roasted caramel taste with a bit of earthy and citrus hop. M: Light-to-medium body with a moderate amount of carbonation. D: Fairly drinkable; interesting and somewhat complex, but not one I would return to again and again. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 10-04-2009

Sampled during RBSG 7/11/2009 on tap at the brewery. This California Common pours a medium orange gold color from the tap. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity and sweet. A medium bodied California Common. The malts are fruity and sweet. The hops are earthy and floral. Big full mouthfeel with a softer carbonation. Nice balance. Good carbonation. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
US trip Aug/Sept 2009 - On tap at RR. Nice and clean beer, didn’t notice the 40IBU. Well brewed, but why?

A reddish amber ale with a thin lacing white head. In aroma, a lightly nutty malt with light cinnamon notes, In mouth, a light oily and nutty ale with more of a german twist, like a good vienna. On tap at brewpub, August 17 2009.

&#40Draught&#41 Pours a hazy golden body with a medium off-white head. Aroma of mustiness, leather, wet hay, light caramel, some peat, and earth. Flavor of grass, earth, tea, peat, and wet wood that somewhat reminiscent of a river stream flowing over moss covered rocks in the mountains. Good steam beer.

Generous 10 ounce sample on tap at the brewpub at RBSG. Spicy, herbal, peppery hop aroma with some light mustiness. Pretty grainy with some cereal, too. Moderately hazy amber body present with a pretty frothy off-yellowish head and nice lacing. Chewy, roasty, biscuity malt start. Lightly metallic, chewy, and a bit of herbal hop to finish. Drinkable, tasty, and good for a "steam" beer.
On tap. Hazy amber golden with an off-white head. Sweet caramellish nose. Medium body, lightly sweet caramel notes with some fruit. Fairly dry and hoppy finish. 110709
Clear orange with a fizzy white head. Floral malty aroma. Brassy citrus and caramel taste. Decent.

On tap at the brewpub. Mostly transparent, coppery amber colored body with a finger of fizzy off-white head. Aromas of lightly toasty malt and some mild-moderate minty hops. Low-moderate fruity ester qualities and a faint caraway-like spiciness in the background. Medium bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel with a soft, malty texture. Somewhat sweet, lightly toasted malt with a rye-bread flavor profile. A moderate hop presence balances the malt nicely and provides an earthy, minty flavor. Moderate fruity esters provide a subtle red fruit dimension that enhances the malt perception somewhat. Clean and pleasant to drink and showcases all of the stylistic dimensions nicely, but a bit more of an assertive hop character would be nice.

September 13, 2018 - at The Pineapple - on handpull cask. Clear gold, small off-white head. Simple dry golden ale aroma with a bit of fruit for some sweetness (7-). Taste follows, a little apple, oddly but not unwelcome at all. Light body, airy, mildly astringent, quick-finishing and no real aftertaste; decently dry and clean.

Pours a clear light golden colour with a small thick foamy near white head. Aroma is predominately light pale malt and a little fruit. A sweet light malt taste, smooth and light fruitiness with a citrusy hop bitterness in the finish.

Cask Half Pint at Kingston Beer Festival, Kingston, Surrey, June 2009 - Pale Gold wheat beer. Very citrus fruity; grapefruit. Lots of grassy hops. Bitter fruity hoppy throughout. Dry hoppy finish. Nice Beer! (2009-06

3/5 rDev n/a Pint at the Willow Walk JDW. A: Bronze, clear, small head. S: Quite malt, almost like a Euro Lager. T: Chestnut, toffee, caramel. M: Not much in the way of carbonation, smooth. O: More of a beer for the cold weather, nothing really stood out.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 2015, Great British Beer Festival, London Olympia, Hammersmith Road, London, England W14 8UX. [ As Twickenham Pale Beauty ]. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy and open, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, light to moderate hoppy, fruity, buterscotch notes. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, pale malt - wheat, fruity, nutty notes. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20150811]
Powerful! The word struck me as soon as I took my first hit.....Very hoppy, with hints of green flowing throughout. As per the description, robust is another word I would use.

Aroma: grain, wheat malts, floral hops. Appearance: clear gold, large, frothy, white head. Taste: light bitter. Palate: bitters continue and intensify, some grass, light lemon. Overall: decent Wheat Ale. Pint at GBBF 2015, Kensington Olympia.

Draught, cask at the GBBF 2015 (London Olympia) on 14-Aug-2015. Pale golden ale, with medium sized white head. Fresh wheat and citrus aroma. Flavour of wheat, lemon, caramel, spices. Medium hopped and a bitter finish.
Cask at GBBF 2015. Pale golden beer with an offwhite head. Hoppy wheaty grassy floral aroma. Hoppy grassy caramell spicy flavour.

Cask at JDW, Tower Hill. It pours a hazy straw color with a medium white head. Aroma is grassy hoppy crispy lightly grainy and citrusy. Taste is medium bitter and lightly grassy and wheaty, with nice clean citrus bitter finish. Quite fruity hops going on here. Light to medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, excellent

column1: Great Basin Brown Ale (Stans the Mans)
column5: on tap with nitro. brown to red pour with a small tan head. the nitro smooths out the finnish

column1: Great Basin Brown Ale (Stans the Mans)
column5: Tap at Brewpub: Dark mahogany, light head and lacing. Nose of sweet fruity california style simcoe with a very small amount of cascade and some nuttiness. Very hoppy yet balanced. Nice finish. Not really a brown ale, but it’s good. This recipe stands out much different from the others here. Oh yeah, that’s right, it wasn’t all them.

"this one is the least interesting of the whole bunch...and we had the Gold!! i enjoy cream ales on occasion (ie-Anderson Valleys winter & summer solstice), but this one is thoroughly boring, lacking in aroma and flavor even next to their other weaker styles."
Doesn’t look like a cream ale at all. Little aroma. This is pretty disappointing. Not that creamy or interesting.
on tap-pours a white head and yellow/gold color. Aroma is light sulphur, grain. Taste is sweet grain with some bite.
On tap at brewpub Appearance: Clear golden with a small white head, good amount of lacing Aroma: Yeast, some light citrus Taste: Malts, spices and yeast OK beer, not much to it.
A golden ale with a thin lacing white head. A lightly sulfury aroma, with light buffer aroma. In mouth, a crisp lightly sweet beer, light and boring. On tap at brewpub, August 2007.
Tap at Brewpub: Gold, nice head and lacing. Nose of light hops (fruity; strawberry) and some dry pale malt. The flavor is balanced, a bit of malty body and a fruity tail. Eh.

the cloudy yellow brew smelled nice before it even got to my nose. zesty, highly carbonated body. a little light, but a spicy, refreshing representation of the style. not quite enough to seperate it from being a mid-packer, but good if it’s what yer in the mood for."

Great spice taste combined with a little citrus. Drank this beer with Great Basin’s Sonoran Fish Tacos and the combination was fabulous! Probably a beer for those who like very flavorful beers versus hoppy beers
This at least looks the part. Very fruity with a very strong wheat flavor. Better than the American hefe they call a German style, but not great.

2010, 2011, bronze world beer cup winner. 3rd best wit in the world. Perfectly blended with coriander, orange peel, and lavender. Belgian yeast give off a lot of fruity esters. Refreshing perfect summer beer, light and happy. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
on tap @GABF-pours hazy straw with a white ring. Aroma is soft wheat, spice. Taste is sweet wheat, light malt, clove, 2nd spice hops.

Date: July 05, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy yellow, fine white head, drippy lace Aroma: light spicy wheat aroma, hint of citrus Flavor: light wheat flavor, nice sweet orange, spicyness comes in to balance it all Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: *4
(Draught) Pours a cloudy pale yellow body with a small white head. Aroma of wheat, coriander, lemon, orange peel, and bread. Flavor of wheat, orange, light lemon, and coriander.

Tap at the brewpub. The body was hazy pale yellow. The aroma was strong corriander with some grassy notes. The taste was strong orange peels with some bitterness. This was a drinkable light wit, but still a little off.
Tap @ brewpub: Light gold with a small white ring head. Sweet aroma with a little egg-fart tossed in. Mild and sweet flavors.
On-Tap at the Brewery Sparks NV, Pours out a hazy gold topped with a small head. Very nice aroma of citrus and grains. Nice sweet tast of fruit and light malts.
Pour was an amber with a creamy head, and quite good lacing. Aroma of hops, malt, and earthiness. Flavors of caramel, malt, hops, and citrus. A pretty good APA, but nothing that stands out.

Tap at Brewpub: Pale bronze color, light head and lacing. Nose of light dry malt and some cascade dryness; a bit earthy. The flavor is balanced, very approachable. The finish is light, dry, musky. Eh.

column1: Silver Peak B Dubs Double Hopped IPA
column5: "a solid take on the style, although i may actually prefer the hop profile in their regular ipa a touch more. good balance, but a ton of amarillos and columbus hops as well. strong hoppy aroma and thick resinous body (better than the ipa)...overall, quite good, but not near the best."

column1: Silver Peak B Dubs Double Hopped IPA
column5: On draft at the restaurant. Aroma: citrusy hop,toasted/toffee malts Taste: toffee, pine/citrus/floral hops, caramel sweetness Silver Peak does a great job on their hoppy beers. I really enjoyed this one.

column1: Silver Peak B Dubs Double Hopped IPA
column5: Draft @ Silver Peak. Pours a bright, clear orange-amber color; off-white head with excellent retention and medium-bubbled lacing; nice looking pour. Earthy hop character and an orange peel note in the nose; very earthy, a touch of reserve here. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: loads of juicy earthy and citrus bitterness: dense orange and lightly toasty maltiness; excellent, resiny hops, very juicy, with just a touch too much sweetness at the core; would love to see this even a touch drier; great hop character. Reminds me a lot of Drakes Denogginizer, actually, though a touch less brash. Lasting earthy and citrus bitterness; resiny, nicely bitter and toasty end.

column1: Silver Peak B Dubs Double Hopped IPA
column5: Pretty decent for an IPA, but to thin for an IIPA. Crisp start then a sweet malt, fruit, and citrus flavor. Quite a nice fruit flavor. Finishes with some hops. A nice refreshing beer, but not real strong or thick for an IIPA.

column1: Silver Peak B Dubs Double Hopped IPA
column5: Tap at Brewpub: Caramel color, light head and lacing. Nose of sweet crispy candy like malts and hops. The flavor is chewy, not much bitterness, but nice body and finish. Fruity! Fairly strong alcohol taste for the low percentage (so they say). Decent!

Draft: Rather transparent yellow color with a small white head. Light lacing. Nose is faint of citrus and wheat, a little malt. Taste is rather thin and feels mostly like lager malt and faint hops. At least it showed signs of being crisp! Light bodied and lacks definitive flavor.

Tap at Brewpub:Murky yellowish gold with no head. The aromas are of honey, lemon and sweet spices. The taste is a tangy yeast, cola and wheat. The feel is almost thin, but leaves a nice flavor in the mouth. It didn’t seem as fragile as many American wheats.

Tap at Brewpub: Light hazy yellow/gold color. Nice head and lacing. Nose of light wheat, some light fruity hop notes. Pretty blank here. The flavor is light, balanced and a bit of wheat shows through. Light body and a thin mouthfeel. Eh, american wheat style with light sweetness in the tail.
From tap at Szynk in Krakow. Not that great as Amber and Dark version, but also standing in Polish ground. Not frsh enough memory for detailed description :(

I agree with the fellow reviewer - this is not as awesome as Smocza Glowa Amber. Golden colour, nice aroma, but significantly less bitter and complex than Amber Ale. Still noteworthy when you’re in Krakow, but pales in comparison with other Browar Stary Krakow products.
light beer, unfortunately not golden. head and saturation can be better in on tap version. maybe soon... bitternes less than Smocza G³owa.
Goud kleurend bier met weinig schuim en koolzuur. Het bier is een typisch doorsnee Franse soort van pilsener. Zoet, granig en verder niks.
Medium head, golden appearance, sweet malty aroma and palate. Quite simple lager.
Tap. pours a reddish brown with slight off white head. Aroma is a light caramel malt with some spice. Oily taste with slight hop finish, smooth and sessionable.
Draft @ brewery. Bready, buttery caramel malt aroma. Hazy amber with a large off-white head. Bready caramel malt and light spicy herbal hops flavor. Medium body, soft carbonation.
Tap at Warsaw. Barley malt and cherry aroma. Reddish amber color with nice head. Very light barley malt flavor. A light beer - don’t really get much flavor out of it but not bad for a hot day.

Draft sample at brewpub. Clear reddish brown color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate sweet toasted aroma. Medium body. Medium balanced flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration.

This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of finely sized tan colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a transparent uncarbonated red brown colored body and a good lacing. The mild aroma was hoppy and malty. The crisp semi-thick mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish sweet aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of malt and hops. An OK brew just nothing special.

Draft at MABC. Small ivory head that mostly diminished, fair amount of lacing, no visible carbonation, transparent, and an orange with some red peeking through. Sweet mildly malty and some light caramel notes for the aroma. The flavor was sweet, mildly malty and some caramel, thin and watery tasting. Blah and boriing. Smooth, watery and thin mouthfeel. Light body. Lacks character, too thin and watery. Missed the mark on the brewing of this one. Very disappointing for this style.

draft - Pours reddish and clear with a moderate head. The aroma is very light malts. The flavor is also light and the palate is too watery. More body and hops would have helped. Drinkable, but that’s about it...

half pint at MA - Aroma is mild malts, hardly anything. Pours transparent red with a big head and decent lacing. Flavor is also mild and boring. Palate is clean and watery. Thin and boring. Hey, some people like their beer that way.
Draft at brewery. Light butter and hay in the nose. Fairly clear light yellow in appearance. Taste is lightly bready with a faint tartness.

On tap @ Placerville Brewing. Pale straw pour with a white head. Pale malt, a little bit of bread, popcorn, and butter. Water, grass, and straw. Flavors of butter, popcorn, and pale malt. Grass, water, and some straw. Light bitterness on the finish.
On tap at brewery. Tasted like bud light, but had more character. Almost some corn flavor
Clear golden straw pour from a taster. Not much going on with this. Very watery and with an interesting bitterness.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours clear golden with a thin white head and a floral aroma. There is a carbonated caramel malt flavor with a bitter finish.
Pale gold color with a white head. Light citric aroma. Med. body. Light citrus and malt flavors. Crisp, clean, dry and bitter.

~Pours a light golden color with little to no head. ~Sweet light malty aroma. ~Starts sweet and quickly turns wheaty. ~Fizzy feel, tongue tingle, clean finish. ~Nice brew. Easy drinking, good summer brew.
Draft at brewery. Strong citrus zest with some lemon notes, obviously mostly tangerine and orange. Hazy yellow with no head. Taste is similar and very clean.

On tap @ Placerville Brewing. Pale golden pour with a white head. Lots of citrus aromas. A bit acidic, tangerine, and some fruity pebbles. A hint of grass and sweet bread. Lots of tangerine and orange flavor. Light acidity, grass, and malt. Kind of bitter on the finish.
On tap at the brewery. This smelled good, but tasted awful, good tangerine flavor, but very tart finish.
On draft as part of the sampler. Very acidic and way over citrusy with a wheat finish. Way overboard IMHO.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours clear orange with no head and a faint citrus aroma. This is like orange juice with alcohol, very flat and uninteresting.

~Light golden color with no head. Looks like juice. ~Strong tangerine citrus and light wheat scent. ~Wheaty tangerine flavor. A bit acidic, but not bad. ~Dry feel, quick finish. ~It’s ok. Not really my style. Good for what it tries to be.
Pours a pale golden color with a white head. Floral, caramel and hop aroma. Floral, honey, caramel and malt flavors. Medium light body and average carbonation with a floral finish.
Draft at brewery. A faint citrus nose. Golden pour in color, small white head. Faint to low hop character in the bitterness and flavor. Subtle grassiness. Just a bit of alcohol noted.

On tap @ Placerville Brewing. Orange colored pour with a white head. Bready malt, some orange peel, grass, and pine. A touch of toast and caramel. Sweet malt flavors of bread, toast, and caramel. Moderate bitterness of grass, orange peel, and pine hops.
Poured on tap at the brewery. Didn’t like this, it smelled skunky. Flavor wasnt any better, not sure what went wrong here.
On draft as part of the sampler. Golden pour with white head, some mild hop aroma. Weird lingering bitterness that all their beers seem to possess.
Tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy light amber with a creamy white head. Smells a little citric. Abt med body. Flavor is some sharp roast malt with citrus bitter. Very pleasant. Long bitter finish.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours light amber with a thin white head and a pine aroma. There is a caramel malt flavor with lots of pine and a dry bitter finish.
~Pours a copper color. ~Light hoppy scent. Not as nice as the cascade pale ale. ~Light bitter hop flavor, very mellow. ~Medium-light feel. Quick finish. ~Good pale ale. Mellow and enjoyable.
Draft at brewery. Mostly neutral nose with a hint of blueberry and fruit. Flavor is moderately fruity, with what reminds me of blueberry. Definitely a fruit-dominant beer. ok.

On tap @ Placerville Brewing. Golden orange pour with a white head. Certainly some berry notes, a touch of lemon zest, toast, and some grass. Flavor of malt, bread, berry, and a touch of lemon. Lightly tart and maybe a little bit of bitter.
On tap at the brewery. Aroma has hints of boysenberry. Flavor also has a good balance of the fruit.
On draft as part of the sampler flight. This brew was sweet at first with a lingering bitterness that was present throughout all the beers at this place. Sounded better than it was.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours amber with a thin white head and a strong berry aroma. There is a kind of nasty pale malt flavor with a strong boysenberry taste.

~Pours a cloudy orange with small creamy head. ~Boysenberry and wheat scent. A bit astringent. ~Boysenberry and hop taste. Kind of a strange mix. ~Medium feel. Bitter sweet finish. ~This is ok. Wouldn’t drink it again. Not my style.

Draft at brewery. Strong malt nose with some pepper as well. Flavor is malt dominant as well. Some weird peppery notes that remind me of Belgian yeast phenols or alcohol. I’m guessing its some higher alcohol here.

On tap @ Placerville Brewing. Golden orange pour with a white head. Sweet sugar, straw, bread, and fruity esters. A bit of pear and apple and grass. Flavors of sugar, bread, and fruit. Pear, apple, paper, and grass. A little bit boozy.

More like a pale ale then a blonde. Pours an ugly clear yellow. Smells a little fruity. Taste is fruity to start, with a hoppy finish. Decent, but nothing to write home about. Had at the brewery in Placerville. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This light gold beer has a pleasing aroma. It is a little bitter but has a subtle fruity flavor. It is a good beer to pair with a spicy burger. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at the brewery. This was a good blonde, nothing special, but decent, and the girls loved it as advertised.
Best beer that I had from the sampler and even that wasn’t enough for me to want to spend $20 on a growler. Mild sweetness with some spice. Lingering bitterness even after having food.
Tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy light amber with a creamy white head. Light malty aroma. Med body. Flavor of light malt with light grassy hop. It’s bitter, but not strongly so. Light malt lingers.

Draft @ Placerville. Pours a bright, clear golden color; thin, fine-bubbled white head. Sweet, crystalline sugar nose; fruity, honeyed, but mostly sweet malt sugars in the aroma. Medium-full body; moderate CO2; a touch of prickly, vinous alcohol. Functions off a combination of sweet honeyed maltiness, warming alcohol that’s well integrated, and a bit of pepper from the yeast; almost along the lines of a strong golden Belgian ale. A touch messy and sweet (especially compared to the version at Jack Russell), all told, but holds itself together proudly. Their bestseller. Long toasty and bready finish; still on the sweet side.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours light copper with a thin white head and a fruity aroma. There is a nice caramel malt flavor that starts sweet and finishes a little bitter.

Stopped on the way back from snowboarding in Tahoe so it may have made it taste better, Poured a pale gold with small head, slight aroma of sweetness, thin bodied. Taste slighty sweet, dough, a little yeasty. Very easy to drink, and like in the desciption "decidedly strong". Two pints got me pretty toasty
Draft at brewery. Light coffee with some creamy milky notes. Moderate roast comes across mid palate. A weird tartness in the finish, very drying. Seems like there is something just a tad off.

On-tap @ Placerville Brewing. Black in color with a thin tan head. Roasted malt, coffee, nut shells, and some dark chocolate. A bit acidic. Roasted malt flavors, coffee, and some cocoa. Nuts, nut shells, and a somewhat acidic, bitter finish.
On tap at brewery as the sampler. This was your basic stout. Aroma and flavor was not offensive, but nothing special.
On draft as part of sampler. Interesting taste with some hints of black licorice and cocoa. Seemed thin for a stout for sure. Not my bag..
On tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown with a thin tan head and a chocolate aroma. The flavor is chocolate and coffee with slight finishing bitterness. This is a good stout.

~Pours a black color with red tints and small off white head. ~Nice coffee choclate malt aroma. ~Bitter burnt malt and coffee flavor. ~Creamy feel. Bitter finish. ~Decent stout. Aroma was nice. Flavor was a bit bitter for my taste and was also lacking a bit. Enjoyable though/
Draft a brewery. Strong vanilla in the nose and continues through in the flavor. Vanilla really dominates the base beer. Some coffee down beneath. Nice

On tap @ Placerville Brewing. Black in color with an off-white head. Vanilla aroma, roasted malt, chocolate, and cream soda. Some butterscotch and coffee, too. Tastes mostly like cream soda. Maybe a bit of chocolate, some roasted malt, and a hint of coffee. Easily the best of their beers.

This beautifully rich looking black stout has a very inviting aroma of coffee and vanilla. It has a very pleasing mild flavor kinda like coffee and vanilla ice cream mixed together. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

An interesting stout. Pours a nice black, but with no head. Smells like vanilla. Lots of vanilla in the taste, unfortunately, it is the extract. A good amount of coffee too. A weird coffee/hoppy aftertaste though. Took a little time to open up, but got better after 10-15 minutes. Decent, but could be better. Had at the brewery.---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured on tap at the brewery. Just like there stout, but with vanilla extract added. Nothing special,
Similar to the stout with too much vanilla. Tasted like they just dumped a ton of vanilla extract into the regular stout.

Poured from a growler from the brewery into an English pint glass. Color is black with thin tan head. Aroma is strong of chocolate, vanilla, and roasted notes - smells incredible. Flavor is similar with a lot of chocolate and vanilla up front, followed with a nice roasted bitterness on the finish. Palate is creamy but a little thin. Overall a delicious sweet stout that would make a perfect dessert beer, but is also good on its own.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown with a thin tan head and a strong vanilla aroma. There is way too much vanilla in the flavor, but there is a pretty good treacle and dark malt base, similar to their impressive regular stout.

~Pours black with small off white head. ~Very nice vanilla bean aroma. Not much else comes through. ~Nice flavour. Bourbon barrel and vanilla definetly improves this stout. Not nearly as bitter. ~Creamy feel. Bitter finish. ~Enjoyable stout. Wouldn’t mind having another

4 ounce sample at the California Brewer’s Festival. Sample #1. Aroma is quite sweet with plenty of milk chocolate and vanilla beans. Lightly roasted, pleasant. Virtually opaque dark brown-black body with a small, tan head. Quite roasted, burnt, ashy, black patent start. Becomes quite sweet and vanilla-like in the middle. A bit of chocolate later on with some more lingering black patent bitterness. A bit too burnt and thin-bodied.
from previous tap: decent smooth medium body and light chocolate, coffee and roast. Average in style, but nice enough.
From a 12 oz bottle. Poured dark amber with a light tan head. Nose orf roasted malts. Medium body and smooth mouthfeel. Flavor of chocolate and coffee,. Good bitter finish. Nice.
Soft and mildly roasted nose. Medium mouthfeel with nice cocoa and coffee notes. Nice clean crisp finish.
less honey and more bitter hops than expected which made for a rough beer at first. opened up nicely and accentuated the hops a little better. Still not the best, but ok.

On tap at the tasting room, first visit. Thick head nice lacing. Aroma is of coffee, flavor is similar, really robust coffee notes. Finishes sweet and sticky. Lots of body for a porter. Overall pretty good.

~Roasty coffee aroma with milk chocolate and vanilla. ~Pours a chocolate color with small off white head. ~Light roasted coffee flavor, slightly burnt. ~Med body, Med CO2, roasty burnt finish. ~Too much roasted malt on this one. Still enjoyable. Would only drink one.
nothing special, but 13th percentile is style seems a tad harsh. More nutty red than amber, or at least a hybrid. enjoyed enough, but no need to get again.

On tap @ Lockdown. Almost cola in color with an off-white head. Aromas of caramel, spicy hops, toffee, cardboard, and maple extract. Maybe a bit of grass. The palate is kind of astringent. Cardboard, pine, and grass. Mild hop spiciness, toffee, and caramel.
On tap at lockwood folsom. Aroma is grainy with a touch of hops. Taste is initially grainy with a toasty roasted hop finish.

Uh oh... infected bottle alert. This one was purchased at Total Wine & More in Sac. All foam in the glass, literally no liquid. A sip of liquid from the bottle turned to instant foam in my mouth with a gagging, soapy, plastic, metallic flavor. I’m sorry to have to do this, but poor quality control deserves a poor rating.
Not too bad but nothing special. It was good. I liked it overall but it was really pretty balanced but just funky as a whole.

This 12 oz. bottle was shared with Strykzone via Facebook chat. It poured a cloudy light amber with a nice tan head and good lacing. Nose is malty with a lot of floral and pine hops on top. Medium body and smooth clean mouthfeel. Flavor is caramel malts with some citrus bitterness. Good bitter finish. Nice.

A 12 oz. bottle from Hayduke with whom it was shared via Facebook chat. This beer poured a hazy light brown with an evenly layered tan head of small bubbles. The nose began with malt but soon was floral and pine hops. The flavor is not really a red ale which is what the name says. A pale ale is closer. The hops are center with that pine and floral. They are rather bitter but there is only a small taste of grapefruit. Caramel malt and some nice fruit compliment. This was a nice beer with just enough complexity and some nice tastes. A very nice beer from Lockdown.
bottle thanks to bhensonb. poured amber with a white head. aroma was caramel, fruity, and red apple. flavor was much the same plus a slight hop bitter. body was light with medium carbonation.
bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. poured a deep amber with a cream head. nose is heavy caramel, light hops, and bitter notes. nice on the palate, flavor is caramel, light hops, sticky finish.
Pours reddish brown with a decent beige head and a toffee aroma. There is a funky burnt malt flavor that is neither sweet nor bitter.
my least favorite they make. totally boring and muddled with no real redeeming qualities beyond it being non-offensive.

On tap @ Lockdown. The pour is sort of a golden orange color with a white head. Notes of orange, earthy, and floral hops on the nose. Some bread, mild spice and pine. There’s a mild bitterness to the flavor. Orange peel and pine, mild lemon, grass, and floral hops. Some bready malt gives a light sweetness. Kind of grainy.
on tap at rancho location. pours copper amber with white head. taste was bread, caramel, grass,. not much there
On tap at lockdown in folsom. Golden coppee pour. Mild hop aroma. Touch of sweetness with mild bitter finish.

12oz bottle, purchased at Total Wine & More - Roseville. While not stellar, this is still significantly better than the draft version at the brewery (the added carbonation helps). Pours a bright, slightly hazy orange color; huge, textured off-white head that lasts forever. Light, soapy aroma with a whiff of green apple / acetaldehyde; minimal hops or malts. Medium body; fluffy, lively carbonation; some soapiness and green apple notes, again, along with very modest levels of earthy/spicy hop flavor and bitterness, and a maltiness that really only shows itself as a toastiness in the finish. A green-apple spritzer, essentially, but not painfully so.

~Light citrusy hop aroma with biscuity malts. ~Light copper color with lasting creamy white head. ~Ctrusy hop flavor balanced with biscuity malt profile. ~Med body, med CO2, Citrusy finish. ~Well balanced and enjoyable.

This was enjoyed in a joint Facebook tasting with Strykzone. From the 12 oz bottle this poured a very clear gold color with a huge white head and glue like lacing rings. The nose is mild and of citrus and floral hops aromas, backed by caramel malts with a touch of grain. Body is medium, and the mouthfeel soft. The flavor starts out with floral hops, followed by citrus and continues to evolve until li finishes strong with a pine bitterness. While this is listed here as an English Pale Ale, it seemed pretty classic APA to me.

Thanks to Hayduke with whom a Facebook chat / tasting was thoroughly enjoyed. This beer pours a clear golden with a big off white fluffy and pillowy. It lasts quite a long time before collapsing. The aroma is not big at all and has some citrus, floral, caramel, and grain. Flavor was floral hops, pine, and citrus with some caramel. That grain, too. This isn’t an English Pale Ale but more of an American version. There might be a smidge of European hops but not a lot. This beer was muddled and didn’t quite know what it wanted to be. That is due to a hop profile that doesn’t quite work. It did finish nicely.
Pours amber with a decent beige head and a nondescript malty aroma. There is a funky grain flavor with some hop bitterness at the finish. An unremarkable brew.
Pours pale golden with a thin white head. Subtle hop nose with some sweet fruit as well. Sweet fruit front to bitter mid and finish. Some ice tea and grain as well.
in style not as boring as some others, but still "just" a blonde ale. Not a favorite. Reasonably crisp and refreshing. Simple.

On tap @ Lockdown. Golden pour with a white head. Nose opens with bready malt, but is also somewhat tart. A bit of grain, lemon, peach, and apricot. Flavor is a bit tart as well. Notes of bread and grain, lemon peel, and grass. Hints of sweet fruit such as peach. Unimpressive.
On tap. Light blond pour. Has some bready notes with anice touch of sweetness. Finishes dry and crisp.
Light yellow in color... Aroma of pils hops... Flavor is slight citrus, light to medium body, and classic pilsner finish... Not a big fan of the style, very unimpressed

Bottle 12oz. from Total Wine. Nothing really “jumps out” from this beer. It’s a solid middle of the road offering that’s not going to make you remember it. Pours a orange pale, aroma of citrus, fruit. medium sweetness, medium bitterness, light body, abrupt finish.

~Light Orangey Citrus aroma with light clean malt. ~Pours a light clear orange color with no head. (Served in a plastic cup) ~Light refreshing orangey citrus flavor with kinda wheaty? malt flavor. ~Med bodied, high CO2, clean light citrusy finish. ~Excellent Summer Session brew. A lighter body would be nice.

Another joint tasting with Strykzone. This poured slightly haze golden color and raised a nice white head that had good retention. The nose is banana and citrus. Medium body and smooth clear mouthfeel. Flavor is tasty with banana and citrus and hint of some spice , Finished much like a hefe. Very nice brew and exceptionally easy to drink..

Kindly sent my way by Hayduke whit whom it was shared via Facebook chat with he and his brother Rick. This poured a mostly clear golden but with lots of tiny yeast particles suspended. A nice white soapy head that lasted a couple of minutes. The aroma was like candy with bubble gum and bananas. Those were prominent in the flavor as well. Throw in some hops with some nice citrus and it made for a very easy to drink beer. It was akin to a hefe but with a hint of attitude from the hops. Refreshing to the max! Perhaps the perfect lawn mowing beer. It did’t try to do too much and it succeeded that much more.
bottle thanks to bhensonb. poured hazy yellow with a white head. aroma was banana, soap, and a mild spice. flavor seemed to be wheat and a tiny amount of spice. body was medium with low carbonation.
bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. poured blonde with a white head. nose is dried fruits, light malts, and more fruit. nice on the palate, flavor is fruity yeast, clean finish.

column1: Top of the Hill Hugh Morton Mango Lager
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Basically Magic Hat #9 with mango instead of apricot. Clear dark gold pour with no head. Aroma and flavor are both marked by cereal grain, heavy mango presence, and maybe the slightest touch of floral hop. Palate is very light, bubbly, and crisp. Mediocre.

column1: Top of the Hill Hugh Morton Mango Lager
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap. Had this a long time ago but it was simple enough to remember in detail. Obviously it is discontinued now. Pours a clear orange with no head- so no lacing. Not a great start. Aroma of canned mango, wheat, lemon, straw/hay. Taste is very watery with an obvious mango presence that is not sweet like added fruit juice but is more subtle as in making itself known through the malt and cereal grain flavors. Not sure what the purpose of the beer is but it is a very poor showing and significantly less impressive than their new fruit beer: the blueberry wheat.

column1: Top of the Hill Hugh Morton Mango Lager
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Pours a light yellow with no head. Nice aroma of mango but the flavor was very lacking and kind of dry. Not one of their better beers.

column1: Top of the Hill Hugh Morton Mango Lager
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear golden color. Head was one finger high and white. There was a little lace on the glass at the end. Aroma was fruit dominated, mostly mango and peach. Dry on the tongue with a pleasant fresh honey-touched cereal grain flavor accented by peach and mango. There were also some noble hops. Pretty decent.

column1: Top of the Hill Hugh Morton Mango Lager
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Great for a light, refreshing summer beer. The flavor is subtle (more apparent in the aroma), and it’s not sweet (about the same sweetness as a Belgian white). Low alcohol content, so take it for what it’s worth.

column1: Top of the Hill Hugh Morton Mango Lager
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Date: 12/19/2006 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear yellow, wispy white head, sweet mango aroma, good mango flavor, only a touch of sweetness and even some light bitterness in the finish, the lack of sweetness makes it much better and more drinkable than the typical fruit beer, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **/4

Tap at brewery. Ginger. That is what this is all about. Lots of the stuff, dripping with ginger in the nose, flavor and aftertaste. Initially it’s pretty shocking, after the first three gulps it tones down and is actually not unpleasant to drink. Suprisingly two beer novices that I shared this with enjoyed it. Medium golden in color, head fades pretty quickly with no real lacing left. An interesting beer although one I wouldn’t drink with regularity.

tap at the brewery. dark brown mahogany. nice nutty aroma with some light cocoa and a hint of smoke. a quencher, this would work better with some food. sweet at first with some brown sugar and peanut flavor. an enjoyable brew that doesn’t finish well for me. something perfumy in the finish that doesn’t compliment this. still drinkable, but unpleasant.
Draft at the brewpub - the pump clip said 6,8%. Sweet bock, true to the style, but much too sweet for my liking. Like they have diluted brown sugar in the beer!

Brewery tap. Dark brown color. Toffee and a hint of roast in the aroma. Blackcurrant, butterscotch, butter and licorice in the flavor. Long licorice bitter aftertaste. More like a strong ale instead of a bock. Nevertheless a fine beer.
Künstliches Orangenaroma, Süßstoffaromen bis in den Nachgeschmack, in dem es das alleinige Aroma ist. Überaus chemisch. Test vom 16.10.2006, Gebinde: Dose Noten: 6,4,4,2,7,3 - 3,65
(Can) Pours a clear pale yellow body with a small white head. Aroma of orange and grapefruit. Flavor of orange, grapefruit, and malt with a carbonated mouthfeel. Quite malty for a Chinese fruit beer.

column1: Big Rock Chop House Belgian Style Tripel
column5: Served in a pint glass with an orange and golden hue. Very sweet aroma turns out to be a bubble gum taste. Didn’t detect much alcohol until the end when you feel the punch. Sweet but still goes with the food well.

column1: Big Rock Chop House Belgian Style Tripel
column5: MBGSF ’10. Sweet estery nose with lots of golden fruits. Taste is moderately sweet, lightly bitter, with lots of apricot, some peach and pears, a bit of cotton candy and honey.

column1: Big Rock Chop House Belgian Style Tripel
column5: 7-22-06 MBG. Copper with white film for head. Aroma has tons of candi sugar, some nice floral and spicy/herbal notes. Flavor on par, candi sugar dominates, floral character come through a tad near the finish. Doesn’t have that drying alcoholic bite most tripels have, but I would take this over other examples any day. Well done.

column1: Big Rock Chop House Belgian Style Tripel
column5: This draft brew from a festival poured a small sized head of foamy fine to medium sized white colored bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a transparent softly carbonated dark orange colored body. The aroma was sweet. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish mild vinous aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of smooth malt sweet mildly vinous and mild caramel. A decent one but not one that I would consider buying again.

column1: Big Rock Chop House Belgian Style Tripel
column5: Draft. Ivory head with sparse lacing, transparent, no visible carbonation, and a gold hue with some orange peeking through. Sweet malt and alcohol nose and ditto for the flavor. Smooth mouthfeel and light-medium body.
Bottle. Hazy yellow, offwhite creamy head. Green leafy Hops, a hint catty, medium body mellow mouthfeel, light grainy malt, grassy, somewhat metallic Hops, falls a bit flat.

Bottle. Clear pale yellow color with white head. Aroma is cardboard, sweet grains. Taste is sweet grains, a touch sulphur, sugary. Oily mouthfeel with natural carbonation. It has a bit of a macro touch.
A tasty Helles from Weissenburg. A very herbal Helles that is a tick heavy but refreshing and satisfying. A good beer but not remarkably memorable.

Sampled at the Sigwarts Braustüberl. Long lasting white head. Clear yellow color. Typical malty aroma with a small tuch of detergent. Crisp malty taste with some hop to balance and give a low bitterness.
50cl bottle. Pours clear golden colour with a small white head. Aroma of pale malt, straw, mild hops. Taste of grain, pale malt, mild hops, boring!

Vom Faß im Bräustüberl, Weißenburg (15.4.2015). - Goldgelb, klar; üppiger Schaumberg. - In der Nase ganz feiner, aromatisch hopfenwürziger Hopfen mit zart blumiger Note. - Antrunk mild hellmalzig und leicht malzsüß. Der in der Nase festgestellte Hopfen hält sich anfangs sehr zurück. Durchschnittlich rezent, schlank, weich im Mund. Erst im Abgang kommen ganz milde, leicht zitronige Hopfenanklänge auf, die das Bier gekonnt abrunden. - Sehr rundes, malzbetontes Helles, sehr dezent aber aromatisch gehopft und sehr süffig. Klassischer Vertreter seiner Art, wesentlich besser als Augustiner Hell und andere hochgelobte Großbrauereienbiere.
Pours a clear golden body with a medium white head. Aroma of grain, grass. Flavor of grain, grass, and earthiness with a crisp clean finish.

Thanks to Martin for this bottle! 0,5l, best before 16.03.15. Süßlich-süffiger Antrunk. Mild und leicht getreidig. Der Hauptteil ist süßlich-getreidig, typisch für ein Helles. Zum Nachgeschmack kommt eine leichte Herbe hinzu, mild-weich mit deutlicher Perlage. Der Nachgeschmack ist leicht getreidig-süßlich, leicht herb und sortentypisch. Lecker und süffig!
0,5 l bottle BB06/14 bread, hay, cereal, grass, herbs, pale, frothy, white foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, average carbonation,
Clear golden color and short head. Sweet aroma of hay and grass. Taste is very malty with some very interesting taste I cannot describe (never tasted that before). Rare bitterness.
Draught: Light sourly, flowerly aroma. Flaovr is quite sourly, spicy and yeasty. Dry bitter finish. Unbalanced
