column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: One of the last bottles in the cellar. Pours a clear clean yellow color with a small fast vanishing white head. The cork smelled sour like vinegar which had me worried. Lively carbonation. The aroma was of light Belgian notes with minimal sour notes. The taste was of light and sweet with some banana in the finish. Dry on the palate with a crisp finish.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5:
2006 Vintage

7/28/2007: North by Northwest Guldenbiere 2006 smells yeasty with some additional aromas of wheat and fruit. This beer has a cloudy yellow/golden color with a white head and nice lacing. The flavor is lambic-like with some fruitiness and a balanced level of bitterness. The body is light and heavily carbonated, but the palate is smooth and somewhat mellow. It isn’t nearly as fizzy as the 2005 Vintage was. Overall this beer is pretty good, but unfortunately it isn’t anything too terribly exciting or special.

Sample from 750 mL bottle (7.5% ABV) shared by moejuck at the "Columbus Tasting: Ate, now with gramatical errors" event. Thanks! Rating #19 for this beer...

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Body-very clear and light with a thick foamy head. Nose-cottony, alcohol, light white spices. Taste-honey, cantaloupe, medium to high sweetness, very soft, lotion, lightly sticky, cloying, way too much honey flavors. Too sweet as it warms.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Yellow straw like color with a lacy decent head. Thick body. Honey hits you at first in the taste and smell. Very sweet. Ginger and some fruit in the taste as well.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: (750ml bottle, 2006 vintage) Pours a clear yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma of ginger, coriander, mustiness, and biscuit. Flavor of sweet malts, peach, pear, honey, and floral hops.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: 750 ml bottle, fruity blueberry nose, very carbonated, heavy ginger, honey flavors

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: 750 ml bottle into Pizza Port pint glass; obtained from fly, my 2007 Secret Santa (thanks to him for this seemingly very rare beer). Yeasty smells all over the place; lemony and skunky at first, it reminds me of a pilsener more than a Belgian beer. When you stick your nose in the glass you get the more characteristic bready and horseblanket aromas, with an undercurrent of woodland berries. Medium bodied in the mouth and very soft, the very gentle carbonation goes well with lactic sweetness in the finish. Lightly fruity middle with very identifiable notes of juicy pear. Reminds me a little bit of a green-tea mochi ball in the flavor both in the middle and late in the finish. A refreshing beer that does what it does well.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: I finally make it on the Top 50 Master Raters List! 25.4 oz bottle. Kept foaming over even after two glasses were poured out. Cloudy straw with a coating white head. Leaves speckles of lace. Nose is funky lemon custard and yeast. Tastes similar; lightly tart milky citrus, some floral and mild grapefruit pith.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: 750mL bottle, 2006, courtesy of mj. Thanks, Mike! Cloudy, yellowish-honey color; white head with good retention and lacing. Dense, floral-dominated aroma; plenty of fresh-cut flowers, white pepper, and yeast. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: the characteristics are more of a standard belgian golden ale: floral notes, belgian sugar, and yeast; basic chewy belgian beer, a bit of a let-down from the nose. Medium, doughy and yeasty finish.

column4: North By Northwest Restaurant and Brewery
column5: Bottle conditioned 750ml, thanks to fly. Cloudy light yellow colored body. Fruity citrus and candy sugar nose, with heavy floral dandelion notes, some coriander, and some sweet soapy scents as well. Soft on the palate, creamy and sweet, with more floral saison-esque spice and floral/perfume notes. An interesting spiced Belgian-style beer, sweet and sticky in the finish. Very decent.

Aroma of muddy sweet brown sugar and barley. Has minimal head and a dark brown body. Flavour is slightly spicy sweet molasses. Weak on the mouth and lacking punch. It's not much exciting going on here.
Dark brown with a fairly puffy, tan-coloured head. Aroma is malt, mocha, and cream. Taste is malt, dark chocolate, and toffee.
On Tap @El Lúpulo Feroz, Oviedo. 07/05/17. Color marrón corona de espuma blanca, aromas tostados, notas a caramelo sabor malta notas dulces cuerpo medio.
Süffiger, trocken herb-würziger Beginn. Wenig getreidig, keine Tiefe. Dumpf hopfig herber Mittelteil, kurzer Nachhall. Unbeindruckend. 7/8/6/7/6/6
* Old rating, 0,5l crown-top bottle, best before 09.03.06. Mildes, süßlich-würziges Helles mit minimaler Herbe.
Goldgelbes Helles mit getreidigen Geschmacksnoten. Klingt verhalten herb aus. Nicht außergewöhnlich, aber ein typisches Hell, ohne groß aufzufallen.
50 cl bottle @ Timo A, BBE 03.01.2013 Aroma has butter and metal. Flavour has butter, some grainy malt and light grassy hops in the finish. Quite bohemian.

50 cl bottle @ Timo A. Pours clear golden color with a small white head. Aroma of mild buttery notes, some grass, hay and sweetish malts. Flavor of grass, mild sweetish caramel malts, some butter, mild corn and some fruity notes. Bitter and slick palate, medium carbonation. Decent. 3514

The bottle looks like a cheap beer, the beer in the glass is not very zippy, foam disappears fast. Sourish and moldy aroma. Tastes mild, dry-malty in the background, finish dry and sourish. Strange beer!
on tap at berlinerbierfest06. a typicallly plain helles, golden, lightly peachy malt aroma, light bitterness, pretty boring
Draught. Golden colour, big stable white head. Bready aroma and flavour. OK medium bitterness.

Für den Stil etwas dunkel, cremefarbener Schaum, milde Karbonisierung. Der Hopfen ist sofort am Obergaumen präsent, der Körper ausgewogen, ein Hauch von Malzsüße ist angedeutet, aber die Hopfenbittere überwiegt. Trockener, sehr lang nachklingender Nachtrunk.
Many thanks to Kappldav for this sample! Smooth and easy to drink beginning. Watery grainy, not too deep but sessionable with a grainy watery back.
Bottle looks very simple. Beer in the glass zippy, small head. Starts mild, fine hoppy, some grasy notes. Finish a bit metallical. Could be more balanced. Okay.
Bottled, from Sagasser, Ilmenau. Clear pale golden, minimal head. Light grassy nose. Dry with light-medium body and crisp, rounded mouthfeel. Some crisp bread and salty grass. Long bitter finish.
Bottle from Sagasser, Erfurt. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, hay and light hoppy - grass. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 210717
Tap at the sandwich guy in fhain - served in a mug - fresh and light bodied pils, floral notes. medium sweet malts. refreshing, good.
The aroma is pepper, fruit, caramel. The appearance is a slighly hazy amber, white head. The flavor is yeasty, pepper, light fruit. The dinish is sweet, and moves toward a spicy end. Ok, not great,
Had this while camping at BCTC this year. Pours a lightly hazed gentle amber brown with a thin white head. Popcorn and fuzzy Belgian yeast, toast and malt. Crisp and malty. Long slow bitter finish.

[Draft @ BCTC 2010] Amber color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel malts, nuts, wood, and toast. Taste of much of the same with some bready malts, and a semi sweet finish.
Draft. Large off-white head atop clear amber body. Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, light bread. Taste is medium sweet, caramel, light bread. Light-medium body.

Growler filled at the Publick House and consumed later the same day. Pours a nearly clear amber with a moderate yellow-white head that lasted until mid-glass and left ample lace. Pleasant spicy aroma with some malt present in the nose as well. The flavor is spicy Belgian yeast with some malt. Dries out as it approaches the finish, where some cracker and black pepper emerge. The black pepper lingers at the back of throat well into the aftertaste. Medium bodied.

On tap at Southampton...Murky, orange body with barely a head, even though it was straight from the tap. It has a very pungent and yeasty nose, not as spicy as I wanted it to be. Also it was surprisingly uncomplex in general, with no qualtiies I look for in a Belgian beer. The flavor is malty, and sour. The tartness really stands out. What is this beer? I’m not so fond of it.

Tap at the publick house - very hazy, moslty golden (amber?) out of the tap - very musty, earthy aroma, with hints of lemon, a tiny bit of spice and belgian sugar - a bit spicy up front, followed in the middle by an unexpected tartness/sourness that I’m not entirely sure the brewer intended - a bit of thin malts come on the back end of that, along with light orange flavor - the unwelcome tartness never completely goes away though - is it possible that this beer was infected?
on tap at the publick house. hazy golden amber color, very light tan creamy head. candi sugar malt and lemony banana aroma too. flavor is lemony banana, a little tart and dry, wheat malt?

gee Joe, i kind of liked this one. Well its better this way, we can keep that record of having almost exactly opposite tastes. Poured into a pint, color is orang-amber with a small but stable head. Aroma is present - beglain fruitiness and fruit sweetness. Taste is more spiced - allspice, nutmeg, cinamon. Leaves a fruity belgian aftertaste.

Tap at the Publick House. Hazy amber colour with an initially lovely spicy aroma of clove, allspice and cinnamon with banana and peach fruitiness over the back. Flavour though is like sucking on old bandaids. Incredibly phenolic and sulfurous with plasticy notes as well. Light caramel malt that probably would have worked if the yeast hadn’t gone crazy. It started out okay, but this one got away from them.
Decent beer, very refreshing would suit a summer day and a ploughmans lunch

Pint of the "house" beer at Regal Beagle actually half a pitcher. The "short" pour in this case was the big one. Held a good head on a gold beer. Tasted like malt liquor without the malt and without the liquor. Just an off alcohol taste, mixed sweetness and weird off-grainy flavours. The wings helped make the beer go down easier. Piping hot big salt-n-pepper wings.

Bright pale yellow colour with a very perfect inch-thick (artificially stabilized) head. The aroma is light pale malt, fresh and breezy. Flavour is sweetish, but more balanced than most macrobrews. The malts are again very clean and breezy. The finish shows a hint of flowery hop as well. As clean and balanced a beer as I’ve had from Labatts. Well worth the trip out to Esquisurrey...I was hoping for a debacle and instead got a really nice macrobrew.Update: Hey Vancouver! Winchester is on tap at Hippo’s Sports Bar at Fraser & Marine. And it’s quite a bit worse than the stuff I rated at the Tudor House. Don’t delay!

(Draught) Sampled at Tudor House in Esquimalt for $2.75/sleeve. They wash the tabletops with fortified vinegar at Tudor House so its difficult to make the aroma - nose of banana Runts and lemon. Cleaar, very mild carbonation. Flavour is somewhat clean with only a mild maltedness and 2% milk in the finish.

pours light white wine yellow. Light apple juice and “that” jalapeno/bell pepper vegetation on the nose. Attack: jalapeno pepper (without the spiciness) Mid-palate: 5/10-dense sweetness, mild apple, honey Finish: medium tartness, clean tangy light-med sweet finish. That jalapeno I taste is the same flavour I get when I infuse vodka with jalapenos for a few months. It’s not exactly pleasant but works okay in this case due to the existence of honey in the mix. Overall this is a slightly above average mead because I enjoy it’s drinkability and clean finish.

Clear liquid with a soft aroma of sweetness. Taste is soft and a little sweeter than I was hoping. Not as good as the European meads I’ve had but a decent effort. Will have to seek out more from B.C.’s meaderies.
Bottled. A light golden mead. The aroma has notes of sweet honey as well as light notes of rosehips. The flavor is odd with notes of spices and honey. Thanks Alex for sharing.

Still, blond color. The aroma is a delicate mix of apples and honey, a bit flowery, already dry. The flavor reminds a german Riesling, just with a bit more body and maybe sweetness, lightly fruity; the final is nice and complex, the mouthfeeling mostly; alcohol well hidden. A new experience after the sweet European Meads, it’s like a good oxidized white wine, amazing.

(Bottle 75 cl) Courtesy of fiulijn. Clear pale golden - no head. sweetish apple aroma with a discreet whiff of honey. Surprisingly light-bodied, dry and tart - the cider really dominates here, while the honey mostly is a piquant whiff. Dry and lightly tart finish. Interesting and rather refreshing - almost like a dry white wine. 300808
Clear light golden with no head. Sweet aroma with alcohol, ripe fruits and honey notes. Sweet flavour with alcohol, honey and somewhat spicy notes. Ends with warming alcohol.
Bottle. Clear pale yellow coloured with no head. Sweet aroma of honey, berries and alcohol. Strange and sharp fruity flavour of alcohol with notes of medicine and chemicals. Alcoholic finish.

75 cL clear bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a fully diminished. Mild spiced and smooth fruity aroma. Sweet and phenolic apple dry base flavour with no sweetness what so ever. Lasting phenolic and dry finish.

[Papsoe tasting 31-08-2008, thanks buddy] Bottle. Pale yellow color. Aromas of medicine, elderflower, honey, alcohol, hint of citrus and apple. Over the palate came mild medicine and what appeared as cider like lively pickling sparkles and alcohol. Very strange and unique mix of cider and mead. Full bodied with a soft carbonation (if any) and thick alcoholic texture. Heavy sweet flavor with light notes of acidic. Lingering sweet honey and medicine finish with an acidic twist.

Golden colour. Still. Lightly fruity, with a complex alcohol signature. Dry. Palate is austere, tastes like a Coen Brothers movie, with an alcohol plotline and appley characters, all set in a rustic meadery. Simplistic structure yet complex as all hell. This cyser is an intellectual exercise.

Visual: Pours a very light orange with a hint of purple. Miniscule sedimentation in the pour. Nose: apple cider vinegar and cranberry on the nose. (6)-aromatic strength. Attack: incoming sweet and acidic sourness, supple mouthfeel Mid-palate: (MAIN) apple cider vinegar, (7)-sourness, (5)-tartness, (5)-sweetness (HINT) cranberry, lavender Finish: light-medium alcohol warmth, medium-heat spicy, sweet-tart finish. Summary: Quite interesting and sippable at room. It’s got a nice balance of sweet-fruit-sour-tart-spice-alcohol in there. (Note: all numbers above are on a 10-point scale, with 1 being weak and 10 being the strongest)

Bottle* 375ml. [ Courtesy of fiulijn ]. Clear light to medium yellow colour with virtually no head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy honey, acetone. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet with a long duration, honey, light grpe - wine, flowers - lavender notes, medicune notes. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20120420]

Handbottled. A light yellow mead. The aroma has notes of honey combined with lighter notes of lavender and cranberries. The flavor is sweet with notes of acetone, honey, and lavender, as well as lighter notes of cranberries, leading to a tart finish. Thanks fiulijn for sharing.

Handbottle 10 cl. Courtesy of fiulijn. Slightly hazy pale golden with a vague pinkish whiff. Acetone notes in the nose and even some cranberry shining through. Medium body, lightly sweet spicy honey but also a light tartness and a chemical edge to it. A rather confusing construction. 200412
Handbottle. Pours pale pinkish, no head. Aroma is citrici and herbal honey. Smooth fruity, cranberry and lavender. Mild citric mixed with a light sweetness. Smooth fruity and lig sweet finish.

Bottle from Spinnakers Spirit Merchants, Victoria, synthetic cork Pale color, close to transparent, with a red-pinkish hue. The aroma is delicate, with some berry fruit, vinegar, glue; actually quite fresh. Semi-sweet Mead, with a lean body, and a mild vinegar acidity; there is a mild fruity trace, light glue and a hidden acetone and lavender note; the final also shows a very light astringency. Vinegar is an unusual component for a Mead, but in mild doses and with some fruits is interesting. The lavender is not really evident, and this is maybe good news.

Tall, runway model slim 375ml bottle. Very light beach coloured still liquid. Thin scent, alcohol, like a white wine. Nice fruit taste at the start; apples and strong honey. Body has a little more depth, in texture and in flavour, than the other four I have tried from this producer. Strong liquid honey body. Could use more tartness but by the far the most substantial character, other than the spiced mead. I think that the lavender adds a gentleness to the flavour.

(Bottle) Sampled at the Royal BC Museum. Comes across more as a tart appley-mead than cranberries - though I did have a small sampling. This item doesn’t hide its ABV as well as the Cyser so there is a small alcohol burn in the finish. Very good.

First mead, so bear with me trying to review it. Poured at a restaurant, heated in a glass placed in a mug of hot water for 1 minute. Clear, pinkish orange. Aroma has honey and cinnamon with some alcohol. Flavour like a light fruit wine, not overly flavourful. Lighter body.

Bottle at Burgoo on 10th Ave W, Vancouver Pale red color. Delicate fruity aroma. Unfortunately they tried to warm it up, so the flavor reminds me of ghlübier (mulled beer, like Unibroue Quelque Chose), it has a pleasant fruity flavor, moderate sweetness, and not much mead character, more a fruit wine.
Purchased in Vancouver private store. Pours Rose coloured. Very attractive spices, smooth taste, though somewhat alcohol warming. Very tasty mead.
Bottle from the Otown throwdown. Light orange pour. Layers of spices and honey notes linger throughout the aroma. Flavor is very tropical and fruity. Nice and delicate.
FRO Throwdown: Peach color. Cinnamon comes through quite clearly. Wasn’t expecting it! Light honey tones throughout.

Sample at O-town throwdown ’09 pours orange with viscous lacing. Aroma / taste are just very sweet-honey and filled with amazing spices. Im a really starting to enjoy these Canadian meads and mead in general. Spices add a nice warming mouthfeel.

Thank you Oakes! Glowing orange color with legs. Aroma is lovely and floral also and full of fun fruits including pineapple, apricot, melon. This is the best mead I’ve had to date. Finishes dry. Retains tons of flowers in the body. Pineapple again. Then apricot. Guava, passion, and other tart tropical fruits join the party. Excellent mead!

Golden amber-orange colour. The aroma is big mead, cinnamon, ginger and apple...oh yeah. Warming, with a muscular alcohol presence. But it’s smooth, tempered by enough residual honey...full-bodied stuff. Deft touch on the spicing - this is well seasoned with the nutmeg and cinnamon.

Bottle… This mead rocks!... Mostly clear amber mead with orange highlights and decent legwork. Rich maple and honey aroma with a wealth of spices unknown (if not for the commercial description). Barely medium-bodied - a bit thin. Certainly well-balanced for a mead. Sweet, herbal, earthy flavors. Dry, almost-raspy finish. I’d like to know the ABV as it’s either relatively low or expertly disguised. Kudos to Oakes for sharing this gem!

Courtesy Oakes. Pours a fairly clear reddish orange, with a lightly syrupy texture. Very spicy nose to it. All sorts of stuff going on here, mint, graham crackers, earth, and honey. Really dug the nose. The flavor is also pretty spicy, some floral notes, and sweet honey combine to form the flavor profile for this mead. I didnt like the flavor as much as the nose, but it was still pretty solid. Not as hot in the finish, but the floralness was there all the way to the end. Pretty solid mead.

Sample at the Ft. Wayne brewpub. Clear golden color with a medium white head that evaporates steadily to an outer ring. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of yeast, hops and malt. Medium-bodied with flavors of herbal yeast, fruit and spicy hops. The finish is fruity yeast up front with a mildly hoppy aftertaste. Decent overall.
On draft at the brewery. Color is a bright yellow. Sweet tasting but easy to drink. A nice beer.
Draft @ brewery. Belgian yeast, bready malt, and light fruity aroma. Hazy yellow with a small white head. Belgian yeast, barley malt, coriander, and alcohol flavor. Medium body, soft carbonation.

This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of frothy fine to large sized white colored bubbles that was mostly diminishing and left behind a transparent typically carbonated dark yellow colored body and a fair lacing. The mild aroma was banana. The mouth feel was tingly at the start with a mellow finish with a mellow vinous aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of malt hops banana vinous and softly acidic. An OK brew just nothing special.

draft - Pours transparent gold with a very thin head. The aroma is mostly sweet malt and candi sugar. The flavor is also very sweet with a little mild hops in the finish, but not much. It’s smooth and medium bodied. This is an easy to drink, sweet, pretty decent ale.

Draft at MABC. Small white head that mostly diminished, poor lacing, miinimal carbonation, transparent, and a yellow hue. Sweet malt nose and ditto for the flavor. Smooth mouthfeel. Just a so-so brew.

Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a yellow to semi-pale light orange color with a bar pour’s kind of white semi-foamy head. Mild carbonation could be seen rising. The aroma smelled like rye bread but mainly in a sweet way. Light grassy hops. The flavor was also sweet through the breadiness and the rye was even fainter in this department compared to the aroma. Mild bready aftertaste and finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a decent sessionability about it. Bready smoothness really scales down any sort of suspected rye harshness. Overall, for a rye beer, it leans towards the sweet side a bit more than expected and honestly, as a fan of rye beers, I tend to like the blend of "sweet" to "spicy" portions melding together. This didn’t do that.

This draft brew from a festival poured a small sized head of fine to medium sized white colored bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a transparent softly carbonated light yellow colored body. The weak aroma was hoppy malty and bready. The thin mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the finish. The flavor contained notes of malt mild hops and was slightly acidic. Not one that I would likely buy again.

Draft. Small white head that was mostly lasting with fair lacing, minimal carbonation, transparent, and a yellow hue. Nose was malty and hoppy and ditto for the flavor. Mildly tingly mouthfeel. Light-medium body.
Very hazy body. Light malt sweetness with a fruity yeastiness underneath. The flavor was yeasty funk, light malty sweetness, and very light floral hopping. OK

This draft brew from a festival poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that was mostly diminishing and left behind a hazy uncarbonated dark yellow-orange colored body. The mild aroma was malty and sweet. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The funky flavor contained notes of malt hops and floral. A decent one but not one that I would consider buying again.

Draft. Very small white head that was mostly lasting, sparse lacing, no visible carbonation, and a butterscotch hue. Nose was malty, subtle hops, and some fruit notes. Flavor was sweet, malty, fruity, and some hops. Tingly mouthfeel. Light-medium body.

Cask at Draft House. Pale yellow, light haze, decent foamy white head. Aroma has straw with some light vinegary lemon. Body is medium, low carbonation, smooth. Taste is light with some wet hay, a bit soupy, astringent grapefruit finish with a breathy bitterness. OK, astringency reduces the quaffability.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Red Lion, Milford on Sea. A hazy copper colourd beer with an aroma featuring some lemony hops. The taste is bitter with more citrus hops. Although there are nice eomponenets to this beer it seemed a bit tired and unfresh spoiling it somewhat.

1st December 2009 Pigs Ear. Very dark brown beer, clear at the edges. Light palate. Seems like a porter to me! Light tangy malt - and err no real chocolate. Finishes light and with more porter like tang. Not bad but way to miss your own beer title!

Cask. Dark reddishbrown, almost black. Roasted malts, well balanced chocolate aroma, a hint of coffee and licorice. Dryish taste, slightly sour roastedness. Slick texture, a bit thin maybe. Good stuff.

Cask (?, Helsinki) 6 chocolate cake and cream aroma 5 dark dark dark, healthy head 7 Pleasant chocolaty taste, but something a tad mdedicinal too. 3 carbonation low. Palate a touch simple. Finish dry. 13 certainly tasty, but a bit thin and dry. Something lacking.

(Draught.) Opaque, very dark brown, with a bubbly, beige head. Intense aroma of heavily roasted malts, with notes of espresso, chocolaty mocha, and strong black tea. Slightly ashy with a hint of smokiness. Flavor roughly reflects aroma, albeit somewhat watery, with more prominent notes of tea, and a hint of dark berries. Long, roasted aftertaste. Very mild carbonation, medium body, slightly oily mouthfeel. Different and fairly enjoyable.

Cask@Old Bank, Turku. Quite much pitch black colour, mediumsized longlasting brown head. Aroma is chocolate, mild coffee, some roasted malts and also dark dry fruits. Flavour is quite much the same. A very pleasantly balanced stout.
cask ... black thin tan head ... ligth chocolate and coffee roast nose ... big smooth chocolate ... some toasted oats ...

Cask gravity at Pig’s Ear BF 09. Bit of a disappointment really as I love this brewery and they normally produce really good tasty beers. Black with ruby edges. It’s disappointing, like a watered down porter with only some choc, definitely not double choc.

(Cask at Angleterre) Poured almost black with medium sized and light brown head. Aroma contained coffee, chocolate and roastedness. Palate was medium bodied with low carbonation. Flavours were malts, coffee, roastedness, chocolate and bitterness. Aftertaste was almost acrid and roasty.

Cask Real Ale 0.25L glass. Pale brown head (5mm). Dark black reddish colour. Quite dry taste. Slight sourness. Taste of dark bittersweet chocolate. Excellent dry stout. At the end soft chocolatey nose from the glass bottom.
Cask at Pigs Ear beer festival, London 2009. Deep ruby coloured pour with beige head. Chocolate aroma. Roasty, chocolaty, sweet taste. Easy drinking, pleasant chocolate stout from Dark Star.
Significantly better than Bulmer's (UK) itself, with a nice balance of apples, tartness, and honeyed booze, it's a real value in a country that sorely lacks it (16.9 oz can, Dublin, Ireland)

Can sample at a tasting at Max’s place. Thanks Tom L. Clear yellow. Decent apples aroma with a sugary hint and a bit of sulphur. Rather dry flavor, mildly tart, with a light sweetish note, and a dry green apples finish with a bitterish note. A light alcoholic note.
Appearance: medium orange/borderline yellow. No head. Aroma: mild apple, apple chews. Flavour: same, apples and apple chews with some carbonation. Unmemorable.
Bottle at yespr. Clear yellow coloured with a medium sized white ehad. Fruity aroma of apples and apple peel. Fruity flavour of apples and apple peel. Tart finish of apples.
clear yellow, small white head. Aroma is apple, slightly spicy.flavor is apple, slightly bitter apple peely
Can. A pale yellow beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of apples. The flavor is sweet with notes of apples.
50 cl bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is citric and crisp apple fruity. Citric and crisp apple fruity. Citric and fruity finish. Simple.
Can @ yespr tasting. No head. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are vague apples, fruits and sugary notes. Medium body, soft carbonated.

Can 50 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a clear yellow with a small white head. Very, very subtle apple aroma. Light body, heavy carbonation, very subdued apple flavours with a lightly tart finish. Macro crap that’s hardly seen an apple. 230212

Can sampled in the cottage in Astee while teaching my parents how to play "asshole." Pours a clear golden yellow body with fizzy carbonated lacing that dissipates quickly. Aroma is light apples. Mouthfeel is very dry, like a cheap champagne with notes of apple, of course.
Butelka 0,33 litra. Barwa s³omkowa, iskrz¹ca. Niska, bia³a piana, szybko siê redukuje. Zapach o œredniej intensywnoœci. Doœæ czysty smak jab³ek. Wysoko wysycony.

Tap @ Hugos w friends/chef. Appearance: pours clear golden with low white soapy head and lacing. aroma/taste: range of apples, light oak and light vinegar. palette: medium fruity aroma, average carbonation, medium body, medium sweetness, balanced by a light to medium acidity, average duration and a watery texture. Overall: well balanced cider
Sweet, great strength, perfect on a warm day, exceeds over others it's price range

has anybody had a issue with the april2019 batch . Pale colour sour smell and the taste is nasty . had to take back to shop londies in clane tryed sample out of 4 cases they where all the same .Iknow when they are right i drink it every night and these where not right
Golden sweet. No head. Good strength . Tarty apple taste. Needs bit more woody flavours. Nice though if not especial.

Can as "Devils Bit Mountain Irish Orchard Cider". Golden body, minimal head. Aroma has fermented apple juice. Taste has sweet, almost full bodied apple juice. Finish has light tartness. Feels rushed - needs some more woody notes and complexity that develops over time. It's perfectly drinkable but I wouldn't give this any medals.

330 ml bottle, as Mountain Crest Canadian Lager, from Mountain Crest Brewing Company, Calgary. Brewed with Canadian 2 Row Malt. ABV is 4.7%. Bought at Vaaland, Bryne. Pale golden colour, moderate white head. Moderate grassy aroma. Bland flavour, but no offensive side-notes. Some malty sweetness, very moderate hops. Won’t buy again.

On bottle as Mountain Crest Canadian Lager at Meny, Vollebekk. Golden color, good foam- stays for a good while. Aromas of boiled vegetables, some malt- When beer gets tempered nasty aromas makes a solid presense, papir. Light body & complexity. Some bitterness Not good stuff

I got this after taking the brewery tour at Minhas. This pours a clear, pale yellow color with a foamy, off-white head. The scent is mostly of grassy grains. There is a pretty good punch from the grain flavor but it doesn’t exactly make for a good taste. Drinks a little chewy and finishes slightly bitter and chalky. A nice step up from Budweiser, but that’s about it.

Bought in the variety pack. Another decent beer by Michelob. These guys could be my favorites of the domestic swill. This sort of reminded me of Shocktop or Blue Moon, but with more of a Belgian feel. Has more fruity flavors such as bananas, cloves, and extra sugar added....also citrusy of course. Lots of sweets, but a little tartness to balance it out. Pours a hazy light orange/darker yellow color. Not a lot of carb. on this one. Glad I sampled in the variety pack, cause I would look for this again as a lawnmower and/or economy beer.

This beer has a hazy and bright straw yellow colored body with a nice two to three finger white head. The head fades slowly and its lacing is slick. The aroma is full of nice banana and some light clove notes from the yeast which also adds nice bready notes to the sweet wheat maltiness in the aroma. There is a tasty sweet bready/wheaty malt base with a nice fruity yeast character that adds to the base maltiness. The banana notes are sweet up front then dry out a touch towards the finish. The body and texture have an average medium feel with average carbonation.

Pours a cloudy (unfiltered) yellow-orange color with a head that stands up about 3/4 of an inch tall. Head quickly reduced to a ring of foam that only covered the outer ring of the glass. Smells of bready/wheaty malts and spices. Taste is similar to others in this style, but I found this beer to have a slight metallic taste towards the finish.

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark golden with a decent white head. Nice aroma of bubble gum and clove with hints of lemon and banana. Flavors of clove, lemon and banana with a hint of some other spice. Decent for a German hefe and also for A-B.
Decent if faint banana and yeast aroma, not a horrible interpretation of a hefeweizen.
A pleasant carbonation is offset by the watery, sour finish. Not enough of that yeasty punch that I like out of a Bavarian style beer. On a hot summer day, it may hit the spot.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a tall Pilsner glass. There appears to be no freshness date only an odd bottle number. (09232 VB49) Appearance: This beer has a hazy and bright straw yellow colored body with a nice two to three finger white head. The head fades slowly and its lacing is slick. Smell: The aroma is full of nice banana and some light clove notes from the yeast which also adds nice bready notes to the sweet wheat maltiness in the aroma. Taste/Palate: There is a tasty sweet bready/wheaty malt base with a nice fruity yeast character that adds to the base maltiness. The banana notes are sweet up front then dry out a touch towards the finish. The body and texture have an average medium feel with average carbonation. Notes: This is an all-around solid beer in my opinion and one that I would like to see it by itself in 6 packs.

Pours a hazy pale orange. Head dissipated almost immediately. No lacing. I can smell the sweet aroma from feet away. On closer inspection a sickly sweet smell overpowers everything else. Smell artificial orange flavoring and something that smells vaguely of circus peanut candy. The more I smell it the more unpleasant it becomes. An otherwise completely average hefe weizen is made worse by artificial orange flavoring and watery mouthfeel. This is more like a beer flavored soda than a beer.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a hazy golden yellow color with a medium sized off white head and decent carbonation. The aroma provides a nice whiff of banana, some cloves, yeast. The flavor is primarily banana with cloves, yeast and wheat playing secondary roles. Light-medium bodied, refreshing. For what it is, this wasn’t a bad option at a party with non craft beer types.
Definite banana and clove aroma and taste with a phenolic aftertaste (which is something I desire in a Hefe-style). Not too bad, but not the best in this style.
Bottle courtesy of Beerhunter111. Thanks. Hazy amber brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, wheaty, caramel and yeasty. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. A bit watery. 060217
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes braunes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, röstmalzig, leicht fruchtig würzig. Geschmack hefig, leicht würzig, leicht fruchtig.
Absolute Einheitsware, die mit ihrer Süße durchaus heftig daherkommt. Hefe, Süße, ein paar Früchte. Normales Weizen ohne Extras.

Deep brown colour with creamy head and medium body. Nose of yeast. Taste of malt, yeast, torf, burnt caramel, leaves, barnyard and wood. Easy to drink but just average, little bit too sweet in the finish.
Cloudy brown yellow, large off-white head. Slightly fruity, wheaty and yeasty. Shy hints of chocolate.

Decent but not ourstanding dunkelweizen. Tongue feels like it has been scraped after drinking this. Initial taste is decent, but metallic feeling in mouth afterwards. Nice color and head, faint aroma, but really tastes like ashes afterwards....
The head is medium, the body dark brown. It smells fruity-yeasty, a bit apple. The taste is yeasty, darkmalty, fruity-sweet. In the aftertaste also a bit bitter. Ok 10/9/10/9/12/9

Bottle 500ml. @ home. Murky - muddy medium gey amber color with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, wheat, dusty, light caramel, moderate yeasty, prune and raisin notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery . creamy, carbonation is soft. [20101003]

(bottle) Hazy, murky brown colour with a big and dense, slightly beige foamy head. Sweet, moderately yeasty and wheaty aroma with soft toasty and nutty accents, restrained fruity notes and shy phenolic spices. Shy sweet and slightly sour flavour, rather light bodied with a calm carbonation. Shy toasted and moderately wheaty and fruity taste with a slightly sourish and wheaty finish. Decent stuff (13.VIII.09).

Bottle (Danke, Jonas!): Hazy, chestnut-amber coloured, smaller, slowly collapsing off-white head; spicy nutty and phenolic nose with dark-maltyand fruity undertones; moderate sweetish-sourish flavour, medium bodied, a bit oily; sweet-malty and sourish finish. Quite well rounded Dunkelweizen.............

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: I love this beer. One of the best Weissbiers I have ever had. It is malty, tasty and the dark cloudiness is awesome!

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: On tap at the Brewpub. A cloudy, dark brown colour with a medium high, creamy, light brown head. An aroma of roasted malt. The taste is medium sweet and light bitter. A medium to full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation and a medium long finish. A really good dunkel

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: Clear dark amber pour with dense beige head, long lasting with significant lacing. Malty aroma with some smokiness. Smooth mouthfeel with some bitterness and malty finish. My favourite at the venue (I’m not that into weis)

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: (On tap) Basically clear orangey brown with a beige, lacing head. Aroma of roasted malt and a little burned caramel. Medium body, solidly malty with roasted accents. Short, dry and lightly hoppy finish. Solid. 160508

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: also at the waterfront wid OMA...she had the cappi....good good lacing, to go with the good head...more wheat folks!...odd bitters...some subtle choco wheat flavours..i’ve had better.

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: [Draught at the brewpub (November 2005)] Muddy nut brown. Toffee aroma. Sweet and lightly roasty with rounded, somewhat mellow mouthfeel. Low hop rate, low bitterness. Not very fun.

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: On tap at the Brewpub. A cloudy light golden colour with a medium high, good lacing, off-white head. An aroma of malt and yeast. The taste is light bitter. A medium body, oily to watery texture, soft carbonation and a medium long, dry finish.

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: Cloudy golden with light medium lasting head leaving some lacing. Neutral malty aroma. High carbonation with some body and bitter finish.

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: (On tap) Very cloudy golden with an off-white head leaving some lacework. Aroma of malt and yeast. Fairly high carbonation. Medium body with good malt accents but also yeast and vitamin C. Dry and lightly hoppy finish. A classic Zwickl. 160508

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: at the waterfront with OMA...Pours a hazy cloudy yellow...great lacing and goood head....mist smell....big wheat influence in all there beers..not that bad.

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: [Draught at the brewpub (November 2005)] Cloudy golden, small head. Bready malt aroma. Sweet and lightly soapy with clean mouthfeel and notes of grassy hops. Medium bitterness.

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: On tap at Paulaner. A cloudy orange-yellow colour with a small, good lacing, white head. An aroma of malt and fruit (grapefruit, pineapple). The taste is light sweet and medium bitter. A medium body, oily and creamy texture, average carbonation and a medium long, light bitter finish

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: [Draught at the brewpub (November 2005)] Hazy yellow, average head. Sweaty grassy hop aroma. Dry and bready with crisp, rounded mouthfeel. Distinct, bitter finish. Jever-like, but meatier.

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: Not a fan of the type. The foggines disturbs me. Too light colour. Rich aroma. Pleasant tropical flavour. Not a fan of the palate.

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: Pours cloudy amber with big fluffy head. Great banana and clove flavour. Medium carbonation and mouthfeel. Predominantly banana with clove flavours. Awesome beer

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: Buena espuma, buena aroma, turbia, buen cuerpo, ligeramente ácida como buena cerveza de trigo.

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: De las mejores cervezas que he probado. Una rubia turbia con gran aroma y mejor sabor, que es una lástima que no se importe a Venezuela.

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: De las mejores cervezas que se venden a gran escala, la apariencia es inmejorable el sabor a cereal y la textura densa típica de las cervezas de trigo

column2: Western Cape: Cape Town, South Africa
column5: Es una de las mejores cervezas que tomé en mi vida. El aspecto es fántastico, el sabor de otro mundo y el cuerpo fenomenal. A partir de hoy está en la lista de mis cervezas favoritas. Grosa Paulaner!

The fat lady in the dirndl muttered "yes, of course", on my question if they really brewed on the premises (I had my doubts), and served me their "Hausbrau", as she called it, for the decent price of € 2,50 for a half litre glass. The beer was also decent, nothing more. Blonde and cloudy. Soft hoppy, powdery, yeasty flavor. Hints of citrus. Just a bit medecinal, bitter aftertaste.

Cask-conditioned at The Grapes, Bristol where it was badged as "Firkin Good Show". I am not 100% sure that this was the same beer but the description is pretty much spot on. Amber in colour with some sweet malts, juicy hops and a decent bitter finish. A good session bitter.

Cask gravity at the South Devon Beer Festival, 21/09/2006. A murky amber colour with a small head. A sweet pear aroma with some hoppiness. Taste is hoppy with honey and citrus. A light roasted malt finish with light bitterness. Not bad at all.
Bottled. Pours a beautiful Amber. Malty aroma with some sweetness. A. It more bitter than expected. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Surprisingly bitter. Almost IPA-ish. I dig it. The initial bite tingles along with the alcohol and the bitter kicks in. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from bradley....decent balance a tad sweet...malty but very drinkable...thanks bradley.
Bottle, Ann Arbor, MI. Amber copper appearance. Spiced malt aroma. Sweet. Bready. Caramel with faint spice finish.
Pours copper with an ample amount of tan head. Aroma has cider esters and light caramel malt tones. Flavor is very sweet with a bit of a metallic finish.
Bottle. Pours hazy copper, tan head. Aroma of sweet bread. Light sweet taste, very metallic flavor might be spoiled. Bitter finish, pretty foul.

Bottle. Amber-copper colored with a big, fluffy, long lasting head. Aroma s malty, slight caramel. Taste was slightly malty sweet up front but the after taste was too hoppy bitter in the finish. Not my idea of what a good American Märzen beer should taste like.
Orangey copper, with a sizey beige head. Smells caramel and toffee, with some grassy hops. Taste is smooth caramel and toffee, with a peppery finish. Not bad.
Red amber color with a white head. Does not have a prominate smell. The taste is chemical and has a bad after taste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

Draft at MBGSF07 from notes. Pours a clear amber color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have toasted bread, grass, caramel, mild bitterness to the finish, like many of their beers, boring with not much to get excited about.

Pint can from Joe’s Beverage Warehouse. Pours dark brown with a thick, lasting tan head. Nice aroma of sweetened coffee and a touch of vanilla. Palate is a bit thin. Very smooth flavor. Sweetened coffee, light vanilla, and just a touch of a bitter coffee bite at the end. Quite enjoyable.
Dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma is vanilla, coffee and chocolate. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter.

Pours black with a three finger, beige head. Aroma is molasses and light roast. Taste is corn syrup, moving to instant coffee and bananas, with some roast. Finish is bitter roast. A less-than-pleasant porter.
12 oz. bottle pours a dark brown color with a small off white head. Aromas of vanilla, coffee, roasted malt. Medium bodied, a little thin, but tastey ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A recent addition to the Wychwood portfolio. Had this in Esquire House, Glasgow (JDW) in July 2007. Pale amber in colour with tight white head. Faint hop aroma with thin mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt base gives a digestive biscuit base with slight green apple fruit notes. Hop resin evident in a dry bitter aftertaste. Finish has a zesty, citrusy, gooseberry fruit flavour in the palate. A good session ale.
draught at the Anchor Inn, Sidmouth (08/2010). Blond colour, white head. Citrusy hops dominate, a bit thin it is, though.

Cask-conditioned at The Star, Bath 6/9/08. Amber with a slight white head. Aroma of butterscotch with some yeast and earthy hops. Flavour started sweet, with red fruit, citrus hops and a moderately bitter finish. Ok.

Handpulled cask at the Southern Cross, Watford.Pale yellow with a small white head. Lager maltiness with a chrisp citric bitterness. Very refreshing and one of the better beers I have tried from this brewer.

Cask @ White Horse, Oxford. Pours a clear golden color with small white head. Fruity malty caramel aroma with some citrus hints. Fruity malty and slightly hoppy flavor with some hints of citrus. Malty and hoppy fruity finish.

A Mes rate: Cask at the Hobgoblin. Mid amber colour with a reasonable head. Farty and sulphuric aroma. Hoppy flavour with plenty of lemon and a malty finish with some light fruity sweetness. One of the better Wychy offerings that they have had on at the Hob.

Cask gravity at Bowl Inn, Charing. I don’t often get the chance to try Wychwood beers in cask, so I’d thought I would try this. Copper colour with lasting off white head. Yeast/hop aroma, ok in mouth, malts are pale and not over the top. Hop on finish is a little dusty, but got good citrus flavours and definite dryness. Reasonably pleasant.

Cask conditioned, gravity dispense at Merton Beer Festival 2006. Light golden in colour, citrusy nose, with a clean and crisp refreshing citrusy taste and nice bite to it. Very good beer. Also had this in Hobgoblin Cowley Road on frequent occasions this summer.
<!-- b -->Aug 06<!-- /b --> Cask conditioned @ Humble Plumb, Soton. Decent light coloured bitter. Moderate citric hoppiness and some sweet malt. Not bad. 3.1
Cask Handpump at the Dispensary, Liverpool 28/08/2006 Hop aroma. Clear golden coloured crisp on the palate and hoppy. Some dryness in a slightly creamy bitter finish.

Bottle. Golden brown with low carbonation. Aromas are tannin with apple skin and yeast. Earthy stewed apple with hints of vinegar. Flavours are sweet jammy apple with earthy apple skin. Peppery with woody aspects. Very solid.

1l flagon, bought from the farm in October 2004. Dry version bought at the same time and rated in December 2004. Not surprisingly, this is similar to the dry (qv) but sweeter. A bit too sweet for me if anything. The sweetness may have been accentuated by the couple of years aging softening out the tannins. Like the Dry, this is very dark for a cider. It seems to have darkened even more with age to deep tawny/ruby colour. Still some fruit left. The oak aging has left its mark in a vanilla tinged aroma. Also a slightly rubbery edge. Very mellow mouthfeel with vinous elements and raisins, to go with the smooth apple backdrop. Interesting, but I preferred the younger Dry version.

column1: La Cidrerie du Village Folie de Glace
column4: La Cidrerie du Village - Vergers Bernard Dubé
column5: Sample 2 oz from bottle. Clear bright gold pour. Aroma is cidery, nice apple wine notes, light caramel, light citrusy notes, mild vanilla. Taste is sweet, cidery, lots of apple peel, unfiltered apple juice, mildly tannic, strong acidity. Palate is med-full bodied. Good.
Dark golden with decent head. Bitter hops...balanced well. Just not that great, ok. I wrote, "Almost Equity". WTF is that? Damn ratings on phones....

Bronzed body with a thin, faded head. Bitter, thin leafy hop nose. On the palate, this one reflects English-style craftmanship with some bitter leafy hops with notes of tea. Watered sugar finish. A decent change of pace the straddles the EPA / ESB styles, more than an IPA.
Draft @ Burien. Hazy, tan. Lots of crystal malt, moderate bitterness. A little old school with All that chewiness.
Draft - Pithy hops and mellow mellow pale malts. Cloudy orange gold with a decent white head. Citrus grapefruit hops, light bitterness and a bitter dry finish. Not bad, a bit on the bland side.

Nose of toast crystal malt and earthy hop notes. Floral and herb in there. Hazy orange amber pour nice head and lace. Flavors of toast, medium caramel, earthy floral hops some dank. Not bad jus uninteresting.
Tap at LCW Clear copper-amber pour. Piney edge to the flavor, very sharp, not in a pleasant way. Prickly mouthfeel. My least favorite of the evening.

Draft @ Elliot Bay. Clear amber with a tiny head. Aroma of sweet caramel with some citrus and herbal hops. Flavor is sweet and malty with low hop bitterness and some fruitiness. Medium body with residual sugar. This is way too sweet and not enough hop bitterness.
On draft at the brew pub. Burien location. Classic lightly floral iPa. Light citrus and piney hops. Refreshing.

Draft (Burien, month or so back): Lots of caramel in the malts. Perhaps a bit too much. Relatively tasty, though. Hops eventually made their way to the top, bringing grassy flavors and spicy nips. Average IPA. Sessionable, just not overly exciting.

Date: September 18, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, Elliott Appearance: hazy copper, fine off white head Aroma: sweet crystal malt aroma, light citrus hops Flavor: sweet caramel malt flavor, lots of earthy and citrus hops, touch of sweet butterscotch, long bitter finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: ** /4

On tap at the Burien location brewpub. Pours out a amber/orange topped with a nice sand head. Aroma of floral hops and a nice malt mix. Tast was of citrus hops, bread malts, and a little sweetness. A solid IPA.
Murky brown with no head. Roasty malt and candi sugar aroma. Medium body. Decent enough earthy yeast and spicy sweet candi sugar flavors with some roasty malts.

This is the one beer I had at EBB that was just awful. Has to be off...honestly, I should have said something to the bartender. Should have taken more notes about the actual aspects of the beer, but I didn’t. Just bad. Hopefully it was a bad barrel.
On tap at Brewpub Seattle. Pours out a cloudy amber topped with a small head. A sweet aroma not a lot of normal hef tast.
Murky amber with not a trace of head or lace. There is a sickening amount of sweetness to this beer. The nose, the flavor, it is everywhere. Thin palate and seemingly uncarbonated.
On tap at brewpub. Decent...enjoyable and refreshing. A little bit of dark fruit with a bite. Worth trying if in the house.

column1: Rock Bottom South Denver Oak Aged Vanilla Porter
column5: The Rock Bottom set of reviews is a reflection of my hasty attempt to drink a small quantity of many beers and produce accurate and helpful reviews. Clearly I’ve failed, but I hope my incoherent and cryptic critiques can help at least a few folks who wander in and want to know what to order. Note: I had this at the Rock Bottom South Denver location. Simply put, the Vanilla Bean Stout is a failed attempt at a sweet stout. What was in my glass was no sweet beer. It was a liquid most disappointing. The appearance is a dull monolithic black with no head, but the nose is an outré combination of cookies and vanilla. Sadly, the taste is a flop, adhering to a simple formula of simple malts bitterness. It hardly allows any of the vanilla to struggle through. Yet another tally mark to count the disappointing sweet stouts I’ve had thus far.

column1: Rock Bottom South Denver Oak Aged Vanilla Porter
column5: tap at the s. denver location. (o.k., first th ing to be aware of, idthat i am typing this out while hammered and sipping a vodka drink after spending quite a bit of time at the brewpub, just know that this was the first beer i had trhere and the only i took notes on,) solid black pour with a nice lasting & lacing coffee with cream coored head. aroma is an assload of chocolate, wet rope, and nller bean. tadte is like a S’more, i know i’ve used this comparison before, but this is more of a fudge covered S’more! vanilla is around in this and does not make a vanilla lover sad. but the vanilla is more of an accent here, not a leading character. vanilla is noticeable and most dominant in the finisdh. this is an incredibly sweet, and chocolately beer. thick, and it makes me happy.
Geprobeerd van tap bij de brouwerij. Het is een helder goudgeel bier met een wit schuim. Het heeft een moutige geur. De smaak is moutig en een beetje pils achtig.

Draught @ Brouwcafé Kareltje. Clear golden color, decent sized white head. Smell and taste remind me of a pilsener instead of a (typical) blond beer. Lightly some bitter, some malts, nothing more actually. A bit weak both in flavor and in body.

Draught @ Brouwerij Heusden, Stadshaven 1, 5256 BA Heusden, Netherlands. Clear medium orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, burnt rubber, light caramel. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090904]

Bottled. Aroma is lemon sour, wheat and hints of banana. Cloudy, yellow color, white head, good lace. Bitter, grain start, soon citric, sour lemon, extra bitter upon swallowing. Light, very refreshing, bit dry. Smells a little infected but this does not return in the flavor. Interesting, looking forward to the other beers.
Bottle 0,3ltr: Amber coloured brew like an Konick but lesser of taste. Its bitter of taste but not an bad product.

Draught @ Brouwerij Heusden, Stadshaven 1, 5256 BA Heusden, Netherlands. Unclear medium grey amber color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, soap, light hoppy, moderate yeasty, soap. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration, fruity. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20090904]
Bottled. Medicinal bitter aroma. Hazy, amber/brown color, beige head, good lace. Light sweet, light bitter, some caramel malts, light herbal, medicinal flavor as well, rather thin.

brown plastic bottle(1000ml). -Croatian beer for slovenian supermarket, hmm??? What to say... As if slovenes don’t have enough of their own shit for supermarkets, now they started to import croatia’s. Question: What good to expect from Osjeèka even when producing for export? Answer: Nothing. Yellow coloured, small but surprisingly lasting white head (chemicals for sure), herbal nose. Slight malty aroma with vegetable (celery) notes, very watery.

Bottle, clear golden blond coloured beer with a small white head and little carbonation. Light older sweeter madeira aroma and hoppy hints. Full palate. FInish is ligth sweet, again somewhat madeira older touched and light bitter. Medium one.
cloudy gold blond coloured body with a white head a hoppy fruity aroma a sweet fruity hoppy taste with a sweet bitter finish
Clear golden bolond coloured beer with small white head and no carbonation. Herby malty aroma. Full palate. Finish is bit bitter and herby.
Bottle, 33 cl. Golden color, with big white head. Medium Body. You taste the alcohol. Very hoppy, but a little sweet to. Very good, but not a topbeer.
Bottle. Dead yellow colour, very weak head, a very light, somehow bad aroma, and an unpleasant taste. Bad.
Superpale yellow beer with a medium, white, froathy head. Superminimal aroma and flavor of a cheap beer with grassy hop, weak malt taste. Nothing, absolutly redundant one.

No 776 Rated: 25.07.2009 Can 500 ml, ratet ib Bogacs, Hungary. Appearance: Pours pale golden, weakly carbonated and with sediments floating in the body texture, head is snowy white, initially medium, slowly decreasing to small, foamy to frothy, leaving some lacing, unstable and quickly changing. Aroma: Very weak aroma mainly denoting watered down and cooked corn grains, dull, again overcooked corn, no hops, no malt, no yeast, no alcohol, non-impressive, graphite. Flavour: Drinking this beer is like drinking mineral water with a drop of regular light lager working only for appearance impression (unfortunately pale golden), slightly salty, notes of cooked corn soup, preety unimpressive, dull, boring, totally without charcater but not negative. Finish duration is short. Palate: Body is light, texture is watery, carbonation on palate is moderate, finish feel is watery, neutral and in fact totally non-existant.
Canned(500ml). -Pale yellow coloured, medium sized white head, few streams of carbonation, neutral nose. The closest description goes like this: water with dust. Dryish finish. Awful.

Can, purchased somewhere in Budapest. Poured a dull shiny yellow body with a big white head that went away fast. No, absolutely no aroma, Ogi sensed something sour, but I simply couldn’t sense anything. Taste? ancient dust with a touch of grain, extremely light acidity. Soft mouthfeel because it’s so watery but bordering on disgusting. 1.1 is WAY more than it deserves. Pécsi probably hit a new low with this one.
Canned. Thx rickgordon Pale yellow with a brief, white head. Artificial sour aroma. Very thin and watery. Flavour from plastered walls and chalk.

Canned. Pale, very pale golden colour, with cottony white head. Dusty, old-ish pilsner nose. Extremely thin in body with a light touch of honey pastilles. Gypsum is also present, but that is more than you can say about other flavour sensations, which are totally non-existing. No bitterness either.
50 cl can thanks to rickgordon On March 7, 2009 Pale straw color, braely yellow. White head. Dryish, plsater, dry-wall scent. Thin chalk taste. Thin mouthfeel, low bitterness.
Can (50 cl), thanks rickgordon. Extremely pale golden, thin fizzy head. Grainy, sourish, honeyish aroma with strong notes of wet cardboard. Thin and fizzy. Quite dry, low bitterness.

Location: Draft at the brewpub, 10/22/14 Aroma: It has a clean malt aroma, some caramel, grainy notes, and a little grass Appearance: Pours a glowing reddish-orange with a thick, a lasting off-white head, and plus lace Flavor: The flavor is a little sweet, clean and malty, with a nice, balancing, light bitterness Palate: It has a light-medium body, easy drinking, with a clean feel, and a lively carbonation Overall Impression: I thought this was a pretty nice, clean example of the style. The nose is a little thin, but not bad at all. It leans malty, but there’s enough of that grassy German hop flavor to provide some balance. It is pretty clean and easy drinking despite a higher than average carbonation. Not an amazing beer, but at over 7% it is very quaffable.

Growler filled at the brewpub and consumed a couple of days later. Pours a lightly hazed deep gold with a moderate yellow-white head that lasted through the first third of the glass and left partial lace. Mild aroma of malt with a trace of German hops. The flavor is thankfully more distinguishable with malt, light fruit sweetness, and a bit of lightly toasted white bread. Quite pleasant actually. Mild bitterness accompanied by some residual sweetness at the finish which lingers briefly beyond the swallow. Soft on the palate. Enjoyable.
Pours reddish brown with white head. Aroma is all malt, toasty caramel. Very very similar to the amber marzen, distinguisged by a little thixker mouthfeel.
On tap at the Brewpub. Pours a pale orange amber color with white head. Sweet caramel taste with slight bitters. Decent.

Standard Marzen. The aroma was malty, caramel, noble hops. The appearance was a slightly hazy amber/red. white head. The flavor was caramel, noble hops. The finish is sweet, caramel, brown sugar, noble hop bittering kicking in after a few seconds. Medium in body. Not bad, hardy exceptional. Fairly standard offering. Thought I could expect more in a Marzen from a Brew Haus.

Tap at the Brewpub: They must change the recipe for this every year. This did not at all seem like an Oktoberfest. Pours a deep hazy amber with a dense off white head. There’s a lot of American hops in the nose. Fruity with lots of zesty citrus (this is definite an American Ale) Has some bready malt undertones, but it’s mainly an orange-rind bouquet. Has a nice creamy feel with a crisp and well hopped flavor. Lots of American hop notes with zesty citrus backed by a soft toasted malt back (which becomes more evident as it warms) Fairly earthy and twiggy throughout, with slightly peppery/earthy American hop notes into the finish. This beer threw me off because it’s supposed to be an Oktoberfest, which it is not, but it’s a decent, well hopped American Ale. I rated it considering style to an extent, but didn’t let that take away too many points because it’s a pretty solid ’beer’, not ’Oktoberfest’.

Murky orange beer - very strong fruity and floral characteristics in the aroma - honey sweetness up front, followed by medium bitterness, then the strong fruitiness comes through, as well as a grainy, almost wheaty flavor - a very non-traditional, but sadly, not very tasty, oktoberfest.

I wasn’t happy with this one as I had it tonight. It looked good, it smelled okay, and the first taste was so off. I was expecting greatness, but I got a terrible tasting beer. I couldn’t suggest it to anyone.

Cloudy orange color with a mostly uninspiring head. Aroma had a distinct spice combination to it. Flavor had something of a general fruity/floral aspect to it. All in all it just feels like the flavor gives up too easily, if it had been a little more intense I would have liked it much more.
I had it on tap from the Black Haus’s sampler that they offer. This beer wasn’t a knock out, but definitely one of the better beers that they offer.

Draught at the brewpub Hazy blond color. A normal Wit, but with a sharper spicy character; they say "coriander and oranges", I say that it has a clean white pepper taste and some aroma as well. A bit strange but pleasant.

Pours a very light gold, cloudy with a nice white head. Aroma is bitter orange rind with a little lemon. Taste is very heavily spiced for a wit. A mild wheat base with strong white pepper, cardamon, and bitter orange flavors. Hints of honey and maybe even peppermint hide in there somewhere, although overall it remains quite dry. Mouthfeel is light and crisp, remains very drinkable even after a few. Rarely have I ever found a wit this strongly spiced; it may benefit from a little aging just to mellow a little.
Smells like soap, nuts, roasted grain, tastes the same, not very descriptive. I am not a huge Oktoberfest fan though.

(Growler thanks to bu11zeye) clear copper with no head. Nose of grain mash, buttered popcorn and light caramel. Taste of alcohol, caramel, grape skin bitterness, earthy cracker, buttered popcorn. Under-carbonated and hot when it shouldn’t be.
(Draught) Pours a clear copper body with a medium white head. Aroma of grain, earth, caramel, and huskiness. Flavor of grain, nuts, caramel, earth, and some citrus.

Handbottle thanks to bu11zeye. Pours with a clear orange body with a small white head. Aromas of grass, corn, toast, caramel and bread. Flavors of grain, corn, light fruit, caramel, cornuts. Medium to light bubbles, medium bodied. Good Marzen.

on tap at the covey thanks to jamie. what can i say other than this is one of the best ofest beers that i have ever had. orange in color with white head. flavor and aroma both were caramel, orange, and spice. one of my favorite ofest so far.

I am glad Jamie decided to brew this beer again. The beer pours an orange-amber color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the malt, but I also get some fruit characteristics. I am not entirely sure which fruit it is, but I think it is most similar to grapes. The flavor is caramel malt, grapes, grassy hops and some other fruit (possibly cherry and also some apple). Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very nice Oktoberfest, that is very drinkable. The alcohol is perfectly hidden, making this a sessionable beer even at 6.7 percent.

Pours a very cloudy burnt orange, with a nice white-ish head. Aroma has a burnt malt and caramelly quality with a certain kind of "funk" that I can only describe as being "lager-esque." Hopefully I can describe that better in the future. Taste has those same qualities, but takes on a distinct roastiness in the finish, as well as a subtle fruit quality. Beer feels pretty thick and slightly grainy for the style, but enjoyed that. Worth trying in the DFW area.

Pours a light orange/amber, cloudy and turbid with a creamy off-white head. Aroma is faint, a light toasty malt. Taste is more rich, toasty malt and thin caramel flavors. Flavors are pretty close to the same base malt as the amber with just a touch of light lager fruitiness. It’s not quite to style, especially with the alcohol content and being left unfiltered (called "Texas style" by the brewer), but that’s not necessarily a bad thing. Mouthfeel is soft with a medium-heavy unfiltered body. On first impression, I might call this a light bock instead. As I said, it’s not very much to style (had to take points off for that) and not suited for O-fest drinking but it did turn out to be an excellent beer.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at Red Rock, pours a clear pale golden with a small white head. Aroma brings out light grainy notes and a touch of earth. Flavour brings out light earthy notes and a touch of rye. Light and unassuming, with barely any rye presence. Rather lame.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: appearance: clear deep amber gold, with a short, fizzy, bright white head. aroma: assertive, peppery nose with some grassy and floral hop notes over toasted rye bread. taste: grainy, with crushed black pepper, lemon verbena, toasted rye, a hint of caramel, with a nice spicy undercurrent. finish: active carbonation, mouthfeel is very bright and zippy, lingering light spice and a little citrus. notes: Maybe the best beer I had in the SLC. This was really, really enjoyable. Excellent character. Draught at Red Rock in Salt Lake City, Utah.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Light aroma: Citrus fruit, bready. Biscuit, sweet malt flavor, fruity, and peppery spice that gets stronger in the finish (assuming it’s from the rye?)

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Draft flight 9/02-Pours a clear copper body with a small head. Aroma of malt, rye, and grains. Taste of the same. This medium bodied brew is well balanced.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Had on draft at the downtown location. This is a rich malty beer. The ABV is surprising since it has such a full mouth feel. A bit rye spicy and oily. Nice beer.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: gold blond coloured body with a white head a spicy grainy hoppy aroma a spicy grainy hoppy bitter taste with a alcholic bitter finish

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at Red Rock downtown Appearance: Clear golden with a medium sized white head and good lacing Aroma: Fruity, rye and spices Taste: Fruity, apricot and rye Nice and clean, easy drinking

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Pours a hazy brownish amber color. Aromas of grains, banana, fruit, and alcohol. Flavor is orangish and spice with a bittersweet finish. Good beer, just not something I would have often

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Enjoyed on tap at Red Rock brewpub. Pours light amber with off-white head. Nose has light caramel and miscellaneous grains. Rye comes through on the palate, although it has a rather thin body and soda-like characteristic - the carbonation just doesn’t seem right. Seems artificially sweet also. Quite watery and drinkable.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Smells of mild hops and rye. Light, mild hop bitterness in the taste. This amber pour has a crisp metallic finish.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pour is black in color. Small tan head. Slight smoky and Carmel malt aroma. Flavor is slightly smoky. Good blend of hops and malt. Slight bitter finish.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a dark mahogany color with a medium grey head. A light aroma of toasted malts and smoke. The flavor is nice; toasted malts, nutty, dry, some yeast, smoke. Smooth easygoing.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub downtown Appearance: Dark brown with a small beige head and some lacing Aroma: Roasted malts and some light smokiness Taste: Smokey, ashy, roasted malts with a slightly grainy mouthfeel A nice smoked porter, well balanced.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: (08/2006. Draft). A tasty beer, more porter than "smoked". Definite hints of smokiness up front, resolving quickly into classic porter aromas. Likewise in the taste ... a hit of smoke, that quickly resolves into a smooth, classic porter. Black. Nice head retention. Moderately carbonated. Medium-full bodied, and leaves just a hint of sweetness and residual sugar on the palate after. A nice beer.

Cask gravity at the South Devon Beer Festival, 23/09/2006. A dark brown/amber colour with a very small head. A strong, sweet toffee aroma. Taste is very sweet with malt, more toffee and caramel. A sweet malty finish with light bitterness. Nice, but too sweet for my liking.

Cask gravity at the South Devon Beer Festival, 21/09/2006. A golden colour with a small head. A slightly sweet hoppy aroma. A hoppy taste with a little citrus in the finish. A nice, simple session ale.
Tap. Press hazy reddish Amber, small off white head, decent lacing. Aroma is Malt, caramel, hints of pine. Flavor is light plus sweet, light plus bitter. Medium body. Kind of a harsh finish.
On tap at Draught House. Pours a clear copper with small white head that lasts. The aroma is toasted grain and caramel. Medium body, pine, resin, grain, bitter finish, good.
Pours with very little head a nice brownish red. Aroma is a nice citrusy goodness. Taste has a bit I’d bitter Bute to it. A little sweetness towards the end. Light body and sharp carb

On tap at the source. Pours with a clear bronze hued body with a tan head. Aromas are fruity, caramel, dry, pine, citrus and a lightly earthy hop character. Medium yeast. Flavors are of tangerine, caramel and dark fruit. Not too heavy on the crystal, it actually finishes dry and a bit grainy. Nicely drinkable.

Pint at draught house. Copper-orange color, small head, stable, collared. Great adhesion. Aroma is chrysanthemums, floral. I don’t taste the citrus as much, more bitter, burnt, and herbal. Hoppy, of course. Medium-bodied. Good beer, especially for a "house" selection. Easy to drink
(Draught) Pours an amber body with a medium off-white head. Aroma of caramel, raisins, and grass. Flavor of grass, caramel, cocoa, and herbs with a dry, bitter finish.

This is one of my favorites at the draught house. It pours a deep red to dark color It has a unique bitterness to it. the hopps are they but subtle. Has a nice head on it. This beer will sneak up on you and its very drinkable. one of my normal orders when I go. If they have it get it quick because it does not last long Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 04-09-2008 09:38:48

Pours medium amber colored with a slight brownish-red tint., slightlly cloudy, small, dense light tan head. Mild hoppy aroma, with a little bit of mineral. Superb lacing. Rich creamy mouthfeel, like a medium pale ale/ cream ale. Flavor is well balanced qualiy barley malt smoothness, combined with rich hops make for a truly outstanding, delicious beverage. Carbonation is on the lighter side but present enough to get a little bit of bite. This beer is perfect in more ways than 4. It’s so flavorul and smooth, yet not too heavy. There is a little bit of cocoa in the finish.

Aroma compares to heavily sugared down coffee with some light hops. Pours a dark mahogany brown with almost no head. Tasted is strong hops up front fallowed by a smoked coffee finish. Med body with well balanced flavor.

Draught at brewpub. Vibrant red beer with just a touch of a white head. Nose is sweet with a bit of hop presence. Flavor is really wonderful, sweet notes of raspberry and strawberry held in check by some light bitterness. Could be a bit thicker, but still a fantastically drinkable beer.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: On tap, dark orange-amber body, wfite fluffy head. Nose had yeast and lots of fruit. Flavor wasa swet and satisifying, and I am not bick on this style, but loved this. Very good fruit components come out as I worked my way thru, Very nice.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Amber with a nice white head. The beer has a spicy warm note but well balanced. . Therer is some alcohol in there but it does not over power the senses. It has a clean finish, making you want to go in for another and another and another taste.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Dark amber color with a medium sized off white head. Mildly sweet malty aroma, with some coriander, dried fruits and a touch of banana. Flavor starts off mildly sweet before becoming nice and dry on the finish. Dark, dried fruits, coriander and brown sugar are the flavors that stood out to me. Beer moved up around .3 pts by the time I finished. Got better with each sip.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: served out of a corny keg purchased at the brewery. lightly hazy pale yellow in color with a medium off white head. Aroma is citrus and floral hops, that mix well with light yeast and pils malt. Taste is lightly fruity, citrus, floral, with sweet pils malt. A light amount of bitterness in the finish. very good.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: My Bottom Line: Spicy hop nobility proffers its delicate citrusy jewels to the straw-hat-wearing, proud malt peasants. A well-crafted soft pils, this is. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam sets into the hazy pale yellow. -Hop flavor moves into grassiness as well, a fine match for the hay/straw maltiness. -Light sulphur is perceivable, fitting nicely with the flavor profile. -A milky cereal sweetness softened up and balanced out the savvy hoppiness. On tap at Tap NY.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Enjoyed at the brewery with the Defiant crew. Smells like freshly cut grass and looked like liquid dandellions. Ironic, considering this is what folks might call lawnmower beer. I had this one while it was still lagering, which explains the slightly sweet taste, but it was still highly drinkable and paired nicely with the pizza I was enjoying. We all noted that as this beer ages (for about another week) it will loose some of the grassy aroma and gain a much dryer and hoppier profile. I can’t wait!

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: A well made Pilsner. Yellow with white head. Up front noble hop aroma is complimented by some malt character. The flavor has a very soft malt with minimal bitterness, no where near as sharp as a German Pilsner.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Drank on tap at Defiant Brewing Company, in a ten ounce mug. Nice malty aromas, not mich head, a very nice and thin porter (as they should be)

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: solid porter, 10 oz. glass at the brewery. Fuggle hop gives it a decent bitterness. Bittersweet, fresh, lacy. Good drinkability.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: 2oz sample at International Great Beer Expo (Meadowlands). Pours dark brown with a thick khaki head. Aroma of dark malts, chocolate, and caramel. Taste of bitter dark chocolate, and roasted malt.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Tap at the brewery. Pours opaque black with a medium, frothy beige head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is roast and chocolate malt, dates, earthy and spicy hops. Flavor is malt dominant with light hops and bitterness, dark fruits and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Draft at the source. Dark brown color, thick briwn head, solid lacing. Aroma of chocolate milk. Taste is rich coffee grounds, bitter cocoa.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Draft at brewery. Pours coca cola brown with a thin khaki head. Slight metallic quality on the nose. Not getting a lot of malt flavor here. Finishes with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Eh!

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Draught at Drink, BK. Nearly black with a ring and a little lace. Sweet roast malt with milk and dark chocolate. Lactose comes through the big roasted malt and chocolate malt. Very bitter end after a sweet start and middle. Palate is thick but fades to a clean middle and coated end. Very satisfying porter.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Location: Sampled at the NY Brewfest on Governor’s Island, 6/19/10 Aroma: The nose has some chocolate, roasted/dark malts, and some caramel Appearance: Pours a solid brown color with a creamy tan head Flavor: This is a medium sweet porter with a bit of a hop kick in the finish Palate: The body is almost creamy, but with more carbonation then a normal creamy porter Overall Impression: This one tastes pretty good. It has a pretty good fell to it, and it drinks pretty nicely. My first beer from Defiant Brewing Company, and I enjoyed it quite a bit. I would drink this one again.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: On tap. Birdsall House. Peekskill NY. Dark thick creamy pour with a tan fluffy head. Roasty chocholet mouth with a Burnt bitter pallet. Go for it!

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Draft. Pours a dark brune body with an off white head. Chocolate malts, light brittle minerals, light roasted malt tones. Licorice with a light vanilla but the finish is drier like roasted malt. Decent porter.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
