column5: Nice and light and crisp bitterness. Dark amber color. Nice and smooth with some citrus.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: Cask at Mugs Ale House: Pours a hazy amber with a dense/strong creamy white head. The body is light and fluffy. The aroma is extremely perfumy and citric. Tart orange and acidic notes. The flavor is the same, with an overall citric acidity and lots of orange juice notes. Stuff isn’t bad, it’s just a bit perfumy and seems artificial in a way. The citric acidity is a bit weird as well, at least for the style.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: TAP NY 08. Lighty hazy amber in color with a small off white head. Aroma is a nice mix of floral and light citrus and english malt. Taste is very nice, and rather assertive with a strong floral hop presence with some light citrus, alot of english, and toasted/biscuity malts- medium bodied, assertive bitter finish. Really good ESB.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: On Cask at the Brazen Head, Brooklyn...This beer is surprisingly spicy and yet very mild. It is bitter, but not too tar. The citrus flavors and malts blend well together. It is very floral, cellared and musty. It makes me feel like I’m drinking something from 100’s of years ago. Maybe this beer is truly "authentic" for the style.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Golden/amber color with a good sized off white head. Nice hoppy aroma with some biscuit malt and a bit of wet hay. Flavor was only mildly bitter, with the hops being nicely balanced by the doughy malt and a bit of caramel. Extremely easy drinking, with a nice clean finish.

column2: Pearl River, New York, United States
column5: The brewers description is pretty accurate. Amber, with just a hint of orange depth in the color. Hop aroma is very earthly, english like, without being ’dirty’. The rich complexity of the malt is accentuated by the hops, with neither dominating the flavor. It has a good medium body, not watery nor to thick.

column1: Perry's Vintage Farm House Cider - Medium (Bottle)
column5: bottle from Seaton. Golden colour. Dry, sligtyl spoarling with tart apple flavours. Well balanced.

column1: Perry's Vintage Farm House Cider - Medium (Bottle)
column5: Bottle from Corks, Bristol. Deep gold in colour, with slight carbonation. Sweetish honeyed aroma. Fresh apple juice flavours, with a touch of dryness in the finish. Ok.

column1: Perry's Vintage Farm House Cider - Medium (Bottle)
column5: Bottle. Golden with light carbonation. Aromas are dry and woody with apple juice and some citrus. Flavours are ripe apple with oak woodiness and peppery notes. Dry on the finish.

column1: Perry's Vintage Farm House Cider - Medium (Bottle)
column5: Aroma is reasonably fresh apples, a little spice and some wood. Taste is similar not to sour but a decent dry finish.

column1: Perry's Vintage Farm House Cider - Medium (Bottle)
column5: [Bottle from CiderShop] Aroma of fresh apples and wood. Light body, slight dryness in finish.

column1: Perry's Vintage Farm House Cider - Medium (Bottle)
column5: Brought over from Dowlish Wake, Somerset, England. sweet aroma, lacks body. Has an oaky taste along with sweet cider. Very crisp. Very drinkable, I liked it.

column1: Perry's Vintage Farm House Cider - Medium (Bottle)
column5: Bottle. Golden colour. Easy drinking cider with a sweet aroma and taste and, though lacking in body, just enough sourness and dryness for balance. 15.10.06 Cask, gravity, at CAMRA bar, Bromham Mill, Bedford. More sourness in the aroma. The dryness was more pronounced. Rated 2.7.

Keg at PP SB, 14/11/14. Clear golden with a decent off white covering. Nose is straw, citric rind, light bread dough, vanilla, rather thin and found wanting. Taste comprises bitter orange, grassy, lemon rind, pale malt, light bread notes. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. So so, homebrew APA!

[ Keg ][ 8oz ][ PP Solana ][ $4 ][ Half Conical Pint ][ 10.10.14 ] >> Low Tide, now billed as an APA at 6.5% and made this year with wet Equinox hops. Pours a clear copper with okay foam. Nose is sticky, dank papaya. peach, grapefruit, a bit ’stinky’ and overripe. Taste is super bitter, grapefruit, soapy, dark bread and crust. Long, aggressive, hoppy finish. Mega IBU presence. Tried back to back with Inhopsicated, and the Inhopsicated felt juicier and easy to drink despite being a DIPA.
Draft at the 2006 Washington Cask Beer Festival. Didn’t stand out like the Wetlands did, but held in there with enough malt character to bite your tongue for more.

On tap at Pizza Port Ocean Beach, pours a hazy golden / copper with a small white head. Aroma and flavour of biscuity, crackery malt, light floral hops, and dry crackery malts. Pretty ordinary, but ultimately fairly boring. Solidly made.

On tap @ Pizza Port Bressi Ranch. Golden orange pour with a white head. Aroma has a nice orange peel character to it. Light pineapple, some floral hops, earth, and pine. A touch of grass and sweet malt. Flavor opens with a toast and bread malt sweetness to it. Lots of pine, orange peel, and flowers. A mild pineapple note on the back end. A touch bitter, too.

On tap @ the brewpub. Deeper gold colour than the Wet Hop, tighter head, early whips of lace. Aroma and hop profile lean more toward pine/conifer with a balanced malty sweetness. Not as explosively flavourful as the wet hop, but certainly still great.

Pizza Port Solana Edition. On tap at The Brickskeller during its "Whet" Hop Ales event with Tomme Arthur. Pours orange-copper with a white head and loads of lacing. The aroma is very light with some pale malt and very slight pine hop characteristics. The taste brings some fresh hops and a bit of greenness. Tomme informed us that this use 180 pounds of fresh hops in a 7-barrel batch. Feel brings some light bitterness and lower levels of carbonation. Overall, this was quite sessionable. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 10-29-2010
Hazy yellow with a persistent, yet thin head. Huge hops in the nose. Heavy handed hops in the mouth.

On tap at Brickskeller DC. Pours a clear orange with a thin, frothy white head. Nice, fresh aroma, not too punchy, lightly spicy, citrus, a little candy. Flavor is mild, sweet, orange, lemons, pine, caramel, some biscuit. Medium bodied, dry finish. Very well balanced. Fresh but also mild.

On tap at Pizza Port San Clemente’s Hoptoberfest. Pours with a clear golden body and a lasting white head. Aroma is grainy, cereal and bready with herbal, and spicy hops. A bit of dry hop grassiness. Flavors of grain, cereal, citrus, herbal hops and popcorn. Very lively bubbles. Dry. Very sessionable, but leans towards the grainy/malty side of things (sort of like San Clemente’s Rip Tide). Re-rate: On tap at the brewpub. Pours with a brilliantly clear golden hued body with a retentive and lace producing white head. Strong fruity aromas, floral, delicate tropical fruit notes, flowery, grassy, light esters and some sweetness. A bit dank the more you sip. Flavors are grainy, bready, dry and a bit of DMS possibly (didn’t smell it on any other PPSB beers). Very fruity, a bit spicy, grassy, floral. Dry. Very grainy, tropical fruit. Light bubbles, dry, lighter bodied.

Draft at the brewery. Pours black in color, small beige head. Lots of lacing on the glass. Very nice dark chocolate, coffee and cream aroma. Taste is very smooth and creamy. Nice dark chocolate and coffee flavor throughout. Finish is very creamy. Hops are very subdued. Medium body and silky mouthfeel. Really good chocolate porter.

Draft sample at the MBGF Summer 08. Pours a very dark brown color with a medium sized creamy tan head with moderate lacing. The aroma is roasted malt, creamy chocolate, mild coffee, and a dark fruitiness. The flavor is roasted malt, some bitterness, mocha, dark chocolate, espresso, and a slight dark fruitiness. Medium bodied, fairly smooth, and solid for a porter of 4.9%.

Draft sample at MBGF Summer08. Poured clear black color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate roasted chocolate malty aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture. Medium roasted dark chocolate flavor with medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid complex beer.

2008 MiBGF: Near black with some reddish highlight topped by a great creamy head and lace, very nice for a porter. The aroma has notes of chocolate, walnut, prune, white raisins, coffee, and heavy roasted malts. The taste is twangy and lactic followed quickly by bitter dark chocolate, espresso, and an overall roasty overtone. The mouth feel is oily and sticky, again better than the average porter... then again this is stout like anyway. A very nice brew indeed, the 3rd best beer I had on day 2.

Tap: black with beige head, oily, coats the glass quite well. Huge choclate up front, roasted grain and coffee background. Flavor much th same, plenty of chocolate, fades into burnt coffee grinds towards the finish, (subtracts from the score quite a bit). Mouthfeel sort of dry, almost oatmeal flakiness dry in a way. Without the big coffee presence, would score much better.
I can taste the chocolate.. poured nice and thick.. Goes down strong but good. A delicious blend. Very good, available only a local micro brewery.

On tap: Lots of chocolate in the aroma with light coffee. Dark brown with no transparency and a small tan head. Decent lacing. Lots of milk chocolate and a hint of cream up front. Nice roasted coffee finish with a hint of nuttiness. Light but creamy mouthfeel with a touch of fizziness.

[CASK: The Victoria Hotel, Withinngton, Manchester 25/09/06] Once again like with all the Hydes Classic’s series... Shame they had to be limited edition! What a beautiful ale. Tasty and full of flavour. Delicious!!!

Amber with a short creamy head. Hoppy with a hint of caramel at the end of the nose. Maybe slightly watery, but with a crisp finish. Slight sweetness present, could be more bitter. Light hops with a hint of toffee malts. Drinkable but bland.

1. Cask Handpump at the Red Lion, Doncaster (JDW) 19/09/2006 Some fruit aroma. Amber coloured and fruity with a little dryness in a crisp and bitter malt finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Vine Inn, Nantwich 30/09/2006 Hop aroma. Golden coloured and hoppy with some fruit flavour. Crisp lasting malt finish.

Cask sampled with Finn at The Glasshouse (Wetherspoon) in Norwich. Golden brown. Missing head. Malty to the nose. Dry and rather faint fruity flavour. Thin palate. Not actually a treasure (26.09.2006).
Cask at The Glasshouse (JDW) Norwich 26 Sep 2006. Golden coloured. No head. Difficult to find any aroma. Watery flavour. Some dry and bitter finish.
Cask-conditioned, gravity dispense at The Sultan, London SW19. Gold coloured with thin white head. Sweet fruity aroma. Tastes mainly of applely esters. Autumnal, I suppose.
Draft. Pours clear gold with a white head. Clean grainy base, a little straw, low bitterness, and a quick and clean finish. Fine.

Tap at Brea. Pours a crystal clear gold hue with a white head that slowly fades. Aromas are grainy and grassy, low sulur and a very light ester. Some minerality. Flavors are dry and medium bitter with an herbal and floral hop character. Light sulfur, very mild ester. Mostly clean and crisp. Lively carbonation and dry
Tap in Brea. Clear light gold pour with a nice white head. Mild aroma and flavor, mild bitterness and very crisp and clean, nice drinker. (2312)

Draft. A light golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma has notes of malt as well as lighter notes of straw and sulphur. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and straw as well as lighter notes of sulphur and citrus.

A: The pour is a very pale yellow color with a mild white head and some mild lacing. S: The nose is primarily of bread with a touch of grainy sweetness and a mild earthy hop aroma. T: The flavor is similar to the nose with a bready malt flavor along with a slight sweetness. The hops are earthy and provide a rather pronounced bitterness. M: The body is light with a fairly lively carbonation and a touch of lingering bitterness. D: As the style should be, a pretty easy drinking beer with a lightness to it and some decent hop bitterness.

On tap at Brea location. Color was a clear golden with an average white head. Aroma of bread, biscuit malt and grain. Flavor was much of the same. For the style it really brought forth alot to like. Surprisingly decent beer overall.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is light cornish. Light cornish and crisp hoppy flavoured. Very subtle bitterness coming through. Crisp bitter finish.
On tap. Clear yellow with a white head. Malty nose. Medium body, good malty feel, a little sulphur. Finish is dry. 060709
on tap in Brea, clean golden pour, nice slightly sweet flavor with an overall refreshing taste.

On tap poured a clear golden color with a nice fluffy white head and good lacing. The aroma was clean and lager-like with a light hop aroma. The taste was super clean and refreshing with some clean malt flavors backed by a dry finish. Well balanced with just enough bitterness. Overall an excellent example of the Kolsch style.

This was the only beer they had on tap there. Pours a nice lighter golden color with a short lasting white head. Lots of hops and bitterness in this blonde ale. The honey is nice and subtle in the background, kinda tastes like a clove honey that blends well with some spicy hops in the finish.

3Dec2017 Sweet grain and bread malts, sweet wheat, caramel, esters, citrus fruits. Clear gold, small, frothy, white head. Light bitter. Bitter citrus fruits, lemon, lime, lively carbonation, medium bodied. Alright. Keg at Quarryman, Sydney.

First impression (smell, looks and taste) isn't great, but if you stick with it the rewards are there. It wouldn't get many takers at speed dating, but might do alright online. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pint on tap at Basement Brewhouse, Bankstown. Pale yellow beer with thin creamy white head. Medium carbonation. Laces well. Nose is spice and caramel. Spritzy mouthfeel with light body. Hints of banana and spice with a lightly bitter finish. Drinkable but uninvolving.

Really sweet nose, apricot and lavender, so clear and no hint of bubbles, watery with remnants of soaked banana lolly flavour. Don’t think I could down too many of these, though it is crisp there really isnt any roundness to it.
330ml bottle. Pokal glass. Typical of the style with some banana and cloves. Not a hugely flavoured beer. Still a nice drop.
Not much fruit in the aroma, but heaps in the flavour. Lots of banana. Goes down very smooth.
[backlog] 02-02-15 // bottle in Sale Motor Village, Australia. Hazy orange. Medium yeasty, some banana and clove. All in all average Hefeweizen.

(Bottle) Clear golden yellow with tiny loose white head. Pleasant aroma - bananas, grassy hops and hint of cardboard. Light bodied and rather fizzy. Fruity start of bananas quickly replaced by citrus for a rather thin tart mid-palate, developing some peppery notes than evolve into a bit of bitterness in the finish. Refreshing, easily drinkable, unexceptional.
From a bottle. Not bad at all, the usual banana and clove present, good example of style.
Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy yellow golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy aroma. Fruity wheat malty weak spicy banana flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy finish.

Lightly hazed golden ale with a thick white head. Sweet malt with diacetyl. In mouth, a sweetish malt, with the same diacetyl, and light hopping. Light bodied and passable. On tap at Gibraltar, May 2006.

Draught at the brewpub, Pilar. A rather standard pale ale with a dry, thin body, a decent malty flavour and some bitter hops coming through in the finish. Decent enough drinking but not that interesting.

On tap - September 2006 Pours a deep yellow-gold colour with a nice white head. Aroma is fruity and herbal. Taste is very balanced, fruity, an acidic touch, ends dry with a hop bite. Quite kolsch like, light, refreshing but interesting.

Draught at the brewpub, Pilar. A pretty good attempt at an Irish Red, but as the style is mundane this isn’t really a good thing. The usual sweet toffee/caramel maltiness of the style fails to press any of my buttons and leaves me disappointed.

Nitro-Tap - September 2006 Pours a deep copper color, aroma is yeasty, a little fruit. Taste is rather neutral, with a hint of malt, slightly dried fruits and bitterness just balanced, not hop aroma nor flavor. Mouthfeel is medium to thin. Not bad but quite flat.

On tap - September. Pours black with some ruby hues and a white head that diminishes to a rim. Aroma is of dried fruits, raisins, liquorice. Taste is of bitter chocolate, some olives, rather acrid. Medium mouthfeel, creamy and some hop flavor. Multi laced, warming and inviting.

column1: Rock Bottom South Denver Chili Gold Mild & Spicy
column5: cask at the brewpub. gold body with not much head to speak of once the artificial head decayed. left an oily residue on my glass though. aroma is staight up peppers. reminds me of jalapeno. smells like salsa and corn chips. taste is very mild pepper flavor; green chili, sweet corn tortilla and salsa. interesting beer, not one i’ll order again for a couple of reasons: the sweet corn and vegetable(tomato and cilantro) flavor are a drawback, i don’t like tomato juice, also there is just an "other" taste i can’t describe, but bugs me. this just ain’t for me. another reason that only came up an hour after i drank a pint is that it gives me a bit of indigestion.

Beer No. 60 on my tour through Austria, Germany and Denmark. Draught at Marcus-Bräu, Berlin as Bärenquell Original Pilsener. Pale golden coloured, medium sized white head, few streams of carbonation, mild grainy nose. Malty, grainy and light herbal with moderate bitter finish. Simple and drinkable.
Draught at the Marcus-Brau, Berlin. Color clear yellow with small head. Aroma fruits, grain. Taste sweet, grain, dry.

06/03 Draught at the Marcus-Brau. It poured clear golden body with small, but persistent head. Some light dry herbal hops in aroma. Bitter, dry flavor as well, although not much in it, just light typical German pils "cardboard" herbal hops. Little bit of biscuit malt as well, showing up more in its short finish along with that dry cardboard. A little bit too industrial, quite boring pils, especially as we got spoiled by local Marzens!

Draught at Marcus-Bräu. Poured a clear golden body with a small white head that went away slowly. Almost no nose, some light grain. Empty taste, odd dustiness, obviously drinkable as it’s so light, but it’s hard to say much good about it.

Draught @ Marcus-Bräu, Münzstraße 1-3, 10178 Berlin, Germany. Clear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, hay, light grain and toasted, light hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light metalic. A bit borring but okay .. [20090919]

It is slightly hazy with small particles, golden and it has a white head. The aroma has notes of butter, malt and fruit. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of butter, malt, light fruit and the finish is dry. Before the butter set in, it could have been a nice pilsner, I think.

From tap at Marcus Brau. Pours hazy yellow with a fully diminished white head. Light metallic and mild hoppy aroma. Flavour is mild fruity and hoppy dry bitter. Light orange fruity lingering flavour. Fruity hops finish with a mild bitterness coming through.
(Draught at Marcus Bräu, Berlin)On June 5, 2008Clear golden color, white head. Butterscotch and sweet malty scent. Herbal and butter taste, malty. Moussy mouthfeel, rather low bitterness.
[i]Draught at Marcus Bräu, Berlin[/i]. Clear golden with medium white head. Clean hayish malt aroma with grassy hops. Moussy carbonation. Bitter finish. Quite ok.
(Draught at Marcus-Bräu, Berlin, on 2008-02-06) Very clear, light yellow colour. Basic pils: dry hops in nose and taste. Some malts in body.

(Flasche) Es hat eine sonnengelbe Farbe, ist filtriert mit einer weißen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist etwas fruchtig, leicht süßlich und grüner Hopfen. Der Geschmack ist eher schlank, sonst wie das Aroma. Bittere gibt es kaum
Bottle. German average. Nothing astonishing, but also won’t hurt you. Good for thirst for sure.
Herber, mild metallern grasiger Antrunk. Süßlich, die Herbe bleibt konstant, trocken bleibend. Mittelstarke Würzigkeit, weich herber Nachhall. Einfach, nett. 7/9/8/8/8/8
17.11.2016 at Sammeth, Weidenbach - Some bitter hop aromas. Thin body. Drinkable but not my favourite choice.
Helder geel bier met schuim. Smaak is bitter hoppig en kruidig, iets van citrus en vanille. Minder krachtig bitter van smaak dan de meeste pilseners maar toch erg goed.

Bottled, from Biershop Bayern. Clear pale golden, rich head. Grassy, spicy nose. Dry and bready with light-medium body and firm mouthfeel. Crisp bread, hay and grass. Salty bitter finish. Distinct and moreish.
* Old rating. Best before 07.12.10. Herbes, frisch grasiges Bier. Intensiv, malzig, eher trocken, Lecker!
Klares goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig, grasig, leicht malzig. Geschmack angenehm herb, grasig. Bitterer Abgang.

Bottled 500ml. Thanks Franz&Liina - fresh bottle from brewery. Clear golden color, small white head, almost sparkling wine like look. Papery, buttery and grassy aroma. Light to medium-bodied. Front is quite watery, then some iron and butter. Quite bitter finish and aftertaste. Reasonably hoppy, typical Franken (filtered) pils.
Bottle. Deep golden with a thin head. Aroma is citrus malt. Flavour is light dry bitter with a gentle malty base. Long dry palate.
*Old rating, best before 02.03.05. Malzig-herbes, neutral-würziges Bier. Nicht zu tief, trocken, intensiv-neutral bitter im Nachgeschmack.

It’s golden with a white head. The aroma has notes of malt, straw, butterscotch and the flavour has a light sweetness, notes of malt, light butterscotch, straw and the finish has a dry, citrussy bitterness. A refreshing beer.
bottle. Clear yellow, tiny head which collapses immediately. Hoppy nose. Quite hoppy flavour, slightly malty only in the background. A bit thin overall, but not bad.
Bottle, 4.9%. Standard lager appearance. The flavour is not very bitter, but a bit rough and slightly bready.
A dark yellow beer with an off-white head. The aroma is sweet malty with a light note of hops, and the flavor is sweet malty, leading to a dry bitter end.
(Bottle 50 cl) Clear, pilsener golden with an off-white head. Malty aroma. Medium body with malty accents and a solid, hoppy finish. 210906
Pours pale golden coloured with a medium sized head. Aroma and flavour of bread, malt and grass. Notes of hops and cardboard. Feels kinda metallic.

Bottle @ Home. Pours golden with a huge offwhite head, Aroma of malt, caramel, smoked meat, ham, bacon. Flavor is sweet, malty, light caramel, lots of smoked meat. Medium body, average carbonation, sweet and smoked finish. 300417
Bottle @ Brewery. Thanks Simon. Pours Copper with a small creamy White head. Woody smoke, Bamberg smoke and sausage. Good hoppy finish. Smooth. Proper.
Bottle from Ricklinger. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity and heavy smoked meat. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. 100417

Das Rauchbock der Ricklinger Brauerei kommt aus der 0,5l Flasche mit Bügelverschluss und ist im Glas bräunlich und trüb mit nur wenigem Schaum auf der Flüssigkeit. Es perlt im Glas sehr stark und schmeckt stark nach Rauchmalz und dennoch auch florale, herbe Aromen nach Naturhopfen im Nachtrunk. Ein erstaunlich süffiges Rauchbockbier.

(swing top bottle) Hazy, orange-golden colour with a blond and huge foamy head. Distinctively smoke malty and slightly salty aroma with notes of smoked ham and a tinge of smoked salmon. Mildly sweet flavour, medium bodied with a smooth carbonation. Present smoke malty taste with a delicately grainy spot underneath, accompanied by shades of herbal hops; moderately sweet and smoky malty finish with notes of beechwood and traces od salty fish. Not a very complex but likeable smoked Bock. 15.IV.14

Bügelverschlußflasche:Deep golden, unclear, visible carbonation, bigger and stable lacy White head; moderate smokey - including traces of smoked salmon - nose, accompanied by pale malt and shy hops; moderate to solid sweet-bitter flavour, medium bodied; lingering "crunchy" sweet bisquity finish with an increasing hoppiness in the aftertaste. A well balanced and pleasant Bock...

500ml bottle [6.5% abv]. Clear, orangey, deep golden to amber colour with average to huge, frothy, fairly lasting, minimally lacing, white head. Smoky aroma has notes of bacon, ham etc., a floral, herbal touch. Taste is moderately smoky, moderately sweet malty, slightly grassy; relatively light body for its 6.5% abv.

A hazy dark amber beer with a brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of smoke, as well as hints of acidity. The flavor is slighlty acidic combined with good notes of smoke and bacon as well as notes of malt and caramel in the background. The end is dry.

Bottle, 7.5%. Quite smoky aroma, like chew tobacco. Almost clear very dark red colour. Unstable head. Unstable head. The flavour has the same distinct and pleasant smokiness as aroma. Also quite malty with a dusty finish. The smoke might be hiding an underlying cardboard flavour. Low carbonation. Nice.

(Bottle 50 cl) Pours a cloudy, orangey brown with a small, beige head. Aroma is purely smoked. Medium-bodied, tart - as always from Ricklinger - with distinct notes of smoke. No real bitterness. 210906
Hellgelbes Getränk mit keinem Schaum. Geruch minimal malzig säuerlich. Geschmack sehr wässrig malzig, getreidig.
(Can) Pours a clear pale yellow body with a small white head. Aroma of light citrus. Flavor of malt and grassiness with a watery mouthfeel.
Bottle, 5.5%. Golden colour, very small white head. Acidic flavour, a bit sewery and sweetish with a hint of hops. Low to medium bitterness.

An orange beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with ntoes of straw and malt, but also a slightly perfumy note of honey. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel, and the body is thin. A boring beer.
(Bottle 50 cl) Clear, pilsener golden with a creamy, white head. Clean, malty aroma. Medium body with sweet, malty notes. Almost no bitterness. 210906
Clear pale golden coloured with a small fizzy head. Somewhat malty and sweet. Very high carbonation level that makes it feel sharp in the mouth. Boring.
(Can) Pours a dark brown body with a moderate beige head. Aroma of dark fruits and toasted malt. Flavor of toasted malt and dried fruit with a dry and somewhat bitter finish.
Auch dies war ein Mitbringsel einer Busreise meiner Eltern. Es ist ein typisches deutsches Helles, das eine etwas stärkere Hopfung zeigt. Es ist nichts besonders, lässt sich aber angenehm trinken.
Leicht stumpfes goldgelb mit reichlich Schaum. Malzig, leicht erdig, heuig, grasig, würzig, spritzig.
Goldgelb Schaum ok, Geruch leicht hopfig getreidig, Geschmack würzig frisch sehr schöne süffige halbe

0,5l Flasche. Hopfen und Getreide Duft. Goldgelbe Farbe, schöner Schaum. Sehr getreidiger Antrunk und bitterer Abgang. Ich bin voreingenommen, da es das Bier meiner Jugend ist. Für mich ein klasse Exportbier!
*Old rating. Best before 05.01.10. Nice smooth and easy to drink beer. Worthy, not too sweetish, nice, fresh, not too sweetish-malty. Nice.

500ml bottle. Clear, yellow-ish, pale golden colour with average, thick, frothy to creamy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, snow white head. Grainy, strawy aroma, rabbit hutch inspired. Taste is minimally sweet pale malty, slightly strawy, a spicy touch of hay, some malt-spiciness; slightly watery.

Bottle 50cl from Quack-Duck. A clear yellow beer with good head and lacing. Nose is on barley sugar with light vegetable touch. Aroma is sweet, grain notes, kind of corn sugar, peppery and grassy hops. Finish on corn sugar too.
Klares goldenes Bier mit ordentlicher weißer Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, würzig, florale Aromen. Geschmack würzig malzig, leichte Kräuternoten, floral.

Bottle. Light golden, small average and fully diminishing head, Light to moderate, malty - grainy and lightly sweetish aroma, faint barnyard and light grassy/herbal hoppyness. Body is light to medium, malty – grainy and lightly sweetish flavor, faint grassy hoppyness. Finish is short to average, malty – grainy and dryish - lightly sweetish, faint barnyard, light grassy/herbal hoppyness. Light bodied helles with notes of barnyard.
Würzig-herber Geruch. Start leicht süß, herb. Danach weiterhin herb, verhalten würzig. Abgang würzig-grasig und süßlich, kaum bitter. Ok.
Bottle in Ulm. Average dunkel not very dark more a chestnut colour. Malt barley wheat notes.

Bottle shared with McTapps. Shared and shocked as this is the first bad Berg I had so far. Dull, nearly tasteless, high carbonated with some sourness. Huge disappointment as I missed a lot of aromas and taste.

Milky dark brown colour with steady creamy head and medium to smooth body. Nose of yeast. Taste of light yeast, spruce, leaves, grass and lemons. Surprisingly unyeasty. It was really fizzy and refreshing, but just too watery and thin.
Pours amber with a slight haze and a dense and frothy off-white head. Yeasty nose with some sweet overripe fruitiness.

Bottle &#40courtesy of Stefan!&#41 Hazy, chestnut-amber coloured, smaller loose off-white head, that quickly collapses; subtle aromas of dark-malt, metal with an earthy-wheaty background; quite sweet, slightly sourish flavour, light to medium bodied, a bit fizzy; malty, delicate wheaty-sourish finish. No more than drinkable.......
Bottled. dark brown color. Cloudy. Yeast, toffee and banana in the flavor. yeasty notes and a hint of citrus in the aftertaste. No more than decent.

&#40bottle&#41 Hazy, chestnut-brown colour with a big but non-persistent tanned frothy head. Discreet aroma: Slightly sweet and minimal sour wheat-malty nose with shy toasted elements and a moderate fruit-character of dark and red berries. Sweet and minimal sour flavour, light to medium bodied with a lively carbonated mouthfeel. Slightly toasted malty and wheaty taste with notes of berries; sweetish and moderately fruity finish. A tad to sweet for my kind of taste. 09.IX.09
bottle, bought at the brewery. Cloudy brown colour, large beige head. Malty nose. Medium-bodied, malty with hints of chocolte and shy hints of banana. Well-balanced Dunkelweizen with a spicy touch.
Bottle, 5.1%. Weak banana aroma. Banana flavour with a refreshing acidity but also a little sour aftertaste.
An unclear orange-brown beer with a huge orange head. The aroma is sweet wheaty with light notes of caramel, and the flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel and light wheaty notes.

Appearance: Clear golden, some off-white head. Aroma: Slight wheat and some banana. Taste: Light wheat, some banana. Some pale malts. Bought: HGS3 hotel (Schelklingen), 500 ml, €3.50 Info: 8/8-2018, BB: ??/??-????
50cl bottle. Pours clear golden colour with a mid-sized most good lasting white head. Aroma of mild banana, some tangerine, yeast. Taste of tangerine, banana, sweet wheat malt, okay!
Flasche 50cl. Borstig-hefiges Kristall mit schönem Schaum. Typische Perlage. Alles in Allem unbesonders, jedoch gut trinkbar.

Farbe: gold, schee mit dicken perlen die aufsteigen. Schaum: ziemlich flach und grob Nase: ganz leich süßlich, banane und weizen Geschmack: hm eher lack, während vorne rum noch bitter und sauer wie in einem normalen Weizen sind dominiert die Süße Abgang und Nachgeschmack. nach Weizen schmeckts schon auch, aber das Bier ist eine Enttäuschung.

Tap. Pours crystal clear gold with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with spare lacing. Aroma is bananas, earthy and spicy wheat malt. Flavor is earthy and spicy wheat malt, bananas and a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.
Ristorante Cafe Bärenhöhle. Bananig, lichtzuur. Die grote glazen altijd.... Backlog from 2015/07/22.

Clear deep golden colour with steady low ehad and medium body. Nose of mild grains. Taste of light gentle elegant yeast, mild hops, ripe grains, hay, straw and roses. Easy and nice to drink, enjoyed it a lot.
Ein typisches Kristall, das die Aromen von Vanille und Blumen in sich trrägt. Viel Buttrigkeit lässt das Ganze schön fluffig runterrutschen. Kein schlechter Fang vom real,- in Dettingen / Erms.
Heller, wenig hefiger Antrunk. Süffig herb, spritzig. Mit der Zeit milder werdend, dabei bleibt die grundsätzliche Aromenkonstellation aber vorhanden. Für ein Kristallweizen gut. 11/9/10/9/10/9
Yellow coloured. Dense off white head. Light banana and yeast in the aroma. Flavour is quite sweetish and yeasty. Fruits notable and a light touch of grape.

17-02-2019; bottle; at home (bought somewhere in The Netherlands). Also had as: Oud Zutphens Tripel The looks of the beer are fine. The beer has a slightly dark golden yellow colour. It is quite hazy. The haziness makes the beer look a little dull. On top of the beer some white foam is formed. Foam retention is rather short. A thin drape is left on the beer. It doesn't look bad, but it is not the best looking Abbey Tripel I've ever seen. The aroma of the beer is nice. Malts are simple. They give a bread note. Hops are nice and spicy, together with some herbal notes and also some fruity touches. The main aroma is caused by the yeast aromas. They give some nice fruity notes. There is some nice fresh apple, that goes well with the spiciness of the hops. Some floral notes are also there, a bit of elder flower it reminds me of. Nice. The taste of the beer also in nice. It is a very well balanced beer. The fruitiness of the beer pairs very well with the sweetness of the malts and alcohol and the nice hoppy bitterness. The bitterness isn't to strong, but it is not weak. It is a bitter beer, but the sweets and slight sour fresh fruits bring enough balance to make sure we end up with a very harmonious beer. Nicely done. The palate of the beer is okay. Medium body, smooth texture and medium carbonation. The finish of the beer has nice alcohol warmth, fruity yeast notes and nice dry hoppy bitterness in the end. All in all, it is a very likeable beer. I'm not disappointed by this beer. Nice.
Bottle. Pours amber. Aroma is candy, greens, soy sauce. Body is heavy and strong, glue, solubles, sweet tea, low carbonation. Bubble gum. All over the place. Boozy. Meh.
Prima tripel met een volle smaak die blijft hangen op de tong. Juiste balans tussen zoet en bitter. Schuimkraag is klein.

Bottle at home as Oud Zutphens Triple. Almost clear dark golden with small white head. Sweet red apple, sugary, honey, estery yeast (cloves, laurel) soft rye, dried orange peel, light herbs. It's quite sweet, but has a solid citrus-peel bitterness throughout which helps to make this a bit mor einteresting than just a very sweet malt-heavy beer. Full bodied. Not really a typical tripel, it doesn't have that much yeast character actually, but it's interesting and fairly decent.

Eén mooi ogende trippel met veel koolzuur. Het bier heeft een zoete en fruitig aroma met bittere aroma's. De smaak is goed in balans en heeft in de afdronk iets fruitig met een zuurtje. -backlog de BierApp-
Een donkergeel bier wat totaal geen schuim bevat. Een zoete, olie achtige, alcoholisch, iets fruitige tripel met een bittere en zoete afdronk. Na 3 slokken aan de gootsteen gevoerd.

Van 't flesje. Amberkleurig met moeilijk te vormen schuim met grotere bellen. Neus: whisky, zoet. Mond: chemische zoetigheid, kandijsuiker, alcohol overheerst, lichte peper, hopbitterheid die constant aanwezig is. Besluit: te zoete tripel met weinig karakter.
Fles 33cl thuis. Wat standaard. Licht zoet, bitter, krachtig, scherp. Licht drogig. Bittere afdronk. (3-2012).

.33l bottle at Drinkers Pub Eindhoven. Poured a hazy darkgolden beer with flakes of yeast floating. Head is thin and dininishes like instantly. Nose is complex, as is its taste. I taste sweetness of malts. Bitterness from the hops. Hints of red fruit and herb and strong alcohol taste. Quite bitter aftertaste aswell. Nice beer but not your everyday triple.

Never rated it earlier, but now I should. Bottle pours hazy golden with a small off-white head. Aroma is full, sweet, fruity, banana, caramel, malts. Taste is quite sweet and moderately bitter, but very nice still. Rather strong carbonation, full bodied, little peppery feel in aftertaste. I like it.

Draft pint poured by the hottie bartender at the brewpub: Very light yellow with a thin veil of a white fizzy foam. Light peachy aroma and a float of peach syrup in the flavor, but in the end it finishes like a pour light beer with an added odd sourness.

tap. brown/amber pour. rising bubbles, good clarity, small tan head. chocolate, burnt malts, mild hop aroma. I was pleasently suprised and pleased with this beer. very nice burnt malts which fade into dark fruit and oak. mild perfume taste. dry burnt finish. some floral hops as well.
On draft at the brewery. Aroma of toasty caramel. Taste of toasted malt. Syrupy mouthfeel. Flavorful, but sticky.
A tasty Oktoberfest beer. Good malt flavor, very crisp and clean. I like it. Could drink a few.

On tap @ Backcountry poured a clear amber with a lingering ring of ivory foam. Aromas of carmel, toasted malt and light fruittiness. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel and light fruittiness with a smooth lightly sweet finish.
on tap-pours an off white head and amber color. Aroma is medium fruit, medium malt. Taste is medium fruit, medium malt-caramel, faint spice hops. OK/mild carbonation.

Draft, Brew at the Zoo Benefit in Denver. Poured a clear orange color. Head was thin and off white. Aroma was of cereal grain and spicy malt. Slight sweet on the tongue with a malt dominated flavor profile including caramel and toasted bread. There was also a subdued dried fruit note and mild bitterness.

tap during octoberfest celebration. live music and raffles. celebrating 10 years of business. congrats. beautiful copper pour. nice clarity, thin soapy head. burnt malts, floral hops and sourness in the aroma. powerful caramel malts followed by sourness and ends in a dry bitter finish. roasted falvor, maple, nice carbonation. sugar peaks around occassionally. not bad.
Draft 6 oz’er at the brewpub: Decidedly apple character. Still has a steady caramel malt body and a standard fest appearance. Right down the center fo the o-fest target area.
tap. this was absolutely disgusting. I really dont know what else to say. why even bother making this
Pours a golden yellow color with a white head. Aroma is light crip malts. Flavor is light malts with a nice bitter hop finish. Not a bad pilsener.

Draft pint at the restaurant/brewpub: very clear yellow, but barely any color at all (influence of adjuncts). But it has a surprisingly robust malt-biscuity flaovr with a nice German-style hop finish. Not bad.

Courtesy of Giovanni Marconi of Compagnia del Luppolo; this bottle and Bov’s/Allen’s are the 2008 version, different from the original one The bottle is a gusher; it pours a cloudy dark amber color, obviously with a big head. Malt, caramel and chocolate aroma, slightly oxidised. It has a good body strength, with very good caramel flavor, bold, some malt; the bitterness is not too high, and in the final there is some evident alcohol warmth. A solid brew from De Graal, very good, if it was not for the gushing effect; it seems that the bottle I gave to Bov was completely different…

Poor appearance. Murky brown with a quick diminishing head. Extremely sweet and yeasty with a lot of banana in both aroma and taste. Residual sugars in the finish. I didn’t enjoy this beer at all. Reminiscent of really bad Quadruple.

courtesy of fiulijn - slightly hazy brown colour with a poor head retention; dusty, malty and nutty aroma with notes of banana; very sweet and full-bodied, unclean palate, long sweetish malty finish with a moderate bitterness and lingering notes of candi sugars and late notes of alcohol - dubious

A Mes rate: Bottle at Chris O’s Pre GBBF Tasting Blonde with a good white head. Sweet and fruity with some good sherberty hops and nice spice. Pleasant Belgian style alcohol notes along with some juniper and coriander. Good bitter finish with a slight peppery sting. Has that standard De Graal sting without seeming infected like I usually find their bottled beers. This is pretty good.

Bottle Deep amber body. Slightly hazy. Lightly brown, frothy head. Mostly diminishing head. Very interesting aroma of malts and hops, liquors, port, ... Very complex and pleasant aroma. Lightly sour, moderately bitter initial flavour. Moderately bitter finish. Quite complex flavour. Very nice and well balanced.

Fruchtiger, aber auch herber Geruch. Nur leicht fruchtig schmeckt das Getränk, im Abgang lässt sich, wenn auch nur in einer sehr geringen Konzentration, eine leichte Herbe neben dem süßlichen Aroma feststellen. Ich bin glücklich, dass dieses Zeug nicht nach Green Lemon schmeckt, es ist als normales Radler anzusiedeln, genau so schmeckt es. Dennoch zu lasch, Bier ist mal wieder kaum zu schmecken. Test vom 1.6.2006, Gebinde: PET Noten: -,7,9,8,8,8 - 8,00
50cl plastic bottle. Lime, sweet, sugar, artificial, watery. Ugly pale green color. Awww shit!
Bottle. Huge head with medium duration. Color is lime green. Aroma and taste are malt and lime. Very artificial.

Lemon aroma. Large frothy light green initial apperance. Fair lacing and mostly diminishing head. Clear light green body. Heavy bitter initíal flaver with a light lemon tast. Light palate and watery texture.
Plastic bottle. Yellow with a distinct green hue. White mostly diminishing head. Aroma of lemon "air fresher" and wunderbaum.Rather artificial flavor of lemon and bubblegum. Fresh and watery.
Plastic bottle, 2.5%. Green/yellow colour. The flavour is mostly like lemonade, but less sweet. Has a good balance with lemon and beer bitterness.
Bottle. Greenish colour with a huge mostly lasting frothy head. Aroma and taste of lemon with a slightly bitter finish. Watery palate.

Plastic bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Greenisch yellow colour. Powerfull lemon aroma, not so artificial as expected. Thin lemon flavor, light bitter finish, watery palate, but you can actually detect that there is some beer in this "thing".

column4: Lion Breweries - NZ (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Pale yelow colour with creamy white head, good lacing. Vegetable oil flavour, thin bodied and weak.

Telluride Blues & Brews Sep 06. This is the best beer these guys could bring to pour in the VIP area? What crap ... clear yellow and bubbly and very, very corny. I wasn’t sure this wasn’t Coors Light. Unbelievable.
Sweet, chemically, cooked cabbage aroma. A pinch of lemoncake. Dry up front, but massive malt sweetness in the finish from foul pale malts. Undrinkable.

on tap-pours an off white head and slightly hazy gold color. Aroma is sweet medium malt, syrupy, alcohol. Taste is sweet medium malt, alcohol. Slight hop bite but can’t pick up hops in taste. Mild carbonation.
Draft 6 oz’er at the brewpub, 9/18/06: Deep amber with a medicinal malty aroma. Sweet and sugary with a nice bitter bite to finish it.

column1: Americas Bourbon Barrel Why Dont We Get Drunk And Brew... Scotch Ale
column5: Here’s a brew to sit back with and to slowly enjoy. It pours a deep, clear reddish brown and is nearly bereft of head. The aroma begins with a warm Bourbon smell followed closely by rich malts, toffee with some butterscotch, a woodiness blended with peat smoke, and a big whollop of alcohol. Dangerously smooth too drink, the Boubon and Scotch flavors are skillfully blended while the peppery alcohol burns the tongue. A very warming drink with a malty, smokey finish and a cool alcohol burn. Very nice. Treated by Mike Rybinski, brewmaster at America’s Brewpub, Aurora, IL

Cask, The Criterion, Leicester. Golden with a small foam. Aromas are earthy with apple juice and eggy sulphur. Citrus notes with traces of caramel. Flavours are sweet and sour sauce with citrus acidity. Spritzy yeast on the palate.
Cask@The Criterion, Leicester. Golden cider with a fruity and dry aroma, and a tart and fruity flavour. Overall a nice dry and tart cider.

An orange gold coloured still cider. The aroma is of artificial fruits, like the pear drops of old, slightly sour, vinegary, with just a tiny hint of sweet apple and a floral, slightly lavender smell. The taste is quite smooth, and easy drinking! There is the artificial fruit element again, which starts out fairly sour, then mellows into a sweetish finish that fades quite readily on the tongue. (Cask - The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draft at source. Nitro. Aroma is deep chocolate with a coffee overtone. Roasty. Taste is less roasty. A touch thin. Seemingly bland. Drinkable but it’s just like, a stout, man. Could use a little more complexity I guess. Ok.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: nitro stout on tap at Pisgah Brewery (from 2011 notes). A - black with a creamy tab head. Looks like a model for the style. Aroma - pleasant but light and fairly simple aroma of dark roasted malt. T - plenty of dark roasted malt flavor with a touch of hops. There’s a bit of burnt grain and smokiness too. Mildly bitter and slightly sour. There is a hint of coffee in the slightly dry finish. M - creamy smooth, with a rather light body (like Guinness). O - more flavorful American version of an Irish stout.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub it is a dark Brown with a creamy head. The aroma is coffee and the taste is a strong bitter flavor of espresdo

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: On draft at the brewery. Pours a hazy cola with a creamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate. Flavors of mocha coffee. Light, smooth finish.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at Grey Eagle for Andrea Gibson. Loses something with plastic serving cups. Overall solid stout- hits all the right notes and stays somewhat subtle- nothing stands out as promient but chocolate, earthy, roasty malt, coffee, dark caramel and smoke/ Really nice on nitro- drinks super smooth and mellow. Almost velvety. Good, but not nothing outstanding. Certified organic is nice touch.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: Keg @ Pisgah during RBWG, Asheville. Deep brown with a small head. Roasted malt, some dark chocolate. Red fruits. Pretty earthy dry character. Praline and caramel. Dark chocolate. Smooth and easy to drink.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draft taster at the brewery. Pours the color of midnight with a creamy khaki head. Notes of coffee, toasted malts, cream, and dark sugars. Medium-bodied, with medium carbonation and a smooth mouthfeel. Works pretty well on nitro.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery Dark brown, beige head. Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. Flavors of roast malts, creamy mouthfeel and chocolate. Nice.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at Pisgah during RBWG. Black with that creamy nitro head. A lot of dark iced coffee in the nose. Fairly mild flavor profile. Mild coffee soda, dark chocolate, and roasted nuts. Creamy mouthfeel but subdued overall.

column2: Black Mountain, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at Pisgah. Pours a dark brown color with white head. Creamy, roasty, slight oat flavor.

Bottle shared at deanso’s. Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow, with a white head. Belgian yeast, sweet malts, dough, grainy, coriander, citrusy fruits. Medium sweet, light bitter. Light body, low carbonation.
33cl bottle shared with Kermis. Medium creamy white head. Cloudy light amber pour. Ok

Bottle shared with and courtesy of an on-heat platypus on an Artic Den Haag winter’s eve. Cloudy golden with an off white head. Aroma of herbs, urinal cakes and light fruits. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter. Light medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle bought at Willems en Zoon in Grobbendonk. Pours hazy dark blond with a medium white creamy head. Well carbonated. Nose: sweetness, sugary, caramel, orange zeste, a bit cheesy, tart, notes of malt, hay.. Taste: Very sweet start, the sugar pops in with an alcoholic wamth and malts. Afterwards a low bitter taste sneaks in with a grainy feeling. The aftertaste is a bit watery, dry with malts.

Aroma is weak. Taste is unbalanced and quite harsh. It’s mostly bitter (citrus) and sour. Coriander, maybe some banana in the back. Also some other fruityness (pineapple). Not bad, but definetly not great.
2015 - 02 - 06 330ml bottle. yellow-golden colour. medium, white head. cardboard, fruit and hay in aroma. light bittersweet taste.

Commissioned beer referring to a Dutch movie series. Medium thick, creamy, moussy, yellowish white head, misty peach blonde colour. Yeasty aroma, apricot, pear, pineapple, honey, orange peel, caramel, coriander; sweetish fruity taste, orange freshness, medium carbonation, soft caramel and honeyish malts, low hops in the finish. Cliché.
Bottle Pours clear blonde , ok white head . Smell is yeasty , bit sweet . Taste is sharp , bit bitter , yeasty . Some sweetness . Bit too much carbo but doable .

golden blond with huge airy white head. nose: yeast, sugarish, bit grainiy, Sweet taste, but get somethng intriguing in the finish, some unexpected bitterness. but taste is mainly about the yeast, some malts, citrus, sweet fruit. overall sweet, bit dry. while feels all fine, somehow, cant convince me. nice for trying.
Een heel leuk flesje en ook het bier zelf stelt niet teleur. Er zijn er betere, maar zeker en vast ook veel slechtere dan dit

On tap at the brewery on 10/21/2006 at the 2nd monthly meeting of the Chicago Ratebeer group. Thin copper color. No head. Nose is thin with some malts and more caramel. Taste is sharp with dark fruits, cream and yeast. Better than your average oktoberfest.

Draught at Maple Tree Inn, Blue Island, IL. Not much aroma. Slightly hazy body with some lace. Nice brew, although nothing abnormally special. Enjoyable. My rating may be lower than it should based on what I understand may be a beer line cleanliness issue at Maple Tree. If I find it somewhere else in the Chicagoland area before it runs out, I’ll give it another go.

Very attractive pour...hazy golden and rocky white head. Very malt heavy, as per style, with a bisquit/bread/caramel profile. A touch more carbonation than usual and a bit more floral hoppiness, too. Quite a sessionable Octoberfest, just ask Heidi!

Revised rating from draft. 9/29 This time, I’ve gotten a better pour, and upped my rating a few notches. This one actually seemed nice and clear, good Vienna malt color, and almost still until you sip. Taste is a bit candyish, like a Werther’s. Not as much yeast taste as my previous sample, obviously. Still, very drinkable and enjoyable for a cool autumn night. Draft. 9/25. Rating: 3 Very, very cloudy. I must have gotten the dregs of the keg. Still, I can report that it is very strong in malts; a nice middle ground between pilsener and Vienna. If the cloudiness here is from yeast, at least it doesn’t much affect the taste. Not much to tell about its hop profile, just an equal to the malts, as befits this style. Darn it, I guess I’ll have to have another to recheck its appearance.

Nice pour from the growler, a hazy orange, slightly brown, with a creamy beige head.There was an unusual but seemingly fitting floral bouquet over a sweet, lightly toasted malt aroma. Very smooth and creamy mouthfeel. The sweet malts rightfully took over in the flavor department with just enough herbal bitterness to keep it from getting cloying. Very quaffable. Thanks to MrsFrankenkity and frankenkitty for bringing me a growler when I couldn’t get to the Oktoberfest at Flossmoor Station.

Served as quite a murky amber/sepia under a thickish, ecru head that held steady over the course of the beer. Floral and lagered aroma with a spicy flavor resting on a sweet, malted backbone. Hefty mouthfeel, but not too fat to keep me and my wife from pounding pint after pint at FSRB’s Oktoberfest. Matt thought the finish could do with some additional finishing hops to clean it off the palate, but I thought this was a nice, heavy Märzen that was a perfect respite to a chilly, rainy afternoon. On tap at Flossmoor Station, Flossmoor, IL 60422

Date: 09/23/2006 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Asheville Appearance: clear copper, whispy head, Aroma: nice floral hop aroma with a touch of carmel sweetness, Flavor: the dms is a bit stronger in the flavor on this one but fades after the first few sips, nice earthy hop bitterness, dry malt, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.4/5.0 Drinkability: 5/10 Score: *+/4

Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a dark brown color with a finger’s worth of eggshell white foamy head that fell off fairly quick. Some light stringy lace. The aroma had some milk chocolate, light citrus smooth sweet pulp, and some peaches. The flavor leaned towards the sweet side taking the previously mentioned aromas into the aftertaste nicely. Finishes semi-sweet. The feel was about medium bodied with a fair sessionability about it. Good carbonation. ABV felt right. Nice smoothness rolling over my tongue. Overall, nice beer, but where was the rye? Maybe I missed the memo and it wasn’t actually supposed to have rye in it.

On tap: Big aroma of chocolate, oranges, and peaches. Dark brown with no transparency and a moderate tan head with sporadic lacing. Lots of orange, peach, and as it warms even strawberry. Cafe mocha flavored finished. No detection of rye. Very different for a porter, but tastey.
Bottle from Sams in Durham. Hazy gold pour with an off white head. Yeast, esters, crystal malts, and grapefruit.

Date: 04/12/2008 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Hickory Hops Appearance: hazy dark yellow, fine off white head, streaks of drippy lace, Aroma: sweet worty aroma with light floral hops, Flavor: sweet crystal malt flavor, lots of yeasty fresh sourdough bread character, well balanced with floral hops, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4
Smells sweet and fruity, and tastes of malts, wheat, and fruityness. Not to bad, It cheap and good!

Bomber. Pours a hazy light gold with a tall head that sticks around for a while. The aroma is tame and slightly musty, though provides some zestiness and wheaty notes. The mouthfeel is light and fairly fizzy, though refreshing. Fokker is pretty clean and has tiny hints at fruity esters and almost something like grapefruit and lemons. Everything is very light, but nicely done especially considering the style.

22oz bottle from TJ’s. Been passing on this for a while but decided I wanted a little something after a few drinks at the bars. Probably should have waited for a more sober time to drink this as I wasn’t really into it last night, but I did save some for the morning to remind my palate. Pours a hazy golden orange with a small white head. Nose is lemons, oranges, bready malts, and wheat. Flavor has a lot of citrus and lemons and a distinct tartness for sure but also has a distinct bready malt character that is more evident in the mouthfeel. Must admit this beer is more interesting than I expected. A nice surprise from Azalea. And I probably would never have tried it if it wasn’t for ratebeer. So that says something about why I rate.

Bomber. Awesome looking bottle with a great, simple design of a 50’s style Marilyn Monroe looking girl. The beer’s a golden copper color, clear, big soapy head that disappears quickly. Very sour, lemony nose with some nice bready malts. I get a hint of sourdough bread, lemons, and sharp carbonation. This brew comes across more like a thin Belgian dubbel than what you’d expect out of a small brewery’s attempt at a usually boring, watery style. This is the best golden or blonde I’ve had to date.

Draught at some kind of beer festival--not sure, rating very old... Pours yellow with medium head. Aroma is bready, sweet. Flavor is thin, but crisp at end. Some sweet malt flavors. Okay, but not too great.
Eh, not bad. yellow with a nice white head. aroma is sweet with hints of citrus. Flavor is crisp clean and rather refreshing. Overall a nice seesion beer.

Pours a clear straw gold, with a decent fluffy white head. Decent hop aroma, pretty crisp and sharp, with some citrus fruit as well. The flavor was also nicely hopped, mild sharp bitterness with some grapefruit flavors. Nice, easy drinking blonde, with some flavor to it. Good session or football drinking brew.
On tap at a brewfest, pours hazy yellowish, ok head. Lightly fruity taste, also kind of tree bark-y. Ok beer, probably wouldn’t order too many of these.

column1: Fort Street Flowers for the Kaiser
column5: Cask: dark golden orange, Nice thick head, fades to film/ring. Huge floral kick up front, lavender and plenty of citrus. Flavor again all floral up front, needs a bigger malt presence to balance, some citrus bite towrads the finish. Nice creamy smooth mouthfeel. Lavender becomes a little one-dimensional, but I sort of like it.

column1: Fort Street Flowers for the Kaiser
column5: Cask: Aroma is loaded with lavender and some light orange. Cloudy orange with a moderate white head with an orange tint. Lots of lavender up front, almost soapy. Moderate citrus hopped finish. Too much lavender starts to wear on me about half way thru the glass.
This is a great beer. Pours a dark Amber color. Malty aroma taste is the same with some spice and a light hop finish.
Growler shared with northropfrye and sam_rates_beer. I can’t believe I haven’t rated this one before. Darkish body, pale head. Malty sweet and spicy taste. Grapes. It’s really fantastic.

On tap at Fort Gibraltar for the Poutine Cup. Dark amber-brown pour with a thin tan head. Malty with dark fruit and caramel, a touch of hops. A nice Oktoberfest brew that goes a little beyond without ruining the style.

Really good beer overall! My local liquor store stored it at room temperature for about a week so I don’t know how good that was for it. None the less though, I poured and drank each one out of a hour-glass styled cup (as recommended) and I really enjoyed it. It is a "light" for a German style Oktoberfest beer but there is many good options out in western Canada for a good beer of this type. I would suggest getting sometime, also loved the packaging- Makes for a "fun" beer!

Cinnamon and spice scent, but unfortunately not very pungent. Rather light texture for an oktoberfest, which is sensible given that this is my first lager of this style. Absolutely delectable taste. Malt, very light roast, some minor spice that is certainty present, but not overwhelming, all followed by a tiny bit of hops to present one delicious tasting beer.

Bottle. Clear medium amber with golden highlights and an average off-white head. Lovely toasted caramel malt structure with just enough hops to offset the sweetness and provide a slight bitter bite to the finish. Delicious!

Pours a clear reddish amber with a small off white head that leaves some lace. Aroma is nutmeg, malts and some earthiness from the halatauer & perle hops. Taste is a good mouthfull of malts up front finishing with a nice blend of spices and a hint of bitterness. Best oktoberfest I’ve had.

Slightly hazy copper-amber with a medium head. Aroma is quite malty, with sweet caramel and some interesting earthy/leafy notes. Flavour starts quite sweet, develops with bready notes in the middle, and finishes fairly dry with a hint of cocoa.

Bottle - Grains, malts and spices on the nose. Actually quite sweet smelling. Dark clear amber with a thin brown head. Bread, grains and malty. Spices are subdued and almost no bitterness. Fairly rich and at 6.6% definitely not something to drink all night.

341ml bottle pours amber in color with a finger of off-white head that dissipates quite quickly leaving a few spots of lacing on the glass. Aroma is caramel and some mild spices and grass. Taste is a big caramel malty sweetness balanced nicely with the grassy hops and spices. Light to medium body with mild carbonation. I found this a little on the sweet side, perhaps I needed some schnitzel and hot mustard to go with it.
Smell is ripe apples. Golden colour. Taste is sweet almost artificial with very appley aftertaste. It's ok but too sweet for me. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Barrel at GBBF 2007. An unclear golden cider with no head. The aroma is slightly acidic and apply. The flavor is sweet with light notes of cardboard and apples as well as a slight acidity. The body is somewhat thin - a boring cider.
A Mes rate: Barrel at GBBF. Golden colour. Very mellow, slightly sweet and drinkable. Swift dry finish. Boring but very refreshing.

Bottle, from Proudfoot in Barton upon Humber. Deep gold, flat. Pleasant green apple aromas, quite thin and surprisingly unalcoholic in the mouth with a gentle soft apple skin dryness, short brief apple juice in the finish.

Bottle. Clear gold colour.Slightly musty aroma, not much of an aroma actually. Palate is a little apple juicy, thin with no complexity. Slight musty apple, with a watery acidity. Some alcohol noticed.

Hazy golden-yellow; good, thick yellowish tinted head. Grain, and fresh, grassy hops,... I even smell the hop plants. Even the head betrays already the serious amount of hops used. Dry bitter, virtually no restsweetness; nettles, thyme and other garden herb flavours - nice. Ever so slightly smokey flavour retronasal. Light but not empty, refreshing. Very nice beer, light & refreshing - good one. Why can an Englishman make a good bottled beer on French soil, and not at home?

Tap. Pours cloudy amber with a medium white head and good lacing. Aroma is very piney, with prominent biscuit and caramel malt notes as well. Flavor is the same, light sweet and very bitter. Just a shitpile of bitterness without much actual flavor nuance from the hops. Some lemon zesty astringency as well. Medium body, oily mouthfeel.

Cloudy orange pour with a white head. Bready malt sweetness, orange, pine, and grass initially on the nose. Very citric, overall, maybe a bit of grapefruit. There is a strong astringency and bitterness to the flavor. Some grapefruit and orange peel, pine, grass, and mild bread flavor and sweetness.

On tap at Sonoma Chicken Coop poured a clear golden amber with a small lingering ivory head. Aromas of biscuit, earthiness, grapefruit, tangerine and light pine. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of biscuit, earthiness, grapefruit and pine with a crisp dry lingering bitter finish.
I had this beer a while back and from what I can remember I enjoyed it. I’ve had this at the pub/brewery so it was fresh. Nothing special about it is popping into my head at the moment.

On tap @ brewhouse, Campbell. Golden, dark red body with a fine white head. Quite strong hop aroma, uncertain what type (not cascade). Pleasant sweet malt, slightly roasted and relatively bitter flavor. Some kind of dry crispy palate. Pleasant bitterness in aftertaste.

column1: Big Boss Surrender Monkey Farmhouse Ale
column5: Draft at WBF Raleigh on 5/2/09. Called Monkey Business Farmhouse Ale. Cloudy gold pour. Short white head. Aroma is rather spicy and yeasty. Taste is equally spicy with more yeast notes, flowers, and fruit coming through. Light candyish sweetness as well. Light-medium feel and very bubbly. Ends with more spices, yeast, light grain, fruit and sweet malt. Listed as a saison, if I recall the fest notes correctly.

column1: Big Boss Surrender Monkey Farmhouse Ale
column5: WBF sample. Pours a hazy soft yellow with a one finger offwhite head. The nose was yeasty, peppery, spicy, Belgian yeast for sure, orange peel, some coriander. The flavor is yeasty, orange peel, Belgian/earthy feel, spicy, slightly sweet, nice flavor. Spicy crisp palate.

column1: Big Boss Surrender Monkey Farmhouse Ale
column5: On tap at World Beer Festival, renamed "Monkey Business.’ I thought this was a sold farmhouse/saison beer. Spicey, with funky yeast and some citrusy fruit. Some banana and perhaps a bit too much clove. Hazy light orange pour with decent head. I could drink a lot more of this.

column1: Big Boss Surrender Monkey Farmhouse Ale
column5: This was one of the worst beers I’ve ever head. On tap at Village Draft House in Raleigh, NC. My friend Jen ordered but I couldn’t resist due to the funny name. It tasted like dirty alcoholic soapwater. It looked normal, but taste normal it did not. my friend Jen could barely bring herself to finish it. "I surrender monkey" was said many times as we surrendered to its awfulness and couldn’t proceed to drink anymore. Now, thinking about maybe something was up with the tap or we were given a dirty glass but do not surrender and order this beer. try another.

column1: Big Boss Surrender Monkey Farmhouse Ale
column5: Brown pour, with a yeast aroma. Clove, coriander, and esters. Decent in a pint glass , but could be better in proper glassware. Earlier Rating: 7/13/2007 Total Score: 3.7 they upped it to 9.2% :) on draft from horiblows. pours dark dark amber with little head and lacing. earthy mouth-feel with sweet finish. very nice! Not sure why they call this a farmhouse ale

column1: Big Boss Surrender Monkey Farmhouse Ale
column5: Cloudy orange, decent white head. Spicy and very fruity aroma - cherry and blueberry and maybe some coriander. Flavor is notes of clove, white wine, some banana and pineapple and perhaps some herbal, oregan-ish notes. At the Raleigh WBF.

column1: Big Boss Surrender Monkey Farmhouse Ale
column5: On tap; poured an orange that was so dark it was almost brown. Aroma of yeast, clove/spice and must. Flavor of belgian yeast, fruit and spice. Easy drinking. Some minimal sweetness. Just ok for me

column1: Big Boss Surrender Monkey Farmhouse Ale
column5: 2007 WBF. This one was terribly disappointing -- Farmhouse ales are generally my favorite overall style. I’m not sure what they were going for, but in my opinion it just didn’t work. Disjointed and lacking depth.

column1: Big Boss Surrender Monkey Farmhouse Ale
column5: On tap at Tyler’s, Durham, NC. Dark, hazy amber with no head. Mild, wheaty nose, some banana. Wheaty flavor, lightly toasty, a touch of funkiness. Grows a bit more saison-like as it warms, with some spicy clove emerging. Odd, but a nice beer.

column1: Big Boss Surrender Monkey Farmhouse Ale
column5: Draft at 42nd St Oyster Bar in Raleigh, NC. Poured a clear dark orange brown color. Darker than I had anticipated. Head was thin and off white. Aroma was of subdued clove and alcohol. There was also an occasional whiff stale beer, akin to what the last few drops in the bottom of a bottle smell like after a day or two at room temperature. Dry on the tongue. Flavor was clove/spice dominated with easily perceived alcohol and a bit of banana. There was also a pleasant dash of brown sugar at the end which asserted itself more as the beer warmed. Plenty of alcohol and clove survived well into the finish. Pretty good.

column1: Beer Works Blonde Faith Abbey Ale
column5: Draught @ Fenway Location: This one pours a cloudy, golden amber color. There was a thin white head on it that left no lacing. The nose is good. Wheat, lemon, touch of sourness, some spices. The taste is good: wheat, lemon, touch of sourness, hint of spices. A nice beer!

column1: Beer Works Blonde Faith Abbey Ale
column5: Tap. Pours slightly hazy gold with little head. Smells of bubblegum and vanilla. Drinks smoothly with little hop bitterness. Light bodied. Tastes of bubblegum esthers with astringency.

column1: Beer Works Blonde Faith Abbey Ale
column5: Pours a murky golden color with a small white head. Smells of pears apples and some biscuity malt. Tastes sweet with some fruity notes. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Beer Works Blonde Faith Abbey Ale
column5: Served in a tulip.   Nose has lots of fruit easthers. Banana and yeast. Clove. Reminds me of a strong hefeweizen. Well above average for such an average brewpub. I found a lot of nice flavor.

column1: Beer Works Blonde Faith Abbey Ale
column5: From tap at the Canal Stree location. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is mild phenolic and light fruity. Dry, light caramelish and distinct yeasty. LIght bitter and dry phenolic finish.

column1: Beer Works Blonde Faith Abbey Ale
column5: tap at Canal St. location - Pours clear gold with a yeasty, lightly fruity aroma. The flavor is sweet with the presence of Belgian yeast very obvious though the fruity character is light. Decent.

column1: Beer Works Blonde Faith Abbey Ale
column5: 1/10/2011 on tap @ Boston Beer Works (2011-476) Clear orange beer, small off-white head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: bubble gum, disinfectant, dentist product, mouth wash. MF: very light carbon, light to medium body. Taste: more mouth wash, bit fruity, rotten fruits, quite a lot of spices, cloves, orange peel. Aftertaste: quite bitter, oranges, some more mouth wash.

column1: Beer Works Blonde Faith Abbey Ale
column5: From the tap it poured straw yellow with a thin head. There was a nice dosage of yeast and spices and a lesser dosage of citrus in the aroma. The body was light and pleasant. The taste came off a bit on the tart side with a very dry finish.

column1: Beer Works Blonde Faith Abbey Ale
column5: Golden orange pour. Nose of spice and berries (more of the latter). Fairly fresh with a lot of sweetness. Overly sweet and chewy without any real spiciness coming through. Meh

column1: Beer Works Blonde Faith Abbey Ale
column5: Pours a hazy golden color with minimal head. The aroma consists of banana, clove, and alcohol. The flavor is slightly sweet with a hint of both bitter and sourness.

This draft brew from a restaurant poured a head of foamy finely sized bubbles that were long lasting and left behind a transparent uncarbonated light yellow colored body and an excellent lacing. The weak aroma was astringent straw like and grassy. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The weak flavor contained notes of straw and was astringent. Not one that I would likely buy again.

Draft at Mad Anthony Oktoberfest. White head that mostly diminished, sparse lacing, no visible carbonation, transparent, and a pale yellow hue. Malty and hoppy nose and ditto for the flavor. Tingly and somewhat of a dry mouthfeel. Light body. Just so-so.

tap - Mild aroma with some light malt and hops. The flavor is mostly malt and a little on the grainy side. The body is light and bubbly on the palate and the finish is mildly dry and clean. It’s okay, but bland.

Cask, 6/17/06, ABF ’06. Medium clarity in this dark mahogany colored beer, showing some caramel/tan highlights and a smattering of dark grey/beige head that is modestly retained and laces lightly. Mild chocolate and some sticky caramel are quite apparent, with a moderately bitter, baker’s chocolate-like note drying things out quite thoroughly. A glimpse of dark fruits, a hint of soft pale sugars (honey and vanilla) and ending on a graham cracker-like papery-dryness.The cask seemed to suffer the most in mouthfeel and flavor, being not quite thoroughly bright and a bit muddled with yeast. Some fruitiness, almost creating a light tartness, mixes with the darker malts to dry the palate, though there is certainly some residual sweetness, almost a caramel-vanilla-like flavor. The finish gets lightly papery, the flavor seemingly washed out on the end. The watery, loose texture certainly did not help things. With that in mind, the draught sample is a more accurate portrayal of this beer.... Draught (same night). Much more approachable, if somewhat more clean, the higher carbonation levels seem to soak up some of the sweetness and fruitiness, allowing a more accessible, dry chocolate malt nose, more clear and bright. Light graham cracker-like malts sit on the finish, and a touch of fresh, yeast nuttiness overlays the aroma. Hints of cocoa, vanilla and caramel, though much more lean and attenuated, comprise the flavor. Clean, clear presentation on draught displays a very easygoing drinkable nature, with light, but appropriate carbonation and only minimal yeast influences of light fruits. Still papery, somewhat watery (as the style would dictate, being only a 3.7 abv beer) on the finish, it finishes without much fanfare and accomplishes what a mild should; quench your thirst. Fine stuff overall, just too bad the cask wasnt in peak shape. The second best beer to come out of Harpoon brewery (behind triticus)!

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Lambs Gold Light Ale
column5: 500ml bottle from Fire & Ice, Narberth. Pours cloudy orange / copper with a proud white head. Vague malt aroma. Taste is rather weak and a touch watery with a mirage-like maltiness. Pleasant enough but not a lot going on really. Which at 3.0% was probably to be expected.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Lambs Gold Light Ale
column5: Bottle sampled at Björn, thanks. Very short white head. Chrystal clear yellow color. Artificial candy aroma. Sweet taste and caramell taste. No bitterness to balance the sweetness. Low alcohole beer is always hard to make, and this is another example of this.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Lambs Gold Light Ale
column5: Bottle from a delicacy store in Cardiff. It poured a hazy golden liquid with a white head. Strong and malty smell but with a note of rubber that disturbs a bit. The taste is similar to the smell except for the rubber. Very low bitterness, I can hardly feel any bitterness at all. Extremely smooth mouthfeel, like velvet in my mouth. A bit onesided beer but also very easy to drink.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Lambs Gold Light Ale
column5: Bottled. Clear pale golden, minimal head. Sweet and fruity with light body and clean mouthfeel. Very light and shallow. Low bitterness.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Lambs Gold Light Ale
column5: Bottle at thewolf’s Kolding tasting, 15 May 2008. Rather surprised to come to a tasting in Denmark only to see a whole bunch of bottles that I could have bought from the organic food shop at the end of my street at home (but hadn’t). Not much to say about this one really. Pale gold colour with a light haze. Don’t know what the hops are (UK organically grown hops are rather problematic) but there didn’t seem too many of them. Drinkable enough in a featherweight sort of way.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Lambs Gold Light Ale
column5: 500ml Bottle conditioned: Not a big fan of this. Watery, weak malt kind of dish-watery beer.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Lambs Gold Light Ale
column5: Bottle from Waitrose. Extremley cloudy with no head smell of sweet hops has a nice flavour of sweet hops.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Lambs Gold Light Ale
column5: 50 cL bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small diminished white head. Mild hoppy and fruity aroma with a mild spice note. Mild bitterness and light fruity note in a rather vague blend. A bit watery. Light acidic and bitter finish, thin but also rather dry.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Lambs Gold Light Ale
column5: Bottled. An unclear golden beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of citrus and hops as well as a light accent of malt. The flavor is sweet with primary notes of yeast, but also light notes of malt and citrus fruits. The body is thin.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Lambs Gold Light Ale
column5: Bottle. Low off-white and lasting head. Hazy golden body. Fruity herbal aroma. Flavor of fruits, a bit watery but still quite tasty in spite of the low alcohol percentage. Low carbonation, short aftertaste.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Twin Ram India Pale Ale
column5: 500ml bottle; BBE Mar 2020. Tried to drink it on 27th May 2019. Infected, came out as flat as a witches tit and murky. Drain pour.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Twin Ram India Pale Ale
column5: Blimey, you can tell this is small batch stuff, with that pungent yeast aroma. Strong fruity flavours battle out through all of that yeast tangyness, but the malts are kept at bay. Still rather “chewy” despite its thinness. Would like to try it from a cask. 500ml bottle from Treehouse, Aberystwyth.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Twin Ram India Pale Ale
column5: Poured a murkey amber despite having been sat a couple of days. This is the second Pen-lon beer I’ve had that has reminded me of my home brew attempts. A little sharp at first before a dry bitter finish with the taste of brewers yeast. Poor.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Twin Ram India Pale Ale
column5: Bottle from Coed Y Dinas, Welshpool. Pours cloudy copper, clear malts. Supposed to have a thick fluffy head but I got nothing of the sort. Grassy with some berries, fairly uneventful but drinkable nonetheless.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Twin Ram India Pale Ale
column5: Bottled, 500ml from James A Bailey Food Emporium, Llangollen, Wales. Hazy bronze with off white head. Smooth malty flavour with a hint of toffee, caramel. There is a leafy, slightly mouldy type of hop note, yeasty then a hint of fruit, Reasonable.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Twin Ram India Pale Ale
column5: Bottle from Björn, thanks. Thick fluffy light brown head. Opaque golden color. Small aroma from light roasted malt and some citrus fruitiness. Big malty taste with a medium body and nice bitterness.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Twin Ram India Pale Ale
column5: Bottled. Clear mahogany colour, mid-sized head. Dry and salty with a nutty roastiness. Fairly light bodied with slight notes of berries. Salty finish with low bitterness.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Twin Ram India Pale Ale
column5: Bottle. Orange-brown with a big, frothy and sustaining head. Aroma is highly fruity (mainly peach, much less strawberry) and hoppy (resin). Apart from that it is also grainy malty and to a smaller degree earthy, dusty, with some caramel. Full body and quite heavy palate, a bit too heavy that is, which is this beer’s one of two minor flaws. Taste is mainly resiny hops, peachy fruitiness, soft malt, some subtle alcohol astringency, and very subtle toffee that is kept down by the quite intensive and lasting bitterness.which is partly sharp-astringent - which is this beer’s second minor flaw. On the whole, however, this is a very good and recommendable brew, despite the partly disappointing palate.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Twin Ram India Pale Ale
column5: Bottle 500ml from Thirst for Beer in Pwllheli (Wales). Ale copper-gold, off-white average head. Aromas of roasted malt, yeast and fruit, touch of licorice. In mouth, the malt and the toffy are supported by spices and hops. The end is drier, always malted with a good herbaceous and resined bitterness.

column1: Pen-lon Cottage Twin Ram India Pale Ale
column5: Bottled. A red-amber beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of fruit as well as lighter notes of butter and hops. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel, leading to a quite bitter finish.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a medium sized head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that were and left behind a softly carbonated light yellow-orange colored body and an excellent lacing. The weak aroma was malty and dough. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a biting aftertaste.
