The flavor contained notes of malt mild hops mild spice sweet mildly vinous and alcohol. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

On tap at Brockway. Poured a clear medium golden with a short white head and some rising carbonation. The aroma found bunches of peppery spices and orange zest over a very lightly-toasted caramel base... banana notes laced through there. The flavor was all spiced up too (white pepper, coriander, and orange zest representing), English toffee, and some floral notes... good, but too focused on the spicage. Medium-bodied with a decent flow.. long spicy finish.

A misbehavin’ head started outrageous and finally settled on being creamy & off-white above a well-hazed golden/amber body. Big banana upfront with spicing secondary, funkiness apparent and alcohol pulling up the rear. Sweet-tart flavor with high astringence and a bitter finish combine to make me say "Oooh!" (at a bar where I don’t know anyone!) Green apple sourness, tart yeast profile, wheat background, mild stickiness, grapeskin upper-palate... well done! A growler of this came home with me and was a nice treat for friends at a Halloween party. On tap at Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL 60067

This poured a very hazy straw body with a modest white head. The aroma is fruity with banana and apples, has plenty of soft wheat, also a little soapiness, some mild spices, and a light lemony tartness. Smooth mouthfeel. The flavor reflects the aromas, the tartness kicking up a notch. Pretty refreshing ale. Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL
500ml bottle from Fire & Ice, Narberth. Pours hazy gold with good bubbly white head. Clean, balanced Welsh lager. Smooth finish. A real thirst-quencher.
Not overly flavoured, gold, clean and a bit under powered as far as the hops are concerned. A bit gassy too. Screams quality though.
Bottled. Clear golden, coarse head. Fruity viola aroma. Fairly sweet with clean, rounded mouthfeel. Light-medium bodied. Rather malty. Low bitterness. On the sweet side.

(Bottled) resembles a germanic pills in color , more bohemian to drink ; good fruity saaz citrus vibes intertwined with a sweet palate , i got subtle toffee pudding notes , grainy dryness. Nice quality.

Bottle from Brewer’s Droop, Bristol. Deep gold in colour with no head and slight carbonation. Sweetish, marmalade malts, a touch of leafy hop and bitter finish. As said below, an ale rather than lager, but drinkable enough.

Bottle at thewolf’s Kolding tasting, 15 May 2008. Rather surprised to come to a tasting in Denmark only to see a whole bunch of bottles that I could have bought from the organic food shop at the end of my street at home (but hadn’t). Perhaps one might expect this to be a grown up version of the Lambs Gold tasted immediately before. Well, it might have a little bit more weight, as one might expect, but the overall impression is still gold, clean and insubstantial. Perfectly drinkable but seemed underpowered and under-hopped to me. Almost certainly an ale made with lager ingredients rather than a true lager.
From the Bottle at Chris O’s 05/08/2009 Hoppy aroma. Golden and slightly pale with some alcohol present. Crisp and bitter malt finish.

Bottle 50cl. @ Chriso’s pre GBBF Shindig ’09. Light unclear light to medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, fruity, light hoppy, citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20090801]
Bottle at Chris-Os Pre GBBF 09 tasting ... light sour hop nose ... light fruit ... little sweet toffee
Bottle at the legend of chriso’s pre GBBF09 tasting. Alround rating: Very yeasty, nutty pale malt, the yeast is like some mildue covered ornage. Which isnt hot.

Bottle - dark with initial large tan head, dissipates to frothy top. Pleasant chocolate, roast, and vanilla aroma. Good mouthfeel. Easy drinking, good finish of standard stout - notes of chocolate, vanilla, coffee roast.

hmm... it has a decent malty coffee aroma and taste I guess, but there’s lots lacking. no head, thin, flat - i like a stout flat, but not this way - does that make sense? i’m not sure it does. It does to me, but I’m not sure if it does to you.

Cask (gravity dispense) at the Pigs Ear Beer Festival, London on 6 December 2006. Deep reddish brown colour. Roasty malt aroma. Smooth burnt malt flavour with touches of chocolate. Quite dry mouthfeel. Decent enough, without generating too much excitement.
Cask conditioned at Harbury Beer Fest ’10. Black with ruby hue, cream head. Sweetish liquorice in a powdery body, some sweet chocolate and a tarry thinnish finish.

[Bottle from brewer’s own stand at the Chiltern’s Festival of Food, Great Missenden] Pitch black with a thin-off white head. Oily mouthfeel. Flavour of smokey treacle mixed with cough mixture. Sour plum comes through, almost vinegary at times. Very odd.
500ml bottle - shared by Mark&Sarah - thanks! Rich black, small head. Slightly sharp palare. A full roast, but not so burnt. Leaves the mouth sticky and needing a good scraping!
Cloudy dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is woody with chocolate and a hint of smoke. Dry, roasted malt chocolate flavour, slightly sour and again with that wood note.

BCA. Opaque, near black in colour with a momentary tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate, prunes and roasted malt. Flavour had plenty of chocolate, more roastiness and a hint of salty sourness in the finish. Unusual.

500ml Bottle conditioned. 4.7%. Very lively with a lot of sediment; had to por carefully but sill lost 100ml or so. Poured almost black with a thick creamy white head. Aroma of burnt chocolate and malt. Chocolate and a pronounced bitterness on the swallow. Quite full bodied and a good example of its type.

Bottle 50cl. @ chris_o’s Pre-GBBF Shindig 2008. Light unclear medium brown color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, burnt, prunes. Flavor is moderate sweet and sour (sweet sour acidic) with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (020808)
0.5 l bottle, thanks Timo A! Golden color. Aromas of clove, pepper and some banana. Sweet spicy taste with clove, pepper, banana and apple. Medium body, high carbonation. Average kristallweizen.

Das ist das erste Mal, dass mir ein deutsches Bier beim Öffnen deartig stark entgegen sprudelt. Schwach hefig-herber Antrunk mit zunehmender Wässrigkeit. Wenig würzig, die Herbe verlegt sich in den Hintergrund und lässt das Bier weiter in die Wässrigkeit rutschen. Leicht abgestanden zum Ende, die Hefigkeit ist konstant geblieben. Trinkbar. 12/8/8/7/12/8

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium orange yellow color with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, white head. Aroma is light malty, wheat, moderate yeasty, light banana. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery - creamy, carbonation is soft. [20100813]
Clear golden with a medium white head. Yeasty aroma with wheat and bananas. Flavor had wheat and bananas. Finished sweet.

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Clear deep golden with a white head. Sweet banana nose. Medium body, again sweet banana accents but only slightly hazy. Very short finish with no bitterness. Not bad for a Kristall. 130810

Bottle, thx to fonefan. It pours a clear, golden body with a dense, off-white head. Lots of banana in the aroma, some cloves, but nothing more. Lots of aroma for a kristall. The flavor too has lots of banana, a touch of cloves, and is quite sweet. Candy-like. Full-bodied and effervescent. Some bitter notes in the finish, there should be more to deal with the sweetness. A nice kristall, but a mediocre one if it was a hefe. 100813
Bottle. Clear golden colour with a medium white head. Aroma and taste of fruits, wheat and yeast. Nice and refreshing.
bottled, berlinerbest06. amber - quite dark for a kristall. very bubbly, light vanilla aroma, quite a crisp finish, not bad
Bottle. Quite fizzy, but suits the taste of the beer quite well. Very banana. Quite sweet with a dry finish.

Bottle. Clear golden colour, sparkling. Stable white head. Banana aroma and flavour. Quite flavourful for a Kristallweizen. Citric in a not so good way. 5 3 6 3 13 Draught at BBF07. Clear copper colour. Very small white head. The aroma and flavour are quite close to any average lager. Low bitterness. No banana, citrus or yeast notes. Seems to be quite different from the bottled version. 4 3 4 3 10

A creamy white head lasts longer than others have today and laces the glass in a sheet. Body is a slight-hazed golden/amber. Aroma exudes Maraschino extract with light, light hopping beneath. Very creamy mouth with strong cherry flavoring that fades to dishwater and ABV. Friendly enough and on-par with brewpub fruit beers, just don’t get one if you’re hoping to taste "beer". On tap at Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL 60067

I’m rating this higher than I probably should because I love the smell of Maraschino cherries, and that’s what the aroma of this golden, creamy headed ale is. Beyond that, it returns to being an American Wheat, only with fruity cherries added to the flavor mix. It finished on a pip-like, bitter note. Where’d the cherries go? Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL

Pours a clear vermillion with an off-white skin. Aroma finds alcohol and fruity citrics alongside sharper Continental hops. Nutty with caramel notes, the flavor gives way to a hint of menthol late. Thin & dry which makes for a nice, clean finish. Wholly sessionable. On tap at Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL 60067

The pour looks promising, a bright orange/copper body with a modest, creamy off-white head. The aroma is full of sweet, rich malts and a little bit of toast. The flavor begins smooth and sweet when mid-way, a huge surge of chewy caramel fills the mouth. It creates an interesting effect that I tried more than a couple of times. The flavor is malt candy sweet. Enjoyable. Brockway Chophouse, Palatine, IL

Darker color, a pretty deep brown. The flavor wasn’t as sprucy as I thought... it didn’t really give you that minty sensation in your mouth. More of a nutty, malty taste to it. But, still a good beer.

Draft pint at the Rehoboth brewpub. Reddish copper with a filmy head. Only a light aroma, but this comes with a full-on palate of squishy hops. This has the texture and flavor of the cool northwest, with a bit of an alcoholic kick as it warms. Quite fitting for this cold November night on a Delaware beach. (#3176, 11/7/2007)

On Tap @ the Rehoboth Brewpub. Poured an amber color w/a moderate off white head. Floral Hop aroma. Had a definite hop flavor up front, kind of like a 60 minute, but a little more of an APA finish. Somewhat of a metalic, floral hop taste. I wouldn’t call this brew mild, it’s got a definite bite to it. Long hop finish. Not bad, but I’d just drink a 60 or 90 MInute instead, they have better balance than this one.
On tap at Dogfish Head, Rehoboth Beach location. Orange caramel, off white head. Aroma is apricot, sage, and coriander. Flavor is hops, coriander, citrus, and floral.

Draft at Manayunk. They bill this as a Belgian brown. Pours hazy medium brown with aroma of candi sugary caramel malt, brown sugar, some banana, and clove. Tastes of caramel malt, brown sugar, candi sugar, figs, banana, and cloves. Very similar to a standard weizenbock, and not bad at all.

Draft 6 oz’er at the brewpub: Clear golden with a shade of red tint and very foamy. Nice wild berry aroma, like rooting around in the underbrush. But the flavor comes off much starchier than expected. Tart finish.

Draft 6 oz’er at the brewpub. Interesting hybrid stye, not readily categorized. It has the yeastiness f a weizen with the citric twist of an American Pale Ale. Different, but not quite right. Points for adventerous brewing.
Draft - Grapefruit and light pine hops. Clearish gold with a nice white head. Dank and fruity with a nice touch of bitterness. Nice.
Draught @ the brewery. Pours a hazy dirty copper colour with a small off-white head. Nose is piney hoppy. Flavour is malty sweet, some grassy green hops, then a moderate piney bitter finish.

On tap at the brewery. A solid brew. Pours a clear copper color with a medium white head. The aroma is all oranges, sticky amarillo. The flavor is resinous, hop oils, oranges, low bitterness, quite flavorful. Smooth. Good.
Draft at the source. Cloudy golden amber color. Aroma of pineapple, mago. Taste is bright tropical fruit. Very nice.
Cloudy orange, light head. Mild citrus nose. Tangerine, grapefruit and orange blossom flavors. Mildly hoppy palate starts off well but leads to a watery finish, makig it feel a bit unbalanced.
My all time favorite IPA. Low ABV and easy to drink but hoppy and interesting and keeps me coming back for more. Sometimes, when it’s not fresh it is less than perfect but when it’s fresh, DAMN

DRaught at Amnesia Brewing. From notes. Tasted in tandem with the Desolation IPA. This one is smoother, with less bitterness than Desolation, better mid-palate. Rounded finish. Good combination of Amarillo and Chinook

On tap at the brewpub in Portland, OR. Pours a cloudy, orange-amber colored body with a finger-width, dense and frothy, beige head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is orange pines and florals with a sweeter caramel malt backing. Some bread, a few resins, and a light spice. Flavor is similar. Orange and citrusy pines with a good amount of florals and a medium sweet caramel malt backing. Some bread, a light earthy spice, and resins as this finishes dry, moderately bitter, and citrusy with some hints of toast. Lengthy aftertaste following a medium body and a moderate carbonation. Overall, a straightforward, but solid IPA. Well hopped with a firm bitterness and a good amount of caramel malts. Not bad.

Tap at Amnesia, Portland - 07/11/12. Pours a hazy orange/amber colour with an off-white head. Nose comprises pine, caramel malt, bitter grapefruit, tropical fruit tones. Taste follows, very bitter pine, orange pith, bitter grapefruit. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, very bitter in the finish. Decent drop !

Hazy orange pour with a tight white head. The nose is orangey and a bit fruity. A touch of spice and assertively bittered. Great palate and a bit of wheaty character that adds body. Bright tasting with some lightly tropical character as it warms up. Light for an IPA, but well-constructed.

Flesje meegenomen van vakantie in Italië en gedeeld met Benzai op 6-12-15. Bleek gelig helder bier met wit schuim dat snel weg zakt. Aroma is hoppig. Smaak is bitter hoppig. Nasmaak is bitter en plat. Matig vakantie bier.
Sampled from bottle shared by Inoven. Clear pale golden color, small white to off-white head. Smell and taste malts, lightly bitter, malt bitter. Low to average body and carbonation.

0.66l bottle from carrefour in milan. pours a clear golden with a small quickly disappearing white head and little to no lacing. aroma of corn. sweetish grainy flavour. a hint of bitterness towards the finish. not good.

Big bottle with Lager Premium written only. Pours a clear golden color, topped with a medium white head. Mild grainy aroma, almost non-existant. Taste similar. Slight sweetness in the start balanced by a very mild bitterness. Grainy body, very light and watery. A bit metallic in the after. Only drinkable when completely chilled. Not the best effort.

One of three beers recently available as part of an "Experimental Series" at the Eccentric Cafe. All highlight the characteristics of a single hop, balanced by light, cerealy malts. The bar staff did not know which particular hop was highlighted in each beer, however. This version had a hazy yellow-orange body, topped by a thin to medium off-white head. Light spicy hops aroma with subtle bready malts in the background. Crisp, lightly malted body with bitter spicy hops that lingered on the palate. Tingly, strong carbonation. The hops developed an interesting soapy, peppery characteristic over time that reminded me of Saaz...but I could be way off. In that case, this probably is best not classified as an American Pale Ale, but I’ll leave that for more discerning palates. In any case, this wasn’t particularly impressive.

The brewer told me which of the three experimental series had which hops...but I’m sworn to secrecy! I liked this one better than the other two--dark gold but with a tangier citrus and a bolder, sweeter hop flavor with orange notes. Wheaty.
Sampler @ Bell’s Eccentric Cafe: Pours a clearish, yellow color, little head, white, lasting. Very wheaty aroma, malt. Extremely malty, acidic, wheaty. More wheaty & acidic than the Melstrand.

Draft at brewpub Cafe. Poured hazy pale color with an average fizzy white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Light sour citrus aroma. Light to medium body with soft carbonation. Light bitter flavor with a light sweet finish of short duration. Drinkable with little character.

One of three beers recently available as part of an "Experimental Series" at the Eccentric Cafe. All highlight the characteristics of a single hop, balanced by light, cerealy malts. The bar staff did not know which particular hop was highlighted in each beer, however. This version was a touch darker than the Ahmeek, pouring a hazy orange color with a thicker off-white head. The hops were light, perfume, and flowery in the aroma. Flavorwise, I prefered this beer to the Ahmeek; the hops variety used is earthier and less bitter/sharp, allowing the light maltiness to breathe a bit. Nice floral, perfumey characteristics. A bubblegummy sweetness develops after a few sips. Another European hops variety, I assume, so this is probably best not classified as an American Pale Ale, either, although it really doesn’t compare to most of the English Pale Ales I’ve sampled. Not bad, but still very plain.

My least favorite of the three in the series, this one had a distinct grapefruit profile with some funky chemical aroma. Turpentine? Pine-sol? this might have tasted better with some really bold food.
Sampler @ Bell’s Eccentric Cafe: Pours a clearish, yellow color, little head, white, lasting. Very wheaty aroma, malt. Grapefruit taste, some malt, very grapefruity.

Draft at brewpub Cafe. Poured hazy pale color with an average frothy white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate sour citrus aroma. Medium body with soft carbonation. Light bitter flavor with a light bitter finish of moderate duration. Good, but not a standout.

One of three beers recently available as part of an "Experimental Series" at the Eccentric Cafe. All highlight the characteristics of a single hop, balanced by light, cerealy malts. The bar staff did not know which particular hop was highlighted in each beer, however. This version poured a slightly hazy yellow-orange, with a medium to thick off-white head. Perfumey aroma with light notes of citrus. This uses the most citrusy hops variety of the three experimental beers, still perfumey, but with crisp grapefruit notes. Nothing huge or bitter here, though. A rather bland beer, otherwise. This series is probably of interest to homebrewers looking to increase their grasp of hops varieties, but the lackluster basic recipe lends little excitement to somebody simply wanting to drink good Bell’s beer. Definitely not as interesting as last year’s wheat experiment.
Bottle at Erzbierschof Monday Club. A bit dusty and murky, some grass. Crisp carbonation over bready light bitter body. Finishes bitter, too. *shrug*

Bottle, 500ml, bottle conditioned. A cloudy dark ruby colour with a large brown head. Aromas of orange, plum, hops and yeast. A malty, fruity taste with hops, caramel and some alcohol noticable. A slightly sweet, slightly watery, moderately bitter finish. Some sourness becomes evident towards the bottom of the glass. Moderate carbonation. There’s something good and unique about the taste that I can’t put my finger on. I liked it.
Sampler at Brewerkz. Hazy orange colour, thin white head. Aroma of malt and grain. Flavour is light sweet, grain, hint of sweet cherry and almonds. Grainy finish. Light bodied. Bad stuff.

Draught at Brewerkz, Singapore. Appears ruby with a medium white head. Aroma and flavour of sweet cherry candy. A very artificial taste and presence. It’s fizzy on the palate too. A touch of sourness in the finish.

Reddish orange with small head of foam. Cherry scents dominate the aroma. Light malt presence with heavy sour sweet cherry flavour. Although sweet and sour, the balance is nice. Manifestly produced using cherry extract or syrup in my view but, the taste is not artificial at all. Great level of carbonation. Light bodied and very refreshing. Hardly any spice element, which is fine by me. The hop complexion is low and the brew is hardly bitter. However, I think the level of hoppiness is appropriate for this style of beer. Leaves a good impression despite slightly dry finish.

Draught at the brewpub Hazy amber color. Smells a bit like a beer left from the previois day. It tastes like a dry but pleasant Ale, with some good hops; the fruitness is almost impossible to detect, and unfortunately there is too much tannic bitterness. Unbalanced flavors.

Fruit beers are a regular fixture at this Singaporean brewpub but I can’t say this impressed. It tastes like the wheat beer laced with cherry essence but I’m happy to be corrected if that’s wrong. In the glass it’s a hazy unfiltered copper with a tawny glint. The aroma is very similar to the Wheat Beer with very little cherry presence. It’s not particularly fruity and remained muddy and ill-defined as it warmed. Thin body, moderate carbonation. There are clove notes, similar to the Wheat, and a thin chemical cherry note. Acidic finish. (Draught at brewpub)

To start with i thought this would just be williams red but not so. Aroma gives grassy hops, caramel, and is lightly floural. Taste has quite a malty base, sweetish, with grassy bittering hops, dry finish.

A malty red ale, floural, honey, buttery, caramel, peppery at times and well balanced, great mouthfeel though nearly flat. Poured straight from the cask on the bar top at Blackfriers Merchant City Festival 2006.
From tap at the Midtown location. Piurs hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is mild estery and fruity. Mild butterish, caramelish and sweet. Light bitter and vague fruity into the finish.

On tap at Union Square. Color is a hazy honey yellow color with little head. Aroma is very sweet and penetrating and is a mix of citrus, hops, honey, and toasted almonds- very pleasant. Taste is lightly sweet and balanced. Palate is light but full- much more than you would expect from Heatland. Good beer to drink all night long.

Light hazy gold, white creamy head. Nose held tones of soured orange, corn, and hints of bread. Flavor unfortunately is one in the same. Light bodied, soft carbonation, citric finish. Not terrible, but really needs some work too...

Pours clear and light golden-yellow in color. A small, fizzy, white head is quickly fleeting and leaves virtually no lacing behind. The aroma shows cereal grains, stale corny malts, doughy yeast, and traces of floral hops. Flavors, too, are based on overly sweet corn malts, again tasting stale and lackluster across the board. Light bodied and moderately carbonated, it basically drinks like a cheap pale lager. Not good at all.

0,5lt Bottle. Light yellow color with a medium white head.Malty and hoppy aromas nad taste. Richer taste and much hoppier than their lager. Refreshing and good in accompanying meals, especially during the hot greek summer.
Bottle bought in Athens. Not bad at all, light, with a crisp bite. Too bad there is a flavor element that reminds me of artificial sweetener, but it is not too dominating.

Draught at a Thessaloniki wine expo. Pours light yellow with a moderate white head. Aroma is light malt and hops with some skunkiness. Flavor is the same. Maybe I got a bad batch, though that’d be odd since it was their own promo staff serving it from kegs at the tasting. Basically a slightly hoppier version of their lager imo.

Light maltiness with a moderate hops that gives a good dry bitterness. Average fizzy head, white but no lacing. Light, clear and sparkling body, on the yellowish side. Finishes with an average and moderate bitterness. A very good pils produced in Greece.
This beer has a great color...dark cherry. hint of chocolate aroma with a semi dry aftertaste. coffee notes with alcohol finish.
Dark copper red with creamy white head. Sweet caramel, roasty, and alcolo aroma and taste with a clean finish.

On tap at the Irvine location. Deep brown, root beer colored pour, lightly transparent, and topped with a thin layer of cream head. Rich, malty aroma of dark caramel, pecan skins, and brown sugar. Thick, full bodied, sticky mouthfeel. My first impression is that its underattenuated some, but that opinion keeps on growing and getting more reinforced as I reach the bottom of my 16oz glass. Most of the malt flavors are clean and rich, but too brown sugary sweet for my tastes. Very caramelly flavors with some deep, dark raisiny notes without crossing the line into the realm of toasty. Nice flavors overall, the the amount of residual sugar left in this one detracts greatly from the drinkability.

column1: Back Street Wheat Naught Bavarian Hefeweizen
column5: On tap at the Irvine location. Very cloudy, goldenrod colored pour with a one-finger head of large bubbled, quickly dissipating white soap. Very yeasty, phenolic aromas with plenty of banana and loads of spice - some sharp clove and herbal tones, and some doughy notes that remind me of sourdough bread. Light bodied, but has a bit of a "weighty" feel to it and a soft carbonation. Lots of yeasty, doughy flavors that are similar to the aroma sensation. A bit over phenolic overall, but otherwise OK.
An excellent wheat beer with a noticeable, but light blueberry flavoring. Clean finish, alcohol flavor well hidden.

On tap. Pours a very dull, ugly brownish-yellow with no head or lacing. (Great Dane has far and away the cloudiest, most opaque non-filtered beers I have ever seen.) Aroma is bluebery muffin with clove thrown in for god measure. For all its prominence in the aroma, the blueberry is almost lost in the intense flavor parade. This beer is alarmingly spiciy, with tons of clove and an almost peppery quality up front. Bluebery and citrus tart are in there somewhere. Very unique, earthy, spicy, organic flavor. Good solid mouthfeel for a hefe, medium-thick palate. This was not at all what I was expecting; a very pleasant surprise. I could see this being a love-it-or-hate-it beer.

Very hazed and buffed goldenrod in color with a beautiful creamy white head and retracting marshmallow lace. Rock candi crusted blueberries roll out the nose, partnering with cloves and strawberry shortcake avec blueberry puree. Plastic squeeze toys and inflatable pool innertubes affirm its carefree status. Yeast strain’s flavor gets in the way of the desired fruitiness this one hoped to achieve. Blueberry angel food cake hits a curtailing lemon chiffon yogurt aristocracy. Sugar encrusted blueberry scones with ground cloves spun in buttercream is a semi-decent attribute. There’s not much hope in getting past the blueberries here. Vanilla combs the meringue and banana, though it barely gets a glimpse of activity. Beet sugar seems to be a major player, and then a touch of gingered apples comes in at the end. Hmph.

tap at brewpub-bright orange with a small froathy white head. lightly hoppy nose-flowery, citric with lots of tangerine and orange. light grapefruit as well. smells nice and delicate. crisp hoppy flavors here with very little malt presence. makes a good light hop drink for me due to all the fresh hop flavor here. finish is sweet and hoppy with lingering fresh hop leaves. nice session beer.

This poured a jet black body in my glass from which a head never emerged. The aroma has some light Bourbon scents neatly blended with roasted malts, a nutty bitterness, and maybe, just maybe a splash of chocolate. The sweet Bourbon dominates the flavor, barely allowing the roastiness to emerge. Some vanilla and oak are added to the mix. The finish is boozey and sticky. Carlyle Brewing Company, Rockford, IL

Draught sample at the brewpub in early October 2006. Opauqe ebony with a thin wisp of lasting head, little in the way of lacing....oaky vanilla notes in the aroma are well balanced with roasty, somewhat burnt chocolate notes, little in the way of alcohol....on the tongue though the bourbon completely takes over, roasty-chocolaty stout characteristics are subdued to the point of invisibility....I like bourbon, so I can enjoy the whiskey-vanilla-corn sweetness of of but it’s way unbalanced and the low carbonation and fairly thick, oily body don’t really help. Interesting, but problematic.

tap at the brewpub-black wit hvery little head and carbonation. Vanilla, whisksy, and light chocolate nose. Vanilla, roast, char and anise on the flavors-im glad the bourbon didn’t mask everything here. the beer still retains its origonal character with an accent of bourbon. pretty tasty. body is lush and silky making the experience that much better. a dose of bourbon heat on the finish. nice effort!
Very strange indeed, but ti was too light for being an old one, however the taste suggested so. The colour too.

Draught sample at the brewpub in early October 2006. Quite dark though not pitch-black, with a dark brown head that bubbles quite a bit and then dissipates....blueberries and bourbon-vanilla meld strangely in the nose, an odd funkiness ensues, like rotting fruit in an old barn, but as it warms a fresher quality takes over with sort of a liquor-cream frosting, all in all quite a complex and interesting aroma....alas this suffers much the same fate on the tongue as the regular bourbon stout, just too boozy and unbalanced though in this case the fruit helps kick the flavor up a notch and the berry acids seem to cut the bourbon’s oily sweetness a bit....it works on the whole but would profit from a lighter hand I think.

tap at brewpub-black with a nice froathy tan head. bourbon and chocolate abundant in the nose. a little fruit as it warmed. flavors are sweet with light chocolate, bourbon, and light blueberry as it warmed. the blueberry was not all that strong. it may have been before the barrel aging. Light vanilla on the finish. well balanced and well done. Light anise on the finish. I dig!

Name: Edenton Pale Ale Date: 09/23/2006 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Asheville crystal clear golden yellow, whispy off white head, touch of lace, light sweet carmel malt aroma with nice floral hops, very nice hop flavor balanced with some nice carmel malt and just the right amount of sweetness, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.3/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **+/4

Had this beer on-tap at Horniblow’s Tavern and took a growler home for myself and a friend coming over this weekend who is just getting into craft beer. Color was a light copper with a robust tan head. Aroma was biscuity with a slight citrus hint. Taste was pronounced malt with mild hop character to balance the brew and no more. I would guess less than 20 IBU’s here. Finish is clean and refreshing with a fleeting sensation of coolness in the back of the throat which was pleasant. This is a good starter ale which I will look to share with the macro-lager masses.

Sampled at the 10th annual Brewgrass festival. After speaking with one of their sales reps, I discovered that one of their offerings at this year’s festival was barreled just in time to bring. As such it was not named yet and had only been released that day. The rep explained that this was meant to be an easy transition into the Pale Ale category for those that were not used to the more biting bitterness of your standard IPA’s. In this task, they were successful. Pours copper and clear with light carbonation and a light wispy head. Very light aroma and is metallic, with light grain and grassy. The flavor is where it is at in this one. I dare to say that this will indeed do a good job of getting people interested in to the world of Pale Ale. Caramel and biscuit malts marked by subtle and well balance citrus and pine hops. There is also a very, very light sweetness. I think you would be fooling yourself not to enjoy the flavor of this one. It is NOT a hop powerhouse, nor is it meant to be. It is exactly what they were shooting for as an intro for non-pale ale drinkers. Medium slick body. Great sessionable brew and one that would do a good job as a crossover beer for macro-drinkers. Great job…..Now, what’s the name??

tap at the brewpub - Pours copper with a good, hoppy, mildly citrus aroma. The head quickly fades to thin, then lingers to leave some good lacing. The flavor is good and hoppy with decent balance. There’s mild carbonation on the palate and a medium body. The moderately long hops finish is pretty good. This is a very tastey IPA.
Rating this one from memory. After trying four of their beers that were absolutely horrid, I tried this one and surprise, it was actually pretty good.

Bottle: &nbsp Deep dirty orange, frothy head, sandy in color, fairly nice lacing. &nbsp Looks almost like a cask draw. &nbsp Oh wow, super strong spruce. &nbsp Might be a bit too much. &nbsp Has quite a bit of that herbal aroma that you find in urinal cakes. &nbsp Its pretty darn spicy. &nbsp Decent body, fairly smooth. &nbsp Well, assertive spruce on the finish. &nbsp A bit one dimensional, but at least it wasn’t infected!

Draught at The Lazy Moon Craft Tavern, Port Angeles Muddy light amber color with creamy head. Mild spruce aroma, stronger flavor, with a Rosemary accent; luckily the moderate sweetness balances a bit this herbal character. I’m against such kind of beers, but this is not bad.
Draft. Pours cloudy yellow with white head. Nose and taste of spruce, light malt and light peel. Lighter medium body.

Pours a cloudy orange-yellow with no head or for that matter, pine aroma, just very faint hops. Tastes very hoppy indeed, earthy, sour, bitter but nothing that really speaks to me and yells "pine you clod!" Thin body, ok carbonation. Drinkable, but high-gravity so not really a sessionable beer. Pine?

@GCBF-on hand pump-pours a retaining thin light tan head and cloudy/hazy gold color. Aroma is a Christmas tree, ? Taste is Christmas tree/pine, orange creamy then malt backbone. Some earthy. Interesting.

Cloudy light golden. Threre’s no getting around it so I’ll just say it. This beer smells like ass. Big piney flavour though (big relief) and fruity but more like grape juice. Kind of an odd beer all around.GCBF.

(Draught) Sampled at the Great Canadian Beer Festival 2007 in Victoria on September 7th, 2007. Thin white head with a yellow body. Nose of pure skunk. Flavour of a rotting peach mixed with tea-bagged hops. So very awful!

GCBF so likely the same batch Enniskillen had a few days prior to the fest. And yeah, it was rough. Hazy golden-amber colour. Aroma of bunghole. More than just a little fecal. I still tasted it, though...big spruce, lots of graininess and a rough alcohol finish. I’m going to presume it doesn’t always smell like that.

I tasted this beer at the 2007 Great Canadian Beer Festival, in Victoria, BC. I have been frequenting the GCBF for several years and I can say that I have never demanded a refund for a beer that I have tasted until I tasted Peak’s Spruce Juice. I was knocked off my feet by the “aroma,” which I can only describe as my hockey bag filled with sweaty hockey gear that has been fermenting in my truck canopy since the season ended this past spring. I don’t know how the brewmaster got the idea that this beer was drinkable, let alone worth the two tokens they charged for it. I could come up with a more palatable brew if I ran a 10K and squeezed the sweat out of my running gear for fermentation.

Sample at the brewery. Low fluffy lasting white head. Clear amber body. Sweet malt straw aroma and flavor with bit of caramel, grassy notes. Little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a short finish.

On tap @ Walnut. Orange pour with a white head. Toast, grass, and some sweet caramel. Apple, really grainy, and a weird vegetal note. The flavor is sweet toast and grain. Caramel, vegetables, and apple. Light yeast, water, and a green apple and lemon tartness.

Husky grainy coarse and acidic with distinct Nutrisweet / saccharine flavor (something like sweet rice cakes). Pretty god awful lager. Rice, cereals, vegetables, soil, wet leaves. Lightly sweet, harsh and acidic texture, low to medium bitterness. Red apple esters and corn kernels and metal. Ugh.
Draught at Walnut Brewery in Boulder. Clear deep red - no head. High red berries, sweetness, ryebread, caramel, high sweetness, mould, earthy, light hoppy, roasted, nice malty. Very low carbonated.

Draught at the brewpub. Clear orange coloured with a medium sized off white head. Sweet aroma of fruits, malts and caramel. Sweet and fruity flavour of malts and caramel with notes of hops and liquorice. Hoppy finish.
on tap-pours a thin white head and copper color. Aroma is sweet medium malt. Taste is sweet medium malt-caramel, smokey, mild hops. OK/mild carbonation.

Draught. Head is mostly diminishing. Body is dark amber. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted bread, cookie, caramel), lightly to moderately hoppy (apricot, flowers). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation. Decent quaffer.

Draught. Head is light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is dark amber. Aroma is moderately malty (cookie, caramel, molasses), lightly hoppy (resin), with notes of wood, bourbon/alcohol/whisky, and overripe banana. Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Guessing this is strong enough to be an ASA, but whatever it is, it’s not bad. A bit cloyingly sweet, and somewhat boozy, but pleasant.

Big Horse Brewing – January 2010 Strong dark malt and coffee aromas. Lots of alcohol in the flavor this was a big black beer. Good flavors this was so thick with dark malts and hops. Big time beer this was.

Had this on tap at the Big Horse Brewery in Hood River, OR. Colour... black with a thin tan edge. Nose... sweet, malty, faintly boozy. Palate.. slightly thin mouthfeel, moderate carbonation, slight hop bite up front, some coffee, booze, roasty malt, dark chocolate and a medium finish.

Tap at brewery. Deep brown to black colored with a smallish, fast fading tan head. Smattering of lacing. Aroma is choco-bourbon. Nice roasty malt presence with some vanillins and bourbon. Medium to full bodied, softer pleasing carbonation. Taste is of chocolate, light bourbon, coffee and hints of smoke. Really rather pleasant, not overdone with the wood or bourbon. Pretty tasty.
Clear golden colour. Sweet malty aroma with cascade citrus character. A little too sweet on the palate. Slightly cloying finish limits the sessionability of this beer.

Cask at the George on the Strand, 17/09/13. Clear chestnut brown with a light beige head that soon dissipates. Nose is a little thin, bready malt, orchard fruits, bread dough. Taste comprises light toffee, apple core, summer fruit, bready malts, faint orange flavour. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation a little on the flat side, light bitterness in the finish. Average bitter.
Ascot Festival 2012. Pours a dark gold colour with a thin white head, aroma is malty and has some fruit, taste is bitter with fruit, with a dry finish.

A Mes rate: cask at Baker St ’Sporks Clean gold with a slight brown tinge and a thin off white head. Aroma is malts upfront with a distinct nutty character and some slight floral notes. Flavour is even more nutty. For all the shouting about hops on the pump clip they are barely there in reality. Peanut butter finish is unusual but is never setting the world alight. Seems a little green to me but maybe that’s the idea...

Cask handpull at Simple Simons, Canterbury. Copper, thin off white head. Yeast/malt aroma. OK fruit in mouth, bit of polish, some almond nuttiness. Good fruit, strawberry towards the end, bit of spice. Odd mix of flavours. Bit of green apple throughout.

Cask conditioned @ Crispin, Wokingham. Golden colour. Fruity sweet malts. Musty yeast. I suppose the musty almost rotting fruit could be slightly autumnal in a damp leafy way but this doesnt complement a light fruity golden ale.

column1: Beer Valley Black Flag Imperial Stout
column5: I avoid IPAs because they are to bitter and taste gross. This Stout is no different and I will never buy it again. Stout should be bold, rich, thick, malty....that's why a lot of us drink it, not for nasty ass hop flavors.

column1: Beer Valley Black Flag Imperial Stout
column5: From Jun 2008 This pours a pitch black with a huge +2 finger head of tan foam. The smell has notes of roasted malt, coffee, and hoppy bitterness. The taste has big roasted malt, coffee, a touch of dark fruit, and a quite big hop profile. In fact, this is a *very* hoppy Imperial Stout. The roasted malt is big too. as is the coffee, but they are having a heck of a time competing with the hops. I think if the hops were calmed down to a lower presence, this would be quite the good example of the style but as is, the hops are just too much. Perhaps some aging would help but as this is my only bottle, I'll leave it to someone else to find out. ;^) It has a nice thickish mouthfeel and the carbonation is light and right for the style. And it *is* one heck of a looker in the glass. Lots of lacing and the head retention is awesome. I'm very glad I got to try it but I probably won't seek it out again.

column1: Beer Valley Black Flag Imperial Stout
column5: Sampled at GTBF 2006: Jet black, creamy brown head. Fairly fruity nose. Big preserved fruit notes. Medium body, chewy thick (but not nasty like the slogan claims). Fruity aftertaste. Bought the awesome T-shirt.

column1: Beer Valley Black Flag Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle sample at a tasting at Tom’s place. Thanks Tom. Black with a tan head. Roasty, a little coconut, a little nutty aroma. Bitter, roasty and a little dry taste. Bitter finish with a hint of cayenne pepper. full body.

column1: Beer Valley Black Flag Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle. Pitch black, nice light brown head. In aroma lots of coffee, but fruity aroma from coffee, some chocolate and roastiness. In taste medium sweet, strong roasted coffee flavour. Full bodied, creamy, soft carbonation, finish is floral bitter hops. Great RIS.

column1: Beer Valley Black Flag Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks Tom L. Pours black with a huge tan head. Aroma and taste of chocolate, coffee, licorice, prunes, cocoa, roasted malt, bitter finish. Full bodied, smooth and warming. Good.

column1: Beer Valley Black Flag Imperial Stout
column5: At a tasting, thanks, opaque black color, small creamy bubbly brown head, flavor of dark bread, chocolate and cocoa, lots of chocolate in flavor, lasting shrubby bitterness and just a hint of smoke, light sweetness getting stronger, tounge coating sensation. Good and solid.

column1: Beer Valley Black Flag Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle sample at a tasting at Tom L’s place. Thanks Tom L. Black with a light brown head. Aroma of roast, coffee, some chocolate and dark fruitsw. Bittersweet flavor, roasty, with chocolate, coffee, a bit of dark fruits, and a bitter hops finish. Medium to full-bodied.

column1: Beer Valley Black Flag Imperial Stout
column5: Pours dark/black With small beige head. Roasted aroma and coffee. Bitter taste of coffee, quite bitter, and dark chocolate, with bitter yet pleasent finish. Mild carbonation with a creamy texture.

column1: Beer Valley Black Flag Imperial Stout
column5: Beautiful nougat colored foam and a delicate aroma of hard toasted / roasted malt with distinct mocha tones. The flavor is cold coffee with a slightly burnt character. Lots of heavy malt body and only a slight discrete alcohol taste held down by coffee, roasted malt and a moderate hoppy bitterness. It’s a really nice imperial, but unfortunately the little anonymous in the amount of Imperial Stouts. It lacks just a little special character to step out of the crowd, and a well-tempered Limfjords Porter from Thisted in Denmark could easily have done it as well.

Pours a clear orange amber colour with a small loose white head. A sweet malt biscuit aroma with some caramel and ripe fruit. Moderately sweet, caramel, grainy biscuit malt taste with a citrusy hop bitterness in the finish. Nice.

Cask @Tree Folk’s (Rome). Pours golden with a fine and creamy foam. Aroma of malt, corn, fruity notes (apple, peach), lemon zest. Taste is well balanced, bread, cereals with a decent hoppy end. Light body, flat. Quite good overall.

Cask at the Rose and Crown, Sandhurst. Straw in colour with a loose white head; citrus aroma with some grain in the background; citrusy, grainy taste - certainly rye; and a dry bisucity finish with some lingering mandarins. Pleasant and easy drinking, unlike wome rye beers I’ve tried.

Cask at The Eagle, Battersea on 13 March 2014. Poured a clear copper colour with a dense, white head. Aroma of apricot, grassy hop and caramel. Initial flavours of rye, cereal and tropical fruit. Finish was progressively bitter, dry grains, hop resin and mild spice.

Gravity at Battersea Beer Festival 2013. A golden coloured beer. Quite a grainy mouthfeel, some sort of unusual funky flavour which I guess came from the rye but not quite sure what it was. Reasonable bitter hop finish, decent taste but somehow nondescript. I slightly irrationally didn’t quite get this beer.
Cask at Bree Louise. Very clear amber colour with small white bubbly head Aroma is very grainy and a bit stinky. Quite thin. Taste is grainy, malty. Finish is a more sweet and less skunky.

Cask gravity @ Battersea BF 2012. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy caramel aroma. Fruity malty grainy rye and caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

Amber color with a small white head. Smells of caramel, some lemon zest, some shortbread. The taste is initially a bit sweet and acidic, a bit of butterscotch. The finish is dry, mildly bitter. Light/medium body. Subtle carbonation. Well constructed but ultimately forgettable bitter!

Cask at the Magpie in Brentford, light copper with a fast settling white head, a little caramel and peach on the nose, crisp and peppery on the palate with sweetness and a little fruit in the mid-body then turning dryish and with a bitter tang.

Casked. Pale copper coloured, bubbly head, which vanishes quite quickly. Vegetables, caramel malts as well as slight hoppyness in aroma. Grassy and hoppy flavour with some sweet caramellish malts in it. Quite wellbalanced. Rather thin.

33cl bottle at our holiday home in France. Somewhat pale amber brown with a medium slightly off-white head. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Medium sweet and bitter tones. Malts, hops, yeast, caramel and tropical fruits. A tasty malty brew.
Poured a hazy amber color with a thin off-white head. The aroma was sweet with a tartness to it. Notes of tea leaf and sweaty. Mildly tart flavor with a mild fruity malt. Light-medium body.

English pale ale? - What? - leave it to the French, man - anyway, thanks to JoeMcPhee for sharing this - murky amber - semi-sour, dank, earthy, basement-ish aroma - some biscuity maltiness and a light fruity character - slight sourness and a bit of funk on top of some mild malt sweetness - a little doughy in the finish, as well as some fruit skin components - tastes infected, but it’s not completely awful.

Bottle. Deep amber beer with a sticky tan head. Aroma is lightly sweet with a cobwebby sort of dusty aroma. Flavour is sweet and a little bit caramelly. Chewy and sweet with a soft herbal hoppiness. It’s got a bit of diacetyl and a sort of slick/greasy mouthfeel. It’s got some decent components, but it also seems like there is some sort of off-flavour as well. Meh... not all that good.

Bottle from La Cave á Bulles, Paris Hazy amber color; big head; traces of yeast below the cap. It has a very nice, aggressive, aroma of English hops, earthy, grassy, tannic and a bit citrusy. It has a good flavor of caramel, with a rather dry and harsh mouthfeel; it has also a strong and quality bitterness, with a citrus touch, and some yeast. Long final. Very good.

Hazy amber beer; good, thick yelllowish head as from eggcake, leaving rings of lace. Grapey hops, garden herbs, lunaria, "citric",... Faint malty undertones, but the hops remain sovereign. Hoppy bitterness with both a caramelly, non-sweet underslung and a sharp, metallic finish. Here, the bittering hops have taken precedence too forcifully. I think that the use of more USA or NZ-originated hops, might have made a less metallic note and better balance. Not very full bodied, refreshing, nearly tart in the end. Still, a very agreable beer, but despite its modest ABV, not really a quaffing ale.
Tap at Kalt-Loch-Bräu in Miltenberg - seems to be the only beer left of this brewery. dark brown color, off-white head. dark malts, medium sweetness. rather dry. okay.

Im Kalt-Loch-Bräustüble, dem ehemaligen Ausschank der Kalt-Loch-Bräu, sind derzeit (April 2017) noch zwei Kalt-Loch-Biere im Ausschank: ein Doppelbock (nur saisonal) und ein Dunkel. - Dunkel: tief kupferrotbraun, klar; lockerer, wenig stabiler Schaum. - In der Nase feines Bayrisch Blockmalz und milder Kirschsaft. - Antrunk glatt dunkelmalzig mit delikater nussiger Note und zarter Kirsche. Nicht zu süß, ganz leicht herb (Kirschkerne). Ein wenig milder rezent, angenehm schlank und frisch. Im Abgang freilich recht matt - hier zeigt sich das Hopfendefizit. - Dennoch ein annehmbares, süffiges Dunkles.

Bottled, 500ml at Kalt Loch Brewery, Miltenberg am Main, Bavaria. Chestnut with off white head. This proved to be a sweet, malty beer with a slightly nutty character, some fruitiness, a bit of a mish mash but reasonable.

Geruch neutral, malzig. Der Antrunk ist säuerlich-vollmundig, malzig. Der Hauptteil wird malzig-röstmalzig-säuerlich. Schön vollmundig. Lecker. Auf der Zunge verbleibt eine trocken-säuerlich-röstmalzige-cremige Note. Gut abgestimmtes Süße-Herbe-Kombination. --> Leckeres Bier! Test vom 3.9.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,13,12,14,12,13 - 12,85
Pours a dark brown color with a large off-white head. A odd aroma of almost sour malts. A toasted malt flavor, light chocolates, again a odd flavor. Lots of caramel. OK, not my thing.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and it’s not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog! Dunkelbraun, fast schwarz, mit guter, mittelporiger, malzbierähnlicher Cremekrone. Geruchlich zeigt sich ein süßmalziges, würziges Aroma. Der Antrunk erfolgt malzig, leicht säuerlich, und dezent süß. Der Abgang wird karamelliger, dennoch bleibts relativ süß. Zur Mitte hin wird’s dezent röstig, aber hier dominiert eindeutig die süße Note, welche mit dem leicht säuerlichen Touch perfekt harmoniert.

Säuerlicher prickelnder Antrunk, in dem Malznoten bedingt erkennbar sind. Die Säre wird zum Ende stärker und begräbt die meisten Aromen unter sich. Das Bier ist so erfrischend, hat aber nur wenig mit einem typischen fränkischen Landbier gemeinsam. Ist die Säuerlichkeit erwünscht? 8/8/9/9/8/8
bottle. Clear amber-golden colour, mid-sized head. Malty with hints of caramel and roasetd malts. Nice.

The bottle looks simple, but good. The beer in the glass is dark, almost black, nice head. Starts malty and strong, not too roasty, but quite sourish from the beginning. That makes the beer interesting. Also some notes of caramel and coffee. Well balanced and very drinkable. A great beer!

50 cL bottle. Pours golden amber with a diminished off-white head. Dried fruity aroma. Flavour is slight chemical but otherwise dried fruity with a roasted malt and chocolate flavour beneath. Ends with dominantly malty tones and not much bitterness.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Columbus
column5: 30-Jun-07 (22-oz bottle: Purchased 09-Apr-07 for $3.75 at Liquid Solutions in Tigard, OR) The beer is golden-amber in color and a bit hazy, but since it’s a little under-carbonated, an aggressive pour is required to yield half an inch of off-white head. A really earthy hop aroma with a hint of vegetal in the nose, but the caramely malt offers nice balance. On the palate, the beer has an earthy hop profile with a bit of resiny bitterness in the finish, and the malts are sweet and fairly caramely. It’s more balanced than the Summit Hop IPA and over time, it shows interesting progression from earthy hop and caramely malt to a more bitter and resiny hop character. Medium in body with medium-minus carbonation. Spotty lacing is tightly packed, but some curtaining effect is visible as well. Overall, nice balance here, and it shows off the hops very well. Good, but not a repeat purchase.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Columbus
column5: Pours amber with a thin white head. Smells of pine resin, pepper. Tastes bitter and dry. Not balanced at all.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Columbus
column5: Pours a translucent yellow/gold. The head is 1-2 finger creamy light yellow. The aroma has many off characters, peanut shells, band aid, some bitterness is apparent. The flavor shows peanut hulls, mild bitterness, some sweetness, off flavors. Thin mildly biter palate.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Columbus
column5: 2006. 100% Colombus hops edition. Pours a fairly dark amber with some mahogany highlights and a fairly thin head. Hop aroma was fresh and earthy but not too assertive. Straightforward hops in the flavor as well along with a lot of maltiness. A bit of toasted grain, with some light sweetness. Nice body that finishes clean. A very pleasant beer.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Columbus
column5: bomber into tumbler. Weird light honey brown pour (not gross, but not appealing for an IPA), hazy, but with a big white head that provided great lacing. Aroma is primarily of fresh pine hops and is much more hoppy and pleasant than the flavor, which was almost sour, strangely bitter, and generally out of balance. Medium to light bodied on the palate with a quick finish. Overall: interesting and definitely unique, though not in the best of ways. Not a horrible brew though.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Columbus
column5: 22 ounce bottle at Belmont Station--Poured a gorgeous orange hue with a decent white top. Pungent wet-dog herbal nose with a biscuity resinous bite. Flavor is immediately an assault on the tongue. Thick, razor-sharp bitterness that lingers on and on. I am fine by that, but it kind of kills any other beer you might drink afterwards. Still, not too shabby.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Columbus
column5: Bottle and served in standard pint glass: Pours a clean deep golden hue with a large foamy head and outstanding lace upon the glass. The aroma has notes of resiny and herbal hop, wet biscuity grains, dusty yeast esters and a hint of pepper. The taste is bitter and resiny supported by mild pale malts. The finish displays some spice and some soapy off-tone. The mouth feel is moderate lively and refreshing enough, dry metallic finish. Not too shabby and an improvement over the normal IPA but I still think Organic hop are missing that something special.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Columbus
column5: This one just showed up from the local BevMo - I liked it. Lits of pine and citrus. Floral, but kind of muted. As they say, a clean bitterness. Unfortunately it has no dankness - which I love in an IPA. This hop is lonely in this ale...and it really shows you how you need the full bouquet of hops to craft the perfect IPA.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Columbus
column5: 22oz bottle. Pours a cloudy brilliant orange color with a foamy white head that fades to a film on top of the brew and leaves good lace. Smells like peanuts, and like someone said previously, vegetables. Tastes a bit nutty as well. Also tastes like vegetable pulp, you know, stalks and stuff. SOme citrus in there but definitely in the background. Full bodied, nice active carbonation. Not that great. I bought it 2 days ago from BevMo but maybe its not fresh.?.

column1: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Columbus
column5: Pours amber, good clarity, with a small white head. Citrus grapefruit nose, a bit herbal, with sweet malts notes alongside. Earthy flavors tend to show up, but don’t last long enough to pay rent due to the big bittering hops that scrape the palate. The hops take on a soapy quality in the finish and show more of their pine and herbal qualities and almost a bit of a dusty flavor.
golden color with a spice nose (nutmeg, sage). very smooth and relaxing. i can see drinking this beer during the summer months and chllaxin’ with some friends. my 2nd favorite of the day

Crystal clear straw body with off-white head. Aroma is medium sweet, candi sugar, some peach, light berry. Taste is medium sweet, candi sugar, some berry, cantaloupe, faint seltzer. Light body with some crispness. Very light beer -- keeps it simple, but that’s not always a bad thing.
tap at falling rock. solid german style pils. a bit dry. nice wheat, grain, lemon grass. enjoyable.

Draught, Falling Rock. Head is mostly diminishing. Body is medium yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain, cookie), moderately hoppy (flowers, grass), with a strong note of urinal cake. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. The aromatic resemblance to walking up to a men’s room urinal is uncanny (there have only been a few other beers that I’ve found this in, but when it’s there, wow is it striking). Not the urine smell, mind you, but the disinfectant/deodorizer cakes. But don’t get me wrong; I’m not knocking this beer tooooo hard for that. It’s not a bad beer. Too sweet, perhaps, but it’s a huge step up from the rest of the Coors line. Huge.

Draft at Falling Rock. Light gold in color with a big, uneven white head. Grains on the nose, but a good variety of oat, straw, grass, and nuttiness. Light palate, not crisp or biting, but a little complicated. Very rustic all around, and natural flavors follow the outline your nose gives you at the beginning of tasting.

On tap @ Falling Rock poured a clear golden yellow with a lasting white head. Aromas of bread, straw, light citrus and slightly grassy. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bread, light carmel and earthy hops with a lingering bitter finish. Tastiest Coors product I’ve had!
Bottle. Ruby red pour with ring of white bubbles. Sweet and a little fruity. Odd cardboard malt flavor. Light carbonation. Not very enjoyable.

This pours a clear copper colour, a finger of foam and good lacing. The smell is of apple sugar and a hint of the hops that they say on the label. Tastes better than it smells to me. Sugary, yes, but it comes across to me as similar to some malt attributes that I have noticed in other non gluten free beers. Apple taste is there and I think it contributes rather than detracts from the overall taste. Very little hint of hops but at this point, it just doesn’t matter. Decent mouthfeel for the lowish abv. Interesting. I’m not sorry that I bought it but there’s little chance of a repurchase despite my not negative review.

Nice amber copper color; Light slightly creamy body; Aroma of malt, floral, & some fruit; Flavor of sweet malt, caramel/honey, fruit, and wheat/grain; Finish is slightly tangy; Not bad for what it is.
500 ml. bottle. Pours a clear pale amber with a small biege head. Aroma of fruit, malt(?), and grain(?). Taste is sweet fruit, sugar, and florals. Might be a good gluten free.

Probably the best gluten free beer that I have tried - though that is faint praise. +++ Sampled from a 16.9 oz brown bottle this beer poured an orange-caramel color with a medium sized soapy orange-white head that lingered and left decent lacing. The aroma was grainy and dryish with a bit of toffee. The flavor was bitter and tart with vague citrus, a bit of perfume and light notes of toffee and nut. Medium length dryish citrus and toffee finish. Medium body. Ok.

Bottle. Medium amber with a flat short lived head. Aroma is caramel, cooked apples, and light corn candy. Caramel flavour, light kirsch, breakfast tea. Medium bitter finish. A bit odd, but not terrible.

500ml bottle in a shaker. Pours amber with an off-white head. Aroma of floral hops, light maltiness but nothing really of substance, and tin. Flavor the same. Average texture. A weird beer, but a nice hoppiness.

Pours clear, light copper with a quick, soapy, white head. Aroma is nondescript hoppy, honey, sugars.... Taste is light, watery and sweet.....a hint of tea-like bitter. Oddly fruited and artificial. Almost like a canned ice-tea with some alcohol thrown in.(and precious little of that) Very disappointing....as I’m a big fan of this brewer.

Pours a one-finger cream head that fades quickly to a thin layer leaving some lace. Crystal clear copper color. Light-medium carbonation and medium bodied. Hints of sugary nose and flavor is sugary hops and a dry finish. Okay but needs some malt. Pricey at $8.99 for a 500ml bottle from Julio’s Liquors Westborough, Ma.

Pint bottle. This is clear and is tea colored with a bit of copper. A decent two finger head lasts a couple of minutes. This smells like grain and brewers malt. The flavor is also grain and what tastes like rye. There is some fruit that is kind of syrupy and some bitterness that tastes kind of artificial. It is a bit sugary and sorghum is tasted. Despite all of that this isn’t terrible and I give any beer with such a low ABV some lee way.

Aroma is sweet rotting vegetables, chewy candy hops mixed in. Has good clear gold body and okay foam on top. Tastes of sweet hops with white wine hints. Mouthfeel is full and has good oiliness. This is a nice iipa, alcohol is well hidden and flavours are strong but not overbearing.

500ml bottle Hazy orange pour with OK sudsy head. Malty aroma with peach, orange and nectarine notes. Medium bitterness which carries through from start to finish. Along notes of honey & buttery malt. Not bad.
In a night spoilt by big, boisterous IPAs, the Stuntman held his own, but did not dominate. Will have to try again in less testosterone- or hop-filled circumstances
A good hoppy smooth sweet taste. Nothing to write home about but very enjoyable drinking.
On tap at Brother’s Beer. Pours hazy with a mild aroma of pine. Flavour is big pine, funk and grass. Decent.

Pleasant pine aroma in a golden pour. Big hop forward balance with a tasty fruit body and big sustained bitter finish. A nice clean example of the style - but maybe a little one dimensional compared to other local examples (eg. Liberty Citra).

[8209-20160509] Tap. Fruity candy store aroma is slightly musty, reminds me of a Bulk Barn dried fruit section. Fruity toasted citrus malt flavour has a grainy base. Medium body. Good. (7/3/7/3/14) 3.4 (@ Hallertau brewpub, Riverhead, NZ)

2016-05-09. Crisp dark yellow body with a small creamy beige head. 3+ Aroma is relatively alcoholic, burying the pleasant lemon and citrus hops to a certain extant. Flavour is hoppy, moderate fruit up front gives way to stronger bitterness that follows. Average plus bodied palate, good carbonation. 3+ Okay, the hops don’t quite stand up to the alcohol enough for my liking. 7/3/7/3/13-14 On tap at Hallertau Brewbar, Auckland, NZ.
On tap at brewery. Golden to amber color, hazy liquid, white quickly fading head. Quite sweet, medium bitter. Boring.

Tried on tap at Fine Wine Delivery Co. Quite a lively beer with some inviting citrus passion fruit flavours, balanced with pine needles and resin. Not over powering for a 8.5% beer, rather easy drinking leaving a pleasant tingle on the side of the tongue.

A nice brown ale with good roast and chocolate notes. Amber/brown color with a decent lasting head. Moderately sweet chocolate and roast make up the flavor profile. A little lingering sweetness in the finish. Nice and drinkable. One of the better brews here.

I wish I could have obtained my infor about this beer, but it was stealthy available only as a cask offering. No description was given or able to be obtained. Cask pint at the brewpub. Lightly malty, chocolate maltiness present in the nose. Slight sweet cocoa aromas make an appearance as well. All in all, a decent brown ale aroma. Transparent dark amber/light mahogany body with a nice, firm off-white head. Nutty, slightly bitter, floral choco-cocoa flavoring. Refreshing and drinkable. Satisfying and falvorful brown ale.

Gold Color with Orange Hue. Off White Head. Bittersweet Very Fresh Smelling Hops. Medium Bodied with a Hazed Hop Mouthfeel. Subtle Pine and Ctirus Notes...Fresh Dry Hop Flavor..with a Light Wet Hop Flavor Also...Light Sweet Malt Taste in the Background, Balancing out the Hop Dominated Flavor..Very Solid and Just Balanced Enough to Enjoy the Fresh Hop Flavors.
Winterfest. Tasty, hoppy mess of a brew! Serious, biting hops in this for sure. Nice tonuge burn! ya!
had at winterfest mm tasty hoppy heaven and im a fan bitter to n end though i still say furious is the way if you want stright up HOP burn but agreat hop route get some now

Winterfest 2007...Hazy colored pour. Heavy grapefruit and citrus nose, very enticing. However, for me the goodness kind of stops there. The massive bitterness detracts from this brew and is rough on the palate IMO. I think two hearted uses a lot of centennial hops, but it is much easier to enjoy. Just a little too bitter; which is surprising for a hop head like myself.
Wow, very very hoppy. Bought a couple of growlers of this,sent one out and enjoyed one with friends. Massive bitter hops with a touch of sweetness that tasted like kiwi.

Lovely orange. Good cream head, dense. A pretty amazing sense of hoppiness, vibrant, attractive aroma. But the flavor is too intense. Incredibly long lasting bitterness. It being on cask added a great dimension that wouldn’t have been there. This pushes hops as far as I’ve seen it, which may or may not be a good thing. (cask at brewpub)

22 oz bottle, courtesy of footbalm. I love hops, dont get me wrong, but this one was just rediculous. They certainly aren’t kidding by saying that this beer is "fresh", because it actually tasted like a pine tree. Or a sprig of rosemary. I remember years ago, I made a batch of homebrew and I decided I was going to throw in tons of hops.....except, I didnt do any homework and check what would be adequate......the result was a very piney, rough beverage. This one reminded me of that beer.

Sampled draught at the Autumn Brew Review in Minneapolis, October 7 2006. Faintly hazy gold with a thick lasting white head....just massively fresh hoppy nose, lots of citric acidic character but it settles down quickly into something like a grapefruit-creme candy with whiffs of wet spruce, ending up fairly soft, inviting and sweet....until it hits the lips which sense the strongest fresh orange/grapefruit juice texture that they’ve ever experienced, tongue-numbingly acidic and bitter, endlessly continuing through to the long, long finish....thankfully there’s just enough light pale malt to carry through and keep it readily drinkable. Pretty terrific.

A huge thanks to footbalm for getting this beer to me. Deep golden color, lightly carbonated with tongue biting bitterness, this brew was great w/ spicy thai food. Be forewarned, it’s a bit one sided in its flavor: there isn’t anything in the way of maltiness to balance the hops.So, if you want a hop assault, this one does it nicely.

Golden shaded brew with a creamy head. Aroma is sweet, floral, and even seems to boast the "freshness" of the centennial hops. Some spicy sensations on the tongue are vegetal like bell pepper. Absolutely bruising in its bitterness and perfect to complement the brisk outdoor winds of fall. A campfire could have made this better as could have a bit of malt to solve its balance issues. So, it’s a good, aggressive brew, but it’s too one-dimensional and not as impressive as the Simcoe or Centennial pale ales.

330ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours clear gold with a tall frothy head. Aroma is corn, lemon, minerals, cardboard. Taste is watery AF, malt, cardboard, next to zero bitterness in the finish. Rather sad.
Medium white body, clear yellow. Smells like the dirty industrial lubricants at an old oil change station. Flavour is bad sweetness with chemical notes. Watery on the mouth. Awful.
0,33l bottle @ Pullman Cairns. Pours pale golden with a medium head. Aroma and flavor are very light malts. Watery. Super dry indeed.

Served on a Qantas flight from New Zealand to Australia. The blurb on the can tells of 4 mates who came together to 'Push The Boundaries' and to strive through failures and success to create 'The Best Tasting Beer'. I fear they never made it past the failures. Native North Americans have a description for this type of beer, so do I but mine is unprintable.
I created an account just to share with you how woefully tasteless this beer is and how downright disgusted I am that enough people purchase it to ensure its commercial viability. Pathetic attempt
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours clear yellow gold with a thin white head. Aromas of light corn and pale malt. Taste is thin, dry, light metallic note and a faint astringent finish.

Not bad for what it is if I'm after a cheap carton or schooner at the pub it doesnt let you down in comparison to others in its category. Light flavoured beer nice for a thirst quencher on a flaming hot aussie summers day.

I buy this beer because I am a diabetic and it does not raise my sister level very much.the only. Problem with it is I get a lot off the stubbies are flat and taste like horsepower the kids have not been put on tight enough I hope someone at the brewery reads this and does something about it as one carton I bought half the bottles were flat to expensive to keep buying

Bottle at the Star Event Centre in Sydney. Pours a golden body with soft white head. Nose is sweet malt. Mouthfeel is thin bodied with sweet malt, sugar, spice and corn. Only slightly better than the '3.5' version.

Can of piss at home, approximately one year old. Clear golden appearance with a big foamy head. Drank ice cold. Some mineral notes with very light herbal hops. A bit of toast. At 32f, it drinks not fucken bad.

column4: Ferme de la Vallée au Tanneur - Jean-Luc Cenier
column5: Bottle from the Merchant City Festival Glasgow. Aroma of fresh shoes and fresh apples. Taste is fresh apples with a slight plasticness but nothing unplessant. Carbonation is huge and furiously sparkles but the mouthfeel is very nice very fine.

column1: Jean-Luc Cenier Cidre Bouche Fermier Brut
column4: Ferme de la Vallée au Tanneur - Jean-Luc Cenier
column5: Bottle direct from the Cidery in France. Slightly cloudy and golden in colour with a little fizz in the glass. Sweet on the nose. Quite sweet to taste - very eating apple flavour and a little sherbuty. Nice as a one off but potentially a bit sweet for my taste in large quantities!

column1: Jean-Luc Cenier Cidre Bouche Fermier Brut
column4: Ferme de la Vallée au Tanneur - Jean-Luc Cenier
column5: Bottle direct for the farm on the Normandy Cidre Trail. Hazy golden with no head to speak of. The taste is fresh and zingy with sherbet and tart apple. Refreshing with a pleasantly dry crisp finish. Good cider.

column1: Jean-Luc Cenier Cidre Bouche Fermier Brut
column4: Ferme de la Vallée au Tanneur - Jean-Luc Cenier
column5: Clear golden colour. Apple aroma, earth, brett, hint of lemon zest. Quite dry apple flavour, only a hint of sourness, yeast. Dry, light bitter apple finish. Lovely, refined and balanced brew! (from 75cL bottle @ home)

column1: Jean-Luc Cenier Cidre Bouche Fermier Brut
column4: Ferme de la Vallée au Tanneur - Jean-Luc Cenier
column5: bottle at toms ... nice golden yellow... sharp apple ... sweet ! apples ... very good apples at that... as well as sharp typical cideryness. but clean and balanced.

column1: Jean-Luc Cenier Cidre Bouche Fermier Brut
column4: Ferme de la Vallée au Tanneur - Jean-Luc Cenier
column5: Aroma is very appley, fresh and a bit sour. Taste is similar with a bit of overly ripe sweet tangyness but very dry. Carbonationa is soo fine the mouthfeel is excellent. A serious amount of yeast in this bad boy also.

column4: Ferme de la Vallée au Tanneur - Jean-Luc Cenier
column5: Aroma of sweet apple juice with a bit of overly ripe apple too. Taste is very appley with a very concentrated apple juice flavour a bit funky also.

Draught, Wynkoop, GABF week 2006. Head is mostly diminishing. Body is murky dark brown. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain, caramel), with a note of buttered popcorn. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter, unclean. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.
on tap-pours a dissipating creamy tan head and dark red color. Aroma is sweet medium malt, dark fruit. Taste is sweet medium malt, dark fruit. OK effervescence.

Draft at Wynkoop. Dark brown. Nose is dark malts, light cocoa, and soft choco notes. Taste is more dark malts, wheat, and cocoa. Body is medium with a near full carbonation feel. Ends with more malt, cocoa and some chocolate.

Draught at the brewpub. Clear brown color with thin off white head that laced the glass. Aroma was a combination of dark cholcolate and and astringent varnish. Chocolate came out again in the flavor along with a touch of clove and banana. Eh.
tap. brown hazy pour. soapy head. hoppy, sour malts, some banana. good but not great.

On tap at the Wynkoop Brewery 9/27/06. Medium brown color, cloudy, thin head. Aroma is dominated by roast--some light banana in the background, maybe a little wheat. Flavor is somewhat stale. Weiss yeast is definitely there, but dominated by roast. A little thin in the body. Overall, not a fan of this one....the recipe needs some work.

Short-lived white head over slightly hazy bright orange beer. Fresh, fruity nose with citrus, some hops and a spicey streak, that I cannot pinpoint. I would say coriander, but restrained and more than just that - NO raspberries. Seems some licorice too, but not sweet. Very short impression of (citrussy) acid, but then an oppressive, dull-doughy, neutral taste takes over, prolonged with a dull spiciness. Definitely not their best try. As partially dried-out mandarines. I cannot taste a single raspberry. Light bodied, but oppressive. Well, for once the hops are not stereotypic and imposing - and I end up wishing they were... not to mention my raspberries!

Color amarillo claro, pajizo, sin turbiedad, transparente. Espuma blanca de poco más de un dedo de espesor y escasa retención. Aroma escaso a cereal, heno y ligero limón. Sabor igual más un toque de manzana amarilla, sin amargor, alcohol bien integrado. Textura acuosa. Carbonatación media. Estoy seguro que se puede hacer mejor cerveza con mijo que esto.

Dieses Bier habe ich vor eingen Jahren in einem Bio-Laden gefunden und gekostet. Damals hat es mich nicht sehr erfreut, da es mch einfach nur ain Vollkornbrot und nicht an Bier erinnerte und mir der klassische Bier-Geschmack fehlte. Heute weiß ich welche Vielfalt "Bier" haben kann, weshalb ich es nicht mehr so übel finde. Den Zusatz brotig lasse ich aber stehen, was es aber wieder interessant macht -nicht nur für Allergiker.
Draught (Pikkulintu, Helsinki, Svenska Dagar 2006). Very bitter aroma, and taste fills the mouth and lasts a long time. Ginger prominent. Good for any time of year.
Draught at SBWF 06 as Höstbryg. I wonder if this is the one. The aroma and flavour are sour, but OK balanced out by some malt.
On tap at Bishops Arms in Malmö. Pleasant stout with all the standard stout flavours present to some degree. Quite dry and bitter - drink one and you want another....

Draught @ Bishop’s Arms, Malmö. Pours a black colour with a tan head. Roasted malty coffee aroma, with some hoppy hints. Sweet roasted malty flavor with hints of coffee, chocolate and hops. Dry roasted malty finish with some bitterness.
[Sampled at SBF, 2006] Pitch black. Bubbly, beige head. Milky chocolate in the aroma. Salty with chocolate in the flavour. Distinct bitterness.

Draught at Bishop’s Arms Black color; creamy head. Nice and delicate aroma of roasted malt, with Digestive cookies and light hops. Medium-light body, the flavor is basically from the roasted malt, with a touch of acidity deriving. The final is bitter with too much burnt sugar. Not bad, but too monodimensional for me.
Draught @ Svenska Dagar, Pikkulintu, Finland. Very sweet aroma of dough and dark... yeast? Almost completely black colour, thick head. Bitter taste of grape fruit. Medium-length finish.

Draught at Stockholm Beer Festival. Beautiful dark colour. Good steady light brown head. Smells lovely. Fresh hoppy. Dry-ish flavour, with a pleasant edgy finish. Coffee. Some bitterness, and very balanced.A good, flavourful stout.

(Draught@Pikkulintu, Helsinki) Very dark reddish brown with a medium, creamy and foamy, lacy head. Slightly sweetish, roasted-malty aroma with licorice. Licoricey, slightly burned, but mostly roasted-malty flavor. Nothing spectacular, but a fine, enjoyable and pleasantly low-abv stout, without excess color malt. Nice!
Pours dark brown, tan head. Roastes malts and coffee in aroma, with some notes of cocoa. Slight hoppy flavour with good bitterness and roastyness. Somewhat chocolatey.

Sampler at pub. Lighter yellow than the Belgian I started with, with a thin layer of foam. Malt smell is pretty light, but in the "refreshing" range. Taste shows a bit of orange peel and yeast (the beer menu suggests marmalade). Warming alcohol, with just the slightest note of farmhouse funk. I still haven’t pinned down how a saison "should" taste, but this one is nice.

Draught pint at the brewpub, mid-October 2006. Hazy, bright gold with a large slow-diminishing smooth white head, bit of soft lacing....delicate lemon-spicy (coriander, white pepper) dominated nose also shows touches of vanilla and is backed throughout by a pleasant sweet cookie-dough yeastiness that seems at first too soft but eventually offers a deeper earthiness....body is sweet at first but nice earthy, grainy and mineralic hints show up quickly, iron and sour wheat, sweet orange at the front slowly turning to bitter Seville orange at the dry finish....very full, smoothly and naturally carbonated, obviously unfiltered with a "rustic" mouthfeel full of light yeast fleck....the finish on the whole is a bit sharper, hoppier than might be truly authentic but all in all this is a fine example and easily the best beer I’ve had from this brewpub. Well done!
Draft @ brewpub. Looks like murky sewage, awful and flat to. Strong bubblegum, funny phenols, and glue. The palate is also like glue. Remember liquid cement? This looks, smells, and tastes like that.
