Draft pint at the brewpub. Reddish orange with a sticky top. Yeasty aroma. Alcoholic punch with an orangey aspect. Not as overpowering as you’d expect from 8.5%!

column1: Turtle Mountain Triple Play Pale Ale
column2: Rio Rancho, New Mexico, United States
column5: Tap at brewpub pours lite orange hue with a small white fizzy head nose is fruity pebbles diacytl flavors of piney hops and diacytl wow notbing really good here watery body and poor apearance needs work

column1: Turtle Mountain Triple Play Pale Ale
column2: Rio Rancho, New Mexico, United States
column5: Pours a nice cloudy deep golden with a lasting frothy head. Aroma is huge pine and citrus, lots of grapefruit and oranges. The body is med. with low CO2. The flavor is near perfect. Tons of juicy American hops. No diacetyl or other offs, just a lot of hops. The finish is supremely bitter.

column1: Turtle Mountain Triple Play Pale Ale
column2: Rio Rancho, New Mexico, United States
column5: Draft pint at the brewpub, 9/19/06: Identical to the IPA, maybe a half shade lighter. Nice "aley" outdoorsy nose. Very light flavor complexion. Mildly earthy and easily quaffable, but also somewhat boring. Haven’t been to TMBC in a while, but I was disappointed (good old memories taken down). #2470.

column2: Rio Rancho, New Mexico, United States
column5: Draft pint at the brewpub, 9/19/06: Again, zippo for a head. Midnight red. Just the barest of malty aromas and just a hint of caramel malt flavors. Shiner Bock has more flavor. Very disappointing but mildly more malt-ballsiness as I went. Capped a disappointing return to TMBC. #2471.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft. Pours light brown. Tan head. Nose/taste of candied fruits, malt and some light caramel notes. Medium body. Slightly off.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Had this on tap last Fall. Has a nice touch of malts,hops and a REALLY good nutty aftertaste that I have been longing to have ever since I’ve had this! One of the best beers I’ve had in a while. Will make it a point to get this brew again when I’m in the area and around the season. Highly recommended

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours a light tan head and amber color. Aroma is medium malt-peat. Taste is medium malt-peat/some sweetness, secondary/faint hops, yeast-some fruit. OK/mild carbonation.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Poured amber with a tan head. Pretty good retention. Smells like sazz hops, german malts, caramel and grain. Taste is solid with a good caramel presense. Mouthfeel is watery yet pleasant. Sazz hops come though in the finish. Pretty nice stab at the style.

On tap at the 10th Annual San Diego Strong Ale Festival: Pours a slightly hazy golden bronze with a small, wispy-lacing, frothy white head. Lightly peppery earthy citrus hopped aroma. Body starts sweet and sugary with a lot of candy flavor and fruity esters turning into warming alcohol and some citrusy bittering hops. Unbalanced and somewhat thin for the style.

10th Annual SD Strong Ale Fest: Very hazy copper color with a medium sized off-white head. The malt aroma was on the light side. Light notes of lemon and citrus with some alcohol present . Earthy hops peeked out as well. Sweet malty flavor. The bitterness is mild. Decent alcohol warmth but can taste some of it as well. Hop flavor shows on the finish. Silky mouthfeel.

Tasted this in the Three Judges, Glasgow in November 2004. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear copper red in colour with a thin white head. Slight malt note in the short nose. Thin watery mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt gives a weak maltloaf base with tart redcurrant fruit. Metallic tang of hop resins gives a dry spicy bite to the long aftertaste. Finish is weakly malty and quickly runs out of steam. Not one of their best from the portfolio.

Cask, handpump at The Hop Pole, Aylesbury, Bucks, 11.10.10 This version is 4.3% . Pours amber with a white head, light aroma some malt and fruit. Taste is rasping fruity bitterness, bit harsh I think, some pithy fruitiness, not totally my thing bit unbalanced, but that said not bad either. A6 A3 T6 P3 Ov12 3.0
[Cask from The Three Judges] Gold/yellow with a thin layer of head. Nose if peachy and citric. Light fruity palate, sweet upfront, touch of bitterness.
NIce taste, very foamy and takes a while to settle. Golden but bitter in aftertaste.

Holy crap. Plain dull caramel water Clear nutty in the glass with a fine tan head. Ok lacing Decent sweetness and almost no bitterness Caramel waterish flavor [Cask at Number Twenty2 in Darlington, England] Brewery #2107

Cask at Olde Ship Inn, Seahouses. Amber colour, white foam head leaving lacing and aroma of roasty malt, fruity. Taste is malty, roasted, caramel with tangy nutty bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry nutty bitter finish. Quite drinkable.

Cask gravity at the Red Lion, Isleworth. A classic Northern bitter, copper coloured, with a lasting head and fruity malt aromas, leading to a balanced malty body, with caramel and nutty notes and a faintly earthy light bitterness.
Cask (Museum Vaults, Sunderland) - Amber in colour. Earthy hops and sultanas in the aroma. Nicely balanced taste with sultanas, nuts and earthy hops.

Cask conditioned handpump Mr Foleys Leeds 06/02/13. An amber coloured beer with a white head and lace. Very ashy and grainy. So malty. This reminded me of Caledonian Flying Scotsman which isn’t a compliment. Like chewing lightly burnt barley. Late fruit but not pretty.
On cask at grey horse, consett. Pours caramel brown, quite biscuity, some caramel. Average chugger. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask @ 3 Judges. Golden colour, creamy medium off-white head. Aroma of biscuit, caramel malts. Flavour of caramel malts, some sweet fruits, toffee, medium bodied. Slightly bitter and fruity finish. Very sessionable.
Cask Handpump at the Memorial Hall, Northwich Beer Festival 21/09/2007 Some fruit aroma. Bronze golden coloured fruity and slightly sour with a slight malt finish.
Aroma started particularly hoppy however faided away a bit. Taste was similar caramel in the mouth with floural grassy notes.
[Cask at The Three Judges] Light amber, thin layer of head. Floral, caramel, deep red fruit. Medium body, sweet fruity palate, dry.
Bottle. Clear bright yellow color medium white head. Light straw aroma. Taste is light cereal light straw with a bit of pepper. ok
diacetyl, perhaps it shouldbe there, but i am not sure, hardly foam, hard co2, good bitterness.
Bottle - Clear golden color with small head. Dry and hoppy pils with some metallic notes and a rather poor malty body. Nice bitter finish though. Lingering between average and good.

Flasche aus einem Edeka-Markt in Ehrenfriedersdorf. - Goldgelb, blank. - In der Nase leicht zitroniger, heuiger Aromahopfen und etwas stumpfe Süße. - Im Antrunk heuiger bis grasiger Hopfen, gefolgt von einer für ein Pils etwas zu dicken Malzsüße. Eher mild rezent, vollmundig. Im Abgang leicht krautiger, grasiger, insgesamt aber wenig aromatischer Hopfen. Mäßig bitterer, etwas dumpfer Nachtrunk mit Fehlnoten von Schweineschmalz. - Eher lieblos gehopft, arm an feineren Hopfenaromen und ohne Eleganz. Und einen "visionären Nachtrunk" (M. Rudolf) habe ich hier schon gar nicht gefunden ...
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein klares goldenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig, getreidig, grasig. Geschmack hopfig, grasig, lang anhaltende Bitterkeit.
Clear yellow with normal white foam head. Aroma is little bitter barley, some herbal. Aroma is a normal German pilsener, nothing special. Short bitter aftertaste. (Dresden 201312)

Bottle, danke David. Pale golden, big bubbles, big white lace. Grassy and herbal (onions,chives) hop notes. Light to medium sweet malt body, broad hop characteristics, citric and herbal notes primarily - interesting. Sparkly, light on the palate. Mowed grass aftertaste.
0.5 l bottle, thanks Timo A! Sweet honeyish aroma with herbal-peppery hop in the background. Sweet honeyish and herbal-peppery flavor with medium bitterness and hint of metal in finish. OK pils.
Spicy hops nose with a light sweetness in the background. Yellow colored with a medium sized white head. Light hoppy flavor with a dryish end.

Bottle. Light golden, small to average and fully diminishing head. Moderate malty - lightly grainy and lightly sweetish aroma, light grassy - faint herbal hoppyness. Medium, malty - lightly grainy and lightly sweetish flavor, light grassy hoppyness. Finish is short to average, malty - lightly grainy and dryish, light grassy - faint herbal hoppyness. Dryish pils with light hoppyness. OK, but nothing special.
The alcohol in this beer is pretty much the only thing you can taste. the body has some chewiness to it that may help a bit, bit it’s also not super cleanly brewed. D&S dresden

50cl bottle. A clear dark golden beer with a mid-sized most good lasting off-white head. Aroma of medium sweet strong malt, cereals, caramel. Taste of strong malt, pale malt, hints of grains, caramelish malty finish, not bad!

Flasche (MHD: 1/2015) von einem Edeka in Ehrenfriedersdorf. - Rotgold, klar, kurzlebiger Schaum. - In der Nase pappig-süßes Karamelmalz, dahinter schwacher, dumpfer, leicht käsiger Hopfen. - Im Antrunk unsauber limonadige Karamelsüße mit unappetlichen Fehlaromen, die wohl Röstmalz und Frucht darstellen sollen, aber eher an gekochten Kohl und Kindershampoo erinnern. Eher mild rezent. Im Abgang ein wenig käsiger Hopfen, immer noch überlagert von stumpfer Karamelsüße. Schwacher, matt bitterer Nachtrunk. - Scheußliche, fad süße Brühe. Habe nur mit Mühe ein paar Schlucke heruntergekriegt - man will so eine Verkostung ja standhaft durchziehen. Den Rest kriegt der Ausguß. Genug ist genug.

#797 Der Schwarze Specht ist dunkelbraun mit zu wenig standhaftem Schaum. Das Aroma ist leicht rezent. Der Geschmack ist dann ziemlich malzlastig, zuwenig Würze für meinen Geschmack, eher nach Süßholz abklingend. Der Alkohol meldet sich leicht sprittig im Abgang wieder. Insgesamt deutlich zu süß und der Alk.-Gehalt drückt auf die Süffigkeit. Test vom 9.9.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,9,8,8,8,9 - 8,55

Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. MOderate malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Some licorice notes. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate. NIce heller bock.
A amber colored beer with a white head. Aroma malts sweetness and fruits. Flavor malts sweetness fruits some spicy and hops.

bottle, although mine came in a bottle with a red label. same abv and no mai or weihnachts or anything before the bock on the label. anyways, a generic but decent bock - copperish with no real head; aroma of pear schapps; some tinned fruit and red berry. purchased at pivoteka in pilsen

Frischer, aber schwerer Geruch, der ins metallerne übergeht. Sehr süßer Antrunk mit Malaromen, die Dank der Süße einfach nur störend wirken. Im Mittelteil verstärkt sich das Ganze einfach, der hinzukommende hopfige Teil wird ebenfalls von der Süße erschlagen. Der Nachgeschmack bietet kaum etwas anderes, erst wenn die Süße abflacht erkennt man, dass das Bier durchaus Potenzial hat, die würzigen Teile in Verbindung mit der nun nicht mehr störenden Hopfigkeit haben ihren Reiz. Das wars dann aber auch schon. Die Süße ist in diesem Bier überproportioniert, auch wenn sie eher durch ihre Klebrigkeit als durch ihre Stärke stört. Test vom 20.3.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 11,8,7,8,8,8 - 8,15

0.5 l bottle. Copper color. Sweet, toffeish and honeyish some warming alcohol and beetroot. Sweet toffeish and honeish, with some tropical fruits and some musty notes of root vegetables. Full body. Not my kind of bock.

500 ml, BB date reads 21. April 2011, into tulip. Pours light amber body with good clarity topped by medium, frothy white head with good retention and stickage to the walls. The nose is moderate maltiness with light toasty notes, evident spiciness from the noble hops used and noticeable alcohol. Moderate pale malt flavor with light toasty qualities, peppery spiciness originating from from noble hops and/or alcohol, some hoppy bitterness lending dry finish. Very clean. Light to medium bodied and moderately carbonated. In short: a clean Heller Bock with evident noble-hop spiciness.
Nice dark lager. It is clean and crisp. Pretty straightforward for the style, buy for an introduction to dunkles beer perhaps. Planwirtschaft dresden
Bottle. Dark clear brown color light tan head. Aroma of lightly toasted caramel. Taste has burnt caramel and dark fruit. Decent
Bottle. Light aroma of caramel. Taste is medium sweet with hint of bitterness. Flavor of tasted bread, caramel, red dried fruits.
Aus der Flasche in der Planwirtschaft getrunken. Dunkelrotbraun mit feinem weißem Schaum. Im Antrunk malzig. I. Nachtrunk kann man dezenteste Hopfennoten erspüren.

500 ml bottle @ Tammela Vintage Tasting. Pours a dark brown colour with a small white head. Aroma of nuts, sweet malts and some raisins. Flavour of sweet bready maltiness, mild bitterness, raisins and a bit of earthiness. Medium bodied. Smooth mouthfeel. Rather heavy. Nice.

50 cl bottle @ Tammela Vintage Tasting. Pours clear dark mahogany color with a small head. Strong malty aroma, burnt notes, caramel sweetness and some mild nutty tones. Flavor is nutty and malty dry, subtle fruity notes, mild caramel, sweet and quite bready. Decent malty beverage. 4324
50 cl bottle @ Tammela vintage tasting, BBE 07.01.2017 Aroma has nuts and roasted malt. Also some toffee and cola. Flavour has chocolate, roasted malt and nuts. A solid, chocolatey dunkler bock.
Bottle shared by Niklas. Dark brown with cream off white head. Caramel aroma and taste with some roast, dark fruits and brown sugar. Quite nice with a roasted turkey, but bland to drink by itself.
Fairly sweet. Lots of mocha, caramel, molasses and dark cherries in the mouth, but a bit too sweet for my liking, but really great depth.

Flasche aus einem Edeka-Markt in Ehrenfriedersdorf. - Mit 6,1 % Ethanol ist dies kein gewöhnliches Schwarzbier mehr, sondern ein Starkbier. - Rotgoldenes Kastanienbraun, klar; kurzlebiger Schaum. - In der Nase ein wenig matt-süßliche Fruchtigkeit und schwache, süßlich-käsige Noten von Hopfenextrakt. - Im Antrunk mildes Röstmalz mit plumper Karamelsüße und marmeladenartig-süßen Fruchtnoten. Durchschnittlich rezent, für ein Starkbier eher wäßrig. Im Abgang kommt ein wenig schweißfüßiger Hopfenextrakt ohne nennenswerte Bittere zum Vorschein, aber die fade Süße bleibt dominierend und hält sich bis in den unangenehm pappigen Nachtrunk. - Allzu simple, gefällig süße Brühe, der alles fehlt, was ein Schwarzbier auszeichnet, nämlich anständige Röstaromen und eine spürbare Portion Aromahopfen. Für ein Bockbier wiederum zu wäßrig und lasch im Geschmack. Könnte glatt als Malztrunk durchgehen, wäre da nicht der unsinnig hohe Alkoholgehalt. Enttäuschend. Kalt getrunken gerade noch genießbar.
Gold, clear, white head. Grainy-sweet pilsner malt, noble hop aroma and flavor, touch of sulpher, but not much. Well made pilsner.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear yellow color with a thin white head. Banana esters dominate the flavor, some yeast and grain. A sweet honey dipped grain flavor. Not much on the side of hops, but decent. Earthy and sweet.
on tap-pours a thin white head and yellow color. Aroma is sweet grain. Taste is sweet grain, secondary hops. OK carbonation.

[Colorado Road Trip – 2006] A nice hoppy flavor a good dry beer with some flavor with the hot wings. This was one of there better brews. This is not a seasonal but they call it one. Liked the hops and the use of grains. Good Brew.
On tap at the brewpub Cloudy straw color with a small white head, some lacing. Aroma is fruity. Flavors of apricot, plastic and wheat Ok
on tap-pours a thin white head and hazy/cloudy straw color. Aroma is wheat. Taste is apricot, wheat, musty, a bit syrupy. OK effervescence. A nice variation on their wheat.

[Colorado Road Trip – 2006] A nice fruity brew. Needs more Apricot flavor to really bring out the fruits. Very hard to taste the fruit under the wheat flavor this was a good attempt at a fruit beer but not the best. Apricot can be a tough brew. Liked the finish it was dry and crisp. Good luck on your next fruit beer.

Bottled (backlog, thanks Kim N & co). Golden colour with a mediumsized white head that leaves some lace. Aroma is bready malts, some grains, mild honeylike sweetness as well as some herbal notes. Flavour is sweet malts, some bready malts as well as some herbal, hayish and grassy notes. A bit watery. Gets a bit rubbery as it warms up a bit.
"Chutné, lidové a kvalitní èeské pivo". Jinými slovy hnus. I když toèené mi kdysi v Brnì celkem chutnalo. Lahváè.
dough, floral, roasty, butterscotch, pale, clear, frothy, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, thin feel, light body, fizzy, bitter,
bottled. dusty aroma, pale and fizzy, messy bitterness; just cheap supermarket swill
Bottle. Golden beer, small head. Malty nose. Peaches, sweet apples. Flowery and dusty hops. Quite decent.

Bottle 50cl.
Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, grain. Flavor is moderate sweet and light light bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. (050908)
Bottle at chris_o’s pre beer exposed tasting. Alround rating: Pale grainy malts, grassy herbal hop, on the sweet side, but still drinkable enough.

50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a fully diminished white head. Aroma is cardboardish and dry aroma. Mild sweet and mild malty base flavour with a distinct bitterness showing through. Medium dry finish.
Botella. Clear deep golden colour. Good medium white head. Grainy bit malty aroma. Grainy bit malty and lightly hoppy flavour.
Clear golden with large white head. Sweet aroma malty notes and caramel notes. Sweet flavour with malty, cardboard and caramel notes.
Direct from Brewery. Dark gold in colour with a minimal white head; earthy aroma; earthy malt flavour; and a dry lightly bitter finish. A pleasant bitter.

Cask (gravity dispense) at Reading Beer Festival, May 2008. Hazy amber. Surprisingly citric aroma - orange marmalade. Quite bitter Seville orange flavour. Mouthfeel has a firm bitterness, a little astringent on the finish. Not bad at all. Didn’t find much malty or fruity character myself, so perhaps a little more balance would not have gone amiss for some drinkers .

Cask gravity @ Reading Beer Festival 2008. Clear medium amber orange color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, damp-stained, light hoppy, grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (020508)

A Mes rate: Gravicask @ Reading Beer Festival. Solid brown colour with a decent head. Alcoholic marzipan nose with toffee and slight fruit and hops. Fruity notes come on strong in the flavour with some nice late hops too. Slightly watery in the mouth. Unusual dry yet sweet finish.
Gravity Cask @ Royal Oak Beer Festival 2006, Fritham (New Forest). Darkish colour. Dark fruity malts and mild hops. Dry yet toffeish finish.
Gravity Cask @ Royal Oak Beer Festival 2006, Fritham (New Forest). No discernible honey. Swetish rounded malts and little hop. Appley flavours. Not too bad if lacking in character.

column1: Lyme Bay Jack Ratt Vintage Cider - Dry (Bottle)
column5: Bottle at ash’s. Pours golden amber, nose is earthy, dung, apple, taste is very dry, crisp apple.

column1: Lyme Bay Jack Ratt Vintage Cider - Dry (Bottle)
column5: Bottle from Beers Of Europe. Appearance - amber with no carbonation which is good. Nose - farmyard notes. Sour apples slightly going off. Taste - proper tart apple, sweet apples at the front, then sour, sour, sour. Apple skin. Palate - close to medium bodied with a long lean middle and end. Overall - lovely properly made cider.

column1: Lyme Bay Jack Ratt Vintage Cider - Dry (Bottle)
column5: Bottle shared with Ashton McCobb and Stuu666. Pours still golden orange. Aromas of barnyard, earthy apple and spice. Dry apple skin. Taste is tart apples, more skin and a chalky paracetamol vibe. Proper cider!

column1: Lyme Bay Jack Ratt Vintage Cider - Dry (Bottle)
column5: 2.5l bottle from Stowford farm shop, drunk on campsite. Amber cider, still. Aroma of earth and musty apples. Taste is musty apples, some dryness, Apple pulp and a little wood. Decent.

column1: Lyme Bay Jack Ratt Vintage Cider - Dry (Bottle)
column5: 1L bottle. 2012 vintage. Clear golden colour, no head and aroma of apple, fruity, wood, vanilla, light barnyard. Taste is dry bittersweet apple, apple skin, wood, rubber, earthy, tannins. Oily mouthfeel, medium bodied, low carbonation, dry tannic finish. OK.

column1: Lyme Bay Jack Ratt Vintage Cider - Dry (Bottle)
column5: Appearance: Clear golden amber with bubbles on pour. Aroma: Apple, woody, buttery, white wine notes. Taste: Medium acidity, medium/high tannins and low sweetness. Palate: Thick smooth texture, medium/heavy body, low carbonation, lingering dry, chalky tart apple finish. Comments: Very good and refreshing. Rating is for 2013 vintage bottled version.

column1: Lyme Bay Jack Ratt Vintage Cider - Dry (Bottle)
column5: mnah... mnah... tuh tuh tuh.... hhhhcccchhhhhhhhh..... tchuh tchuh that’s the taste... and it lingers a little

column1: Lyme Bay Jack Ratt Vintage Cider - Dry (Bottle)
column5: bottle from Waitrose Sidmouth.Golden colour, still. Apples + cardamom, mild apple flavours, yet full-bodied.
Cask Stillage from the Cellar at the Crown Inn, Oakengates 02/05/2005 Golden coloured and hazy in appearance with an acidic taste. A hint of dryness in a malt finish.

Gravity Cask @ Royal Oak Beer Festival 2006, Fritham (New Forest). Some peppery hop character. A little rough yeast in the mouth but soon erased by the tasty bitter finish. Fairly good, I think most of Stumpys problems are bottle related.

From all the different variants of this mead brand I tried, this is perhaps the one I preferred. Not many differences with the others despite the almond evidence on the bottle. You can discern it in the aftertaste but it?s really not that much present. Overall taste is maybe a bit deeper than the others but not by a lot. I had a very positive feeling with all of these, mead lovers should give these a try. Not incredible but very pleasant, beware of the alcohol level though, considering it?s a quite easy to drink mixture ! APPROVED BY TAVERNY?S BLACK METAL CREW!
Bottle. Golden/copper color, no head. Malty sweetish almond aroma, fruity, figs, honey, spicy notes, nuts and marzipan. Sweet honey flavor, raisins, figs, almonds, some marzipan. Very sweet.

Bottled. Deep honeyish golden colour, no head. Aroma of almond, honey, sugar and stinging alcohol. Flavour is almonds, honey, dry wood, alcohol and some slight spices. Aftertaste is almonds and honey.
Bottle at the Kookfest back in Sept 06. Nutty sweet mead. Almond nougat flavour. Thick in mouth, slightly harsh and uncultured. Not subtle. Rough.
Bottle. Smells like candy. Some marzipan and Nerds in the aroma. very sweet mouthfeel, a little sickly and sweet. Too much candy sweetness for my liking.

Bottle at Kookfest, September 2006. Thanks to Mungo for the bottle. Shame he didn’t take away the remaining 90% of the bottle when he left. This is marzipan city. Rather like the almond essence I remember my mother using for baking years ago. And married most inharmoniously with the underlying gloopy sweet honey. No redeeming acidity to relieve the unremitting, sickly, syrupy character. Even more unfortunately, the flavour and aftertaste lingers interminably on the palate and in the memory. Very nasty indeed. At least a dash mixed with the pint or so of mixed Fullers Vintage left over from the comparative tasting and used as a marinade for pot roast beef provided an interesting culinary use.
Kookfest 06. Overly sweet with nutty honey flavours and excess alcohol. Not great.

Bottle picked up from one of the supermarkets, consumed at home Attenkirchen Sunday 23rd June 2019 in the company of Isobel who has been with us for a few days. Pours a little hazy, colour is yellow with a white head. Simple easy drinking beer, soft carbonation, a touch of creamy vanilla, soft a gentle bitterness. Fine.
0,5 l Flasche. Gelbes, milchiges Bier mit geweihten Schwebstoffen, stabiler, cremiger Schaum mit schöner Gardine. Riecht und schmeckt wie ein Witbier, Pfefferminz auf der Zunge.
Bottle.Clear golden colour with small white head.Aroma of citrus and malt,mild corn and hops,slight toasted nots aswll light and mild finish.

Bottle. Hazy golden color with white head. Aroma is honey, pale malts, bready yeasts. Taste is more honey, bready, a touch lemon, some straw. Silky mouthfeel with natural carbonation. Decent, but not amazing, also a bit too sweet. 6-3-6-3-10 Bottle again, much better this time. Overall score was definitely undervalued last time - this is really süffig, though still a bit too sweet. Definitely a solid Kellerbier, it has enough lemony hops in there to give a balance to the sweet maltiness.

August 2017 - Keg at GBBF 2017, Kensington Olympia. As 'Hohenthanner Schlossbrauerei Kellerbier Hell'. Very pale yellow gold, clear and still with a foamy off-white head leaving full lacing. Aroma is leaves, touch of mint, cotton. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is smooth light malt, sugary, biscuity. Clean and drinkable. Quite good actually. (6-4-6-4-14=3.4)

0,5L MHD10/2017, Stadelbauer €1ish. - Caramalt gives this clean, but sweet&soggy Keller a soaked cornflake bowl quality. Clean honeypops soaked in skimmed milk golden cream. Hence it’s not the most sparkling nor rustic specimen, its pathos to be located so many supraregional Kellers in the cleanliness of execution, a social-democratic subjugation of ere-catholic provincial character to the benefit of the greater good of Süffigkeit.

Cask at the GBBF 2017. Day 3. 10/08/2017. A light hazed bright yellow straw coloured pour with a fine white head. Aroma is semi sweet, cereal malts, honey, Nobel hop. Flavour is composed of semi sweet honey, crisp pils, little straw, apple,.. Palate is crisp, moderate carbonation, soft. Good stuff.

Bottle at GBBF 2017. Hazy pale gold colour lasting white head. Bready cereal aroma. Good lemon on flavour. Lemon curd. Good in mouth. Lovely in mouth. Lovely lemon hoppy finish. Good kellerbier. Tasty.
Kitzeliger Feinhefer mit Spice und Muff im Gepäck. Leicht säuerlich, mit schlaffen BrauseStyleAbgang. 0,33l Flasche. Adventskalender Stuff. Hat hoffentlich bald ein Ende ;).
Süß-herber Start. Wenig hefig-getreidig, die Süße bleibt im Vordergrund. Weich getreidiger, eher milder Mittelteil, etwas zuckrig. Nie wieder auch nur etwas herb werdend, monoton. 8/7/8/8/9/8

column1: Flying Dog Wild Dog Colorado Saison
column5: This is a backlog rating from 2010 from a bottle, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are pale malts, bready, yeast, mild spices, some funk.

column1: Flying Dog Wild Dog Colorado Saison
column5: Pours a hazy dark yellow with a thin white head. Sweet floral aroma with hints of plum. Smooth grassy and wheaty. Not too sweet.bit of lemon ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Flying Dog Wild Dog Colorado Saison
column5: Bottle on 01/15/2011 at the 13th Richmond Gatherong. Hazy orange body with a small white head. Big floral and spicy hop aroma. Earthy malt with citrus and floral notes. Medium full body with moderate carbonation.

column1: Flying Dog Wild Dog Colorado Saison
column5: Honey color, white fizzy head gone in seconds. Earthy nose, light mushroom, honey, and a bit of citrus and paint thinner. Flavor shows more honey, earth/cork. Bit thin overly fizzy, and some heat in the finish. Have to admit this is one of the worst examples of a saison that I’ve tasted.

column1: Flying Dog Wild Dog Colorado Saison
column5: Medium gold and decent head at the Richmond Gathering. Aroma of honeysuckle and grassy hops. Flavor is honey accented malts, floral and hay notes. Nice.

column1: Flying Dog Wild Dog Colorado Saison
column5: (Sample Date: 1/15/2011 Source:Maniac) Very earthy with some yeast character underneath. Clear golden with small white head. Flavor is moderately sweet and earthy. Some yeast character but not really that spicy. Medium body and mouth. Finish is medium sweet with earthy spicy residual.

column1: Flying Dog Wild Dog Colorado Saison
column5: C&C 750 mL bottle courtesy of maniac. Thanks! Pours a clear amber with a medium white head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel, bread, honey, apples, lightly tart finish. The taste is tart apples, bready notes, tart finish. Medium-full bodied. Decent.

column1: Flying Dog Wild Dog Colorado Saison
column5: A: snifter. cloudy pale orange with a solid white head. good retention and moderate lacing. S: a lot of orange peel aromas, solid sour tone followed by the sweetness of the malts. good spice characteristics. T: solid sour orange in this. not much of the honey, but it is present. great spice character s well. the sourness is good but not overwhelming. M:very bubbly mouthfeel. very clean and crisp. carbonation is a little high and the body is a little thick for a saison. D: very good beer, but a little sweet for the style. there is also too much orange in this. worthy of a try, but I don’t see myself searching for it.

column1: Flying Dog Wild Dog Colorado Saison
column5: Found this gem at Stateline liquors in Elkton, MD...in late July. Poured into my Chimay chalice. My first review of a retired beer. A- Nearly opaque golden yellow body with a giant frothy white head that takes forever to settle down (which is what is prohibiting it from a 5.0...I couldn’t pour it without it overflowing). It finally settles to a 1 finger thick eggshell white head. Cloudiness is thick and dynamic. When held up to the light bubbles can be seen rising to the top. A truly beautiful beer. S-The smell good but not as potent as the rest of the brew. Mild floral hops tingle the nostril first followed by a fruity scent of pear and apples. T-Upfront is a semi-tart/semi-sweet fruity flavor of pear and apples. This is accented by minimal floral hop flavor and a big bready yeast backbone. The finish has a sudden presence of floral hop bitterness along with a touch of alcohol. What lingers is a hint of floral hops and the bready yeast. P-Medium carbonation and a mouthfeel full of yeast. Its much thicker than others I have tried of this style (which may come with age). Big silky and smooth. O- I really liked this and I wish I would have picked up more than one bottle. I know the other reviews for this are much lower than mine...but maybe all this beer needed was some aging...I’m sure it was much boozier in the beginning. This is a wonderful brew overall and the best I have tried from this brewing co. edit: when sorted high to low...all of the highest ratings are from 2008...just more suggestion that this one needed some aging. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 09-12-2008 00:24:05

column1: Flying Dog Wild Dog Colorado Saison
column5: (bottle - corked & caged 750 ml) Hazy orange pour with very little head or carbonation. Mild spicy and funky aroma with some mild sweetness and spice. Flavor is very dry and earthy. Funky spice flavors move in with a very, very dry and almost damp tasting finish. I think I may have let it sit too long.

column1: La Motte Juillet lArverne Cervoise Noire
column5: Intens dark brown beer with a quick disappearing big bubbled head. The smell is like the crust of caramelized apples with hints of sour Greek Yoghurt on top. Soft touches of cinnamon, raisins, wet furniture and bee wax. The body is a bit thin and the beer tastes a little sharper than the nose . Ther are earthy aspects and touches of sour forrest berries (unripe ones), wood, nut peel and black tea. In the afthertaste fresh almonds, caramelized unripe sour apples, buttermilk (watery version) some forrest soil accents and waxed furniture. Agree with honeyed hints in the nose but the beer is to thin and watery to detect any honeyed sweetness in the taste. Is more interesting when it warms up. At a kitchintable in Ursel (East-Flanders) Thanks Joris.

column1: La Motte Juillet lArverne Cervoise Noire
column5: Off-white head, small and disparate over near-black beer with a slight red shine. Good little lactic component, as well as dark grains, but not burnt, in the nose. Maybe a bit Maillard? Slight lactic acidity over more classical light stout features (dark grains, this time some roasted barley). Like a cross between a Flemish brown and a stout. There’s some almondy, frangipane streak there too, however not sweet. Carlo talks about caramelised apple juice. Warming up, I get oxydized, warm speculoos. Quite light body, like most beer from this brewery, which does not mean empty. Nice, and a bit surprising. Less sweet than expected, but also less hoppy.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig würzig, Geschmack angenehm malzig würzig mit ganz minimaler Bitterkeit.
Pours a clear golden body with a thin head. Sweet caramel malt flavor, nuts, biscuits. Sweet, lingering aftertaste.
Schaumkrone mittelmäßig, farblich eher dunkel. Geschmacklich ist es malzig, süßlich, relativ mild. Fazit: Nicht so gut! Test vom 24.8.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,7,6,6,8,6 - 6,45

Flip-top half litre brown bottle, best before 24th April 2008, drank on a wet and windy 31st Jan 2008. Poured into a straight sided Berliner Kindl half litre glass. Amber in colour,clear and very carbonated, bubbles rising swiftly up to the large white foaming head, it looks good to me. Hoppy and yeasty, a lot more aroma than your normal lager/pilsners, they obviously made the stuff with better ingrediants in 1689 than the German producers of today. The flavours are stronger too, no weak girlie tasteless blond feel, this has some umph, its colour aroma and the 5.2% ensure it is a different beast to the breweries standard pilsner (which I also like). This is bitter and unlike any mass produced German pilsner, in short, it has taste. Thicker and more wholesome, this is a truely fine beer and one I will seek it out when in the area of the Mosel and Koblenz.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and it’s not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog! Ins Glas ergießt sich ein dunkles, leicht rötliches Bier mit einer guten mittelporigen Krone. Es riecht angenehm malzig und recht mild, minimal röstig. Eben wie ein gutes Dunkles. Der Antrunk ist ebenso. Kräftig würzig, leicht röstig und ein kaffeeartiger Nachgeschmack rundet das Ganze perfekt ab!
Bottle 50cl. Sweet Malts and a decent hoppiness are emblematic for this brew. Too Sweet for my taste but interesting though!

500 ml bottle @ Timo A. Thanks! Pours a copper colour with a small, quite thick head. Aroma of sweet raisins, caramel some nuts. Flavour of sweet malts, honey, nuts, raisins and some metallic notes. Medium bodied, quite high carbonation and a slick mouthfeel. Finishes malty and somewhat nutty. A bit too thin and has some weird tones.

50 cl bottle. Thanks Timo A. Pours clear golden colour, small head. Aroma is grass, nuts, some biscuits, malts and notes of wheat. Flavour is malts, caramel, nuts, biscuits and some wheat. Quite bitter palate, some metal and a bit of sourness at the end. Something disturbing on the aftertaste. 4323

Königsbacher steht bei mir bisher nicht unbedingt für gutes Bier, hier macht aber bereits die Flasche deutlich, dass es sich hier um ein Produkt handelt, dass dich deutlich von den anderen der Brauerei unterscheidet, es wirkt edler, nicht nur durch die Bügelflasche, auch durch das Etikett. Mild malzig-getreidiger Geruch. Mild malziger Antrunk, der von einem herben Ton deutlich unterlegt wird. Im Mittelteil kann sich kein Arome in der Vordergrund stellen, es wirkt etwas verwaschen, aber nicht unharmonisch. Im Nachgeschmack kristallisieren sich erneut ein malzig-herber Ton heraus. Test vom 9.8.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,9,9,8,11,9 - 8,95

Swing-top bottle. Sweet toffee malt and light grass hops aroma. Hazy amber color with moderate head. Sweet toffee malt and lightly bitter hay hops flavor. Medium body - finishes a bit light. Not bad, not great.

Date: 09/28/2006 Mode: Firkin Source: Brewpub opaque dark red, frothy beige head, sweet carmel aroma with a hint of banana and very little sign off the 2oz of amerillo dry hop, creamy body, nice sweet carmel malt flavor, light bitterness for balance, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+/4
Had this beer as a cask sample on my first visit to the Grill. hazy red amber. smooth sweet flavorwith a pleasent hop finish. Not alot of alcohol present, was just too enjoyable!

My first cask ale sampling ever occurred at Embers Grill in Alpharetta. The beer was served in a 20 oz. Imperial Pint glass, and looked reddish brown in color with a translucent body. As anticipated the head was small and didn’t last very long. When sniffed, this malty brew displayed an aroma with notes of chocolate, toffee, floral hops, and some orange peel. The taste was sweet with some sour citric complexity. The temperature out off the cask was nicely warm, which allowed the flavors of chocolate, toffee, raisins, and red apples to come across full and rich. Towards the middle of each sip, the hops balanced out the malt, and at the end of the sip dried up the mouth. Lusciously soft and soothing on the tongue, this beer felt quite full bodied and creamy, a lot of which was undoubted resulting from the traditional dispensing method used. The alcohol never felt as high as it was until I finished two pints. This beer felt quite similar to a Belgian Dubbel to me, and was quite easy to gulp down making my first trip to Embers a memorable one. Hope they feature more varied styles on cask soon.
Golden appearance with a small head.Pleasant clear appearance. Slightly dry with a herb like flavour in the background. Different, pleasant but nothing outstanding about it.

[50cl bottle from Morrison’s, Bracknell.] A pale amber pour with a thick cream head; malty caramel aroma; jammy in the mouth, but not too sweet; then a biscuity finish with a light herbal bitterness. Not bad.

Bottles from Co-Op, Washington and Fabeers, York. Hazy straw coloured with a thick white head. It has a floral fruity, toffee and peppery hop flavour with a smooth, spicy and earthy finish. Not bad. Bottle Conditioned.

Butelka 500ml. Jasno-zloty kolor. Piana œrednia, bia³a o drobnych pêcherzach, opada doœæ szybko. Aromat s³odowy z nut¹ ziarnista i lekkimi cytrusami w tle. W smaku s³ód,trawa,ciastka,biszkopty,lekkie cytrusy. Bardzo lagerowe z posmakiem kukurydzianym. .jestem na nie...

column1: Pennichuck The Big O Oktoberfest Lager
column5: (Bottle) Pours deep dark amber with reddish mahogany hints. The aroma is nice German-ish malty with tones of sweet caramel and bread. Grassy and herbal hops. Bit cinnamon spicy on the nose. The flavour is medium to heavily sweet and light bitter. Robust/full malty and light hoppy with notes of sweet caramel, bread, spices, herbs and grass. The mouthfeel is round and clean. Lingering malt aftertaste. Medium to full bodied.

column1: Pennichuck The Big O Oktoberfest Lager
column5: 22oz bottle. Pured a deeper amberish color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, toasted nuts, bread, and earthy. Tastes of the same.

column1: Pennichuck The Big O Oktoberfest Lager
column5: Three cheers to Pennichuck! This is likely the last beer I’ll ever have from them, which is sad as I had really grown to like them and rumors of distribution to my state almost immediately preceded their demise. Thanks to jblauvs for the 22 ounce bottle. Pours a clear dark copper color with a thin head. Fair head retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel and toffee with lightly toasted malts and a very faintly hoppy finish. The taste is toasted malts, berries and toffee with a mildly hoppy finish. Medium bodied. Pretty decent.

column1: Pennichuck The Big O Oktoberfest Lager
column5: 22oz bottle. Pours a beautiful deep reddish copper color. Tall off-white frothy head. Perfect lace. Aroma has a touch of wooded earthiness. Nice hop floral. Aroma is mostly malt, nice Vienna and a touch of caramel. Toasted malt sweetness. Flavor is very mild. A bit of the sweeter side. Lots of toasted cereal flavor. I have yet to be disappointed by this brewery. Lingering flavor of a malt nuttiness. Lots of Munich malt character, not too musty, earthy, bready, sweet. Finishes with the slightest bit of wood flavor. Sticky texture, medium bodied. Full flavored. My 50th Oktoberfest/Märzen! Not sure how the name reflects firefighting but still a really good beer.

column1: Pennichuck The Big O Oktoberfest Lager
column5: Name: The Big O Date: October 01, 2009 Mode: Bottle Source: Ale Atlanta Appearance: clear dark amber, wispy beige head, drippy lace Aroma: sweet caramel aroma, lots of breadyness, nice earthyness Flavor: sweet bready flavor, lots of Munich character, light earthyness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+ /4 I would like to rerate this beer.

column1: Pennichuck The Big O Oktoberfest Lager
column5: Pours a dark golden ruby/coppery amber color with a .5 finger off white head that quickly dissipates into a lasting ring. Roasted malt aroma with a lot of autumnal spice. Toasty caramel, biscuit malt that has a slight nut character. Hints of cinnamon and brown sugar. Crisp medium body with lots of toasty malt, autumnal spice, sweet fruit and subtle hops. Lots of sweet caramel malt with a good amount of roasted toasty flavor along with spicy cinnamon and brown sugar. Slight biscuit presence and nice crisp dry hops in the finish. Very nice balance of sweet and roasted notes and the ABV is completely undetectable. The spiciness is pretty prominent with some subtle vanilla and clove to go along with the cinnamon/brown sugar notes. Nice interpretation of the style.

column1: Pennichuck The Big O Oktoberfest Lager
column5: Bottle/22 - Pours a pretty dark ruby amber in color with a small off-white head that faded to a thin rim around the beer, Aroma is of bready yeasts and lots of caramel maltiness. Flavor has a big malty hit with bready yeasts and some hop spiciness. Slightly bitter from the middle to the end. Nice palate. A good one... I hear that Pennichuck may be closing... too bad... will miss their beer!

column1: Pennichuck The Big O Oktoberfest Lager
column5: Feels like fall so I had to grab this one today. Poured this one into a large Nonic it produced a two finger white head that lasts and follows the brew down the glass. The body of the beer is a clear ruby red in color There are Great aromas of sweet caramel malts along with a great breadiness. As it warms you get a slight fruitiness as well in the aroma. The flavors of sweat grains and bread filed my mouth there is also a little bit of alcohol burn as it warms. The brew had a great feel in my mouth with ample carbonation. An easy to drink brew one of the better of the style I have had. I will defiantly grab more of this brew

column1: Pennichuck The Big O Oktoberfest Lager
column5: Dark brown/copper pour with a pretty big eggshell white head. Aroma is malty some some vegetable notes. Medium-bodied with a nice, crisp flavor. Toasty, nutty with some caramel and woodsy flavors on the back end. Pretty rich and flavorful for an ofest. Nice brew!

column1: Pennichuck The Big O Oktoberfest Lager
column5: On tap at the Barley. Deep Orange pour with a slight offwhite head. Aroma is toasty malts and some caramel, Flavor is sweet caramel but also tangy and reminiscent of wet pine cones, A really nice slight roast on the malt. Really excellent octoberfest, makes me think of wet leaves and autumn. Stylistically the best Pennichuck I’ve had. Not just another dull Octoberfest, something stand out.

Bottle. Dark brown with a medium sized diminishing off white head. Roasted malt, brown bread, light wood, caramel. Light to medium body, mild sweet and mild to medium bitter, very light acidity. Malty finish.

Friday 1st Feb 2019; 7th Pre-Brugge Bier Festival International Beer Swap, De Bierboom. This is one of the many bottles that landed on my table for me to try, it is OK to take a decent sized sample (within reason) because there are so many beers to share. Copper/Bronze with an off-white crown. Malty nose and taste with a little caramel sweetness throughout. A bit thin body wise compared to some of the beers that came and went around it on the night (Yes, I know it's really a dark lager and isn't supposed to be rich or slick in nature), but on another day it would have been fine.
Danish dark beer. Caramel toast taste, expected medium sweetness. Not too hoppy classic dark.
En anelse karamelt, men ellers en ret mild og pilsneragtig dunkel. Flot farve.

From tap at the brewpub as Camden Best Bitter, 3.6. Pours cloudy dark amber to hazzlenut brown and with a small, tan and creamy head. Aroma is rosted malty, light hoppy note. Smooth mouthfeel. Quite hoppy and with a roasted mild malty base flavour. Light fruity hops flavoured. Rather dry and bitter flavoured into the finish.

Cask (handpump) @ McLaughlins Horseshoe, 28 Heath St, Hampstead, London, Greater London, England NW3 6TE. Clear medium amber orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, moderate hoppy, pine, orange, anis notes. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20081229]

Cask (gravity dispense), Pigs Ear Beer Festival, London, December 2006. Reddish copper colour. Plenty of tangy, oily, resinous hop bitterness. There is a slight underlying toffeeish note, maybe even a hint of smoky malt but it’s the hops that dominate. A nicely assertive biter that punches well above its weight. SilkTork is right - I do like this.
Cask, handpump at The Horseshoe, Hampstead London. Ruddy brown coloured, raw-edged malty bitter. Tart appley fruit, tarry dryness and a bitter finish.

Pigs Ear. Old fashioned English hop soaked biter. Very pleasant and flavoursome. Good, solid beer, well done. Not quite to my taste, but pulls well above its strength. Tastes like Fullers ESB. I should think that Chris_o will like this.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Pigs Ear BF. A slightly hazy anber coloured beer. The aroma is biscuity and malty with alcohol showing itself. The taste is malty and a little fruity. OK and pleasantly drinkable.

Cask@The Horseshoe, Hampstead, N London. Quite dark for a bitter, and i’m sure the guy behind the bar said it was stronger than 3.6%, i could be wrong. This was a loveley bitter, richer than you’d expect a bitter to be. This was quite earthy, with a toasty malt character and some light roastyness. Wholemeal grain characters, with touches of dark fruit. Some nice citric hops in the finish and some nice bitterness. Quite rich/full bodied for a bitter.

On draught at the brewpub in Hampstead. Copper-coloured with quite a creamy offwhite head. Fruity hop aroma. Citrussy hop flavours on a caramel toffee base. Light to medium body, dry mouthfeel. An agreeable new bitter in one of London’s best neighbourhoods.

Aroma; bread, honey, malts, soft zatec saaz hops, nice hana malts. Look; off white head, near clear golden body. Taste; bread, sweet hana malts, soft hops, toffee, nougat - smooth pilsnerish finish. Feel; good body, soft co2, very nice. Overall; a good policske kvasnicovy jedenactka. [@U Kudeje, Olomouc. 7474’15]
Tap (U Kudeje, Olomouc) Very light bready pale malt aroma. Taste also full of grains. Alas some minterally aspects. Palate light soft carbonation. Finish minerally and quite aggressively bitter.

Tap (U Kudìje, Olomouc) as "Policka Nefiltrovany 11%"). Clear dark golden color. Medium size, thick white head, stays. Metallic, jammy, cumin, herbal and sweet in aroma. Sweet, malty, faint cumin, herbal in taste. Sweet malts in aftertaste. Tastes bit weird.

12/VII/15 - on tap @ The Immigrant (Brno) - BB: n/a (2015-917) Clear blond beer, creamy off-white head, pretty stable, adhesive, leaving some lacing in the glass. Aroma: some banana, sweet, bit yeasty, marzipan touch. MF: soft carbon, medium to full body. Taste: fruity start, hint of overripe banana, some sweet malts. Aftertaste: bit sweet, bitter hops, some citrus, sweet touch, hay, malts, dry finish.
A light color beer, with foam, soft carbonized, good aroma, served from tap in 50cl glass.

(draught) pours a slightly hazy golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of herbal hops, banana and honey-tinged pale malts, quite leafy, with a hint of yeast. flavour is heavy honey and banana, quite yeasty, with a spicy herbal-hoppy finish. medium-bodied with soft carbonation.

Draught at Hrom do Police, Prague. Slightly hazy pale golden beer, with a rich lasting offwhite head. Malty bready aroma, slightly spicy, caramel, grassy hops, hay, citrus, some grapes. Malty caramel flavor, spicy notes, minerals, hay, grapes, some citrus. Bready finish, some hay.

Tap @ Kulovy Blesk, Prague. Pours slightly hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma of malt, grassy hops, flowery, lightly sour. Flavor of malt, flowers, lightly bitter grassy hops. Thin body, soft carbonation. 070812

On tap at Klub Malých Pivovarù, Plzen. Slightly hazy golden colour, white head. Aroma of sulphur, swamp, wet straw, green apples. Flavour is green apples, light malty, dry grainy, watery, a bit tasteless, grassy bitter finish. Light bodied. This beer had a lot of flaws imo.
Clean golden, small white head. Dung, straw, yeasty malty. Light bitter, farmhouse. Okay.
Tap at pivní opice brno. Clear pale colour with stable head off. Aroma of malts,bread. Taste of malts,bread. Easy drinking,moderate bitter finish

As “Polièka Záviš Ležák 12° Unfiltered” F: big, white, long lasting. C: deep gold, clear. A: malty, bit bready, bit vegetables, bit caramel. T: malty, bready, caramel, taste is better than aroma, medium body and carbonation, not bad enjoyed, from tap @ U Hasièa in Bratislava, Slovakia.
Bottle from Pezinská pivná pumpa. Quite nice pilsner even though I drank better from Polièka. It must be much better on tap.

Pet 1000ml z Czarodziejka Gorza³ka. Kolor z³oty, klarowne, piana solidna grubopêcherzykowa doœæ dobrze trzyma siê szk³a. Aromat chmielowy z zio³ami w tle, smak s³odowy, chmielowy, goryczka solidna. Typowy czeski lager, dobre piwo.
Typical Czech Pilsner, herbal hoppy aroma and taste. Very refreshing and drinkable.

Modest off white head and unclear yellow golden body. Mosaic lacing. Scents of cz hops, fruity malts, mild aroma. Tastes smooth malts, vgtbl hops, grass, apple, honey, sweet barley, and finishes light apple-malty, slightly dry. Smooth on palate, dry end. Overall tasty, very normal czech.

0,5l from tap at pivni opice, brno shared by a friend. Light yellow light hazy colour, small white head. Smells ripe fruits, light apples, but acidic, light sweetness. medium body, soft carbonation. Tastes of grains, light fruits, Apples, some sweetness, bit fruity. Finishes rather balanced with notes of apples and grains. Good.
Beer with gold color, light body, soft carbonized, low foam in top, (50cl from tap in Opice).

11/VII/15 - on tap @ U Kudìje (Olomouc) - BB: n/a (2015-909) Clear deep blond beer, creamy white head, little stable, adhesive, leaving a nice lacing in the glass. Aroma: citrus, sweet malts, bit fruity, yeasty touch. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: bit sweet, very malty, grains, hay, some banana, bitter hops. Aftertaste: very malty, hay, some caramel, grains, fruity, more banana, little watery, sweet, some marzipan.
bottle bel dorato buona schiuma discreta persistenza note erbacea buona nota maltata un lieve zolfo discreto amaro
Clear golden color with off-white head. Aroma has caramel, malt and hay. Taste is malty sweet with quite long somewhat bitter aftertaste. Flavors of caramel, malt and grass.
Vycap zbrojný. Vôòa chmelovo sladova. Farba zlatista. Chu vodova chmelova nádych.
Can from SB. Golden with a thick white head. Malty and bready tones. Malt, cereals, hops and bitterness. Medium body with a dry finish.

0.3 l on tap at 'Piváreò Budík'. Clear, golden amber with a thin, dense, almost stable, white head. Faint, sweetish, a bit grassy-spicy aroma of grains, some straw and faint hints of butter. Slightly sweet, moderately bitter, gently grassy-spicy taste of grains, some straw and traces of butter, followed by a short, moderately bitter, slightly grassy-spicy finish. Almost medium-bodied, smooth and slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Okay, nothing special really.
From the lauter keg at the brewery. Golden color with little head. Fresh taste, smooth finish.
Prakticky tady pøidávám tento komentáø, jen aby tady nìco bylo, protože zpìtnì dopisuji 900 piv z mého seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zbláznit.
Aroma: sweet malty, light metallic hints, yeasty, Taste: light to medim sweetness, light hoppy bitterness, light oily feel, sweet oily finish.

Huh, down at Pivovarsky Klub as the Unfiltered 12, but matches this it would appear. Quite clear, if not fully, golden body. Honeyish maltiness with a sprinkle of vegetables. Very mild taste, initially herbal, some graininess and yeastiness, ends tart. But all is very subdued. Mild, neutral, drinkable.
Draught. Creamy White good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Light bitter bready flavor. Some butterscotch. Light bitter short finish. Watery palate.

White head, ringy lacing, mostly clear straw golden body. Aroma has mild hops, mild bread, caramel n malts with honey notes. Tastes mild hops + a pale apple touch, some caramel, honey notes, leaves - leading to a finish in leafy hops, apple peels and fruity malts. Normal on palate, very clean and fresh feel. Overall a very quaffable easy fresh beer, food friendly, comfortable brew. [1L@Budvarka,È.Budejovice]

cask at the Maltings, York: Comes of sprinkler pump with nice quarter inch of head and is a golden color. Aroma is of earthy, dusty, hops, and some pale malt in the shadows. flavor is of crisp earthy slightly citurssy hops. quite nice to sip on. rather thin palate. quite enjoyable.
Tap at SF Beer Week Opening Gala. Pours sloudy brown. Aroma is ripe dark fruit, dried fruit, some candy sugar. Heavy body, sweet, not overpower, good balance, yet not overly complex.

Keg at the brewpub, 29/01/16. Murky mahogany brown with a decent tan cap. Nose is dark fruit rinds, light spice, Belgian yeast esters, toffee, dates. Taste comprises tangy dark fruit, boozey Xmas cake, yeast trace, toffee, light spice, raisens, dried dates. Medium + body, fine carbonation closing with a tangy dark fruit rinse. So so ... unrefined - too bitter and sharp in places.

Draft at the brewpub. Pours deep amber-brown with a creamy, tan head. The nose holds plums and prunes, faint toffee. Medium to big sweet flavour, with more toffee, ripe berries, plum, candi sugar, fruitcake, bread. Medium to full bodied with average carbonation. Lightly warming on the finish, with further rich and ripe fruits, toffee, bread. A good and drinkable. quad.
Draft: Poured a dark brown with tan colored head. Aroma is dark fruit, yeast esters. Taste is yeast ester, dark fruit, and some alcohol.

On tap @ brewpub during RateBeer weekend, January 2016. Cloudy reddish brown appearance with a creamy brown head. Plum, raisin, grape, caramel. Moderate high sweetness. Moderate low bitterness. A bit twangy. Candy sugar and caramel, especially in the flavor. Ok but a little muddled.

Draft at the brewpub, served in a flight. Pours a hazy amber color with a small off-white head that settles into a ring. Notes of fruitcake, brown sugar, caramel, dates, raisins, figs, mild spice, and earth. Medium-bodied, with modest carbonation and a sweet, malty mouthfeel. Good balanced take on a quad.
[1/29/16] Draught at Marin Brewing in Larkspur. Dark brown. Aroma of caramel, dark fruits. Sweet flavor with caramel, dark fruits, alcohol.

Sample on tap at the brewpub. Hazy amber copper pour with gold head. Aroma is nutty, dried fruit, earthy notes, light booze. Taste is sweet, toasty, quite boozy. Palate is med full bodied with good carb. Nothing extraordinary but a pretty solid quad.

Draft to taster at the brewpub (2016 vintage). This batch is 10.8% with 25 IBUs. Looks good; a hazy purplish brown with off-white lacing. Smells solid; a nice balance of Belgian yeast, raisin, and plum. Tastes like it smells, but less balanced. Very raisin-forward. Mouthfeel is medium full-bodied. Solid, but smells better than it tastes.

Draught at Marin Brewing Company. Almost opaque deep brown liquid with small light tan head. Aroma of dried fruit, raw sugar, raisins, toffee and warming alcohol. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of dried fruit, raisins, booze and toffee. Full bodied with medium carbonation. Ok.
Hazy gold liquid. Thin aroma. Sweet flavour and nicely hopped. Light, enjoyable and drinkable. Thanks TimE.

Deep golden color. Very little nose, but the German malts are very present. Deep, rich german malts tickle the back of your throat on first sip with strong bready notes. Given the lack of bitterness, I am wondering if this could actually be a Baird beer? Some apples and cherries make a brief appearance, but nothing notable. The body is incredibly smooth. Finishing rich and very mildly sweet. Excellent example of the style.

An imperial red for the middle of summer is an interesting choice to say the least. I was really surprised that a lot of the fruit salad character I got with the American Dream was also in here. I didn’t think the hops stood out as much. It certainly was fuller bodied than the American Dream, but did not get me as excited about the beer. I think I would perfer in the winter, but overall it didnt do alot for me.

column1: Baird Yabai Yabai Strong Scotch Ale
column5: Bottle sample at a tasting at Lior D's place. Thanks Stas. Hazy amber. Malt, caramel, oxidation, some fruitiness, sweet, medium-bodied, some alcohol.

column1: Baird Yabai Yabai Strong Scotch Ale
column5: At Lior's Place, pours brown with a beige head, aroma of malt, caramel, toffee, flavor of malt, caramel, toffee, medium bodied

column1: Baird Yabai Yabai Strong Scotch Ale
column5: Taster at LBK Craft, Nara. Dark nutty red. Slightly fizzy body. Malts to the max, but nicely balanced and warming. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at GJBF, Osaka, 2008. A great, flavorful, rich stout. Strong, well roasted, rich and powerful but very well balanced. One of the best Japanese stouts I have had. Very rich and creamy.

Tried with TimE on tap I think at Towers in Tokyo. First, I think it is wrong to use the word imperial for a 7% beer. Oh well, on the other hand freedom is a good thing. Black color. Very chocolatey in taste and aroma. Dryish (I prefer sweetish). Aroma has some malty notes.

Bottle from grocery store. Was looking forward to trying this one as Sankt Gallen puts out some fairly good (if not somewhat predictable) beers. Poured a deep dark black with a rocky head. Smell of dark chocolate on the nose, roasted coffee..but overall subdued in the aroma dept. Taste was bitter...wow. more bitter than i was expecting. Something not quite right about this one. I was glad i tried it, but the balance seems somewhat skewed. Maybe I am just missing something. I like bitter beers, but i think that the mouthfeel doesn’t match the taste and the flavours are just not matching up. Not a bad brew by any means...just not sure if this is my idea of an ideal Imperial Stout.
Tasted @ GJBF Yokohama: Dark black, nice light tan head and nice lacing. Nose of roasted malt, nice fruit and bright cocoa, strong and lots of sweet roast in the flavor. Decent, fairly strong finish.

[on tap at Ushi-Tora] Plumy, roasted barley aroma with detectible hops. Opaqe yet clear black-brown with no top. Excellent stout, burnt/bitter flavour with a sweet Belgian dark chocolate finish. Lingering bitterness and moderate carbonation.

An excellent brew, but the bitterness prevalent is just a bit too overpowering. Otherwise this is an excellent example of the imperial. Rerate 2009 edition. The bitterness has been toned down and it’s smoother than previous years. very nice

Poured black with a nice tan head. Roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and a little bit of alcohol in the aroma. Flavor was chocolate and roasted malts with some whiskey hidden underneath. Finish was about as bitter as I’ve ever had in an imperial stout. Body was rich and full. A very well made stout.

A lot of hype around this beer. Didn’t quit live up to all the hype, but still not complaining at all. Pitch black. Little head. Whisky, dark chocolate notes in the nose. Big bitter dark chocolate mouth. I meant really bitter. Some dark fruit and caramel notes as well. Full bodied. Big bitter finish with lots of dark chocolate. Excellent stuff.

Orange amber ale with a thick off white head. Caramel and butterscotch aroma, with fruity esters. A thin beer with sweet caramel malt and English hops, lightly carbonated from casking. Quaffable. Cask, Oct. 7, 2006.

The color is brown, it has a nutty aroma of malt. The flavor is of fruit it has a mild bitter taste. The brewmaster does not know if he will make it again, but I hope he does, it is for me their best so far.
Cask at Bedford BF ’06. Dark gold with a small white head. Intense sweet fruit and floral hop aroma. Sweet taste is followed by a fruitiness and some bitterness to finish.

Cask conditioned at The Olde Reinedeer, Banbury, Oxon. Full brown gold with white bubbly head. Aroma of newly mown hay and earthy fields. Hoppy bitterness throughout this beer, long and dry and refreshing. Malty biscuity base and green fresh hops, there is a grapefruit citrus feel to the flavour. Ends with a roar rather than a whimper. A very decent pint indeed.
Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 22/09/2006 Fruit and hop aromas. Clear golden coloured hoppy and fruity with some dryness in a crisp and creamy finish.
Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Mid to dark gold. Hoppy nose with some fruit. Strong fruity taste with some malty sweetness and a little dryness to follow. Quite delicious.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Tap. Black, with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Taste is the same, but slightly richer than expected. Body was medium and a bit creamy. Decent stout.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: 12 oz single via can from Silver Dollar Liquor (Pagosa Springs). Rich, dark and roasty with notes of coffee and light chocolate. Medium to light body with a smooth feel and a mild sweet finish. Good.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: This is a nice porter though unfortunately it has ceased production. Mellow with light note of a typical brown ale just hardier

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Pours opaque coffee with a thick buff head. Aroma yields roast malt, nutty, semi-sweet chocolate, and a sharp alcohol bite - surprising for something only 6.4%. Flavor provides roast malt, semi-sweet chocolate, nutty, subtle molasses and earthy tones. Texture features so-so body and fair fizz. Do your hard time.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: 12 oz. can Pours black color with a white tan head, some lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, artificial chocolate, and ash. Flavor is sweet with caramel, artificial chocolate and a very thin body. Tastes like chocolate extract was overused. Nope.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Can. Dark brown with a khaki head. Heavy lacing. Aroma of cocoa, milk chocolate, roast and nuts. Tastes lightly bitter and a little sweet. Medium bodied.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Pours dark brown from the bottle and leaves a frothy, beige head. Aroma is strongly of coffee, accompanied by smokey, earthy notes. Taste is bittersweet with a very mild sour twist at the end. Overall covers a wide spectrum of flavor, and does so with a rich, smooth body that keeps the alcohol well hidden. Good stuff.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: 12 oz. can. Pours almost black with a creamy beige head. Aroma of sweet roasted malts, chocolate and coffee notes. Taste is roasted malt at the forefront, with chocolate and coffee in the background. Some nuttiness also. Mildly sweet finish.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Very dark red with half finger tan head. Aroma of vanilla, coffee, and dirt. Taste has roasted coffee, earth and vanilla. Palate is fizzy and medium bodied.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Dark brown pour. Aroma is cocoa and coffee. Smooth bodied, medium mouthfeel. Solid offering.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: A good looking beer - pours black with a well contrasted white head. Aroma is nutty, coffee, molasses. A bit too thin and boring on the tongue.... More roasted malts, coffee, a little cocoa, not bad but a bit too much like the best beer at a bad brew pub.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Sampled at Great American Beer Festival 2019 in Denver, Colorado. Light, clean, kinda boring.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Can into mug. Pale golden. Kind of funky musty pils. Not much of a beer. Not one to go back to

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: 5/26/19 - Santa Fe, NM - on tap at their taproom. Sparkling, light golden, bubbly snow white head. Solid standard pils, no flaws, sweet, grainy, refreshing. Crisp mouthfeel.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: From a 12 oz. can. Pours a clear pale gold with an off white head. Aromas are bready. Flavors are sweet pale malts with a touch of hop bitterness. Okay for a hot summer day.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: This is just a plain American style rather tasteless blond beer - with perhaps more hops than most of its iik. To say it is a German-like pilsner is absurd in my opinion. It has no body at all. Basically, it tastes like water, alcohol, and hops.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: 12floz can, BBD: 04.19.2019, $1.75 unit cost, pint glass. Smells like weeds/wildflowers. Appears a gold color with off white head taste is American, more of a green grass flavor than hay/cereal grain that is more typical for the style. Hoppiness is higher than the typical pills too, but it is mild relatively to other ales. There is a dull dirty tang that lingers. In summer, nothing great. Yet it's fairly light in body and does pass as consumable.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: On tap. Pours a clear light golden color with a small head. Aroma of Malt sweetness, grain with just a hint of citrus. Taste of malt sweetness, some grain and citrus. Some bitterness and a clean finish. Light body, smooth with a slight crisp feel.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: 12 oz. can. Clear straw color, white head. Aroma of cereal, corn, mild hops, floral notes. Taste is cereal, lemon, corn, traces of hops, grass. Okay.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Aroma of mineral and biscuit. Sparkling lace. Flavor is of mild mineral water and floral hops. Neither truly mineraly nor hoppy. Updated 6/18: Flavor notes on point. But 3.0 was too low.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Clear straw hue with only the smallest of white foamy caps. Biscuity german lager nose with a gentle floral grassy tone. Bright crisp flavor that’s got a good dose of Pilsen malt and grassy hops, a fair little bit of a floral tone and a clean lagered crisp finish. Exceptional Pilsner.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Tap at brewery. Pours a clear dark amber with minor head that subsides quick. Has a fruity ester aroma with light citrus hops and roasted malt. Taste starts smoothly sweet going into darker malt tastes and finishing with a decent bitterness. Goes down smooth with a balanced bittersweet finish.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: On tap @ 1702 for Santa Fe Brewing night - Pours a clear amber color with a thin white head. Faint lacing. Aroma is light esters and toasted malt. Flavor is lightly sweetened malt, faint yeast, and light esters. Medium body. A good beer.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Sampled at 1702; April 2009 The beer arrives from the tap a clear, dark amber color, it has a touch of brown to it and shows a brilliantly clear, amber hue to it when held up to the light. The beer is pretty light colored overall for something that the brewery describes as a Dubbel. The aroma has a light herbal hop note to it up front, but sweet fruit aromatics quickly sweep that away; notes of plum, red-grapes and a tart-sweet fruit character are easily noticed. There is a touch of malt character towards the finish that provides aromas of biscuit-malt and brown sugar crusted bread. There is a ton of fruit aromatics here, but it comes off as smelling almost more tart than sweet, which is nice. The flavor has a fruitiness to it up front but the finish has a spicy, yeast-driven finish that isn’t the same level as the fruit. The fruit flavors are actually found throughout the flavor profile, even into a lingering note in the finish. There are lots of sweet-tart plum notes, a pretty big berry flavors, some grape like flavors, and even some sweet-tart wine notes. The spicy notes provide flavors of earthy almost coriander, woody pepper and lots of clove notes (that accentuates the sweetness), and perhaps even a touch of allspice. Some toasted grain flavors seem to meld in pretty well with the spiciness here. This is a nicely done beer. It definitely has grown upon me as I work my way through it. I like that it has a light vinous quality to it, but it is definitely fruit dominated, but it does have enough complexity to it to keep interesting.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Sampled on tap at 1702 on 4/23/2009. This abbey double pours a medium orange gold color from the tap. Medium sized white foamy head with nice retention. The aroma is fruity, yeasty and sweet, A medium bodied Double. The malts are fruity and sweet. The hops are earthy. Nice balance. Good carbonation. Nice Belgian yeast and esters. Very smooth finish. Perhaps a touch of the thin side. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Thanks to Tomthompson89. A funky aroma to this one, an unusual yeast play but not spoiled. The alcohol comes through also on the arma and taste. A bit of laste. A thin mouthfeel and low carbonation. Not really hitting the style, but a kind of Belgian.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: nice beer a little odd for a Dubbel, but a intresting beer, slightly yeasty spicy nose. amber golden color with very little head. flavor is kinda odd not really strong but kinda acidic and yeasty with a little malt in the back, drinkable but not amazing. Happy they r trying though

Samea, hailakanruskea olut kohtalaisella, mutta aika pikaisesti katoavalla vaahdolla. Tuoksu pähkinäinen, aniksinen ja karamellisen maltainen. Maku aika kuiva, hieman hapan, maltainen, aavistuksen sitruksinen ja mausteinen. Keskitäyteläinen suutuntuma. On tässä jouluisuutta yritetty hakea, mutta hiivainen happamuus on turhan vallitsevana.

Sameanruskea, vaahtoa ei juuri synny. Tuoksu on mieto ja metsäinen. Mieli lähtee matkalle havumetsään, jossa tonttu keittelee sahtia piilopirtissään. Perille päästyä saa maistaa kulauksen puisella kauhalla. Maku on havuinen, katkera ja pihkainen. Tämä on ehkä tonttujen taikajuomaa, mutta itselle liian sahtimainen. (20.12.2014)

From Mar 2007 Pours from 22oz bottle(room temp) a clear deep amber with a huge billowy head of foam that lingers throughout the session as a solid layer with lacing. A very nice looking brew in my Chimay goblet. The smell is on the light side. I can just detect some roasted and caramel malt. The taste on first sip is of roasted malt, caramel malt, and grain. It's on the sweet side but not overly so. More sips in and there's a bready flavour in there as well and a touch of nuttiness along with a hop bite that is most prevalent in the finish. An interesting tasting American Brown Ale for sure and it's hitting my taste buds in a good way. Oh, and the alcohol is pretty well hidden so this one goes down pretty easily. Bottom line: I like this example of the style and I'd say try it. PS: When I bought this bottle at Wilburs in Ft Collins, because of the name, I thought it was going to be a Belgian style ale...

Old rating. Bottle from Old Town. Pours a amber brown color with a big head. Caramel, almond, prune, fig and cinnamon on the nose. Spice and fruit flavors really stand out as it comes to room temperature. Long bitter finish with a bit of pepper present as well. A little astringent but not overly so.

Bottle from old backlog notes. Pours a hazy brown color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have caramel and chocolate malts, herbal notes that bring up tea, some fruity character, strange that there isn’t much Belgian character.
Draft. Complex sweet malty beer, body is a little thin with some sharp notes. Light head, clear, amber colored. Not my favorite from Rogue.

650ml bottle pours an amber brown color with a 2 finger white head that settles down to some nice lacing. Aroma is caramel malty sweet with a nice blend of hops. Taste is quite bitter with some mellowing from the grainy malts. Medium bodied with adequate carbonation. Full flavored ale that is very refreshing and easy to drink despite the high ABV.
Pours a bright golden amber color. Aromas of hops, fruit, and a little yeast. Has a light lemony taste, with some yeasty notes, and a good hop flavor.

2007: 22oz bottle... Colossal ice cream float had. Deep, hazy dark red. Lots of carbonation, and a massive icy lace. A very pungent malty (almost Belgian) smell. Spicy but very dark and very nutty. Heavy roasted malt. Quite a sour accent. Hops are there but in the background. Has a sweet/sour mix of toffee. There is a taffy/caramel element. A bit much. Strong. Thick and creamy but bubbly. Stays on the tongue long after. Really thick. Formidable. It tastes good but is very strong. Both sweet and pungent.
From an old note: bottle. orange-brown pour with large white head. dark fruit and molasses in the aroma. tangy, sweet and bitter with caramel and pine. long bitter finish. need to try again sometime.

Pours a two finger cream head that fades slowly leaving a good lace. Cloudy amber/brown color. Medium carbonation and medium bodied. Caramel nose. Flavor is some caramel sweetness but mostly a hoppy wood. Lingering hoppy aftertaste. $6.49 for a 22oz bottle from Manchester Wine and Liquors Manchester, CT.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a medium sized head of foamy finely sized tan colored bubbles that were long lasting and left behind a hazy with fine particulate softly carbonated and a fair lacing. The smooth aroma was brown malt and dark malt. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a biting aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of mild hops dark malt and brown malt. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

Take-away from cask @ Bitter Virtue, Soton. Initial fruity (sweet citrus) and mild hay hop aromas. Malt simpler than many Loddon beers. Tasty but slightly lacking in bitterness with the malty sweetness growing to dominate the finish.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Berserkr Porter
column5: A light chocolate/bourbon/woody taste, smooth on the palate, med. carbonation, and a clear maple appearance. Good Stuff

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Berserkr Porter
column5: Sampled at Dutch 70’s "Tasting in the Woods; Part Deux". Dark brown/mahogany with a high, light brown head. Somewhat of a subtle oak character in the nose. Flavor definitely has a nice chocolate chip cookie dough flavor along with notes caramel, chocolate, brown sugar, vanilla (sounds like a cookie recipe) and some wood. Pleasantly sweet with a nice bittering hop presence. Medium bodied with a smooth texture and moderate carbonation. Enjoyable.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Berserkr Porter
column5: TITW Part Deux - Large handbottle courtesy of scraff! Pours a dark brown appearance, with a dark tan head; good retention. Chewy vanilla oak and light bourbon in the aroma. Nice level of carbonation; medium mouthfeel: sweet bourbon, toasty vanilla, light oak, light (almost watery) milk chocolate/porter background. Medium finish: slightly dry, showing dark chocolate and oak.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Berserkr Porter
column5: TITWPD. Brown body with a whispy, tan head. The aroma is oak, molases and chocolate. The flavor is vanilla, chocolate, light roast and caramel. Medium/light body with a slightly thin textrue and a dry finish.

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Berserkr Porter
column5: Bottle - TITW Part Deux - Deep brown, bordering black, creamy tan head. Nice tones of chocolale chip cookies, vanilla, and oak, with just the faintest hint of coconut. Flavor was soft with more of the above notes, but add a very faint maple tone to it. Was well balanced throughout, rich, with a light bitterness rounding it out. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, dark chocolate-like finish. Very good stuff, but would have been better suited to be called porter vs. baltic porter. No matter, I dig it! Thanks Jim. Keep up the great work...

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Berserkr Porter
column5: Bottle... TITW Part Deux... Maple-colored ale with a small, creamy, off-white head. Notes of vanilla, chocolate and wood, but no bourbon, in the aroma. The flavor is malty and rich, but only lightly sweet with a hint of oak and gobs of chocolate chip cookie dough. Full-bodied and creamy with fizzy carbonation. Finishes crisp with a slightly bitter note of dark chocolate. Another strong offering from an already solid lineup of beers at DuClaw! Thanks, scraff & Jim for providing the bottle!

column1: DuClaw Oak Barrel Aged Berserkr Porter
column5: First sampled from the brewfest in Union Mills, MD on Sept. 30, 2006. The porter has great character in general with generous amounts of roastiness that are exentuated with the oak barrel. Alcohol is definately stronger than the non-aged draft, but is blended well with the aforementioned oak blend. Great Offering!
Bottle. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. No tasting notes kept, just rating.
Bottle. Red in colour. Very earthy taste. Hoppy; earthy & grassy hops. Fruity. Malty; grainy malts, caramel. Strong fully flavoured taste. Too strong for my taste. Didn’t like it! (2008)

500ml Bottle conditioned: a present from my son, the last of four beers from this brewery he gave me earlier this year.
