Gusher, all over the bloody place, still pouring it’s self all over the draining board even as I write this, some foam got into an Abbot Ale glass tankard at home on 25th Nov 2015. Murky brown with a red hue to the body, the foam a tanned fountain of bubbles. Malty and fairly sweet, a slight bittering in the finish. I might have liked this if it hadn’t erupted all over the dining room tablecloth, making me leap up and rush into the kitchen to drink what was left.

Cask, The Salmon, Leicester. Rusty copper with a cream foam. Aromas are earthy with red berries and wine barrel. Toffee with herbal notes and spices. Some background orange with pine. Flavours are toffee and grapefruit with raspberry. Pithy and dry with earthy notes. A nice fruity ESB.

Ruby red, not quite clear. Patchy, light, off-white head. V Light carbonation. Light roasty aroma, with brandy and winey sweetness, fruity alcohol and a bit of vanilla and coke? But the aroma is not very strong, overall. Taste is caramel sweetness, dark fruits, some slight choc and light roast. OK body, but could maybe be a little heavier/fuller. Dry, lingering bitterness; would be nice to have more of the sweet fruity flavours left on the palate. Fairly nice, malty red ale, but the hops are fairly uninteresting and understated. Bit too sweet for the amount of flavour it has.
A - fruity with roasted coffee and chocolate A - reddish-gold with thin head T - light sweet with roasted bitter P - mid O - ok

Appearance: Chestnut brown, some red. Clear. Enormous amounts of creamy, off-white head. Aroma: Malt, hops, metallic. Some fruit. Taste: Malt, bitterness. Some fruit, lemon? Standard - slightly disappointed. Info: 500ml bottle, 25/8-2011

Bottle at home shared with Lyoli. Cloudy amber pour with a weak, white head. Strong caramel and toffee notes in the aroma. Interesting flavor, pretty sweet, bready, nutty, some prunes maybe, and leafy bitters. Medium in body with average, fizzy carbonation. Finish is kinda weird too. Not bad, but has some uncommon characteristics. More bread and nuts with some fruits and caramel. Decent.

11th October 2007 Warning! Early amateur rating! Reddish brown ale. A bit monotone! Dry and crisp. Fairly bitter finish. Improved a little by pouring some of the sediment in but overall an average beer.

500ml bottle - at ChrisO’s - thanks! 5 Sweetish malty aroma 3 Deepish copper 5 Subdued dull malty taste, only slightly sweet once swirled. 3 Needed swirling to soften the palate 10 Not unpleasant, but desperately boring.

cask at the Yorkshire Terrior Inn, York: aroma was of earthy hops and pale malt. rather pale yellow color with which cask head. flavor was dusty earthy hops, probably lots of goldings. Nice session beer. easy drinking palate. cheers!

Beige-straw colour. Bit of diacetyl in the nose along with light bread/grain. Light flavour and medium body. Grainy taste, some adjuncty notes, hint of hop (grass). Not much else. Aims low, hits the target.

column1: Azalea Coast East Coast India Pale Ale
column5: Pours copper with some stray white bubbles. Smells of sweet malt and boozy. Tastes earthy and slightly resiny.

column1: Azalea Coast East Coast India Pale Ale
column5: Lots of sweet in this IPA. Saw it on the shelf while visiting NC and thought I would take a chance. Not munch of an aroma, but overall not a bad IPA. Decent beer. Some of these bad reviews may have received bad bottles.

column1: Azalea Coast East Coast India Pale Ale
column5: 22 oz bottle poured medium orange and cloudy. Decent hop aroma, but not noticeable what was going on. Same sour flavors as in the stout.

column1: Azalea Coast East Coast India Pale Ale
column5: 22oz bottle. Pours orange/amber with a huge, crisp white head, sticky lace. Smells of vinegar and some hay with some hops as well. I smell Brett yeast? Tastes like a lambic as well. A bit of barnyard with some subdued astringent hops, a little sour. Medium body, vibrant carbonation.

column1: Azalea Coast East Coast India Pale Ale
column5: Large tan head, retention is good as is the lace. Clear, orange gold color. Funky nose of scented liquid dish soap, sorta perfumey, light honey notes. Body is med/light, prickly carbonation, astringent feel on the palate. Perumey hop flavors, soapy, metallic notes, light maltiness. Finish is lightly sweet, astringent, errrph. Bottle procured in a trade with oldstylecubfan i do believe? Thanks Todd!

column1: Azalea Coast East Coast India Pale Ale
column5: Bomber. Pours hazy brass color with fizzy off-white head. The aroma is lime, orange, and candy apple. The flavor is unpleasantly grassy with some cotton and apple tastes. There’s a weird chemical sweetness toward the finish that’s really turning me off. Some pine bounces around too. Not a particularly tasty IPA.

column1: Azalea Coast East Coast India Pale Ale
column5: Orange copper pour with a creamy white head. Sweet caramel and butterscotch flavors. Grassy hop flavor. IMHO, not a good IPA - even when we tried to compare it to more traditional UK IPAs. Strangely enough my wife, who hates hoppy beers, liked this one.

column1: Azalea Coast East Coast India Pale Ale
column5: Bottle; a pretty attractive pour. Color of copper with a big off white head. Aroma was strange; oranges, bread, and caramel with a pronounced sour/tart component. Flavor; probably would never have guessed this was an IPA; probably would have guessed some form of amber ale. Not too hoppy in the finish. That being said, it didn’t really taste all that bad. A little bit of balance and some complexity. Decent beer, just not a great representation of the style.

column1: Azalea Coast East Coast India Pale Ale
column5: 22oz bottle. Golden color. Stale aged aroma. Flavor is blah. Big bitterness in the finish. That’s all this bottle had.

column1: Azalea Coast East Coast India Pale Ale
column5: Bomber. Pours a copper hue with a fairly see-through body. Perhaps the slightest of haze is visible. A decent white head forms and lingers for an extended period of time. The aroma has hints of sourdough, caramel, hot cinnamon candy, and peppers. This isn’t nearly as aromatic as I’d like an IPA. The mouthfeel is lighter, but not watery. All of the flavors meld together awkwardly in a combination that certainly resembles an india pale, though rough. The hops add an acceptable level of bitterness that mostly is noted in an aftersting, but never really shine through. The malt flavor has a very generic personality touted especially in an almost corny/apple-like sweet note. This is not necessarily abysmal as a beer, but does not do well to quell my craving for an IPA.

650 ML bottle Murky sort of dark black but not all the way black color, hints of ruby. Light tan head, falls to a thick collar. Good strips of lacing. Looks good in glass. Nose is chocolate, tobacco, dark bitter fruits, roasted malt, some ash and tire. very earthy nose with touches of fruit. taste is earthy chocolate, coffee, wood, earth, apple, red cherry but not sour cherry. Very smooth for all that is going on with the beer. Well hidden alcohol. Easy to drink. Love to have another.

Pours coffee sable with a nice light tan head. Strong aroma presents roast malt, molasses, even fruity tones. Smoky roast malt, molasses and coffee tones comprise the pleasing flavor, along with a subtle fruity note. Mouthfeel features good, firm body and fizz. Get your Baltic on!

650 ml. Deep ebony body has a glint of ruby and a thin film of cream on top. Nose is toffee, chocolate, apple, and touches of coffee and dried grass. Tastes of semi-sweet chocolate, molasses, dry grass and some light notes of sourish orange and apple. Long finish of espresso, raisin and dry cocoa. Medium-plus body has smooth medium carbonation and a easy drinking balance with no hint of the 9%.

22oz bottle, thanks to whomever shared this! Dark brown, near-black color. Thin off-white kind of khaki bubbly head. Dots and bits of lace. Bigger body. Smooth, kind of chewy, lighter carbonation. More dry finish. Great dark chocolate, cocoa nibs. Light to moderate roast, mild coffee. Moderate sweet-plus taste, moderate bitter. A very solid assertive roasty baltic porter.

Refrigerated brown bomber poured into a snifter. Dark brown with off-white head. Aroma is rich chocolate, medium body, medium/light carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is chocolate, smoke, roasted malt, some herbal hops, and some ash. Good beer, alcohol is well covered, and would have been one of the best I had have if no ash.
From old tasting notes - Dark brown with ring. Roasted coffee and chocolate aroma. Nice toasted nutty coffee and chocolate. Nice soft palate. Excellent.
Malty aroma, pours a deep ebony with a thin brown head. Malty taste with hints of alcohol.
Draft at Churchkey. Very dark maroon color, thick tan head with good lacing and retention. Aroma of earthy but sweet cocoa powder. Taste is smooth milk chocolate, coffee. Nice.

I brought this one to our Stout Day party. A - Pours extremely dark brown with a nice one finger tall off white head leaving small streaks of lace down the glass. S - This one is fairly roasty with hints of coffee and chocolate. It has a tiny bit of mineral flavor as well. The smokey charred wood aroma mixes well with the dark roast. T - Starts off with some slightly sweet dark roast quickly giving way to a mix of coffee grounds, dark chocolate, and charred wood. The finish is a mix of dark roast and light smoke, lingering on the pallet for some time. The smooth feel really helps this one out, helping to bring all the flavors together. M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Smooth, roasty, feel throughout. Very little booze flavor in this one. O - I really enjoyed this one. It had plenty of flavor and was easy to drink. One of the better baltic porters I have had recently. I didn’t detect a lot of alcohol in this one, I think the year in the cellar did this one some good.

Draft. Dark brown body with medium beige head. Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, some roast, faint alcohol. Taste is moderately sweet, coffee, some roast, alcohol warming, light vinous. Medium-full body, some stickiness.

On tap at George’s in Wayne, PA. Served in a pint glass. Lots of very light, fluffy head. Coloring was a mild yellow-gold. Taste was of hops with a little malt flavor, but not much. Hop flavor was fairly bland, not really piny or citrusy but just the biting hop flavor. Mouthfeel was fairly light, bordering on wattery. All in all, there are a ton of other IPAs out there that are better than this one so I doubt I’d order this again.

Bottle. Aroma-Fruity. Appearance-Same as any other IPA. Flavor- About as boring and standard as the semi-gloss paint on a kitchen wall. Palate-Nothing big to mention. This is just an average IPA, with nothing to make it stand apart.

On-tap at the brewpub: Slightly hazed gold with a nice firm capping of white foam about a finger high which keeps its present at length. Lots of sheeting lace is stretched across the glass. Aroma is quite nice of citrusy juices where orange, lemon, and grapefruit collide over a little pineyness and sweet malt backing it up. Crisp, clean, hoppy, and inviting nose. Taste is smooth and clean with a nice citric realm of lemon, orange, and grapefruit taking a nice mildly balanced flavor across the palate. Nice touches of caramel malt and sweetened, piney bitterness grab with just a touch of grassyness. It kinda reminded me a bit of Two-Hearted, but somewhat lighter and not as lengthy. Pretty solid taster though. Very smooth, lightly crisp, and enjoyably drinkable. Body is about medium, smooth and carefully hopped with a nice balance and well rounded clean crispness to its bitterness. A favorable drinking IPA. Its not flashy for an IPA, its a nice hop fix and tasty. Not to mention, super damn drnkable to boot. I had a few these in a hurry as they went down oh so nice.

Hand-pulled pint in The Nag's Head, Covent Garden on 8th Aug 2019. Decent enough, amber bodied with a slight red hue, white crown. Nice fruity nose and flavours, good balance between the hops and maltiness. Liked it.
Cask @ Old Bank of England as McMullen Original IPA. Mörk bärnstensfärgad öl med inslag av rött. Doft och smak av malt, hö, karamell och jordig humlekaraktär.

Cask at Cowper Arms @ Digswell, Welwyn Garden City. Amber colour with reddish tinge, white foam head and malty earthy aroma. Taste is malt, caramel, fruity with some earthy bitterness. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry bitter finish. OK
July 2018. The Angels Hitchen. A bit tannic. Some fruity sweetness almost rotten fruit. OK.

Draught (Nag's Head, Bishop's Stortford) (7:4:6+:4:13+=3.4++) Reddish, tight head. Soft malty aroma, some honey, classic proper English bitter. Lovely soft palate. Rich malty taste, pleasant esters. A simple bitter, but just lovely.

Cask (handpump) @ Nags Head, 10 James Street, Covent Garden, Greater London, England WC2E 8BT. [ As McMullen IPA ]. Clear medium to dark red amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, hay, pale malt, caramel, light to moderate hoppy, woody hops. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, sweet malt, pale malt, caramel. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20160808] 6-3-6-3-12
Light bitter. V fruity almost cidery taste. Bit More balance would improve
Cask (Nags Head, Bishop Stortford). Clear amber color. Medium size, beige head, stays. Citrus, grassy, grainy in aroma. Grainy and grassy bitter. Nice one.

Cask at Kingfisher on the Quay in Camberley. Brown pour with a good head, very smooth body but little going on flavour-wise other than some light resiny malt, almost like a nitro keg bitter. Drinkable but bland.
Cask. Pale amber with a lovely foam head. Scent is nothing. Taste is light boring bitter without hops and hard to believe this is called an IPA. Finish is nothing. Sticky. Poor.

Ah! The taste of my childhood. Can’t really remember if it was this beer I was drinking because I forgot to write the name down in my notes.... It was a Alehouse dark mild, so its got to be this one. Dark brown body, small cream head. Lots of Mild flavours: citrus fruit, tea, hint of spice. A good example of the style
Cask at The Lower Red Lion St Albans 29 Sep 2006. Dark brown coloured. A small tanned head. Anonymous with a not-too-pleasant aftertaste.

Cask conditioned at The Lower Red Lion, St Albans, Herts. Black with a brown tinge, slight head. Od fruity sweet tea flavour is the initial impact, smooth with a tarry background, maybe too much flavour for a mild, but it does carry a reasonable beer.
Cask at The Lower Red Lion St Albans 29 Sep 2006. Dark brown coloured. A small head. Some hoppy aroma. Fruity hints in tha flavour. A pleasant dry bitter finish.

Cask conditioned at The Lower Red Lion, St Albans, Herts. Classic amber with bubbly white head. This was my beer of the day on our tour of St Albans, a Beautiful crisp hoppy bitter with dry citrus grapefruit notes and mouth cleansing peppery hops on the long finish. A real gem.

(Cask at Font Bar, Manchester, 27 July) Orange/amber colour with small head. Fruity nose with citrus (grapefruit, orange peel) and hops. Fruity taste with notes of grapefruit and orange marmalade. Nice balance between sweetness and bitterness in the fairly hoppy finish.

Ah... didn’t have the info to add this after my trip to England (and stop at the York Brewing Co.), glad someone did finally so I could add my rating. Brownish body with a light head. Slightly hoppy aroma, some malts. Taste is rather nice, though nothing amazing. Rather nice beer to have on an afternoon.

Cask conditioned at The White Lion, St Albans, Herts. Gold with white head. Thick sucrosy mouthfeel which is rescued with a particularly farmy sulphery dryness. Nice hop finish, quite long. A good beer on the finish after a dubious start.

Cask 1/3 pint at the 46th Cambridge Beer Festival, 2019. Black colour, tan head. Nice aroma and flavour of roast malts, chocolate and coffee, also fruity hops. (I sampled only a small number of the beers available at the festival, but this one was "Beer of the Festival" for me.)

Cask at Oakham Brewery Tap, Peterborough. Black brown colour, beige foam head leaving lacing and aroma of dark malt, fruity hop. Taste is roasty malt, earthy, dark chocolate, coffee with alittle hop and ashy bitterness. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry roasty finish. Nicely drinkable.

Gravicask at the 23rd St Albans Beer & Cider Festival. Filmy layer, spotty lacing, almost black in the glass. Promising smell of roasted malts, hints of cocoa. Blended flavours of cocoa, coffee and dark dough. Roasted malty bitterness to the ending. Fine depth. Likable. (Shared with Finn, 27.09.2018).
A - citrus and chocolate A - dark with thick head T - sweet and sour with roasted and hoppy bitter P - mid to full and soft O - interesting

Cask at Battersea Beer Festival, 13th Feb 2009. Deep dark brown appearance. Chocolate & treacle nose, quite dry and tart on the tongue. Quite thin, closer to a mild than a stout porter, but good and drinkable.

A dark, chocolate brown beer with reddish tints and a thick beige head. A light nose, with some hop and a biscuity malt aroma. The taste is bitter, with plenty of dry hops that really overpowers. There is some smokiness towards the end. The finish is very dry. (Cask - The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).

Cask@The Magpie&Crown, Brentford, WLondon. Black colour, brown edges. Aroma is earthy and a little fishy. Don’t actually get too much out of the aroma. This doesn’t really taste that dark. Has some some light sweet caramel and then a minty menthol character, then a fishy character and then some chunder. Didn’t like this so much.
Cask @ Wenlock Arms, London. Pours a black colour with a tan head. Fruity hoppy aroma. Fruity malty and slightly hoppy flavor. Has a malty and hoppy, bitter aftertaste.

A Mes rate: St. Albans Beer Festival 2006. Quite unusual. Seems to be having an indentity crisis. Slightly smokey and just a little too mellow all round for me. I like my porters to have a little more guts than this. More hoppy than most and a rather bitter finish. Let down mre than anything by the thin mouthfeel

From notes, on tap at C'est What. Pours a reddish black with a nice creamy head. Aroma of mocha, coffee and sweet malts. Slight hazelnut in aroma. Flavour is sweet coffee, chocolate with slight hop bitter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPad

On nitro tap at C’est What?. Pours a clear black with a thin to medium sized beige head. Very intense aroma redolent with dark roast coffee. Tastes like coffee, only a bit thicker, with some light roast highlights and a big bitterness. Finishes with long roast bitterness. This would be even better if it wasn’t on a nitro tap.
draft at c’est what in toronto. jet black with nitrogen head, the aroma is smoky and coffee. it has caramel flavor that is fruity and creamy.

Draft at CW. Ruby tinged black body with thick creamy mocha head. Aroma of moch and cold coffee, moderate malt. Very muted hazelnut in aroma. Sweet, nutty coffee-mocha flavour, notes of hazelnut and chocolate round out the bitterness of the cofee and roast malts nicely. Average but quite smooth palate. This is quite tasty, and I much prefer this to the regular version since I am not a coffee lover. I expect I would enjoy this even more if I was.

Draught at C’est What. Ruby-brown with a medium sized creamy tan head. Aroma is fantastic, like hazelnut coffee laced with some bittersweet cocoa - yum! Mouthfeel is soft and creamy, thanks to the nitro. Flavour of fresh roasted coffee, sweet toasted nuts, and chocolate milk - a little mellower than the aroma suggests, but still very nice.

Draught. Dark brown with lighter edges and a creamy yellow head. The aroma is great - nice hazelnut, vanilla, chocolate, and maple. The flavour is roast and chocolate oriented with toffee and nut flavour - though not as prominent as in the aroma. It thins out to some extent in the finish.
On tap. Coffee flavour and aroma but I found it a bit weakish compared to the millstreet coffee porter, which i enjoyed more.

Tap. Dark brown with smallish creamy top. Light acidic, nutty, creamy coffee aroma well described by beer name. Chocolate front, soft medium, creamy coffee at end. Nutty character around. Think Tim Horton’s.

Rich roasted coffee aroma, and dark chocolate, deep brown, with a tiny tan head, wee bit of lace. Full dark chocolate flavour, lots of coffee too. Creamy smooth, very bitter, quite a pleasant offering. Really well done!

Cask. A dark amber beer with a thin buubly off-white head. The aroma has notes of caramel and fruit. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel, leading to a dry, alcoholic, and metallic finish.

Cask handpull, The Star, Bath. Bright copper under a thin white lid. Nose lightly vinous with strawberry, cherry and caramel. Watery coffee, dank biscuit, shampoo hop and mushroom finish. Dry and uncomplicated; milky coffee, umami, chestnut, leaves. I’m making it sound more exotic and interesting than it is. Drab.

Cask@St Albans BF 06. Quite malty, and felt a bit sticky to me.Slight raw malt notes come through, with some light citric, earthy hop notes in the finish. More grainy/malty characters come through and as i mentioned its a bit sticky aswell.
1. Cask Handpump at the Gardener’s Rest, Sheffield 08/10/2004 Golden amber in colour with some wheat grain flavour. Slightly bitter malt finish.

Cask (gravity dispense) at St Albans Beer Festival , September 2006. Very attractive, burnished copper colour. Light, softly malty aroma. Full bodied, with a quite fat mouthfeel and a touch of sweetness, but a decent amalgam of earthy malt and spicy hops produce a well-balanced overall impression.

Cask at Craft Beer Co. Pours a thick dark brown with a slight beige head. There is a heavy roasted malt and black coffee/dark chocolate aroma to this beer which is very inviting. A touch thin but also creamy and oily on the palate. It has a rich coffee taste and a lingering bitter roast malt aftertaste. A nice beer but a little one-dimensional. Satisfying and certainly not bad it just seems to be lacking another side to its character .

Cask (handpump) @ Fat Cat, 23 Alma Street, Sheffield, South Yorkshire, England S3 8SA. Clear medium to dark black color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, beigeto off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, burnt, prune, wood - tobacco. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and modrate to heavy bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20090418]
Cask@St Albans BF. Deep brown to black. Aroma is a little bacny. palate is thin and watery, with an annoying acidic quality. Light roasted malt flavours. Not a hell of a lot going on otherwise.

Cask (gravity dispense) at St Albans Beer Festival, September 2006. Named because Dr Feelgood were the music act on Saturday evening. Quite dark. Flat, dull mouthfeel. Rather sweet, but ashy at the same time. Didn’t taste too fresh or lively to me. Not a well put together beer.

[on cask at Beau’s Oktoberfest as "Wet Hop Bomb with Brampton Hops", 2012] Sweet caramel aroma with some weak, fruity hops. Clear copper under a bubbly, white cover. Well balanced sweet versus bitterness, but weak in general. Light to medium body, moderately bitter finish, moderate carbonation.

Cask at Vankleek Hill’s/Beau’s Oktoberfest (as Wethop Bomb). Clear orangeish straw with short lasting white head. Smell is herbs, hops, and hay. Taste is quite sweet, cereals. Light hopping. Somewhat herbal. Medium bodied. Somewhat disappointing...
lots of hops! wow! kinda skunky though. nice though, foggy straw color. its just a hop assault cask at c’est what

Cask. Foggy orange body with a small creamy white head. Creamy, cookie-ish aroma with strong orange hops and leafy notes. Raw grapefruit citrus hop flavour with underlying biscuit. Soft and chewy creamy palate. Quite drinkable.
Cask at c’est what. This is the second cask beer I have tasted from Black Oak ( the other one ive tried was Hop Bomb). A really unique tasting and well balanced beer, my favorite of the festival.
Cask. Fine haze, medium large creamy top. Aroma was quiet grassy, fresh green grapes and grainy finish. Creamy texture, very soft body. Grassy hoppy middle. Light grainy (raw) finish.

Cask at C’est What. Wow! Hops are upfront in the aroma and flavour, but are balanced just right. This was quite complex and very interesting flavour-wise, with a beautifully lingering finish. My favourite beer of the 18th Festival of Small Breweries in Toronto. Impressive stuff!

Cask. Big fresh leafy hops aroma, opaque yellow, nice foam retaining head.Flavour of hops are front and center, though less than the nose, fine malt backbone too.Very creamy, really well balanced, bitterness is just right. Great Session Ale. Well done Adrian and Ken!

Cask-conditioned at the Inn on the Green, Bristol 18/02/10. Golden in colour with next to no head. Sweet malt and citrus aroma with a hint of spicing. Flavour had ginger and coriander notes, before a sweetish, orange blossom hop finish. Ok.

Cask. Freshfield Hotel,Formby. Light golden colour with small white head. I’m struggling with both aroma and flavours. Citrus perhaps but also a vey noticeable fllavour which I am finding very hard to identify. Perhaps some grapefruit , more peach possibly but not really sure. Only to say I found it most agreeable. Subsequently drunk again last weekend @ the Freshie and decided taste was very much like Cumberland sausage!
Cask, The Criterion, Leicester. Pale gold with small head. Aromas are lemon meringue with lots of resinous grapefruit and citrus. Flavours are crisp grapefruit with lemon. Tasty, refreshing and good.

Cask conditioned at The Guest House, Southport. Pale gold with white head. Lovely lemony hops tothe for, rich and oily in character, dry bitter, citrusy with a touch of peach. Long bitter finish, great stuff. Re rate at The Turf Tavern, Oxford 28/08/09. Cloying sweetness, lime, overbearing.
Cask Stillage at Edgeley Park, Stockport 02/06/2007 Hoppy pale and slightly citrus aroma. Clear golden coloured and hoppy with some spice flavour. A little bitterness in a creamy finish.
Cask gravity at Pembury Tavern. Gold with disappearing white head. Odd chalky medicinal aroma. Bit herby. Not very pleasant at all. Ginger spice and horrid medicine is what I mostly got.

cask @ 2nd pembury festival. Pale gold. Sour smell of stale urine. It’s like walking down Southwark Bridge Road near Minstry of Sound on a summer night. Perhaps someone DID have a wee in it. Some people at the table had reached their expiry. Taste is miles better. Peach, pineapple, orange zest and grass. Light bitter finish. Not bad if you can get past the smell.
A Mes rate: Gravicask at the Pembury. Sweetish but generally hoppy and herbal. As with some other All Gates beers there is a clear note of ginger. Not bad but the ginger note just masks it a little.

Cask (gravity dispense) at St Albans Beer Festival, September 2006. Pale gold/amber colour. Fresh, grassy, herbal aroma, with hints of sulphur. Clean and dryish, with a fair amount of juicy fruit and noticeable resinous hop in the flavour. A decent early effort from a new brewery.
5th August 2009 Cask at GBBF. Pale gold beer, clear. Good lemon and nettles flavour without being too bitter. Finishes crisp. Refreshing.
VEry nice one, and a little sweet. The way I like the blondes. Not so goldy and nice features in it.

Cask conditioned at The Turf Tavern, Oxford. Gold with white head. Straight into a lemonade flavour initially ok but then an astringent ginger note and it really is heavy drinking, a struggle. Sweet and grainy, not a good combination of flavours.
Cask/gravity at GBBF 2009. Pours a dark gold with small head. Aroma of ginger and orange follows through into the palate, initially clean taste becomes slightly cloying.

Cask (handpump) @ The New Oxford, 11 Bexley Sq, Salford, Manchester, England M3 6DB. Clear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, fruity, moderate to light heavy ginger and soap. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to light heavy ginger bitter with a average duration, and a peppery - ginger sweet finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20090715]

Cask at The Friendship, Fallowfield. Looks gorgeous - light gold with thin, lasting white head. That’s the positives done. Awful flavour. I just can’t describe it. Something herbal and unpleasant. I left it half way down as I just couldn’t stand it any more. Too thin and no discernible aroma, either.
Cask, Sweet Green Tavern, Bolton. Golden yellow, fruity, christmas cake aroma. Flavour is too overpoweringly ginger for my taste, but if ginger is your thing, then this has obvious appeal.
Cask at GBBF 2007. A hazy golden beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with light notes of grass. The flavor is sweet malty with light notes of grass.

An original ale that looks a bit greenish around the edges of its clear golden hue. 1cm white topping. Nutty and fairly toasty considering its pale colour. Mysteriously flowery with almost no bitterness. Those aromas are quickly overtaken by sweet, direct, very grainy flavours that could use some balancing counterpower.

Cask @ GBBF 2007. Pours a plae yellow color with a large white head. Fruity malty and spicy ginger aroma. Fruity anf malty spicy flavor with hints of ginger. Fruity finish with a spicy citrus aftertaste.
Can 50 CL. Dark brown color with big foamy head. Roasted malts, nuts, metallic, coffee. Pretty thin. - beerbasher

500ml can from a supermarket in Kotka, 4.6% abv. Cola brown colour, medium frothy mostly lasting beige head, good lacing. Mostly malts in the aroma, cookie, toast, caramel and a bit of chocolate, hint of generic floral hops in the background. Taste is initially slightly sweet and acidic, turning into a moderately bitter and slightly burnt finish. Light to medium body, dry texture that turns watery as the carbonation dissipates, lively carbonation. Drinkable, albeit somewhat artificial-feeling but tastier than most supermarket lagers.

Beige head, some lacings, dark brown body. Mild aroma of roasted malt, faint hops and grass. Roasted malt, some syrup and some chocolate to the tongue. Fluffy feel in the mouth, a bit hollow to palate. And hollow finish, some chocolate malts though. 1/2L can, 4.6%. B@K-market Finland Kilpishalli & brought back home. Enjoyed@home with druzhyna Annya 2014JAN23. Tested 1/1 beer/cocacola light, almost as light traditional ale then.
500ml can. Malty, mild roast in aroma. Metallic, watery, caramel in flavor. Overall drinkable, but bit too watery.

Can from supermarket, ABV 4.6%. Dark brown color, beige head. Bittersweet taste with caramel, a bit of roasted malts, chocolate and nuts. Light body with mostly malts. Bittersweet finish with roasted malts and nuts. Decent, drinkable beer.

Dark brown to black/red with big frothy/creamy beige head that is medium long and leaves lacing. Bit roasted sweet aroma has licorice, some dried dark fruits, milk chocolate. Watery, thin feel, light body, low carbonation, mildly sweet, not much bitterness, not much flavor or finish, bit like Czech dark lager. Watery and thin and bit like diluted beer, not my cup of beer.
Can 0.5l from local market. Colour is almost black with brownish white head. Aromas and flavours are roastiness, caramel and malts. Surprisingly watery.
500ml can, thank Kr!. Dark brown, almost black color with beige. Aroma is roasted malt and sweet. Flavor is roasted malt, watery. Not bad but not great either.

500ml can, 4,6% Pours pitch black with a light head. Aroma has hints of malts and metallic notes. Taste is watery with hints of metallic notes and hints of malts. Finish has some mild notes of roastiness. Bulky, quite tasteless.

50cl can, 4,6%. Poured dark brown/black with a creamy beige head, quickly disappeared. Aroma has metal, roasted malt and sweet candylike notes. Flavor is roasted malt and lots of metal. Thin body. creamy mouthfeel. SImilar to Kozel dark, byt maybe sligthly less sweet, but instead more metal and watery.

275ml bottle from Shropshire. Vintage 1990. A little condition left attracting a ring of foam around the glass. A very dark beer. Quite a beefy aroma with some cardboard around the edges. Some cola flavours. More of a mild than an ale. Curious. Burton Ales tended to be dark and strong, this is dark and weak. Quite pleasant.
On tap at the brewery. Sweet malts and light herbal aroma. Cloudy, amber/yellow color, off-white head, fair lace. Light sweet, light herbal, light bitter, sweet flowing in the finish, soft.

A Sim Rate (cask at St Albans BF): Smells distinctly of chocolate-covered pretzels. Hops, wheat, salt. Flavour is particularly bitter with a bitter finihs. Great to smell but not very good to drink. Looks like a straight-down-the-line lager. No head. No lacing.
Cask/gravity at The St Albans Beer Festival 29 Sep 06. Labeled "Roman’s Load". Yellowish coloured. Hardly any head. Rich fruity aroma. Citric flavour. Sourish bitter finish. A bit dry. Unbalanced.

Also presented as Romans Load at the St Albans Beer Festival ’06. Half pint on gravity dispenser. Golden body with great clarity, but missing head. Citric smell and very fruity in the initial flavour. Abrupt, dry ending (29.09.2006).

A Sim Rate (cask at St Albans BF): It’s awful! Full of hops, sweaty feet and cheese. Quite a lovely combo for such a lovely beer. Bitter in the flavour. Unpleasant to sip. Thank you SO much for filling my glass past the half-pint line. You don’t realise in your generosity how much of a disservice you’ve done me.

A Sim Rate (cask at St Albans BF): Full hops aroma. Equally hoppy flavour, but at least it’s got a bit of guts to it. Has a tinge of hard liquor in the flavour. Looks like Mike’s Hard Lemonade - my first taste of alcopops. No head. No lacing. Quite standard for a british beer. Looks almost like a lager.

Bottle. Hops, ripe fruits and roasted malt in aroma. Dark brown colour with huge light brown head. Nice bitter hops flavour with grass, surprisingly for an imperial stout. Liquorice and malt in the end.
0.7 l bottle at Timo A’s tasting session. Hazy dark brown color with small vanishing head. Coffeish and yeasty aroma with licorice. Weird sour and roasty flavor with licorice, coffee and chocolate.

Bottle. [thank you, Myrup] Bottle opens with a loud fizz, lots of head pouring out. Pours deep near-black and the head in my glass is off-white, frothy and bubbly. Aroma is lightly fruity, liqourice, some viniousness. Okay mouthfeel. Flavour is lightly sour fruits (is that the point?) raisins, apples, lots of roasted malts, some chocolate. A dry, chocolate aftertaste, which is actually quite nice.
Black with small head.Light tosted aroma and taste of licorice and coffee but still mild long finish.Ad the Beerfest in Slagelse.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is licorice , vanilla, alcohol, mature apple. Flavour is mature apple, licorice, alcohol, vanilla, roasted, malt. Interesting beer.

Bottle. Dark, actually very dark brown body, but not black, topped by a dense, beige head. Dried fruits, a little sour note, vanilla, coffee and licorice in the aroma. Quite complex, but still not top notch. The flavor has a good dash of sweetness, followed by roasted malt and dried fruits. Full to medium body. The finish is sweet and with dried fruits. Kinda strange imperial stout, but nice. Could be interesting with more hoppiness in it. (070705)

700 ml bottle. Dark red/brown body with a beige head. Complex aroma of coffee, liquorices, chocolate, roasted malt and even some vanilla. Flavor is a harmonic mixtures of all the above indigenes. More like an experimental Christmas ale than Imperial Stout. I like it anyway. And it just looks perfect.

Dark brown, near black colored. Medium sized brown head. Strongly chocolaty aroma with roastiness and mild alcohol, some vinous tones also come up. Medium bodied. Flavor is also vinous with licorice and chocolate, still too sweet for being excellent. Mild vegetables in aftertaste with alcohol and sweet sugar.

Bottled. Murky and hazy brown colour with a rather small, longlasting head. Aroma is slightly roasted malts along with coffee and caramel. Flavour is pretty much the same, with some vanilla and licorace added.

Bottled 70 cl Dark brown color, small steady cappuchino head. Alcohol, woody hops and dark coffee in the nose. Roasted malts, licorice, a bit sugary, some vanilla - whisky barrel notes. More interesting than good, but anyway underrated here.

Cask at the Brewery in Manchester (August 07). Golden color with a slight tinge of red. Hoppy, fruity aroma with some citrus; very fragrant. Amazing fruit flavor; lots of citrus, but the overall effect is not sour. Good malt-slightly sweet but again with excellent hop balance. Fruity, hoppy finish.
Cask Handpump at the Crown Inn, Stockport 28/10/2006 Hop aroma. Clear golden coloured very hoppy and pale with some bitterness in a crisp and dry finish.
A Sim Rate (on cask at Marble Brew House): Lovely sweet flavour. Very citric. Very perfumy aroma. Chanel No. 5?

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Name: Stingin’ Brits India Pale Ale Date: 12/20/2006 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, Charlotte hazy amber, scant beige head, light malt aroma with only a hint of hops, good light hop flavor well balanced by lightly sweet caramel malt, nice light bitter finish, pretty light for an IPA, even an Engligh one -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Name: Stingin’ Brits India Pale Ale Date: 07/28/2007 Mode: draft Source: brewpub Charlotte Score: 2.8 to 3.3 clear dark amber, wispy beige head, streaks of lace, sweet munic malt aroma with lots of earthy hops, lots of bready biscuit malt flavor, lots of hop flavor, mild bitterness complements the hops and balances the malt, touch of sweetness completes the story, like an octoberfest turned into an IPA which makes for a very good rendition of the style and much better than last visit Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.3/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **+/4

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Summertime Brews Fest. Murky cloudy brownish orange. Not showing too much aroma. Or flavor for that matter. Mild in all respects. Not super.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: on tap-pours an off white head that laces with copper color. Aroma is faint malt, hops. Taste upfront is caramel malt, mid-taste the hops joins in. Less hops than expected.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Had a little bit better luck than the first guy... granted I was already half in the bag, but this was a reasonably good citrusy IPA with a nice hop bite to finish.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Draught during my NC brew tour. Pours dark red, strangely dark for the style. The aroma has much tamer hops than I would expect. It’s more of a medicinal, sweet scent. The flavor is also strange, not the hop profile I was expecting. It’s slightly leathery overall with hints of NyQuil. Some citrus bite stings ever so slightly in the finish. I didn’t enjoy this one.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Poured a cloudy orangish yellow. Aroma was non existent, very mild hops. Flavor was bland hops and stale malt.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Pours out a darker brownish orange color. Aroma was somewhat hoppy but more malty than any thing else. Flavor was less than hoppy. I was hoping for somehting much better than this was.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Sampled at the Charlotte Oktoberfest 2006. Draft pour from a steel cask. Beer was dark brown and there was not much of a head. Smell was slight hops and a little bit of sweet malty flavors. Taste is sweet and a little bitter, but without much carbonation. This is the first thing I have drank from a cask (to my recollection) and if thats any indication to how all of the cask beers are, Ill stick with the beers that are poured from bottles or kegs.
Tap @ ’t Arendsnest. Orange, yellow colored brew. Citric, yeasty aroma. Flavor is slightly sour, some bitterness. Apple, hops. Balanced brew.

Tap @ ’t Arendsnest. Aroma has citric hoppiness, bit flowery, some yeast. Hazy, yellow coloured with a lasting, white head. The taste is slightly bitter has some sweetness, is hoppy, citric and a little malty. well balanced and easy drinkable. Good brew.

A light hazed blonde ale with a thin creamy lacing white head. A pleasant hops aroma, citrusy, resinous. In mouth, a good biscuitty malt with good hops, grapefruits, pinhey hops. A medium bodied ale. Tasted more like an APA ut enjoyed it! On tap at Arendnest, Nov. 2006.
On tap @ Arendsnest. Nice dry hoppy and a bit citrussy and malty blond beer. Nice bitter finish.

On tap at ‘t Arendsnest, Amsterdam. Cloudy orange coloured, small to medium sized white head, fruity flowery nose. Fresh hoppy, biscuity malty and fruity with mild spicy yeasty notes. Pleasant lingering light bitter hoppy finish. One of the best Saison I’ve tried so far.
Draught (Arendsnest, Amsterdam) Sharp slightly citrussy aroma. Massive dry resiny bitter taste. Long bitter finish. Not as simple as an American I/APA. Earthy hops - some pepper finish.

On tap at ’t Arendsnest. Cloudy, deep golden with a small head. Rich fruity hop aroma. Delicious hoppy flavours, a hint of sweetness, matching grapefruit and apples hops. Very bitter, but refined. Good mouthfeel. A great blond beer.

Oct, 2007 On tap at ’t Arensnest the day after the marathon Fruity, yeasty Saison style pale ale. Some spice, some alcohol weight - yet light and easy to drink. Cascade hops give an APA feel. A firm pale ale. Gorgeous. [4.3]

Very cloudy orange beer covered by a slowly diminishing off-white head. The focus is clearly set over the hops. They are both grapefruity and floral, assumingly cascades again, this seems to have a growing popularity in the Netherlands. Aromatic and fresh, vibrant offering. Its biscuity malts offer a firm support that borders chewiness. Beautifully integrated from start to finish, frank and bright. Good!

Draught at Arendsnest Amsterdam. Frothy white fair mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Light malty powerfull hoppy aroma, americvan hopps for sure. Heavy bitter flavor. Long wellbalnced bitter finish. Oily palate. Good stuff.
Cask Conditioned at the Market Porter, Borough, London. Amber colour with a slight, frothy white head. Best described as tank water that grows on you. Next please.

Cask at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. 3.8 ABV. Hazy orange appearance with a low white head. Vegetal aroma with touches of candied pears and metal. Thin flavour of red apples, salad, and sugar in flavour with a harsh metallic bitter aftertaste.
(Cask at Oliver Twist, Stockholm) Label said 3.8%. Slightly shady copper color, small white head. Hoppy and bitter taste. Bitter aftertaste. Fruity scent. Rather light body.
[Cask at Akkurat] Hazy golden. Some light citric aroma. Some harsh licorice(?)- in the flavour. Really thin.
[Cask at Akkurat, Stockholm] Amber colour. Earthy, reallybig on soil with a harsh bitterness. Very watery with a bit of resin.

Cask@akkurat(3.8%). Deep golden colour, mediumsized white creamy head. Aroma of fruit, oak and slight honey. Flavour is honey, spices, wood and some candy. A bit grass also noteable. Pleasant and quite full cask, for having an ABV of 3.8%.
Cask@Akkurat, alc. 3.8%. Pale copper brown, small white head. Grassy, mild hoppy nose. Cut grass flavor - very intensive. Long grassy aftertaste.
Pale golden, white head. Citrus aroma. Thin citric flavor with some malty notes. Watery and not to my liking.
[Cask at Akkurat, Stockholm (board said 3.8%)] Amber colour. Vaguely piney nose. Plenty of wtaer and some caramel. Bold, but empty. Some resin but mostly void.
Cask conditioned at a Wetherspoons. Gold with white head. A pretty restrained, low impact beer, some hop note, quite malty, some fruit, hard to tell in a Spoons what its meant to be. Average.
Dark golden with a lasting white head. Arom a of grassy hops and caramel. Dry and malty flavour with a hint of smoke.

Cask @ GBBF 2008. Pours a pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty slightly hoppy aroma. Fruity malty hoppy bitter flavor. Has a malty hoppy bitter finish with some hints of citrus.

Cask @ Great British Beer Festival, GBBF 2008, Earls Court, London, England SW5. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, light to moderate hoppy, light to moderate yeasty, horse stable, peat - rubber. Flavor is moderate sweet and biter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. (060808)

Cask, third pint, early on a Thursday afternoon at GBBF 08. Pours a slightly unclear amber body with a thin, bubbly tophead. Notes of cowshed in aroma followed by a more or less decent grass-hoppy taste. Medium bodied (07.08.2008).
A Mes rate: gravicask at GBBF. Clean gold with a vanishing white head. Rather eggy and dull. Faint spice and yeast with some reasonable floral and citric hops in the finish.

(Cask at GBBF, London, 6 Aug 2008) Pale amber colour with brief, white head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of orange and apricots. Fruity, malty taste with biscuity malt, apricots and orange. Well balanced and refreshing, not really exciting though.
CFask@GBBF2008. Golden colour, small beige head. Aroma is mild wood, some yeast and mild notes of spices. flavour is blue cheese, some hops and yeast. Also some mild herbal notes.
Cask at GBBF 08. Clear gold with a spicy slightly sweet arom and a pronounced meaty note in the flavour. Strange stuff.
Cask at GBBF ’08. Gold. Faint malt aroma. Grassy hops present. Mid bitter finish. Amiable beer, quite acceptable, but uninspiring.

Antrunk schön mild-hefig. Der Hauptteil ist leicht süßlich-malzig, insgesamt aber ziemlich neutral. Im Nachgeschmack kommt noch eine kleine Herbe dazu, auf der Zunge bleibt eine säuerlich-malzig-herbe Note zurück. Das Bier ist schön süffig, aber irgendwie nichts Besonderes.... Test vom 21.5.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,11,12,9,12,10 - 10,60

It’s unclear brown with a huge, creamy head. The aroma has mild notes of caramel, wheat and light yeast. The sweet flavor has notes of caramel, yeast, wheat and light fruit, and the finish is slightly spicy. Quite nice dunkles weizen...
chocolate, floral, dough, rotten eggs, alcohol, amber, sparkling, minimal head, frothy, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness, salty, medium body, soft carbonation,

Mocha brown, cloudy wheat, with little foaming. Smell yeasty-sour. Starts slightly acidic, very pleasant and drinkable. A slightly malty and sour note is noticeable. The further course shows some sweet-malty aromas, also some roasted malts. Successfull Dunkelweizen!

Screw-cap bottle. Chestnut-amber cpoloured, mid-sized, stable off-white foamy layer. First impression: dark berries in the nose, second impression - when it gets warmer - : wheaty fruitiness with a delicate maltiness underneath. Moderate sweetish-sourish flavour. Light hints of appels in the fruity and wheat-malty finish. Not bad, but tastes nearly like a Hellweizen...............

Bottle, 5.1%. Sweet malt aroma. Fat banana, perhaps butter, but not bad. Muddy brown colour. Stable tan head. The flavour is sweet and malty, some butter in the good way. High carbonation, slightly citric.
Bottle. Banana, clove, and toffee malt aroma. Cloudy orange-brown color with large tan head. Very light orange and toffee malt flavor. Extremely watery palate. Not much to this one.
Bottle. Sourdough and clove aroma. Murky brown,low lacing brown head. Bready and nutty base, Franconian spicyness, fairly light body, sparkly mouthfeel. Bready aftertaste.

Can. Light aromas of grain, herbs, dough and a faint hint of cinnamon. Head is small, creamy, white with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is sparkling clear amber. Flavor is lightly sweet and light to moderately acidic, then finishes lightly bitter. Palate is light to medium, watery and has a soft carbonation. An average tasting beer, I guess true to style for an American Pale Ale.
Didn’t notice this was Gluek or I would not have bought it. I got sucked in by the packaging and price. $5.50 a 4 pack. "OK" and drinkable but would not buy again.

Dark gold body with a slightly off white head. The aroma is like unrisen bread dough a little bit of dandelions. The mouthfeel is lightly carbonated. the taste is slightly burnt sweet apple pancakes with some rotting grapefruit. The finish is a little bit citrus, but also earthy sweat. This is not too bad, but I would definitely not try again.

Found a four-pack box of these on the floor at the Polish market. Pours an amber/copper color. Not much of a head unless you give it a hard pour. Husky grain malt aroma with some fruitgum and a touch of caramel and soap. Cereal/grainy malt flavor with underlying fruity esters and some mild grassy and citrusy hops at the end. Has an overall metallic tone. Medium bodied, little carbonation. Could actually work well if drunk straight from the can at a tailgate or something. Otherwise nothing special.

Can from BevMo online. Medium golden in color upon pouring. Malty aroma with a splash of hoppiness. A little bit of yeast and root beer as well. Somewhat bready malty flavors up front. Hop character seems a little sour. Tastes more like beer than most Glueks.

473ml can (thanks to Joe Sixpack). Slightly hazy, golden brown body under a frothy, white head that slowly fades away. Firm malty aroma. Pale malt flavoured water with a hoppy note. Finish off with a hints of sourish vegetables. Missing tail. Smooth mouthfeel. Not a great drink, but my best n/a so far (15.01.2008).
Corn malt and a little hops on the nose. Similar taste. By far the best Gluek product I’ve tried.

Going out on a limb, I didn’t know what to expect with this and figured it would be pretty bad. However, it was actually moderately good. I don’t know baout the bubble blurbon the package, but this did have a very nice, thick, lasting white head that left good lacing, on an amber body. The aroma and taste were mild but definitely present and generally good, with a mild yeats, biscuit aroma. The taste is mild malt, biscuit, a hint of sweetness and a hint of biterrness, generally smooth, drinkable & refreshing if fairly bland.

above average pale ale, very refreshing. very little head. creamy caramel taste with little floral hop bitterness. not sure why they make such a big deal on this being a draught style - "open the can and millions of tiny bubbles release" - well, that’s just beer in a can. bought at bev mo in sunnyvale, ca

Poured pretty nice with a thick frothy head. The color was dull amber and opaque. The smell was very malty and sweet--it was hard to detect the hops or ID this as a pale ale. Taste was pretty dry and flat. It wasn’t nearly as malty as it smelled but definitely was primarily caramel and sweet. The palate’s actually pretty good too. This is the best beer I’ve ever had that Gluek made--which isn’t saying much. However, I would drink this again.

cask delivered by gravity at the Maltings 14th Annual Beer Festival, York: Yellow with a tinge of orange. Initial aroma is dusty earty hops and some toffee. Initial flavor is toffee with eathy hop backround. finished with more dusty hops then toffee. Not impressive

A big thanks goes out to CanIHave4Beers for the chance to taste this beer. Brownish hazy brownish orange color. Thin alabaster head. Some choco-malt inthe aromatic volatile sweetish lager aroma. Nice label on this 16 oz can. Almost heller or something in the aroma and taste. Quite beery in every aspect. Finsih is a bit sweet and perhaps not cloying nor syrupy. Not bad overall. Good beer in a can.

A little shocked this beer is only ranked in the 10th percentile, I even drank it head to head with Surly Bender and while it pales in comparison to that brew I would not say it is 83 percentage points worse. A little too over carbonated and a strange palate to it, but not a terrible brew all in all.

Carmel, grape and pear nose. Creamy head dissapears in about a minute. Leaves nice natural lacing. Tastes like t smells. For 4.25 for 4 pints. This aint a bad beer. Best I have had out of the brewery. I will buy again. Nice fridge stuffer.

160z can: The whole "Pub Pints" angle seems a bit gimmicky. I cut the can open after pouring to look for some sort of "widget", but the can is empty. The beer does poor with an initially thick and healthy beige head, but it settles rather quickly as you begin to drink. The nose is sharp, almost tart, with alot of CO2 it seems. Eventually it settles and mild hints of caramel and esthery plum come forth. The body has a nice, creamy mouthfeel and is medium bodied. Notes of sweet caramel, honey and nuts are abound. Easy to drink and finishes just sweet enough to leave me wanting more. I kind of like this for a session brew, although the "extreme carbing" ruins the nose. Oh well, still a good drinker.

16oz can. Poured clear reddish-orange with a short cap of off-white/beige head. The aroma picked up sour fruit skins with caramel and nutty notes way in the background.. not good. The flavor was also marred by persistent fruit skin sourness and acidity.. caramel and some dark fruity sweetness come through on the back-end, and is almost decent for a split second.. this finishes very metallic, sour, and tacky. Light-bodied with higher carbonation.. sour, ugly, and lingering feel at the end. The worst part may be that being "light-struck" is ruled out b/c of the can, and I think this is a fresh batch.

Can purchased at the New Pioneer Co-Op in Coralville, IA. Dark orange amber body with a light kahki coloredv head. Smells of caramel and hot cream of wheat cereal. The taste has some light toffee and iced black tea. There is just a little bit of pear core in the finish. This is drinkable but certainly not pleasurable.

Medium head with a huge smell of chocolate and sweet malt. Nice full body and it delivers on the sweet malt and chocolate preview. There is a bit of metallic taste? I could accidently drink too many of these.

Pours amber with lasting tan head, looks good, smells of alumminum, very sweet, malty and slightly hoppy, this is one of the worst beers i have tasted, the only reason i gave it an overall 5 and not a 1 is because it looks pretty. I had to pour it out have way through.

Can poured a clear brown with a small lasting light tan head. Aromas of carmel. chocolate, light fruitiness and a hint of nuts. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of carmel and light fruitiness with a crisp clean finish. A verey disapointing beer!

22-May-07 (16 oz can: Purchased at BevMo in La Jolla, CA) I was prepared to say, "This isn’t THAT bad," but after just one sip, yes, it really is that bad. When first taking each sip, the beer is lightly sweet, fairly sugary, caramely and somewhat toasty, certainly not great quality here, but its drinkable I suppose. But as soon as I swallow, those flavors disappear and the mediocrity take a hard nosedive. The palate-torturing aftertaste is metallic, papery and tart and leaves me with cottonmouth. Light-medium bodied, mostly an impression created by the sugar, finishing thin and watery. Brown sugar, acidic earth and sauerkraut in the nose. Amber-brown in color with only a slight haziness. Small, light-tan head fades to a small ring, leaving no lacing. Pretty awful stuff, especially the atrocious aftertaste which is one of the worst I can remember.

(Gravity) No head. Very dark brown. Roasted scent with a hint of sugar. Some fizziness. Dry finish. In the mouth, it’s mainly smoke. Not unpleasant, but there’s little sign of the raspberries, just a slight sweetness after the smoke, revealing some cherry tartness.

Cambridge Fest. A mildly roasty and slightly milky stout. A pleasant drink, though there is no raspberry flavour, and - indeed - very little impact all round. Rather more full bodied and creamy than a mild. Slips down nicely, but leaves little impression.

Cask at the Maltings, York. Deep black with ruby highlights in the light - beautiful. One finger, small-bubble brown creamy head. Aroma is a bit slight - roasted malt, slight sweetness, a bit of tartness from fruits. Taste is nice, and surprisingly so. Roasted notes mix with milk chocolate and a light, very nice fruit note that lightens things up. Not in-your-face raspberry by any means - this could be any berry, or dark fruit, perhaps. Slight hop presence, with a moderately bitter, roasted malt aftertaste. Flavors overall are subdued but meld well together. Oh, and just the slightest, nearly imperceptible band-aid off-taste to it - glad I got a pint when I did. Palate is creamy, very little carbonation but enough to tingle the tongue ever so slightly. A treat.
Cask at Cambridge Winter Beer Festival. Ruby,black beer. Roast flavours dominate, no detectable raspberries, but pleasant enough.

Cask (handpump), Market Porter, Southwark, London, January 2007. Lets get one thing straight at the outset. I didn’t really pick up too much in the way of raspberry. Perhaps my nose was having a bad day. Elements of tart indeterminate fruit in the palate - yes. Raspberry - no. And, however, you look at it, I think that has to be regarded as a shortcoming in a beer with "Raspberry" in its name. Conversely, whilst this was predominantly dark brown in colour, there was a very noticeable red (dare I say raspberry?) tinge. There’s a good solid malt backbone - firm, if not heavily roasted and some bitterness propping up the finish. Certainly not a powerful stout and, no doubt, not intended to be. But, without a great depth of fruit, it ends up seeming just a little meek and slight. None of this is to suggest its a bad beer. I just think an extra punnet or twenty of raspberries would liven things up enormously.

Cask handpull at Market Porter, Borough. Deep ruby colour with thin beige head. Nice stout. Bit thin in mouth, but the raspberry fruit is nice, bit like raspberry ripple chocolate ice cream. Dark choc on aroma, choccy ice cream in mouth. Raspberry tingle on finish. Icy. Lacks a bit of fullness, but I like the choccy/raspberry flavours.

Cask Close to black but with beautiful ruby highlights; small brownish-pink head. Stout-like, liquorice nose, a bit like coaled wood. Very little fruityness or sweetness in the nose. Here we have a good balance: classical roasted stout flavours are mildered without becoming really sweet (let alone fruity). Only retronasal the raspberry starts to give an impression - as if from artisanal Italian raspberry ice cream. Medium bodied, no burning, very good balance. I’m pleasantly surprised - and a lot of other tasters were too.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Malt Shovel Northampton. A black coloured beer with abeige coloured bubbly head and a little pink scum around the edge. The aroma is a little roasty and a tiny bit fruity. The fruit comes through better in the taste, but it is again no more than hinted at. The base stout beer though, is very smooth and drinkable with good dark malt flavours, a little chocolate and a nice long finish. An accomplished well-balanced beer.

cask delivered by gravity at the Maltings 14th annual beer festival, York: black with ruby color at the bottom. Roasted nose with some tobacco and faint bit of raspberry. Flavored is roasted but dominated by tobacco notes. Very little raspberry in the backround. Medium Palate. Nothing Great

Sampled at Augusta Festival. This poured with some amber hues and just a little foam. Clear. There are light spices in the flavor and aroma. Soft malts that included a bit of caramel and a hint of grain. This is light fare.

Sample from beerfest in Augusta. Going off notes. Amber pour with a tiny white head that was gone within seconds. Aroma was malts, caramel, candies and sugar. Flavor was bready, malty and caramel. Thinner and kind of weak. Stronger malty aftertaste. Average to above average at best.
Tap - not much head, medium copper color, sweet malty aroma and flavor with mild nuttiness

Sampled at the Artisans Craft Beer Festival 2012. It poured a clear golden color with a medium off-white head. The aroma was of nuts, grain, and some caramel. The taste was of nuts, honey, caramel, and grain.

On tap at the brewery<!-- p --> Clear amber with a thin off white head. The nose is your typical octoberfest with malts and grains. No hop character really. The taste is soft with some more malts and what I see as earthy tones with just a hint of copper. Very drinkable and enjoyable.

Cask (gravity dispense) at St Albans Beer Festival, September 2006. Golden amber colour. From the name I expected some US hop influence but I can’t say I found it too much in evidence. Seemed like a fairly straightforward bitter to me, with light spicy hops and a little dry malt. Tasted more like a regular best bitter than a stronger beer.

cask delivered by gravity at the Maltings 14th annual beer festival, York: Amber color, with small white head. Sweet buttery aroma with matly elements. Buttery malty taste. Not enjoyable. medium palate.
Cask at the Three Guineas, Reading. Straw with a thin white head; citrus aroma; sweet, zingy, grapefruit flavour with a grainy body; deely bitter and fruity finish. Refreshing.
Cask (Gravity) in hotel room Sheffield (RBESG 2009). Golden amber color. One of the many average golden/blonds that we had during RBESG 2009

[bottle] Slightly sulfury popcorn aroma with some sweet base malt. Anemic straw appearance with a white ring. Light base malt flavour with moderate bitterness. Weak and mineral watery. Light body, moderate carbonation, moderately bitter finish.
Cask in the Market Porter. Alround rating: Sweet pale malts, a bit nutty, floral hop doesnt really balance, on the sweet side. Acht not my bag.

Bottle 50cl. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, moderate to light heavy hoppy, grass, dry hop flowers, hop - urinal alike. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to light light heavy bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20090719]
Cask (Gravity) in hotel room shefiled... amber ... odd lemon some banan nose ... sweet light bitter lemon.
Cask @Northampton Beer Festival, 2009. Golden beer with a lightly hopped and caramel aroma. The flavour is dry, caramel and hopped. Overall a nice hopped beer.

Bottle. Golden and bright with a small white head. Aromas are biscuit malts with lots of sweet hops. Quite lager-like with some addictive saltiness. Flavours are biscuit malts with peppery, spicy hops. Has a good fruity bitterness. Dry on the finish. A decent crisp bottle conditioned ale.

Cask at the Maltings 14th Annual Beer Festival, York: Lovely aroms of citus, earthy and dusty hops. Loads of good grapefruit and citrus flavors. Nice balance with the pale malt, but this beer definitely show off the hops more. Bitter as you finish. Beautiful lacing. Medium Palate. Yummy brew

cask at the Maltings 14th annual beer festival, York: Golden color with white cask head. Aroma is a mix of floral hops and citrus. Malt is more pronounced then most golden ales and balances nicly with the flavors of the floral and citrus hops. fruity and crisp. bitters towards finish but still remains lots of malt flavor. The most balanced golden ale I’ve ever drank. Quite nice.

Draught at the Tahquamenon Brewery, Tahquamenon Falls, MI. Cloudy golden color with a tiny off-white head. Wheat, dryness and sweet malt in the aroma. Yeast, wort, wheat and sweet malt in the flavor. Not quite ready? ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a bubbly hazy golden yellow with a thin head. Aroma is light wheat malts, and so is the flavor. Light body, plenty of carbonation. Not much going on.

Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass at the brewpub. The appearance had a decent bronzed amber color with a fairly decent transparency about it to leave some carbonation rising in the body. The head was there and it had about a finger’s worth and ended up barely any lacing about it. The smell had some light wheat to grainy breadiness overcoating a decent apple - like substance. The taste was mainly sweet and allowed a decent apple quality in the aftertaste. On the palate, this one sat about a light on the body. The sessionability is somewhat there but also has a carbonation that seemed okay for the style and to me. Overall, I say this was a fairly good beer worthy of having again.

On tap at the brewpub. Pale yellow colour. Difficult to get a real good impression from the tiny taster provided - no sampler trays at this brewpub (with only three beers available there wouldn’t be much point anyway) and I sure wasn’t going to have a whole pint. Clean enough but lacking in flavour and body. But that’s pretty much the style I suppose. Inoffensive but uninspiring stuff. Not sure I could have distinguished this from the Lumberjack Lager in a blind tasting.

Pour of pale golden, clearish, with a frothy white head and little visible carbonation. Aroma of wickingly sweet off-malt, with stinky corn sugars. Flavor was similiar with some bizarre artifical flavor of some sort, with peach pits, candied bananas and tangy bubblegum. Not real pleasing, but not too gross. Whatever. Light and kind of drinkable. Blah. Carbonation was a distant percolation. Not really there either. Ugh.
cask at the Maltings 14th annual beer festival, York: very light yellow color. Aroma is floral hops. balanced. very watery. Some citruss and eathy tastes. Nothing to brag about. Pretty Boring

This was 2012 version, so 4-years old, on tap at Craft Heads on the occasion of their 7th anniversary. Poured nice and dark, formidable beige head. Aroma had some cocoa, bitter chocolate and also a decent cupful of roast. Wow! I think this beer has only benefitted from the age, feels like its peaking at the moment. Flavours have blended nicely but by all means have not faded - crisp roast character with shiny biter chocolate and toffee sweetness. Impressed!

"An overlooked (given the awesomeness of Night Rider(S) right after) tasty american IS. Roasty, hoppy beast, with some fainter chocolate and coffee in the background. Big bodied, but medium next to NRider."
Black color with tan sheen. Chocolate malt shake, deep roast, coffee aromas. medium body. Very nice deep roast malt, milk chocolate, earthy flavors. Super smooth finish.
Sweet, roasty aroma. Poured black in color with a strong head. The sweet/roasty notes carry through the taste with a good hop finish. Notes: GABF ’09
On tap at Carlsblad. A good stout, though not a RIS. Way above average roast, too much roast. Dark brown, lacey. Overcarbonated. Drinkable, tasty.

Growler thanks to JohnnyJ. Pours a clear deep brown with a brown head that lasts throughout the beer. Aroma is full of roasted malts with some coffee and dark grains with a hint of dark chocolate. Flavor begins with chocolate and deep sweet grains with a strong roasted malt finish that was bitter.

(Draught) Pours an opaque black body with a medium cream head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, toasted/burnt grains, and citrus. Flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, coffee, nuts, and some earthiness with a dry, bitter finish.
Cherries, coffee, dark chocolate, wood, earth, brownies in the nose. Intense. Well balanced lots of dark chocolate and rostiness in the mouth. Alcohol very well hidden. Long roasty bitter finih.

On tap at Stone Bistro. Pours black with a creamy tan head that left nice lacing. The nose is chocolate, coffee and hops. The taste is citrus hops, cocoa and coffee with some resin in the finish. Lots of hops in this one. Semi-creamy mouthfeel. Tasty.

on tap at pizza port carlsbad. pours an oily, jet black with a thick, creamy, khaki head and thick lacing. aroma is awesome, reminds me of GI Nightstalker, with big, green, piney hops and orange zest backed by roasted malt, dark chocolate, and hints of black coffee. flavor is great as well, like a cocoa dusted orange, with big pine esters, roast coffee, dark chocolate, and light wood on the back end with a long, bitter, roasted finish. palate is full bodied and smooth with light carbonation and slick on the swallow. overall, a damn tasty impy stout.
Tap at the brewery. Pretty shit aroma smells like Carlton draught. Real rough rusty aroma. Taste is malty with not much else going for it. Average ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A very authentic Oktoberfest style beer. Clean, malty (toasty) and easy drinking. Only the lightest caramel sweetness which is a common fault in these beers (IMO). This place brews some real gems from time to time. Had a litre of it yesterday which led to a nice sleep on the couch when I got home.

First though this was an coppery amber body but up against the bock it was yellow/dull golden colour with a short lasting head. Not a lot of aroma. Caramel in the taste at first then a small dose of resiny hops, medium body and sticky finish, not my style, probably easy enough to drink plenty of for the Octoberfest.
Cask by handpump at Bon Accord, Glasgow (14 May 12) - clear deep gold ale, thin white head, floral hop aroma, good temperature, citrus, berry fruit, high carbonation, bit watery, bitter aftertaste

Cask at the Hobgoblin, Reading. Amber with a fast fading white head; earthy malt aroma; thinly bodied with a light citrus flavour supported by earthy malts and caramel; the finish is dry with a touch of pepper.

Cask at 5th English Rose Beer Festival, Luton, Bedfordshire. Gold with a white head. Not much aroma at first, then it suddenly disclosed a burst of old fashioned toasted malt. Unusual taste: I can only say it was cloying without being sweet. Concentrated grape juice perhaps. Some dryness at the finish. Strange stuff - quite rewarding.

Cask. At Market Porter, Borough. Pale gold with an average white frothy head. Dry, leafy, slightly sweet aroma. The taste follows - dry, a little sweeter, quite grassy - mild, no alcohol. Light body, a little astringent, quick-finishing; pretty characterless, and extremely light.

Cask gravity @ Reading Beer Festival 2008. Clear medium yellow color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, celler, light yeasty, earth. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is flat. (030508)
A Mes rate: Gravicask at Reading Beer Festival. Bright gold with a thin white film. Grassy, appley, young and pretty bad. Out of order.
Another malty ale, hops are there. Pleasant enough and not "another" hoppy summer ale.
Dark brown clear colour with poor head and lacing. Smoky malt hop aroma. Malt hop slight smoky flavour. Smooth palate.

Very cloudy straw coloured body, average lasting head. This beer reminded me of the ’’Belgian Ice" at the Indian Ocean Bar although the orange characters don’t stand out as much in this. Some aroma of mushy banana. Zesty, medium body, cloves, yeast and the alcohol is hiding waiting to get you. One of the better beers that Mash have done or was it just that I had a couple prior to this.
From the archives: 9 years ago. Found it pictured. Actually was drinking it for some time. Remember it as an OK alternative to A Le Coq pilsner.
Pale yellow of color with a white head. An aroma of vegetables, butter and hay. A flavor of butter, grass and bitter.
(Bottle). Strange aroma and flavor with some hints of sour malt and perhaps citrus? Actually a really disgusting beer!
500ml bottle. Pale yellow color. Hop extract, malty and buttery in aroma. Cardboard, malty and caramel in taste. Sourish fizzy carbonation. Doesn’t make me drunk.
Bottle. Pale gold color, medium sized foamy white head. Hoppy bulk-lager-esque aroma. Very watery, bland bulk-lager flavor. Light carbonation, very light body. No thanks.
Light yellow colored, little white head. Estery and lemony aroma. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is also sweet and lemony, some unclean cardboardy tanginess in aftertaste. Carbonated palate.
Faint aroma of yeast. Almost white colour, not much of a head here. Not much initial taste, but quite bad finish. Tasted worst than I expected.
Bottled. Pale yellow, very small head. Sweet corn-malty and faint grassy aroma. Metallic, harsh, taste of sweetcorn. No hops found.
Bottled. Pale yellow colour, minor white head. Metal, hops and malts in aroma. Flavour of nothing. Weak malts. This was not too exciting...

[Cask at The Three Judges] Pale gold colour with a medium dense head. Nose of apricot, citrus fruit and perfume, like parma violets, some dusty yeast character. Light and parma violetish on the palate, not thin despite the low abv. with a dry finish.

column1: Lake Louie Kiss the Lips IPA
column5: Bottle. It pours a dark gold with a quickly disipating white head and minimal lacing. The aroma is citrus, pine and some caramel maltiness. The taste has a light skunky aftertaste. The bitterness level is moderate. It is an ok IPA but nothing special.festival

column1: Lake Louie Kiss the Lips IPA
column5: 12oz bottle picked up at Best Western in Madison Pours clear dark golden with a medium sized off-white head, good lacing. When I cracked the tip I could smell skunky beer. But after I got it in a glass it mellowed out some but it's still skunky. The flavor is better, pale malts, wet grains and resin Old school bitter ipa.

column1: Lake Louie Kiss the Lips IPA
column5: 12 oz bottle from backlog. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have pale malts, light caramel, citrus and some earthy hops, mild plus bitterness, fairly soft ipa.

column1: Lake Louie Kiss the Lips IPA
column5: 12oz bottle pours a mostly clear gold with a ring of white head. Nose has orange, some tomato, passion fruit, hand soap. Flavor is boozy and spicy, some habanero, pink peppercorn, pine. Finishes a bit hot. What is this?

column1: Lake Louie Kiss the Lips IPA
column5: Clear, pale gold, small, creamy, white head. Light bitter. Creamy citrus fruits, sherbet lemon, tropical fruits, mango, passion fruit, soft carbonation, medium bitter and dry finish. Beautiful IPA, somewhat weak in the aroma, but plate is an explosion. Keg at The Old Fashioned, Madison, WI.

column1: Lake Louie Kiss the Lips IPA
column5: Draft. Moderate orange candy and lemon aroma. Taste is moderately bitter orange candy flavored bitterness pithy. For me it is a tad too sweet and need more hop flavor

column1: Lake Louie Kiss the Lips IPA
column5: A little watered down, and a more malted IPA rather than refreshing and bitter

column1: Lake Louie Kiss the Lips IPA
column5: Bottle poured a clear amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of bread, earthiness and light pine. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of bread, earthiness and a hint of pine with a crisp dry moderately bitter finish.

column1: Lake Louie Kiss the Lips IPA
column5: Bottle into a tulip. Deep cloudy, brown gold with an ample tan head, rather large bubbles. Deep malty, molasses notes, some piney resin, lighter citrus, some floral notes. Bitter, quite tangy. Deep back of the mouth sweetness predominates through the finish. Hint of spice. Medium body, very acidic. Touch of carbonation, though the acidity keeps it lively. Reasonably clean, quite chewy. Decent.

column1: Lake Louie Kiss the Lips IPA
column5: Bottle. Hazy golden body with a frothy white head. Aroma of citrus, pineapple, pine. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Some floral and resin notes emerge in the taste, but mostly citrus in the form of grapefruit rind and bitter lemon peel.

Cask-conditioned at the Cross Hands, Winterbourne Down, S Gloucs 26/7/07. Impressive gold colour with a white head which left lacing all the way down the glass. Aroma was hoppy with some spruce and flowers. As mentioned below, the flavour started with biscuit malt before a very dry finish. Very enjoyable.

Hand-pulled at the altar. Brilliant gold clarity with a tint of green. Admirably bitter, but far too lean and lagery for the style. A chew of pencil. Licking that freshly polished table again. Too much biscuity malt for an IPA. Very little in the way of lacework. Underwhelming, high quality hoppy lager.

[Cask at The Three Judges] Pale gold colour, medium dense head. Nose is Dominated by hops, floral, pine with some epach notes and some catramel malt in the background. Medium bodied with a good dose of bitterness in the finish.

750 ml bottle and previous samples. Thanks Ted. Burnished gold body with steady jets of carbonation and a full, frothy white head. Nicely conditioned aroma with notes of dough, pineapple, orange peels, and light spicy phenols. Full flavored with significant attenuation, which accentuates some substantial cutting bitterness. Some of the early fruity esters receded and allowed this to come together nicely.
Bottle courtesy of Zuchinicat. Pours a semi cloudy orange with a fizzy white head. Smells of citrus, sugar and malt. Taste is lightly bitter with a nice pilsnery finish.

Multiple samples, GABF 2006. Body is clear light yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain, cereal), lightly hoppy (flowers), with notes of chamomile and DMS. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Nose is somewhat raw, simple. Ok balance, but not very interesting.
Pour is clear golden yellow with a thin white head...lemony wood and grain aroma, slight funk...sweet grainy flavor with hints of funk...

GABF 2006. Pours to a glowing yellow gold body with a thin white head. The aroma is banana’s foster. Lots of tart wheat going on. Sweet confusing yeasts and wheats. The palate is tart, good wheaty feel. A mess, however.

on draft at GABF. Golden pour small white head. Aroma is mostly wheat and not much else to really distinguish it. Pal was pretty avg. Flavor is belgian yeasts some ligth bananna bread defeinate wheat notes, almost hefe like. Ok beer.

A dark, coper brown beer with a reddish tint, topped by a thickish off white head. The nose is light, only a tiny hint of malt, coffee and caramel. The taste is smooth, if a little watery on the mouth, burnt sugar, coffee and a sweetish cereal-like flavour comes through, the finish is quite weak. (Cask - The Fox & Hounds, Heachan, Norfolk).
[Cask at The Three Judges] Dark amber, moderate head. Caramel, toffee apples, floral notes, faint burnt aroma. Medium body, dry hoppy finish.
cask at the Maltings 14th annual beer festival, York: Sweet Malt Aroma with hops in the background. Buttery Toffee flavor, with not much bittering. medium palate. Not very enjoyable
