cask at the Maltings 14th annual beer festival, York: Aroma is of citrus, dusty, and earthy hops. Sweet malt is also in the nose. light golden and amber colored. Very balanced flavor. better than average golden ale. light palate.

column1: BJ's Smokin in the Monks Room
column5: Draft...GABF ’06... This beer rocks!...Clear amber ale with a mid-sized, creamy, khaki head. Terrific retention. Smells like a marriage of smoked malt (bacon), caramel malt and dark raisins. The flavor is mildly tangy, lightly smoky, gently sweet and a little fruity (banana & pear). Medium-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Tangy, smoky finish. World class experiment!

column1: BJ's Smokin in the Monks Room
column5: GABF 2006. From BJs Portland location. Pours to a glowing amber body with a lasting tan head. The aroma is strangely smokey malt. The flavor is a smoked malt and light banana. Moderate palate, alcoholic.

column1: BJ's Smokin in the Monks Room
column5: Light brown color thick tan well laced head. light smoky aroma wheats and light carmel malts. Palate is well coated lightly creamy w/ nice carbonation. Flavor is odd and nice.. light smoky burnt grains a good sweet carmel kick and a warm swallow. Pretty good.
Three brews at Bell’s, differentiated only by the hops. They tasted completely different. This one had a nice balance with a crisp hop flavor, lots of yeast.

Draft sampler at the Eccentric, 12/2/06. The premise here is that they’re making a series of pale ales named for U.P. towns. This one’s blond in color, with a light malty nose. A ring of foam in the taster. Good malts at the start, then nicely hopped. A bit of yeast shows that it’s unfiltered, but it still looks nice and clear.
Sampler @ Bell’s Eccentric Cafe: Pours a clearish yellow color, little head, white, lasting. Very wheaty aroma, malt. Very malty, nutty, dusty, almost acidic, some hoppy. Fizzy, creamy mouthfeel.

Draft at brewpub Cafe. One of the reasons I like to go to brewpubs is to test new offerings, this is one. Poured hazy copper color with an average fizzy white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate complex sour citrus aroma. Medium body with soft carbonation. Light bitter flavor with a light smooth bitter finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable beer.

column1: Rock Bottom Des Moines Ménage a Trois
column2: West Des Moines, Iowa, United States
column5: GABF 2006. I didn’t write down much about this beer to enter it. That being said, it poured to a brassy caramel colored body with a thin white head. The aroma is bourbon cereal. The flavor is cereal, vanilla, tart bourbon. Not really all that special, but it tastes pretty decent. Alcoholic palate.
bottle bb 28/3/19 leggermente dorato limpido abbastanza frizzante succo mela zuccherato poca pera

50cl bottle at home, bought at De Slijterij, Borger. Appearance: crystal clear light straw with no head. Aroma: pear and white wine. Taste: high sweetness and low bitterness. Notes of pear and some white wine. Palate: light bodied, watery texture and lively carbonation.
Bottle @ my birthday shared with benzai.. No head. Clear golden colour small carbo.. Smell some fruity some sweetness little pear.. Taste pear sweetness. Basically pear juice with alcohol..
Bottle shared by Thompson. Clear golden color, quickly disappearing white head. Smell and taste pear, sweetness, lightly sugar. Oh well, a nice drinkable lemonade.
Bottled. The aroma has pear, citrus. Clear, golden coloured perry with not much head. The taste is light sweet, has fruitiness. No complexity from yeast. Quite carbonated. Still refreshing.
Wie auch der Apfelbruder ist dieser Cider nicht wirklich authentisch und bietet viel Parfum und Kunst. Kaum trinkbar, künstlich, dumpf.

Bottle from Dilo in Bochum. The cider has got a clear ligth golden-vanilla colour with a sticky body. Mild carbonation. Aroma of sugar, sweetness and ripe fruits. Taste of pears out of a can, sugar, overripe pears, vanilla and caramel. Artifical touch and way too sweet. Did not like it.
On tap polar bear Leicester. Golden no head. Aroma is sweet pear. Taste is very sweet sugary pears. Nice body soft carbonated. Nice sweet perry.
50cl bottle from intermarché supermarket. Clean light gold color. Thin body. Medium sweetness, medium bitterness. Pearl, wine, apple aroma.

500 ml bottle bought at YATA in Grand Centry Place, Mong Kok. Clear light golden yellow ciolour; Razor-thin head and residual soapy white foam which fades in 5 seconds; No lacing with fairly fizzy carbonation; Tart and musty aroma of dry white wine, with light apple juice, faint sugar, cellar and tannic; Medium sweet taste of apple-pear wine, with notable alcohol, light pear juice, sugar, tannic and light tartness; Light body, watery palate; Mouth feel is quite sweet pear and apple wine with strong boozy notes. Notable tannic and light tartness to counter the winey pear juice palate. Moderate sweetness. Okay… Fairly dry after taste. Very easy and slightly boozy to mouth. Comments: Like its Apple Cider proper, this one is also light and watery, as well as very peary, fairly winey and boozy with good tannic and tartness. Very refreshing especially in Summer or after a hearty meal. Drinkable.
Sampled at Thunderbird hostel. No head. Clear golden pour. Ok. Average cider

50 cl bottle. Not really interesting, taste is full of alcohol, some vague fermented pear that is somewhat sour. I can’t really understand why the alcohol is so upfront, it’s like drinking vinegar to an extent. It’s not worth it!
Bottle from an off licence in Great Wyrley. Aroma of pear skin. Taste is some pear, sweet and Sour. Not great

bottle @ De Tolly Joogipood. pours clerar golden color with many bubbles and almost no head. Aroma of dry wine,light pear, some wood, alcohol. Taste is smooth pear, wood barrels in aftertaste. Light body. I like this cider actually,
50cl bottle from intermarché supermarket. Clear gold color. No head. Body is thin but smooth. Medium sweetness, light light sourness. Pear, light light brett, alcohol aroma.

500 ml bottle bought at YATA in Grand Centry Place, Mong Kok. Clear golden yellow colour; Very-thin head and residual soapy white foam which fades in 5 seconds; No lacing with quite fizzy carbonation; Tart aroma of dry white wine, with cellar, wood, faint pears, moderate alcohol, and strong tannic; Very light sweet taste of pear wine, with pretty strong alcohol, faint pear juice, tannic light tartness and barrels; Light body, watery palate; Mouth feel is strong perry with very low sweetness, moderate tartness. Light winey taste with little fruity elements; Yoghurt taste is very light, fairly good tannic with notable light woody taste. Potent but pleasant booze. Okay… Fairly dry after taste. Very easy and boozy to mouth. Comments: This is a level-up version of its Premium Pear Cider, with very little sweetness, stronger booze, tannic and barrels. Its aroma is better than taste, and overall as a strong Perry, it’s still a little too light in taste and feel. Still, an okay and easy one to wash down meals.

50cl bottle. Perry aroma - that is already good. Earthy, cellary, oaky - tastes and feels like hand pumped cider. A bit too heavy on the sugars, but this is inevitable, otherwise there be only yeast and acid at the same time. Finish is sweet with a dash of toffee. Abv is well hidden. One of the few perries available in Estonia, and I can live with that.

BB Jun 2014. Clear yellow, sparkling, little white head. Smell - rich cider, sweet acidic notes, slight vinegary. Body - medium with medium to low carbonation. Taste - syrupy sweet and sour, minerals, overly acidic, teeth are rotting. This one was a drain pour unfortunately - I just didn’t enjoy it.

Bottle. Golden body, head disappears faster than Usain Bolt. Aroma has pukey medicinal bitterness, toffee and rotting apples. Taste has raw pears with some apple jam and toffee. Not really woody; a bit funky but in the wrong way. Mostly medicinal alcohol bitterness and green apples in the finish. This is clearly more natural but only slightly more preferable to the local sugarbomb-horrror pseudo perrys.

500ml bottle from backstage at Thekla, Bristol. Only managed a sip of this before throwing away. Has a needlessly strong alcohol taste, sharp tart character and poisonously sweet pear taste. Hard to imagine people buying this and actually enjoying it.
more whiskey in smell. 2013 vintage. very good malting. dark. very drinkable.
750 ml bottle from Costco. 2015 vintage. Caged and corked with no carbonation. Tastes of brown sugar, 5 spice and figs. As the beer warms up there is bit of whiskey taste from the barrel. Great beer.

July 9th, 2015 - This is a big boy, and like an adolescent labrador it doesn't know it's own heft, but it settles on your gut anyway. For such a dark sounding beer, it actually let's some light through the shaker pint glass it occupies, casting a dark brown haze onto the table. But the nose is true to form, with three primary notes at play: booze, wood and whiskey. The palate is noticeably oily, with alcohol and plenty of whiskey to burn, which deserves to be shared. The flavor is neither too sweet nor too intense, and repeated sips reveal subtler notes of leather. But make no mistake - this brew is hot with ethanol.

750ml 2015 vintage. Copper colored pour, small bubbly head. Sweet heat in the aroma, molasses, malts and booze. Taste is also sugary sweet, smooth, enough warmth to be noticeable. Not over the top, but right where it needs to be.

Rating #2786 - 2016.08.29 - Capstone for our Bottleshare at CBI. Hazy orange-brown pour, bubbly head, not much lacing. Aroma is burnt sugar, vanilla, cooked plums, earth. Not much alcohol on the palate, tempered nicely, some sweet sticky texture and a ton of body. The search for Bigfoot continues.

It pours brown with reddish hues. Head retention is moderate and it has visible legs. It has numerous malty and hoppy aromas initially. The malty flavors are caramel and molasses. The whiskey notes are moderate. There are also some citrus flavors and dark fruits of figs and raisins. There is a hint of spice in the background. The whiskey flavors are prominent with the caramel and molasses. There is also a slight brunt note in the background. In addition there are cherry pipe tobacco notes with figs, floral, and citrus flavors in the background. It has a full body that is not quite chewy with a moderately bitter after taste with a slight hot alcohol warming into the finish. Overall, there are an abundant aromas and flavors the work well together than become more clear as the beer warms. The slight hot warming is just enough to make it enjoyable and not overly done.

Bottle: Poured a deep brown color ale with a medium size foamy head with OK retention and some light lacing notes. Aroma of caramelized malt notes with light residual sugar with vanilla and oak notes also perceptible. Taste is a great mix of caramelized malt notes with light sugar notes also perceptible, with some oak, vanilla and bourbon notes also present. Body is full with good carbonation with light warming alcohol notes. Quite the big beers but still keeping some good drinkability with plenty of complexities.

Bottle from a friend. Deep copper color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, resin, hops, pine, dried fruits, oak and bourbon. Bitter finish with citrus, hops, bourbon, oak, dried fruits and pine. Excellent barley wine.

Pours a root beer color with a thin off white head which is gone in a hurry....aroma of whiskey, oak, vanilla.....taste is oak dominant, quick hit of sweet barley wine taste shows up, then moving into a bit of booze and vanilla, slightly dry finish of earthy bitterness.

Draft at the NC source. Pours dark brown with a thin tan head. Dark malt up front then raisins, molasses, vanilla, oak, wine, hops. Big flavors. Lingering, warming finish. Fairly awesome. Bought a bottle of the 2015 vintage for later. (notes)

Cask, Last Plantagenet, Leicester. Hazy gold with a small head. Aromas are sweet and fruity. Syrupy with pear promiment. Some vanilla notes. Flavours are biscuit malts with sweet pine hops. Some toasty notes with a fruity, then bitter, finish. Pretty good.

column1: Eel River Barrel Aged Raven's Eye
column5: GABF 2006. Black bodied. Nose is bourbon, vanilla, chocolate and roasted malts. Pretty typical. Taste echoes that with more bourbon, roasty malts, dark fruits, chocolate, woody notes, and sweetened coffee. Body is creamy. Medium-full feel with light carbonation. Finishes with more roasty malts, chocolate, light coffee, vanilla some wood, and bourbon.

column1: Eel River Barrel Aged Raven's Eye
column5: GABF 2006: Very dark brown color with a tan head. Yummy creamy vanilla aroma. Vanilla played a big part in the flavor as well. The aroma and flavor had just enough bourbon. Notes of chcolate and roasted malt as well.

column1: Eel River Barrel Aged Raven's Eye
column5: black pour tiny tan head viscously coats the glass. over barrell’d aroma lots of bourbon some light woods vanillas chocolates. Thick well coated palate. Warm swallow after a supremly buttered toffees malt flavor a good amount of bourbon as well. Pretty good but needs to mellow under some more aging.

column1: Eel River Barrel Aged Raven's Eye
column5: GABF 2006. The beer pours to a black body with a nice brown head. The aroma is chocolate, sweetened condensed milk, oatmeal, some oak. The flavor is creamy chocolate, semi-sweet chocolate chips, oaky vanilla barrel. A bit much barrel. The palate is woodsy, creamy and coating.
Smells like pineapples, taste like pineapples. If you like pineapples this beer is a win. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: floral, light citrus and banana aroma, fresh! Appearance: soft yellow in color cloudy. Taste: soft banana up front smooth middle great carbonation balance. Palate: light smooth soft carbonation flavor. Overall: A very smooth and well balanced Hefeweizen, not overly sweet or have an overwhelming banana flavor.

A bright, crisp beer that pairs great with hot weather. I love this beer because it tastes very true to Hefeweizen style- to me there’s almost a rustic feel to it. I enjoy the unfiltered yeasty-ness. Notes of banana, citrus, spicy, bready yeasty-ness.
A nice subtle banana aroma and bright yellow appearance. Crisp flavor, not too sweet. There are hints of tropical fruit that add a brightness to the flavor. Love love!

Bottle (leftover judging beer 2006 GABF)poured a hazy gold with a small lasting white head. Aromas of wheat, yeast and hints of banana and spice. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of wheat, lemon and a hint of banana with a crisp clean finish.

nearly clear no real head touches of straw almost a krystal. Light honey grain aromas some bananas and breads. Light palate some fluffiness to it. A very nice bananna bread an honey w/ light wheat aroma. A very well done hefe.

GABF 2006. The beer pours to a filtered looking gold body with a lasting white head. I figure it’s not a kristallweizen because my buddy Dave’s hefe looked very similar and wasn’t filtered. The cold seemed to drop out the murkiness. The beer has a nice wheaty aroma with cloves, clover, banana. Rich and very clean and crisp. Same with the flavor. Creamy crisp refreshing palate. I’d definitely drink this again.
amber pour tall dense tan head some thin lace. Odd sweet aroma of strawberries, carmels, sugars, and an odd fruit and spice. Pal was pretty avg. Flavor was a wheaty grainy carmel, pretty plain.

For some reason this was on at PP Carlsbad in February. Orange to caramel in color with a off white head. Aroma of fruit, caramel, and toasted nuts. Flavor of fruity caramel in the base with an earthy finish. Some bread, apple, and a faint hint of sweetness. A bit unusual for the style, if there is such a thing, but nothing great.
Tap at Fair Oaks’toberfest. Amber color with an off-white head. Medium body with smooth carbonation. Flavor is lightly smoky caramel. Finish is mildly astringent. Tasty ale.
This amber ale poured with a thin beige head. There is a hearty smoked malt flavor with some sweetness and nice balancing hops.

On tap at the Sacramento location. 4 ounce sample. Somewhat spicy hop aroma with some more toasted maltiness present. Light floral hop notes are also detected, while the aroma as a whole is somewhat faint and lacking the sweetness I expect from the style. Moderately/mostly hazy unfiltered orangey-amber body with a nice, firm off-yellowish head. Attractive. Toasty, malty, slightly smoked start, which becomes very spicy and pretty hopped to finish. Hops are too present for this style and malts are not sweet enough. Not really to style. This is different, but good.

Gravity, Turf Tavern Autumn Ale Festival. Shiny pale gold, cap of off-white. Spicy, pine hops with a nice fruity esters. Pleasantly soft palate, good chewy bitterness that transitions to a nice mellow mellow malt. Solid.

Cask handpull at Simple Simons, Canterbury. Clear gold with lasting off white head. Hoppy aroma. Lovelyin mouth, right balance of pale biscuity malt with some later juicyness. Then dry hop finish. Hop is slightly astringent on aroma, but reasonably subtle on end. Utterly drinkable. Hop shows a little sherbert on finish. Another nice beer in this series

Cask@The Magpie&Crown, Brentford, London. Quite crisp and bitter, with a definite grassy hop note. Surprisingly clean and as i mentioned before, especially for a cask beer. Some light sweet honeyed characters aswell. Not bad.

Cask conditioned, gravity dispense at St. Albans BF ’06. Gold & headless with perfumey hop aroma & a bitter & perfumey-hoppy flavour. Another enjoyable "One Hop" beer. A quick Google reveals Magnum to be a hop usually used for "bittering" rather than to provide aroma or flavour so its full characteristics are probably rarely on show as they are here. The "One Hop" series is now well into its mid-thirties- I’ve managed eight. How many more cultivated hop varieties are there?

zapach lekko przypomina kompot z suszu, lekko podwêdzany, owocowy, lekko kwaskowy, ze z³odami w tle. kolor jasnomiedziany, klarowny, w smaku pe³ne, s³odowe, karmelowe, suszone owoce, bardzo delikatna wêdzonka i zporo zió³. goryczka umiarkowana, zio³owa z karmelem i piwnic¹. nasycenie umiarkowane
Bright amber color with no head. Vegetal, swamp water, caramel aromas. Medium body with low co2. Sourdough bread, spicy caramel, vegetal flavors with a lightly sour finish___off--and weak.

Taster at the brew pub. Pours clear medium brown with almost no head. Tastes like malt, nuts, and grains with a hint of orange and caramel. Light body and low/medium carbonation. Smells like malt and pecans.

Tap at brewpub. Pours clear copper with a trace of fizzy off-white head. Aroma is cereal and cookie malts, light caramel, fig, light dates, light floral and woody notes, and faint toast. Flavor is dry malt base with a touch of sweetness and some yeasty floral notes, light stone fruit, and light caramel; smooth finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Clear orange. Poured from draft at the avenue pub in New Orleans. Sweet. Decent for the style.

On tap at brewpub. A red amber with a nice, lasting beige head. Taste is cereals, brown sugar, caramel, biscuit. Some herbal hops with earthy notes. Nice, herbal and spicy finish. Medium bodied. A decent oktoberfest.
Thinnish tan head. Copper color. Very thin body without the heavy malty character I associate with Oktoberfests. Drinkable, but not a beer that I would have again.

I sampled this beer on tap at the brewpub in New Orleans. The beer had a earthy hop aroma with some roasty malt notes too. It was a light brown-amber color, was clear, and had a small, tan head with low retention and cling. The flavor was earthy hop and some grain, with a bit of malt, and a bit acidic, almost vinegar-ish. It had a thinner, light body with a smooth, light finish and low carbonation. I was not impressed with this beer at all.

on tap-pours a thin light tan head and hazy copper color. Aroma is medium malt-sweet, roasty/peat. Taste is medium malt-sweet, roasty/peat, secondary copper/earthy hops. Light side of medium body. OK effervescence.
Draft. Amber pour with minimal off-white head. Nose was malty and earthy with a taste similar. Nice smooth enjoyable beer. Definitely my favorite of the beers I tried at CCB.

Hard to imagine that I would ever rate a Mich this high, but I found this to be pretty good. Might be my favorite domestic semi-swillish porter so far. I am comparing this to Yuengling Porter, but a bit more of a robust flavor.....mainly of chocolate, coffee, some slight tart flavors of fruits/raspberry with a little bit of bitterness. I am tasting the coffee more the second time around. Got this in the variety pack, so I'd say is the best out of the 4 in there. I would buy again as an economy beer.

My second highest rated beer out of the sampler craft case. This one was a standard porter. As with the other beers out of that case there was hardly any aroma, except some very light coffee hints. Thin mouthfeel, flavors of roasted coffee, and nuts with some chocolate, with a coffee aftertaste. It was a little thin in all areas, a decent brew, but only a little above average. Originally rated on 11/28/08.
Pours a dark brown. Aroma of chocolate/coffere. Flavors pretty much the same as the nose.
"a little thin for a porter...maybe more on par with an average american brown ale. not bad, but not something worth buying again, especially with all the more robust porters out there. "

The body has a thick, dark brown color with deep crimson highlights. On top sits a creamy light tan head that builds up tall before fading down to a thin covering that just hangs on till the last sip. The lacing is slick and slides down the glass just behind the head. The aroma is very sweet. There is a lot of sweet roasted malt with hint of caramel and chocolate. Also there is a very slight non-descript hop presence coming though as well. There is a big roasted malt sweetness with notes of honey, dark caramel and toffee. In it there are some light coffee and dark chocolate tones as well. Hop flavor is very modest but adds some bitterness and mild piney notes. The roasted flavor and light bitterness quickly fades off the tongue in the finish. The body is about medium with a very creamy and slick on the tongue. Its carbonation is soft but still in good balance
Bottle from 2007 as a joke at a bottle share. Pour is reddish brown with barley noticeable tan head. Aroma and flavor include faint chocolate, coffee, and hop bitterness. Actually not too terrible.
December 2009. From bottle. Pours very dark brown with a short tan head. Some roasted malt characteristics, chocolate, but too watery to really be good.
Bottle. Possibly the worst porter on earth. They get points for giving it a go though. Far too sweet.
355 mL bottle. Not a bad intro to the style. No head, and a little thin, but the flavour is decent, if a little one-dimensional. A little sweet up front - could use a touch of roast.
12 oz bottle pours dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma is malt and a bit of sweet chocolate. Taste is the same with a hint of coffee

column1: Bernard Jantarový Ležák 12° / Amber Lager / Øezaný Ležák
column5: # 1603; 10/2019. Aroma of bread, roasted malt, slightly spicy. Copper color, clear; nice creamy persistant head. Flavor is strong bready, spicy, prominent bitter, slightly plum and cherries. Finish is bitter. Very good czech amber lager. 0,5 l bottle, market, Pilsen (CZ).

column1: Bernard Jantarový Ležák 12° / Amber Lager / Øezaný Ležák
column5: Pe³na harmonia smaku i aromatu - idealnie zrównowa¿one. Piana doœæ obfita. Czerwono - bursztynowy kolor. Delikatne i przyjemne w piciu.

column1: Bernard Jantarový Ležák 12° / Amber Lager / Øezaný Ležák
column5: Copper color, middle-sized foam lasts long enough. Caramel, roasted malty aroma and taste. A little bit spicy and yeasty mildly bitter aftertaste. A little bit watery, but just fine. Simple, but good amber lager.

column1: Bernard Jantarový Ležák 12° / Amber Lager / Øezaný Ležák
column5: Bottle. Clear ruby with off-white head. Roasted malts, coffee. Medium dry, lightly acidic, bitter finish. Soft carbonation.

column1: Bernard Jantarový Ležák 12° / Amber Lager / Øezaný Ležák
column5: Amber with off white head - Malty aroma - Malt body with hints of caramel and some hop and bitterness to balance - The malt and hints of hops goes into the finish - This was nice

column1: Bernard Jantarový Ležák 12° / Amber Lager / Øezaný Ležák
column5: Cerveza de estilo amber ale color rojizo, sabor a caramelo y madera y cuerpo ligero

column1: Bernard Jantarový Ležák 12° / Amber Lager / Øezaný Ležák
column5: (Bottle) Reddish brown colour with frothy, beige head. Malty, slightly roasted nose with dark bread, toast, dark fruit, chocolate, prunes and a touch of cherries. Malty, taste with notes of caramel, dark bread, raisins, toast and a mild spicy bitterness. Medium body, with a slight sweetness. Tasty, harmonious and well balanced. Quite nice.

column1: Bernard Jantarový Ležák 12° / Amber Lager / Øezaný Ležák
column5: (klasszikus csatos üvegbõl töltögettem, egy 3 dl-es kiskorsóba.) szép sötét vörösesbarna, mint a házi karamell (az odaégés elõtti utolsó fázisban ilyesmi) vagy vörösréz. a habja sárgás piszkosfehér, sûrû - és meglepõen tartós maradt a második, kevésbé hideg kitöltéskor. kellemesen kesernyés, pörkölt, aromás! talán mintha kicsit karamellás utóíze lenne. itatja magát. nem híg, de nem is túl testes. teljesen elégedett vagyok vele. :)

column1: Bernard Jantarový Ležák 12° / Amber Lager / Øezaný Ležák
column5: Tamnocrveno pivo, bogate pjene, odliènog okusa i mirisa... jako pitko i osvježavajuæe...

column1: Bernard Jantarový Ležák 12° / Amber Lager / Øezaný Ležák
column5: Aroma is little bit soapy at start, and honeyed at end. Taste is not very saturated, usual bitterness for lagers. No any reasons to call this beer is bad, but no any reason to call this beer is special or uncommon.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Can TWM Sterling - I had it a while ago, but found it an average porter with an artificial coconut thing happening.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: 12oz bottle...Jan 2012 rich red amber color ...coconut in the nose but faint, muddled with just an ordinary "beer" smell ...flavor is of a diluted brown ale with some coconut not a nut about this beer but it is okay for something different

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: The coconut flavor is subtle but present, but like most of the kona’s I have had, this beer falls flat both in palate and overall enjoyability.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On tap. Clear dark brown color with tan head. Big toasted coconut, chocolate, coffee aromas. Light bodied. Good flavors of chocolate, coconut, and coffee--a bit thin tho

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Great balance of roasty porter goodness with just the right amount of coconut flavor.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Beer pours very dark amber color with a off white colored head. Aroma is a nice combination of roasty and coconut. Taste is sweet with a dry finish. A nice quafable beer, IMO.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: ...had this out of the bottle in a Publix parking lot, hahaha. Went down smooth, with nice coconut and nutty flavors to round it out. Had nice dark roasted malt notes too, the flavor was pretty balanced, Dinished smooth, with a toasted coconut aftertaste, good beer.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On tap at Lunchbox Laboratory in Seattle, WA. Pours a medium brown with minimal white head with loose bubbles. Aroma is of mildly oily toasted coconut and a touch of fruit. Tastes like a thin and generic brown ale with a subtle coconut aftertaste. Not overly malty, not overly nutty, hops exist only for bitterness. There’s a strange vegetal aftertaste and slightly slick mouthfeel that leads to a disappointing finish.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: This is an excellent beer to try if you can get your hands on it. I had a sampler and a full glass on a local visit to the brewery-restaurant. I’m not a huge fan of coconut in general, but this beer was tasty. Partially because I was in the mood due to the location/vibe and wanting something unique (I’m otherwise a hop head). The coconut is front and center in the aftertaste and aroma. I will have another the next time I’m there.

column4: Kona Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: I’m not a big fan of Porter beer but a buddy of mine gave me one and this is a very interesting beer. The coconut takes away the stiffness and makes it easy to drink. I wouldn’t recommend this beer for much but if you want a taste of the island, then this one might be for you. Cheers!
Looks like grapefruit juice with good head. Definite berry presence, but not overwhelming. Not a good mix....but interesting.
on tap-pours a white head and hazy purple/orange color. Aroma is sharp light/medium fruity. Taste is tart, sharp light/medium fruity, some malt, yeast. OK effervescence.

Draught at Brewery: Aroma of Sprite, menthol, Vicks, and medicne. Poured violet in color. Small white head lasted. Particles. Cloudy. Opaque. Flavors of blackberry, menthol, medicine, and banana. Not very blackberry. Sweet. Short finish. Full body. Soft carbonation. Overall, not so hot.

tap. looks like a peach smoothy. thick thick head and alot of fruity sediment. nice aroma fo banana, yeast and berry. Very interesting. full bodied. tart berries and lively palate. yeast and dry finish. This is a chunky beer.

column1: Pumphouse Hot Shots Harvest Double IPA
column5: Draught at the brewery, on October 10, 2012 Hazy brown color, tan head. Hoppy, citrus taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high dry bitterness. Fruity, hoppy scent.

column1: Pumphouse Hot Shots Harvest Double IPA
column5: Tap @ Pumphouse. Hazy orange appearance with an off white head. Pineapple, grapefruit, tropical fruity, a touch piney hoppy aroma. A little resiny, grapefruit, pineapple fruity, hoppy flavor. Alright.

Bottle from Sainsbury’s Heaton, Newcastle. 2006 beer drank in 2013: This beer has turned a hazy, murky brown colour. It still has vanilla and sweet fruity notes but it has slight ‘wet paper’ flavours followed by creamy American cream soda and floral notes on the finish.
Pint @ Flyers. Little less flavorful than the amber. Kind of tastes floral, like flowers. Smells grainy with a medium body. Meh...

Nose is malty with light fruity notes - orange, light citrus, a hint of buttery caramel. Pours hazy orange, thin head. Flavors of light fruity malts, soft buttery caramel, toast, and light bitterness. Pretty stylistically on point and very easy to drink. Not too interesting but well done.

Tap at the brewpub. As Spitfire Best Bitter. Pours orange/gold with a creamy white head. Floral aroma. Creamy medium body. Floral and caramel flavors. Very smooth floral, mild bitter finish. Brilliant.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours deep gold with copper core and thin white head. The aroma has noble hoppiness and grassiness with mild malts and grains off in the background. The taste begins with a quick pulse of sweet malts that are soon vanquished by a hoppy assault of spicy hops, some graininess and a modest level of earthy hops. The hops get pretty tart with bitterness by midway and into the finish.
&#40Draught&#41 Pours a clear yellow body with a small creamy white head. Aroma of grain, honey, cereal, and grass. Flavor of grain, grass, and citrus with a dry, bitter finish.

GABF 2009. Pours clear amber with an average, frothy white head, mostly lasting with good lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, hay, straw, cereal, meal), light hop (herbs), average yeast (earth) with notes of plum. Light bodied, slick texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish. Average duration, light sweetness and acidity, moderate bitterness.

Orange-amber with a small layer of head. English hop dominates aroma with some peripheral citrus. Flavor is again dominant with the English hops--not so much my thing. Musty hop finish. A fairly well-made English style bitter, just not my fancy.
On tap at the brewpub, dry on the palate with definite grassy hop notes. A decent selection, but not my favorite beer from Flyers.
Light, clear copper with small head. Solid hops with a bitter finish. Bready/earthy malt balances well.
Hazy amber, small beige head.Nose is fruity and earthy malt. Mellow nutty malt flavor, nice medium strength hop finish

@ Ram N’Gate. Hazy light brown color/ tan head. Rich rootbeer spice, brown malt, belgian yeast estery aromas. smooth medium body. easy drinking flavors of spicy earthy yeast, brown sugar, brown malts. good.

Bartender called it this. Pours dark auburn with a thin head. The aroma has notes of caramel, sugar, yeast esters, banana booze, and a touch of metal. Lightly sweet caramel followed by some sugar and light esters. Not complex, but not unpleasant by any means. Lingering sweetness with a light hint of metal in the finish.

tap at the highlands ranch location. first they poured it into an ice cold pint glass, then i asked them to not do that and they put it in a normal pint glass. it is an amber red body with an almost brown hue. white head that laces. aroma was some cotton candy and caramel with warm rubber. taste was sweet and plastic like. nothing real bad, but veryu bland and metallic. i don’t know if this was filtered, but it was just unremarkable. a bit of copper, a bit of sugar water, a bit of strawberry, a hint of caramel. not a beer worth drinking, but better than the alternative.
Bottle from Jussi in Euro Local Swap 1/2019, many thanks! Solid west coast ipa with firm bitterness, pine and citrus.

Thanks japppp for sharing! Clear amber body with a thick, foamy and persistent white head. Aroma is hoppy (resin) and malty (caramel, some almonds). Taste is bitter, piney, but with a pleasant malty base. Dry resinous finish. Medium body, soft carbonation, slicky texture.

Kuparin värinen lasissa jättäen korkeahkon vaahdon. Tuoksu on hedelmäinen ja maltainen, ei niinkään kovin sitruksinen. Maussa humala ei pure niin kovaa kuin ehkä voisi, mutra kyse on silti hedelmäisestä, helposti juotavasta IPA:sta.

Bottle, courtesy of japppp, thanks! Pours unclear amber. Aroma is pine needles and resin, dominant malt nose, some grass. Body is medium, mostly bitter with some backbone, but not too much. Medium carbonation, lots of pine and resin again. Rather dry palate. Good, but with rough edges.

On tap at Plevnan, pours a clear copper with a small beige head. Aroma brings out lots of biting piney hops upfront, with crisp biscuity malt. Flavour is quite bitter, with piney hops upfront dominating, with a dry biscuity malt backbone. Bitter and biting, but tastefully so. Very good.
Hieman turhan vetinen. Ehkä kesäpäivän janojuomana hyvä, mutta omaan makuuniplev voisi olla hieman reippaampi humalointi.
Tap@plevna. Golden color with lacing off-white head. Aroma has malt, citrus, pine. Taste is malty with long bitter and quite dry aftertaste. Flavors of malt, pine, caramel and citrus.
On tap at Black Door, Helsinki. Pours clear weak brown Golden with a small head. Aroma of caramel malts and marmelade. Taste is moderate bitter piney hops, ripe oranges. Weak bitter finish, nice.

On tap at Stone’s, Helsinki. Clear amber with a surprisingly dense, off-white head. Solid hoppy aroma dominated by citrus, pine and notes of tropical fruits too, mild malty with hints of caramel. Moderate to medium sweet with medium flavour in and a solid bitterness in the finish. Solid brew and certainly a tasty IPA.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: (draft @ 2006 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY) When I had this at the festival, I realized it was the same beer I had at The Old Toad a while back. Slightly cloudy amber color with a fizzy white head. Aroma is slightly wheaty and kind of sour. Flavor is very sour and bitter with a touch of wheat. Very bitter and cloying at the finish. Maybe I need to have more of these to get the feel for them.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Sample at Autumn Festival of Ales - Mildly hoppy nose, malt palate, some depth in flavor. Slow to catch my interest, but finished well.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: (draft @ 2006 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY) Dark brown color with a thin tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty with some caramel and chocolate. Very sweet and malty flavor with a nice and balanced finish. Aftertaste is sweet and kind of nutty. Good malts as well. Really nice if it had a little more body to it.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap sample at Custom Brewcrafters in Honeoye Falls, NY. Clear, sparkling dark copper orange with almost no head. Good head. Floral, toffee and graham cracker aroma. Flavor includes caramel and toffee but is unusually bitter for an ESB. Lightly foamy with small bubbled carbonation, creamy mouthfeeL Very nice. Overall an odd duck. Soft and creamy, but atypically bitter for an ESB. Easy to drink but little to make it worth going out of the way for. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 2010 Autumn Festival of ales - Standard looking pour. Floral hop aroma. Average body of malt and hop. The bitter ending was a little too bitter for my taste.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Hazy light orange brown with bubbly head. Toffee, graham crackers and hop notes in the aroma. Small bubbled carbonation, creamy mouthfeel, some toffee in the palate along with some hops. Neutral finish. Sampled from growler.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Sample at Cottage hotel - Hoppy nose, citrusy palate, some depth in flavor. A solid but forgettable ale.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: (draft @ 2006 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY) Copper in color with a tan head. Aroma is kind of bitter with a decent amount of hops and a touch of malts at the end. Flavor is rather bitter at the beginning with a nice and bitter hop middle and some caramel malts at the end. Not too bad, but kind of ordinary.
Pours a muddy orange with a small head. Aroma of hops and fruit - maybe a bit perfumed. Very mild flavour of fruit and a bit watery with a dry end.

Bottle. Pours a nice hazy orange with a good foamy off white head. Aroma is caramel sweet with quite some American hoppyness. A touch spritzy. Extremely watery flavour (getting slightly better as it warms up). A touch of initial sweetness and a slightly dry end.

An unclear amber beer with sediment floating around in the beer under a lazing light orange head. The aroma is sweet and very hoppy, the hops giving it notes of flowers - nice aroma. The flavor is sweet malty with a strong hop presence, giving it flowery notes, before a dry bitter end sets in. Closer to a bitter Bitter, than a Mild Ale.

The color is beautiful amber-golden and the head is small, but creamy. The aroma is mild with notes of caramel and hops. The flavour is round, smooth with notes of caramel and a nice, light citrussy bitterness, that grows in the finish. 1866

Bottled. Light amber coloured. Unclear. Fluffy beige head. Herbal and sweet aroma. Some spicy notes. Light citric and fruity flavour. Light caramel. Mild and quite thin. Is a bit unbalanced imo. Light bitter end. Dos’t remind me too much of a mild.
Bottle. Golden/orange colour with a beige head. Aroma is sour , hop. Flavour is hop, sour, apple, malt.

Bottled. A clear, golden beer with a beige head. Both aroma and flavor is a bit sour and hoppy, and there is pine as well in the aroma. The flavor has a weak malty background. Medium mouthfeel. A strange beer I think. (061122)

Bottle. Small white and quickly disappearing head. Hazy orange body. Spicy hoppy aroma of oranges. Flavor clearly dominated by hops bitterness and a good deal of carbonation which contributes to making it a decent beer. The taste stays in the mouth for a long time.

(Bottle 50 cl) Pours a hazy, amber golden with a yellowish head. Light aroma of citrus. Medium body with some malt, but otherwise completely dominated by bitter, grapefruitish notes. Appears to be simply a lighter version of the brewery’s IPA. 231106
Muddy orange colour with a large off white head. Malty, light caramel sweet aroma with a hoppy fruity and piney note. Light malty sweet flavor with a hoppy citric and floral note.

column1: Blue Cat Saison de Quatre Ville
column5: This was served a Witbier-hazed pale yellow, mildly sparkling, holding a creamy, white head. Light sulfurs disperse above light funk and predominant yeasts in the nose. Crisp in the mouth yet finishing soft... which tones down the tart yeasts to seem delicate rather than sharp and cheesish as first perceived. Well done, and kudos to the brewers for thinking to age some. Probably not worth mentioning (but I will): I enjoyed several moments of levity shouting "Saison de Quatre Ville!", in a French accent, at my cats. Draught sample at AleFest 2007, Arlington Park Racetrack

column1: Blue Cat Saison de Quatre Ville
column5: On tap @ AleFest. Hazy yellow in appearance with a small white head. Light malt aroma, almost nothing there. There are lots of lemon and orange flavors, spice, yeast and a light sweetness. Finishes dry. Drinkable, but not that great.

column1: Blue Cat Saison de Quatre Ville
column5: I learned at AleFest Chicago that this is Blue Cat’s Illinois Craft Brewers Guild ReplicAle from 2006. Good stuff. The aging did it well. It’s a somewhat hazy pale straw ale with a good frothy head that laces nicely. The aroma has lemon, grasses, sweet malt, lively spices, and a bit of barnyard funkiness to it. It’s lightly tart, has some clove and white peppers, a splash of sweet pale malts, and a refreshing grassy bitterness. The finish is dry and mildly bitter. A job well done. Monthly Chicago Area RateBeer Gathering at AleFest, Arlington Heights, IL 4/14/2007.

column1: Blue Cat Saison de Quatre Ville
column5: on tap, pours hazy lemon with white head. nose has lemon and mild funk to it. flavor is very odd, sweet, dms, mild peppery, and loves. alcohol was well hidden, but this is not a good saison.

column1: Blue Cat Saison de Quatre Ville
column5: Draught at the brewub. Slightly hazy yellow-orange color with thin white head that left some lace. Attractive aroma of white wine, clove, and fall leaves. Tastes of white wine, clove, and a touch of alcohol. Tangy, dry, and vinous. Very good Saison.

column1: Blue Cat Mocha Madness Coffee Stout
column5: on tap at the brewpub. this was all about the coffee. dark brown on the pour with a tan and laced well. seemed more like whipped coffee and cream than beer. nicely done

column1: Blue Cat Mocha Madness Coffee Stout
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Poured an opaque black color with foamy khaki head that laced the glass. Smelled of coffee, vanilla, and cream. Roasty and slightly sweet on the tongue with distinct coffee and dark chocolate flavors. Pretty good.
Cask-conditioned at the Seven Stars, Bristol 13/1/2018. Golden in colour, with a slight, white, head. A touch of leafy hops, stone fruits, weetabix malts and a moderately bitter finish. Ok.
Cask at Samul Pepys, Slipton. Pours golden with an off white head. Boring, golden session bitter. Nothing much going on. Meh. Certainly not a retired beer it’s quite common in Northamptonshire.
Cask, gravity, at St Neots Beer Festival ’10. Gold with a small white head. Offputting sulphurous aroma and grim sour taste. Mid bitter finish. Perhaps this wasn’t quite right on the day.

Cask, Leicester Fest ’08 (Thurs afternoon session). Beer Of The Festival so far. Heaped lacy gold. Nose of tangy citrus, with a rub of hopleaf and green apple. Citrussy hop spike softened with oaty mellowness. Big hop finish. Still and silky. Nice.

Cask, Leicester Fest 07. Golden with an off-white foam. Aromas are zesty citrus with apricot and pear. Has a good level of hopping with some soda water. Flavours are soft buttery malts with some lemon. Nice and hoppy with grapefruit bitterness on the finish. Decen pine hops on the aftertaste.
Cask@Leicester Beer Festival 2007. Golden beer with a light head. The aroma is fruity and zesty and the flavour is lightly hopped and nicely dry. Overall a nice lightly hopped golden beer.

Cask conditioned at Merton Beer Festival 16-02-07. This beer poured a golden colour with just the merest hint of a haze and a white quickly dissapearing head. The aroma was really sulphery and as Glenn mentioned we felt that it compared with Pedigree some years ago. The beer had a nice hoppiness with it and a very pleasant citrusy tang and at 3.8% I felt that it had pretty good depth with a lingering finish. Overall a decent beer that was still just a tad rough around the edges.

Cask conditioned at Merton Beer Fest 07. Orange gold beer with thin head. Big sulphery, eggy note to the aroma, plenty of Burtonisation going on, the aroma of the old Marstons pedigree we agreed. The beer itself is a light bitter with a lemony citricity and a dry finish. I couldn’t describe this as a session beer as there is too much going on, but pleasant enough.

Cask conditioned - handpump - OGs Wellingborough. A light golden coloured beer. The aroma is sharp lemony hoppiness. The taste also is nice sharp hops a la JHB style beer. Good flavour for its ABV and a vast improvement on the first Digfield beer I had.Score 3.6 Subsequent ratings scored 3.3 and 3.4. Average becomes 3.4

12oz bottle 1/13/10 (RSRIZZO’s Winter Gathering courtesy of BeerandBlues2)-Pours a hazy orangish amber with no head. Aroma of sweetness, hops, and grapefruit. Taste of the same with alcohol. This light to medium bodied brew is past its prime.

Thanks to a friend for sharing this bottle. The beer pours a hazy brown color with no real head. The aroma is very sweet, with some pine and orange notes coming through from the hops. There is also a strong molasses character in the aroma, which I can’t really explain. The flavor is also interesting. There is a lot of alcohol and sweetness, similar to an aged barleywine. I also get some molasses, leather and tobacco character. There is a strong toffee malt backbone, as well as some faint pine and orange notes from the long-faded hops. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. As expected, this 6-year-old Double IPA has become more of a barleywine, but I am still excited I got to try it. Now, if I could just track down a Divine Reserve No. 1 I would have tried all 12 in the series.

Bottle thanks to mar) Pour is amber with no head..Nose is caramel malts, leather, spice, alcohol..Taste is spice, toffee, malts, leather, caramel..This sitting so long turned it into a barley wine pretty much.

9 year old bottle. props to sloth, fly, Kaggie97, via coldbrewky. same burnt orange hue with slight ruby tones. no head jsut foam on the edges. sweet caramel nose with dark fruit. bigger body than the #11. caramel still melts around the mouth. Hop flavor has fadded, but bitterness remains at the same level.

Thanks to the slob/sloth and Fly/Kaggie for getting me this brew. Consumed directly after the 11. Yes for nine years old it is a bit faded but still quite consumable. Light malty nose...some plum. Up front it is a bit bigger than the 11. It is a hop mirage at this point...bitterness is still there but not overtly detectable as hop bitterness. A light tinny finish punctuates the even and long mouthfeel that is reminiscent of an English Barley wine. Groovy.
Clearly well passed its prime. This beer still had some really nice rich malts and deep hoppy shadow of something that was likely better once.

Süßlicher Hopfengeruch, eher mild. Sehr aromatisch-hopfiger Antrunk, den ich nur in abgeschwächter Form erwartet hätte. Der Alkohol ist hier bereits erkennbar. Sehr aromatisch und wichtig auch ausgeglichen, stark, sehr malzig werdend. Cremig, der Abgang ist etwas weniger würzig aber weiterhin noch stark aromatisch. Weiter angenehm, insgesamt milder werdend, bis noch eine süßliche Note bleibt. Etwas gealtertes Auftreten. Vielen Dank an den Doppelbock! 10/12/10/13/12/12

Poured this 2 years after it was bottled 9/11/2008, wish I would have remembered it was a double ipa before now. Pours a cloudy murky deep amber without much of a head. The aroma has got some citrusy grapefruity hops left in it and some strong caramel malt in there as well. Taste is about the same as the smell. The hops are there, but not in your face like most big ipa’s. Taste is grapefruit, caramel, pine and resin. I’ll bet this was a monster fresh. Creamy tart mouthfeel, thick body, ample carbonation. I would have loved to try this fresher but it somehow got lost in my cellar. Good brew that I’ll bet was great a couple of years ago.

From the saint Arnold divine reserve vertical tasting @ the common table on Dallas. This beer pours a golden amber with little to no head. The aromas are citrus, closet aromas and dough. The mouthfeel is sticky, bitter and not as hoppy considering its age. It has q little more acidity and less hop in the mouth. I liked it. Cheers!

A: The pour is a burnt orange/copper color with a nice white head. S: Sort of what you would expect from an old DIPA...oranges, sugar, and sweet malts. There’s also some vanilla, which is sort of surprisingly. T: Still a really nice bitterness to this beer, which is surprising after such a long time. A semi-sweet malt character, oranges, orange peels, and again the hint of vanilla. M: Medium body with a fairly lively level of carbonation. D: One of the better beers of the series, actually. This is sort of along the lines of how Stone 10th is now.
Hand pulled somewhere in Brum. Chestnut beer. Sweet, quite smooth. A little tobacco and metal, but restrained. A bit nutty. Quite OK.
Wszed³ bez pisania, taki nudny klasyczek bez sza³u, wyobra¿am go sobie gdzieœ w pubie w Anglii na przedmieœciach.
Thuis ut een halve liter fles. Veel schuim, maar niet mooi vast en dik. Bijna zwart, zwak aroma. Smaak is goed, zeker voor het abv. Lichte chocolade tonen en in de nasmaak ook wat zuur.
Tap at the brewery. Clear pale gold, big frothy white head. Aroma of malts, bready, grainy. Taste is malty, grainy, light citrus hints. Medium body.
Draft at the Pint Shop. As expected for a lager, pale golden with small foamy head.Crisp grain bill with a nice crisp bite, small hop presence, mostly some tasty grains. Refreshing.

Keg at the Pint Shop, Oxford, 19/05/18. Clear golden with a well presented off white head. Nose is pale malts, cereals, straw, grains, hint of lemon. Taste comprises light breads, corn, lemon drizzle, straw, bready malts, toasted grains, light chalky minerals. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with a light hoppy whisper. Decent lager ... good refresh juice.
500ml bottle from local farm shop. Pours bright yellow gold, very fizzy with watery head. Aroma fresh with some light tropical fruit and a little treacle. Also somewhat floral.
Bottle. Pours light gold colour with a thin white head, skunky malt aroma, the taste is light malt and has a dry finish.

500ml Bottle and Cask via The Harte and Magpie in Amersham. This quite simply my favourite lager and my favourite session beer. It is exquisite. Like its sister the Cotsworld Premium, this is an unpasterised lager that is so full of flavour. Its very hoppy on the nose and that transfers well to the taste and the palate. It is low in abv but it does not lose any of the taste of its stronger sister. Conversely it isnt over hopped which is a common problem with lower alcohol beers. If it wasn’t for the fact this is almost impossible to get where I live, Id be drinking it just about every session!
Bottled. A golden beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of butter and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of butter and malt. Thanks yespr for sharing.

Draught at Isis Farmhouse, Oxford, England. Very pale golden colour with small white head. Weak, almost no aroma. Flavour is grain and mild grassy hops. This is somewhat watered down. 5% version is much tastier.
Bottle at Yespr’s - Thanks. Clear yellow - white head. Zesty, light hoppy, light malty, freshness, light bitterness, cirtus, hay, straw notes. OK.
Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear. Small off white head. ARoma of bread, sweetness and light herbs. Flavour of bread, sweetness and ripe fruits. thin bodied. fruity end.

From Mar 2007 Pours from 12 oz foil wrapped bottle a very dark brown with reddish hues and a small head of foam that disappeared almost immediately. The smell is wow. Huge notes of cocoa, dark fruit, vanilla, molasses, brandy, caramel, fig... The taste on first sip is loaded with dark fruit like plum, raisin, fig, black cherry and then... there's the vanilla floating around in the background along with some toffee and maple syrup. Wow. This brew really demands your attention but at the same time says, take your time lest evil befall you... And that's no problem for me because as complex and as tasty as it is, there's *no* denying the prowess it has in the abv department. Damn, I wish it was about 20 below out...just kidding. ;^) I *will* say that I'm not getting an alcohol "burn" but hey, I'm taking very VERY small sips. Well, I'm going to finish the review before I finish the brew and that's quite unusual for me but, I have to say, of the really huge brews in the +15%abv range that I've tried, this one is the most "drinkable". Well done Bristol Brewing!!

Lucked into this in Colorado Springs several years ago. this was brewed in 03 and bottled in 2006. So it aged for 10 years - I had for probably 1/2 of that. I notice not many recent reviews. this was a treat due to my luck and age. this was part of a dark beer day/weekend and this was toward the end. the 18% put me on my ass - snuck up on me. my notes are fuzzy for that reason - definitely complex - 10+ things happening here. I really enjoyed it - very little alcohol in taste. glad to have had this experience

Bottle shared by alexsdad06 pour cola brown with minimal tan head. Nose maple syrup and molasses, light earthy, caramel, toffee. Taste is all over the place molasses and honey first, dark cherry, progressing to light roast, then ashy and smoke. Crazy progression.

Bottle back in like 2007ish?? Thanks again to Skyhand! Found some old notes the other day from some tastings we did, so the next few entries will all be tagged with Skyhand and not too long as I don’t remember much. This was a doozy though. Seemed quite mellow for 18%, with all those maple and honey flavors mixing perfectly with the roasty and licorice notes from the Impy Stout. Damn good stuff!

Bottle at BeerDig 2011 on 03/06/2011. Dark brown/mohogany body with a thin off white head. Big roast chocolate and soy aroma. Coffee and ash flavor with roast chocolate and creosote. Medium full body with moderately low carbonation.

Bottle: Brewed in ’03 & bottled in ’06. Thanks, Jeff! Deep brown body with literally no head - only a few small carbonation bubbles. Looks like Utopias but thinner. Aroma has lots of brown sugar, molasses, wet oak, very faint maple syrup notes, lots of vanilla candy in the finish, & slight signs of oxidation. Taste is pretty sweet with molasses, brown sugar, & big-time toffee up front. Again, light oxidation in the form of boozy sherry, only a very mild hint of staleness. Cocoa powder, vanilla, either maple or butterscotch... Hard to pinpoint exactly. Lots of dark fruit in the finish. Guys we were with suggested it finishes like a Port, & it absolutely does... Slightly boozy with a big, dark currant & fruity sweetness. Good stuff... BIG stuff, but doesn’t seem like 18%+.

Bottle, courtesy of Ratman197 (Thanks!). Brewed 25/9/2003, Bottled 9/5/2006. It pours like coke with a fizzy and frothy beige head, that quickly disappears. Aroma is vinous, sherry, sweet dried fruits, bourbon, chocolate, alcohol. Taste is light cardboard, bitter chocolate, dried fruits, sweet alcohol with a warming finish.

Brewed 25/9/2003, Bottled 9/5/2006 Pours not as dark as expected. Foams like coke, very quick and then dissapears. Smells sweet with influence of dried fruits. Tastes good, ends with raisins and other dried fruits.

Bottle: Thanks Madmitch: Served in a Chouffe glass: Brewed 2003/Bottled 2006: Brown pour. Very small lively and fairly quick changing/disappearing beige foamy head on top of a black colored beer. Aromas of vinous notes with liquorice, raisin, pepper, chalk, toffee, mocha, dried prunes, figs, hints of soya, brown sugars and sticky barley roast. Flavours of spices, roast, wood, chalk, ginger bread, port, toffee, raisin, dried prunes, coal, liquor, pepper, liquorice wood, some yeast, sweet barley malt roast, some bitters, some malts, some chocolate, some berries, light sticky sweet tar tones and hints of honey roast... Complex! Aftertaste is quite lingering mix of spices/pepper, raisin, toffee, wood, light sticky, some coal and chalk. Very interesting peppery tone! Low carbo, soft creamy yet spicy mouthfeel, full body and a creamy texture. Alcohol is well hidden! Nice beer for sure! Spicy but not alcoholic, tasty but nothing unbalanced. Interesting, strong, complex and some new flavours to discover.

2003 brew date with a 2006 bottling date; this has gone past it's prime. Aroma has quite a bit of alcohol still, but behind that alcohol is notes of soy sauce, cardboard and sherry. There is also a teriyaki beef jerky note to the aroma. There is a hint of a fruity, dark berry note. Lots of alcohol. Pours a very still dark brown, not quite black with no head. Huge legs to this one. Flavor has quite a bit of alcohol, but also huge smoked, barbecue meat notes. Low to moderate bitterness. Some chocolate and coffee notes, but secondary to the alcohol and meat. Obviously no hop flavor. A bit of soy sauce, but the oxidation isn't as bad as in the flavor. Mouthfeel is medium full bodied; it's not as thick as one would expect a beer this large to be. Absolutely no carbonation. Lots of alcohol warmth. Overall this beer is well past it's prime, but has held up better than many other beers would have. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had on draft at GABF. A special offering by Rocky River Brewing Company based on their award winning Smokestack Porter. The same, but with chipotle and 4 other chilies added for addtional flavor. I’ve tried a few chipotle-smoked porters before, but this had the best balance of chile, smoke, and porter to date. Wonderful smoky nose with a kick. Medium bodied, roasty/smoky/chile/nutty/coffee flavors open up on the tongue. Just enough chile kick to let you know it’s there without being overwhelming. Really an excellent beer, I hope I come across this again.
Can at the local housing group work Day. Low but clean aroma. Very mild malt taste with a medium bitterness and medium body.
Beer share at Lennarts, Malmö - Yelllow golden coloured pour with thin white head. Grassy hoppy and sweet malty, very grainy, corn sweetness, papery cardboard, light watery body.
Can at Lennart. Clear golden colored with a small white head. Malty aroma of grain, metal and hops. Malty flavor of hay, grain and hops. Watery.
Can from Lucullus in Örebro. Very mild smell with an artificial fruit arom and some light boiled vegetables. Also some sulfur. Similar taste, very light.
Pojrs pizzy yellow with low disappearing white head Aromas of basicly sweet malt syrup in dishwater Taste has lager like taste with sweet corn, malt syrup. Hints of hops
Clear golden body with a medium white head. Malty, with some sweet notes and grass.

500ml can from Hemköp. Clear golden with some small bubbles in the glass, medium size frothy head that leaves good lacing. Weak grassy aroma. Mouthfeel is watery and aggessivt carbonated which makes it pretty hard. Thin taste bread and grass, neither bitter nor sweet, just too watery.

*Can from Hemköp in Stockholm. Sweetish strange beginning. The malty body is too sweetish, the water is refreshing but the beer is unround. No bitterness there, refreshing but lots of grain in the body. Strange.
Can from a local supermarket in Örebro. Odd smell of fructose powder, in the background I get a chemical fruity aroma. Very light taste, like carbonated water.
Clear golden body with a medium white head. Malty, with some grass. Light palate.

Off-white decent foam, diminishing and leaving some dots inside the mug. Pale golden clear beer. Sweet malts with a chemical signature to the nose along with some grassy wet hops. Tongue gets pale malts, grassy hops and some bread. Somewhat watery but not diluted. Easy to drink, inoffensive, and the mild finish is short and contains a few hops and bread. Possibly improved since ShitBeerFestival in Kiruna nov.2009 [50cl can, 2.8%abv° BB 07.11.14]
Can. A little musty (but not watery) beer. The texture is a bit special but I like the fruity aftertaste.
Very soft body, light taste with a bitter end. Light color and kind of sweet. Overall a good beer
Canned. I agree with Cunningham, why did I even try to drink this? Water is better to drink. Crap!
500 ml can. Pale yellow with white head. Aroma sweet, malty and grainy. Taste grainy, malty and the with a bitter and grainy finish.
Can. Golden colour with a white head. Sweet malt aroma. Thin. Weak malty flavour.

I remember drinking this on tap in Ind Coope pubs in the late 70s early 80s. Used to be one of my favourites. This canned beer seems to had list its alcoholic content dropping from 5.2 to 3.5. It appears to have become a budget beer...not what it used to be. If you can get hold of any of the original in bottles go for it. This canned version is nothing to write home about. Cheap and plain
I used to enjoy Lowenbrau and saw it on sale in Lidl. I should have checked, it was too cheap and only 3.5%. It is now a budget lager and to be avoided!

Draught @ Cambridge House: This one pours a mostly orangish dark amber color. There was a very small off white head on mine. The nose is quite nice. There is some nuttiness, fall spices and malts in there. The taste is equally good. The body is good, and there is a very good blend of the spices, malts and hops to make a very drinkable beer. There is a slight sweetness and roastiness in there also. Another winner for Steve and Dave. Hopefully ther will take this one to the GABF next year!

Pacific Northwest Vacation 2007 8/26/2007: San Juan Starboard Porter is dark mahogany brown with a lasting thin beige crown. Only a faint trace of chocolate can be found in the aroma. The aroma and flavor are also VERY yeasty to the point that all other flavors are suffocated. The finish is dry with a slightly roasted flavor. This beer has a medium body and moderate carbonation but somehow is not very smooth! Overall this porter was a disappointment. 4 oz draught sample (4.2% Alc By Wt, #1039, OG 1.051, Brewed 7/19/2007) at the Front Street Ale House in Friday Harbor, Washington. Rating #2 for this beer...

Bomber [extremly short filled] poured a clear dark brown with a diminishing tan head. Aromas of coffee, chocolate and vanilla. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of coffee, hint of chocolate and roasted malt with a slightly roasty watery finish. My boss brought 2 bombers back and they were both short filled below the neck.

On tap at BBC. black with dark brown/amber edges. nice khaki head. vanilla bourbon butterscotch chocolate aroma. chocolate butterscotch werther original flavor. flavor is uhh...quite boozy. warm butterscotch chocolate finish. full body. creamy carbonation. nice.....but i was slightly bothered by the werther original thing going on throughout the beer.....something seemed kinda artificial.
sampled at GABF. Black pour with thin head. Outstanding aroma of oak, vanilla and sugar. smooth vanilla. nice alcohol warming. Delicious beer.

Backlog, bottle in 12 or 13, hazy orange golden with large and lasting head. Notes are pepper, spices, orange skin, brett, grass, and other funk herbals. Body is lighter with a spicy but refreshing finish.

Bottle. Lemon, orange, biscuit malt, cardboard, and straw aroma. Hazy golden yellow with minimal head. Moderately sweet orange, lemon, biscuit malt, yeast, and moderately bitter hay flavor. Good body.

Bottle from Capones. Slightly opaque orange with a thin film that changes into ring around the glass. Yeasty and muted citrus aroma with some orange and lemon up front, a bit of pepper and wheat. Moderate carbonation and body, some booziness, a bit bitter, becomes somewhat dry with a boozy and lemon yeast finish.
Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle corked and capped poured into a tulip. Opaque nice orange with no head. Aroma is off ripe fruit, medium body, no carbonation, and no lacing. Taste is off ripe citrus.

750ml. bottle shared with Quevillon.The color is a hazy honey with a thin blond head.The tatse is herbal,grainy and of hops plus fruits a mixe of berries and bananas,yeast and a bit of malt. The aroma isas above.A nice saison for any time of the year.
750ml bottle pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of malts, yeast, fruit and some spice. Taste is spicy yeast and malts.

(Cask at Akkurat, Stockholm, 20 Oct) Golden amber colour with small white head. Fruity, nutty nose with notes of apricots and dusty hops. Fruity taste with apricots and a fairly dry, metallic bitterness with earthy hops. Refreshing? Yes. Exciting? Not really.

Cask at Akkurat, Stockholm. Clear deep golden. Sweaty, dusty and fruity with bold malt profile and light body. It has notes of green apples but dust and vacuum cleaner bag dominates. Being thoroughly killed in a side by side tasting with cask lagers from Franconia.

Cask at Akkurat, Stockholm. Golden with a low white head. Minerally aroma with notes of wet grass and rubber. Thin flavour of metal, grass and lemon.rind with a bland minerally aftertaste. Dull and not so refreshing.

11th September 2009 Cask at Chapel Beer Festival. Clear gold beer. Light hoppy nose. Palate is neutral to slightly dry. Light dry malt. Juicy hop fruits. Okay but somewhat let down by the tired malts.
Cask @Ascot Beer Festival 2009. Pours a dark golden colour with a thin white head. Real citrus aroma, with a spicy bitterness in the taste.

Cask at the Monks Retreat &#40JDW&#41, Reading. Gold with a thin cream head; weak grainy aroma; watery with a wheaty body; and a touch of bitterness to finish. Disappointing and forgetable - not Loddon’s finest.

(Cask at Akkurat, Stockholm, 19 nov 2007) Amber colour with frothy white head. Fruity nose with orange, apricots and earthy hops. Fruity taste with notes of orange peel, grapefruit and a nice dose of earthy hops in the finish. Some malt sweetness lingers in the background throughout. Nice session beer with a distinct bitterness.
Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Hazed gold with no head. Sweet, honeyed and perfumey to me, quite flowery and apple like, possibly too young. Not very keen on this one.

Cask at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Pale brownish amber. Fruity nose with a fair amount of resiny hops. Dryish and medium bodied with rounded mouthfeel. and vague notes of apples. Lingering resiny bitter finish. Quaffable bitter, but with a striking bitterness.

Cask at Akkurat, Stockholm. Dark golden with white creamy foam. Fruity and a bit metallic aroma of red apples, mandarin, candied pears, wet grass and fragile pale malts. Fruity but a bit thin flavour red apples, grass and resin. Short aftertaste of grass, apples, vegetables and metal.

Draught, 6.6% as Flakhaven Porter. Very buttery aroma. Black colour. Big stable brown head. Full flavour, quite sweet and with distinct liquorice notes. Very buttery flavour too, but almost hidden by other flavours. Could be a very nice beer without all the butter, must be infected.
Heavy malty aroma. Small initial apperance. Light brown head color. Vertually none lacing. Dark brown body hue. Moderate bitter initial flavor. Medium palate.
Draught at the brewpub. Dark brown colour allmost black with a nice light brown head. Aroma of liqourice. Light roasted sweet flavour with notes of licourice.

Draught at the brewpub Black color; thin creamy head. Light aroma of caramel and malt, no liquorice. Round mouthfeel, with residual sweetness, some roasted malt and the artificial, sweet, liquorice candy stick. Odd. Why brewing such stuff?

Very near black with no head. Aroma is roasted with tones of liqoirice. Very roasted flavours at first, then turns toward dark chocolate. Quite sweet and quite high carbonated. No bitterness but a good mouthfeel.
Black with a light brown head. Burned toffee, caramel aroma. Dry and only lightly bitter
Black colour with a medium dense brown head. Roasted malty aroma and taste, with some hints of coffee and a clear liqourice note. Dry finish.
Dark, black color. Light brown head, fully lasting. Laqurice in aroma and flavor. Oily palate. A nice porter, pleasent laqurice.
Draught at brewpub. Creamy lightbrown good fully lasting head. Dark-brown colour. Powerfull malty licorice aroma and flavor. Long finish. Oily palate, really a good beer.
On tap at Clemens. Almost black colour with a nice mostly lasting creamy head. Rich aroma and taste of malts and licorice. Medium body and a dry finish.
Draft. Milky barley malt aroma. Golden yellow with minimal head. Sweet milky lemon and barley malt flavor. Nice body. A well-made Koelsch.
On tap at Jamesport. Clear light gold pour with a sudsy white head and aromas of grain dust and honey. Flavor is honey and dough with a bit of a peach/pear fruitiness. Kinda bland for the style.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear yellow with a white head. Aroma of sweet fruit and lots of bready malt. Flavor of malt mostly, especially bready malt with a touch of sweet fruits. Pretty plain but ok overall. 6/4/6/3/13 [3.2/5]

Had this one on draught as part of the sampler at the brewpub in Ludington, Michigan. Cloudy, medium yellow pour with a nose of lemongrass and mild hoppiness. Astringent citrus but a clean finish, pretty good start to my flight!

On tap. Pours a cloudy pale amber color with a light, white colored head. Aroma is lemony, toasty, grains. Flavor is grain, some citrus. Palate is light and watery, medium carbonation, finishes lightly on the sweet side. Not great, but drinkable.

Draft at brewpub. Poured clear pale color with an average fizzy white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Light sour citrus aroma. Light to medium body with soft carbonation. Light sweet flavor with a light sweet finish of short duration. Soft drinkable beer.
Thanks to Phil_L! Black of color with a beige head. An aroma of coffee, chocolate, dark fruits, apples and liqurice. A flavor of liqurice, chocolate and nice bitter finish.

Bottle. Now, this was an unfortunate experience. I was quite looking forward to trying this. Black, with ever so slightly brown edges. Quite dry, yet felt quite sugary and also metallic. Something about it reminded me of lead pencils and asphalt. Some slight old socks and light soggy woody flavours. Probably the most dissapointed i have been with a beer in a long time.

A Mes rate: 50cl bottle at Chris O’s extravaganza. This followed the Dark Lord so it had to be really impressive to not seem dull and lifeless. Thankfully this did the job very well. Black with a cream head. Malty stouty nose with an edge of alcohol. Lovely liquorice flavour with perhaps just a little too much alcohol. Wonderfully thick and creamy soft palate. Very enjoyable stuff.
ChrisFestSoft and dreamy, then seems to fold in on itself and go on for ever. Awesome beer. Very yummy mummy indeed.

Bottled at Chris_O Fest March 2007. A black coloured beer with a decent whitish head. The aroma is slightly fruity with some oily notes. The taste is stouty and oily. Some fishy notes. Highly carbonated. Ok but misses a few tricks.

33cl bottle care of Phil_L. Thanks Phil. Black with brown edges. Lasting tan head. I had this with dessert on Boxing Day (chocolate torte with raspberries) and it went pretty well with it. Good carbonation on opening. Pours well with lasting head. Slight charcoal on aroma along with the expected roasted malts. Dark choc and blackberry/black cherry aromas. A little over carbonated in mouth. Stunning chocolate flavours in the mouth. Great balance, not too oily or powdery. Quite juicy, but with good depth. Very choccy throughout. Really rather nice. Can’t say the alcohol threw it out of balance either. Good English Impy stout.

Impressive Dark Ale, to celebrate the brewery’s departure from the Brewhouse in the Harbour. Light roast on the nose, not in yer face, warm and dry the same on the sip. immediate alcohol. Dry on the finish. BREW THIS AGAIN!
(330cc bottle) Pours a clear golden body with a tall foamy white head. Aroma of lemon, grass, and grain. Flavor of grass, lemon, yeast, and florals with a moderately dry finish.
frutal, sabor intenso que perdura en la boca. Agradable pero para no mas de dos unidades.

Una Amber Ale de color ámbar anaranjado con espuma alta a media. Su aroma es a levadura, bizcocho, caramelo y frutos oscuros secos (ciruelas y pasas). Su sabor es a miel, caramelo, almendras, manteniendo un suave amargor que se funde en un final cítrico con un toque de frutos secos (ciruela). ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark amber body white head nice lacing. Sweet biscuit and dried fruit aroma. Sweeter snd more flavor than most amber ales. Quite nice.
330ml bottle. Super hoppy smell, IPA like. Deep amber color with white head. Sweet sticky taste, completely fills your mouth and kind of stick to the walls of the head. Meh, it’s good.

Dark ruby with very low head retention, it has a very strong caramel and berry aroma and flavor, bitterness is more in the low end. It has a dry aftertaste. Just not amber for me, I don’t like the fruity berry flavor, seems like artificial.

Bottle from Kyoto Isetan. It pours an opaque amber brown with a sugary caramel aroma that is like a candied toffee. The taste is malty sweet caramel with a bit of a bitter bite. Not bad it has a nice nuttiness to it.

Aroma: Grassy hops, vinuous, herb, earthy Appearance: Slightly hazy amber body. Medium off-white head. Flavour: Herb, medium hops flavour, grassy, medium-sweetness, medium bitterness, Palate: Full body. Medium, soft carbonation. Overall: A good example, 330 ml bottle, poured. 10B. American Amber Ale

330ml bottle. A very hazy amber on the pour with a fizzy, rapidly fading white head. Like an unintentional though gentle sour. Orange, pith, lemon, some funk and toast. Confused. Quite tart on both nose and palate. Light to medium body, medium carbonation and a lingering mid-fruit dry tartness. If I thought it was supposed to be like this I might have scored it higher so sue me.

(330ml bottle) Pours a cloudy golden amber body with a medium off-white head. Aroma of pineapple, red apple, grapes, kiwi, and grass. Flavor of grain, orange, caramel, and grass with a moderately dry finish.

Botella, en Jumbo Los Ángeles. Color negro oscuro con cabeza de espuma muy leve. Aroma a chocolate y café. En boca se presenta sedosa, con un amargor moderado, equilibrado con el dulzor de las maltas. Se perciben notas a chocolate, frutos secos y café. El sabor a tostado de las maltas especiales es muy potente. El calor en boca recuerda un buen brandy. Baja carbonatación, acorde con el estilo. Una buena Stout, pero me esperaba un poquito más.

Bottle courtesy of Mick. Szot Negra stout 5.8% a dark black pour with a big foamy light beige head. The nose is rich umami, sweet chocolate & berries. Medium bodied, very smooth with w round carbonation. The taste is a reach sweet malty fruit dark malts. Light roastiness, sweet tangy fruits & dark chocolate - damn good stuff.

330ml bottle. A deep, opaque brown in colour with a fine though lasting fizzy light tan head on the pour. Surprise, surprise and so my disappointing run with this brewery continues. In a vein similar to my experience with the Szot Amber and Strong this is dominated by a tart acetic character. There’s nothing other than tart fruit on the nose and the roasty component you’d expect and hope for in a stout is barely discernible beneath the apply dryness on the palate. So frustrating particularly given the majority of positive reviews this one’s garnered. Light to medium body, medium carbonation and a touch of coffee on the back end but it’s otherwise controlled by a sour fruit tang.

33cl bottle from Arve_Christian - thanks a lot! Pours clear dark brown with a reddish hue and a small but lasting beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, dark fruits and licorice with hints of coffee and wood. Medium sweet and roasty with some fruity and wooden notes and a quite balanced bitterness. Medium body with fairly average carbonation. Well balanced and easy to drink. Nice stout, fits perfectly on a hot summer day like today.
Poured black, with light beige head, pretty looking beer. Slightly bitter aroma, oak, coffee, chocolate, malts. Strong flavors of chocolate and coffee, roasted wood and malts. Good beer, enjoyed.
Darkish brown. Very thick head - too much, really. The aroma has some tartness, which is unfortunate. Mostly chocolate, but again with a little tartness.

On bottle from Lider Express, Ñuñoa, Santiago, 5.8 abv Black color, good foam. Good intensity aromas of licorice, coffee,malt and notes of dried fruits . Notes of funky yeast. Medium / full body & complexity. Good sourness, and ok bitterness- well balanced. Very enjoyable
Bottle, 5%. Fruity aroma, a bit of roasted tar. Almost black colour, clear red shine. Small tan head. The flavour is nicely roasted, good coffee note, slightly acidic to balance. Good for ABV.

33 cL bottle. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is light yeasty, phenolic and dark roasted malty. Acidic dark roasted malty. Liqourice and hard roasted malty flavoured. Dark and acidic dry malty finish.
A decent stout, chocolate, roasted, coffee, medium carbonation. It is a good one in the Chilean market, not excellent, but s good one.

18/12/2018. Bottle from Jumbo Costanera Centre, Santiago. Pours pale amber with a huge foamy off-white head from a bottle that kept giving. Aroma of sweet malt, toffee, grain, light fruit and a little milky chocolate. Medium plus sweetness, light bitterness. Medium body, oily texture, average carbonation.
I really enjoyed this beer, thick and tasty but still refreshing. A nice unfiltered beer for agreat price that keep its bubbles. Would drink again, would buy again.
Appearance and taste are the best qualities of this beer. It’s pretty light and thick, sweet and refreshing.
Bottle. Thanks Will. Interesting, grassy hops, little bit of maltiness. Nice enough but unsurprisingly underwhelming.
Bottle shared, thanks Will. Big piney hop bite and bitter caramel, not too sure what style that is though but it may be an interesting pairing with spicy chili. Pretty average and unbalanced overall.

Super old bottle bought from the final days of Masuyo (now closed). Drank one week before best buy date. Heineken-like skunky nose with some light grain and pepper. Taste is well-balanced and rather light-bodied, but refreshing. Good bitterness on the finish with some white pepper. Not bad for being almost a year and a half old.
