Bottle, 33cl. Murky wheat golden colour with a minimal offwhite head. Sweet, spicy aroma with hints of caramel, citrus zest, green grapes. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Sweet and quite bitter. Very refreshing and drinkable, with great herbal and malt character.

Bottle from Isetan Kyoto. Amber-orange color, quite cloudy, with a tall, fine head and evident carbonation. Very rich, malty nose, caramel, a bit of fudge. Almost more like a dunkel in the nose. Sweet malt, minerals, caramel, peaches, something a bit astringent, light hop flavor, then decent bitterness. Rather dirty in the malt area, yeasty, seems like they used extract. Not convincing. Heavy and cloying.

Rubia al Vapor, quite a nice looking pour - a deep cloudy honey amber with a thick beige creamy head with no lacing but a creamy film floating atop the beer. Malty and fruity aroma, not bad. Medium bodied with a spritzy carbonation. The taste is surprisingly bitter, malts, nuts, some fruitiness maybe occasional subtle hints of fusel. Not too surprising as this beer seems to have been made in February - the height of the Chilean summer. Overall not too shabby. My general impression is a bit more boozy than the 5.8%, nice malts, bitter caramel, a bit of fruits, reminds me of some Mikkeller beers I had ages ago... decent but california common doesn’t spring to mind. Actually as it warmed up it grew on me and became more appetizing.

Aroma: Resin, bready, spice, alcohol, toasty, Appearance: Hazy amber body. Medium white head. Lacing, Flavour: Medium-high bitterness, medium-high sweetness, hoppy, bread, pepper, burn, crisp, toasty, fruity, Palate: Medium-full body, creamy carbonation. Overall: Nice! Full flavoured. 330 ml bottle, poured. Thanks Andre! 7B. California Common Beer
Gran cerveza muy buena relacion precio calidad. Resulta un poco dificil encontrarla. Pero vale la pena probarla cuando esta disponible.

A truly great beer. Flavourful with the right carbonation and a very ’alive!’ feeling to it. Alcohol is well integrated to the natural beer flavours. I normally pour the yeast remains in with the beer, but I’m glad I didn’t do it with this one, as there was just too much of it! I’m sure it made it great, though!

Pours copper/gold with a thin ring of bubbles. Smells of sweet fruit, some tarte hints, earthy, tea, some boozy elements, toffee, molasses, peppery. Tastes of tarte fruit, some oaky hints, vanilla, dry, some spicy hints, some hints of sweet citrus, earthy finish. Full bodied. 2007 bottle. One of the best South American beers I’ve had to date.

500mL Bottle at Bar Irlandés. Bottle said it was made in Dec06 and bottled in Feb 07. Aroma-right away you can tell it’s a been aged a few years-dank, cigary, flat flavored old beerness-I would say it’s about 6 months past it’s prime, but still drinking very well nonetheless. Hops have all faded from the nose, but they are still very much in the flavor and palate. This beer has an aggressive bitterness in the finish-like a chinook/colombus combo if I had to guess-piny and rough with some earthy herbalness. The finish was definitely the stand out moment in this beer, particularly the hops. Dried out nicely, not much for residual sweetness, but tons of deep caramel flavors. No alcohol heat, smooth as can be. Flavor has quite a bit of cherry that is borderline cough syrupy (a mixed bag), some wood, old ale "flavors", chocolate, caramel (but doesn’t come through as much till the finish). Carbonation was right where it should be. A very solid 4.1.

Very complex aroma an flavor. Some nuts, toffee and liqcuor touches. Same in palate, plus some citrus touches, even though I expected a little more sweetness. Carbonation was very low, but probably that was a defect on this particular bottle.
Powerfull and long lasting taste.. Szots best beer. Shows some notes of malt, oak and still fresh tropical, peaches, pears.

iBottle at Sicosis/i A Barley wine / Strong ale sold in a 500ml bottle seemed a bit strange but none the less it was one of the better beers I tried whilst in Chile. Prominent though not overpowering caramel aroma, really smooth taste, hidden alcohol and also a touch of honey on the aroma.

Appearance: dark amber color. Medium head, ivory color, dense and persistent. Good adherence at glass. Aroma: sweet malty, toffee, candy, butterscotch, vanilla, oak and cream. Evidently complex. Fruitiness of peaches, ripe pears and plums. Floral hoppy, some aniseed. Nutty, cherries and cinnamon touches. Flavor: syrupy malty, toffee, butterscotch, cream and vanilla notes in start. Sweet-fruity of syrup plums, red raisin, apricot and cherry. Too nutty, almonds, cinnamon and humid wood touches. Persistent hoppy finish, with aniseed and mentholated notes. Hidden liquory, reminiscences of camomile and amaretto liquors. Complex and self-personality. Palate: medium body, syrup texture. Little and medium carbonation. A Chilean nicety, complex, power and balanced.

Bottle. Color amber, very dark. The cloudy and cremy head. The Aroma is to strawberries and caramel. In paladar is very malty, with toasted seeds and wood. Some alcohol signs appear, in a penetrating sweet flavor. Very good finish, unexpected. A beer to recommend single to that they know to drink, because the alcohol well is camouflaged (Hidden).

Bottle, april 07. Thanks to Lilith, Nigredo and Panzerfaust!. Shinny, clear, deep copper/ burgundy color with light red hues and a creamy, dense, light beige head. Aroma is fruity, some dates, fruit cake and some brandy. Flavor is nutty, sherry brandy rich maltiness, complex, layered with some dried fruits. Excellent. Full MF, packs a flavor punch, deep, complex, satisfying and not heavy. Highly refined, nutty BW, which may be the finest south american brew.

column1: Big Buck Fire in the Hole
column5: Draft... GABF ’06... Clear golden lager with a small, creamy, off-white head. Very subtle, smoked bacon aroma. Smoky, beefy flavor. Well-balanced; moderately sweet, moderately bitter. Medium-bodied and fizzy. Short, crisp, smoky finish.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Woodys Light
column5: Clear yellow color with no lacing. Clean aroma with mild orange peel notes. Very crisp and clean throughout. Better than Budweiser.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Woodys Light
column5: Bottle. Pale yellow pour with a small foamy white head. Nose is all corn malt macro smelling skunk. Flavor is much of the same. palate light bodied and watery flat. Overall it’s crap but I bet the hicks and emo fags love it.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Woodys Light
column5: Pours a clear golden color wuth a thin creamy white head. Weak aroma and flavor of honeyish sweetness. The body is light with a watery texture and lively carbonation.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Woodys Light
column5: On draft at brewery. Poured water with a slight hue of gold. There was a nice bright white head. The aroma was sweet malt and little else. The taste is a bit thin with some sweet malt and hints of hops about midway to the finish. The beer ends a bit sweet. Really light in body and comes up a bit short on flavor. Still no real flavor faults to be found.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Woodys Light
column5: This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a transparent softly carbonated light yellow colored body and a good lacing. The mild aroma was malty. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of malt hops astringent and was slightly grassy. Not one that I would buy again.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Woodys Light
column5: Sample at the brewpub: Clear pale golden color with a thin white head and small patches of lacing. Weak aroma of sweet malt and a touch of hops. Light-bodied and bubbly on the tongue with a light hops flavor and an undetlying malt sweetness. The finish is crisp and short with barely detectable hops. Average overall.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Woodys Light
column5: Draft at Black Forest Brau Keller in Frankenmuth, MI. Poured a small white head that mostly diminished, very nice lacing, visible carbonation, transparent, and a pale yellow hue. Malty sweet nose. Flavor was malty sweet, crisp and refreshing. Mouthfeel was tingly. Light body.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Sullys Irish Stout
column5: This stout poured the usual black colour with a nice creamy brown head. To the nose was a light coffee scent with chocolate and some earthy notes. First sip was smooth with flavours of chocolate and burnt ash. A little coffee flavour added. The finish was very lightly hopped with a very small bitter flavour lasting to the end.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Sullys Irish Stout
column5: Pours a deep black color with small bronw highlights and a thin light brown head. Interesting aroma of chocolate and roasted malt. Mild flavor of chocolate and roasted malt with a bitter finish. The body is light with a dry texture and lively carbonation. As with the porter the flavor doesn’t follow through with the promises given by the aroma.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Sullys Irish Stout
column5: On draft (nitrogen) at brewery. Poured pitch black with creamy light brown Guinness type head. Excellent aroma of sweet caramel, roasted malts, molasses, and chocolate malts. Rich and inviting. The mouth feel is a tad thin but not too bad for the style. There are lots of sweet caramel malts, roasted to burnt malts and chocolate malts. Very tasty brew that left nice lacing behind.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Sullys Irish Stout
column5: Draft from the brewery. A burnt black beer. A bit grainy taste that makes it quite different. A very good beer, if not very stouty.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Sullys Irish Stout
column5: This draft brew from the brewery poured a head of foamy finely sized brown colored bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a opaque no visible carbonation black colored body and an excellent lacing. The aroma was brown malt dark malt and burnt malt. The semi-flat mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of malt brown malt and burnt malt. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Sullys Irish Stout
column5: Sample at the brewpub: Deep black color with a medium creamy beige head. Sticky spots of lacing on the glass. Roasted coffee, malt and a little bit of bacon in the nose. Smooth and creamy body with bitter espresso, malt and hops flavors. The finish is mildly bitter and keeps with the coffee theme. Pretty good overall.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Sullys Irish Stout
column5: Draft at Black Forest Brau Keller in Frankenmuth, MI. Huge tan head that mostly diminished, excellent lacing, mostly opaque, and a dark brown. Nose was roasty, chocolate note, coffee, and hop note. Flavor was coffee, chocolate, roasty, somewhat of a burnt flavor and bitter hops. Nicely done and very tasty. Smooth palate. Light-medium body. Another nice brew from this establishment.

Deep amber, light tan creamy head. Nose held soft notes of toasted florals, earth, caramel, and milk chocolate. Flavor was well toasted with more touches of caramel, chocolate, and just a hint of citrus. Light to medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry bittersweet finish. Not bad by any means...

Growler brought back by my brother-in-law. Nice ruddy copper body. Nose is peanutty malt, a little caramel, slight alcohol burn, perhaps a bit of light fruitiness. Flavor is caramel, more bitterness than I expected, a bit of fruit and a peanut-brittle finish. A bit odd.

Baltimore Location - 17.9 OG - Deep hazy amber, thick creamy white head. Intense hop bitter nose of evergreen, pine, and grapefruit rind, with a softer underlying wave of peach, apricot, and sweet gooey caramel. Flavor is deeply hoppy yet very smooth and well rounded by the caramel tones. Full bodied, soft carbonation, bitter finish. Really nice...
had two of these with dinner tonight. Pours copper, minimal head, translucent. Slight bitterness on top of crackers and malt. Slight floral finish. medium body.

Pour from a brown growler that I bought at the brew pub while passing through Ludington. Cloudy amber orange brew with decent head, ample delicate lacing in the glass. Moderate aroma blending citrus (orange), floral hops, a little each of wood, resin and spice. taste is moderately sweet caramel at the start, modest hops at mid swallow - woody, bitter, resinous, a little earth and fruit - a modest citrus flourish at the finish building on the mid swallow hop profile. Has the restraint and malt of an English IPA and half of the hops profile seems English (reminds me of fuggles hopped ales) but some of the citrus punch of an American IPA. Kind of straddles the styles but to my taste does so very successfully. I could easily kick back much more than this one growler!
Hazy gold draft as part of a flight in Ludington. Sweet citrus aroma like mandarin oranges. Green hops with some resin in the flavor. Nice.
Draft at the brewery. Caramel color with minimal head. Malt and hop aromas and flavors. Citrus too.

5 oz. sample on 5-20-12 (Flight 2)-served a murky light copper color, great nose of pine, citrus, and lake perch (yeah, even I didn’t get that one). Hits the mouth with a medium body, very fine malt laced with caramel up front, small hop wave in the middle, finish is mildly acidic. zzzz...

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear orange with a small white head. Aroma of light fruits, jam, and malt. Flavor of toasted wheaty malt, floral hops, and bitter hops in the finish. More of a pale ale than an IPA but a pretty decent drinker. 6/4/7/3/13 [3.3/5]

Growler straight from the brewery about a week old, courtesy of my girlfriend :) . Pours a decent light golden color with a beautiful thick creamy off white head. Aroma is a delicious blend of fresh piney hops with a nice sweet caramel malt backbone. Very fresh and delicious. Slightly citric with some sweet fruitiness. Flavor starts with a nice hop burst that isn’t too overly pressing, allowing the pale and caramel maltiness to come through. Kind of fades towards the finish and becomes a bit bland before a final medium bitterness that lingers for a bit. Medium creamy body and a weak carbonation from sitting in the growler. Not a bad IPA, not as bad as some other people seem to think. I think its easy drinking and not overly bitter

Tap: Clean golden hue, small ring of foam and good lace. The aroma has muted piney hops, apple and apricot esters, bready malt and a hint of diacetyl. The taste has an initial sharp hop bitterness and acidity but fades quickly, some pale malts but not much depth. The mouth feel is watery, soft and with a touch of mineral. A underwhelming beer that lacks any character.

Part of a sampler at the restaurant. I note that I had a cold when I visited and could not get a great sample of the aroma of the beers that I sampled. Very strong aroma (noted even with my cold). Strong citrus aroma and flavor (almost too strong).

Had this one on draught as part of the sampler at the brewpub in Ludington, Michigan. Clear, medium orange pour with lots of rosiness in the nose, very tannic and bitter with black tea, strong finish. A decent IPA.

Picked up a growler of this. poured a cloudy honey with a small off white head. aroma when I was pouring this got a big hit of malt but once in the glass it mellowed a bit, sour fruits, yeast, brown sugar, and alcohol as it warmed. flavor, spicey hints of cinnamon, malt and than the yeast. nice dry mouth feel on this one

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: On draft at the brewpub 11-10-06. Mahogany brown with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma of brown sugar and caramel. Medium body, lightly carbonated. Some hop flavors complement the brown sugary sweetness, but it still finishes a little sweet.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Medium brown, little head. Little aroma, faintly sweet. This was a light brown ale, a hint of coffee and chocolate, and a gentle but undefined hop bitterness to dry things out at the end. A fairly standard brown in all aspects, but not a bad one. Wish the exotic ingredients had made their presence felt a bit more.

75 cl bottle with simple paper label. Pale blonde. Coreander, citrus and banana in the aroma. Sweetish, wheaty flavor with citrus and touches of coreander. Label says hefe weissbier, but it has style marks of both Belgian and German wheat beers. Nevertheless a nice beer.

Growler at JJPM’s palce summer 07. Pours a hazy light orange and a thin lasting head- good lace. Aroma is initially orangey andpine hops whcih are nice but you also get some DMS and vegetal components. Light resins and citrus flavors, pine sap, orange peel, and a light caramel sweeetness- light toast- good bitter finish with more herbal notes in the end. Finishes clean as well.
On tap at the brewpub. Clear gold with a big white head. A solid sweet caramel is bludgeoned with grapefruit, pepper. Intensely bitter, but not overly sharp - the bitterness builds on you. Very good!

Growler shared by jjpm74. Golden hazy in color with a nice white head. Hoppy citrusy malty aroma. Piny, orange notes. Malty and hoppy flavor. Orange and grapefruit citrus notes. Nice. Sweet tasting. Finish is bitter. Medium bodied. Nice beer. Drinkable.

Growler generously shared by jjpm74 at his gathering. Poured a cloudy golden with a creamy white head. Rich hoppy aroma of pine, grass, and a bit of orange. Really nice. Flavor is somewhat yeasty with notes of grapefruit rind, orange, and some grass. Nice bitterness, yet not overflowing with hop flavor. Although the taste did not live up to the aroma, it was still a tasty double IPA.

Sampled from a growler on 9/20/06: Pours a clear copper orange with a nicely-lacing white head. Has a sweet caramel and fresh piny grapefruity hoppy aroma. Body starts lightly sweet but very bitter without much flavoring hops. Finishes pretty dry and bittersweet. Could use less bittering hops and more flavoring hops.

Slightly cloudy copper body with a medium long-lasting off-white head. Typical strong american ale aroma of alcohol, slightly roasted malts and a hint of hops. Rather strong alcohol presence made for a taste that felt more malty than hoppy. Taste was mainly warm malt caramel with some light wooden hops flavours. Mild-medium bitterness. Alcohol felt at least 8.8%, maybe more. Solid beer but not very flavourful. While I was at the brewpub I had three excellent IPAs. It’s ironic that the double IPA was half as good as a regular IPA (it mathematically evens out I guess).

Any first impressions? -Creamy lacing is painted atop the glowing pale amber. -Sandy, wooden hoppiness, and light biscuity maltiness fail to attract the nostrils. -A rough flavor profile still hits efficiently, as oranges, sand, and toast ferociously tango with their targeted tastebuds. -Well-malted and properly carbonated, this mouthfeel has a severity to it which some might tiring. What if you dig deeper? -Soaring sandy, piney hop bitterness has little malt support to ease its fierce approach. -A more constructive malt apport would have been soothing here. -This is a surprisingly average Double IPA from Willimantic; maybe this hop experiment is just not of the right lineage to please my tastebuds. On tap at the brewpub.

Sampler size sample. An odd take on the dIPA style, this poured with the usual head and with decent lacing. The aroma was of citrus and light pine. The flavor, while it had citrus and pine elements, was lacking a malty rich base that many a dIPA is known to have. The flavor offerred by the malts was also minimal, yet some sort of an odd character was underneat the hops, some funny candy-like aspect? The alcohol was well hidden, hard to believe a dIPA. A decent brew by a brewery that doesn’t confine itself to style guides.

Growler thanks to mkgrenwel. Poured a golden color with a small off-white head. Sweet malty aroma with a good amount of citrus, sweaty and earthy hops. I thought it was fairly balanced with the sweetness. For me with an IIPA I like unbalance with a huge forward hop profile. But still very good. Nice mixture of malt and hops. Moderate bitterness on the finish. Pretty drinkable.
Pours gold with a white head. Smells hoppy with some basic underlying malt. Taste is on the bitter side with some floral elements. Not as balanced as other IIPAs I’ve tried from them.

Draught sample at the brewpub. Pours amber with a thin tan head. Smells of perfume, toasted malt, some citrus. Tastes of toast, some earth, a hint of bitterness, some wildflowers. Well rounded and full bodied.

Pours light coppery orange with a nice thin white head and great lace. Aroma is floral and lightly citrus hops and a great bready malt backbone. Great bready doughy light toasted malts int eh flavor cut with a fresh herbal and floral german hops - slight grassiness, perfect moderate bitternesss for the malt used and just insanely drinkable.

Sampler size sample. Poured a pale golden yellow, nice initial head, pretty good lacing. The aroma was malty, some honey and bread. The flavor was comparable to that, rather refreshing with some fruity esters adding to the profile. The mouthfeel was dead on for a summer beer, full enough of flavor yet not thick or heavy. In the big scheme of life, a boring style (and beer), but done quite well within the category.

Very dark amber color. Lots of chocolate, bready, a caramelly touch, a bit of cherries. Malty, a bit unbalanced, but not as great as expected, but still not bad. A touch on the sour side. A touch of bread in the finish.
Nose is grainy with a hint of spice and biscuit, taste is dry, good bready flavors and mild sweetness.
tap at RnH - apricots and creme caramel, finishes buttery, astringent and sugary. See Paul’s rating.

Tap at Rattle N Hum for the Ballast Point Promo night with Joe and Zach. Pours an amber copper with an ok head. Slight butter in the aroma (tons in the flavor), caramel malts, toast, a bit sweet with grassy light hops. Flavor is light herbal, grassy hops, a big fat sweet malt profile with a slick and buttery middle and finish- Meh.

Tap at Rattle n Hum. Pours a light ruby-brown with a firm, off-white head. Pretty malty nose, some fruits. Very sweet flavor, plenty of caramel and deep maltiness. Medium in body with nice carbonation. Finishes sugary, a little sticky. A bit sweeter than the Oktoberfest brews I’m used to, and this is an OK thing.

Location: On tap at the Brewery, Linda Vista Location, 1/7/10 Overall Impression: This was a pretty solid Oktoberfest style beer. Not a huge variation off of what you would expect from the style, but solid, enjoyable, and well-made.
Pours a clear red copper with a thin head..Aroma is sweet and malty as is the flavor.. Slight oktoberfest yeast... Very drinkable.

Pours clear reddish copper wih a short beige head. Aroma is some sweet malt and a bit of honey, hints of spicy hops and yeast. Flavor is swwet clover honey, yeast, bready malts and light citrus. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation.

On tap @ the Linda Vista location. Clear copper orange with a small beige head, fair retention. Light caramel and toasted malts dominate with some lager yeast behind in the nose. I pick up a little ethanol in the flavor and lightly spicy hops. Bitterness peaks @ a 3, semi-dry. Moderate carbonation with a medium body. Not too bad.

Pint on tap@t Ballast Point Old Grove brewery: Deep amber, the color of rootbeer, with a small (bar pour) light beige head. Aroma is sweet malty caramel. Flavor starts caramel sweet balanced perfectly by a spicy hop bitterness in the finish. Medium body is smooth with moderate carbonation.

Draught ("fake" hand-pump)@Pullmans, Helsinki. Almost opaque black, small but firm tan head. Crisp, menthol like aroma mixed with grass and vegetables. Slightly toasted, a bit sweet porter with chocolaty, roasted aftertaste. Quite boring.

(Draught, fake-hand-pumped@Pullman, Helsinki) Very dark color with a creamy, beige head. Bitter and roasty, mildly acidic aroma with licorice hints. Ashy-roasty, licoricey flavor with some sweetish maltiness and vegetable hints. Almost medium-bodied, smooth-carbonated palate. A decent stout, but lacks that special something, and is a bit thin.

Cask Stillage from the festival bar at the Brunswick, Derby 29/09/2006 Strong and slightly fruity aroma. Black rich on the palate and very strong in alcohol. A slightly nutty and fruity bitter finish.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Out Of The Vaults Leicester. A black beer with some loose beige bubbles and a little lacing. The aroma is rich with coffee notes and sour fruits and berries. The taste is very intense with licquorice, coffee and fruit. A little sweet and bitter on the end like a camp coffee. Highly flavourful but not all together wonderfully balanced. Ultimately rich though.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Czech Pilsner
column5: Draft at the brewery - labeled Proto-Pils: Lemony yellow pour with a spritzy cap that settles into a thin ring. The Hallertau hops own the nose with grassy and piney influences. The body is light and lagery, with subtle hops playing off the bready, nutty malts. A simple beer that works ok - but it lacks that clean, zippy hoppiness that the really great pilsners display. A nice attempt at a tough style.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Czech Pilsner
column5: Pours a bright clear gold with half an inch of white head. Minimal head retention and just a bit of lacing. Mild lemony-hoppy aroma. Clean crisp and smooth beer that starts out with a hint of sweetness and then is topped by grassy spicy hops. Nice residual bitterness in the finish and aftertaste. Almost medium body, moderate carbonation.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Czech Pilsner
column5: This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a transparent softly carbonated straw yellow colored body and an excellent lacing. The mild aroma was malty. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the finish. The flavor contained notes of mild hops. Not one that I would buy again.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Czech Pilsner
column5: On draft at the brewpub, light to medium straw, white head that hung around the edges, good amount of lacings on the glass, lots of carbonation in this brew, some hops in the nose, also, the malts were faint, hops and low malt taste in the drink, hop bite with something just a little off in the finish maybe a metal taste, not sure, light to medium mouthfeel.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Czech Pilsner
column5: Sample at the brewpub: Clear yellow/gold color with a thin white head that fizzes away pretty quickly. Thin, spotty lacing as well. Saaz hops aroma with a touch of spice. Light-bodied and crisp with low amounts of hops and malt flavor. The finish comes through a little better with a nice hops presence. Overall though this is pretty forgettable.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller Czech Pilsner
column5: Draft at Black Forest Brau Keller in Frankenmuth, MI. Appearance was a small white fizzy head that mostly diminished, fair amount of lacing, visible carbonation, transparent, and a straw yellow hue. Malty, hoppy and bitter nose. Flavor was bitter, malty, hoppy, and crisp tasting. Smooth mouthfeel. Medium body.

column1: Coast Range Farmhouse Fresh Hop Ale
column5: Tap @ Toronado. A wet hop IPA. Golden color with a white head. A citrus aroma, light on the malts but very smooth. A slight mint touch in the flavor. Not as bitter as I would have expected.

column1: Coast Range Farmhouse Fresh Hop Ale
column5: Draft. Hazy amber beer with a nice white head. Low spice and malt aroma. Grassy, earthy, slight malt flavor with some spice. Lingering muddled spice and more. It’s a wet hop IPA, but it just comes across as muddled english hops.

Reviewed from notes. Is this place still open? I don’t know, but here’s my take on this beer. This was poured into a mug. The appearance was a fairly decent golden yellow to bronzed orange color. There was a one finger white foamy head that dissipated within less than a minute. Lacing, well, there was some, but it wasn’t much. The smell had some openly sweet German malts invading my nose at a fairly decent pace and then lets in a light hellartau (spice) that comes across fairly nice. The taste was mainly sweet and added a fair graininess to it. The hops take a back seat the more it warms, spice - what spice. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. Overall, where’s the Bavarian pretzels, ’cause that’s what I want with this beer - if this place is still open.
hazy gold, respectable fluffy off white head. nose of musty malt. flavor is malty with a trace of caramel. medium bodied, dry finish. a touch too mild for me.
a good buzz can make it hard to remember the details. this beer was pretty decent though.

This draft brew from the brew pub poured a medium sized head of foamy finely sized tan colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a transparent typically carbonated orange brown colored body. The mild aroma was malty and sweet. The crisp mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the finish. The mild flavor contained notes of malt and wheat. An OK brew just nothing special.

Draft at Black Forest Brau Keller in Frankenmuth, MI. Poured a small smooth off-white head that was mostly lasting, fair amount of lacing, transparent, visible carbonation, and a gold hue. Malty, sweet and caramel nose and ditto for the flavor. Smooth mouthfeel. Light-medium body.
Rich amber beer with a slight red color and off-white head. Slight lemon citrus aroma with some caramel. Lemony citrus flavor with some grass and malt. Light, drinkable, but too much lemon.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller American Brown
column5: Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass at the brewery. The appearance was a fairly decent hazy brown color with a bar pour’s kind of slim white film of a head. The smell had a fairly decent earthy to sweet to bitter to somewhat rolling roasty nutty to even just a tad of vanilla in there. Yeah, its there, super slightly, but its there. The taste took those previously stated flavors and combined to taste. Mmmm....it ended up coming across pretty good as it combined. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a decent sessionability about it. The carbonation left a bit to be desired, but no worries as it came across super smooth rolling over my tongue in a super smooth sort of way. Overall, just an absolute wonderful Brown Ale. This is the kind of brown ale that brown ale fans could get behind!

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller American Brown
column5: On draft at brewery. This beer poured sort of dark copper to amber in color with thin off white to tan head. There wasn’t much aroma to speak of. I think I smell a bit of sweet malt and a touch of hops. The flavor had a slight caramel to nutty maltiness mild hop bitterness. OK beer.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller American Brown
column5: This draft brew from the brew pub poured a small sized head of foamy fine to medium sized bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a transparent uncarbonated brown colored body. The mild aroma was malty. The crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a medium hoppy aftertaste. The strong flavor contained notes of mild malt and crisp hops. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller American Brown
column5: Sample at the brewpub: This brew is dark brown with ruby around the edges. Thin light beige head with fair retention. The aroma is nutty and hoppy. Medium-bodied and rather smooth with caramel, malt and hops flavor, with a touch of nuts. The finish is bitter and hoppy, moreso than is usual for the style. Still this is an above average beer.

column1: Black Forest Brau Keller American Brown
column5: Draft at Black Forest Brau Keller in Frankenmuth, MI. A very small tan head that mostly diminished, decent amount of lacing, no visible carbonation, transparent, and an orange brown hue. Nose was hoppy, malty and somewhat sweet. Flavor was malty, hoppy and some chocolate. Hoppy mouthfeel. Medium body.

Tried at the Great Central Railway beer festival 2018. Aroma of hop fruits and pale malts. Pours golden with diminishing white lace. Taste is medium bitter to lightly sour. Palate is medium bodied, oily texture, average carbonation and a soft sour finish. Not as pungent as promised and the well hopped finish drifts from bitter to sour.

Cask conditioned at Harbury Beer Festival ’16, Harbury, Warks. Beautiful, clear amber with white head. There is a sweet, fruity maltiness to this, biscuity with a tropical fruit note. Some toffee, caramel hints. Lasting on the palate. Really very pleasant.
Cask at the Victoria, Rugby 14/10/14, Golden ale with hoppy finish, thin white head, Very good.

Cask @ Black Hotel, Sheffield Amber, dense thin white head, good lacing Aroma - some cereal malts, pale caramel, little aroma Taste - cereal malts, fairly bitter english hops, dab of honey, light caramel, not a lot going on here for 5.2% abv Palate - soft carb, thin to medium body, quite oily. Finish of caramel malts and soft bitter cereal hops Overall - Hmmm it’s NO hop bomb, more a single bubble bursting in some bubble wrap

Cask at the Victoria Inn, Rugby - 19/09/12. Clear copper with a bubbly white head. Toffee and caramel on the nose allied to light biscuit malts. Tastes as nose, more depth, more toffee. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation and a decent smooth finish.

Cask, The Crown, Nuneaton. Ripe hop citrus rounded with oaty biscuit. Deep gold with faint haze. Sulphur and citrus aroma with a rub of musty hopleaf. Billowing and lovely. Approaching something very good indeed.

Cask at GBBF 2007. A dark golden beer with a white head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel and grassy hops, as well as light notes of alcohol. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel as well as light notes of alcohol, leading to a slightly bitter finish.

Clear golden pour wearing an initial white head that rapidly diminishes. Brightly, strongly hopped ale trying to live up to its name. Very dry, floral, orangey and even grapefruity aromas. The light grassiness feels more English already, so does the growing sunflower seed and sesame, cerealic sweet maltiness that we find in mouth. Mostly an aromatic hop bill. Well-balanced and with a grip. Light-bodied, fitting carbonation.
Cask at GBBF. Dark golden few head. Hoppy and citric aroma with notes of pine-needles. Flavour of green hops, citric fruit and subtle pale malts. Long bitter finish of grapefruit and resin.

(Cask at GBBF, London, 8 Aug 2007) Golden yellow colour with copper hints, brief white head. Fruity, hoppy nose with notes of grapefruit, orange and pine needles. Fruity taste with grapefruit, pine needles, orange peel and a resiny, slightly sweetish finish. Nice, hoppy golden ale.
Cask at the Bishop Blaize, Richmond. White head. Amber body. Malt and sulphur. Bitter. Dry finish.
Wales 2014. Beer no 21. Cask@the Wellington, new quay, wales. Amber beer with medium head and some lacing. Aroma of malts. Taste is malts, a touch of caramel and mild hops. Basic stuff.
Cask at Christmas market in Kingston. A touch of spice, nice balance, some doughy malt and hop bitterness. Decent session beer.
Actually 5%. My ale of choice in the Queens Vaults, Cardiff. Nice bitter, golden and hoppy

Gold with a white head. Pear fruit aroma gave way to treacly slightly sweaty malt. Taste was malty and sweet. Rather doughy flavour intruded. Very gassy beer lacking a satisfactory finish. To be honest I wasn’t too keen.

Cask Stillage at the Assembly Rooms, Derby Beer Festival 11/07/2008 (Listed as 5.0% ABV) Hoppy slightly sweet aroma. Golden coloured and hoppy with a sweet honey flavour. A little spicy. Floral and slightly bitter malt finish.
Cask at the Derby Beer Festival. I found this hasy, golden, fruity beer to have a weird flavour and unpleasant aftertaste.

Cask (St. Urho’s, Helsinki) Cherryade colour, almost no loose head. Spicy fruits, dark berries, cherry, apple, some raspberry. Powerful malty, but still quite thin, or watery, taste. Big on the apple and fruits.
Cask at troon beer fest 07. Aroma is packed with biscuity sweet pale malts. Taste is so sweet its almost cloying and very unbalanced.
Cask at Charlies. Amber colour with a small white head. Light caramel malty, fruity aroma and taste, hoppy. Medium body with a bitter dry finish.
09.10.2009 on tap at the brewpub. Brown colour with white head. Very nice malty aroma and I have written "Beautiful" in my notes.

Firm white head, amber color. Fruity and refreshing beer, quite complex. It is almost there, but a little too thin, brewing this at a little extra strength would possibly have done the trick. Still, this is a micro to look out for.
Simplistic and clean, both in looks, taste and body. Hopless, disappointing even with my low expectations. Ugly grey head gives rise to a too carbonated body. Yuck. (25cl bottle from Auchan)
Couleur dorée, bonne mousse blanche. Bon nez malté. Corps leger ss trop de carbonation, mais malgrés tout gout malté et legerment céréales. Pas trop mal pour une lager 1er prix.

25.07.2013. 0,5l Can. Brussel. Golden yellow colour with white head. Aroma of Malt and yeast. Grassy hops with good bitterness. Malty medium body. Aftertaste is bitter and leaves a dry bitter mouthfeel. Ripe apples.
0.5 l can, thanks Timo P! Pale golden color. Sweet aroma of honeyish malt. Sweet honeyish and grainy flavor with restrained herbal hops. Light bodied, fizzy watery palate.
Aroma is sugary malt, a tad malt liquorish. Flavour is watery malt, some spice.
Das Billigbier von Auchan. Die Schaumkorne hält mittelmäßig. Geschmacklich ist es sehr wässrig nur etwas malzig. Test vom 21.9.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 7,5,5,4,7,4 - 4,75

50cl can. Golden beer with minimal quickly diminishes white head. Aroma is floral hops and herbal. Flavour is moderate bittery with a short final that is not very noticeable by its bitterness. Carbonation is medium. Body is light.

can from Auchan Illkirch-Graffenstaden France. Clear pale yellow colour, large and very persistent white head. Sweet malty nose. Light-bodied, yet quite malty. Sweet malt falvours with some rather shy hops. Bitter hops dominate, aromatic hops are in the far background only. Really not bad for a cheap lager.

Canned 0,50L. Sterling Premium Pur Malt. Golden yellow color, little bubbly aspect. Escaping and evanenscent head. Poor nose with little notes of grassy, maize and dampen cereals. Gaunt taste, lighlty alcoholic with notes of cereals, wheat and little other. Very watery and little unbalanced with metallic notes on the end.
Can 50cl at Auchan. A creamy lager, better than expected with medium body and ok malty character. Quite drinkable for a cheap lager, not acid and not too dry.

8 oz draught glass at the brewpub. Opaque, dirty caramel hue, fairly still with no real head....banana-clovey typical German wheat aromas, a bit of dry grass and sweetish chocolate....sweet banana-shake and a bit of sourdough in the body, grassy bitterness towards the end, good caramelized malt backdrop, fairly low carbonation.....a bit of lemon-lime/7Up sorta feeling to the finish though the carbonation isn’t sodalike....mineralic qualities a bit strong. Ehh.

A bomb of a beer, poured a light brown color (filtered?), almost non-existent head. Aroma was initially bananas and cloves under some roasted character. The flavor seemed to take on that aspect, but at the same time it hammered each sip with a chemical type off-taste, really off. The chemical taste got disgusting after a few sips, quite sad. Don’t know what happened to this one, but something wasn’t done right.

Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a dark brown close to black color with a finger’s worth of eggshell white foamy head that dissipated at a mild pace. Some stringy lace. The aroma had some char/ash, rugged coffee grounds, burnt toast, dried earthy hops and lets in a nice expected smokiness. The flavor lead with the smoke and brought in touches of sweetness melding with the coffee grounds somewhat. Aftertaste is "char-like" with some hints of dark chocolate and earthiness. Not much finish, but was somewhat dry. The feel was about medium bodied with a fair sessionability about it. Sly smoky smoothness strolled along my tongue. Carbonation felt nice. ABV felt appropriate. Overall, pretty nice smoked porter worthy of more pours, but not at the same level as Alaskan’s.
A unique flavored beer... as you might guess it tastes smokey. Something to drink by the camp fire on a cold night
On tap at the brewery. Pours black with a beige head. Slightly smoky roasty aromas. Roasted slightly bitter charred malts. Finishes dry and roasty. Nothing too special, but decent.

Growler- Thanks Mike- Dark deep brown, some head. Growler is about 2 weeks old. Nose is gentle, some smoke and some roast malts. Drinking is easy, great breakfast beer, some smoke in the backround, sweet roasted flavors up front.

Tap: Deep brown with some head and okay lace. The aroma has notes of smoke and roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, herbal and citric hops, and some toast. The taste starts with a nice chocolate and toasted malt character supported by some ripe plum and coffee bitterness. The finish is smoky and earthy with a touch of resiny hop. The mouth feel is smooth and dry, chalky and a tad thin. With better mouth feel and depth this would be very good, still quite drinkable and worth a try.

Growler courtesy of Pailhead. Very dark brown almost black, minimal head. Big choclate aroma up front, fades to smoke and pine resin. No coffee detectable whatsoever, (this is a good thing for me)! Flavor much the same. Choclate up front, not quite as strong as aroma suggests. Some roasted/burnt grain and just enough smoke to register. Lingering pine aftertaste. Silky smooth palate and mouthfeel. Very well done.

Courtesy of my friend Sean Growler: Aroma of moderate smoke, chocolate, and faint roasted coffee. It pours a dark brown with no transparency and a small beige/brown head that quickly fades to a ring around the edges of the glass. The flavor starts with moderate chocolate and roasted malt. There is some faint coffee in the background. It finishes with moderate bitter burnt, smoke, and pine flavors with a hint of wood. Medium bodied with mild carbonation. A solid smoked porter.

On tap at the brewery. Opaque medium brown body, medium cream head. Light chocolatey, roasty aroma (but served too cold). Light sweet body, lactic, with notes of milk chocolate, coffee, and dry roast. Light peaty notes add a salty, leathery characteristic to the beer. Good complexity, but slightly astringent and a bit rough on the palate.

Draft at brewpub. Poured dark brown color with an average brown frothy head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate roasted sweet malty with a light smoke aroma. Medium body with a creamy texture. Medium sweet flavor with a medium bitter finish of moderate duration. Good drinkable porter.

column1: The Brew Kettle Dead Poets Imperial IPA
column5: Love this beer! Suggestion- if you start with this beer, you will need to finish with this beer. All of the other beers will not taste normal to you.

column1: The Brew Kettle Dead Poets Imperial IPA
column5: Bottle pours amber color with off white head. Aroma was bitter hops. Not the best nose I’ve had for this style. Just average. Medium mouthfeel. Flavor was very bitter, has a somewhat nice malt backbone. Again, just average. Finishes dry and bitter. So this was an average brew all around.

column1: The Brew Kettle Dead Poets Imperial IPA
column5: 22 oz bottle via homebrew Mys Swap 1.0 (thanks crizay!). Ok, so this one comes out as an almost clear amber with an average size beige head. Nose is mellow and i am not picking up a whole lot for an IIPA...just some muted hops..cannot make out much on profile..perhaps some orange and pineapple. Taste starts and ends with the malts....this is more like a wannabe yet thin barleywine than an IIPA. Lots of fruity esters, a bit of fusel alc, some toasted grains, and some subdued earthy/spicy hops. Body is light/medium, carbonation is adequate. THis seems like a beer that has not found it’s identity. Is it a light-bodied barleywine that needs more time? It is certainly closer to that than it is a fresh hoppy IIPA...

column1: The Brew Kettle Dead Poets Imperial IPA
column5: Date: 03/12/2007 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting clear gold, frothy off white head, streaks of lace, sweet malty aroma with a sharp floral edge, light sweet malt flavor, good hop flavor, a touch of an astrengent and soapy character, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: **/4

column1: The Brew Kettle Dead Poets Imperial IPA
column5: Bottle...Clear amber ale with a small, creamy, white head. Rich aroma of toffee and caramel with an earthy note of juniper and fruity jolts of peach and orange. Crystal malt flavors of caramel and toffee are beaten down by heavily bitter, earthy hops. Medium-bodied with a skim-milk mouthfeel and prickly carbonation. Lengthy, bitter finish with a topical anesthetic effect on and around my tongue. Thanks, crizay, for sending the bottle!

column1: The Brew Kettle Dead Poets Imperial IPA
column5: Bottle courtesy of crizay. Pours copper with a nice white head. Smells of citrus, roses, sweet malt, some tangy hints, hints of earthiness. Tastes of tea, pepper, some dry malt, some resiny hop notes. Mouthfeel is full bodied. Finish is bitter and lasting. Not as over the top as many IIPAs I’ve sampled. This one has some depth to it and reminds me more of a ramped up English Pale Ale. Either way, kudos to the brewer!

column1: The Brew Kettle Dead Poets Imperial IPA
column5: Bottle sampled on 3/12/07: Pours a transparent bright bronze with a large, frothy well-lacing white head. Aroma of sweet biscuity pale malt with some earthy piny hoppy notes. Body starts fairly sweet and pale malty with some toasty toffee notes and some bittering piny hops with a touch of citrusy notes. A decent IIPA.

column1: The Brew Kettle Dead Poets Imperial IPA
column5: Poured a clear yellow color with a medium sized creamy off-white head. The aroma was of light lemon and citrus. It kind of reminded me of an American Wheat with the lemony notes. The flavor was light and semi-sweet. Lemons but without the tartness. Moderately dry and bitter finish. Light to medium body.

column1: The Brew Kettle Dead Poets Imperial IPA
column5: Thanks to the Atlanta crew for sharing. Light gold, white head. Nose is lemon, mango, fruit, light caramel. Flavor is light caramel, bitter catty lemon, slight malty toffee.

column1: The Brew Kettle Dead Poets Imperial IPA
column5: 22 oz bottle, bottle conditioned (surprisingly): Light medium amber w/ a lasting off white head. This beer, according to Jeff the bartender is the Olde 21’s little brother! Citrusy grapefruit hops with a heaping helping of piney hops. Younger sibling diacetyl also shows up to annoy his bigger brothers. Lightly toasty and malt presence a bit overshadowed by the hops, but we do the hokey pokey and we turn ourselves about, that’s what it’s all about! Flavor is pretty well balanced, but a bit on the sweet side from start to finish. A good bit of grapefruity and floral hop flavor, but does not quite overshadow the malts like it does in the aroma. Malts are mostly toasty with some caramel with the diacetyl a bit lighter in the flavor than the aroma. Finish is on the slightly sweet side and the aftertaste is a bit hop flavored, but it sort of fizzles in the aftertaste a little bit. Smooth fuller medium body, well hidden alcohol (whatever it might be, Jeff was unsure). A pretty good drinkable beer, save for the diacetyl, which isn’t overbearing, but there.

Cask conditioned @ Guide Dog, Soton. Amber colour. Restrained malts with some caramel and fruity sweetness. Dominant factor here are the orangey leafy hops. There is a slight problem with this, in as far as the fresh hop character on occasion comes across as bearing a similarity to the ’freshness’ of some cleaning products. Apart from that its quite pleasant and ends on a tasty mouthfilling bitter finish. Light and enjoyable but doesnt stand up to closer inspection.

column1: Kenco Farms Honey Wine Dry Mead
column5: Bottle shared by Jeremy. Pours clear light golden, no head or lacing. Honey, herbal, light cinnamon. Decent

column1: Kenco Farms Honey Wine Dry Mead
column5: 750ml bottle pours out crisp golden. Nose is nice sweet honey vanilla floral notes and some citrus. Taste is more of the nice sweet honey vanilla floral mix.

column1: Kenco Farms Honey Wine Dry Mead
column5: Bottle tasting at Travlr’s. Clear gold with no head. Sweet floral honey. Pretty good.

column1: Kenco Farms Honey Wine Dry Mead
column5: [ Bottle ][ 1oz ][ Tasting ][ ][ Snifter ][ 11.09.14 ] transparent hay-gold, smallest white bubble collar. High plastic booze nose, fusel with light honey sweetness, hay. Sweet front palate, honey and sugar burning, lightly sticky, thin body mid with high alcohol in the hot finish.

column1: Kenco Farms Honey Wine Dry Mead
column5: 750 ml bottle. Poured into a brandy snifter. Pours a clear, light yellow. The aroma has sweet honey. Very sweet taste. Mouth coating. Easily drinkable.

column1: Kenco Farms Honey Wine Dry Mead
column5: From a bottle at the DC Pre-Turkey Day Tasting, Novemeber 9, 2014. Courtesy of Travlr. Pours a clear pale gold with a scant head. Sweet floral nose and flavors. Pretty tasty.

column1: Kenco Farms Honey Wine Dry Mead
column5: Bottle shared by Travlr at DC Pre-Thanksgiving tasting. Thanks! Poured a flat golden yellow color with no head. Aroma was light floral notes, honey sweetness. Flavor was sweet, slightly dry notes - some light vanilla.

column1: Kenco Farms Honey Wine Dry Mead
column5: Decent. Peppery with a little touch of citrus. Pours golden. Sweet finish. Bottle at tasting.

column1: Kenco Farms Honey Wine Dry Mead
column5: Bottle shared by Travlr. Pours clear gold and still. Aroma is sweet honey, light vanilla notes. Flavor is sweet honey and a dry finish. Full body.

column1: Kenco Farms Honey Wine Dry Mead
column5: Bottle. Crystal clear golden yellow color. Very aromatic, perfume and flowers. Taste starts sweet, floral, bright citrus, dry finish. Not bad.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Poured a hazy amber color with a white head. Let minimal lacing as it went. Aroma was grapefruit, spruce, pines and grass. Flavor was hoppy with pines, citrus and hops. Oily and sticky mouth feel.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Sample at Autumn Festival of Ales - Hoppy nose, citrusy hop palate, some depth in flavor. I’d have it again.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Growler from the brewery. Dark amber with a light tan head. Big citric and floral hop aroma with just a hint of caramel. As the aroma promised, this is a very hop-forward IPA, lots of grapefruit bitterness, but it does have a touch of honey-like sweetness in the background. Long, bitter finish. Pretty full bodied, nice smooth carbonation.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Very good IPA. clean finish makes the dirtiest mouth feel clean. No matter what this beer is a good way to restart a horrible day!

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: (draft @ 2006 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY) Dark amber in color with a thick tan head. Aroma is really hoppy with lots of floral notes and some citrus. Flavor begins with some hops and then a caramel malt middle and a lightly floral finish. Not too bad.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: It had a dark coppery amber color with good clarity. The head was small, slightly off white in color and faded to a thin, slick ring of lace on top. The aroma had a deep burnt caramel and toasted malt presence with a somewhat spicy and leafy hop aroma. The flavor had a deep muddled malty sweetness. There are notes of burnt caramel, dark molasses and brown sugar that mix with slightly spicy and leafy hops. Overall this gives it a dark and murky character. The finish has more of a hops bitterness popping the deep maltiness as well as some grainy alcohol notes. It has a full body with a heavy, smooth and slightly slick texture and light to average carbonation.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 2010 Autumn Festival of Ales - Honeoye Falls, NY Amber in color with a thin tan head. Aroma is rather malty and bitter with some hops, but mostly sweet malts. Flavor is smooth and malty with a nice sweetness at the end that is a slight hoppy.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap, poured an orangeish brown. Nothing spectacular, but a standard Oktoberfest here. Malty, somewhat nutty with a nice sweetness. Pretty crisp.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Bitter bavarian/sharp malt aroma. Mild hint of butterscotch. Needs agitation or comes off as stale. The appearance is hazy reddish orange. Short-lived head. Nice color, clear body. The malt flavors are very sweet and butterscotchy, but with a little bitter bite at the end. Feels very smooth and buttery, true to style. An easy-drinker. Be careful not to let it sit too long or it will get musty.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: copper pour with a tight white head. Crisp Malt aroma with some slight hop. Flavor was crisp, sweet caramel malt, and a clean toasted finish. Not bad

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Att Cottage Hotel following Autumn Festival of Ales - Really flat, a signature it seems of this style, with some wood on palate. This one was vaguely creamy. Not for me.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a pint glass. This bottle was purchased at the (2008) Buffalo Central Terminal Oktoberfest and was specially labeled for the event. Appearance: It had a dark coppery amber color with good clarity. The head was small, slightly off white in color and faded to a thin, slick ring of lace on top. Smell: The aroma had a deep burnt caramel and toasted malt presence with a somewhat spicy and leafy hop aroma. Taste/Mouth feel: The flavor had a deep muddled malty sweetness. There are notes of burnt caramel, dark molasses and brown sugar that mix with slightly spicy and leafy hops. Overall this gives it a dark and murky character. The finish has more of a hops bitterness popping the deep maltiness as well as some grainy alcohol notes. It has a full body with a heavy, smooth and slightly slick texture and light to average carbonation. Notes: Its dark deep murky complexity is very interesting but seems to take away from its overall drinkability.

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. pours a light colored amber. malt filled aromas. Toasty caramel taste. Not a bad marzen

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: (Growler from Hegedorn’s) CB Oktoberfest is a hazy amber beer with a foamy off-white head with pretty good retention and lacing. The aroma is of pretzels and malt. It’s a simple and soft smell. The are hardly any hops in the nose. When detected, they seem wooden and minty. It is smooth and medium-bodied-- a bit syrupy. The carbonation is prickly and it feels a bit silty. It’s well-balanced. The malt is like a sourdough pretzel. The hops are firm but smooth and quite medicinal. There is almost a quinine aftertaste. This growler made for good drinking in the back yard on a picture-perfect autumn day. Eins, zei, drei, zuffa!

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Ah hah! They did it again! Fabulous brew. I was happy. For once in my measly miserable life I was happy. Then it was gone and I could resume my regular status.

Bottle 50cl, an amber brown beer with huge head. Nose is light on malt and wheat, touch of fruit with tart notes. Aroma is as well as for the usual hefeweizen with a sourish background that kills the body, less wheat and toasted / roasted notes, quite disappointing, very basic for germany.
Klassisches Dunkelweizen ohne Ueberraschungen. Gewohntermassen Malz, Hefe, Weizen und ein paar Pflaumen oder Rosinen. Fuer Fans.
The beer has got a cloudy dark brown colour with a steady head and smooth body. Aroma of wheat and yeast. Taste of roasted wheat, dark bread, fruits, yeast and nuts. Dusty finish. Average brew.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes braunes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, röstmalzig, leicht fruchtig würzig. Geschmack hefig, leicht würzig, leicht fruchtig.

500ml bottle. Cloudy chestnut colour with small, frothy, diminishing, off-white head. Wheaty, fruity aroma, hints of apple, dark bread, a spicy, yeasty touch. Taste is minimally dry, minimally tart, spicy yeasty, hints of dark bread; bitter hoppy finish.
Pours a decent copper with hints of autumn harvest. Aroma of wheat, banana, and clove. Flavor is banana, nut, caramel, and a touch of molasses.

Bottle 500ml. @ home. Hazy matt medium brown colour with a average to large, frothy - open, quick, good lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, wheat, caramel, light to moderate yeasty. Flavour is moderate sweet with a average duration, caramel, wheat, fruity. Body is medium, texture is watery - creamy, thin, carbonation is soft - fizzy. [20131006]

Bottle from Bierzwerg! Gusher. Pours muddy brown with very soapy head. Smell is malty and nutty with some caramel. Starts slight yeasty sourish with flat carbonation. Very nutty and malty sweetish, with lots of caramel. Finish is yeasty, well balanced sweet and sourish with some roasted nuts.
bottle (gushing) from Bierzwerg. Murky brown, bubbly-fluffy beige head, quickly collapsing. Chocolatey and wheaty with a yeasty-fruity touch.

(bottle, a gusher) pours a murky brown colour with a fizzy off-white head. aroma of banana, caramel, light nail polish remover, gravy and roasted wheat. flavour is mostly the same, lots of roasted wheat and caramel, with a hint of orange peel and nutmeg. medium-bodied with fizzy carbonation.
On cask at Smiths of Bourne. Black colour with a thin head. Aroma plum and hints of toast. Taste sweet fruity plum. Medium light body.

Draught at The Bailiff's Tap, Banbury, Oxon. Dark brown with cream head. Well this certainly has a plummy flavour, sweet and juicy in character. The dark roasted malts come through, hint of smoke, charcoal. Reasonable but a little full for the palate on a lunch time. Decent.
Draught, looks lovely, near-black with a lasting crema, nose is lightly smoky, very lightly plummy, an initial slight fruity tang gives way to a smoky-roasty maltiness with just a distant plum note.
Cask at Early Doors Daventry. Clear red mahogany with good cream head. Nice fruity plum nose with sweet plum chocolate notes
Cask @ The Jolly Brewer, Stamford. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, little plums, chocolate and coffee. Sweet plum finish.

16/10/2018. Cask at the Jolly Brewer, Stamford. Pours dark mahogany brown with a small creamy off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt, sweet fruit, toffee, hint of chocolate, nut and spice. Moderate sweetness, medium bitterness. Medium body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation action. Roasted bitterness to finish.

Cask @ Jolly Brewer, Stamford. Clear very dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, roasted malt and plum. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted moderate bitter finish. 161018
Cask. Very plummy aroma. Pours chestnut brown with white lace top. Taste has fruit to the fore - hints of strawberries behind the plum. Acid finish but overall a pleasing porter.

Dark brown, translucent and pretty flat. Plum is in abundance in the aroma, along with charcoal, liquorice and slate. Very sweet at first, fading slowly to bittersweet in the finish with gooey plummy notes all the way down. Aftertaste has a bit too much acidity. All in all it is quite delicious, and is one of those lower strength beers that still manages to feel boozier than it is.

Cask (gravity) @ NWAF 2016, National Winter Ales Festival (2016), The Roundhouse, Pride Park, Derby, Derbyshire, England, DE24 8JE. [ As Nobbys Plum Porter ]. Clear medium to dark brown color with a average, frothy - fizzy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, candy, fruity, plum, strawberry, UK yeast notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a long duration, plum, roasted, dark malt, strawberry sweet. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20160217]

[Colorado Road Trip – 2006] A deep golden brown brew with a very refreshing aroma. This had subtle spiciness in the nose. Good flavor and a medium body to this beer. This was a good example of a Marzen. Had a malt balance with the spices. I liked this beer.
Tap at brewpub. Pours pure, decent gold. Aroma is wort and cereal. Light hops flavor. Coating mouthfeel. Pleasant and light.

[Colorado Road Trip – 2006] A deep amber color with a nice aroma of malts and hops. This was a medium style of beers with a lack of the bitterness that most EBS would have. I did like the flavor but as for style this was off.

Bottle (schwing top) split at CBC Islington, belated Tipple 10K, thanks to Kenny 18/12/18. Rich chestnut brown with a moderately appointed beige covering. Nose is dark malts, soy sauce, oxidised notes, earthy fruits, toffee. Taste comprises treacle toffee, fruit cake, brown sugar, dark malts, dates, light spice. Medium plus body, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Passable number .... taste picked up from the nose but I wouldn't want a whole lot of this number.

Bottle shared at Craft beer co Islington. 18/12/2018. Many thanks! An thick oily caramel brown coloured pour with no head. Aroma is sweet oily, flabby, boozy caramel. Flavour is composed of, sticky sweet, musty brandy, sherry, cakey malts, flabby , oily, grappa. Paaltes i smedium sweet, sticky, low condition. Flabby sovent, boozy.

Swing-top shared in London - cheers to Ken. Pours clear amber with a small, creamy topping. Quite oxidised, lots of oily caramel, alcohol, brown bread. Full bodied, chewy, with no carbonation. Warm to hot finish, some sticky sugars, a little cardboard. A bit rough.

18Dec2018 Intense sweet malts, ovaltine, molasses. Clear, very dark brown, small, frothy, beige head. Heavy sweet. More ovaltine, chocolate, molasses, cacao, dark malts, soft carbonation, full bodied. Nice, very boosty. Bottle shared at CBC, Islington.

18th December 2018 Craft Islington Bottleshare. Hazy amber beer, no head. Smooth and slightly viscous palate. Soft sweet malts. Lovely smooth caramel. Modest toffee. Smooth sherry, modest port wine. JW Lees Harvest ale type ripe fruits. Smooth finish brings a very mild savoury vibe. Fruity linger. Very nice indeed, bloody drinkable!
Cool flip top bottle thanks to Toby pours out copper color with no head. Nose is tons of sweet malts vanilla booze brown sugar and maple. Taste is more of the nice big sweet booze notes port like.

thanks to Dak for popping this on my birthday. Wow... I can’t believe this isn’t oxidized. It tastes very fresh. Im very surprised. Very very very cloying sweet and the booze is well hidden. Also, minimal carb / completely flat

Flip top bottle. Poured a dark amber color with no head. Wow, this one was 20% - some alcohol, but not 20%. Sherry, vanilla, oaky/wood, caramel, port, and brown sugary sweet. Sipper for sure - nice, but over priced.
Big brown sugar and a mouthful of sweet graham cracker and caramel. This beer holds up!
Sad it"s all gone. What a smooth beer with so much character. Hides the alcohol content very well.
cask at guilford ... brown ... thin tan head ... soft roast nose... soft light bitter dark fruits and roast malt

Cask conditioned at Stratford upon Avon Beer fest ’07. Brown beer with white head. Expecting a great deal and delivering not very much really, flavour and aroma wise hardly anything, there is a touch of dry tea in the body, it is dryly bitter on the finish with a deeper roasted malt. Unexiting.

A Mes rate: Cask at the Wenlock Arms. Mellow nose with not a lot going on but nothing offensive. Redish brown body but with pretty much zero head due to the lack of carb. Caramel, toffee and tobacco. Slight floral hop notes but generally malty and semi sweet. Palate lets it down a little. So so.

Dark copper to umber color with a diminishing ecru head. Toasted malt and some raw grain scents. Sweeter start with again a mix of grains and malt. Slightly astringent. An slightly better than average amber lager. 2/16

12oz bottle pours a deep ruby/Amber with a large khaki head. Aroma of rye like caramel and toffee malts. Spicy grainy caramel and toffee malts, pencil and rye. Not bad, some nice flavors going on for the style.
Not bad. Has a nice malty, toffee aroma. Flavor’s like nose but with a touch of bitter in the finish that doesn’t really help it out. Body is a touch thin. Fairly drinkable overall.

Bottle poured a clear reddish amber with a lingering ring of amber foam. Aromas of caramel, toasted malt and earthiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of caramel, toasted malt and light earthiness with a smooth dry lingering toasted malt finish.
Tap at Pizza Luce. Deep orange with no head. Caramel, caramel, and malts. Medium sweet through. Medium body, light stickiness. Nothing wrong or off, just very one-dimensional.
Bottle. Murky orange amber pour with a small but dense foamy head. Very sweet malty, but with a dryer finish. Decent enough.

Pours a dark amber with a small beige head. Aroma is malty with bready notes. Flavor is rather bready with hints of caramel malt and toffee. Light body with medium carbonation. Pretty basic; not great.

Bottle from Skyview, thanks! Clear copper with a vanishing tan topper. Aroma of toffee, sweet toasted malt and a bit of breadiness. Taste is straight up caramel and toffee with a touch of honey and no hop presence.

Pours a dark amber with white head. Caramelly malt aroma. Taste is sweet and malty. Caramel, spice, dough and some toasted malt. Maybe a tad thinner and sweeter than the typical Marzen but good nonetheless.
12 oz bottle from the Four Firkins. Caramel colored pour with an eggshell colored head. Malty, caramel aroma. Very sweet, caramel, roasted malty flavor.
Bottle at home bought from Chucks wines Ohio. My first Sake. Opaque colour with a fragrant fruity nose. Taste is warm down your throat wine rice noted creamy coconut .
37,5 cl bottle @ home Aroma has footsweat, lime and perfume. Also green apples. Flavour has sweet and green apples, some lime and mild grapefruity tones.
30 cl bottle. Pours hazy gray color with a small head. Aroma has faint grapefruits, lemon, some herbs. Flavor is lemon and some herbal tones, subtle grapefruit tones. Pleasant. 3444

300ml pink-white bottle. No nareszcie chyba najciekawsze Sake jakie testowalem. Ladna mglista buteleczka, barwa sake biala metna jak sciete bialko jaja gesiego. Smakowo gesie jajko troche kokosa, mnostwo ryzu i posmak jakby lawendy?? Ciekawe fajne lekko o oleistej struktorze. Napewno bedzie idealne robionych w Sylwestra moich Sushi. Gleboki poklon dla Japonczykow za ta wyborna tradycyjna Sake

I’ll say it up front, I do not enjoy smoked beers. This came in the sampler glass with an orange color with a frothy white head. Slightly wheaty/grainy aroma just a hint of smoke. Slightly grainy, slightly yeasty flavor but the initial flavor has little smoke. The light smoke flavor comes in at the end which coats the back of the tongue and palate. Not much else here other than the smoke flavor, which I don’t care for to begin with.
Hazy, light amber body with a creamy off-white head. The aroma is light smoke, bready and herbal. The flavor is biscuit, some caramel, hickory and grassy. light body, soft carbonation.

Lightly hazed amber body with creamy beige head. Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, some smoke, herbal, turpentine. Taste is medium sweet, caramel, smoke, light herbal, turpentine. Low carbonation, light-medium body, light stickiness.

Tasted by half-pint at the Black Bull, a freehouse nr. Whitechapel, East End London, on 13/09/2006. The beer seems to commemorate the famous English painter around late 18th to early 19th century, John Constable, who used to hang out in Essex and Suffolk and painted quite a few landscapes there. Appearance: chesnut red hue, with a fluffy and thin off-white beer head; low carbonation, great clarity. Smell: medium-bodied, mildly sour-sweet apple-ish and pear-ish fruitiness, plus dried-grassy and earthy note of hops. Smooth and simplistic. Taste: lightly roasty bitter-sweetness with a malty tinge of toffee, roast nuts and black tea-leafy hops on a par with the mild entry of peary fruits; the second part of the palate sees an increasingly tangy and dryish bitterness lingering at the back, with a slightly citric-zesty kick to go with the bitter finish, where lots of hops hover in the end. Mouthfeel: softly carbonated, fresh, with fruity malts balanced with a superb length of earthy and roasted hops with a 3D-textured bitterness... A brilliant autumny bitter, aptly named after a lengendary English painter, as this is a true landscape in a glass.

column1: Shady Grove Sparkling Blackberry Thistle Mead
column5: Bottle. Pours hazy green-yellow with light carbonation and a small white head that quickly fades. The aroma is sweet honey and some fruit notes, with a distant hint of vanilla. In the mouth, the blackberry hits first giving it a slightly tart beginning, but it smooths into honey flavors in the middle. Lots of vanilla flavor suddenly emerges, almost startlingly so. The finish has touches of sulfur and alcohol. Decent, but not superior.

column1: Shady Grove Sparkling Blackberry Thistle Mead
column5: Bottle sampled with Tronraner and cohorts. Pours a light bronze, I was expecting maybe some purplish hues, but no, it’s not there. The nose on this is very tame with light hints of fruits, honey, alcohol. Upon taking a sip, I discover that the vanilla is right up front. I was surprised to find such an easily discerned flavor in a mead from Shady Grove, who usually makes very light, subtles meads. The blackberry comes out faintly in the finish. The whole thing is quite delicate and tart, probably not as enjoyable to me as their standard dry mead.

column1: Shady Grove Poplar/Clover Sparkling Dry Mead
column5: Bottle. Pours a very pale hue, almost clear, with light effervescence and high legs. The nose is floral with hints of honey sweetness, alcohol, and some woody notes. The flavor is tart up front and rather floral. The middle is a bit vinous, with a decent honey quality. The finish, though, is weird to me. It reminds me way too much of this wintergreen-scented rubbing alcohol I have. It might not be so offputting if I didn’t make that association, but it’s a bit strange. Ok mead, but not outstanding.

column1: Shady Grove Poplar/Clover Sparkling Dry Mead
column5: Bottle, sampled with Tronraner and co. Effervescent, very light pour. The aroma is thin with suggestions of honey comb. This has a light, spritzy mouthfeel with an even, though thin, distribution of honey over the palate. The finish reminds me of sarsaparilla. This is a tasteful drink, but not big enough to sate a true mead craving.

Same as the Eugene City Coffee Stout. This was a really nice, big coffee stout. Pours black with a medium tan head. Tons of rich coffee in the aroma, not overly roasty, but a nice sweet ground coffee smell. Taste had a big blast of fresh coffee. It was nice because it didn’t have the overly roasty, big bitterness that many coffee stouts had, this one relied on more of a sweeter, smoother taste. Medium body, with a nice trailing coffee ground taste. Oh yah, and try this mixed with the rogue chocolate stout for an amazing after-dinner beer.
GABF 2006. black maple pour. tan head. coffee, chocolate, apple and oak aroma. veyr mild. fruity and sugary.

Bottle. Pours neon yellow with falling legs. It has an interesting molasses-like aroma, kind of "dark," for lack of a better word, with deep wildflower, honey, and cork. The flavor is very floral with some profound honey tones and some syrupy grain notes. Pretty smooth.

Bottle consumed alongside Tronraner and crew. This mead pours semi-thick with plenty of tiny little white floaties disperesed throughout the liquid. Even, slowly descending legs are left on the sides of the snifter after a good swirl. This has a very floral, ala hibiscus, nose with not subtle-at-all honey. Oh, and a weird scent of cheese or, less pleasantly, sneakers. Mouth feel is fairly coating and has assertive, though not overdone, honey throughout. Tons of flowers and soft-wood notes refresh my palate. This is decent mead, the one strange thing in the smell is the only real downside in my opinion.
The head is medium. It smells fruity and a bit sour. The taste is mild, soft, a bit malty. boring but ok. 9/8/7/7/11/7
Yellow colour with a white head. Moderate malty nose. Medium sweet flavour with some hops.

Leicht getreidiger Geruch, der ans Neutrale grenzt. Leicht getreidiger Antrunk, eine herbe Note kommt hervor, die das Bier immerhin nach etwas schmecken lässt. Nach und nach wird es sogar etwas herber und leicht hopfig, sogar Malz ist im Nachgeschmack, dem "Highlight" des Bieres zu erkennen. Ansonsten kann man nicht viel von diesem Goldbier erwarten, Gold halt. Dafür annehmbar, ganz im Gegenteil zu der Geschmacksangabe auf dem Etikett: "Die dezente Präsens von Pfirsich und Vanille entfaltet ein besonders harmonisches Bouquet." Zum tot lachen. Test vom 17.3.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 3,7,9,9,8,9 - 8,05

Bottle 330ml. clear glass. Clear medium yellow color with a average to small, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, light hoppy, grass, light vegetabel and cardboard. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration, vegetable and cardboard. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20100910]
Clear golden with a medium white head. Malty nose with hints of caramel and vague hops. Flavor had grassy hops, malt and hints of diacetyl.
clear yellow, smooth white head. faint sweet aroma. flavor is sweet, malty. macro.

Bottled. A golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma has notes of straw, malt, and a bit of hops. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, straw, and a bit of metal, leading to a dry metallic finish.
33 cL clear bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is grassy and slight cornish. Bitter and cornish to grassy into a bitter and dry finish.
Bottle 33 cl. Pours a clear golden with a white head. The nose has malt and chicory. Medium body, malt and brewing cereal with a dry finish. 100910

My wifes sisters hosband, I don´t know what that makes him in English, but he interdused me to Welde beers some years ago, telling me that they use hops from a hop field just across the road from where he lives, and this winter I visited him and saw the hop field, wich was quit small and with no hops cours of the winter, but good to see anyway. Well this time I tryed Welde gold extra mild beer "bottle" it looked like any German Gold beer, Golden colour with a big white head. the aroma was caramel, tobaco and dirt, and the taste was also caramel tobaco and herbal, not wery good, ok medium body, but boring.
cask delivered by gravity at the Maltings 14th annual beer festival York: Another sweet amber colored ale. No head from the barrel. Slightly ciderish. Too surgery. Not enjoyable.
Draught. Low fluffy white lasting head. Malt caramel nuts aroma and flaovr. Low carbonation. Long bittersweet aftertaste.

Draught at the brauhaus Hazy dark amber color. Light caramel aroma; as it often happens for these beers, the hop must not be too aromatic, while the brewer didn’t make the caramel show up more clearly. Good body structure; the caramel flavor is good, maybe very god, round enough, with a limited complementary residual sweetness; correct bitterness. Balanced, and very good.
Draught. Murky dark brown colour. Small light brown head. OK malty flavour. Nice, spicy hoppiness.
Kind of like a dark aber or red. Not real malty as I would think. Lean on body, easy drinking beer but nothing to it as a Scottish should. .
Muddy orange, hoppy, dry, bitter, plain. I wish I had more to say about this beer, but it just fell flat for me.
Draft. Hazy brown color, large bubble white head. Aroma of subtle white bread. Taste is rising sourdough bread, caramel, light spice. Nice.

Hazy, reddish-amber. Lots of earthy, chocolatey, caramelly malts and woody, dry American hops. Sweetish, light caramel and chocolate, but with lots of woody hops again. Quite a bit of bitterness. Not Scottish in any way, but a good brew.
Clear amber color/ ivory head. Spicy caramel, floral, fruity hop aromas. medium bodied. Mild floral, fruity hop flavors with spicy sweet caramel--good

Draft @ brewpub. Gorgeous lace! Dark red. Sweetish, brown cakey malts and raisin bread. Balanced by the "I can’t help myself!" hops. and alcoholic heat. Alcohol coming out a little too much! Unfortunately. But the hops are powerful. A slow sip allows for a careful study of the beer, which starts with the raisin flavor but that is quickly overshadowed by the hops. Seriously not a Scottish ale, the hops are out of control, but as a seattle parody of a Scottish it works fine. Dates. Ultimately the hops win the battle, although the malts Put up a good fight at first. Won’t be winning awards in its category tho! Very interesting even if more like a hoppy brown

Ruddy amber color, clingy head. Big nose with grassy and piny aromas. Crisp texture ontop a medium malt body. Big hop taste in the middle and end, lingering peppery character. Just a little heavier than an IIPA, but not quite as heavy as something like Bigfoot.
Seattle-Draft, Nov. 2008: Nice golden amber color. Medium lacey head. Nice hoppy nose - some grass in there too. Medium hoppy taste- not bitter. Vanishes soon with a short after kick. really nice.

Draft at Tangletown. Pours a crystal clear rubied garnet. Should have known right away with would not be a typical scottish. Big sudsy light tan head up top. You almost expect to see flecks of milled grain in it, ’cause it looks so much liek bread dough. Big sticky sweet smelling nose, lots of caramel and brown bread, with some floral and light piney hops poking through. Creamy medium body. It’s not quite literally sticky, but, man, is it close. What a malt monster. Brown bread, caramel, maybe a little bit of honey underneath a truly notably hopped flavor profile; there’s earth, some peppery pine, and a nice little resiny bite at the end. The malt bill needs some serious diversification if this beer is to attain greatness, though. It’s a great concept, but right now it’s a super-hopped sticky-sweet brown ale. It needs more peat, smoke, molasses, maybe some leafy bite to the malt. Maybe some roast. I don’t know, but some differentiation has to be there. Still, the pint was easy to put down with gusto.
