Seeing such obvious room for improvement with simple changes (who doesn’t love buffing out a specialty grain bill?) bodes well for the future.
For me this was a nice scotch with not much smoke and moderate bitterness. Very nice smooth malt sweetness. Some wood almost enhances the richness.

Tap: brilliant copper, nice off-white head. Great lacing. Nice malt character up front, caramel and toffee, little subdues but there. Citrus and grass background. Again, caramel and toffee dominate the flavor, just enough hop presence to clean the palate. Amazingly clean brew, very easy drink.

On tap: Aroma is a tad light with some fruit, caramel, and a hint of grass. Bright transparent copper with a moderate off-white head that has very good retention and good lacing. Starts moderately sweet with caramel, brown sugar, and a hint of fruit. A touch of citrus in the background. Light grassy finish with a hint of pepper.

Cask: dirty amber/mahogany with minimal head. Aroma and flavor both dominated by ginger, makes it hard to pick up anything except some residuel malty sweetness. Not bad, sort of one-dimensional though.

Cask: Aroma has moderate ginger and light caramel. Hazy amber with a small white head that leaves sporadic lacing behind. Starts with some light caramel and a hint of citrus flavors. Finishes with a moderate ginger and a hint of grassiness. I like the addition of the ginger as it almost comes across like a pumpkin beer.
Draught BBF2013. Clean gold with a white head. Aroma is light grain. Flavour is grainy with a wet hop finish

Pours in golden yellow clear body with white very thick head. Aromas include hops, malts, grains, wet socks and some berries. Palate is thin watery, with medium lively carbonation and mouth-feel. Aftertaste is sweet and malty, with some grainy rough notes and medium short hops finish. Overall pretty edgy Pilsener. Not utterly bad , but somewhat unbalanced, the dry bitter edge was enjoyable, however that sweet mash flavor was not.

Bottle by 16.07.12. Sweet thin nose. Pale golden with a soapy white head. Taste is relatively dry and extremely grainy, just a really rough mash. A little more alcohol showing than is proper for 4.8%, though there are some occasional floral flutters in the not entirely clean medium body. Drinkable.
Bottled. A hazy light golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma has notes of malt and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, straw, and bread, leading to a dry and bitter finish.
Bottle 50 cl. Clear golden with a white head. Bready aroma. Medium body, malty and bready with a dry and lightly bitter finish. 220309

Bottle 50cl. w. swing top. Clear medium yellow color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, sour malt, sugar. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090322]

50 cL bottle. Pours almost clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Mild toasted malt aroma. Subdued sweetness and light bitterness in the flavour. Uncomplicated and straight forward, a bit boring. Ends medium dry.
Draught. Clear golden colour, small white head. Malty flavour, but otherwise quite boring. OK, but not very interesting.
When we lived in Salt Lake City my wife and I went here all the time. The beers are all excellent. The wings are the best in the state.

On tap at the brewpub. Listed as Bruce’s 80 Shilling, hopefully this doesn’t necessitate an alternative listing, it is the same beer. Pours a amber/red/brown color with a small white head. A light malty nose, some dark fruit notes also. The flavor is very nice; lots of rich fruity malts, somewhat dry, like a huckleberry or boysenberry. Some light bitter hops also. Very full flavored. A nice brew for sure.

[GABF, Denver Co - 2006] A deep amber color brew. This had a very nice intense Scottish flavor and the smoked peat was very good addition. Te hops and the malts where very good. I liked this brew. I would almost say this is a 90 schilling style.
Draft. Clear amber color, medium white head. Aroma of caramel and nuts. Taste starts sweet then bitter straw.
draft@Taps, nice amber colour, malty roasty aroma, low carbonation, aromatic but light bodied, finish is good but ends quick, finally nice beer..

Bottle from marchcow. Thanks. Poured a clear amber color. The head was tall and light tan with good retention and lacing. Smelled of steeping pale malt/cereal grain. Medium bodied and slightly sweet. As in the nose, malt dominated the flavor profile. Corn syrup, molasses, hay, and light cereal grains.

Süßlich-malziger Geruch, bananig. Malziger Antrunk, etwas wässrig, im Hintergrund findet sich die erschnüffelte hefig-bananige Note. Im Mittelteil wenig kräftiger, die einzelnen vermischen sich, so wirkt das Bier frisch und verwaschen. Im Abgang malziger, der Alkohol ist in angenehmer Weise erkennbar. Die anfängliche Hintergrundnote ist nun im Vordergrund und wirkt deutlich würziger und vollmundig. Das Malz wird im Abgang würziger und rückt mehr und mehr in den Vordergrund, angenehm und aromatisch. So kennt man türkische Biere eher weniger. Test vom 11.8.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,9,10,11,11,10 - 9,85

Bottled@The 1st Vaasa CS/ES beer session (Thanks AM). Ambery brown colour with mediumsized beige fluffy head. Aroma is caramel malts, some slight alcohol as well as some slight fruity and berryish notes. Flavour is quite strong on sweet malts as well as some berries and mild notes of alcohol. Fruity and bitter wooden finish.
Bottle. Amber colour with a small white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, caramel, fruit and hops.
Draught at Taps Istanbul, Istanbul. Rough notes from May 08. Poured amber with a strong presence of caramel malt character. Some fruitiness in the flavour with a bitter finish.

Malty aroma, slightly smoky quality, some yeast and rye notes. Amber color with frothy tan head. Flavor is malty caramel with some slight rye notes, sweetish. Low carbonation. Slightly flat. Bottle may be a bit old. Duration is bitter sweet and lingering.

Bottle from Migros Supermarket in Bursa: No suitable glass available so drank straight from the bottle. Virtually no fruitiness or much taste at all. The only thing that made me think that this was anything other than a standard light beer (which is the norm in Turkey) was the taste of the Belgian yeast strain. Very dissappointing. This is not a good representation of a Belgian Strong Ale. Granted, the bottle could have been sitting in the cooler for god-only-knows how long.
Bottled at North Shield, Istanbul. Brownish amber. Sweet and caramelly. Medium bodied with rounded mouthfeel. Solid and warming with lingonberry and caramel. Medium bitterness.
Tasted at 2006 Portland fresh hop fest--Not a very hoppy tasting fresh hopped beer, but very smooth and well balanced. Comes across more like an exemplary pale ale.
On tap at Horse Brass Pub, Portland. Hazy gold, no head. Raspberries. Nicely hopped bitter. Bit of yeast. Floral hop aroma, some caramel malt, goodish structure, hops on end. Floral, nice.

Yah, i’m with steve on this one, this was one funky brew, just tasted like sweet wort. The finish tasted sweet and cloudy with got in the way of any good fresh hop tastes. I’m hoping when i have this next week at the fresh hop fest in portland its better, cause this is the first bad brew i’ve had from Ninkasi.

Tap at Hood River Hops Fest. This dog should have been put down long before it reached the public. Pours a medium amber color and fairly clear, scant white head that fades quickly and little lacing. Aroma is freshly boiled wort. Thick and syrupy, plenty of IBU’s. Taste is far too sugary to even have gotten half way through fermentation. Seriously, this beer tastes like wort would if it were carbonated. A true shame that this was served...

column2: Ashby De La Zouch, Derbyshire, England
column5: A light straw gold coloured beer with a thickish white head. The nose is light, with a distinc citrusy hop aroma, lemony and a touch of grapefruit. The taste is dry, slightly sharp, with the citrus fruit elements from the smell coming through, again lemon and grapefruit. The finish is dry and fruity. (Cask - The Fox & Hounds, Heachan, Norfolk).

Pour is a golden with a nice whie head. Aroma is a nice crips pils malt with a decent amount of clean hops. Flavor is in the decnt category with a nice biscuit and grain. Hops do show up which is where many pils fall short. A pretty decent offering.

On tap at the Heritage Brew Festival 2008. Pours a pale yellow with a decent small, but lingering white head. A nice crisp pils with a slight malty sweet hoppy taste. Great session lager. One of the best pils in the domestic market.
This was their best beer by far. It had a nice hop aroma and bitterness. The malting was light, but not overly light like BMC-type pilsners. It was overall just a decent beer.

tap at Augusta bottoms beerfest-Pours light yellow with a small soapy white head. nose is very grassy, kind of like the trampled grass that we are standing on during this beerfest (the fest was in 2 tents out in the middle of the Missouri River valley). Nice flavor profile here-nice grassy/spicy hops with a malt structure that is definately not like most of the ilk-not soggy or boring. very tasty, classic and true to style. Nice body with medium carbonation. doesnt feel flimsy at all. very dry and spicy hoppy finish. I totally dig this beer from this new brewery! I actually voted this beer best in show due to its solidness and how true to style it is.

Sampled at Augusta Bottoms Beer Festival 2006. Pours clear yellow with light carbonation and small white head. Aroma was quite grassy and husky with a hint of hops. Light / medium body with some sharp carbonation that was great for the style. The taste had the husky graininess that works well with pilsners and a big spicy hop finish. On one hand it is nothing earthshattering, but it is a very well done solid pilsner that doesn’t have the negative characteristics that mar so many others. My first beer from this new brewery & I look forward to many more.

column1: Broad Ripple Scotty Got'em Scottish Ale
column5: Taster on tap, Nitro version, at the brewpub. Labeled 4% ABV. Clear, darker orange color, with a slight reddish amber hue. Thin off-white / light tan head. Decent splotches of lace. Nice smokey aroma up front. I like that. Light caramel malt. Medium body, lightly sticky. Very light carbonation. Moderate sweet taste. Solid scottish ale, I dig the smokiness. Good bigger aroma for the light ABV.

Draft sample at Alandale. Very light and hazy, still can see bubbles rising through the glass. A fine wheat smell. Has the standard zest of an American wheat with no out of place esters. Just a nice light drink.

Wow, this is a bad beer. There was almost no noticeable aroma, a poor, soapy head with large bubbles, and almost no flavor profile that I could detect. It tasted like an even lighter Bud Light, if that is possible. I want to like this brewpub, I really do! I live not 2 miles from the place, and I want to see it do well because I want a good, local watering hole, but I just cannot stand these bad beers.

tap sampled with vyvvy at the Augusta Bottoms Beerfest. Poured very cloudy yellow, especially for an american wheat, with a small soapy head. fruity nose with light husky notes. somewhat estery as well (nice yeast tone). lightly fruity flavors with some spicy hops on the finish. body is light, but its not watery. This would be an awesome session beer on a hot august day here in STL. One of the best AW i have ever had.

Sampled at Augusta Bottoms Beer Festival 2006. Poured cloudy yellow with a small white head. Aroma has smooth apricot / peach with a bit of husk. Medium body with light carbonation. Thte taste has the fruit from the aroma with citrus and hoppy spice. A nice wheat ale from a new and promising brewer.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: tap at the brewpub - Pours very pale, hazy yellow-green with a small, lingering white head. It has a light, citrus accented aroma. The flavor is light and sweet. Unfortunately it’s also a thin, watery beer with some off bandage like flavor. Not good.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: Rating these in the order sampled… Watery brew with virtually no head and not much aroma. Light bodied and light amber in color. At first I thought I detected a nice lemony citrus sensation when I sniffed it, but that was just the lemon hunk in it. Flavor dominated by a clean bitter wheat and yeast combo at the end of the swallow. My sample was a bit warm and the weak, watery, and warm combo didn’t work well for me. Not much else there. For a light beer – it is good. Had I known this was a light beer, I would have passed it by – the sign aobe the bar just said “Puddingstone Wheat.” In a way, I’m relieved to discover (here on ratebeer) that is a light and so the taste merely reflects on the compromises inherent in brewing something like that, and not on the brewer’s skill. (Yeah – I know – I should reign in the fawning compliments.)

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: Thin lightly hazed yellow pour. Rim of white. Light skunky waft of malt. Distant corn tinged sugars of faint malt. Carboard and coarse grain. Palate has a smack of toast and weak plants. Body isn’t bad, but why beat up an American Wheat as your entry level blonde? This comes across as a Broberon Bud Light.
Bottle. (Brief tasting notes and rating from old records) - BCA – Strong, citrus-fruity, malty, slightly sweet golden ale. Dry malty finish. (Backlog)

500ml bottle @ the 5th Shrewsbury Bottle Share May 14, courtesy of blackhaddock. Pours hazy brown, autumn leaves aroma, tickling bitter biscuit with a slight hint of whisky for some reason. Not that bad despite being 5 months out of date.

Jan 2009: Brown 500ml bottle conditioned beer, poured into a straight Uk pint glass with 6 months life left according to the bottle. I wanted to pour it slowly and leave the sediment in the bottle, I failed. The beer looked clear and a pleasant amber/brown until I got excited and the glass became the home of a murky brown liquid with a wispy white head on top. It looked like a beer your mate has brewed, but couldn’t wait for it to clear before offering you a pint. My appearance score reflects my stupidity. Hops and yeast, yeast and hops, sorry, reminds me again of a mates good homebrew. Hold on thought. There is a richness in the aroma that carries on into the taste and mouthfeel too. The taste is bitter and hoppy (English Goldings and Progress hops), I found it a very good blend of flavours with a tangy, spritzy feel to the whole experience. As I mentioned above, the beer has a richness, there is a depth of body too, which I can only assume comes from the high alcohol content. The alcohol is well hidden because of the complexity of the brew. I have mentioned homebrew in this review a couple of times, but this beer is well above any homebrewers products I have ever had.

Bottle 500ml. [ BBF 0709 ]. Clear medium amber orange yellow colour with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, berry, chalk, oxidide notes. Flavour is moderate to light light heavy sweet, light light acidic and light bitter with a average duration, malty, berries, sweet malt. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110728]
Bottle at Chris O’s pre GBBF shindig, 2011. Cloudy orange pour, white head. Barley sugar nose. Sugary fruit flavour. Quite dull.

Vintage 2009 bottle at ChrisO’s Pre-GBBF Shindig 2011. Foggy brown pour with a slim head. Honey and caramel malts on the nose. Flavor was kind of so-so with bland, slightly tart malts, mild sweetness. Light bodied and flat.

500ml vintage bottle. Best before July 2009. Amber colour with an orange tinge. Drunk on 28 July 2011. Woody aroma with hints of cardboardy oxidation. Some sharp fruit and sweet malt underneath. Fruity on the palate. Finishes quite tart, maybe a touch sour. Not sure that was intended but it actually works fairly well. Definitely showing signs of age but not too past it.
Bottled. Amber colour, small beige head. Aroma is fruits, wood, some slight toffee and mild notes of berries. Flavour is wood, fruits, mild berries as well as some slight yeasty notes.

Bottle.Light brown with a small head,aroma of berry fruits,progress hops and a hint of toffee,taste of hops caramel flowers,alcohol honey and wood,dry apple finish,the alcohol is not too invasive and it goes down really easy for this strength.

Bottle that I picked up from Bellingers, Jet Garage, Grove Near Wantage, Oxon consumed 18-09-09 Pours very hazy amber with a light white head. Sweet and sour, also fruity with the strength noticeable. All things considered this is really a fairly poor bottled beer, its a lazy sludgy mess that barely deserves the mark I’ve given it. A4 A2 F4 P2 Ov8 2.0
Sampled at the Highlands Brewery. Not a bad amber ale. It had a medium, caramel body with a slight citrus. It was a normal Amber Ale, different, but not bad as many other Ambers Ales.

On tap at Highlands brewpub. Amber with a thing off-white head. Aroma of caramel, malt and very mild hops. Taste of burnt malt, caramel, and diacetyl. Very little flavor and finishes up with an off-flavor.

Amber in color with a low white head and carbonation. A mild malt aroma with a grassy hoppiness. Flavor has a nice malty presence, light floral and grassy hops middle and ends with a nice hop bitterness. Density was good. Overall a decent amber that leans towards the hoppier side of the amber style with a solid malt ending.

Pours amber with a medium head. Aroma is sweet caramel, toast, and mild pepper in the nose. Flavor is clean, nutty malts and yeasty notes blend well with toast and balanced hops. Very balanced and easy to drink.
Tasted 4/14/08. Draft from the brewpub. Filtered with a dark amber hue. Off whhite clinging head. Another diasytl bomb. Caramel and buttered toast. Smooth and medium bodied, but meh...

Sample at the brewpub. This beer is a clear orange/amber color with a thin beige head that diminishes quickly. Rings of lacing on the glass. The aroma is mildly malty with touches of citrus and hops. Light-bodied with grainy malt and caramel flavors, and subtle piney hops present as well. The finish is malt and toffee with a lingering mild hops aftertaste. Decent overall.
Draft sampler. Malty amber smell with a good copper color. First beer I’ve had here that shows American hops; not at APA strength, bit a bit of citrus and pine to make it interesting.
On tap at the brewpub. Deep amber with a nice off-white head. Aroma of caramel / crystal malt. Nicely full-bodied. Little bitterness. Good session-type beer.

Draft 12 oz’er at the brewpub. Dark amber with a lightly laced top. Caramel aroma. Nice and like their other beers this is full-bodied. Light toffee with a twinkle of caramel, just an easy drinking beer. A metallic caramel comes on stronger as it goes. (#3031, 7/17/2007)
(at the brewpub) Nice dark amber with large off white head and great lace. Aroma of some malt and citrus hops. Flavor is malt with a nice balance of hops.Reasonable body. A solid amber ale.
Draft at the brewpub. Medium Amber. There’s a big malt component to this, with just a light flourish of hop ... I’d call it British more than American. (#6264, 8/7/2016)

Part of a sampler flight at the brewpub, on draft. It poured a pale orange amber colour, slight chill haze, with white foam, short-lived but left behind lace. Crisp grains, slight caramel sweetness dominated by intense US hops: grapefruit, tangerine, black currant, cedar, dank resin. Light body, strong carbonation, dry finish with lasting hoppy bitterness and flavour. A very familiar flagship A- IPA overall, but well-crafted and tasty. Cascade and Chinook get the job done every time.
Bottle. This was a mess. Smelled ok but had buttery notes really killed this one

Shared 16 oz. cans poured to snifters, displaying a coppery gold color, with a presentable, off white head, and spots & streaks of lacing. The nose was dank, with a little cattiness, dryness, and esters as grapefruit. Medium bodied, with decent carbonation, the hop presence was also medium intensity, citrusy, earthy, and lingering, as the taste was basically dry, with no discernible sweetness, and suitable malt to temper the hops. A standard IPA, but the drier impression agreed with me as a nice change from the usual fruity or malt sweetness of most IPAs.

Can @ home. Hazy amber pour with a fluffy khaki head. Nose is heavy on lemon and pine. A fair amount of grass. Lightly floral. Lots of caramel maltiness and some toast. The flavor has a rather intense caramel quality. A big toffee note, too. Some bitter pine and grass. Orange peel and candied lemon peels.
Draft sampler pours amber with a off white head. Aroma of citrus, malts and floral. Taste is caramel and citrus.

Draft... RBSG 2014… Cloudy amber pour with a small, fizzy, white head. The nose offers grapefruit and tea biscuit. Light to medium-bodied with an astringent mouthfeel and kicked-back carbonation. A bitter, raspy flavor is flanked by a bitter, dry finish.

Flight pour on tap at the brewery (Kirkwood, MO). Pours a deeper amber copper hue, well hazed with frothy offwhite head atop. A nice layer, good ring and mellow lacing overall. Aromas are gentle citrus hops, a touch of florals, faint fruit and bready malts, bit of caramel and biscuit. Sweeter, muted. Touch of grapefruit as it settles more. Initial is lighter end of medium bodied, some decent bittering hops show some grapefruit, touches of florals and gentle fruit. Some biscuit, gentle sweeter malts into thje middle show caramel, gentle biscuit and bready malts. A touch sweeter but not overwhelming. The knock here Is that the hops are a little overdone when they could do more. Backend is a bit bitter, earthy with gentle bready and carmelized malt elements. A touch sweet, underdone. The hop elements do show some nice jabs at tomes and the maltbill is efficient.. It just needs some more hop oomph. At times, it’s nice, at others it’s a bit sweet. Meh. It’s ok. I’d drink it.

Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy light amber with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has notes of light citrus and grass backed by earthy grains. Flavor has more bitter citrus with a bit of grass and earthy grains underlying.
Draft - Grains and resin. Cloudy orange with a decent white head. Tastes as it smells. A very basic and uninteresting beer.

O n tap at Shamrocks. Pours a black color with a tan head and bit of lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, dark fruit and hint of chocolate. Taste of roasted malt dark fruit with just a hint of chocolate. Nominal bitterness and a clean finish. Fairly full body, smooth, flavorful and not boozy as expected. Nicely crafted.

Very complex aroma. Coffee, chocolate, dark fruit, a little boozy. Pitch black with a brown head. Tastes roasted with a good amount of chocolate and lactose sweetness to balance. Great smooth finish, palate is full and rich. This lives up to its reputation.
Decent brew I'm glad a buddy sent me a surly pack. The new had a decent color mild head and a good finish. An average brew

Tasted from bottle aged 4 years. Pours black with thick beige head. Aroma is raisins, cocoa and molasses. Thick and chewy. Lots of cherry on the flavor. Some coffee, cocoa, raisins. Awesome RIS. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is a backlog rating from 2011 from a bottle shared by Tmoney99, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are roast, chocolate, very average.
Decent stout that has a few minerally aftertaste and palate attackers, but generally will do the trick.
Black color, medium body and average head. Aroma and taste are traditional stout roasted malt---dialed down to pretty bland. Little hop bitterness.

Poured a very dark brown - almost black - with a light tan head and minmal lacing. Aroma was of malts and coffee with a slight fruitiness. Taste was complex - roasted malts, nutty, coffee, chocolate hints and a light hop finish. Mouth was decent. Overall, a nice ’milder’ stout.
Pours black wuth brown head...coffee sweet arom...taste is light but not bad...nothing really special about this stout

Pours a dark brown almost black with a nice sized head of tan foam. Nose is cocoa and dark malt. The texture is full with good creaminess. Taste is full of cocoa, coffee and dark roasted grains. It has a nice finish that is not too sweet or too bitter. A well made stout that compares well to Guiness. Try it with with smoked cheese and crackers.

Dark brown pour, large tan head that dissipates rather quickly. Start is malty with caramel overtones, then reveals the chocolate & coffee flavors. Finish is smooth with no surprises. Not much bitterness, not an emphasis on hops. Pleasant, a brew for the summer months: light for a stout.

This is the best of Schell´s lineup. That being said, it is still quite thin and unremarkable. The color is very dark, but that is about it. I have spent a good deal of time in London drinking Stouts and have never run across anything like this (which is a good thing).

Bottle poured a clear dark rerddish brown with a lingering ring of tan foam. Aromas of roastiness, bitter chocolate and coffee. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of roastiness, coffee and light cocoa with a crisp lingering roasty finish.

Bottle in hotel room. Dark brown appearance with a brown head. Roasty dark chocolate, cocoa, espresso, light vanilla aroma. Burnt dark roasty chocolate malty flavor with notes of char, wood, and smoke. Not bad.
Clear, amber pour with a small off-white head. The aroma has caramel and toast. It has a medium body with sticky texture and average carbonation. The taste is sweet with a more balanced finish.

Shaker pint draft at the Morgan Street Brewery in St. Louis, Missouri. The pour is a mostly clear copper golden with a small light tan head. The aroma is nut, caramel and a bit of toasty malt. The taste is nut caramel malt of the nose along with a bit of grass and general fruit sweetness. The palate is medium bodied with flattish carbonation and a bit of apple fruit yeast to the finish.

Can. Pours ahazy dark copper color with a small head and some lacing. Aroma of citrus, caramel, grain and trace of malt. Taste of caramel, grain and bit of fruit. Mild bitterness and a fairly clean finish. Modeate body, smooth with festive feel.

12 oz. can via in-person STL trade. Pours a clear orange-amber color with an inch of khaki head that dissipates quickly into a lasting uneven film. Notes of toast, caramel, tobacco and other dried leaves, subtle spice, and a little fruit. Light-bodied, with medium carbonation and a crisp, toasty mouthfeel. Solid Oktoberfest.

The color of this brew is a dark orange color with a large white head, and the aroma blends the scents of dough yeast and caramel malts. The taste is mildly sour and a touch sweet although this blend is quite nice, and the palate combines a medium body, thick texture, average carbonation, and a sour yet fairly abrupt finish.

Pour is a brown with a large white head. Aroma is a nice rich caramel malt. Flavor is the same. Decent maltyness but a little watery around the edges. Leaves a little breadyness on the tongue after the swallow. It’s decent but again a bit to watery to give it a higher score.

Sampled at the 2012 Heritage Festival. It poured an orange color with a white head. The aroma was of some caramel, malts and a hint of fruit. The taste was of spices, some clover and notes of caramel. A decent Oktoberfest.

Tasted at the 1st annual Urban Chestnut - Wolpertinger beer festival in St. Louis, MO, USA from tap into sampler beer boot. Labelled as Märzen, but I assume it’s the same brew. Poured a nice clear orange-amber color with decent white foam. Aromas and flavors true-to-style. Rich malt sweetness, mildly caramelly, noticeable Munich malt. Light body, strong carbonation, crisp lager finish.

Sample from Augusta beer fest. Poured an orange color with a white head. Aroma was caramel, malts and banana. Flavor was spices, clover, and caramel. Some malty, candy finish to it. Kind of weak, and watery. Not a very good beer, but still very drinkable.

Sampled atbthe Augusta Bottoms Fest. A big frothy orange foamy head. The beer is clear and golden with amber. A lightly spicy aroma with malt. The flavor is grassy for an oktoberfest. It has light spices. This is not a great beer.

Draught at the brewpub. Does indeed seem to be a different recipe than their 6th Anniversary IIPA. Suitably hoppy aroma, tinged with tangerine, orange, grapefruit and berry accents, some faint pine and flowers here as well along with some faint background honeyish malt sweetness. Mostly clear medium-dark golden amber color with a slight head. Flavor is a bit different than aroma would indicate, with some bubblegum sweetness up front, more pine and citrus dominating the middle and finishing with a good amount of bitterness and hop flavor, accompanied by a relatively gentle alcohol presence. Some cidery and cereal malt notes amidst the hops here. Body is a bit lighter than anticipated, the palate oily and smooth. Pretty basic interpretation of the style but not bad.

Sampled at the Augusta bottoms beerfest alongside vyvvy. Read his description about how this beer was poured-you will get a laugh. pours turbid brown (yes, brown) with a very small white head. tons of hop floaties from the dry hopped cask, which stick to the sides of the glass. If drug tests looked for alpha acids, then i would fail badly! nose here is chalk full of a tub of hops-everything you can imagine-pine, resin, citric, grapefruit, wood. however, the flavors are very resinous with some earthy/piney character. Also, the hops were fresh, so the green hop character is there as well, malt? what malt-this is liquid hops. For what it is, its definately not great for the style. however, this beer was novel, unique and definately had to experience this one first hand. the 9% was nowhere to be found, until after the 3rd sample.

Sampled at Augusta Bottoms Beer Festival 2006. Poured somewhat from the cask. There was some much hop residue this was not able to come out of the cask in the normal fashion. It was periodically drained into a pitcher and poured from there. It is probably needless to say, but this is very hoppy. Pours brownish orange with lots and lots of sediment and very little head. The aroma has a multitude of hop qualities - grapefruit, wood, pine, spice, etc with lots of resin. Medium body that is light for the style and the aroma. Almost no carbonation in the beer. The initial taste is fairly light with some hops and fruity-like malt. The finish however is a hop bomb having woody and piney hops in the forefront. Lots of resin is in there. Very very dry finish that is a little harsh. Quite interesting take on the style.

Tap at the brewpub. Full black pour, smallish head. Aroma is all coffee, with maybe a twinge of roast malt. Taste is medium bodied with the espresso taste right up front, though nicely blended and balanced. Overall a decent beer.

tap at Augusta Bottoms Beerfest alongside vyvvy. pours pretty much black with a light brown tinge around the glass even when held up to the sun. aroma screams expresso beans-fresh ones! flavors are all expresso with some nice chared bean notes. really not much beer here, but this could pass for coffee in a mug-seriously! i could drink this at work and nobody woud know. body is somewhat thin, but really not detracting. cool and novel beer here.

Sampled at Augusta Bottoms Beer Festival 2006. Poured blacker than night - I couldn’t get anything but black even when held to the sun. There is also a good looking brownish orange head. The aroma is all dark expresso with beer not being detectable. Medium / light body with little carbonation. Much lighter than you would think for something this dark and aroma so bold. The taste is all expresso with not much of a beer taste. This is great if you are a big coffee fan.
tap. hazy golden thin head. big yeast and banana aroma. tastes the same. way too much banana. one dimensional. bogus.

Sampled at the brewpub. I requested that they not include a lemon slice on the rim. Pours a cloudy pale straw color with a decent white head. Aroma is faint, and predictably consists of phenols from the wheat. Taste is watery, of faint banana and clove, with a hint of floral hoppiness. Thin bodied, well-carbonated. This makes a good beer for a scorching hot day if it’s served cold. Maybe that lemon would have helped the lackluster flavor out.
Standard American Wheat. The description claims to have lots of hops... don’t get your hopes up. This is your standard bland wheat beer with not much aroma, flavor, or body.

This beer is not to be confused with Pacific Western Genuine Draft that is brewed in Prince George B.C. This beer is a "house brand" marketed by the Sobeys grocery store chain, and available only in their proprietary liquor stores. It is very cheap-- I paid $4.14 for a sixpack! And considering the price, the beer is actually not bad at all. Standard pale lager fair, but there is none of the bad stuff that makes the cheap ones so nasty. Fresh grainy and bready aroma, clean palate with noticable pale malt, and a slightly bitter finish make this a decent beer. I would choose it over Canadian any day!

On tap at the Tugboat Oct. 6, Pours very dark. Despite being very dark it smells insanely hoppy and does not have a strong malt smell. Taste is too hoppy also with a little hint of malt but not nearly enough. No nut taste at all, and doesn’t coat the mouth very well. Disapointing.

Close to black body with a small, frothy, short-lived, tan head. Sweet, strong aroma of dark caramel, dark chocolate, sweet liquorice, dark roasted malt, and coffee in the back. Fairly strong flavour of dark roasted malt, sweet liquorice, alcohol, and coffee, and faint dark caramel. Light to moderate sweet taste with a moderate to light bitter finish. Mid-bodied, watery texture, close to flat carbonation. Fairly decent. [50 cl bottle, enjoyed 9 months before BB date, from Dagli' Brugsen Blokhus, Jylland, Denmark]
A danish, black oatmeal stout with low, brown head. Aroma is heavy liqourice, light coffee, light prune. Taste is bitter.

Copenhagen 24/8 2018. 50 cl bottle from Meny. Stensbogaards usual design with a black label with a orange stripe. Pours clear dark brown with small white head. Settles as thin patchy layer of foam crawling of the side of the glass. No lacing. Aroma is sweet, Glue, brown sugar, nuts and metallic alcohol (impressive for a beer with an ABV of around 5). Light carbonation and thin, watery texture. Flavor has fairly strong sweetness followed by moderate bitterness. Aftertaste is bitter. Lingering. Not a wholehearted take on a Brown Ale. Disappointing.
Cask conditioned - handpump - Malt Shovel Northampton. A copper coloured beer with a dry aroma featuring a little grass. The taste is malty and dry. Ordinary really.

Cask conditioned at The Turf Tavern, Oxford. Amber with white head. Reasonable enough session bitter, crisp, refreshing, easy going malts, a little sweet with a touch of caramel, then a dose of bittering hops. Good enough.
Cask at Bedford BF ’06. Dark amber. Peppery hop aroma. Enjoyable malty flavour with some sourness and a mid bitter finish. Decent, tasty beer.
From cask. Pours dark brown with no lasting head. Roasted malt and breadish. Roasted malt, mild fruity and with a light bitterness coming through. Crisp fruity bitterness into the finish.
Smells like a basket of fruit. Pours a dull golden color. I really enjoyed it right off the top, the hops hit you like a brickwall. I will definitely be smuggling some back.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Pale straw colour, small white head. Sweet, soapy floral aroma, slightly artificial and not very promising. Taste begins similarly, but soon delivers a grape and apple fruitiness with a pleasant strawy aftertaste. A long, intense bitter finish. This is one of those beers that you don’t like at first, but ends up being rather appealing.

Draught samples at Kennett 06 and Boston’s Belgian Beer Fest 06 Lightly hazy golden beer, very saison like in appearance, with tiny bubbles apparent in the liquid and a medium amount of well-retained white head that provides plenty of lacing. Light honey fermentation notes in the nose (pepper, flowers, light medicinal notes and some vanilla) immediately complement the delicate B. Brux fruitiness. Some more residual sugar than Substance D seems to give the beer more an Orval-like note, with a moderate hoppiness, lots of perfume, lilacs and fresh grass. Very strong aroma, growing very tart, lemony and lightly herbal-astringent on the end. Honey dabbled over biscuits, with some very soft suggestions of light caramel are the extent of the malt notes. Not lactic or acetic, but just very dry fruit skin notes from the brett. Both sour and tart at once, in the flavor, from the honey (which lends a light bittersweetness) and the very tart, and very prominent brett. Meanwhile, plenty of spicy notes form all over the palate, not being anywhere overdone. Engaging carbonation, and a moderate level of it help keep things very bright and crisp. Some sharp esters grow apparent with warming, as well as just a touch of alcohol warmth, and definitely some spicy phenols, but some (hops?) are noted on the end, adding some hay and grass notes and bringing the beer back down to earth. Touch of sweet honey on the finish and plenty of light dough and vanilla. The Kennett version had a very large amount of diacetyl, nearly ruining the beer for me. Shaun thought it was an infected keg with pediococcus adding the diacetyl, and I believe it, it reminds me of the diacetyl issues with RR’s supplication. The keg at BBF was flawless, however. Score is for the BBF version

First sample at the KSBF 06. Pours a cloudy gold and acloudy fluffy white head- and great lace. Aroma is brett upfront wiht some fresh cut hay, light herbal spiciness and phenolic- sour as well. More lemony tarteness in the flavor- full bready malt with lots of farmhouse funk and stinky wild yeast and cheese. Full body despite an obviously low OG and finishes off very tart and sour- almost lambic-like. Great brett-laced saison.

KSBF 2006. Hazy deep lemon body with a modest white head. Ultra-bretty aroma with elements of grapefruit, barnyard, organic honey, nuts and wheat. Very dry, moderately tart and wild flavor with an oaky bitterness. Some nice, unexpected texture. Very enjoyable beer.

KSBF 2006. Pours a hazy golden yellow with a foamy white head. Aroma of brett, funk, citrus, barnyard, honey and some yeast/spice. Flavor of the same kind of a bready/honey tinged spicy Saison. Good stuff!

On tap at KSBF ’06... Appears a hazy light gold with a fluffy white head that doesn’t fade out. Lots of spotty lacing is left around the glass. Smell is of honey infused lemon with some yeasty spiciness followed up with a subtle brett aroma that doesn’t overpower. Taste is of the same aromas with a balanced amount of brett that compliments the zesty, smooth honey flavors with a wild flare. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, fluffy, like a chardonnay that has been aged and opened at the right time. Well done, Shaun!

On tap at the KSBF ’06. Poured a deep and cloudy golden color with an averaged sized white head. Aromas of honey, lemons, brett, and some spices. Tastes of honey, brett, citrus and spices. I’m usually not crazy about honey, but found that I really enjoyed this beer. Refreshing and one of my favorites of the connoisseur tasting.

Poured a hazy, orange golden color with a large, white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of honey, with funky brett notes, citrus fruits, and spice. Taste of much of the same, with some buttercream, and a moderate bretty tartness in the background.

Poured from a growler (from Victory in KS); professional appearance in a pint glass - thick, white head and clean, filtered look. Nose imparts hops and bread/toasted crackers. Crisp and freshing with a well-balanced hop/malt taste. Cheers!

Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass at the World of Beer in Pooler, GA. The appearance is a clear gold color with a small white head. The aroma is full of tropical fruit and hops and spices. The taste is hop/grass and tropical fruit driven
Aroma is piney hops and orange/citrus/slightly juicy. The flavor is orange/citrus, pine needles, grapefruit, malts and a mix of tart and bitter/spicy in the finish.

Nice dark amber pour with a tall head and lacing. Aromas like a bag of fresh hops, spruce and grass and clove-spiked oranges. Perfume palate, honeysuckle and bitter hops, ruby grapefruit. Really delicious.

Poured from bottle. AROMA - Hops, malt and ocean. APPEARANCE - amber orange with lacing. TASTE - malt, pine/citrus hops, not in the IPA range, spice and earth notes. PALATE - dry, clean, refreshing. OVERALL - surprisingly excellent, even for Victory.

Pours a burnt orange color. In tulip glass. Has a good cream color head, about one finger, but thick. Good retention. Very thick, clumpy lacing. Looks great. Aroma is peach! Grapefruit! Wow! Biscuity. Floral. Taste is citrusy, orange peel. It’s sweet, but quickly turns bitter. Well balanced. Taste isn’t as good as the aroma, but breathing it in as you drink it, sort of makes up for that. Mouthfeel is medium bodied. Crisp, dry. Juicy. Overall, this is really good. Very enjoyable. I would recommend it, and I would buy it again.
Amber with foamy Lacy beige head; aroma is hops notes of tea; flava is moderately bitter and spicy; feels medium light with nice fizz; finished bitter slightly woody

Copper and toffee coloured body with a smallish, single centimetre tall off-white head and a bit of an amber glow as well. Aroma of fresh grassy, floral and perfumey hops with a nice malt and toffee scent as well. Medium-bodied; Strong biting floral and grassy hoppy flavours up front with a smooth and sweet caramely and biscuity malt presence along with some dry herbal flavours and a touch of sugar at the end - very well balanced. Aftertaste shows some grain, a bit of caramel, a good deal of dryness and a lot of floral, grassy and very perfumey hop characteristics along with a great balance of malt throughout. Overall, a very nice fresh hopped APA with some good dry elements and a very well struck balance between the hops and the malt. Definitely worth trying (especially fresh) if you can find this! I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Total Wine in Alexandria, Virginia on 15-November-2016 for US$3,24 sampled at home on the Eastern Shore of Virginia on 14-January-2017.

Cloudy, burnt orange pour with the tiniest white head. The aroma mild floral hops with citrus notes. It has a medium body with oily texture and average carbonation. The taste is mildly bitter with slightly sweeter finish.
strong hoppy aroma. amber and clear in color with nice head. taste is well balanced malt/hop profile. light caramel malts and piney hop notes. finishes smooth and clean.

Bottle in a pub on Arran. Hazy blond with a thin off white head. The taste is lightly sour with some toasty notes in the finish. Quite pleasant as a sour ale, but I strongly suspect that this bottle is infected.

Good looking deep golden color with a fine white head. Toffee, fruity, some wood and some spices. Quite nice and tasty beer. Medium (+) body and a fine carbonation. Tad sweet and a moderate bitterness. [Bottle at The Brewery]

Bottle from Arran brewery. Appearance - deep amber to red. Nice fluffy head. Nose - biscuits and wood. Taste - biscuit and orange. Palate - close to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a fairly good finish. Overall - decent ale.
Bottle at Ashton McCobb’s. Pours clear with a thin white head, nice lacing. Aromas of dark sugar, spice. Taste is sweet, cooked orange. Sweet finish. Last wee tasting of the summer
Bottle from Cornelius, my first visit there I believe. Pours golden amber, nose is floral, citrus, taste is light citrus, sweet.

Bottled (backlog). Orangeish amber colour with a small off-white head, which leaves some lace. Aroma is fruity, caramelly, and mildly toffeeish. Also mild wood and grass with a slight acidic touch. Flavour is wood, caramel malts, some toffee, floral hops, mild nuttiness as well as some crystal malts. Alcohol does give a slight sting too.

Near-clear orangey-gold. Tall white foamy head. Citrus fruity and peachy hop aroma. Some toasted malts and a note of mild spices. Good body, oily in the mouth. Grassy and lemony bitterness. Moderate sweet malt body, toasted with a light buttery note. Dries up in short, light bitter ending. [Sampled at the brewery, 01.09.13]
On cask at SIBA beer festival Glasgow a deep Amber beer slightly sour but mostly dried oranges and hops fruity and floral if a bit flat this is a nice beer but is better from the bottle

500ml Bottle as a gift from Arran, Scotland: Strong fruity notes with some orange, lemon and a slightly tropical aroma with some passion fruit in the mix. Some acidity followed by a sweetness and hops but overall it is the blend of fruits that dominates. The smell isn’t particularly well balanced and is overly strong sadly. Copper with a thumb-sized, creamy white head on top that holds remarkably well over. Fruity orange & tropical fruit flavors with some hops & some spice too. Strong citrus with some hints of caramel interspersed with various of hints of fruit. Medium bodied and very fruity throughout with a slight citrus tang and hints of alcohol too. The carbonation is medium to high and the finish is a sweet one. Not a beer I was particularly impressed with poor balance. Orange & tropical fruits dominate from the offset and neither being particularly enjoyable. The beer also seemed over-carbonated and just didn’t sit well with me for one reason or another.
Tried the Arran range while visiting and brought a crate back. Lovely amber ale, citrusy and with a dry finish.
Old rating. Best before 23.02.06. Grainy smooth beginning. Round but grainy with a moderate sweetness.
Bottled. A dark golden beer with an off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel, leading to a lightly bitter finish.

Bottle 50 cl. Clear deep golden with an off-white head. Aroma of malt and a little butter. Medium body, sweet malts, a little caramel and metal. Rather subdued bitterness with a light tartness in the finish. 040409

Bottle 50cl. w. swing top. Clear medium amber color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel butter, vegatable, acrid butter. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20090404]

50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Dry malty, butterish and light roasted aroma. Light acidic flavoured, a touch of butter and slight cornish flavoured. Mild acidic touch and bitterness into the finish.
on tap at berlinerbierfest06. very grainy, muesli aroma, brown, no real bitterness, pretty dull
Draught. Very dark brown colour, small white head. Grainy aroma. Bready flavour, slightly roasted. Slightly sweet. Mild flavour, not too bad.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: Only beer I’ve ever had by this brewpub. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a hazy burnt orange color. Bar pour yields no head. The smell had some cinnamon and pumpkin. Light ginger is inviting. The taste was mainly sweet but carried a nice spicy connotation about it. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation was there but was standard for the style, nothing bothersome. Overall, good pumpkin ale worthy of having again.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: I had this one over two years ago, but it has left an undying memory in my mind as one of the finest seasonal beers ever brewed and drank.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: On tap at the brewpub. A cloudy thin yellow whitish tinged pour, with a rim of white. Distant aroma of cinnamon grease. A very saccharin pumpkin pie spice flavor, with a far away maly dingyness. Not enough body or nice maltiness to carry the pumpkin spice. The palate has a real dry cinnamon pithyness. Overall, weak.

Can: Pale gold color, drank from a can so I’m not sure on the waveformation on the head retention. The nose is lightly grassy with some light husk and sweet malt. A bit sharp in the malt department, with very little adjuncts in the finish. Clean, a bit acidic on the palate. Decent product.
slighty lemony, seltzer water... weird. tastes more like a bad wine cooler? or perhaps, a weird chu-hi? i’d rather have chu-hi!!!

The second of three new brews for "Japanese Swill Night". This one looks like the last, another horrid offering from Asahi called "Style Free". This one has a bit more gold to it and the head flat out disappeared in record time. Not much of an aroma, what is there reminds me of a damp mop that was used yesterday to clean up spilled lemonade. Doesn’t taste much better. Not sure which was more a pathetic excuse of beer between this and the last one. Basically, both suck.

My wife informed me that this is not beer at all but a substitute that is supposed to be "Healthy" for people who want to drink beer but have stomach problems, organic. "Gubinama" means "Gulp Drink" , Japanese love onomatopoeias. Little watery and hoppy. Lots of carbonation, dont drink too much of this stuff please.

Light yellow colred, fastly vanishing white head. Lively carbonation. Lemon dominates in aroma, some fruity honey in there too. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is very thin and watery, some unclean corn with sweet touch. Mildly dry aftertaste with some lemon. Carbonated palate.

Can. Clear deep golden color, no head. Sweet malty and grainy nose. Watery, cardboardish, very thin (especially for 5% beer). Some sour notes in the finish. Very plain and watery. Much worse than eg. Asahi Super Dry.

Canned. Pale golden colour, no head. Aroma is quite non-existant, some slight malts and rice. Flavour is not much either, slightly hoppy. Easy to drink, but I almost drink water rather than this if I am thirsty. Alcohol also shows up a bit, as there’s not much else to cover it...

Thanks to whoever game me a pour from their growler at DLD. I haven’t had the normal bender so I really can’t compare. Poured a light brown color. Aroma was bready, nutty with a bit of bourbon. Taste was much the same, distant bourbon, light nuttines, I thought it was sort of watery overall and a little thin. I have had some great surly brews, and this just didn’t quite do it for me. Not hard to drink, but not outstanding.

poured from a growler on DLD. thanks for the person who shared this with our table..... poured a dark caramel brown with a bubbly edge of barely noticeable head.... aroma was of light bourbon and somewhat nutty..... flavors of a small amount of bourbon and lightly toasted. mouthfeel was a bit watery and thin.... must try this fresh of the tap one of these days.

on tap at DLD 08. thanks to whoever walked about with a growler of this. pours brownw ith tan head. a bourbon and nutty aroma. flavors are nutty, bourbon, caramel. and a real smooth finish. a solid beer and it actually works. bender shows he can be used well in many ways.

(Draft) Pours an amber-brown body with medium beige head. Aroma of toastiness, rye bread, vanilla, fig, and chocolate. Flavor of oak, vanilla, toasted/caramel malts, rye, and light chocolate with a dry finish.

FOBAB 07.Surly’s not living up to its reputation so far! Dark cola with beigeish head on the pour. Nose of bourbon caramel, vanilla, chocolate malts. Flavor is just off it seems, very blah. Sweet with small bitterness and bigtime alcohol.

On tap at FoBAB 5. Poured clear, deep reddish-brown with a light cap of beige head. The aroma picked up sweet caramel and chocolates with lesser oak and vanilla.. not much bourbon was perceptible.. lighter and quite complex (especially from a brown ale!). The flavor had vanilla, sweeter chocolates, toasted oak, and marshmallows throughout.. very tasty.. drier and a touch light right at the finish. Sweet and very enjoyable on the palate.. lighter-bodied, complex, and a great feel throughout.

FoBAB 2007: Dark brown with a fading head. The nose detects vanilla, walnut, fig, plum, caramel and bready vapours. The taste starts twangy and lactic like with a rich bready layer of malt under in all. The finish is oaky, nutty, and quite dry for a brown ale. The mouth feel is sticky and soft and as mentioned quite dry upon the finish. Not too shabby but I would have liked to see a bit more malt driven character.
ABR 2007. Funky oak and bourbon of the malty nose. Vanilla, oaks and a faint sourness in the body. Some hops survived. Not bad.

Draft at ABR 07. Poured a nice medium to dark brown with a tan head. Nice roasteed sweet malt on the nose, but the bourbon shines a little more on this than the darkness, and I am a little over that character in beers. Still very nice, but not as good as I had hoped.

First beer sampled on draught at the ABR 07 in Minneapolis, MN. Pours a semi-clear dark brown brew with a fast dissolving tan head that leaves behind an off-white head and some film on the brew top. Aroma of distinct bourbon and aged oak wood with a touch of dark caramel malt. Taste is creamy, smooth, slightly syrupy with more coconut and bourbon flavors than hops and malt. Finish has a slight hop bitterness that quickly disappears to a light bourbon aftertaste.

column1: Blue & Gray Baron von Steuben Oktoberfest
column5: Half stein pour. Copper pour with a slight white head. Metallic, roasted malt, sugar. Taste is roasted malts, caramel, candi sugar. Bit of a bitter bite. Not bad. easy drinking.

column1: Blue & Gray Baron von Steuben Oktoberfest
column5: Reviewed from notes. Pours a medium reddish brown with a a bit of an off white head. Nose brings forward some caramel as well as slightly-toasted bread. The taste is definitely a malt bomb, with no hops at all to speak of. Some slightly-sweet caramel along with a bit of roasted toast. Mouthfeel is medium; a bit heavy for the style, and it works alright. Decent depth of flavor. I’d say it’s a pretty decent American version of the style. Serving type: growler Reviewed on: 10-15-2010

column1: Blue & Gray Baron von Steuben Oktoberfest
column5: (Sample Date: 9/19/2009 Source:Other) Courtesy of Madison. Accentuated malt aroma with light spicy hop notes. Mostly clear amber brown. Spicy upfront bitterness over caramelized malts. Finish is dry and moderately bitter.

column1: Blue & Gray Baron von Steuben Oktoberfest
column5: Enjoyed this one from 7.5 gallon keg purchased at the brewery in Fredericksburg, VA. Pours to a beautiful, bright, deep chestnut color, with a thick, and creamy off white head, and a soft to moderate amount of carbonation. The nose on this beer is very inviting ,with lots of good toasty and nutty malt aromas paired with good herbal/grassy hop aroma. The palate is very polished and clean with excellent, deep malty flavors of toast, nuts, light hints of caramel. This beer finishes with more great malty, toasty/nutty flavors, then ends with a nice grassy hop bite that balances the malt sweetness of this beer. So fresh and flavorful from the draught, we drained a keg of this beer in record time. So flavorful yet, so, so drinkiable. This beer is an excellent local example of Oktoberfestbier/marzen that was the perfect match for bratwurst hot of the grill.

column1: Blue & Gray Baron von Steuben Oktoberfest
column5: Nice deep amber coloured body with ruby highlights and tints of orange. Aroma of malt, a bit of hops and a good amount of mild spices. Medium-bodied; Large malt backbone with a good yeastie and fresh hop flavour going strong. Aftertaste shows some caramel, a bit of coriander seed and a fair amount of floral hops. Overall, a good beer - not amazing, but definitely nice for the style and to try in general. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Clarendon, Virginia on 18-September-2008, sampled on 26-November-2008.

column1: Blue & Gray Baron von Steuben Oktoberfest
column5: 22 oz. bottle from Whole Foods in Richmond, VA. Pours a reddish brown with a thin white head. Grainy taste with caramel and corn notes. Very big taste of butterscotch, breadiness and caramel. Medium bodied.

column1: Blue & Gray Baron von Steuben Oktoberfest
column5: Clear dark amber body with a small off-white head. Sweet malty aroma. Slight hints of fruit punch. Sweet malty flavor with light breadiness and some toastiness.

column1: Blue & Gray Baron von Steuben Oktoberfest
column5: Courtesy of maniac who dropped by with this and a couple of other "beers" for an impromptu tasting. Darmk amber, reddish highlights, slight head. Aroma faintly malty with a slight odd twang of cheddar. Sort of full, slightly burnt malt, but thin at the same time. Better than I’m making it sound, this wasn’t bad. But not great.

column1: Blue & Gray Baron von Steuben Oktoberfest
column5: From a 25 oz bottle ... poured with a big poofy head over an amber brew. Light malty aroma. The beer drinks with the smoothness of milk, with a big bready maltiness with a sharp cheesy bitter twist at the end. Quite good.

Pour was a dirty blonde with a large white head. Aroma was nice a fruity with some vanilla and yeast. Flavoir was also above par with a touch of pepper and citrus fruit along with some corriander and spice. Nice example of the style.
Beerfest in Chilton. Fruit aroma, sweet and hops, honey color. Nice start.

Small pour (approximately 3 oz.), on tap at Gitchee Gumee Brewfest in Superior, WI on 4-5-08. This was the fifth of 12 beers that I rated (out of about 20 total beers that I tried). It was listed as simply "Muskie Capital Saison" at the festival. This was my favorite beer of the Brewfest. Pours a clear, dark brass / medium brown, quite dark for a saison. Small amount of beige head. Very nice, Belgian-style, sweet aroma with some dusty dryness. The taste has a very sweet start with a lightly dry finish. Medium body. Crisp, smooth, and lively in the palate. I was highly impressed by this offering and will seek out Muskie Capital if I am ever in its area.
A growler courtesy of Skyview. Cloudy, dark copper color with a large head. Nice farmhouse, banana and yeasty aroma. Big bread, yeast, cloves and malt taste. Excellent.
Musky grapes and banana aroma. rich caramel color. malty sweet light and crisp. nice carbonation for a thirst quenching beer.

Poured from a growler; rustic, cloudy orange appearance. Slightly old bananas in the aroma, with lots of pure cinnamon and clove spiciness; hints of toasted vanilla, almond, and caramel. A generous powdering of nuance settling on a delicately balanced body of calm sweetness; very pleasant. Flavor is flowery and sweet; quite delicate with light tones of pistachio, lavender, white pepper, banana, and ginger. Very creamy, soft, and well arranged in the mouth; balanced and interesting. Finishes with a soft milky sweetness. A fantastic domestic saison. Thanks for sharing, Bob!

On draught at the brewpub in Hayward, Wisconsin. Pours a clear copper amber amber with a thick, creamy and lumpy off-white head that has some excellent retention and thick lacing. Aroma of clean crystal grain malt, some grassy hops, a touch of banana esters and cloves. Taste is light to medium bodied, some carbonation with flavors of light multi-grain malt, banana esters, a touch of white pepper and herbal spices. Finish is semi-dry, a mild bitterness with some aftertaste of light banana, cloves and cereal grain malt. There was no sediment in this saison but still quite drinkable.
Gold Color with Cream Head. Coriander and Belgian Yeast Aroma. Follows Through on Flavor...Sweet, Yeasty with Spices..Lightly Bready and a Bit Earthy. Very Solid American Saison

Sampled draught at the Autumn Brew Review in Minneapolis, October 7 2006. Dark hazy amber with a smallish but persistent head....nose at first very sweet, herbal (cardamom, ginger) character showing up quickly as the sugary notes die, dry grassy notes start to dominate....body rather tart, earthy, low-to-moderate sweetness, lots of doughy yeastiness in the mouthfeel....finish is borderline sour with some interesting mineral qualities. Not bad.

One of the highlights of the 2006 Autumn Beer Review. This nanobrewer did this Saison right (and did a much better job than Town Hall’s half-hearted effort a few months ago). The aroma makes this beer immediately recognizable as a saison. There is yeast and barnyard weirdness. More yeast in the flavor, a little sour and some weird spices as well. Touch of citrus and lightly hopped. A cloudy yellow beer, looks like it might not be filtered. -------taste from growler March, 2007. Score raised by 2 points.
Autumn Brew Review 2008. Copper color with a thin head. Barley any aroma, just very light grain. The taste seems to be a bit of rye and oatmeal.

On-tap the Brewpub: Coppery toned color with a finger high capping of fluffy, firm, light tanned foam. Keeps a good bubbley skim and a solid collar present. Laces in teathered rings around the glass. Aroma is of toasted berries, pale malt, and dried breads. Taste has nice rounded flavors that balance well with a mild berry tone within a semi sweet toffee sweetenss pinched with vanilla and dried fig. The Vienna malt is lightly placed in a sweeter, fresher, bready tone then toasty and finishes with a feathery burntness under the sweet berry malt. Feel is about medium, mildly sweet and snappy with a nice rounded, soft, malty smoothness. Quite drinkable and refreshing. A nice Vienna. The berry fruityness is nicely played along a toffee breaded sweetness.
ABR 2006. This is a solid Vienna. Lots of malt. some light hops. Well balanced and a good session beer. Red color.

column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: [Tap] Called ’Back Country Blonde’ at Lake Tahoe Pizza Company. I am guessing it is the same beer as the ’Summer Blonde’ based on the ABV and other ratings. Pours a light brown color with a ton of foamy white head. Nice lacing on the glass. Nose is of mild spices, light hops, cereal grains and caramel malts. Distinct malt profile is unlike most blonde ales. Caramel, some toffee, hints of smoke and a decent hop kick. An interesting beer, but a little out of whack for the style.

column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Draft. Amber beer with a cream colored head. Light malt and light spice aroma. malt and spice flavor with light grass. Medium bodied. Malt and spice lingers with light hops.

column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: (10/2006. Draft.) Very light malty aromas evident, but by and large very neutral. Ever-so-slightly-hazy golden with a white head that dissipates relatively quickly into a lasting, medium-thick, white film with decent lace. Very smooth flavors. Malty sweetness balanced by a subtle hop spiciness imparted, no doubt, from a noble variety (Hallertau, I’m guessing!). Pleasantly bitter on the back end, medium-bodied with a nice, warming sensation imparted from the relatively high alcohol that remains very tame. Lingering, spicy aftertaste from the hops. Medium-low carbonation.

Really wish I could remember where and when I had this, but I remember it being such a disappointment that I know I’ve had a few sips. Way too much bourbon with not enough body to back it up. Hints of cherry mucked up by weird sours flavors. A great idea gone weirdly wrong...not to say I’m giving an A for effort to FS for trying something a bit more out of the normal realm!

Hot boozy nose overwhelming with bourbon and cherries. Would not recommend lighting a match near this beer for fear of the fumes igniting. Slight ethanol-paint thinner-nail polish remover nose. Funky as all hell. The pinot and wood flavors come to life later with each sip. Quite memorable and for this I give it merit, but I would not frequent this beer, even if I could.

Complex beer, but does suffer a bit from the phenolic nailpolish bite. The aroma is overwhelmed by sharp nail polish smells, but the flavor remains a jungle of flavors. Tart cherry, dry wood, pinot flavors, moldy cheese, and other interesting flavors that make you think. I really enjoyed the sourness and the depth of flavors, it would be very hard to nail them all down. My only problem was the aroma, the flavor was excellent.

Bottle from J. Harris: Golden color with some bubbles but no head. Aroma is sweet, fruity, woody and wine like. A light body that is swet and fruity at first, then slightly tart and acidic, a little alcohol warmth, you also get a slight bourbon flavor and definitely some pinot noir flavor. A dry wine and wood finish. Very very unique, i gather this is a love it or hate it beer. It is amazingly complex and one of those beers where you can easily pick out 6 different flavors that are all unique. I wouldnt drink a pint of this but very much enjoyed the glass.

Everyone who tried this at GABF should try and get a hold of another sample. I shared this bottle with John Harris, and while it didn’t affect my perception of the beer I think it gave me a better understanding of what he was shooting for. Once you get past the opening notes of acetone there’s a wonderful funky/sour/tart beer lurking underneath. No head to speak of. Flavors of bourbon and acetone give way to a heady mixture of brett/lacto funk and a vinous finish. Not something I could drink every day, but I’m sure glad I had the chance to taste this abberation :) Thanks again John!

Rating this one from memory...tasted at GABF. Worst beer that I have ever tried. So bad I had to try it twice to make sure it really was that awful. What’s not to like? How about the taste of gasoline mixed with a bit of paint thinner? No no no no no no no. I’d rather drink non-alcoholic beer.

Draft at Falling Rock. Amber bodied. Nose is very "unique". It’s quite liqueur like. Maybe melon liqueur. Very alcoholic nose and over ripened fruits. Taste is sour fruits, oak barrel, alcohol and paint thinner/nail polish. Some malt in there as well. Body is medium with a sour astringency and lots of dry notes. Finishes with more paint thinner, sour fruits and alcohol. I appreciate the attempt, but in the end, I couldn’t finish the glass.

Draft @ Falling Rock: Dark golden color. It is love it or hate I see. I thought it was pretty tasty. Nice and sour. Vinous notes that was a little odd mixed with bourbon but I didn’t think that was a problem. Grapes, cherries, vanilla and sour. Whats not to like.

sampled at GABF 2006. This beer is by far the worst beer I’ve ever tried. I spit it out almost instantly. Besides being extremely combustable it will also peal the paint off your walls. I love Full Sail but this was AWEFUL.

Tap @ Falling Rock and again @ GABF. Had to try it again to insure the first one wasn’t just horribly infected. This was by far the worst beer of the 100+ I sampled during the GABF week. I love barrel aged beers, but this was pure finger nail polish remover. Enough said.
"not bad. a little light for my taste, but that is made up for by the incredible freshness of the beer. quite satisfying. it has a lighter hop profile than mirror pond, but equally as good."

On tap at the Bend brew pub. I found this to have an odd fruit tone along with a dank, musty flavor. It’s clearly a pale ale, but it;s grass and hay instead of citrus and pine. Not even remotely what I expected, and although I have yet to ride Phil’s trails (perhaps this Summer), I would have thought he would expect more. I would not drink this one again and find this sub-par for Deschutes. Nothing more than Mirror Pond, if that.
On CASK at Brewpub Pours out amber topped with a small head. A little malt and grass on this one. just so so.
Tap @ Brewpub: Hazy deep gold,small off white head.Faint malt nose. Light smooth malt profile, sparsely hopped

Tap @ Brewpub: Gold, nice head and lacing. Nose of husk and funky, musky malts. The flavor is musky, lightly bitter and grassy. The finish is thin, forgetful, light malt. Dry. Not as good as the Painted hills I had right before this one.

On Tap at the BrewPub. Oeange amber with a sandy head. Nice balance of rich malts and citrusy hops. Tazte is more bitter hops tham the otjer pale. Nice strong late nitter trail. Nice Pale. Deschutes shows guts having 2 PAs on at the same time.
Amber-tangerine orange color w. faded head. Bubble gum and pleasant floral hop bouquet with a moderate sweet malt background. Malty, bubble-gummy flavor with some floral character.

column1: Deschutes Mirror Pond Pale Ale - French Oak
column5: Dense orange appearance with short lasting white head. Light fruits and hops with background hops. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Deschutes Mirror Pond Pale Ale - French Oak
column5: this is like the fresh hop version that was bottled, which is already quite nice...then throw in some oak flavor and aroma...pretty dang good!

column1: Deschutes Mirror Pond Pale Ale - French Oak
column5: Pretty damn tasty offering from a pretty damn tasty brewery. A bit mjore complexity than the standard mirror pond as well.

column1: Deschutes Mirror Pond Pale Ale - French Oak
column5: One of my favorite American Ales. Much better on tap than in a bottle. Just had one last night at a local sports bar after a softball game with a bacon cheeseburger. Nothing could be better! Medium color, I’m guessing 15 SRM. Nice cascade aroma from dry-hopping, yet overall bitterness is subdued. Good head retention, and a nice dry, crisp finish.

column1: Deschutes Mirror Pond Pale Ale - French Oak
column5: On tap at the brewpub (and subsequently on growler at home!). Pours an almost clear orange-brown with a medium, cream-colored head like ocean foam. Leaves decent lacing. This is a wonderfully aromatic pale ale, with more than just the usual suspects. To be sure, there’s a healthy amount of lemon-lime citrus and some caramel (not really very pronounced before warming). But these combine in such a way, and undoubtedly with help from the oaking, to convey rose-petal perfumes and a bright fruity character you might find in a dry white wine. The beer is on the light-bodied side with very mild bittering. The body is sweet in a perfumy sort of way and there’s some lemony acidity. Finish is medium in length and light caramel lingers. This is a very nice twist on a pale.

column1: Deschutes Mirror Pond Pale Ale - French Oak
column5: On tap at the Deschutes pub. This was really nice, the pale was dried out a lot by the oak. Sweet caramel hint of front blended nicely with the oak and the finish was crisp and very dry from the citrus hops. Pours a clear amber with a tall white head. This beer didn’t stand out much before, but the oak adds a subtle character that makes it much more interesting.

column1: Deschutes Mirror Pond Pale Ale - French Oak
column5: Nice light amber, but a soothing cascade hops and honey-suckle aroma. Medium body w.th just enough cascade hops to keep it from being bland. Simple, but crisply hopped beer and a pleasant finish.

column4: Unicer Bebidas (SBG Super Bock Group - Carlsberg)
column5: Bottle from supermarket in Portugal. Old notes. Golden color, white head. No taste whatsoever

column4: Unicer Bebidas (SBG Super Bock Group - Carlsberg)
column5: 33 cl bottle .A long time ago.One more seasonal Super Bock beer. Watery. No character at all.

column4: Unicer Bebidas (SBG Super Bock Group - Carlsberg)
column5: Bottled. Pale golden, small head. Evident papery nose. Sweetish, thin and bland. Cardboard dominates. No bitterness. Extremely tasteless, except for cardboard.

column4: Unicer Bebidas (SBG Super Bock Group - Carlsberg)
column5: Bottled (BB 04/2007) Golden color, small steady white head. Mostly skunky and papery aroma. Watery pale lager with cardboard and grainy malty flavors. Watery aftertaste. Not very cool, more like useless.

column4: Unicer Bebidas (SBG Super Bock Group - Carlsberg)
column5: Bottled. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is green apples as welll as some hops, maybe maize too. Flavour is hayish hoppy with some sweetish hints.

column4: Unicer Bebidas (SBG Super Bock Group - Carlsberg)
column5: Let me firts make an introduction: this is not the same beer as Super Bock Cool Beer, that existed some 3 years ago. This new product is a weak copy of that beer, launched only for the 2006 Summer. Super Bock Cool Beer was an Ice Beer that demanded special refrigeration and therefore had big distributions costs. So Unicer dropped that particular beer. This year, Sagres, the main rival of Unicer, launched a beer called Sagres Chopp that is intended to please the large brazilian comunity that lives in Portugal. The reply of Unicer was this Super Bock Cool. But this is not an Ice Beer. In fact, it’s a very weak pale lager. With an easy to remove cap, Cool is very pale (straw colour) and has a small white head, mostly diminishing. Not much lively this one!! It has also a strange aroma: very few hops but a strange presence of apple reminding a cider. Flavour has nothing: weak and watery. Nevertheless, this beer can be very refreshing although more bitterness could help. A very bad product and another desillusion from Unicer.

Just called Saison and listed at 6.4% abv. The body was medium gold with a bright white head. The aroma was sweet bubblegum and banana with some cinnamon. The taste was bananas and clove. There was also some hay. Just a big bowl of ok.

Had one tonight in the mug club vessel, though I heard one server say it is officially served in "the gay glass"...and here I pour into a pint glass for this assessment. Looks nice, chalk white foam stands tall in the glass, leaving lace, very hazed, pale orange appearance...very nice. Citrus, spice, straw, and a stick of bubblegum mark the nose. Lively and delightful. Again, I find myself liking it. Soft on the palate, then sweet and mellow, revealing slices of lemon and whiffs of orange, with a tangy yeasty kick. Citrus feels sharp later on, with a peppery twist. Lays long, but lightly, on the tongue. Loaded with character, brimming with fine flavor. A very agreeable saison, tasty, well-made, not lacking in any way that I can consider. A must-try treat at the pub right now. Well done!

aka Saison Deux Trois. Pours a hazy straw color, topped by a short-lived head of sudsy white foam. A ring provides scant lacing. Wet hay, dog-blanket (as opposed to horse blanket), and lemongrass in the aroma. The malt is sweet and dry at the same time - sweet honeymalt, dry wheat. Lemongrass and a bit of orange behind these. Lighter body, mild carbonation. I don’t think lemongrass is an actual ingredient, but I detect a lemongrass-like flavor and aroma. I am not a fan of lemongrass.

For three years in a row, Rock Bottom has done a respectable Saison for the Autumn Beer Review. This beer is bitter and spicy, some wheat. Cloudy yellow with a white head. Light barnyard aroma, some yeast, and a little bit sour.

500ml bottle from Oakchurch farm shop, Herefordshire, that Jim shared with me - cheers! Cloudy straw colour with a huge white head. Yeasty aroma and taste. Dry with a little citrus and bread. Some sourness. Not great.

Tasted this at the Crystal Palace, Glasgow (JDW) in September 2008. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear pale amber in colour with a thin creamy white head. Subtle note of citrus fruit in the short aroma. Thin but zesty mouthfeel. Pale malt complex gives a digestive biscuit base with a grapefruit note evident. Dusty hop resins give a bitter bite to the dry, floral aftertaste. Finish is again slightly bitter with hop resins giving a grapefruit pith note in the palate. An ok session bitter.

Cask (JDW, Uxbridge, RBESG2011) Picked onion aroma. Yucky sour sulfurous taste. Clearly an OK boring bitter, but this has comitted suicide at the hands of McSpoons. There is even a bit of roast still poking through. Shame.
cask at spoons whwite lady ... light copper ... thin white head ... soft light fruit malt ... over cold ... light bitter sof hop ... dull malt background ... almost but not quite sour
Hand pulled at the Wetherspoons under the Central Library, Birmingham. Malty, biscuit cracker. Folded glue foreground. Charisma of a table, but OK really. Brown/amber.
Copper colour with a thin white head. Slight malt aroma. Bitter malt flavour and texture.

Cask@JDW Sir John Oldcastle, London. Ambery golden colour, small white head. Aroma is sweet malts, some floral and fruity (sweetish) hoppy notes as well as some wooden notes. Flavour is wood, herbs, quite floral and also quite bitter in the finish.
Cask at the Wetherspoons at Victoria Station. Amber with a rather scummy looking beige head; malty aroma; rather thin with a sweet grainy malt flavour; and a biscuity finish. A rather average bitter.

Caskhandpull at Blakes Dover. Copper brown clear. Thin disappearing off white head. Not great to be honest some bleach flavour in the middle with some biscuit on the finish. Could be better. Otherwise its a not very bitter bitter.
Cask handpull, The Crown, Nuneaton. Dirty gold with a loose white halo. Orange and honey aroma; some earthy malt and alcohol on the palate, pine and TCP spashes. Solid.

15th July 2014 Chelmsford Summer Beer Fest. Cask. Almost clear gold beer. Bubbly white head. Palate is light, semi dry and crispy. Light malt sweetness, touch of honey. Nice mellow orange marmalade. Little floralness. Let down by some sulphur off notes. Drinkable though. Light semi dry finish.
Cask at the GBBF. Golden with a small white head. Aroma of fruit and grain, with a faint phenolic note. Nice malty flavour with some fresh cereal, some herbal hops and a mild bitter finish

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 2011, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear medium orange yellow colour with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted - caramel, fruity, sour malt, apples. Flavor is moderate sweet, light light acidic and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20110802]

column2: Santa Cruz de Tenerife, Canary Islands, Spain
column5: Tenerife 06. Straw color and a huge head. The aroma has notes of wet grain/malt, and this is found in the flavour too. Most non-alcoholic beers are revolting, but this one can be drunk, if you really want to... 1569

column2: Santa Cruz de Tenerife, Canary Islands, Spain
column5: Can (BB 07/2007) Golden color, not much head. Aroma of sour milk and wet cardboard. Carbonated, crisp mouthfeel, very very watery, mostly tasteless. Only weak harsh malty notes.

column2: Santa Cruz de Tenerife, Canary Islands, Spain
column5: Canned. Golden colour, not much head. Aroma is malts, rice, maize and some hints of a wet "old" ashtray. Flavour is metallic and has the same ashtray -thingy in the background. Not pleasant in any way. Really I can’t give points for anything in this one.
Bottle. Poured with a big head. Golden clear and bitter. Nothing else going for it. Very mundane.
