Bottle. Golden brown with a large lively foam. Aromas are caramel and low spiced oranges with overipe pear and brown sugar. Flavours are sweet caramel with mellow orange and lemon with soft spices. Some hints of banana with a yeasty finish. OK.
bottle, labelled Budleigh Bitter. Hazy golden colour, large off-white head. Slightly fruity, bitter, intensive carbonation.

Cask gravity at the Abbotskerswell Beer and Food Festival, 07/10/2006. A dark amber colour with a small head. A sweet aroma with caramel and roasted malt. A strong roasted malt taste with some hoppiness and citrus in the finish. Moderate bitterness. Quite tasty.

Cask gravity at the Abbotskerswell Beer and Food Festival, 07/10/2006. An amber colour with a small head. A floral hop aroma. A hoppy taste with caramel. The typical Tarka citric sourness in the finish. Pretty average. Aroma: 5, Appearance: 3, Flavour: 5, Palate: 3, Overall: 14. ———— Bottle, 500ml, bottle-conditioned. A dark amber colour with a few whisps of head. Aroma is dominated by caramel with some hops and malt. Taste is strong caramel with a lot of malt and a little hoppiness. In the finish, a light lemon and lime fruit flavour appears seemingly from nowhere to lighten-up this otherwise fairly sweet and heavy brew. There’s also some floral hop in the finish as well. Moderate carbonation. Seems somewhat better than when I previously had it in cask form.

Cask gravity at the Abbotskerswell Beer and Food Festival, 07/10/2006. A dark amber colour with a small head. A strong aroma of manure. The taste is a little hoppy with some sourness and undertones of manure. Something is not right with this - a bad cask perhaps? The first beer I’ve ever drain-poured.
On tap at the brewpub. Trübes dunkel goldgelbes Bier mit einer mittelgroßen beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch getreidig malzig, leicht süß, leicht hopfig. Geschmack kräftig malzig, süß, würzig hopfig.
Sehr hefiger Antrunk mit heller Malzigkeit. Herber und würziger im Mittelteil, steigende Getreidenoten. Zum Ende hin steigert sich das Ganze noch einmal, mild süß. Gelungen! 11/11/11/11//11

Draught at the brewpub. Sweet malty aroma with yeast and a weak fruity note. Quite doughy taste, overcarbonated, a bit alcoholic in the finish. For a marzen not too shabby. Actually, I might even write I liked it somehow.

Draught at the brauhaus Deep blond color, clean, with compact head. Light aroma of malt and honey. A bit more carbonated than the other beers from this brewery, it has light malt flavor, light honey touch, low bitterness, not much hop character. Not interesting.

Draught @ Webster Brauhaus, Dellplatz 14, Duisburg, North Rhine-Westphalia Germany 47051. Unclear - hazy medium yellow orange color with a small to average, frothy, good - fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, light hoppy, grass, light yeasty. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, light sweet yeasty. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20101005]

From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy yellow to orange with a small white head. Aroma is hoppy and toasted malty. Flavour is the same. Rather malty, light toasted and grassy hoppy. Full bodied and smooth. Ends dry malty and slight bitter.

(draught at the brewpub) Hazy orange-golden colour with a small foamy, minimal off-white head. Dusty sweet wort-aroma, slightly apricot-fruity. Yeasty bitter and slightly sweet flavour; unripe malty and yeasty and worty taste with restrained fruity notes; sweetish yeasty and light-bitter finish with only traces of herbal hops. Rather unpleasant (03.10.06).

Cask gravity at the Abbotskerswell Beer and Food Festival, 07/10/2006. A dark brown colour with no head. A malty aroma with caramel. Taste of roasted malt with a little cocoa. Some citrus in the finish. Moderate bitterness. Not bad at all.
Vom Fass. Hellgelb trübes Bier mit festem Schaum. Viel Banane in der Nase. Es schmeckt zitronig und nach Banane. Der Hopfen ist im Abgang da.
Trübes gelb schaum ok, im geruch klassisch viel banane und citrus, grasig banane Grüne banane im Geschmack Hefe leicht süß, recht klassisch

On tap at the pub. Smooth mild Weizen yeast, typical banana with a bit more clove than banana. Nice carbonation, fresh, smooth with a nice bitterness, that is higher than expected, but fits in great. Smooth bitter clove yeasty aftertaste with hints of grain. Nice.
Aroma of wheat, light banana, fruits, yeast, clove, spicy notes. Flavour is moderate sweet with a light bitter finish. Tasty and enjoyable Weizen.

Frischer und heller Hefeantrunk, leicht bitter. Die Hefigkeit nimmt im Mittelteil zu, das Bier wird süßer. Süffig, vollmundig nach Banane, die Bitterkeit ist gänzlich verschwunden, minimal herb. Sommerweizen! 12/8/10/9//9

On tap at the brewpub. Poured out ( poor me in 0.5l) in a cloudy orange-golden colour with big steady head and medium body. Aroma of yeast and wheat. Taste of intense yeats, straw, overripe fruit salad, flowers and wheat. Bready-sweet finish with a high carbonation. Nice one and drinkable. yet nothing spectacular.

On tap getrunken und von Beginn an mit dem Kopf geschuettelt. Weizen sind an sich schon speziell und wenn es wieder mal einen Hefeblock im Glas gibt, wird es umso schwieriger. Ansonsten leicht grasig und stellenweise schwer, runterzuwuergen. Nicht mein Ding.
Draught at the brewpub. Classic hefeweizen with an aroma of banana, clove and some nutmeg, a soft mouthfeel and a very fruity taste. Their best beer, definitely.

Draught at the brauhaus Cloudy blond color with generous, compact, persistent head. The aroma is quite spicy, with a light banana presence. Soft mouthfeel, some wheat flavor, delicate spiciness (cloves), subtle fruitiness (banana and hint of tropical); low bitterness. Quite good Weizen.

By far their best beer of the three I tasted. Poured a pale hazy golden yellow with an off-white head. Smell is the typical banana, clove, sweet fruit. Taste follows the nose and ends dry. Smooth with a fine carbonation structure. This was a nice weizen with full flavor.

Bottle from the Shops at Dartington. Appearance - golden with a nicely proportioned head. Nose - creamy and almost lightly cheesey. Some grassiness. Taste - still a touch of cheese plus grassiness again. Palate - creamy and light bodied. Dry but somehow not refreshing. Overall - not sure it's in quite the condition the brewer would've hoped.
Bottle shared with Ashton McCobb. Pours clear golden with a thin white head. Aromas of caramel, faint lemon. Taste is more of the same, plus a soapy note. Thin finish.

Cask, half-pint on 17th July 2018 in The Lamb, Sandford, Devon. Light golden body, white crown. Citrus notes in the nose, floral touch too in the aroma. Subtle citrus flavour on a bed of pale maltiness, drying finish.
Cask at the Bull and Blacksmith, Chillington, Devon. Gold with a white head. Floral aroma. Mild citrus in the flavour. A light, refreshing brew, pleasant enough but maybe a little bland by the end.

On gravity at the Green Man, Bristol 27/09/10. Amber coloured with a slight, off-white head. Caramel aroma with some red fruits, floral hop and hint of earthiness. Toffee flavoured, with more fruit, a trace of roasted malts and decent, dry finish. A good sweet beer.
Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Dark amber with white head. Dry malty bitter with quite a strong alcohol tang. There is a perfumed hop with a nasal dry finish. reasonable.

Cask gravity at the Abbotskerswell Beer and Food Festival, 07/10/2006. A dark amber colour. A sweet caramel aroma with musty leaves. Quite hoppy taste with caramel, honey and a little malt. Quite well balanced. Light bitterness. Quite tasty.

Cask at GBBF 2007. An amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with primary notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet malty with light notes of caramel, leading to a dry finish with light notes of straw.
Copper beer with a small, but lasting off-white head, leaving some lace. Malt and caramel aroma with a strong note of butterscotch. Semisweet rich flavour with a bitter finish

Cask @ GBBF 2007, London. Clear medium amber color with a small, frothy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, light to moderate hoppy, citrus, strawberry pudding. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat.
Cask@GBBF2007. Amber colour, creamy beige head. Aroma is big grassyness along with caramel, toffee, wood and some bisquits. Flavour is slightly leathery, caramel malts and quite sour wood.

Cask gravity at the Abbotskerswell Beer and Food Festival, 07/10/2006. A dark amber colour with no head. A lightly hoppy aroma with caramel. A light hoppy taste with some malt to balance it out. A moderately bitter finish. A little boring.

bottle from Threshers Sidmouth. Clear amber colour, mid-sized fluffy off-white head with a brown touch. Rather thin-bodied for the ABV with a shy malty background and some nice aromatic hops and a dry mouthfeel.
Bottle. Clear appearance. Slightly bitter, robust mouth feel. Hoppy, bitter aftertaste and left no lacing. The title may give the impression that its a dark ale.It isn’t.Quite nice though.

Cask (gravity dispense), St Albans Beer Festival, September 2007. I expected a dark beer but it wasn’t - more a standard copper colour. Crystal clear. Not much condition. Subtle tropical fruit notes in the aroma, together with some resinous hop. Clean hoppy attack on the palate, with touches of fruity malt. Fairly firm mouthfeel. Quite decent but not really much like the description. Did they forget the chocolate malt? I had this noted down as 4.7%.
Cask@St. Albans BF. Pretty bad. Green apples in the aroma hints thats it wasn’t fresh, it its just plain bad. Grainy mouthfeel, with a watery finish. Very dull.

A Mes rate: Gravicask at St. Albans Beer Festival. Golden brown. Hoppy aroma with slight malt and just a little alcohol. Hoppy flavour with straw, slight bitterness and some very faint apple. A tad watery. Totally standard.

Cask gravity at St Albans BF 2007. I expected a dark beer, but this wasn’t. Copper, thin disappearing head. Peachy aroma. Peachy in mouth, slightly sweet, but some hop on end. Nice fruity strong bitter, alcohol gives it a certain sweetness.
Cask gravity at the Abbotskerswell Beer and Food Festival, 07/10/2006. Aroma is malty with dark fruits (plum). A malty, fruity taste with moderate bitterness. Delicious.

This was called New Years Fest but it seems to be the same. 2007 version. Medium to dark amber color, tall head. Rich malt aroma, slightly nutty, a bit sweet, also a bit buttery. Rich malt flavor. Nutty, bready, a bit sweet. Round and mellow, a bit too buttery, but with good hops as well, better than usual for the style. A little too much carbonation. Almost gassy. Strong, dry, amber malt and hop finish. Lingering bitterness. Very different to a Munich festbier.

Cloudy light amber color. Some hops are noticable at first, but as beer warms up bready and caramel notes become more present. Kicks off with a deep bready malty and caramel mouth, but balanced with some hop bitterness in mouth. Very light bodied. Dry bready caramel finish. Beer definetely got better as time went on.

Tap @ Oedo beer festival, Shinagawa Intercity (as Aki Agari). Pours amber, some white foam on top. Malty nose, light bitterness. Tastes malty, sweetish-malty, linger has some herbs.Overall still mainly sweetish and malty. Not bad but just simple, brewed well into the style I think.

Tap at Craft Beer Picnic 2017 as Chateau kamiya Aki Agari Amber red-brown in color with a medium raspy body. A bready somewhat smoky aroma. The taste is biscuity and nutty but balanced. I'd say it is a Vienna lager or maybe an Oktoberfest type. Quite good.
Sampled at Keyaki. Caramel malt, grassy hops, bittersweet finish. Decent stuff for the style, quite drinkable and sessionable.

Keyaki fall 2016. Really nice malt character, good caramel and toasted biscuit character. Easy drinking with a light bitterness on the finish. Really solid. Keyaki Fall 2015. Clear copper with a smallish off-white head. Good malty aromas with some light caramel and currant. Nice carbonation and medium body. Easy to drink, but pretty straightforward for the style.

Tap at the brewery. Light amber colour, small off-white head. Total rebate from last time as it is so different. Aroma is caramel, malty, light hoppiness. Taste is good, pretty sweet, lots of malt, something interesting, maybe floral. Pretty good I think.

Draught at the Ji-Beer Festa in Hiroshima, 2012. Deep gold, tinge of amber. Nice head. Malty aroma, lightly hopped. Nicely balanced flavor, rich malts, earthy hops. Good bitterness. Well done but not really surprising.

It was odd that they have an Ocktoberfest and a Marzen. The Ocktoberfest was clearly a seasonal, this one I am not so sure. I found this clear deep amber brew was similar to the Ocktoberfest, but better malty flavors and the finish was not so dry. Went excellent with caramelized onions!

Tap at the brewery. Light amber colour, off-white frothy head. Aroma is sweet malt, bit of hoppiness, wheat. Taste is pretty good, light fruity sweetness, solid maltiness, light caramel, apples, slight spiciness. Quite like this, maybe my favourite of the day.
Reasonably straight forward lager. A bit bready and a soft bitter finish, but without the magic of the sublime helles. Still a pretty decent drop though.

Deep golden color with a slight tinge of amber, and a tall foamy white head. Rich malt aroma, biscuity and grainy, with a decent hop character as well. Rather fragrant indeed somewhat sweet and very rich. Rich malt flavor, biscuits, cereals. Round and smooth. Hops are in the background but always evident. Medium or better bitterness. Moderate sweetness. A nice, rich lager in the Helles style, but with a much stronger hop character—I guess a Dortmunder Export type. Very interesting and pleasant. Good hop bitterness, and a great hoppy finish. Probably their best beer I have had so far.
Sampled @ GJBF Yokohama: Gold, yellow, light white head, nice lacing. Nose of light fruit and yeast, light malt and a balanced nutty finish. Decent.
@ GJBF 2007. Golden color. Tosted malts, some fruit, and hops. Flavor is just and extension of the mediocre aroma. It’s not a bad brew, but just sorta there.

Deep golden color. Toasted barely nose. Soft fruity nose of bananas and peaches, which was a bit odd I thought. Soft mouthfeel, slightly winey with bananas and toasted malt and a nice toasted malt finish. I think it was aiming for a Dort, but it seem to have some odd, though not unpleasent, other characteristics.
Fles 50cl thuis. Wat dun, malttonen, hoptonen, niet zo bitter, gemiddeld. (1-2018).
Bottle from deli in Devon. Pours clear slightly coppery brown. Decent head. Aroma fairly run of the mill - rather malty and some treacle, slight spiciness.
Bottle from waitrose, holsworthy, devon. Drunk in caravan near holsworthy. Amber beer with small head. Aroma of malts and fruity. Taste is malts, caramel and fruity hops. Decent.

On cask at the Cove, Outer Cove. Appearance - amber with a proportionate head. Nose - light toffee and cereal. Strawberry jam. A bit jammy dodgers. Taste - more jammy dodgers. Tangy red fruits and cereal. Palate - light to medium bodied with a crunchy texture and a dry crunchy finish. Overall - a decent bitter.

Aroma: grain and bread malts, caramel, some fruitiness. Appearance: slightly hazy amber, medium, creamy, white head. Taste: light bitter. Palate: intense malts, bread and caramel, light floral hops, some grass. Overall: nice Bitter, good sweetness throughout. Bottle from Waitrose, Exeter.
Bottled ; Devon ; UK ; Malt,caramel,fruit and nice floral aroma ; Cloudy amber color with smaller lasting head ; Lighter sweet taste with bitter long finish ; Medium body ; Very pleasant.

[31/3/13, 500ml bottle rebadged for National Trust "A La Ronde Best" that my Dad shared with me - cheers!] A slightly hazy effervescent amber bitter with a large cream head. Good mouthfeel - a bottle conditioned ale that actually achieves the mouthfeel of cask ale. Orange and lots of bread yeast up front, with some herbs. Rather astringent in the finish, with a spicy, earthy bitterness afterwards. I liked it initially but swiftly went off it and struggled to finish it. 7/3/4/4/9. [Re-rate, 1/8/14, cask at the Cherub Inn, Dartmouth rebadged as "Tolchards Devon Coast"> Stupid, stupid cheating fecky rebadges. Though this was a new brewery. Bastards. It’s not even like it was a decent beer that I particularly wanted to re-rate. This time it’s dull amber with a thin white head. Very bland - just a slight floral and citrus hint as if someone wavd a hop pellet vaguely in the brewery once upon a time. That said, there’s no off notes, and the beer has a reasonable enough body and is quite thirst quenching; it’s just completely dull, as if a competent brewer was asked to make a beer on such a low budget that he couldn’t afford enough hops. 5/3/5/3/10

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium orange colour with a small, virtually none, fair lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, nutty, caramel, dusty malt, victorian furniture. Flavour is moderate sweet and light acidic with a average to long duration, dry, caramel, thin fruity tart. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20120805]
Bottled@chriso. Amber colour, small head. Aroma is mild toast, some sweet malts, fruits and some slight spicyness. Flavour is bitter fruits, wood and some slight herbal and grassy notes.
Bottle at home ... copper ... thin bubbly off white head ... soft toffee fruits nose ... sweet metalic roast ... thin malts ... long light bitter linger .

Draft at Keyaki Spring 2015. Deep gold color with a modest pillowy white head. Aromas of spice, clove, pepper and banana. Taste is spice forward with a little sweetness. Creamy mouthfeel and average carbonation. Nice and refreshing.

Draft at the Brewery. Orange blond colour, small off-white head. Aroma is wheat, bananas, bit of white pepper and some creamy sweetness. Taste is not as full-on as some weizens, but still has banana sweetness, more creaminess than in the aroma, just a touch of bitterness, and bready malt. Small prickle in mouth. Very nice solid weizen.

Draught at the Brewery. Deep darkish gold, cloudy, with orange tints and lots of bubbles. Aroma of crackers, cookies, banana and citrus, cloves. Relatively fruity, with good citrus. Sweet and creamy, with lots of banana and wheat malt and a good sour tang. Too much carbonation, though--prickly, actually. Also way too cold. Nice taste overall, with good balance, but too gassy.

Hazy golden color. Fragerant banana bubblegum nose. Clovey, banana loaded mouth. Surprisingly full-bodied for 4.0% ABV. Like Kamiya’s other beers, above average, but not that will blow me out of the water.

column1: La Barberie Rousse Forte au Miel
column5: on tap at brewpub. slightly hazy dark golden, red tint, with a small off-white head, some retention. candied malts, brown sugar, honey, booze, dried apricots. candy. decent grassy finish. lightly acidic. unbalanced. average carbonation, light body - boozy, decent finish.

column1: La Barberie Rousse Forte au Miel
column5: Lightly hazed reddish amber ale with a thin off white head. A sweet souirish aroma showing beginning of infection, phenolic. In mouth, a big sweet malt with some nutty notes, but very harsh and astringent, with loads of tannins. This one went in the bushes. On tap at brewery, Oct. 8, 2006.

Kennett 06. Pours a cloudy golden body with a fluffy almost pure white head and some nice lacing. Spicy peppery yeast aromas- which seem like they are becoming a trend in thier beers- almsot like a house belgian character- slightly citrus with a bit of lemon essence. Hay, grain and spice in the flavor, light pils malts, some other spicy notes like cinnamon, and some other yeasty phenols like clove. Pretty good and smooth mouthfeel. Nice overall belgian ale.

Draught samples at Kennett Fest on 10/7/06 Lovely, soft, hay-yellow body shows medium-low clarity and boasts an immaculate white head, dense and creamy with very high retention, modest lacing. Reminds me almost exactly of Unibroue 10’s appearance, though more hazy than that one. Lemongrass, saffron, coriander, white pepper and very modest ginger are all things that come to mind, not sure which one(s) of those are actually in there. But it’s done with delightful moderation, allowing very dry honey and baked white biscuits to emerge, providing a strong balance to the spices. Dry, creamy wheat seems apparent, giving that smooth, nutty, almost vanilla-like note. Yeast apparency is not heavy, but it is noticeably Belgian, contributing light pears, peaches and a hint of clove. No alcohol noted in the aroma and a medium strength to it overall. Spicy flower petals, muted ginger and fresh, somewhat acidic herbal notes dot the palate, upon the first sip. Light baguette-like malt notes creep in slowly, but are kept minimized by a brisk carbonation. Snappy finish shows light fruit esters (more peach/nectarine and some light apple) and plenty of coriander and white pepper-like dryness. Great level of attenuation, possibly even too dry for my tastes, so that’s saying a lot. Honey atop biscuits is about the extent of the malt. Just a dry, sort of grainy/biscuity flavor and texture with moderate touches of sweetness. Spices linger on, but the usual spice astringency in beers like this does not seem to build up. No alcohol apparent. Very clean and refreshing. No wateriness or alcohol noted. VERY drinkable for its size. Toning down the carbonation a touch and maybe even stepping back on the spices, while getting a little more succulent honey notes from pils malt would be my reccomendations.
Wonderful mix of friuty and piney spiciness. A bit of an alcohol kick, but normal for the type. Fruity upfront, tasty all the way.

KSBF 2006. Pours a hazy golden amber with a large foamy off white head. Aroma of Belgian spices, yeast, pilsner malt, bready and some "holiday" spices. Flavor was spicy, cinnamon, bready and more of the holiday spices along with some citrus and pine from the hops.

On tap at KSBF ’06... Appears a hazy gold with a small off-white head that slowly fades away. Spots of lacing are left around the glass. The smell is of cinnamon, coriander, saffron, cardamom, and a spicy apple and citrus aroma that feeds off the doughy, Belgian yeast. Taste is of the given aromas with a nod to the Belgian yeast, which sets the style up for being a spiced Belgian Ale. Mouthfeel is smooth with gentle spicing flicking the tongue during the swallow.
On tap at the KSBF ’06. Poured a deeper orange / amber color with large sized off white head. Fruity aroma (apples) with spices and some citrus. Tastes of spices, fruity and citric.

Kennett 06. Pours a hazy bright orange with a thin diminishing head. Straigh up sharp and hot bourbon aroma and sweet sticky caramel malts- pretty hot though. Sweet sharp malt flavor with lgith vanilla and solventy esters, somewhat fruity and dominated again by a hot bourbon burn in the end. Citrusy hops in the flavor as well and the bitterness competes with the alcohol burn. Too much bourbon.

Flat pour, roused up a small offwhite head that faded quickly. Fairly hazy amber hued brew. Nose of whisky and wood, faint citrus notes if huffed hard. Thin bodied, flat, sorta watery. Thin oak and whisky flavors, grainy malts, hops? A hint malty. Finish is dry, thin and fast.

KSBF 2006. Pours a lightly hazy brownish amber with a small bubbly off white head. Aroma of light bourbon, hops some caramel malts. Flavor of caramel, vanilla, light bourbon and more of the hops. Very toned down compared to the regular version. Not sure I liked what the bourbon aging did to this one.

On tap at KSBF ’06... Appears a hazy brown, caramelized, cola color with a small, soapy, off-white head that slowly fades out. Little spots of lacing are left around the glass. Smell is of bourbon, oak, vanilla, caramel, and subdued hops. Taste is of the aromas with a bit of a bitey harshness that’s either from the oak tannins, or the residual hoppiness that is trying to crawl through the bourbon oak aging. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, sweet, bitter, with oaky wood lingering in the swallow. Overall, not a bad experiment.

On tap at the KSBF ’06 [Cask]. Poured a deep amber color with small sized off white head. Aromas of wood, vanilla, light bourbon and a trace of citrus. Tastes of stronger bourbon, wood, and citrus. The bourbon tastes were too strong and overpowered the other tastes. I’m usually a fan of BA beers, but the bourbon tastes (and I like bourbon) really didn’t add anything - actually took away from the hoppiness I liked in the regular Hedonism.
Draught: Poured a orange brown with an off white creamy head. The aroma is sweet honey. The taste follows that up with a nice sweet malt and honey. Very interesting beer on a hot weekend.
on tap at berlinerbierfest06. amber with a lingering head. aroma of honeycake and hay, a little on the sticky side but not quite unpleasant

Draught. Cloudy red/bown colour. Nice, creamy, stable light brown head. Quite sweet, very sweet flavour. Also malty and a bit roasted. The sweetness seems to come from malt sugars rather than the honey. OK, but I could not drink much of this.

This is for the 2004 batch. He makes this is a similar context to OSA. Dark amber color, nutmeg, cloves, cardamon and cinammon in the nose. Full mouth, creamy. Reminds me of apple pie. Smooth sweet malty finish with a caramel, nutmeg and cinnamon after taste. Drank in August 06. Aged very nice.

column1: Flying Dog Extra Special Heller Hound
column5: 750 ml corked and caged bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a lingering ring of tan bubbles. Aromas of cherries, barnyard, oak, plum and raisins. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry tart finish. Flavors of cherry, grape, oak, barnyard and light carmel with a crisp dry tart lingering fruity finish.

column1: Flying Dog Extra Special Heller Hound
column5: 750 bomber - thanks to Ratman for this. Pours a clear wine-reddish color with very little head or lacing into a New Belgium globe. Aromas of zinfandel and oak, with hints of cherries and zest. Flavor was more tart than expected for a Heller bock, with a sweet,funky palate and a sour cherry fruitiness.. Finished with a tart, vinous note. Quite the crackerjacks box.

column1: Flying Dog Extra Special Heller Hound
column5: Bottle shared with Doodler and Ratman. Awesome choice Don! Cloudy dark red brown appearance with no head. Tart, red fruity, Bretty, vinous nose. Tart, acidic, Bretty, horseblanket, red fruity flavor. Tart, red fruity, sour, oaky, Bretty aftertaste. Nice beer but shows no characteristics of a Heller Bock. I probably rate this higher for a sour ale style.

column1: Flying Dog Extra Special Heller Hound
column5: Pours copper with a thin tan head. Smells of caramel, fruity, some floreal hints. Tastes oaky and dry with a lot of sweetness. Barrel aging did not do this beer justice.

column1: Flying Dog Extra Special Heller Hound
column5: Bottle shared by MIBRomeo on 12/16/06: Pours a hazy copper mahogany with a thin ring of tan bubbles. Aroma of sweet caramel malt, light oak, and tart fruity cherries. Body has a nice balance of sweet caramel malt and tart fruity notes. An interesting and enjoyable brew.

column1: Flying Dog Extra Special Heller Hound
column5: Bottle. Pours a hazy copper with a ring of white foam. Malty lemon aroma with some brett. Medium body and carbonation. The taste has some wood, tea, nuts, apricot. I pick up a bit of oak in the finish.

column1: Flying Dog Extra Special Heller Hound
column5: Hazed dark copper color with only a few bubbles adrift atop. Light oak and pale malts filter through the nose. Hint of sourdough in the backdrop along with some mild fruits. Smooth and full in feel. Flavors of Door County cherries, with a linger of sourmash. I like it.

column1: Flying Dog Extra Special Heller Hound
column5: 750ml thanks to MIBRomeo and "Magic Fridge 2006". Hazed vitamin B12 goodness having the sediment end of this rare treat. Much lighter brett character when compared to the Extra Special Gonzo. I’m not getting much of the heller bock aspect at all as the brett is still stealing the show. Light malts evident, 2-row coming through just barely. A little hint of oak and smoked character to round out the palate, but the wild yeast is definately the show in this one although not as well done as with its brother.

column1: Flying Dog Extra Special Heller Hound
column5: Bottled at the Magic Porch... thanks to MIBRomeo for scoring this brew! Poured a lightly hazy reddish/iced tea brown with only a few loose bubbles around the edges. Nose was of tart cherry and dust funkiness with underlying smoky caramel, toffee, and a hint of lemon... odd concept for a beer, but worked very well. Flavor was heavily laced with funky brett fruitiness.. really liked how it complimented the sweet toffee and smoked wood beneath. Sour on the palate with a light and somewhat grainy body.. felt good. This was a very unique beer that I am glad to have tried! Thanks Chuck!

column1: Flying Dog Extra Special Heller Hound
column5: Hazed and caramel-amber in color with only a few dust speckles on the surface. Pencil erasures, almond shell shavings, muskrit, cumin and maple sourdough take the nose for a ride. Apple candied toffee, sandalwood and dried cider vinegar discourage the tastebuds early on. Sweet granny smith apples are ripe from the picking, imparting a near citric-shine on the brittle bark. Brown sugar gets liquefied with some tart, accentuated oxidation. Barely a body, and no carbonation, leaving no room for the soured caramel and golden raisins to hide. Dry, waxy tongue and apple butter jam the exits. Thanks for sharing, Chuck!
on tap at the legends bar in downtown hanoi. hazy yellow with a shortlived fluffy head; some bubblegam and banana ice cream in the aroma; soft and lightly tangy wheat syrup, faint straw; not too bad
A German-style ‘witbier’ is the pick of the Legend bunch. Smooth and fruity, quite strong but lots of flavour punch.

Draught at Legends, HoanKiem location. Cloudy golden, creamy head. Fruity phenolic nose. Rather sweet and light bodied. Wheat malt and phenols are evident, esters are nor. A bit mushy but still refreshing. A reasonable weizen, and the only one I could find in Hanoi.

Draught at Legends Beer restaurant. My general thinking that pretty much any wheat beer will usually be at least ok appears to hold up even in Vietnam. Pours a darkish orange with a nice looking foamy head that disappears quickly. Tastes of orange peel and wheat. Flavour is fairly rich and satisfying, but does suffer a tad from a slightly garbagey finish.
Sweet malty toffee, caramel, butterscoth nose. Very rich. Malty mouth with lots of butterscotch flavors, but not as full bodied as I would like and a disappointly dry finish.

5% can in Takayama. Lovely looking amber-bronze with a light beige finger of foam. Very nutty aroma, caramel and raspberry. Toasted grain malt flavour, nut and berry flourishes. Sherbet-type fizziness with a bit of chew to the body and plenty of bitterness to finish. A bit underrated on here, I thought this was a great English ale.
Tap @ Beer House Craft Man, Kyoto. Pours hazy dark orange with an off white head. Aromas and flavours of malt, caramel and fruit. Smooth texture. Okey.
Bottle 50cl / Botella 50cl. @ Iketabakeshouten, Takayama, Japon. A: Hazy amber / Ambar turbio. T/S: Malt, caramel, slightly bitter / Malta, caramelo, ligeramente amargo.

Half in Good Beer Faucets, Shibuya. For a dark ale it’s surprisingly clear light and reddish coloured with a medium white foam head. Nose is touch fruity ale-ish. Taste is fruity like an ale but with a bit of raspberry and strawberry sweetness. Crisp and with a dryish lager like hop bite.
Draft (at Bagpipe Cafe in Takayama). A chestnut brown with a large frothy head. A fruity, caramel nose. Quite a light palate, but toffee and orange softly mingle in the mouth.
Bottle. Light fruity nose Amber, lowish head Chewy fruitybread, light roast and honey, ok bitterness to balance. ok drink.

Bottle (500ml) at Sosuke Ryokan, Takayama – shared with Mette. Cloudy chestnut – white head. Almost no aroma. Taste: Nutty, roasted, caramel, nice hoppy, fruity, light dried fruits, smooth body, light sweet pleasant finish.

Bottle from Yamaoka in Kyoto. This beer is 5%, and so really is not so much an English Strong Ale as an English brown ale, I would say. Rich dark malt aroma, with caramel, nuts, grains, and detactable but light hops. Medium reddish/amber color, a bit too light for the name “dark ale," but attractive nonetheless. Very thin head that went straight to lace. Rich, malt-centered flavor, nutty, with lots of cereal malts, caramel, a touch of chocolate, and a slightly roasted flavor. Quite complex. A bit of dark fruit, with a slight citrus touch. Lightly hops, but they come in near the end to provide a rather bitter finish. Well balanced and tasty. Good stuff.
Bottle. Clear amber with a small head. Caramel aroma. Well-balanced caramel flavours and hoppy flavours, as well as some toffee. Decent, but not overexciting.

Biggish light beige creamy lasting head. Amber body. Watery, mealy aroma with notes of fruit, spice, and roastiness. Fruity wooden taste with notes of strawberry and spice. Carbonation in the mouth. Dry, musty fruit aftertaste. Not at all bad. (0.32l on draft.)

Had this on tap first and it totally blew. Then at this year’s Yokohama Ocktoberfest, it was cask conditioned and dry hopped. Night and day. This is only for cask beer. Dark brown color, chocolate brownie nose. Light bodied, sweet chocolatey mouth, moderately strong bitter finish.

column1: Fujizakura Heights Mori no Weizen Octoberfest
column5: Draught at Popeye, Tokyo - as Smoke Weizen. Cloudy amber - white head. Banana, fruity, smokey, wheaty, flowery, light bitterness, yeasty, sulfor, white sugar. Not my style.

column1: Fujizakura Heights Mori no Weizen Octoberfest
column5: Appearance: Hazy medium brown. Aroma: Coriander, banana, restrained smoke Flavor: Coriander, firm, medium-bodied malt, banana, Palate: Creamy Comment: On tap. Hoppier than the German Weizen beers. I liked the increased bittering-- well balanced. One of my favorites of the evening.

column1: Fujizakura Heights Mori no Weizen Octoberfest
column5: Lovely weizen with a nint of smoke. This was really moreish. Lots of fruity essences working their way to the top

column1: Fujizakura Heights Mori no Weizen Octoberfest
column5: 2009 Version on tap at Q-Brick. Excellent. Perfect balance, light but flavorful smoking, rich,, sweet, and cakey yet never cloying. Perfectly rich, smooth mouth. Best Japanese wheat beer to date? 2008 "Mori no Weizen" Oktoberfest, a weizen rauch. Bottle from Yamaoka in Kyoto. 8/4/8/4/16. Very cloudy medium brown color with orange—almost a dunkel. Enormous, frothy head that lasts forever. Aroma of wheat malt, bananas, spices, smoke. Rich, somewhat sweet but balanced by the lightish smoke. Nose is subtle but very appealing. Light smoke in the flavor balances the wheat malt very well. The wheat, banana, and spice still come through rich and strong, but less sweet and cakelike than their regular weizen. Very well balanced, with the smoke lasting through to the finish and longer. Very nicely done.

column1: Fujizakura Heights Mori no Weizen Octoberfest
column5: Sampled @ GJBF Yokohama: Cloudy ebony color with a nice off-white head. Nose of smoke, chalk, meat, light hop, subtle yeast, fruit. Good and smoky flavor.

column1: Fujizakura Heights Mori no Weizen Octoberfest
column5: @ GJBF 2007. Aroma has some sweet malts, soft banana notes, fruit, and smoke. flavor is like smoked steak, with fruits underneath and a malty backbone. Finishes with a little bitterness. Light, refreshing body. A different wheat to say the least. Enjoyable.

column1: Fujizakura Heights Mori no Weizen Octoberfest
column5: A smoked wheat. Deep hazy amber color, cloves, bananas and smoke in the nose. Smoke is very light. Body is not balanced and leans more to a hefe, with just the faintest hints of smoke. Nice smokey finish. Rerate- more balanced than before.

Bottle 33 cl. %% ABV according to the label. Pours a hazy golden with a small, white head. Very Hefeweizen yeasty, but without the clove. Medium body, malty sweet, again with the yeast as the driving force before some late bittering hops. Very "wheaty" but also quite different from a German Hefe. 030419
Bottle from systembolaget. Pours a golden colour beer with a medium head. Fruity and yeasty with notes of banana and herbs. Dry finish.
Plain yellow, plain wheat flavor a little flat. Small white ring head. Fizzles out quickly
Bottle. Cloudy, golden, frothy, white foam, medium bitterness, light sweetness, medium body, oily feel, average carbonation, & bitter finish.

On tap at Naka-Meguro taproom. Served in a weizen glass. Hazy gold in color with soapy white head. Clove, coriander, wheat and yeast all present on the nose with a slight fruit undertone. Taste is more of the same with some fruit coming out: papaya, pineapple and a slight pear. Medium body. Dry finish. Refreshing.

0,33L bottle (as Wheat King Wit from Koht, Tallinn), BB 07.05.15. Pours slightly hazy yellow with small white head. The head doesn’t stay. Aroma is weak, wheat, spices, fruits. Flavor is sweet, acidic, fruity, metallic, some spices, and citrus. Overall: not very good, but not drain-pour.

Tap at Craft, Bangkok. Poured a hazy light amber with a frothy white head. The aroma is yeast, zesty citrus. The flavour is acid citrus with an earthy mineral yeast light toothpaste bitter palate. Medium bodied with average carbonation. I’m not a huge fan of the style but this was a good, easy drinking example.

330ml bottle (thanks FatPhil). Clear golden color. Tiny size, white head, stays. Very faint coriander, sourish, malty, armpits in aroma. Somewhat spicy, straw, slightly starchy taste. Soft carbonation. Papery aftertaste.
Liquid is clear pale yellow, head is minimal white foam, tastes lightly sour.

330ml bottle (Pothouse, Tallinn) Clear, the beer smells of butter popcorn, a little bit sour. A tiny splash of the crud covered only part of that horror. Rough and harsh in the mouth. Shivers down the spine. Ug, I guess it’s spicy clovey wheat, but it’s nasty. Do not want.

Another Central-Vietnamese beer this time served on tap. This particular offering is brewed with malt instead of rice. What I would term as being a ‘light’ beer with a rather grainy element but a rather sharp, sour, synthetic, citrus flavoured after taste. Slightly oily texture when swallowing. Not as bad as some of the cheaper Vietnamese beers, but certainly not on the same par as Huda.
A locally produced beer, with light color, light body, not much foam, soft carbonation, served in bottle.

Bottle via Bill. The beer pours to a dark brown body with ruby highlights. A nice light brown/tan head sits on top with spotty lacing. The aroma is lightly charred malt and smoke. Reminds me of a Scotch or Scottish ale. Chocolate. The flavor is smoky chocolate and also Scottish like. The palate is sweet, moderately bodied, and nicely textured.

Dark opaque pour w/ a nice tan head and some decent lacing. Light chocolaty and smoky aroma almost like the chocolate gingerbread girl scout cookie dunked in coffee I had this morning. Palate is a bit thin. Flavor is fairly smoky a bit of camp fire some dry roast chocolates and coffees. not really impressive.. has a dry almost off hoped finish.

Dark reddish brown body, normal-looking light tan head. Lightly smoked sweet malt aroma. Not overly sweet, but it is more of a generic sweetness. Peppery chipotle-like smoke on a roasty (maybe that’s the chipotle) malt body. Smokey chocolate towards the finish. Okay, well-rounded beer.

Bottle shared by Blake. Black body under a small tan head. Charred licorice and chicken aroma. Dry, smoky chocolate at first with a sweet pale malt and berry base underneath. Great lasting chocolate finish with a light and enjoyable char. A very solid porter with a good smoke element.

On tap at the brewpub. Light nutty smoky aroma. Caramel and a bit of Tootsie Roll. Mild fruity hops with a nice sweet hint of chocolate and cafe creme. Dark black brown clear with a thin creamy off-white head. Medium-heavy watery body with medium carbonation. Starts sweet with caramel and sugary sweetness. Big smoky taste from start to finish. Chocolate and a bit of fizziness leads to a carbonic tang. A bit watery but finishes with a nice nutty bitterness and a dry roasted grainy after. A bit sweeter than other porters, but the smokiness helps smooth it out to a drier finish that is fairly clean.

Draft@KSBF:06 Near flat pour. a virtually black porter. Nose of chocolate and light roast, smoke? Light/medium body with a light creaminess. Chocolate flavor up front, bittersweet, cocoa and roast. Ever so slight hint of smoke creeps in the mix but very faint. Finish is almost dry, roasty. Smoke,m if ya got,em??

On tap at KSBF ’06... Appears black with brown edges and a small, light beige head that slowly fades out. Spots of lacing are left behind. Smell is chocolatey, with malt balls, roasty grain, creamy with just a touch of smoke. Taste is of the mentioned aromas with a chocolate malt presence that tastes enjoyable but not quite as enticing as the aromas. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, with hints of the roasty, baker’s chocolate coming through in the form of bitterness. The finish was slightly thin but not terrible considering the amount of bitters that are trying to engulf this beer. The smoke was just an afterthought but it wasn’t bad with all things aside.
KSBF 2006. Pours a dark brown with a bubbly tan head. Aroma of chocolate, light coffee and hints of smoke. Flavor of light smoke, chocolate, light coffee and light hops.

On tap at the KSBF ’06. Poured a dark brown with a small sized off white head. Aromas of chocolate, roast and light smoke. Tastes of chocolate, roast, light coffee and light smoke. The smoke part of this beer was very light and in the background - it was definitely more roasty and chocolaty. Thinner body. I liked this as a porter but found it weak for a smoked beer.
Blik uit shop op Phu Quick eiland. Smaak is eigenlijk niet eens zo slecht. Licht bitter hoppig met een licht zoetige ondertoon. Redelijk bier.

Poured from a 330 ml can. Aroma is malt forward with grain, white bread and hints of adjuncts. Faint hop notes and esters with no phenolics. Pours a very clear, pale, yellow gold with a medium large, pillowy,white head that exhibits decent retention as it recedes to a thin film that lingers for a bit. Light lacing and no legs. Flavor is slightly sweet with light grain notes and hints of adjuncts. Light floral esters and hop notes with faint grassy note. Low bitterness and no phenolics. Mouthfeel is light bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. Overall, this is a very bland beer. Malt profile is very light and everything else is even lighter. Not really any character.
Cans on phu quoc island aroma is straw & grain taste is dry bitter a bit malty, average but refreshing as it’s real hot here

Aroma: intense grain, some bread malt. Appearance: light yellow, small, white, frothy head. Taste: light bitter. Palate: grain, bread malts, lively carbonation, short finish. Overall: boring Pale Lager, actually worse than most other Vietnamese industrial brews. Can from a random corner shop, Phu Quoc.

I drank this one on my vacation in Hoi An. To keep it simple - it was disgusting. The beer’s color was a very bright yellow - it looks like apple juice mixed with very poor carbonated water. And it tasted nearly the same. The grain, the hops, the malt - everything was close to be tasteless. The only good thing about this is that the aftertaste won’t last too long. Bottle 450ml
bottle, in hoi an. very pale shade of yellow with a disinterested head; aroma of raw grain and industrial cleaning products; no bitterness or flavour whatsoever
Not a good Vietnamese, they kind of know how to make Pales and this one is a little bit disappointing...
Bottle in Nha Trang, Vietnam. Very typical asian lager. Pale golden color with white head that dissipates. However, nice lacing on the glass. Straw/grassy, not much else. Nothing exciting.

Hoi An area of Southern Vietnam is an area that lacks decent beers. Bivina is an alternative to Beer Saigon, a poor alternative. The pale colour gives an indication that the alcohol content is weak, the taste is poor by International standards. At least they have ISO 9001 Quality Standards, to ensure every bottle is equally bad no doubt.
Bottle (450 ml) in Hoi An. Clear yellow - white head. Fresh, light hoppy, straw, light light malty, corn, light grains, eggs.... you know the rest.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a hazy pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy citrs aroma. Fruity wheat malty spicy flavor with hints of citrus. Has a sweetish fruity wheat malty spicy finish.
On tap at the brewpub, pours a nice head with a light flavour, good body. bit weak but overall good offering.

tap @ Flakhaven, Odense. muddy yellow-grey. Lovely, staying, creamy, white head. Aroma is sweet, light citrus, mild doughy and wheaty with lots of butter. High carbonation, grainy and light thin palate. Flavour startd buttery, vanilla, banana, nutmeg. Very sweet. Lingering vanilla sweetness. Not good.
On tap at the brewery. Poured hazy light yellow with little head. Very sweet and can taste the spices. Very smooth.

[1766-20081004] Tap. Spiced fruity pumpkin yeast aroma. Slightly hazy, light brown orange body with a medium-lasting creamy white head. Nutmeg and pumpkin pie crust flavour has some sweet sugary coating. Medium body. Nice pumpkin throughout.
(@ Pepperwood; Burlington, ON)

2008-10-04. Lightly hazy orange body with a small off-white head. Modest aroma, light spice - nutmeg, cinnamon? Flavour is mild with prominent spice up front - nutmeg and cinnamon again - Light bitterness in the finish, touch of pumpkin is mild really. Pretty solid, rather nice as is but I would like a little more oomph all around for my tastes a la ST Pumking. On tap at the brewpub

Slightly spicy, caramelly, pumpkiny aroma. Cloudy amber colour is slightly orangey. Big, fleshy pumpkin, caramel taste with lots of hoppy dryness. Perhaps a touch of lacquer-like phenol in the finish, which is troubling. Sorry Paul - my trip to Pepperwood was a spur of the moment thing!

Hazy orange, a roasted pumpkin/yam color with thick white head. Phenols and some rotting vegetables unfortunately mar the aromas. Good carbonation level. The flavors are garbled and vegetal with no pumpkin pie spices. Seems to be well-hopped and good but sadly suffers from some problems.

Pint at Pepperwoods Oct 9/06 with S.B. Pours a nice orange colour with very little head to be seen, somewhat disappointing. The nose is of pumpkins, cloves, cinammon, and malt. Taste consisting of much the same, a very complex beer. Palate is of malt and cloves. This is like mixing grandma’s pumpkin pie with beer.. Very interesting and delicious.
Surprising selection for a small brew-pub, this was nice. It poured a clear red/maroon color, with sour cherry, malt, and spice in the aroma and flavor. Nicely balanced: quite good.
Cask at the Watford Beer Festival 2016. Clear mid golden. Aroma of dried fruit, pear drops and pale malt. Good bitter sweet flavour mix.

September 19, 2018 - at The Earl of Essex - on handpull cask. Deep clear and refractive deep gold with a decent off-white head. Catty and dry aroma, light alcohol with a bit of tart fruit (8-). Taste follows - light but catty, hint of green pepper and mid-level alpha acidity, masks the alcohol quite well. Slick, still, average body, medium-long catty tingly dry non-coating finish, nice dry pungency in the aftertaste - very good.

Handpull cask at the Salmon, Leicester. Golden and cleat with a small uneven white head. Pear drops, apple juice, resin in the aroma. Sweet juicy taste with a biscuity sweet note giving a gentle balance. A simple little pale ale but a joy to drink.

Sample@GBBF2018, London, with the the Malmö crew - pours golden with a white head. Sweet pale bready malty, light doughy yeast, with some citrus fruity notes, hay, straw, medium to light body, fruity and grassy hoppy finish.

Cask at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon in Oct 2018 during Spoons Fest - Clear orangey gold in colour. Good foamy white head. Good lacing. Citrus fruity aroma. Fruity; citrus fruity, lemon, grapefruit. Hoppy; moderate hop bitterness, grassy hops. Malty; bready malts, grainy. Quite dry. Moderately bitter citrus fruity hoppy throughout. Nice citrusy bitterness. Decent. (2018-10)

18/10/2018. Cask at the Roebuck Inn, Nottingham. Pours dark gold with a lasting creamy off-white head. Aroma of hops, grass, citrus, flowers and grapefruit. Moderate sweetness with medium bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation.
Cask @ Roebuck Inn, Nottingham. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and moderate hoppy - citrus. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 181018
Cask @ Roebuck Inn, Nottingham. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are fruits, malt, hops and has a nice bitter finish.

Cask at The Strand. Clear golden amber, thin offwhite head. Aroma is really fruity, grapefruit, citrus, sweet. Taste is grapefruity, malts, light sweetness, moderate bitterness. Medium bodied, almost flat carbonation.

(Cask at Akkurat, Stockholm, 1 June 2018) Golden amber colour with frothy, white head. Fruity nose with citrus, apricots and mango. Malty, fruity taste with notes of apricots, peaches, soft malt, citrus and a balanced citric/grassy bitterness. Medium body, with a slight sweetness. Fresh and tasty. Nice one.

330ml bottle. Golden orange in colour, clear with moderate carbonation. Flat and thin looking with no head. Aroma has a hint of sweetness mixed with herbal undertone. Sudsy and soapy but lively enough in the mouth.
Sweet floral hop malt aroma. Clear amber colour with fair head and lacing. Malt hoppy flavour with fruit and flowers. Fizzy palate.

A pleasant suprise. Wasn’t expecting much with the dodgy labelling but inside was a well made well balanced beer. Again alot of citrus and floral aromas. A good Newcastle alternative to the less good Blue Tongue.

Golden yellow with lots of medium sized bubbles buzzing around. A fruit salad aroma that provided a different bouquet to your usual pale lager. The flavour was mostly balanced, but with some unfortunate metallic bitterness creeping in at the finish. The thin body was a little weak to contain the alcohol, which is a surprise given that it is only 4.4%. Worth a re-rate from the bottle, but I won’t be rushing out for it.

Conditions often play a big part in the raing of a beer even though they shouldn’t. I had this last Saturday when the mercury was neaqrly tipping the old cenntury fahrenheit mark. It has all the hallmarks of your typical pale lager in that it is fairly unexiting, but one can’t fault the quality. Standard lager look but no adjuncty cereal nose to speak of. Clean, reasonably balanced and refreshing, mind you that wasn’t hard given the conditions on the day.

This new brewery in Newcastle, NSW, has made the unusual move of launching with two lagers. This, the second of the two, is pitched as an everyday quencher in the hope of wooing a few macro drinkers away from the likes of VB and Tooheys New. A bottled version is creeping into Sydney bottlos (the Australian Hotel in The Rocks had it in October). The draught version sampled at the recent Australian Hotel beer festival and rated here was fresh and really rather good. No fireworks but it seemed a nice, fruity lager - very clean and without obvious flaws. Standard lager appearance with a skinny corona. Light and fruity aroma - canned pineapple, lychee and dustry hops. Very promising. Standard palate, quite soft. Good malt flavours, perhaps a bit papery, with some lime notes. Sourish quenching finish with some lingering bitterness. A very fair everyday drinker.

column1: Barley Brothers Leather Face Pale Ale
column2: Lake Havasu City, Arizona, United States
column5: Draft... GABF ’06... Lightly hazy yellow ale with a small, wispy, white head. Excellent retention. Woodsy, earthy nose with spicy hops; notes of leather, grapefruit and pine. Medium bitter, citrusy, lemon rind flavor. Medium-bodied with a coarse mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Finishes astringent and dry.

Tasted 04/10/2006. 330ml bottle from the brewery - 4.6%. Mid gold with a disappearing off-white head and gentle carbonation. Aged red apples and a gentle hint of lime on the nose. Off-dry in the mouth with a pith lime note and short roasty wood finish. Nicely carbonated but quite watery. Drinkable in the Queensland head but severly short on flavour.

500ml bottle [Special thanks to Grumbo for filling the last English county gap]. Minimally cloudy, yellow-ish golden colour with average to huge, frothy, slowly osteoporosing, minimally lacing, white head. Floral, grassy, minimally fruity, hoppy and minimally strawy and biscuity, pale malty aroma, a touch of rhubarb and gooseberry. Taste is minimally sweet pale malty, crisp fruity hoppy, minimally citrusy, hints of gooseberry, rhubarb, a touch of lemon peel. Nice.

Bottle from Sidmouth Wines, Sidmouth. Golden-amber with an extremely thin head. Quite fizzy and active in the palate, it’s a fruity ale in the main, with some toffee also available in its nose. It’s perhaps a little thin in its taste, but crisp, with a light easy-supping nature.v
Bottle Conditioned. Pours a orange colour with no head and not much carbonation, weak fruit aroma, the taste is sweet and a bit watery with a dry bitter finish.
Bottled 0.5l ; Devon ; UK ; Almost no aroma ; Cloudy gold color with no head ; Weird taste ; Very poor, will try some other time.

Bottle at home ... golden yellow amber ... big white head ... soft bitter peppery floral hop ... too fizzy ... way too fizzy ... light floral orange bitter ... mellow slight toffee .. hint of bananana back bone ... soft light and easy,

March 2010: This bottled conditioned 500ml of beer was consummed 3 months before its BBD. Poured into a vase shaped pint glass. A haze took the shine of this pale amber/orange coloured ale, on top sat a pure white head, deep initially, losing depth at a steady rate. Not sure if I poured in any sediment, or the beer is supposed to have a haze? Hops provided the most smell coming from the glass, flowery, grassy and with a hint of citrus fruits. The taste more or less followed the smells, with an extra tangy feel, an almost ginger style hotness too. The alcohol at only 3.8% ABV doesn’t sound interesting to some BA’s, but this is a well produced, balanced British Bitter and well worth trying.

Pale in colour with a slight haze after pouring. Aromas slightly fruity - pears, yeast and hay along with the usual malt and citrussy hops. In taste this was reasonably bitter but a bit thin on flavour and lacking in body. A nice enough thirst quencher though.

No noise once the cap comes off and it appears still in the glass. A radiant light orange in colour, almost bright and headless bar a ring of white on the meniscus. Nose is predominately lemon peel, bitter orange and white Semillon grapes with just a touch of yeast and pine nuts. In the mouth it is quite weedy, lots of pine, nettles and gritty, dusty grain, straw and toothpick. Very dry. Long, long dry, gritty pine wood and dried bitter herbs swallow. Drew out and absorbed all the saliva in my mouth. Light body, very light, and almost still in feel with just a tease of carbonation up front. Lacks balance and is a bit messy flavour wise. Drinkable but not sessionable as it left me parched! (50cL, BBE 08/12, Greendale Farm Shop, Woodbury Common, Exeter, Devon)

50cl bottle from Moor & More Beer, Plymouth. Slightly hazy amber with a ring of translucent head; citrus and honey aroma; pleasant light citrus taste to strart, then watery; the finish has some grapefruit and gentle bitterness but is very thin.

Cask, gravity at Luton BF ’10. Pale gold with a small white head. Curious burnt match aroma, maybe with a hint of vinegar. Or tomato ketchup. Or popcorn. Taste was rather nasty, suggestive of corn or rice. Or Snickers bar. Slight bitterness. Didn’t work, I regret to say.

Had this excellent local Scottish ale at the Troon Beer Festival October 2006. Cask, handpump dispense. Dark copper red in colour with a tight white creamy head. Floral hop aroma with a good silky mouthfeel. Complex dark malts in taste giving a very fruity flavour of juicy summer berries and an unusual delicate bouquet of parma violet sweets! Refreshing fruit notes linger on with a slight dryness from the aromatic hop finish. A cracking summer session ale for those fed up with drinking Deuchars IPA cloned citrus types.

Cask at Smithfield Hotel, Manchester. A hazy amber beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma has strong notes of hops and grass as well as lighter notes of citrus. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, grass, and grapefruit, leading to a dry bitter finish. The body is light.
Cask gravity, The Angel, Atherstone. Thinly lidded straw with lace dabs, faint citrus and biscuity aroma. Watery lemon puff notes, wheat, card, disinfectant. A bit odd and watery, but OK.

Cask @ Smithfield Hotel, Manchester M4. Pours a clear copper color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy grapefruit aroma wth some hints of caramel. Fruity malty caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel finish with some hoppy grapefruit hints in the aftertaste.

Cask (gravity) @ Smithfield Hotel, 37 Swan St, Manchester, Greater Manchester England M4 5JZ. Clear medium amber orange color with a average, creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, moderate to light heavy hoppy, grapefruit, grass, orange shell. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20090122]
Cask 2nd South Shields Beer Fest. Hazy copper beer with a citrusy and fruity hop nose and a lightly fruity taste, a bit thin with a slight finish.

cask, troon beer fest. pours cloudy bronze copper ith a great white sudsy head. smells spicy, watermelon? tastes sweet but well balanced much nicer then pedens cove, more body n but more bready. sticky mouth feel. hop finish is apparent.
Cask at troon beer fest 07... Copper colour ... little sweet spirit ... soft light malts ... little sharp caramel malts. odd but not unpleasent somthing
Cask at troon beer fest 07. Aroma starts peachy, however goes onto grassy and citrus notes. Taste is again fruity down the poeachy citrus line, well balanced.

Cask Stillage from the cellar at the Hillsborough Hotel, Sheffield 16/12/2006 Hoppy aroma. Amber coloured with a slightly hazy appearance. Hoppy and fruity pear flavour. Bitter and slightly dry lasting finish.

Tasted 03/10/2006. 330ml bottle from the brewery. Mid-gold with a tentative off-white head. Light barley and wheat notes on the nose. Faint fruitiness. Very dry and watery in the mouth, slightly limey. Characterless in all departments.

column4: Beijing Five Star Tsingtao Brewing Co.
column5: Canned. Pale golden, clear, no head. No aroma. Very light bodied with thin but rounded mouthfeel. Possible there’s a very light hint of wheat malt. No bitterness. I’m glad that Carrefour in Beijing offered an English translation of the name on their shelves, as otherwise there’d been no way I’d been able to know that this was indeed a wheat beer.

Sampled this in the Saltcot, Saltcoats (JDW) in October 2006. Pale straw in colour with a slight touch of palest amber. Fragrant dry hopped aroma. Very thin mouthfeel and poor lacing. Typical Caley biscuit malt in the mouth but lacking in complexity and body. No fruit notes but hop resins give a dry hop bite in the aftertaste. Finish is dry with citric notes present. Overall poor considering the ABV, give this one a miss.

Cask (handump), Penderels Oak (JDW), Holborn, London, October 2006. Golden colour, with a lasting white head. Lively condition, but not too fizzy. Scant aroma, but it was a bit cold. Modest citric notes in the flavour but not a huge amount there really. Dry, clean finish. Nor unpleasant but I would expect a bit more depth from a 4.7% beer.

Clear golden body. Completely missing head. Light floral hoppy to the nose. Golden beer with mix of citrus and malts. Shades of butter, but otherwise alright with a vague bitterness in the ending. Right beer for an indian summer in late September (Half on gravity at The St Albans Beer Festival 27.09.2006).

cask at the Maltings, York: Aroma is of floral hops and pale malt. The beer came off the tap with a small white cask head and had a golden transulcent body. Nicely balanced taste, that was heavier on malt, but went more into floral hops in the finish. better than average bitter.
Pale golden colour with a small white head. Malty and caramel sweet aroma with a light hoppy note. Malty, sweet flavor with a vague hoppy finish.

1/2 pint cask, Kenilworth, Edinburgh. Pale golden colour with a somewhat coarse off-white head. Nice soft shortbread-like malt-aroma. Smooth malty flavour with some citrus fruity hops. Somewhat boring after a while.

Cask@The Market Porter, Borough, London. The name of this beer refers to Colin Montgomerie, the Scottish golfer and i’m guessing it was a special for the Ryder Cup golf. This was sweet and buttery (diacetyl!) and caramelly. Lots of butterscotch. I’m not sure if it was the condition at the pub or the beer is meant to taste like this.
Canned. Lightly hazy pale yellow, average head. Prune aroma. Sweet, fruity and light bodied with some paper. No bitterness. A fairly solid lager by Chinese standards.
March 2010. From bottle. Pale yellow color with a white head. Aromas of malt, yeast and hops. Crisp and clean with a refreshing finish.
From Albertsons in Clarkston, WA. Poured pale yellow with almost no head. Nose of grass. :Light body. Fizzy mouthfeel. Flavor is European Lager. Reminds me of Heineken.
Clear yellow with a white head. Hat aroma. Taste is sweet malts with some lights hops.

Hay, grass, mint, and skunk aroma, very green. Clear yellow, no head. Light malt, lemon prominent at midpalate but present throughout. Not real strong, but tasty. Good for what it is, better than Heineken.
A quirky one. It is almost pilsener-like. It is a surprisingly tasty EPL if you get it fresh and unskunked.
Clearly a Heineken rip-off, which shouldn’t be too hard to screw up, but this one really isn’t too good. Luckily you will drink it fast, without thinking about it too much.
12 oz. bottle- Pours golden with a better than expected head, decent lacing, aroma is a little skunky, but not bad. The flavor is what I expected, Heineken. Average, average, average.

12 oz bottle. Aroma is not like Heineken, which I was expecting. I was expecting a skunk beer and ended up with a decent smelling Euro lager. This is just the aroma, mind you. Appearnce is as a standard Euro lager--pale gold, little head, average lacing. Tastes like straw, cheap adjuncts; no skunk, surpsringly, given the green bottle. Better than I was expecting, but definitely not great.

Wow, this is a really interesting beer that flies under the radar. It is a spartan brew, and can best be described as cold, clean, and direct. Very smooth and very clean is the beginning. And the finish is the same-- remarkably smooth and clean. The middle is surprisingly complex and unexpected, given how the beer begins. Yes, this brew might be in the same category as Heineken, but it is much smoother and fresher and of higher quality than that middle of the road beer. Straight from the fridge, this beer is very satisfying and almost intriguing.

***review from June 21, 2008*** Another crap beer from the wonderful Beers Around the World mishap. Poured out a crystal clear medium hued solid gold brew, a small white cap, thin ropy lacing and retention just above a skim. The aromas was very dry and quite interesting somehow. Sort of sweet, a large grain content, plastic? and an odd underlying smell. The taste is less than appealing as it is very harsh and very watery with bad hops and a bit of metal. Comes across empty with a weak flavor similar to a light beer. Gassy and foamy too. Slight malt can be found in the aftertaste, which is unsavory. Why bother even finishing this?

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: Tap at the source. Pours mildly unfiltered but very very pale yellow. White head. Aroma is banana city, some clove, wheat, touch of lemon. One sided. Flavor is banana, lemon, wheat. Ehh. Underwhelming. Too much of a banana note.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: A: Hazy Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Mild Lacing S: Lemons, Banana, Wheat T: Banana, Lemons, Wheat, Mild Clove M: Average Carbonation, Light Bodied, Mildly Bitter Overall, a little too much citrus for a hefeweizen but decent drinking

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: Draft. Pours hazy yellow orange with a thin white head. Fruity and yeast, with banana, lemon, cloves, and light floral notes. Good stuff.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: on tap poured into a pint glass, not served with any fruit wedges (this is the way it should be). a: pale yellow/amber color, hazy, small silkey head with fair retention s: slight fruit (banana), yeast and wheat t: light banana, slight spice, light grassy hop m&d: thin watery mouth, smooth. Very drinkable in the summer heat.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: I’m not a big Hefeweizen drinker but this one is pretty good. The banana aftertaste is both barely noticable and somehow extremely pleasant. Give this a try for sure.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: In short: A watery lemonade with some rotting bananas. Yep, that good. How: Tap at brewpub The look: Cloudy pale yellow body topped by a very small white head In long: Nose has the basic lemon and banana notes that I expect from an entry-level brewpub hefe. It goes downward from here. The body is very watery. The wheat is elusive. This like a lemonade with rotting bananas in the after-taste. This is less than bland, this is a bit offensive. It irritates me a lot when I am served a shitty beer in a brewpub. Plus I never know how much I should tip a waiter I just threw my pint at.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Yellow though marketed as unfiltered. No head. A story in bannana. Not as a mastery of yeast, rather as a chick fruit drink with bannana syrup from a can thrown in. That’s how it tasted. Not so drinkable like that, but I can see patrons liking it so.Sticky aroma and mouthfeel.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: tap: thought this was a great hefeweizen. arouma is banana, trail mix (dried fruit, yogurt covered nuts, apricots) cloves, touch of cinnamon. Hazy yellow pour. smooth tasty with just a touch of bitter hops.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: Pint at the restaurant, the drink menu states that they use the Weihenstephan yeast strain so I was very excited. What I got was a beer that had the smell, but was not cloudy at all and had that "every other beer Otter makes" aftertaste. I didn’t really taste anything like a hefeweizen until the bottom quarter of the pint. Terribly disappointing, and someone needs to tell the brewmaster to sterilize those fermentation tanks between runs so the beers don’t all taste the same.

column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: (Old BA rate - tap0 Light yellowy-green color; half-finger of fizzy white head. Lightly yeasty; touch sour and acidic; pretty mild. Lightly tart, yeastiness; a little out of the style, but still some notes of banana and clove. Light and very prickly carbonation. Not bad drinking; light and refreshing enough if not a little bland. Overall, not the best example of the style, but not terrible.
Bottle courtesy of and shared with Kermis. Thin white head. Hazy golden pour. Light sweet and bitterness.

"Alt Reuther Zoigl", Flasche von Edeka, Kemnath. - Dunkles Goldbraun, trüb. - In der Nase blasses dunkles und karamelliges Malz, apfelige Frucht, kaum Herbe - nicht gerade vielversprechend. - Antrunk brausig rezent mit brotig-karamelliger Malzsüße, etwas Apfelschale und blasser orangenfruchtiger Hopfenherbe. Stark rezent, dünn. Im Abgang scharfe, dünne Bittere. Ranziger Nachtrunk. - Für ein Bier, das sich Zoigl nennt, erstaunlich schlecht, dünn und knapp gehopft. Und so was bekommt dann den "Preis der Besten in Gold"! (9.5.2019.)

Bottle. Pours clear copper with a white head. Aroma of grass, caramel, hay, harsh grains, hay, caramel, slight citrusy, light toasted malts. Taste is rather bitter, notes of bready malts - biscuits, sligt citrus, hay. Past is prime.

Draft at Zoiglwirtschaft d’Eisenbahn in Vohenstrauss: Hazed pumpkin with a golden shimmer. Broken and uneven collar of foam. Soft and mellow, but polished, aroma of orangey esters, toast, powdered chalky candy (Fun Dip), honeysuckle, yeast, and lemon. Slightly airy, as well. Excessive carbonic acid is prickly and seltzery. Initial sip shows nice balance between fruity and firmly malty, with delectable notes of deep toast and haylike pils malt. Stiff punch of minerals and a lightly sulfurous twinge of yeast add character. Discordant carbonation displaces much of the floral vibrancy of the Hallertau and yields a borderline stark and hollow center, but thankfully the well-extracted cookielike malt persists. Fruitiness is more of the unripe peach variety rather than supple marmalade, though an adequate dose of oily lemony acids helps compensate for the lack of richness. Flavor intensity tapers off in the dry and snappily toasty, yet empty, finish. Lemon is subtle as it lingers. No apparent flaws here other than the pointy carbonation, and it does lack the soulfulness of the high-quality examples of the style, but in the end it’s a very quaffable, if simple, Zoigl.

Draft at Zoiglwirtschaft d Eisenbahn in Vohenstrauss. Hazed amber-gold with a white head of decent retention. Aroma is lightly hoppy and malty with notes of floral lemon, cracked pepper, toasted cereals, wheat crackers. Mostly clean aroma and flavor profile, it’s an extremely gassy beer and even with some of the carbonation shook out it still strongly subdues the malt sugar, which comes across as saccharine / nutri-sweet impression at warmer temperatures. Medium-light bodied, light to medium sweetness with balanced bitterness. It’s carbonic, zesty and toasty, but not all that complex or rich, coming across a little too pointed / sharp, especially in the finish. Still a decent drinker with adequate hop expression.
Leicht trübes bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit wenig Schaum. Geruch malzig, getreidig. Geschmack malzig, getreidig, leicht würzig.

Bottle. Light amber, hazy, small to average and fully diminishing head. Moderate malty - lightly sweetish aroma, light caramel and light bread with light fruitiness, faint hoppyness. Moderate, malty and lightly sweetish flavor, light caramel and light bread. Finish is average, malty and lightly sweetish, light caramel and light bread with light hoppyness. Kellerbier with light caramel/bread. OK but nothing special - not too sweet, though.
Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass light brownish, small head. Starts malty dry, a bit woody-scratchy. Fruity hints of plum. Finish modest sweet. Interesting.

0,5 l bottle. BB 11. Apr 13. From Getränke Liebick Dark amber, clear, minimal head, tan foam, bread, cereal, citrus, herbs, leaves, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, soft carbonation,
It’s hazy copper with a creamy, lasting head. The aroma has notes of caramel, malt, fruit, and the the moderately sweet flavor has the same notes with a dryish twist towards the finish.

column1: Kamikokoro Ohshima Shuichi Junmai Daiginjo Sake
column5: 500ml bottle pours out a sand color no head. Nose is melons stone fruit booze and some sweetness. Taste is more of the fruit notes heat and a little sweetness.

column1: Kamikokoro Ohshima Shuichi Junmai Daiginjo Sake
column5: 500mL Bottle: Pours a light beige color with thick legs and a light misty haze that could be confused for condensate on the glass. The nose is bright and fruity, lots of light anise, pear skin and peach. Fair amount of heat hides behind this sweet fruity curtain. Warm alcohol but only to convey the flavors. Moderate acidity washes up with the sweetness, I find it moderately sweet, although it’s probably -2 or -1 on the scale. I always undershoot these junmai daiginjos. Very nice and delicious. Good enough to finish the bottle, I think I will.

Pours a hazy yellow with a thin white head. Smells of spices of cinnamon, clove, coriander, lemons, and grass. Coriander overwhelms the palate with cinnamon, clove, lemon grass. The fiinsh is rather spicey.
Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker. Taste was herbal and lots of chamomile. I don’t really like this one.

Reviewed from notes. Poured into a tulip. Pours a hazy yellow color with a bit of a light apricot hue. White head that doesn’t persist for long. The nose is...whoa. There is a lot going on. It’s all a bit too much and I don’t think everything comes together at all. I get some lemon, tea, flowers, chamomile, grass, and a bit of grain. The taste worsens this as there is a weird sort of bitterness from all these earthy, plant-like flavors. Feel is a bit astringent. In the end, I really did not enjoy this. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 11-13-2010

Wow, just wow. I was stoked to find this awful tick in my friends fridge. Bottled 11/19/10. I had this when it was fresh but I didn’t review it. Also back then I didn’t know anything about saisons. A- This is a pretty dark saison. Deep amber red. Short head with slouchy lacing. S- Weird. Butter, toffee, salt, pepper, hay and a weird funky earthiness. T- A mish-mash of damp spices and mold. A strange butteriness comes in toe with cheese. This finish is bizarre and alarming. M- Very, very dry. I need some water.
Light gold color with small head. Aroma and flavor are pretty weak, but still have nice light hoppy and bretty notes with some faint fruitiness. It’s okay

From 12 ounce bottle. Pours hazy gold with loose white head. Yeasty bread aroma with some grassy and floral notes. Thin on the palate with malt, lemon, and a weak, astringent bitterness. Not a standout - not a great example of the style.

I would have to agree with those who say Great Lakes make some great beers. However, I was given this beer by a friend to ensure he wasn’t crazy. I assure you, he is not. The beer is beautiful in color and produces a nice head. The initial smell I picked up was saison yeast, just a slight fruitiness. Drinking tastes like a mouthfull of mown grass. Overwhelming mown grass, and not at all in a good way. Shared the glass with two others. After 3 drinks, I poured it down the drain, something I have never done. I’m thinking you should save those herbs for tea and pasta. Way to screw up what is probably a very nice saison.

Smells like a cheap French Hooker. Rarely have had bad brews from Great Lakes but Chamomile? C’mon guys. Lemon balm? Sounds more like a chcik’s shampoo than beer. This was the first six pack I’ve bought in years that I couldn’t finish.
Poured a clear yellow color with a white head. The aroma was of grass and melon with odd notes of shrimp. Yes I said shrimp. Malty flavor with a taste of cut grass. Medium bodied.

Bottle. A hazy golden straw color with a huge,lasting foamy white head , high level of carbonation , some jagged lacing left . Aroma of grass , lemon, and yeast esters like cloves and banana . Flavor is a mix of spices, slightly herbal, quite yeasty , lots of clove and grass flavors , nice toast on the malt if you can pick it out . Odd finish , like fresh hay with a bit of shuger , slightly dry ,medium body for the style , slightly chalky mouthfeel . Drinkable , and could be sessionable but one of these is plenty for me , not really sure why but just not what im looking for .

column1: Mineno Hakubai (White Blossom on the Hill) Tokubetsu Junmai Sake
column5: Bottle: Pours a crystal clear color with a decent amount of legs. The nose is earthy with some masculine koji, fresh spring onion, potato and kiwi skin. The impact is dry initially but the acidity doesn’t kick in until later, so the mouthfeel feels thick and sweet but it doesn’t taste sweet at all. The low acidity and +3 rating are certainly a sweet spot for me. A more fragrant yeast or rice varietal might perk this one right up. It certainly transports me back to Japan though with the mild koji and rich umami. Yum!

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: Very cloudy, tan beer. Looks like a milkshake. Aroma is fairly spicy with banana/apple and some light peachiness as well. Flavour shows peach and apple, lean wheaty body, some yeasty breadiness in back of all of the spiciness and esters. Light black pepper spiciness. Nice balance of fruit and spice. Could be a whole lot dryer, but it’s still tasty enough.

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: Stopped at the brewpub, and was pleasantly surprised by this. It was a cloudy pale amber color, little head. NIce aroma and flavor, with sweet fruit, malt, and spice. Very nice!

column2: North Conway, New Hampshire, United States
column4: Moat Mountain Smoke House & Brewing Company
column5: Stopped at the Moat Mountain restaurant for lunch while on vacation recently and we tried a few brews. This was our first selection and it was pretty good. A lot of quality craftsmanship was apparent in the flavoring and texture. The pour was a cloudy orange/gold with a nice white head. A flowery aroma was capped by a sweet caramelly malt flavoring. Excellent.
Draft. Amber beer with an off-white head. Malty aroma with some earthy spice. Rich caramel flavor with earth and spice hop backing and some slight citrus. Medium bodied.

On draft at Pete’s Brass Rail and Carwash. It was explained to me by the bartender that this is a blend of TR’s IPAX and Titanium made specifically for Pete’s Brass Rail. The pours is murky and light brown with a white head. This isn’t the best looking beer, that’s for sure. The aroma is malty with a grapefruit hop note. Hop forward flavor with more citrus notes. Tastes like it may have some wheat in it. Very dry finish.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear, copper-amber colored body with a thin, frothy, beige head that dissipates slowly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is some pumpkin spices with cinnamon, nutmeg, and a bit of ginger with a nice malt sweetness consisting of some toffee bread, a touch of toast, and a light caramel. Flavor is similar. Some bready toffees, a light toast, and caramel up front before an even amount of pumpkin spices come in. Nutmeg, a bit of ginger, and a light cinnamon that increases slightly towards the end as this dries with a light toasted toffee sweetness and balanced spicing.
