Lengthy aftertaste following a medium body and a moderate carbonation. Overall, a pretty nice pumpkin beer. Pleasantly spiced and a light sweetness that is all well balanced and easy drinking. Solid.

Sample at Brew Kettle on 10/7/11. Clear copper pour with a medium beige head. Super spicy nose with cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg and allspice notes with a pleasant malty sweetness. Allspice and nutmeg character on the tongue first, then maltiness before cinnamon and ginger round it out. Very solid.

Sample from growler courtesy of a traveling friend. The beer pours a clear copper-amber color with a medium off-white head that recedes steadily to an outer ring. Partial rings of lace. Aroma of cinnamon and cloves as well as malt. Light to medium body with flavors of sweet spices, pumpkin and malt. The finish is sweet with a nutmeg and pumpkin aftertaste. Fairly straightforward but well-executed beer overall.

This poured a dark amber color with an off white head. Aroma was of cinnamon, nutmeg and slightly roastd malt. Flavor was a fairly strong allspice flavor, cinnamon coming out the most with a blander malt finish.
draft at TBK- had so many pumpkin beers this weekend, and not one really distinguished itself- a lot of spicing, mostly nutmeg with sweet cinnamon, and a well made beer.

Bottle from Brew Kettle. Poured clear dark orange color with an average off-white frothy head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Solid spicy pumpkin pie aroma. Moderate body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium pumpkin spicy sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Solid seasonal beer.

I was glad to see Brew Kettle still serving a pumpkin beer during my visit in late December...seems like a lot of brewers plan to sell out of pumpkin beer by Thanksgiving, and to me the flavor is appropriate through the new year. This one is a touch light on the pumpkin and maybe too light in the body, but is nonetheless a very solid beer with lots of nutmeg and other spice. Appearance-wise, it looked a great deal like the Chief’s Rye - not quite colorful enough in the amber body, and with a medium amount of head. Aroma was very spicy, but both the aroma and taste led me to doubt the inclusion of actual pumpkin in the recipe, although the menu said it was in there. Flavor was more spice than pumpkin, with lots of nutmeg and I thought it pretty good. Mouthfeel was pretty good. A nice beer. I would recommend this beer. I had it on-tap at the Brew Kettle in Strongsville.

On tap at the brewery. They are calling it pumpkinhead ale. I’m guessing this is the same version. Pours dark orange color with off white head. Has aroma of sweet pumpkin and its spices. Body is medium. Flavor is loaded with pumpkin flavor and its spices. Nutmeg, cinnamon, and maybe some clove. Its pretty spicy. I enjoyed this more than most pumpkin ales and its up there with the best in my mind.

Draft @ brewkettle: Damn, someone got around to this sooner than I did. Amber in color with a light tan head. Aroma of nutmeg and cinnamon, and a bit of pumpkin. Flavor, mild pumpkin notes, some spices, it was a bit tart. The mouth feel was a little thin for me. Solid beer though.

On tap at the brewkettle - Pours dark amber with a short white head that faded pretty quick. Good aroma of pumpkin and nutmeg. Flavor is pumpkin, nutmeg, a touch of toffee, some caramel notes as well. Medium body. Pretty fair pumpkin ale..

Bottle of Glacial Grind Coffee Porter. Poured thin and black with a 1 finger tan head. Aromas of coffee and dark malt. The flavor is also mostly coffee with some dark malt. And easy drinker for a porter.
Had something called Wagner Glacial Grind Coffee Porter. Pretty good though very dominated by the coffee in taste and nose. Appearance is standard dark and mostly clear.

On tap for growler fills at Half Time. Pours a deep dark black with a thin beige tan head. Soft chocolate and coffee on the nose. Medium bodied, tart coffee,s bit of chewy malt and toast. Gentle bitter cocoa and coffee on the finish.

(draft @ Wagner Valley Brewing Company - Lodi, NY) Dark brown pour with a tan head. Roasted coffee aroma with some light chocolate and cream hint. Roasted coffee and chocolate malt flavor. A bit thin bodied but has the great taste of an iced mocha.

First rating in 4 years! Draft. Pours near black with a beige head. Lightly roasted malts, medium sweetness, fresh brewed coffee, and a hint of vanilla. Lo lingering bitterness that occasionally comes with coffee beers. Good stuff.

12oz bottle. I worked for Wagner’s for two years. During my 2 years, I spent much time at the fabled "House," where general cacophony occurred nightly. Upon exploring the basement of The House, a few coworkers and myself discovered several bottles of beer, aged nearly 5 years. These bottles, and The House, had belonged to the owner of Wanger’s- legendary Bill Wagner. We drank these beers like little regard for history, and soon regretted it. These beers had aged like a cheap Parisian trollop. 1 of these lethal brews was enough to cause fall-down drunkenness. Nevertheless, we soldiered on...

Growler. Dark brown, near black with a small ring of brown head. Smells of bitter coffee roast (and lots of it), some sourness, and chocolate. Creamy, nutty body with coffee bitterness and oat flavours. Pretty solid though it thins out quickly towards the finish.

Sample from a bottle. Fresh, sharp vegetal espresso nose, really bright coffee in the aroma, and very rich smelling as well. Lightly pasty/empty texture, medium-to-light frothiness. Coffee flavors prevalent, with some light roast, if any, or maybe more of a burnt dark roasted coffee flavor, and I’m just thinking roast. The coffee is quite delicious – I love coffee stout – but it covers pretty much the entire ‘porter’ in this porter. Still a solid coffee beer.

Draft. Pours a dark brown core; light brown head with good lacing. Roasted coffee and dark chocolate in the aroma; hints of vanilla. Medium, well-roasted mouthfeel: plenty of roasted coffee and milk chocolate; slightly oily, inky viscosity; hints of toasted malts at the back end. Medium, coffee and cream finish.

on tap. first coffee porter i’ve ever had. dark black color with a nice head. strong coffee aroma. nice feel and a strong after taste of the coffee. loved how the chocolate came thru as it warmed but the coffee was still in the forefront. brought a growler home.

column1: Steel River Platts Folly Old World Lager
column5: Not too bad. Big on malt if that is your thing. It has an interesting aroma which is mainly dominated by the malty character. Poured as a clear golden colour. Minimal head which was dissappointing.

column1: Steel River Platts Folly Old World Lager
column5: 330ml bottle. Surprising in a good way. Bright amber in colour with a wavy uneven white foam that goes quickly but sticks to the side of the glass. Well carbonated with a hop aroma and smooth texture in the mouth. Worth hunting for.

column1: Steel River Platts Folly Old World Lager
column5: Dull orangey amber body with poor head. Caramelly sweet aroma, some cardboardy notes in the taste as well as the caramel. Drinkable for some people just not for me.

column1: Steel River Platts Folly Old World Lager
column5: Bottle. Pours a deep orange with a small white head. Disappeared pretty quickly leaving no lacing. Initially nice malty aromas with a hint of citurs hop aromas. As the beer warmed slightly however the nose turned quite harsh with a weird sweetish aroma. Something I couldn’t quite place though. Flavours unfrotunately were much the same. Initially some malt and hops but the this harsh after taste. Didn’t like this one unfortunately.

column1: Steel River Platts Folly Old World Lager
column5: Not a bad beer and nice to see a brewer going for a Lager style over ales. Slight malt nose, pour is amber with an off white head. Flavour is a mix of initial biscuity malt with some fruity back end flavour that has a slightly washed out finish.

column1: Steel River Platts Folly Old World Lager
column5: This did not seem like a lager to me but more of an american pale ale. A nice reddish/ golden hue. Lots of citrus and florals in the taste and aroma. Above average I thought.

column1: Steel River Platts Folly Old World Lager
column5: Dunno where our esteemed colleague Sully got his story from, but my bottle tells a different version. Apparently the Platt on my bottle had 2000 acres up in the Hunter Valley back in the 1820’s and failed in his ventures into timber milling, farming and coal mining. The only link to the beer is that the brewery’s next to where the old homestead was! Anyway, on to the beer... which looked decent with a golden orange hue and moderately lasting head. Nice enough floral aroma with some musk and a touch of toasty malt appearing after a while. Fairly bitter, and not just like sucking on copper coins which can be a feature of many Australian beers. Medium bodied, the carbonation is pretty close to the mark, but the aftertaste is forgettable. A step above the macros, but not much to really rave about.

column1: Steel River Platts Folly Old World Lager
column5: In the bottle from the Bottle-O in Newcastle. Rich gold in color with a poofy, but fleeting white head. It seems to me that Oz lagers come in 2 types- no flavorand just a hint of flavor. This falls in the latter category. I’m getting just a bit of hop-induced floral flavor and a slight residual bitterness post quaff. Better than many, but not worth flying to Australia to try.

column1: Steel River Platts Folly Old World Lager
column5: The story of this brew is some ramble about silly old Platt and the folly of trying to grow grapes or some such crap. He embarked on brewing in the ’20s and so it was said he had hit on a winner with his lager brewed to the old style of beers, using only the best blah blah blah. I’ll tell you the bloody folly my lad. The belief that this is significantly different from your typical Aussie pale lager. A bit more complexity than the macrocrap but really, where is all the substance to support the guff they go on with? Just another beer with some small degree of malt and hop balance but as characterless as a Kevin Costner performance.

column1: Steel River Platts Folly Old World Lager
column5: Rerate 11/1/07: The gulf between fresh draught lager and the bottled version is often broad. The arrival of this in bottles in Sydney offered a chance for a comparison, and regrettably, a downgrade. The bottled version is more muted in the glass, but still fruity and summery on the nose. Quite a full mouthfeel for a lager, soft and morish. Pleasantly fruity but with an unwelcome late astringency that I didn’t pick in the draught version. Bit of a disconnect between the summery fruits at the front of the palate and the harshness of the finish. Still drinkable but not as fine as it seemed on a warm spring afternoon sitting outside the Australian Hotel. Original rating: This was the first of two lagers brewed by this new venture based in Newcastle, NSW. The second, Steel River Lager, was created later to cater for macro lager drinkers who found this too demanding. At least, that’s my understanding based on a conversation with the brewer at the recent beer festival at Sydney’s Australian Hotel. This is fruitier, a little stronger and more complex than SRL but the differences are so marginal that I’d be surprised if this survives once the range expands. It’s a deeper gold than SRL with excellent head retention. Bit nutty at first sniff, with the same lychee fruity notes, a hint of attic and a faint herbal quality. Quite subtle and hard to pin down. Medium bodied and softly carbonated. Not as malty as SRL, with a more pronounced hop presence. Very fruity - lychee and blackcurrants, quite tart in the swallow, with some sherbet. Undemanding summer drinking. Original score: 6/4/6/3/12 (3.1). (Draught at Australian Hotel beerfest)

Sampled draught at the Autumn Brew Review in Minneapolis, October 7 2006. Not as impressed with this one as JK was though it’s competently put together....dull, dirty amber in complexion with little head....fairly weak and typical PNW hoppy nose, stronger on the twiggy-bark notes than citrus, touch of caramel malt....body is much more caramelly-sweet, just lightly bitter, clean enough but for me terribly boring and by-the-numbers. Their saison was much better.

ABR 2006. This is a solid ipa, very drinkable if not outstanding. The aroma is herbal hops and promises a bitter flavor. The flavor is more hops, bitter, some flowery and a little spicy. Dark orange. Good effort.
Great beer! Always excited when this is on tap! I wish this is one they had year round!

On draught at the Fitger’s brewpub in downtown Duluth, MN. Pours a clear, near opaque dark reddish brown colored brew with a creamy off-white head that has some nice retention and lacing. Aroma of toasted dark malt, a hint of coffee, some roasted nuts and light grapefruit. Taste is medium bodied, flavors of toasted dark malt, a hint of grapefruit, coffee and and light chocolate. Finish has a mild citrus bitterness with a lingering toasted dark malt/coffee aftertaste. One of the more hoppier porters I’ve tried.
Very dark brown with a short lasting head. Definitely walnuts and a little coffee and chalk. Just enough innocuous hops to balance. OK, not real special

REAL ALE TENT @ GTMW 2008: Dark brown and very good head and lace. The aroma has notes of prune, walnut, caramel and chalky yeast esters. The taste is twangy and fruity on top of dark dry malts, woody finish. The mouth feel is soft and smooth. An okay porter, you could worse.

On cask at GTMW. Poured clear medium-deep brown with a loose cap of off-white head. The aroma picked up toasty lighter chocolate and caramel notes joined by a faint, well-placed smoky presence.. solid. The flavor had caramel and semi-sweet chocolate at the core with dry coffee and earthy bitterness around.. dry, lighter, non-descript finish. Lighter-bodied and dry on the palate with a nice choice of malts, but perhaps not enough of them especially toward the back.. this may have been better with a little CO2 behind it.

I can’t find this on the Fitger’s website but there are a few references to this beer on the Internet. It looks like a tribute to someone at Fitger’s. Anyway, it is a better than average porter. This beer has substantial palate, but it is not as thick as their stout. The beer is black and has a small head. Some dried fruit in the aroma, and roasted malt and light, sweet fruit in the flavor.
I will never go back to this piss. mild and sweet barley malt and my suspicion of corn is increasing. low carbonated, carbonation dies quickly. sweet aftertaste.
Vaguely sweet but fresh malt aroma. The taste is sweet malt with a grainy, sour and bitter aftertaste. Unpleasant beer!

Can, 50cl - Pale orange golden colored beer with a large off white head. Aroma is bready malty with notes of metal and hay. Flavor is weak malty with hints of roasted bread, caramel and light metallic notes. Not very good, but not very bad either.
500ml Can - Gold/light amber in colour, with a foamy head. Grassy aroma with grain and some light citrus hints. Malty and slightly bitter taste with grain and a faint sweetness.

50 cL can. Pours clear and golden yellow with a huge white head. Cornish and malty aroma. Semi sweet and slight syrupy flavoured with a mild bitterness and slight cornish ntoe coming through. Ends medium bitter and dry.

Can. High white fluffy and lasting white head. Clear yellow body with an awful lot of bubbles. Weak barley malt and corn I guess. Flavor very mild and sweet barley malt and my suspicion of corn is increasing. In spite of the many bubbles the beer is low carbonated, or the carbonation dies quickly. Short sweet aftertaste.
Can. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, hops and caramel.

500 ml can. Golden colour. Crystal clear. Very tall fine-laced white head that clings to the glass. Clean grassy hop aroma. Initial bitterness. Smooth texture with high carbonation mixed with oily malt flavours. Feels rather rich, and reminds me a bit of the contemporary Oktoberfestbiers. Finishes with a metallic bitterness that cuts through the oily malts.
Sweet, dusty grain on aroma. Gets better as you taste it with some nice and not so sweet caramel flavour. Not very exciting, though.

Big offwhite lasting head. Coppery yellow body. Clean malty neutral aroma with faint peppery hops. Traces of rubber. Dry-sweet light malty corn taste. Sharp fizzy mouthfeel. Dry rubbery watery corn aftertaste with grainy notes. Bland. (0.5l can, Systembolaget, Göteborg.)
Bright yellow. Bubbly head that doesn’t last long. Super saccharine. Not great.
You get what you pay for and more with 4 cans for 5 euro. Pleasantly surprised by the taste and aroma. Would recommend if on a tight budget.
Im from Ireland, great drink, great price (4 for €5) always sold out in my local shop, regardless of that, overall very good and sits well!
citrus, floral, grass, jak na czeski lager to s³abiutko wypada, spodziewa³em siê czegoœ lepszego.
old log.. can 500 ml.. rates are as i remember them.. drank it from can... light, bitter.. grassy.. soft lager

Can from Centra [190315] Had Tyskie on the same night and this was a bit better. Dirt cheap at only €4 for 4 cans. Drinkable enough so up to 2.2 Can from Centra, Mohill [030814] 3/3/4/2/8 2 Golden yellow, clear, frothy white head Aroma of light lager malts, soft cardboard, little on nose Taste of pale lager malts, bit of cardboard, some light sweet malt, not much taste but no nasty flavours. Palate - soft carb, light body, slightly sweet. Finish has a slight rough bitterness. Overall - Dirt cheap at only €5 for 4 cans ... Actually tastes better than the crap Heineken from the pub at €4/pint. Bit better than a lot of macro lagers. Quite drinkable. Good buy for the money.
Can from Continental Food Store, Wakefield. Golden-yellow with no head. Dryish textured lager with some flavour to it.
Gold pour with watery white head and lace. Aroma is a bit skunky. Corn and sweet malt flavor with not much of a bitter. Medium bodied with ok carbonation. a beer that tasted better than it smelled.

500 ml can picked up in Ireland. pours a pale yellow with a big soft white head. Aroma is hops and urine. Taste is better but butterscoch and cardboard. not terible and the palate ends sweet. Dont know what to make of it really. Better than most cheap macros but blah.

I shouldn’t be surprised that this is the kind of beer that Panamanian Super markets import. It’s almost as bad as an Atlas or Panama lager. Smells and tastes pissy, drinks flat and has a sour aftertaste. Of all the Czech lagers to import.

Anniversary Trip 2007 5/17/2007: Very black with an ultra creamy head and dense lacing from the top to the bottom of the glass. Aroma is dry and roasty as is the flavor. There is also dark chocolate and a hint of an ashy/aspirin quality in the flavor as well. Medium-full body and creamy. This is a Dry Stout that delivers on the dry! Draught sample (4.5% ABV) at The Livery in Benton Harbor, Michigan.

Tap at brewery and served in pint glass: I really did not take good notes on this one, more about the conversion and the "early sample of a future release" than I was worried about note taking. I few comments I did write down include: Chocolate, rye, coffee, bitter, clean and simply smooth. A fresh "dry" stout and is so much better than the commercial beers. That is all...

10 ounce pour at the brewpub. Opaque black with a creamy brown head. Strong hoppy aroma with roast and coffee. "Guiness" twang with chocolate and coffee flavors. Light body witha a dry finish. Pretty enjoyable.

Draft sample at brewpub. Poured dark brown with a average creamy brown head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Heavy complex roasted coffee aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture. Medium roasted sweet flavor with a medium burnt bitter finish of long duration. This is a standout beer.
A rich mans carlton draught. Pretty much just as bad but has a nice looking bottle
Gold pour good strength carbonation aroma metallic grasy flavour metallic sweet some malt soapy but that usual taste finish metallic grasy note soapy ver off putting

Bottle. I had this at Daikoku restaurant in Nadi, Fiji. The meal was fantastic, but the beer was a bit of a dud. No BBD on the bottle, but I think this one has been "on the menu" a while! Pale yellow, grainy, on the watery side, no hop character at all really. Dry boxboard finish.
Very watery and flat tasting. Poured with almost no head - a very ordinary beer. Glad I only bought one bottle.
No mention of CUB on the label but this is watered down VB. No head at all. Mild watery taste with the usual CUB metallic taste. Actually better than Crown because it is watered down. Nasty.
I paid a lot of cash for 6 bottles of these, and By God was I let down. Terrible, it makes Heineken look like the nectar of the gods.

Thought I might get this out the way as quick as possible. Like ripping off a band-aid, sneak this one in between pints and its all over. Not that I doubt it being an award winning, complex and balanced lager. No ’pfffft’ when I cracked it but sure enough the CO2 erupted once it hit the glass. Clear, medium gold, typically Australian looking with lots of carbonation and a big, fluffy white crown that legged it well. Metallic ’rusted-car-body’ and stale hop nose with just a little watered down lemon cordial. Soapy and wishy-washy in the mouth, featherweight in body and stretched for flavour. Slightly dank, metal tinged flavours with a flutter of malt showing. Finish holds very little, though an unsalted peanut flavour lingers. Tastes a little chlorinated too. Sadly this was better than a standard Crownie in the fact that it went down with more ease and was honestly less offensive. Still, clear bottle, very little flavour and mid-strength, hmmmm! (375mL, 28/06/07, The Beer Store, Morley)

Picked up two stubbies of this to try out but the second one may sit in the fridge because one is more than enough. Clear bronze body, which was darker than I was expecting, on a rocky average size white head. Hops on the nose that don’t smell that fresh. Taste is what the nose promises, not much! CUB have released another winner, now waiting for the Crown Pilsener which may be dearer than the real crownie.

column1: Fire Station 5 Bunker Gear Winter Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Fire Station 5 Brewing Company--Portland Brewing Company--Pyramid Brewing--Bunker Gear Winter Ale--2006 Release--12 oz. Bottle--6.50% ABV--20 IBU’s? (3.5 / 5.0) Winter Ale--Roasted--Dense foamy mild lace copper head. Clear thin bright dark bronze color. Mild roasted hop front. Dry sweet thin burnt almond caramel mild fruit body. Dry clean roasted mild hop bland Winter spice end. Sampled 8/22/2007.

column1: Fire Station 5 Bunker Gear Winter Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Mahogany color pour with a cream colored head. Smells like a caramel malty sweet treat. Taste started off sweet but quickly fell into a bitter aftertaste mess. Left an astringent flavor in my mouth with a metallic feel as well. I can’t say that I enjoyed this brew, it started with promise but fell short in delivery. I hope the other Fire Station Brews are better than this one...pretty cheap to obtain for a craft brew, but fell short, too short.

column1: Fire Station 5 Bunker Gear Winter Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Great, sweet aroma. Pours to a nice, rich-looking brown color with minimal head and lacing. Nice, medium-bodied flavor. Not overly strong flavor; drinkable. Nice, palate. A very enjoyable winter beer, although not as potent as some other winter beers. I’m usually albe to pick this beer up at a good price, to boot.

column1: Fire Station 5 Bunker Gear Winter Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: [12oz Bottle] A deep dark brownish color with a light head. This has a carmel and toffee aroma but it was very lgith. The beer was lacking in deep rich winter ale flavor and the matalic flavors where presnt again somehtign in this brewing process they get the metal in it. This brew just lacks and was a begginers type winter ale.

column1: Fire Station 5 Bunker Gear Winter Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 12-oz. Gorgeous looking. Pours a deep dark and very clear brown with nice tinges of garnet highlights. Big thick light tan head, moussy and lightly bubbly. Strong caramel & two-row malt beaming through on the nose. Subdued attack: medium body, low carb, moderate flavors. Two-row, biscuit, and caramel on the palate, with some c-hop at the end. Some slightly astringent alcohol fumes on the finish. Drinkable, fairly well complete in its thinking, and dull. I don’t see the alcohol or the thinness quite so tragically as the last reviewer. I would probably drink this stuff again if they were offering it for nothing, but wouldn’t push it much farther than that.

column1: Fire Station 5 Bunker Gear Winter Ale
column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 12 0z brown long neck. Quite a surprisingly attractive ale to look at dark amber almost brown, reddish tinges and a huge thick tan head, nice. Aroma is weak, but not unpleasant mostly choclate styled malts. Flavour again is all malt getting a little bitterness near the end, low carbonation , which i think helps this pretty thin "winter ale" Unfortunatlly some alcohol shows..pretty bad for a 6.5% beer. Too thin on the palte only saved by the low carbonation. Not a good beer really. Just the usual second rate stuff for this contract brew.
on draft at Smokeless Joes, brown copper colour, smoked peat on the nose, decent brew, not as smokey as i would have liked but nice. could have drank a few more pints

Tap at Volo. Malty nose, slightly medicinal with hints of vanilla, darker roasted accents show up late. Brown appearance with neat ruby hue, bright white top contrasting neatly with darker base. I was surprised with smoked malts up front which were well balanced and leaving long lasting aftertaste. Late mineral touches. Smoked Okto?

Draught at Smokeless Joe. Pours a clear reddish-amber with a spare diminishing white head. Mild, sweet malty aroma with some faint smoke. Watery flavour of sweet malt, faint smoke and a very light bitterness. There’s an unpleasant hint of alcohol/metal in the flavour and I didn’t care much for the aftertaste. Light bodied. Another mediocre (at best) Amesterdam beer.

Draught. At Volo. Poured a deep clear copper with a decent white head. Aroma of roast malt, woodsmoke and peat, mild hops. When I tasted it I had to ask if they’d poured me a Church Key Holy Smoke instead - very smokey and earthy, tangy roast malt and mild herbal hops for a base - I really liked it, I didn’t get metal, I got a nice minerally peat character to it. Medium body but nice and sticky, lightly carbonated and astringent with a reasonably quick minerally finish - easily one of the best Amsterdams yet - almost a rauchbier.

An intentionally weird combination of American wheat and caramel. Dark copper. Minimal head. Caramel malt and a touch of vanilla. The caramel malt is too strong for the German hops and the wheat. Oh well, it’s for charity.
Aroma: carbon, malt & light fruity notes Appearance: black, tiny head, no lacing, highlights of brown Flavour: sweet malt, some caramel & carbon Palate: Thin and gently carbonated

Tap at Slowbeer, Richmond, Melbourne. Poured a clear dark brown with a frothy tan head. The aroma is caramel malt, liqouirce, chocolate, charcoal, light dry coffee. The flavour is moderate sweet with a smooth rich oily roasty liqouirce hop bitter palate. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation.

27Nov2017 Dark roast malts, dark roast filter coffee, dark chocolate, cacao, charcoal. Hazy, very dark brown, medium, creamy, beige head. Light bitter. More dark chocolate, cacao, dark roast malts, coffee, pralines, soft carbonation, full bodied. Beautiful. Bottle from Leura Cellars, Leura.
Bottle 330ml (Beer DeLuxe, Melbourne). Roasty, coffee in aroma. Semisweet in taste, chocolate, coffee with toast bitterness and delicate booze. Medium body, smooth, tasty.
Coal black and plenty of molasses, coffee and toffee malt. Trace of vanilla but slightly too much liquorice and aniseed for my taste

Deep and dark, pours black with a dark tan solid creamy head, light aroma of coffee and chocolate, creamy texture with the flavours of chocolate, coffee and a light spice, finishing with a mellow bitter aftertaste.

Pours dark brown, mocha head. Nose is coffee, molasses, vanilla, plum, raisins. Flavor is more of the same, sweet toffee, lots of raisin and fig, coffee on the finish. Very complex and layered flavor, really delightful. You get a nice transition between the sweetness of the mid palate and the coffee notes on the end. Gorgeous, really really gorgeous.
East of Everything ontap(24-Sep-16)Choc coffee malt aroma. Black,solid cream head&sticky sheet lace. Coffee herbal veg flavour. Bitter coffee finish&roast malt aftertaste.

6/8/2016 - draught at Red Hill Brewery - same as comments for bottled version. 11/6/2016 - bottle- Poured an opaque black with a one-finger light tan dense foam head that retained for ages but laced poorly. Carbonation low to moderate. Aroma subtly of chocolate, roasted coffee and syrup/treacle. Taste of sweet brown sugars, roasted malt, dark chocolate, dark fruits and vanilla with alcohol on the back palate; low bitterness. Medium body but a little thin for the style. Smooth and creamy with a lingering subtly sweet vanilla finish that also has alcohol notes. Nice enough.

Aroma - strong and simple Taste - 10/10 Full bodied, with slight coffee taste. Beautiful malts. Very creamy (maybe slightly too much) Simple stout flavours, its not trying to be anything else apart from a stout which is refreshing these days. Surprisingly hoppy bitterness to end on. After taste - Beautiful lingering taste, with that full body malty taste hanging on for a long while. Tip: Sensational with a bit of good quality dark chocolate!
Bottle gift from SJ. thin / watery body, notes of bold coco and chocolate. Some roasted malts. It was ok, but highly overrated.

WOW the king of kings 2006 bottle thanks to Skyview pours reddish black and rather thin with the aromas being of chocolate and chocolate i was EXPECTING PURE GARBAGE but anything it was far from it rather a very tastey treat for a chocolate lover a real chocolate beer and from a Macro

Bottle - 2006… Clear, very dark lager that is impenetrable to even the Florida sun. Small, creamy, khaki head with fantastic retention. Nice chocolaty aroma, very reminiscent to Southern Tier’s Choklat - I like it. Full-bodied and creamy with barbed carbonation. The flavor is very chocolaty and a little too sweet for my palate – almost cloying - and I have a big-time sweet tooth. The finish is also sweet and chocolaty. Age might have something to do with the complete lack of balance, but either way, this is pretty darned great for a Miller product. Major thanks to Skyview for providing the bottle!
12 oz bottle into a pint glass Aroma is mainly milk chocolate and the flavor is sweet chocolate with a lingering dark chocolate flavor. Really not too bad.

12oz bottle from 2006 thanks to 3Faveryrogue. Pours dark brown with a small beige head. Has a fair amount of sediment. Still very well carbonated after three years. Aroma is of cocoa, caramel, malt, and wheat. Taste is of chocolate, caramel, a slight bit of wood, malt, and wheat. Mouthfeel was very light and crisp. Only had the slightest hint of being oxidized. Lingering taste of dry chocolate. Has a lot of drinkability for a chocolate lager. Definitely the best Miller product that has been made.

I probably consumed the last two 4-packs in existence. OK. Maybe theres some more of this floating around, but highly doubtful. REALLY glad I found this gem. $4.99/pk from the local beer museum. Bunker had some, planted someones vomit in my frontroom shortly afterward, and tried destroying the evidence. Bastard. On to the beer..... Vintage 06. Survived time extremely well. 7/10/09. Great pssst. Nice dark pour, and respectable head. This beer smelled perfect. Not so stouty. Chocolate truffle, wafers, swiss miss, hersheys bar. Some lager and maybe a trace of that wheat somewhere. Point well made. Chocolate beer. Flavor and mouth excellent. Crisp finish. Taste is NOTHING like a Southern Tier Choklat or Mokah. Those come off as syrupy chocolate sodas. Way too overpowering to drink a 22 to oneself. THIS is a sessionable chocolate brew. Surprised that this didnt WOO the masses. Wish there was tons more available. Best Miller product ever.
Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate. Chocolate flavor. Very sweet.

Pours a deep red brown with a thin beige head. No lace. Potent chocolate aroma, specifically of tootsie roll candy. This is a good thing. Flavor is also dominated by the same sweet chocolate elements. Caramel-malty in a cream soda sense. The malts are slightly papery; this is the only offness in this beer. Medium bodied, smooth on the swallow.

(11/3/08) Bottle sample at a tasting in Pizza Port in Carlsbad (thanks whoever). I hope this is the right beer because what I tried just had a hand-made label for some competition. Brown color. Aroma of dark bitter chocolate and cocoa. Sweet flavor of dark chocolate, some malt and caramel notes. Medium-bodied. Like liquid chocolate.

2006 12oz Twist-off. Thanks Sean! Rather vibrant cocoa nib chocolate nose. Bits of dutch liqeur, Irish Creme, and Smores. A bit saccarhin, dusty and reduced, but decent. Pours a mid-brown, chesnut cloud, with a fast fading creamy tan head. Flavor reminds me of alcohol prepackaged hot chocolate, done cold. Liquor-like. This tastes a lot like someone added a bunch of sugar and chocolate liqeur to Seltzer water. I appreciate the carbonation level, but the flavor is a little brash. Wheat lager? I might be able to pick up a touch of that, but I don’t know. Okay, so actually this isn’t terrible. It has flavor, isn’t overly sweet or weird. I can dig that. Probably the best beer I’ll ever have from Miller.

On tap at the resort location in Sedona. Poured a brilliant pale golden color w/ a medium sized, semi creamy froth. Good residual lacing. Aroma of sweet malts w/ a hint of crispy spice. Nice! Full nectar with soft residual effers. Very creamy. It’s so thik you can chew on it. A huge malty backbone and a moderate sweetness factor w/ a candy spice character. The finish is long w/ a refined velvety bitterness that lingers. It was cold that night and this brew kept me warm. Highly recommended.

column1: Oak Creek Earth Angel Belgian Saison
column5: What better way to enjoy a sunny late afternoon after hiking Bell Rock in Sedona than with a classic Belgian farmhouse ale? Well, I wouldn’t exactly call Oak Creek’s Saison a classic or a particularly faithful representation of the style but it’s a refreshing brew and I was lucky enough to enjoy it on the deck of their brewpub at Tlaquepaque. Hard for any beer to go wrong in that setting. That said, it pours a hazy orange (which looks particularly good against the backdrop of the Sedona red rocks) with a two finger moderately dense white head. Mildly yeasty aroma with fresh citrus and corriander. Crisp and lightly hoppy flavor with herbal notes that tip a bit closer to a wit than a traditional saison. Soft mouthfeel that’s a tad watery for the style but pleasing nonetheless. Crisp and slightly peppery finish. Not a great saison but still apretty well crafted and refreshing brew. It’s their current seasonal offering so you’ll need to head out there within the next several weeks to give it a try.

column1: Oak Creek Earth Angel Belgian Saison
column5: Sampled on tap @ the brewery...seasonal selection. Bright Florida orange body with a lemon-colored 1/2 inch head. Aroma is citrus and indistinguishable spice...flavor mostly tangerine with minimal banana notes. Wasn’t crisp at all, more of a mandarin hefe...

column1: Oak Creek Earth Angel Belgian Saison
column5: On tap @ th brewery. Server said it was a seasonal ale. It was served with a big massive Orange wedge floating in the glass. So, I quickly fished the wedge out of the glass and flung it on to the floor. Anyway, annoyed, I fledged on...........Appearance and aroma were pretty much spot on for a saison. It was a little thin in body, but that is probably because it was sloppily poured into a pint glass and lost a whole bunch of fizz. It wasn’t very cold either which was strange. In short, this was a pretty good beer, but it could be enjoyed much more if the bar had any clue how to serve it properly.

column1: Oak Creek Earth Angel Belgian Saison
column5: Had this on tap at the brewery. Pours a hazed golden with a slight orange hue. Aroma was malty w/ banana spice and rock candy. Medium nectar w/ mellow residual effers. Flavors are on the malty side w/ the usual banana spice but there was also a slight pumpkin thing going on. Interesting enough. It lacked the crispness I find in the usual Saison profile but was a great specimen none the less. It had a mellow lemon rind bittering on the finish. I liked it better cold.
Amber, beige head. Nice fruity malty nose, quite exotic. Taste is malty sweet with the same fine fruits.

Tasting from Jul’ 2008. Shimmering auburn amber body riddled by furious, hasty to rise medium sized bubbles that lift a mere quarter inch of compact, creamy off-white head that lasts and laces well. Strong, sweet, sugary, toasted malt and biscuity nose with good warming, alcohol spice evident. Lifted nutty, sweet caramel and toasted grains in the mouth. A little almond marzipan with burnt bread notes late. Swallow is like a rough praline, nutty and sweet with the alcohol well masked here though a strange chemical taste kicks in faintly late into the aftertaste. Nice rounded body, not heavy, with soft, prickly carbonation. Good linger of sweet malts and roasted nuts. Overall a little one sided but not that bad a beer. Certainly goes down without a blink of the eye-lid! (50cL, BB 27/08/08, International Beer Store, Morley)
27th January 2008 Stromng smooth malty lager - no sharp edges on this one. Finish is both soft and zingy!
Bottled. An amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of malt and metal, and so is the flavor. Thanks yespr for sharing.

500ml Bottle. Clear dark golden body with short but lasting white head. Sweet aroma, malt and honey. Taste is exactly what you get from the aroma and then some caramel and sugar. A drinkable euro strong lager but that doesn’t mean I like it

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of yespr. Clear deep golden with a tall, dense, off-white head leaving laces. Discreet aroma of sweet malt and alcohol. Medium body with a soft mouthfeel and a somewhat low carbonation. Solid malt base with notes of caramel. Almost no bitterness. 270408
Clear golden with tiny white head. Sweet malty aroma with caramel notes. Sweet flavor with caramel and malty notes. Ends sweet.
Bottle. Clear yellow coloured with a medium sized white head. Aroma of malts, caramel and alcohol. Sweet flavour of malts, caramel, alcohol and hops. Burning alcoholic finish.

50 cL bottle. Pours clear and orange with with a diminished white head. Alcohol and malt aroma. Flavour is light grainy and with a solid alcohol presence. Goes into an alcohol dense and warming finish.

[i] [b] Bottle from the Dodgi’ Deli’ Cowley Road had this 24-04-08 [/i] [/b] Pours golden with white bouncy head, some corn on the nose. This isn’t bad and at 89p a bargain, ok its sweet malty and the alcohol whilst not overpowering sometimes gets in the way but I will happily stock up on a few more at this price.

Draught at the Gaylord location: Dark and hazy brown color with a medium thin bone white head. Thin and spotty lacing. Well-spiced aroma along with some malt. Medium-bodied with malt, dark fruit and spice flavors. The finish is spicy and has a bit of alcohol in it. One of Big Buck’s better offerings.

Ein ziemlich trüb-hellbraunes Bier, das es nur in Pfandsyphons oder Fässern zu kaufen gibt. Hier der test aus dem Pfandyphon: Der Geruch ist malzig-säuerlich, der Antrunk etwas sauer, aber nach wenigen Sekunden weicht die Säuerlichkeit einem hervorragenden Malzigen Aroma mit leicht herber Hopfennote, das auch noch lange nach dem Schluck im Mund verbleibt. Einen so charakteristisch-positiven Nachgeschmack hab’ ich schon lange nicht mehr erlebt. Supertoll! Das Aroma erinnert auch etwas an Torf oder Erde - ein Dunkles Bier, wie ich es mir vorstelle!!! Test vom 1.7.2007, Gebinde: sonstiges Noten: 12,15,15,15,6,15 - 14,25 Nach meinem Syphontest letzten Sommer, wo das Bier voll meinen Geschmack traf, nun der Test vom Faß: Der Antrunk ist schön hefig-frisch, der Abgang leicht säuerlich wie Ale, sehr süffig-vollmundig-weich. Im Abgang ist es auch leicht herb, aber nicht zu penetrant. Allerdings kann ich im Gegensatz zu meinem letzten Test überhaupt keine Röstmalzaromen ausfindig machen, auch schmeckt es dieses Mal nicht annähernd so gut, wie bei meinem ersten Test. Komisch.... Vielleicht hat jeder Sud ja seine speziellen Aromen?? Wer weiß... Immer noch ein leckeres Bier, aber dieses mal nicht mehr in meiner Spitzenklasse! Test vom 20.6.2008, Gebinde: Fass Noten: 12,11,12,12,-,12 - 11,84

Milder karamellmalziger Antrunk, malziger werdend. Das Bier wirkt unter anderem wegen dem etwas wässrigen Mittelpart frisch. Im Abgang kommt dann die Karamellmalzigkeit erneut zum Vorschein, zudem etwas getreidig. Mit der Zeit erscheint das Bier etwas eindimensional, auch wenn zum Ende hin ein herb-bitterer Ton aufkommt. Test vom 12.5.2008, Gebinde: Fass Noten: 13,8,9,8,-,9

On tap @ Am Stöter, Wiiten-Bommerholz: Hazy, amber coloured, quite firm stable head; faint yeasty, caramelly nose with a light bitterness; first slightly sweetish, bcoming quickly moderate to strong bitter; sweetish-caramelly bitter finish; light bodied, quite well balanced. A spicy, well rounded brew..............

(draught) Hazy, chestnut coloured effervescent hue with a mid-sized, slightly off-white foamy head. Sweet and yeasty, slightly toasted malty aroma with caramel and shy notes of herbal hops. Bitter flavour, light to medium body, crispy carbonated mouthfeel. Initially toast-malty with caramel and a quite strong early evolving herbal bitterness; dry and well-rounded soft malty and herbal hoppy bitter finish. Reminds me of a rural version of Hövels Bitterbier from Dortmund.

Sampled on draft the brewpub this beer poured a caramel brown color with a medium sized foamy orange-tan head that left decent lacing. The aroma was malty with fruity hops. The flavor was bitterish and tart yet sweet with faint caramel and fruity hops. Medium length finish. Medium boyd. Ok.
Kind of odd, and not really much of an altbier. Pours clear amber with pretty good head and lacing. Some musky wooden aroma. Light sweet finish. Tap at brewpub.

Appearance: medium amber, slightly opaque, short and creamy tan head quickly fading. Aroma: dark brown bread, maybe a hint of caramel, fresh newspaper, and earthy hops. Taste: rustic brown bread, roasted grain, a hint of coffee, and a pronounced lightly sweet nutty note. Finish: clean and dry, with a hint of that nutty roasty malt note lingering. Notes: A pleasantly drinkable beer. Liked the alt-style malty-without-sweetness character, which melded nicely with the nutty aspects. Would drink again, and Zoltan--a true altbier fan if ever there was one--pronounced it good. Bottle from Ye Old Spirit Shop in Frederick, Maryland.

Always looking for a new take on a favorite style, I was happy to try this on tap AND later in a bottle. This Alt wasn’t quite what I expected, but I liked it. A tiny bit lighter in color than your typical German Alt (slightly opaque amber--looked just like the Oktoberfest others at my table were having, though the head was a bit more tan) and the same malty freshness in the nose and in the taste. Some hops in the aftertaste--a somewhat pronounced bitterness that really rounded the flavor nicely. Excellent and very drinkable. Almost like being in Dusseldorf. Then I just found this in a bottle and tried it again. I enjoyed it even more. Same quality flavor profile, a bit darker color and a bit lighter body than I remember (both good traits) but equally good. I hope they keep bottling because I’ll keep buying. Those fancy little flip top bottles of Uerige I’ve been buying are expensive.

rich gold, large bubbled thin white ring. Papery nose, salt with sea water reminiscent of oysters. Flavor equally salty, light dough mid before a grainy wash finish, hints of honey throughout. Thin body glides over palate. Decent if the sea notes are odd.
355mL thanks to Travlr or beerandblues2. Pours a clear amber, weak white foam. Nose is malt, toffee, caramel. Taste is caramel, cereal grain, lemon tea. Thin, lemon palate.
12oz bottle pours a clear orange with one ring of white head. Nose is sweet, floral, honey, orange, a little bread. Flavor is malty, orange, bread. Clean finish.

12oz bottle, thanks Travlr. Crystal clear amber body with small off-white head. Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, some bread, light orange. Taste is medium sweet, bread, some caramel, earthy, light orange. Low carbonation, light-medium body, light stickiness.

Bottle at the brewpub. Poured an orange color, weak head, weak lacing. Aroma of nuts. Flavor followed with not enough depth in malts or hops especially to do the style justice. Just call your beer an amber and quit the alt moniker nonsene. Mouthfeel weak.

Bottle at home courtesy of sonnycheeba. Pours clear amber with a medium, frothy off-white head, medium retention with fair lacing. Aroma is toasted and nutty malt, dates and figs with earthy and spicy hops. Flavor is malt forward with light hops and bitterness and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

column2: North Woodstock, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Draft at brewpub. Multiple tastings. I have had everything they have to offer as we come here often for dinner while in the area. As with their food, the beer is OK but nothing spectacular. In fact, most of their beers are in my opinion, sub-par. This one was just OK.

column2: North Woodstock, New Hampshire, United States
column5: On tap @ the brewery, this was a clear, dark brown, minimal head. The aroma was sweet, fruity, with raisin, and the taste followed suit. There seemed to be too much carbonation in this one, but overall the flavor was nice.

Draft at Manheim, 4Q10. Pours hazy brown with medium head. Nose is earthy, nutty, malty. Flavor is bold, complex, with malt, earthy nuttiness, some backup hops, and a smooth palate with very well hidden alcohol.

On tap at the PA Renaissance Faire. Billed as the Skull Annihilator. Served in a platic cup. Poured a deeper and cloudy brownish color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, nutty, vanilla, and grains. Tastes of caramel, nutty, citrus, grains, and fruity. Smooth body with the alcohol content hidden.

Draught @ PA Renaissance Faire (as Skull Annihilator). Pours a translucent brown/orange/copper with a creamy off white head. Aroma of sweet grains, malts, caramel and some vanilla. Flavor was sweet and malty with some dark fruits, hints of banana, citrus and light yeast.

On tap at the PA Renaissance Faire(as Skull Annihilator). Appears a dark brown with a red hue when held to the light. The large, off-white head fades into a mild, 1/4" head. Tons of lace is sprayed all over the glass. Smell is malty, grainy, with hints of caramel, cocoa, and a touch of vanilla. Taste is of the mentioned aromas. Perhaps a bit of a blandness that could be a bit better but not bad. Mouthfeel is slightly unrefined but balanced for the most part with brown sugar and hop bitterness. Medium bodied with fine CO2 levels and a creaminess that comes out as it warms. This one actually gets better as it warms with mild traces of bananas and nut flavors that arise.

This is a big beer. The nose is redolent of toasty caramel malt and the alchohol is not at all hidden. Sweet and malty throughout, this beer ends with a quick upturn of bittering hops at the very end of the swallow, offsetting what might otherwise be an unruly sweet ending. Well crafted and easily in the league of its traditional German counterpart, a the caramel aftertaste lingers long and welcome.

On tap at Phantom Canyon poured a translucent dark brown nearly black with a lasting creamy tan head. Aromas of coffee, bitter chocolate, roasted malt and light smoke. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of bitter chocolate, coffee, vanilla, roasted malt and smoke with a smooth dry lingering smokey finish.

Draught at the brewery. Beer is very dark brown, nearly opaque. Head is moderate-to-large, light brown, creamy/frothy, mostly lasting head.The aroma is malty with moderate notes of roasted grain, chocolate, light note of caramel; Yeasty with a light note of dough, basement.The flavor is lightly-to-moderately bitter, trace acidic, lightly sweet with a moderately long, moderately bitter, lightly sweet finish. Slightly smoky and husky retros.The body is medium-to-full, the texture is velvety-to-creamy and the carbonation feels like nitro.

On tap at the Phantom Canyon Brew Pub. Poured a dark brown color with a small sized off white head. Aromas and of chocolate and roast. Tastes of bitter chocolate, roast, and light dark fruits. Body on the thin side for a stout.

Hand pulled at the brewery. Pours opaque with a creamy light tan head, lined creamy lacing. Aroma is coffee, heavy roasted chocolate malt (straw, meal), yeast (leather) and milky chocolate notes. Lactose, dark chocolate, creamy malt and leathery, bitter yeast, metallic prune notes, hops and bitter toast, medium sweetness. Dark bodied and oily.

Cask-conditioned. Served via a beer engine at Phantom Canyon Brewing. Black pour, with a dark tan head. Raisiny nose. Smooth, roasty, raisiny flavor. Very soft mouthfeel, very dry finish with a nice hint of hops. Very nice!
A surprisingly well balanced barley wine. Most brewpubs tend to have the over-the-top alcohol blast, not this. a fair amount of hops and a lot of caramelly malt. very solid

On tap at the Wayne, PA location. Poured a deep, deep orange color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of toffee, nuts, citrus and light alcohol. Tastes of caramel, toffee, nutty, soem dark fruits, and citrus. Medium alcohol bite in the finish.

KSBF 2006 RB after party. Sampled from a growler. Pours a translucent golden amber with a small off white that left some lacing. Aroma of dark fruits, caramel malt, grains, vanilla, sweet mince meat pie. Flavors of the same with hints of citrus from the hops.

Poured a dark, reddish brown color with a small, off white head that left light lacing on the glass. Aroma of dried fruits, some oxidation, sticky caramel malts, citrus fruits, and light alcohol. The taste was still sweet, more caramel, some brown sugar, citrus, lots of black cherries, wood, and a bitter hoppy finish. Some alcohol in there as well.

Brewed by John Rehm at John Harvard’s in Wayne, PA. Viscous deep amber body with a lush, velvety cream-colored head. Candied chestnut aroma with additional notes of brown sugar and premium maple syrup. Flavor is intensely nutty and very decadent. Great depth with abundant balancing qualities, including some nice savory elements and subdued hop characters. Thick and rich mouthfeel. Perfectly dialed in as a quintessential dessert beer, rather than something that hasn’t fully attenuated. This will be unbelievable in about 2 years, if it still exists.

It’s golden with a creamy, white head. The aroma has notes of grain, flower and malt. The flavor has a light sweetness and notes of grain, flowers, light straw and bread, and the finish is slightly dry.

bottle, Danke Frankenland! Clear golden colour, mid-sized, quickly diminishing head. Malty nose. Full-bodied, fruity and sweet malt flavours balanced off with aromatic and bitter hops with a shy herbal accent. Bitter-sweet character. This definitely tastes like a very good Bohemian Bilsener, like a good Czech 11° or 12°. A delicious Helles, really lovely, I thoroughly enjoyed that!

(bottle, received from pivnizub) Slightly hazy, golden colour with a short foamy white head. Dusty, sweet malty and honey-fruity aroma with hay and a delicate herbal hoppy shine. Light to medium body, crispy mouthfeel; moderately sweet malt-accented taste with a herbal hoppy background leading to moderately dry and well-rounded hoppy finish. Quaffable and moreish Helles.

Bottle: Pale, quite firm mid-sized fluffy head; sweet-grainy, a bit yeasty, nose with hints of hop-resins, tobacco (!) and wood; medium bodied, robust sweet-bitter flavour; a bit yeasty, short sweet-bitter, slightly fruity finish. An unusual, indivudual Helles, tasty, hearty and well rounded.

bottle, vielen Dank an Frankenland! Clear, amber coloured beer with a medium-sized off-white head. Malty-citrusy nose. Full-bodied, malty background with malt flavours and hints of roasted malts, citrus fruit and herbal hops. A very unusual, but nice Export that looks like a Vienna and tastes like a Landbier.

(bottle, from pivnizub - many thanks) Slightly hazy, amber coloured hue with floaties swimming around and a big fluffy, but non-persistent eggshell-coloured foam. Slightly dusty, spicy barnyard aroma with a touch of herbal hops. Spicy toast-malty taste upfront with minimal roasted notes, light to medium bodied with a crispy mouthfeel; moderately dry, slightly bitter finish with toasted malt and herbal hops. Absolutely uncommon Export with a rural Landbier character.

Bottle (purchased at the brewery) Amber coloured, thin off-white foamy layer; sweet-malty nose with a distinctive herbal hoppiness; medium bodied, soft MF, robust sweet-bitter flavour, sweetish finish, balanced by a lingering herbal hoppy aftertaste. A bit on the sweet side, but well made and pleasant. Not really a Helles, it should be better called "Landbier".............
Cask at cloisters. Pours golden, nose is grassy, nutty, taste is harsh, floral, thin.
Cask (4.5%), 1/2 pint, hand-pulled at Bon Accord, Glasgow on 28 Sep 2017: eggy aroma, pale golden with a thin white head and thick lacing, lemon, cereal, earthy flavour, creamy, quite dry,

Cask. Golden colour with a small white head. Aroma is bready and biscuity malts along with some herbs, grass and mild lemony and nectary notes. Flavour is bready malts, mild grains as well as some herbal, grassy and mildly floral hops to go with it. Nice bitterness to it.

Hand-pulled pint in The Wyndham Arms (their brewery tap in Salisbury) on 12th Oct 2013. Pale, straw blond in colour (like so many of their beers), with a thin white covering for a head. As the name might suggest, the aroma and taste were of a hoppy nature, but nothing was strong enough to give it a bitter or repugnant over hopped smell or taste. OK, but moving towards bland in my eyes. In fact I had to have a bottle of Entire Stout as my second beer, just to give my senses something to do.

Gravity cask at the Solihull CAMRA beer festival 2013. Poured a crystal clear straw colour with a bubbly white head. The aroma is stale malt. The flavour is weak bitter with a weak liqourice slightly caramel palate. It may have been a Hopfest but I don’t think the hops wanted to party! It’s refreshing enough, but I expected more.
Cask at Woking Festival 2011. A gold colour pour with plenty of hops and fruit in the aroma, the taste is sweet and fruity with a dry finish.
Cask conditioned, gravity dispensed at The Turf Tavern, Oxford. Gold with white head. Light, pine-like, resinous beer, wheatabix malts with the sprucey hops. Fairly pleasant and drinkable.
Cask at Twickenham beer festival. Gold with fruit and hop nose, sweetish body, herby finish, nice though it doesn’t live up to its name.
Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 21/09/2001 Straw golden coloured coloured with a pungent aroma and a hop finish.

Cask, The Crown, Nuneaton, 5%. Lagery golden pint. Clean, crisp and quenching. Struck matches, lemon and lingering crackerbread. Pairs up US hop character with that of a cask English golden ale quite tastily, but doesn’t live up to its name.
Nicht sehr überzeugend. Karamell, etwas Röstaromen , Süße, wenig herb. Kurzer Nachgeschmack, etwas wässrig. Alles in allem trinkbar, aber nicht mehr.
On tap at the brewpub. Trübes orange goldenes Bier mit einer geringen weißen schaumkrone. Geruch schwach malzig, wenig hopfig. Geschmack leicht malzig, fruchtig, gering Karamell.
Mild und leicht süß, dazu stellenweise grasig und erfrischend. Hier und da Kekse. Angenehmes, sehr trinkbares Piwo.

On tap at the brewpub. The beer has got a hazy brownish colour with an low head and medium body. Aroma of hops and straw with malt. Taste of hops, leaves, straw, light. honey, biscuits / cookies and malt. Hints of citrus fruits. Refreshing and quaffable, very easy and nice to drink.

Pours a hazy amber color with a small tan head. The smell is some fruit, roasted malt, hay. The taste follows the smell with some caramel and ending with a bit of dryness. Light in body with carbonation that is a tick below average.

Draft at the pub. Cloudy amber colour, smooth nose. The beer starts smooth and slightly sourish. Very easy to drink. Malt, grain. Hints of smooth breadiness. The aftertaste is smooth, yeasty soft, slightly malty-sourish. Very nice Brewpub-beer. --> 12/12/12/12

Draught at the brauhaus Cloudy dull amber color with compact head (not a Dunkel color). Nice delicate aroma, malt, hinted sweetness, wäldhonig. Malt flavor, a hint of cereals, and some residual sweetness; correct bitterness; it has a light touch of grassy hops. Strange beer, not a Dunkel by the book, it’s a pleasant beer, like a good Märzen, soft and lightly sweet.
Draught at the brewpub. Sweet toasted malt, toffee, with strong floral-honey notes in the aroma. Contrary to my expectations the beer was rather dry, no too flavourful and boring. Still drinkable.
Muffig dunkler Beginn, mild herb, wenig Karamellmalz. Süffig aber recht wenig aromatisch. Trinkbar isses... 8/7/8/7//7

(on tap at the brewpub) Slightly hazy, golden (not amber - Bernstein) colour with a short but stable foamy white head. Shy aroma, slightly herbal hoppy, slightly worty with faint fruity notes. Light-bitter flavour, light to medium body. Herbal hoppy taste on a soft malty base, quite balanced with a dry malty and light bitter finish. Average but pretty drinkable (03.10.06).
On tap at the brewpub. Trübes goldenes Bier mit einer ordentlichen weißen schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, spritzig fruchtig, leicht. Geschmack leicht bananig, hefig, schlanker Körper, süffig, ok!
Für seinen Stil recht angenehm und trinkbar. Frucht und Hefe in vernünftiger Balance, natürlich etwas süß. Schon ganz ok so.

On tap at the brewpub. The beer has got an unexpected hazylight brownish colour with an steady low head and medium to smooth body. Aroma of yeast and dough. Taste of yeast, bananas, cloves, dough and pizza dough.Flowery hints and a sweet finish. Good for its styleq

Draught at the brauhaus Cloudy blond color with creamy head. The aroma is spicy. Good wheat flavor, spicy, with light residual sweetness, and light banana touch. Modern, maybe a bit clumsy, but with pleasant components.
Hell hefiger Beginn mit angenehmer Herbe. Frisch, rund, süffig. Spritzig, zum Ende bleibend hefig. Ein gutes Standardweizen. 12/10/11/10//10

(on tap at the brewpub) Cloudy yellow colour with a short foamy white head. Sweet wheat-malty, quite strong banana aroma with a light sourish touch, no cloves. Sweetish, fruity flavour, wheat-accented taste with banana; light to medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel; fruity and wheaty finish. Unspectacular but solid Weizen (03.10.06).

Mild hopfiger Antrunk mit deutlich hausgebrautem Charakter. Im Mittelteil eher wässrig, wenig hopfig. Leicht malzig, zum Ende hin wird der Hopfen etwas würzig. Mir ist das Bier zu dünn. Test vom 12.8.2008 Noten: 8,3,7,6,-,6

Draught @ Zunftsuben, Prinzensrasse 64, D-47475 Kamp-Lintfort, Nordrhein-Westfalen, Germany. Light unclear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, fully - mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, moderate hoppy, perfume, citrus grass, citrus - lemon - lime. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration nad refrishing. Body is light to medium, texture is watery - oily, carbonation is soft. [20081212] [ Good BEER Guide Germany #805 ]

Draught Gold-yellow, very good white head. Volatile smell of cornflakes, honey, sweetish grain, but very subtle, discreet. Maize, corn, but in the taste no sweetness. Rather a bit grassy, greenery, and drier finish. Light to medium bodied, lots of grist slickness. Decent Helles. I’m told it can be better at the fount of origin.
Draught at BBF07. Hoppy aroma. The flavour also has some aroma hoppiness. Medium to high bitterness. Uncomplicated, but OK Helles with extra hops, which is nice.
A nice lager with a good bitter taste. Tasted on draft in Viersel Germany at bierfestival

(live on tap at the Zunftstuben, Kamp-Lintfort) Light-hazy, pale golden colour with a short foamy white head. Slightly sweet malty, citrousy-yeasty aroma with a distinctive spicy, herbal hoppy note. Bitter flavour with an initial sweetish touch. Soft malty base with a rather strong but pleasant herbal hoppiness; dry and bitter, herbal hoppy finish. Quaffable with its own character (03.10.06).
Draught at BBF07. Good caramelly aroma. Cloudy amber colour. Very small head. The flavour is also nicely caramelly, with a hint of pepper and some aroma hops. Quite good.

(live on tap at the Zunftstuben, Kamp-Lintfort) Light hazy, amber colour with a mid-sized off-white foamy head. Slightly sweet malty aroma with caramel and a touch of aromatic spicy hops. Sweet-bitter flavour, medium bodied with a smooth carbonation. Malty, slightly toasted taste with a medium-dry, bitter and slightly sour-fruity lingering malty and herbal hoppy finish. Not as good as the Dunkel but still highly quaffble (03.10.06).

(draught at the Zunftstuben, Kamp-Lintfort) This one was offered to me and DerDoppelbock by the brewer as his latest creation: Almost clear, pale golden colour with a fluffy white foamy head. Herbal hoppy, spicy aroma with minimal fruity accents. Rather strong herbal and spicy hoppy taste on a malty base; dry and bitter lasting finish (03.10.06).

Bottle poured reddish-brown in color with a minimum of head and very little lacing. Aromas of roasted malts. Taste is malty sweet up front with a lingering hop bitterness in the finish. Overall, this beer is nicely balanced between the sweet and bitter.

***old, recently found paper review done the week that this hit the stores, Nov 2006.*** Poured out a nice mahogany brew with a 3-4mm thick creamy light tan head that never dissapears. Lots of spotty lacing. Lots of toasted malts - very strong on the malts, some fruit (plum?) to be found in the aroma. The taste is all malts as it should be, slightly sweet tasting malts, very tasty with tons of flavour. Notable alcohol burn but it’s a mouth burn only and it is short lived. The bitterness is a touch too much but totally acceptable. The finish is decent but a bit too bitter. Near to full bodied, light to no carbonation and smooth overall. A decent brew, however it has near to zero shelf life. Drink fresh!

Dark dark ruby red almost brown looking body and a small skiff of a cap was produced constantly being rebuilt by columns of bubbles coming up from the bottom. The aroma seems sweet and packed with caramel malts, some noticeable hops, overall this is smooth and very pleasant I’m starting to notice some alcohol in the aroma the more the beer warms. Tasty dark malts with a hint of apple juice and a touch of alcohol in the finish, the aftertaste is sweet with the roast malt character lingering for a short while. Very tasty brew crisp, clean, lots of good flavor, highly enjoyable it looks like for once Alley Kat did good.
Bottle. Pours an opaque copper with a thin off-white head. Tastes of caramel and chocolate. creamy. one of the most excellent brews ever from Alley Kat.

A reddish brown ale with a thin off white head. Sweet caramle malt with notes of figs, burned sugar and molasses. In mouth, a nice sweet chocolate with notes of molasses, treacle candy, alcohol warmthé A rich lingering spiceyness of cloves and burned caramle linger in mouth. Glenn, you are a good brewer! Thanks to Presario for this one.

Lightly hazed bright auburn color with a quick, foamy, tan head. The nose is sweet with malt, brown sugar and a bit of molasses. A hint of raisin and alcohol round out the bouquet. The body is semi-sweet with a light bitterness. Light fruit in the middle with a hint of brown sugar sweetness. This is a nice, creamy doppelbock that ends with a splash of fruit and a light bitterness.

On draft at Hop N Brew - Hazy med brown color, white head. Looks tempting. Milk chocolate, bread, caramel, slightly sour nose. The mouth is a bit too sour, but the depth was great with bread, caramel, cherries, milk chocolate all dancing together. Alcohol is well hidden. The finish reminds me of a cherry chocolate milk shake Too sour overall, but getting past that, this beer is phenomenal.

Bottle: rough pour puts a brilliant clear cola-red lager with a massive rocky tan cap into the bock glass. Great lacing on the glass ( lotsa protiens) Marvelous aroma: bready , herbal, musty with dried fruit and some cocoa.....pungent layered and balanced. Good solid malt spine, silky mouthfeel, medium-full body, drinkable malty character. Up front a good chew on spiced raisin bread, mid-palate the hop mixture creates some more layered flavors; herbs, nuts spice, cocoa...then the finish is excellent...this chewy malt monster dries out in a light herbal bittering and a warmth generated by the alcohol...light cocoa-bready aftertastes...like unsweetened chocolate. Overall impression: Not as rich or full bodied as some doppels but a very drinkable flavorful doppelbock...very satifying and warming, mellow but layered, malty but easy to have more than a couple...one of the best I’ve tasted from North American brewers.

Deep copper in colour with medium carbonation. Fairly malty aroma, with secondary notes of sweedish berries, caramel, and cola. Quite bready in the mouth with a bit of black pepper and loads of smooth munich malts. Thick mouthfeel. Perhaps not as overwhelmingly boozy as doppelbocks can be, but I liked that it was a bit on the light side for the style. Good stuff indeed!

Deep ruby copper, modest head with scant retention. Milk chocolatey aromas, a little earthy, a little pruney. A nice mouthful of flavours, including chocolate, faint coffee (that would make it mocha I guess), and some vague stewed fruit that lends a lighter touch to the overall feel. This is excellent, but not as dense or rich as the gold-standard Celebrator.

Draft: Curious raisin and yeast aroma. Greenish dark copper color with a medium head. It has a nice initial tangy punch that gives way to a pleasant moderate hoppiness. I have found that the quality of hops this brewer uses is top knotch. It’s a tad tinny, but finishes cleanly.

On tap at Alt Platz. Color was a dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma was malty with floral hops and a bit nutty. Flavor was a nutty chocolate with a nice hop bitterness in the finish. Keep up the good work Tom.
On tap at the brewpub. Dark brown color with no head. Aroma and taste of coffee and chocolate, really dark for a amber ale.
Draft at the brewpub, 10/28/06: Looks like a flat coke ... and kinda tastes like one too. Dirty sock aroma. Bit of a sour tone, like sweet malt soda. No thanks.
On tap at the brewpub. Deep clear brown with a small tan head. Nutty chocolate nose, herbal hops. Mild chocolate and nut flavors, hops come to the fore in the finish, a herbal bitterness. Very nice!
Sedona Bronze Ale. Clear, dark brown/bronze. Minimal head. Nutty aroma maybe a bit of raisin, sweet to taste, a bit smoked flavor and a light sweet chocolate aftertaste. Good stuff.

Tall(24oz)- purchased onsite. Was not on tap yet, but the bartender pulled me one from the cooler( Very Nice Gesture) They call it a Brozne- a hybrid brew based on the dark almost reddish brown(bronze) appearance-Excellent aroma- nicely hopped-immediate bite on the palate then a smooth rush of maltiness with a touch of sweetness- one thing I will say about this brewey is their ability to balance the beers with hop/malt tones without over powering- the beer is very pleasant and different - Unique would be the term. Once again I left happy with that all natural buzz from a great brew. Also had a pizza- and it was phenominal!!!! Dough for the pies is made onsite also- a 24oz superior beer and a great pie for less than a movie- this place floundering- I beg to differ!!!! The impertinence this brewery is getting is a disgrace- and those that are spreading it should be throttled about the head and neck reagion! Well done Alt Platz!!! Keep up the good beers!!!!!
Draft. Murky amber brown color, thin white head. Aroma of loghtly toasted caramel. Taste is toast, blackbpepper. Inoffensive.
Draft @ beertemple. Aroma is spicy hops, Flavour is medium hop bitterness, quite spicy, bergamot. Nice.

On tap @ Schouskjelleren, Oslo. Hazy deep orange body, small off-white head. Aroma is grass, resin, syrup and hints of herbs. Taste is grassy herbal syrupy tones with some rather unexpected (but fairly pleasant) hints of salty licorice. Moderate bitterness, light body. Comes across as slightly watery, but pretty OK nevertheless.
Tap @ beer temple. Hazy dark orange pour, thin off_white head. Aroma of fruity spicy hops and some tea. Flavor is bitter hops, somewhat malty spices and citrus. Nice brew.
On tap at Beer Temple. Nice amber body with slight head. Nose is malty and toffee and caramel. Taste is also really nice of malts and caramel. Some hops and bitter in there as well. Nice balance.

On tap at The Beer Temple, Amsterdam 29.02.12 Pours copper in colour, clean as a whistle with a white head. Bitter and without the heavy maltiness I associate with some American beers, though this does suffer a little from being consumed shortly after a peppermint. . Soft in mouth with a light lemony surge, tasty but not too exciting. A6 A4 T7 P4 Ov13 3.4

Draft @ Fermentoren, Copenhagen. Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy caramel aroma. Fruity malty weak hoppy piney flavor with weak hints of caramel. Has a fruity malty weak hoppy bitter finish.

On tap. Pours an opaque amber with a frothy, dense and creamy off-white head with a nice retention leaving a neat lacework as it dissipates. Mellow, fruity aroma. Fairly light body, a dry fruitiness and a little nuts while the hops come late leaving a dry finish. Pleasantly quaffable. 240212

On tap @ Beer Temple. Color is amber, unclear, yeasty. Off white head, sticky. Aroma’s: Resin, sweet’n’sour fruit, pine needles, laurel. Flavor is bitter. Medium body. Finishes heavy bitter, but also with a hint of caramel. Not really balanced but nice anyway.
Hazy orange with a lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and light hoppy - grass. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate biter. Dry and modertae bitter finish. 160212

Color amarillo dorado, cristalina. Dos dedos de espuma con buena retención. Aroma a cereal, notas de húmedad y verdura hervida. Gusto a cereal, ligero maíz y humedad, regusto dulce. Cuerpo acuoso. A pesar de tener elementos a priori de defecto, la cerveza no estaba mal del todo.
Bottle shared at a tasting at troubles' place. Thanks mom for this bottle! Clear golden. Corn, a bit of vegetables, sweetish, graininess, bitterish finish, light-bodied.
At Dror's place, pours yellow with a small head, aroma of caramel, lemon, malt, flavor is slightly bitter with herbs, medium bodied
Coming from Iceland myself, I have to say this one is totally ok. Best coming from tap.
Nice light grains. Clear gold with a decent white head. Grains and a crisp finish. Quite solid.
One of the best lagers in Iceland. Great filling, a bit bitter, nice aroma. Quite strong but definitely a beer that's nice to drink. You have to have it on tab. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

[8875-20161110] 330mL bottle. Toasted biscuit leafy aroma. Clear, golden orange body with a quick foamy white head. Straw sweet grains flavour. Medium body. Fair. (4/3/4-/2/10) 2.3 (c/o Timo, w/ blankboy, jercraigs) Overheard: "The only thing that’s touching anything is my upper thighs."

[My bottle (330ml) shared with j&m] Pours a clear deep golden-orange with a small lasting frothy white head. Aroma of grain and buckwheat along with vegetal notes. Malty and grainy flavour with a light bitter finish. Average bodied. Just passable.

Keg at Kaldi Bar - Reykjavik. Pours clear yellow-gold with a creamy, white head. The nose holds crispy pale cereal, a little dough, straw. Light sweet flavour more crisp cereal, pale biscuits, mild bitter hay. Light bodied with average carbonation. Decent balance in the finish, more of the same - crispy biscuits and cereal. Nice simple lager.

2016-11-10. Crisp golden body, small off white head. 3+ Aroma is sweet and roughly grainy. Flavour is similarly rough, sweet cereal with a kiss of caramel. Lightly oxidized. Smooth average to light bodied palate, soft carbonation. 3+ Not great unfortunately. 4/3/4/3/8 Bottle courtesy of Timo from Finland.

Another reddish brown ale with a thin off white head. In aroma, pumpkin spices, nutmed and allspices. In mouth, a light sweetish malt with pumpkin pie spices added, probably the Raven with spices, very light. On tap at brewpub, Oct. 10 2009.

On tap at Paddys Pub in Wolfville, N.S. Amber colour with a thin white head. Sweet aroma. Flavour is sweet and smooth, hint of ginger and nutmeg. Smooth texture. a little dull but Pumpkin Ale is hard to perfect.
cloudy amber appearance with a fluffy off white head. the aroma is spicy air. i caught a wheaty -banana-y flavor. not a bad beer overall, but the banana was a bit overpowering to me.

Pristine polished copper color with a merging tan wrung for the head. Aromatic trepidation from the get-go, unveiling ginger, honey butter and nectar, sickingly seeping from the comb. Candi sweetness has not dried out. Unflinching, resinous sweetening is a match made in heaven for the sugar that failed to ferment. Clover. Honey over. Some cotton pricks on the palate add insult to injury as a creamed apple blend finishes the task at hand. Thanks for bringing a growler, Brigadier!

Saison #5 I attempted to consume ’blind’ at the Pewaukee tasting but the "blind" phase of the tasting was starting to break down. Clear, light amber color. Wonderful blended aroma of hops, yeast. Mildly sweet, some hop flavor, sourness. Lacking the barnyard edge of other Saisons sampled tonight. Perhaps not the most traditional Saison with the notable hop presence but one of the most enjoyable I have had tonight.

Growler. The beer pours to a very clean amber/orange body with an ultra-thin white head. The aroma is sweet. Light brown sugar, clover, banana, and spice. The flavor is clover, light brown sugar, earthy yeasts, and star fruit. Very unique flavor. I’m digging it. The palate is moderately bodied, nicely textured, and creamy.

On tap at Flossmoor This was the first of the special releases. Since the others were either hop bombs or very dark complex beers I opted to start with the saison. I have not had enough to really decide how much I like the style but this was not a bad specialty. I might be bringing a growler to an upcoming tasting to see if other people agree. Aroma / Appearance - The hazel colored body is covered by a slight amount of head. The nose is horse blanket with a low hop profile. Underneath are some fruity notes of peach cobbler and cherries sitting by a slow burning fire. Flavor / Palate - Thick chewy molasses coats the mouth upon the first sip. As it fades in comes caramel, chocolate and a light amount of sourness. Cherry licorice greets the throat before a Robotussin finish dampens things a bit. This is definitely more of a sipping beer than anything before it and with some uniqueness that makes it stand out.
On tap at brewpub in January. Clear golden with good head. Lots of belgian yeast in taste and aroma. A bit sour. OK.

Draught. Pours clear dark yellow with an average off-white creamy head, mostly lasting, good lacing. Aroma is average malt (hay, straw), light hops (grass), average yeast (sweat, earth) with notes of bubble gum and pineapple. Medium bodied, oily texture, soft carbonation and a bitter finish. Average duration, moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness; sour milk notes.
Light yellow color small white head cherries? smells like cherries. Malty. Tastes like wet crackers. Easy to drink with a short finish. Funky feed bag.

I had a butcher of this beer at Flossmoor station. I thought it was pretty good. This beer poured a handsome golden color with a slight amount of haziness and abundant head. This saison’s aroma is mild and a mix of yeastiness and biscuit aromas. The taste was more of the same, with a lot of yeastiness, some isoamly acetate (banana) notes, and abundant spiciness (although I can’t put my finger on just what it is). Quite good. Mouthfeel is crisp and clean. I thought this beer was very drinkable.

On tap @ Flossmoor Station: Pours a yellow amber with a tall head, nice aromas yeast wheat, spices, apples and fruit. Balanced flavors, make this a good session beer. Pears and fruit make this sweet at first spices, biscuitty, lightly bitter and finishing dry. A tasty beer.

From the tap, served in a dimpled goblet. Poured a golden, orangey copper (maybe amber, they keep the bar area so dark it can be hard to make things out sometimes) with a foamy white head. Aromas of citrus, orange zest and lemon rinds, slightly floral with a caramel maltiness in the background. Good carbonation and a crisp, creamy smooth medium-light bodied mouthfeel. Tastes of caramel malts with some buttery toffee, amarillo hops, of course, citrusy, oranges and lemon rinds, a good IPA bitterness on the tongue, and a sour hoppy balanced by a sweet malty finish. A good, very quaffable IPA from Rhodell’s.

This one hit the spot. The clear golden-copper body sports a creamy white head which emits an aroma of tart oranges, lemon zest, tangerines, and orange blossoms over a trace of the sweet malt base. In the flavor, the contast between the caramel & toffee and the hoppy bitterness is striking. They clash, but manage to merge into a satifying taste in the mouth. The prolonged bitter finish made this hophead happy. Very well done. John S. Rhodell Brewery, Peoria, IL

Interesting look for a wit, very gold body (hence the name), quite hazy, with a thick creamy head. The aroma is a skillful blending of tart oranges, wheat, corriander, a sprinle of lemon, and some mystery spices. This brew truly dances across the tongue, peppery and spicy, the corriander growing stonger. The various flavors work well together, the citrus dominating with the spices playing a strong secong, challenging for dominance as the ale warms. A very good example of the style. John S. Rhodell Brewery, Peoria, IL
