Darker blond coloured beer with some light carbonation and a short white head. Light fruity aroma. Full sprankling palate. Finish is fruity, some tart hints (grapes?) Very special.

Bottle, bought @ Delirium, Brussels. Pale, hazy yellow-golden with a medium, fizzy, white head. Aroma has lots of sweet green grapes, light peach, some sweet malts and oranges. High carbonation, fine mouthfeel even if the spritziness does ruin it a bit. Flavour is mild, light Belgian sugar with a liqourice touch. Lots of sweetish grapes, cucumber, oranges. A hint of tartness with grape and apple peel. Quite nice, really.
Clear blond coloured beer wit small white head and only few carbonation. A hoppy fruity aroma. Full sparkling palate. Finish is fruity ending rather dry. Sweet beer with dry aftertaste.
gold blond coloured body with a white head a spicy yeasty fruity hoppy aroma a spicy yeasty fruity little sour taste with a sour bitter finish

(Bottled) Hazy golden with a large, foamy and lasting head. Neutral-malty, slightly grape-vinous aroma with some honey. Quite acidic, slightly sour flavor with grapefruits pretty evident. Some fresh hops are present, but they get a bit buried under the grapes. Yeast brings more sweet fruitiness to balance the grape sourness, and after that it’s actually pretty nice. Medium-bodied, very foamy-carbonated and moderately acidic palate. A quite nice experiment from Alvinne, but not up to their better brews.

A beer named after 2 persons Bachus god of wine and Arnoldus, Saint of the biers. A beer with 15% grapes. The smell of grapes you can find , but there is also the smell of hop. A little touch of bitterness make this beer till an average but good beer

Bottle. This golden-coloured beer had a rush getting out of the bottle, so quite a bit ended up on the kitchen table. Cloudy with a lot of sediment. Cloudy. Huge, rich head. Initially sweet candy sugar aroma, but vegetables soon takes over. Quite sweet flavours, some vegetable flavours, but also hints of grape juice towards the finish. Good carbonation. Interesting experiment.

Bottled. Unclear golden colourd. Dense white small head. Quickly diminishing. Sweetness, yeast and fruits in the aroma. Flavour is a bit grapy. Has fruits and sweetnes and loads of sugar. Medium bodied. A bit dry. Ends on a very sweet note. Thanks to Joris for this beer.

A Mes rate: Bottle sampled at ZBF but the thanks go to Mads for breaking out the bottle. VERY sweet stuff. I found it rather artificial and spicy. Plenty of hops in there and obvious berries but the fake sugaryness seems to mask everything. Something a little sickly in the nose. Very swift, almost vanishing blueberry finish.
Tap at Bles, end Bottle, 33 cl. Tasted it saterday and sunday. Dark yellow-amber color. Hoppy, little bitter. Original beer and good !

33 cl. flip-top bottle @ home, bought @ Edeka, Kleve. Clear light golden with a big white head. Grassy grainy aroma. Taste is medium bitter with some metallic notes and a long bitter finish. A typical middle of the road German pilsener: solid but unexciting

26.06.2019 -- 0.33l flip-top bottle from rewe hennig in münster, bb 04.10.2019. pours a clear pale golden with a frothy head. mild aroma of grass and some grains. flavour of grass and grains. some bitterness is present, not too bitter however. smooth round mouthfeel. clean and drinkable, but nothing outstanding.

Sampled from 0.33 l bottle from 'Rudat', best before August 2018. Clear, golden with a medium large, frothy, slowly diminishing, white head. Sweetish, slightly grassy-spicy aroma of grains and some straw. Slightly sweet, moderately bitter, slightly grassy-spicy taste of grains and some straw, followed by a short, moderately bitter, slightly grassy-spicy and moderately dry finish. Thin to medium body, smooth and slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Not bad but far from great, way too tame for a Pils, disappointing.

0,33 l swing top bottle. Pale golden, little bit unclear, nearly two finger off white head. Grassy and hay on the nose. Taste has some caramel, grassy with sweetness, low malt in the background. Low bitterness for a Pilsener. Medicore.

330 ml bottle. BB 4/O/16. From a trade with Erzengel. Vielen Dank Gabriel! Clear pale golden color with a small white head. Dry malt, mild sweetness and grain in the aroma. Dry grainy malt, harsh grassy hops and playdough in the flavor.

Pours cristal golden with quickly deminishing head. Nose is metallic and straw. Taste is bitter grassy but a bit dull. Mouthfeel is quite bubbly, finish ia dry... And yeah... makes me reflux half the way... Odd and disappointing
0,33l Flasche. Gelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Toller malziger Geruch; schmeckt sehr malzig, eher dezent gehopft.
0,33 l swing top bottle golden, clear, frothy and creamy white foam head. cereal, herbs, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, slick feel, average carbonation,

Bottle. Clear pale body with medium frosty head, evading quickly. Aroma is grainy, malty, hoppy. Taste has higher noble bitterness, lasting across the after taste with light malty sweet touch. Body is full, medium carbonation.
Geruch nach Malz, im Geschmack dann restsüß, Cara-Anteile. Im Abgang wenig bitter, kaum Hopfen. "norddeutsches Pils" geht anders.

16 ounce can into tulip glass, canned on 4/9/2019. Pours slightly hazy deep golden/orange/amber color with a 1 finger dense and rocky off white head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Thick foamy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of big red grapefruit, tangerine, lemon, peach, pear, pineapple, apricot, mango, melon, citrus peel/zest, light peppercorn, pine, honey, toasted biscuit, light caramel/nutty, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of citrus/fruity/fairly earthy hops and dark/bready malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big red grapefruit, tangerine, lemon, peach, pear, pineapple, apricot, mango, melon, citrus peel/zest, light peppercorn, pine, honey, toasted biscuit, light caramel/nutty, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness. Light-moderate pine, citrus peel/rind, herbal, floral, grassy, peppery bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of red grapefruit, tangerine, lemon, peach, pear, pineapple, apricot, mango, melon, citrus peel/rind, peppercorn, pine, honey, toasted biscuit, light caramel/nutty, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a while. Great complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/fruity/fairly earthy hops and dark/bready malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance, and no cloying/astringent flavors after the finish. Light-moderate increasing dryness from lingering bitterness. Medium carbonation and medium-plus body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready/grainy/sticky, and fairly resinous/rindy balanced mouthfeel that is great. Minimal warming alcohol for 8.2%. Overall this is an excellent IPA. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/fruity/fairly earthy hops and dark/bready malt flavors; very smooth and easy to drink for the ABV, with the mellowly bitter/resinous'/drying finish; nicely soft feel, and not aggressive. Feels like Centennial/Cascade. Very juicy, vibrant, and fairly dank earthy hops; with a great balanced dark/bready malt backbone. Light residual sweetness with lingering resin dryness. A very enjoyable offering, and spot on classic tasting Midwest style example.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a darker golden, clear, with a white head. Juicy grapefruit and orange citrus hop aroma with pine. Flavor is juice and sticky grapefruit and pine hoppiness. Really great stuff. Something must have changed in the years since this was last rated!

Easy to drink with food. Mild hop aroma with some pine and citrus. It had an amber color with a small head. It had an average weight mouth feel with a crispness on the finish. It wasn’t hoppy enough to fall under the India pale ale category but a pretty good blend of flavors. However, there was a harsh bitterness at the end that was a little too sharp. A decent offering.

Black Lotus’ beers are far below average and their IPA is one their best because it is just below average...one one of the few drinkable beers they make. Update: tried this again and it look like a glass of pea soup with crud floating in it...disgusting.
Sample at the brewpub on 7/23/11. Clear amber/copper pour with a thin off-white head. Floral hop aroma with pale and amber malts. Malty flavor with floral hops, slight pine and a grapefruit finish.

Pours a clear golden color with a thick white head, not too bad, the aroma is citrus and piney hops, the taste is decent but not remarkable, it doesn’t have the balance I look for in a great IPA, it’s a little one dimensional. The palate is a little thin for my liking but not bad it is at least refreshing. All in all this isn’t bad, but uninspired, they were a little safe on this one.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear orange with a thick white head. Aroma of citrus, hop oils, and caramel malt. Flavor of citrus and floral hops -- this had a very nice hop character and was plenty hopped for an APA (that’s what it was labeled at the brewpub, although it certainly tasted more like an IPA). A solid hoppy pale ale and probably their best offering. 8/4/8/4/15 [3.9/5]
i’m not that experienced with IPA’s, and maybe a lot of them just taste the same to me. i thought this was drinkable. the only beer they had on tap that actually had any bite.

Lost my notes on this one. This was, however, much better than expected. Although my tasting was at a festival, during the consumption of several beers. Alas, my scribbles are illegible, but the numbers stand
Draft pint at the brewpub. Golden amber with a sudsy head. The beer is taken over by a bit of tea-leaf character, along with a flat corny malt. Not horrible, but not real good. (#3820, 1/26/2010)

16 ounce can into tulip glass, canned on 4/9/2019. Pours slightly hazy deep orange/copper/amber/light reddish color with a 1 finger dense and rocky cream colored head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of caramel, brown sugar, toffee, brown bread dough/crust, and toasted biscuit; with lighter notes of nuttiness, vanilla, cocoa, peach, plum, pear, red apple, herbal, wood, floral, grass, pepper, and yeast/toasted earthiness. A bit too fruity/yeasty aromas, but not overwhelming. Slight touch of diacetyl. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/bready malts, light-moderate fruity yeast, and light earthy hop notes; with solid strength. Taste of big caramel, brown sugar, toffee, brown bread dough/crust, and toasted biscuit; with lighter notes of nuttiness, vanilla, cocoa, peach, plum, pear, red apple, herbal, wood, floral, grass, pepper, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Mild herbal, floral, woody, grassy, spicy bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of caramel, brown sugar, toffee, brown bread dough/crust, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, vanilla, cocoa, peach, plum, pear, red apple, herbal, wood, floral, grass, pepper, and yeast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Great complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malts, light-moderate fruity yeast, and light earthy hop flavors; with a solid malt/bitterness balance, and no cloying flavors after the finish. Lightly increasing dryness from lingering bitterness. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/silky/bready/grainy, and lightly sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is great. Minimal warming alcohol for 6%. Overall this is a very nice amber ale. All around nice complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malts, light-moderate fruity yeast, and light earthy hop flavors; very smooth and easy to drink with mildly bitter/drying finish, great soft feel. Very well rounded and nicely rich malt complexity, restrained fruity English yeast, and solid earthy hop presence/balance. Light residual sweetness with lingering dryness. A very enjoyable offering, and well made style example. Feels like more of an English style, but still delicious.

Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a ruddy burnt amber color with a finger’s worth of white foamy head. Slowly dissipated. Sly stringy lace. The aroma had some light fruity hops, mainly sweet with a nice caramel/toffee backbone. Super light grassy hops. The flavor leaned towards the maltiness. Nice malty smooth aftertaste with the same sort of finish. The feel was between light and medium bodied with a pretty good sessionability about it. Good carbonation. ABV felt good too. Overall, good amber lager worthy of having again if I could get it.
Sample at the brewpub on 7/23/11. Clear red pour with a medium beige head. Malty nose with dank earthy hops. Flavor starts malty with dank tobacco character before an earthy hop finish.

Tap at the brewpub. The beer has a deep, slightly hazy amber pour. Light munich malt sweetness and a touch of medium crystal malt sweetness. Fairly herbal with an assertive bitterness. Light fruit on the finish.
Tap @ Black Lotus - Orange pour, some toffee, caramel malts. Smooth body, some nutty notes. Not bad.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours brown/amber with a white head. Aroma of caramel malt and sweet fruit. Flavor of sweet fruit (mostly apple) and lots of malty notes. Perhaps not the most exciting amber ale but it was pretty tasty and quite drinkable. 6/4/7/4/14 [3.5/5]
i think i can sum this beer up with a single word: bland. since when was a 5.5% amber anything but bland? it’s a boring style, and this one was extra boring.
This beer can be very good, on occasion, but more often it is very flat and lacks flavor and body.

On tap: The aroma is very light with some fruity caramel notes. It’s a transparent amber with a small off-white head. The flavor starts lightly fruity with some faint caramel. It finishes with a mild citrus hoppiness with some faint roastiness.
I was disappointed. Good head and Lacing with a light red color. Heavier malts and a real earthy undertone. Nothing distinctive stands out. The least enjoyable of the ones I sampled this date.

On tap at the brewpub. There is nothing good about this beer. No aroma, weird cloudy appearence, and dirty dishwater taste - just plain nasty. Did not/could not finish this. Hard to believe that someone that owns/operates a brewpub could make beer this bad and not even be aware of it.

Sample at the brewpub on 7/23/11. Clear yellow, almost no color at all pour with a thin white head. Aroma of dank malt that’s very faint and watery. Malty and crisp flavor with a thin, dank and watery finish. Not my thing, but could be a great gateway into craft beer for the macro lager drinker.

It pours a clear yellow with a not quite fizzy white head, not too bad. The aroma is grassy hops with a little caramel malts, quite boring. Taste follows the nose, not bad but uninteresting. Palate is watery and crisp. I know Black Lotus can do better, they make this beer for the sole purpose of attracting the BMC drinker.

Tap at the brewpub. Very pale straw-coloured pour. The nose is lightly grainy with a soft herbal hoppiness. Really, remarkably, incredibly bland. It’s not really bad per se, it’s just so incredibly boring.
Tap @ Black Lotus - arouma is skunky and grassy. Caramel malts, smooth. Hops are a bit offensive and dry. blah.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear light yellow with a thick white head. Aroma of sweet fruits and grainy malt. Flavor of sweet fruit and light sweet fruits (although it is not too sweet overall). Dry and drinkable. A pretty good pilsener. 6/4/7/3/13 [3.3/5]
On tap at Black Lotus. Neon yellow in color. Aroma is grain with sweet sugar smell, maybe hits of peppermint. Taste is 1 step mostly grainy through out little bitterness. Easy drinker.

On tap: The aroma consists of light lemon and grass. It’s a transparent gold/yellow with a small white head. The flavor starts with some light pilsner sweetness and a hint of lemon. It finishes with some light grassy bitterness. Not a big pilsner fan, but this is pretty solid.
While I’m not a pilsner person (too much American pilsner has made me sour on the beer), this one is ok. Light as many decent pilsners are (i.e. Bell’s).

column1: Black Lotus Black Bottom Oatmeal Stout
column5: Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a dark brown color with a good finger’s worth of foamy off white head. Dissipated gently to leave some clingy stringy lace. The aroma had some sweet milk chocolate, gentle Irish coffee creamer, roasted coffee beans and some dark chocolate nibs. The flavor blended very nice between the roast and the sweet fully encasing all of the aromas together to present a very nice aftertaste (what every oatmeal stout should be going for). Quick roasty to semi-sweet and light bitter finish. The feel was medium bodied with a fair sessionability about it. Oatmeal helps smooth out the roast which tried to bring some abrasion to my tongue. Overall, remember in Indiana Jones movie when Belloq points to the ark of the covenant and says "this, this is history?" Yes, this is what I say, "this, this is the oatmeal stout you all have been looking for. Make your own history and get this beer.

column1: Black Lotus Black Bottom Oatmeal Stout
column5: Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is chocolate malt, and flavor is chocolate and traces of sweet vanilla. Has a creamy mouthfeel. Pretty good.

column1: Black Lotus Black Bottom Oatmeal Stout
column5: I’m not usually an oatmeal stout fan, but this is really good on nitro. It has a smooth finish.

column1: Black Lotus Black Bottom Oatmeal Stout
column5: Pretty average stuff. It had the typical dark brown stout color with a tan head. The aroma was a slight roasted malts with a little bit of coffee. It had an average weight palate that was a little creamy from the oatmeal. The carbonation was a little low as this was the nitro version. Decent roasted malt flavor with a slight hop bitterness. Easy to drink but not unique.

column1: Black Lotus Black Bottom Oatmeal Stout
column5: On nitro at brewery. The pour is black with a creamy head. The aroma is nice and malty. The taste is creamy and smooth. Not tons of flavor but decent. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Black Lotus Black Bottom Oatmeal Stout
column5: Not as good as the porter, but decent. On tap, dark, notes of coffee and chocolate, overall very good

column1: Black Lotus Black Bottom Oatmeal Stout
column5: On tap at the brewpub...thin, watery black beer. The only hints of hints of coffee and chocolate were in the description. Not good.

column1: Black Lotus Black Bottom Oatmeal Stout
column5: Pours an extremely dark brown with a tan head, looks pretty good. Smells of roasty malts, bitter chocolate and coffee pretty good but a little restrained. Taste follows the nose, it seems like it could be better again feels a bit restrained. The palate isn’t what I expected, it’s a little thin and watery, they really need to make this thicker, all in all it’s decent, but go with the imperial stout, they really went all out on that one.

column1: Black Lotus Black Bottom Oatmeal Stout
column5: Sample at the brewpub on 7/23/11. Darkest brown pour with a thick tan head. Roasty aroma to the point of char with some light chocolate notes as well. Roasted malt flavor with chocolate and a burnt coffee finish.

column1: Black Lotus Black Bottom Oatmeal Stout
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours black with a thick, foamy tan head. Aroma of roasted, smoked, and charred malt with some parmesean cheese. Flavor of chalky bitter chocolate and a weak malt base. A decent stout but nothing special. 6/4/6/3/13 [3.2/5]

Growler / Tap. Waitress mistakenly gave this instead of the requested IPA. Disappointed from the first few ounces to hit the bottom of the glass. Pours like water, looks like yellow water and tastes very bland. Bud Select may have something on this.

Wow! Very light golden color with some lacing. Nice balance of flavors that go much deeper than any light I’ve had. An amazingly thick mouthfeel. I’d actually serve this one! One of their best offerings.
Cask at the Wharf. Weakly spicy aroma. Clear chestnut colour. Refreshing teaish flavour, sourish with some cardboard. Some hoppiness which is also teaish and fruity.

Cask (handpump), Duck & Drake, Leeds, October 2006. Darkish amber colour with a thin white head. Toasty malt dominates, accompanied by undercurrents of soft berry fruit. Enough bitterness to provide a decent counterpoint. Solid stuff.
Cask at Charlies. Amber coloured. Malty and fruity aroma. Sweetish flavour of berries with a slightly bitter and hoppy finish. Decent bitter.

[Cask at Charlie’s Bar, Copenhagen] A hazy amber beer with a thin tan head. The aroma is light with a sweet malty base on which light notes of berries appears. The flavor is sweet malty with strong notes of berries, leading to a dry bitter end.

This beer disappointed massively. Once upon a time there were a number of good quality squires beers. Now they have been caught up, left behind and their standards have dropped. None of the desirable Belgian qualities are there in the aroma and the only flavour on display is the 8.5% of alcohol. Disappointing again Dr Hahn.
22nd November 2009 ChrisOs Kook Tasting. Clear golden beer. Light carbonation. Sweet malt and a little fruit. Pretty authentic tasting tripel. Not bad.
Bottle at Chriso’s Kook Tasting 09. Thanks to Kook. Pale gold, cardboard. Some fruit. Bit of peach. Poorish

Once again, the encyclopedic knowledge of the waitstaff at this establishment is quite staggering. After ordering this beer I asked if they had a description of the beer. ‘Huh? Its like, uh, a Belgian beer’ (Big smile at being able to connect an abbey beer with Belgium. OK, anything else? ‘Well, what does it say on the sign around the tap (facing me)? Candy Sugar and Spice say I. ‘Oh well that’s what it is then. And its 8.05%’. Don’t you mean 8.50%?. ‘Yeah, that’s what I said.’ What about the hops used, yeast, any special malts? ‘Would you like a middy or a schooner?’ Denial of a question ever being asked being perhaps the best response in these circumstances. While writing this the beer is sitting in front of me, looking like a Duvel in its body but with only a thin crema of a head. There is a spiciness of nose but not very prominent. The mouthfeel is immediately sharp, and while clearly alcoholic, it doesn’t have the balance of a Belgian tripel, even a common one like the Leffe. I always appreciate brewers who give something different a go, even though the release of this style for a beer in the month when all other brewers are trotting out their Oktoberfestbiers is a little odd. Expectations of all brewpubs these days may be sometimes unfairly high but if the brewers hold themselves out to be premium beer producers while charging the prices they do the public has a right to expect top quality and integrity of style. I late spoke with the bar manager who was unable to give me any extra information about the beer, but that Chuck (Hahn) and Regan (Pallandi) were not giving up any information about the ingredients of the beer. Why not?

Hah! I thought I rated this already. Bottle. Smells like a fest beer. Darker hue pale. Nice head and lots of lively co2 visible in the brew, hope it carries over to the palate. Each slug is the same, it wants to be a decent fest beer but the middle turns into an unpleasant higher alky astringent annoying kick of bitterness, quite surprising in its power. It lingers in your moth for such a long time. This gottah be way more than 30 IBU, no shit and its difficult too! Grinding gooch, gook, gringo, guido, grahzilla. Very unwanted sharply bitter finish, whew.

12 ounce bottle into dimpled mug, bottled in fall 2015. Pours crystal clear deep orange/copper color with a 1 finger dense off white head with great retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of big honey, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/bready malt and earthy hop notes; with good strength. Taste of big honey, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate herbal/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of honey, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, grass, light pepper, and herbal/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt and earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Very clean on lager flavors with minimal yeast ester notes present. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready, and slightly sticky mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent Oktoberfest style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt and earthy hop flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink. This was a touch hoppy for the style, but everything else was spot on. A very enjoyable offering.

12oz bottle, thanks to robotopera. Clear kind of light brown color. Bigger off-white head. Good nuttiness, toastiness to the aroma. Medium body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. Mild slick. Good fullness to the texture. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter. Pretty solid, tasty oktoberfest, better than expected. Nice to enjoy with my sandwich.

Bottle. Clear copper pour with very little head. Aromas are sweet grains, bread, and fruit. Tastes moderately sweet. Mostly bread with some light caramel and grassy hops. Medium body. Very dry finish. Average beer.

Copper color out of the bottle with a fluffy ivory colored head. Sweet malty nose. This is a sweet malty beer with lots of malts, brown sugar and lightly toasted white bread. There is a hint of lemon tang. Okay Oktoberfest.
Draft - Caramel with some dark grain notes. Clear copper with a decent white head. Grainy with some caramel and a light bitterness. Finish is grainy.
Aroma of malt and hops, amber color with a short lasting head. Delicious taste of malt and hops with a dry feel and a chalky malt finish.

Pint at Maumee Bay on 9/7/13. Clear amber pour with a medium off-white head. Malty and caramelly nose with lager yeast and crisp noble hops. Malty and caramelly flavor with a lager yeast character before a crisp noble hop finish. Straightforward, but very well done for the style.
Maumee bay oktoberfest pours rich copper with a small white head. Nose is happy malt with hints of caramel. Taste is more of the same malt happiness with caramel throughout mild hops. Good finish.

Sample at the brewpub: This beer pours a dark reddish-amber color with a nil off-white head. Thin, spotty lacing. The aroma is malty with a fair amount of hops as well. Medium body with more bitter hops than are usually found in the style, however the malt base is still there. The finish is soft and sweet without much lingering malt. Just average.
Cask conditioned @ South Western Arms, Soton. Pale colour. Tart lemony hops and some sugary malt. On the whole fairly dry and a bit too thin but the hop finish is quite robust. Not great.

Cask gravity at Red Lion, Snargate. Golden, bubbly off white head. Grapefruit, resiny hop aroma. Slightly dry and dusty on aroma too. Fullish in mouth, with delicate grapefruit hop dancing on the tongue. Grassy. Lovely finish. Sublime.

Bottle 50cl. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toffee. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. (030808)

Bottle, bought @ Sainsburys, Camden. Lightly hazy golden with a small, staying, bubbly, off-white head. Sweet malty aroma, some pine and flowery hops. Fine carbonation, perhaps a bit too much, rather dry. Flavour is medium bitter, okay maltiness and a fine hoppy finish. Not excactly bitter, but nicely drinkable.
Bottle, 4.7%. Green apple aroma. Pale golden colour, small white head. The flavour starts off a little sweet, turns hoppy, not very bitter, but with some grassy hops and a rough finish.
Bottled. Golden colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is cookies, grass, fruits and some nectary sweetness. Flavour is harsh grass, vegetables, fruits and mild herbal notes.
CLear golden with medium off white head. Floral hops in the aroma along with fruity notes. Hoppy flavor with caramel and mild fruity notes. Finishes somewhat bitter.

500ml bottle (Sainsbury’s) Pale gold, brief head. Weetabixy and light hoppy aroma. Some cornflakes, and sweet. Quite fizzy palate, hot harsh. Earthy taste, reasonable full light malt body, quite biting bitter noble hops. As it warms the aroma becomes more like buttered toast, and the burntness comes over more in the taste too. Has ups and downs over time - at its best its very full and tasty, at its low it’s plain and corny. Feels quite sophisticated and well made though.

Bottle: Slightly hazy, mid-sized, slowly collapsing white head; moderate fruity-hoppy nose; bitter-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied; lingering bitterness in the sweetish fruity-hoppy finish. Decent.....

(bottle) Hazy, pale golden colour with a small blonde foamy head. Slightly sweet and yeasty malt aroma with light-fruity (citrus) and woody hoppy notes. Light-bitter flavour with soft sweetish edges, light to medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Initially malty, slightly chalky and subtle fruity taste; moderately dry and bitter finish with citrousy and slightly herbal hoppy notes. Decent beer (05.03.08).
Gold with a white head. Floral hop aroma, developing some malt. Taste is citrus with just a little biscuity malt. Some dryness in the finish. It’s not bad.

Bottled, pasteurised, 500ml from Sainsbury, Dronfield, Derbys. Gold with white head. I think that this should be called SO Boring Ale. Very little on the flavour front, perhaps some sweetness with a minimal floral note and a dash of honey, bland malt. A complete non entity really.

Cask. Reddish copper coloured with mediumsized slightly off-white head, which last for a while and leaves some lace. Aroma is bready and caramelly malty along with some slight fruity and berryish notes and mild nuttyness. Flavour is fruity, nutty, some slight berryish notes as well. Semi-dry finish with a slight grassy touch to it.

Cask conditioned at The Turf Tavern, Oxford. Gold with white head. Quite a nutty bitter, hazelnut dryness with a dry tea flavour mixed in, not a favourite combination, but quite drinkable. Pretty standard overall.

Cask conditioned handpump Brunswick Derby. A copper coloured beer with a whitish head. The aroma is plain with a little fruit skins, and some sweet malts. The taste is malty to start with some citrus flavours coming through later. A bit boring. Made me realise why I rarely drink pints.

Small coarse white head. Amber body. Faint fruity floral aroma. Sweet-dryish earthy prunes taste with papery floral notes. Mid-bodied. A bit cloying. Soft, mild mouthfeel. Dryish papery caramel aftertaste. Decent, but a bit boring, and a bit cloying. (0.25l cask, The Edgar Wallace, London.)

cask (handpump) @ The Old Ship in Sidmouth. Hazy copper colour, small head. Fruity aroma. Malty, with caramel and lovely fruity flavoursd (lemon, orange peel). Dry and hoppy finish with a fruity touch. Brilliant!
Cask at the Old Manor (JDW), Bracknell. Gold with a loose off-white head; fruity aroma; malty tasting with a slight citrus edge; dry and moderately bitter finsh. A forgetable bitter.
Cask-conditioned at the Cornubia, Bristol. Amber coloured with a slight off-white head. Fruity aromas followed by sweet malt taste and a bit of a dry finish. Ok.
Cask (Angleterre, Helsinki) Orangy nut coloured, no real head. Initially some orange citrus aroma, later maize or bran - rabbit food pellets. Huge malty taste, very nutty, long finish.

Cask conditioned @ Gravity cask @ Hants Bowman, Dundridge. Quite fruity. Apples, pears and plums and a smooth bitterness. Fairly prominent yeasty flavours. Too much on the sweet side for me but the aroma is quite interesting. Too be fair this was slightly flat and getting towards the end of the barrel (av rating given).

Cask handpull at Market Porter, Borough. Copper colour, lasting off white head. Raspberry rich malt, quite a good malt aroma and flavour, raspberry fruit, dusty hop, dryish finish. Odd, some off flavours, but nice enough.

Thin dense head of fine bubbles and light carbonation. Nice hoppy aroma with plenty of spruce and citrus notes along with some sweet malts. Appearance is a cloudy dark mahagony brown. Nice hoppy bitterness in the flavor. Loads of spruce, caramel, roasted grains. Noticable alcohol presence. Very well balanced. Long warm finish with good bitterness and lingering maltyness. A damn good IPA. Hits all of the marks just a littlle bit weak in the aroma dept.
Cloudy dark amber color. Roasted hoppy nose with light floral notes. Very robust for an IPA. The taste was of roasted nuts as well as bitter hops. Full mouthful, great lacing.

Deep amber body with some haze and a filmy off-white head. Dank, crusty hop aroma with a toasted malt underbelly and some apparent alcohol. Grainy, toasted bread character in the flavor with moderate sweetness and assertive, lacerative bitterness. Still solid, but a previous batch seemed a little more lively, particularly in terms of hop aromatics.

Amber color with a medium white head. Aroma is quite malty with just enough citrus and pine. Flavor is sweet & hoppy with lots of citrus, pine, and caramel maltiness. A really nice take on an IPA - a bit maltier and sweeter, but one of the better brews GL has put out recently.

Brown hue, bone white lacing, bitter but not in the 90’s (IBUs,) metallic in flavor, some of the general brews are running together in my mind despite my best attempts to differentiate...So...so, there are better out there but locally still in the top 2.

On tap at the GLI (I assume this is the one I had as I noted down IPA on my notes). Poured a medium amber color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of spices and citrus. Tastes of spices, citrus and light caramel. Medium bitter.

Copper pour with aroma of caramel malt, hops, fruit. Tastes caramel malty, with backup hops and fruit, plus some spicy black peppery notes. Not a hop bomb, but subtlely and deceptively hoppy as it warms.

Draught at Brewery: Faint hoppy aroma. Poured copper/orange in color with a big, creamy, off-white head that lasted. Cloudy and sparkling. Excellent lacing. Flavor was bitter and tasty. Notes of Simcoe hops and cream. Lightly sweet and moderatly bitter. Medium body. Short finish. Fizzy carbonation. Not as hoppy or bitter as Sly Fox or Weyerbacher Simcoe-based IPAs. Good, but not as good as its description makes it sound.

Deep amber, creamy white head. Nose was richly hoppy with pine, earth, and hints of sweet orange marmalade. Flavor was one in the same and very bitter throughout. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, bitter finish. Very good brew and just a bit off center from your typical IPA…

23/2/2019. Cask at the Great British Winter Beer Festival 2019, Norwich. Pours very dark brown with a bubbly beige head. Aroma of malt, hops, dark fruit, lactose, coffee, chocolate and liquorice. Moderate sweetness, medium bitterness. Medium to full body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Dry, chocolate finish. Good!

Roasted malt, chocolate and cocoa aroma. Pitch black color with small sized tan head. Sweet chocolate taste, cocoa bitterness, roasty. Medium body, soft carbonation. Quite tasty, not exactly imperial. //bottle from Carringtons
Bottle from Beer Central, Sheffield. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, chocolate, coffee, caramel and hops.
Bottle from Beer Central, Sheffield. Clear dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt and licorice. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. 171018
On tap at the Golden Eagle beer Festival 2018. Almost black colour with a tan head. Dark malty chocolate aroma slight liquorice. Dry taste. Full rich and smooth body.

On tap at spoons. Black with a bit of brown foam. Scent is mild malt properties and a bit stinky. Taste is pulverized pencil shaving malt with a fair bit of stickiness but otherwise fair. Finish is bland. Not bad.

Pours a deep dark brown almost black colour with a reddish hue when held up to the light and a small lasting tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee and dark chocolate. A roasted malt taste, moderate sweetness with liquorice, coffee and burnt grainy flavours. A dryish bitterness in the finish.

Cask (6%), 1/2 pint by hand-pump at The West Kirk, Ayr on 26 Dec 2017: weak chocolate malt aroma, opaque near black, thin beige head, pattern of fine lacing, dark chocolate, liquorice, subtle spice, creamy, dry malty finish.

7 3 8 3 15 Cask at Moon in the Square, Bournemouth. Dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate, Roast, cocoa and caramel. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with very soft carbonation.

Black with off white head. Licorice malt and chocolate flavours. Really good. Not able to detect aroma but excellent taste and strenght. Much superior to Guinness. Will explore again re aroma on another night.

2014 rating. Pours a foamy white cap and has a pale golden appearance. Weak lacing. Aromas of wheats, grainy malts and very faint hops. Flavours are fairly bland, malty and wheaty notes with a bit of corn in the finish. Quite excessive carbonation. Very easy to drink and perfect for hot summer days lounging on the patio.

column1: Kinshihai Yuki-Kage (Snow Shadow) Junmai Tokubetsu Sake
column5: Bottle at Epcot Japan Clear. Aroma is woody, fruity, peaches, dry Tasty

column1: Kinshihai Yuki-Kage (Snow Shadow) Junmai Tokubetsu Sake
column5: This bottled Sake from a bottle shop poured a extremely small sized head of frothy medium sized clear colored bubbles that were very quickly diminishing and left behind a uncarbonated transparent clear colored body and no lacing. The strong aroma was green apple musty and mild vinous. The mildly vinous clean mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and strongly tingly at the finish with a lingering vinous aftertaste. The balanced flavor contained notes of polished rice and vinous. A decent one that I would consider drinking again.

column1: Kinshihai Yuki-Kage (Snow Shadow) Junmai Tokubetsu Sake
column5: Bottle while enjoying some curling on tv. Pours light olive juice with light melon nose. Tastes of light olive brine, honey dew, pears, and almonds. Alcohol is faint. And creamy mouthfeel.

column1: Kinshihai Yuki-Kage (Snow Shadow) Junmai Tokubetsu Sake
column5: Rated in 2010 (Backlog) - Clear with OK legs. Aroma is of floral, light buter, and berries. Taste is of booze with a sweet rice finish.

column1: Kinshihai Yuki-Kage (Snow Shadow) Junmai Tokubetsu Sake
column5: Thanks to bman1113vr from way back. The look is clear, no color, decent legs. The smell is almonds, sweet, rice,and ok. The taste is rice, almond, and sweet.

column1: Kinshihai Yuki-Kage (Snow Shadow) Junmai Tokubetsu Sake
column5: Bottle. No head (still). Body is colorless. Aroma is notes of potato, grain/rice, glue, alcohol. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, no carbonation, moderately to heavily alcoholic, lightly astringent. Pretty bad...typical cheap sake odors with some raw potato to boot. Not much to balance the sweetness, watery texture, and a hot/burning finish. The only thing nice about it is the bottle it comes in, sadly. Swill sake despite the price.

column1: Kinshihai Yuki-Kage (Snow Shadow) Junmai Tokubetsu Sake
column5: (300ml, bottle 01/2010, courtesy of BMan1113VR) Pours a transparent body with descent legs. Aroma of almond, alcohol, and rice milk. Flavor of almond and light florals. Not much character or complexity.

column1: Kinshihai Yuki-Kage (Snow Shadow) Junmai Tokubetsu Sake
column5: (300ml bottled 1-10 thanks to BMan1113VR) clear, coats the glass with excellent alcohol legs. Nose of soft white peaches, nice alcohol burn, sweetness, cooked white rice. Taste of subtle fusels, sweet rice, mango with a slick medium to light dry body and a hot finish.

column1: Kinshihai Yuki-Kage (Snow Shadow) Junmai Tokubetsu Sake
column5: Thanks to bman1113vr for sharing this bottle. Very clear with some bubbles. The aroma is alcohol and rice with some citrus and floral notes. The flavor is more of the same with the citrus and alcohol standing out.

column1: Kinshihai Yuki-Kage (Snow Shadow) Junmai Tokubetsu Sake
column5: bottle thanks to bman1113vr. clear with no head. nose is very floral, almonds, and alcohol. nice on the palate, flavor is almonds, alcohol, and more florals.

On tap at RB College Park. Cloudy orange brown color with a creamy tan head. No way I’m seeing through this one. It has an expected an nice wheat, yeast, and fruity aroma. Ester and yeast with some bananna comming through. The flaovr is a great tangy wheat up front. Lots of body and character. Yeasty to an extent and some alcohol comes through. As it warmed some bubble gum and a bit of bananna appeared. I like this one.

column1: Rock Bottom College Park Pumpkin Ale
column5: On tap. Labled Pumpkin Smasher. All around just a mild spiced ale. Just a bit of clove, nutmeg, and cinnimon type spice in both the flavor and aroma. Medium body with rather high carbonation. Some sweetness in the finish. Not a fan.

column1: Rock Bottom College Park Pumpkin Ale
column5: Clear amber color with a white head. The aroma is of a mild, but noticable spice. Cloves, allspice, and other give it the expected pumpkin pie aroma, but with the strenght of others I’ve had. It left room for some of the light ale to come through in the aroma. The flavor is very much a light ale with pumpkin pie spices. Light and with a decent amount of pie spice, a little bit of sweetness and tangyness is also available. A tad too thin, but still a well crafted beer.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear amber with a thin white head. Soft citrus on the nose, a bit of malt, a hint of sweetness, caramel and toast. Medium bodied, soft malt, toast, light citrus. Slow earthy bitterness into the finish.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: On tap at the premise. Pale copper witb a dense white foam that dtick to the glass with beautiful lacing. Aroma is malty with notes of bitterness. It use to me more hoppy before !!! Same for The taste. Alcohol is present. High body, creamy and medium carbonation. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Würziger Antrunk mit leichter Süße, verhalten malzig. Im Mittelteil dagegen wässrig und leicht sauer, die Aromen sacken hier auf quasi 0 ab. Erst im Mittelteil kehren sie zurück, etwas herb, leicht würzig, aber grundsätzlich noch wässrig. Nicht gerade ein Spitzenprodut. Danke an Jevers Zeuge. Test vom 5.9.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 5,5,6,5,5,5 - 5,15
bottle, courtesy of pivnizub! Clear golden colour, large white head. Strange fruity nose. Malty, slightly hoppy with an unusual fruity character.
Botlle. Golden, plentiful carbonation, foam layer. Grassy and citric bitterhop aroma. Light fruity malt base, fairly sparkly nee overcarbonated, dry and flowery hops. Fresh.
Bottle. Sweet barley malt aroma. Clear golden yellow with moderate head. Sweet barley malt and lightly bitter grass hops flavor. A bit too sweet - not so good.

Bottle from Bier-Spezialitaten-Laden, Berlin. Clear golden with a rich, offwhite head. hoppy aroma with notes of hay, sharp fruit and dust. Grassy hop flavours balancing bready maltiness. Some acidic fruit in the background. Cellar notes, quite dry. Interesting.
Burgundy with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel and breadish notes. Flavour was sweet with roasted malt, caramel and rye bread. Finished sweet.

Bottle (thanx to MoritzF): Straw golden coloured, small foamy white layer; robust sweet-malty, a bit worty nose with a big touch of aromatic citrousy hops; moderate sweet-bitter flavour, solid malty base; delicate shorter sweet-bitter finish. A very tasty, aromatic Helles..........

(bottle) Clear, pale golden colour with a short foamy white head. Sweet, slightly buttery malty aroma with spicy, herbal hops. Moderately sweet, slightly bitter flavour, medium to light bodied with a soft carbonation. Malt-accented taste, slightly grainy and buttery with almost Bohemian attributes; dry-ish, slightly bitter with herbal, slightly floral hops. Surprisingly quaffable brew from a brewery whose brews I haven’t been satisfied with so far. Blindfolded I would have guessed this was a decent Bohemian Pilsener.
Bottle. Dark golden brown. Off-white mostly lasting head. Heavily malted aroma. Malt and hops in the flavor suplemented with a little fruity note. Average finish.
Bottle5.5%. Sweet, fruity, dusty aroma. Golden colour, small white head. The flavour is like the aroma, sweet, fruity and dusty. Drying out a bit in the aftertaste. Not very bitter. Tastes obergärig.

Tasting at Ferris’, corked bottle; vintage 2011 Dark brown color, near black; no carbonation and no head. Sour aroma, acetone, old clothes, skunk. Oily mouthfeel; cherry and acetone flavor, nasty acidity. Seriously, this got out of control, undrinkable acetone soup. I don’t want to get nasty…

750mL bottle, pours a dark mahogany with a small beige head. Aroma brings out vinegar, sour dark fruits, and some Worcestershire sauce. Flavour is extremely vinegary, with Worcestershire sauce, and intense vinegar. Some woodiness, but this intensely vinegary. Gets easier to drink after a while. Good stuff, but too vinegary to be drinkable in more than taster sizes.
Bottle - Sour and bad balsamic. Deep brown copper with no head. Tart malts and balsamic. Sour and a little unrefined, more balsamic than anything else.

750 ml bottle This 2005 vintage was shared with Travlr, BeersAndBlues2, and some others. I wish I’d opened it at home sooner. Instead of a promising sour the outcome was a mess of vinegar and fruits. I think I would rather have used the bottle as salad dressing or for cooking than rate it. Aroma / Appearance - Raspberry fluid liquid flows down the neck into the glass with a sweeping ivory head. Tart raspberries and vinegar create nothing more than a lactic bomb. If there was any depth or complexity it is long gone. Flavor / Palate - Vinegary raspberries shock the senses. Sour fruits are less lambic and more cooking vinegar. Far too sour for its own good it masks anything else that could redeem it. I’m not sure where it went wrong. Whatever the reason though if you are sitting on a bottle open it soon, drink a few ounces, and use the rest to make sorbet or flavor a salad.

2005 Bottle shared by Brigadier. Pours lightly hazy tawny with a small, bubbly off-white head, medium retention with spare lacing. Aroma acetic vinous notes, brown sugar and light molasses, balsamic vinegar, toast and cookie malt with old and stale hops. Flavor is acetic cherries, vinous notes, light vanilla, brown sugar, malt backbone, light hops and bitterness and a dry finish. Medium body and light carbonation.
Bottle courtesy of Brigadier, thank you Nathan! Hazy maroon amber color. Aroma of plums, prunes, raisins. Taste is extremely tart plums. Harsh.

Bottle thanks to somebody, rating from my backlog. The look is cloudy, thin white head, and brownish red in color. The smell is fruits, tart, sour, and candy. The taste is same as the smell with some vinegar.

[5102-20130202] Bottle. Lightly spiced malt grain booze aroma. Clear, amber body with a quick foamy white head. Sour yeast flavour has a spicy hot base. Medium body is surprisingly hot. Interesting to sample but intense. (7/3/6/3-/13) 3.2 (@ Sourfest 2013, Buffalo, NY)

2013-02-02. Dark red brown body, headless. 3++ Rich aroma, fruity vinous quality, bit of woody oak like quality. 8+ Flavour is intense, sour, bit of wood, malt, lactic touches. Becomes a bit overwhelming as you go on. Average bodied palate. Starts great and gets to be a bit too much by the end. 2005 Vintage? Bottle at Sourfest, Buffalo

2005 bottle. Big crazy aroma of turpentine & nail polish remover. Harsh sour tartness, astringent, chemical throat burn, blueberry, sweet. It insanely sour. My stomach feels like the bathtub in Breaking Bad season one. Eating away
Pours a golden yellow with a white foam head. Aroma is grass and bread. Flavor is sweet bread and citrus. Smooth and creamy. Okay - off-putting aroma.

column1: Charlevoix Vache Folle Simcoe Double IPA
column5: 500 ml bottle from local iga grocery A: candy, orange, light caramel app: clear dark copper minimal white head t/p: full body with moderate long body finish. Soft carbonation. O: not enough bitterness / aroma to support this full body.

column1: Charlevoix Vache Folle Simcoe Double IPA
column5: 500 ml bottle. Bottled on date of August 6, 2015 so I’m not quite sure just how "retired" this is. Pours a hazy bronze hue with a tan head. Aromas of resinous hops, apricot, passion fruit, light strawberry, faint caramel. Medium sweet, with almost toffee like undertones, some definite alcohol, grapefruit, and resinous hops that head into malty notes, mineral notes, light caramel, and some Extra Stength Fisherman’s Friends like notes in the finish.
Draft - Light grain and caramel. Clear copper with a decent beige head. Light grains and caramel. Standard and decent Marzen.

Odkapslowanie butelki skoñczy³o siê fontann¹ piany, w wyniku czego, straci³em 20% zawartoœci. Za to odejmujê punkty. Kolor br¹zowo-miedziany, mêtne. Piana jasno be¿owa, bardzo obfita ale opada szybko. Nos: kawa zbo¿owa, przyprawy korzenne, pumpernikiel, palony s³ód, Paszcza: s³odycz niska w górê, lekka goryczka, cia³o œrednie w dó³, alko nie czuæ, posmak przypalonej skórki od chleba, biszkopt, wysycenie wysokie, W sumie smak mi podchodzi. Pasuje mi to piwo ale minusem jest to, ¿e po otwarciu butelki, która sta³a sobie spokojnie od kilku dni w szafce mam fontannê piany. Przegazowanie, zaka¿enie, potencjalny granat?
Flets donker bier. Te weinig smaak. Geen afdronk. Jammer, want met wat meer uitgesproken karakter zou het een aangenaam biertje kunnen zijn

Bottle of 33cl, in a Trappist glass; from the fridge. Gold in colour with a nice white head, this beer is strong in malt, both aroma and taste. Unfortunately, it got this "cheap malt" flavour, which is not the best.

Barwa z³ota, zamglone. Piana niska, œrednio trwa³a. W aromacie dominuj¹ ¿ó³te owoce z brzoskwini¹ na pierwszym planie. W smaku podobnie, s¹ owoce, s³odycz niska, goryczki brak, jest dosyæ lekkie, finisz wydaje siê wodnisty.

May 2019 330ml dark bottle, unfiltered, from BeerWulf. Needs the yeast swirled in to give it some depth and spice. Otherwise its tastes a bit thin and raw for the strength. Once the yeast is in, it has a good body, a range of candy flavours, and is quite an attractive drop. Yeah, I'm happy.

Many thanks for this beer to Eric De Geyter. Thanks for buying in Brussel. Piwo ma gesta ladna i bardzo trwala kremowa piane, jasna metna barwe o aromacie brzoskwin i nieco bananow. W smaku slodowe, morelowe, troche slodzone cytrusy. Fajne.
Bottle 33 cl. Bright yellow color, good white foam. Aroma: malt, pear, yeast, light perfume and spice, a little candy and sweets. Taste: malt, apple seeds, light spices, fruity, sparkling.

Bottle. Clear gold. White well-lacing froath. Aroma: corny malts, overripe fruit, candy, perfume, light industrial feel when cold. Medium body. Taste: light to medium sweet, malty. Corn, overripe apricot, candy, perfume, light hopping. Nutty hints. Tasty.

Een licht troebel blond bier met een schuimkraag wat meer op belllenblaas lijkt. Beetje zurig zoet bier dat wel iets weg heeft van mousserende wijn, hop, gist. Drinkt makkelijk weg omdat het heel zacht is. de nasmaak is fris zoet en heel kort.
Bottle from Belgibeer. Cloudy yellow with a large head. Aroma of Belgian yeast and spice. Flavour is boozy yeast and pepper, fruity finish.
Dunkbar Pilsnerfestival Pre-tasting. Hazy golden with a small white head. Heavy spicy and fruity Belgian yeast aroma, with peach, banana and marzipan. Sweet fruity and spicy flavour.
Bottle @ Pre-Pils-Festival, Odense. Pours Hazy Golden with a White head. Marcipan, Esters and yeast. Sweet and Warming alcohol.
Bottle from Hopology, Nottingham. Deep ruby colour with a thin tan head. Aroma light fruity and roasted malt. Slight thin body. Taste light bitter.

Cask at the Wellington, Birmingham. Poured a clear dark brown with a frothy light tan head. The aroma is light roasty malt. The flavour is moderate liqourice bitter with a light watery, roasty, light creamy caramel, light chocolate palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Had this at The Tabot, Amber Brewery Tap, Ripley, Derbyshire consumed either at festival site or nearby Golden Valley campsite 26.07.13 Pours very dark brown, perhaps a little thin but I really, really like this. Some watery spent coffee grains, a good roastiness, simple, decent, non fussy stout. A6 A4 T7 P3 Ov14 3.4
Off cask at the fishpond matlock bath. Very tasty. Lots of chocolate and coffee, good stout indeed.

Bottle. Golden coloured beer with a strong frothy head. The aroma is dryly hopped with some yeastiness. The flavour is very strongly hopped with a long dry finish with some yeastiness. Overall a nice pale ale.

Handpull cask at the Ilson Tap, Ilkeston. Light gold, clear and lively with a drothy white head. Light lemon aroma, grassy notes, boiled sweet. Tastes sweet with a grapefruit hop coming in mid-sip but never overpowering. While it's a nice, drinkable enough golden, it doesn't have a lot of character. Not the best of Magpie's beers.
Very sessionable, easy drinking and tasty, a little bitter elevates it from being a run of the mill golden ale/bitter.
Cask at praf 2017. Pours clear golden, nose is peach, grapefruit, taste is similar, musty.

Cask. Stale bread aroma is not a promising start. Pours golden with an off white lace head diminishing. Taste is sour rather than bitter and fruity rather than malty but on a warm day it refreshes with a fairly classic soft finish.Not one of their best.
Rochdale Beer Festival 2015. Golden with a light hoppy character and some maltiness.
Cask @ Station Hotel, Oakengates. Pours pale gold, bubbly white head. Pale malt character, grassy with mild floral notes. Not destined to set the world alight.
Pint bottle from a deli in nottingham. Pale gold colour with a white head. Citrus and pine aroma. Bitter finish. Easy to drink.

568ml Bottle - Golden with a slight haze and a foamy white head. Grassy and slightly biscuity aroma with a hint of citrus. Earthy taste with lemon, grassy hops and some grain. Not bad, but not the best one I’ve had from Magpie.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 2012, Great British Beer Festival, London Olympia, Hammersmith Road, London, England W14 8UX. Clear medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, pale malt, wet straw, earthy, vomit. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120808]

[cask at the 2008 SRAF] Pale yellow beer with a thin white lacing. Aromas are grassy hop and a little spiciness – definitely got that musty Fuggles aroma. The palate is more grassy hop, together with some citrus. Malt is there too – quite a decent bitter [21062008]
Sweet citrus aroma, golden yellow colour. Apricot flavour with smooth palate and bitter smokey aftertaste. Very nice.

Cask @ National Winter Ales Festival 2009, Manchester. Pours a pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity hoppy grapefruit aroma with some hints of citrus. Fruity malty hoppy flavor with some hints of grapefruit. Has a fruity malty slightly hoppy finish with some hints of citrus in the aftertaste.

Cask @ Reading Beer Festival 2008. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate hoppy, grape, lemon shell. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long to average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is flat. (030508)

Cask at Glenrothes BF 08. Nose is passionfruit and mango, strong and dominating. Mouth is hoppy grassy bitter, then the mango and passionfruit almost burning, ouch. Lasts fruity, Bit too severe at points.
cask troon beer fest. pours cloudy yellow like pee. smells like clean, tastes spicy very spicy, clean finish nothing inspiring except for the strange spice.
Cask at troon beer fest 07... Bright yellow ... ligth fruity hop ... bright sharp fruit ... little citric hop ... touch watery.
Cask at troon beer fest. Aroma is citrus grassy hops, with a slight wiff of chorine. Taste has again chlorine over a grassy pale malts base, but a bit yeasty.
Cask@Reading BF. Quite bitter, but in a slightly infected sort of way. Palate is woody, with strange saw dust flavours. Finish is short and slightly rancid. Not very good.
Tried this at the weekend at The Faiblford Inn. Spoke to the owner/brewer who confrmed this was an improved recipe there had been a bad batch which may have been the one in Reading

Cask (handpump) at the Wenlock Arms, Islington, 31 July 2009. Darkish amber. More malt than hop character. Fruity and sweetish on the palate. Pleasant enough although, personally, I would have preferred a little more bitterness.

Cask @ Market Porter, Southwark, London SE1. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma Fruity malty caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

Cask (handpump) @ Wenlock Arms, 26 Wenlock Road, London, Greater London England N1 7TA. Clear medium red amber color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, roasted, caramel, tobacco, moderate hoppy, overriped apple - plum notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090731]
Amber with a lasting white head. Biscuit malt aroma with a little sulphur. Dry and grassy flavour with too much sulphur

Half, cask at The Market Porter, London Bridge. Deep naked surface, slightly unclear, dark amber content. Aroma of sweet fruity hops. Fresh fruity taste mixed with sweet malts and ending with discreet bitterness. Medium bodied (01.08.2009).
Cask in the market porter. Alround rating: Sweet brown bread, fairly grassy a bit peppery, its on the sweet side of balance and not very good.
Cask@Wenlocck Arms. Amber colour, not much head. Aroma is wood, caramel, some earth. Flavour is quite much the same along with a flowery and grassy notes coming in as well. Semi-bitter finish.

(Cask at Wenlock Arms, London, 1 Aug) Mahogany colour with almost no head. Fruity nose with notes of dried fruit and raisins. Fruity taste with dried fruit, black-currant and blackberries. Blueberries and some hops in the finish. Goes down, but hardly exciting.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Oxford BF. A dark brown coloured beer. The aroma is malty with berry fruits and a fair amount of sweetness. The taste is sweet and fruity but a tad cloying and artificial. A little complicated maybe?Score 2.8 Subsequent rating scored 2.9. Average unaltered

Bottled. Orangeish amber colour with a mediumsized foamy slightly off-white head, that leaves some lace. Aroma is bready and caramel malts along with some fruits and a big time ginger kick to it. Flavour is strongly gingerish with some mild bready and caramelly notes along with some slight wooden notes. Surprisingly fresh.
On cask at Cloisters. Pours a golden colour with a fair white head. Aroma of lemon, ginger and caramel. Similar flavours with mild carbonation and an oily mouth-feel.

Tasted this in The Crystal Palace, Glasgow (JDW) in October 2007. Cask, handpump dispense. Crystal clear gold in colour with a thin white head. Strong aroma of ginger root and spicy cloves. Thin mouthfeel and poor lacing. Pale malt base gives a thin, weak flavour of sweet ginger and christmas spices. Hops add an astringent bitter aftertaste which marrs the whole flavour. Ginger cuts through the mishmass into the sweet but really thin finish. Lacking in depth and complexity for 5% and tastes rather weak overall. Not the best from the TSA portfolio.
Cask at Ealing beer festival 2011. A golden coloured pour with virtually no head at all. Aroma of ginger and not much else. Tastes of ginger and spice. Not my thing.
Cask @ The Counting House. Sweet flowery aroma & flavour. Rich golden colour. A bit bland.

Bottle 500ml. @ home. Clear medium amber orange color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted - caramel, soap, ginger. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, sweet, candy sweet, dry, sweet ginger, ginger flowers ! Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110201]

Cask (gravity dispense) at Ealing Beer Festival, July 2009. Cloudy amber colour. Aptly named. Massive ginger attack on the nose. More ginger on the palate. Lingering ginger aftertaste. Spicy but not too hot, as some ginger beers can be. Quite tasty.

A Mes rate: gravicask at Ealing Beer Festival. Semi hazy golden brown with no head. Erm... hellooooooo ginger!!! F**king hell. It’s just ginger biscuits. Looking at the other rates this must have had extra ginger in as other people were able to detect other stuff. All I can get is giiiiiiiiiiiinger and as a result, this is the best TSA beer I have had...
Bottle. Pours a hazy orange color with a small off-white head. Has a sweetish spicy ginger aroma. Sweetish malty and slightly fruity spicy ginger flavor. Has a sweetish malty spicy ginger finish.

Bottle. Hazy gold with a thin head. Aromas are very sweet malts malts and ginger. Flavours are sweet caramel malts with sweet ginger beer. Lacks the usual warming effect of ginger. Way too sweet for me.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: It has a deep amber colored body with some visible carbonation and very good clarity. On top sits a modest light tan head that hangs on well and makes some nice spotty lace on the glass. The aroma has good strong pine and citrus hops with notes of grapefruit and lemon. It has a solid, rich malty base with very solid and pleasant citrus hop notes throughout. The hop bitterness builds towards the finish and lingers a bit before it slowly fades off the tongue. It has a solid medium to full body with a smooth yet lively texture and nice carbonation.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: November 2009 from bottle. Mixed sampler case of Magic Hat beers. Caramel, malt, spice and fruit aromas. Good balance and flavors.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Backlog rating 12-16-2008 (Bottle) This beer pours a medium sized ivory fizzy head that mostly diminished, fast rising carbonation, fair amount of lacing, hazy body, and a deep orange hue with a golden tint. The Aroma is earthy, malty, some caramel, citrus, grapefruit, and pine hops. The Taste is mildly bitter, fruity and acidic. The Palate is tingly and this is a medium bodied beer. All-in-all, not a lot going on with the taste of this beer and became rather boring to drink after a short time.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: It’s been quite awhile since I’ve had this brew. It was very tasty with a great malt character. One of those beers you wish they wouldn’t have retired. Copper pour into the glass with a nice white head. Big malt character on the nose. Very well balanced with caramel malts really shining through on the palate. A great autumn beer.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle shared from a friends cellar. Great looking ale with a huge rocky head, nice lacing, citrusy hop aroma. Flavor notes are plenty of hops, subtle malty sweetness in the finish.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Originally reviewed: 2/13/09. Pours a deep ruby color with a massive off-white head. Excellent retention and great webbing along glass edge. Smells very appealing. Great hop scent, with some grapefruit, and grassy notes as well. Every sip I take, I get a great whiff of this. Spot on. I’m really surprised at the hop bitterness this one holds. This really reminds me of Big Hoppy Monster. Some prominent bready taste in there as well. Not the most balanced as the bitterness could be a bit harsh for some. Crisp mouthfeel that aids drinkability well. Slight dry finish.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Good flavor with that omnipresent magic hat hops blend. Too bad its only limited edition. I hope it comes back again for more to enjoy it.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Deep amber with a light tan head that was gone in 60 seconds. Nose of raw green hops gives way to caramel, then diacetyl. Flavor was initially the same, but with the hop profile increasingly giving way to the caramel maltiness and diacetyl.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: a: amber/copper color with foamy 1/4" head that reduces to nice lacing. Carbonation s:pine hops, caramel t: hops dominate flavor with hint of pine, malts, and citrus Mostly grapefruit notes. Fairly well balanced beer.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: From notes. Originally reviewed 12/16/2008. Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass. Pours a caramel / amber / cherry color, with a 4 cm white head, half of which remains and leaves some nice lacing on the glass. Apricot is the strongest fruit smell in Roxy Rolles, but there are quite a few citrus odors in the mix. Definitely some caramel bread notes as well. A little bit of caramel malt up front, it is quickly followed by some nice tart, citrus flavors, with the apricot I noticed in the smell, as well as a little orange and grapefruit. Some bready flavor sneaks in, but the citrus flavors really lead into the hops nicely. The citrus slowly fades but still remains about half strength all the way until the end. The hops stay strong through the rest of the sip and I am left with a tart, bitter taste at the end. Quite enjoyable. Roxy Rolles has a medium body with a little less than medium carbonation. Although I like the citrusy and hoppy taste, I am left with somewhat of a tart aftertaste in my mouth, which is less than desirable. This is an easy-drinking amber ale. The nice caramel malt adds a smoothness throughout each sip that pulls together the citrus flavors and hops.

On tap at CooperSmith’s. Black appearance with a tan head and thick lacing. Roasted malty aroma, light chocolate, bitter hops and mild dark fruits. Similar flavor with a medium to full body, a creamy feel and lingering finish. Pretty good.

Draft: Chocolate chestnut. Nitrogenation produces a tight, puffy beige froth which quickly settles. Unappealing nose of prunes, iron, and cream-infused caramel. Very gassy as well. Quite watery on the palate. Smoothly roasty, initially, with nutty malts and harsh notes of alcohol. Flabby bed of grains disallows any rich char to establish itself. Hints of burnt cookies, but little in the way of char. Roastiness yields a firm woody dryness along with a touch of fluffy smoke. Nougaty sweetness fails to overcome the abundance of chalky minerals. Unripe plums are overbearing at times. Earthy yeast complements the silky note of roasted barley. Finishes softly with whispers of coffee, but severely lacking in malt depth. Despite the relatively low ABV, the alcohol is rather prominent in the aroma and sharp in flavor. Obviously suffers from the use of nitrogen.

tap at the brewpub. -cinnamon, lets get that out of the way. cinnamon in the nose, in the taste, and it works well here. pours nearly black with a khaki head. aroma is chocolate, cinnamon, banana, some roast coffee. flavors, some booze, roast all over the place, some sour chocolate, & something like cotton candy. a bit thin but there are things here i like. a lot of chocolate flavored guinness here, but saved by the coffee finish.

Growler. Pours almost opaque with a thin light brown lacing. Aroma is chocolate, cherry esters, possible coffee. Taste is light coffee, roasted malt, soy. Overly alcoholic presence for only 7.4%. Slightly oxidized. Finish brings out a more roasted character.

330 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 10/16/2017. Pours slightly hazy/cloudy deep reddish orange/copper color with a 1-2 finger dense and rocky cream colored head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Thick foamy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of lemon, orange, peach, plum, pear, apricot, red apple, peppercorn, clove, caramel, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, nuts, brown bread/crust, wood, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance and complexity of fruity/spicy yeast, dark/bready malts, and light-moderate earthy hop notes; with solid strength. Taste of big lemon, orange, peach, plum, pear, apricot, red apple, peppercorn, clove, caramel, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, nuts, brown bread/crust, wood, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness. Moderate herbal, floral, woody, grassy bitterness; and peppery yeast spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of lemon, orange, peach, plum, pear, apricot, red apple, peppercorn, clove, caramel, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, nuts, brown bread/crust, wood, herbal, floral, grass, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Great complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy yeast, dark/bready malts, and light-moderate earthy hop flavors; with an awesome malt/bitter/spiciness balance, and no cloying/astringent flavors after the finish. Moderate increasing dryness from bitter/spiciness and carbonation. Medium-high carbonation and medium body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready/grainy, and fairly crisp/sticky mouthfeel that is great. Minimal warming alcohol for 7.5%. Overall this is a delicious Belgian brown ale. All around nice complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy yeast, dark/bready malts, and light-moderate earthy hop flavors; very smooth and fairly crisp/refreshing to drink with the modestly bitter/spicy/drying finish. Well rounded Belgian yeast complexity, with a nice rich dark/Munich malt backbone, and balancing noble hops. Minimal residual sweetness with crisp dryness. A very enjoyable offering, and impressively well made style example.

Bottle. Color: Clear ruby, off-white head. Aroma: Malt, brown sugar, caramel. Taste: Very malty, caramel, notes of brown sugar, butter. Metallic notes at finish. Medium sweet. Medium to below medium body, below average carbonation. Too little taste, too thin, nasty matallic notes. Not my beer, no need to try again.

Bottle at Wagon Leo, Bastogne. Served in a stone bowl. Slightly hazy chestnut brown, foamy beige head. Typical Dubbel notes, quite pleasant and balanced: bready, brown sugar, some dried fruit, dry, light-medium bitterness in the finish. Medium-good body, medium carbonation.

Bottle bought from a vendor at a small Ostend funfair, poured into a nice, big, plastic cup, tasted on the beach. Pours hazy brown with a big, tan head. The aroma contains nuts, caramel, some dark fruits, hops & herbs, malt and iron. It tastes light to medium sweet and light roasted bitter; never fully coming to life, with metallic hints lingering throughout. Medium body, rather watery texture, fizzy carbonation. Not an exciting Dubbel.
Sweet toasted aroma. Metallic flavour. Some sweets. Head disappears quickly. Drunk from a porcelain helmet.
33cl bottle. Clear brown with big off-white head. Malt, caramel and bread. Drinkable.

F: big, off-white, pretty stable. C: dark red to dark brown, almost clear. A: weak, malt, caramel, bread, hint of milk chocolate, grassy, hint of yeast. T: malt, caramel, dark bread, hint of coffee, grassy, cardboard, quite watery, lemon, hint of plums, medium body, low to medium carbonation, it´s controversial beer there are good tones mixed with bad, so for me light above average, 0,33l bottle from Spar supermarket in Oostende.

Bottle 33cl bought at De Bierboom in Brugge last year. Pours dark brown with a big beige head leaving a nice lacing on the glass. Nose: chocolate, roasted malts, dried fruit, caramel. Taste: medium carbonation. Little bit of the same: chocolate, some dried fruits, roasted malts and caramel. In the end bitter hints.

Sampled @ Kerstbierfestival Essen 2015 as "Airborne Christmas (Lamborelle) 8%". -- Clear amber brown color, average sized off-white head. Smell and taste malts, lightly sweetish, some caramel but decently balanced actually. Decent body and carbonation. Not bad.
Clear, dark copper colour with dense head. Syrup aroma with some sourness. Roasted malt taste. Rather sweet, light body.

Commissioned by a quiz club from Ranst near Antwerp, with thick, firm, moussy, yellowish white head and yellowish orange blonde colour, cloudy. Fruity aroma, strong iron, gooseberry, apricot, parsley, apple, vanilla, straw, grass. Light fruity taste with honeyish touch, medium carbo, caramel malts, subdued sweetness and spiciness, bitterish, not too pleasant finish, bit sticky and bit alcoholic, and even a bit phenolic.

33cl bottle. Col doré/foin sur un léger orange, col blanc épais. Arôme a ce petit bouquet de vieille levure, malté, houblon fruité et grains bien en avant. En bouche, malt caramel voire biscuité qui est bien agréable, houblon en retrait rajoutant un côté Cascade qui est quasi inaperçu. Le tout est épais avec une levure qui reste en avant et s’accompagne d’un malt caramel et houblon herbacé de Goldings en amertume. Ce qui ressort le plus selon moi, est le profile malté biscuité.

Bottle @ home. Clear yellow / golden color, huge rough white head. Appears to have a lot of carbo on first sight. Smell some sourness, alcohol and lightly infected. Taste malts and a little rancid. Acrid light bitter aftertaste. (not sure if ’acrid’ is the correct word, I mean what is called ’wrang’ in Dutch) Medium carbo, medium body.
Clear blond coloured beer, with a small white head. Aroma and taste of malts, hops with some yeast and sweetness. Light dry finish.
33cl, as KWis Bierke, exclusive brew, from Willems Grobbendonk, complex brew, floral and slightly bitter/spicy, not balanced, hazy, rocky head, nice brew

Bottle 33 cl from Willems in Grobbendonk (B). Golden blonde with nice dome of white foam that sticks well on the glass, fine intense crackling. Smells sweet, malt, toffy and hop. The mouth is round, deliciously malty, grassy hop notes and lemon. A bittersweet beer very typical of Belgium.
Bottle 0,33ltr: Hazy amber coloured ale with an decent sweet taste, and have some bitter finish.
Cloudy amber with a medium white head. Sweet malty aroma with caramel and ripe fruits. Sweet flavour with toasted malt, caramel and overripe fruits. FInished dry.

Bottled. A hazy golden beer with a huge off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt, metal, caramel, and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, metal, and caramel, leadign to a dry metallic finish.

Bottle 33 cl. Courtesy of KimJohansen. Pours a cloudy and opaque amber with a lacing off-white head. Phenollic and chemical aroma. Medium body, overripe fruits with a massive oxidization. Subdued biterness. Unfortunately way over the top. 110110
Bottled. A deep red beer with a thick tan head. The aroma has notes of sweet and roasted malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and straw. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.

Bottle 330ml. Clear medium brown amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, roasted, chocolate, coffee. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20081129]

33 cL bottle, courtesy of Papsoe. Pours clear and golden deep hazzlenut brown with a diminished white head. Light hoppy aroma with a backbone of roasted malt. Sweet and roasted malt flavour with a nice and light spiced feel and lingering roasted finish. Smooth and easy.

Bottle, 7.0%. Roasted, slightly burnt aroma, hint of cream. Clear dark brown colour, red shine. Very small tan head. The flavour starts off slightly sweet, turns more liquoricy and ends with a little creamy coffee. Not as powerful as the ABV could suggest, but well-balanced quite nice.
Bottle 33 cl. Clear orangey brown with an off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt and prunes. Medium body, sweetish roasted malt, licorice and dried fruit. Ends on a light malt bitterness. 291108
Bottled. Almost black in colour with a medium sized off-white head. Lightly roasted and malty with notes of chocolate, liqourice and berries. Ok but a bit thin.
I’ve had this one in New Zealand on my honeymoon. Very nice brew. Bitterness is decent. A bit too much locorice.
Bottle at Bagers (Thanks Sune). Dark dark brown - offwhite head. Licorice, roasted, light burned, dark berries, dark bread, light light chokolate. OK !!

Nice dark colours. Aromas a little cherry and raisen. Sweet with come complexity but a thin body lets it down. Nice dried fruit flavours but a typical lightweight version of a style that Monteiths are becomming known for.

Pours a dark brown with a nice off white head, foamy head. Smells of malts and light milk chocolate. Mellow sweetness with flavors of malt and chocolate. Medium bodied. Sweet finish with a tiny hint of alcohol.

Cask@The Wenlock Arms, North London. Some soft aromatic hops in the nose. pale gold. Grainy, lightly sweet and quite bland, pale malt character. Some nice clean aromatic hops. Finishes a touch watery.

2007-Draft and Growler. Rating from Growler. Pours golden yellow with TONS of carbonation even after it exploded in my car on the way home. . . oops. Nice white, foamy head, quickly disapating. Hint of banana on the nose, otherwise soapy and wheat malt. Classic German Hefe taste, hint of banana and clove, but predominated by malt, a bit of skunk and then crisp hop finish, not too overpowering. A good Hefe and a decent seasonal.

On tap 10/25/07 as part of a sampler. Slightly hazy yellow, quick dying white foam, no lacing. Very slightly banana in the nose. Flavor is a bit thin, only a hint of classic hefe character and a little bit of sulfur.

On tap at Marzonis in Allison Park. A very average Hefe. Aroma was not very strong. Could pick up some yeastiness but nothing else. Pour was nice..a hazy light orange with a decent 2 finger white head. Please waitresses...I know it’s a personal preference...don’t put the orange slices in the beeer unless asked. Taste was kind of spicy and watery. If the taste carried through to the end this would be an awesome beer. It just gave up too soon.
