Very citrusy aroma. Lemon oil and balsamic notes. Aroma is reminiscent of Flemish sour ale, tart and woody. No banana or clove. Cloudy pale amber-gold, with thin wispy lacing white head. Medium watery body with light-medium carbonation. Starts with nice citrus and estery yeasty flavors, mild Beemans gum. Nice sweetness, followed by lemony chalky bitter finish. For a German hefeweizen, it’s a little too lemony and bitter. For a witbier, it’s perfect.
*Old rating, best before 18.03.04. Schön frisches, mildes Pils. Nett herb, etwas floral, lecker.

Bottle 330ml. Clear medium yellow colour with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, grain, hay, sweet malt, cheese and soap notes. Flavour is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20111208]

Bottled. A light golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet malty with light notes of straw. The flavor is sweet malty with light notes of straw and caramel, leading to a bitter finish where the straw note lingers.

Bottle. Hazy green golden, lowish head. Metallic bitterhop nose. Straw maltyness, quite chewy, fat fruity notes hinishing on a herbal, light metallic hop note. Full, sparkly mouthfeel. Aromatic retronasal.

Bottle, 4.8%. Fine hop aroma. Shiny, clear, pale golden colour. Small white head. The flavour is quite sweet for a pils, slightly soapy, but OK aroma hop flavour. Low bitterness, but a flavourful beer for its style.

Bottled: Pale yellow color, low head. Grainy aroma with hayish hop notes. Flavor is sweetish, grainy and light corny. Notes of straw, flowerly and grassy hop notes in the end. Astringent dry finish. Boring pilsner.
(Bottle 33 cl) Clear, pale golden with a white head. Clean, malty nose. Medium body, lightly sweet, clean malt and a dry, hoppy finish. Touches of cardboard and metal. 180907

Bottle. [Courtesy of Papsoe, yet another great tasting @ Henrik´s] Small white fizzy head that mostly diminished. Clear sparkling body with a yellow color. Spare lacework. Aroma of light grass, hint of grain, light sweet malty notes. Light to medium bodied with a light dry texture and an average carbonation. Balanced sweet and bitter flavor. Light dry and bitter finish. 18-09-2007

33 cL bottle. Pours pale yellow with a little lacing white head. Slight fruity aroma hops nose with a little grassy note. Flavour is slight soapy, slight sweet with a decent bitterness into the finish. Minor fruity and malty notes.
Light blond color. Quite bad aroma, of eggs, straws… Light mouthfeel, quite watery, with some cereals taste and light sweetness (even if it’s a bit dry). Difficult to drink a whole bottle.

Pour is slightly amber with a thin off white head...smell is strongly smokey with lots of pork fat...taste is overly sweet up front...the smokey flavors are nice, but thrown way out of whack by how sweet this beer is...

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Pour is clear golden with a big dense off white head...smell is doughy and very grassy...taste is crisp and clean with some mild sweetness, with a nice strong grassy bitterness...

5/17/18. 12oz bottle from Warehouse. My notes say "Back home :(" because I had just finished a trip to Wisconsin followed by a super fun tuba conference and then a 4 day cruise to the Bahamas... back home :( indeed. Golden pour with a small white head. Crisp aroma, doughy pale malts, a touch of grass and lemon peel. Crisp flavor, doughy pale malts, a bit of lemon peel, grass, hay. Not bad.
Refrigerated 12 oz. brown squat bottle poured into a cup. Clear amber poured into a cup. Aroma is caramel malt, medium body, lower carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is caramel malt. Okterfest?
Dry hoppy to a point. Very light in color. Dependable summer brew. Went down easy.

It pours a very pale yellow color with a medium sized white head. It has a crisp malt and noble hop aroma.This is a very nice, crisp & refreshing beer. I think I taste a biscuit flavor, maybe bread. Very enjoyable. I recommend this one.
Keg at the Old Pack Horse, hazy gold with a thin head, lemony malt and light noble hops on the nose, light bodied and crisply bitter. It's a lagered pale ale, but is it Kolsch?

355 ml bottle bought at Q-Club in SoHo, Central. Looks: Clear pale golden Half finger head with soapy white foam which fades in 40 seconds; Very good sticky lacing with active carbonation. Aroma: Very fragrant Lager malt, with apricots, light yellow fruits, soda, floral, light sugar, strong spices, wood, dry biscuits, lemon and strong strawy grass. Taste: Very light sweet fair Lager malt, with notable tartness, light yellow fruits, floral, light sugar, strong spices, wood, strong herbs, dry biscuits, lemon, medium bitter hops and strong grass. Body: Close to light body. Dry and quite slick palate. Mouth Feel: Fair Lager maltyness in a thin, well-attenuated background. Very spicy Noble hops dominate with light yellow fruit esters. Flowery with light sweetness, woody strong herbal with grassy lemon to round. Excellent! Hoppiness: Floral, strong spices, wood, lemon and strong strawy grass in nose, same in taste but with strong herbs; Bitterness is fairly strong and grassy for a lasting, medium astringent bitter-sweet fair malty finish. After Taste: Very dry. Crisp, herbal spicy and bitter to mouth. Comments: This SN Koelsch is a good interpretation of the real thing: nice pale golden colour, well-attenuated good maltyness, spicy grassy Noble hop characters prevails in the aroma and taste with a crisp dry finish. The Loral hops here is a bit too restrained and could be a bit more expressive. Damn nice and I want more!

12oz bottle pours with a clear gold body that supports a thin white head of foam. The aroma offers up floral hop infused corn and then a faint lime note. The taste delivers an integrated blend of spicy, floral and slightly lime like hoppiness. To midway the malt base starts to surface with a bit of sweetness and corn. Decent interpretation of the style as it stays clear of becoming to sweet or heavy.

I always like a good kolsch, and this is a good kolsch, therefore, I like it. Pale gold, small head. Nose is floral hops, bready dough, a hint of resin. Light bodied, not watery, balanced with a soft bready malt, floral hop flavors, and light-med bitterness. Lingering noble hop flavors in the aftertaste, a tad spicy and grassy (in a good way).
Keg at London beer festival, so short rating. Malty, hints of citrus. Slightly hazy golden body, white head.

Bottle from Albertsons. Poured into a stange. Pale golden with small foamy head. Aroma tells me this is done right, crackers, biscuits, light grains. Taste builds on this, crisp grainy flavors, mild hoppy snap finishes it. Spot on. Well done.

Big alpha hops nose and taste. Sharp orange in color and with a nice swirling froth head representative of most stalwart IPAs. Fresh hop beers get no livelier. Pungent and delicious was this German tinted bold ale. Makes me look forward to next autumn!

On tap at the 2006 Hood River Hops Festival. Pours orange wih a smooth white head. Very floral and green hop nose, fresh and citrusy. Flavor is sweet and has a ton of hop character, like liquid citrus hops with a lightly bitter finish.

[Tastival 2006 SNOB Event – Tap] A nice fresh hopped brew. This had a ton of added Goldings and late addition magnum hops this was a truly fun to drink beer. The crowd liked this and loved the name also. The beer had some slight issue with the finish but this was not too much to take from the flavor. Good Brew.
Fresh hop version. Dark orange body with white head. Hoppy aroma with notes of cedar and citrus. Hoppy taste with an all over the mouth finish.

Fresh Hop version: A lightly hazed dark amber ale with with a thin off white head. In aroma, classic caramel malt with a good dose of floral c-hops, piney and smooth. In mouth, a crisp and dry biscuit malt with dry puckering British hops, lingering, a b it harsh but overall, OK. On tap at brewpub at Hawthorne, Oct. 7 2012.

Tap @ Green Dragon... Poured amber with an off-white head. Strong hops on the nose. Nice dry hops with a caramel presence. Delicious hops through out the whole drink and sort of a woodsy finish that was a bit earthy.

Draft. A hazy dark amber beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel and malt as well as light notes of hops. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel, and the body is thin.

Pouring at the Oregon Fresh Hops Festival--Poured a light orange-golden-amber color with a thin, wispy white head. Nose of grassy, fruity hops and mildly sweet grains. Taste was a peculiar hoppiness with sweet maltiness in the finish. Overall, however, the finish was thin and somewhat watery. Skunky and funky as can be. Not one of my favorite fresh hop brews, but okay.

Lucky Lab and fresh hop sounded great, but I found myself not enjoying this beer and wondering why. I haven’t found many beers from the LL in the past that I haven’t liked. This beer was so light and watery, I know the subtleness was to amplify the fresh hop flavor, but the hop profile of this tasted funky, touch of cat pee. Overall the wateriness of this was overwhelming, no body, very mild wet hop sweetness. Just not what the wet hop beers are about.

Draft: Pours a cloudy orange-bronze with a thin white head. Nice fresh hop aroma with some sweet malts in there. Flavor is lightly malty and semi-bitter with a nice big floral hop finish with a hint of those oily finish as it dries crisply on the tongue. Easy drinking and good but could have used even more fresh hops.

[Tastival 2006 SNOB Event – Tap] A nice fresh hopped brew. This had a ton of different added hops. The beer was refreshing and had a malt balance with the hops that was very unique. I liked this beer a lot and loved the hops that added to the flavor. It was said it had 4 different hops used. Good stuff.

Tap at the Lab in Multnomah Village. Listed as "fresh hop Nugget IPA". Light amber colored to deep golden. Clear. Small, fast fading white head with spotty lacing. Aroma is pleasant and fairly bright with floral notes. Medium bodied. Really bitter without becoming harsh. Lingering bitterness is a bit piney. Pretty decent, definitely a hop forward beer.

[Tastival 2006 SNOB Event – Tap] A nice fresh hopped brew. A nice use of the golden hops and the freshness was very exquisite. I liked the malts sued and the balance was good. The fresh hops did add to the flavor and give this beer an over the top NW hop flavor. A great beer.
Draft. A hazy amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with grassy notes of hops, and so is the flavor.

Enjoyed at the Hedge House in Portland, Oregon--Poured a hazy amber-copper with a small thick off-shite dome. Hoppy and sweet simultaneously. Finished astringent, dry and quite bitter. A unique beer for the autumn season.

Draught pint at Redbones on 11/15/06. Listed as "Harvestman Alt" but I’m betting there’s a good chance that that was just a misinterpretation of "Harvest moon Ale". Regardless, I’m not creating a new entry. Heavily cloudy amber-copper colored body has an off-white head that is dense, moderately well-retained and laces the glass in rings. Plentiful carbonation rises. Hoppy, spicy nose is supremely dry, with perfume, light soap and a crunchy/earthy note from the malt. Extremely, extremely attenuated, you can tell from the nose, lending no sweetness, or perhaps, just a pinch of light toffee. Seems like some rye or other spicy/nutty grain was used, though that could very well be the hops. Medium strength of aroma, but the yeast presence in their beers always dulls it. Hops range from lightly citric, to spicy, to perfume-like and slightly floral. They collect all over the palate, lightly juicy, but with a ton of bitterness that goes overboard (for me anyways). Some soapiness on the finish, with astringent, slick, toasted malt that is all but 100% attenuated. Maybe a bit of toffee and pale malt sugar slips in, but it’s fleeting. Heavily bitter finish, very fatiguing. The highly yeasted texture is somewhat of a comfort, giving that slick, yet substantial feel. But it’s hollow, there just isnt any malt definition and the hops are 95% bitterness.

[Tastival 2006 SNOB Event – Tap] A nice fresh hopped brew. This had a interesting flavor as this was trying to be a harvest beer with over the top Hops added. Crystal hops where used and this had a flavor of an IPA meets a Oktoberfest type beer. A great try and a great cool weather beer. Good Job and nice mixing of styles.

[Tastival 2006 SNOB Event – Tap] This Pilsner was anything of a old style Pils. His had fresh hops added (Crystal) and they where awesome. I liked this and a lot of great comments from others about this beer. A good use of malts and hops and the late addition of fresh hops where good stuff in my book.

column1: Mia and Pias Fresh Hop Mug Club Madness
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: [Tastival 2006 SNOB Event – Tap] This was a fun beer with a deep amber color and the fresh hops used where awesome. We could get two of the hops Cascades and Crystals the others where hard to pick out. This was a very fresh brew.

[Tastival 2006 SNOB Event – Tap] Another harvest ale. I wish they would say what this was supposed to be. Harvest is not a style. But this was a nice mix of the Oktoberfest style and IPA style. The hops (Cascades) where added and made this a truly great to drink beer. Deep malts and hops added to the flavors. The Amber color and nice head where also very good. This was a great beer.
Tasted @ the Triumph Brewing Company in Phili. Amber colored brew. Hoppy aroma. Flavor: mild, hoppy, smooth. Nice one.

Draft Olde City Triumph in Philadelphia, PA- Pours a brown-amber coloring with approximately 1 inch of head. Aroma is hopfilled, and a nice amount of malt is easy to detect. Flavor is good a medium to strong. Very enjoyable. Good atmosphere... odd bathrooms.
Excellent IPA. Very nice color and aroma. I’ve walked out of the Princeton Triumph numerous times with a growler full of their fine IPA.

on tap-pours a rocky offwhite head that laces with copper color. Aroma is citrus hops-grapefruit rinds, faint medium malt. Taste is lots of citrus hops-grapefruit rinds, musty, faint medium malt. Finish is raw, dry hops. OK carbonation.

July 28, 2015. Tasting at jtclockwork’s, thanks for sharing! Murky brown with a small frothy tan head. Aroma is quite oxidized, some toffee, raisin, notes of sherry, hints of dark berries, oak and alcohol. Taste is sweet with caramel, dried fruits, oak, light bitterness with cardboard, toffee, sherry and cardboard in the finish. Medium bodied, a bit watery finish, soft carbonation. Age has taken its toll...
Bottle. Pours dark brown - nose/taste of oxidized caramel, burnt bread, molasses and sherry - medium body.
Bottle. Brown pour with tan head. Old aromas, oxidation, booze and some sweet aromas. Oxidation, cardboard, sweetness, and mint, age hasn’t done well.
Malty bourbon smell. Taste has notes of minerals, malt, and chocolate. Good, but not great.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured light brown color with an average frothy tan head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy sweet malt, wood and earth alcohol aroma. Medium to heavy body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy dark sweet flavor to medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met with a mature complex beer.

22 oz bottle shared with the group. Pours a clear brown color with a small beige ring. The aroma and flavor have caramel, molasses, brown sugar, alcohol (still?), some bitterness, wood, aged fruits, oxidation is there, downhill from when I had this in 2011 but still pretty good for its age.

Bomber to snifter (shared by alexsdad06). Looks good for the style; a translucent dark hazelnut with very light beige head that steadily dissipates into bubbly lacing. Smells solid; dark fruit, oak, and toffee. Tastes like it smells with a solid mouthfeel. Some oxidization present. Still, enjoyable.

22oz bottle, thanks to local raters for sharing. Labeled 12%. Mildly hazy dark brown color. Minimal ring of off-white head, dots of lace. Vinous, raisin, dark fruit aromas in the nose. Medium to bigger body, a little thinner than expected. Lightly slick texture. Some alcohol warmth, mild burn at the end, but it’s not awful. In the flavor, more roast, dark malt, stout-like flavors. Bigger bitter taste, little sweet. More dry. A little hot and intense, but pretty cool stuff. Tasting better than expected for being 7 years old or so.

Bottle, thnx to NorCalGrowler, shared with friends. Pours a pitch black beer with a small beige head that settles into a small ring. Looks very daunting. Aroma is madeira, port, caramel, fudge and vanilla. Some oak characters still lingering on in the background, but the port and madeira are taking over the palate in a good way. Flavor is incredibly sweet and has again a big load of madeira in there. Some bourbon and oak flavors in the background again, but you can definitely tell that this beer has age on it, and it has aged very well. Very complex and balanced and a true treat to drink this stuff. Amazing!

Poured a clear dark brown with a reddish hue and a light frothy head. The aroma is big creamy caramel fudge roasted malt alcohol. The flavour is strong bitter with a smooth boozy alcohol bitter palate. Medium to full bodied with average carbonation and an oily texture. This is a super smooth, flavour packed whale of a beer where the higher ABV really adds to this beer which isn’t always the case. Taste it if you can and i’m sorry for you you guys that can’t.

Tap (sampler): Clear, copper brown, thick head and nice lace. Dark malt, roasted, caramel, ester and banana. Dry to off dry, not sour and moderate to medium high bitterness. Roasted flavors. Medium to dense. Long. Roasted. Smokey. Clean and fresh. Nice flavor

In a pint glass at the Brewery. Pours a deep reddish-brown. The head is beige and did not last long - leaving a faint rim around the edges. Nose of rich malt but light for a dunkel. Crisp, clean nutty malts on the palate. Medium mouthfeel with pronounced carbination on the finish. A light version of this style.

Strong fruited malt with a nice tinge of burnt. Better than other attempts of this style I have tried and well made. Good carbonation an mouth feel. Overall, nothing crazy good, but great for the style.

On tap at the brewery. Super dark red color with a creamy beige head. Light toffee, and caramel aroma. The flavor has some brown sugar, caramel, and nuttiness, with light bitterness. Light bodied with hight carbonation. At first, I had a sampler size glass of this and really liked it, but a whole mug on my second visit wasn’t nearly as good. It tasted a little weaker and not quite as fresh. Still decent and quit drinkable, but missing the richness of flavor that would demand a second mug.

Draft at the brewpub. Strongish caramel aroma. Hazy dark brown color with a flat beige head. Near medium body with sharpish carbonation. Flavor is darkish caramel with a little noble hop. Could be a hint of chocolate. Fits the style. The finish does develop a small amount of bitter that accumulates.

On tap, part of the 10 beer sampler. Poured a dark amber color. Very close in flavor to the Doppel Bock, but with less body and flavor Update: Had it a second time and had more flavor. Upped it 0.2 points.
On tap at Sudwerk. Similar to the Doppel-bock, this one is a bit more watered down version. Flavors are similar (chocolate and caramel), but are muted or distant.

On tap at the brewpub last week. .3L sample. Similar roasted, cereal-like malt bill to that of the Ur-Pils that I just finished. Some spices and metallic hops notes are also present in the nose. Doesn’t really smell like a dunkel. Mildly hazy dark amber body with a smooth, small, off-white head and ok lacing. Toasted, roasted, malts to start. Becomes lightly floral and a bit hoppy with some lingering bitterness later on. Tastes a lot like the Ur-Pils I just had. Kind of funkel for a dunkel.
Beautiful nose of mild honey, herbal hops and mild biscuit. Full and round mouthfeel with a very pleasing bitterness and soft herbal hop flavors. Clean and honeyed finish.
Draft. Hazy gold beer with a small white head. LIght grasssy, light biscuity malt aroma. Grassy, spice, and light malt flavor. Medium body. Lingering grass and slight citrus. Not bad.

On tap at the brewpub last week. .3L sample. Aroma has plenty of cereal, grainy, biscuity notes present. There is also a nice, but delicate, crisp, metallic and citric hop aroma present. Nice aroma. Moderate/mostly ahazy golden yellow color with an off-whitish head. Fair lacing. Dry, cereal-crunchy, grainy, start. Turns metallic and mildly bitter in the middle with some spicy noble hops to finish. A refreshing and flavorful pils.

A nice colored beer with persistent foam. Smells sweet and indefinable fruity (peach or apricot?). Extremely good taste of the fruit with a good and long dry finish. Maybe a bit too much hop flavor in the aftertaste.
Nose is sweet caramel, cinnamon, leather, sweet malt, feel Is watery, carb is mediumweak, taste is rye, cane sugar, caramel, medium roasted malt, mediumweak hops bite
Clear amber color with a off-white head.. Flavor of caramel and slightly fruity with note from the hops.

Bottle served by Anker. It pours clear amber with a medium off white head. The aroma is malty and caramelish with light hoppy and toffee notes. Light buttery. Quite buttery flavour with notes of caramel, sweet fruit and light berries.
7th May 2010. Copenhagen Beer Festival. Clear brown beer. Dry malt - a little bit of smoke. Boring.

Copper color with an offwhite head. Good lacing. Aroma: fruit, caramel, hops. Taste: caramel and hops. A little anise/liquorice in the background. Low carbonation. Pretty good beer. Very tasty for a 4,9%.
Bottle. Copper coloured with a medium sized off-white head. Somewhat malty with notes of caramel, fruits and hops.

column1: The Tap Srybnys Pumpkin Patch Ale
column5: Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a semi-clear orange color with a thin white foamy head. Dissipated to leave some stringy lace. The aroma had some cinnamon, nutmeg, pumpkin sweetness, light toast, dark bread along with some earthiness. The flavor had the spices up front, fairly bold over top of the pumpkin sweetness. Some pie spice trying to mix it all up a bit further. Aftertaste was full of the spices; the finish was the same way. The palate was between light and medium bodied with a decent sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine. Spices had some harshness but weren’t too distracting, felt pleasant for the most part. Overall, good enough pumpkin ale that I could have again.

column1: The Tap Srybnys Pumpkin Patch Ale
column5: Growler. Pours mostly clear light orange with a thin head. Aroma is lightly spiced- cinnamon nutmeg, clove, allspice, toasted pumpkin-squash vegetable- and lightly earthy with some hints of DMS. Flavor is vegetable with some light crackery and toasted malts, pumpkin spices subdued- light thin body with a lingering astringency.

column1: The Tap Srybnys Pumpkin Patch Ale
column5: Bottle. Squashy pumpkin, nutmeg, sugar aroma, fairly straightforward. Nice body, with an even carbonation, and a vegetal, chalky, chewy flavor.

column1: The Tap Srybnys Pumpkin Patch Ale
column5: Growler Shared at Ryan & Max’s Tasting @ Pauls under the name "pumpkin eater", which i figured is an alias for this brew. Pours a copper orange body and a large head. Big grainy malt bill dominates the pumpkin pie and allspice notes. A bit thin and weak.

column1: The Tap Srybnys Pumpkin Patch Ale
column5: Growler at Paul’s tasting. Pours a clear orange with a thin white head. Pumpkin flesh, spices, cinnamon, nutmeg. A little empty and nearly astringent malt. Finishes with a light bitterness and a touch more spice.

column1: The Tap Srybnys Pumpkin Patch Ale
column5: On tap at the Tap in Haverhill, Massachusetts. 2008 batch with a new name "Pumpkin Eater Ale," but it still uses local pumpkins for the recipe. Pours orange with a decent but short-lived head. The pumpkin spice aroma is solid and inviting. The taste is a lively mix of pumpkin, cinnamon, allspice, and cloves. Overall it was a mild and easy to drink brew. I liked it better than a lot of other pumpkin spices I’ve tried.

column1: The Tap Srybnys Pumpkin Patch Ale
column5: Pours a dark maroon leaving a thick tan head. The nose is fruity, pumpkin, clove, and cinnamon. The tase is very malty, very fruity essence upfront like molasses and a hint of roasted nuts that then moves to just a small bitter hop feel for balance but finishes sweet, bready, and refreshing on the palate. This is a quality pumpkin ale one of the best I’ve had this fall.

column1: The Tap Srybnys Pumpkin Patch Ale
column5: Draft. Dark tawny brown with a quickly fading head. Roasty malt, light peat, VERY light pumpkin notes, not a thick sticky mouthfeel. Overall kind of thin and leans on the bland

column1: The Tap Srybnys Pumpkin Patch Ale
column5: Tap @ The Tap. Pours a reddish mahogany with a thin head. Nose is thin but there is a distant spice going on. Typically, these pumpkin ales are more of pumpkin pie spice ale and sort of forget about the pumpkin itself. I was hopeful by the description that this would be the opposite but it was not, in fact, there was not a whole lot of spice either. On first taste, this had some bourbon notes but even that couldn’t hold this one together. Not a very good pumpkin ale.
Bottle. Little hazy golden colour with a little head. Malty aroma with notes of toffee and caramel.Mlaty flavour of sweetness and caramel.
Bottle. A hazy yellow beer with a white head. Malty, cookie aroma and taste. Medium body with a sweet finish.

Light cereal nose with a hint of dry astringency. Pours copper/gold with a fluffy head. It’s downhill from here - very pedestrian lager with a cloying finish. Thirst-quenching perhaps, but not much else to redeem it.
Bottled. A golden beer with a beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with light notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel. Boring, but nothing wrong.
From 50 cL bottle. Pours hazy yellow/orange with a white head. Malty aroma, dry. Malty and slight dry, not much bitterness. Finish is dry malty. Decent but nothing great.

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of Pernille. Pours a hazy golden with a small, white head. Aroma of malt and butter. Medium body with lightly sweet, burned caramel. The bitterness is very subdued. Decent though. 290607

Bottle. Small fizzy white head that quickly was gone. Fair lacework. Clear flat body with a light yellow color. Aroma of hay, grass, grain, butter, fruit and a hint of cardboard. Light to medium bodied with a dry texture and an average carbonation. Light sweet malty flavor with light to moderated bitter notes. Dry and bitter finish.

Many thanks to kevnic2008 for sharing. Smooth and mild, fresh and smooth. Not too much brown/dark malt, sessionable with a dry and moderate bitter body, but not too much character for a Dunkles. Mild sweetish-dry aftertaste, ok.
1l bottle from brewery. Pours a brown color. Caramel, malty extract, light fruity aroma.

Draught at the brewpub. It’s clear brown with a huge, creamy and lasting head. The aroma has notes of caramel, syrup and roasted malt. The flavor has a moderate sweetness and notes of caramel, light syrup, fruit and roasted malt. The finish is slightly dry and bitter with hints of nuts.

(Draught, from a wooden keg) Dark reddish amber color with a bright white, creamy head. Very diacetylic, sourish and mildly roasted-malty aroma. Roasted-malty, licoricey-salty, diacetylic flavor with a salty-roasty finish. Medium-bodied, slicky and low-carbonated palate. A decent, but quite unclean brew - can’t always win with these...

Draft served in a flight at the brewpub. Pours a slightly burnt orange color with a small khaki head that settles into a ring and film and laces the glass. "Pumpkin pie in a glass" isn’t quite the best deScriptor here because the use of actual pumpkin makes it a little more earthy and vegetal, where others use a bigger malt backbone and more spices to make theirs bigger and sweeter. This one also has your usual slate of spices - cinnamon and nutmeg, namely - and the malts are a bit lighter but still provide enough of a satisfying backbone. It’s all in balance, too. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation. Nicely done pumpkin ale.
Spicy pumpkin pie flavor. Pretty tasty actually. Sweet and creamy. I like. Had this poured from draft at Square One brewery in St Louis.
Draft sampler pours amber with a off white head. Aroma of malts, pumpkin and spice. Taste is cinnamon, cloves, pumpkin and malts.
October 30, 2012 on tap at brewpub. Clear dark golden pour with limited head. Typical pumpkin, has the malt, cinnamon and nutmeg along with it in aroma and taste. Light body and soft carbonation.
Draft at amber with white head. Aroma is nutmeg forward, cloves, and pumpkin. Flavors are sweet caramel, pumpkin mash, nutmeg and cinnamon, thin body, fizzy feel. Not bad.

Sampled at the brewpub. This is one of the better pumpkin brews in the area. It poured a dark copper-amber color with a white head. The aroma was lots of pumpkin with a little malt in the background. The taste was of pumpkin, clove and malt. Excellent finish with a nice pumpkin aftertaste. Very tasty.

Sample from beer fest in Augusta. Poured a copper color with a little hue to it. Smaller white head that was gone rather quick. Aroma was dominated by the pumpkin, with some nutmeg coming through. Flavor was spices, cinnamon and pumpkin in the finish. The more pumpkin beers I drink, the more I start to like them. This one was decent.

Sample at the brewpub. The beer is a dark copper-amber color with a thin off-white head that diminishes to a film eventually. Short strings of lacing on the glass. Pumkin aroma with some malt in the background. Medium body with flavors of pumpkin, clove, and malt. The finish is nicely spiced with a lingering pumpkin aftertaste. Above average overall.
I like that this has more pumpkin flavor than many I’ve tasted. The spice flavor is a bit much, though--it’s unbalanced. It’s a good effort, not great, but enjoyable.

Growler from the brewery. Color is copper. This beer is great for the style. Every sip tastes like a bite of pumpkin pie. Flavors of nutmeg, corriander, and yes pumpkin come through. Very drinkable, not too sweet or artificial, a great fall beer.
On tap at the brewpub. Trübes orange goldenes Bier mit einer ordentlichen weißen schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, leicht phenolisch, reife Banane. Geschmack hefig süß, reife Früchte, etwas Nelke.

(Bottled, 1.0l) Opaque, dark orange color with a medium head. Slightly smoky, dark-malty, dark-fruity, yeasty aroma with some sourness. Smooth, sahti-like, slightly roasty, ashy flavor with smoky hints. Medium-bodied, sahti-like-rough palate. A nice microbrew, like a "light" sahti.

I’ve had this bottle for about six years and finally decided to open this at a recent tasting. Pours clear reddish brown color with no carbonation. Aromas of sweet apples and brandy. Very sweet apple flavor with brandy and a hint of booze. I was expecting a lot more alcohol flavor due to the 16.5% ABV. Thick and syrupy mouthfeel. Interesting cider.

Poura a darker amber color with a thick syrupy texture. Smells of funked out apples that have been out in the sun and have turned sour. Get some honey and tannins in there as well. Very sweet and tannic apple characters with no carbonation. Goes down pretty easy and the sourness is subtle. Kind of a funky aftertaste of rotting apple though that kind of ruined it for me. Its not great but it isnt bad. Not something I’d buy again.

500mL corked bottle. Cork is crumbly and cider is seeping through most of it. Not a good sign. Let’s see. Ugly multi brown, flat. Looks heavy. Nose of rich apple pie, oak, subtle alcohol, lots of sweetness. Flavor of very sweet apples, oak, apple-pie-like-spice, caramel, honey, small dose of tannins, alcohol in second half and finish. Sweet calvados aftertaste. Full, smooth, viscous palate. Heavy, weighty. No noticeable cork related damage. They label it an aperitif cider- too sweet for that. Maybe just a couple ounces if served before a meal. Definitely more of a dessert drink. Share with a few friends, no way I’ll finish this bottle.
Cloudy amber golden color. Not too estery, but some apple pie notes. Not the best body. Not as smooth as expected. Below average

19-10-16 // 1000ml bottle from the brwepub. Shared at home. Best of Date passed for 2 weeks. Must be better fresh. Had a really light sour taste. Still a decent weizen. Yeasty, light banana. Not a heavy weizen.
At the brewery. Cloudy amber color, thick white head. Fruity, banana aroma. Sweet taste, low bitter, low sour. Fruity, malty aftertaste. Fresh carbonation, but hin texture.
1000ml Bottle from the Brewpub. Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes goldenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig, bananig. Geschmack hefig, bananig fruchtig, minimal würzig.

Tap. It’s unclear, warm golden with a creamy, lasting head. The aroma has notes of slightly sour yeast, wheat and light fruit. The sweet flavor has light barnyard sour notes of yeast, wheat, light fruit, and the finish is slightly dry with a light sweetness. A bit too sour for my liking.

Brewery tap. Blonde, cloudy. Soft citrus flavor with hints of skimmed milk. Also milk and citrus in the soft aroma. Goes down well, but doesn’t leave an impression, except for the shortish lemon aftertaste.

(Bottled, 1.0l) Opaque yellow-orange color with a large, bright white head. Acidic, not very sweet, banana-fruity aroma. Neutral, mildly acidic, sourish flavor with lemony fruitiness. Light to medium-bodied, quite foamy-carbonated palate. A pretty light and acidic weizen.
Bag in box at sraf. Pours pale, nose is pear, toffee, floral, taste is sweet, pear, juicy.
Bottle. Golden color. Soft grainy aroma. Grainy, dry, grassy flavor. Just below medium bodied. Grassy finish. Slightly disappointing.
0,5 l Flasche. Flacher Schaum, goldgelbes Bier. Geschmacklich leicht und süffig, kaum Bitterkeit. Den leicht erhöhten Alkoholgehalt schmeckt man nicht raus.

Flasche aus der Getränkewelt, Chemnitz (MHD: 8/14). - Tiefes Goldgelb, ins Orange spielend, blank. - In der Nase eher schaler zitrusfruchtiger Hopfen, Malzsüße. - Antrunk weich mit dezenter Malzsüße, einem Anflug von Karamel und eher gedämpftem orangenfruchtigem Hopfen. Mild rezent, vollmundig, weiches Mundgefühl. Im Abgang nur mäßig bitter mit etwas Orangenschale und Heu. Etwas trockener, mäßig bitterer Nachtrunk. Bei Erwärmung zeigen sich leider dumpf-pappige Aromen, die den guten Eindruck empfindlich trüben. - Recht süffiges, „rundes“, angenehm gehopftes Bier in Märzen-Stärke, das aber nur gut gekühlt schmeckt.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein klares goldgelbes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig, grasig, leicht metallisch. Geschmack hopfig, grasig, würzig, im Hintergrund leicht metallisch.

0.5 l bottle at Timo A’s. Golden color. Sweetish honeyish malty aroma with hint of herbal hops. Taste of malt and herbal-peppery hops in even balance with medium bitterness with some minerals in finish. Some metallic notes. Fairly good firmly malty pils, although tastes a little old (BB this month).

500ml bottle. Clear golden colour with average, frothy, diminishing, white head. Grainy and strawy aroma. Taste is strawy, minimally sweet hints of cereals, dry, minimally floral hoppy overtones; half-way lasting hoppy finish. Not a Pilsener IMO.
Bottle 50cl, a clear yellow beer with medium head. Nose is on cereal and round malt. Aroma is malty, slightly sweet, cereal touch and grassy hops, light caramel, very classic.

(bottle) pours a clear deep golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of pale malts, light cardboard and honey, with a hint of floral hops and pepper. flavour is mostly floral hops and straw, slightly vegetal, with notes of earth and apricots. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Geruch getreidig, leicht grasig. Etwas süßer Start, grasig. Mittig bittere Töne. Abgangs weiter bitter mit einigen Malznoten. Ok.
bottle from Bierzweg. Clear pale yellow, creamy white head. Malty base, light and elegant, with hoppy flavour and a touch of grass, hay and resine.
Sample, thanks to Jonas. A slightly hazy brown color. Aroma of strong caramelized fruits, toffee, melasse, grains. Taste of heavy sweet caramelized malt, melasse, boozy.

[Munich 2018] Thanks to Jonas! 330 ml. bottle. 2005 Vintage. Apparently this needed a lot of age & it was undrinkable fresh. Dark brown amber, no head obv. Nose is extremely cloying oxidized malt syrup. Taste is insanely sweet, baffling cloying sweetness overpowers the oxidation which still lingers in the finish, alcoholic syrup, sugar, caramel, orange, cough syrup,… Great but only in very small quantities, too much cloyingness but otherwise it wouldn’t work I think.
Dark brown and viscuous. Aroma is vanilla, nut, syrup, tonka as well, chocolate, maybe bourbon. Taste is incredibly oily honey. Sweet and oily syup mouthfeel. Good.
Black/brown color. Sweet malty aroma, huge malt ball vanilla flavor, very smooth. Almost no hops. This would be amazing with any kind of vanilla dessert. Wow, try it if you can!

0,33l bottle at Vienna gathering shared by jonas, big thanks. Bottled 17.11.2006. dark brown color, no head. smells of whisky, oxidation, spices, earthy, doughy, nice smell. full body, no carbonation, oily mouthfeel. tastes very oily, cocoa, bitter chocolate, raisin juice, caramelly, sirupy, cough sirup. finsihes rather sweet with notes of sirup, molasses and some cough sirup notes. very tense, actually I kind of like it.
Bottle, dach gathering. Pours dark brown. Aroma is sweet, booze, oxidized. Flavor is sugar, sweet, oxidized, malt, cinnamon, caramel. Finish is sweet. Overall: ok, tastes better than smells.

Bottle, many thanks jonas! Viscous hazy amber color with soapy head. Aroma is cough drop, oxidized, dried fruits. Taste is chocolate, real chocolate, very sweet. Extremely oily mouthfeel, no carbonation. If there were such a thing like chocolate oil, this would be it!
2006 Bottle at RBVG 2018 Grand Tasting. Dark brown color no head viscous pour. Aroma of burnt chocolate. Taate is oil lightly oxidized chocolate syrup. Drinkable and interesting

Likör artige Konsistenz, wie erwartet keine Schaumkrone. Es erinnert mich stark an Schwarzbrot und Rosinen und ist sehr süß. Der Alkohol tritt gar nicht mal so sehr hervor! Fazit: Schmeckt wie Flüssiges Schwarzbrot! Interessante Sache. :) Test vom 7.2.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,9,7,8,-,8 - 8,10

Auch wenn es Bierschnaps heißt so ist es doch richtiges Bier, 2005 wurden 340 Liter des Bieres gebraut, das in diesem Jahr im Guinnessbuch der Rekorde stand. Nur mit Hilfe von Sherry-Hefe konnte dies erreicht werden. Das Ergebnis ist allerdings alles andere als Ein Genuss, schon der Geruch erinnert an Dosenananas und damit ganz und gar nicht ab Bier. Im Mund hat man dann eine dickflüssige und sehr süße Masse, die allerdings nicht alkoholisch schmeckt, so viel ist sicher. Die Ananas ist merkwürdigerweise auch im Bier schmeckbar. Extrem süßer Nachgeschmack, der dennoch bodenständig wirkt. Keine Ähnlichkeit zu irgendeinem Bierstil erkennbar. Test vom 29.4.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,2,3,2,11,2 - 3,20
on tap-pours a tan head with black color. Aroma is dark roasty malt. Taste is dark roasty malt, smooth.

Amber-golden pour. The nose is quite clean with a well-lagered, munich malt sweetness. A bit of light herbal hoppiness on the back. Crisp but with a lightly spicy nose. A little bit of bready maltiness. It’s okay, but could definitely use a bit more zip.
Currently on as Beautiful Dreamer. Pours copper with a white thin head. Smells of caramel and some tea and earth. Tastes caramelly with a hint of bitterness on the finish. Solid.

on tap-pours a creamy offwhite head with copper color. Aroma is sweet medium malt-caramel. Taste is sweet medium malt-caramel, medium/dark fruit, smokey, secondary hops with a slight light bitterness at finish. OK carbonation. 3.5

Husky and grainy in the nose. Clear copper with decent head that recedes slowly to ring. Very sweet and somewhat grainy with plenty of buttery diacetyl and a light bitterness in the finish. Sticky, slightly oily mouthfeel. On tap at the brewpub with DYCSoccer17, MartinT and Rastacouere.

Well, I personally had the iconoclastic palate the day I met up with the other Montreal boys here. It seemed as though everything I thought was ok, they hated, and vice versa. Creamy, sweet caramel malt aroma with hints of btter and maybe brown sugar? Perhaps these are "lactic" aromas, but I am not so certain what lactic smells like. Coppery orange color with nice frothy off white head. This beer pulverizes me with malts. Tons of caramel, butter, and roasted notes. Mildly metallic, quite sticky. Not too shabby.
Hopeless lactic notes amongst the hay...A hop mini-fart sticks to the frail body which is not very sweet but still manages to be sticky...This place was not good with lagers at all that day...
Perhaps the best Oktoberfest I've had. Right up there with Trinity. Very rich and malty, with just enough hop fruitiness. Beautiful indeed!

column4: Redhook Brewery (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: on tap @brewery(only)-pours a white head with gold color. Aroma is faint wheat. Taste is wheat, mild hops bite. OK carbonation.

This is a marvelously quaffable brew. Sampled on draft at the brewery the beer poured a bright amber color with a large yellow-white head. The aroma is sweet light malts and crisp floral hops. The flavor is rich and malty with hints of caramel and light floral hops. Very nice.
Aus der Flasche im 2014-06 getrunken. Dieses leichte Helle trinkt sich ganz gut, aber ist leider auch recht langweilig.
Malt, honey and caramel aroma. Cloudy yellow to orange color with medium sized white head and floaters. Malty lager taste, some bitterness, mostly boring. Thin body, average carbonation. //bottle
Uit de fles. Bier stinkt. Smaakt raar, stal, niet best. Te veel koolzuurgas.
Bottle. Hazy orange beer with a small white head. Aroma is malty with notes of caramel, corn, toffee and wheat. Flavor is malty with notes of caramel, toffee, corn and wheat. Sweet.
Aroma slightly floral, weakly yeasty. Fairly sweet, floral, with lingering sweet aftertaste. Not good.

Aroma of weak cardboard and orange water. Has little head and an orange body with heavy carbonation. Flavour is soft malt and sugar grain notes with no complexity. Weak on the mouth. Boring on every level. What is the point of this?

0,33l Flasche. Trübes gelbes Bier, weisser Schaum. Es riecht nach Hefeteig mit einem Hauch Zitrone und Gras. Herb getreidiger etwas wässeriger Antrunk. Dann Säure und Metall. Schönes Konzept für dieses Bier, aber leider ist es mir geschmacklich zu flach. Hat was von einem Weizenbier-Schorle.
Ein mildes schwaches Bier. Geschmacklich ok, aber nicht mehr. Eine 4 ist das Maximum ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Coop. Pours slightly cloudy yellow with a medium head. Aroma is spent pale malts, grains, low butter. Body is light and dominated by a crisp carbonation, followed by a rather thin malt sweetness. Dough, grains, straw. Dry palate, watery. Good as a simple summer refresher.
Mutno naranèasta boja, dosta slatkasta i blaga piva. Ima samo 3.5% alk. Jedino fora n aovoj pivi je ovaj svizac na etiketi.

column1: Gale's Hard Cider The Chieftans Blend
column5: Draft at the winery. Aroma is lemons, oak, spice, tartness, funk, basement, peels. Flavor is spices, tart green apples, fruits, and tartness. Extremely dry. Probably the best cider I’ve had.

column1: Gale's Hard Cider The Chieftans Blend
column5: Pale golden color, slightly hazy. Mildly carbonated. Aroma is apple wine (a combination of weak apple juice mixed with a generic white wine). Flavor is just like the aroma, starting with apple, then becoming pleasantly tart, and then moving toward a wine-like and lightly woody finish. The aftertaste is somewhat sour and acidic. My wife thinks that the finish and after taste are reminiscent of gueze or moldy cheese. Body is slightly heavier than water and the carbonation and alcohol are nearly undetectable. When I initially poured this I was careful not to distrurb the yeast cake in the bottom. After the initial glasses, I swirled up the yeast in the bottom and poured the final glass. With the yeast mixed in, the color is like pear juice. Aroma is apples with a faint amount of yeast. The flavor is more tart and more like white wine than apples. The wood/oak flavor seems to come through a little more as well. The Gales Hard Cider "The Chieftans Blend" has a lot more character than the regular Gales Hard Cider. The apple aroma and flavor are more pronounced and the tartness is a welcomed twist. 750 mL brown bottle (7% alcohol), $6.99 from the Thomas Family Winery.
Bottle. Brown color. Malt, soft roast, chocolate and caramel in the aroma. Full bodied. Malty sweet, chocolate, caramel. Soft roasty finish with cacao. Delicious!

Bottle. Clear amber Brown, medium white head. Malty, dark honey Aromas. Taste is sweet, with light bitterness. Aftertaste is Malty, bready with a hint of honey. Medium Texturen, with a good and balanced carbonation.
bottle from Bierzwerg. Deep golden, almost amber colour, mid-sized creamy off-white head. Malty, slightly hoppy with hints of honey. Smooth palater, very velvetey.
Dark amber color. Malty grassy aroma and flavor with hints of butter. Caramelly notes.

Verhalten malziger Antrunk mit vereinzelten hopfigen Bestandteilen. Die leicht süße und getreidige Malzigkeit wird im Mittelteil deutlich stärker, wirkt aber weiterhin verhalten. Der Hopfen spielt hier eine größere Rolle, erkennbar ist nun, dass dieser ein leichtes Banenenaroma aufweist. Im Abgang wird das Malz abermals stärker und nimmt einen leicht röstigen Charackter an, die Süße schwindet zum Glück, so steht das nun kräftige und cremige Malz alleine. Das eindeutig beste Produkt der Brauerei. Test vom 15.1.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,11,12,12,9,12 - 11,70

The bottle looks really good, beer in the glass dark, but not black, nice head. Wonderful malty aroma with nice caramel notes. Starts malty, not too roasty. fine caramel notes and chocolate. Wonderful balanced. Finish not as strong as the beginning, could be a bit more intense, malty-earty notes. A really good bock!

Bottle. Clear medium to dark amber color with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, nutty. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. (Flavor is young and fresh). Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. (150208)

Bottle: Reddish-amber coloured, small foamy layer; sweet-fruity (black berries) and dark-malty nose; moderate sweetish flavour, medium bodied; moderate - again - sweet-bitter finish with a touch of metal and vegetables: Not very impressive, not very tasty, but quite well drinkable, nevertheless..........

(bottle) Clear, mahogany colour with a medium-sized beige foamy head. Sweet, dark-malty, slightly roasted aroma with caramel and light spicy hop notes. Sweet flavour, medium bodied with a smooth carbonation. Strong malt-accented taste with caramel and dense notes of dried fruits; sweetish malty and light bitter finish. Not that convincing for a dark Bock.

column1: Big Horn Gen X Pale Ale
column5: On tap @ CB and Potts Flatirons poured a clear amber with a small diminishing amber head. Aromas of carmel, toffee and toasted malt. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of malt, carmel and earthiness with a mildly bitter finish. Very drinkable but nothing special.

On tap @ CB & Potts Broomfield poured a clear reddish copper with a lasting amber head. Aromas of carmel, sweet malt, a hint of apple and light citrus. Palate was medium bodied. Flavors of carmel, sweet malt and a bit of fruitiness with a sweet lingering finish. This was one of the entries in the GABF Pro-Am competition.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Seems infected to the whazoo but still very pleasant. Champagney with bubble bath foam. Touch of peppermint. Some floral aromas. Light and slightly thin but very lively body. Finishes with a bit of nut spice. Spectacular.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: I had this beer at a party with some friends. I am not a Chai fan, but like IPA’s. But this beer is truly unique. Initial Chai essence, and then a well balanced and nicely bitter finish. This beer came out of a growler, so I assume it is on tap, but I’m not sure if it is available in bottles.

column2: San Luis Obispo, California, United States
column5: Bottled straight from the tap at the brewery. Kept cold at all times and drank about 3 weeks later. Opaque reddish orange, and for a Beer capped right in front of me from the tap, the head was absolutely amazing, thick and sturdy! Green, wet and citrucy hops, with sort of an acidic, herbal twang that almost smelled like a bad perm, something I’ve detected and hated before, but this time the C hops subdued this effect just enough for me to not be turned off by it. A really interesting mix of curry spices, hops and definately some tea leaves, possibly gunpowder. I detected some tea-like tannic bitterness along with the hops, the finish had oranges and spices, caraway seeds perhaps. A really interesting Beer that surprised me when I sampled it at the brewery, and I’m glad I brought one home.

Couldn’t imagine I would ever ever ever have an Asahi as a celebration beer but somehow time and place determine a lot. It’s super competitive to get into public daycare in Japan and my six month old daughter just got into our second choice. We decided to take a boat to Asakusa (Asahi headquarters area) and the boat only served special Asahi beers (no Super Dry). It was a warm February afternoon and we got seat at the back of the boat where it was open. A beer was a must. Would have been better if I brought something from my house but you deal with the hand you are dealt so I had this beer. Nice malt character with lots of caramel, bread and cherry notes. Not a masterpiece by any stretch but better than I hoped and I am a happy man.
On tap at Asahi taproom, Asakusa. Red color, clear, big white head. Aroma of light roasted malts, caramel and faint herbal. Light body, average carbonation, decent amber lager.
Pours bright clear amber. Aroma is malty, sweet, bread, caramel. Taste is malty, sweet, caramel.

caramel, toast, nuts, brown, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, flat. Malty and toasted aroma straight out of the can, but devolves into a boozy root-beer smell as it sits. Nearly headache inducing eventually. Thin, lightly sweet. Tastes artificial, and far boozier than a 5% a.b.v. Really not feeling this, and certainly doesn’t taste "premium". Not particularly dunkel-like either.

Can from supermarket in Kanazawa. Nose of caramel, toasted malt, and a bit of spice. Medium reddish/brown, thin tan head. Light roast malt, caramel, gentle bittering, thin sweet fruitiness, and a mild sweet finish. Thin-medium body. Okay. Would be better without the rice and starch. Shouldn’t really have "premium" on the label.
very very good dunkel style larger! clear and crisp so so clear, very drinkable.

On tap in the backstreets of Gion Matsuri. 300 yen for a small 500 yen for a large. I was told it was 6-7% ABV but I have no idea if that is accurate. A clear amber pour with a thick creamy beige head. The aroma is sweet grainy light caramel. Light bodied but somewhat watery. The taste is biscuit, light bready caramel goodness. Well balanced. Pretty good.
Bottle at Tokyo Dome Hotel. Clear amber-brown colour with a bit of head. Rather weak aroma of caramel, fruit, malt. No flavour really jumps out but there is a weak mix of caramel, dried fruit.
Draft (some german bar in Kyoto?). Pours a clear brown. A bigger malt flavour, drinks better than the standard Asahi.

Tap at the Asahi beer hall in Kyoto. Very much more a vienna or amber lager than a dunkel, but that’s what they call it. Pretty amber-red color with a very fine head. Aroma of caramel and fruit, though not very fragrant. Soft flavors of caramel, plums, cherry, plus a bit roasty in the finish. A bit of adjunct noticeable. Decent stuff for a macro.

On tap @ Rock Bottom Denver. Pours a hazed golden orange color with a white head. Nose is resinous pine, alcohol, and grapefruit. Lightly herbal. Some sweet caramel. Flavor is harsh resin. Bitter pine and grapefruit. Alcohol, sweet caramel, and a bit of orange.

Bottle, 500ml. A dark brown/black colour with a medium-sized brown head. Aroma of bready malts, chocolate, caramel and a little sour citrus. A very malty taste with bitter chocolate and caramel. Only slightly sweet. Cocoa and the usual Tarka sour citrus in the finish. Moderate carbonation. This has echos of Youngs Double Chocolate Stout, but isn’t as sweet and doesn’t have anything added to give the chocolate flavour. Generally I find that the typical Tarka sourness present in all their brews diminishes the beer, but in Black Hen it adds an interesting extra dimension to the flavour. I’ll be sure to have this again.

Handpull cask at the Elm Tree. Dark gold or honey brown. Take your pick. Not quite clear. Smells of TCP and fresh grass. Taste is sweet and herbal with notes of bay and caramel. Smooth finish. Good but odd. More odd than good.
Cask at the Standing Order. Pours light copper, nose is light zesty fruit, taste is sweet toffee.

Cask at The Moon Under Water (JDW), Watford on 5 Nov 2012. Poured a hazy golden, with a thin white head. Aroma of cake, dough and some floral hop. Grainy flavour, with some apples and cereal. Finish was light resin, toffee and copper.
Clouded golden ale with a small head. Is full of malts and malty bitterness.

Cask conditioned at The Royal Blenheim, Oxford. Amber with slight head. Quite a grainy, stewed type malt bitter with a sourish edge to it. Drying bitterness late on but it doesn’t save it. Not very good.

Cask, gravity dispensed, at the Back of Beyond (JDW), Reading. Golden amber with a ring of translucent head; floral aroma; soft and fruity in the mouth, with apples and pear flavours; then some warmth and a sustained, gentle, earthy, bitterness to finish. Not bad.
[Cask at the Monks Retreat (JDW), Reading] Amber with a moderate white head. Some florals, some lemon, some caramel, but it’s all rather vague, bland and messy. A half-hearted attempt at a beer.

Cask handpull at Society Room Spoons Maidstone. Golden brown with slight haze lasting near white head. some bisciut some malt. almost a bit of rubber. in good condition. some drying sting on finish. yes biscuit and just a touch of rubber. Fine
6th November 2008. Clear gold beer. Not to dry or bitter. A little sweet banana in there. Reasonably well balanced.

Cask @ Willow Walk, JDW, Victoria SW1. Pours a pale amber color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty citrus hoppy aroma. Fruity malty hoppy flavor with some hints of citrus. Has a fruity malty hoppy finish.
A clear light golden colour with a small thin white head. Strawberry aroma overlaying a light sweet maltiness. Similar flavour, light sweet malt and strawberry with a light dry finish.

Cask @ Flying Horse Hotel, Rochdale. Golden with a creamy head. Has an aroma akin to a fruit beer from Flanders and there’s plenty of strawberry in its taste as well, although the texture is familiarly ale-like.
Cask at Ealing beer festival 2013, London. A golden coloured pour with a thin white head on top. Definite strawberry aroma. Tastes of strawberries, slight bitterness.
Cask Stillage at the Metropolitan Cathedral Crypt, Liverpool 22/02/2001 Strawberry aromas and flavour are most definitely prominent here.

Cask, Jersey Fest 06. Bright orange/gold with a small head. Aromas are caramel and earthy strawberry. Some lemon sourness. Sweet with some sulphur. Flavours are sweet honey with caramel. Fruity with not a great deal of strawberry.

Recently brewed again for reopened Tipsy beer festival which I missed. Was happy to see it available at the 2019 beer & cider festival in St Helier, Jersey. A half pint, pours amber colour with little head. Aromas of malt. Tastes of biscuit & malt. Medium body. Medium fruity bitter finish. Decent bitter.
Cask gravity, Jersey BF 2007. Dark amber with a hoppy scent. Slightly bitter with a dry end. Slightly watery. Light carbonation.Slightly sweet, with straw and grass malts and hop. Simple, OK.

Cask, Jersey Fest 06. Dark brown with no head. Aromas are malty with chocolate and light weetabix. Some fruitiness. Flavours are rich and malty with some roast character. Dry and hoppy on the finish. Some pine bitterness. Moreish.

A Mes rate. Cask at Bar Fringe. Very clean gold with a thin white head. Plenty of fruity hoppage in the aroma with plenty of citrus and some pleasant tarty sour notes. Really sniggable actually. Similar flavour. Very Bank Top in style. Standard in content, really enjoyable in reality. Good dry citric finish. Jolly good session stuff with lots of flavour.

On Cask at NERAX 2008 Somerville, MA. A strong sour aroma that makes you expect a skunky beer, then a surprisingly excellent balance of light sour and citrus flavors. Very drinkable and continuous enjoyable flavor.
on cask at clockwork. clearly not in great condition - musty caramel, some citric sourness, rusty tea, caramel, flat and listless
Cask at Clockwork, Glasgow. A light golden beer with a rocky white head. The aroma is sweet citrusy, while the flavor is sweet with light notes of malt, citrus, and cardboard. The body is thin.
Cask at Clockwork, Glasgow. Orange /amber. Sweet and fruity. medium bodied with unusual flavour of salty old buns, notes of cellar and phenols. Salty finish.
Cask, Clockwork, Glasgow, RBESG 07. Clear golden, thin white head. Hoppy fresh, some citrus and floral hints. Dusty malt in the mouth, some hoppy grassiness.
Clockwork, not in good nick. Aroma is vinous tart fruit. Taste is similar, noteably tart.
Cask handpull at Clockwork, Glasgow. Pale gold, lasting white head. It’s a soft and gold and citrusy beer, little bit of stale malt. I think it’s pretty drinkable, decent tingly finish. Fine.
Cask Handpump at the Bar Fringe, Manchester 26/02/2005 Clear golden coloured hoppy and slightly citrrus flavour. Some dryness in the finish.

Cask, Jersey Fest 06. Hazy gold with a bubbly head. Aromas are biscuit malts with floral notes. Zesty lemon with grapefruit hoppiness and sulphur. Flavours are dry and hoppy and not very malty. Has zesty citrus with lots of grapefruit bitterness. Peppery and dry on the finish. Very tasty for its 3.6%

Bottle. Clear amber colour with a medium slightly off-white head, nose is malty, slightly roasty and floral with notes of hay, bread crust and honey, taste is roasty and slightly sweet with a malty and quite dry finish.
Looks great, tastes to have more interésting name. Well flavoured with Austrian Hops

Bottled:Aroma is light malty sweet. Light bronze, hazy color with small head. Fine malty, pithy and light nutty flavor. Light to medium sweetness, medium bodied. Remarkable bitterness in the end, quite dry finish.
Draft. Bronze beer with an off-white head. Slight caramel and grassy aroma. Caramel, grassy, earthy flavor. Slight astringency. LIngering low grassiness. Medium bodied.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours cloudy copper witha sweet floral banana aroma and a nice beige head. There is a thin caramel malt flavor with a dry slightly bitter finish.
Draft. bronze beer with an off-white head. Low caramel aroma. Caramel, slight earthy, spicy flavor. Lingering caramel sweetness. Medium bodied, Easy to drink.

Draft at the brewpub. Roasted caramel aroma (not very roasted) with floral hop. Slightly reddish amber color with a transient white head. Smooth, medium bodied, with near creamy carbonation. Roasted caramel with balancing floral hop. The finish is very balanced. Rather consistent from start to finish.
Draft. Copper color with a big off-white head. Sweet toffee/caramel aroma. Balanced malt/earthy caramel flavor. Medium bodied. Very clean. Slight vanilla flavor.
On tap at The Hideout Brewpub. Hazy amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of toasted malt, caramel and light fruit. Taste of toasted malt right of the ferry from Munich, caramel and mild hops.
on tap at brewery. pours dark amber with nice head. aroma is very subtle, almost nutty. flavor is malty, mildly hoppy, very smooth.
on tap...unfiltered orange body with small white head...light piney hop aroma and flavor backbone, leading to a more malty, toasty and sugary body...nice herbal component here as well...nice palate

On tap at Hideout. Hazy orange-brown body, thin off-white head. Toasty aroma with grassy hops. Nutty, biscuity body, with toast and brown sugar complementing grassy, earthy hops. Fruit skin adds a sweet component. Leafy finish. Good complexity and dangerous drinkability. Resembles some brewers’ Oktoberfests, but Hideout’s Oktoberfest is a heavier, sweeter beer with greater emphasis on caramel.

column1: Fort Street A Feather in Your Cap
column5: Tap: golden yellow, 2 finger white head. Great lacing. Soft pale malt sweetness up front, faint grass and yeast. Flavor again pale malt up front, corn like sweetness through the middle, decent grass and floral finish. On par, pils aren’t my thing though.

column1: Fort Street A Feather in Your Cap
column5: On tap: Aroma is loaded with orange and orange peel. Transparent gold with a touch of haze and a moderate white head with good retention. Sweet lager yeastiness up front with some light citrus notes. Big flowery hopped finish with a touch of citrus hops as well. With all the orange and orange peel in the aroma, it suprisingly not there much at all in the flavor.

Commissioned by a rugby club. Very thick, rocky, off-white head even increasing a bit after pouring but eventually collapsing into loose ’islands’; brownish orange blonde colour, cloudy. Fruit sweetishness, herbal hoppiness, melon, pineapple, bark, earth, pepper, dill, soap, mint. Rather neutral onset with restrained fruitiness, sharpish carbonation, one-dimensional maltiness with spicy yeasty notes, peppery, dry hop bitterness in the finish. Not well-balanced, like most Bouillon beers.
Bottle. Pours a hazy and light amber beer with a white head. The aroma is malt, yeast, fruit and spices with anis. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall an average beer.
Hazy golden with a small white head. Weak malty and spicy aroma with a yeasty note. Sweet flavour dominated by yeast and spice
Bottle @ Odense Tasting, December 2010. Pours cloudy golden with a white head. Nose is yeast and spices. Dry and spicy flavor. Medium bodied. Ok
Pours golden with a white head, chunks. Flavour is malt, fruit, yeast, dry and light paper. Flavour is malt, sweet fruit, yeast and alcohol.
Dark golden coloured and white head. Litte sweet and bitter, too simpel taste, notes of honey and fruit gives a direction thoiugh

Bottle 330ml. Clear medium orange yellow color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, flowers, honey, moderate yeasty. Flavor is moderate sweet and light light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20100917]

Bottle 33 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours golden with loadsa floaties and a white head. Fruit and phenols in the nose. Medium body, fruit, Belgian yeast and perhaps a whiff of honey. A drinkable Bouillon though. 170910
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, yeast, hops and honey.

(bottle, 33cl) Hazy, deep golden coloured hue with loads of particles floating around under a medium-sized foamy white head. Moderately sweet and subtle grainy malty aroma with distinctive notes of honey and a touch of fruity and mouldy sourness. Sweet flavour, medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Malty and slightly fruity taste with a tinge of honey and a minor dry-out effect towards the sweet and slightly bitter-tart finish. Simple and easy-going brew. 22.III.10

11/7/2008, snifter at Clybourn. Black with a dark brown edges, and a one finger beige head that faded to a ring after a few minutes. Lots of bourbon up front in the aroma, but the smoke opens up quite a bit as it warms, and comes out as smoky wood and/or campfire, not smoked meat. A fair amount of roast and chocolate is also present. Flavor still has plenty of bourbon and wood, and there’s still a fair amount of smoke, but it is a bit underwhelming. Bone dry with bitterness at a 4. Not BCS bourbony, though. Low to moderate carbonation with a full body. I prefer regular Ed, as the bourbon here is overdone--my particular batch spent nine months in the bourbon barrels.

FoBAB 2008. Poured an opaque dark brown color with a soapy tan head. Nice aroma of vanilla, bourbon, subdued smoke, and a hint of bacon. Medium to full bodied and delicately sweet. Flavor followed the aroma with smoky bacon, chocolate, booze, and vanilla. The barrel aging was a nice addition to an already great beer.
Pours brown with no head. Sinky fresh smoked nose. Not too hammy or porkish. Flavor is a bit more meaty with a bit of ash and a lot of alcohol heat. Medium easy drinking body with a long finish.

Draft at GI Clybourn. Pours dark brown, almost black with almost no head. Very noticeable carbonation. Aroma is of smoked meat, vinegar, raisiins, roasted malt, and bourbon. Heavy alcohol presence in the aroma. Taste is very heavy malt, balanced by smoky meat flavors, bourbon, and chocolate. Mouthfeel is thick and sticky. Alcohol is not hidden, but right up front in the taste. Amazingly good.

Tasted 4/30/08. Sample from Clybourne. My notes only said "Ed", so I called the brewpub and they were less than convincing that this is the beer I sampled. But, hey, here goes. Filtered with a dark brown hue with ruby highlights. Smokey nose. Good smokey nose. Full bodied and rich. Good smoke malt character. Mild effervescence and a nice hidden burn. Mild hops. Sticky and nutty with a cola note. Solid example of a smoke beer, but still not really my thing.

Dark dark brown color, off white head. Bacon, beef jerkeyesque tanned leather nose. Interesting, just a little too much towards the meat side. Flavor is something alltogether different. Beautiful chocolate and smoked malt blend together extremely well with a back end of roast to finish it off.

Tap at Clybourn, served in snifter (too cold), Boy I was so happy to see this listed after passing on it at FoBAB: Mahogany hued with a small but lasting beige head that left some foam on the glass along with some oily legs. The aroma is powerful but not as much bourbon as I figured, some vanilla along with smoky charred oak. Also detected walnut, chocolate, caramel, rye bread, raisin, ripe cherry, and some pepper esters, NICE! The flavor start with a nice dose of sweet caramel and toffee malts, bready and vanilla too. The midsection displays a molasses and fruity twang (not sour however, again more akin to ripe sweet fruits) before leading off towards the smoked meaty and lightly spiced finish. A bit boozy but it did not get in the way and actually helped cleanse the palate. The mouth feel is sticky and oily with prickly biting towards the finish. This rocked and is without one of the better smoked beers I have had of late. Too bad I once again could not get a growler, sniff.

Date: 02/10/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Extreme Beer clear brown, scant frothy head, sweet smokey chocolate aroma, creamy body, chewy smokey chocolate and bacon, strange combination that somehow works, a bit more caramel sweetness than the normal smoked brown which may be the secret to this beer Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.6/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I would like to rerate this beer.

Nose: wet grass, melon, ice Head: medium-small, dissolves after a few minutes Eye: clear, light, medium amount of bubbles Taste: orange peel, sweet turns to bitter, aftertaste stays sweet Overall: nice refresher but after a pint it’s too sweet for me and so wouldn’t do for an all-nighter
Bottle 33 cl. Clear golden, lacing white head. Biscuity aroma. Medium body, soft and mellow malts, some cardboard. Hardly any bitterness. Quite overrated. 230719
Bottle from Sainsbury’s, Edinburgh. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, corn and light hoppy - straw. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 150419

Had on draft in Scotland. Not bad for a lager, a bit of a light scent, deep golden color, light lager taste. It’s an ok local beer but I’ll probably try something else ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask conditioned at Harbury Beer Fest ’07. Dark brown with no head. Heavy coffee notes with a strong and punishing bitterness. A sharp acidity sits in the background, it is a challeging beer and not one to try often.

Cask handpump at The Wellington, Birmingham. Black with almost no head. Some citrus and toast in the nose. Very watery. Dry finish and slightly sour. The bitterness hits you at the back of the throat, with the slight hint of dark chocolate, not before. In the front, there is nothing much more than lime and water. Despite this, it is quite rich. I agree with Doppelganger, however, that it really is not worth the name.

Gravity, Oxford CAMRA Festival. Brown/brown with a small layer of off-white head. Burnt marshmallow and toast aroma, which actually is more pleasant than that would imply. A buttery quality add a nice softness to the aroma. Perked coffee flavor, carmel. Lighter roast and body than the aroma lead you to expect. Mineral, slightly plastic finish. For something with a name like Death by Chocolate, it seems like the chocolate is fairly minimal, and the palate is on the thin side. Not a bad stout, but doesn’t live up to it’s billing. Not a lethal dose of chocolate at all. (Shut up! You’ll be dead in a minute!)

Bottle. High creamy and lasting light brown head. Pitch black body. Mild coffee choccolate aroma and flavor with a good deal of hops bitterness. High carbonation. Long aftertaste. Ginseng? Sorry mates I could find no traces of it.
Canned in KL, Malaysia. Well I could really taste the ginseng, otherwise kind of mediocre.

The standalone Stout is a very good counter to all of the locally produced lagers. It has a great coffee and dark roast malty flavour that oddly works well in a climate such as in Malaysia. I had a couple the other night with some stir fried pork (yes pork in KL!) down Chinatown way. On the other hand ginseng is one of those herbal additives that are said to be good for many a common malaise. But it tastes like medicine. When added to this beer it still tastes like medicine. A shame but still erk.

Can Black color; thin persistent foam layer. Mixed aroma of roasted malt and herbs, ginseng, yes. The body is medium structured, with a strong roasted malt flavor, some sourness from it, a typical ginseng bitterness; dusty. Not bad, but a FS and ginseng are two flavors that I don’t love, together they don’t make much better.

wow i really wasnt expecting to find anything like this in Malaysia. this beer grabbed me by the head and didn’t let go for a while. aroma is roasted malts and herb. flavor is sweet, thick on the palate. black in color. not sure about the ginseng effects but the alcohol was definitely there.
Bottle. Black colour with a reddish shine and with a light brown head. Aroma of roots and earth. Strange flavour of roots, ginsing and some roastedness. Very special.

Bottled. A black beer with a red shine under a thick brown head. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of roasted malt as well as spicy notes of the ginseng, while the flavor is plainly sweet malty with a dry roasted end. Not my thing.

Deep reddish brown colour with a light brown head. Roasted malty aroma with a light chocolate sweet note and hints of the ginseng. Light roasted flavor with a sweetness from overripe fruits. Bitter finish with notes of ginseng.

Bottled. Dark reddish brown coloured. Light brown head. Distinct flavour and aroma of ginseng and ginger. In the aroma theres some fruits as well. Flavour is apart from the very dominant spices light roasty, light buttery and grassy. Medium bodied. Is a very weird brew, that I have problems liking.

Bottle. Pitch black colour, light nrown head. Aroma of ginseng, roasted malt, chocolate. Flavour is spicy (ginseng), lots of maltiness and good chocolate, with bitter hops. Long dry aftertaste of roasted malt and chocloate. Thick tasty stout, quite unusual.

column1: He'Brew Monumental Jewbelation Tenth Anniversary Ale
column2: Clifton Park, New York, United States
column5: From May 2007 This pours from 22oz bottle(Brewed and bottled in Saratoga Springs, NY) a dark brown with a medium sized off-white head of foam that shrinks quickly leaving just a ring around the glass with a little lacing. The smell is pretty big. I note caramel malt, roasted malt, and an ample nose of alcohol. The taste on first sip has the caramel malt right up front and it's pretty sweet but it's joined almost immediately by some very nice roasted malt tones and some dark chocolate that stops the flavour from becoming too sweet. Nice and, boy, this is going to be a sipper for me for sure because I'm getting the alcohol kick right after the swallow and it's quite warming but the flavours of this American Strong Ale are very tasty so I'll have no problem dealing with that. ;^) Further sips in and I'm now getting some toffee and *that* just makes me smack my mouth in appreciation and...the finish starts off sweetish, turns toward the bitter side but ends up on a slightly sour note leaving a lingering and delicious aftertaste. I'm pretty impressed with how complex and diversified the flavours are but they all work together very nicely. The only "negative" thing I can say about it is that, for me, it's not something that I can finish at one sitting. Not a 22oz bomber. But that's okay. Bottom line: This is a pretty impressive example of the style in my book. If you haven't tried it before and see some, buy one and sip on it. PS: I'm "capping" the 1/2 bottle I have left and I'll sip on it some more tomorrow.

column1: He'Brew Monumental Jewbelation Tenth Anniversary Ale
column2: Clifton Park, New York, United States
column5: Bottle buried in my cellar. I know I had this fresher, but this is in front of me now. Pours a clear amber brown color with a small beige head. The aroma and flavor are caramel, toffee, ample dark fruits, a hint of orange, oxidation is noticeable, hops are long gone, decent considering the age.

column1: He'Brew Monumental Jewbelation Tenth Anniversary Ale
column2: Clifton Park, New York, United States
column5: On tap at Champps in Brookfield. This should be the correct one ... called Monumental, and advertised as 10 hops and 10 malts. Reddish brown pour. Sweet malts and stone fruits. Thick, strong and somewhat grainy. A definite alcohol presence. And rough. Very much a stereotypical "American Strong". To the sweet side of bittersweet. A tough brew to drink. Too much to it to really enjoy. 13.7

column1: He'Brew Monumental Jewbelation Tenth Anniversary Ale
column2: Clifton Park, New York, United States
column5: I liked this one. Pretty good balance between the malts and hops. A lot more hoppy than sweet, but that is expected of this kind of ale. I wouldn’t call it a hop bomb though. This was my first introduction to the Hebrew Beer family. I tried one or two others besides this, and I would say that this was their best that I tried. Probably not a beer that will "super-wow" you or to beermail your buddy about, but I’d say it is worth trying. I would buy again....especially for the 10% ABV!

column1: He'Brew Monumental Jewbelation Tenth Anniversary Ale
column2: Clifton Park, New York, United States
column5: Sweet, plum like, and dark fruit. Slight brandy like flavor. Good, but not as good as some of the later jewbelations.

column1: He'Brew Monumental Jewbelation Tenth Anniversary Ale
column2: Clifton Park, New York, United States
column5: 2006 vintage keg at Black Squirrel. An interesting beast to be sure – it would have been interesting to try this eight years ago as well. Pours muddy dark brown with great head and lacing. Roast and smoked peat aroma in malt. Good head and lacing. Finishes with medium bitterness. Same aged taste in this as well. Light astringency. Very thick consistency. Good stuff.

column1: He'Brew Monumental Jewbelation Tenth Anniversary Ale
column2: Clifton Park, New York, United States
column5: Sampled on draft at Hou Thou this beer poured a black color with a small foamy tan head that faded quickly and left no lacing. The aroma was strong sweet dark fruits, plum, cherry, raisin and tart grape jelly. The flavor was tangy and tart grape jelly, plum, raisin, cherry, a bit of toffee and tobacco. Somewhat boozy. Long tart and tangy fruit, toffee and booze finish. Full bodied. Excellent.

column1: He'Brew Monumental Jewbelation Tenth Anniversary Ale
column2: Clifton Park, New York, United States
column5: 12oz bottle, part of the 2011 re-release, has spent at the majority of that time in the fridge. There is a little pleasant oxidation right off the bat. Aroma of dark fruits, dark caramel, dark chocolate, some vanilla and a little orange peel. Thick and chewy, but mostly balanced in the end. The dark fruit and chocolate lingers in the finish, making this a nice night cap. Warming, but not hot, alcohol.

column1: He'Brew Monumental Jewbelation Tenth Anniversary Ale
column2: Clifton Park, New York, United States
column5: Another solid offering in this series of strong beers. Trippelish, lots of dark fruit, breadiness, and tons of alcohol.

column1: He'Brew Monumental Jewbelation Tenth Anniversary Ale
column2: Clifton Park, New York, United States
column5: Tasted off draft at "Kickback’s" in Riveside, Jacksonville, FL. Would recommend trying this one if you can get your hands on it still!

draft at the southport location poured a dark brown in color with a decent tan head. aroma has sweet brown malt, chocolate, mild spice, and a bit of brown sugar. mouth feel is solid medium and coats well. flavor has good malted base, chocolate, medium sweetness, and some spice. I will agree this is the best beer tried from these guys.

This beer goes by many different names, but is going by the name #65 this year. Pours a brown mahogany color with a thin but persistent ring of tan bubbles. Smells of licorice, sweet malt and some cloves. As it warms, some raisins and figs show themselves. Tastes of chocolate, nuts, earthy hops, lots of spices. A grassy metallic element takes a little away from the taste, but this is otherwise a great example of this style. The alcohol on this one is well masked. By far the best beer I’ve tried from this brewer.

Draft - October 2006 At the brewpub in Villa General Begrano during the Oktoberfest. Pours a deep beatifull copper color with a nice white head that last just enough. Aroma is malty and toasty. Taste is very balanced, a bit to the sweet side, a bit grainy and an intriguing smok/ ham aftertaste. Mouthfeel is medium and creamy. Interesting.
