column2: Santa Rosa de Calamuchita - Cordoba, Argentina
column5: Bottled at Monk’s Café Wallingatan, Stockholm. Pours out in a clear ruby amber colour with a small creamy tan-coloured foam. Earth, nuts and cocoa in the aroma with touches of oranges, banana and berries. Light-bodied with notes of roasted malts and dough. Metallic and doughy finish.

column2: Santa Rosa de Calamuchita - Cordoba, Argentina
column5: Bottled at Monk’s Café Wallingatan, Stockholm. Deep ruby, small head. Very dry and lightly fruity with notes of black currant. Light bodied with clean, spritzy mouthfeel, notes of dusty dough. Black currant outpower the vague bitterness. Simple, but pleasant.

column2: Santa Rosa de Calamuchita - Cordoba, Argentina
column5: Bottle- October 2006. Pours a trasucent brownish black color with almost no head and cola like fizzy carbonatation. Aroma is almost non existant. Taste is neutral with some burnt and resiny notes. Watery mouthfeel. Boring and flat.

column1: Left Hand SmokeJumper Imperial Smoked Porter
column5: Pours black with two finger, tan head. Aroma is heavy smoke and some caramel. Taste is brown sugar and nuttiness, warming to strong smoke, roast and a touch of clove. Finish is smoky malt. A very good smoked beer.

column1: Left Hand SmokeJumper Imperial Smoked Porter
column5: I can't think of a better tribute to Colorado's smokejumpers than this beautifully balanced Imperial Porter with a smoke element. Modern brewing takes everything to extremes be that roast, alcohol, hops, sourness, or smoke. This Smoked Porter is much more reserved by comparison. Pour is just between brown and black. There's a touch of smoke on the nose, but it's barely noticeable along with the roasted malts. Flavor is slightly more smoky, but "slightly" is the operative word. While some of these beers go to ash try levels of smoke or have a meatiness comparable to a smokehouse, Smokejumper instead keeps it to a minimum and lets the toasted barley and herbal hops come through. There was even a bit of syrupy malty sweetness redolent of honey. Both the smokejumpers and the brewers at Left Hand deserve to have glasses raised in tribute to them.

column1: Left Hand SmokeJumper Imperial Smoked Porter
column5: Bottle. A- Mild smoke, cola. A- Dark brown color, dark liquid, light brown head. T- Smoke, cola, cocoa, molasses, roasty, mild bitterness. P- Full body, average texture, average carbonation, roasty finish. O- This is almost as much Imperial Stout as it is Smoked beer. The smoke is very much there but not overwhelming. Really balanced and no umami sort of flavors.Paired very well with some potato bologna. This bottle had about 2 years of age on it.

column1: Left Hand SmokeJumper Imperial Smoked Porter
column5: From a bomber purchased in Denver it is a dark brownish black color With a creamy tan head the Aroma is a roasted malt And the taste is mild bitter with hints of smoke and shoe polish flavor With a smiley finish

column1: Left Hand SmokeJumper Imperial Smoked Porter
column5: From a bomber purchased in Denver. Pours a clear deep cola with a creamy tan. Aroma of roasted malt with smoke smokiness. Flavors are mild bitter and smoke. Pretty decent.

column1: Left Hand SmokeJumper Imperial Smoked Porter
column5: Bacon, toasted malt, light maple, campfire, and barley. Taste is toasted malt, slightly sour, blackberry, a little juniper.

column1: Left Hand SmokeJumper Imperial Smoked Porter
column5: 22oz Bottle on the RBSG bus tour. Dark brown, opaque, small tan head. Smokey, ashy aroma. Taste reflects the smoked malts, campfire, ashtray, tobacco. Dry finish with small bitter bite

column1: Left Hand SmokeJumper Imperial Smoked Porter
column5: Bottle share at the RBSG 2017 in Boise. Pours dark black with a tan head. Nose is heavily smoked malts. Medium body. Flavor is a ton of smoke and chocolate and coffee. Finishes somewhat dry and bitter. Superb.

column1: Left Hand SmokeJumper Imperial Smoked Porter
column5: Sampled on draft this beer poured a very dark brown color - almost black - with orange highlights and a medium sized foamy tan head that left decent lacing. The aroma was bacon and toasty malts. The flavor was sweetish, toasty and woody with notes of bacon and bread crust. Long finish. Medium body. Solid.

column1: Left Hand SmokeJumper Imperial Smoked Porter
column5: Enjoyed at BTBF 2017. Hazy brown color, tan head. Heavy smoke aroma! Deep smoke. Malts, Roast. Flavor is beefy smoke, roasted malts. Rauchbier for sure.

column1: McCall Brewing Black Diamond Oatmeal Stout
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a dark cloudy color with a medium white head. The aroma is mostly sweet chocolates and milky notes. The flavor is similarly a smooth rich chocolate and milky/earthy mix. Quite nice.

column1: McCall Brewing Black Diamond Oatmeal Stout
column5: On draft at the brewpub. This poured very black with a tan head and moderate lacoing rings. Nose is strongly of roasted malts with chocolate, coffee, and ripe fruits. Rich and creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is much like the nose with chocolate and roasted malts dominate, and there is some light hop bitterness in the finish. This is a well done beer.

column1: McCall Brewing Black Diamond Oatmeal Stout
column5: Tap @ Brewery: Black with a light head, some tan lacing. Nose of pleasant sweet roasted chocolate and light coffee. Subtle maple, vanilla and brown sugar with some cream. A nice sweet roastiness. Mellow mouthfeel, light roasted fruity flavor. Clean finish and a lingering light hop bitterness. A little lacking toward the flavor side, but a great nose and decent followthrough.

column1: McCall Brewing Black Diamond Oatmeal Stout
column5: On tap at brew pub Pours out a black topped with a nice cream tan head. A nice aroma of coffee and swettness. Tast of coffee bitter dark chocolate. Not bad.

column1: McCall Brewing Black Diamond Oatmeal Stout
column5: On Tap: Dark brown, near black pour with a tich tan head and thick lacing. The description proclaims this to be thick, dark, and of chocolate; and is mostly correct. There is also a blend of coffee and roastedness that leads into a bittersweet chocolate finish. Quite good!

column1: McCall Brewing Black Diamond Oatmeal Stout
column5: On Tap at brewpub: Inky black color with a rich malty, choco-coffee aroma along with butter and alcohol. Even though you can detect the 7.3 alcohol % in the aroma, it is hidden well in the actual tasting. The flavor is big and rich - dominated by coffee and butter. It has a smooth slick aftertaste. This brew is extremely enjoyable. Do not drink it if you are looking for bad beer. Well done brewmaster Greg on this new one!

Tap at brewpub. Pours deep black with an olive-green head; nice lacing. Smoky chocolate aroma. Wood-smoked chocolate flavor. Mouthfeel is thick and spreads nicely along the tongue. Great brew; definite repeat.

column1: Rock Bottom South Denver Raspberry Wheat
column5: cask at the brewpub. well, it is a decent looking beer. hazed dark yellow and a white head. smelled of lemon, and some raspberry. taste was thin honey, a bit of raspberry, and a good dose of lemon. this is not a beer that will scare anyone away. i think my bartender put it best, it is really more of a beer for the ladies. a very timid flavor all around.

This beer was very different. I had Baird Pale Ale, Shiga Kogen Draft Pale Ale and then this and the scope of what a pale ale is, blew my mind. This is a deep, deep, deep mahogany color. It looks much closer to a brown ale or a dopplebock than any pale ale I have ever seen. The nose is very soft with a touch of malty buscuitiness and a touch of hops. The mouth is velvet. I have never drank a softer beer in my life. My friend said it was like something from Trent on Burton Pale Ales. I was amazed. There was a soft soapiness and a touch of toffee flavors in the softness. Mildly bitter finish. Interesting.

column1: Birra del Borgo Christmas Ale Special 2006
column5: From 2006 and drunk March 2008, think it would be way better if it was fresh. Hazy deep orange with a small white head. Aroma was strong spicey along with fermented mandarine (was probably fresh few years ago), the spices included cloves and pepper. Flavor was sweet/spicey and completly lacking hops i think.

column1: Birra del Borgo Christmas Ale Special 2006
column5: Bottled. A gusher when opened. A murky orange beer with lots of sediment floating around under a lazing tan head with small specks of sediment. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of oranges and caramel, but also a light plastic note. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of spices, caramel, and oranges, leading to a dry spicy finish, the spices include cinnamon and cloves. Drunk a month prior to the best before date - should probably have a shorter best before date on it, since I think the gushing is due to too much refermentation in the bottle.

column1: Birra del Borgo Christmas Ale Special 2006
column5: It’s a vintage 2006 and I had it January 2008. Red-golden and hazy with a huge, nice head. The aroma has notes of Christmas spices, orange, malt, caramel and sweetness. The mouthfeel is annoying, the carbonation makes it very fizzy. The flavour has a slightly bitter grapefruit note, a light sweetness, spices, old (OK meant) orange peal, slightly sour malt and grapefruit in the finish. IMO the balance could have been better.

column1: Birra del Borgo Christmas Ale Special 2006
column5: Bottle. Unclear light to medium amber color with a huge, frothy, excellent lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, hay, moderate to heavy hoppy, grass, peper, spices, pepper. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet, and moderate bitter with a long to average duration, and a nice dry finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is lively to soft. (171107)

column1: Birra del Borgo Christmas Ale Special 2006
column5: bottle. golden color. large head. very sweet and xmassy. bits floating around in the bottle. not nice.

column1: Birra del Borgo Christmas Ale Special 2006
column5: Bottle bought in Tivoli gardens. Pours amber with a light brown head. Aroma of spices, roasted/caramel malt. Flavour is sweet, somewhat fruity and spicy/herbal. Dry finish. Overall an enjoying Christmas brew.

column1: Birra del Borgo Christmas Ale Special 2006
column5: Bottled. Clear (though still chunky) deep amber collured with an off-white head. Oh my god the sweetnessss! Notes of syrups, candied sugar, bread and liqouriice. Very sticky and strange.

column1: Birra del Borgo Christmas Ale Special 2006
column5: Bottle (Per). Clear amber (with small parts in) - white head. Sweetness, candy, caramel, raisins, ryebread, sharp, licorice, a bit sour. It sounds good - but is a bit wierd.

column1: Birra del Borgo Christmas Ale Special 2006
column5: Pours a dark amber with a tanned head. Smelled of vinegar as I opened the bottle after that brown sugar with a hint of apple. VERY sweet with lots of caramel and fudge flavors. Buttery, I suspect a diacetyl infection. Dry and very sweet finish with some flowers and sugar. Way too sweet.

column1: Birra del Borgo Christmas Ale Special 2006
column5: Bottle. Brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is hop, cellar notes, fruit. Flavour is sweet, hop, cellar notes. Mild and easy drinkable.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Draught at Benelux. Pours a deep brown along with some ruby hues and a small lasting creamy off-white head. Slightly mild aroma is malty and yeasty along with a bit of "metal" and fruit. Flavour of Belgian yeast, caramel malt, dark fruit and some light floral hops. Medium to full bodied. Pretty good but I expected better.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: On cask at Benelux 4th anniversary Appearance : Dark amber. Aroma : Spicy and sugary. Notes of red fruits. Taste : Fruity and spicy. A bit mineral. Finish is mineral, spicy and fruity. A bit sweet but rather dry. Overall : Nice fruity profile. A bit too spicy and mineral. Not so good. I was a bit disappointed by this one.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Appearance: deep dark red with a small off White head. Aroma: slightly metallic, malt, quite a lot of yeast too. Flavour: Yeast & malty as hell, bran, bread, Raisins, sticky, long malty finish.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: At Benelux. Cloudy ruby with a solid lasting creamy beige head. Aroma is tantalizing - like a roasty/caramel Orval-y thing. Taste is nicely balanced between roasty sweet caramel, pungent floral/grassy bitterness and dry spice - hardly any alcohol at all. Sticky and slight astringent mouthfeel, a nice dry pungent and yeasty linger. solid stuff.

column4: Benelux - Brasserie Artisanale / Brasserie du Canal
column5: Tap at brewpub. Well-done strong brown belgian, comparable to some quadrupels I had but without the magnificience... Medium to full body, with more spicyness than sweetness and with a powerful herbal hop presence taking a lot of place in the mouthfeel. Notes of various spices and a discreet caramel touch. Nothing seems wrong but nothing is overwhelming neither.

EBF 2007 - had to try this one, both for the name and the unique recipe - reddish purple pour, with minimal head - very earthy, vegetable aroma, though not specifically of beets - the beets are there in the flavor, though, along with notes of other root veggies, like taro and parsnip - moderate sweetness ads on almost fruity aspect to the otherwise heavy vegetable flavor - I’m not a big fan of beet, and because they’re so apparent I didn’t enjoy this as much as I could have, but I have to give them credit for making something so unique.

Draft at The Tap. This was an odd one-I applaud the brewers at The Tap (and everywhere, for that matter) for having the guts to brew using very unorthodox ingredients. Unfortunately, for every successful experiment there are many failures. This one is most defiantly not going to be produced for mass consumption, but it was fun to try! Body is red like cranberry juice, nose is sweet and beety. Taste is exactly what you would expect-beets and malt sweetness. The beet flavor was not too much, like I had anticipated. A fun beer to try, but I don’t believe I would ever have it again. Once again, I tip my hat to the brewer who was creative enough to attempt this beer.

Tap @ The Tap. Pours an incredible lighter red, not exactly blood, but pretty cool. Nose is sweet and fruity. Flavors are a light raspberry/cranberry,smidge of sweetness and quite good. No way you notice that this one is 8%. Nor can you taste the presence of beets, just their residual sugar. The alcohol is very well hidden. Be careful with this one, although this blood is everyones type, too many may raise the levels of blood fairly high but check it out!
on tap-pours amber with a light tan head. Aroma is soft carmel-medium malt, nutty, earthy. Taste is carmel-medium malt, nutty, earthy. Some off notes-butterymouthfeel, then drying.

Draft at River City. Poured copper color with an average white frothy head that was mostly lasting with fair lacing. Moderate toasted sweet malty aroma. Light to medium body with a watery texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of short duration.
On Tap at the brewpub. Orange pour. Malty nose. Caramel matly body. Pretty decent, but not great.
Aroma started really fruity, berry sweetness but as it warmed it seemed to loose everything it had to offer. Taste was similar with more of a toffee malt character acting throughout it.

column1: Northumberland Legends of the Tyne Jim Montgomery
column5: Aroma gives pale malts and grassy hops, biscuts come through towards the end. Taste is similar with the grassy hops giviong a good amount of bitterness, yet not a very dry finish.

Pours a murky brown color with a thin beige head. Strong aroma and flavor of ginger bread, cinnamon and nutmeg, it’s a bit too strong on the spices for my tastes. The body is light with a liquorous texture and moderate carbonation.

This draft brew from the Michigan Brewers Guild festival poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a transparent uncarbonated red brown colored body. The strong aroma was spicy and heralb. The mouth feel was very tingly at the start and at the finish with a spicy aftertaste. The strong flavor contained notes of malt cinnamon nutmeg, strong herbal spices and many more. A decent complex one with an excellent aroma but not one that I would consider drinking again.
Cask at GBBF 2010. An unclear golden beer with a yellowish head. The aroma has notes of malt and youghurt. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and straw.

Cask @ GBBF 2010, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear medium to light dark yellow color with a small, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, fruity, wheat, light to moderate yeasty. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, fruity. Body is medium to light, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20100804]
Cask Handpump at the GBBF, Earl’s Court 07/08/2010 Hoppy wheat aroma. Golden coloured and hoppy with some banana fruit flavour and a dry lasting finish.
Cask at GBBF 2010, 4th Aug 2010. Slightly hazy yellow looks. Nice clove wheat beer nose but the taste disappoints. Citric but rather flat and lifeless.

Cask@GBBF2010. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is wheat, nectar, wood and some mild spicy and citrusfruity notes. Flavour is quite much the same with mild honey and some slight acidic notes as well.

Cask (GBBF2010) 6 Rich bready aroma, slightly wheaty 3 Gold, brief head 6 Rich bready taste, very simple. Some herby pie taste. 3 A bit sticky. Finish sweet and with some sherbetty hops. 11 Not crisp enough, too sweet and sticky.
Cask at GBBF 2010. Poured a hazy golden colour, the aroma is all orange and wheat. Plenty of orange and spices in the flavour which leads to a dry sweet finish.

15th July 2010. Chelmsford Beer Festival. Hazy pale gold beer. Little suddy white head. Banana and bubblegum light nose. Light palate, low carbonation. Soft banana and bubblegum. No cloves but a hint of spice. Not bad.

From cask. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma is mild estery. wheaty and slight fruity. Fruity and malty flavoured. Sweet and slight bitter, Dry and hoppy grassy to hayish into the finish. Mild estery touch.

Bottle conditioned, 500ml. Greenish gold with stable white head. Clearer beer than expected and certainly not a standard wheat beer. There is a hint of banana in the flavour and a citric lemon note, but all very much understated. Fruity bright finish but slightly flabby. Reasonable.
Pours Golden with a thin white head. Heavy carbonation. Taste is unremarkable, no noticeable or notable influences. Palate is similarly weak. Drinkable not a good beer

Tap, Bohemian Hall, Queens, 17/12/11. Burnished orange; light haze, slim lid. Light apricot/dried fruit nose, a litttle candy. Grassy and anonymous. Tickle of citrus and candy cigs. Not a Golden Ale, just a lager in my book, but then I’m from England where the style can outhop a US DIPA. Not bad, just bland. Gave up and had the Oatmeal Stout instead.
Unpleasant color, overly hoppy brew. I am not an IPA fan, and this wasn’t up my alley. Not an IPA but seemed much the same to me.

On tap at a local beer store. Overall it is sweet, the style really doesn’t come through, too fruity for a blond. Has a citrus taste, heavy wheat, but some taste of flour or bread hops....not sure. Decent co2, not well balanced. It is drinkable, not one I would seek out, but I would drink this again.

355 ml bottle in New York. Amber color, little head. Fake citrus aroma. Hoppy unnatrual sweet sticky taste. Palate is hoppy. This is the typical Ice Cream flavored brewery stuff. Not good. As with many breweries here they try to make many beers unable to perfect any.
tap from tasting room- pours yellow, tastes oddly smokey/toasty- maybe some of the toasted lager in this one. Not that good.

Pours golden, like the name. Aroma of some light floral scents. Flavor strongly of wheat. It is almost as if it is a fruit beer that is simply waiting for the right fruit to come along. Rather sweet either way.
on tap-pours a white head with yellow color. Aroma is grain, musty-funky. Taste follows with some hops. OK carbonation.

Sample at the brewery tasting room. A rather unattractive yellow color with a thick head. Has a deceptively medicinal and herbal aroma. However, all this leads to a surprising and deliciously sweet malt flavor. Slightly biscuit-y a la a British bitter mixed some strong sweet malts. Mouthfeel has a perfect level of felt carbonation. A surprising delight. 6/2/8/4/15Rerate: definitely a different batch and a very different beer. Not so unattractive yellow anymore. Taste is a lot more hoppy (some citrus some herbal hops) and less on the biscuit. Still very quaffable though. 7//3/7/3/15.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at the brewery, pours a hazy, dark gold with some lacing, white head. Nose has an odd soap note, very industrial, some stale bread. Flavor of lemon and soap, honey, some tea. Watery finish. A big mess.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Tap at the brewery. Pours fairly clear orange copper. Some lacing. Some overripe pineapple and grapefruit in the flavor. Not sure what to make of this IPA.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: On tap at brewpub, pours a clear light amber with a thin soapy head and spotty lacing, the aroma has a slight hop touch to it but there isn’t much there, the flavor has a light hop front end with a malty finish, pretty middle of the road ipa.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Solid brewpub IPA. Big, bold, balanced. Golden tan, rich. Toasty golden malt tones. OK.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Draught pint at the brewpub, mid-October 2006. Amber-bronze colored, very clear with just a smidgeon of white head but nice lacing....faint aroma offers wafts of tart apples and cherries, muted pine sap, but it all blows away before you can enjoy it....malty and relatively sweet on the tongue, very light pungent hoppy notes, somewhat thin, earthy and moderately bitter at the finish, tingly carbonation. Ehhh.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Clear light orange color with thin white head that laced the glass. Aroma and flavor of grapefruity hops with plenty of hop bitterness. Nice IPA.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: The body was dark gold with a white colored head on top. The aroma was grapefruit with some dish soap. There was also a little bit of bread crust. The taste was bitter bread crust with some spice of black pepper. There was also a little bit of toffee. A decent IPA.

Draught at the brewpub. Hazy red-orange color with thick off white head that laced the glass. Spicy aroma with light brown sugar and subdued sprucy hops. Dry on the tongue with flavors of dried fruit, brown sugar, and a touch of raspberry. Decent oktoberfest.

10/8/12. On tap at the brewpub... apparently they’re still making this! Clear red pour with a small khaki head. Sweet, malty aroma with biscuits and a touch of toast. Sweet, malty flavor as well, again with biscuits and toast, with touches of caramel and barely a hint of chocolate. Eh.
On tap at the brewpub. Light copper with a small beige head. Foul nose and flavor - something went wrong here. Skunky, sourish malt and no hop presence. Awful.

Draft at brewpub. Poured a clear copper color with an average fizzy off-white head that diminished slowly with good lacing. Good roasted sweet malt aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Good well balanced flavor of malt and a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Good brew.

Draught at Greenville Barley’s. Bronze pour with a well sculpted white head. There’s assertive juicy grapefruit and caramel in the nose with fainter notes of grass and pine. I’m surprised to find such a clean and well balanced beer given my other forays into this brewery’s products. There is a nice level of honey, sweetened green tea, grapefruit. The finish is drying and biting with just a medium level of aggression. No real complaints.

On cask at Max’s, Baltimore. Strange to see how long it’s been since there were any ratings of this, but this is how the beer was clearly designated on the list at Max’s. Heavy amber pour with a thick creamy head, and a pungent nose of both bright hops and some added spice. Herbal and grassy notes tend to complement the modest autumnal spice that comes through, and the thick body seems appropriate although clean and easy-drinking.
Clear amber body with off-white head. Aroma is medium sweet, grapefruit, some caramel. Taste is medium sweet, grapefruit, some caramel, light bread. Light-medium body, light stickiness.

To start with I expected a lot from this brew and was left wanting. Lightly hazed amber-copper body. The aroma took a while to come out as it was served VERY cold! It really lacked the big citrus burst I have come to expect from a wet hop ale. More herbal than fruity to me. In fact the whold experience was very ESBish. A good dose of biscuit malt flavor keeps things interesting but teh hops are subdued throughout. In the end a decent beer but it does not live up the expectations that I had. Oh well.

Enjoyed this one on draught at the brewpub in Ashburn, VA, and a 2 liter swing top growler to take home on 10/23/06. Hop Havest, "fresh" hop, or "wet" hop ales have been done for a while, by West Coast breweries. This beer is brewed with fresh hops, just hours off the vines. Many hop heads and beer geeks are surprised and dissapointed, that these beers are not hop blasts with tons of hop aroma and bitterness. If that is what you are expecting, then you will be dissapointed. Wet hop ales, allow you the experience to enjoy the aroma, and flavor of young, fresh, hops. In Dominion’s case it is fresh Centennials and Cascades grown in NY. This beer pours to a hazy, amber color, with a nice white head that fades, and a soft carbonation. The nose on this beer is pleasing, with gentle aromas of fresh hops, fresh bread, and biscuity malt. The palate is firm, with good carmel and biscuit malt flavors, paired with a very pleasing citrus hop flavor. This beer finishes with more good pale and carmel malt up front, then ends with a pleasing, gentle citrus hop bittereness that lingers. Well done, very tasty wet hop ale. You really get very enjoyable citrus/bitter hop flavor in this beer, but it is by no means a hop blast, but it isn’t meant to be. Worth a try to see what fresh hops, hours of the vines are like in a beer.

On tap at Dominion 10/20/06. Was very much looking forward to this. Unfiltered, somewhat hazy amber with a white head that which thins out but lasts for the most part. Has a floral PacNW hop aroma but nothing that really stands out or blows you away. Flavor has notes of caramel, pine, grapefruit/citrus. Moderately sweet with a good hop presence which actually isn’t all that bitter. It could use some more malty heft as the taste ends a little watery. Medium bodied with a smooth texture and moderate carbonation. Overall, a solid, well-hopped American Pale Ale. But, I have to admit, it was disappointing - in fact, I brought my growler for this and didn’t even fill it up after dinner. Nothing about it really stands out as being from a fresh hop harvest - just kind of normal to me.

Draft... Murky amber ale with a small, wispy, white head. The nose delivers subtle notes of black tea, toffee, biscuity malt and very light grapefruit. Perfect balance is the only way to describe the flavor. Fresh, bitter lupulin countered by sweet, breadsy yeast and malt. Medium-bodied with a milky mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Crisp finish with only a whisper of bitterness. Refreshing, quality beer. Certainly not good enough to keep me from ordering a "brewpub version" Oak Barrel Stout as my second pint of the night. Good American Pale Ale or English IPA... or as jeffc666 mentions, it could just as easily be classified as a Bitter.

Draft at Rattle with Npodendorf. Pours deep brown with a beige head. Wheaty base, with some light sweetness, very light fruity notes, and low bitterness. Comes up just a bit short, but enjoyable nonetheless.

Poured draugh at Rattle N Hum in NYC. Pours very dark, cloudy brown color. There isn’t much aroma to this beer; a slightly sweet smell but nothing notable. There is a mild taste without anything standing out. No banana/colve notes as is typical is many dunkleweiss and hefeweiss beers. Not memorable.

Sampled at 4th NoVA Summer Brewfest. Pours hazy brown with a small, fizzy white head, no retention or lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (caramel, toast, bread), average hops (floral, citrus), and light esters (apple/pear). Flavor is malt with some hop bitterness. Light body and warmth, medium carbonation and a dry finish.
Copper color, white head some lacing. Cereal and some hops greet my nostrils. A light to medium body and good wheat flavor and some earthiness. Overall an easy drinking wheat.

Poured into a weizen glass. Thanks to thagr81us for this. 4.0 A: This is the third RJR brew I’ve had recently and surprisingly this (a wheat ale) has the least amount of carbonation. Hazy yellow-orange color. Two and a half fingers of frothy white head. Average retention and moderate lacing. 3.5 S: Neutral wheat with musky cellar funkiness. Not really anything else going on, but not too bad. 3.0 T: Low in flavor. The strongest flavor is a mild hop bitterness. Neutral wheat, musty funkiness again, and yeasty. Not really any spiciness. 2.5 M: Lighter body. Carbonation is high, but within the style. Not creamy at all like a good wheat and leaves a chalky aftertaste. 2.5 D: I’m not a big fan of this brewery. Nothing really good about this brew. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 08-14-2010 03:29:28
A straightforward clean tasting dark American style wheat. Not a bad beer, just not a whole lot to it. The finish is the best part, it is mostly malty with a bit of nuttiness.

Served from bottle into a Samuel Smith Euro pint. Pours a yellow-orange with white one-finger head that quickly subsides to a minimal amount. There was no apparent lacing present. The aroma was comprised of only malt and wheat. The flavor was of citrus and wheat. It was light on the palate with medium carbonation. Overall this brew kind of lacks robust flavoring to be good. It is not bad however, and would be an awesome lawnmower beer as it is quite smooth and drinkable.

Pours a barely transparent hazy golden yellow with a decent white head. Aroma is wheaty, yeasty and just a little lemony, about average for this style. Mouth filling flavor is crisp and wheaty with a nice undertone of citrus, mainly lemon, a little bit of summer sunshine. Texture is smooth and fairly fizzy.

12oz bottle. juicy, peachy pear aroma. hazy orange under a very large rocky cream colored head. the fruity pear continues into he flavor with a soft honey toffee flavor. light body. a pretty tasty wheat ale.

This is why I don’t like hefe weizens. It’s hard to pull off a great hefe. They didn’t get it right here. Drank it from the bottle. Slight hint of mystery fruit. Overwhelming yeasty taste. One of six on my SC trip. Nov 09
75 cl bottle clear yellow bubbles for head. sroma of apple and leather. typical spanish cidef aroma tart. flavor is sweet apole leather rubber. a little too sweet for my taste.

250ml bottle from a corner shop in Málaga. Pours clear yellow gold with no real head. Aromas of sour apple, tart. Taste has a light sweetness though. Back-sweetened I'd guess. Worth the €1.75 I suppose.

Color dorado amarillento, translúcido, con capa de espuma blanca de un dedo de grosor y escasa retención. Carbonatación alta visualmente. Textura acuosa y efervescente. Aroma manzana, piel de manzana, manzana ácida, cuero. Sabor a manzana, con buena dosis de piel de manzana ácida. Básicamente dulce, pero con ligera acidez durante todo el trago, lo cual hace que no sea empalagosa. Final dulce. Postgusto a manzana dulce.

Bottle from a supermarket in Benasque. Clear golden color with white head that goes down quickly. Aroma is apples, vanilla custard, a tiny touch of funk. Taste is apples, vanilla, sweet. Medium carbonation. Too sweet for me, but okay.
Bottle share at Chriso’s, golden pour with a dry-sweet appley nose, estery sweet on the palate.

Shared bottle at the holiday villa, Abades, Tenerife. Very pale straw with tiiiiny bubbles. Sweet apples, dry oak, hint of woodglue. Moderate sweet, medium dry. Light fizz. Light funky cheesy gluey finish. Ok, and best I’ve had in a while (this holiday).
23 ounce bottle purchased at Bravo Supermarket Pembroke Pines, FL for $2.49 Good.

700 ml "champagne" bottle, as Sidra Zarracina, in Spain. ABV 4.1%. Pale yellow colour, pours very fizzy with a short-lived white head. Moderate aroma of cider apples and eating apples, notes of sulphites. Medium sweet flavour of eating apples, hints of sulphites. Light bodied.

Bottled, 70cl with champagne-corking. Vauw, what a surprise, a nice cider, and it is Spanish, I wasn’t aware of that tradition. It was very nice to find something else than the thin, pale lagers available on Tenerife. It pours clear, a bit sparkling, pale yellow. It has a distinct aroma of apples, and some yeast, sourness, dust and cellar. Yellow apples, sourness, yeast and cellar in the flavor. Medium, sparkling mouthfeel, but it lacks some astringency to finish it off, it’s only apples and some cellar. A nice one. (070210)

16 oz. can from Craft Beer Cellar-Clayton. Pours a clear orange color with a small off-white head that settles into a ring and wispy film. Big pumpkin character, obviously, but more than expected, and it hits both pie and vegetal receptors. Vanilla, nutmeg, clove, graham cracker, leaves, and a dash of cinnamon. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, mildly spicy mouthfeel. Not a category beater or anything, but a solid pumpkin ale that bested expectations.

On tap at the brewpub. Poured a coppery color with a small head. Aroma of grain with a bit of spice. Taste of a light malt sweetness with just a wee bit of pumpkin and spice. Mild bitterness and a fairly clean finish. Light body, smooth but not much in the way of pumpkin and spice. Fairly ho-hum pumpkin beer.
Just meh. Barely any pumpkin flavor when it should be bursting with it. Tasted at Kansas City Beerfest at Union Station October, 2015. I had so many that this rating might be a bit off. ;)

Tap - small foamy head, medium Amber color, well balanced moderate pumpkin and spice aroma and flavor, not overpowering but definitely enough to know its there, not a bad pumpkin beer overall ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma is spices, malts and mild pumpkin bread. The flavor is spices, mild pumpkin and a mix of slight funk and sweetness in the finish.
Good balance of flavor between the pumpkin and the spices. Nice blend of sweetness and bite. It was crisp, sharp and smooth. A light to medium bodied ale

Pour is a cloudy orange-ish with a small white head. Aroma is full on pumpkin pie spices. Flavor is again a real nice pumpkin pie spice and you can almost taste some crust in there. Finish leaves a nice spice on the tongue. Lots of cinnamon in this. This may be a bit thinner than some other pumpkin ales but its quite tasty and lower in alcohol than most.

Aroma is definitely a malt beverage, not a beer. I’m getting some pumpkin pie spice and vanilla, but it’s all muted and weak. Looks nice; amber reddish color with a small amount of white foam. The taste is truly like pumpkin pie. They even got he crust and the whipped cream right. A dessert beer for sure, but the taste delivers what it promises. If you are wanting pumpkin pie in a 16 oz can, this beer is for you.
2013. Yep another pumpkin beer...yawn. it’s ok, but schlaflys is still the gold standard for pumpkin beers. I wish this one had more alcohol.

Sample at Augusta Bottoms Fest 2011. Bring on fall and bring on the Pumpkin Beers! This one poured a darker amber, orange color. Aroma was cinnamon, nutmeg and spices. Flavor was cookie, nutmeg, and some vanilla coming though. Finish is were the pumpkin flavors really hit you. Great pumpkin beer.
On tap. Pours a clear amber. Sweet malty aroma. Easy to drink lightly malty beer.
Draught at Alandale Brewpub. Amber in color with a very faint caramel aroma. Hints of caramel with a semi-bitter finish. Kind of bland.

Sample at the brewpub. Pours a clear orange color with a medium thin light beige head that diminishes quickly. Latticework lacing on the glass. Mild malt and caramel in the nose with a touch of hops. Medium body with sweet malt and spice flavoring, with touches of hops and fruit poking through here and there. The finish is mildly malty with a lingering sweetness left over. Just average overall.
Sampled at the Heritage Festival. Filtered with a golden amber hue. Spotty white head. Mild caramel cereal nose. Mild and light to medium bodied. Nice breadiness. Touch metallic. Meh...
(draught at the brewpub) light-medium amber. Moderate head with a little lace. Mild malt aroma. Flavor is malt, a bit of hops, not sweet. A good session beer.

This was not a good example of style. It was slightly hay-like. It had a very grainy taste, like vyvvy said. I just think it was not very well made. A decent mild hop and smooth beer, just not very good overall.

Very light pale yellow with a smallish white head. Aroma has lightly sweet malt with light mustiness and some graininess. The aroma is very clean. Medium body with light carbonation. Taste has grainy malt that turns more smooth and sweetness starts to trickle in along with some fruitiness. The finish gets more crisp and adds a bit of spicy hops. Pretty nice.

tap at brewpub-pours pale yellow almost orange with a small fizzy white head. nose is somewhat grainy with some lager character. grainy and malty flavors with a touch of spicy hops. alot like the pale lager, but with more malt sweetness. nice clean character with nice lager yeast twang. nice finish with some light hop bitterness. good!

Poured a clear orange amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of carmel, raisin, plum and light molasses. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, toffee, raisin and light brown sugar with a smooth lingering carmel finish.

Draft sample at St. Louis Microfest 2011. Pours a clear amber color with a small eggshell white head. The aroma has caramel malts, toast, nuts, raisins, and minerals. Flavor of sweet caramel malts, toffee, toasted brown sugar, nuts, and some dry fruits. Light-medium bodied, with a sweet, malty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. So-so doppelbock, a little light, with a nose that is hurt by the mineral presence.

On tap at Highlands brewpub. Orange-amber with a thin white head. Aroma of toffee, malt, corn, alcohol and mild dark fruit. Malt bomb has flavors of toffee, mild fruit and caramel. One of their better offerings.
Pours a dark brown orange. Nice rich malty aroma. Nice thick mouthfeel and lots of malt and caramel flavor that hides it s strength well.

On tap at Heritage Brew Fest 2008. Pours a light amber in color with a a smooth thin but lingering white head. A rich malty dopple but a little on the thin/sweet side. Very good and refreshing w/o much alcohol presence in spite of the 8.1 ABV and smoothly malty. Very deceiving; don’t drink too many unless you’re ready.

Draught at the brewpub. Alandale’s version of the style is a mostly clear dark orange/copper color with a medium light beige head that diminishes steadily. Short strings of lacing. Malty nose with some alcohol and dark fruit in the background. Medium and syrupy body with a strong malt profile. Notes of caramel and grain flavors are present as well. Light hops saves it from becoming cloying. The finish is malty and sweet, leaving a grainy malt aftertaste. Above average overall.

12 oz. draft. They like to push this when they sense you’re a beer lover, and I can see why. This has a color between pils gold and copper. Smell shows caramel cremes and Bit-o-Honey. Now I’ve been sucking cough drops all day, so I may be tasting this as sweeter than it really is. But there are heavy malts approaching syrup quality. Alcohol is smooth and warming on a cool afternoon. Good sippin’ beer.

Draft 12 oz’er at the brewpub. Deep amber color with a sticky tan head. Not much to the aroma, but this has a gargantuan malty powerhouse of a flavor. Rich and sugary, maybe a bit too much for a hot July day. Quite good. (#3029, 7/17/2007)
(draught at the brewpub) medium-dark amber with moderate head, nice lace. Mild malt aroma. Flavor is sweet malt, body is reasonably thick; noticeable hops in the finish, metallic aftertaste.

Again, what is with these weak beers? The malting on the dopplebock was very sub-standard. There was no complexity to brew. A slight caramel, sour, metallic flavor with a hint of sherry. Just a poor effort.

Lovely little harmony between stout & fall! Pours black w/ a mocha head & lots of lacing. The aroma is dominated by the pumpkin & fall spices. The flavor is more roasty w/ the cinnamon & nutmeg more as complimentary parts. The body is a touch thin surprisingly but allows the beer to go down easy! Delightful!

Deep super dark brown coloured body with a thinnish, single centimetre tall tan head that fades very fast. Aroma of squash, light spices, licorice, molasses, alcohol, earth, hazlenuts and a good deal of caramelised sugars. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong rich earthy and malty flavour with a good bit of squash, anise, molasses, raisins, figs and a peat-y flavour that shows well near the end. Aftertaste is rich with complexity showing the sugars, spices, body (from the squash) and pungent near the end, from the alcohol. Overall, a rich and exciting beer - just about perfect for the style and the name - it’s exactly what you’d expect to be getting, and done in a can - very nice! I sampled this twelve ounce can purchased from Whole Foods in New York (Bowery), New York on 27-May-2016 for US$2,99 sampled at home in Washington on Halloween, 31-October-2016 after just trick-or-treating with my daughters.
It’s no pumpkinator but it’s pretty darn tasty. Pumpkin, pie spices, molasses, bittersweet chocolate. What’s not to like?
Draught from maddy dc. Brownish pour. Pumpkin cinnamon. Malts and pretty good stuff .

12 oz. can. Black with a medium khaki head. Smell is milk chocolat and pumpkin. Comes off a little weird. Cinnamon and nutmeg. Taste is better. More roasty. Pumpkin behind it. Nutmeg and cinnamon spice linger in the back end. Still has a bit of weirdness. Medium body. Well carbonated. It’s just a little bit off-putting. No sure what it is, though.

Draft @ Barcade, Brooklyn. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty spicy caramel pumpkin aroma. Roasted malty spicy pumpkin and chocolate flavor. Has a roasted malty spicy pumpkin and chocolate finish.

Pours an inky almost black with a healthy, dense light brown head which lingers......aroma is pumpkin, molasses, slight chocolate.....taste is excellent! very smooth taste of coffee, a touch of pumpkin, the spices seem to be drowned out by the bittering coffee ground finish. Quite enjoyable, just begging for a bourbon barrel finish.

Silver can at America on Tap Deep brown bordering on black. Rich chocolate and roast with some brown sugary sweetness and just enough pumpkin pie character to let you know this one is a little different. Enjoyed!

Pint on tap. Ebony but uncloudy body has a thin creamy disc of bubbles on top. Nose of earthy pumpkin, cocoa and spices. Tastes of dark chocolate, pumpkin and nutmeg. Medium body is well balanced and has a smooth medium carbonation.

1 centimeter of fine, tan head which fades in 30 seconds to a ring. Black with glints of brown-red at the very edges. Aroma of pumpkin pie and a bit of roast (burnt coffee, toast.) Some dark coco. Body is watery, moderate, fat carbonation with little-to-medium burn. Lots of pumpkin, some nutmeg, general spice, mild coco. Dusty grain. Overall, a neat pumpkin stout, but disappointing in that it lacks the richness and body of a satisfying stout of any sort (unless your into more of a weak Irish variety.) I wish it went all the way, my palate is aching for more intensity.

on tap-pours a tan head. Color is black with red tint. Aroma is dark malt-licorice/chocolate/coffee. Taste follows with secondary hops. Medium body. OK carbonation. 2.7 080404-rerate 3.2************ *130221-cask @NERAX-3.6

Bottle 33 cl. Blond almost amber incolour, medium white head. Malty aroma, (caramelmalt ?) malty and halfsweet taste. Bitter touch, medium to full body. A very good beer from this brewer ! Not great in alcohol, but it ill really love it, i buy a hole krat of 24 bottles and (the are all reserved for myself)

As the renowned Dr*nk rater before me has noted, this is much more of a quaffable blond than it is a strong ale. Nice looking pour, a slightly hazy yellow body with constant bubbling, albeit coupled with a slender white head. The nose presents some soft malts, a touch of the citric, and a suggestion of sweet cherries. Sweet and lightly fruity with a quick, mildly tart finish, this is an ale one could enjoy all night long without the fear of getting totally snuckered. Rock Bottom Yorktown, Lombard, IL

Mug Club Draft. Despite the name, this seems to fall into the purview of a Belgian Blond Ale, too light to be an Abbey Dubbel. Cloudy yellow to brown pour in my mug, with a bubbly but thin head. Clean pale malt smell. First taste impression is of oranges, followed by a healthy dose of those light Belgian malts. And agreeable fruity ale component. Hops come on like the bratty little brother of a La Chouffe: one moment spicy and grassy; the next running back home to ma. Substantial and worth contemplation. Finish turns slightly hoppier and lemony. Another surprise from Chris Boggess’ recipe book.

pours a white head with yellow color. Aroma is bold light/medium citrus hops-grapefruit. Taste follows with some bite, hint of malt. Finish highlights the raw hops and light/medium body of this nice beer. Good carbonation.

Bottle at home. Pours clear tawny and still. Heavy sweet candied and nearly caramel apples, lingering sweetness with some apple tartness, light tannins and a sweet finish. Full body and still. Earlier Rating: 11/3/2013 Total Score: 3.7 Bottle at home. Pours clear amber. Aroma is caramel, apples, and light oxidation (sherry). Flavor is blended apple varieties, caramel, earthy notes and a sweet finish. Medium to full body.

Sampled thanks to SinH4 @ hotelroom tasting after Borefts 2018, Day 1. Clear amber color. Aroma is sweet super ripe apple or maybe even somewhat sugary. Flavor also has super ripe apple as well as light sugary notes. Quite pleasant.

column1: Rock Bottom Des Moines Pumpkin Ale
column2: West Des Moines, Iowa, United States
column5: State week month, week 2 Oct 9th - 15th. State: Iowa. Pours a deep orange with a medium head and good lace. The aroma is pretty well dominated with rich pumpkin pie spice, there is a subdued fruitiness and a mild soapiness in there as well. The flavor is very centered around pie-spice (allspice, cinnamon, etc). The beer is moderaltly sweet and has what I precieve as a yeast driven clove character, but who knows... it could just be from some cloves.

column1: Rock Bottom Des Moines Pumpkin Ale
column2: West Des Moines, Iowa, United States
column5: Hazy brown body with a little hint of copper. There is a thin white head. The nose is massive pumkin and a little nutmeg. There is also cinnamon and a little caramel. The taste is like raw pumpkin with a little bit of apple and nutmeg. A hint of cinnamon. This is served with a sugared rim, but the bartender was nose enough to only rim half the glass.

column1: Rock Bottom Des Moines Pumpkin Ale
column2: West Des Moines, Iowa, United States
column5: Draught at Lost Duck Brew Pub in Ft. Madison, IA. Clear ornage color with thick off white head that laced the glass. Smelled and tasted of pumpkin pie and cinnamon. The flavor and aroma were just right, not cloying, as some pumpkin beers can be.

Veyr good, a little heavy, like it’s name says, and is veyr alcoholic. Thr foam stays there for ages and it seems that no matter how much you drink it never stops forming. Very dark one. The taste is sweet, due to the alcohol percentage, the barley is also good.

Canned. Poured clear, honey golden with a short cap of bright white head. The aroma picked up honey, corn syrup, and pale malts.. a hint of cleaner on the back.. syrupy sweet overall. The flavor found more of the corn and honey at the core, with lemon zest tartness and bitterness around tacky finish.. slightly metallic. Light-bodied and a bit rough on the palate.. drinkable, but not much more than that.
Pours yellow with minimal white head. slightly citrus aroma with metal and grass. Flavor is grassy and citrus.

355ml can. Pours dark straw colour with a fast fading white head. Aroma has some sweetish barley with lemon notes. Flavour is grainy, bready with lemon. Dry finish. Seemed to have a bit more body than your average pale lager. Fairly active and prickly carbonation.

Picked this up from the singles bin at Willow Park in Calgary. Can only. Had to call the number on the can to figure out the origin of this beer. The guy on the other end was very friendly and happy to answer my questions. I guess this was originally a beer brewed by Labatt in B.C. back in the ’40s and they’ve revived the label in import form. There are a few Wisconsin-born brews that are sneaking into Alberta without declaring their origins! Anyway, I thought this was a decent pale lager actually. Perhaps it was because my expectations were so low (being can-only), but I had this with dinner tonight and it was okay! Pale yellow, big head with medium retention. Grainy and faintly sweet, crisp palate with a bit of citrus in there (especially noticable against the alfredo pasta I was eating). Definitely not the worst of the can-only bunch.

Notizen: -süßer, etwas penetranter Geruch -süßer werdend -künstlich, muffig -leicht bitterer Nachgeschmack -spontaner Gedanke: Gummi (warum auch immer) Test vom 3.12.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 4,3,3,4,10,3 - 3,60
Light brown. Clear. No head. Thin, barely any character. Hints of roast in the finish. The aroma is weak dark nutty boringness.

The label says "Top Quality Premium Lager". Well, it ain’t............ This one came in a clear bottle, not the green ones some beloved by China’s brewers. The misfortunes began with a tan, rocky head of short duration above a not bad looking and very dark body. NO light was getting through this one. Aroma was not so bad either, with some dark malts and maybe some coffee notes as well. Taste was quite something else, and not in a good way, either. Syrupy sweet with some other mysterious flavours as complements (melamine, perhaps); mouthfeel was sticky and the finish was also by far too sweet. This was almost undrinkable, and I feel I took one for the team by finishing it.

Bottle 0.6 l. Cola brown, completely disappearing lemonade head. Fresh nose of hops and some coffeeish roasted maltiness. Berries. Flavor is candyish sweet (not sticky tho) and non bitter roasted maltiness. Berries here too with some paper. Very flavorful and fresh for a dunkel. This is not too far from good german dunkler bocks. Pretty damn nice surprise after regular Reebs. Smooth carb, nice body.
Maybe the best cheap beer I had in China. Dark, but light body. Not too impressive in taste. Malty, but could use more spice.

Poured with a nice tan head and later a bit of lace. Brown walnut color. Lightly aromatic nose of toffee, a bit of cocoa and whiskey. Flavor is so so. a bit of a tang - some sharpness, although I do pick up some nice chocolate malt in there. Best of the Chinese beers yet. Drinking this 500 ml clear glass bottle of brew in my hotel room Shanghai.

Cask @ Trackside, Bury. Darker clear chestnut-brown colour with a thick frothy head. It has a light malty nose, but it has a much more stated taste with some dry grainy malts that produce quite a nutty flavour that lingers in the palate a while.
Cask Handpump at the Smithfield Hotel, Manchester 26/09/2002 Amber coloured and fruity with a little grain flavour. Slightly bitter and dry hop finish.

Cask, The Highcross, Leicester. Chesnut red with a dense head. Aromas are toffee malts with lots of fruitiness. Spritzy and yeasty. Flavours are chocolate and weetabix malts with nicely balanced fruitiness. Spices and light pine on the finish.
Cask, gravity, at 2nd Globe BF, Globe Inn, Dunstable, Bedfordshire. Amber beer with a fruit and hop aroma. Refreshing fruity sour taste with some bitterness.
Malty and nutty aroma. Dark golden cloudy colour with ok head. Malty up front with a long aftertaste. High carbonation and medium body.
Clear orangey straw body with compact but lasting head. Yeast and then some peach in the aroma, taste is pretty straightforward, fairly thin with a touch of bubblegum.
Honey aroma. Golden transparent colour with little head. Awesome smokey honey flavor with delicious aftertaste. Very nice low carbonation with good warmth.
Clear amber colour, weak aroma, little foam, No sweet taste at all some what bitter. A cheap tasting Easter brew.
Bottle. Clear amber color, medium tan head. Aroma of malted milk balls. Taste has mostly cocoa. OK.

Heavy caramel malt aroma. Dark maple body with on a thin film for a head. Sweet nutty taste. Goes down smooth on the tongue. Has a heavy mouth feel. More suited for winter enjoyment. A sipper verses a guzzler.
March Ale Alpharetta. Toasted wheat, caramel, brown sugar, biscuity. Pretty on point for the style.

16 oz. can, shared at Ale Alpharetta. Clear brown, with a thin, beige head. Nice nose of light coffee, caramel, a little salt, and syrup. Very sweet, with a touch of bitterness. Medium to heavy body, creamy, and clean. This is not a bad doppelbock.

Pours clear Amber with a nice eggshell head. Aroma has notes of toasted malt and dusty hops. Flavor has toasted malt, caramel, and subtle hoppy tones. Texture has average body and fizz. Navigate to any bar or beer store that had it.

Growler from the brewery. Pour is a brownish amber. Lighter and clearer than I was hoping, but still looks nice and is appropriate for the style. Thin head. Nose is sweet and fruity. Raisins and some nutty malt. Flavor is the same. Honey, candied pecans, red apple. Very sweet but not sticky. No hops or bitterness. Super smooth, slick palate. Really appealing mouthfeel for the style. Growler was consumed day of fill, but carbonation is low. Again, appropriate for the style. I picked this up hoping for a darker beer more like Celebrator, so I was initially disappointed, but it’s still a solid beer. Probably a little too much unchecked sweetness, but the style is all about malt, so I can’t complain.

Draft @ Cape Ann. Served year round since it’s July and I just drank it a few hours ago. Light amber color with thin head in a shaker glass. Aroma is caramel malt, toasted grain and light lager yeast. Flavor is again toasted grain, caramel malt, mild hints of fruit and light brown sugar. The carbonation gives a creamy texture that ends sweet. All malt in this brew, as it should be. For the style is just above average and I’m glad the spice was taking away from the recipe several years back. It is a nice, straight forward example of the style and not overly complex. German lager loves will not get to excited but it should do you just fine if you like this style.

Pours a hazy garnet color with a minimal beige head. Sweet toasted malt aroma has notes of agave syrup. Soft toasted malt flavor has a touch of caramel and vanilla bean. Slightly spicy with a hint of cinnamon on the palate. Overall, just average.
Not a giant fan of this one. Tastes slightly burnt, whether a burned candy or even butter. Medium bodied with a decent head.
GCB Draught. This is really cloying and heavy beyond what i am used to for the style.
Amber colour with a small head. Malty aroma, hints of caramel. Malty caramel sweet flavor with a waterish end to it.

Bag in a box at Hovelling Boat Ramsgate, Clear pale gold colour no head. I mean this was go to drunk juice as a teenager. Some sweetness brown sugar some apple juice. Flat. Some racy acidity towards the finish. Apple flesh flavour. Good dryness on finish. Not too bad . Not subtle

Draught at Number Twenty2 Darlington. Hazy pale yellow colour, short-lived thin fizzy head and fruity apple aroma. Taste is sweet, tangy spicy apple with light tannin. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry sweetish finish. OK.

Clear golden colour, no real head. Aroma of apple and cheese. Sweet apple flavour. Finish apple and cheese. Bit too sweet for me. (from bottle @ Sunday Bottle Share / Not Quite So Grand Tasting, CBC Clerkenwell; RBESG 2014, London. Thanks for sharing, rb crew!)

Bottle shared during the RBESG 2014 Sunday tasting at Craft Beer Co. Clerkenwell. Pours clear honey yellow-gold with a few bubbles for a head. The nose holds ripe and sugary apples with touches of creme and alcohol. Medium sweet flavor with artificial apple character, stewed apples, caramel. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Sweet finish with gooey sugars, white bread and heavy, syrupy apples. Meh.

Bottle shared at the RBESG 2014, grand tasting 10/08/2014 Craft Beer Co Clerkenwell. Clear golden coloured pour with no head. Aroma is honey, earthy sweet and some vanilla. Flavour is composed of artificial apple, honey and sweet sugars. Palate is flat and sweet. Distinctly average.
Bottle @ RBESG 2014 Sunday Tasting. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity spicy apple aroma. Fruity sweetish spicy apple flavor. Has a fruity sweetish spicy apple finish.
RBESG 2014, Sunday tasting at Craft Clerkenwell, London. Clear golden, no head. Fruity apple aroma, yeasty, caramel, candy notes. Sweet apple flavor, yeasty, some caramel.
How: Bottle. Where: RBESG 14 not so grand tasting. Appearance: Golden colour with a small white head. Aroma: Sweet apple. Body: Medium body, low carbonation. Flavour: Sweet apple, a bit acidic.
Bottle@Craft Clerkenwell (RBESG 10/08/2014) - golden pour with tiny white head. Aroma and taste is barnyard and orchard apple fruity, nice acidity, light and crisp. Ok.

Bottle at RBESG ’14, day 4 not so grand tasting at Craft Clerko, 10/08/14. Clear golden with moderate off white edgework. Nose is bitter apple, straw, spice. Taste comprises cooking apples, straw, light smoke, orchard wood. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, light dryness in the close. So so.

From tap at Solothurner Biertage 2019. Nearly black chestnut brown with a nearly white light beige head. The aroma is lightly malty (toffee, mild coffee) with hints of fruity yeast notes. Medium body with a light sweetness and a light bitterness. The flavor is lightly to medium malty, lightly roasty with toffee, some coffee, some grains and hints of earthy hops towards the finish. Finishes with a light roasty bitterness. Aroma: 6 Appearance: 4 Taste: 6 Palate: 3 Overall: 10

50 cL brown bottle, Volg Krauchthal (CH). Dark brown with a hint of red, brilliant (yeast at the bottom of the bottle), good head retention. Aroma: Nuts, caramel, no hops. Taste of caramel, slightly sweet with notes of coffee and nuts. Medium body, lively carbonation. Sweet aftertaste. Easy drinkable beer. Fresh and flawless beer.

Bottle 50 cl from Volg in Krauchthal (CH). Dark brown to black, fine and short carbonation and fleeting foam. The smell of roasted malt wins, there is butter, chocolate, nuts. That we found to the taste, soft, toasted, medium roundness, without particular charasteristics, a little flat and thin. Final roasted, sweet. An easy and light beer.

Bottled. Dark brown colour, not much head. Slight roasted malts and lots of sticky coffeeish and chocolateish sweetness in aroma. Flavour is quite sweet malts along with some ashed and dust. Also a very sweet flavour sticking in the background. BBE was late 2006, so maybe it starts showing signs of that the BBE actually was back then .) Still drinkable, but not too exciting, quite watery and empty.

pours a clear dark brown colour with almost no traces of foam remaining; gently toasted with light notes of cocoa, chocolate and butter; quite sweet and medium-bodied at best; no bitterness and a dry finish showing notes of ashes and dust - terribly lacking of character and complexity
Aroma of floral hops, pine tree and some citrus. Taste is light and fresh. Juicy citrus hops with some grass. Also a bit thin and lingers a bit with the food.

Medium copper with a thin lasting head Aroma is citrus and resinous hops- pnw with a touch of fresh cut grass- light dough and crystal malt as well. Flavor has more pine sap and rsin along with an almost lime like citrus hop character- good fresh chinook- almost a cold smokey piney resin character and a light sweetness backbone with nice harsh resinous hop bitterness. Becomes a bit weak as it warms and turns a bit watered down but if this were to be amped up it would be real nice.
Tap. Aroma of pale malt and perfumy, floral hops. Flavor of sweet, fruity malt with a mildly resinous hop presence. Ok.

Draft at brewpub. Poured amber in color with a small beige head. Aroma of pine and citrus hops mostly. Tastes of piney and citrus hops with a light caramel sweetness in the base. Hops certainly tasted fresh but the mouth feel was a little thin.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a light orange with a small white head. Aroma of sweet pale malts and light citrus. Flavor of sweet apricot, light fruits, and a slight hops tinge. Tasty and the best Bullfrog beer I had on my brief visit.

On tap at the Bullfrog Brew Pub. Poured a medium amber / orange color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of floral hops, citrus, pine, and a trace of caramel. Tastes of citrus, pine, and caramel. Light sweet start with a medium bitter finish.

Poured a clear amber color with a small, off white head that left light lacing on the glass. Aroma of pine, floral hops, grass, caramel malts, and toast. Taste of sweeter caramel, citrus, toffee, light toast, pine, and light grapefruit in the finish.

column1: La Brooklynette / La Gnomette Part II
column5: Converting ticks to ratings. Had this back in 2006 on tap at In de Wildeman. I remember this to be a very heavy, strongly hopped beer, biting bitterness, nettles, pine, some citrus, alcohol, yeasty. Had a palate that was used to sweet Belgian beers, this was quite a shocker. Didn't really enjoy it back then.

column1: La Brooklynette / La Gnomette Part II
column5: One-off IPA brewed in collaboration with Brooklyn Brewery, with no less than eight American and English hop varieties, of which five were used for dry-hopping. An IPA from a time when the style was only just beginning to get a foothold among Belgian micro breweries, with a fruity and malt sweetish onset quickly evolving in a dry, herbal and leafy, citrussy, very complex, long hop bitterness. Wonderful experiment, too bad it hasn’t been continued.

column1: La Brooklynette / La Gnomette Part II
column5: Tap at BT. Orange amber body with a thin off white head. Citrus with earthy and floral hops. Nice spices, and some strong hop resins to finish.

column1: La Brooklynette / La Gnomette Part II
column5: Tap at the Blind Tiger for the Brooklyn event. Very hoppy aroma, a touch of sweet and spice. Bacony, dank, peppery, deeply and wonderfully complex. I could smell this thing for ages. The flavor is sweet, savory, Belgian-inspired, with a thick body and good carbonation. Fairly mild, despite strong hops. Very interesting.

column1: La Brooklynette / La Gnomette Part II
column5: Draught. Pours a cloudy pale gold with almost no head. Nose is fruity, candy pineapple and citrus hops, quite sweet. Taste is a huge candy pineapple sweetness up front paired with citrusy hop note, with the spicy yeast presenting itself with a candy ginger note. Resiny pine hops emerge as the flavor progresses, lingering on the finish with more of the sweet candy note. Alcohol is present, but doesn’t get in the way. Mouthfeel is full bodied and slightly syrupy with subdued carbonation. Huge beer, unbelievably sweet, but not overly complex - but undeniably different.

column1: La Brooklynette / La Gnomette Part II
column5: Pours a slightly fogged gold with minimal head. Nose is strong with a tangerine/nectarine kind of thing. Flavor is beautifully hopped. It seems like the hops are well mixed with the Belgian yeast aspects. You can tell there is 9% alcohol on this one. It is a very slight detractor from the overall, though. Feel is very smooth liquid and nice on the carbonation too. Absolutely amazing beer. You don’t see a lot of IPAs in the Belgian style, but I would consider this an outstanding example. A complete travesty this is not mass produced.

column1: La Brooklynette / La Gnomette Part II
column5: "The Final Batch" Hazy oranged colored pour with small head. Florally, pine cone aroma with a strong citrusy, perfumy flavor.

column1: La Brooklynette / La Gnomette Part II
column5: Sampled on 2/16/07 on tap at Max’s 3rd Annual Belgian Beer Festival: Slightly hazy dark golden bronze appearance has a thin, wispy-lacing frothy white head. Aroma of sweet bready Belgian malt with some light fruity notes. Body starts full and pale malty sweet with some biscuity and caramely notes with a smooth toasty, bready yeasty finish. Nicely-balanced, an authentic malty Belgian strong ale, although I don’t see why this is classified as an IPA.

column1: La Brooklynette / La Gnomette Part II
column5: Slight hazy pale with small white head. The aroma is light, banana, bread and honey. The flavor is pepper, honey, pear, apple and corriander. Medium light body with sparkling/prickly carbonation.

column1: La Brooklynette / La Gnomette Part II
column5: draught at ZBF 2007: Hazy summer late afternoon glow with large thick meringue head. First impressions on the aroma was hops, hops, sweet summer fruits, slight eau de cologne, and umm... hops. After the first approach I began to notice some stale, sorry "aged," hop aroma. Expecting to be overwhelmed by a harsh hop explosion, I was delighted to be met with a wonderful balanced (well... maybe not balanced) creamy libation. Sweetness, followed by bitterness, spice, green hop, then mellow hop. Hints of orange sherbert coming from deep within. The hops offered a nice interuption amongst many sticky sweet beers at the ZBF.

Shared by Egadjzis. Pours a mostly clear yellow gold with a thinning head. Aroma is tons of bourbon, sweet sugar, belgian fruity esters almost out of contol and lots of green apple skin acetaldehyde. Flavor is apple juice, wood, oak, vanilla, solvent, cough syrup, phenolic yeast, fruity esters, pear and apple mixed, bourbon is strong, more acetaldehyde, and lemon and orange zest in the finish which leads to some oaky astringency. Kinda messy.

Well i finally got eaglefan to try this puppy. Had to bludgeon him into finally trying this one! Was worth the wait though. Poured a small white head with decent retention and a bit of spotty lace. Clear, gold colored. Light bourbon notes up front with a gentle tropical fruitiness and some laid back wood notes too boot. Body is medium with a soft carbonation and a light pricklyness from the wood maybe? Flavors of mellow bourbon and wood backed by light Trippel notes of pepper and fruit, light citrus and some pencil shavings thrown in for good measure. Lightly sweet finish is bourbony and fruity. The bourbon notes were dominant but not stealing the whole show. Fairly well balanced and enjoyable. Aged nicely. I rather enjoyed this one. Thanks Brian!

750 bottle from summer of 06, finally got to this one. Pour was clear golden, nice white head, good retention, although it did thin to a smaller but complete covering. Carbonation was lively and healthy even after aging almost two years. The primary aroma components were apples, bananas, pears, sawdusty wood/oak, some bourbon too. Flavor followed the aroma, bourbon more in the aftertaste than primary experience (which is how it should be), some honey and other spicing, chainsaw wood notes. Only shortcoming of this was the lack of phenolic and light hop character that I love in my tripels, which could have been a result of the aging that otherwise did wonders for this brew. Good stuff, Stewarts!

Much thanks to egajdzis who finally decided to break this out of his cellar since getting one of these rarities not too long ago. Appears a transparent gold with a small white head that slowly fades out into a mild cap. Spotty lacing is left around the glass. Smell is of coconut, vanilla, peach, pineapple, mango, and citrus. Taste is of the mentioned aromas with tropical fruit salad, and vanilla standing out in a luscious flavor that I find addictive. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, lightly acidic, with tropical fruit and vanilla lingering in the aftertaste. I loved this beer and hope that it finds a way to me again.

Poured a medium cherrywood color body with some white head lace. Aroma of spices, dry wood, bourbon, and belgian yeast. Flavors are sweet bread, vanilla, bourbon, mild spices, and a little citrus, with a dry oaky finish. Thanks Eric!

Poured a dark amber color with a thin, off white head that left light lacing on the glass. Aroma of citrus fruits, vanilla, wood, bourbon, and light spices. Taste was sweet, caramel malts, citrus fruits, coriander, light spices, vanilla, strong bourbon, light alcohol, with a dry, woody finish.

22oz bottle shared courtesy of egadzis. Bottled on 07/06. Poured a medium amberish color with a smaller sized off white head. Lots of small floaters. Aromas of light bourbon, wodd (subtle), coconut, oak, yeast, and soem citrus. Tastes of bourbon (more than the aromas), vanilla, citrus, wood, and lightly fruity. Alcohol content well hidden.

Thanks to egadzis for sharing this rare treat. Pours a mostly translucent golden with amber notes and a smaller bubbly white head. Aroma of oak, some funkiness, Belgian spices and yeast, citrus notes, bourbon. Flavor of vanilla, some bourbon, wood, sweet then to a dry finish.

Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in Apr 2010 - Pitch Black in colour. Malty; sweet malts, dark chocolate, caramel. Fruity. Hoppy; some hop bitterness to balance the sweet malts. Good malty/fruit/hop balance. Sweet malts dominate ending in a moderately bitter hoppy finish. (2010-04)
Black color with reddish lights. Thin body, watery texture. Nice roasted aromas. Roasted malts on taste as well. Easy going but pleasant beer.

14th April 2010. Clear dark red brown beer. Smooth semi dry palate. Nicely joined up beer. Smooth dark malt. Pretty fruity - cherry, orange, tangy. Some subtle dark chocolate underneath. Dry finish. Tasty and very drinkable.

Cask (handpump) @ The Back of Beyond, 104-108 Kings Road, Reading, Berkshire, England RG1 3BY. Clear dark red brown color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to light beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, bread, roasted, brown sugar. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100428]

Cask Handpump at the Penny Black JDW, Northwich 09/04/2010 Fruit and roast aromas. Beige head. Dark red coloured a little rich on the palate and fruity with a creamy dry and slightly bitter roast finish.

Herold Black Lager is a real drink , the best Schwarzbier in the world imo. Had this cask at a JDWS and it was cool and more interesting than most in their festival. Roasted chocolate and burnt raisin profile , with a little motor oil in the finish . Swillable ,tasty Schwarz.

[Gravity cask at the Back of Beyond, Reading] Black with ruby hints, no head. Sweet chocolate, camp coffee and a bit of treacle causes it to be rather sweet up front. However, it’s saved by roasted malt coming through in the surprisingly dry finish. It’s rather nice actually.

Cask @ Edward Wylie, JDW. Dark brown - red colour, tan lacings. Aroma is toasted malts, sweet licorice. Flavour of sweet licorice, roasted malts, some fruits. A bit watery. Agree on the aniseed mention. A bit smoky. Lots of things going on in this beer, but its a bit on the sweet side.

Hand pulled cask at the Moon and Sixpence (JDW) Hatch End. Almost black with a creamy tan head. Dry roast coffee and chocolate with a little caramel and peppery Saaz hops. Interesting to try this cask conditioned.

Cask at the Monks Retreat (JDW), Reading. Black with a reddish glow and ring of tan head; aniseed aroma; thinly bodied, the flavour blends aniseed and fruit with a light waft of smoke. Very drinkable.

Brown 500ml bottle, obtained from Beers of Europe, best before 28 Jul 2011, drank and reviewed 4 Jul 2011: poured into na UK pint sleeve glass. My bottle clearly called this Tom Wood’s Lincoln Red. True reddy brown coloured body, with a large off-white bubbley head on top, looks a treat. Aroma of roasted, toasted malts with semi-sweet molasses thrown in. The taste follows the smell, malts and molasses, but with a hop dry bite towards the end of the mouthfeel. As the mouth really dries between gulps the hop bitterness turns into an almost citrus mini-sourness (pink grapefruit?). Very nice in deed.

A dark brown to red coloured beer with a thickish, off white head. A slightly sweet, malty nose, some toffee and a little perfumed. A bitter smoky malt taste, again a bitter sweet toffee and caramel, with a touch of liquorice, then a slightly spicy hop flavour. The finish is bitter and dry. (Bottle BCA - purchased from the Butcher’s stall at the 2006 Sandringham Food Fair).
Cask Handpump at Wetherspoons, Manchester (JDW) 18/10/2006 Small white head. Mid brown amber coloured with some alcohol present. Hoppy with some dryness in a crisp and bitter malt finish.

Cask conditioned @ Standing Order (JDW), Soton. Brown colour. Fruity malt aromas. Berries and raisins with bisuits and a little tofeee. Fairly dry in the mouth with plenty of old fashioned english bitterness. Tasty.
A Mes rate: Cask at Baker St. JDW. All off milk and beef to me. An odd thing indeed. Think this may have been a little out of order.

Cask conditioned - handpump - JDW Northampton. A dark brown coloured beer with a russet hue and a whitish head. The aroma is sharp and fruity with orangey notes as well as beeries. The taste is very bitter with good English hops. Earthy also. A nice beer.

courtesy of Philipp and Thomas - translucide and bright bronze beer with a little foam left; aroma of wort and plastic; thin-bodied, solidly carbonated and with a fair grainy tartness, some harsh bitterness and a short dry corny and plastic-like finish - ugly

pale yellow with decent head. Smells like a normal beer, not like an alc-reduced one. Quite malty, slightly hoppy and dry. Rather full bodied for a light beer. Normally I don’t like light beers very much, but this one is really good.

Cask conditioned - handpump - OGs Wellingborough. A copper coloured beer with an off-white head and lacing. Hidden in this beer is some citrus hop and a little alcohol character, but sadly my half was blighted by age and signs of the bottom of the barrel. Fruit skin aromas and flavours and a thin cardboardy palate. Not good nor right.

Cask at the Wellington Arms, Bedford. Dark gold. Only the faintest aroma. Some maltiness in the taste. Rather thin and lacking in body. Not surprising considering the name. Some residual bitterness. Not one of B&T’s best. And the pumpclip design is amateurish.

Seichter Zitrusantrunk, der in trocken herbem Gefilde liegt. Entäuschend fällt die Würzigkeit aus – sie ist kaum vorhandden und beschränkt sich auf hellmalzige und gleichartig holzige Nuancen, äußerst schwach und sogar wässrig. Laff gerstig, wenig erfrischend. Schlechter Bock. 8/6/7/7/9/6

SBJ 2010 - clear amber-bronze colour and with a little but persistent head; aroma of oranges with light notes of solvant; sweet and rounded palate, medium to full-bodied, no real bitterness and a sweetish, slightly fruity finish with hints of warming alcohol - lacking of malt presence for a beer that strong
large head, deep golden yellow colour. Lovely aroma. Very full bodied with complex flavours: flowery hops, malt; bitter-weet character.

From Feb 2008 I got this bottle in a trade with Nutbrown. Thanks Alan! It pours from 750ml bottle a clear medium gold with a good 2 finger head of foam and some nice sticky lacing. Subsequent pours bring a slight haze to the appearance. The smell I noticed as I popped the cap. A nice mix of fruit(apple & pear) and a healthy dose of hops. The taste matches the nose. Almost equal portions of fruit and hops that gives the overall flavour of tartness and grass. I read the label and they say that they don't consider it to be a true Belgian Tripel because of the hop presence(it says American Tripel) and I'd tend to agree though, after a few more sips, I'm getting notes of candy sugar and some peppery flavour. Call it what you like, this is a darn good Ale and a darn god sipper.Btw, no sign at all for me when it comes to the abv...good job! The mouthfeel is on the thick side and the carbonation is light but adequate, and it finishes with a lemony twang. Very enjoyable! This one is worth a repeat, in my book.

May 22, 2014 - 750ml - my 2006 dated bottle - shared with blankboy, gregclow, jercraigs & mabel. Cloudy gold gusher with a huge white head. Bone dry aroma - fruit sweetness, floral bitterness and lots of yeast - like a devolved tripel (7-). Taste, well, it’s old - apple, yeast, alcohol ... solid body, airy - definitely oxidized, but for 8 years in my fridge, pretty frickin’ solid. I am betting it was beyond solid in its day.

Pours a hazy gold with a thin white lacing of head. Aroma is peppery with banana, pear and mango. Definitely some belgian phenols going on with some fruity hops. Taste is sweet and honeylike up front, followed up with stone fruit and pear following it up. Finishes spicy and clean with a light lingering bitterness.
Bottle. Pours a clear gold with thick white head that lasts leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is honey and yeast. Medium mouth, fruity, light spice, citrus, hides alcohol well, good.

750mL bottle bought from brewery 12/28/14 and drunk fairly shortly thereafter Initially large white head tops a sparkling golden-copper body that is very clear. Hmmm...almost too clear. As suspected, no sediment whatsoever at the bottom. Which is fine, I guess, but was hoping this would be unfiltered (or less filtered, anyways). Fruity esters mix with leafy, fragrant hops. Amarillos are one of my favorite American hops and they are fine here, if a bit unexciting. Little bit of tangerine, mint, touches of white grapefruit and tons of yellow fruits from the yeast (pineapple, nectarines, peaches). Alcohol heat is definitely felt, though not raw or overpowering, while the malts seem a bit absent. Very dry crackers, white bread and a touch of honey mixing with the alcohol and esters to give sort of a marmalade note. The flavor comes off heavily peachy; moreso, even, as it warms. Sort of a bittersweet component, with light pineapple, alcohol warmth and touches of black pepper.
