Hops aren’t too bitter, thankfully and there’s some malt sugar to lend balance, but it’s a bit messy, coming off lightly syrupy and yet grainy/husky as well. Carbonation is initially engaging, if somewhat prickly, but falls off too quickly, leaving the beer feeling a bit flabby and exposing the syrupy and boozey qualities. Could easily be a top notch beer if this wasn’t so filtered and the alcohol was dialed back even 1%. The lack of bottle conditioning really detracts here.

750ml bottle, slight hazy honey gold hue, with a white head. Nice fruity belgian yeast nose, with light a floral leafy, grassy, piney, coniferous hop, honeyed pale, toasted, pilsener, bready malt accent, with some citrus, grapefruit esters, and a faint lemon pie crust, panettone cake dough, phenolic note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a fruity, doughy, yeasty, faint funky, flowery citrus,leafy, grassy hoppy character, with some fait spicy pepper lemon, honeyed pale, wheat, toasted, bread malty, subtle candyish honey lollipop, candied lemon, grapefruit rind flavours, leading towards a honeyish maltiness, lingering citrus, leafy hop bitterness finish.

A yellow hay color extremely cloudy, decent head retention lingers. Black pepper yeast aromatics, soft peachy fruit aromatics and sweet honey. The flavor on this thing is huge fruit mango, peach hop flavor. Overall very drinkable, American triple fully appreciate the unique play of this style.
The aroma is fruit, pepper. The appearance is clear yellow, white head. The flavor is fruit, pepper, spicy, yeast. The finish is yeasty, breaady, spicy. Nice overall.

(bottle - 750 ml) Cloudy orange pour with a fizzy white head. Fruity and yeasty aroma. Not much else to it. Some hop bitterness in the flavor but predominantly fruit, honey and yeast with some spice coming up at the end.
A bit medicinal for a Belgium tripel style. Pretty clear hay notes, vey strong alcohol flavor.
Will Adams, Gillingham. Fruity, full, mildly tangy, fresh. A good best bitter. Refreshing, tasty and satisfying with a drying finish.

Volo Cask Days ’06. Light gold. Nose is jalapeno, doughy malt. Smells like a great pizza. Flavor is dominated by jala but not overwhelmed. Peppery, light toasted malt. Honestly the best pepper beer I’ve had.

Cask at Volo Cask Day 2006. Pours a clear pale gold with a small diminishing white head. Aroma: whoa, that’s jalapeno alright, pretty much nothing but! Flavour of jalapenos along with some hops -- not as hot as I expected from the aroma. Light bodied. I’m rating this slightly higher then I actually liked it because I’m not very fond of jalapenos but for what this is, it’s fairly well done.

Can at Tallboys in Toronto. Lightish brown with huge creamy white head. Bready sour aroma and flavour, rather unpleasant. Roast in the background. Watery on the palate. Didn’t bother taking much more notes... And only now I read it’s brewed with wine. Haha, might explain some things, I thought it had gone off. Anyway, an unpleasant failure in my book.
Sweet milk chocolate aroma. Opaque ruby colour. Flavours of chocolate and raisin; short bitter finish. Medium in body and carbonation. A really enjoyable beer.

unclear light brown reddish with a small light beige cap, some retention and sticky lacing. roasted fruitiness, burnt caramel, nuttiness, bit of coffee, red grapes but ends up tasting like red wine, cheap wine, touch of acidity, cardboard, chalk, minerals, booze. moderate carbonation, light body - oily, grassy-peppery finish. just like an ackward dogfish brew. meh.

Poured dark reddish brown with medium frothy head. Nutty malt aroma with some sweetness. Well balanced nut, slight wine, and malt. Still had a bit of sweetness, and slight bitterness, but very nicely balanced. Nothing was overpowering. Quite enjoyed it.
Pours clear copper with dying head and medium lacing. Only thing persistent in this is nut. Some bitterness, pretty high carbonation. Couldn’t detect any wine here. On tap at Bar Hop.

On tap. Dark ruby pour, thin tan head. Aroma has dark fruit (I assume from the merlot), a little tobacco, vanilla. Light and oily. Pretty sweet throughout with a clean finish. It’s nice but unchallenging.
On tap at 3030 - not that good, may have been off? Very light and acidic quality, almost medicinal? Thought about not reviewing but was told by the owners that is how it is supposed to be. Not good.

This porter poured a deep black colour with a big, foamy, tan coloured head. Little lacing. Scents include molassass, caramel, lightly roasted malts and a little coffee. First sip was flavourful with swet caramel notes, coffee, light smoke and a tiny bit of cocoa. Finish is roasty with a little bitterness on the palate. Delicious.

can from brewery 5.5%. Poured clear chestnut brown with a creamy mocha head. Malty caramel nose. Creamy thick mouthfeel. Full flavour, caramel malt and a nice herbal bitterness. A bit astringent finish.
Malty, nutty, soft bitterness. White creamy head that sustained to the last sip. Pleasantly surprised.

Cask at Volo Cask Day 2006. Pours a hazy golden-yellow with a spare diminishing white head, Aroma of sweet malt, maple syrup, brown sugar and fruit -- no smoke though. Flavour of sweet malt, grain, maple and light hops. Medium bodied. Pretty good but I got no smoke at all from it.
Cask. Hazy yellow-golden body. Acidic aroma - peaches, apple, and grape skins. Heavy palate - sticky malts, sugary fruit, touch of smoked dark malt. Strange.
Cask @ Volo. Not bad. Poured a cloudy and yellow-gold colour. Taste was sweet(I tasted sweet more than maple) with a bitter after taste. I didnt pick up too much of a smokey taste.

Cask at Volo Cask Day 2006. Light, hazy yellow-gold. Aroma of maple candy and orange juice, not much smoke. Flavour hold more maple and dark sugar, some fruitiness, and still not much smoke. I didn’t mind it, but I really hoped for a smokier character.

Cask. Aroma: sweet citrus nose, orange, sweet maple. Good combination. Appearance: hazy gold, with smallish white (pourous) head. Green, citrussy front, short bitterness followed with sweet finish. Drinkable bitter-sweet ale. I am afraid that hops and maple totally covered smoked malts with its dominance here.

Cask. At Volo Cask Day 2006. Hazy-cloudy light gold, small head. Candy/brown sugar sweet grainy aroma, a hint of burnt peat and ripe peaches or apricots. The taste is sweet malt - my brain alternated between processing it as "burnt maple syrup and woody malt" and "stewed apricots" - weird. An average paleager body, sticky and syrupy mouthfeel, very cloying but has an odd smokey/bitter aftertaste - it’s better than you’d think, but I preferred their earlier Maple Bush Lager in the big-ass bottles.
on tap at the beer bistro. overall a nice marzen, very nice maltiness to it, nice and dry aftertaste. for sure a small brewery nice to see them try different things. nice effort
Decent beer, glad these guys are trying new things, had on tap at ronnies local. lotsa malt on the nose, kinda sweet. Amber orange colour. decent hops, lots of caremel, easy drinking.
Aroma is a solid malt with mild spice, amber, pours a small cream head. Flavour is a spicey malt, some good hops, caramel notes too. Balanced, smooth, easy drinking, quite nice.

On tap at the Alex P Keaton in London, Ontario- Thanks to Mark and Andrew for getting this one in their line-up! Pours copper liquid capped with a frothy one finger cap. Minute lace. Very malty aroma, burnt sugars, and cookie, with a mild hop profile. Pretty bitter with lots of bready malt, and a touch of sweetness to finish. Caramel lingers. A well done beer, albiet only my second in this style.

Draught at Volo Cask Day 2006. Pours a clear orange with a lasting creamy white head. Decent lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, toffee and grain. Flavour of caramel malt, some toastyness, grain, maybe a hint of diactyl and a light bitter finish. Light to medium bodied. Decent.

Draught. Cloudy orange with a small white creamy head. Aroma of toasted rye, creamy grain, and butter. Flavour is harsh, astringent, and bready. Butterscotch notes are present too. Strange consistency and a bit too sweet.

Draught (Keg) at Volo Cask Fest 2006. Clear golden. Aroma is herbal with a very green character, and a fresh maltiness - nice, but a little young. Flavour is nice as well, a good balance of fresh hops and soft malt that becomes more prominent in the finish, but again, it seems a little undefined and rough around the edges. As Radek suggests, another couple of weeks of lagering would do some good, but even so, it was enjoyable.

Tap. Sweet malts with bitter strong overtones, hint of citric hops followed by hints of alcohol. Gold amber appearance, smallish bubbly white top. Surprisingly thin bodied with raw, green grain character. Malty finish. Character is softer at finish that covers alcohol well. In my opinion this beer was rushed bit to fast to customers. Few extra weeks of lagering should do the trick.
Lagerish taste though neutral aroma. While this brewery has yet’t offend me. to impress me, this was drinkable and didn

Draught @ Het Brouwcafe, Dr. Lelykade 28, Scheveningen, Netherlands 2583 CM. [ As Brouwcafe Brouwbok ]. Clear light dark red brown color with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, berry, toffee, brown sugar. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet, light light acidic and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, burnt sugar sweet and bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20091101]

Bottle 0,75ltr: Found at the of Burg Brouwerij and named now BrouwBock, Ermelo. Hazy brown coloured brew with an fine bitter taste and fine hints of caramel. Tap at Brouwcafe: Dark ruby coloured bock with a great caramel taste, very smoothy drinkable bock.
Brewery tap. Caramel and Buisman in the aroma. Brown sugar. Very sweet flavor with a hint of raspberry and laurel, especially in the aftertaste. Fairly weak but a decent brew.

On tap at the brewery. Aroma of dark malts with hints of chocolat and faint fruity sourness. Dark brown color, beige creamy head, good lace. Very nice mouthfeel, soft and silky. Dark malts, light sweet, light bitter, hint of chocolat, no sourness in the flavor.
The beer has got a hazy light yellow color with a steady head and medium body. Aroma of wheat and fruits. Taste of wheat, fruits, bread, yeast. Mild finish.
Many thanks to kevnic2008 for this bottle! Smooth grainy beginning. The yeast is dusty with hints of clove. Bitter-neutral, round but refreshing with a nice malty bitter aftertaste.

Many thanks to kevnic2008 for this bottle! Pours hazy deep golden colour with a mid-sized off-white head. Aroma of clove, some banana and yeast. Taste of banana, yeast and nice clove in the background.
Pours a hazy yellow color with white head. Aroma is yeast, wheat and cloves. Taste is sweet. Thin to medium body.

Bottle at the brewpub. It’s unclear warm golden with a huge, creamy head. The aroma has initial barnyard notes together with yeast and wheat. The sweet flavor has notes of butter, barnyard (especially initially), yeast, wheat, light fruit and a hint of smoke in the finish - infected..?
Hefiger unspektakulärer Antrunk, der schnell milder wird. Ab dem Mittelteil wässrig, laffer Abgang. OK. 11/8/7/8/8//8

500ml bottle (OPP, Helsinki, German Weeks 2009) Sour aroma, otherwise a quite typical hefe-weizen. A bit pissy crotchy. Taste follows that, alas - there was once a good orangy weisse, but it’s gone scheisse.

Bottled@One Pint Pub, Helsinki. Deep orangeish golden colour, small white head. Aroma is wheat, yeast, mild acidicness as well as some mild wooden notes. Flavour is wheat, fruits, some mild sourness as well as some wood and mild yeastyness.

(bottle, courtesy of Quack-Duck) Cloudy, orange-golden colour with a big and minimal off-white foamy head. Slightly sweet and yeasty fruity aroma of apricots and citrus with a moderate wheat-character and traces of cloves and vanilla. Light-sweet flavour with a tinge of acidity, light to medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Yeasty-fruity and wheaty taste with clovy spice and shy hoppy spots; light-sweet and sourish finish with a light bitter tartness and cloves in the aftertaste (14.08.08).

bottle, bought at the brewery. Hazy pale yellow, large white head. Fruity nose. Medium-bodied, yeasty and wheaty with a touch of banana and lemon. Shy hop notes in the finish. A well-balanced Hefeweizen.
bottle from MoritzF - díky! Murky yellow colour, large white head. Malty-fruity nose. Malty, yeasty, very wheaty with a nice touch of fruit. A very good light beer.

Bottle: Deep golden, hazy, stable creamy off-white head; sourish orangey nose with a caramelly-wheaty background; creamy MF, light bodied without being watery; lingering citrussy and wheaty finish with a light - rounding - caramelly touch. A fine light Weizen......

(bottle, purchased at the brewery) Cloudy, golden colour with a grey-ish and huge foamy head. Slightly yeasty, fruit-accented aroma with notes of apricots and banana, accompanied by a mildly wheat-character and phenolic spices when it warms. Slightly sweet flavour with a light tinge of acidity, light bodied but not watery, well-carbonated mouthfeel. Wheaty and fruity taste with light notes of cara-malt and a touch of barnyard; mildly sweet wheaty and fruity finish with even a lasting malty aftertaste. Slim but balanced and refreshing. 05.X.10

column4: Brauerei und Gasthof zur Krone Tettnang
column5: (bottle, vintage 2008, 5.0% abv, thanks to Stefan) Clear, brown colour with a light-beige medium-sized foamy head. Sweet and slightly toasted malty aroma with a nutty touch, light notes of toffee and shades of herbal hops in the background. Sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Toast-malty base, nutty taste with light notes of caramel/toffee; dry and slightly bitter finish with a toasty malty aftertaste. Nice but not world-shaking Dunkel (03.XII.08).

column4: Brauerei und Gasthof zur Krone Tettnang
column5: Bottle #3937, thanx to Quack-duck ! Amber coloured, sweetish-caramelly nose with a touch of toasted malt and some herbal hops underneath. Moderate sweet-bitter flavour, light to medium bodied. Nutty traces in the toasted, moderate sweet-bitter finish. Nice brew

column4: Brauerei und Gasthof zur Krone Tettnang
column5: bottle @5.0% ABV, 2008 vintage, bottle #3925 (of 5000). Clear golden colour, large white head. Malty nose. Malty body with some hints of caramel and roasetd malts and lovely Tettnang hops. Not as powerful as expected, rather light - but still full of pleasant flavours. Good.

column4: Brauerei und Gasthof zur Krone Tettnang
column5: Light coppery colored, little white head. Whoppaaa how buttery aroma with strong sweetness! Medium bodied. Flavor is quite original to be German beer: butter dominates, sweetness, hops and some bitterness come up also. I like this mix.

column4: Brauerei und Gasthof zur Krone Tettnang
column5: Edition 2006 (BB 12/2006). Copper brown, very small white head. Buttery, grassy, strong diacetyl in the nose. Quite grassy hoppy, but also caramelly and diacetylic hoppy. Not sure how to call this, but entered it as an altbier.
Bottle. Light hazy dark golden, offwhite head. Aired caramel, light mealy nose. Medium full mellow body. Good balance between caramel malt and grassy hops. ok.
Amber with little white head. Aroma is citrus, some grassy hoppy character, bubblegum, gummybears, toasty malt. Taste is shallow bitter hops with some sweet phenolic spicy malt. Ok.
Bottle. Pours clear golden. Aroma is some caramel, paper, butter, grains. Body is medium, sweetish, buttery, with a lively carbonation, still grainy. Doesn't feel very ambery. Okay.
Bottle. Golden color with white head. Aroma is grainy, caramel, papery. Taste is grainy, malty, earthy. Medium carbonation. Ok.

Many thanks to kevnic2008. Smooth malty beginning. Moderate bitter, slightly grainy with a nice caramelly malty body. Easy to drink, refreshing and smooth. Nice sessionable beer with hints of nuts and nice dry caramel.

Many thanks for this beer to kevnic2008. Piwo niemal ze zbiegu Szwajcarii, Austrii i Niemiec oddzielone tylko jezorem Bodenskim. Smak piwa jak na dolnofermentacyjny styl dosc wyrazny, tresciwy i porzadanie wytrawny. Przyrumieniony, stary karmel, nieco mokrej deski i piwnicznej wilgoci. Troche ma to piwo z pewnych cech kellerbier. Nie za slodkie, barwa miedziana piana srednia ale w miare trwala. Jak na styl wiedenskiego lagera to bardzo dobrze wypada. Danke Mariusz
Danke an kevnic2008. Süß herber Antrunk. Zunehmend getreidig, etwas karamellig. Brotig, hell malzig, süffig aber monoton. Okay. 10/8/8/8/7/8
Bottle at the corresponding hotel in kressbonn. Pours a beautiful Amber. Nose is citrus, apricot, just a bit buttery. Palate is sweet, bread, also a bit buttery and hoppy. Bitter finish. Good!
Pours an amber color. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, light leather - grass. Flavour is moderate sweet.

500ml on tap at the brewpub in Kressbronn. Aroma is ripe peaches, malt. Appearance is light cloudy copper with a light white foam. Taste is light to medium sweet, slightly bitter. Light dryness. Very good.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Clear blond colour with thin head. Aroma and flavour are malty, grainy. A little too sweet

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Pours dark blonde. Ok to small white head that falls dead within seconds. Completely flat looking beer in uncer 2 seconds ! Smell is spiced, bit sweet, some metallic notes. taste is fairly bitter, dry spices ( lemongrass pops in mind, coriander) bit oxidation as well. medicinal as a whole, thats for sure.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: sample from bottle, poured a light hazy dark golden to more orange colour with a white head. nose of light crisp malts, soft wheats, light citrus notes, coriander, belgian yeast, spices, nutgmeg?, light sweetness of orange. taste is dry, with a bit to much yeast.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: F: big, light off-white, very quick gone. C: orange to gold, hazy. A: malt, orange peels, coriander, spicy, floral, hint of funky, yeasty. T: malt, orange, coriander, spicy, yeast, medium to light body, very lively carbonation, not bad but easy forgettable Belgian ale, 0,33l bottle from Delhaize in Eupen.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Cerveza de color anaranjado turbio, la espuma blanca cremosa abundante. Aroma afrutado con notas de maltas, trigo y con ciruela. Sabor medianamente amargo, sabores de trigo reforzado con puntas de ciruelas y pitillo en boca con una astringencia media al final de boca. Buena cerveza.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: 29/XII/14 - 33cl bottle as "La Botteresse Blonde" from Geers (Oostakker) @ holiday - BB: 1/IX/16 (2014-1559) Clear orange beer, big creamy off-white head, little stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: very floral, bit sweet, spicy touch, sugary, orange peel. MF: lots of carbon, medium body. Taste: citrus, floral, little bitter, sweet, and is that lavender? Aftertaste: very floral, soapy, some citrus, bitter touch, still thinking about lavender here...

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Regional beer with loose, snow white head and clear orange blond colour. Fruity, grainy, pear, some honey, sourish touch, citrus; not the mostle subtle or well-balanced beer I ever tasted, but enjoyable.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: 33cl bottle from Cora in Brussels. F: gusher after opening! Medium, tan, quick diminishing head. C: brown, hazy. A: sweet malty, sweet fruity, caramel, bit bready. T: malty, caramel, vaguely fruity, bit candy sugar, toffee, quite simple and sweet all together, higher carbonation, bit yeasty, ok yet nothing really special for me and gusher…

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Bruin bier met weinig schuim. Smaak is zoet en licht bitter hoppig met iets van chocolade, karamel en een heel licht zuurtje. Is wel wat waterig maar desondanks een goed bier.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Une ambrée ronde et douceureuse sur des notes maltées et torréfiées avec une bouche marquée par la sucrosité et les notes torréfiées.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Copper colour with thin head. Aroma and flavour have some sweet malts. Carbonation is low and there's a tart tinge of vinegar suggesting a possible infection. Not very good.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Bottle @ home. Clear copper to amber color, fizzy instantly diminishing off-white head. Smell and taste malts, some caramel, leaves, sourish. Appears to have an infection. Medium body, high carbonation. Bleh.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: light sweet caramel and bread aroma,amber, hazy, off white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, light sweet alcoholic finish.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Amber coloured and hazy. Has a white head, medium duration. Sweet aroma, yeasty notes and light toasted bread. Flavor starts sweet, nice soft yeasty notes, fruity too. Moderate bitter finish.

column4: Brasserie Artisanale La Botteresse de Sur-les-Bois
column5: Hazy amber, small creamy off-white head. Cloves and fruits nose. Light body. Rather sweet taste. Some fruits palate. B@H
Frisches und sueffiges Bierchen mit ein wenig Gras und einigem an Hopfen. Sehr trinkbar, vollmundig und ausgeglichen. Nicht schlecht.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours out in a hazy light dirty golden colour with steady head and medium body. Aroma of hops and straw. Taste of fresh hops, hay, straw, grains, barley and malt. Flowery finish. Not a bad one.
Many thanks for this bottle to Erzengel. Cloudy golden colour. Grassy, hoppy aroma and a light malty, Medium body with a light malty finish.

Golden and slightly hazy in the glass. The beer starts easy to drink, a bit grainy, a bit malty. The mainpart is "brew-pub-typical" grainy-flat, easy to drink and smooth. The aftertaste is medium, a bit grainy, slightly bitter. Ok, but nothing special. --> 7/12/7/7

Hell herber Antrunk, mäßig frisch. Dabei recht mild, manchmal nahe der Wässrigkeit. Im mittelteil hefier, später noch etwas herber, wodurch das Bier frischer wirkt. Ein Sommerbier, höchstens. 10/8/9/7//8

Bottle 100cl. w. swing top. Unclear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, toasted, light hoppy, grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is light medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090306]
Bottle, 4.8% bought at the brewpub. Hayish malt aroma. Cloudy yellow colour. Very small white head. The flavour is haylike, bordering on bready. A bit of good yeast flavour, quite clean though.
Bottle, thanks to MiP for sharing. Hazy yellow coloured with a small white head. Fruity aroma of malts, hay, grain and hops. Fruity flavour of hay, caramel and hops with notes of grass. Hoppy finish.

1 L bottle, courtesy of MiP. Pours hazy to murky pale yellow with a small white head. Slight malty and brewmashy aroma. Cornish and distinct perfumed hoppy flavoured. Slight bubblegum yeasty flavoured with a light bitterness showing through. Ends dry and bitter. Slight cornish.

On draught (at the brewpub): Pale, hazy, yellow coloured, mid-sized firm rocky white head; distinctive sweet-malty and aromatic, grassy hoppy nose; light bodied, moderate to robust bitter-sweet flavour, quite dry, soft MF; grassy bitter, slightly lingering finish. A very aromaic Zwickel. Good !

On tap (@the brewery): Clear, amber coloured, quite firm, small head; delicate hoppy and malty to grainy nose; bitter-sweet flavour, light bodied, quite fizzy; light, short bitter-grainy finish. Drinkable, not overwhelming............

Malvern Location. Poured used motor oil Black with a small brown head. The aroma was sweet and chocolaty. Flavors were dark chocolate, sweet smoke, and a sort of green olivey finish that I couldn’t figure out. The olive flavor didn’t ruin the beer completely but it did knock it down a few pegs I thought.

Poured an opaque black color with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, anise, and floral hops. Taste of more roast and chocolate, with some smoke, and a citrus / cascade hop finish. A little brother to Storm King.

On tap at the Malvern location. Menu said it was like its counterpart Russian Imperial Stouts but not as strong (RIS Lite!). Poured a dark black with reddish / brown edges and a small sized off white head. Light lacing left on the glass. Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate and dark fruits. Tastes of roast, dark chocolate, dark fruits and a nice coffee bitter finish. The bitter chocolate / coffee was a nice balance to the sweet fruits. Light to medium alcohol finish (being a RIS and the alcohol in the finish, I would have guessed this one was more than 7%). Overall, nice and quite drinkable.
Bottled (BB 10/2009) Thanks Björn! Golden color, small white head. Papery, cardboardish, sticky nose. Grassy, harsh, cardboardish flavor. Harsh.
Bottled@Björntasting. Pale golden colour, white head. Aroma is hops, mild earth, wood and some grains. Flavour is malts, some mild notes of herbs and also mild earthyness.
Bottled. Clear pale golden, rich creamy head. Buttery soft malt. Sweet with medum body. A creamy and harmonious malt oriented beer with fairly low bitterness.

bottle. Clear golden yellow colour, large and creamy white head. Malty-fruity nose. Solid malty body with pleasant fruit flavours throughout. Slightly more hoppy in the finish. A very pleasant Export.

Bottle (purchased at the brewery): Grainy nose with a touch of a herbal "wooden" hoppiness; pale golden coloured, slightly hazy, small foamy, sticking to the glass; delicate sweetish-bitter flavour, light to medium bodied; mild but rather spicy short bitter-sweet finish. Quite well drinkable, but nothing special........
Cask at The Wig and Pen Norwich 26 Sep 2006. Golden coloured. A small head. Lacing on the glass. Malty aroma with fruity hints. Cautions fruity flavour. Some bitterness in the aftertaste.

Half pint on cask, found in good condition at The Wig and Pen, Norwich. Dark golden. Great clarity, but no head. Malty sweetness in aroma. Vanilla taste with a hoppy touch behind. Dry ending. Average (26.09.2006).
Cask at The Moon Under Water (JDW), Watford in 2012. Clear mid golden with a white head. Aroma of dried fruit, wet grass and malt. Fairly standard, malt forward cask bitter.

18/7/2019. Bottle shared at the South West tour bottle share. Bought at Three Trees Farm Shop, Chiseldon. Pours dark amber with a small bubbly creamy white head. Aroma of buttery toffee, sweet malt, fruit and hops. Moderate sweetness and bitterness. Moderate body, quite watery texture, soft carbonation.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, nuts, malt, hops and has a sweet caramel and light bitter finish.

Re-rate as I work my way through a case of this beer at home. A good session beer and overall a pleasant pint. Plenty of malt, some bitter hops and a biscuit and farmyard flavour. And a nice and low abv. Drinking this puts a smile on my face.

500ml bottle from local Co-op. Pours cola brown with bubbly grey head. Aroma of chocolate and Madeira. Taste malt heavy with bitter chocolate and coffee. Hops very light, lacking character, but overall a decent bitter.
Bona cervesa, bastant equilibrada i gustosa. Buena cerveza, bastante equilibrada y sabrosa.

Pint at the Isis Sunderland. Brown beer with a white head. Toffee aroma and flavour. Didn’t get much hop flavour, smooth or otherwise. Shame. Some rough sexy hops would have been nice; instead, I was bored, looking at my watch, and inventing a suddenly remembered appointment elsewhere..
Bottle at Nya Tröls. Clear orange coloured with a small off-white head. Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel, dried fruits and hops. Fruity flavour of grass, hops and citrus peel. Hoppy finish.
50 cl bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small off white head. Aroma is light fruity and mild butterish. Bitter and toasted malty finish.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown colour with a thin white head, malty aroma with some chocolate, the taste is lightly sour, chocolate malt with a dry finish.

Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear amber with a toupe head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a nice grassy hop note with a hint of pine and a strong grain backbone. Flavor has a combination of grassy hops with some nice grain notes and a hint of alcohol.

I had a version of this at FoBAB ’07 that had for its description, "Wild red ale aged 1 year in a French oak barrel, blended with young red ale." My rating’s going here since, not having had the original, I really don’t know if there’s a difference. It had a dirty amber body with a slender ecru ring in lieu of a head. The aroma had a wild kind of funkiness to it, not too strong, over scents of orchard fruit. The flavor had a sweet base, caramel, fruit, and light brown sugar, with a moderate bitterness and a touch of the wild. Pretty decent brew. Festival of Barrel Aged Beers, Chicago, IL 11/03/2007

12 oz draught at the brewpub, mid-October 2006, as "Brewers Reserve Strong Red Ale." Pretty nearly opaque burnt amber to dried blood in color with a creamy-bubbly light tan head, nicely lasting with a touch of lace....lots of PNW hops in the aroma, caramel and a hint of vanilla-whisky, seems perhaps barrel aged or flavored with oak chips?; piney-grapefruity characteristics dominate, touches of dried fruit also in evidence....the body is mostly malty-sweet, brown sugar dominating pungent, bitter oily hops.....carbonation fairly low, oakiness evident towards the finish which is just a bit too lactic/sour for what it is. Still an interesting, drinkable example.

Hazy and dark ruby chocolate in color with a dark tan head that’s hugging lastingly to the glass. Rhubarb and plum caramel meet a fabricy softness for a clean and sweet aromatic introduction. A touch of caramel marinated grapefruit and liquefied red figs join with a praline toffee trait on the tails of the waft. Big flavor presence with black cherries and plum butter sinking into graham pie crust. Rhubarb and an emphasized simcoe and cascade presence give an authoritative bitter/flavor hop combo. Figs are there with some rummy red toffee. Come to think of it, nearly all fruited contributors are red. Sure, there’s some nuttiness from the dates and accent flavors of broiled grenadine poured over pralines, but we’re principally dealing with dark red fruits here. Amaretto wafers and caramelized dates meet the bright blood red grapefruit juice for a cleaving, flavorful finish.

column1: Church End Bobs Dog Jumping Frogs
column5: Cask Handpump from the outside festival bar at the Star Inn, Huddersfield 03/12/2005 Clear golden coloured very hoppy and citrus flavoured with a crisp and slightly bitter malt finish.

column1: Church End Bobs Dog Jumping Frogs
column5: At the Ridge Lane brewery. Brilliant gold pint with white suds. A puckering blast of quinine-bitter American hop zestiness. One of the bitterest pints I’ve ever had. Very sulphurous, very grapefruity, very biscuity. Very everything. A hint of shampoo to finish. Sweet biscuity afters cushion the hop punch. At least as bitter as XX Bitter, Orval et al. Musty hopsack and Burton snatch aroma. Tangerine, grapefruit, oats and pencil shavings. As hoppily bitter as an American IPA, if not as lip-smackingly fruity. Bonus point for sheer hop pungency.

column1: Church End Bobs Dog Jumping Frogs
column5: Cask handpump at The Wellington, Birmingham. Golden with a short head. Slight melon and lemon scent, but not much. Slight carbonation and a slightly oil finish. Bitter but only a hint of hop, mainly berry fruit here.

Gravity at The Wellington, Birmingham. A bright red-orange colour with no head and flat looking. Hoppy and orangey scent. Good mouthfeel, not very bitter. Hoppy with some orange taste. You have to work hard to pick out the earthy beetroot in the end of the hoppy aromas.

courtesy of Laurent Mousson - cloudy orange colour with some impurities floating within; the foam is disappearing very fast; aroma of apple, sugary; very sweet with a high carbonation; some bitterness with a dry and quite flat fruity finish - unconvincing
Pours clear Golden with a thick white head. Aroma of pilsener malt. Taste has wheat beer elements with a slight acerbic element. Palate has slight sweetness to it. Eh.

This is a backlog rating from 2011 from a bottle, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are pale wheat malts, honey, orange citrus, watery.
Light hazy body and a white foam. Aroma of wheat and some citrus but the aroma is light. The taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Smooth low carbonation.

Looks like Blue Moon dropped "Summer" from their Summer Honey Wheat [it's now just Honey Wheat]. They must have dropped the honey too. I expected a little more honey flavor and was disappointed to find that it was nearly non-existent. It's still a good wheat beer. It's just not a honey wheat beer.
Hazy body with medium head. Nose is sweet and citrus. Taste is fruity and malty with caramel notes. Honey comes through as well. Too sweet for me.
Pours a golden yellow with a thin white head. Aroma is fruit and bread malts. Flavor is sickly sweet malts and some fruit. Has a soft body. Too sweet, without much flavor. Meh.
Ljusgul öl med ett vitt skum. Smak och doft av honung, hö, och en lätt örtighet.
Pleasantly sweet. Refreshing. No bitterness. Mild "beer" flavor with a floral note

Honestly, I think this beer deserves a higher rating than it deserves. Refreshing wheat aftertaste with the slightest hint of honey. Not overly sweet, which is a plus. Slight improvement over original flavor. Best consumed after an eight hour shift.

Well. I didn't have a cataclysmic brain aneurysm after drinking it so I consider that a success. Or not. When you're looking to shake up your feeble and ever-diminishing brain cells, load those wily bastards up on Blatz and let the good times roll.....right into oblivion. That's my kind of party.
Vintage 2012. Minneapolis Cloudy and golden-orange. Grainy aroma with furry notes. A little off, but still kind of good.

Backlog rating on 9-14-2012 at Cap n’ Cork Covington Plaza, Fort Wayne, IN, beer tasting. This bottled beer’s appearance is a small white head, pale yellow transparent body, very little carbonation, and spotty amounts of lacing. The aroma is white grapes, fruity, citrus, wheat, and yeast. The flavor is sweet, white grapes and wine. The mouthfeel is smooth and this beer is medium bodied. This beer is very quaffable and the 8.5% ABV is well masked.

"Pours a hazy gold with a small quick-fading bright white head. The aroma dominated by grapes with a touch of honey and light spice. The taste is all grapes up front followed by some banana sweetness, lemon, and light clove on the finish. The mouthfeel has moderate carbonation and a slightly syrupy mouthfeel. Overall it’s tasty and refreshing with big Chardonnay grape flavor and just a hint of booze. Nice high ALC of 8.5% it’s hidden well.

Bottle sampled at Jax Beer Fest 2013 as Blue Moon Vintage Blonde. Random tick off my wants list thanks to this re-labeling. Hazy golden pour with a small off-white head. Light bready malts, esters, phenolics, and some sweet winey aspects. Overly sweet, fruity, malty. Meh.

June 2012. From a 750 ml. bottle labeled as Blue Moon Vintage Blonde Ale 2012. Pours hazy golden color with a nice white head. Aromas are straw, citrus and spice. The chardonnay doesn’t really show through, but a very drinkable beer.

Interesting offering. Aromas of malt, yeast, and grapes. Sweet flavor maybe a bit heavy on the grape juice but still respectable I would still try it again. I wonder if cellaring this one would help it evolve a bit.

Bottle, shared with Ian and Colin over a game of Power Grid. Lager-like pour, medium gold, average head, poor retention. Aroma is sweet, perhaps suggestive of white grape juice, but mostly sweet grains. Flavour is sweet, like soda, like Canada Dry ginger ale mixed with a basic sweet lager. Not my thing at all, not even as a summer beer. Drain pour actually.

Bottle @ home picked up at Wilbur’s Foco a while back. Bottle titled Vintage 2012. Pours a touch hazy yellow appearance with a dissipating white head. Somewhat zesty/spicy, white wine, grape, pear, a bit musty aroma. Fairly sweet malty, a bit sugary, white grape, apple, pear, light banana, somewhat tangy flavor. Fairly decent but kind of a one-dimensional fruit bomb that’s not even that dry.

Sampled from a 750 ml brown bottle this beer poured a clear yellow-gold color with a medium sized soapy/foamy white head that faded quickly and left a bit of lacing. The aroma was sweetish and had touches of wood and chardonnay. The flavor was tangy sugar, candied grapes and a touch of cardboard. Medium length tangy sugar and grape finish. Moderately full bodied. Decent.
From a bottle poured a straw color with a small amount of head. Light sweet malty flavor with a quick finish.

Half pint at The Fat Cat in Ipswich. Amber coloured. Missing head. Fruity notes come through in a weak aroma. Flavour has accent of raisin and dried fruits. Some hoppy hints can be detected. Dry finish. Standard kind of English bitter (22.09.2006).
Cask conditioned at Mahars. Pours a dark brown with no real head. Aroma is sweet and caramel. Flavor very sweet and caramel tasting, nice and even.

(cask @ The Real Beer Expo - Rochester, NY) Dark copper color with not much head. Aroma is very buttery and malty with a lot of caramel malts. Flavor reflects the aroma very well... lots of caramel, sweetness, and a lot of butter. Very rich and sweet with a nice smooth and sweet middle and a warming and caramelly finish. Very chewy.
On tap at 2 be. Hazy yellow. Frothy white head. Smells and tastes like a pina colada. Light bodied.
Fles gedeelt door Sander. Het is een licht geel bier met een wit schuim. Het heeft een kokos achtige geur. De smaak is moutig en kokos achtig.
Flasche 33cl. Erinnert stark an die Kokosbällchen auf der Kirmes. Die hatten wenigstens keinen bitteren Nachgeschmack. Unterirdisch...
Hazy pale yellow pour. Not sure whether I can call it a beer, but because of the coconut it is def refreshing
I've heard of good coconut flavours in beer. This is not one of those. Backlog.

Shared bottle at Ethiopian restaurant in Amsterdam. Again probably a mix of brewed ver and an coconut extract. The only thing you smell and taste is fake coconut. Not as disgusting as its banana brother, bit still a bad idea.
Draught at The Delirium Cafe Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal. Clouded straw with white head. Heavy, sweet coconut milk notes, full on the palate, heavy perfumed notes. Not my thing.

on tap at brewery. dark, dark brown color. Smoky scent, smoked taste that leave the tongue dry. roasted pumpkin seed aftertaste. The use of pumpkin is interesting in this beer, as the smoked flavor obscures most of the pumpkin taste.

Dark bodied w. a cola head. Pleasant, deep, complex roasty aroma with a light smokiness. Like the stout, a nice roasted flavor, but no pumpkin.Chocolate notes, w. some graininess and the roastiness well-balanced by a soupcon of bitterness. A great porter, albeit lacking in pumpkin qualities.

Definitely a tasty smoked porter...didn’t get much from the pumpkin, but who cares? Lots of smoke taste, but not fake tasting. I hope to try this again in a week or two at the other Elysian Pumpkin fests.

Bouillon beer with thick, off-white, coarse and dense head and deep orange blonde colour with brownish hue, cloudy. Sweet fruit aroma of orange juice, pineapple, red apple, lemon peel, freshly grated carrots, ginger, honey, coriander, gingerbread. Sweetish taste, yeasty fruitiness with light citrus touch, rather harsh carbonation, honeyish and caramelly, as well as slightly nutty malt base, sweet but not sticky, brief hop bitterness in the finish, spicy. Okay and thirst-quenching.

Half pint on gravity dispenser at The Ipswich Beer Festival ’06 (festival special). Deep mahogany in colour. Missing head. Mild malty to the nose. Flavour contains a conbination of fesh and dried fruits. Light bitterness towards the end. Rather ordinary (22.09.2006).
Süffiger, eher trockener Antrunk mit milder Bananigkeit. Würziger, spritzig herber Mittelteil, wenig bitter, moderat hefig. Süffig, dunkel hefiger Abgang. 10/9/10/10//10
On tap at the brewpub. Trübes orange goldenes Bier mit einer geringen weißen schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, Nelke, leicht phenolisch. Geschmack würzig, viel Nelke, kaum fruchtig.

(draught at the brewpub) Hazy, amber colour with a short but dense foamy white head. Sweet and distinctively wheat-malty aroma with a rather restrained fruit-character, except for some notes of bubblegum, lighter grainy spots and a whiff of phenolic spices. Moderately sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a lively carbonation. Present wheaty base with a touch of cara-malt and shy fruity notes; yeasty bitter and a bit slim finish. 03.X.10

Festival special at The 24th Ipswich Beer Festival. Hazy, pale brown body under a bubbly, low level of foam. Moderate fruity aroma. Ripe fruity in taste with hints of figs and apricot supported by hops. Short bitter ending (Half pint on gravity, 23.09.2006).
Tap at the corresponding hotel. Pours with a hazy orange gradient (probably the glass). nose is citrus, banana, floral, Peach. Palate is bubblegum, banana, a bit watery, bananabread finish. Good.

500ml on tap at the brewpub in Kressbronn. Aroma is light oats, malty. Appearance is cloudy dark orange with a fine white foam. Taste is light sour, some sweetness. Strong carbonation. Refreshing. Very good.

Draught at the brewpub. It’s unclear dark golden with a huge, creamy and longlasting head. The aroma has slightly yeast and fruity notes. The flavor is sweet with notes of yeast, both a slightly spicy one and baking yeast, fruit, wheat, and the finish is slightly dry and a little spicy.
On tap at the Brewpub. Trübes goldenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig, würzig. Geschmack hefig fruchtig, reife Bananen, leicht würzig.

On tap at the restaurant, near Kressbonn, Lake Bodenessee, Germany, 14-06-10 Sat drinking this whilst admiring the views looking out across the vineyards and over to Lake Bodenessee. Pours deep orange colour with a very hazy thin white head. Nice beer, refreshing, aroma little unusual instead of the expected banana, cloves etc (I did get them) I noted some steamed vegetables. Yeast and more Hefeweizen like flavours in the mouth, soft as well, good stuff despite that unusual aroma. . A7 A4 F7 P4 Ov14 3.6
Draught at the restaurant. It pours a murky golden beer with a beautiful, nicely remaining creamy white head. Slightly acidic flavor. Very drinkable. A pleasant Hefeweizen.

draught at the brewery restaurant, sample shared with Allen (Hallo!). Cloudy pale yellow colour with a large and persistent creamy white head. Fruity-yeasty nose. Wheaty malt flavours, not as fruity as many other beers of the style but the typical banana flavours were clearly detectable. A nice example of the style. Not exceptional but good solid quality.

(Bottled, 2.0l, nice one :). Hazy yellow with a smallish head. Banana-fruity, slightly perfumy aroma. Somewhat acidic, banana-fruity flavor with some sweetness. Light to medium-bodied, slightly acidic palate. An acidic, but easy and light weizen.
Taster in Ella, Sri Lanka. Pours a pale orange gold. Sweet malt, straw, grain, cheap booze notes. Sweet malt, mild lemon, grain, biscuity malt flavours. Thin bodied. Cheap boozy flavour balance.
Can from Samagi Wine Store, Galle, Sri Lanka. Pours clear golden with no head. Aromas of malt, candy, peach and grass. Flavours of malt, sugar, alcohol and grass. Not very good at all.

(Can) Pours clear pale gold with small white head. Aroma is neither appealing nor offensive - cereal / bread with citrus notes.Medium body with reasonable carbonation. Taste is pretty awful. An unpleasant artificial bitterness combined with an alcohol bite with little to balance or moderate it. There's a little grainy malt, and in the mid palate some syrupy sweet hints. Very unpleasant (lets see if red curry chips will mask it).

Intense grain and cereal malts, wet cardboard. Clear gold, small, creamy, white head. Light sweet. More grain and cereal malts, alcohol, weird other flavour which is heavily sweet and lightly bitter, lively carbonation, medium bodied, alcohol in the finish. Stay away from this stuff, not worth the calories, horrible aroma, awful taste. Sri Lankan brewed can from Food City, Kandy.
Pretty okay if you haven’t had decent beer in a while, especially considering the abv. Don’t expect too much though.

[ bottle ][ 1.5oz ][ @Tasting ][ $? ][ Schnapps snifter ][ 03.25.16 ] transparent gold, thin white ring with oily cap. Soured paper rot nose, as if on magellans ship, light soft pretzel grains. Front palate is hot, grainy, light. Finishes urinal cake and cotton candy, paper throughout.
12oz can I brought back from Sri Lanka, pours a clear, dark gold with a ring of white head. Nose has honey, honey comb, malt. Flavor is malty, honey. Finishes watery. Could be worse.
From a 12oz can at the DC tasting on March 25, 2016. Poured a yellow color with a small white head. Aroma was sweet corn. Sweet macro sweet bready notes. Macro garbage.

Can shared at the DC Tasting on 3/25/2016. Thanks nimbleprop! Clear golden yellow with off-white head. Aromas of malt, corn, wheat, hay. Tastes of malt, wheat, corn, caramel. Light body with a dry finish.
This is a lot more terrible than i would expect froman anchor. Golden pour with ok head. Weird aftertaste. Can of love shared at tasting.

column1: Wells John Bull Finest Bitter / Ale
column5: Bottle. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. No tasting notes kept, just rating.

column1: Wells John Bull Finest Bitter / Ale
column5: Bottle. Refreshing flavoursome bitter-orange fruity hoppy bitter (but not too bitter). OK. Drinkable. (2008)

column1: Wells John Bull Finest Bitter / Ale
column5: Bottle 50cl. @ Cerveceria Internacional, Seville, Spain. A: Golden. T: Malt, sweet, slightly bitter.

column1: Wells John Bull Finest Bitter / Ale
column5: Draft at Bull Pub Krakow. An ok bitter. Nothing more too it. Should be more bitter. :)

column1: Wells John Bull Finest Bitter / Ale
column5: 500 ml bottle. Amber body with a small tan head. Aroma of malt and caramel with some toast. Flavor is sweet malt, toast, caramel and moderate bitterness. Medium to thin body and moderate in aftertaste. Smooth malty bitter without so much bitterness.
Black with a short foamy head. Sweet with sugary hops in the scent. Disappointingly thin and watery. Coffee and chocolate in the aroma with some berry fruit and sugar.

2019 vintage. Pours a dark copper color; small head; pleasant aroma with fruity, woodsy overtones. Heavy cherry flavor. Mild on the palate and throat. This is an atypical ale with a flavor that will appeal to the aficionado. Best enjoyed with cheeses and good friends. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask @ Leeds Station Wetherspoon, Leeds. Extremely dark with a lightly smoked aroma and taste, and a very easy-supping texture.

Cask Half Pint – JDW Fest Autumn 2016 in Oct 2016 - Pitch Black in colour. Good creamy tan head. Malty; roasty malts, grainy, coffee, chocolate notes. Hoppy; grassy hops. Moderately bitter roast malty throughout. Drinkable. (2016-10-13)

Cask-conditioned, on gravity, at the Commercial Rooms, Bristol October 2016. Near black with a thin, off-white, head. Sweetish stout with some chocolate and liquorice, a touch of caramel and gentle finish. Ok.

On cask at the Standing Order. Appearance - opaque black with a lovely fawn head. Nose - chocolate, charcoal and a hint of molasses. Taste - charcoal and very dry liquorice. Some molasses comes through at the back. Palate - close to medium bodied with a dry crunchy middle section that continues through to the end. Overall - should be loaded as a dry stout I think. Decent though.
Herbet Wells, Woking. Not much of an aroma, spived fruit. Dark brown, OK beige head. Sweet and malty. Watery. Snore.

Cask at The Green Dragon, Leek (JDW) A deep brown colour with a medium beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, treacle, some caramel, slight liquorice, a little umami and subtle smoke. Taste of roasted malts, liquorice, treacle, some umami, slight plastic and subtle chocolate. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A dryish, slightly treacley, roasted bitterness in the finish. A weird one this. Roasty and chocolatey like a standard stout but treacley with a touch of umami to finish. Sweeter than most stouts too. Satisfactory.

Cask, belated festival ale, 1/2 pint, hand-pulled at Hengler’s Circus, Glasgow on 24 Oct 2016, roast malt, chocolate, liquorice aroma, near black with a thin bubbly beige head and no lacing, coffee, chocolate, some liquorice, oily, malty aftertaste.
Draught at JDW real ale festival. Pours almost black with a thin, beige head. Smoky malts with hints of chocolate. Thin body, but decent enough compared to the rest on offer.

Cask at CW Spoons. It pours darkest brown (near black) with a small, bubbly beige head. The aroma is earthy roast, umami, say sauce, Asian cooking vibe, liquorice and smoked ham. The taste is thin, very bitter, earthy roast, burnt malt, liquorice, plastic, peppery spice, charred wood, umami and astringent. Finish is crazy dry. Light body and low carbonation. Pretty crap.
Cask@st Matthews hall, Walsall. Black beer with large head and good lacing. Aroma of roast malts and chocolate. Taste is same with ash. Pretty basic.

A massive crackling three plus finger head jumps off the jet black body. Rocky foam fades leaving some lace. Toasted malts, buttery toffee and rich coco are all over the satisfying nose. Oh so smooth on first sip showing the oats really did their job. Mellow silky sweetness graces the mouth with hints of rich toffee and slightly smokey caramelized malts. An exceptionally satisfying and sessionable stout. A bit of powdery bitter does develop as you continue to drink. Mouthfeel is pleasant and well balanced. Amazingly well drinkable.

Draught at the brewpub as Old Nicholas Imperial Stout. Black with a beige head. The aroma was somewhat funky with some dried fruit and roast. Smooth, roasty flavor with lighter bitterness. Relatively light overall. Medium-full body with light carbonation. Pretty nice flavors but something was going on in that aroma.

On tap at brewpub September 26th, 2007. Was told by the bartender this was a new beer and that it was 9% alcohol if I remember correctly. Dark brown almost black with a brown head. Huge chocolate aroma. Flavor has some chocolate, some dark fruit sweetness, some rostiness, some vanilla, and some maple syrup. Very creamy body with alcohol warmth in the finish. This was some good stuff!

On tap @ El Toro Brewpub poured a nearly opaque black with a minimal brown head. Aromas of roastiness, licorice, coffee, vanilla and bitter chocolate. Palate was medium to full bodied and smooth. Flavors of roastiness, coffee, vanilla, licorice and bitter chocolate with a smooth lingering bitter finish.

GABF 2006. Black body with a small brown head. Nose is coffee, dark chocolate and roasted malts. Taste is more coffee and dark chocolate with roasty malts and intermittent burnt notes. Body is medium-full with a silky carbonation. Finishes with more dark chocolate and coffee. Pretty typical for the style but nicely done.

GABF 2006: Just about opaque black with a brown colored rim and brown head. Chocolate hits the nose first then big coffe notes that grow and grow. The flavor is dominated with coffee and fairly roasted malt. Bitterness on the finish is moderate with some chocolate notes mixed in.

column1: Hank is Wiser Dry Hopped Pale Ale
column5: Tap at the brewpub, a solid beer, but again missing the bright hops I want to see, really drinkable and definitely able to be sold for mass markets.

column1: Hank is Wiser Dry Hopped Pale Ale
column5: Tap at brewpub. Porus an average cheddar orange with an aroma of sweet bubble-gum hops. Notes of watermelon (really, watermelon) are dominant against a backdrop of sour citrus and faint pine. Average mouthfeel. More like a fruit beer than a pale.

column1: Hank is Wiser Dry Hopped Pale Ale
column5: MWBF 2006: really nice big citric cascadey aroma, of course from the dry hopping. However, the malts were rather light, giving this a sort of hop juice character. More heft! Cloudy appearance.
Pint at the Crusoe Hotel in Lower Largo, Fife. This was quite nice, hazy gold in colour, with a good white head, quite nicely balanced, went well with my fish and chips!
Bottle. Bronze with a small head.Clear and slightly dry. Bitterness dominates without overpowering.Says on the label that it is a session ale. Well thats what it is -and a good one at that.

(cask) clear deep amber colour with a creamy off-white head. aroma of raisins and pale malts, quite doughy, with a hint of powdered sugar and grass. flavour is mostly peat-smoked malts and tobacco, with a touch of marzipan, some sugar icing and a light-bitter nettle finish. medium-bodied with soft carbonation.
Cask at Abbotsford. Pours amber. Nose is biscuit malts, caramel, light fruits. Tastes smooth, bitterish, resin, fruits.
Bottle. Clear amber with a fluffy little head. Faint fruity and slightly medicinal aroma. Dry, spicy, smoked and very dry. This was a bit too phenolic for my liking, too harsh.

Cask at Marine Hotel. It pours clear amber with a small white head. The aroma is brown bread, cereal, grainy, leather and toffee. The taste is bitter, lemon peel, pithy citrus, brown bread, leather and a touch of astringency with a drying finish. Light - medium body and soft carbonation. Pretty basic bitter action.
Cask at the Tam O’Shanter, Dumfries. Pours clear amber with a thin white head. Aromas of light sulphur, faint acetic note Taste is tangy. Light sour finish
Cask pint at The Sanderling (JDW) at Glasgow airport. Dark brown colour with some head.
Cask at the White Lady. Pours amber, nose is biscuit, toffee, taste is dry, crisp, floral.
Sampled @ Finest Spirits and Beer Convention Bochum 2014: Orangegelbes Bier mit geringer weißer Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr hopfig, grasig, malzig. Geschmack holzig, malzig, grasig, hopfig.
Bottle.Chestnut and blood in colour with a small head,chocolate and hop aroma,taste is of biscuit chocolate grass and some peachy fruit,dry finish.The label of martin made me laugh good.

Cask at Maypole Inn, Yapton, March 07. Very dark ruby colour with a good-sized loose ivory head. Coffee aromas, with an initial coffee hit, followed by a roasty, dry finish. Mouthfeel a bit on the thin side.

Cask/gravity at St Albans Beer Festival 28 Sep 06. Dark brown/black coloured. No head A sweet tempting aroma. Fruity roasted flavour. Well rounded and balanced. A pleasant bitter aftertaste that evolves. A nice surprice.

Completely black with only a small layer of off-white foam. Pleasant aroma of dark, roasted coffee beans. Anise in flavour with moderate sweetness of dark chocolate. And yes, some milky hints can be spotted. A well-judged stout (Half pint on gravity at The Ipswich Beer Festival 22.09.2006 and another half at The St Albans Beer Festival 28.09.2006).

Cask-conditioned at the Seven Stars, Bristol 05/08/10. Deep gold in colour with a decent, off-white head. Lemon and green herb aroma. Slightly sweet malt flavour, with a hint of lime and massive bitter finish, which was a touch touch aggressive for me. Good.

Cask handpull, The Devonshire Cat, Sheffield. Pale bronze with a level white head draping the glass. Good aroma; flowery hop, honey on wholemeal, lemon meringue. Dankness, lemon and honey: a winning combo. Quietly impressive, with some pungent, off-beam, dank dishcloth hops.
cask at the bow ... nice golden amber ... sweet green fresh hop nose ... dry front ... juicy sweet creamy soft hop ... subtle but tasty ... reall like this

Half pint, cask. Shiny, golden brown body. Bright, naked surface. Fragile lacework on the top of the glass. Discreet smell of malts and fruits. Earthy malts and sweet fruits in flavour along with a bittersweet ending. Rather jam-like. Soft in the mouth. Medium bodied. Enjoyed in very relaxing Sunday atmosphere at the Duck and Drake in Leeds, 11.07.2010.

Cask, gravity at Merton Summer Beer Festival, 17-07-10 Pours gold with slim white head, nice clarity to this. Aroma is a bit zingy with citrus, a touch of freshly chopped garden herbs and a little pine. This is a clean tasting fresh crisp tasty bitter beer, the lemon and pine show a little in the mouth, and whilst this is really enjoyable its never likely to have that wow factor. A6 A4 T7 P4 Ov13 3.4

Cask conditioned at Merton Summer Beer Fest ’10. Gold with white head. These single hop showcases are great and thought provoking, Green Bullet tasted like a Czech,lagery hop to me, pine and lemon, a little resinous. I’m not sure we will see a lot of this hop over here, it doesn’t quite fit an Ale, but good stuff all the same.

A Mes rate. Gravity at Merton Beer Festival. Thanks to Fin for making sure I got to try this as it was on the way out. Very clean gold with a greenish tinge and a thin but lasting white head. Lovely New Zealand hoppage on the nose but let down a little by a hint of diacetyl. Thankfully it’s not apparent in the mouth. Maybe just a light unexpected sweetness but it’s not a bad thing. In fact it sits really well alongside the assertive bitter and grassy hops. Very good citric notes. Slight leather and peat from the malt, which does a good job of carrying the flavours. A new hop to me and one I found to be quite interesting.
Cask Handpump at the Penny Black JDW, Northwich 11/06/2010 Malt and hop aromas. Small white head. Golden coloured hoppy and bitter with a little dryness in a pale malt finish.
Cask (handpump) at The Palace, Leeds, October 2006.Amber colour. Well hoppy. Almost US in style but with a strong lingering bitterness on the palate. Very clean and crisp. Excellent.

Gravity, Turf Tavern Autumn Beer Festival. Pale gold with a cap of off-white. Blackberry and mint aroma, just a faint touch of sulfer clouds the otherwise very pretty hops. Big clean bitterness, rounded soft malt, a nice touch of bready warmth in the finish. Solid.

Pale golden coloured. Low level of foam. Inviting hoppy aroma. A rich flavour of hop fruitiness ending with moderate bitterness. Pale ale impression (Half pint on gravity dispenser at the Ipswich Beer Festival 21.09.2006).
draft at pub-murky brown pour-thick beige-brown head-aroma and taste of spice,dough, sweet brown sugar creamy finish

(draught at brewpub) murky brown with a cream head. Nose of Belgian yeast, toasty brown sugar, and ripe banana. Taste of pumpernickel an rye bread, ripe banana, and golden raisin. Medium light body with a creamy carbonation and fruity linger.

Draft sample at IBGF 06. Poured a dark copper color with an average off-white fizzy head that was moastly lasting with fair lacing. Solid complex yeasty aroma. Medium body. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Complex drinkable beer.

Bottle from Aldi Supermarket, Keighley. Amber-red with a very thin head. Fairly standard mildly sweetened bitter. In terms of texture it's also mildly sticky-sweet, tasting slightly dry within its balanced hops and malts.

Bottle whilst barbecuing the f*ck out of some mackerel. Coppery ruby with a fine beige foam going the distance. Dull but perfectly serviceable big regional nutmeg and egg custard yeast and Allsorts tones. Aroma the same with Everton mint. Sugared liquorice. Nil hops. Pleasant.
A nice dark red colour, head vanishes quickly. Malty backbone with plummy fruit flavours coming through, but not overpowering. Not an ordinary bitter and the better for it. I quite like it
50cl bottle from Aldi. Almost no head. Very low carbonation. Clear amber pour. Malty aftertaste. Not their best beer

50cl bottle from Aldi, Bracknell. A reddish amber pour with a billowing beige head; aromas of purple fruit; sweet caramel malt taste with some musty fruit; and a light earthy bitterness. Reminded me of a watered down version of Hobgoblin. Unexciting.

500ml bottle: BBE March 19. Drank at home on 24th June 18. Red hue to the brown body, beige head. A malty brew with a caramel leaning in the aroma and sweetness within the taste. My sweet tooth liked it, but the beer is a bit 'one dimensional' really.

Butelka 500ml. Ciemno-bursztynowy kolor. Piana doœæ obfita, bia³a,o drobnych pêcherzach,opada doœæ szybko. W aromacie ciastka,karmel,biszkopty,susz owocowy. W smaku doœæ s³odkawe ...suszone owoce,rodzynki,karmel, skórki chlebowe. Porz¹dne lecz bez zachwytu...
Bottle - reddish tinged brown with large white head. Clear, high carbonation. Decent fruity aroma. Ok mouthfeel. Gentle tasting, not much aftertaste. Easy drinking.

Bought a couple of cans of this over the weekend, unfortunately turns out they were spoiled and I left a less than favorable review, which I've removed (rating stays though, because it's the truth!). I guess this shit happens. Looking forward to maybe trying this properly one day.
Cask@Hilltop Railway, Aberystwyth. Amber beer with medium head and good lacing. Aroma of malts and caramel. Taste is caramel, earthy and malty. Not great.

10/18/08 On draught at the brewpub, Fairfield, Ca. Aroma is faintly sweet. Appearance is clear yellow with a very well maintained white head. Flavor is candy sweet forward with a light citrus bittering and an odd, but blended, cream note. Mouthfeel is fairly creamy with low carb texture and medium body. Overall, different but drinkable.

On tap at OBriens 2008 Wet Hop Festival weekend. Backlogged rating. Something went wrong here. I remember tasting something like spoiled peanut butter. Flavor is also of rotten wort. Hops are there, though, in the finish.
Tap @ O’Brien’s. Pours clear gold with great lacing. Nose was kind of funky, grainy, and fruity........not bad.
Pours clear yellow with a big white head. Stinky aroma of banana and sweat. Thin mouthfeel. More banana in the taste, but with pine oil. Another miss for Blue Frog.
Tap. A little bizarre in terms of the flavor and aroma. Aroma was malty and BOish. Gold color with a white head. Fruit and strange flavor. A bit watery. Not very good.

Tap @ O’brien’s during wet hop fest. Blue Frog really sucks from what I’ve had. Pours yellow with a bright white head. Nose is light and dead. Taset is light and crappy, not surprised that this ain’t good.
Draft at O’Brien’s. Actually pretty nice. Spicy aromas. Some banana on the flavor suprised me a bit. More spice on the flavor mixed in with the fresh hop flavors. Pretty hoppy on the finish. Good.
Phenolic and DMS laden nose. Biscuity and herbal palate with floral hop notes. Herbal and fruity finish.

Tasted on tap at the 2007 Bistro Wet Hop IPA Festival. This IPA pours a light gold color. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma begins with strong floral hops and then gives way to some yeast and esters, very fruity. A medium bodied IPA. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are floral and citrusy. Interesting beer. A hoppy Belgian blonde or a fruity IPA? Take your pick. Fruity with a bone dry finish. Nice balance, but a touch sweet. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and crisp and fairly dry. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

On Tap @ The Wet Hop Event at the Hayward Bistro. It pours a hazy deep gold with a copper hue running through the middle and thin bright white head. The aroma is mild with hints of sweet malts and vague hoppiness but also with pretty big Belgian yeast notes of banana and bubble gum. The hops show up first in the flavor but are quickly outshined by banana and mild bubble gum notes. Midway the Centennial hops break free of the Belgian influence and bath the flavor in subtle hoppiness. Interesting offering.

Cask at Holborn Whippet with Sarah. Pours a clear gold with a creamy white head that dissipates slowly to the edges and laces. Aroma has a note of musty hay with a good amount of grass and some wet grain. Flavor starts with grain and hay with a bit of grass coming out in the finish.

A Mes rate: Cask at Twickenham Beer Fest. A good fresh hopped English Ale. Tobacco, hops and just a touch of malt in the aroma. Standard looks. Brown body with a bubbly head. All fresh hops flavour wise. Slightly tart. White grapes in the finish with more fresh hops. All about the hops. Nice beer.
had this awhile ago, just noticed someone entered it. pretty good brew, bit of a creamy body, lightly hoped with a nice blend of milk stout, pretty good.

This was the latest cask release on tap at LBC on 10/21/06. It’s a preblended mix of Red Rose Ale & Milk Stout, making for a deliciously, malty brew. Appears a red toned, transparent dark brown with a light tan head that slowly fades out. Spotty lacing is left all around the glass. Smell is of caramel, nuts, light cocoa, sweet, roasted chestnuts, spices, along with a florally bouquet of hops mixed with brown sugar and fruit. Taste is a nice mix of the mentioned aromas touching upon the sweetness of the stout and the malty/hop balance of the Red Rose. Mouthfeel is smooth, sweet, malty mix of the caramel and hops running along the tongue in a slick but satisfying motion.

Cask (handpump) at the Palace, Leeds. Hmm. Handwritten pump clip. No ABV shown. According to the barman "Yes I am sure that’s what its called" and "No, I don’t know the ABV". I can’t find any reference to this beer anywhere, nor can I identify any other Anglo Dutch beer that fits the bill. And the brewery website is a fat lot of use as the "Latest Brewery News" is from November 2004. So I think I’ll have to take the pump clip at face value. The beer? Oh, its fairly standard autumnal stuff with crystal malt to the fore, providing caramel and toffee notes and a soft underlying bitterness. Mid copper colour. Nothing out of the ordinary.

column1: Cornerstone Present Use of Mary Bradley
column5: pours a dark brown with a light tan head. notes of nuts, toast, bread, irish moss, and honey. good.

column1: Cornerstone Present Use of Mary Bradley
column5: On Tap @ Cornerstone some time around 3/15/06, just found this one in my notes that was not entered: Medium coppery brown, clear, w/ a lasting medium sized off white head. Toasty malt aroma w/ a hint of roast and caramel. Slightly sulphury yeast w/ some green apple fruitiness; clean otherwise. Flavor is well balanced w/ clean toasty/bready flavors and a hint of roast and green apple same as the aroma. Just a touch of dark grain tartness. Fuller light body, smooth, low carbonation adds to smoothness. When I had it I thought that it could have used a bit more age to get rid of the green apple. I know it’s a short turn around style, but I still thought it could aged just a bit longer, otherwise a solid session beer!

column1: Cornerstone Present Use of Mary Bradley
column5: Great beer. The server said that the brewer wrote a book on this style of beer and it shows. It was nice and roasty, but wth no off-putting sharpness. i drank four pints and would love to buy it in bottles. I hope that they start packaging soon. Well worth the effort of finding the pub (not close to a highway)

The forebearer to the watered down version of Stella was an acceptable effort that was still as tasty as others from the same family. Had this at one of the bars inside the Millennium Dome o2 complex.
29.09.2007. On tap at the St. Giles hotel in London. Pale yellow colour with white head. Weak malty aroma with moderate bitterness.

Bottle 50cl. Clear medium yellow color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, wheat, citrus and coriander notes. Flavor is light to moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20081228]
Draft @ Crown & Kettle, Manchester M4. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head. Fruity malty aroma with some spicy hints. Fruity malty slightly spicy flavor. Has a fruity malty finish.

1. 440ml Can 09/09/2007 Carbonation. Clear golden coloured hoppy and slightly spicy with a crisp and dry malt finish. 2. Keg Handpump at the Slug & Lettuce, Manchester 19/01/2008 Floral hop aroma. Golden amber coloured and hoppy with a crisp and slightly dry lasting malt finish.
Can. Clear golden colour with a nice white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, wheat, spice and caramel.
Can. Clear golden colour, medium white head. Aroma is slightly malty, metallic and grassy. Flavour is grainy with sweet malts.
Can - Poured to a fizzy head which did not last. Didn’t really enjoy what flavour there was, the coriander notes just didn’t work for me.
Draught. Awful. Imagine a watered-down version of the ghastly Stella and you are pretty much there. Wheat beer my arse!

Tap @ The Dovetail, London. Pours a clear, dark golden with almost no head. Weak malty aroma, some light caramel. High carbonation, a bit thin. Flavour is practically non-existent. No malts and no hops to speak of... not bad, just more water than anything else.

[cask at the Grain Barge, Bristol] Pours the expected dark ruby in colour, thin white head. Very slightly spicy from the Bramling Cross, rounded aroma from the sweet malt. Sweet and caramelly on the palate, but with no cloying edges. Finish is sweet, quite long in duration, and pretty satisfying [17102009]
Cask (handpump) @ The Microbar, Manchester, England. @ [ RBESG 09 ]. Red brown with a big foamy head. Malty with spicy note. Some toffee caramel. Easy drinking and a nice change after all the blonds.

[cask @ RBESG 2009] Almost chocolatey malt aroma with toasted almonds and cream. Hazy red-brown with a dense, tan foam. Creamy nuts flavour with a touch of brown sugar and a weak bitterness and not hops. Weak flavour overall. Light body, low carbonation, very slightly bitter finish.

A Mes rate: cask at the Microbar. Darkish amber with a pretty impressive off white head. Assertive fruit and nut character but with some really good earthy malt in the background. Big caramel finish. Possibly a little under hopped but for something that I would not usually think too much of, I rather enjoyed this.
Cask (handpump) @ The Microbar, Manchester, England. @ [ RBESG 09 ]... red brown ... big off white foam head ... spicy malty nose ... soft and creamy ...toffee ... easy
Cask @ Microbar Manchester. Dark amber color. Nutty caramelly aroma. Malty sweet nutty flavor with apple.

RBESG Sheffield 2009, day 3, MicroBar, Manchester. Cask. Dark amber colour, creamy off white head. Aroma of toffee and grainy malts. Flavour is light sweet, nutty, light grainy. Bit less than medium bodied.

Cask at the Hop Pole, Aylesbury 29-06-09 Pours reddy brown good nick with a white head. Some fruit and nuts on nose. Solidly bitter, really fruity, served just a tad warm otherwise a good beer. A6 A4 F7 P3 Ov12

Cask, Derby Winter Fest 09. Red brown with an off-white head. Aromas are earthy and spicy with sweet Autumn fruit and caramel. Quite "Kentish" in its hops. Flavours are dry and earthy with light berries. Peppery and bitter on the finish. Decent>
Cask@Derby Winter Beer Festival, 2009. Dark amber beer with a strongish head. The aroma is toffee and caramel, and the flavour is plainly toffee and hopped. Overall a nice beer.

Draught@Pikkulintu (way back in 2006). Hazy deep ambery brown colour, small beige head. Aroma is fruity and floral hops along with some spicyness. Flavour is spices, hops and some sweet malts. Balanced and quite pleasant beer, that probably suits the X-mas table.

Brown, hazy, with red notes. Malty aroma with notes of barnyard, sweet fruit, citrus and spicy hops. Citrus flavour with notes of american hops, vanilla and cinnamon rolls. Round with some kick in the finish and some acidity.
Hazy dark amber, with a medium head. Hoppy, spicy aroma. Some hints of liquorice. Flavour is spicy as well. Decent bitterness. Really dry. Long finish.

On tap at Bishops Arms, Göteborg, Sweden, in december 2006. Nice appearance, aroma quite herbal and hoppy. Flavor a dissapointment. A little thin and with somewhat sticky hop notes. But interesting in some way. Have had better Dugges.

[Draught] Cloudy orange colour. Not the biggest head. Rich fruity aroma with tidbits and red apple. Bit spicy. Rounded, almost oily mouthfeel and very British. Berries and licorice was what I detected in this orgy of hard-to-track flavours. Pale spicy. Very flavourful with perfect balance in bitterness.
Draught at Akkurat. Good winter ale, hoppy, spicy and malty.. A bit thin palate maybe, best swedish xmas-beer sampled so far though...
On tap at Haket, Göteborg. Hazy amber color with a thick tan head. Lots af spices and orangepeel tones. medium body with a spicy, slightly bitter finish.

Draught at Bishop’s Arms, Malmö Cloudy dark amber color. Very nice aroma, malt, but most of all hops (earthy, English). Good body, where the caramel preveals, on some malt, roasted malt and hop. Final bitterness, equally from the roasted malt and the hop.
On tap at Glenfiddich Warehouse No 68 Stockholm 30 Nov 2006. Deep red/brown coloured. A creamy head. Sweet aroma and caramellish flavour. Cautious spicy aftertaste. Well balanced.

Draught @ Bishop’s Arms, Malmö. Pours a slightly hazy dark reddish colour with an off-white head. Hoppy spicy malty aroma. Sweet malty piny hoppy flavor. Dry hoppy finish with a long bitter aftertaste.
Cask Handpump at the Beer House, Manchester 21/06/2001 Lime green coloured with a clear appearance. Plenty of hops in the finish.
Cask/gravity at The St Albans Beer Festival 27 Sep 06. Golden coloured. Unclear. Hardly any head. Dry flavour with fruity hints. Dry sweet finish.

Hazy, (dark) golden in colour with a tiny little head. Rounded malty aroma. Dry fruity flavour supported by weak notes of caramel and some bitterness. Abrupt, dry ending (Half on gravity dispenser at The St Albans Beer Festival 27.09.2006).

Bottle, 300ml, bottle conditioned. A dark black colour with a large brown head. Strong aromas initially of fresh grassy hops and citrus then evolving into sweet plum and toffee with a touch of malt. The aroma is very fruity and lasts as long as the beer without diminishing one bit. The taste is initially treacle, then very malty with chocolate and toffee. Fairly sweet but not overly so. A quite sweet, strong bitter finish with alcohol evident. Moderate carbonation. This is a good warming ale with an outstanding aroma and flavour; if this was the only beer I could drink for the rest of my life, I would be happy.

Cask Conditioned at Charlie’s Pub, Copenhagen Cloudy amber color; thin head. Some aroma of malt, yeast, earthy, manure. Medium body, malty, some residual sweetness, good bitterness (both quantity and quality); an impression of ripe apples. Strong final, still with some malt. A good bitter, sweether than the average, good English character.

[Cask at Charlie’s Bar, Copenhagen] A hazy dark orange beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma is sweet and very malty. The flavor is sweet malty with strong notes of oranges, but also light metallic notes, light to a lightly bitter end. The body is a bit thin.

Cask (handpump) at the Minster Inn, York. A functional but uninspiring Midlands style best bitter - more malt than hop. Nutty overtones. Copper colour, tight sparkled head. A touch more body and flavour than the standard Banks’s Bitter. Bostin is actually a term used in the Midlands (whether it comes from Birmingham or the Black Country is open to debate) to show rapturous approval. I can’t go that far with this beer. Nothing wrong with it, and goes down quite well. Just a bit dull.

Cask handpull at Folkestone Wetherspoons. Mid brown colour with lasting bubbly beige head. Drinkable inoffensive malty bitter. Stronger choc malt than most bitters. It’s fine. Nice tangy hop on end. Better than I expected.

Cask conditioned @ Standing Order (JDW), Soton. Dark Copper. Clean malts and nutty crystal malt. Dusty bitterness starting at the back of the mouth and moving forwards to fill the mouth. Joined by almost cloying finish which wasnt to my taste and a bit odd as it was fairly dry. Some whiskeyish undertones.

Thanks to dickinsonbeer for the hand filled bottle... Appears a transparent, copper toned amber with a small white head that slowly fades into a mild cap. Scattered spots of lacing are left around the glass. Smell is very mild of earthy notes, light diacetyl, buttery cream, citrusy hops, and light caramel. Taste is of the mentioned aromas with a bitter, buttery, light caramel flavor sort of washing the palate. This is definitely not one that will overload the senses. Mouthfeel is bitter, citrusy, clean for the most part, with a little bit of a residual yeastiness that hangs on the swallow.

Had bottled sample courtesy of Dickinsonbeer (thanks!). Poured a darker and clear amber / orange color with a small sized off white head. Softer aromas and tastes of caramel, fruity, citrus and some toasted malts. Although nothnig really stood out in the aromas and flavors (did I mention the word softer), I found this easy to drink and refreshing.

Pours a clear deep copper/amber with low carbonation and a thin head. Color is very deep for a dortmunder and borders on jsut being an amber lager, although there are some fruity ester hints reminding me a bit of an ale throughout. Aroma is slightly fruity, toasted malts, very herbal and hoppy. Very hoppy bitter flavor with some nice rounded sweet malts and a bit of esters. Herbal hops all the way through. Carbonation is a bit low for a lager as well. Decent drinking beer, but doesnt really fit in any style- not like there’s anything wrong with that.

(Draught at Oliver Twist, Stockholm, 1 Dec 2018) Dark brown colour with frothy, beige head. Malty, fruity nose with roasted malt, dried fruit, prunes, raisins, dark bread and brown sugar. Malty taste with notes of dark bread, roasted malt, dried fruit, spices (anise, nutmeg, clove), chocolate and a mild spicy bitterness in a warming finish. Full body, with a certain sweetness. Really tasty and warming winter beer. Very nice.
Hoppy spice malt aroma. Murky brown colour fantastic head and lacing. Malt spice flavour. Smooth palate.

33 cl bottle at El Gato Verde, Alcalá de Henares. It pours dark chestnut-hued with reddish hues and a nice, thick, long-lasting, beige head. Aroma es rather intense and sweet: loads of cherry, chocolate, cinnamon and some metallic scents. Taste is sweet, powerful, with a nice umami and metallic mouthfeel that yields to a long-lingering, bitterless finish. To sip calmly and thoughtfully, as all Xmas ales should, IMHO, be.

Flaska. Dimmigt brun med ett stort beige skum. Dofter av karamell, torkad frukt, jäst och söt fruktkaka. Smakinslag av torkad frukt, karamell, örter, brunt socker, jäst och ljus choklad. Medel mot stor sötma. För sött för min del.
