Uporac sie z korkiem naprawde warto gdyz nadwyraz delikatny zapach miodu,popruszony lekko wanilia i innym pelnym tajemnic zielem rozprzestrzeni sie wokol i przeniesie Cie na kwiecista lake... a tam juz tylko radosc. Subtelny koniakowy kolor .Lagodny smak. Blogie odprezenie. Cos z dawnych, slodkich lat.... Warto sprobowac. Teresa.

Draught @ Peters Brauhaus, Mühlengasse 1, Köln, Nordrhein-Westfalen, Germany.
Clear medium red brown color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, dark sweet bread, brown sugar notes. Flavor is heavy sweet with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20081009][ Good BEER Guide Germany Köln #11 ]

Hazy dark reddish brown, moderate head with decent lacing and retention. Aroma is sugary with fruits, only minor cardboard notes. Hard to find a lot of out the aroma though. Medium to light body with a sweet finish. The only low alcohol beers I have to compare this to are made by BMC, and this blows them away. Actually enjoyable. Bottle picked up in San Diego.

Deep garnet, smallish off-white head. Fruity, rooty, sugary nose is not without a certain charm despite feeling a bit artificial. Quite good in fact, a bit soda-pop reminiscent, but fair flavours of various berries, blueberries, strawberries, raspberries.. Rather juicy profile with low carbonation. Obviously, it remains very sweet, but it drinks easily and I’d have been more than glad to drink this as a child.

(Draught 20 cl, at Peters Brauhuas) Clear dark red to brown color, brown creamy head. Extremely sweet scent, almost like it hasn’t been fermented at all. Very sweet taste, no bitterness at all. All in all it’s just very sugary. (The waiter at Peters Brauhaus told me the Malztrunk was indeed brewed by the same brewery that makes the Peters Kölsch, though he explained to me that it was a childrens beer and was very suprised when he realised I was actually ordering one to drink for myself...)

column1: Hoppin' Frog Hoppin' To Heaven IPA
column5: Very drunk notes from many years ago. Dry, citrusy with a good dose of caramel. Well balanced. I really liked it.

column1: Hoppin' Frog Hoppin' To Heaven IPA
column5: BBE ??? Jaffaisa, semikuulas kuparinen väri, niukka vaahto. Suutuntuma täyteläinen, tasapainoisa, suuta kuivaava. Alkoholi taustademonina, kuitenkin äärettömän hienosti piilossa. Sellainen IPA jota toivoisi aina juovansa. 5/5.

column1: Hoppin' Frog Hoppin' To Heaven IPA
column5: Bottle@birger. Amber color with lacing white head. Aroma has caramel, tropical fruits, citrus, malt. Taste is malty with long bitter and dry aftertaste. Flavors of caramel, malt, citrus, grass.

column1: Hoppin' Frog Hoppin' To Heaven IPA
column5: Bottle 66cl @ Birger. Pours clear orange, white head. Pine, caramel, tropical fruits. Carmel, bitter, tropical fruits in the flavor.

column1: Hoppin' Frog Hoppin' To Heaven IPA
column5: 30cl van de tap bij Zeezicht, Breda Alcoholpercentage van 6,8% Uitgetapt in Zeezicht glas Uiterlijk: goudoranje met redelijke schuimkraag Aroma en smaak: bloemig, hoppig, fruit als grapefruit, tropisch fruit, flinke bitter Conclusie: goede ipa goede smaak en neus

column1: Hoppin' Frog Hoppin' To Heaven IPA
column5: On tap at hopaholic. Clear yellow color small white head. Nose is sweet honey, some booze. Taste is strong acacia honey, light licorice. Low carbonation. Expected more but might be just old.

column1: Hoppin' Frog Hoppin' To Heaven IPA
column5: Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupe³niania profilu na ratebeer.

column1: Hoppin' Frog Hoppin' To Heaven IPA
column5: 567 Hoppin Frog Hoppin to Heaven IPA Ar - 7 Ap - 4 Fl - 7 P - 3 O - 15 Rate 3.6 Hazed golden to amber in color liquid. Thick tan head. Heavy malt aromas, with caramel and honey. Floral to herbal hops scents. Flavors follow closely with the aromas. Heavy malt with an orange citric backdrop of bitterness. Alcohol shows up and is lightly warming and slightly biting. A very traditional IPA in my book. 5/11

column1: Hoppin' Frog Hoppin' To Heaven IPA
column5: 66cl bottle from Alko. Pours in an IPA glass clear amber colour with extremely high frothy a bit off-white head. Nose is pretty much muted at first by the endless foaming (good retention too). Later it reveals to be very floral, citrusy and pine and honey induced. Taste is nicely aroma hop forward, smoothly turning into loong bitterin hop finish. Malt body is quite moderate, but noticeable. Sweetness balances the high carbonation.

column1: Hoppin' Frog Hoppin' To Heaven IPA
column5: Kirkas kuparinruskea olut runsaalla ja pitkäkestoisella tiiviillä vaahdolla. Tuoksu todella herkullisen hedelmäinen. Vahvasti mangoa, kevyemmin sitruunaa ja lisäksi karamellista maltaisuutta. Maku viljaisen maltainen, kuivemman hedelmäinen. Greippinen jälkimaku. Melko täyteläinen suutuntuma, hiilihappoja vähäisesti. Tasapainoinen ja laadukas IPA, joka pelaa enemmän tasapainoisella karamellisella makeahkolla mallasrungossa kuin runsaalla humaloinnilla.

11.04.2015, 0,65l bottle shared with friends: Small bubbly shortlasting head. Aroma is slightly harsh fruity, thinner, caramel malts, yeast, almond essence, candied sugar, dried fruits, grass. Taste is slightly harsh, dried fruits, yeast, harsh grass, candied sugar, almond essence, nuts, caramel malts. Medium bitterness, slightly sweet and harsh mouthfeel. Meh!

Color ámbar, translúcido y tirando a rojizo si le da la luz, con capa de espuma de un blanco algo sucio de dos dedos de grosor y muy poca retención (se disipa casi al instante). Carbonatación media visualmente, nada presente en boca. Textura oleosa. Aroma ligeramente floral, a caramelo, malta tostada, especias, fruta madura, toques de madera, un mínimo de alcohol. Entrada dulce, con mucho caramelo, azúcar moreno, canela, clavo, pasas, higos. Final dulce y ligeramente licoroso.

65cl Bottle @ LaBIRRAtorium, Madrid, Spain. Hazy copper colour with a thin white head. Aroma is malt, molasses, raisins, honey, yeast, fruits, syrup. Taste is malt, molasses, raisins, yeast, alcohol. Full body, soft carbonation.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupe³niania profilu na ratebeer.

A reddish brown, a head is small and blond. Aroma has fruitness, brittish orange marmelade some dry cake, fruit candies and wood. Sophisticated. Taste has richness of (dry-)cake, some orange in marmelade and fruit candies. Full bodied, low carbonation. Not a belgian style, but more like brittish. Sophisticated, strong and dried fruity. All styles of beers are just succesfully from Hoppin Frog.
Bottle from Beergium. Hazy reddish/copper with a white head. Sweet with yeast, "tutti-frutti", caramel and some fruit. Drinkable but really sweet.
@ Basunen 16-6-18: Rätt trevlig doft. Smaken är rätt het med tillbakadragna toner av jäst och kryddor med en aning gula frukter
Bottle in the hotel. Pours hazy orange, nose is spiced, caramel, esters, biscuit, taste is sweet, rich toffee, caramel, light fruit.

650 ml bottle at home. Pours a very dark chestnut brown with a tan colored head. Aroma of roasted malt, charred wood, burnt nuts, oats, dark coffee, dark chocolate, hints of dark fruits and faint herbal notes. Medium-full body with a light to medium sweetness and a light to medium roasty bitterness. The flavor is similar to the smell with more dark chocolate, some burnt notes, burnt wood, tobacco, some dark fruits. Becomes more roasted towards the finish - burnt wood, ash - and a notable earthy herbal hop presence. Finishes with a light roasty bitterness and light burnt notes. Classic roast forward RIS. Good. Aroma: 8 Appearance: 4 Taste: 8 Palate: 4 Overall: 16
Dark brown color. Very odd yeasty nose. Very smooth. Liquid dark chocolate. Light and smooth body with some roasted malt and peaches.
Pours a nice deep dark golden brown. Aromas of hay, hop flowers, carmel malts, candy sugar, honey. Flavor: oak, caramel malts, grapefruit, light hops, brown sugar, and alcohol
650ml bottle. Black color with beige head. Hoppy and roasted malty aroma, piney, fruity, chocolate coffee. Sweet and bitter taste like aroma. Medium oily body with soft carbonation
Black pour with slight tan head. Malty nose. Big hoop taste with some nice malt sweetness on the finish.

22 oz bottle purchase at One Stop Market about 2 months ago. Aroma shows roasted malts and an assertive amount of citrus hops I was not expecting. Bold. Flavor has a good amount of the Boris with the citrus/grapefruit bitterness coming through in the finish. The base is Boris for sure with the IPA lingering and giving balance. Not sure I would have blended these two beers together but the result is really nice. This brewery continues to put out a nice product.
Bottle at home. Pours black, nose is pine, chocolate,coffee, taste is similar, fruity, roasted.

Roasty and grapefruity hop are the aromas that immediately come to my nose. Followed by chocolate & just a touch of toasty caramel. Flavor is well balanced overall, maybe just a bit too well. Although, a little IPA bitterness sneaks into the finish. Chocolatey & roasty flavors present in moderation, as is a light grapefruity hop, but it’s up front and doesn’t really last into the finish.

Poured from a bomber. Pours a dark brown with a thin khaki colored head of foam. Aroma is fairly hoppy with fruity notes dominating a smooth malty oaty backbone. Taste is a lot like a black IPA in bitterness and roasty notes. Good malt body. Very nice.
650 ml. Opaque with a lasting creamy film. Aroma is caramel, cocoa, orange and resin. Taste is the same delicious mix. Medium body is chewy, balanced and has medium carbonation.
Bottle sample at He’Brew Brewery tasting at Beer&Beyond, Tel Aviv. Dark brown with no head. Sweet balanced aroma, carobs, light hoppy. Flavor of carobs, very sweet, light hoppy.

Cask, Everyman, Liverpool. A slightly underwhelming dark golden bitter with a dryish finish. I personally would always support this brewey though as they come from Silloth, a lovely part of the country, which has a wonderful golf course well worth seeking out !!

1. Cask Handpump at the Vernon Arms, Liverpool 28/08/2004 Golden coloured slightly rich on the palate and fruity. Some dryness and bitterness in a pleasant malt finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Leopard, Doncaster 19/09/2006 Fruity aroma. Amber coloured and slightly sweet on the palate. Some sour fruit flavour. Malt finish.
Had this on draught. Remember this one being strange and boring, big on the grass and pepper. One dimensional for sure.

It was just ok. I expected more. More taste, more hop, I realize and appreciate that is crafted in a true old school not much added recipe. I really think with a little more crystal malt, some candi sugar and raisins with a little more amber color it wouldve passed the test otherwise it was alright

On tap @ Bend, brewpub. I wasn’t going to rate this because it was so bad, but decided to warn people. Way over spiced, band-aid and a foul yeast character made this pretty much undrinkable. How could a place like this serve something this bad? Yuk!
On draft at the brew pub in Bend. Pours golden with a light white head. Aroma is yeasty, spicy and a bit of brett. Flavor is spicy, a little sour and grassy. An alright beer.

Draught at the Bend brewpub. A big surprise coming from these guys. I don’t even know If I’ve had a Belgian style beer from them before, and this was quite good. Poured a lightly hazy gold with a lasting, creamy white head. Big tropical fruit notes in the aroma with pineapple, guava, passion, and some lavender and chamomile as well. Lots of fruit juice flavors and some light pale malt, accented by some soft herb flavors. The finish is tangy and dry. Light bodied and clean on the palate with higher carbonation. Really nice bright fruity notes, and very well attenuated.

5 ounce sample on tap at the Pub in Portland, OR. Scant spiciness in the nose with some doughiness and faint esters. The aroma is rather tame. Slightly hazy golden body with a creamy white head. Fruity estery start with some metallic hints in the middle. Tame banana-yeast esters later on. Light and watery, lacking body and complexity. Not really any horseblanket or any other significant saison flavors.
Draught. Poured gold with thin white head. Moderate lacing. Spicy aroma with a little hop. Full earthy flavour, some herb, some spice and some sweetness. Lasting finish.
On tap at Stone Sourfest 09. Pours a yellow body. Fruity nose, brett.Flavor is dust, spicy herbs, thyme and a nice funk.

Draught at Deschutes Brewery and Public House in Portland. Fruity Belgian yeast aroma, cereals, honey, and something not right. Strange medicinal flavor. This misses the mark by a lot. Don’t know what they’re getting at.
On tap at the stone sour ale fest 09. Gold pour, white head. earthy malt, light sweetness and acidic vinegar, funky brett, and flowers. Pretty sour for a saison.

Aroma of sweet syrup, malt and wheat. Dark oak colour. Good off white head wit a medium carb. Nice smooth fruity initial flavour. Charcoal wood feel with a crisp sweet note. Lovely beer to drink. Great caramel after notes. If I was to be picky would have liked it a bit stronger in flavour, not so watery. Nice beer.

GABF 2006: Slightly hazy dark amber color with a beige head. Nicely balanced aroma of vanilla, bourbon and dark fruits. The flavor was bigger than the aroma with the bourbon. Fruity notes of sweet cherries and raisins. Bitter finish. Nicely done beer.

Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pilsener glass. The appearance was a stiffly looking bronzed burnt brown color with a ruddy transparency about it. Thin white foamy head that quickly dissipated. No lacing. The smell started off with some burnt caramel/toffee malts. Lights nuttiness. Some roast but turns into some toasty/breadiness. The taste was moderately sweet with that crisp bready/toastiness to it. Lingering sweet bready aftertaste, moderately sweet toasty sort of finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium in body. Good sessionability about it. Carbonation runs fairly light. Overall, its a decent bock, mainly nothing over the top.

Amber to brown color. Not much dark malt aroma or flavor, though. Very malty like a typical heller bock, but with more hops than usual. A long lasting hop finish. Nice, though not too original. Hops added something.

Dark copper with a good head and decent lacing. Aroma of sweet caramel malts and not much else. Flavor was thin and light. Tasted some hops and roasted grains, but there was no aftertaste or lasting flavor.
Bottle. Pours a copper body with an off white head. Sweet caramel malts, dusty hop character with some earth y notes. Light fruit notes and some tin. eh.
Pours copper with a thin white head. Smells sweet and biscuity. Tastes of sweet malt with some tea and spicy hints.

Very nice. The aroma is definitely malt dominant, with some sweetness, and some bready nose. It’s a dark amber color, with a thin head. It’s flavor is a bit safe, but the sweet malts and honey do make themselves present. The beer is a minor bit hoppy at the end, but adequate, not overwhelming. A nice session bock.

Bottle; quite a deal at 99 cents and it also gets me my second example of the style. Poured an orange caramel in color; nice looking. Aroma was pretty sweet, malty and bready. A little watery as others alluded to, but not too bad. Flavor wasn’t great; bread and honey with some peppery hoppiness. For me it wasn’t as good as the commercial description, but not as bad as some of the ratings here.
Medium-bronze color slight malt sugariness in aroma that translates similarly flavor. An easy-drinking, well-balanced bock that is a good intro. to the style.
had this a while back, i remembered it sucked just like 95% of there winter selection. ill rerate if i get a chance to try this swill again.
Nothing special here, nice looking but tasted quite watery. Not dry enough for me and quite sweet. Bought in the winter seasonal varity pack.

Poured in standard pint glass. A- deep, dark orangeish brown with tan head. S - toasted malts, hops T- Pronounced hoppiness (citrusy and piney) reflects Americanized ale. Both malt and hop flavors are quite evident, with hints of coffee and a slight burnt taste. Has a bitter and hoppy finish. M - thin for a beer this style; Moderate carbonation. D - more complexity would increase the appeal.

Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a mug. The appearance was a delicately bronzed to transparent brown color with a decent little white head. Moderate lacing. The smell started off with some roasty malts, light toast, some nuttiness. Then gets kind of dirty to earthy. The taste was mainly the same. Dirty/grassy/earthy aftertaste and finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body but has a really great sessionability about it. Boy, one could really slam these if they wanted to. Overall, it’s like a session brown ale, if there really was one. Hmmmm...almost makes me wonder if it needed more body, lol, oh well, not sure.

Bottle from notes (2011 picked up at Kroger). Pours a clear brown color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have light roasted malts, toasted bread, mild nutty character, earthy and lightly bitter hops. Boring, very average.
Mix pack offering is a pretty standard thin bodied Brown ale. Nothing stands out, good or bad. A touch of earthy hops And nuts over light roast and cocoa."

The brown ale forms a thick light tan head that sits on top of a clear dark amber brew. The head makes nice lacing as it sides down the sides of the glass. The aroma is full of sweet malts. On the tongue, caramel and maple sweet malts give way to bitter dark chocolate and coffee notes. The palate is medium bodied and smooth with average carbonation. Saranacs Brown Ale is well balanced and very drinkable.
Not a particularly great brown. Mild and a bit too sweet. Nice appearance, medium bodied.
June 2011 from bottle. Amber color, white head. Sweet malty aromas with caramel, spice and nuts. Slightly bitter finish, but nothing unusual or memorable about this brew.

6/14/2011: Saranac Brown Ale... Aroma: Typical for the style. Appearance: Mahogany brown color with an average head of darkish beige foam. Flavor: Mostly toasted malts with dark roasted malt bitterness and a reserved sweetness; littler bitterness or hops shine through, but that’s expected for the style; pleasing nuttiness throughout. Palate: Medium-bodied; smooth; average texture. Overall: Soft, but decent Brown Ale, but not necessarily the best offering from Saranac. 12 fl. oz. bottle from Kroger in Harrison, Ohio. Rating #243 for this beer.

The beer is mahogany colored with an inch of tan head that leaves plenty of lacing on the pint glass. The aroma is pretty weak, with some toasted bread, malt, caramel, and nuts. The flavor is OK, with a light roast presence. The hop character is amped up a bit more than expected. The body is thin, with ample carbonation. Overall, this is a drinkable brew, but nothing special or exciting happening here. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 07-13-2011

pours a semi-clear reddish-brown with a medium size yellowish head, and some lacing. smell is faint, floral, brown sugar, spice, and malt. taste is of spice, malt, caramel, and hops in the back. ends spicey and bitter.

On Tap at the Five Islands Brewery. Let this one warm up for a good hour prior to tasting. Arrived hazy straw with an averaged sized frothy, white head which lasted well. Aroma was of creamy caramel with strong notes of Werthers Originals (butterscotch), good nutty notes and some tangerines. Flavor was similar to aroma with a mild hop bitterness, dry biscuity malts, creamy caramel, butterscotch, mandarin and some metallic/resin notes in the finish. Light bodied with soft carbonation, a dry/creamy mouthfeel and a decent finish.

on tap, strong toffeeish notes from heavy use of a light crystal malt i would assume. dark straw colour very cloudy appearance. sweet but not cloying. an unusual hop taste i could not really place. not a bad drop, but an aquired taste.

on tap at the brewpub. served in a frosty glass to maintain that ideal 0.5degree temp. orange copper colour with a meek head. i dunno, i find all 5 islands beers to be too rough and too clean at the same time. the aroma was a bit composty and toffeed and there was some over-ripe banana and golden syrup flavour, then a clinical dry finish

On tap at Hopfest #13 at Alehouse Project. Pours black with healthy but dissipating head. Burnt toast, toffee and caramel nose. Simialr flavours with some chocolate in there. Very welcome shift in flavours after a night on the hops.
Aroma: tobacco and chocolate App: Black with a red heart, tan head and sudsy lacing Flavour: choc and carbon with some balancing hop bitterness Palate: finishes with some carbon and grain
Lovely aroma of wine and port. A little sour and vinegary though. Too wine let Le for my taste but pleasant and interesting

From bottle in tulip. Pours dark brown with tan head and choc malt aroma that was a bit muted compared to the 2 porters I had before this. Taste is initially cola-esque but becomes more porter-like as it warms.
Good body and lingering coffee and smooth caramel notes and just enough hop.
Aromas of vanilla and chocolate, pours black with a small but lasting light brown head, medium bodied ale with a nice smooth bitter aftertaste, it’s a shame I only had the one to try.

Bottle from Bright Brewery (October 2013). Almost-black, solid lasting tan head, lots of chocolate, roast grain, coffee, dried fruits, light-medium body, medium bitterness, long dry finish. Quite good.

Black with a good sized beige head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted grains, hint of dark fruit and stale fruit. Relatively thin bodied, roasty on the palate with some sweet and fruity notes, a slightly tannic finish. Flavour is chocolate, raisins, black tea, roasted grain.

On tap at the brewery- Served a deep mahogany color with a nice tan head that fades to some lacing. Aroma of richroasted malt and chocolate with some coffee in the background. Smells fresh. taste of roasted malt, some bittersweet chocolate and a bit of coffee in the background. Mild bitterness and a dry finish. Medium body, smooth and creamy with a nice robust flavor. Nice beer to relax with at the end of the day.

Deep dark brown coloured body with a very thin, one half centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of prunes, raisins, grapes, figs, and other pitted fruits - potent sweetness and fruity notes. Medium-bodied; Assertive malty flavour with a ton of raisin and prune notes, a touch of grapes and light chocolate and finishes with a dry, musty malt flavour. Aftertaste is relatively mild, but the chocolate, malt and far and away the strongest taste is still the fig and prune flavours. Overall, not such a great beer - but nice to try on the opposite side of the world, especially after a year and nine months time. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Slowbeer in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia on 31-December-2009 for AU$6.00 sampled on the opposite side of the planet at home in Washington on 02-October-2011.
Cask @ Alexandra Arms, Rugby. Clear yellow-blonde with a creamy head. Light and clean textured, it has a lightish bitterness in its aftertaste.
Cask @ Stafford Beer & Cider Festival. Small head with short duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, citrus, fruits and hops. Light citric fruity finish.

Cask @ Stafford Beer & Cider Festival. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, light citric and light lemon. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and light bitter finish with a light acidic edge. 280717
Cask at The Victoria Inn Rugby. Poured clear amber with white head. Nose is pine citrus fruit. Taste is light floral malt citrus mild hop fresh finish. Enjoyed this

Cask conditioned handpump Victoria Rugby 28/09/13. A blonde beer with a white head and lace. A nice light hoppy beer. Biscuity notes and a bit of sweet toffee join the hops in the aroma. Very palateable. Good stuff.

Cask at the Victoria Inn, Rugby - 19/09/12. Slightly hazy light amber in colour with a good white head. Excellent lacing ensues. Light tropical fruits on the nose, mango, peach and floral hops. Light citrus tones in the taste, grassy, orange, peach with a slightly tarte edge. Medium bodied, minimal carbonation with a smooth and creamy texture. Have had this many times since they began brewing down at the Alex and it’s quality never dips - a truly decent session beer!
Cask handpull Castle Fournival Street. Gold clear rubber flavour. Not great earthy. Rubber throughout is unattractive

Cask-conditioned at the Seven Stars, Bristol 18/05/10. Golden coloured with a slight white head. Decent, grapefruit and lemon hop aroma with a touch of sweet malt. Very easy drinking, with plenty of citrus hops balanced by the sweetish malts, and a dry, lingering finish. An excellent thirst quencher on a warm afternoon.

Cask gravity @ Reading Beer Festival 2008. Clear medium to dark yellow orange golden color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, light hoppy, grape, citrus - lemon. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. (010508)

Cask, The Victoria, Rugby. Still,clear,golden and lacy. Citrussy grapefruit hop attack on the nose with a hint of wet dog. Fibrous tropical fruit notes coming through (Amarillo). Muscular hop punishment to the point of astringency. Earthy, resinous IBUs belonging to a much stronger American IPA/pale ale...the description sounds great, and I love those flavours, but they’re somehow jarring and one-dimensional here. Nuthusk/peanut oil abrasive bitter afters. Malt drowned out by hops. Not quite there. (Cask, The Crown, Nuneaton). Massive musty green lime and grapefruit hop aroma. Waft of hutch. Aggressive hop dryness and husky dry roasted malt earthiness. Intense. (Back at The Victoria) Rabbit urine, celery and vanilla ice cream added to the blender. One of the freshest, most pungent hop aromas it’s ever been my pleasure to sniff- smells exactly like a freshly rubbed handful of those narcotic little cones. Church End used to brew beers like this. Outstanding sessions.
Cask@St Albans BF 06. Slightly eggy/sulfuric aroma. Balanced between hop and malt. Grainy hops, citric hops, earthy mouthfeel/flavour.

Cask (gravity dispense) at St Albans Beer Festival, September 2006. Golden colour. The name suggests some US influence but I can’t say I picked up too much US hop presence. What you get is a dry, crisp and clean session bitter with slight touches of fruit. Not jam packed with flavour but fine as a quaffer.
Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 22/09/2006 Sweet aroma. Golden coloured slightly fruity and sweet tasting. Some dryness in a crisp malt finish.

Soft creamy head tops a clear gold liquid. Soft caramel aroma with nothing else to mention. Flavour is tinny malt with a hint of donkey hair. Sharp weird funk aftertaste that does nothing for anyone. I need to finish this one quick as some guy thinks I'm ogling his fat girlfriend while she plays the lotto machine at this sleazy Isle of Man pub - like dude seriously, that land whale ain't worth fighting for. And for that matter, neither is this beer.

Cask at the Southampton Arms on Christmas Eve 2010. Copper with a thin whitish head of foam. Sweetish aroma, malty and a little pungent. Grassy, herby hops in-mouth, rounded by biscuit malt and some berry fruits. Bitter sweet aftertaste, with an accumulating bitterness. Light mouthfeel. Not had Manx beer before. Nice little treat for Christmas.
Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 22/09/2006 Strong aroma. Golden coloured with some spicy coriander flavour. A little bitterness in a crisp and slightly creamy malt finish.
Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 22/09/2006 Fruit wine aroma. Amber coloured with some alcohol present. Fruit flavours. A little dryness in a crisp lasting malt finish.
Cask/gravity at Ipswich beer festival 24 Sep 2006. Golden coloured. A small head. Hoppy and fruity aroma. A rich flavour of chocolate and fruit. Pleasant sweet bitter finish.
Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 22/09/2006 Some sour fruit aroma. Amber coloured and slightly rich on the palate with a little sour fruit flavour. Lasting dry malt finish.
Cask at JDW, Bedford. Amber with a tight white head. Oddly yeasty aroma. Sour, fruity taste. Low bitterness.
Cask @ Manchester & County, Manchester. Golden with a thin head and a crisp smoothness. There’s some very small fruit notes.
Clear nut brown colour. Again this brewery gives a beer with an aroma and taste of peas. Quite earthy and sweet. Also smooth. Not very bitter.
1/2 pint from cask @ The Brewery Tap. Pours clear brown with a low tan head. Aroma is malts and rye. Flavor is malts, rye and some hops. Nice!

Bottle conditioned (500ml brown bottle) session bitter, drank and reviewed Sunday 9th Jan 2011. Poured into an ’Abbot Ale’ glass tankard slowly, so as not to allow any sediment. I failed and a little got into my tankard, which means the body of the beer was contaminated with small ’yeast floaters’ and the light brown body didn’t look to great. My appearance score is low however because there was no head and the beer looked flat. A pleasant hop/mild malty aroma, nothing strong or in your face, just a hint of what is to follow in the taste. The beer may have looked flat but it certainly wasn’t, the body was in fine condition and was a lovely brew, well balanced and flavoursome, a good mix of the hops and malts coming together to produce a fine Bitter. At 3.6% ABV you are never going to get a rich heavy beer, having said that, this beer is a great example of a British session bitter and the depth of flavours often hidden within.
Bought from Wetherspoons in Stockport. I think the beer is off, tastes funny. Either that or its a bad beer.
Enjoyable pint that went down well, not had a bad pint from this brewery yet

Cask @ Winter BF Manchester. Had the Marble JP Best the night before and intended to start with it again the next morning, only to find it was gone. I wandered in search of a light hoppy brew of equal proportion but instead ended up with this, what a mistake. Golden with a only a white ring of head inside the glass. Smelled like an ashtray and the taste wasn’t much better. Bitter, malty and buttery with a hint of apple. Not a good start to the day.
A Mes rate: Gravicask at Manc Winter Fest. Golden brown, no head. Very rough unbrewed malt with much to obvious tea notes. Cleary not right and even if it was I doubt it would be great.
Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 22/09/2006 Slightly rich aroma. Amber coloured and wheaty with some bitterness and dryness in a crisp malt finish.
Cask at Town Street Tavern, Horsforth. Pours light amber, thin off-white head. Aromas are nuts and biscuits. Taste is more of the same, light bitter finish. Not bad.
Cask the auctioneer Blackpool jdw. Copper colour ok white head lacing. Aroma is toffee fruity malts. Taste is similar. Medium body.
Fine looking but less than fine tasting ale. Has a malty bitter base but little to shout about. Golden with a thick creamy head.
On cask at Wellington; Birmingham- half a pint- Golden color, good foam. Good fruitiness, some red fruits, malty aromas. Medium body & complexity. Good bitterness, well balanced. Enjoyable

Cask Conditioned Gravity Dispense Old Monk Exchange London. A copper coloured beer with a thin off-white head. Fruity and fairly hoppy with good citrus fruits. A touch of sweet malts hinting at caramel. A decent chewy body. Nice.
Cask Handpump at the Crown Inn, Stockport 06/06/2009 Fruit and hop aromas. Small white head. Clear golden coloured hoppy floral and fruity blackcurrant flavour with a crisp and bitter malt finish.

A Mes rate: Cask at The Gatehouse JDW in Highgate. What a fitting drink for our Halloween night little drinking session. Yeasty nose. Slightly cloudy golden amber with some nice thick lacing. Dry dusty hops in the mouth with a tangy bitter finish.
Cask at The Pilgrim’s Progress (JDW), Bedford. Served chilled so virtually no aroma. Some fruit in the taste, otherwise utterly anonymous save for a very late bitter trace.
Cask Handpump at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 23/09/2006 Hop aroma. Clear golden coloured hoppy and slightly sweet on the palate. Some dryness in a crisp malt finish.
can @ supermarket. unpretending mass product with cheap price and softly beer-like taste notes. waterish piss. STAY AWAY FROM IT, IF YOU WANT GOOD FOR YOU!!
Bottle. Boooooooooring cheap pale lager from Pécs. Pale yellow, weak head, zero aroma and taste of bitter water.
0.5 l can from supermarket in Hungary. Yellow color, thin white head. Sour aroma. Taste, watery, hints of malt. Bad beer
500ml Can (Thanks Doggythedog) - Golden in colour. Grainy aroma with grass and hay. The taste has notes of corn and malt. Rather boring.

500ml can - shared by SaintMatty, I think from doggythedog originally - thanks! Painfully pale and fizzy. Weak dishwatery aroma. Exceptionally watery palate, fizzy. Nasty hard water taste. papery hops. Bad, and outragiously watery.

Lindenhof was added to the site on 26.10.2006. I get to be the first one to rate it. Great. Thanks to ogivlado for the tip on where to find it (he saw it in the window of the CBA Prima that’s on the corner of either Városház and Plivak or Városház and Pariszi streets but the store was closed that day), I REALLY hope I manage to get another can on my way back for him! Poured a pale yellow body with a medium-big thick white head that went away fast. Fizzy. The nose was actually more complex than I expected. Dust, vegetabley hopiness, malt. Ok for a Pécsi supermarket lager. The taste, however... oh the taste. Mineral water. That’s it. Prickly carbonation and not much else. Yaaaaaaaaay!
01-05-19 // tap at Braumanufaktur Forsthaus Templin Clearish golden. White head. Smooth grainy. Spicy grains. Mild hops, fresh. Good. #Radtourbier

Decent maibock. Has a touch of tin, with some decent malt complex. A little butter but not too much. Finishes with some cloying aftertaste. Hazy golden with OK head. Bottle drank on the train back from Potsdam.
Dark orange body with a thick persistent white head. Aroma is spicy and flroeal. Taste is pretty the same, with a slightly grassy note. Medium body, soft carbonation. A nice example of Maibock
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, würzig, grasig, leicht alkoholisch. Geschmack sehr malzig, würzig, leicht süß alkoholisch.

Flasche 50cl. Hellbraun, hefetrüb. Wunderbares Malzaroma verbindet sich mit einer dezenten Hopfennote zu einem wirklich schmackigen Bock. Sehr gut gemacht und mit biologisch erzeugten Rohstoffen. Chapeau!

Bottle at yespr. Clear golden coloured with a small white head. Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel and bread with notes of hay. Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel and bread with notes of hops. Hoppy finish.
Bottled. A yellow beer with a beige head. The aroma has notes of straw and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of straw, malt, and alcohol, leading to a dry finish.
50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is dry toasted malty and cornish. Sweet, toasted malty and grassy to straw. Bitter and dry malty finish.

0.5 l bottle at Timo A’s. Copper color. Sweet honeyish and fruity aroma, surprising tropical fruity notes. Sweet honeyish Taste with apricot, water melon and low bitterness. Full body. Very fruity lager, I found it off putting.

500ml bottle. Clear orangey golden colour with average to huge, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, white head. Caramel malty aroma with grainy overtones, somne bitter hop. Taste is minimally sweet malty, dry, minimally grassy hoppy overtones, fruity hints of red apple and pear; dry finish with hints of fruit parings. Harmonically balanced, integrated, precise.

Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 23/09/2006 Fruit aroma. Clear golden coloured with a slightly hazy appearance. Apple fruit flavours. A little rich on the palate. Hint of bitterness in the wheaty malt finish.
can @ supermarket. unpretending mass product with cheap price and softly beer-like taste notes. waterish piss. STAY AWAY FROM IT, IF YOU WANT GOOD FOR YOU!!
Can. True hungarian-style cheap beer number 735. This time from the folks of Borsodi Brewery. Redundant, minimal one.
500ml can. It is not very cheap but bad beer. Watery, yeastly, citric and thin, very bubbling CO2. Dob’t try it!

0,5 l can with a new design, bought in a random store, Budapest. A cheap one again...Poured clear yellow with a small lacing head. Minimal malt and sourish yeast in the empty and boring aroma. Average and dull flavor with some malt, minerals, cardboard, yeast and grassy-metallic hop. Meaningless, redundant, massproducted piss.

No 790 Rated: 25.07.2009 Can 500 ml, rated in Bogacs, Hungary. Appearance: Pours pale golden, moderately to weak carbonated body with some sediments floating in the body texture, head is initially small, quickly diminishing but leaving some lacing traces, head is foamy, weak, non-stable, greyish white in colour. Aroma: Stronger but only a bit when compared with Greif from Ptcsi Sorfozde, in fact denoting more or less the same aspects, cooked corn, dullness, very weak due to being slightly watered down, poor in terms of wort extract, no hops, no yeast, no alcohol but only corn dominating over completely covered notes of barley malt. Flavour: Fornt is very watery, sour because of corn adjuncts, some artificial oriented hints of hops, alcohol is felt, metalic and mineral, salty and perceptably highly carbonated, cooked corn, some gentle tantalizing aromatic hoppy accents but too thin and too weak, totally no bitterness and no barley malt background felt, finish duration is short. Palate: Body is light, texture is watery, carbonation on palate is weak, finish feel is flat, slightly sour from corn, mineral.
Thanks to larsniclas. Canned. Pale golden, white head. Weakflavor, maybe some hops showing in the finish.

Rating No.1400 Canned(500ml). –Pale yellow coloured, medium sized airy head, very fizzy. Lively carbonation. Watery without any significant aroma except cardboard. Taste is similar to camomile tea exposed to the sun for at least 10 days. What a remarkable milestone.

0.5l can shared courtesy of and shared with ozujsko (thanks !) Poured a yellow-golden colour with a medium sized white head that went away fast. Fizzy. Surprise surprise. Nose... ooh, rubber... my, my. Why doesn’t that surprise me. A touch sourish too. If it smelled that good, you must be thinking that the taste was spectacular. Damn right it was. Watery, hints of rubber again, corn, cardboard. Just what I want in my lager. The Hungarian supermarket...beers? never cease to amaze me, and this one was certainly (hopefully) a unique experience. Not wanting to be outgunned by the Bosnian steel flavoured n/a’s, the Hungarians developed a lager that smells (and tastes) like rubber. Magnificent. It hit a new low with style. Borderless beer taste ? Let’s hope not.
50cl can. Pours clear golden colour with a huge most good lasting white head. Aroma of grain, pale malt, cereals, mild cheap hops. Taste of mild hops, pale malt, cereals, watery body, not good!
Golden colour with small head.Weak malt aroma. Malt syrup flavour.Light body with light carbo. To avoid.
Vollkommen sinnloses und dünnes etwas, das höchstens etwas Malz und Reis durchklingen lässt. Der Rest ist Wasser mit einem bittersüßen Ende. Bah.

Can from Lidl in Austria. The beer pours out in a clear golden colour with low head and medium body. Aroma of mild hops and straw. Taste of mild hops, grains, bread and straw. Metallic finish. Not a good beer.

Can 500ml. [ As FinkBräu Schankbier ]. Clear light yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, fruity, pale malt, vegetables, light grass. Flavour is moderate sweet with a average duration, malty, fruity. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20131229]
Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 23/09/2006 Hop aroma. Golden coloured with some alcohol present. Crisp and malty hop finish.
Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 23/09/2006 Some fruit aroma. Golden coloured and hoppy with a little dryness in a crisp malt finish.

This bottled Sake from a restaurant was served at a cold temperature and poured no head in an a uncarbonated body cloudy white colored body with no lacing. The mild aroma was of polished rice. The thick mouth feel was vinous with a mellow vinous alcohol aftertaste. The sharp flavor contained notes of vinous alcohol over polished rice. A decent one that I would consider drinking again.

Bottle… After being agitated to rouse the sediment, this sake pours murky and white with white grit left on the glass everywhere the sake touches. The aroma features sweet coconut, rice pudding and vanilla. Full-bodied and gritty with no carbonation. The flavor is sweet, milky and coconuty. Tasty. Interesting. Fun.
I’m not sure it tastes like soy sauce, as some would suggest, and I don’t taste any fruit in it either. To me it’s just a great Nigori.

On cask at the brew pub. Appearance: very dark brown, almost black, thick latte coloured head. Aroma: Mild, a little chocolate and malt, somewhat roasty with some grass notes. Flavour: Mild mouthfeel with a hint of chocolate & malt, toasty, simple, quick milk chocolate finish. Pleasant.
A dark brown to black in colour with mild coffee aroma. A slight chocolate taste and bitterness to finish. --- BeerItsNice
Come sempre la porter si dimostra la birra migliore per i birrifici irlandesi...pttimo tostato, con finale cioccolatoso...
scura schiuma media discreta persitenza inizio tostato discreta luppolatura corpo medio discreta luppolatura media secchezza

2012 version on tap at Messrs (4.8% ABV). Pours deep, dark, murky ruby with thin off-white head - great lacing. Aroma is fairly subtle roasted, smokey malt, chocolate, and slight coffee. Taste is much the same with pronounced chocolate, smoked, and coffee flavours all combining well. A little bit watery - not quite as full a mouthfeel as I would like, but still a very decent and satisfying porter.

Deep brown coloured body with a thinnish tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and some nuts. Medium-bodied; Creamy and roasty flavour with a nice bitterness at end. Aftertaste clean and sharp, but relatively nice. Overall, a nice break from Guinness, but the reminders of THE irish beer are still everywhere in this one! Definitely nice to try in Ireland. I sampled this pint on draught at the MessRS Maguire Brewpub in Central Dublin on 19-February-2009.

Bottled at Stockholm Beer Festival 2007. A black beer with a brown shine under a thin brown head. The aroma is sweet malty with strong notes of roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of roasted malt and hints of smoke from black malt, leading to a dry roasted finish.

Draft at Bull and Cork, Dublin. The pour was dark brown in color, ok initial head and below par lacing. The aroma was milk chocolate and light roast. The flavor was milk chocolate first and foremost, light roast second, and a variety of lesser harder to detect hints of licorice and maybe some dark fruits. The mouthfeel was low on carbonation, somewhat sticky. Overall a sweeter take on the porter style, also not complex, but enjoyable (not sessionable: too sweet).

Black, though with very little head. The aroma is quite mild. Dry, decent roasted flavours, coffee more so than chocolate, pronounced bitterness, but not to the point of being harsh. Medium bodied. One of the better Irish brews IMO.

Draught@SBWF 2007 Dark ruby, almost opaque color, nice expresso head, some lace. Some roasted and papery notes in the nose. Coffeish, coffee beans all over. Clean, a bit lagerish product. Nicely drinkable.

Tap. Pours clear pink, medium fizzy pink head, some lacing. Aroma is raspberry liquor. Flavor is super sweet, tiny bit of sour on the back of the tongue. Medium body. Not a bad dessert beer. My wife would love it.

Draught. Poured pinkish red with thin head. Aroma is raspberries set off with wheat malt. Flavour is tart raspberries. Doesn’t taste as strong as it is. Lasting fruity finish, with some tartness to keep it from being sicky sweet. Recommended.
GABF ’09. Pours a deep sangria red with a nose of raspberry filling baked atop a sweet pie crust. Flavor is like a frozen raspberry popsicle. Thick and lasting on the tongue. Yummy.

GABF 2009: Nice pale red color with off-white halo. Nice sweet, vivily raspberry nose but no sourness detected. Good raspberry flavors...this is a very nice fruit beer but i dont taste any of the claimed brettanomyces or much sourness or funk at all. But for a fruit beer, its quite nice.
From a draft pour this was a hazy pink to orange with a small white head and light lacing. Nose of raspberry. Medium Mouthfeel. Favor is raspberry and vanilla. Fruit and dry finish.

(Draught) Pours a hazy pinkish-red body with a small light pink head. Aroma of raspberries, earthy, greens, and yeast. Flavor of fresh raspberries, earthiness, light funkiness and some oak with a dry finish.
draft. Nice berry aroma. Red amber color. Hint of tart. Pretty nice, but not outstanding.

Draught at GABF 2008. Hazy orange coloured with a medium sized off white head. Aroma of raspberries with notes of vanilla. Fruity flavour of raspberres with notes of vanilla. Tart berryish finish. Light watery.

GABF 2008 poured a hazy red with a small lingering pink head. Aromas of tart raspberries with some yeast notes. Palate was light bodied and crisp with atart finish. Flavors of tart raspberries, light yeast and a hint of wood with a crisp lingering tart fginish.

GABF 2008. An intensely fresh raspberry nose, so fresh it reminded me of the fresh fruit cuvees we made at the Muddy Pig’s Belgian beer festival. The body was very tart and had a vegetal bite that again reminded me of incredibly fresh raspberries.

Bottle (assume fresh) consumed at Fugakyu, Boston on 9/30/06. Clear, but somewhat viscous appearance supports light legs that are not terribly large or sticky. Graceful, yet strong aroma is full of light, pear-like fruits, hints of tangerine and mango skin and very delicate phenols that contribute a spiciness on the end. Smooth and refined, it shows none of the alcohol. Strong pear and rice notes combine and strengthen as it warms. Hints of unripened plumskin and perhaps some vanilla are notable as well. Much stronger in flavor, though no less elegant, it boasts a warm, round, nuttiness, that also has hints of fruity sweetness and a white grapeskin tartness on the end, that combines light alcohol warmth with spicy phenols to balance the beginning. Thicker texture than expected, as well, with a palate-coating viscousness (which I’m overexaggerating, it’s not as if it’s truly thick or syrupy in the least) that really drives home the rice richness up front and allows complexity to emerge as the palate dries through the middle and end. Very interesting and drinkable, quite hearty for a sake. Rice sharpness and some acidity do build up over time, with increasing nuttiness and alcohol warmth.

Bottle. Amber pour. Aroma of sticky caramelised malt, raisin, bitter pine, baked orange and grapefruit. Taste has sticky raisin, caramelised malt, bitter piney hop, orange, port-like ripened malt and a little yeast. Nice old school bitter barley wine, some age did it well I think.
Vintage - Apple and toffee. Cloudy copper with a small beige head. Bitter, acidic apple and toffee.

355ml bottle @ Matt's. Date stamp of 08/31/2017. Pours a murky copper brown with a small beige head. Nose is bready and gentle caramel. Flavour is caramel malty, bready, caramel, and hints of dark fruits. Light to medium bodied, light carbonation, and a mild sweetness with a mild bitterness. Seemingly drinks with some age and not bad.

Vintage 2012. 12 oz. bottle, pours a murky dark reddish brown with a small beige head. Aroma brings out caramel, bready toffee, and subdued resinous hops. Flavour is very malty and somewhat boozy, with bready toffee, caramel, some dark fruits, and subdued hops. Very malty and fruity, very old school. Pretty solid, but unremarkable, old barley wine.

Amber, with a little bit of haze. There's actually a fair bit of jammy fruit, and some piney hops. Tastes a bit old, maybe a bit flat. Touch of jammy notes, a bit harsh but maybe the bitterness has mellowed. Not great, old school, aged okay but just okay.

Off white head left a spotty cover on a reddish brown still body. Stewed fruit, caramel, malt & raisin aroma. Medium to full bodied, oily in the osgate with a tingly back. Malt, demerara, raisin, berry, orange & caramel tastes.

Bomber 2006 vintage poured a hazy reddish amber with a lingering ring of amber foam. Aromas of toffee, sherry, dried fruit and spice. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of toffee, sherry, dried fruit and spice with a crisp dry lingering dried fruit sherry finish.

A fair Olde ale...a bit too bitter on the end for my taste. I hope to find a dated bottle now though as mine was not. I’m curious to try a bottle I can confirm some age on because I would definitely up my rating if the bitter truly does disappear with some aging. Though not the best, still by far not the worse Olde ale I’ve consumed.
Bottle. Pours a hazy brow/red color. Aroma and taste are caramel and toffee.

The sampler, Brooklyn tap: pours clear brown with whitish head that leaves lacing. Aroma is malt, sugar, tobacco, and booze. Taste is somewhat sweet but not cloying. Some bitterness in there. Not too much aftertaste. Not bad.

Tap at brewery. Opaque dark red. Really nice foamy head and Belgian lace. Sweet, cereal grain nose. Nice sweet malt without being cloying tempered by a surprising dry hop presence. Well camouflaged ABV

Poured from the bottle of a four pack this is the 2010 vintage so we’re talking 5 year old beer. Dark brown with a lot of chunky foam. Taste is sweet malt and really boozy, maybe there were some hops used but I can’t taste them because it’s so sweet. Very strong like a barley wine. It says that this is 9% but I think the 5 years in the bottle has made it stronger. You probably won’t come across this in your travels but if you do be careful, it’s English and it’s rough. Not for the faint of heart.
Really malty and bitter flavored. Some caramel notes in this one. Bitter finish with some boozy notes. Pours brown in color with a thin tan head. Had at Arcadia ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught. Cloudy brown with small spongy beige head, no distinct aroma, caramel and roasted malt taste, thin body, medium carbonation, longish finish with alcohol aftertaste. Interesting but not spectacular

bottle @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Aroma of sweet caramel and malt. Dense, but clear, dark mahogany brown, Long-lasting 2" tan head, swirls of lace. Taste is toffee, malt, and alcohol, all competing to be tasted. Then, the addition of hops on the swallow. Big, strong brew, but I can’t see how it fits the profile of Olde Ale. Good, not great.
Bottle. Brown pour with an off-white head. Aromas of toffee and dark fruits. Flavor is similar. Pretty good but not spectacular.

500 ml sampled in 2008. Black body with a medium sized, dense, brown head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and some fruit. Flavor has sweet malt, mild chokolae, coffee and light bitterness. Thin body and a bit short in aftertaste. A bit disappointing actually.

50 cl bottle @ vPBF. BBE 08/2008. Originally rated on 29.8.2009. Pours deep dark red, almost black color with head. Aroma of liquorice, malts, some dry chocolate and mild tar. Flavor of dark berries, dark chocolate, ash, cocoa and mild toasted malts. Dry and bitter malty palate. Seems to maintain the form through time nicely. 4424

500ml bottle @ vPBF Pours dark brown, almost black. Aroma of roasty malts, some berries, hints of vanilla. Smooth and roasty taste with notes of vanilla, chocolate and hints of coffee and berries. Finish is smoothy and slightly roasty. Decent, quite easy to drink.

50 cl bottle @ vPBF, BBE 08/2008 Aroma is somewhat sweet with cocoa and milk chocolate. Somewhat watery palate. Flavour is somewhat bitter in a harsh way. It has some milk chocolate and cocoa. What a surprise! This does not feel aged or contaminated at all and actually this tastes quite the same it did in 2009.

500 ml bottle @ vPBF 2012. BBE 08/2008. Pours a black colour with a beigeish head. Aroma of roasted malts, dark berries and nuts. Flavour of roasted malts, dark chocolate, cream, nuts and some grass. Medium bodied, slick mouthfeel and a smooth, roasty and light bitter finish. BBE was 4 years ago and this is still in a good shape.

April 2007: Brown 500ml bottle, purple label, can’t find a best before date on the bottle. Poured into a Frankenheim Alt glass twice. If there is a darker beer out there, I haven’t seen it, dense and black, with a small bubbled rich light brown foaming head. Very strong burnt malt aroma, dark chocolate and treacle smells add to the malt, which gives the beer an over cooked chocolate cake aroma. This beer is what it claims it is, a smooth and creamy Chocolate Stout. This is what lets the beer down a little, it is watery for such a heavy looking and smelling stout. I enjoyed this beer, a pity about the mouthfeel, but drank with some Belgian chocolates made with beer (as bought at the Zythos fest), which I did with the second bottle, it stood up very well.

[Daleside Brewery, Harrogate] Pours dark brown with a yellowish head. Nose has some faint chocolate and a bitterness. On the taste - chocolate malt hints only, not as chocolatey as others I’ve had in the past. Quite light in alcohol so taste is pretty thin, some coffee in the aftertaste, which finishes quite smooth. I don’t think the three malts are that well balanced – and it’s just not that chocolatey [04092008]
Dark black in colour with thin creamy toffee coloured head. Chemical/hop aroma. Bitter chocolate flavour with shortsour finish
50cl bottle, local store. very dark color, beige head. chocolate aroma, quite sweet and smooth.

bottle 500 ml from S-market summer season saleEXP 30 09 09 murky black beige head lacing tickling carbonation dark roasted malts bitterness and sourness in aftertaste. Dash of dark chocolate or over aged bottle with wild yeast? Mouthfeel turns more Belgium than UK. Dry end I might give this second change

Tap at brewpub. Pours golden and slightly hazy. Aroma is strong lillikoi. Taste is more lillikoi with little support elsewhere. Maybe some yeastiness in the finish. Easy drinking for sure, but I don’t think this is quite as good as Kona’s wheat.
Slighty hazed yellow pour with white head and lace. Aroma of medium malt and a tad of fruit. Lightly sweet malt and fruity with a light medium bitter. Medium bodied with good carbonation.

A well executed fruit beer. Sun orange color with a flat looking body. This brew is indeed characterized by a lovely orange and passionfruit boquet that is both playful and enticing. Unusual for many fruit beers, this one is full-bodied and replete with passionfruit flavor. Quite natural tasting and with peach fuzz and citrus twang on the finish.

Draught at the brewpub. Attractive hazy caramel-orange with white head that left some lace on the glass. Smelled distinctly of passion fruit with some light flowery hops. Flavor was similar. Dry and slightly bitter on the tongue which is balanced nicely by a lingering fruitness.
Aroma is apples and grainy/sweetish malts. The flavor is apples, fruit, mild effervescent body, malts and a tart finish.
12 oz bottle...pours an amber color small off white head...slightly sour aroma, yet clean.....the palate is thin/watery apple flavor....by the aroma I expected more

Nice idea if it didn't quite work. Appearance has a tiny bit of head, no lace, copper Amber clear color. aroma is marshmallows malt and cider. Flavor is an unpleasant blend of malty beer & cider. Somehow of the body doesn't work because of that unpleasant blend. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Light body. Reminds me of Redds. Sweet caramel apple aroma. Pretty good tasting. Kind of tastes like Spotted Cow with apples. Slight banana flavors as well. Not up there with New Glarus Apple Ale, but would drink again.

Hazy copper color with small head. Sweet woodsy apple aroma. Taste - pleasantly surprised as I wasn’t expecting much. I was expecting a cider which I’m not too fond of and instead I got a cream ale with some sweet and tart apple flavors. Not as acidic as a cider and you get the grainy beer backbone. This is unique and a fine summer session ale. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle 5/3/14 (Woodmans- Waukesha)-Pours a clear goldfish amber with a small white covering. Aroma of caramel apple. Taste of tart, apple, bitterness, and sweetness. This light bodied brew is a bit different but still tasty.
Cloudy amber. Nose is caramel covered tart apple and sherry. Flavor is bitter, tart apple with wet malt. Bitter apple skin finish. Just not good.
12oz bottle-shared by jtc-disappearing offwhite-hazy gold. A-banana/apple, grain. T-apple cider, grain.
mmmmmm uhhhh yuck. just like that. what the heck. second sip, better. but what is this? And from furthermore too? I expected something else.
Kinda strange yet I kinda liked it. Like half cider and half beer. Apple was predominant and beer flavors take back seat

GABF 2009: Pours an amber color with a full sheet of off-white suds. Sourish wheaet ale nose but not much if any smoke deteceted. Sweet, corn-like flavors with just a hint of smoke...i think. Tastes lagery for an ale...just overly sweet and corny. How does this ever win a GABF gold medal?

GABF 2008. Clear pale amber. Barely a hint of smoke essence in the aroma. Palate is thin and watery, flavours of caramel and cidery apple fruit. I couldn’t tease any smoke out of this beer. Disappointing.

Clear copper colored body. Weird nose of butter syrup and burnt corn with some light notes of toasted bread crust and toasted barley.... nose is truly weak, the set up is quiet poor, but then it actually tastes pretty good and holds up well on the tongue. Medium to full body, well attenuated, has the right thickness of a true German smoked lager, but the flavor doesn’t seem to go anywhere. Very plain, mild and transparent all around... weak notes of burnt toast and charred grains. Disappointing.

G.A.B.F. 2008: Deep copper dense light tan head. The aroma is toasted and sweet with some dough, brown sugar, mild smoke (peat). Interesting flavor. Brown suagr, toast, mildly sweet hickory notes and mildly smoky wood. Not a lot of smoke, but the flavor is unique with a very hickory like presence.

GABF 2007. Pours to a clean filtered looking shiny fossilized amber body with a thin white head. The aroma is strongly mesquite smoked wood and pale malts. The flavor is kind of like a mesquite smoked toffee or nougat. Very unique. The palate is slick, lightly salty, and medium bodied.

I raced over to have this once it was announced as a winner at GABF 2006. I figured a gold medal winning smoked beer must be exceptional, right? Clear brown. Nose is malty and sweet but only faint smoke. Taste brings a subtle smokiness and some burnt wood along with caramel and light cocoa. Body is medium with mild carbonation. Finishes with more caramel, cocoa and only faint smokiness. This wasn’t a terrible beer, but a gold medal winner?

GABF 2006: Ok so this won the gold so I grab a sample. Mostly clear amber color. Malty aroma and flavor with some caramel notes and there was smoke but to me it was overbalanced. I thought there wasn’t enough smoke. The taste was fine but when I drink a smoke beer I want that to really shine. Jus tlike when I have a fruit beer.

column4: Knappstein Enterprise Winery & Brewery (Lion Co Kirin Holdings)
column5: One of the best Australian beers. Perfect balance of bitterness and sweetness. Sadly, The new winery owners have decided to stop its production.

column4: Knappstein Enterprise Winery & Brewery (Lion Co Kirin Holdings)
column5: My all time first choice of beer. Complex flavours. Hard to find these days....hope its still being made.

column4: Knappstein Enterprise Winery & Brewery (Lion Co Kirin Holdings)
column5: Bottled. Pours a pale biscuity copper gold with a white head. Aroma: biscuity malt, grass, mild caramel, sweet malt, mild lemon notes. Taste: biscuity malt, straw, mild sweet malt, mild caramel, very mild lemon flavours. Thin bodied. Moderate to high carbonation. Easy drinking. Ok but not good.

column4: Knappstein Enterprise Winery & Brewery (Lion Co Kirin Holdings)
column5: From bottle in shaker. Pours pale yellow with 1-finger head and lively CO2. Fruity aroma is mixed with a bit of breadiness. Quite tasty and the Nelson Sauvin hops take this lager a cut above the rest. One of the best lagers in Oz imo.

column4: Knappstein Enterprise Winery & Brewery (Lion Co Kirin Holdings)
column5: Fruity nose but initial crisp malt on the tongue witha hoppy/bitter finish and aftertaste. Quite complex.

column4: Knappstein Enterprise Winery & Brewery (Lion Co Kirin Holdings)
column5: Pours pale straw with a nice floral aroma. The taste is something really different from what I’ve experienced with other beers. The savion hops bring a white wine taste along with floral and fruity notes, quite nice! The only real let down for me was it is over carbonated for my liking. Quite fizzy... Overall, I would happily have it again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

column4: Knappstein Enterprise Winery & Brewery (Lion Co Kirin Holdings)
column5: Pours a crystal clear pale straw gold with a good head of white foam. The aroma shows nice sauvin white grape, biscuity lager malt, a hint of general fruitiness. The taste is very clean, grainy, fruity hop. It’s light on the feel, but flavour alludes to a higher than average ABV. It’s crisp and refreshing, not too dry, nicely carbonated. Great lager.

column4: Knappstein Enterprise Winery & Brewery (Lion Co Kirin Holdings)
column5: Bottle. Pale. Weird large bubble thin head that does not last. Hazy straw color. Nice fruity floral aroma. Floral taste. Notes of lemon and passionfruit. Slightly tart. Decent. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Knappstein Enterprise Winery & Brewery (Lion Co Kirin Holdings)
column5: Pours yellow, golden color with a minimal head. True: Smells like a fruity white wine. also picking up some floral notes. Sweet, bready taste with a smooth finish. Carbonation is a bit low. Surely not a ordinary lager, but not quite my style. Does’t mean it’s not good.

column4: Knappstein Enterprise Winery & Brewery (Lion Co Kirin Holdings)
column5: Smells like a Savignon Blanc wine! A lovely, flavoursome lager - probably the best Australian lager I’ve had. Slightly sweet, little bitterness, pale yellow, little head. Would benefit from a little more acid. A great showcase for the Nelson sauvin hops.

Soft orange gold body and strong carbonation but no foam. Soft sweet apple with a hint of twig. Flavour is good dry apple, not sweet at all. Very crisp. Could use a bit more punch but still very well done.

4 oz sample from bottle. Light hiss when openening, pours clear rich gold pour with thin white froth. Aroma is nice and wild, tart, funky, leathery cider notes, noble rot, apples. Taste is tart, funky, nice apple flavor, dry mineral finish. Palate is light bodied and bone dry. Good!

pours clear bright gold with some tiny bubbles surfacing - liquid tends to stick. obvious fragrant leathery bretts if not pungent, apple and caramel - a quality caramel that is; dried honey solids, fermented tea - kombucha-like; calvados - wood, earthy stone fruits, flowers. slightly fizzy carbonation, light to medium acidity - some disturbing acetic as well; light body; firmly tart and bretty-spicy finish. ultra bretty, dry but with an awkward acidity profile. interesting specimen of course.

Sample (4 oz) from bottle (750 ml) at home. Thanks to SlovakSniper for this one! Clear bright golden a small instantly vanishing white head. Aroma is a bit farmy with leathery notes, tart apples and green apples notes. Taste is also quite farmy with nice tart apples presence leathery - not bretty though - notes and earthy/mineal notes. Light body. Still. A bit tannic. Bone dry finish. Very interesting product. Nice farmy and leathery character. Easy drinking and quenching.

375ml bottle @ home. Pours a clear light copper colour with no head. Nose is lightly of alcohol, apple brandy with a hint of acidity. Flavour is mildly acidic but quite sweet apples with a tannic and tart boozy character. Medium bodied, mildly syrupy, no carbonation, very sweet with a mild acidity. It's OK but needs some refinement, complexity, and balance.

Bottle @ The Greenwald Residence. Amber in color with a pretty decent viscosity. Kind of a weird cider. Slight smoke. Very acidic and tannic, but also has sort of a jolly rancher/candy sweetness to it. Certainly some bitterness to the finish, which is very odd. Almost vegetal/celery finish and certainly some booze. Not sure I’m a fan.

Sample. Pours hazy light brown/dark copper with no head. Aroma is of acid, vinegar, apples, fruits. Taste is of tartness, apples, acid, perfume, flowers. Palate: Full bodied. No carbonation. Mouth-puckering. Alcohol warmth. Overall: Somewhat odd, but good.

Sample. Hazy deep copper red pour, dull color. Aroma is really off, light smoke, leather, cherry, rotten apple, what’s going on here, medicinal notes. Taste is sweet but also very acrid, bitter leafy notes, woody as all hell, as if they put the whole tree through the cider press. Palate is full bodied, lingering boozy finish. Definite drain pour, worst ice cider I’ve ever had.

column1: Sea Cider Rumrunner (2006 - Newfoundland Screech Rum)
column5: Clear golden. Aroma is marshmallow, piment, melasses, apple (peel). Taste is slight sweet apple at first with a balanced sourness and spice. Later more apple peel and harsh alcoholic. Quite dry with a complex spice finish. Heavy but not oily. Drinkable. Warming. Unique.

column1: Sea Cider Rumrunner (2006 - Newfoundland Screech Rum)
column5: Bottle, many thanks jonas! No fizz. Clear deep golden color with white head. Aroma is rum, apple skin, bratapfel-like. Taste is barrel, brown sugar, rum, almost sauternes-like, apple skin, red apples, christmas. Oily mouthfeel with just a touch of fizz. Awesome flavour profile, christmasy!

column1: Sea Cider Rumrunner (2006 - Newfoundland Screech Rum)
column5: Vanilla caramel rum aroma over a golden whisky colored pour. Taste is hot buttered rum in apple cider, wow. Still has some remaining sugar - something added at the end, or malt? Highly recommendable.

column1: Sea Cider Rumrunner (2006 - Newfoundland Screech Rum)
column5: Copper pour with no head or lace. Aroma is apples and honey. Flavor is sweet apple and honey. Medium bodied with good carbonation. BL

column1: Sea Cider Rumrunner (2006 - Newfoundland Screech Rum)
column5: Amber pour. Medium bodied with low carbonation. Combines some tart and sweet apple flavours with smoky rum and molasses notes. Lots of complexity for a cider.

column1: Sea Cider Rumrunner (2006 - Newfoundland Screech Rum)
column5: This stuff is both delicious and dangerous. Sweet but not overpowering. Great apple flavour. Easily my favourite cider.

column1: Sea Cider Rumrunner (2006 - Newfoundland Screech Rum)
column5: Pours a dark brandy colour. Big apple aromas and flavours. Nice kick from the booze as well. Deep and complex. Excellent!

column1: Sea Cider Rumrunner (2006 - Newfoundland Screech Rum)
column5: Thanks Bvery Amber pour with no discernable head. apple, woody, brown sugar aroma nice apple flavour, woody spiced rum as well. Very drinkable and the alc is not noticable at all.

column1: Sea Cider Rumrunner (2006 - Newfoundland Screech Rum)
column5: Date: February 19, 2012 Mode: Bottle Source: BVery Description: Translucent light brown pour with pretty much no head. Aroma was sweet, apple and some alcohol / rum. Taste was basically the same.

column1: Sea Cider Rumrunner (2006 - Newfoundland Screech Rum)
column5: Bottle. Clear orange-amber pour with minimal head. Aroma is booze and appple. Medium slick palate. Taste is apple, cinnamon, spice, booze, and simply amazing. Fantasic cider!

Cask conditioned - handpump - Malt Shovel Northampton. A copper coloured beer which looked pretty lifeless in the glass. Aroma has fruity hops, probably US with an orangey undertone. Taste is dry and thin, shows signs of fruitiness but this does not progress. Drinkable but a little dull.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Milton Keynes BF A copper coloured beer. The aroma is malty with hints of toffee and caramel. The taste is dry and fairly well balanced with hints of chocolate malts
Cask, gravity, at Milton Keynes BF ’08. Copper. Gentle sweetness in the aroma, with some apple. Taste is earthy malt with background biscuit. Mid bitterness. Quite liked this one.
A Sim rate (cask at the Junction): Hoppy, sweet and malty aroma with apple and wooden notes. Bitter woodiness again in the flavour. Slight hops, but mostly malty with a bitter finish.

[cask] Nice floral hops plus citrus and some caramel malt. Chocolate and vanilla notes. Clear, dark honey with very lacey white bubbles. Excellent mild blend of caramel malt and citrusy from both hops and fermentation. Slight nutty notes. Very slight green apple also, ending with a barely perceptible dark malt, coffee/chocolate/vanilla. Light to medium body, moderate carbonation, "empty" bitterness.
Cask @ The Eagle, Hoxton. Amber with an off white head. Malt, yeast and orange in the nose. Taste is much the same with some tobacco and a hoppy finish. Somewhat decent.

Cask at 3 Greyhounds. Deep amber beer, aroma is quite malt-accented for the UK, with lots of caramel, earthy chocolate on the back and a light sulfurous note. Hope are quite subtle in here, but there is a kiss of earth and spice. Quite sweet with lots of toasted rye-like malts, a bit of molasses and light dustiness. Nutty and sweet but it remains drinkable.
The Buccaneer, Eastbourne. A fruity bitter with a mouthfeel above its strength. A gentle, balancing bitterness. Nice, wholesome and tasty.

Gravity Cask @ Highfield Inn, Beer Festival. Odd and not entirely pleasant nose, slightly fruity with some rotting wood. Unfortunate aromas fade leaving a mild hop finish which goes with the mild flavour profile. At best a little boring, otherwise verging on the offensive.

Cask handpull at Phoenix, Canterbury. Hazy copper/orange with lasting bubbly off white head. Mild inoffensive bitter. Bit of spice on end. Some orange/satsuma fruit. Quite full and juicy in mouth.Not sure where the surprise is.

Good copper colour, thin creamy head. In the nose, there’s a slight citrus hop with a hint of malt, but not much. Quite thin and lacking in taste: orangey hops but not much else, and I really didn’t get the chocolate. Slightly bitter. No surprise here, it’s just bland and boring.
2003 Bottle. Poured a mahogany color with an averaged sized head. Earthy, caramel, dark fruits, and yeast. Drinkable but past its prime.

Friday 1st Feb 2019; 7th Pre-Brugge Bier Festival International Beer Swap, De Bierboom. This is one of the many bottles that landed on my table for me to try, it is OK to take a decent sized sample (within reason) because there are so many beers to share. Deep Ruby body, beige head. Malty nose with some dark fruit esters also. The taste is also malty and slightly fruity with a fairy sweet flavour, nice slick body feel too. A very pleasant beer all round.

Draft at FOB, Rimini, Italy. Pours a nice reddish intense colour, with limited white foam. Aroma is weak malty and vinous. Body is just slightly sticky with moderate carbonation. Taste is moderately sour, with some bitterness and limited sweetness. Finish is slightly long and sour.
A brown, Belgian Strong Ale with light head. Aroma is malt, caramel, light liqourice, spices. Taste is bittersweet.

Bottle from Dranken Geers, Oostakker. Pours hazy dark brown with a lasting, small, foamy, tan head; little lacing. Aroma of licorice, plum, caramel, 'spicy cookie', fig, peanut, milk chocolate, liqueur, tea. Taste is medium to heavy malty sweet, caramel & cookie but a bit fruity too; countered by a medium spicy bitterness, herbal, accent of sourish fig. Dryish, herbal hoppy finish, spicy, lingering malty caramel & dark fruit. Medium to full body, syrupy texture, soft carbonation. Sweet stuff but just managing to remain balanced. Nice one.

330ml bottle. Opaque, darkest brown colour with average, frothy, moderately lasting, minimally lacing, off-white to beige head. Sweet-ish, dark malty, fruity, minimally sugary aroma, notes of dried fruit, raisin, sultana. Taste is sweet, dark malty, slightly fruity and sugary, hints of rock sugar, dried fruit, raisin, sultana; minimally alcoholic finish. Smooth and soft palate.

Draft at FSRB. Now I’m told this is strictly pumpkin pie spice with no pumpkin. Hard to be sure from the color: a beautiful, deep cloudy brown with brassy highlight, like a varnished cabinet, and a brown-eggshell half-inch head. Big spices in the nose, perhaps a bit too much, but there’s a big foundation of malts to try and support it. Hoppiness, too, but not in excess. Can’t help but taste all the usual pumpkin pie spices, and somewhere, I get an impression of ginger, too. Don’t know how I can qualify a "stunt" beer from a place better known for its great regular beers. All I can say is, you gotta be prepared to drink this one.

Well, a day late and a dollar short, I too enjoyed this just after the release. Served with a light-hazed, copper body under a cream-colored head that held long and settled frothily. Despite bartender Becky’s observation that last year’s Peter Pumpkinhead was more pumpkiny, I felt that this year’s rendition held a fatter pumpkin character. Spices that normally overtake this style were in delicate remission as were the lagering yeasts that formed a hearty yet subtle backdrop. Yeasts and alcohol were forefront in flavor with tart pumpkin heart quick to follow and dry spices late. ABV dries the palate (maybe a little too harshly) but the spicy festivities were allowed to linger nonetheless. (Becky also mentioned she took pictures of Matt hollowing out pumpkins for last year’s brew and I might just pay cash money to see them!) On tap at Flossmoor Station, Flossmoor, IL 60422

I missed the Mug Club preview at Flossmoor but, seeing RAYBOY01’s review, I thought I should stop by since I was going to be only a few miles away. Nice pour, a clear orange body with a good lacing, creamy white head. The aroma is softly spiced, nutmeg, cinnamon, clove, and allspice. A touch of toffee is added as it warms. The flavor has a solid caramel base to keep the spiciness in check, and it all blends well into a tasty Autumn treat. Nice. Flossmoor Station, Flossmoor, IL

This autumnal specialty possesses a very deep orange glow with a medium creamy head. The nose was surprisingly subdued for the style, usually too over the top with "holiday" spicing. I detect nutmeg and cinnamon and a touch of clove. The first taste reveals a medium creamy body (almost like dipping into the first bite of pie and coming up with nothing but whipped cream) The cinnamon, clove, nutmeg, coriander, allspice are all intermingled nicely and serve as counterpoint to a touch of vanilla and maple syrup as well. Sweet caramel maltiness anchors the whole beer nicely. These can never be my favorite style of brew, but it is rather well done, considering the last-minute nature of the particular brewing circumstances involved here...Matt decided hurriedly to respond to several customer requests for another pumpkin beer and coincidentally a tap opened up because several of his special beers (Black Wolf, particularly) sold so quickly! Just proves once again, Matt is completely incapable of brewing a bad beer.

Aroma is spicey hops with grass and biscuity toffee malts, with an intresting twist from the elderberry giving some lychee citrus flavours. Taste is similarly complex but a bit to bitter in the finish withoput a decent amount of dryness to justify it.

Tasted this in The Esquire House, Glasgow (JDW) in October 2006. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear pale copper red in colour with a thin white head. Floral hop flowers present in the short aroma. Thin but resiny mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a robust fiery digestive malt base with tart redcurrant fruit and burnt caramel. Dusty floral hops in the astringent metallic aftertaste. Finish is rather dry with golden syrup and malt extract flavours. A decent session ale.

Cask at The Cleveland Arms with Lyoli, Xiaobo and Kevin. Pours clear amber with a foamy, slightly off-white head. Nice beer overall. Pretty basic but tasty. Nice toasty malts, some ripe fruits, bit of sugar. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Sweet finish, very light leafy bitterness, toasty malts, fruits. Nice, easy drinker.
Cask. A dark golden beer with no head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel, leading to a bitter finish.

Cask (gravity) @ Crescent, 18-21 The Crescent, Salford, Greater Manchester England M5 4PF. [ As Davenport Lone Wolf ]. Alc. 4.2%. Clear medium amber orange color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, toffee. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, toffee, licorice notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20100121]

Cask. My notes claim: "Davenport Lone Wolf" at 4.2% ABV. Clear amber golden with a small off-white head. Nuts and burned caramel in the nose. Medium body, flat, sweet caramel and nutty accents but hardly any bitterness. 210110
dark amber in colour, witha honey malt nose, bitter fruity with a pleasent malt backing

JDW, Eastbourne. Pump Clip showed 4.3%, but Wetherspoon literature showed 4.6%. Strained taste - a little thin, with apple notes, like a session bitter; quite dry. Tastes more like a GK IPA than anything more meaningful. More fruit and hops than GK IPA, but not great.
A Mes rate: Cask at Baker Street JDW. Rather fruity. Plenty of malt. Hint of gents toilets in the bitter hop finish unfortunately.

Cask handpull at Folkestone Wetherspoons. Copper colour with disappearing bubbly beige head. Quite a fruity bitter. Fruity yeast on aroma. Reasonable fullness in mouth, Turkish Delight fruit. Bit of gingerish hop on end. Fruit lifts it above average.

Cask at The Pilgrim’s Progress (JDW), Bedford. Dark gold with a small white head. Served so chilled it was hard to discern any aroma. The first taste was intensely sweet, reminiscent of a fizzy lemonade, however a pleasant fruitiness developed, slightly citric, with some bitterness.
Draft the source. Dark amber color, small off white head. Aroma of creme brulee. Taste has an interesting sweet and bitter combination. Body is light. OK.
From tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is roasted and light caramelish. Bitter, dry, roasted and light bitter flavoured. Roasted and medium dry finish.

Getrunken beim RB Treffen in Düsseldorf am 6.1.07 Ein recht leichtes Altbier mit herb-malziger Note und deutlich fruchtigem Teil.
