Die leichte Marzipannnote gefällt, der wässrige Nachgeschmack, in dem höchstens ein hopfiges Aroma leicht erkennbar ist, weniger. Test vom 7.1.2007, Gebinde: Fass Noten: 9,8,7,7,-,8 - 7,78

Draught @ Festival der Bierkulturen, Bürgerzentrum Ehrenfeld, Venloer Str. 429 , Cologne, Germany. Clear medium to dark amber color with a average to large, creamy to frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, nutty, light roasted, light toffee and butter but only in aroma. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, nutty. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100515]

Draught @ brewpub in Dusseldorf. Looking at the other reviews I no longer feel crazy. Pours was typical alt, with ruby hints and well clairty. Nose was rather floral, with some nice smoky aspects. Taste was alt in a sense but came with a slightly fruity buoyancy (from the other ratings I see I wasn’t the only one). This was indeed not a bad thing. Different and I rather enjoyed it. Some like apple or peach, and maybe a little bit of a dark fruit like a plum. The follow up on the palate is semi-sweet bitterness and soft. Enjoyable indeed.

I happened to live less than 2km away from this place during my stay in Düsseldorf, far closer than I was from the city centre, so I of course had to take the stroll to try their alt on tap. It shows a rather hazy dark amber body mounted by a fading off-white head. Fruity for an alt, this is almost cherry-like and the yeast breadiness almost brings it to pie-like level, but the sweetness takes a more caramelly orientation. Not quite as toasty as I like, but it develops fun nutty notes, rather almondy in character. Its fruitiness feels a bit tart in mouth, almost vinous and this interferes a bit with the hops that seemed to be pretty floral and aromatic for an alt, but now feel a bit subdued. Still, a rather wholesome, fruity alt, if not gloriously balanced.

Draught at the brewpub. Sweet malt aroma. A bit sour with a hint of diacetyl. Hazy dark brown/red colour. Small light brown head. Watery butterscotch flavour, some malt and a little aroma hops. Very fruity flavour, not what I expect from an Alt. OK beer, by no means overwhelming.

(draught at the Düsseldorf RB gathering) Hazy, amber colour with a small, slightly off-white foamy head. Moderately sweet, strong fruity aroma with a wide range of red berries to exotic fruits, accompanied with spicy hoppy notes. Medium-bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Initially malty, slightly toasted with a distinctive fruit-character and notes of marzipan. A bit slim but aromatic malty and herbal hoppy finish. Uncommon but pleasant Alt.

On draught at the brewpub: Amber coloured, small lacing off-white head; yeasty, malty nose with a touch of toasted malt; solid bitter-sweetish flavour; light bodied; quite dry hoppy finish. Better than many industrial conoctions......
Bottle at the Düsseldorf Gathering. Hazy, muddy body. Lightly brown, creamy head. Flowery orange aroma. Lightly bitter, lightly sweet flavour. Ok alt.

#1289 Also Google verweist mich hierhin, aber ich glaube es ist total falsch. Die Bügelflasche trägt das Etikett "Rudis Hofbier Bernstein Dunkel", stammt vom Schweinswirt in Uelsen-Halle, also Niedersachsen, was mit der Privatbrauerei Höss in Sonthofen nicht die Bohne zu tun hat...sei´s drum. Schließlich steht da ja auch was von Höss Brau- und Vertriebs GmbH&Co. KG in Immenstadt. Das Bier selbst ist ein äußerst fades, wässriges Dunkel mit zuwenig Stammwürze, quais am Malz vorbei gebraut. Der leicht bittere Abgang rettet den äußerst mäßigen Gesamteindruck auch nicht mehr. Von wegen saugut...

(bottle, as Rudis Hofbier Bernstein-Dunkel, 5.2% abv) Clear, dark amber to chestnut-brown with a dense and tanned mid-sized foamy head. Slightly toasted malty aroma with notes of toffee, leaves and shy hints of herbal hops. Moderately sweet and slightly bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Dark and moderately toasted malty aroma with notes of burnt caramel and herbal hops; medium-dry sweet-bitter toasty and slightly hoppy finish. Likeable Dunkel. 06.II.12
Bottled. An amber beer with a thin lazing beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet malty with a light touch of hops, but the body is thin.
2 liter zyphon bottle. Amber brownish coloured with a small head. A bit malty and sweet with notes af caramel and kinda grassy.
(Siphon bottle 200 cl) Pours a beautiful, clear orangey brown with a dense, off-white head. Malty, sweetish aroma. Medium-bodied, sweetish malty without much bitterness. Quite pleasant. 221006
2 liter Zypon bottle. Amber colour with a big tan head. Caramel malty, light corn aroma and taste. Medium body with a sweet dry finish.

Where and how: Bottle @ Volo Aroma caramel, alcohol, clean approach with aromatic top. Herbal backing. Appearance : Top: medium cap. Base: dark brown. Palate : mineral feel with watery finish Taste: brown sugars, some chocolate. Other notes drinkable, fresh.

Bottle in a poor light barvolo. Huge aroma that jumps out of the glass, big sweet chocolate, roast and some grain or cereal note. On the palate it is sweeter than I expected it, velvety texture and rich long finish. good stuff.

341 ml bottle at Volo. Pours a rubyish brown with decent sized light tan head. Aroma is brown sugar, toffee and nuts. Flavour is on the sweet side with toffee, brown sugar, a little chocolate and some nuttiness. Active carbonation. Nice.

341 mL bottle. Dark ruby brown with very little head. Smells big for a brown, with chocolate and American hops in the nose. Not that it smells really hippy, but you know they are there. The flavour is sweeter than i expected, and doesn’t quite live up to the nose. Nice though.
Bottle at Bar Volo. Starts as a nice chocolate malt, and ending with a decent hoppiness. Good drinkability. Dark brown body with abundant white head. Good for the style, refreshing.

Really well done session brown with a well placed hop. The pour is a nearly opaque dark brown with a foamy tan head. The nose is sweet, medium roasted malts with a great light chocolate and good torrefaction. The flavor is well composed with a rich roasted malt and a sizable hop on the finsih with light citrus and a mild astringency into the aftertaste. Overall, well balanced, great flavor and fantastic malts.

Pours a dark brown with a frothy off-white head. Leaves a bit of lacing Smells of sweet caramel with citrusy, floral hops, and a hint of coffee. Feels light on the tongue but smooth and satisfying. Flavours start with malty, dark chocolate coffee that transitions smoothly into floral, citrusy note. Aftertaste is similar to the start with a nutty chocolate biscuit flavour. I like it.
Brown. Nice lacing. Creamy, tan head. Nutty, vanilla in the nose. Roasted, nutty, chocolate. Slight bitterness. Leaves a hop bitterness on the palate. Medium feel. Nice and easy drinker.

Ruby tinged brown, tan head. Grainy hops and very muted toasty malt. Watery coffee grounds like bitterness up front is a bit off putting to me, washed out malt in the middle, hops escape in the finish with a last minute citrus note. Average palate. Actually not a bad take on a brown ale, but does very little for me personally.
Deep brown, near black. Caramel aroma with some roasted malt. Lots of malt, caramel and a bit of coffee in there. Some nice citrus hop bite. Really good brown ale.

Bottle. Lively pour, amber orange, off-white head requiring a pause in the pour to allow it to settle. Low aroma of toffee and cooked peaches. Similar flavour, palate is rather thin with low bitterness. Not bad, just thin and a little lacking in character.

Poured hazy amber tending to bronze with a substantial loosely packed head that dispersed rather quickly. Aromas are reserved, dry grass seems dominant. Palate is a tad more complex. Some more dry earthy hop notes with hinting toffee from the darker malt. Finish is rather bitter and a tad astringent. Not a bad interpretation of the style. Kind of reminded me of hop back summer lightning, which isn’t a bad thing.

Large frothy head on an orange coloured ale,good carbonation.Aroma citrus and stonefruit(peach).Flavour grapefruit,pear apple(sweet)interesting taste.bitter is good an ale that flavours go together well.Finish bitter dry.
(Bottle, from Brewery) Overall acceptable English style pale ale, some of the bottles appear to have some hints of infection. More woody bitterness than pleasant hop flavour a problem
Bronze coloured body with short off-white head. Malty nose. English hops in the taste, light to medium body, not a lot of backbone but easy to drink.

This is the best English Pale Ale brewed in Australia. The Brewery has not been opened long. I was there about 6 weeks ago and meet the brewer. Andrew Larsen is a young New Zealander who set the brewery up and created the beers. Having meet him in person and picked his brains, I can tell why he has created such a good beer. Well done, keep the good work up.

Foggy amber colour, moderate ivory head. Aroma: caramel malts, candy sugar, fruity esters. Light to medium body. Taste: special malts, fruit, candy sugar. Long hoppy ending. Light plus bitterness. Pleasant bitter aftertaste. Decent one.
A small taste from a friend (tap) @ Konttori. Pours clear amber with a medium head. Aroma is sweet malts with some caramel. Flavor is sweet malts, caramel, hops. Good.

Bottle in Croydonia. It pours clear deep reddish - amber with a medium, foamy white head. The aroma is soft, sweet, malt - driven, some jammy fruits, caramel, rivita and bread. The taste is soft, bitter - sweet, brown bread, sticky, caramel, jammy, toffee, earth, wood and light spice with a dry finish. Medium body and average carbonation. A bit sweet and flat. OK.

Aroma: soft caramel malts, very fruity, red, dark berries. Appearance: dark, clear amber, small, creamy, reddish head. Taste: medium sweet. Palate: soft carbonation, sweets continue, malty, fruitiness continues. Overall: quite a nice Irish Ale, nice fruity flavours. Bottle at The Fine Line, Canary Wharf.

Draught at Bishops Arms. Clear, deep amber with a reddish tinge. Sweet aroma with caramel malts, fruits, nuts, a grassy bitterness. Taste is sweet. Medium body with a creamy texture and a soft carbonation. Finishes slightly dry and fruity with caramel and fruits. Subtle and balanced. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone
12.12.2014. Clear orange. Slightly bitter fruity aroma. Easy to drink, red berries, british bitter.
Tap@O’Connels, Tampere, Finland. Light in all aspects with some buttery flavors. Still nicely balanced and definitely better than ordinary bulk tap stuff.
Shared. Aroma of toasted malts and dark fruits. Taste of dark fruit, caramel, and some booze.
I'm new to barley wines but this one is really solid. Thank you Kevin for the share.
Excelente sabor, cuerpo, apariencia, paladar y conjunto. Todas las Cucapa y las cervezas artesanales mexicanas.

From a bottle, likely 2011. Aroma is fairly malty with a ton of caramel, toasted bread and toffee. Medium light honey and faint wet cardboard oxidation. No hop aroma. Medium raisin, sugar plums and prunes. Light alcohol spice. Faint hints of roast and treacle. Pours a cloudy, burnt amber with some brown colorings and a thin, tan head that quickly receded leaving just a hint of bubbles on the edges. Light lacing and sheets of alcohol, not legs. Flavor has a light sweetness with moderate malt character. Moderate caramel and toasted bread with lighter toffee notes. Faint roast and chocolate. Medium bitterness with no hop flavor. Medium light oxidation notes of wet cardboard. Light alcohol spice. Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium low carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. Overall an interesting Mexican beer, and likely the most flavorful I have had. The oxidation helps round the beer but also detracts with the wet cardboard notes. Lots of nice malt complexity. Very clean beer.

thanks to Sparky for sending this my way! .. . Shared with Jose while watching the Euro’s (Netherlands V Portugal) .. . pours a deep sherry brown .. mild head, tiny spots of lacing .. . deep fruit, brandy, and sweet earth .. . soild mouth feel and long finish .. . very nice beer, stoked i got the opportunity to try this .. . Roses are red, Violets are blue, I’ve got Alzheimer’s, This little piggy went to market.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: I never even noticed this until it was pointed out to me by my friend but it sounded real good and like a real treat. The aroma is caramel based malt with a whiff of alcohol. Appearance is a dark mahogany color with a puffy small head which dies in a matter of seconds after the pour. Flavors are rich with sweetness and a bit of bitterness. Tastes range from a thick caramel you would put on a green apple to English style ale with cigar tobacco.
Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel and dark fruit aroma. Sweetish malty caramel and dark fruit flavor. Has a sweetish malty caramel finish.

Pours a copper color with a small tan head. Sweet and fruity on the nose with plenty of caramel, sugar, and toffee. A light toastiness, some floral hops, and a hint of alcohol. The flavor has a mild bitterness, alcohol, and lots of malt notes. Some toasted bread, caramel, and toffee notes. A light fruitiness to the beer, which I find enjoyable. Not bad, but not my favorite either.

Not much carbonation when popping the cap. Pours a light tan three fingered head. Murky brown umber body. Sweet aroma. Wonderfully malty sweetness with an alcoholic backbone. Reminds me a lot of that British barley wine with the devil on the label, whose name is escaping me right now. Bit of warming in the throat. Probably the best Mexican beer I’ve ever had!!

Cloudy orange brown color with little to no head. Big malty aroma with some oak, caramel and port. Rich and sweet malty flavor with toffee, molasses and dark fruits. Could have used some more carbonation. Felicidades to this Mexican brewery for creating a bar that’s up there with its neighbor’s in terms of a tasty and solid barleywine.

A shade darker Copper, Good Head, Some Lacing. Same as others from sample pack, lacks flavor sharpness. Bland and subdued. Tastes Malty, Light Bitter and finishes little sour. Enjoyed it the least from this sample pack. Drinkable, but meh... Pass it....
Bottle. Bready yeast and barley malt aroma. Clear amber with a small white head. Bready yeast and barley malt flavor. Medium body. light carbonation.
Bottle. Lightly sweet barley malt aroma. Golden yellow with small head. Sweet caramel malt flavor. Nice clean lager but not really any typical bock characteristics.
Dark brown, almost opaque. Molasses, oatmeal, raisin, hint of walnut. Oily feel. Relatively sweet. Nice seasonal.

Bottle, just said ’winter ale’ on the label. Light oxidized roasted and fruity aroma. Dark brown, offwhite layer. Fullbodied, light oily mouthfeel - quite a bit residual sweetness, nutty, roast, herbal hop balance - not entirely harmonious IMO.

Bottle - Deep mahogany pour with a thinnish tan head. Nose is moderately sweet, bready malt, with a bit of molasses and next to no hopping. Taste is watered-down sweet bread, muted toffee and raisin notes, and a mildly sweet malt finish. Ample carbonation fluffs up the body a bit, but it’s pretty slick and thin. About what I expected.
Aroma is malts, berries and an off note. The flavor is mild caramel malts, berries and a smooth finish.

bottle - Pours dark amber with a small off-white head. It has minimal aroma. The flavor is very sweet with some caramel. It tastes off though. I’m not sure what it is about it. I don’t think it’s infected, but whatever’s going on, it’s not good. Thin. Odd. Meh.

Cola coloured, fluffy tan head. Ok, here’s where it gets strange...I looked at the other reviews and mine is in left field.....maybe a bad bottle....don’t know....here’s my take: Aroma is spice and Tomato...Taste is vaguely like a weak bloody mary mix....That’s what I got out of it....I’m going to try another just to check myself. Strangely, it wasn’t that bad. That’s my justification for the mid-range rating. I’ll get back to this. TAKE 2: Different bottle, (of course) purchased at different location.....same result, maybe not as much tomatoe-zing, but it’s there. Other reviewers report iron and metallics, maybe that’s what’s throwing me off. I’m going to let this stand and try next winter’s offering.
An unoffensive and forgettable brew, but decent enough to drink. Minimal bitterness. Mild maltiness. Faint notes of raisins or prunes. A little too subtle for me.
Stale ash tray aroma. Murky yellow brown colour with poor head and lacing. Smokey stale malt flavour very unplesant. Flat palate.

I just don’t get this beer; coffee in a pale ale... why? I’d much rather use the complementary tones of darker malts to showcase some coffee flavour. A weak coffee aroma with a touch of banana. Flavour mainly of coffee and some wheat grain character. Thin palate doesn’t carry the coffee well, yet some lingers longer than it should. Coffee porters may not be original, but the style works a lot better than this.
Tried this in the middle of a long session - needed the caffeine hit. Surprised at the light colour. Coffe aroma and flavour apparent. Best example of coffee and beer I’ve tried, but not a must try.

Aroma is a bit lacking with a touch of coffee and smells sort of like a Macro/Corn syrup based beer. Flavour is a bit wierd, it is a sourness with coffee floating in and out and slight nuttiness. Finish is has some coffee in it too, but again it seems to swing in and out rather then consistent and progressive. A nice experiment, but doesn’t quite pull off.

A bit disappointing really as to my mind this beer doesn’t really achieve anything despite the coffee bean aspect. Pours like a macro albeit the dull orange haze gives the impression it wasn’t heavily ’cleaned up’ prior to bottling. There’s no doubting the bouquet; coffee chocolate notes dominate. Palate is definately ho-hum as the coffee, milk chocolate, cocoa etc, overlayed with a citrus note, looks quite awkward and unbalanced. As a few other notes have observed coffee flavours work well with stout or porter styles yet Malilda Bay has tried to infuse into a pale lager / pilsner format. It just doesn’t work at all.

On Tap, Balmoral Hotel, EVPk The Coffee aroma and flavour retention is great, with a real nuttiness and spiceyness coming through, not sure how it will last in the bottle, but is a great spacer beer on tap.

An unusual cup of Joe, this. Coffee-infused beers are fairly common, but they tend to be stouts/porters with strong espresso-type notes developing through a blend of beans and dark malts. This coffee-infused Australian beer brewed with pale malted barley and wheat sets out to be more like a caffe latte, or creamy white. It looks like a lager, albeit one of unusual golden intensity. It’s unfiltered, resulting in a very slight haze. The head is moderate but endures well. The aroma is where things get interesting. Close your eyes and you could be sniffing a robust porter. Dry cocoa powder tickles the nostrils, but it’s bedded in tropical fruity esters. It’s an odd mix - limey citrus and coffee beans. In the mouth, it’s a weird melange of pale ale and porter - a sort of Black’n’Orange. The first taste impression is of sweet ruby grapefruit hops and bubblegum but the Arabica beans fight for attention in the mid-palate and provide some kick to the swallow. The palate is thin with moderate carbonation. The finish is dry, phlegmy and fairly abrupt. It’s encouraging to see a mainstream Australian brewer break new ground but I wish the end result was more satisfying. One view would be that the reason this hasn’t been done before is that the combination simply doesn’t work. I thought this might make an accompaniment at a beer dinner but it’s hard to see where it would fit. On the plus side, I am feeling unusually alert after 500mls of this stuff. Might just skip bed tonight and go for a run instead. (750ml bottle from Liquor on Parade, Kingsford. Best before Sep 11, 2008)

In retrospect the best thing about this beer was the price. I was at the bar in Northbridge and after ordering an Alpha Ale I asked what this one was like. The girl gave me a sample of about 100ml, quite enough for a rate. It is quite pale and not what I thought it would be. Then the looks becomes deceiving card is played as I smell and taste it. Only a subtle coffee note but enough to give the game away. Look, in a robust stout this flavour works as it complements roasted malts and the bitter finish of a strong beer. In this it is just pretending to be a coffee flavour, like a decaf soy double latte. coffee shops call these ’why bothers’, I agree.

Tried this on tap at the Queens Tavern a few weeks ago, served way too cold, it had a bright clear pale gold body with a decent head that didn’t want to hang around for long although it did leave some rings of lacing down the glass. Fairly light in body, nutty, very light coffee buzz on the aftertaste, bubblegum with mild carbonation. Some citrus characters especially on the nose. To me this is essentially a wheat beer for those of you who think they need their caffeine fix as well. Bring back the Barking Duck!!

Bottle (at Liquor on Parade’s tasting): Hazy gold with a thin white head. In the nose coffee dominates over some gentle grainy sweetness. However, it is the aroma of an espresso that has been left untouched overnight, a little off and urine-like, and quite odd. In the mouth things are much better - dry coffee beans (’raw’ my notes say) and again some grainy sweetness. But this is all there is, essentially a one note instrument, and there is a giant hole in both the aroma and mid- and back-palates. It’s certainly a interesting experiement, but I think it need some tweaking to really find what the strengths of this method of using coffee are. I’ve given this a slightly higher rating that I thought it was worth simply for being so unique. I like it when people push boudaries, even if they are little ones.
Ugh..............you know, it is tastes of boring malts it smells of boring yeasts....boring.
Trübes goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig. Geschmack hefig, fruchtig nach Banane, leicht würzig.
On tap at Lohhofer. Very true to type Hefeweissen, banana, a hint of citrus, silky wheat mouth feel. But not very thrilling.

It’s unclear golden with a creamy, lasting head. The aroma has notes of yeast, fruit, a hint of baking yeast and of course wheat. The sweet flavor has notes of yeast, clove, fruit and wheat, and the finish is fairly spicy.

500 ml bottle. L12816. BB 12/12. From bierzwerg.de. Hazy yellow golden colour with small to average sized off-white head. Wheat, green apple and mild tartness in aroma. Flavour is wheat, mild yeast, mild bitterness and mild tartness. Very drinkable.

500ml bottle. Hazy golden colour with average to huge, foamy, rapidly diminishing, white head. Spicy, wheaty aroma. Taste is moderately sweet-and-sour wheaty, minimally spicy. Initially nice creamy palate, later more watery and highly carbonated.
Bottle 50cl from quack-duck, an almost clear yellow beer with medium head. Nose is low, aroma is malty and sweet, less weizen notes, more grainy and pils like than anything else, pleasant but basic.

Bottle, bought @ Edeka Allershausen. Clear golden with a medium, frothy, white head. Good lacing. Aroma has quite a bit of banana, sweet wheat, light pepper. Medium carbonation, fair dryish mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet, sugary malts, wheat, mild citrus and soft banana. Okay

Bottle. Golden, hazy, small to average and diminishing head. Moderate, malty – wheaty and sweetish aroma, fruitiness and some banana, some yeast. Body is medium, malty – wheaty and sweetish flavor, some fruitiness and banana, yeast. Finish is average malty – wheaty and sweetish, light fruitiness and light banana with yeast and faint hoppyness. Sweetish and fruity hefeweizen - that’s it.

Bottled (from bierzwerg.de). Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is wheat, citrus, mild toffee, rubber and some slight yeasty notes. Flavour is banana, wheat, citrus, mild toffee and some slight yeastyness. Rather smooth to drink with a smooth carbonation as well. Excellent for hot summer days.
Pours a tan color with foamy white head. Nice fresh aroma. But taste is very light missing any strong wheat or yeast notes. Disappointing
*Old rating, best before 11.12. Schön weiches, leicht röstmalziges hefiges Weizen. Rund, mild, weich. Sehr süffig mit schön weichen Nelkentönen.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes braunes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, röstmalzig, leicht fruchtig würzig. Geschmack hefig, leicht würzig, leicht fruchtig.
Bottle from Rehills, Newcastle. This dark brown hazy beer exploded out of the bottle. It has spicy, zesty lemon and vanilla flavours, chocolate notes and a creamy fruity finish.

Bottle: Chestnut-amber coloured, hazy, small and slowly collapsing off-white foamy layer, traces of cacao-powder in sweetish-sourish caramelly-fruity nose; average sweet-bitter flavour with a light acidity in the background, light to medium bodied, a bit fizzy; short sweetish-sourish finish with a chocolatey bitterness in the aftertaste. Decent, but all in all unspectacular Dunkelweizen…

It’s unclear red-brown with a creamy head. The aroma has notes of yeast, caramel, fruit and wheat. The mouth feel is a bit too carbonated/fizzy. The sweet flavor has notes of caramel, yeast, light fruit and wheat, and the finish is slightly spicy/dry.

500 ml bottle. L1616. BB 11/12. From bierzwerg.de. Dark murky brown colour with big foamy light tan head. Wheat, hops, mild spices and bread in aroma. Flavour is wheat, metal, mild hops and bread. Not very typical or good Dunkelweizen.

500ml bottle. Hazy dark amber to brown colour with average, frothy, lasting, off-white head. Minimally spicy and wheaty aroma with a touch of hay. Taste is initially minimally sourish wheaty, heavily carbonated, later minimally caramel malty with a nuttily touch.

50 cl bottle @ home, BBE 25.11.2012 Aroma is somewhat stale and floury with some sweetish toffee, grainy malt and hints of tartness. Feels a bit like a kellerbier. Flavour is slightly sour and tart – feels almost contaminated. It has toffee, some roasted notes and yeast. Decent, although the sourness disturbs a bit here.

(bottle) Hazy, dark amber to brown colour with a big and tanned foamy head. Fruity and mildly toasted malty aroma with a moderate wheat-character and notes of caramel and strawberries. Moderately sweet and slightly bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a prickly carbonation. Toasty malty and slightly wheaty taste with caramel, a nutty touch and again notes of strawberries; sweet and mildly bitter, rounded fruity and toasty finish. A good example of the style. 31.VIII.12

00ml bottle (One Pint, Helsinki, German beer festival). Pale and uninteresting lager. Definitely not helped by it being filtered. Trawling for details you might spot some hoppiness and uninspiring malt.

Bottle @ the German beer festival, One Pint, Helsinki. Not much taste, not much aroma, not much finish, not much else either. A mediocre lager, unfortunately there’s not much more to say. It’s pale yellow with a small head. Aroma of... well, nothing. Taste is an arbritary question, but there is some grass there. Hops in the finish.

Bottle. Dark chestnut, fluffy tan head. Fruity roast aroma. Medium light body, metallic dry. Roast grain, rust, light burned notes, roasted chestnut, fairly dry - as in lacking restsweetness - which makes it weird that it has a light sticky roast finish.
Bottle. Clear dark chestnut color with grey head. Aroma is chestnuts, light grains, nutty. Taste is berries, light earthy, chocolate. Mineraly mouthfeel with natural carbonation.

50cl bottle. A clear orange brown beer with a mid -sized good lasting beige head. Aroma of dark soft roasted malt, nuts. Taste of mid sweet caramelish dark malt, nuts, mild roasted malt. Easy to drink!
Etwas zu süßer, dunkel malziger Antrunk. Geringe Bitterkeit, geringe Herbe, im Mittelteil leicht würzig, Nuancen von Karamell. Spritzig, moderat herb, süffig, schnell abflachend. Okay. 9/8/9/8/9/8

0,5 Euro-Flasche direkt aus der Klosterbrauerei Ursberg. Rostbraun, trüb, wenig Kohlensäure, kleine Schaumkrone. Riecht sehr malzig, nach Weizen, fast metallisch. Im Antrunk süß, würzig und wird dann sehr malzig.
Rotbraun und klar. Geruch nach Erd- und Waldbeeren. Geschmack leicht restsüß. Im Abgang eher wenig bitter mit Malznoten. Süffig.
Dark ruby/brown body. Aroma of toast, caramel and burnt sugar. Taste of caramel.

It’s mahogany with a light red hue and a creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, caramel and light nuts. The flavor is light to moderately sweet with notes of roasted malt, caramel, light nuts, burnt sugar, toast, and the finish is slightly dry with hints of licorice.

Bottle: Clear, dark-amber coloured, visible carbonation - therefore stable lacy off-white head; relatively dry toasty-nutty nose; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, nearly medium bodied, quite soft; pronounced nutty (reminds You of walnut-oil) flavours in the bitter-sweet finish. Fine, delicious Dunkel....

bottle, thank you MoritzF! Bronw colour, large off-white, neraly beige, head. Aroma of caramel. Medium-bodied, malty, hints of caramel, roasetd malts and chestnut, also raisins and chocolate. Very nice.
Bottle @ Poelbergsite, Tielt. Dark brown colour, creamy beige foam. Nose is sweet, caramel. Thin body. Taste is sweet, caramel, dark fruit, plums, rather watery. Nothing special.
Trübes Braun mit relativ wenig Schaum. Malzig, Röstaromen, brauner Zucker, leicht fruchtig, dunkle Beeren, etwas Nelke, Zimt, leicht herb.
Floral aroma. Nice sweet and malty flavour. Hardly any head. Nice beer, though.

9/I/2012 33cl bottle from Smetje en Zoon (Nevele) @ home - BB: 5/V/13 (2012-18) Pretty clear rust brown beer, big creamy yellowish head, adhesive and stable. Aroma: sweet malts, caramel, bit fruity, some spices, nutty. MF: good carbon, medium body. Taste: bit sweet in the start, some caramel, spices, touch of sourness, cloves, some red berries, bitter, cinnamon. Aftertaste: spices, bitterness, bit medicinal, fruity, oranges.

bottle, very dark amber coloured with medium stable white head. Nice lacing beer. Strange style, is this ’brown ale’ ? I don’t know. Smell some industrial cheap, candy sugar, passion fruit. Taste: very fruity, some malty notes and nice hops. A bit heavy beer, may be a bit unbalanced but very special one and one of the nicest bottles ever!

Bright red-amber beer with a small beige head; medium carbonation. Very caramelly nose, with notes of parsley; bit of human sweat, coloured malts. Good dark malts returning in the mouth, and bitterish-bready(crust), without burnt, nor overly sweet notes - good balance. Dry hopping obviously worked, without conferring unwanted IPA-touches. Warming up, some less flavoursome oxydized malt notes. Medium bodied, slick, even refreshing despite the caramel overtones. Another one that is better than the sum of its parts.

(Bottled) Very hazy red-amber with a largeish, tanned head with some lace. Toffee-caramely aroma with strawberries and some flowery hops. Toffeeish, somewhat acidic and mildly ashy-dryish flavor. Medium-bodied, quite foamy-carbonated palate. Not very clean or balanced, although decently drinkable. Label says it’s dry-hopped, but can’t find much hops here.

Bottle 33 cl, found at Schotte. Red brown color, white head. Medium body. Sweet aroma. Malty and sweet. Little dry. Not bad. Years ago this beer was maded by Riva (Now i like this more - taste is better .)
16.07.2019 AR: Banane, Karamell, Zitrus,Nelke, Brot AP: trübes rotbraun TA: Banane, Karamell, Zitrus,Nelke, Brot
* Old rating. Thanks to kevnic2008 for this bottle. Best before 08.10. Malty-roasted, yeasty smooth beer. Nice and round.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes braunes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, würzig, fruchtig. Geschmack hefig fruchtig, würzig, Röstmalz.

The color is unclear bronze-brown with a huge, creamy head. The aroma has notes of butter, caramel and light yeast. The sweet flavor has notes of yeast, butter, milk, caramel and light fruit - way before BBF date - no excuse...

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and it’s not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog! Ins Glas ergießt sich ein nussbraunes, mitteltrübes Weizen mit prächtiger Cremekrone. Der Geruch ist röstmalzig, hefig und dezent nussig bitter. Der Antrunk erfolgt ebenso. Sehr lecker röstmalzig mit dezenter Schokoladennote. Dazu wieder die bitter-nussige Note, die das Ganze perfekt abrundet. Zur Mitte wird’s ein wenig hefiger, der bittere Ton geht etwas zurück, ist aber immer noch gut spürbar. Im Abgang kommt ein deutlich malzbitterer Ton durch, zudem eine saure Hefenote. Ein sehr gutes dunkles Hefeweizen, hier gibt’s nix zu meckern!

500 ml bottle @ One Pint Pub. Pours a hazy brown colour with a minimal white head. Aroma of a decent amount of wheat, banana and citrus. The flavour has elements of wheat, citrus, banana and mild caramel. Medium bodied, oily/watery mouthfeel and low carbonation. Well made Dunkelweizen.

bottle from Bierzwerg. How weird, wehen I visited the brewery last year there was no Dunkelweizen available. Cloudy brown colour, mid-sized fluffy beige head. Chocolatey nose. Full-bodied, solid malty-wheaty base with nice chocolate and banana flavours. Good one.

Bottled (from bierzwerg.de). Hazy ambery brown colour with mediumsized off-white head. Aroma is fruits, wheat, some mild herbal notes, caramel and mild alcoholic sting as well. Flavour is caramel malts, some wheat, mild sweetness as well as berries and toffee.

(bottle) Cloudy, amber to chestnut-brown colour with a big and tanned foamy head. Slightly acidic berry- and citrus-fruity and wheaty nose with traces of cara- and toast-malt and rotten eggs. Slightly acidic and sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Moderately fruity and wheaty, shy toasty taste; slightly sweet and sour finish with fruity and toasty side-effects. Smells horrible, the rest is okay. 09.IV.10
500ml bottle (One Pint, Helsinki, German beer week 2006). Light and inoffensive in the mouth. Doesnt deliver the maltiness the colour promises. Nothing actually wrong with it.though.

On tap im Brauhaus in Oberstdorf. Fast klares hellbraunes Bier, feiner heller Schaum. Hefe und Roggenbrot Duft. Recht dünn im Geschmack. Hefe, etwas Karamell. Im Abgang leicht Gummibärchen. Muss ich nicht haben.
On tap. Pours a dark amber color. Yeasty aroma, with some malts, citrus and banana.

On draught at the Brewery. The color is between a Dunkel and a regular Hefe. Not much of an aroma to be honest, a bit yeasty. The taste is a bit sweetish, some banana. Nothing wrong with it, but very middle of the road.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes dunkelgoldenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig, leicht würzig. Geschmack hefig, fruchtig, leicht bananig, etwas würzig.

Erfrischend herb-hefiger Antrunk. Dabei wird eher die Herbe als die Hefigkeit stärker, insgesamt wenig aromatisch. Im Mittelteil mild, geringe Karamellnoten, keine Änderung zum Ende hin. Erfrischendes, etwas karges Weizen. 8/7/8/8/9/8

Bottle (kindly delivered by Quack-Duck!): Deep golden, cloudy, mid-sized white head with a little lace, bubble-gum and cooked vegetables in the nose, not much wheat detectable; sweetish flavour, sticky MF; shorter sweetish-grainy finish. Not good, not at all...
Pours a very dark glass of beer and has a bitter taste. Overall not bad at all.
Draught at the brewery.Hazy dark golden colour with large white head.Strong fruity taste of banana and melon,really fresh taste and well balanced,maybe the best Dunkel weizen in Germany ?.

Thanks to quack-duck for that bottle. Looks really good. Beer in the glass fine turbid, nice head. Starts malty-yeasty, not too dry, fine fruity like banana. Modest sourish. Finish with some lemon hints. Well balanced and very drinkable. Nice!

5l cask from the brewery. Cloudy amber golden colour, mid-sized, very creamy off-white head. Banana, roasetd malts, caramel, slightly yeasty. Not a classic Dunkelweizen but rather like a Bernsteinweizen or Ur-Weisse - neuther pale nor dark. Very well balanced, smooth palate with low carbonation. Delicious - any time again.

Draught @ Biermatinee Oisterwijk 2012. Hazy opaque yellow color, medium sized a bit creamy white head. Don’t smell much. Tastes a bit sourish, some fruity, orange peel. Quite balanced though, decent beer with a medium body and fresh finish.
Tap at KBC, Den Bosch: Simple whitebeer from this tiny North-Brabant brewery, its hazy, some spices, some thirstquenching.
Bottled. Aroma of grass and 7-up. Hazy, pale yellow color, white head, no lace. Light sweet, citric, light but nasyy bitterness, veggies, thin, very much one dimensional.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Golden with a small white head. Very sweet floral hop aroma. A little sweetness and fruit in the taste, but the mid section lacks impact and direction. Quite a pleasant lasting bitter finish.

Enjoyed a half liter of this one on draught at the brewery in Farmingdale, NY. Pours to a bright, golden color, with a nice white head, that faded, and a lively carbonation. The nose was inviting, with some light, salty/sooty smoke aroma. The palate is firm, with some good tart, wheat malt flavor, and a touch of sourness, that made this beer refreshing. This beer finished with some more tart wheat malt flavor up front, then ended with some light, salty and smoky flavor that lingered. Tasty beer, but it lacked the fruity esters of a good Bavarian hefe, and appeared not to be a true hefe, as it poured bright, and I didn’t get any yeast aroma or flavor. That being said, it was a tasty, refreshing beer, and I enjoyed the rauch malt aromas and flavors. A good beer that would work well with the German fare on the Brew Haus menu.

On tap at the brewpub tonight...A good beer overall. To me, it tasted much more like a lager than an ale, and certainly not much like typical american heffes. Very clean tasting, refreshing, with no citrus or too much wheat. The smoke is not very prominent, and just complements the flavor, which is slightly grassy and herbal. Nice.

An interesting take an a hefe - much more lively, "sparkling" carbonation than your typical hefe, with an aroma that is much less dominated by the citrus and banana fruity esters than you’d expect, with just a light smokey quality far in the background - the flavor, much like the aroma, lacks those up front banana and clove flavors, which is a welcome change - there’s some light lemon, a mild bready quality, and a light yeastiness, with a very faint, but still quite present, smoke flavor - finishes fairly clean, almost like a pilsner or lighter lager - quite nice, actually.
Amber with medium white creamy head. Slight fruity aroma. Good bitterness full of fruity notes. Slight metallic touch. Bitter aftertaste with some metallic notes.

On tap at the brewpub. Poured a virtual black color it ha small tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, bit of nut and caramel. Taste of roasted malt, some coffee and trace of nut. Nice bitterness and a dry finish. Fairly full body, with a bit of a grainy texture with a hint of character.
Dark black. Medium beige head. Really sweet. Tastes like chai. But as thick as I would expect with oatmeal. Subtle cinnamon. Interesting.
Had this at their tap room Fall 2012. Not really impressed with any of their beers. Not bad for this one.

Tasted on tap at the brew-pub. It poured an almost opaque dark reddish brown color with thin but persistent head of beige foam and a little lace. Not very stout-like. Not very toasty or roasty, very little oatmeal silkiness/creaminess. Tart, mildly fruity, acidic, dry finish. Just sort of a non-descript dark ale. Fairly smooth and easy-drinking but not particularly memorable.

Sample at the Highlands Brewery. Pours very dark brown and the aroma has heavily roasted malt. Medium/thick body and the taste has roasted malt. There is also some light fruitiness - like grapes? The finish has most other flavors dropping out except for the char. Not a bad stout.

Draft sample at the brewpub, the tenth of ten in our sampler. This one poured a deep, dark brown, pretty much opaque, with a small beige head. The aroma was pretty faint overall but I got some roasted malts, toasted oats, and earth from it. The flavor improved upon that, with more of the same notes, some light coffee, and a bit of cocoa. Medium-bodied, with average carbonation and a roasty, grainy mouthfeel. Along with the Marzen, this was my favorite from Highlands, and those were the two beers I felt were executed well. A good finish to the sampler.

tasted 8/7/10. Sampler from the Brewpub. Opaque with a brown hue. Layer of khaki head. Aromas of dark roasted malts and a mild anise note. Hints of rustic breads. Rather full bodied with a great malt roast. Flavors of dark chocolate and cocoa dust. Mild coffee note without the astringency. Smooth body with a nice sweet flavor. Mild grassy hop note in the finish. Well crafted.

Sampled at the 7th Annual Parkville Microbrew Festival on April 24th, 2010. Pours black with a big-bubbled dark tan head. This has a wet blanket aroma. Medium roastedness. There’s also a big of smoke wrapped up in this. A fairly good stout.

On tap at Highlands brewpub. Dark brown with some ruby lowlights and a thin tan head and a few spots of lacing. Aroma of roasted dark malt, mild smoke and a touch of grains. Taste of roasted malt, a hint of coffee but no real sweetness. Thin bodied and finishes up with some malt bitterness. Reminds me more of a dry stout than an oatmeal stout.

Sample at the brewpub. This brew is a brownish-black color with a medium tan head that diminishes steadily. Roasty aroma with notes of coffee and malt. Medium, smooth body with flavors of roasted malt, chocolate and a touch of black coffee. The finish is sweet chocolate up front with a lightly bitter coffee and hops aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

A dark chocolate brown coloured beer with a weak effevescence. A strong, perfumed, tropical fruit nose of lemon, mandarin and lychee, then a faint hoppy aroma. The taste is bitter, slightly sour, again, tropical fruit, lemon, grapefruit, mandarin and lychee, then a dry hop flavour, that is followed by a slightly sweet malt finish. The brewery’s 10th. anniversary celebration brew. Apparently dry hopped and with the addition of maple syrup in the cask (?!?!). (Cask - The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).
Fantasitc red ale with a balanced earthy malt base. Typical hop finish with a weighty body. Really good.

4/23/18. Reddish amber appearance with a beige head. Aroma of toasted malt, zesty hops, mild pine and light earthiness. Similar flavor, adding a moderate bittersweet balance with a medium body, a smooth feel and a lingering finish. Good.
Aroma is malts, fruit and a mix of slight sugar and citrus. The flavor is fruit, caramel, malts, grapefruit/mild tropical fruit and a mix of whiskey/liquor and hops/alcohol in the finish.
Pours a clear orange, fair amount of yellow-white foam. Aroma is grassy and piney. Flavor is also grassy and piney, some citrus fruit, sweet and sticky. Very nice stuff.

Aroma of oak, vanilla, caramel, and light hops. Pour is orange and red with a lasting lace of off white head. I really enjoy the american strong ale style when done right, which this is. May not appeal to some as it is not hoppy, but this is a nice break from the styles I've been drinking lately.

Bronze pour, finger of tan beauty atop. Nose is deep caramel and understated cedar. Middle is chewy caramel, medium + kilned malt, kiss of wood, mild stone fruit rounds out the bill. Finish is warm, malty, and leans sweet. Nice after dinner.

Bottle, 2018 vintage. Whiskey aroma with notes of vanilla, stone fruit, pine resin and oak. Pours reddish caramel colored with a thin tan head that has little retention and some lacing. Starts with stone fruit and pine resin flavors. Finishes dry but quite smooth with whiskey, vanilla and oak flavors with a hint of booze in the background. Really nice red.

Bottle given by alexsdad06. Poured dark amber color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate toasted earthy hop aroma. Medium to full body with slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. This is a solid brew.

I sorta dig reds and this showed up at my best local shop, had to buy and try. The 12 oz bottle, Cellar Series/2018, is opened and poured into my New Belgium snifter, yep, red all right with a light tan foam rising to the top. An ipa-ish scent, okay start. Tasting now, ipa again, kind of woody, biscuit, a small caramel hit. Okay for sure, buy again? At the price I paid for the bottle, no.

Bottle from Brewers Haven. Dark amber, crystal clear, instant foamy head disappears. Aroma is big caramel malts. Tadte too favors the malt, caramel and toffee notes. Mild sweetness, some latent barrel accents. Tiny bit of alcohol warmth.
Nice malty beer. Pours brown with medium head. Sweet and malty flavor. Sublte cocoa and nuts. Light body and really drinkable.

On tap @ FFF: Dark brown color with a nice tan head. Chocolate aromas a little roast although they aren’t too strong. Chocolate and roast domintate the flavor as well, definitely baker’s chocolate that dry almost chalky chocolate with a nuttyness and a chocolate roast bitter finish. Pretty tasty for a brown, although i wish it had a little bigger body.

Tap at brewpub: Hazy brown with a small frothy head and very good lace. Wow, a surprisingly hoppy nose backed by caramel, walnut, apple, juicy fruit, and grapefruit vapors. The flavor is fruity and chewy with a lot of malt background brfore a heavy (for a brown ale) bite. Finishes with a hint of mocha and nut. The mouth feel is resiny and dry with some snap on the finish. I liked it, not normal for sure.

this is a GREAT beer... this is my first rating too ... i’ll try to do well.... soooo sweeeet and tasty..... arrrrggggggggghhhhhhhhh..... 8% alcohol, and is soooo sweeeeet and tasty!!!!!!!! arrrrrrrrgggggggghhhhhhhh (did i say that already?) sorry, just had a 120 min. ipa and a dreadnaught......

No boring brown ale here! This one has a deep rich brown pour with medium tan head that lingers throughout. Very roasty flavors pervade...mostly chocolate and nuts, oh yeah...and a ton of PNW hop bitterness. Citrusy hop zest was a big surprise in whay usually is a very bland style. Quite well hidden ABV...I would have guessed more in the 5.5% range. Very nicely done.

On tap at the brewbup. Pours and orangey brown with lots of dry hop haze, and a bit of white head. Aroma is typical for FFF. Buckets of Amarillo and Simcoe? Some light nuttiness. Same with the flavor. Just a shit ton of hops with some nuts and chocolate as it warms. Pretty easy to drink with along bitter finish. I personally would like a bit more brown ale charcter. Alway a pleasre to try a new FFF brew though.

On tap at the brewpub. Dark reddish amber color beer with a big frothy beige head. Malty nose with hints of chocolate. Very smooth beer with a light body given the ABV. The taste is dominated by dusty bitter chocolate, with some raw grain and bready notes, and an almost cherry sweetness. It has the standard Three Floyds hop profile, but it is more subdued. You get chocolate burps instead of hop burps. I wish I could try the brown without the chocolate.

This was my first brown type ale and was very happy.It had malts and roasted oats roasted in their very own ovens.I had one sample and would like to try more .Alcohol is well hidden and beer is very smooth to the finish

I forget what the Deneb means, or perhaps I didn’t even ask. The S&A is one of those places you are attracted to because of the promise. It is situated in Fremantle, has an ample bar and possibly good food. The beers are the potential attraction but overall they fall short. For a black beer it is probably too pale, even though it looks fine in the glass. The head dissipates quickly but this is not as disappointing as the sweetness and cloying overbalance of sweet malt to the hoped for burnt flavour of black malts. OK, but only enhanced by the company, Bluevegie and my work colleague Petra.

This Beer is actually a Munich Dunkel. Filled with malt driven flavour supported with a secondary nutty biscuit that the Munich Dunkels are famous for. It has the Rawhide brown tan colourwith a hint of amber red. Has a light hint of Hallertau Hops. A great expression of the style!

Tried this on tap at the Sail with Sully. Nut brown body, light tan lasting head, cloying sweet taste, some chocolate notes showing but not much. Bit too sweet for a dark lager for me, perhaps I was expecting and hoping for more roasted bitterness
Slightly better than average bitter. Strong cereal malt notes with a leathery touch. Low weight.
Copper pour, thin off white head, visible carbonation. No nose. Taste is balanced. Not much hop presence. Some light malt flavor. Light to medium body.

On tap @ Lucky Labrador. Orange in color with a white head. Pretty herbal hop nose. Some bready malts and toasted grains. Maybe a hint of grass and citrus. There is a rally intense herbal and vegetal note. Sort of sweet and malty. Odd almost eucalyptus finish. Weird.
Bronze and clear, aroma is somewhat bland, with a weird diacetyl taste with strawberries, not liking this.

On tap at Lucky Labrador, pours a clear dark copper with no head. Aroma is basically non-existent. Flavour brings out notes of detergent and other poor soapy hop notes. Pretty nasty stuff. Not drinkable.
Draught. Rather pleasant hop aroma, citrus and floral. Bready flavour, not sure what happened to the beer between nose and mouth. Somewhat oily finish.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear copper color with a medium white head. A sweet hoppy big citrus flavor. This is a really hoppy bitter! Some oranges, lemon, very clean, caramel. Nice brew.
Clear orange, white lacing. Mild cereal aroma. Hoppy, but very well balanced palate contains cereal and bread flavors with a hint of citrus and tea leaf that lead to a lingefing, crisp finish.
On tap. Clear amber pour with a white head. Scent is sweet and bread. Taste is sweet with a lot of tea.
Malty and fruity notes comingling. Amber/golden color. Pale until the hops kick in at the end.

tap at the brewpub many years ago - I found some very old notes. Consider this beer long since retired judging by the other ratings. Pale yellow with some lacing. The aroma is very light with a little malt. Flavor has mild hops bitterness. It's light and refreshing but I wasn't that into it.

Hawthorn Lucky Lab. Bright yellow gold with a soft white head. With my pup by my side and a delicious spicy sandwich in hand this beer really brought out the summer in today. Big citrus hop flavor, fruity up front, but bitter bias finish. Crisp and great at cleaning away the spice from the turkey sandwich. Good overhopped golden ale.

Pours a bright yellow with some orange colors. Cloudy but very bright like a sunset. Aroma of honeylike malts and sweet peach. Some floral hops. Flavor is sweet and malty but not cloying. I detect a slight herbalness and peach esters. Light bitterness and citrusy hops on the finish. Very drinkable and thirst quenching.

On tap at Lucky Labrador, Quimby St, Portland. Gold colour with thin off white head. Bit of a stale aroma along with nettley hop. Bit of cat pee aroma to the hop. Altough a well made beer, it is not that attactive to drink.

column1: Lucky Labrador Single Hop IPA - Willamette
column5: On tap at Lucky Labrador, Quimby St, Portland. Deep gold colour. Herby blackcurrant aroma. Harsh hop, it’s got that cat pee thing that the summer ale had. Strong hop finish. Odd, but like the other beers I had here, well made, good flavoursome ingredients.

Cask ale, shared with Finn at Merchants 1688 in Lancaster. Bright nut brown body under a stable pearl white head. Rich lacing. Bread-like malts on the nose, hints of leafy hops. Mixed taste of stewed fruits, bread and caramel. Rounded ending, bittersweet. Satisfying. (06.02.2019).

Bottle at a Beermalade blind tasting. Combination of unpleasant red fruits and caramel with high fruity esters and sweetness, with harsh grassy vegetal hops character and bitterness in the finish. SOmehow feeling empty despite this all. Flawed on several levels. Ungood.

Lahev (RBESG 2019): Deep golden, stable off-white foamy layer, mild hoppy and caramelly-bready nose; light to moderate bitter-sweet flavour, more light than medium bodied; lingering bitter-sweet caramelly finish. This Wittingau (Tøebon) brew is not really earth-shaking, but quite O.K. ...

0.5 l bottle, thanks Marko. Shared with Višnja 666. Clear amber, small off-white head. Aroma is nicely toasty and spicy, leaves, light caramel. Very refreshing. Light green apple in the flavour. Flavour is caramel and toast malts. Dry finish, light bitterness. Light to medium body, moderate finish.
Bottle. RBESG 2019. Amber color. Caramel in the aroma. Malty sweetish, caramelly flavor. Just a hint of roast. Bready. Not unpleasant.
RBESG 19 Grand Tasting. Bottle. Amber-red body, off white head. Clean malty aroma. Clean malty taste, light caramel. Generic, okay.
Bottle. Clear amber color with white head. Aroma is caramel, raisins, sweet toffee. Taste is caramel, raisins, toffee. Oily mouthfeel with natural carbonation. Ok.
Bottle from BeerBox, Budapest. Copper color with a bit beige little head. Has malty aroma, and nice sweet, caramel malty, bit toasted and bready flavor.
Velice zbyteènì pøesládlé pivo, které pak kvùli této skuteènosti nemá kvalitní sladový ani chmelový charakter. I tak ale díky za zkušenost.

Bottle. Pours light brown with a finger of head. Bready, sweet malt, toast aroma. Mild medicinal bitterness, malty, slick oily mouthfeel. Finish is more mild herbal bitterness and sticky malt. Decent enough, but not my favorite.
Caramel malt aroma. Brilliant amber color with minimal sized white head. Caramel taste, sweet. Watery, thin, soft to average carbonation.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft. Pours orange brown with tan head. Nose/taste of malt, all spice, artificial canned pumpkin and bready malts. Medium body.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: I’m pleasantly surprised by this beer. It’s not nearly as complex as craft brew pumpkin ales, but its a tasty option you can get almost everywhere.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Red brown ale. Looks good. Pumpkin (obviously), alcohol, strange sourness and spices. Well balanced taste but quite artificial. Not very good. (On my FL trip.)

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: (Draught) Served way too cold. Poured amber and clear. Formed a small and white head. Spices and malts in not so pleasant aroma. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. I noticed malts, spices, sweetness and bitterness in taste. Aftertaste was spicy and bitter. Easily forgettable.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft today at a harvest festival. Nose of weak spices. The coors light plastic cup did not help much to set a decent tone, but neither did every aqua-net whore and Jersey Guido wannabe Yankee fan that seemed to appear at this upstate festival. A nice orangish amber in the cup with at fizzy head. first sip reveals a medium body with a good bit of chalkiness. Pumpkin finally arrives in a funky finish. Some other spice tones pop out here and there. Lackluster.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Nice orange color, light colored head. Smells of hops and a slight pumpkin smell. However, the beer is lacking in pumpkin flavor, the hops overpower any flavors in the beer. dull ""vegetable like"" after taste. Not one of my favorites

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Pours a deep golden orange color with a huge white fluffy head. Aroma of wheat and clove. Taste of wheat with a slight hint of pumpkin. Nice texture. Nice brew.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Amber pour with off white tight foamy head and lace. Pumpkin spice and malt on the nose. Pumpkin, clove, medium bitter and a hint of abv. Foamy medium bodied beer. Nice full bitter pleasant surprise.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: bottled. pours amber with a large cream colored head. nothing noted other than hops and alcohol on the nose. flavors are lacking and dilute. some nutmeg, and a touch of bitterness from orange peel, but very mild. of the pumkin ales i’ve had this is my least favorite.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Cask at Chelsea Cask Fest. Mild pumpkin & pie spice in the aroma. Some nutmeg and allspice. Flavor is very thin, vegetal. Brussel sprouts and eggplant. Odd. Muddy, minor pie spice flavor. Pretty dull, tough to drink.
A bit boozy on the nose but with excitingly buttery hops. Not hugely fascinating in the mouth but smooth and with a wonderful finsih

Cask. Good fruity hop aroma. Hazy orange colour. Small white head. The flavour is very nice, not powerful. Clean hoppiness, not so bitter, but with a nice fruity flavour and refreshingly citric. Thin mouthfeel, but in a nice drinkable way. A very good session pint.
Cask at Charlie’s, Copenhagen. Hazy, golden. Light citric nose. Flat and stale with dry citric flavour; grapes.
Cask at Charlies Bar, Copenhagen. Golden color, small head. Fruity and somewhat hoppy aroma. Fruity, hoppy flavor, grapes, malt. Fruity and somewhat hoppy finish.

Cask at Charlie’s Bar, Copenhagen. A slightly hazy golden beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with light hoppy and flowery notes. The flavor is sweet and very malty with light hoppy and citrusy notes. Not as wild as expected.
Cask conditioned at Charlies. Classic earthy fuggles notes in the aroma and in the flavour. Not really hoppy enough for a single hop brew though.
Cask Stillage from the festival bar at the Brunswick, Derby 29/09/2006 Hoppy aroma. Golden coloured and hoppy with a slightly creamy crisp and bitter finish.

column1: Kelham Island Pale Rider Autumn Almanac
column5: Cask Handpump from the backroom bar at the Flower Pot, Derby 29/09/2006 Some hop aroma. Clear golden coloured and hoppy. Crisp and dry on the palate in the finish.
Cloudy amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, caramel and heavy hoppy - grapefruit and pine needles. Flavor is rather sweet and very bitter. Dry and very bitter finish. Very nice. 041007
Bottle. ABV 9 %. Copper colour with a beige head. Aroma is citrus, grapefruit, hop. Flavour is sweet, grapefruit, malt, hop, citrus. Nice mouthful and a nice beer.

Bottle... Clear amber ale with orange highlights and a small, frothy, white head. Decent retention. The aroma is all about resin and rich caramel. Full-bodied with an ultra-creamy mouthfeel and reserved carbonation. Leans on the sweet side of balance, but not by much. A bounty of earthy hops stand firm on a juggernaut of caramel malt. Alcohol and hop bitterness barely keep the sweet malt in check. The finish is lengthy, sweet, modestly bitter and then dry. Thanks to pepsican for floating this bottle in my direction!

50 cL bottle. Pours hazy deep orange to amber with a lacing tan head. Aroma is dense hoppy of fresh hops with a lurking sweetness beneath. Flavour is sharp bitterness/acidic from the hops with a rather thin caramel malt body to counter balance this. A bit too overhopped for my liking but still a fine brew. Lingering dry and bitter flavour of loads of american aroma hops flavours.
Unclear amber of color with a orange/beige head. An aroma with hops, grapefruits, sweets, malt and pines. A flavor with malt, hops, bisquit, grapefruits and sweet.

Deep orange-amber in colour, thin but lasting beige coloured head, excellent lacing. The aroma is very hoppy, grapefruit and orange citrus, quite sweet with lots of tropical fruit. The flavour is very rich and chewy, caramel sweetness, some toffee, lots of fruit, very juicy. Moderately bitter mouthfeel, large body, medium/high carbonation. Finishes very long, very hoppy and quite sweet. This was quite fun to drink. It was very well made, so big, rich and chewy. Fantastic. I’m really liking the "softness" of the European IIPA’s. 600ml bottle obtained in a trade with MPA, thanks Mads Peter. Opened on January 31, 2008 Batch #68, Best before August 31, 2008.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy amber/brown with a small, creamy beige head. Sweet candy hop aroma with citrus and faint spice notes and a creamy touch to top it off. This is really great. Flavour is sweetish with hops, malt, and fruity and slightly spicy notes. Faint metallic notes as well. Finish is a mix of fruity and bitter liquorice notes and lingering bitter and apple notes. Creamy palate. A really nice beer. 21-06-08.

Bottle from pepsican - thanks! This one has a pretty darker amber color with an aroma of sweet and earthy hops. Flavor is sweet, citrusy, herbal/earthy, and pretty smooth. Shows very little of its 10% ABV. Not bad at all, a bit different than most U.S. DIPAs. Lacks the "wow" quality to set it apart.
Cloudy amber/brown pour with a thin white head. Aroma is strong malt and a bit of hops. Flavor is earthy hops, toasted malt, burnt toast, peanuts, sweet caramel. Finishes slightly bitter.
0,5 l bottle, at Hopheads tasting at Roger´s place. Brown color, nice beige head. Aroma is hoppy and fruity -lovely! Flavor is hoppy and fruity, sweet. I love it!

Bottle, mht. 31-08-2008. Black with a beige head. Aroma of lime, chocolate, coffee and licorice - surprised about the lime. Porter/citrus water flashbacks. I like that, as this was how I grew up to be a beer drinker tasting it in my childhood. Flavour is the exact same thing with sweetness and a roasted bitter finish. Aging did nothing bad to this imo.

bottle sample from my gotenborg trip. poured a dark black colour with a tanned head. nose really adds that old tart port notes. way over it’s peak. that’s clear. red fruits, some licorice, salty chocolate, still a bit of roast, port, wine, slight metallic sour.
Bottle. Pours muddy black. Aromas of port wine, malt, olives, dust, chocolate. Taste is port wine-like, malty, roasty, dusty, licorice, dark chocolate.
Bottle @ Dangerous Bottleshares meets Arla Unika. Black pour with a tan head. Old vintage, really old... Notes of roast, licorice, dust, chocolate and sweet malts.

column1: Kelham Island Riders On The Storm
column5: Bottle from Beer Central, Sheffield. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, bready, light fruity and light hoppy. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 171018

column1: Kelham Island Riders On The Storm
column5: Bottle from Beer Central, Sheffield. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are grain, malt, fruits and hops. Light bitter finish.

column1: Kelham Island Riders On The Storm
column5: 22nd June 2018; cask half-pint at The Pheasant Inn, Wellington Shropshire. Golden pour, white blanket of foam on top. Light hop nose and taste with a good malty backbone for the hops to ride on, giving the beer a slightly sweet flavour.

column1: Kelham Island Riders On The Storm
column5: 500ml enjoyed with mixed takeout curries, Sheffield April 2017. - Thinly spread stone fruit jam on a rather diluted malt biscuit: watery pockets and some generic fruit sugars mar the broth before a decent lemony hop twang kicks in towards the finish. Fine with curries though. // Rerate new bottle 2ß18-4, merci Miles. Commerative Dave Wickett pours this time. Hard to put my fingers on why, but I like this more than I rated it as: could be the sub-5% easygoing lemon goodness...

column1: Kelham Island Riders On The Storm
column5: Cask at the Post Office Vaults, Birmingham. Poured a crystal clear straw colour with a frothy white head. The aroma is malt, light woody resin hop. The flavour is moderate bitter with a smooth, malty, yeast, light fruit, hop bitter palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

column1: Kelham Island Riders On The Storm
column5: Drunk from 50cl bottle bought from Asda in Wakefield. Enjoyable golden ale. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Kelham Island Riders On The Storm
column5: Cask at the Golden Eagle, Marylebone, London. Pours golden brown with an off white head. Aroma of light malt, caramel, light fruit. Medium sweetness, light bitterness. Light/medium body, rather thin texture. A bit disappointing.
